column2: Tons of thousands of men from farms, workshops and offices are flocking to towns in government territory wherever military barracks are established in response to the recent mobilization order. Registration of those eligible for the classes of 1932 to 1936 inclusive was begun a fortnight ago and they are now being summoned for training.

Arguing that as an American citizen she was entitled to live in any residential section she chose, regardless of her race, Mrs. Joshua Cockburn testified today in opposition to a neighbor's suit to oust her from a new $20,000 home on Fort Hill Road, Greenburgh.

The world wheat markets developed an irregular trend today. Highly beneficial rains were reported as having fallen in the eastern half of Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska and had a depressing effect on the new-crop deliveries of that grain in the domestic markets, while the May was strengthened by relatively higher foreign markets, the development of an aggressive foreign demand for old-crop North Pacific Coast wheat and a good domestic flour demand.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been appointed by the Walgreen Company co-transfer agent of 100,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock with common-stock purchase warrants attached; also warrant agent of the common-stock purchase warrants. The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company is registrar for the preferred stock.

The all-metropolitan basketball team, chosen by a poll among the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association, received certificates last night at the Forty-fourth Street Hotel when writers and the Metropolitan Officials Association held a joint annual dinner. The presentation of scrolls was made by Everett B. Morris, president of the writers's group.

It was Sunday night when Joseph Benedek first showed his 14-yearold son, Joseph Jr., a revolver and said he was going to end it all. From that moment until about 4 A. M. today, when he dozed off in spite of himself, the boy had not slept a wink nor let his father out of his sight.
A company has been registered called the Additional Companies with a capital of [Pound]365,000 ($1,825,000) to assist members of Lloyd's underwriters in connection with their foreign business.
Packaging will play a prominent role in the battle between national and private brands, created by new and impending legislation, such as the Robinson-Patman law and other fair trade acts, Irwin D.

Miss Alice Depew, daughter of Dr. Arthur Depew of this city, has chosen April 17 as the date for her marriage to Robert Anthony Mauriello, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Mauriello of Orange. The ceremony will be performed in Hillside Presbyterian Church, Orange, by the pastor,

Sit-down strikers who have been occupying the Champion Shoe Manufacturing Company's plant at 104 Bleecker Street since March 11 were ordered to leave by noon today in an injunction granted yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller.
Baldwin High captured the first annual Long Beach interscholastic invitation swimming meet at the Lido Beach pool today.
The Terminal Industrial five-man team of Flushing, L. I., was disualified and removed from second place in the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress championships yesterday.

Jewish members of the regular army and of the Civilian Conservation Corps will receive furloughs to participate in the observance of the approaching Passover holiday, it was announced yesterday at the army's Second Corps Area headquarters on Governors Island.

Stirred by an address of Homer Chaillaux, national Americanism director of the American Legion, calling upon Americans to "arouse themselves from she indifference that has permitted subversive activities to gain a foothold in the United States," the American Legion of Michigan today started a campaign which its leaders declare is the opening attack in a nation-wide drive on Communists and other subversive movements.

Ambassador Georges Bonnet of France and Mrs. Bonnet were honor guests at a large tea which Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury gave today at El Mirasol. Captain and Mrs. John H. Gibbons gave a dinner tonight at their villa for Admiral Adolphus Andrews, chief of the Bureau of Navigation in Washington, who arrived today to be their guest.

Expressions of approval of New York's request for a $5,000,0000 Federal appropriation for the 1939 World's Fair came from House Foreign Affairs Committee members today after Grbver A. Whalen, president, and a large delegation representing New York organizations had given evidence.

Anglo-Italian pinpricks, which gradually have been increasing in number and getting deeper, brought a small explosion in a non-intervention subcommittee today simultaneously with Premier Benito Mussolini's outburst in Rome.
The Nazi government declared a truce tonight in its quarrel with rebellious Protestants rather than engage in simultaneous conflict both with Catholic and Protestant churches.

Unless a further decline in the market for government securities should occur to disturb confidence, it seems likely that the acceptance market will not see any additional advance in rates for a little while. On the contrary, some slight retreat from the levels established yesterday would not be surprising.

One of this American sculptor's outstanding characteristics was his immense fund of productive vigor. Before the turn of the century, though still a young man, he had to his credit a lavish group of ambitious plastic works, among these the celebrated fountain that with such charm of rococo blitheness epitomized the Chicago World's Fair and reflected the spirit of the now half-fabulous Nineties.
T. Yorke Smith, a member of the South Jersey Port Commission and former Camden City Commissioner, died today of a heart attack at his home in Haddonfield. His age was 63.

State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner Frederick D. Burnett ruled today that Easter eggnog may be sold in licensed establishments beginning Thursday and until next Monday midnight. Here is his official opinion:

Asserting that "an anti-German propaganda in this country" recalls the years from 1914 to 1917, Dr. Hans Borchers, German Consul General, declared last night that it was time to "put a stop to the estrangement of two great nations," and echoed Secretary of State Cordell Hull's appeal for an end to the controversy arising out of recent remarks by Mayor La Guardia.

It is officially announced that Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano will leave at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning for Belgrade, where he will arrive on Thursday to conclude an understanding with Yugoslavia that is variously described as an exchange of assurances similar to the AngloItalian declarations of Jan. 2 or a non-aggression pact based on the status quo.

Mrs. Annette Kennedy Mantz, wife of B. Stafford Mantz, vice president and treasurer of the Corporation Trust Company of New York, died here today of pneumonia in the North Community Hospital at the age of 44. She was a daughter of the late McPherson Kennedy, former chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange.

Mr. and Mrs. Leo Frank of 290 Riverside Drive gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the Metropolis Club, 105 West Fifty-seventh Street, to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage. Those present included their three children and eight grandchildren.

Four musicians, three from New York, who literally received a black eye on their first invasion of musical circles here, departed for Turin today after scoring a triumph before the Rome Philharmonic Society. The ensemble, known as the Manhattan String Quartet, received two encores last night when they played

Ponce tonight made mobilization plans in what was described as a move to guard against. "serious labor trouble" in the downtown shopping area. Police Superintendent Edward W. Fallon said he had learned indirectly that a sit-down strike might be called tomorrow in department stores and that cleansers and dyers might strike at the same time.

In a protest against President Roosevelt's new policy governing grants by the Public Works Administration, the United States Conference of Mayors stated today that to base such grants on the amount of wages paid to relief workers "is just a polite way of killing the present PWA program."

Francis "Peaches" Browning Hynes, who married the late Edward W. Browning of New York, will get her dower right to some property of Mr. Browning as the result of a decision of the Court of Appeals today.

Miss Mary C. Trackett of Madison, Wis., has been selected by the faculty of Barnard College as the winner of the $1,400 fellowship established by a gift of $30,000 from the Woman's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, it was announced yesterday.

Seven races, the first of which is to take place at Pimlico on Wednesday, May 5, have been arranged for the thirty-six imported foreign jumpers bought by subscription and distributed by lot at Belmont Park earlier this year, according to an announcement from the offices of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association yesterday.

The Detroit Red Wings opened the defense of their National Hockey League championship and the Stanley Cup with a smashing 4-to-0 victory over Montreal's Canadiens before 12,495 spectators at the Olympia tonight in the first game of a three-out-offive series.
Gold produced in Canada in January amounted to 328,545 ounces, compared to 277,554 in January, 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Although rated only a sprinter, Jewell Dorsett from the Lone Star Stable carried her speed for a mile today to defeat eight other Louisiana Derby eligibles in the Jasmine Purse at the Fair Grounds. The Derby will be run Sunday.

A general price advance averaging 10 per cent will go into effect on all classes of machine tools April 1, builders reported yesterday. The increases are based chiefly on the higher costs of steel, but are due partly to higher production costs in builders' plants.

A new Maryland law requiring 'forty-eight hours' notice of marriage intentions will put a curb on quick weddings at Elkton and other Maryland "Gretna Greens" after June 1. The new law, effective on that date, provides that $1 must be paid the clerk of the court two days in advance of issuance of a license.

Commander Armando Revoredo Iglesias plans to take off at midnight Friday in a solo non-stop flight to Buenos Aires, Argentina. He will use an eight-passenger four-ton monoplane constructed by the Faucett Aviation Company in Peru and will carry 600 gallons of gasoline and 22 gallons of lubricating oil, also Peruvian products.

The complete "Stabat Mater" of Pergolesi will be sung by the University Women's Chorus, under the direction of Ruggero Vene, tonight at the Spring Street Presbyterian Church. Walter Damrosch will deliver a lecture-recital on "Beethoven and Wagner" tonight at the meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa Alumni and Alunmnae at the Hotel Ambassador.

Stockholders of the Miami Jockey Club announced today approval of corporative action allowing payment of $400,000 in dividends on the outstanding 10,000 shares of preferred and 50,000 shares of common stock.

Paced by Dr. John R. Huffman, the national three-weapon and outdoor saber champion, the powerful New York A. C. team last night successfully defended its national senior saber championship on the strips of the Winged Foot gymnasium.
Lew Raymond, Baltimore welterweight, won from Johnny Bonito, Washington Heights, in the star bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night.

A complaint charging Doran Roach, 27-year-old Negro odd-jobs man, with first-degree murder will be laid before the grand jury on May 10, Prosecutor Abe J. David announced today after the prisoner had shown how he killed Mrs. Louis Kadesh, 60, and critically injured her daughter, Bessie, 23, with an iron pipe after breaking into their apartment at 324 Franklin Place early Monday.

The Federal Home Loan Bank System, now offering thrift and home-financing facilities in almost every county in the United States, will go a long way in preventing the recurrence of a collapse of the nation's mortgage structure such as took place during the recent depression period, according to John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank board.

Germany sent a man to Switzerland today to tell Dr. Ernst Hanfstaengl, in effect: "Come home; all is forgiven." [Dr. Hanfstaengl was reported to have been sent to Spain after losing favor with Chancellor Adolf Hitler. Instead he appeared at a Zurich hotel last week.]

In approving the reorganization plan of the Louisiana Northwestern Railroad, the bureau of finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission suggested, in an opinion made public today, that the plan be modified to eliminate the issuance of guaranteed income securities exceeding $1,000,000 and instead that $1,100,050 of stock be issued to sell at $10 a share.

Yesterday's gradual but sustained recovery in United States Government bonds may have indicated that readjustment in prices of such securities has nearly or quite run its course. The incidents of the recent market have been natural enough, except perhaps for the fact that the decline in prices was more rapid because of having been so long delayed.

The custody of 13-year-old Prince Rainier, heir to the Principality of Monaco, was awarded in Chancery Division of High Court today to his maternal grandfather, Prince Louis II of Monaco, who had waged a long legal fight with the boy's father.
The British Government gave unmistakable proof today that it is determined to check the flood of funds from London to New York, although it has no legislative authority to do so.

A program of music from the organ on the north balcony of Grand Central Terminal will be heard for four hours daily during Holy Week, from noon until 2 P. M. and from 4 to 6 P. M., it was announced yesterday. On Easter morning a dawn service will be sung by the Mary Lee Read singers and a choir of seventy-two children from the Saviour's Lutheran Church, Brooklyn, from 6:45 to 8:30 A. M.

A banking group headed by Bancamerica-Blair Corporation bought at private sale an issue of $1,489,000 Seattle, Wash., municipal light and power revenue 3 3/4 per cent bonds, maturing from April 1, 1943 to 1953, inclusive. The bonds were reoffered for public subscription at prices to yield from 3.75 to 4.10 per cent, according to maturity.
The Duke of Windsor is leaving Enzesfeld Castle next Monday or Tuesday for another temporary home-Appesbach,. near St. Wolfgang, on the Wolfgangsee in the heart of the Salzkammergut Lake district.

After thirteen years of disappointment, Oxford faces an excellent chance of winning the university boat race tomorrow, in the opinion of critics here. Despite the long string of defeats stretching back to 1923, when the Dark Blues scored their last victory, one competent authority says:
It would seem that General QUEIPO DE LLANO has been the victim of a foul slander. He denies that he treated the people

Professor Raymond Moley, whose appearance at the Capitol in the past signified that the administration had brought up its heaviest guns in support of a program, took the witness stand before the Senate Judiciary Committee today to condemn President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the judiciary as an "easy path of expediency" which may eventually lead to the "atrophy and death" of democracy.
Irish Billy Beauhuld, 135, Jersey City, defeated Joe Boscerino, 132, Carbondale, Pa., in an eightrounder tonight. Beauhuld almost ended the fight in the first round, flooring Boscerino twice.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that at the request of the applicants it had consented to the withdrawal of the following registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933:
Two of yesterday's Manhattan deals, one in the Dyckman section and the other on the upper East Side, represented purchases to complete the assembly of large plots.

Because of "four years of domestic and international public policies which have disturbed business and investment confidence, sabotaged production and artificially expanded demand," Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, said in an address last night that "a vicious spiral of ascending costs and prices has been started and in such a situation inflation is-inevitable."
The Interstate Commerce Commission today heard that the railroads now are saving about $175,000,000 a year on locomotive fuel, compared with 1922.
Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott said yesterday that his department would get a new million dollar fireboat, following authorization by the Board of Estimate.

During her record-breaking trip from New York to Bishop's Rock, the French liner Normandie at times reached and maintained a speed of thirty-three knots, it was revealed today when the ship docked here.

A man at the National Military Home has written a novel of 50,110 words without using a single "e." He tied down the "e" bar on his typewriter. The author is Ernest Vincent Wright, 66, of Company 14, a musician in the World War and a Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate of '89.
Twelve army teams will play sixtytwo contests in six sports this season according to the Spring schedules released by Lieut. Col. J. L. Devers, graduate manager of athletics, today.
Jean P. Leinroth of the Public Service Corporation of Newark was elected president of the New Jersey Gas Association here today at the twenty-sixth annual convention of that body.

Mr. and Mrs. Herman Le Roy Emmet will return tomorrow from Bermuda and will be at the Madison. Sir John and Lady Cadman and their daughters have arrived from South America and are at the Pierre before sailing for their home in London.

Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor released today the monthly employment and payroll figures compiled by the department and reported that the February employment index had reached 98.9, its highest level since 1929, while factory weekly payrolls have risen to 95.7, which is the level of April, 1930.

Although 90 per cent of the people of France are opposed to either a Communist or a Fascist dictatorship, the Chamber of Deputies spent yesterday and last night discussing those theoretical dangers, at times waxing hot in the argument. The debate, which began at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, was suspended at 9 o'clock and resumed at 11.

Contrasts between slum dwellings and PWA housing were strikingly demonstrated yesterday to thirty five members of the League of Women Voters of the Fifteenth Assembly District, Manhattan, who toured the Ten Eyck Homes development in Williamsburg, slum dwellings on the East Side and the First Houses project at Avenue A and Third Street.

A renewed drive for legislation to give the government power to take over the twelve Federal Reserve Banks was started today by Representatives Wright Patman of Texas and Charles G. Binderup of Nebraska. Democrats.

More than 400 residents of the First Assembly District, drawn chiefly from civic and social groups in the heart of the lower East Side, enthusiastically endorsed last night a resolution denouncing Assemblyman James J. Dooling of that district for voting against the Child Labor Amendment.

Big fortification works are in process of erection in Czechoslovakia facing the Austrian frontier, according to the newspaper Angriff. These fortifications, mainly huge concrete earthworks, are being built along the Pressburg-PeterzalkaBerg-Lundenburg line, and the entire district is being cut off by gendarmerie and intelligence service officials.
Samuel Goodman, vice president of the Florsheim Shoe Company, was elected yesterday chairman of the board in Chicago to succeed the late Milton Florsheim.

Miss Grace Amory of Westbury, L. I., upset Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L. I., 4 and 3, today to advance to the quarter-final round of the annual woman's invitation golf tournament. Tomorrow she meets Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, three times Georgia State champion, who beat Miss Helen Dettweiler of Washington, 5 and 4.

Dedicating Waco's new $400,000 Federal building and postoffice, Postmaster General Farley pointed to a rise of $35,000,000 in postal receipts over the preceding fiscal year throughout the country as an indication of returning prosperity.

An order authorizing the Long Island Lighting Company to sell $2,000,000 of its first refunding mortgage 4 per cent Series C bonds due on June 1, 1960, at par and accrued interest was published yesterday by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission.
The demands of growing businesses were reflected yesterday in the report that a number of firms in the financial and export districts had taken new and larger quarters.

Taking advantage of the first good weather of the season, the baseball teams of Columbia and Manhattan engaged in a five-inning practice game at Baker Field yesterday. It was an informal contest and no score was kept, Coaches Andy Coakley and Bert Daniels using almost every man on their squads in the course of the drill.

Employes of more than 10,000 public school districts throughout the State, in addition to school teachers, are subject to civil service regulations, a decision of the Appellate Division ruled today.. Associate Justice Benjamin B. Cunningham, in a written opinion, made the ruling in the suit of Calvin D. Palmer of Geddes against

Professor Frank L. Clapp, Professor of Education at the University of Wisconsin for the last seventeen years, died in a Madison hospital today. He underwent a major operation about a month ago. He was 59 years old.

Unless the United States is to suffer serious inflation and share in the economic collapse which will result from a prolonged armament race, the gold content of the dollar must be "emphatically raised" and the budget balanced, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, declared yesterday.

Albert C. Stannard of St. Louis, first vice president of the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, was elected president today to succeed Albert B. Elias, who was made chairman of the board of directors.

Sound economics and proper trade relations are the most satisfactory bases for permanent peace, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, declared yesterday at the thirtieth anniversary luncheon of the Swedish Chamber of Commerce of the United States at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Mayor La Guardia urged yesterday public support of the Salvation Army's Citizens Appeal for $600,000, which will begin at a meeting in the Army's Centennial Auditorium, 120 West Fourteenth Street, on Tuesday, April 6.

Charles Weinblatt, a lawyer, who had represented many Yiddish actors during the last sixteen years, died yesterday morning in the Polyclinic Hospital at the age of 55. Mr. Weinblatt had been counsel for Jewish theatres, and for the Hebrew Actors Union.

Two six-story apartment houses in the Bronx, costing $200,000 and $140,000, and two in Brooklyn, costing $300,000 and $140,000, were filed yesterday. A two-story parochial school for the Church of Our Lady Help of Christians, at 1,302 East Twentyninth Street, Brooklyn, also was announced. The list follows:

Physicians from twenty-nine countries will participate in the First International Conference on Fever Therapy, which will be held for three days next week, beginning Monday, it was announced here yesterday by Dr. William Bierman, general secretary of the conference.

Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, Commissar of the Four-Year Plan, announced today a decree under which the State will appoint a trustee to administrate the affairs of a farmer who fails to meet the demands made by the national self-nourishment program. The State can, if necessary, take complete control of the land, rent it to another farmer and order the owner to cease farming.

Secretary Roper in an address delivered here today said that "a factor of vital concern to both business and labor is the new departure of certain labor units in seizing private property as a means of emphasizing grievances prompting strikes."

The police routed 150 pickets of the Pacific Slipper Company of Clifton, who were paying a call on the forty sit-down strikers in the Atlantic Slipper Company here this afternoon when Eli Mesiansky, owner of the Atlantic shop, reported what he believed to be a riot.

The volume of freight arriving in this port is setting a new record, according to traffic executives. In some instances the piers lack sufficient space and lighters and adjoining roadways have been utilized for storage purposes.

The American boy is buying fewer and costlier harmonicas, according to the Department of Commerce. A total of 10,390,286 mouth organs were imported in 1935, with a value .of $830,746, or an average of slightly less than 8 cents each, while in 1936 the number imported was 9,592,005, valued at $830,789, or an average of nearly 9 cents each.

Dr. Manuel Gimenez Lanier, Secretary of the Interior, was shifted tonight by President Federico Laredo Bru to the Treasury post vacated by the recent resignation of Eduardo Montoulieu, a palace spokesman announced.
A poll of baseball writers conducted by The Sporting News disclosed today overwhelming support for the Yankees and Cardinals in the 1937 major league pennant races.

The situation on the Guadalajara front, northeast of Madrid, is rapidly approaching a deadlock as a result of resistance by Spanish Insurgent monarchists and Fascists, who originally held the line along the Soria road.

Two more newsprint companies, the Minnesota and Ontario Paper Company and the St. Lawrence Paper Company, announced today that they would follow the lead of the International Paper Company and five other Canadian concerns in increasing their contract price for newsprint to $50 a ton for the first half of 1938.

Students enrolled in classes of Dr. Giovanni Conterno, instructor in charge of the band at City College, signed petitions yesterday protesting against the decision of the college administrative committee not to reappoint him in September and asking the Board of Higher Education to reconsider the action of its committee.
Trust funds were held in cash to the amount of $14,458,695.01 for 30,000 individuals by the City Chamberlain's office, Chamberlain A. A. Berle said yesterday in his report for 1936.

The engagement of $3,707,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $3,584,000 in England and $123,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank reported the arrival of $7,980,600 gold from England. Of this amount, the Bank of Manhattan Company received $525,000 that institution announced.

The Senate registered its opposition today to mandatory jury service by women, but indicated that it would pass a bill for permissive jury service. Senator Williamson of Westchester moved to have the Judiciary Committee discharged from consideration of the mandatory bill of Miss Jane Todd,
Oddesa Lady, from the Oddesa Farms, easily chalked up her second straight triumph in the four furlong race for 2-year-olds that attracted the best field at Tropical Park today.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth French, daughter of Mrs. John French of 142 East Thirty-eighth Street and Woodstock, Vt., to Ethan Allen Hitchcock of this city will take place on April 2 at the Brick Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill will perform the ceremony.

Miss Christine Paschall Davis, daughter of Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, and Mrs. Davis of this city, Stockbridge, Mass., and Washington, D. C., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert P. Whiton Stuart of this city at the home of her parents here, 59 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Calumet Hecla Consolidated Copper Company capital stock, $25 par value, has been stricken from listing and registration by the New YorK Stock Exchange. This security was suspended from dealings in September, 1936, and new $5 par value capital stock is now listed.

Clement March, former resident of New York, died this morning at his home, Greenland, Kinderhook, N. Y., after a protracted illness. He was 75 years old. Mr. March was born in the home of his grandfather, Charles March, at 23 Fifth Avenue, New York, in 1862, the son of the late John Pyne and Mary Lowndes March.

Mr. SOLON Low, the new Treasurer of Alberta, has a symbolic name. It stands for the wisdom of Premier ABERHART and the financial condition of the Province. In spite of the courts, Alberta will pay only about half of the interest on its bonds.

John Wight Austin, 36 years old, a disbarred lawyer and former junior partner of the law firm of Choate, Larocque Mitchell at 41 Broad Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon in the District Attorney's office on the charge that he had defrauded clients of the firm and some of his own friends of a total of $360,000 in the last four years.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are March 22, unless specified: Breese, at Lahaina. Clark, Hampton Roads to Southern Drill Grounds, March 23. Cummings, Cristobal to New York Yard via Guantanamo Bay, March 23. Gamble, at Lahaina. Hatfield, La Pallice to sea. Louisville, San Pedro to Puget Sound Yard.

John B. Berryman, chairman of the Crane Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Chicago yesterday that a resumption of common dividends was near, but that he could not say when that would be because preferred dividends in arrears were $5.25 a share, requiring $12.25 in preferred dividends to be paid before the common stock could share in the profits.

The Robinson joint resolution which provides that the appointment of Joseph P. Kennedy of New York to be chairman of the United States Maritime Commission "shall not be deemed to be in violation" of the Maritime Act was reported to the Senate today by the Committee on Commerce.
Alexander W. Weddell, United States Ambassador to Argentina, returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Lucia for his first vacation in three years. He came back filled with praise of Argentina.

Motor car drivers who limit their top speed to fifty miles an hour and adhere to the safety creed of the "Not Over 50" Club are 72 per cent safer than the average motorist, according to results of a survey made public yesterday by the American Lumberman's Mutual Casualty Company of Illinois which fosters the club.

The New York City Cancer Committee will open fourteen booths this morning to recruit members for the Women's Field Army for the Control of Cancer and to disseminate information on the care and cure of the disease, it was announced yesterday. The booths will remain open until Saturday, April 3.

Homer Martin today told the largest crowd of automobile workers and sympathizers ever assembled here that they must "work, strike, fight, march and vote together" toward a common end, which could be achieved without violence. The number in the demonstration was estimated by Police Chief Frahm at 60,000.

Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Byrne in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday an indictment charging Frank Frankel, former Mayor of Long Beach, L. I., with misappropriation of public funds. The indictment charged that Frankel, while Mayor of Long Bea?h prior to 1933, had diverted to the use of relief agencies $221,297 collected by the city as State and county taxes. It was not charged that Frankel had diverted any of the money to his personal use.

James J .Walker, former Mayor, and two psychiatrists were appointed yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi of General Sessions members of a commission to take testimony on the sanity of Lawrence (La-la) Mullens, 34 years old, an ex-convict, one of five gunmen who held up Barney's clothing store on lower Seventh Avenue on the night of Jan. 2.

The offering back to the publishers of about 36,000 unsold copies of the novel "Gone With the Wind" by R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and the acceptance of them by the publishers, the Macmillan Company, together with the announcement by McKessQn Robbins, Inc.,

Harry Balsamo, Harlem middleweight, stopped Tait Littman, Milwaukee veteran, after 1:45 of the first round in their scheduled tenround feature bout before 3,500 persons at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
John L. Lewis said tonight that he would try to contribute "constructively" toward settlement of the Chrysler automobile strike at a conference tomorrow with Walter P. Chrysler and Governor Murphy.

A petty larceny charge against James Harper, 34 years old, of 9 Ascot Ridge, Great Neck, L. I., brought by the Hotel Pennsylvania after a $50 check cashed there was returned marked "No funds," was withdrawn in Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning.
The Republicans in the Assembly have decided not to fight Governor Lehman's main budget bills. They will bring the bills out of Ways and Means Committee in the form in which
New Rochelle High School won the first indoor track-and-field championship at the County Center tonight and gained a leg on the three-year trophy offered by the County Recreation Commission.

Captain Dwight Longendyke, for years a master of freight vessels on the Hudson River, died on Sunday at Rhinecliff, N. Y. His age was 73. Captain Longendyke lived in Kingston. He had followed a river career for many years.

FIRE insurance salesmen are only a nuisance when one's house is burning down. At a time like that one wants succor and assistance, not sales talk and good advice. All the policies in the world won't beat out flames in the attic or stay a roof from falling in.
President Roosevelt continued his vacation here today, but kept in close touch with the labor crisis caused by sit-down strikes in Detroit and elsewhere throughout the country.

A 44-year-old veteran of the tennis courts will take on the world's amateur champion of the past three years in Madison Square Garden tonight and the prospect is that upward of 15,000 people will pay in some $30,000 to see the match.

Genia Robinor and Louis Bailly presented a program for piano and viola at the Town Hall last night. This combination of instruments is seldom heard in the local concert halls, and while the repertoire for it is limited there are works that deserve to be performed. Miss Robinor and Mr. Bailly plan another concert with a complete change of program for April 26.

A sit-down strike in five of the F. W. Grand stores operated by the X. L. Green Company appeared to have been ended last night as representatives of the Department Store Employes Union and officials of the company reached an agreement at a meeting at the New Yorker Hotel.

Eight hours and five minutes after having left Honolulu, the Pan American Clipper alighted on the lagoon here tonight, ending the second leg of our 7,000-mile survey flight from Alameda, Calif., to New Zealand.

Petitions for the appointment of a separate trustee for the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway Company, a part of the Missouri Pacific lines, were filed in Federal court today by the Irving Trust Company of New York, trustee under a first mortgage, and a committee of five men representing holders of first mortgage bonds of the railroad.

Increasing tension between the Japanese military in North China and General Sung Cheh-Yuan's Twenty-ninth Army, which is garrisoned in Hopei and Chahar Provinces, took the form yesterday of three demands made by First Secretary Denjiro Kato of the Japanese Embassy in Peiping upon Peiping's Mayor, General Chin TeChun.

Harry Linton, 52 years old, was suffocated last night by smoke from a fire in the bedroom of an apartment in which he lived with his father, John Linton, 76, and mother, Mary, 68, on the second floor of a three-story building at 485 Elderts Lane in the East New York district of Brooklyn.

The Emergency Relief Bureau reported yesterday that its supply of skilled construction workers was virtually exhausted, but the Works Progress Administration announced that 37,915 skilled laborers were employed on local engineering projects.

Failure of the March income-tax returns to meet the expectations of the Treasury, as indicated by receipts cleared up to today, has served to concentrate attention upon the necessity of exerting every effort to keep down emergency expenditures if an upset in the Federal budget estimates for the current fiscal year and the fiscal year 1938 is to be avoided.

Edward R. Dunning, executive vice president and manager of the New York office of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., addressed more than 300 members of THE NEW YORK TIMES class in national newspaper advertising last night at The Times Building.

Yale University's crack swimming team tuned up for the national collegiate championships at Minneapolis Friday and Saturday by routing a picked squad of Northern Ohio stars, 53 to 22, in a dual meet tonight.
Steel ingot output increased last week when a slight decline was seasonal and the adjusted index advanced to 120.4 from 118.1. It was 78.1 for the week ended March 21, 1936.

A twenty-six-year leasehold formerly held by the Bank of United States, in liquidation, on the property at 168-04-18 Jamaica Avenue, and the Armory Garage on 168th Street, Jamaica, Queens, has been acquired by the Jamaica-168 Corporation.
A reign of terror in the trucking industry four years ago formed the basis yesterday of indictments handed up by the special grand jury against two living men and a dead one.

Miss Mary Frances Mason, who retired as superintendent of the City Hospital Nurses Training School here in 1922 after holding the post for twenty-four years, died yesterday at her home here. She was born in Newark, attended the Nurses School and was made an assistant superintendent after her graduation in 1898. Eight months later she was made superintendent.

The first tangible outcome of King Leopold's visit to London developed today when it became known that after the present by-election had ceased to engage the attention of Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium, Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, would probably go to Brussels to initiate negotiations over Belgium's future status.

Members of the bar and the judiciary participated in a memorial service in the Supreme Court here this afternoon for George A. Slater, Surrogate of Westchester County for eighteen years, who died on Feb. 23. Surrogate William J.

Aetna Ball Bearing Manufacturing Carlton M. Higbie Corporation of Detroit and Rawson Lizars Co. of Chicago will offer today 54,675 shares of common stock in the Aetna Ball Bearing Manufacturing Company of Chicago, priced at $12.75 a share.

Holders of stock of the Flintkote Company at their annual meeting today are to be asked to approve the decision of the board of directors to reserve 10,000 shares of the company's authorized but unissued common stock for issuance to employes from time to time.

Filing in the United States District Court in Brooklyn of the modified reorganization plan for the Bush Terminal Company and its subsidiary, Bush Terminal Buildings Company, which had been scheduled for yesterday, was adjourred until Friday at 2 P. M.

Herbert Bennett, president of the New York State Electrical Workers Association, former chairman of the Harrison Fire Commission and former Harrison School Trustee, died yesterday at his home. He was 53 years old.

Sit-down strikes and other industrial disputes probably would be considerably fewer if there were free and accepted functioning of the Wagner Labor Relations Act, Secretary Perkins asserted today at a press conference.

Norman D. Darmstatter, dean of insurance men here and a member of the old Passaic City Council, died at his home here this morning. He was 61 years old. He was president of the Passaic Park Building and Loan Association.

In a decision handed down yesterday, Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman awarded Allen N. Spooner Son, Inc., $528 in their suit against the city for $400,000 in connection with the construction of the Hudson River piers where the Normandie and Queen Mary are berthed.

A plea that non-striking employes who are prevented from working have property rights in their jobs just as much as sit-down strikers was put before Judge George A. Welsh today in Federal District Court by John Rhoda, counsel for the Rosedale Employes Association.

The hardening tendency of the money market was carried further yesterday when discounts on bankers' acceptance were increased by from one-eighth to three-sixteenths of 1 per cent and the rate on prime commercial paper rose from threefourths to 1 per cent.

The sale of 85,000 shares of New York Central Railroad stock in the open market by the Delaware Hudson Company, of which L. H. Loree is president, to help raise funds for a $7,500,000 bond maturity was announced yesterday by F. W. Leamy, vice president of the D. H. About $3,750,000 was realized from the sale, or about $44 a share. he added.

The Supreme Court of Nicaragua decided today that Nicaraguan currency-cordobas-must be accepted in payment of debts regardless of its value. Mrs. Manuela Cajina attempted to collect on a mortgage in which there was a clause stating the debtor would pay at a rate of exchange equal to the United States dollar.

More than 2,000,000 white-collar workers and others, earning up to [Pound]400 a year, were brought into the British Government's vast social security program today when a bill was submitted to Parliament enabling them to insure themselves for widows', orphans' and old-age pensions.

The Bishop of Linz, Dr. Gfoellner, has just returned from a visit to Steenockerzeel, Belgium, where, on Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's behalf, he endeavored to minimize to Archduke Otto the effect of the Italian declaration that the Austrian monarchist agitation was a public nuisance.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William F. Finney of Plainfield, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosemary Finney, to William E. Edmonston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar D. Edmonston of Baltimore.

A resolution denouncing sit-down strikes and asking an investigation of their causes with a view to enacting remedial legislation was introduced in the House today by Representative Dies of Texas. He had previously bitterly attacked leaders of the sit-downers in a half-hour speech which received repeated outbursts of applause.

A Gloucester County grand jury ignored the instructions of Supreme Court Justice Frank T. Lloyd here today and refused to return a murder indictment against Edward Hubbard, 28-year-old Monroeville farmer. It was the third grand jury since the slaying of Layton H. Hessler, 22, of Williamstown, on Labor Day, 1936, to refuse to return an indictment in the case.

A bill just offered in the Dominion Parliament provides for a coast-to-coast airway which comes much nearer to being di a publicly owned enterprise than had been expected. Its introduction followed failure of the government to get Canadian aviation interests to cooperate.

Following an open hearing of the pending controversy between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers Union, an order has been issued by the Wayne Circuit Court requiring evacuation of occupied plants.

Frequent quarrels between man and wife do not furnish grounds for a legal separation, the Court of Appeals ruled today in the case of Elsie Smith, who charged that her husband, Thomas P. Smith Jr. of Brooklyn, had been cruel.

President Roosevelt expressed the hope today that there would be no increase in taxes at the current session of Congress. His remark was made at a press conference in reply to a question arising out of the suggestion for increased profits and income taxes to balance the Federal budget and prevent inflation made last week by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

While business failures decline the manufacturing division in the week ended March 18, compared with the previous week, there was an increase from 91 to 123 in the retail group, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

That stores throughout the country will promote private brands on a quality appeal, based on testing, was indicated yesterday with reports of a sharp rise in the number of testing laboratories being installed in retail establishments.

Captain Edward Clark, Secretary of State and National Guard officer, who participated in the court of inquiry into the New London school disaster, told Governor Allred today that the investigation had uncovered nothing to warrant prosecution.

Governor Lehman recommended in a special message to the Legislature the adoption of two constitutional amendments to set up a $100,000,000 revolving fund for housing loans to municipalities for slum clearance.

Crude-oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,448,150 barrels daily, a new high record, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Output was 75,300 barrels more than the average of 3,372,850 daily, the previous record, in the preceding week.

Creation of a single department of national defense, with three coequal branches, the air, the navy and the army, was advocated yesterday by Major Gen. William C. Rivers, retired, who served fortyseven years in the army.

Favored sextets reached the quarter finals today in the women's national A. A. U. basketball tournament. The champion Tulsa Stenos, who drew a first-round bye, advanced at the expense of the Wamego (Kan.) High School team.

Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin of Britain, in speaking yesterday to a freetrade deputation, was addressing himself to other possibilities than the prospective negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement for the United Kingdom and the United States, according to interpretations placed on his remarks here today.
John McIntosh, 21 years old, accused of beating his father to death, was acquitted by a jury in the Queens County Court yesterday after two hours' deliberation.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 20: CAPTAINS Beauregard, A. T., Naval War College, Newport, R. I.; to command the New Orleans. Kinkaid, T. C., Bureau of Navigation, Navy Department; to command the Indianapolis. Van Mater, R. K. (S. C.), Aircraft Base Force; to Navy Yard, Washington, D. C.
Increases of $309,780 in maintenance expenditures and of $347,512 in tax accruals largely accounted for a decrease of $165,326 in the Norfolk Western Railway's net income for February.

The American "strip tease" may be art, but "it's too hot for England." That is the dictum of George Black, British producer, after a preview of Diane Raye doing her Broadway specialty. She was imported from New York for a new show to open Monday, but the argument over "strip teasing" started even before she landed in England.

In accordance with his wish, a simple funeral service was held for Jacob de Haas, a leader in the Zionist movement, yesterday morning in his home at 50 Morningside Drive. The Rev. Dr. David De Sola Pool, rabbi of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, officiated.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has bought three paintings from the 112th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design, now current at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The paintings, which will hang in the museum's permanent collection, are all by artists hitherto unrepresented in the museum.

Two judges of the United States District Court, attorneys and members of the 369th Infantry, the former Fifteenth, with which he served during the World War, winning the Croix de Guerre with palms, yesterday attended funeral services for Lieut. Col. Seth B. MacClinton.

Ernest Angell, New York regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will deliver the sixth of a series of eight lectures on the New Wall Street being given under the direction of Rudolph L. Weissman of Robinson,
Leasing of an apartment of sixteen rooms and seven baths in 117 East Seventy-second Street by Fraser M. Horn, lawyer, was the leading item of the residential rentals reported by brokers yesterday.
Chicago was free from sit-down strikes tonight as a result of the determined action of the police and State's Attorney's office to halt the occupation of property by sitters.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Socity of New York yesterday made known the dates for the 1937-38 season of Young People's Concerts under the direction of Ernest Schelling. As has been the custom, the concerts will be given on Saturday mornings at Carnegie Hall.

The six-story apartment house at 500 West 144th Street, corner of Hamilton Place, on a plot 125 by 99 feet, has been sold by the 500 West 144th Street Corporation to an investing client of Levy, Murphy Stolz.

Negotiations between Brazil and foreign creditors to fix a new basis for its foreign debt payment plan will be begun again next week. According to Treasury officials, tentative parleys have been going on for some time and a new basis has been studied, though nothing definite has been settled yet.

County Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea, whose views on sit-down strikes have aroused the opposition of other officials, declared today that if subpoenaed he would testify for the United Automobile Workers of America against the police on the question of evictions.

Scores of children threw eggs, vegetables and rocks at Frank F. Candioto, their citizenship teacher, last night in protest against establishment of a playground in a section not favored by the children.
The administration's $100,000,000 Crop Insurance Bill reached the Senate floor today, accompanied by a favorable report from the agricultural committee which approved it after adding an amendment to

The Philadelphia Company, holding its meeting in Pittsburgh on April 27, will be asked to approve the act of the board of directors in granting an indefinite extension of the respective dates on which scrip certificates issued as common-stock dividends on April 30, July 30 and Oct. 31, 1927, and on Jan. 31, 1928, may be exchanged for full shares, subject to sixty days notice of cancellation of the privilege by resolution of the board.

Hearing Av. (16-4455). e s. 180 ft s of Mace Av., 45x100; J. Chris Murray, referee, to Julia Brand, 1,131 Waring Av., mtg., $12,000. Butterick Av., 214 (18-5606), Lofaro Realty Corp. to Vincent Serino, 214 Butterick Av. TRemont Av. (11-2867),
Although the training campaign finds the Giants zooming along at a most amazing pace, Colonel Bill Terry still has a few problems to which a final answer remains to be written.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, opened its concert last night in Carnegie Hall with a composition of a novelty that startled a majority in the audience. The work in question is the D minor Passacaglia for organ, as instrumentated by Lucien Cailliet.

Important changes in English Rugby rules affecting scrummaging and converting of penalty tries have been made by the International Derby Board. Proposal to cut down the value of a drop-kicked goal from four points was considered but it was decided to make no change.
WAUOH IN ABYSSINIA, by Evelyn Waugh. (Longmans, Green, $2.50.) Mr. Waugh writes of his experiences as a war correspondent and also as the first non-Italian visitor to Ethiopia under Italian rule.

Governor Lehman recommended today that the State's milk advertising campaign be continued for another year despite a report from the special legislative committee on the milk problem which advised abandonment of that campaign.
Small dwellings figured in most of the' realty deals reported in Brooklyn yesterday. Three residential sales were announced by William G. Kittelberger, broker.

Larger supplies of hogs, in part representing supplies which should have arrived yesterday, had a depressing effect on prices, which declined 10 to 15 cents. The top sale of $10.40 was 10 cents below Monday and the day's average was- 10 cents lower at $10.15.

Ten thousand employes of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in three Pittsburgh district plants received today a guaranteed wage increase of 8 cents an hour for men and 6 cents for women.

For thirtysix hours now the aged Duke of Bedford has been sitting in his bedroom in Woburn Abbey answering all telephone calls with the gradually fading hope that he may hear his wife's voice saying she is safe. She is involved in one of the strangest mysteries in British
An organization of local men who served in the United States Ambulance Service with the French Army, the Mallet Reserve, and the Norton-Harjes and American Field Service units during the World War,

Simon Frank, who was active in religious, social and political work in the Borough Park district of Brooklyn, and who was deputy sheriff of Kings County twenty years ago, died on Monday at his home, 1,424 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of several weeks. He was 80 years old.
In a bitter contest that had as its climax a mass fist fight, the Rangers reversed the dope by upsetting the Maple Leafs tonight before 15,000 spectators.

Details of the United Cigar Store Company recapitalization plan are expected to be announced on Monday, it was learned yesterday.- It is understood to give preferred shareholders twenty shares of new common for each share of old preferred.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday were less than in the preceding week. The total was also well below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

With 125 in attendance, the eighth annual Oxford and Cambridge dinner was held at the Harvard Club last night on the eve of the famous boat race between the universities on the Thames. It was felt by most of the guests that Cambridge would win.

Imminence of a shortage of skilled laborers, due chiefly to the suspension of training programs and the abandonment of trades by trained workers during the depression, is anticipated by the National Industrial Conference Board

Stockholders of the Foundation Company voted yesterday to increase the authorized capital to 500,000 shares to provide 400,000 new shares for financing purposes, and approved the change from no par to $1 par value. It is proposed to offer 150.000 new shares to stockholders at $7.50 a share on the basis of 1 1/2 new shares for each present share.

The designation of William P. Kenneally, one of the leaders of the Twelfth Assembly District, as spokesman for Tammany during the illness of James J. Dooling, now in Florida, is the latest suggestion for preparing the Manhattan Democratic organization for the coming Mayoralty campaign, it was learned yesterday.

A funeral service for Frederick William MacMonnies, American sculptor, will be held tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, 36 Fifth Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Donald Aldrich. the rector, will Officiate.

The lone remaining out-of-town team, St. Cecilia High of Elizabeth, N. J., was eliminated from the eighth annual metropolitan Catholic high school invitation basketball tournament last night at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, clubhouse, bowing to St. Simon Stock of the Bronx, 23-20, in the quarter-final round.

The Federal Trade Commission made public a set of trade practice rules today to govern the wet-ground mica industry. This product is used extensively in the manufacture of rubber, wallpaper and paint, has a total invested capital of about $1,000,000 and has annual sales amounting to about $300,000.

The collection of Shakespeare's portrait material formed over many years by the veteran British Shakespeare authority, Marion H. Spielmann, has been bought by Gabriel Wells and will be brought to this country.

Macklin Marrow, composer and conductor, and Miss Violet Orthwein of this city and St. Louis were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Lockhart Amerman, in the presence of relatives and a few friends.

An assertion that a virtual monopoly exists in the radio broadcasting industry was made by Representative Richard B. Wigglesworth, Republican, of Massachusetts, before the House Rules Committee today. He supported a proposal to appoint a special committee to investigate the broadcasting field.
The Senate passed today the McCall bill authorizing savings banks for another year to invest in railroad securities that do not meet the strict requirements of the Banking Law.

The field of twelve which will compete in the world pocket billiard title tournament starting next Monday was completed yesterday when Jimmy Caras, defending champion, posted his entry fee. The contest will be held at the Ponzi Billiard Academy for $8,000 in prizes.

After early signs of weakness induced by declines in Paris quotations and news from Wall Street yesterday, the stock market here closed stronger today. Gilt-edge issues did better, and among the foreign securities Brazilian issues staged a small recovery. International stocks were irregular. International Nickel shares rebounded from their recent depression, but those of United States Steel fell.

The engagement of Mrs. Viola E. McMurray, former wife of William J. McMurray of New York, to Rene Morgan La Montasne, also of that city, both of whom have been spending the season here, has just been announced.

The tentative schedule of Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championship dates, which will be acted upon by delegates at the general meeting at the Harvard Club on Friday, April 2, contains twenty-two regattas, one of them not yet assigned. The list was announced yesterday by Secretary Kingsley Kunhardt.

Senator Rush D. Holt of West Virginia said today President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley are "cracking the party whip" for the President's court reorganization plan. He spoke under the auspices of the North Carolina Political Union, non-partisan student organization at the University

Arthur T. Vanderbilt, trustee of the Lincoln Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company, sold to the Inter-Suburb Realty Corporation for an indicated consideration of $85,000 the four-story twenty-eight family flat,

Prices on the Cotton Exchange lost yesterday virtually all of Monday's recovery and under scattered realizing by both domestic and foreign holders closed with losses of 12 to 18 points. A reaction abroad offset the influence of a brisk upturn in the outside markets here, and while mills continued to fix prices on near months, new crop positions eased under liquidating pressure. May ended 26 points under spot quotations at the designated markets.

The section of painting and sculpture of the Treasury has invited twelve painters and three sculptors to execute decorations for the new building of the Department of the Interior. The theme of panels in the main stairwell will be conservation, and other themes to be treated pictorially are reclamation,

As a trustee for Chesapeake Corporation ten-year 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds due in 1944, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York has notified the Stock Exchange of the conversion of $15,000 of bonds and the consequent withdrawal of 300 shares of Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company stock from the pledged collateral.

Eugene C. Rogers, a son of the late Gilbert Rogers, who was a founder of C. Rogers Bros., Meriden (Conn.) silverware manufacturers, later merged in the International Silver Company, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home, 350 East Fifty-first Street.
James T. Farrell, whose recently published "A World I Never Made" caused a storm, has completed a volume of short stories that will be published early in May by Vanguard.

Angered by what a large part of the world's press, especially British newspapers, have been writing about events in which Italy is directly or indirectly concerned, Premier Benito Mussolini delivered today a characteristic speech to a large crowd of Fascisti, giving vent to his feelings in language more uncontrolled than he has used in recent times.
Slush ice reported ten to fifteen feet thick in some spots today postponed plans for opening the Port of Buffalo to Lake Erie shipping.

Chief Little Wolf, 218, of Colorado pinned Mike Mazurki, 228, of New York in 25:02 of a feature finish wrestling exhibition at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The Indian scored with a flying tackle and body spread.

Promptly at noon yesterday Max Schmeling announced that the deadline for acceptance of his $350,000 offer to James J. Braddock for a title meeting in Germany next Summer had passed and that the entire proposition has been withdrawn.

In a characteristic speech yesterday MUSSOLINI celebrated the eighteenth anniversary of the birth of Fascism. Primarily the discourse was addressed to Great Britain and is to be interpreted as another contribution to the increasingly acrimonious debate between Rome and London.

In applying for registration of its Class A no-par common stock, the Gabriel Company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission an intention to offer 7,000 shares at about $7 a share on a brokerage basis, without underwriting. As of March 1, the company had 300,000 shares of this class authorized, 255,112 outstanding,
The short position in all stocks on the New York Curb Exchange on Feb. 26 was 83,259 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday. This figure compared with 86,597 shares on Jan. 29.

Packers selling goods to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company are requested to place trade allowances in escrow with the Chemical Bank and Trust Company of New the York, according to testimony adduced today at the Federal Trade Commission hearing in this city on trade practices of the company.

W. A. Thomas, president of the Humble Employes Security League, said today that 86 per cent of workers in the Baytown plant of the Humble Oil and Refining Company had signed a pledge to oppose C. I. O. organization.

Mrs. Madeleine la Ferriere, who police said admitted she shot Count Charles de Chambrun, former French Ambassador to Italy, because he thwarted her love for Premier Mussolini of Italy, received today a week's respite from an intensive police inquiry of the attack.

The new price level reached by United States Government bonds on Monday induced sufficient buying power in yesterday's market on the New York Stock Exchange to bring about a substantial rally throughout the list.

Feeling that the publicity peak has been reached on the controversy over who shall appear in "Gone With the Wind," Selznick International has begun to solidify plans for production of the Margaret Mitchell novel, and it is probable that shooting will begin by the end of May.
Twenty-six of the fifty-six men who, as members of Congress, voted against the declaration of war by the United States in 1917 will dine here on April 6 to mark the twentieth anniversary

The "Musical Moments" broadcast of the Chevrolet Motor Company, canceled at the beginning of the recent General Motors strike, will be resumed within the next week on an even larger scale than before.

James Caras, world champion, took a 3-1 lead over Ralph Greenleaf in their twelve-block pocket billiard match by winning both the afternoon and evening encounters at the Strand Billiard Academy yesterday. In the afternoon Caras conquered Greenleaf, 125-76, in nine innings, while in the evening he was victorious by a 125-86 count in ten frames.
The newspaper Echo de Paris reprints today an account from a Havre newspaper declaring that 119 volunteers for the war in Spain landed at Havre from the United States liner Washington last Wednesday.

Franklin Allan Wagner of Colonial Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital of heart disease after a fiveweek illness. His age was 59. A lawyer and corporation official, he had long been a member of the law firm of Davis Wagner, 120 Broadway.

On his own application: PATROLMAN - James Sweeney, 114th Pct., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 10, 1905. Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-Ralph C. Lewis, 47th Pct., assigned to clerical duty; James T. Keans, from 44th to 25th Pct.; John P. Cunningham, from 105th to 114th Pct.

The estate of Robert N. Brown, consisting of a white frame Colonial house and outbuildings on more than eleven acres on the westerly side of Bacon Road in Old Westbury, L. I., has been sold for occupancy to a client of HenryA.

A resolution authorizing the cancellation of the war debts owed to the United States by the governments of Great Britain and France, but calling for the collection of the full amounts owed by the "dictatorship States," was introduced in the House today by Representative William I. Sirovich of New York. It read as follows:

Black Highbrow, the fast-stepping 4-year-old of D. J. Sullivan 3d, closed with a rush to win the feature race before some 8,000 fans at Epsom Downs today. Time for the six furlongs was 1:123-5. It was Elks Day, and the top race was the Elks Claiming Handicap.

Filipino representation has been added to the American delegation which will attend the International Sugar Conference in London on April 5. under the auspices of the president of the economic commission of the London Economic Conference of 1933.

The guest of honor at the luncheon meeting of the Pan-American League in the dining room at the International Pan-American Airport today was Mrs. Clayton Sedgwick Cooper, widow of the late president of the committee of one hundred.

Pupils of the Central School in South Huntington demonstrated their loyalty to their principal, James E. Wardle, today with a combined sit-down, walk-out strike and picketing to the beat of drums and the chanting of "We want Wardle!"

Slavko Gruitch, Yugoslavian Minister who came to London in September, 1935, from Washington, died at his legation here of a heart attack this morning. His age was 66. Mr. Gruitch had long served his country in the United States, where he was widely known.

24th St., 325 E., 25x98.9; president and directors of the Manhattan Company to Max Sperling, 602 W. 139th St. ($12). 31st St., 434 W., vacant, 22x91; United Hospital to John L. Collins, 411 Godwin Av., Ridgewood, N. J. ($4).

Testifying at a hearing of the National Labor Relations Board at 45 Broadway, yesterday, five former employes of the Borden Milk Company charged that they were dismissed for union activities. The hearing was on a complaint filed agaizist the company charging it with violations of the National Labor Relations Act. Charles Wood, trial examiner, presided.

That brand of baseball peculiar to Brooklyn upset the calm of Waterfront Park today but the Yankees managed to fight off the Dodgers in the opener of their fivegame series and gain their seventh victory in nine starts before a gathering of about 1,500. The score was 9-6.

Nine teams have forwarded their entries for St. John's University's eighth annual metropolitan intercollegiate invitation rifle match which will be held at the Manhattan School of Firearms on April 3, it was announced yesterday.

Gross business of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company is larger than a year ago, and net profits probably are higher too, A. E. Goodhue, vice president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday in Jersey City. No announcement could be made at this time regarding a capital readjustment plan, it was stated.

BRANNAN, EUNICE DANA (Nov. 14, 1936). Gross assets, $102,324; net, $99,947. To Eleanor Brannan, daughter, and Dana Brannan, son, one-half residue in trust each. Chief assets: stocks and bonds, $96,945. Chase Mellen, attorney, 43 Cedar St. CAHN, ELIAS (May 17, 1936). Gross assets, $22,883; net, $21,824. To George Cahn, brother, residue. Chief assets: stocks and bonds, $19,223. Levinson, Niner Levisohn, attorneys, 366 Madison Av.

The Worcester, Mass., Art Museum has acquired the important Flemish painting "The Rest on the Flight Into Egypt" by Quentin Massys (1466-1530). The purchase was made through Durlacher Brothers, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, at whose gallery it was exhibited last November in an exhibition of paintings by Massys.

Passengers sailing today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include Lord Aberconway, chairman of John Brown, Ltd., British ship builders, Lord and Lady Plunket, the Duchess of Sutherland, Lady Gladys Burney, Miss Cecilia Colledge, figure skating champion; Mrs. James Duguid,

An impassable burglar alarm barrier of "black light," which spreads a net of invisible rays over a large area by means of tiny hidden mirrors and sets off alarms in distant places without intruders being aware of it was demonstrated yesterday in the General Electric Building, at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

The first group of Christian German refugees to depart from Europe with the aid of the American Committee for Christian German Refugees are bound for Colombia aboard the steamer Virgilio, which sailed from Marseilles. The committee has paid all expenses of the voyage of the fifty men, women and children.
Mrs. Mark Garrison of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Hildegarde Bushnell, to Theodore R. Sucher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Sucher of New Haven, Conn.

Governor Lehman in a special message to the Legislature today urged favorable action on two constitutional amendments to prepare the way for State. and municipal participation in expenditures for slum clearance and housing projects.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 22: MAJOR GENERAL Hughes, J. H., General Staff Corps, 3 days' leave, about March 26. COLONELS Fair, ?. S. (Cav.), National Guard Bureau, 1 month and 7 days' leave, March 23. Beebe, ?. E., Inf., Ft. Hamilton, N. Y.. detailed in the Inspector General's Dept. and ordered to Washington, D. C., Sept. 17.

Sidney Newborg, as trustee, sold to Benjamin Zimmerman the premises at 195-197 W. Tenth St., taking back a purchase money mortgage for $84,500, due in five years at 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 per cent, with quarterly amortization of $211.25 to $422.50, the stated consideration on the sale being $101,000.

The city's maternal death rate was further reduced last week when five deaths occurred, bringing the rate to 2.6, the lowest since the week ending Jan. 30, when it was 2.1, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. The rate for the eleven weeks since the first of the year is 4.2 as against 4.8 for the corresponding period in 1936 and 5.0 for the same period in 1935.
The rector of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem brings the hopeful word of "ultimate peace and amity" between Arabs and Jews in Palestine.

Threats of higher prices and fears that sit-down strikes may tie up shipments of American products have brought about a spurt in export sales. Exporters reported yesterday that foreign customers are calling for immediate shipment of goods already on order and placing commitments for additional quantities.

G. Stanley Cochrane, the saxophone soloist who manages the Detroit Tigers, sat in the shade and said cheerfully that he was afraid everything was going to be all right. "Greenberg is himself again," said Black Mike. "That will make a whale of a difference in our team. Hank played only ten games for us last year, you know."

The restaurant racket case will go to a jury in Supreme Court today, it was indicated last night when defense attorneys completed two days of summing up evidence. Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook ordered another night session to hasten the case to its close.
Students who survived the explosion which killed 455 schoolmates and teachers here last week will resume classwork near the scene Monday, the School Board decided tonight.

Sentencing a taxicab driver to sixty days in the workhouse and imposing also fines totaling $200, Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio complained bitterly yesterday that he could not impose harsher penalties. The chauffeur had pleaded guilty in Intoxication Court to driving while intoxicated and obtaining a license fraudulently.

Sales of copper were made yesterday at 17.225 cents a pound c. i. f. the European base ports. The greater part of the trading, however, was done around 16.80 cents. It is understood that there were some rather heavy purchases of the metal by Japanese interests.

At a meeting of The World-Telegram unit of the New York Newspaper Guild last night a resolution to call a strike on Monday in the event that The World-Telegram had not made satisfactory concessions before that time was rejected by a vote of 91 to 66.

Although he is on relief, John Dean, a Negro, has been able to entertain women handsomely ever since New Year's Eve, but he also suffered heavily in dice games. His story was told yesterday to United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter by John J. Dowling, Assistant United States Attorney, who accused the Negro of cashing stolen relief checks.

A warning against uniform packaging of a line of products was sounded yesterday by Egmont Arens, designer, at the-conference on packaging sponsored by the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Such uniformity may destroy the individuality of each product, he said, one of the drawbacks of the country store, which tends to exist today in certain drug store items.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 22: CAPTAINS Baggaley, W., Washington, D. C., to duty as commander of Destroyer Squadron 1. in May. Barker, G. N., Harvard University. Cambridge, Mass., to command the Houston, about June 28. Earle, J. B., the New Orleans, to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C., July 26. Fitch, A. W., the Lexington. to instruction at the Naval War College, Newport, R. I., in June.

The marriage of Miss Rena Rhonheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Rhonheimer of 525 West End Avenue, to Harold Shonberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac I. Shonberg of Brooklyn, took place last night at the home of the bride's parents.

The Rev. John J. Donovan, assistant director of the Division of Families of the Catholic Charities of the New York Archdiocese, has been appointed director of that division, according to an announcement yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, secretary to Cardinal Haves for Charities.

Contrary to the general result among other railroads, the Lehigh Valley Railroad may not have benefited last year from the deduce tion in passenger fares made on June 1, E. E. Loomis, president, said in the annual report issued yesterday. The reduction was made by order of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Board of Education of the Central School at South Huntington moved a step ahead of its striking school children today by advancing the opening of Easter vacation from Thursday and closing the building twenty-four hours ahead of schedule.
Sir Thomas Mottram, the government's chief inspector of mines, 1920-24, and one of the world's leading mining experts, died today in Doncaster at the age of 78.
Robert Adair, Montreal financier, died in a hospital today after a short illness. He was a native of Scotland and came to Montreal at the age of 19. He was 73 years old.
A general voluntary return to a forty-hour week by those cotton mills which had lengthened hours in recent months was predicted in the local market yesterday.

Harvard's Spring football squad was swelled to eighty-six today, when forty-four upper-classmen joined the forty-two freshmen who began Spring practice last week. The workout was held at Soldiers Field.

Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General in New York, will arrive today from France on the French liner Paris. Also on the liner are Thomas W. Lamont, banker, and Mrs. Lamont; Vincent Mayers, banker; George F. Keller, Colonel H. R. Isham, Baron and Baroness Jean Pollenc, Mrs. Myriam Gruenberger, Countess de la Falaise, Baroness de Luze.
Henry Ford today is ready to "do business" with his employes, but not according to any rules that may be laid down by Homer Martin, youthful President of the United Automobile workers of America.

A radio block signal system for the airlines of the country, which will inform the pilot of his exact position in any sort of weather, is being planned by a committee of technical experts of the Bureau of Air Commerce.

Powerless at the plate until the last of the ninth, the Cardinals dropped an exhibition game to the Senators, 5 to 3, today. A loose first inning allowed the Senators two runs. Joe Medwick's homer in the last of the ninth with Stu Martin and Pepper Martin on brought the only Card tallies. The score by innings:
Ex- wit ports of fresh fruits from the United States in 1936 were valued at $38,866,385, compared to $43,472, 594 in 1935 and $32,707,391 in 1934, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The Senate debated neutrality proposals, approved a resolution declaring Joseph P. Kennedy eligible to membership on the Maritime Commission, received from Senator Borah a proposal for a new child labor amendment and adjourned at 3:41 P. M., until noon tomorrow.

Making her maiden trip from Southampton, England, to Cairo, Egypt, the British four-motored flying boat Capricornus crashed this afternoon in a forced landing on the fir-fringed slopes of Beaujolais Mountain, thirty miles north of here. Four of the five men in the crew were killed outright. The only passenger, Miss B. M. Coates, died of her injuries.

The Argentine Government has decided to apply about $40,000,000 out of the cash resources of its treasury to the retirement by Oct. 1, next, of the entire amount of its two issues of external 6 per cent bonds, due respectively on Oct. 1, 1959 and 1960, it was announced yesterday on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz,

One seeing the moon as it shone in its glory Tuesday night would be disposed to let it determine the recurrence of Easter: "the first Sunday after the " full moon which happens upon or next "after the twenty-first day of March; "and if the full moon happens upon a "Sunday, Easter Day is the Sunday "after."

Twentieth Century-Fox will deposit today its new picturization of Austin Strong's "Seventh Heaven" at the Radio City Music Hall. Simone Simon and James Stewart have the roles delineated by Janet Gaynor and Charles Farrell in the silent version in 1927. The supporting company includes Jean Hersholt, Gregory Ratoff, Gale Sondergaard, J. Edwin Bromberg and Mady Christians.

A"black ice cream cone" swept through the outskirts of Winchester and cut a swath through Clark County late today, injuring at least thirty persons, five seriously, and destroying between twelve and fifteen homes.

A new language was added last night to New York's babel of tongues when Dr. Max Talmey read parts of President Roosevelt's speech at Buenos Aires translated into Gloro, an international language of his own creation which sounds like a mixture of Latin and Spanish.
Since Judge Saul Streit took his place on the General Sessions bench last Jan. 1 he has refused to ride to court in his own automobile and has hired taxicabs.
Congress, taking pity on minor diplomats struggling to make both ends meet in foreign capitals where the cost of living is high, appeared ready today to increase the envoys' allowances.
Fred N. Corley, president of Marshall Field Co., was elected a trustee of the American Retail Federation at the meeting of the board of the federation held yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

Mrs. William Y. Dear of Montclair, N. J., gave a dinner tonight in the Town Casino Club honoring Miss Martha Tinsley Bright and her fiance, John Hubbard Chatham Jr., who will be married in Trinity Methodist Church of Miami on Saturday night.

Michael O'Connor, a patrolman who was attached to the Coney Island precinct in Brooklyn, was convicted after trial yesterday before Justices Hofmann. Lindau and Gresser in Queens Special Sessions of a charge of leaving the scene of an accident. O'Connor,
