Third reading was given last night by the Legislative Council to the Duplessis government bill to "padlock" all halls or other meeting places used to disseminate Communist propaganda.

Gold St.. 36, s cor of Eden's Alley, 23.7x 73.2. and facing s s of Ryders Alley; Creek Holding Corp. to 11 W. Fordham Rd. Corp., 500 5th Av. ($28). Broome St., 329, 25x100; trustee will of James H. Ransom to Louis Fish, 623 Bedford Av.. Brooklyn; consideration. $16.500.

George Adler has joined the garment oenter office of Berley Co. Inc. Edwin E. Tanzer, Inc., reports the completion of renting the buildings at 321 E. 69th St.. 323 E. 69th St., 344 E. 78th St, 346 E. 78th St., 304 E. 75th St. and 40 E. 85th St.

Rose Croix Chapter of the Scottish Rite of New York City will hold its Feast of the Paschal Lamb at 8 o'clock tonight at the Hotel Astor. The event takes place annually on Maundy Thursday. John W. Davis,

Premier A.berhart's appeal for an end to a bitter budget debate and for a speeding up of the business of passing estimates was answered today with adverse votes from twenty-one Social Credit supporters, and defeat of his appeal by two votes on the floor of the Legislature.

A $10 proposition had Chicago's $1,000,000 heavyweight fight plans up in the air today. Bewildered by the Illinois State Senate's angry action last night in passing a bill to limit the maximum price of prizefight tickets to $10, Promoter Joe Foley applied brakes to his machinery for bringing Champion James J. Braddock and Joe Louis together at Comiskey Park June 22.

The Newark Bears scored twice in the second inning today and were never headed in their 4-to-1 triumph over Baltimore. The International League rivals were fairly evenly matched in hitting, the Bears making nine to the Orioles' seven.

A record-breaking performance by Miss Sylvia Jan Rothenberg, unattached, of Coney Island featured the women's metropolitan senior field-event championships held last night in the gymnasium of P. S. 196, Brooklyn.

The Federal Trade Commission hearing here in the proceedings to determine whether purchasingpractices of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company are in violation of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, closed today. William Reeves,

The Isbrandtsen-Moller Company, operator of freight and tanker services under the Danish flag to several parts of the world, announced yesterday plans for the addition of eleven ships to its fleet. They will include five modern freight ships in its New York-Far Eastern service, two freight ships in its world service and four tankers.

Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, announced yesterday a $12,260,000 expansion and improvement program to increase productive facilities and to effect economies in operation.

For the first time in their more than four weeks of training, the Giants today had their plans seriously impaired by the weather. A tropical thunderstorm swept out of the Gulf during the night and flooded the ball park to such an extent that the scheduled game with the National League champions' Jersey City farm club had to be canceled.

Contracts for 12,568,000 pounds of steel for submarine and destroyer construction were awarded by the Navy Department today at a total cost of $629,956.05. It was the second major purchase of steel this week under the terms of the Walsh-Healy act which prescribes working hours and conditions.
American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company rights and Interlake Iron Corporation rights have been admitted to trading on the New York Stock Exchange on a "when issued" basis.
Form players were subjected to severe treatment again today at Tropical Park. The fifth and sixth races, most attractive events on the card, were particularly disastrous for their choices.

Joseph M. Jacobs, labor attorney who has been the storm center of Chicago's nineteen-day taxicab strike, tonight blocked a plan devised by Alderman and Federal conciliators which was expected to result in settlement tomorrow.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on March 13 totaled 290,613,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines of the Department of the Interior.

Stockholders of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., authorized yesterday an increase in the number of authorized shares from 1,500,000 shares of $5 par value to 3,000,000 shares of $2.50 par value and the exchange of each present capital share for two shares of the new stock.

Mrs. William Garland Heeks, executive chairman, and Mrs. A. Harris Gaines, head of the junior committee, entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for several of the women working for the success of the Bassinet Dinner Dance to be held at the Ambassador on April 2 for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery.

The final "gala program" of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday night will be under the direction of Wilfred Pelletier. A post-season performance of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" will take place on Tuesday evening, March 30, to assist German-American Charities.

Secretary Swanson stated today that he had signed a contract with the operators of the German Zeppelin airship line for the use of the Lakehurst Naval Station as a terminal during the coming season. The "extension,." he said, was for a year, but contained a clause for revocation of the agreement "at our will."

Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan approved today a compromise under which creditors of the New Jersey Fidelity and Plate Glass Insurance Company will be paid more than $850,000 by the Commercial Casualty Insurance Company.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today a stop order suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the National Invested Savings Corporation of Washington, D. C., of which former Senator James E. Watson is chairman of the board.
John B. Simmons, dean of the Racine County legal profession and former law partner of the late Representative Henry Allen Cooper, died today.

Wearing an iceman's jacket of rubber over his uniform, Manager Joe Cronin of the rich Red Sox sat on the bench and watched Uncle Tom Yawkey's hired help go about their Spring training chores. Under direct examination, Joseph Edward Cronin, 30 years old, white, home residence San Francisco, said in part as follows:

Satisfied with their showing in Toronto, where they defeated the Maple Leafs in the first game of their play-off series by 3-0, the New York Rangers are ready to battle their Northern foes again tonight. The teams will clash in Madison Square Garden,- and a capacity crowd of more than 15,000 persons is expected to witness the contest.

Evidence submitted today in London, Paris and Geneva by the Spanish Government that 80,000 Italian troops are fighting with the Rebel forces and are acting "in connection with the Italian Government" should be followed by the withdrawal of foreign forces, Dr. Fernando de los Rios, the Spanish Ambassador here, declared at a press conference.

The warfare of words between the Fascist and Communist powers raged as fiercely as ever at the meeting of the Non-Intervention Committee today, although no crisis developed and the end of the battle left the situation much as it was before.

The situation between the Vatican and Germany remained unchanged in the last twenty-four hours. No step has been taken by the German Government either to denounce the concordat or to withdraw the Ambassador to the Vatican or even to protest against the Pope's recent encyclical condemning curbs on German Catholics.

The work of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem may help to bring about better understanding and greater cooperation between she two racial groups of the Palestine population, Professor Hugo Bergmann declared last night at a dinner given in his honor by the American Friends of the Hebrew University at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Inquiries made by the writer in local shipping circles brought replies tending definitely to show that volunteers for both sides in the Spanish civil war are still being recruited in the United States, despite the State Department ban.

An American skater will appear in an interpretive ice dance for the first time when Miss Maribel Y. Vinson presents her "Valse Triste" in Madison Square Garden on Saturday night at the opening of the international carnivals for the benefit of Bellevue Hospital and the Carroll Club.

The marriage of Miss Helen Eugenie Ketzinger, daughter of Mrs. Katherine Ketzinger of Norwalk, Conn., to Dr. Eugene Cornelius Beck, also of Norwalk, took place here yesterday morning in the First Hungarian Church on East Sixty-ninth Street.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. A. L. Beesinger of this city of the marriage of their niece, Miss Elma Kathryn Nilsson, to Earl W. Speicher, son of Mrs. Hattie Sneicher of West Orange.

Prosecutor Arthur C. Dunn sent two policemen to Trenton late today after hearing that Howard A. Miller, wanted for questioning in the murder of his estranged wife in Haledon Borough, had abandoned a truck there and that a man answering his description had stolen another machine in Trenton and abandoned it in Mooresville, Pa.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange quieted down materially yesterday because of the approaching holiday 'and the uncertainty- over the government's intentions toward making further releases of loan-cotton after the present arrangement ends on April 1.

MANHATTAN FAIRCHILD, SARAH LENITA (July 16, 1936). Gross assets, $79,834; net, $75,730. To Jarvis Rose Fairchild. husband, residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $49,984. Olin, Clark Phelps, attorneys, 120 Broadway.

The State Milk Control Board will decide next Monday whether to order a reduction of 1 cent a quart on all grades of milk, as urged at a hearing today by processors and retailers. Producers protested against the proposed change.
A salary of [pound]2,000 a year is provided for the leader of the Opposition in the House of Commons in the Ministers of the Crown Bill, the text of which was made public tonight.

The Department Store Employes Union threatened last night to call strikes in all thirteen F. W. Grand stores in this city, but deferred final action until 11 A. M. today at the request of Mayor La Guardia. Sit-down strikes have been in progress for twelve days in five stores.

The City Commission passed on first reading today an ordinance introduced by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein to set up a municipal labor relations board to promote industrial peace by conciliation. A public hearing will be held at the City Hall on April 7.

Dr. Inglas Frost, in 930 Park Av.; Ledyard D. Gardner, in 1,010 Fifth Av.; F. ane Horton, in 12 E. 88th St.: Charles Cord, in 47 E. 61st St.; M. Grace Schiller, in 57 W. 58th St.; Pease Elliman, Inc., broker.

Charges that former Governor James M. Curley and Dr. Joseph Santosuosso, attorney, wrongfully possessed $50,000 which they allegedly received in settlement of a $65,000 claim against the city of Boston in 1933, were made in Suffolk Superior Court today when the city brought suit to recover the money.

The nation's medical leaders in the fight to discover a preventive and cure of cancer pledged themselves today to a re-intensified and coordinated campaign. The pledge was taken at the thirtieth annual convention of the American Association for Cancer Research.
AL SMITH is planning his first trip to Europe. It is good to hear that business at the Empire State Building has been picking up and
Two Conservative former members of the House of Commons were returned to Parliament today in byelections, retaining for the government the seats of Farnham, Surrev and Tonbridge, Kent.

Interest on mortgages insured under the National Housing Act and interest on debentures issued thereunder is subject to the Federal income tax, according to an opinion by Herman Oliphant, general counsel for the Treasury, made public today. After reviewing the appropriate sections of the law, Mr. Oliphant stated:

Farmers' cash income from marketing in February was the highest for that month since 1930, it was reported today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The total of $504,000,000 compared with $449,000,000 for February last year and $257,000,000 in 1933.

It may be said of Dr. HANS LUTHER, the former Chancellor who retires at his own request after four years as German Ambassador to the United States, that he has represented his country with dignity under very difficult circumstances.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an application by Massachusetts Utilities Associates, a subsidiary company of the New England Power Association, v a registered holding concern, for authority to acquire from the New England Gas and Electric Association minority interests in sixteen subsidiaries, of which the applicant already owns 70 per cent of the voting securities.

Nellie Gutowski, alias Norma Parker, 20 years old, so-called gun girl whom a psychiatrist described as "of high average intelligence, sophisticated and world weary," was sentenced by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions yesterday to an indeterminate term in the Westfield State Farms, a women's reformatory, in Bedford Hills.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today the Refrigeration Engineering Institute, Inc., of Youngstown, Ohio, has agreed to revise its competitive methods in selling courses of instruction in electric refrigeration and air conditioning. Under the agreement,

One hundred airmen and thousands of land and sea searchers returned to their bases in East Anglia tonight without discovering a clue to the whereabouts of the 71-year-old Duchess of Bedford, who disappeared while flying her airplane from Woburn Monday afternoon.

Although Premier Leon Blum's Popular Front majority held together, with the exception of about a dozen Radical Socialists who abstained from taking part in the vote at the end of last night's long debate in the Chamber of Deputies on the Clichy rioting, it is obvious that sooner or later events will move toward a break with the Communists.

President Federico Laredo Bru tonight announced the appointment of a commission to consider the possibility of resuming payment on Cuban public works bonds sold in the United States and in default since 1933.

Greater secrecy than ever before shrouds the annual war games of the United States fleet, scheduled to start next month. For the past three years censorship of fleet activities has been drawn tighter and tighter, and less information about fleet exercises and training activities has been given out this year than any time since the World War.
Commenting today on Chief Justice Hughes's recent letter on the President's court program, Attorney General Cummings read the following statement at a press conference:
Organization of the infants' and children's knitted outerwear division of the Knitted. Outerwear Association was announced here yesterday.

The value of the 6 1/2, per cent cumulative first preferred stock of the Eitingon Schild Company, Inc., dealers in furs, was put at $55.4996 a share on Nov. 30, 1933, in a report filed yesterday in Supreme Court in an accounting suit brought by minority stockholders.

Central Illinols Electric and Gas Company-For 1936: Net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, amortization and other 'charges, $867,950, against $670,523 in 1935. Total operating revenues increased to $4,640,754 from $4,204,511.

Insurgent Generalissimo Francisco Franco ordered nationalization of all Bank of Spain gold today and directed Spaniards residing abroad to submit accounting of all their foreign currency and securities holdings.

The former Harriman Bank Building, a twelve-story office structure at 527 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-fourth Street, has been sold by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to an investing client of Anton L. Trunk, Broker.

The directors of American-La France Foamite Corporation have declared payable on April 16 to registered holders of twenty-year income notes of record of April 10, interest at the rate of 53A per cent per annum for the period from April 16 to Dec. 31, 1936.

Creation of, the Palisades Interstate Park Commission as a joint corporate municipal instrumentality of the States of New York and New Jersey is provided in the Mailler bill passed today by the Legislature and sent to Governor Lehman.

A "terrific increase" in New York traffic fatalities for the first two months of 1937 was noted by Charles A. Hartnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, who reported 202 automobile accident deaths in February.

The Lejack Holding Corporation bought the seven-story elevator building containing fifty-three apartments and four stores at 1,950 Washington Avenue, corner of 178th Street, the Bronx, paying cash over a first mortgage of $101,000 held by the Greenwood Cemetery.

Film programs, which will be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools. The list follows:

The top-flight five in singles was the only division to admit a newcomer in the fifteenth session of maple crashing at the American Bowling Congress championships yesterday at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

Organization of the public relations activities of the real estate industry in a manner similar to that adopted some time ago by the Stock Exchange to 'lift real estate from the role of stepchild' as an investment medium,' was proposed yesterday by Leonard S. Gans, broker, at the meeting of the brokerage division of the Real Estate Board of New York in the Hotel Commodore.
The appointment of Captain Leek A. Bowen as port captain of the Munson Steamship Line was announced yesterday by Captain L. H. Porter, director of operations.

French patience with the Italian attitude and activity in Spain is wearing thin, Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos today warned Sir George Russell Clerk, the British Ambassador, and Count Johannes von Welczeck, the German Ambassador.

A $15,000,000 issue of New York State gradecrossing-elimination bonds due in from one to fifty years was awarded today by Morris S. Tremaine, Controller, to the Bank of the Manhattan Company and associates at a net interest cost to the State of 2.9578 per cent.

The Salle d'Armes Vince trio of the Misses Marion Lloyd, Madeline Dalton and Maria Cerra last night defeated the Brooklyn College women's fencing team on the strips at the Vince studio. The score was 9--0.

Revenues from Pullman travel nearly doubled in 1936, when the basic cost was reduced from about 4 cents a mile to 3 cents, the annual report of Pullman, Inc., issued yesterday, discloses. The net return from travel last year, after depreciation, was $4,193,324, in contrast with a net loss of $1,646,980 in 1935.

Usually at this time of year citydwelling members of the Beaverkill Trout Club count the days until they can leave dull care behind and start on a peaceful expedition along the banks of their favorite stream.

Mosholu Pkway. S., 116 E. (12-3313); Mosholu Housing Corp. to Josber Building Corp., 475 5th Av., installments, 6 per cent; $30,000. Mace Av., 785 (16-4439); Bernard Kalmus to Union Square Savings Bank; extends mortgage to March 19, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent: $100,000.

Eighteen persons, six of them women and one a 4-year-old child, were killed near here this afternoon and five others were seriously injured when a bus carrying the troupe of a roller-skating derby blew out a tire, swerved into a bridge abutment with terrific force and caught fire.

The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net profit of $18,906,371, which was equal, after preferred dividends, to $8.23 a share on the common stock, compared with $15,913,251, or $6.90 a share, earned in 1935.
Victor Tillery, 12 years old, was wounded perhaps fatally in his home here tonight when, according to police reports, he was shot by a younger brother at his own request. Victor and his brother,...
Seven entries had been filed today for the third annual Aiken point-topoint race which will be run tomorrow over a two-and-a-half-mile dragline course in the Hitchcock Woods.

Playing against a team chosen from New Zealanders who will tour England in the Summer, the Marylebone Cricket Club eleven today hit 334 runs for seven wickets. R. E. S. Wyatt compiled 144 and Leslie Ames 97.

The heads of three State banking and mortgage agencies joined yesterday in a plea for passage of the mortgage bank bill, now before the State Legislature, as a means of providing machinery for "sound mortgage investments in the future."

Miss Margaret Bostwick of the Apawamis Club and David McElroy of the University Club yesterday continued on their way to becoming the new metropolitan mixed doubles squash racquets champions by administering a sound 15-7, 15-4, 13-18, 15-4 semi-final round defeat to Miss Mary and Lewis Francis, sister and brother team. who were playing on their home Heights Casino courts.

The Jewish festival of Passover, commemorating the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt more than 3,000 years ago, will begin tomorrow at sundown. Special services will be held in temples and synagogues throughout the city, preceding the traditional Seder ceremonial, at which a narrative recalling the exodus is recited and unleavened bread is served.

As part of the enlistment campaign of the Women's Field Army for Cancer, which is being conducted throughout the nation this week, a number of New York department stores are distributing pamphlets about cancer and aiding in the campaign through their medical and welfare departments, it was announced yesterday.

With European nations moving to protect holdings of their nationals in war-torn Spain, American exporters yesterday completed plans for presenting a united front in safeguarding upward of $35,000,000 due American companies for goods shipped to Spain and returns on investments in that country.

Illustrating the possibilities of new resinous raw material which Germany has been substituting in some instances for metals under the four-year plan, Dr. Fritz Huth has just completed an airplane from such material.

Chicago's Golden Gloves stars, chiefly the youngsters ranging from 118 to 160 pounds, conquered New York's best tonight in the tenth annual interoity tournament by a margin of nine bouts to seven before 21,280 excited spectators in the Chicago Stadium.
The Herman bill to impose a 5 per cent tax on all bets made at the New York race tracks obtained a new lease on life today.

The production of crude petroleum in Canada last year was the highest since 1931, according to the Canadian Pacific Railway. The 1931 output was the record peak for Canadian wells and the 1936 production has been exceeded in only one other year, 1930.
Electric power production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index increased to 108.5 from 107.9. It was 96.0 for the week ended March 21, 1936.

The B. F. Avery Sons Company, manufacturer of farm implements and machinery, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for $1,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent notes and 36,500 shares of $25-par 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock with warrants. F. Eberstadt Co., Inc.,
Samuel Harrison, veteran justice of the peace, may give up public office when he is 100, but today on his eighty-fourth birthday he was not even considering it.

James D. Andrew, engineer, who had been manager since 1933 of the American Boiler Manufacturers Association and Affiliated Industries, 15 Park Row, New York, died on Monday of pneumonia at his home here. His age was 62.

While applauding Representative Wadsworth's statutory device to clear away the debris of unratified constitutional amendments, make consideration by Statewide conventions the preferred method, and put a time limit on that consideration, Supreme Court historians have taken vigorous exception to one of his arguments.

Homer Martin and the other officials of the United Automobile Workers of America, who had accompanied him from Lansing with the Chrysler-Lewis agreement to evacuate the sit-downers, arrived at the Dodge plant at 2:20 A. M., and were immediately admitted, while newspaper men were kept back by a group of pickets.
The Hill Diesel Engine Company, Lansing, Mich., has announced the appointment of Kirkgasser-Drew, Inc., Chicago, to handle its account. A campaign will be run in general and business magazines.
Joseph E. Davies, United States Ambassador to Moscow, predicted today an early expansion of United States trade with the Soviet Union.

Bonwit Teller, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiary, Bonwit Teller Co. of Florida, reported yesterday a net profit of $183,727 for the year ended on Jan. 31, which contrasted with a net loss of $108,929 in the preceding fiscal year.

Princeton will resume football relations with Army after a lapse of thirty years when the Tigers and Cadets meet at Princeton in 1938. It will be the first time the teams have played since 1908, when they battled to a scoreless tie.
Yale lost the second and final Rugby game today, bowing to an All-Bermuda fifteen, 5 to 0. Clint Frank, brilliant three-quarter back, had many fine runs and thrilled the large crowd.

The marriage of Miss Alma Mann of Brooklyn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Mann, to William J. Stuebe of Woodhaven, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Stuebe, took place yesterday afternoon in the Flatbush Congregational Church.

The average dollar value sales on all National Security Exchanges per trading day was $136,362,677 in February, the highest since it began publication of data of this kind about two years ago, the Securities and Exchange Cbmmission reported today.

Lawyers who sell their knowledge to racket operators are more vicious than the "dumb racketeers," William B. Herlands, assistant prosecutor, told the restaurant racket jury in Supreme Court yesterday n asking convictions for all the seven men on trial. Two of the defendants are lawyers.
Following is tie text of Governor Murphy's letter as sent to the United Automobile Workers Union, which has been occupying Chrysler 'plants by means of sit-down strikes:

The great need of the Salvation Army for the $600,000 to be sought by the citizens appeal beginning April 6 to finance anticipated deficits of its fifty-seven New York City welfare centers, was stressed yesterday by Chalmers Wood, chairman of the appeal committee.

Governor Frank Murphy tonight paved the way for a settlement of the Chrysler strike by getting an agreement from John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, to order the immediate evacuation of the eight Chrysler plants in Detroit by the 6,000 sit-downers who have held possession of them for seventeen days.

Declaring that "the world needs a little more of the faith of our fathers," Police Recorder Vincent C. Duffy provided Bibles today for four young prisoners whom he had sentenced to the county jail with instructions that they be compelled to read a chapter of Scripture a day during their three-month terms.

The City of New York filed plans yesterday for the building to house its exhibit at the World's Fair. The building, a permanent one to be used after the fair by the Department of Parks, will cost $1,000,000. It was designed by Aymar Embury 2d, architect. and will occupy a site 421 by 215 feet on the east side of Grand Central Parkway, 1,789 feet north of Horace Harding Boulevard, Flushing.
Secretary Perkins said today that no special situation had been brought about by the sit-down strikes any more than was evoked by other stoppages of work.

Mrs. Benjamin Eaton Crispin gave a tea yesterday in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for members of the executive committee working with her in behalf of the dinner dance for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Bennett School next Tuesday in the Rainbow Room under the auspices of the Bennett Club of New York.
A measure, sponsored by District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn, to permit blood tests in criminal cases was introduced today by Assemblyman Breitbart, Brooklyn Democrat.
John Banks Tillotson, a former Village Trustee and Police Commissioner, and a retired building contractor of Ossining, who died at his home here Sunday, was buried today in Dale Cemetery, Ossining.
The four favorites in the annual Augusta invitation golf tournament trudged down muddy fairway today to enter the semi-finals.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Adele B. Alsop, eldest daughter of Mrs. Basil de Selincourt of Kingham, Oxfordshire, and Reese D. Alsop of New York, to the Hon. Henry Anthony Camillo Howard, youngest son of Lord and Lady Howard of Penrith.

The year 1936 produced an all-time record in the number of hospital beds available and in the number of patients, one person in fifteen in the country, admitted to the country's 6,189 registered hospitals, it was reported today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
Six awards for paintings in the exhibition by the Junior Artists group of the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, were announced last night at a dinner at the club.

The Interstate Commerce Commission was called upon today to decide a question involving the sidewalks of New York. The Master Truckmen of America, Inc., whose members are interested in trucking in the garment district, filed a complaint against the Pennsylvania, Erie, Baltimore Ohio, Lehigh Valley and Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroads and the Old Dominion Steamship Line, charging that these companies are violating a ruling of the commission handed down in October, 1936.

United States Senator Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin and Robert H. Jackson, assistant United States Attorney General, told a large audience in Carnegie Hall last night at a rally of the .American Labor Party to support President Roosevelt's plan for enlarging the Supreme Court, that the conservative majority of that tribunal must share the blame for current industrial unrest.

The Bureau of Mines recommended today a daily average crude-oil production of 3,243,000 barrels to meet the estimated demand during April. This recommendation was 84,000 barrels higher than for March and 227,000 barrels higher than for April, last year.

A resolution providing for a complete legislative investigation of the planting of dictographs in the office of ary Governor Ammons, Democrat, was went introduced in the State Legislature today by Representative William Higby, Republican floor leader. Action on the resolution was set for tomorrow.

A lone woman worker labored over her lathe today turning out mop handles and handles for other kitchen utensils while her thirty male fellow workers sat down - on strike for a 10 per cent wage increase.

MANHATTAN ABERT, BENJAMIN (Feb. 15). Estate, more than $20,000. To Annie Cohen, sister, 1,188 E. 12th St., Brooklyn, life estate in one-third residue; Flora Mendel, 1,081 Jerome Av., Bronx, sister, one-third residue; Isaac Abert, brother, executor, 230 Riverside Dr., $200 and one-third residue; Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, $3,000;

With three city representatives on the board dissenting, directors of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company voted today in favor of the reorganization plan consolidating the city's traction interests in a syndicate company. Mayor S.
William H. Dunn, former shoe manufacturer, died at his home here today. His age was 81. His wife, Emma Elizabeth Buff Dunn, died last month.
In the Literary Supplement of The Times of London is a long dissertation on TALLEYRAND suggested by the recent books of Count DE SAINT-AULAIRE and Mr. CRANE BRINTON:
The Assembly approved and sent to the Governor today the Berg bill making changes in the unemployment insurance system of the State.

Ralph Spagnola of Newark, N. J., outpointed Sammy Ventimilia of New York in the final 126-pound bout of a Jewish benefit amateur boxing show at the St. Nicholas Palace last night, The Associated Press reports. Earlier, Spagnola won a decision from Carmina Fatta, New York.
A "mental epidemic" is what William T. Root, head of the Psychology Department of the University of Pittsburgh, calls the sit-down strike. He remarked:

Two men were arrested during a disturbance at 7 o'clock last night outside the Alabama Laundry Service at Liberty and Alabama Avenues, Brooklyn. More than 1,200 members and sympathizers of Laundry Workers Union, Local 280, who have been on strike against several Brooklyn laundries for a week, were massed at the Alabama laundry for a demonstration.

The Maine Senate disregardea today a declaration that "the State has no more use for the September election than a hog has for a cyclone" and voted to retain the traditional early day for the State's general election.

The Robinson joint resolution making Joseph P. Kennedy of New York eligible for confirmation as chairman of the Maritime Commission was passed by the Senate this afternoon and now goes to the House for concurrent action.

A band of robbers forced the night watchman into a vault early today and then ransacked the town. The population is about 2,500. Safes were blown in four places. Miss Willie Cook and Mrs. Lewis Miller, sleeping on the second floor of a building on the public square, were awakened when a safe was blown in a pharmacy across the street.
The engagement of $6,023,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $4,788,000 in England and $1,235,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Saying the "public must be reassured that there will not be a recurrence of such an outrageous disorder," Magistrate David L. Malbin in Flatbush Court yesterday found thirty-eight hospital sit-down strikers guilty of disorderly conduct and ordered them not to "congregate in or disturb" the hospital.

The Pan American Clipper completed this afternoon the third leg of its flight that is preparatory to the inauguration of regular airliner service from the United States to New Zealand. The Clipper, with seven members in her crew, descended to an easy alighting on the choppy waters of Pago Pago Harbor, having flown from Kingman Reef, 1,600 miles distant.

Fuller Barnard Jr., former State's Attorney of Allegany County and Democratic leader, died suddenly last night while in Annapolis on business before the Maryland General Assembly. He was 50 years old.

The Senate passed today and sent to Governor Lehman a bill paving the way for construction of an $8,000,000 automobile plant in Tonawanda, near Buffalo, which will provide jobs for upward of 5.000 persons.

Leave of absence for four days. effective on or about March 30, with permission to leave the continental limits of the United States is granted 1st Lt. Patrick B. Fay, Chap. -Res. Each of the following Reserve officers. now on active duty with the CCC is. with his consent, continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name:

Three men were arrested on criminal attack charges In Brooklyn last night as District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan and the juvenile aid bureau of the Police Department opened a w9de drive against sexual crimes involving children.
Japan and Burma have reached an agreement whereby Japan will export cotton cloth to Burma while pur chasing a large share of Burma raw cotton.

Declaring he was "opposed to the wording of signs which offend any race or creed," Mayor J. Alden Talbot said today that "Christian membership only" signs on top of billboards at the Boonton Avenue entrances of the Fayson Lakes development here would be "changed."
The inevitable deadlock has now been reached on the Guadalajara front. This has permitted all eyes in Loyalist Spain to turn to international developments, particularly Italian activities.

After receiving a petition signed by 173 citizens requesting that the town be moved to a hill not far from the present floodravaged site, the Town Board has promised cooperation with citizens and the Red Cross in effecting the relocation.

A warning against what he considers loop holes in the McReynolds neutrality legislation, which the House of Representatives adopted last week as a substitute for the Senate measure, that would. "open wide the gateway to an untrammeled and unrestricted trade with belligerents in time of war" was given to the Senate today by Senator Homer T. Bone of Washington.
If Japan is intending to restore East Hopei to China as the price for Chinese economic cooperation, officials of the puppet government there are blissfully unaware of it.
Mrs. Eleanor Beers Redfield, widow of Walter M. Redfield, died at her home here today. Her age was 57. She served for a number of years as secretary of the Republican Town Committee.

While the wholesaler is usually considered a merchant selling to retailers for resale, figures on operations in 1935 showed that less than half of the sales were made in this manner, it was revealed today in a report issued by the Bureau of Census.

The article by Chairman ECCLES of the Federal Reserve Board in Fortune is in effect an elaboration of the statement he made a week ago. It helps to clarify a number of points regarding Mr. ECCLES'S views which the previous statement left obscure.

Substantial increases in sales of window shades, part of which may be attributed to the manufacturers' cooperative advertising campaign, were reported here yesterday at a press preview of the Window Shade Institute at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Two moves were made in the Senate today in the fight to restrict child labor. Senator Borah of Idaho offered a new Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution which would fix an age limit of 14 years instead of 18 years, as provided in the Child Labor Amendment now pending before the States.

The weekly report of the Unitea States Weather Bureau follows: Winter wheat is greening very slowly in the Ohio Valley and there have been further complaints of heaving, particularly in Indiana and Illinois; Winter killing varies greatly being material in some sections.

A group of Americans who served under French or Italian command in the World War will form a permanent organization at a meeting to be held Saturday at 3 P. M. at the offices of Bunce Allen, 425 Fourth Avenue. Mr. Allen is acting as temporary chairman of the group.
The Metropolitan Chauffeurs Association called a strike tonight of all drivers for the Checker Cab Company.

Apprehension in government and economic circles because of the rapid rise of wages and prices, together with growing concern over spreading labor unrest, has had no discernible effect upon steel production or incoming business, which are mounting to peaks similar to the best records of 1929, Iron Age says this week.

Oxford won the university boat race today and avenged thirteen straight defeats by crossing the finish line three lengths ahead of Cambridge. Not since 1923 have the Dark Blues known the joy of victory, and although it was the slowest race in sixty years it was one of the most thrilling.

The Assembly Committee on Public Service took prompt action today to block the attempted raid on the five-cent fare on the city owned and operated subway in New York City which was sprung in the Senate yesterday. The Senate passed,

The Legislature today voted to remove Philadelphia's three-man civil service commission and authorized a new board of five members. The "ripper" will become effective Monday when Governor Earle affixes his signature to the enabling measure.
The defending champion Tulsa Stenos led the march of seeded quintets into the semi-finals of the women's national A. A. U. basketball tournament tonight.
William H. Vrooman, a veteran of the Civil War. died today at the age of 90. He was a descendant of the original Dutch settler on the Schoharie River flats. The tract is called "Vrooman's Land."

Passage of the Feld tenure bill to give permanent office to associate superintendents would cause "stagnation" in the New York publio school system, the Board of Ed ucation declared at its meeting yesterday in unanimously adopting a resolution voicing disapproval of this measure.

A substantial point was gained last night when Mr. LEWIS agreed to ask his sit-down strikers to evacuate the plants of the Chrysler company without waiting for a settlement to be reached on the issues of the strike itself. This is a gain because, so far as Mr. LEVIS is concerned, it represents willingness to comply with the law and with the order of the courts.

THE first thought after reading "Suns Go Down" (Macmillan, $2), by Flannery Lewis. is that even Clarence Day could hardly have done a better job with the same material. Mr. Lewis writes in the hard and virtuous way. His prose is restrained, honest, simple, the kind of prose that is good when new and that wears a long time.
The Japanese Navy has enough oil in store to sustain a protracted war if it broke out now, Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai, Minister of the Navy, stated in the House of Representatives.

Continuing to offset with increased traffic the reduction in rates resulting from discontinuance of the emergency freight surcharges at the end of 1936, the first ten railroads to report for February showed an increase of 8.6 per cent in gross revenues, compared with February, 1936.

To the Editor of The New York Times On March 16 you published a letter from Edward P. Doyle about housing, which contained many misstatements. "It is very unfortunate," writes Mr. Doyle, "that people who are interested in what they think is reform, feel that they must depend on exaggeration to carry their point."

The Walgreen Company yesterday called for redemption on May 24, at $113 a share plus accrued dividends, its 6 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock. Payment will be made by Goldman, Sachs Co. April 1.

Georgie Zangaras of the East Side conquered Midget Doyle of Garfield, N. J., before 1,000 persons at Mecca Arena last night. In the second round Referee Al Reich stopped the action and awarded the decision to Zangaras, who outclassed his opponent. The time was 2:15. The weights were 136 for Doyle and 135 for Zangaras.

Greenwich Village-or that part of it which does not believe that the village is "the nation's greatest rash of art, literature and temperament in the raw"-wants President Roosevelt to know that the community resents the things the WPA Federal Writers' Project has been saying about it.
The Rev. William J. Ryan, Professor of English and Sacred Oratory at St. Bernard's Seminary for several years, died today in St. Mary's Hospital. He was 63.

By WILLIAM KENNELLY 36th St., 48-50 W.; 4-story building and store, 33.3x98.9; East River Savings Bank against 48 and 50 West Thirty-sixth Street Realty Corp..; due, $119,681; taxes, $670; to plaintiff for $50.
The Hershey Bears shut out Atlantic City's Sea Gulls, 2 to 0, tonight in the first game of the three-outof-five play-off for the James J. Walker Cup of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League.
The player who once strode the tennis courts like a colossus came to the end of his string in Madison Square Garden last night.

Mrs. Laura L. Steers Bayles, eldest daughter of former Borough President and former Magistrate Alfred E. Steers of Brooklyn, died yesterday morning in her home at 118 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, after a brief illness.

Robert E. Webb, chairman of the Kentucky Railroad Commission, suggested to the Interstate Commerce Commission today that "a better economic structure" of railroads would be preferable to higher freight rates. He submitted a statement and exhibits to support his arguments against higher schedules asked by the railroads.
Henry T. Braman, who claimed to be the oldest member of the Rhode Island bar, died at a hospital here tonight. His age was 91.

John E. Benton, solicitor for the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners, urged Congress today to place interstate sale and transportation of natural and mixed gas under regulation of the Federal Power Commission.
provement in living standards and increase in "real wages" in Soviet Russia are growing more evident daily as the second Five-Year Plan augments the quantity of food and consumers' goods.
Two younger members of the Massachusetts House of Representatives turned their fire today on a law giving to war veterans preference in civil service examinations.
Replying to "the malevolent Polish press reaction" to statements made by the National Socialist regional leader here, the deputy leader declared today:

Topped by Lou Gehrig's $36,000 contract, which makes the Yankees' Iron Man the highest salaried figure among baseball players or managers for the first time in his career, the 1937 major league payroll is the fattest on record.

Miss Edna Crane Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Alfred Chapin of this place, 'has selected April 9 as the date for her marriage to Horace Tantum Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Horace Tantum, also of Nutley.
Professor Winfred W. Braman, who retired last October after thirty-three years as a member of the faculty of the Pennsylvania State College, died today. He would have been 63 years old next Monday.
The position of the Socialist party in the present dispute between rival unions will be discussed during the party's four-day special 1937 national convention opening here tomorrow.
To nine graduate students and younger faculty members of Harvard University have been awarded Sheldon traveling fellowships, totaling $12,500, for study in Europe next year, it was stated here today.

President Roosevelt tonight attended a "family party" in Georgia Hall of the Warm Springs Foundation, given by his own staff and the patients at the foundation. Mr. Roosevelt substituted the party and supper for his annual presence at the Thanksgiving Day festival of the foundation.
Sheriff F. Herman Harding announced today that he would use "every resource" at his command to prevent showing of the film "Spain in Flames," in Middlesex County.
General Pera Zhivkovitch, former dictator of Yugoslavia, who has been devoting himself to political work as head of the Yugoslav National party, has been definitely pensioned by Prince Paul.

Band Orders The members of the Department Band shall be directed to report, in full uniform, to Captain Julius A. Unrath, at Station WNYC, Municipal Building, Manhattan, at 5 P. M., Saturday, April 3.
A cocktail party was given today by Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio at their home for their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Bates of Geneva, Switzerland.
Through the official government broadcast today came an appeal for volunteer Red Cross nurses for the former German African colonies as well as Portuguese Angola.

The five-story flats at 329 Broome St. were sold by Louira L. Ransom, as trustee of the will of James Hervey Ransom, to Louis Fish, who gave back a purchasemoney mortgage for $11,500, payable April 1, 1944, at 4 per cent.

Governor Lehman announced that, at the request of the Republican Assembly chiefs, he was ready to hold a conference during the next week to discuss proposed budgetary changes. He called for enactment of a full revenue program to meet the $370,000,000 budget expenditures now approved by both houses.

The Ontario Legislature, in what was believed the stormiest session in its history, tonight voted unanimously to repeal separate school tax legislation passed in 1936. The 1936 legislation granted a greater share of corporation taxes to Ontario's Roman Catholic schools, called separate schools, in contrast to the State-supported public or common school system.

" Far too little is spent annually for research on cancer" answers the Cancer Council to one of a series of searching questions put by Mr. WILLIAM LAURENCE on behalf of the National Association of Science Writers.
The question of holding a meeting of Tammany Hall's executive committee to settle the leadership controversy was debated yesterday by leaders of various factions in the organization.

With a view to developing a unified employer viewpoint, Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, last night urged the amalgamation of the three leading associations in the dress industry to effectuate fair trade practices and to deal with other problems confronting the producers.

The band of men and women sitdown strikers in the Champion Shoe Corporation, 104 Bleecker Street, bowed to the order of Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller, who on Tuesday ruled they were to leave the plant before noon yesterday. They had been on strike since March 11.

Adolph Steinhardt, former business man, was found shot and killed and his wife seriously wounded late today. Witnesses told the police that Steinhardt, who was 58 years old, shot his wife as she was leaving a doctor's office on the ninth floor of the Canal Building and then went to his own office in the near-by Mason Building and fired a bullet into his heart.

A squad of nearly 100 athletes reported to Coach Peter L. Waters for Manhattan's initial outdoor track practice at Manhattan Field yesterday. The board track having been taken down and stored away until next Winter, the candidates went through their paces on the cinder path.

A story of soldiers firing upon 800 hunger-crazed farmers as they attacked rice junks at Yungchwan, southwest of Chungking in Szechwan Province, reached here tonight from agents of the Bank of China. A large number of the farmers were killed.

The nation's newspaper editors, outside the metropolitan centers, are opposed to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan by about 3 to 1, it was announced yesterday by The Publishers Auxiliary, a trade paper published in Chicago.

They stretched Pinehurst's crack course to full length today and only Byron Nelson of the early pacesetters could handle the extra length, along with a whirling wind and cold rain, in the second round of the North and South open golf tournament.
The stock market here today was quiet but steady on the whole. Gilt-edge issues attracted little interest, but their tone was firm. Foreign securities were unchanged for the most part.

Charles Miller, a Yale graduate of last June, organizer and president of the "Coastal Air Freight Corporation," started air freight traffic between here and San Francisco today at cheaper than air mail rates. He hopes eventually to expand to Seattle.

While Governor Lehman's proposal to amend the State Constitution in aid of slum clearance is a "sound long-range proposal," it is not a substitute for the Moffat bill, under which slum clearance probably would begin next year, in the opinion of Harold Riegelman, chairman of the legislative advisory committee of the New York County Republican Committee.

A suit to compel Police Commissioner Valentine to revoke his order directing policemen to note alleged traffic offenses on drivers' licenses at the time a summons is issued was begun in Supreme Court yesterday by Herbert E. Rosenberg, an attorney of 261 Broadway.
Representatives of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee announced early today that a strike at the two plants of the Allegheny Steel Company had been settled two hours after it started.

I. J. Harvey Jr., president of the Flintkote Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Boston yesterday that as a result of efforts to spread operations more evenly over the year by greater diversification of products earnings for January and February this year were $183,771, in contrast with a loss of $20,391 for the 1936 period.

A contributory retirement plan, to supplement old-age benefits of the Federal Social Security Act for employes of the Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., here, was announced today by officials of the concern. About 2,500 employes will be affected.

A campaign to minimize the slashing of millinery prices immediately after Easter has been undertaken by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, which yesterday called attention to the stand against such price-cutting which has been taken by the Eastern Women's Headwear Association, Inc., and tho Joint Board of the Millinery Workers Union, locals 24 and 42.

Protests of C. I. O. lawyers failed to prevent passage tonight by the Town Council of an ordinance to prohibit free distribution of pamphlets and other literature. vote was 5 to 4 and the ordinance becomes effective immediately.
Metropolitan Museum of Art, "The Art of Italy." Ethelwyn Bradish, 11 A. M.; "The Collection of Greek Art," General Tour, 2 P. M.; "Furniture: Upholstery Fabrics," Grace Cornell, 8 P. M.

Frisby Av. (15-3984), s. e. cor. Benson St., 100x100; Albert Kuhnemuth to Madeline Wulff, 2,574 Frisby Av. Prentiss Av. (18-5521), n. e. cor,. Mullan P1., 100x37; Daniel E. Weaver to Michael Mahoney, 318 Pennyfield Av.

An increase of 10 cents an hour for the 1,400 time-card employes of the Tide Water Oil Company here, the second pay rise to be granted in four months, was announced by H. S. Chase, general superintendent, at a meeting of the works council today.
The British Labor party today gave Sir Stafford Cripps and other "embarrassing" talkers just two months to cease their flirtations with communism on pain of expulsion from the party.

Installation of two escalators in the Grand Central Terminal for the benefit of commuters whose trains arrive at the lower level would cost $150,000, according to testimony at a hearing held yesterday by Transit Commissioner Reuben L. Haskell.

The first suit here under the 1935 New Jersey Fair Trade Act to restrain price cutting since the United States Supreme Court upheld similar acts in other States was filed In Chancery Court today by the Schenley Products Company, sole "immediate" distributor of Schenley brands of liquor, against the Franklin Stores Company, operator of a chain in this area.

Another stirring episode In the court rivalry between St. Francis Prep and Brooklyn Prep was written last night as the former beat the Crown Heights unit, 25--24, in the semi-finals of the eighth annual metropolitan Catholic high school basketball tournament.
Dr. Otto E. Kopetschny, for fifty years a practicing physician here and for many years personal physician to Mayor Frank Hague, died today at his home, 591 Jersey Avenue, at the age of 76.

A sharp falling off in, hog receipts checked the declining tendency in the market today, and sales generally Me: showed an advance of 5 to 10 cents with some heavy butchers' hogs up 15 cents, while the better grades light weights were strong to 10 cents higher.

Continuing their drive against the illicit narcotic traffic here, Federal agents seized four men and a woman and drugs valued at $25,000 early yesterday. This was the latest move in the campaign by the Treasury Department's Narcotic Bureau, which last November began to concentrate on distributors instead of addicts.

Mrs. Elizabeth Y. Dillon obtained a divorce today from John H. Dillon I of New York City. to whom she was married on April 20, 1933. An agreement provided for custody of their child. Mrs. Dillon charged cruelty.

By I. LINCOLN SEIDE Webster Av., s w cor Gun Hill Rd., 2-story office and store building; Fifth Av. Bank of N. Y., trustees, against Edgerton Park Co.; due, $123,616; taxes, , $5,696; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Four 12-year-old school girls, who, according to the police, admitted having snatched more than 100 pocketbooks from women in the Borough Park shopping district of Brooklyn in the last two months, are to be arraigned in Brooklyn Children's Court today on charges of juvenile delinquency.

A painting by Edouard Manet that has not been publicly shown in this country since last century, has just been added to the retrospective Manet loan exhibition at the Wildenstein galleries, being held for the benefit of the French Hospital and the Lisa Day Nursery.

This evening will be distinguished by the premiere of Brock Pemberton's second production of the season, the same being "Chalked Out," a drama of prison life by Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing and Jonathan Finn.

About 1,400 workers on the night shift of the Allegheny Steel Company's Brackenridge mill walked out tonight in protest against failure of the company to sign a contract with the Steel Workers' Organizing Committee.
Dr. Thomas F. Higgins, City Physician here for more than a quarter century and a member of the staff of the Elizabeth General Hospital since 1913, died today of pneumonia.

One hour after Judge Koenig had turned the case over to it, a General Sessions jury late yesterday afternoon acquitted Edward Drolette, 35 years old, a seaman, on a felonious assault indictment. The indictment grew out of the attack on Detective Matthew Solomon of the alien squad in the rioting between Nazis and anti-Nazis on the deck of the steamship Bremen on the night of July 26. 1935.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under the direaction of Artur Rodzinski, yesterday afternoon included in its program at Carnegie Hall a first hearing of Samuel Barber's Symphony in One Movement.

An all-Mozart program will be given tonight at the WPA Theatre of Music. The conductor will be Samuel Gardner. The soloists are Therma Jerguson, and Mina Horne, sopranos, and Stephen Maxymciw, bassoonist.
Schools were closed in at least two Oklahoma cities today as heavy clouds of dust swirled over parts of four States, cutting visibility to near zero in some sections.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 6 per cent for the week ended March 20 over the corresponding week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.
Harcourt, Brace have just received a cable from England reporting the death of Serge Zolo, author of the recently published "Sentenced to Adventure," off the Devon Coast.

Tholigh Soviet' officials deny reports published abroad that a fleet of Soviet airplanes is en route to the North Pole to establish weather stations and intermediate landing places for the projected Moscow-San Francisco air line, the Soviet press gave great prominence today to P. G. Golovin's flight toward Rudolf Island, only 800 miles from the North Pole.

Unusual scholarship by Yale athletes and other leaders in campus activity is shown by the dean's list, announced today. Of the 653 upperclass men and ninety-one freshmen who attained the average of 80 or more in their scholarship rating, 47 per cent are self-supporting and 25 per cent of the varsity and junior varsity teams were included.
Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, sailed yesterday on the liner Manhattan for the International Sugar Conference to be held in London April 5.
Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Chadbourne have returned to the Berkshire from Palm Beach. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Holt are at Mid Pines Inn, Southern Pines, N. C., for the Easter season.

George Sutherland, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, will be 75 years old tomorrow. He, the fourth member of the present tribunal to reach the three-quarter century mark, planned to spend the day at his office.
An order authorizing the sale of 137,730 common shares of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., was issued in Superior Court here today by Justice Prevost.

Sales in New Jersey through the Fidelity Union Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company of Newark reported yesterday included the seventeen-family apartment house at 667 Park Avenue, Union City, to the Harsil Realty Corporation through Joseph J. Harris, Inc., broker. Residence deals in which the mortgage company figured were as follows:

Picketing of a factory where no strike is in progress is unlawful, the Court of Errors and Appeals held today. The opinion affirmed the Court of Chancery in restraining the Ladies Garment Workers Union from picketing the Newark plant of S. Feller Sons in an effort to induce employes to join the union.

Moderate improvement continued in the bond market yesterday, with interest again centered on the action of United States Government ,issues. The latter group proceeded upward at an accelerated pace during the first half of the day, but encountered some profit-taking at their best levels and settled back to close with net gains ranging from 1-32 to 16-32 point.

Dr. Matthew Carney, who was divisional dental surgeon of the Twenty-seventh Division in the World War, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where he underwent an operation a week ago. He was 49 years old.

Regretting that he has but one voice to give, Bing Crosby is surrendering it cheerfully at the Paramount to the uses of the Hawaiian Board of Trade, the pineapple industry and sundry tourist agencies. His "Waikiki Wedding" places him in a welter of grass skirts, tropical sunsets, Martha Raye and a razorback pig called Wafford. Undismayed he sings on-things like "Okolehao" and "Sweet Leilani."
All powers and rights of the Dominion Government will be used to prevent the sit-down strike gaining a foothold in Canada, Justice Minister Ernest LaPointe told the House of Commonns today.

Captain Yanagisawa, aide de camp to Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai, Minsister of the Navy, today declared that reports that Japan was preparing to build battleships of 40,000 to 50,000 tons were "absolutely untrue."

Edward Kreamer, associated with the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company more than fifty years and active for forty years as a layman in the Catholic church, died suddenly of a heart malady at his home here today. His age was 69.

A "fair trade" mass meeting of retail druggists in the metropolitan area and other parts of the State will be held on April 13 at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association, it was announced yesterday by Milton S. Malakoff, executive secretary.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company has been cooperating with the Police Department in efforts to exclude panhandlers and peddlers from its trains and stations, Federal Receiver Thomas E. Murray Jr. said yesterday.

Abraham Saffir, former Republican leader of the Eighteenth Assembly District in Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday to grand larceny, second degree, before Kings County Judge Algeron I. Nova. Saffir, who lives at 1,378 Carroll Street, was released on $1,000 bail pending sentence.

William Gallagher, 7 years old, of 820 Tenth Avenue, was killed yesterday afternoon by a hit-and-run truck driver as he was crossing Fifty-fourth Street near Tenth Avenue. A playmate, Owen Flynn, of 442 West Fifty-fourth Street, called Patrolman Joseph Turbidy of the West Forty-seventh Street station, who took the injured boy to Roosevelt Hospital in a taxicab.

The State Federation of Labor tonight "extended its moral and financial support" to the Boston local Retail Store Employes 'Union as uniformed policemen ended an uneventful vigil at . Boston's retail stores awaiting a possible disturbance.

Outscored in the first half, Long Island University's basketball team rallied after the intermission to top the Harlem Y. M. C. A., 43--31, in an interesting game last night at the Renaissance Casino.
Yesterday's activity in the commercial leasing field was marked by a brisk demand for whole floors by concerns engaged in many lines of business.

Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser of Brooklyn is now in her 102d year, by virtue of celebrating another birthday yesterday. The event was observed strictly according to her wishes and was remarkable for the active part she played in every scene.

The once great Nikolai Bukharin and Alexei I. Rykoff have been strenuously resisting official efforts to draw from them admissions that they participated in or even knew of the campaign of sabotage and terrorism of which they have been suspected since January's sensational "Trotskyist" trial, it was revealed today.
Haverford College has received a rare seventeenth-century painting, "The Quaker Meeting," by Egbert Van Heemskerk the Younger (16451704).
The agreement between Rome and Belgrade will be postponed until after the visit of the Czech President, Eduard Benes, to Belgrade early next month, it was learned today.

Advances in technology are creating an "astounding multiplication" of careers in which persons more than forty years old succeed more easily than young men and women, Dr. Walter B. Pitkin, Professor of Journalism at Columbia University, writes in his new book, "Careers After Forty," published today by Whittlesey House.

The 1937 tax levy as adopted by the Board of Aldermen on March 1 is illegal, the Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday in its monthly bulletin sent to civic groups, banks and business houses. The levy, the commission declared, exceeded by $43,834 the legal limit of $437,608,385 under the city charter.
Following is the statement of Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, to the Senate Judiciary Committee on the proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court:
Last Saturday Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers scored their first victory of the Grapefruit League season over the Phillies. Today they hung up triumph No. 2 over the world champion Yankees, 9-6.

Reinstatement Reinstated as a patrolman, first grade, effective March 23. 1937. subject to the approval of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, the interval between Oct. 27, 1936, the date upon which he resigned without fault or delinquency on his part and the date of reinstatement, is not to be counted as service in the Police Department, and assigned to 105th Precinct: Charles G. Burkhard.

Mrs. Flora McKnight Pierce, widow of William L. Pierce, patent lawyer, died at her home here today after a long illness at the age of 79. Three children survive, William L. Pierce of Englewood, textile merchant; H. Denny Pierce, stockbroker, of New York, and Mrs. Carl Blegen of Athens, Greece, wife of an archaeologist.

The world price of wheat today continued the advance that has been under way for the last month, with all deliveries in Liverpool, Buenos Aires and Rotterdam and the near-by futures here and in Winnipeg selling at new high prices for the last eight years.
The appointment of Dr. Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff as Ambassador at Washington was officially confirmed today.

William Morris Imbrie, retired investment banker, former New York Stock Exchange member and a philanthropist, died yesterday at his home, 21 Franklin Street, here, after an illness of several years. His age was 87.
Germany, which hitherto wore clothes consisting almost entirely of foreign wool and cotton, now is meeting about one-third of its textile raw material requirements through domestic production,
When a man breaks out of a penitentiary, that is news. But what is it when he breaks in first, loots the institution of valuables and then departs without having disturbed the guards?

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Freeman of this city have announced the secret marriage of their daughter, Miss Clarice Jane Freeman, to Edward Savage Jr., son of Mrs. Jason C. Matthews of Warren, Pa., and of Edward Savage of New York.

Mrs. Helen N. Rapp, widow of Garrett V. Rapp, who was a Brooklyn builder and owner of up-State stone quarries, died today in the Lawrence Hospital She was 77 years old and resided at 24 Oriole Avenue, Bronxville. Mrs. Rapp was born at Fort Plain, N. Y., and lived many years at Canajoharie, N. Y.

Emily Roosevelt, soprano, returned to the local concert platform last night in Town Hall after an absence of five years. Her recital was well attended and the singing she put forth enthusiastically received.
President Roosevelt tonight received by telephone from Secretary Perkins intimation that an agreement was in sight at the Chrysler conferences tomorrow.

Jose Gancedo Gonzalez, a hobo, hanged himself in his jail cell today exactly a month after the kidnap-killing of 2-year-old Eugenio Pereyra Iraola, a crime Gancedo Gonzalez twice confessed and once repudiated.

Before a joint session of the Legislature, which six weeks ago recorded its opposition to President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan, Postmaster General James A. Farley today made a fighting speech in favor of the plan and was thrice interrupted by applause.

The Museum of the City of New York has received as a gift from Harry Shaw Newman of the Old Print Shop, 150 Lexington Avenue, a wood engraving showing "The Children's Picnic Excursion-Organized by THE NEW YORK TIMES in 1872." This print will be added to the collection of the museum, the purpose of which is to recreate for the present New York's past.
Wall Street received yesterday advance notice of important developments in regulation of investment banking by the Securities and Exchange Commission. William O.

James R. Simpson of Elizabeth, N. J., outstanding sprinter and middle distance man, was elected captain of the Princeton University swimming team for next year at a meeting of lettermen today. Simpson will succeed Howard L. Canoune of Plainfield. N. J.

Ruling that the grain market transactions of J. C. Vandagrift, former bank president charged with embezzlement, constituted gambling, Federal Judge A. Lee Wyman, in a decision on file today, returned a judgment for $25,000 against the Burke Grain Company.
Housing properties in the upper West Side and Washington Heights areas proved attractive to investors yesterday. Savings banks figured as sellers in some of the deals.

The Continental Insurance Company announced the resignation of C. M. Leonard as a director. Thomas S. Gates Jr. of Drexel Co., Philadelphia, was elected a director of the Scott Paper Company, to succeed William W. Tomlinson, formerly advertising manager:

Henry Weld Newton, a retired chemical manufacturer, died of a throat infection yesterday at his home, 10 Soundview Drive. Until his retirement last Summer he was president of the Pixie Corporation, a chemical firm which moved from New York to Larchmont in 1928.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts will consider tenders on Monday for a new issue of $4,000,000 of short-term notes. The notes will be dated April 2, 1937, and will become payable on March 22, 1938.
Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Werner of 20 East Seventy-sixth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Werner, to Leonard L. Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav W. Katz of Baltimore.

An increase in quotas allocated to foreign countries on their sugar exports to the United States was favored by Secretary Hull today in a statement transmitted to the House Agriculture Committee, which is of considering legislation for the production, control, marketing and importation of that commodity.
D. Walker Wear of Binghamton was named today for the third time as a member of the State Athletic Commission.
Verdi's "Aida" will be presented at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night, April 4, it was announced yesterday by Alfredo Salmaggi, director of the Hippodrome Opera Company.

MATHEMATICS FOR THE MILLION, by Lancelot Hogben. (Norton, $3.75.) An exposition for the general reader. TODAY IS FOREVER, by Ramona Herdman. (Harper, $2.50.) The story of a woman's search for personal identity.

H. C. Beaver, president of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, announced yesterday that a special meeting of stockholders has been called for May 12 to act on a recapitalization plan approved by the directors designed to fund accumulated preferred dividends, which were $4,620,502 at the end of '1936, and to reduce future preferred dividend requirements.

An action to prevent the New York Anti-Vivisection Society from disbanding and distributing about $80,000 now in its treasury to organizations with instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by Miss C. Helen King of 310 East 118th Street.

Max Baer resolved today to earn more than $300,000 before he leaves England in August. He said he would get $30,000 for fighting Tommy Farr at Harringay, April 15, between $30,000 and $35,000 against Walter Neusel later and the rest when he meets Joe Louis at White City.

A dozen young women will help tug St. Cloud's 2,500-ton granite postoffice down the home stretch to new moorings tomorrow. Supplanting the two horses which have pulled the building three blocks, Supervisor E. W. La Plante said the women had consented to tug the bulky structure past one cross street.

The Board of Transportation delivered to the American Car and Foundry Company and the Pullman Standard Car Manufacturing Company yesterday a joint contract for construction of 150 steel cars for the city's Independent Subway System.

From President Harold Willis Dodds of Princeton University, as he sat quietly smoking his pipe at a spirited session of the Senate Judiciary Committee, came the suggestion today that issues raised by President Roosevelt's judiciary reorganization plan be committed to an independent commission for study and settlement "as remote as possible from the heat of political controversy."

Movement of naval vessels follow, all dates are March 23 unless specified: At Philadelphia Yard, March 24: Cassin, Shaw. At Naples, March 24: Charleston, McDougal. At Norfolk Yard: Chaumont, March 24; New York, Tucker, Wyoming. Hampton Roads to Southern Drill Grounds, March 24: Clark, Phelps.

Jimmy Caras and Ralph Greenleaf broke even yesterday at the Strand Academy in their pocket billiard match. In the fifth block, Caras ran out his 125 points in the opening inning after Greenleaf had broken the pile.

Cyrus B. Denman, president of the National Livestock Marketing Association and a former member of the Federal Farm Board, will join the staff of the National Association of Food Chains on April 1 as agricultural counsel, it was announced yesterday by John A. Logan, executive vice president of the food organization.

Chang Soo Lee, convicted on March 11 of administering poisons to Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves, received the maximum penalty allowed by statute today from County Judge Gerald Nolan. He was fined $2,000 and sentenced to five to ten years in Sing Sing. Deportation to Korea, his birthplace, will follow release from prison.

King George has intimated to foreign governments through official channels that he does not wish gifts on his coronation. This follows the precedent set by his father, George V, who said shortly before the last coronation that outlays for lavish official presents were needless burdens on others and should be discouraged.

Isaac Robinson of 220 West 120th Street, a truck driver, was cleared yesterday of a charge of homicide in the death of a 5-year-old girl by Magistrate Frank Oliver in Bronx magistrates court, when the latter was informed that- the evidence against Robinson had already been presented to the grand jury and found insufficient to warrant a trial. The girl,

Dedining to accept a compromise of their demands, 150 employes of the Electro Dynamic Works, a subsidiary of the Electric Boat Company, went on strike this morning, forcing the plant to close. The company offered a 10 per cent rise in wages, but insisted on a 44-hour week.

The third and final presentation of Puccini's "Madam Butterfly" for the current season was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. With the exception of one change, the cast was the same as in the previous productions.

Two men working in the railroad signal tower alongside the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad were injured this morning when a derailed car of a Washington to New York express train struck the tower as it careened down an embankment.

After six weeks of investigation of the recent Jack Torrance-Earl Phillips scandal, the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday vindicated all who were accused of requesting Phillips "to take a dive" for the world's shot put record-holder in their scheduled bout in Louisiana last month.

After assailing Governor Lehman's executive budget as falling short by $38,000,000 or more of supplying the needs of the State for the next fiscal year, Republicans in the Assembly joined with the Democrats today in voting for his main budget bills and all of the Governor's revenue measures except the one which would restore the fourth cent of the emergency tax on gasoline. The footing of the budget is $370,139,937.

Celtic defeated Motherwell, 2--1, in a fourth-round Scottish Cup replay today. The teams battled to a 4-4 draw a week ago at Glasgow. In the semi-finals, April 3, Celtic will oppose Clyde and Morton will meet Aberdeen.

A bill changing the Central Bank of China into a central reserve bank capitalized at $50,000,000 (Chinese) was approved today by the Central Political Council. The bill goes to the Legislative Council which can not amend it, so early approval is expected.
Benjamin R. Halley, former Deputy Grand Chancellor of the Knights of Pythias, died on Tuesday night in his home, at 248 Audubon Avenue, after a short illness.
Extremely close bidding, particularly for an issue of such a long maturity, marked yesterday's sale of $15,000,000 of New York State grade-crossing bonds.

G. Lynn Sumner of the G. Lynn Sumner Co., Inc., and Mark O'Dea of O'Dea, Sheldon Co., Inc., will be chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the program committee for the twentieth anniversary convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies to be held at The Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., April 29, 30, and May 1.

Planning a direct protest against Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley's proposal to again investigate the Emergency Relief Bureau in New York City, the Municipal Affairs Committee of the New York City League of Women Voters voted yesterday to carry their fight to the Mayor and Board of Estimate by letter.

The National Council of Gasoline Station Operators, affiliated with the American Federation of Lab6r, voted today to oppose any efforts of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization to organize the marketing division of the petroleum industry.The council,

Work began yesterday on the construction of the city's new $273,000,000 Delaware River water-supply project when Mayor La Guardia fired a dynamite blast at the first shaft for a water tunnel in the town of Gardiner. Ulster County.

Isaac Robinson of 220 West 120th Street, a truck driver, was cleared yesterday of a charge of homicide in the death of a 5-year-old girl by Magistrate Frank Oliver in Bronx magistrates court, when the latter was informed that- the evidence against Robinson had already been presented to the grand jury and found insufficient to warrant a trial. The girl,

Dedining to accept a compromise of their demands, 150 employes of the Electro Dynamic Works, a subsidiary of the Electric Boat Company, went on strike this morning, forcing the plant to close. The company offered a 10 per cent rise in wages, but insisted on a 44-hour week.

The third and final presentation of Puccini's "Madam Butterfly" for the current season was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. With the exception of one change, the cast was the same as in the previous productions.

The thirty-eight acre property, formerly known as the Warfield estate, in Greenwich, Conn., has been sold by Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., to a client of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

At least 100,000 persons took part last year in a mass movement of farmers, still in progress, precipitated by the parched plains and seared farms of the drought-ravaged Great Plains after recurring years of low rainfall, according to a report to the Resettlement Administration from its Pacific Coast representatives.
Extremely close bidding, particularly for an issue of such a long maturity, marked yesterday's sale of $15,000,000 of New York State grade-crossing bonds.

G. Lynn Sumner of the G.
