Lynn Sumner Co., Inc., and Mark O'Dea of O'Dea, Sheldon Co., Inc., will be chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the program committee for the twentieth anniversary convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies to be held at The Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., April 29, 30, and May 1.

Planning a direct protest against Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley's proposal to again investigate the Emergency Relief Bureau in New York City, the Municipal Affairs Committee of the New York City League of Women Voters voted yesterday to carry their fight to the Mayor and Board of Estimate by letter.

The National Council of Gasoline Station Operators, affiliated with the American Federation of Lab6r, voted today to oppose any efforts of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization to organize the marketing division of the petroleum industry.The council,

Work began yesterday on the construction of the city's new $273,000,000 Delaware River water-supply project when Mayor La Guardia fired a dynamite blast at the first shaft for a water tunnel in the town of Gardiner. Ulster County.

Of the five victims of the T. W. A. plane crash near Pittsburgh who resided in the metropolitan area, Frederick Lawrence Bohnet, the pilot had lived with his wife, the former Lulu Belle Pederson of Detroit, in Jersey City for the past two years, having gone there from Kansas City.
Professor Thomas Salignac of the French National Conservatory of Music arrived yesterday on the Paris of the French Line for his first visit to this country in thirtythree years.

Mrs. Leslie D. Forman of this place has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Katherine Forman, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Radcliffe Forman of Montclair, to Dr. George A. Scheller, son of Mrs. George A. Scheller of Newark.
The Rev. John A. Weiand, S. J., assistant pastor of Gesu Church, and well known as a Catholic educator, died today. He was 65 years old.

A reduction of 20 per cent on premiums for bonds posted by municipal treasurers and tax collectors was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance. He announced a similar reduction on probate bonds of $2,000 or more.

Five hundred geologists, engineers and their guests participated last night in celebrating the seventieth birthday of Dr. Charles P. Berkey, Newberry Professor of Geology at Columbia University, at a dinner held in the new ballroom of the Hotel Astor.

Democratic leaders adjourned the House in disorder today after Representative Church, Republican, of Illinois, had asserted that a $6,400 fee had been awarded to a law firm headed by Representative Sabath, Illinois Democrat, in connection with an inquiry into a real estate bondholders' committee.

The United States Assay Office, Old Slip and South Street, sent its seventh shipment of gold to the Federal Treasury vaults at Fort Knox, Ky., last night. The latest consignment was $180,000,000, bringing the total from New York to $1,050,000,000.

Miss Vivian Wellman King, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Roscoe King and the late Mr. King, was married to Charles P. White yesterday afternoon at Eversley, the home here of the Rev. Samuel J. Evers, pastor of the Union Memorial Church, who performed the ceremony.

Representatives of the railroads and steamship lines serving the North Atlantic port cities ranging from Boston to Newport News authorized the creation of a joint committee to devise means of combating the diversion of import and export freight to other American ports and to Canada at a conference yesterday afternoon at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.
Since Warden Lawes, the benign turn-key, is co-author of "Chalked Out," which was put on at the Morosco last evening, the prison scenes have the ring and clang of truth.
Coming through with a "suddendeath" goal, the New York Rangers defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs in a thrilling hockey play-off battle at Madison Square Garden last night.
The security and commodity markets were generally under the preholiday influence yesterday. Trading was comparatively small and prices mainly fluctuated within narrow limits.

A bill legalizing sale of 3.2 per cent beer in Kansas, which has been constitutionally dry since 1881, received final legislative approval today over the protests of the men whose name it bore as co-authors.

The eighth in the series of MozartHaydn concerts last night at the WPA Theatre of Music attracted a large and enthusiastic audience. The chamber orchestra was under the direction of Samuel Gardner and the soloists were Stephen Maxymciw, bassoonist, and Thelma Jerguson and Mina Horne, sopranos.

The Aiken point-to-point race was work today by Gunner Johren, ridden by L. E. Stoddard Jr., and owned by Mrs. Stoddard. The winner gained the lead at the sixth jump and was never overtaken, finishing five lengths in front of Captain Lee piloted by Barney Balding.

The word that scup'ss come," which fishermen consider the surest harbinger of Spring, ran along the waterfront today after the schooner Cape May came in with a varied assortment of fish. Besides 400 pounds of scup, the Cape May, owned by Captain Ben Pine of Gloucester,

The Chamber of Deputies this evening passed a bill fixing hotel prices in France during the Paris Exposition this Summer, by a vote of 313 to 275, thereby safeguarding tourists visiting the country between May and October against "hold-ups."

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Toward Democratic Organization," H. A. Overstreet. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "World - Wide Political Current Events," Mrs. Henry R. Caraway.
A blue-ribbon jury in Supreme Court found seven defendants in the restaurant racket trial guilty on every count last night. It received the "thanks of the State" from Justice Philip J. McCook.

Italy and Yugoslavia signed today a political and economic pact guaranteeing their mutual frontiers and the status quo in the Adriatio for the next five years, granting concessions to the Yugoslav minority in Italy and committing each government not to tolerate on its territory propaganda or other activities against the other.

Miss Adele Van Cott of Watertown, N. Y., will be married to Dr. John A. Clarke of Greenwich, medical examiner of the town for the last thirty years, Tuesday morning at the home of Miss Christine Devendorf, 266 Mullin Street, Watertown, with whom Miss Van Cott has made her home. The Rev. Dr.

The new Italian Line pier at the foot of West Fifty-second Street was officially placed in use late yesterday afternoon when the liner Saturnia arrived and landed 747 passengers from Mediterranean ports.

The ship lines operating in conference groups between Atlantic and Gulf ports and the West Indies and South and Central America notified shippers yesterday that a tenday limit would be allowed for the assembling of out-bound cargoes on piers, effective April 26.

Salvatore di Rosa, 41 years old, of 87-32 Seventeenth Avenue, Brooklyn, who defrauded several persons of more than $10,000 of securities they had entrusted to him for sale, was sentenced to a penitentiary term up to three years by Judge Streit in General Sessions yesterday when he pleaded guilty to petit larceny.

President Roosevelt ended a maritime controversy today by signing a bill making it merely optional for seamen to carry "continuous discharge books." Under the original Copeland Safety-at-Sea Act, all seamen were required to carry the books, which contain a continuous chronology of their service.

Fred Perry of England, former world's amateur tennis champion, defeated Ellsworth Vines of California, world's professional champion, tonight in straight sets of an exhibition match. The scores were 6-1, 6-2.

Twenty per cent of the country's urban population now believes that the United States is on its way toward communism, according to the results of personal interviews with 5,000 families in sixty cities in forty States from coast to coast.

The Provident Institution for Savings of Jersey City sold to Edward Chechick the four-story fiat at 127 Van Wagenen Av.. Jersey City. The buyer gave back In part payment a purchase money mortgage for $47.500. due Jan. 1. 1940. at 5 per cent.
Behind the combined six-hit pitching of Walter Signer, Harry Eisenstat and Hank Winston, a second team of Dodgers today defeated Louisville of the American Association 12 to 1.

The locomotive and four cars of the Pennsylvania Railroad's Liberty Limited, Chicago-to-New York express, left the rails and plowed up 200 feet of roadbed at Forty-fourth Street near Girard Avenue here today. None of the eighty-six passengers was hurt.
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived here at 7:30 P. M. (9:30 A. M., Eastern standard time) after a flight from Karachi.
A money bag, equipped with a bomb that sends out heavy smoke when opened by a person unfamiliar with the catch, worked to perfection this afternoon when it was seized by two armed bandits.

Scrawled pages in a soggy diary found beside the frozen bodies of two young hunters in the wilderness of Northern Quebec revealed today a story of death from cold and starvation. Death, approaching slowly for days, wrote "finis" to the record of the last days of Willie Collin, 23, and his brother, Edgar, 20,

Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Stehli gave a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club before their departure Monday for New York, whence they sail for London. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Farrell and Miss Ritchie Farrell were dinner hosts. Mrs. M. Bernard Phillips also gave a dinner.

Stockholders of the United Electric Coal Company approved yesterday in Chicago an increase in the authorized common stock from 535,000 to 750,000 shares, and a change in par value from no par to $5 par.

Three carpenters employed by the American Smelting and Refining Company died of gas poisoning about noon today while working in the "bag house" of the concern's State Street plant here. Two other carpenters were overcome in trying to rescue them.
The Massachusetts Senate today again voted in favor of repeal of a law requiring teachers to swear allegiance to the Federal and State Constitutions.

The Customs Bureau reported today that the number of well-to-do .women who try to smuggle in Parisian gowns has increased with better times. During the depression, bureau officials said, many American women returned home empty-handed from the fashionable Paris salons.

The Bruins rallied valiantly to continue in the National Hockey League play-offs and displayed amazing improvement while shutting out the Montreal Maroons, 4-0, in a thrilling game tonight before an overflow crowd of 16,500 at the Boston Garden.

The work of the five committees of the "little NRA" platform commission of the National Retail Dry Goods Association is "progressing," but definite approval of a program has not been reached, David E. Moeser of Conrad Co. and president of the association, said last night over the telephone from Boston.

The three transcontinental airlines of the country announced yesterday fare revisions to take effect May 1. American Airlines and United Air Lines reduced their rates, while Transcontinental and Western Air revised its rates upward.

The appearance as soloist of Lotte Lehmann and the first New York performance of a symphony by the young American, Sam Barber, were predominant features of the New York Philharmonic Symphony concert given under the direction of Artur Rodzinski last night in Carnegie Hall.

John M. Morehead, former United States Minister to Sweden, and Mrs. Morehead are at the St. Regis. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt left yesterday to join Brig. Gen. Vanderbilt on their yacht Winchester at Miami.
Robert Lee Williams, for eighteen years United States judge for the Eastern District of Oklahoma, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be judge of the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals.

To the command "En garde" at 10 o'clock this morning, steel will ring against steel in the temporary Salle d'Armes of the Hotel Commodore and the forty-fourth annual intercollegiate fencing championships will get under way, a dueling marathon that will require some twenty-five hours to determine the seven titles at stake.

Horace C. Jones 2d, '38, of Conshohocken, Pa., has been elected chairman of the Princeton University orchestra for 1937-38. The announcement was made by the retiring chairman, Peter de W. Hauser, '37, of Llanerch, Pa.

George Stevenson Patton, member. of the Colonial Parliament, chairman of the Bermuda Board of Agriculture and member of the Executive Council, died today in King Edward Memorial Hospital at the age of 69.

The bleacherites on the citrus circuit still call them the Senators, though Clark Calvin Griffith would like his club to be known as the "Nationals." Last year Bucky Harris moved the Senators up from seventh to fourth place, getting the jump while everybody was looking the other way.
After an interval of five years vanadium ore again is being shipped from Peru in large volume owing to the increase in world metal prices and to the rapid expansion of the iron and steel industries.

Mrs. Anne Meredith Kitson, widow of Samuel J. Kitson, English sculptor, died yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hospital after a brief illness. She was 82 years old and lived at 27 West Sixty-seventh Street.

Appeals to Jews in this country to increase their aid to their persecuted brethren in Germany, Poland, Rumania and other foreign lands will mark the Jewish festival of Passover, which begins tonight at sundown.
The Marylebone Cricket Club touring team carried its first innings' score from 334 runs for seven wickets to 427 in its match against a New Zealand eleven today.

Republican leaders in Manhattan are becoming convinced, it was disclosed yesterday, that they will be unable to get the rank and file of Republican voters to support Mayor La Guardia for re-election, even if the leaders decide to give him the party endorsement.

In comparison with last week, Easter trade has improved sharply in local stores-during the last few days. Although weather conditions have not been favorable, some stores here on several days of the week have scored sales gains ranging up to 20 per cent over the same week last year.

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 17.45 cents a pound, or more than 1 cent a pound above the domestic level. The bulk of the business was done around 17.225 cents. On Wednesday the range of prices abroad was between 16.675 to 17.225 cents.

Following is a summary of the formal statement presented today by Young B. Smith, dean of the faculty of law of Columbia University, as a witness before the Senate Judiciary Committee in connection with the President's proposals:

William Alexander, secretary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died yesterday, it was announced by T. I. Parkinson, president of the organization. Mr. Alexander, who was 88 years old, died at Winter Park, Fla., after he had suffered a heart attack two days ago. He succumbed after a second attack yesterday.
Mrs. Rutgers Clarkson of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lillie May Clarkson, to Walter E. Stager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram W. Stager of Nutley.

With the foregoing changes, yesterday's statement of the Bank of France, which represents its actual position at the end of last week, compares as follows with reports for previous weeks, in millions of francs:

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 969,000 bales, against 943,000 a week ago, against 941,000 two weeks ago, 969,000 three weeks ago and 716,000 a year ago; of which American 423,000 bales, against 420,000 a week ago, 391,000 two weeks ago, 415,000 three weeks ago and 350,000 a year ago.
Three men remained alive today, survivors of one of the country's worst motor bus accidents, which claimed the lives of twenty members of a professional roller-skating troupe.

P. B. Baldwin, general sales man ager of the Collins Aikman Corportion, has been elected to its board of directors. The Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been appointed registrar for the $1 par value capital stock of the Pennsylvania-Central Airlines Corporation.

The Diplomatische Korrespondenz today issued the first response from the government to the papal encyclical. Although the Pope charged bad faith, the paper makes no threats, and it would seem to indicate that there will be no concrete results from National Socialist wrath.

Several hundred New Yorkers departed last night- on snow trains from Grand Central Station to spend the Easter week-end skiing in the Eastern Slope area of New Hampshire and the Laurentians of Canada.

Shareholders of the Consolidated Laundries Corporation will vote in Baltimore on April 7 on a compensation agreement with Arthur S. Jenkins, president. The contract provides that, in addition to his salary, Mr. Jenkins shall receive 5 per cent of the annual consolidated net income available for dividends in excess of $200,000. The agreement is to run until the end of 1938.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling: Gold coin and bullion..increased ?2,000 Reserve in banking dept.,

Officials of the Etched Products Corporation were notified yesterday that a violation of the building code had been posted against their plant at 39-01 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, for permitting sit-down strikers to live in the building.

James J. Walker, former Mayor, was sworn in yesterday as one of a commission to take testimony on the sanity of an ex-convict awaiting sentence in General Sessions in a hold-up. Later he spent some time on the General Sessions bench with Judge John J. Freschi, who appointed him the day before, and announced he was not seeking a pension from the city through the job.
Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 81.5 from 80.4. It was 77.3 for the week ended March 21. 1936.

In the introduction to his interpretation of PLATO under the title "The Son of Apollo," Professor FREDERICK J. E. WOODBRIDGE said that when we write the life of PLATO "it is a group "of students of philosophy that we see "surrounding him "-a group "holding "itself largely aloof from current "events and talking about virtue, tem"perance, justice, love, the one, the "many, the proper constitution of cities "and the probable constitution of the "world."

The Hamburg-American liner Hansa is due late tonight from Hamburg, Bremen and Channel ports. Her passengers include a group of about twenty-five German tourists who will visit Eastern American cities during the Easter holidays.

STOWE, Vt.--Skiing perfect; 24 to 30 inches snow in Smugglers Notch, increasing to about 6 feet on mountain; 12 above. RUTLAND, Vt.-Nine inches new snow covering 30-inch base on Shrewsbury trails; prospect for week-end excellent; 20 above. Three inches new snow at Manchester; ski tow will run.

The marriage of Miss Cynthia M. Stull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Stull of this place, to Donald Simonson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris W. Simonson, also of Madison, took place today in the Green Village Methodist Church.
Mrs. J. D. Hertz's Flying Breeze made his first start of the Fair Grounds meeting a successful one today by coming from behind in the stretch to win the feature, a sixfurlong race.
Ralph J. Jacobs, retired stock broker, died yesterday at his home, 37 West Seventieth Street, after an illness of three weeks. He was 75 years old.

The St. Regis Paper Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net profit of $730,085 after all reserves, charges and taxes, including $154,000 provision for surtax on undistributed profits.

The marriage of Miss Lydia Maria Diaz of Puerto Rico to Charles O'Day, son of Representative Caroline O'Day of New York, was announced here today. The ceremony was performed on March 18 at Caracas, Venezuela, where Mr. O'Day is United States Vice Consul.

The board of directors of the Standard Power and Light Corporation, which owns a majority of the common shares of Standard Gas and Electric Company, has been reduced from fifteen to five, with the relative strength of Class A and Class B directors preserved.

Commissioner Henry Mapp, the Salvation Army's chief of staff, is ill under a doctor's care, it was learned today, and there is some doubt whether he will be able to return to his post at the Army's internal tional headquarters here.

John Drinkwater, poet and playwright, died in his sleep this morning at his home here of a heart attack, said to have been induced by his excitement at the Oxford-Cambridge boat race Yesterday. He was 54 years old.

Engineering construction awards for the week are $49,006,000, the second highest weekly total this year and a 40 per cent gain over the corresponding week last year, according to The Engineering NewsRecord. The total is made up of private, $25,698,000; public, $23,308,000, and for the same week last year the figures were: total, $32,611,000; private, $11,385,000; public, $21,226.000.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date while total bills discounted were at the highest.

Willem van Hoogstraten, conductor of the Portland Symphony Orchestra and who has served as guest conductor of the concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium during the Summer, will direct the WPA Symphony Orchestra on Sunday evening at the WPA Theatre of Music, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street.

The presidents of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks of the country, meeting here today, commended as "one of the soundest investments ever made by the United States Government," the Home Owners Loan Corporation's investment of $146,525,300 in augmenting the home-financing funds of 1,060 savings and loan associations.

All ten passengers and the three members of the crew of a giant Transcontinental Airways skyline were killed about 6:45 o'clock tonight when the plane crashed nose first into a small gully in Clifton, ten miles from here.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public its first report on a plan of recapitalization submitted under the Holding Company Act of 1935 relative to an application by Illinois Power and Light Corporation, a member of the North American Company system.

Tear gas, laughing gas, celluloid bullets that sting but do not penetrate the skin and spraying machines that mark clothing and faces with stains that cannot be removed for several weeks are all suggested as weapons to be employed by Paris police in place of revolvers and carbines, which too often kill and wound bystanders instead of manifestants.
Edward S. Knapp Jr. and Joseph Blaisdell, Class C players, beat higher-ranked opponents in the Poggenburg Cup 18.2 balkline tournament at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night.

The TWA airliner which fell near Pittsburgh today plunged to earth within fifty feet of a passing motorist, who gave a vivid eyewitness account of the tragedy. H. S. Griest and his wife were driving along McMurray Road on the way to their home in Mount Lebanon.

Aubrey (Dit) Clapper, right wing on the Boston Bruins, was fined $100 yesterday by President Frank Calder of the National Hockey League for having struck Referee Clarence Campbell in the play-off game between the Bruins and Maroons in Montreal on Tuesday night.
Advocates of repealing Texas's law permitting pari-mutuel wagering on horse racing scored an important victory tonight when a Senate committee voted, 8 to 6, to report favorably a repeal bill.

Colonel Ralph H. Isham, who in 1927 discovered enough of James Boswell's hitherto unpublished papers to fill eighteen volumes, and three years later discovered the original manuscript of Boswell's "Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides with Samuel Johnson," has made a new discovery-an eighty-four page dairy kept by Dr. Johnson between 1765 and 1784.
Transport Workers Lodge No. 1,547 of the International Association of Machinists carried its fight against the Board of Transportation to the State Federation of Labor yesterday.

The Texas Corporation reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net income of $38,260,341 after charges, reserves and taxes (including $380,000 for undistributed profits taxes), equal to $4.10 each on the 9,336,739 capital shares outstanding.

The Harvard student council in a comprehensive report on Harvard athletics, made public tonight, has made important recommendations to President James B. Conant and to William J. Bingham, chairman of the committee on the regulation of athletic snorts.
The Spanish Government tonight challenged the right of the international "hands off Spain" committee to interfere with its commerce in policing Spain's coasts.

Ten thousand square miles of Southern California were shaken by an earthquake this morning. From San Diego to Santa Monica and from the Mojave Desert to the sea a series of light shocks was felt about 9 o'clock.

The government launched a push at dawn today against the Insurgents at Pozoblanco, in the northern part of Central Cordoba Province. [The campaign around Pozoblanco is due to a Rebel drive to capture the important mercury mines at Almaden, about thirty miles north of that place.

Argentina's foreign trade in January and February left a favorable trade balance of 359,775,000 pesos, as compared with 84,380,000 in the first two months of last year, according to a report of the National Statistical Bureau, published today.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., will offer today $2,850,000 of Allegheny County (Pa.) 2 3/4 per cent bonds, due April 1, 1938 to 1967, inclusive. The bonds will be priced to yield from 1.00 to 2.75 per cent, according to maturity.
A little band of Pennsylvania "plain people," garbed in the somber clothes of their religious faiths, demanded in Federal District Court today that the government stop trying to lend them money.

Miss Amelia Elizabeth Lepire, daughter of Mrs. Charles O. Webb of this place and the late Louis L. Lepire, was married this evening to Richard Christopher Smyth of New York, son of Mrs. William R. Smyth of Waukegan, Ill., and the late Gerry A. Browne, at the Bedford Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Daniel K. Poling officiated.

Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General in New York, arrived on the French liner Paris yesterday after a visit to his home. He forecast that the 1937 season would be a recordbreaking tourist year in France because of the Paris Exposition, in which the American displays are expected to attract many.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company and subsidiaries report for 1936 gross operating revenue of $4,149,055, and net operating revenue of $698,745 after expenses and depreciation. Net income after taxes and charges was $159,173. Previous reports are not comparable.

These Dodgers are becoming positively disrespectful toward their betters. After trouncing the world champion Yanks yesterday the gruff Grimes boys today pulled a surprise attack upon the former champion Tigers and whipped them decisively by an 8-3 score.

" On the Level," this year's musical show of Harvard's Pi Eta Club, had its world premiere at the Winthrop Square Clubhouse in Cambridge tonight with the 250 graduates to whom attendance was limited going on record that the show was one of the best in years.

" What I said several weeks ago about sit-down strikes not being tolerated in Connecticut still goes," said Governor Cross tonight, when his attention was called to a sitdown strike yesterday in a Plainville factory which overnight developed into a walkout.

Postmaster General Farley said today that regular air mail service to Europe might begin this year. He spoke at the dedication of new postoffices here and at Gretna, small towns across the Mississippi River and below New Orleans.

The five-story apartment house at 710 Lexington Avenue, between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth Streets, has been sold by Philibert Combier of Paris, France, to an investing client of Moses Polakoff. Assessed at $100,000, the flat is on a lot 17.10 by 100 feet and was bought for cash over a first mortgage held by the Dry Dock Savings Institution.

Retail furniture dealers, interior decorators, upholsterers and household furnishings concerns were prominent among the principals involved in yesterday's commercial leasing reports. The list follows:

The twelve-story apartment at 40-56 University Place, known as the Beauclaire, was among the eight Manhattan properties sold yesterday at auction. The plaintiffs, Tillie Jasie, and the Public Service Ticket Office, Inc., in foreclosure proceedings against the Greenwich Village Development Corp., acquired the building, which occupies a plot 185 by 49.4 by irregular feet on a bid of $697,500.

Liquor cases "are cluttering up the courts," and the police "should be out after criminals instead of A. B. C. violators," Magistrate Anna M. Kross declared yesterday and urged, in Harlem Court that the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board should have its own staff of investigators.

Leroy Deering Peavey, former president of Babson's Statistical Organization, Wellesley Hills, died today at his home here. His age was 61. We became president upon the retirement of Roger Babson, who formed the organization.

Net profit of the Packard Motor Car Company in 1936 was reported yesterday as $7,053,220 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, $10,654 provision for Federal surtax on undistributed income and other deductions. This is equal to 47 cents a share on 15,000,000 no par shares of capital stock. In 1935 the company earned $3,315,622, or 22 cents a share.

Security and Commodity Exchanges here and abroad will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. Abroad Good Friday is the most widely-observed bank holiday of the year, apart from Christmas, and throughout Europe and most of Latin America all financial business will be suspended.

William Hillard Conyngham was elected today chairman of the board of directors of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company. He succeeds the late Frank Wheaton. Leonard Sullivan of New York was elected a director to succeed Mr. Wheaton on the board.
The Reichsbank's statement as of March 24 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Miss Louise Mackay Ireland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Ireland of Jackson Heights, was married yesterday to F. Lee Ramsdell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. L. Ramsdell of Washington Terrace, East Orange, N. J.
The Insurgent-held portion of Spain tonight was in the midst of Holy Week celebrations, with military observers expecting little fighting in the eight-month-old civil war until after Easter.
While thousands of Londoners crowded the sidewalks and sometimes choked traffic for a glimpse of them, Anzacs marched through the city today for the first time since the war.

Following his injunction of last Tuesday ordering the sit-down strikers of the Champion Shoe Corporation, 104 Bleecker Street, to vacate the premises-an injunction which the strikers obeyed Tuesday evening-Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller issued a final decree yesterday commanding the strikers to cease picketing the establishment.
A passenger in a hit-and-run automobile was charged yesterday in Queens Felony Court with being an accessory in the criminal negligence case against the driver.
A continued urgent demand for cash wheat from importing countries sent the price of futures soaring in European markets and in Winnipeg today to new high levels in about eight years.

Mrs. Jeanne Marie Scott Cable of Paris was married to Paul Lennon, also of Paris, here this afternoon at the North Lake Trail residence of Mrs. H. Ashton Henry, which Mr. Lennon has taken for the late season.

Philip Breitmeyer, former Detroit Mayor, announced tonight the formation of a voluntary organization known as "Citizens of Michigan," saying the "sole object is to affirm respect for law and to encourage impartial law enforcement for the benefit of working men and all alike."

Walter B. Brooks Jr., prominent for years in the business and social life of Baltimore, died suddenly today of a heart attack at the age of 53. He was president of the ArundelBrooks Concrete Corporation.

With less speculative activity in commodities in the week ended on Tuesday than there had been re- 4 cently, according to The Annalist, that publication's index of wholesale commodity prices advanced 0.2 point to 144.5 from 144.3 (revised) on the Tuesday previous.

As a result of a compromise reached after considerable discussion, the name of Martin Luther has been removed from one of the six mural panels now being painted by WPA artists in the rotunda of the County Court House, it was learned yesterday, but the portrait of the German religious reformer has been allowed to remain.

During the week ended March 24 member bank reserve balances decreased $252,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $192,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $82,000,000 in non-member deposits and- other Federal Reserve accounts, and $26,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by a decrease of $10,000,000 in money in circulation and increases of $26,000,000 in gold stock and $13,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit.

To the more striking possibilities of next season add a new musical comedy by Richard Rodgers, Lorenz Hart and Clare Boothe. At least it has reached a point where all three are "seriously discussing" it, and Max Gordon is quoted as having said already that he will produce it.

Frances Marion, screen writer, who, according to. her publishers, was earned $1,500,000 in the last ten rears writing moving picture sce??arios, has written a book called 'Writing and Selling the Film Story," that Covici, Friede will pubish in the early Fall.

Patrolman Jesse Baldwin, veteran member of the Hempstead Police Department, received a suspended sentence of three months in the Nassau County jail from Police Judge George B. Serenbetz here this morning after being found guilty by a jury of having sold a revolver to an unlicensed person.

The Dionne quintuplets will soon be in the millionaire class. The sisters, 3 years old on May 28, already have received payments topping the half-million mark and those receivable will raise the total to $861,148.39. The Ontario Government announced today that the babies had received $573,765.05 from twenty-four motion picture,...

Wallace G. Garland, who became known as "The Wizard" after his graduation from Yale University, when he interested Professor Irving Fisher in his scheme to guide traffic by a so-called electric eye system, received a prison sentence of two years yesterday from Federal Judge John C. Knox.

The Electric Bond and Share Company, one of the largest public utility holding companies in the United States, decided yesterday to continue its fight on the constitutionality of the Publio Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

While laying over here, waiting for the storm center to pass west of the new air track still to be surveyed between here and Auckland, New Zealand, the Pan American Clipper was being serviced today for the final stage of our flight from the United States to Australasia.

Miss Julie Sandler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Sandler of 40 West Seventy-seventh Street, was married to Harris B. Steinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Steinberg of Brooklyn, last night at the Gotham.

Business in the Pittsburgh district continued to improve last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The volume of trade increased somewhat, but the gain was less than seasonal.

Isaac H. Green, who. retired as an architect fifteen years ago after having constructed many of the large mansions along the South Shore of Long Island, died yesterday after a prolonged illness. He was 79 years old.

Mrs. Robert Winthrop Kean will entertain with a dinner on Monday night at her home, 11 East Seventyfourth Street, for her daughter, Miss Elizabeth S. Kean, and later will take her guests to the Junior Get-Together dance in the ballroom of the Pierre.
Opponents of John L. Lewis's steel union drive within the ranks of the 120,000 employes of the CarnegieIllinois Steel Corporation announced the formation today of the American Union of Steel Workers.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, famed concert pianist, was reported "making normal progress" today against an attack of bronchitis. Friends of the former Premier of Poland said that his condition was "reassuring."

Following two years of study and research, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers has launched a campaign to secure the general adoption in the industry of standards of construction and insection for women's full-fashioned hosiery.
A gale blew so much water out of Buffalo harbor early today that the first steamship of the season, coming up Lake Erie, did not immediately attempt to enter port for fear of running aground.

An official opinion of the State Department on the question of whether Italy and Germany are in a state of war with the Loyalist government of Spain with a view to declaring an arms embargo .against those countries would be required by a resolution introduced in the Senate today by Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota.

A mortgage for $72,000 on 819-825 10th Av., held by the Emigrant Bank from the 243 W. 66th St. Corp., J. Abrams, president. was extended to Dec. 2, 1941, at 4 per cent. Jesse E. Goldberger assigned a mortgage for $75,000 on 11-13 Waverly Pl. to Lucille Jakobson, who assigned it to the Montrose Industrial Bank, Brooklyn.

Playing as a well-matched unit, Miss Frida Scharman and A. W. Paine last night earned the right to meet Miss Margaret Bostwick and David McElroy in the final of the metropolitan mixed doubles squash racquets championship, which will be played on the Casino courts this evening at 5:30 o'clock.

Joseph H. Nuelle, president of the New York, Ontario Western Railway, was elected today president of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, succeeding Samuel D. Warriner, who was made chairman of the board of managers, a new post. Mr. Warriner had been president of the company since 1912.

In line with expectations of a sharp sales increase this Summer, advertising budgets for men's lightweight clothes of various materials have been expanded from 25 to 50 per cent, reports here yesterday indicated.
The Works Progress Administration announced today approval of allotments totaling $2,429,607 for projects which include schools, sewers and repair work on public buildings.

Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, established today a revised system of grading German films according to merits in the regime's eyes. Films "fulfilling with distinction the National Socialist idea of films" will be graded as "politically and artistically especially valuable."

Mrs. Eunice Skelly, widow of Hal Skelly, the actor, won a verdict of $10,000 yesterday in Federal Court New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. Mr. Skelly was killed on June 16, 1934, when an engine operated by the railroad hit a truck in which he was riding at Cornwall, Conn.

B. Charney Vladick, general manager of The Jewish Daily Forward, New York City, testified at a Federal Communications Commission hearing today that the publishers of his newspaper had pledged at least $250,000 to "build up" radio station WEVD of New York.

In a ceremony that was faithfully carried out in all the medieval pageantry of its origin, Maundy Thursday was celebrated in St. Paul's Cathedral today by the presentation of gifts to eighty-two indigent men and women-one to each man and woman for every year of the King's age, 41.

An out-of-court settlement of the sitdown strike at the Rosedale Knitting Mills of Laureldale, near Reading, relieved Federal Judge George A. Welsh of the necessity here today of ruling on the question of workers' property rights in their jobs.
Apartment house deals again centered on Washington Heights yesday when operators figured as principals in several deals. Several of the properties were acquired for investment.
Captain William H. Harvey, retired, a native of Brooklyn, died at Walter Reed Hospital yesterday, the War in Fit Department announced today. His age was 60.

The New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission ruled today that State banks, trust companies and savings institutions were subject to the State Unemployment Insurance Act, whether or not they are members of the Federal Reserve System.
British Board of Boxing Control today declined to interfere with the bout between Max Baer and Tommy Farr, Welsh holder of the British heavyweight championship, to be held April 15.

Andrew (the Gyp) Canzoneri, 30 years old, a professional gambler according to the police, has been indicted for first degree murder in the killing of Alfred Rossi, manager of the Honeymoon Lane Dance Hall, 711 Seventh Avenue, on Monday, Police Inspector Michael McDermott announced last night.

The engagement of Robert P. Raskob, son of John J. Raskob, financier and former National Democratic Committee Chairman, to Miss Dolores Horter of Reno was announced this evening at a dinner given here. The marriage will take place in June.

The Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad incurred a profit- and loss deficit of $161,269 in 1936, the annual report of Matthew S. Sloan, president, showed yesterday. There was a profit and loss surplus of $78,246 on the books at the beginning of the year, but the net loss of $138,208 for 1936, with $37,422 debits from retirement of road and equipment and $83,956 miscellaneous debits, offset $20,072 miscellaneous credits applied to surplus in 1936.

The statement of Chief Justice Hughes and that of former Supreme Court Justice Clarke are alike in their rigid abstention from any discussion of the political merits or faults of President Roosevelt's proposed law.

An individual plot of 18,000 square feet on Lyons Place and Hartford Street, Mount Vernon, has been sold to a client of Harry D. Cole, broker in the deal. The city of Mount Vernon, which had previously taken it in for unpaid taxes, was the seller of the property.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David St. Lifer of 12 Algonquin Place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gwendolyn St. Lifer, to Oscar Kuritsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Zacharia Kuritsky of Plainfield.

Good Friday will be widely observed in the churches of the city. In Roman Catholic and most of the Protestant Episcopal churches three hours agony services will be held from noon to 3 o'clock to commemorate the time which Jesus Christ hung upon the cross.

Stop Scout, 10-to-1 shot, making his first start of the year, won the featured Rosenberg purse before a large Ladies' Day crowd at Epsom Downs today. Closing fast, Stop Scout ran the five and one-half furlongs in 1:07 1-5.

It is reported in investment-banking circles that the New York Curb Exchange is preparing soon to apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the privilege of unlisted trading in several additional bond issues now dealt in only over the counter, and brokers and dealers in the latter market are making ready to protect their interests.

Another deep cut in their holdings of United States Government securities was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in this city in their condition statement issued yesterday. The drop amounted to $83,000,000.
A foreign government has ordered $3,500,000 worth of high-speed bombing planes from the Vultee Airplane Corporation in Downey, Calif.

Their sensitive noses sniffing pavement and asphalt for a threeday-old trail, and baying as they went, two bloodhounds yesterday tugged policemen for several miles through the Bronx to the Harlem River in a vain attempt to locate a policeman's wife who has been missing since Monday morning.

A claim for $41,800 brought against G. A. Pierce Co., brokers, by Otto Madlener, a customer of the firm, was upheld today by the arbitration committee of the Chicago Board of Trade. The judgment is one of the largest the Exchange ever made against a member firm.

Seven members of a family were burned to death early yesterday in a fire in a three-story frame tenement at 47 Jordan Avenue, Jersey City. The victims, a widow, her five children and her brother, were Mrs. Rose Burkhard, 54 years old;

The marriage of Mrs. Georgette Gerard-Varet Hyde to Harris Fahnestock of this city and Lenox, Mass., which has been planned for next Tuesday afternoon, will take place at the home of Mr. Fahnestock's brother and sister-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Fahnestock, at 954 Fifth Avenue.

The announcement of wage increases of about 10 per cent by many of the large producers resulted in a resumption of the upward swing in wool goods prices this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

The Cardinals dropped a ten-inning decision today to Columbus of the American Association, 4 to 3. St. Louis broke a 2-to-2 tie with a run in the tenth, but the major leaguers' farm club bounced back in the last half with two.

The names of the twenty-four Vassar sophomores who will carry the daisy chain in the class day exercises, commencement week, were announced today. The girls are chosen for not only their beauty, but also their standing as representative members of the class.

There is fairly general agreement that if the three elections in which the President himself was the chief issue had not brought so great a public registry in his favor, his judiciary plan would have no chance to pass the Congress. What these elections did for Mr.

William M. Barrett, president of the Adams Express Company for twenty-seven years until his retirement a month ago, died at 6 o'clock last evening of an attack of heart disease at his home, 272 West Eighty-sixth Street. He was 78 years old.

Amelia Earhart plans to reattempt her around-the-world flight late next month. Miss Earhart, who crashed last Friday in taking off from Honolulu for Howland Island on the second leg of the flight, returned home today on the liner Malolo to be greeted by her husband,
Skippers of yachts competing in the eighth annual St. Petersburg-Havana race will meet tomorrow to receive final instructions and clear their vessels for foreign waters.
Mrs. ELINORE HERRICK presided night before last at an anti-Supreme Court meeting in Carnegie Hall addressed by two United
Assorting the correspondence: A word or two about surf fishing is contained in a letter from Nick Guarino, secretary of the Rockaway Point Surf Anglers Club. Says Mr. Secretary:
Senator Schwellenbach, Democrat, of Washington, urged Congress today to ask the Supreme Court for an advisory opinion on the constitutionality of the administration's crop insurance proposals.
A letter urging Secretary Hull to take diplomatic steps in the case of Helmut Hirsch, sentenced to death in Germany, was received at the State Department today.

Stocks erased early fractional gains and closed irregularly lower; turnover, 1,249,740 shares. United States Government bonds weakened and closed lower, corporate and foreign loans irregularly higher; transactions, $11,844.300.

With the introduction of a bill in the State Senate this week to prohibit the use entirely of secondhand materials in the manufacture of bedding and upholstered furniture offered for sale, the Bedding Manufacturers Board of Trade, Inc., will push its drive for the adoption of the legislation.

A movement for a constitutional amendment calling for compulsory retirement of Supreme Court justices at 70 or 75 years of age as a substitute for President Roosevelt's judiciary reorganization program assumed definite proportions in the Senate Judiciary Committee today after Young B. Smith, dean of the Faculty of Law of Columbia University, had testified.

A further advance in the general level of wholesale prices in the week ended on March 20 was reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, rose to 87.6, compared with 87.2 in the preceding week, and 79.3 on March 21, 1936.

The preliminary annual report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries for 1936 shows net income of $4,009,103 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to 63 cents a share on 6,399,002 capital shares, compared with $2,553,013, or 40 cents a share, on the same, basis in 1935.
The Rev. Asygell W. Carrington, rector of Emmanuel Episcopal Church here for the last four years, died today following a two weeks' illness. He was 58 years old.

The Yale Gallery of Fine Arts has opened an exhibition of American genre painting and Victoriana. The paintings, which have been lent by Yale alumni, are typical of the vigorous tradition of representing humble scenes from everyday life which flourished in this country during the latter half of the nineteenth century.

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson today refused to order an investigation to determine whether mismanagement had been a cause for the financial reorganization petition of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company.
Purchase of thirty-one six-family apartment houses in Sunnyside, Astoria and Jackson Heights, Queens, was reported yesterday by the Norman Lila Estates, Inc., operators, headed by Samuel Horwitz.

The Senate received from Senator Thomas a bill to broaden the powers of the Federal Reserve Board over the value of the dollar; from Senator Nye a resolution to request from the State Department an opinion as to whether existing neutrality laws provide for embargoes against States cooperating in a civil war in another country;

Louis G. Hatzfeld, 27 years old, son of Louis E. Hatzfeld, New York broker, was cleared today of criminal responsibility for the death of Miss Valerie Angel, 21, of Saskatoon, Canada, by Dr. Amos 0. Squire, Westchester County Medical Examiner.
New York Stock Exchange membership of the late Michael F. Brady has been transferred to Edward Golden of Wagner, Scott Co.

A conference with legislative leaders of both parties to discuss basic changes in budgetary structure, as well as differences with the Republicans on the current budget, was set for Tuesday by Governor Lehman today.

D. C. Jackling, president of the Mesabi Iron Company, has written to stockholders that, while present conditions in the iron ore industry are better than those prevailing in 1924 when the company suspended operations, the directors feel that resumption of operations at the present time is not warranted and under existing conditions is, in fact, impossible.

Arturo Toscanini's seventieth birthday was warmly observed in Austria today. The Viennese press published eulogistic articles especially stressing the great conductor's musical activities during the last few years and his close connection with the Salzburg Festival.

Dates for the trial races to select a defender of the America's Cup, as well as those for the New York Yacht Club cruise, were announced last night at a meeting of the New York Yacht Club at 37 West Fortyfourth Street. Notices of both were given by Commodore W. A. W. Stewart, who also is chairman of the America's Cup committee.

Newspapers and other publications having second-class mailing privileges are prohibited under the Postal Laws from printing news items about lotteries even if the publications are not sent through forwarded to THE NEW YORK TIMES by Postmaster Albert Goldman yesterday.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Mor- defend genthau Jr. today invited bids for Treasury bills aggregating $100,000,000. The bills will be in two issues of $50,000,000 each, the first of seventy-nine-day maturity and the second of 273 days.

The personal wardrobe of the late Queen Alexandra, including her coronation gown, twenty dresses worn on State visits of royalty and many intimate items of fashion of the Victoria era, was shown privately yesterday by Samuel Soden, fashion designer of London, at his suite at the Hotel Astor.

The New York Curb Exchange, defending champion, prevented the New York Stock Exchange from capturing the Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League crown by topping the Brokers, 3-2, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
A total of 275,087,968 passengers traveled to and from New York City by railroad last year, according to a survey published yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

An early improvement yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange carried July above 14 cents a pound but the rise was halted by an increased supply of contracts which brought about a reaction and closed the list with losses of 3 to 8 points.

The House Rivers and Harbors Committee agreed today to include in the omnibus Rivers and Harbors Bill a $2,480,000 project for the improvement of New York Harbor. Representatives Francis D. Culkin of Oswego, N. Y., and Alfred F. Beiter of Williamsville, N. Y., are members of the committee.

The New York Rovers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 2, tonight in the first game of the Hershey Cup series, consolation play-off in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League. The Rovers scored all three of their goals before the Orioles tallied. Both Baltimore scores came in the last six minutes.

Concerning the problem of foreigners fighting in Spain, the French Government has departed from the relatively reserved attitude it hitherto has observed and, in conversations with the British and German Ambassadors, Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos has clearly defined the line he intends to follow.

William H. Martin, who held patents on the monoplane principle used in modern flying, died today. He was 82 years old. He developed a successful monoplane through glider models in the same period of the Wright biplanes. A model is in the Smithsonian Institution.

The sitdown army of 5,000 to 6,000 men paraded from eight Chrysler plants in a stinging blizzard here this afternoon, and tonight State troopers with the fan-shaped insignia of Michigan on their sleeves guarded the gates which were patrolled by strikers for eighteen days.
The world's first social credit premier tonight faces a complete deadlock in his party, and a crisis in his own career. First indication that Premier Aberhart might be backing down came yesterday,
Attorney General Cummings sent to the Senate today a 183-page volume, outlining thousands of suits which he said had been filed against Roosevelt administration laws since March 4, 1933.

Merger of the Parker-Wylie Carpet Manufacturing Company with the Alva Carpet and Rug Company, both of Philadelphia, was announced here yesterday. The organization will be known as the General Carpet Corporation, with A. G. Fromuth chairman of the board and W. G. Wylie president.

An immediate spur to the sale of private brands as the result of the resale price maintenance legislation now effective in twenty-seven States was reported yesterday by department store buyers of toilet goods and cosmetics at the monthly meeting of the toilet goods and cosmetic buyers' group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at Gimbel's Restaurant.
The threemonths' marriage of Julia Laird, actress, and John M. (Jack) Kirkland, playwright, ended in an uncontested divorce here today. The charge was mental cruelty.
The volume of business was small today as the stock markets prepared for the Easter holidays shut-down. Nevertheless, the tendency in most groups was firm.
Building plans submitted yesterday included a project for twentyfour six-story tenement houses in Sixty-fourth Avenue, Forest Hills. The houses will accommodate 864 families and will cost $3,000,000.

J. S. Mack, president of the G. C. Murphy Company, has advised holders of common stock that they will receive rights to subscribe at $60 a share to an additional 15,500 shares of common stock, on the basis of one new share for each thirty shares held, subject to a registration statement filed with the SEC on March 8.

Miss Ida Pleet, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Pleet, formerly of Baltimore, and sister of David H. Pleet of Merion, was married today to George E. Stone, Hollywood character actor and son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Stone of Paterson, N. J.

The control scheme for Spain which was to come into operation next Monday is now unlikely to be completed and working until a week later. This is due to technical delays in the appointment of personnel.
Objections by Chairman Black of the Senate Labor Committee today prevented immediate confirmation of President Roosevelt's five nominees for the Federal Maritime Commission.

Prices of hogs advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight here today to the highest levels in the last ten weeks, the extreme top being 10 cents higher than on Wednesday at $10.60, the highest price paid since Jan. 12 and only 20 cents under the best price since Sept. 15.
Mr. and Mrs. Claude Lazard gave a musical last night at their home, 8 East Eightieth Street. The Loewenguth Quartet was heard.

The four-department supply bill, carrying 1938 fiscal appropriations for the State, Justice, Commerce and Labor Departments, was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate. The measure, by amendments, was increased from $121,222,000 recommended by the Appropriations Committee, to $123,099,000.

SEVENTY-TWO years ago, on Good Friday of the year 1865, Abraham Lincoln was shot through the back of the head in Ford's Theatre, Washington, and died within nine hours. Why was he shot? Because a young actor, halfcrazed by the impending defeat of the South. sought a personal revenge?

Back on the scene of his major victory in his spectacular rookie season eight years ago, Horton Smith, Chicago professional, fired a sub-par 69 through whirling winds on the homestretch today to win the North and South open golf tournament again with a total of 286.

Miss Helen Keller, who is on her way to San Francisco, where she will embark Thursday on the Asama Maru for Japan, her first trip to the Orient, is carrying with her a message of good-will to the people of Japan from President Roosevelt, it was learned yesterday.

Frederick Beck Patterson of Dayton, Ohio, vice president of the National Cash Register Company, in Federal Court yesterday won his damage suit charging plagiarism of "Shooting Big Game With a Camera," an African jungle thriller he made in 1927 with the assistance of the present King of England.

Mrs. Audrey Wuppermann Brooks has completed plans for her marriage to William Melhuish Byam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy H. Byam of Yonkers, N. Y. The ceremony will take place at the home here of the bride-elect's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Edward Wuppermann, on April 9.

The first post-evacuation peace conference in the Chrysler strike was held at the State Capitol here tonight without any tangible results. The session, called by Governor Frank Murphy for 6 P. M. ended in less than two hours, to be resumed at 9 A. M. tomorrow.

Holders of record at the close of business on April 1 of Standard Gas and Electric Company certificates of deposit for twenty-year 6 per cent notes due in 1935 and for 6 per cent convertible notes due in 1935 will be paid the interest of 3 per cent due on Oct. 1, 1935, according to a notice received by the New York Curb Exchange.

President Roosevelt today told the farmers of the Pine Mountain Valley Resettlement Project that the future of the project and the resettlement program rested not with the Federal Government but with those whom it is benefiting.

Patrolman Thomas Gentles, 28 years old, of 409 East Thirty-fourth Street; Maurice Rue, 25, of 249 East Thirty-third Street, and John Levy of Miami, Fla., were convicted yesterday in Special Sessions of conspiracy and oppression.
NEWS OF METROPOLITAN REAL ESTATE DEALS

Bayonne night at the American Bowling Congress championships produced one of the feature performances in the tournament thus far when the Bayonne Wheelmen scored 2,947 at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory last night to move into second place in the five-man team standing.
Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, long - driving professional from Texas, and Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky.. will fight it out Saturday for the women's Augusta golf title in a pro-amateur final.

A hook and ladder truck of Engine Company 49, at 1,079 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, drove for more than a mile last night through upper Manhattan and the Bronx after the tiller-man had been knocked off its rear end in a collision with an unidentified automobile.

Ill tidings for Easter shoppers came from the Weather Bureau yesterday. There was a possibility of snow early this morning accompanied by a forecast of sharply dipping temperatures which may reach the 25-degree mark and hold it for some time.

The French liner Paris arrived yesterday nearly a day behind schedule because of rough weather and because she left her course last Tuesday to search for the sinking Norwegian freighter Bjerkli 500 miles east of Nantucket Lightship.

Entry blanks for the annual Class B metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships which will be held at Randalls Island on May 8 have been mailed to twenty-six colleges in the metropolitan area, it was announced yesterday by Louis R. Oshins, business manager of Brooklyn College, which annually sponsors the event.

Professor Albert Bessemans, former president of the University of Ghent and director of the Institute of Hygiene and Bacteriology in the same city, arrived last night on the Italian liner Saturnia to attend the first International Conference on Fever Therapy.
Louis C. Madeira 3d, executive director of the Anthracite Institute, opposed before the Interstate Commerce Commission today the railroads' application for increased freight rates.

Reversals of form featured the preliminary rounds in the metropolitan A. A. U. senior wrestling championship tournament at the New York Athletic Club last night. The competition, in which seventytwo grapplers went to the mat, will be concluded tonight with semi-final and final rounds.

After a long hearing yesterday on a motion to confirm a report of James G. Moore, special master, on the general plan for reorganization of the Prudence-Bonds Corporation Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn reserved decision.

Mrs. F. Rossiter's 5-year-old Marson, a gelding that earned $50 last year and failed to win a race in eight starts, easily defeated five other Class C sprinters in the Le Jeune Handicap of six furlongs today at Tropical Park.

Gains in cotton exports from Argentina during the first two months of the current year compared correspondingly with 1936 increased from 4,190 metric tons to 4,720, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Walstrom, Assistant United States Trade Commissioner at Buenos Aires, and made public today.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as co-trustee for Pacific Gas and Electric Company first and refunding mortgage 3 1/2 per cent, Series I bonds, due June 1, 1966, will be prepared to deliver definitive bonds in exchange for outstanding temporary bonds on and after April 1, 1937, it was announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Estelle Laura Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Shaw, to Arnold Michael Denby, son of Mrs. Frederick Glaser of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 500 West End Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum.

United States Government longterm bonds underwent another sinking spell yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, and, before the decline was arrested, numerous issues on the list had equalled their lows for the year, reflecting, atone time, extreme declines of 22-32 point.

Charging that the Manufacturers Trust Company had forced the Barclay-Arrow Holding Corporation into bankruptcy in 1931 by illegally taking the cream of its assets, the Irving Trust Company, as bankruptcy trustee, filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court to compel the Manufacturers Trust to make restitution. Cash and securities having a face value of more than $7,000,000 are involved.

An increase of $8,560,597 over the preceding week was shown in deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada during the week ended March 24, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today.

Some persons hard to please used to complain that JOHN DRINKWATER was too much of a highbrow. If he was he got it by a better education than Balliol could give. One envies the early advantages of a lad who had the luck to follow his schoolmaster-father turned actor through all the vicissitudes, hard knocks and fun of the "road." Life is a good show enough.

Andrew W. Mellon's dream of a great national art gallery for the United States has become an actuality. The White House today announced that President Roosevelt had signed the joint resolution permitting the government to accept Mr. Mellon's $65,000,000 gift.

Cooperation of all plant and selling executives in the development of new packages in order to prevent serious mistakes, was advocated yesterday at the closing sessions of the packaging conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

William E. Andrew, former city magistrate here, died this morning in Fitkin Memorial Hospital. He was 60 years old. Mr. Andrew practiced law in this city for more than twenty-five years and served as magistrate from 1933 to 1936, when he resigned.

The Travelers Aid Society of New York assisted 47,798 strangers and transients who met with difficulties in this city in 1936, according to figures issued yesterday by the society's executive secretary, Miss Virginia M. Murray.

The educational cornerstone of the United States Military Academy for more than a century has been the precept laid down by its honor system, declared Lieut. Col. Herman Beukema, Professor of History, Economics and Government at the academy, in a luncheon address yesterday at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.
More than seventy-five executives of forty railroads watched a snubnosed Diesel-electric locomotive double its capacity today in a process vaguely reminiscent of the reproduction of an ameba.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and subsidiary companies showed a net income of $3,226,132 after all charges, Including provision for Federal income taxes and $225,000 for undis come taxes and $225,000 for undistribute profits tax, according to the annual statement for the year ended on Jan. 31, to be made public today by Bernard F. Gimbel, president. In the preceding year the net income was $1,017,333.

Mayor La Guardia was astonished at City Hall yesterday when a 9-year-old girl emphatically declined the opportunity to pose for a photograph with him. Donald Carney, known as "Uncle Don" on the radio, brought the youngster, Doris Loshak of 1,902 Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn, to City Hall with Robert Klein, 10, of 3,395 Reservoir Road, the Bronx.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe said at a hearing yesterday that he would approve a contemplated plan for the reorganization of the Munson Steamship Line under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act and directed attorneys to submit a formal order embodying the action to be taken.

Governor Lehman signed today the Davidson bill authorizing five-sixths jury verdicts in civil cases. In 1935 the people of the State, in of referendum vote, approved a constitutional amendment to permit such verdicts but last year the enabling legislation was blocked.

Mayor Bangs was out of jail tonight for the first time in nearly nine months. 'This place has come to seem like home,' he said as he left the county jail, freed by an order of Special Judge Huber M. Devoss. "But I'll be mighty glad to spend a night at my real home again."

With the evacuation of the Chrysler plants, the issue at Detroit becomes the question of union recognition. That question has been posed in a way which makes it a matter of national interest. The company offers to recognize the union, in the future as in the past, as the accredited spokesman of its own members.

The Giants' winning streak of six straight exhibition games suddenly came to an end today when the Milwaukee Brewers, American Association pennant winners, made off with three runs in the last half of the ninth to trip up Bill Terry's National League champions, 4 to 3.

The fastflying Red Wings pulled within a game of their third successive National Hockey League championship tonight, defeating the Canadiens of Montreal, 5 to 2, for their second victory of the five-game play-off series.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Business again centered on specialties for the Easter trade. Smoked meats, poultry, kid goats and Spring lamb were generally active.

Within the last few weeks the Legislatures of New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts have emphatically rejected the proposed child labor amendment. Though the approval of at least eight States is still needed for ratification, only nine Legislatures can even act on the subject in their regular 1937 sessions.

Offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., of $3,150,000 of Indianapolis Union Railway Company refunding and improvement mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series F, dated March 1, 1936, and maturning on March 1, 1986.
The Galveston Anicos blasted the Tulsa Stenos' hopes for a fourth straight women's national A. A. U. basketball championship tonight, conquering the Oklahoma team, 23--13. in a semi-final game.

Indications that California's sons would bear the brunt of the United States Davis Cup burden in the opening round matches with Japan were given yesterday when Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant Jr. announced in Atlanta, Ga., that he would not seek a place on the team that meets the Nipponese.

Once more Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club heads the ranking list of the National Squash Tennis Association. The honor was bestowed on the sturdy holder of the national crown for the eighth year when the rankings were announced last night at the association's annual dinner at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
Business activity in New England continued its upward movement in February, the New England Council's index registering 111.8 as compared with 108.3 in January.

The Regional Plan Association, whose offices at 400 Madison Avenue are now found to lie on the northwesterly outskirts of the city, announced yesterday that its engineers have discovered, for the first time, that a certain back yard in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn is the geographical center of New York City.

Upsetting of a sailboat drowned Cleon Mosely of Clearwater and marooned three companions without food or water for thirty-six hours, J. L. Pippin, lighthouse keeper, said today. Rescued from a perch on Bird Rock, several miles off shore, were Lester Clark of Clearwater, Miss Irene Paris of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Madona M. Ferwick of Celina, Ohio.

Sailors and waterfront charactersloitered under the jibbooms of merchantmen projecting across South Street as young Mahlon Brewster Smith turned his back on that thoroughfare on his way to apply for a position in the Seamen's Bank for Savings seventy years ago.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today the Eastern Wine Corporation, Bronx Terminal Market,. had stipulated to the commission it would cease using labels or vintage strips which do not accurately and truthfully represent the age of wine.
Thirty thousand Boy Scouts will unite on a day early in July to do a single good deed for the day, and President Roosevelt will be the beneficiary.

In a four-to-one decision, the Appellate Division reversed yesterday a lower court ruling and granted a peremptory mandamus requiring the Emergency Relief Bureau to employ only persons with a civil service status except those taken from relief rolls.

A dozen leaders of the Committee for Industrial Organization and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers opened a campaign here today to organize the 55,000 to 60,000 up-State textile workers, making Rochester headquarters.
William Sacks, postal clerk who became a lawyer, oil operator, banker and prominent figure in Missouri Republican politics, died early, today d at Barnes Hospital. His age was 63.

Charles Looney, active for forty years in Masonic circles of New York City and State, died yesterday morning of pneumonia at the Park West Hospital, 170 West Seventy-sixth Street. His home was at 825 West End Avenue. He was 72 years old.

Oralargument in connection with the allegation of manipulative activities in the capital stock of A. O. Smith Corporation on the New York Curb by White, Weld Co. will be heard by the Securities and Exchange Commission on April 23, it was announced today.

Modern merchandising methods and their tie-up with accounting and other equipment was the theme yesterday at the beginning of the two-day session of the sales force of the National Cash Register Company at the Hotel Commodore.

Commodity futures were mixed in comparatively quiet trading yesterday. Coffee, rubber and zinc were higher, while moderate losses were made in raw silk and cocoa. In the cash market, wheat, corn, rye, oats, butter, eggs, lard, tin and rubber were higher, while coffee, cocoa and cotton were lower.

George Frederick Hallock, former newspaper editor and founder of this community's first newspaper, was found dead in the rear of a parking lot here this morning, the victim of a heart attack while on his way home last night. He was 80 years old.

Former President Herbert C. Hoovor is expected Monday as the guest of George F. Getz of Chicago on board the latter's yacht, Virago, for a fishing cruise of two weeks among the South Florida Keys. Others in the party will include Arthur M. Hyde, former Secretary of Agriculture in the Hoover Cabinet;

The question "Is a World System Possible?" brought varying answers last night from an English Labor peer, a Spanish internationalist and a former diplomat in the United States service, speaking on the Town Hall of the Air from the auditorium of Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

A gala entertainment and supper dance will be given in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night for the benefit of the Opportunity Shop, a mart at 46 West Forty-seventh Street which, through the resale of donated articles, contributes to the support of several philanthropic organizations.

Maurice Levin, philanthropist and president of Hearn's department store, has been selected to receive the plaque of the 1937 fine arts award of the Manischewitz Foundation, according to announcement yesterday by Dr. Israel Goldstein, chairman of the committee of awards.
Stockholders of the International Silver Company approved today the company's recapitalization plan by a vote of more than two-thirds of each class of stock.

The weekly newspaper Happy Days, published in the interest of the Civilian Conservation Corps personnel for several years, has no official status, CCC officials said today after receiving a request from the editor of Champion of Youth, a magazine, that Robert Fechner, CCC director, "repudiate" the paper.

A double bill consisting of "Le Coq d'Or" and "Pagliacci" was heard by another sold-out house at the Metropolitan last night. Both operas were given for the fifth time this season and each was enthusiastically received.
The champion Yankees to win, hard pressed by the Tigers, with Boston and Cleveland battling it out for third place!
A total of 111,909 young men and war veterans will be selected for replacement enrollment in the Civilian Conservation Corps immediately after April 1, Robert Fechner, director, said today.

Following physical tests given by the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday to fifteen firemen, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott said the new standards set by the commission were too high and should be modified in a number of particulars.

The New Jersey Industrial map was a checkered picture of peace and turmoil today as the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced a substantial pay increase and the first eviction of sit-down strikers occurred.

Joseph P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., has accepted the chairmanship of the realty division of the commerce and industry committee to solicit contributions for the Salvation Army, which will seek during April to raise a minimum of $600,000 for its services which are not self-supporting. The appeal will be launched with a pageant in the Memorial Auditorium, 120 W. 14th St., on the evening of April 6.

Dr. Charles E. Mackey, member and former chairman of the Boston School Committee; Alice Costa, 19, a nurse in Dr. Mackey's office, and her brother, Paul Costa, 21, employed in the Mackey household, were shot and killed in South Boston today by the physician's brother, Jeremiah Mackey, who then committed suicide.

The Socialist party, opening its convention here tonight, was told by Norman Thomas, its 1936 Presidential candidate, that "the gigantic strides taken by labor in industrial organization within the last few months" gave "great encouragement" to the party's aims.

Twentieth Century-Fox's new edition of "Seventh Heaven," which will be the Music Hall's Easter show, is not likely to cause any one to change his mind about remakes never being as good as their originals. It is a disappointing picture for a number of reasons, the first two being James Stewart and Simone Simon in the roles played by Charles Farrell and Janet Gaynor in the 1927 silent film.

James A. Emery, general counsel to the National Association of Manufacturers, denounced yesterday the proposals in the pending bill submitted by United States Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming for "the licensing of corporations in commerce," as a type of legislation that grants excessive power to the Federal Government over corporations chartered by the individual States.
A funeral service was held yesterday afternoon for Frederick William MacMonnies, American sculptor, at the Protestant Episcopal p Church of the Ascension, 36 Fifth Avenue.

A revalued dollar set at a level "which will serve the best interests and best promote the domestic economy of the people of the United States" would be established by law under a bill introduced in the Senate today by Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma and defended by him in a speech on the floor.

Engagement of $11,306,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought to $322,700,000 the total of gold obtained in London for American account since Sept. 26, 1936.

The Criminal Courts Building and the Tombs prison, the objects of caustic comments by grand juries for several years, were again condemned as unsafe and insanitary yesterday by the March New York County Grand Jury.

Louis Miller of Chester, N. S., for two years winner of the annual Bermuda amateur golf championship, was eliminated in the quarterfinals of the current tournament today, along with the surviving United States players.

Mrs. Mary Whittinghill and Mrs. Helen Kerfoot were on sitdown strike today, seeking new Easter outfits. The husbands, Russ Whittinghill and Lester Kerfoot, say their incomes as WPA workmen prevent the demanded outlay of money.
With a helping hand from Mayor La Guardia an agreement was reached yesterday afternoon to end the sit-down strike of employes of five of the F. W. Grand 5-and-10cent chain.

Buckingham Palace is changing cooks again. The campaign to restore good conditions in the royal household as much as possible to what they were during King George V's reign even extended to the kitchen today.
