The greatest collection of swimming celebrities assembled since last year's Olympics will start tomorrow in the two-day fourteenth annual national intercollegiate championships at the University of Minnesota.

The regular starting line-up of the champion Yankees today swung into action at Waterfront Park for the first time this year and performed like a smooth-moving machine just long enough to tumble the Bees.

Two hundred and fifty Deputies announced tonight the creation of a "FranceUnited States group." Deputy Max Hymans said that the group would do its best to "make Americans understand it is in their interest to obtain repeal of the Johnson act."

R. Wentworth Hicks, former vice president of Benson Hedges, tobacconists, died yesterday at his home here. He was 67 years old. Mr. Hicks held the vice presidency of the company from 1900, when he first came to this country, until his retirement from business in 1927.

Congress heard suggestions today that President Roosevelt speak out on the sit-down strikes, that Secretary Perkins be "more careful" not to "incite" them and that sitdown strikers be subjected to fines and imprisonment.

The Bronx County Trust Company sold to Morris Luskin the five-and-a-half-story walk-up on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1,362 Grand Concourse. Assessed at $135,000, the building contains 143 rooms laid out in forty apartments. It rents for $21,500 a year and was sold for cash over mortgages aggregating $134,000.
Contracts were awarded at the Army Quartermaster Depot today, under Invitation 227, on 600,000 pairs of denim work trousers for the Civilian Conservation Corps, including the following deliveries:
Fifty Italian sailors sacked the office of a Spanish newspaper and attacked the Spanish telegraph office here tonight. Four sailors were wounded.

The Senate Committee on Finance today reported a bill to make permanent the "hot oil law," which prohibits the shipment in interstate and foreign commerce of petroleum and petroleum products produced in violation of State law. The present law expires June 16.

Clarence A. Fallon, real estate broker and World War veteran, died of a heart attack today at his home here at the age of 46. Mr. Fallon was born in New Rochelle and was a member of a family long identified in city affairs. He was a brother of former Acting City Judge Richard Leo Fallon, now Democratic-city leader.

PRESENT INDICATIVE, by Noel Coward. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.) Mr. Coward's autobiography. TWILICHT OF A WORLD, by Franz Werfel. (Viking, $3.) Fiction, with the last days of the Austrian Empire supplying the setting

In spite of a rainy, generally unpleasant day, New Yorkers by the thousands began leaving the city last night to celebrate the Easter holidays. The exodus of those eager to spend the week-end in their Home towns or at out-of-town resorts is expected to continue today and tomorrow, with an estimated 500,000 New Yorkers in all departing from the metropolis.

Louis Morris Starr, former president of the Ridgefield Historical Society and the First National Bank and Trust Company of Ridgefield, Conn., left a net estate of $1,973,781, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

Asserting that it was extremely unlikely that Canada would ever send another expeditionary force to Europe or that Britain- herself would ever send an expeditionary force to the Continent of Europe, Premier Mackenzie King late tonight in the Canadian Commons caused members to pay close attention to his unheralded declaration of peace policy both for the country and the United Kingdom.

Yesterday's grist of overseas news showed every European capital freshly agitated by developments in the war over Spain. Another furious debate between Italian and Russian representatives on the non-intervention committee, followed by Italy's angry refusal to withdraw her "volunteers," goaded France to propose a complete naval blockade of the Spanish coasts and to threaten to appeal the whole case to the League of Nations.

James Keogh, 5 years old, one of seven children of Mr. and Mrs. John Keogh of 311 East 141st Street, the Bronx, a family on home relief, was killed last night by a hit-andrun automobile driver at Alexander Avenue and 140th Street.

Miss Frances Robbins, well known for the last seven years among the followers of horse shows on Long Island, died this afternoon of pneumonia in Southampton Hospital here. Miss Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pelham Robbins of 19 East Eightieth Street, New York, was at her parents' Summer estate here when she became ill a few days ago.

A new rowing snen named in honor of former United States Senator Gccrge Wharton Pepper was launched on the Schuylkill River today and then used by the University of Pennsylvania varsity crew in its daily workout.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were 28.2 per cent above the corresponding week last year. The total for the principal cities throughout the nation was $6,889,833,000, compared to $5,372,442,000 in 1936, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The gain in a similar comparison a week earlier was 2.1 per cent.

Miss Josephine Meany, daughter of Postmaster and Mrs. William S. Meany of Greenwich and sister of Miss Helen Meany, former Olympic champion diver, will be married to Harris Grant Nelson of Minnesota in Shanghai next month.

Members of the Hospital Workers Union, Local 171, who conducted two sit-down strikes in the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital last week, renewed their labor quarrel with hospital officials yesterday morning when union employes in the institution's laundry staged a surprise walkout.

Dr. Harold Saft Olcott, 27-yearold research associate in the University of Iowa, has been chosen by a committee of the American Chemical Society to receive the second Eli Lilly Co. Award in biological chemistry, it was announced yesterday by the society.
Easter music in the form of oratorios, cantatas, carols and instrumental selections will be a feature of the services tomorrow in ?? city's churches. The programs ?? include:
Sixteen shipwrecked mariners landed here in safety today because a youthful skipper of a little old Norwegian tramp ship spent hours off watch learning something about radio.
Scholarship awards were made at the end of the Spring term at Williston Academy to those boys who have been steadily on the honor roll. Part are purely honor scholarships without stipend.
Dr. William A. Martin, literary editor of The Buffalo Evening News, died today of injuries suffered last week when he was struck by an automobile. His age was 52.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company applied to the Supreme Court yesterday for permission to sell the Hotel St. Andrew, Broadway and Seventy-second Street, which it holds as trustee under the will of Morris Schinasi.

The International Conference on Fever Therapy, scheduled to start here Monday and continue for three days and which will be attended by more than 200 physicians from twenty-nine nations, was informed yesterday that the German delegation would be unable to attend for "technical reasons."

An advisory committee consisting of Richard M. Russell of Warren, Garfield, Whiteside Lamson, William H. Davis of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Harold Williams, lawyer, has been formed for holders of insured first-mortgage certificates of the Conveyancers Title Insurance and Mortgage Company, it was announced yesterday.
The public is about to get its first glimpse of the Paige pastels from the second Byrd Antarctic expedition, depicting the wonders of the South Polar sky.

The Delta Tau Delta fraternity was the winner of the recent interfraternity play contest of Dartmouth College. The prize of $50 as well as the Mary Gile Cup was presented by Alfred E. Reinman Jr., president of the Dartmouth Players.

The sit-down strike of nineteen employes in the plant of the Etched Products Corporation, 39-01 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, ended at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when half a dozen strong-armamen herded the strikers out of the it building in the presence of high police officials who refused to interfere.

Trinity Church was filled to capacity yesterday afternoon during the three-hour Good Friday service. The police were kept busy handling the large crowd of worshipers as they came and went from the church.

There at prices that is much pessimism in political circles over the situation which has arisen as a result of the refusal of the Governors of Madras, Bombay, the United Provinces and Biharthe States in which the Congress party obtained a majority-to "barter their obligations" under the new Constitution in return for the cooperation of the Congress party.

Receipts of hogs today were somewhat in excess of trade expectations and, with a slow shipping demand, prices generally declined here 5 to 15 cents with the practical top of $10.50 a hundredweight showing 10 cents under the best level on Thursday.

Astor Av., s w cor Lodovick AV., 2 1/2-soury brick veneer dwelling, 36x26; Harsan Construction Corp., 3,190 Westchester Av., owner; R. J. Marx, architect; cost, $12,000. Manhattan Alterations 25th St., 137-139 W.; to 12-story library; Frank J. Taylor, Controller, City of New York. owner; R. Glucroft, architect; cost, $10,000.

New bond financing this week was composed wholly of State and municipal loans for the first time since the week ended on Nov. 6, last year. Seven new tax-exempt issues were placed on the market, aggregating $20,382,000.

A demand for American iron and steel products has developed in Lithuania owing to delays in deliveries from Belgium and the United Kingdom, Vice Consul Basil F. McGowan has reported to the Department of Commerce.

Through some unaccountable oversight, Universal omitted the kitchen sink, but it tossed practically everything else it could find into its new musical colossus, "Top of the Town," which an overburdened Easter rabbit left at the Roxy yesterday.
An Easter egg decorated in the Ephrata Cloisters 161 years ago was displayed today by the Lancaster County Historical Society.

" Brook trout are biting," the announcement read. At first glance it did not seem true. April 3 was still opening day for New York State and Connecticut, and New Jersey trout anglers would not set out until April 15. Then, on second glance, we noted the address of the Maine Development Commission, Augusta, Me., in an upper corner of the letter.
The Rev. Dr. Fred Elmer Marble, Baptist clergyman and author, died here last night. Hi age was 75.

FIRST RACE--Purse $500: claiming; 3year-olds and upward; six furlongs. Scrip Money, 107(Cornay) 3.50 2.60 2.50 Crowned H.,117(Manifold) .... 3.50 3.30 M. Greenock, 107(Roberts) ........ 3.60 Time--l:16. Scrambola, Elect Jessie, Mullet, Beau Charlie, Scholar Girl, Amite, *Whisk K., Jessie P. and *Bright Vale also ran. *Field.

A capacity gathering of more than 16,000 will attend -tonight's premiere showing of the international charity figure skating carnival at Madison Square Garden. Slated to be presented Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of next week as well, spectators will witness one of the most elaborate ice shows of its kind when the skating begins this evening at 8:30 o'clock.

Dr. DUMAS MALONE, who was associated with Dr. ALLEN JOHNSON in the selection of 13,500 names to be included in the Dictionary of American Biography, a monumental work published under the auspices of the Council of Learned Societies, has set himself the exercise (or game) of naming the forty greatest Americans in history.

The Senators extended their winning streak- of exhibition games to a string of seven today by defeating the Tigers, 6--4. After five scoreless innings they sent across two runs in the seventh. A freak hop of a ground ball from Bluege's bat contributed two of the three tallies scored in the eighth, which decided the game.
Good Friday saw many visitors from all parts of the country at the Greenbrier, with more to arrive tomorrow for the Easter week-end.
Two thousand armament workers, engaged on the British Government's $7,500,000,000 defense program, threatened today to go on strike unless they received a 2-cents-anhour wage increase.

Stephen Di Rosa, a detective with an excellent record, was named yesterday as the man who gave information obtained in Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's office to Abraham Cohen, one of seven convicted in the restaurant racket case.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Fullan of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, gave a dinner in the Persian Room of the Plaza last night at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amelia Scott Fullan, to William F. Mohan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Mohan of Bellaire, Queens.

Captain Charles R. Morrison of the 245th Coast Artillery, New York National Guard, charged with conspiracy to defraud the government by presenting false vouchers for services and supplies for the regiment, was placed on trial yesterday in the Federal court, Brooklyn, before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz and a jury.

Increased participation by the laity in the Catholic church's efforts to help youth was urged by the Rev. Dr. Edward Roberts Moore, director of the Division of Social Action of Catholic Charities, in the annual report of his division made public yesterday.

ARMY-D. Walker Thackeray, Maurice Taber. W. Henry Lewis. C. C. N. Y.-Sidney Kaplan, John Sieck, Bernard Marks. COLUMBIA-Bruce M. Wallis, Francis E. Drake Jr., Leo S. Wise. CORNELL--George Detmold, Robert Shaw, Roy Steyer. HAMILTON--William B. Clark, Addison Wardwell, J. S. Fullerton. HARVARD-Edward S. Skinner, James L. Cahn, Joseph T. Doyle. M. I. T.-Leo R. Dantona, Jerome Salny, Emil Mallick.

Miss Mina Curtiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard C. Curtiss of Darien, will be married to C. Frederic Underwood, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence F. Underwood of Stamford, on April 17 in the First Presbyterian Church here, by the Rev. Dr. George Stewart. A reception will be held at Mr. Underwood's home at Shippan Point.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 20 amounted to 759,269 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,276 cars, or 1.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 190,418 cars, or 33.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 152,091 cars, or 25 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Although vagaries of the weather caused retail sales to run somewhat under expectations, Easter trade in this city picked up vigorously during the last few days and gains for this month are likely to range from 9 to 15 per cent over 1936, store executives here reported yesterday.
Easter music will be heard in the churches of Brooklyn and Queens at all services on Sunday. The programs include vocal and instrumental compositions on the theme of the Resurrection.

Two railroad brotherhoods today started a strike vote of 8,000 Southern Pacific Company enginemen, trainmen and yard men employed on the company's Pacific lines embracing territory from Portland, Ore., to Dawson, N. M., and including the Northwestern Pacific Railroad and the former El Paso and Southwestern system.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is more wool moving both in the spot market and in the West. Demand here is keenest for Australian merinos and to a lesser extent for crossbred wools. Prices have ruled firm.

The Right Rev. Robert Lewis Paddock, retired Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Eastern Oregon, was named principal beneficiary in the will of his wife. Mrs. Jean Aitken Paddock, who died at her home, 400 East Fifty-ninth Street, Jan. 31. Her will was filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday.

Edgar T. Appleby, a Class A entrant, defeated Edward S. Knapp Sr., 200 to 109, in 40 innings in the Poggenburg Cup 18.2 balkline tournament at the Lawler Manhattan academy last night. A high run of 70 aided the victor. Anthony La Via, a Class B player, vanquished Carl Graff, 175 to 82, in 26 frames, and Philip Meise, Class C, scored over Lucien Collart, 125 to 67, in 33 innings.
An original Whistler etching, stolen from Oregon State College, was recovered today on the campus where it had been abandoned by the thief.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad reported today that it operated last month with a deficit of $342,329, against one of $132,762 in February, 1936, which had one more day. Gross revenues were $6,314,475, a decrease of $3,515 compared with February, last year.

A certified copy of the order of the Supreme Court in the Bronx, declaring the Economy Credit Union of New York dissolved and its corporate existence ended, has been filed with the State Banking Department, it was announced today.

Sound of the tom-toms rose today in many a Yaqui Indian village as frenzied natives began their annual Easter "dance of death." This fantastic finale to the half pagan, half Christian rites will end only when participants drop from exhaustion as dawn breaks over the bleak hills of Lower Arizona and Northern Sonora, Mexico, Sunday.

Experiments in metal mining for the improvement of underground working conditions affecting the health of miners will be conducted by the Bureau of Mines in a research tunnel established on the government reservation at Mount Weather, Va.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated, March 24: CAPTAIN Davis, R. G., Medical Corps, Washington, D. C., to Naval Air Station, Pensacola, Fla. COMMANDERS Boone, H. R., Medical Corps, the Lexington, to Naval Hospital, Puget Sound, Washington in June.

All is not well in New Hampshire. At least there is a suspicion that all is not well with the most famous personage in the State. The Old Man of the Mountain, the Profile, is thought to be shaky. Mr. HAWTHORNE'S Great Stone Face needs to be saved. The Manchester Union says that one of the Franconia Selectmen is asking the State Forestry Department to investigate the Old Man's debility or want of stability.

Consolidation of all factions in Tammany and the nomination of Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins for Mayor as a candidate upon whom all Democrats could unite were suggested yesterday by John A. Hogan.
The most important question to come up at the Little Entente meeting here on April 1 will be that of an enormous enlargement of the scope of the military clauses of the entente pact.
A wave of anti-Semitic agitation, accompanied by bombings that caused considerable property damages, swept over strike-beset Poland today.

Mrs. Mary Pinkerton Carlisle, wife of Jay F. Carlisle and daughter of the founder of Pinkerton's National Detective Agency, died yesterday of pneumonia in New York Hospital. Mr. and Mrs. Carlisle had their town residence in the Waldorf Towers.
The North Carolina tennis team opened its season today by blanking Yale, 10 to 0. The Tar Heels took every set of seven singles and three doubles matches. The summaries:

Although the principal security and commodity markets of the world were closed yesterday, the foreign exchange market was in operation here. The volume of trading, however, was extremely small. Banks in this country were open for business as usual, but bank holidays were observed in Europe.

Prison sentences piled up to an even dozen for convicted Kansas City vote thieves today when Federal Judge Albert L. Reeves sentenced two Democratic precinct captains to three years each in Leavenworth Penitentiary.

The recent. action of the Illinois State Senate in voting to limit the price of boxing tickets to a maximum of $10 is the latest obstacle to arise in the path of the successful promotion of a world heavyweight championship bout between James J. Braddock and Joe Louis in Chicago on June 22.

The world champion Yanks today avenged the defeat they suffered last Monday at the hands of the Newark Bears, but it was a tight squeeze. By the margin of 4 to 2 Colonel Jake Ruppert's varsity thrust back the freshmen to hang up their ninth conquest in twelve Florida games.
The steel situation is causing serious difficulties for Japanese manufacturers, and naval and military headquarters are watching the effects of their programs with rising anxiety.

Orders for structural steel in February amounted to 88,946 tons, compared with 140,943 in February, last year, according to the American Institute of Steel Construction. Bookings in January were 130,651 tons, against 120,364 in January, 1936.

Vassar College has brought the subject of family life out of the midnight "gab-fest" into a lecture hall with the result, one young woman said today, "that there is less chitter-chatter about sex among the students."

A warning that the "integrity and efficiency" of New. York City's schools are threatened by five educational bills now being "rushed" through the Legislature for political purposes was made yesterday by the Public Education Association.

Thirty small, unoccupied bungalows at Plumb Beach, in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, in the colony which has been taken over by the city for the development of Marine Park, were destroyed by fire yesterday. Engine Company 246 was marooned there because of the high tide.
Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Edith Quier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Addams Quier of Reading, Pa., to Dr. Harrison Fitzgerald Flippin of Philadelphia.

A field of nine of the best jumpers now in training will face the starter tomorrow in the eighth running of the Carolina Cup Steeplechase over the beautiful Springdale course, and it is expected that 20,000 persons drawn here from practically every State east of the Mississippi will witness the race.

Member trading in round lots for own account and the percentage of total volume represented by member trading fell off on both the New York Stock and New York Curb Exchanges in the week ended on Feb. 27,

Representative ALFRED N. PHILIPS Jr. of Connecticut, who has been making Congress hum since he joined up, has a plan to save America from poisonous reptiles by stuffing forthwith all those now impounded in zoos,

William Madison McDonald, a 70year-old Negro politician and banker, told from a witness stand today the story of why Colonel E. H. R. Green took his fortune into politics as a Republican leader in Texas.

The Erie and the Chesapeake Ohio railways will buy 1,000 box cars each, according to Iron Age. The Seaboard Air Line is expected to buy from 500 to 1,000 box cars. The Pacific Fruit Express Company will buy 500 refrigerator cars. The Lehigh New England is inquiring for 100 gondola cars.
Chicago's taxicab strike which engaged most of the 5,500 drivers in the city, ended at 9:30 o'clock tonight when a peace agreement was signed at the City Hall by company executives and union leaders.
One diamond wedding and thirteen golden weddings will be celebrated here Monday. Jean-Baptiste Lebas, Minister of Public Works, will preside at the annual ceremony in the local church.

Wrestlers from the New York Athletic Club gained four of the individual titles as well as the team honors in the senior metropolitan A. A. U. wrestling championships last night at the Winged Foot gymnasium as a former champion regained his laurels and two of last year's leaders retained their honors.
The Western Corn Belt needs a bumper crop this Fall, government farm experts said today, if the area is to regain its place as principal producer of hogs and important feeder of cattle.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Cotton mill activity continued unchanged last week at a period when a slight rise is seasonal, and the adjusted index declined one-half point to 139.4 from 139.9 in the preceding week. A year ago the figure was 100.5.

The holidays have brought many visitors. Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. White of New York arrived this morning at their cottage. Mr. and Mrs. C. Joseph Dexter of Philadelphia, accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Peace Smith, James M. Patterson and Mr. and Mrs. S. Ashton Douder, are occupying a cottage.

Stratford Av. (14.-3744), e. s., 716 ft. s. of Westchester Av., 100x100; Julia Lorber to Ezra Holding Corp., 152 W. 42d ST.; mtg., $93,000. Trinity Av. (10-2639), e. s., 420 ft. s. of 165th St., 50x100; Rodehau Holding Corp. to Johann Schmitt, 960 Sherman Av.; mtg., $32,000.

A disquisition upon Wagner's "Parsifal," given its single performance of the season yesterday, on Good Friday afternoon, in the Metropolitan Opera House, and a consideration of the public response to this unique music drama, might properly begin with the observance of the sovereign facts that while creeds and philosophies are subjects of hot dispute, the religious spirit of man is indestructible, and must, in one form or another, find expression.

Certificates for safe airline operation will be awarded, it was ascertained yesterday, to domestic operators in three categories at a dinner to be given by the National Safety Council at the Hotel Astor on April 14.

League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "This Changing World," Dorothy Thompson. Columbia University Club Forum on Public Affairs, 4 West Forty-third Street, 12:45 P. M. Address by Dr. Lin Yutang.

Dwellings and apartment houses in scattered sections of Manhattan and the Bronx changed hands in mild realty activity yesterday. The five-story apartment house at 79 Baxter Street was sold by Bridget L. Patton and Sarah E. Hanan to Herbert Baum, who has filed plans for altering the building. E. H.

An analysis of official and press reports from Europe has contributed to a feeling of optimism here against the imminent danger of a European war growing out of the recent defeat of the Italians in the Spanish Civil War by the Loyalist forces.

The final scores for the National Hockey League's marksmen were posted tonight by league officials. For the second consecutive season Dave (Sweeney) Schriner of the New York Americans led the field, scoring 21 goals and making 25 assists for a point total of 46.

Bright and Early, carrying the colors of R. Robertson, nosed out the Motor City Stable's well-liked Appealing in the Ted Baily Handicap at Oaklawn Park today. G. Watts's Panic Relief, which set the early pace over the Oaklawn course of a little less than six furlongs, finished third in a close stretch battle.
Henry M., 3-year-old gelding from the stable of Louis de La Tour, chalked up his first victory of the year today in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

William F. Marshall, former assistant cashier at the Kingsboro National Bank, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday in the Federal court to embezzling $21,420 from the institution.

Police Sergeant James Coppinger late today reported that 26-year-old Kenneth M. Robinson had "confessed" setting "more than thirty fires in Lynn" that did damage he estimated at "hundreds of thousands of dollars."

A small but smoky fire was discovered late last night on the fourth floor of St. Catherine's High School and Convent, 1,075 Madison Avenue between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets. Few of the 180 nuns in the building were aware of the fire, which was extinguished in ten minutes.
State patrolmen today turned back about 300 pickets who sought to stage a demonstration around an Auburn shoe factory, one of nineteen plants in which John L. Lewis's C. I. O. has called a strike.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe refused yesterday to dismiss a proceeding aimed at seizure of $150,000 worth of furniture and art objects to satisfy a judgment against the late Harris Hammond, son of John Hays Hammond, mining engineer and inventor, who also is deceased.

ARNOLD, PEARL (March 12). Estate more than $10,000. To Madeleine ?? Stoermer, daughter, executrix, 160 Centre Park S., household, personal effects are residue; three others receive specific by quests. Leon Vogel, 370 Riverside Dr.?? and Bankers Trust Co., 16 Wall St., executors.
Mr. and Mrs. Elias Sunstein of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Sunstein, to Theodore Woodrow Kheel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kheel of this city.

The Nebraska unicameral Legislature today rejected ratification of the proposed child labor amendment and threw supporters of the amendment here into deep gloom. Even the most ardent backers of the proposal conceded that it was highly improbable that it would be written into the Constitution this year.

Senator Key Pittman revealed today a "new policy" of predetermining the fitness of candidates for appointment to high Federal positions in Nevada, and said he had referred the names of fifteen applicants for the post of United States marshal to the Attorney General for investigation.

Wilfred J. Funk, editor of The Literary Digest, has just compiled a list of what he considers the ten most overworked words. Previously Mr. Funk caused a furor with his lists of the ten most beautiful words and the ten masters of American jargon.
Albert J. Leo, president, treasurer and director of the American Petrometal Corporation, a steel concern of Long Island City and 38 West Forty-second Street, died yesterday of heart disease.
The credit of the Madrid government increased considerably today when it was learned that following the protest made by London acceptance houses overdue Spanish bills for [Pound]20,000 had been paid.

An editorial criticizing Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York City for his attempt to renew his Congressional investigation into Nazi and Communist propaganda in this country appears in the current issue of The American Hebrew, out yesterday.

Representatives of Canada's two major railroads and the railroad unions agreed today to resume direct wage negotiations, breaking a deadlock which ended talks Wednesday. They will confer tomorrow morning in Montreal, Norman Rogers, Labor Minister, announced.
The Treasury, which is seeking greater protection for its silver hoard, disclosed today that it intends to build a squat steel and concrete depository near the West Point Military Academy.
Thousands of Filipino "flagellentes" flogged and tortured themselves today in villages throughout the Philippines in their traditional fanatical observance of Good Friday.

Brokers' reports of commercial leasing yesterday were featured by a number of contracts for office space. The list follows: Dr. Alex Chessin, Pierre M. Clear, Jerry S. Glaubman. Frank L. Dimmock. Morsan Co., Inc. Port-O-Phone Corp., Harry C. Smith Agency, Inc. Thoder Realty Co., in 7 E. 42d St.; Irving O. Freedman, George S. Kebabian, Jean Scott, Herbert A. Sherman, in 10 E. 43d St.; Thomas J. O'Reilly broker.

Lieutenant Daniel C. Doubleday of Wright Field, Air Corps radio expert, brought a new-type army attack ship safely to earth on one wheel late today after trying for nearly two hours to free a recalcitrant landing-gear.

Seymour Magoon, 28 years old, a lieutenant of Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein, was held without bail for hearing March 30 on a charge of homicide when arraigned before Magistrate Anthony Savarese in the Queens Felony Court yesterday.

The People's party of New York, composed of "old guard" Socialists who supported the ticket of the American Labor party last year, will hold a State convention today and tomorrow in the Debs Auditorium, People's House, 7 East Fifteenth Street, - Herbert M. Morrill, its secretary, announced yesterday.

The War Department issued the following orders today. dated March 25: COLONELS Myers, D. S., General Staff Corps, 10 days' leave, about March 26. Mason, C. W., Infantry, to retirement. Seone, C. A., Signal Corps, Baltimore, Md., to headquarters, Atlanta, Ga., June 30. Van Horn, J. H, Signal Corps, Atlanta, Ga, to headquarters, Boston, Mass., June 30.

The marriage of Miss Oenia Janith Payne, niece of Mrs. William M. K. Olcott of Great Neck and Quogue, L. I., to George Goodnow Bradley, son of Mrs. Mark S. Bradley of Bloomfield, Conn., and the late Dr. Bradley, took place here late yesterday afternoon in the West End Collegiate Church.
Governor Lehman signed today the Reoux bill removing jurisdiction in actions for damages for breach of promise to marry from the New York City Court.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick McEwan of this city and Convent, N. J., have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Helen Vreeland McEwan, to Lewin B. Barringer of Philadelphia, which will take place on April 17 in St. Peter's Church, Morristown, N. J.

After the Saar plebiscite in January, 1935, several thousand of the inhabitants who had worked actively against the return of the territory to Germany fled across the border into France. About a thousand men, women and children found temporary refuge in a disused barracks-built by the Germans-on the outskirts of the near-by city of Strasbourg.

Senator Schwellenbach announced today that he would introduce on Monday a resolution asking the Supreme Court to adopt a rule giving Congress the right to ask for advisory opinions whenever it thought pending legislation so warranted.
William C. Chanler, First Assistant Corporation Counsel, 'said yesterday that the city was now ready to appeal from the decision holding the proportional representation system of voting illegal.

The editor of the magazine Champion of Youth wrote a letter yesterday to Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, in a renewed effort to remove the "official standing" of the weekly newspaper Happy Days, published in the interest of the CCC personnel, it was announced in the office of the magazine, 2 East Twentythird Street.

Mrs. Kate Havens Bissell Lockwood, a member of distinguished old American families, died on Thursday night at her home, 863 Park Avenue, after a brief illness. Mrs. Lockwood was the widow of Le Grand Lockwood Jr., banker. Her age was 92.

New Yorkers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian motorship Saturnia include Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Colin, Mrs. George B. Francis, Mrs. Landon Marvin, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hottinger, Mrs. H. H. Sherwin, Mrs. Agnes B. Slater, Mr. and Mrs. David H. Taylor, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur West, Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Hill, Miss Frances Williams, Morton S. Davis and Dr. Ernest Wagner.
Contracts on large quantities of textile supplies for the Army and Civilian Conservation Corps were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot here today. They were as follows:
Dr. Jose Robles, Associate Professor of Romance Languages at the Johns Hopkins University, is being held incommunicado in a Valencia (Spain) jail, according to advices reaching here today.

The music at the Easter services in Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, of which the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie is the rector, will be sung by the church's choir of twenty-six boys and twelve men. Ernest Mitchell is the organist and choirmaster.

The social forces that caused Christ's death were the same forces that are at work today, dedared the Rev. Dr. Francis J. McConnell, Bishop of the New York area, in the Good Friday sermon at the Old John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 44 John Street.
The New York Hippodrome Opera Company yesterday announced a change of date for its production of Verdi's "Aida" at Madison Square Garden. The performance will be given on Friday evening, April 2.

A law to put a "little of the 'fear of God' " into fly-by-night employers who default on their. payrolls is urged by Harrison Tweed, president of the Legal Aid Society of New York, in the society's sixty-first annual report, made public yesterday.
An Increase of 5 per cent on hourly and piece work pay for nearly 3,000 employes of the L. C. Smith and Corona Typewriters, Inc., effective Monday, was announced today by Hurlbut W. Smith president.

The police of the Alexander Avenue Station took up a collection yesterday and completed plans for the burial of 5-year-old James Keogh of 313 East 141st Street who was killed Thursday by a hit-run driver on Alexander Avenue near 139th Street.

This has been a sad Good Friday here, but at least it was one of the most peaceful days since the siege started nearly five months ago. General Francisco Franco's artillery did not shell the city nor did his planes come over as on Christmas, New Year's and Epiphany.

Flashing blades of New York University swordsmen carved their way to the threshold of three championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association yesterday as the forty-fourth annual tournament started at the Hotel Commodore. The Violet duelists, in the process of winning forty-three bouts with three weapons, performed the practically unprecedented feat of taking thirty-two of their thirty-six foils and epee contests.
Mrs. Louise Taylor Sherlock, widow of Charles Reginald Sherlock, former vice president of the United Cigar Stores Company, died at her home here last night after a brief illness.

Arsenal O, Stoke City 0. Bolton Wanderers 1, Sheffield Wednesday 0. Brentford 1, Preston North End 1. Chelsea 3. Charlton Athletic 0. Grimsby Town 1, Portsmouth 0. Liverpool O, Manchester City 5. Manchester United 2, everton 1. Middlesbrough 3. Birmingham 1. Sunderland 6. Wolverhampton Wanderers 2.

Declaring in an opinion today that "the ox wagon age has passed and is forever gone," Kentucky's Court of Appeals, highest tribunal of the commonwealth, called for a broader interpretation of the Federal and State Constitutions.
They will be making another attempt this evening to open "Driftwood," the Samuel J. Park melodrama that so far has rolled up a total of seven postponements.
The general public is going to have to stutter a while longer in pronouncing "hors d'oeuvres."
Eleven Turkish Army officers with their wives and children passed through here today en route to Kabul to start long-term engagements as instructors in the Afghan Army.

Educational Pictures, Inc., New York City, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 150,000 shares of 60cent-dividend $5-par-value cumulative convertible preferred stock and 499,729 shares of $1-par-value common stock.

There is perhaps nothing like a rainy afternoon to toss one into a reflective mood, and as it poured right merrily all over this gulf country today, Colonel Bill Terry, boss of the Giants, proved himself no exception. In fact, not only did he become reflective but he was strangely communicative, a quality in which he rarely tries to excel.

With Lieutenant Warren Wentzel scoring fifteen goals, the 112th Field' Artillery polo team defeated Squadron C of New York tonight, 21 1/2-11 1/2. The winners overcame the New Yorkers' three-goal handicap in the first period and lengthened their lead in succeeding periods.
The Little Rock (Ark.) Flyers won the women's national A. A. U. basketball championship by defeating the heavily favored Galveston (Texas) Anicos, 17-10, tonight.
Dr. and Mrs. Reginald Burbank will give a dance for their debutante daughter, Miss Marion Burbank, on April 3 at their home, 6 East Seventy-eighth Street.

The largest crowd to worship there in the last ten years, more than 20,000 persons all told, participated in Good Friday services yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. From early morning until late last night the cathedral was thronged.

Production of pig iron and ferroalloys in the United States last year amounted to 31,029,187 tons, compared with 21,372,699 in 1935 and 16,138,573 in 1934, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Production in the last half of 1936 amounted to 17,277,055 tons, while that in the first six months was 13,752,132 tons.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens announced yesterday after a luncheon conference at the Downtown Athletic Club with property owners along the Queens-Nassau boundary that he would advocate the change in the boundary asked by the owners.
The membership of the board of directors of the New York World's Fair of 1939 was increased to forty-six, with the addition of thirteen new members at the regular monthly meeting of the board in the

The "brief but tragic experience of the United States in operating air mail services with government planes" was advanced by Transport Minister Howe in the Canadian Commons last night as the chief reason against the Canadian Government operating the new trans-Canada air service.

While the unseasonal weather has held down sales of men's clothing at retail, store executives yesterday predicted a substantial improvement in volume on Spring styles during April. Most stores have been showing the new ranges for only about two weeks. Because of the weather, which retarded topcoat sales particularly, the higher prices asked on Spring styles have not been thoroughly tested as yet, store officials declared.
A military court of inquiry reported preliminary findings today on the New London Community School explosion which killed 455 March 18.

Rugby in the metropolitan section was ushered in for 1937 last week at Randalls Island. Thus, it seems appropriate to answer those who often ask, "What is rugby all about, anyway?" The game of rugby is perhaps the least advertised, least commercial, the most strictly amateur and, of amateur games, the most internationally widespread in the. world. It is one of the few remaining games standing at the frontier of amateurism.

Fees received by referees and special guardians appointed by the Surrogate's Courts and the New York County Supreme Court are not exempt from Federal taxation as income, Federal Judge John C. Knox decided yesterday, rejecting a claim for rebates of more than $12,000 made by John Godfrey Saxe, attorney, of 102 Maiden Lane, in a suit against the Collector of Internal Revenue.

Official British sources said today that the refusal of the Spanish Government at Valencia to permit interference with its shipping would not affect the four-power naval neutrality patrol because the patrol does not have jurisdiction over government or Insurgent shipping.

High-scoring performances by keglers from Bayonne, N. J., Hartford, Conn., and Lansing, Mich., brought revisions yesterday among the tourney leaders in three divisions of the American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

The final surge of Easter shopping this week carried retail sales to a new high for the year, although volume was under the estimates set for the period, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Actual shipment of 100,000 bushels of wheat from the Pacific Coast, marking re-entry of the United States into the world wheat export trade, was reported today by the Farmers National Grain Corporation. The first business of this kind since last Fall, the wheat shipment was destined for Rotterdam. The transaction was made through brokers in London.

Mrs. Nevada Davis Hitchcock, a well-known pioneer newspaper woman, died suddenly here at her home, 111 Main Street, today after several weeks' illness that began with influenza. Her age was 73. Funeral services will be held on Sunday at 3 P. M.

The split between the American Federation of Labor and John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organizastion emerged tonight as a prime issue before the Socialist party's special convention, which opened today.

Yesterday's debate in the British House of Commons, in the course of which some very harsh things were said about Italy, has caused a new wave of resentment and indignation to sweep over the whole Italian peninsula.
A sudden strike of produce handlers here threatened tonight to cause a shortage of green vegetables and fresh fruits for the Easter market in western New York.
Dr. Solomon R. Halley died yesterday morning at St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street, after an operation. Dr. Halley, who was 64 years old, lived at 71-19 Loubet Street, Forest Hills.

Sixty thousand Mexican school children went on strike today in sympathy with 800 students of the government charity school, who demand self-government. The charity students contend there is no such thing as "charity" in Mexico and demand the right to organize and run the school.

Most of the reliable indexes show that industrial production and trade are still below normal, despite the fact that when it is taken into account that the population of the country has increased about 5 per cent since 1929 the demand for goods and services should be correspondingly larger, according to the monthly business survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.
Dr. Frank Lea Niles, school physician of this borough, was found dead at his desk at 3 o'clock this morning. An autopsy revealed poison in his stomach, and police said Dr. Niles committed suicide.
City ash and garbage wagon drivers voted to quit work each day at the end of eight hours and to refuse to work on Sundays.

A spectacular spill marked the fourth race at Tropical Park today. Mrs. Payne Whitney's Minster, favored in the field of seven, went down with Eddie Arcaro approaching the sixteenth pole, horse and rider sprawling in a pool of water on the sloppy track.
A dispute as to whether Judas Iscariot hanged himself from a redbud treeis raging among club women here. The Legislature recently passed a bill naming the redbud as the State's official tree.

Dr. John G. Kirkwood of Cornell University, winner of the 1936 award in pure chemistry given by the American Chemical Society, has accepted appointment as Associate Professor in Chemistry at the University of Chicago, Dr. Emery T. Filbey, vice president of the university, stated today.

The shock of his recent conviction and sentence to a six-month workhouse term for tampering with witnesses in an accident case has so overwhelmed Milton Speiser, a lawyer, that he is on the verge of permanent mental and physical collapse in his cell, two psychiatrists asserted in affidavits yesterday.

The ten-round bout between Lou Ambers, holder of the world lightweight championship, and Pedro Montanez of Puerto Rico, was postponed yesterday, according to an announcement by James J. Johnston, in charge of boxing at Madison Square Garden, where the fight was to be held next Friday night.

" You and I standing today before the cross may easily make a mistake," the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, said yesterday afternoon in a broadcast over Station WJZ.

Walter R. Sonstroem of Bristol has been elected captain of the 1937-38 Wesleyan basketball team, it was announced today. He has been high scorer on the team for two seasons and during that time has tallied more than 140 points.

Special musical numbers will be supplied by the Salvation Army Cadet Band, under the baton of Adjutant William Maltby, bandmaster, and by Kamiel Lefevere, carillonneur of the Riverside Church, which is near by, at the sixteenth annual Easter dawn service to be held tomorrow at 7 A. M.

Gross assets, $20,937; net, $2,450. To nephew, Frank Burke, niece, Alicia Burke, sister-in-law, Alicia Burke, $300 each; friend, Dr. A. J. Korey, $500; Holy Cross Cemetery, $250; two friends and two cousins, $200 each; Passionist Monastery, $5; Society for the Propagation of the Faith, $50 and one-fourth of residuary estate; Society of St. Vincent de Paul, Home for the Aged, St. Peter's Hospital. one-fourth of residuary estate each.

The siege of Pozoblanco, about forty miles north of Cordoba in that province, has been broken by a sortie by government troops, who penetrated the Insurgents' ring around the town and advanced three miles in the direction of Alcaracejos.

Notifications of suggested resale prices on a large number of cosmetic items and some liquors were received by stores here from manufacturers of branded products operating under the Feld-Crawford law.

The strike at the plant of the Consolidated Film Industries in Fort Lee, one of the most important motion picture film developing and printing concerns in the country, has seriously crippled production.
Fatally wounded in what Sheriff John Sharp said today was the climax of a newspaper feud, Claude L. McCracken, 46-year-old editor, reported the story of his own shooting and died two hours later.

Confident that final settlement of the Chrysler strike would speed the end of the last lingering sit-downs here, this city was quiet today except for minor early morning violence in the taxi strike which was called late Wednesday.

Several leases for large suites on Park Avenue were included in the contracts for residential space reported yesterday. In 812 Park Avenue, Walter G. Dunnington leased a penthouse apartment of fifteen rooms and six baths through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc Pease and Elliman, Inc., was the co-broker.

Officials in the confidence of President Roosevelt said today that on his return to the capital tomorrow he might intervene again in a legislative tangle that threatens the existence of the Central Statistical Board, an agency he created early in his administration and which is credited with saving the Federal Government nearly $1,000,000 in its first eighteen months.

" The past ten years have produced more improvements in the strength and efficiency of advertising media than any similar period in business history," according to Sidney W. Dean, writing in the current issue of People, monthly bulletin of the J. Walter Thompson Company.
The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a subsidiary of the New England Public Service Company, has been authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission, under the Public Utility Act,

The 333-foot motorship Fijian, abandoned by its crew of thirty after it caught fire at sea, sank five miles from Aurhi Island in the Marshall group, the Chamber of Commerce Marine Exchange reported today.

Opponents of President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the Federal judiciary were endeavoring today to obtain agreement on some form of constitutional amendment which might be suggested as a compromise on the issue involving the Supreme Court.
Movements of naval vessels follow; all dates are March 25 unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Acushnet, March 26; Phelps.

The Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians announced yesterday that plans had been completed for a strike of all technical employes of WPA to forestall the announced plan of the WPA to cut wages of technical men in some instances as much as $50 a month and to dismiss all non-relief engineers on April 15.
Waddell P. Andrus, active in business here for twenty-five years, died today at the age of 69. He was formerly president of the Hi Speed Hammer Company, Inc.
Toots, a 45-pound collie dog, is the hero today of the Rural Hill section near this place for saving Robert Kline, 15, from the savage attack of a 1,500-pound bull.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Hilaire Belloc and the other speakers who punctured the theory that Spanish Loyalists were good and holy should receive a vote of public thanks. I was born and educated in a Protestant environment, but I am certain of nothing more than Mr. Belloc is right that the Spanish Loyalists, so called, are fighting against the church of God.

Counsel for more than 200 employers, including the Alpha Portland Cement Company, urged the Supreme Court today to restrain collection of the payroll tax of the Social Security Law until the court has passed upon the validity of the Alabama Unemployment Insurance Act.

The completely modernized "home store" of John Wanamaker, New York, will be opened formally Wednesday, it was announced yesterday. About $200,000 was spent in the modernization work for the "home store," which extends from the second to the ninth floor in the south building.
Four Broadway theatres will bring in new pictures today. They are "History Is Made at Night," with Charles Boyer, Jean Arthur, Leo Carrillo and Ivan Debedeff, at the Rivoli;
Bright headlights on automobiles using lighted sections of Westchester County parkways were banned today by Thomas F. Reynolds, Parkway Director of Public Safety.

The Frick Collection filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court to compel the city to return $10,650 collected as sales taxes on three recent art purchases made by the collection. The suit alleges that the collection, located at 1 East Seventieth Street, is a semi-public institution and therefore exempt from the tax.
Smudge pots were lighted tonight to save the Japanese cherry trees along the Tidal Basin as the Weather Bureau predicted a clear but freezing Easter.

Michael L. Walsh, former Mayor of Watervliet and one of the best known figures in the business, political and fraternal affairs of this city for many years, died Wednesday night at his home here after an eight-week illness. His age was 64.

Just in case War Secretary Alfred Duff Cooper's plan for attracting army recruits by giving them domestic help and luxury flats for barracks should make the sailors jealous, the Admiralty tonight issued a fleet order approving the issue of stronger grog-and sheets instead of blankets if the men think linen will make their rocking hammocks more homelike.
A sharp shift in the weather, which brought bright, cheerful skies in the wake of a rainy Thursday, accelerated yesterday the movement of Easter holiday travelers to and from the city.

John E. Chalstrom closed his wall paper mill today, paid off his 200 employes, and told them the plant would remain closed "until the workers realize that an employer has rights as well as an employee "

The tennis courts and patio of Ohaka were the setting today for a tennis tournament to which Mr. and Mrs. Roger Wolff Kahn were hosts, entertaining their guests for luncheon between morning and afternoon matches.

The Federal Water Service Corporation reported yesterday for 1936 consolidated net income of $1,033,166 after all subsidiary and parent company charges, including taxes. This is compared to $491,595 in 1935. Gross revenues were $16,830,059, against $15,880,834.
Defeating Hershey, 4 to 1, before 7,500 spectators tonight, the Atlantic City Sea Gulls deadlocked the play-off series for the championship of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League at one victory apiece.

Combatants on the Guadalajara front watched a spectacular air drama today in which an Insurgent pilot was shot dead as he parachuted to the ground. His body fell inside the government lines and was buried.
Three outdoor dawn services will be held on Easter in Westchester County. Special services began at churches of all denominations today.

Stockholders of the Pure Oil Company approved today an issue of $42,000,000 in preferred shares to replace 8 per cent shares of $7,662,000 par value, to retire all bonded and long-term debt and to provide cash for capital expenditures.

A jury in the Federal court, in Brooklyn, returned a verdict of guilty yesterday against three men on trial on an indictment charging conspiracy to operate an unregistered 500-gallon still seized on Jan. 22 at 52 Terrace Avenue, Freeport. L. I.

After seventeen days in drydock for patching up the large hole in her bowplates, the Dollar liner President Coolidge, which rammed and sank the tanker Frank H. M. Buck in the Golden Gate March 6, was bound today for the Orient.

Only $12,718,262 of new State and municipal bond and note issues are scheduled for award next week. This compares with this week's revised total of $29,910,425. The weekly average for the year thus far is $41,630,445.
Richard J. (Moon) Ducote, director of athletics at Loyola University, died in a hospital here yesterday of a complication of diseases. He was 39 years old.

Charles Carhart Kenyon, known in the textile world for his invention of a machine giving absolute control of the amount of moisture in woolen fabrics, died at his residence at 133 West End Avenue early today at the age of 65. Death was due to heart disease.

Georgia legislators early today closed a sixty-day session which brought enactment of Governor E. D. Rivers's New Deal social program, an $88,000,000 appropriation bill for two years and numerous new taxes.

Many parties for members of the younger set, here from colleges and preparatory schools for the holiday, will feature the Easter ball tomorrow night at the Surf Club. A luncheon will be given on Easter Sunday by Mrs. Oscar Thompson at the Surf Club.
The National Park Service estimated today that thousands of Americans would see Easter services in parks and monument areas Sunday and millions would hear broadcasts from the scenes.

The first Eastern championship will be decided tonight when the New York Athletic Club makes its bid for the right to represent the East in the series against the West, the climax of the indoor polo season. Standing in the way of the Athletic Club trio is the Ridgewood Polo Club of New Jersey. They will clash at the Squadron A Armory in the final round of the Eastern junior championship.

124th St., 5g E.. 18x101; Katherine CSIKY, also known as Katherine Biffy, to Morton Kulick, 1.491 Vyse Av., Bronx; Mtg., $5,000 ($13). 62nd St., 115 W., 25x100.5; Spingler-van Beuren Estates, Inc., to Cappel Realty Corp., 70 Bowery ($10). 75th St., 341 E., 27x75: Bond and Mortgage Gurantee Co. to 341 E. 75th St. Corp., 10 E. 40th St., care of Barron, Rice Rockmore ($16).

Foster Vincent Brown, former Representative in Congress from the Third Tennesse District and Attorney General of Puerto Rico under President Taft, died today. He was 82 years old. For years he was a Republican leader in this section.

This department is led to speculate this morning-since events of the past week in the night clubs have been conducive to little elseupon the current reappearance of a swarm of "society singers" and entertainers of sorts upon the nocturnal scene.

Industrial production, after making allowances for changes in the number of working days and usual seasonal variations, rose to 116 per cent of the 1923-25 average in February, compared with 114 per cent in January and 94 per cent in February, 1936,

Creditors of the National Surety Company filed a proof of claim here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell alleging that the estate of Nicholas F. Brady is indebted to the now defunct surety company to the extent of "many millions of dollars."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

George Brodeur, superintendent of a Fairhaven boat yard, said today that instructions he had received from the owner of the schooner Sewanna indicated that President Roosevelt would cruise New England waters again this Summer.

An increase in its payroll amounting to $7,000,000 annually was announced yesterday by the General Electric Company through Gerard Swope, president. Mr. Swope made known that the increase would apply to all employes of the company and would become effective in the first week of April.
The Agricultural Department said today the dust storm area of the Southwest may be extended greatly this year unless there are heavy rains.

Nick Barcia, 30 years old, of 138 Grattan Street, Brooklyn, and Dominick Tolluto, 35, of 431 East Eighty-first Street, and Rosario Viano, 31, of 3 Goerck Street, both of Manhattan, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn to a charge of passing counterfeit $5 silver certificates.
The British Isles experienced today one of the coldest Good Friday in several years as Winter returned to many sections.
GRAIN PRODUCTS CORP., 11 W. 42d St.. by the Gennesee Brewing Co., Inc., for $7.750; Rochester Brewing Co., Inc., $11,000; Haberle Congress Brewing Co., Inc., $2,600.
A general increase in freight rates between New York and the ports of South Africa will be put into effect on Thursday by ship lines serving that trade, it was announced yesterday.

Oswin H. Shelly, sales manager for the Aetna Steel Construction Company in New York, died today at his home here after a short illness. He was 63 years old. Mr. Shelly was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania.

A tract comprising 193 building lots in Queensboro Hill, Flushing, adjacent to the grounds of the New York World's Fair, has been purchased by a developer as a site for the construction of a number of one-family residences.

The Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, 555 Prospect Place, hired twelve employes yesterday to replace eighteen laundry workers who were dismissed on Thursday. when they staged a sit-down strike. Hospital authorities expected shortly to replace all the laundry workers.
Two sea gulls, forced down in the business section here with their wings coated with ice, continued their migratory flight today, thanks to police and Game Warden F. S. Maloney.

-Ground studies-surveys and approaches to landings-were being completed today at this third station on the 7,000-mile air trade route under survey by Pan American Airways between the United States and New Zealand.

A playful wild goose entertained shore commuters en route to New York this morning by beating a Central Railroad of New Jersey train in a race between Point Pleasant and Long Branch, a distance of twenty miles.
A literal "foot-down" strike was started today by Mrs. Lahawanda Poresky, 75-year-old business woman, against the town fathers and WPA authorities.

Stephen A. Vail, brother of Miss Laura Vail, principal of the VailDeane School here, died this morning at his home after a short illness. Born in Philadelphia, he was a son of the late David and Margaret Martin Vail.

An anonymous attempt to nominate four "liberals" for the Harvard Board of Overseers failed today when the petition was adjudged inadequate. The proposed nominees were Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union; Corliss Lamont, a member of that group, who was recently arrested for picketing activities;
Practically every Eastern Canadian newsprint company will support the $50 base price established by the International Paper Company for the first six months of 1938.

Some surprise was expressed in Congressional circles today at the recent ruling of the office of the Third Assistant Postmaster General to the effect that newspapers might be barred from admission as secondclass mail matter if they printed news of lottery winnings or sweepstake results in editions other than those carried through the mails.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Milton Dammann of 440 Park Avenue and Bedford Hills, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Dammann, to J. Lester Eisner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lester Eisner of Red Bank, N. J., and this city.

This week's fractional rise in commercial paper rates on the New York market would have attracted less attention if it were not for the fact that this was the first change in open-market quotations on that class of loans during nearly three years, and that it has occurred in immediate sequence to the increased yield on United States Government bonds at present lower prices.

The Cabinet of the autonomous State of Catalonia headed by Premier Jose Tarradellas resigned today. President Luis Companys said that a new Cabinet would be announced Monday or Tuesday "at the earliest."

Christianity does not seek to conceal the evil and suffering in the world, but rather offers an explanation in the suffering of Christ and a refuge in His church, the Rev. John Thorn Golding asserted yesterday in a sermon which closed the Good Friday services at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader, received word from the Russian Embassy in Wahington yesterday that his request for a visa, reported originally to have been refused, now has been granted, so that he and his wife may visit Russia early next month.

Secretary Ickes has referred to his legal department a petition from Ben L. Blue, Los Angeles attorney, for a rehearing in the matter of ownership of tidewater lands in Southern California, it was announced today.

The 341 East Seventy-fifth Street Corp., H. Lee Lurie, vice president, gave a purchase money mortgage for $13,500, payable live years hence. at 5 per cent, to the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Co., which sold the property at 341 East 75th St. for an indicated consideration of $16,000.
Railway Age said today that railroad employes had received an average annual salary of $1,734 in 1936 as increased hours of service had resulted from traffic improvements.

Jockey Warren Cornay of New Orleans booted home five winners on an eight-race card at Epsom Downs today. His feat was not a record, but it is duplicated only once or twice a season and the all-time high is six triumphs in a single day.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, wholly owned by the General Motors Corporation, reported yesterday for 1936 a net income of $14,674,849 after charges and taxes, compared with $14,682,895 in 1935.

The result of the poll of Republicans of the Eleventh Manhattan district showing 60 per cent opposed to the renomination of Mayor La Guardia, taken by Robert P. Levis, leader of the district, was challenged yesterday by Daniel J. Riesner, whom Mr. Levis defeated for the leadership.

The twentyyear 5 1/2 per cent war loan that France raised in the United States in 1917 is to be repaid in gold dollars on the basis of 36.853 paper francs to the dollar, according to a communique issued by the Ministry of Finance today.
Seville's famous Holy Week observance, now drawing to a close, has almost reached its accustomed splendor of former and happier years. Very few foreign visitors have come to the city, however.

Sit-down strikers returned to work yesterday in five of the F. and W. Grand 5, 10 and 25 cent stores following an agreement brought about the day before by Mayor La Guardia and Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the National Security Board.
Prince Mohammed Ali, President of the Council of Regents and heir presumptive to the throne of Egypt, was reported seriously ill here tonight. He is a cousin of King Farouk.

The trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad yesterday filed petitions with the United States District Court for authority to discontinue operation of the Providence and New Bedford lines of its steamship subsidiary, the New England Steamship Company.

Mayor La Guardia was asked yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to investigate the circumstances surrounding the delay in admitting Mrs. W. C. Handy, wife of the Negro "blues" composer, into Knickerbocker Hospital on the night of March 11.
A proclamation banning a demonstration planned by the Irish Republican Army at Castlebar on Easter Monday was issued today by Patrick Ruttledge, Minister of Justice.

Although blind since childhood, Mark Shoesmith, 25 years old, has mastered the art of chiseling and whittling compositions out of stone. His sculptures, on their own merits, have been considered creditable pieces of art by sculptors, including Malvina Hoffman.
New student leaders of Athletic Association, Outing Club, Debate Society and Fellowship of Faiths at Mount Holyoke College were announced today following campus elections.

Employers in the garment industry were directed yesterday to file with the Division of Placement and Unemployment, State Department of Labor, statements of claims the employers are expected to make in filing their Federal tax returns for the offset allowed against the Federal unemployment compensation tax by reason of payments made under the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law.
A retail coal merchants' organization informed- the Interstate Commerce Commission today that any increase in freight rates on coal and coke would be passed on to the consumer.
Jews the world over at sundown yesterday began the observance of the festival of Passover, in celebration of the liberation of the Israelites from bondage in Egypt more than 3,000 years ago.

An announcement that the strike which closed the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's mills here for three weeks had been "officially called off" was made this afternoon by Harry Greeninger, president of the local chapter of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers, an affiliate of the C. I. O.

These orders were issued in the Northern New York Area. The following officers of the Chaplains Reserve, recently released to the Northern New York Reserve Area for assignment, are assigned or attached as follows: 513th Coast Artillery-1st Lt. Edward A. Lautenschlager, Ch.-Res., 32 Grove St., Amsterdam. N. Y.

Mrs. Wallis Simpson will wear what are, to her, old clothes on Easter Sunday. She has been unable to get to Paris for an Easter wardrobe, her friends at Chateau de Cande said today. But then, they added, the Duke of Windsor's fiancee plans nothing special for Easter.

The vitality of Paul Cadmus's paintings resides in the potent and subtle draftsmanship rather than in the color. A one-man show of work by this very gifted young American artist opened a few days ago at the Midtown Galleries, 605 Madison Avenue, and will be current there until April 10.

A perjury indictment against Benjamin Heier, who testified for the defense in the Hauptmann trial, was dismissed today by Judge Adam o. Robbins in Common Pleas Court here on the motion of Prosecutor Anthony M. Hauck. Mr. Hauck

Miss Margaret Bostwick of the Apawamis Club and David McElroy of the University Club last night won the metropolitan mixed doubles squash racquets championship for the first time, defeating Miss Frida Scharman and A. W. Paine, 18--14, 15--12, 18--16, on the Heights Casino courts.

This isn't the town it used to be. All the air a solemn stillness holds. Everything is deadly serious since Manager B. Grimes first marshaled his Flatbush flock here and gave the crushing order: "No laughing in ranks!" Clearwater and environs echoed with merriment in the old days under rotund Uncle Wilbert Robinson. Casey Stengel carried on the tradition laughingly. But B. Grimes has put the crusher on all signs of levity.

A statement of the modifications and amendments to the plan of reorganization of the Bush Terminal Company and its subsidiary, the Bush Terminal Buildings Company, was handed yesterday to Judge Robert A. Inch in the Federal court in Brooklyn by Lowell M. Birrell, counsel for Bush Terminal.

A carefully planned payroll robbery netted three men $2,711.95 yesterday afternoon and brought a payless Easter week-end to about 100 employes of the Court Press, Inc., a concern specializing in legal printing with offices on the second floor at 130 Cedar Street, near the Hudson River.
Twenty-four scholarships and fellowships totaling $13,450 have been awarded at Harvard University for the next academic year. The recipients are:...
A new champion will take the Eastern States annual invitation golf tournament, it developed today when J. R. Fraser, Atlantic City youth, failed to defend his crown after winning for four years.

Opposition to the bill of State Senator Philip M. Kleinfeld to require a party to poll 5 per cent of the total vote for Governor to gain the status of a legal party and a place on the ballot was expressed yesterday in a letter to Senator Kleinfeld signed by leaders of five minority parties of political groups.

The government newspaper Izvestia, calling Premier Mussolini of Italy a "false Caesar," declared today Italian refusal to discuss withdrawal of troops from Spain showed clearly II Duce planned to send new and greater armies into the civil conflict.

Opposition to the bill of State Senator Philip M. Kleinfeld to require a party to poll 5 per cent of the total vote for Governor to gain the status of a legal party and a place on the ballot was expressed yesterday in a letter to Senator Kleinfeld signed by leaders of five minority parties of political groups.

Five captains for next year's Winter sports teams have been elected at Cornell University, it was made known today. Tom Rich of Hobart and Carleton Wilson of Milwaukee have been named to co-captain the 1937-38 basketball team, and John Tausig of Harrisburg, Pa., will lead the boxing team. Fred Reimers of Hammond, La., will captain the wrestling team, and Bob Cloyes of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, will head the swimming team.
When the Regional Plan Association fixed the location of New York's geographical center in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

The steamer Seneca, a former Coast Guard cutter, was sold at auction today to the Boston Iron and Metal Company for $10,200 to settle libel claims. Actions were filed by the Boston concern for $17,686 and by an individual, Walter Messick, for $493. The purchaser's bid was offered by Morton H. Rosen, Boston lawyer.
James Barton Smith, Colorado hotel manager, has found that passing the buck-especially when the buck is in the form of a silver dollar-is a somewhat difficult task east of the Mississippi River.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins declared tonight that sit-down strikes did not reflect "any widespread movement to defy the law or impair civil government or change conceptions of property rights," and that their objectives were "the usual objectives of unions in labor disputes."

Forty-four days out of Singapore, the Barber Line freighter Raby Castle docked in Brooklyn last night with many of the seamen on board downcast because of the loss of the ship's mascot, a large cat of unestablished origin.

The University of Michigan served notice it is not yet ready to relinquish its National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming crown by outdistancing a fast field in the first day's events of the fourteenth annual championships. When the firing in six events had ceased tonight the Wolverines were well out in front with 34 points, followed by Ohio State with 27 and Yale with 21.

Raymond Ketcham is with Granberry Co. in their municipal sales department. Arthur M. Betts has been elected a director of Butler Brothers to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Charles C. Haffner Jr.

As a large number of New York's Congressional delegation went home today for the Easter holidays they left behind twenty-one petitions indicating the keen interest of President Roosevelt's home State in his Supreme Court reorganization program.
The capital's champion egg-rollers entered final training today for their annual contest on the White House lawn Monday.

Three hundred sit-down strikers evacuated plants of the E. P. Reed Shoe Company tonight as the management signed a contract recognizing the United Shoe Workers of America, C. I. O. union, and granted a 15 per cent wage increase.

Government control of bootleg coal mining was suggested to Governor Earle's anthracite investigating commission here today by the Rev. J. J. Petrovits, rector of St. Mary's Church, Kulpmont, a community hard hit by the reduction of colliery working time.
Robert A. Taft of Cincinnati, whose father was President and Chief Justice, said here today that he was "seriously considering becoming a candidate" for the United States Senate in 1938.
Return to the pioneer days, when youths in their early teens could assemble a muzzle-loader and pick off game fifty yards away, was sought in a bill before New York's Legislature today.

Yielding to what he termed an "uncontrollable" desire to kill somebody, James McCullough, 41, an employee of the Pennsylvania Hospital for Mental and Nervous Diseases for twenty years, battered a fellow-employe to death today with an iron bar and a plaster scraper, according to an alleged confession made public by the police.

John Elborn Highton, appointed Permanent Under-Secretary of State for Scotland three weeks ago, died today at the age of 58. He had been a member of the civil srevice since 1905 and before his recent appointment was secretary of the Department of Health for Scotland.

Discovery of a chemical, tentatively named leukotaxine, which plays an important part in the body's fight against disease, was reported here today at the meeting of the American Association of Pathologists and Bacteriologists.

Traffic on First Avenue between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets was held up for thirty minutes yesterday afternoon when a large truck, loaded with sheets of a cellulose product, caught fire, causing damage estimated at $5,000.

George E. Vorbach, who came to Mechanicsburg High School as head football and basketball coach and instructor of physical education from Newport News (Va.) High School six years ago, died here at his home today following a heart attack. His age was 33.

Skippers of ten trim sailing yachts, the smallest fleet to enter a St. Petersburg-Havana race since 1932, eyed the skies tonight and prepared for rough weather in the eighth annual Gulf racing classic. Forecasts were for possible squalls and uncertain winds, a contrast to the start last year when twenty-one yachts flashed across the line in perfect weather.

Despite a deadlock on the question of collective bargaining, Governor Frank Murphy announced tonight that Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, were getting closer together in their conference at his office.

A baby born prematurely at Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, after a gestation period of only four months and ten days and that weighted only nine ounces, put up a valiant struggle for life for 18 hours 24 minutes, thus establishing of this age and size as far as available medical records could show.
Frederick L. Maytag, manufacturer of washing machines and a pioneer automobile maker, died in Good Samaritan Hospital here today. He was 80 years old.

David Smith, son of a furniture manufacturer, disappeared late this afternoon between his home in Shippensburg, 11 miles away, and the Church of the Brethren in this city, where he was to have been married at 6 P. M. to Miss Kathleen Bard of Chambersburg.
Rested after two weeks at Warm Springs, President Roosevelt tonight was heading northward to plunge into the fight over his proposal to increase the membership of the Supreme Court.

Beggars and dives were ordered cleared out of the picturesque old French Quarter of New Orleans, the Vieux Carre, today. Superintendent George Reyer of the Police Department issued the mandate, assigning Captain James Cripps to lead a clean-up crusade against vice, nightly noises and other public nuisances.

Bowling along under the momentum gained by rolling over the Yanks and Tigers, Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers today flattened the Bees and moved above the .500 mark in the Grapefruit League standing. With Tom Baker permitting only. two singles in six innings and Watty Clark allowing only three, the Bees naturally finished on the short end of the 5-0 score.

Mounting services in the Sistine Chapel--without the accustomed presence of Pope Plus--climaxed Good Friday on servances tonight. Cardinal pacelli, Papal Secretary of State and high priest of St. Peter's Cathedral, conducted the ceremonies in the presence of Cardinals of the curia, members of the diplomatic corps and high church dignitaries.

With twenty-six classes making up the card, the Metropolitan Equestrian Club will give its third horse show of the season today at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx. There will be sessions at 10:15 A. M., 2 and 7:30 P. M.

A city detective and a guard shot and killed Herbert Ridiker, 33, a former marine, in the massive Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank tonight after Ridiker had slain his fatherin-law, Charfes Graf, 67, in a family quarrel at the latter's home.

The Constitution authorizes Congress "to establish postoffices and postroads." That is all it says about the matter.
