But few grants of power have ever been more generously interpreted, and Congress under cover of this grant has refused the use of the mails for indecent matter, seditious matter, the sale of grain for future delivery, and lotteries.

Congressional leaders looked tonight to their scheduled conference with the President tomorrow to bring a definite indication of the administration's attitude in regard to sit-down strikes and decisions on other pending problems.
Charles C. Kolars, former County Attorney of Le Sueur County, Minn., died at Le Sueur Center yesterday of a heart attack, according to word received here yesterday.

Sidney B. Wood said today he was abondoning attempts for a place on the 1937 United States Davis Cup tennis team. The slender Easterner said his training plans were abruptly ended. this Winter when mining property in Death Valley, buried by an unprecedented snow storm, demanded his personal attention.

Jimmie Van Sant of Atlantic City, N. J., outsailed thirty-one other skippers today to win the Southeastern individual Moth Class championship. Off to a slow start in the feature event of the first day of the international Moth-type regatta, Van Sant-sailing under the colors of the Evening Star Yacht Clubpicked up speed and scudded home with yards to spare.
Rehabilitation of duck breeding areas of Canada along lines similar to a United States undertaking is proposed by Ducks Unlimited (Canada), incorporation of which was disclosed in The Canada Gazette.

William J. Wollman, securities broker, died early this morning in his apartment in the Waldorf Towers. His age was 69. He had been the head of the New York Stock Exchange firm of W. J. Wollman Co. of 120 Broadway since 1916.

The three-family frame house at 447 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn, on a plot 20 by 100 feet, has been sold by Mrs. S. Schaaf to a client of Edward Ford for all cash. The new owner plans extensive alterations to the property.

The Daily Mirror leased yesterday the five-story building and purchased the equipment, which housed and printed The Brooklyn TimesUnion, at 540 Atlantic Avenue, prior to its acquisition by The Brooklyn Eagle. The signing of the contracts followed several months' negotiations.

John Elborn Highton, appointed Permanent Under-Secretary of State for Scotland three weeks ago, died today at the age of 58. He had been a member of the civil srevice since 1905 and before his recent appointment was secretary of the Department of Health for Scotland.

Discovery of a chemical, tentatively named leukotaxine, which plays an important part in the body's fight against disease, was reported here today at the meeting of the American Association of Pathologists and Bacteriologists.

The Daily Mirror leased yesterday the five-story building and purchased the equipment, which housed and printed The Brooklyn TimesUnion, at 540 Atlantic Avenue, prior to its acquisition by The Brooklyn Eagle. The signing of the contracts followed several months' negotiations.

About 6,000 will participate in ten campus festivals, recitals and exhibits which will close the first year's program of the Cultural Olympics conducted by the School of Education at the University of Pennsylvania.
The New York Rovers defeated the Orioles, 2-0, tonight in a rough and tumble second game of the Hershey Cup hockey series.
Three University of Wisconsin students, human guinea pigs in a scientific experiment, tested their teeth on "real" food today after weeks of nothing but raw milk and fruit.

Demand for women's coats was sustained in the wholesale market here last week and wholesale stocks were in good condition, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Retail stores reported "the largest Spring suit and coat season in seven years." The report continues:
Four hundred persons are expected to attend the Easter dance on Saturday of the Mercier Club of Northern New Jersey, to be held at the Green Brook Country Club in North Caldwell.

The Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science (the University in Exile) is planning a three-day celebration to signalize its completion of four years in a country "where its members no longer feel themselves in exile, but happily and thankfully at home," according to an announcement last week.

The "learn-by-doing" system of education has definitely gained a foothold on the St. Lawrence University campus this Spring semester with the introduction of several workshop courses to the curriculum.
The Tennessee Supreme Court gave the go-head signal today to Memphis and Chattanooga in their plans to construct municipal power plants.
Pembroke College in Brown University has awarded three major fellowships for advanced study to two Brown graduates and one Pembroke undergraduate.
IN the late Sixties, when the Old Vic Theatre had not yet become aged enough to be called the Old Vic, but was known merely as the Royal Victoria Theatre, H.S. Leigh, in his "Carols of Cockayne,

A nip of Winter in clear sunny skies will chill Easter promenaders here and celebrants at outdoor ceremonies in many other parts of the country today, according to the forecast issued last night by the United States Weather Bureau.
Miss Dorothy E. Latshaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claire N. Latshaw of Suburban Royesford, was married to Spencer K. Mulford Jr. of Jamison , Pa., at noon to day in the home of her parents.

AN exhibition of models embodying suggestions for the World's Fair in New York has been opened in the Galleries of the Architectural League by members of the Society of Mural Painters and Collaborating Architects, Sculptors and Landscape Architects. It will be current this week.

Only soothsayers with clairvoyant powers can know whether this outbreak of sit-down strikes is just another dime chain-letter fad, or the forerunner of the industrial revolution. If in a week or a month or a season it vanishes, like other epidemic crazes in America, that will be that. But if, as it seems,
Two persons were burned to death and four others escaped a similar fate today when they leaped from a second-story window as fire swept an isolated farmhouse five miles from this place.

The marriage of Miss Kay Steele, daughter of Mrs. William Calvin Steele of 450 Riverside Drive and the late Dr. Steele of Mount Olive, N. C., to Clisby Blakeney DuBose, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Palmer Clisby DuBose of Camden, S. C., took place yesterday afternoon in the Broadway Presbyterian Church.
William Hugh Johnston, former president of the International Association of Machinists, died at his home here last night after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

TWO salient facts of the Metropolitan Opera Association's Winter season of 1936-37, which came to an end last night, are before us, and both of them are deemed matters for congratulation. One is the re-engagement for two seasons,

Ted Fenwick of Montreal won the Bermuda amateur golf championship today by defeating George West of Bermuda, 3 and 1, in one of the most exciting thirty-six-hole matches ever played on a local course.

Premier Benito Mussolini's latest claim to be "defender of the Moslem faith" may have startled the Western world and caused it uneasiness, but Moslems of the Near and Middle Eastern countries, on whom Mussolini has had an eye for the past few years, apparently have not been at all aroused by it.

WHEN the Governor General of Canada arrives In Washington this week for a brief visit to the President of the United States, the doors of the White House will swing open to one of the most unusual personalities in the British Empire. John Buchan, Baron Tweedsmuir, who represents King George VI in the government of Canada, is like no other Governor General the Dominion ever had.
Joseph M. Swearingen, who served twenty-five years as a judge in Allegheny County's Common Pleas Court, died today at his home, 112 West Prospect Avenue. He was 82 years old.

In recognition of his fifth anniversary as president of Rutgers University, Dr. Robert C. Clothier will be guest of honor at a dinner to be given by Rutgers alumni in the Hotel Commodore on Wednesday, April 14, at 7 P. M.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Oscar R. Houston of Kings Point, Great Neck, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Houston, to John Lewis Grose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Grose, also of Great Neck.

Declaring that estimates place the total amount to be spent on home building in the New York area this year at more than a quarter of a billion dollars, Peter Grimm. chairman of the advisory committee of the North American Homes Exposition, to be held in Madison Square Garden May 12 to 23, predicted yesterday that the show is timed at the moment most likely to accelerate residential building activity.

With the present collective agreement expiring at midnight Wednesday, negotiations between soft coal miners and operators for a new contract covering the wages and hours of 400,000 miners in the Appalachian region were reported deadlocked last night.

The six-story walk-up tenement house at 317 East 106th Street, fronting 25 feet between First and Second Avenues, has been completely renovated, states the agent, Edwin E. Tanzer, and the rooms which formerly rented for $3 are now all occupied at an average rate of $5.50 per room.

Lydia d'Autoney, a French artist who does portraits in colored stone mosaics, arrived yesterday on the United States liner President Harding, bringing a mosaic bust portrait of President Roosevelt, which she will present to him. For many years a resident of New York, Miss d'Autoney has been visiting in her native land for the last thirteen months.

FELIX RIESENBERG, whose long list of salty and racy books has given delight to many readers, stands as a human link between the seagoing of the past and seagoing today; for, although qualified in sail, Captain Riesenberg moved into steam when he saw that the era of tall ships was definitely drawing to a close.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Cullinan of East Saddle River, Hohokus, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mercedes Molyneux Cullinan, to Robert Morton Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Adams of 32 East Sixtyfourth Street and The Terraces, Saddle River, N. J.
A plan for the removal of pushcarts and the erection of a group of street-to-street arcades has been submitted by James A. Felt, broker, to William Fellowes Morgan, Commissioner of Markets.

A reduction in the interest rate would make it possible, declares Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, for several million additional families to become home owners.

WARRENTON, Va.-George W. Cutting, secretary, has announced an additional race for the program of the Virginia Gold Cup races to be run on May 1 at the course on Broad View Farm near Warrenton. It is to be known as the Noel Laing Memorial, in honor of Noel Laing of Amissville, Va., gentleman rider, who died in November, 1936, at the age of 25.

If Hitler and Company wonder why Germany is "misunderstood" abroad they have but to consider the tactless arrangements made to commemorate the University of Goettingen's formal opening two hundred years ago.

A TEN-WEEK series of short wave travelogues to be inproduced by W2XAF and W2XAD, Schenectady, tomorrow will aim "to sell America to the rest of the world as a country of historic and scenic beauty which should appeal to foreign tourists." The broadcast will be in English, French and Spanish.

Rutgers University and West Chester State Teachers College battled' to a 7-7 tie in a practice football game on Neilson Field today before a crowd of 1,000 spectators, including 200 New Jersey high school mentors attending the fifth annual Rutgers Coaches Clinic.

A strong feeling that Dominion taxpayers should share the cost of Great Britain's vast rearmament program persists, according to reports reaching here from London. The theory is that if Britain is threatened the whole empire will be in danger.

Year in and year out, metropolitan college baseball teams manage to rank with the best in the Easteither right up with that perennial powerhouse, Holy Cross, or just a shade behind. This season is likely to prove no exception, even though graduation has hit most of the local schools very heavily and robbed them of key men.
WHEN in a single week six stewardesses of one airline quit their jobs to wed, the announcement became news because of the concentration of time and numbers.

ANNA SEWARD'S reputation has come down from the eighteenth century linked with that of Dr. Johnson, whose deification, either during life or afterward, she strenuously opposed. When every one else was goggle-eyed with wonder at the great man's omniscience, wit and oratory, she withstood him to his face and in writing.

The Boston Retail Store Employes Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, today prepared demands for a five-day. forty-hour week, 20 per cent wage increase for employes receiving more than $18 a week and a minimum wage of $18.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Legh Richmond Powell Jr. of Norfolk, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Whidbee Powell, to Ernest W. Borkland Jr. of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest W. Borkland of Longmeadow, Mass.

Fear that well-intentioned evasions of the Constitution "might so distort methods of control that they would do permanent injury to American economic and social life" was expressed tonight by Dr. Mildred H. McAfee

Class 1, Riding Academy Horse (to be Judged on manners and suitability)-First, P. H. Montulet's Blue Bird: second, Kennelworth Academy's Garma; third, P. H. Montulet's Nicky; fourth, Miss Pat Martin's Storm Cloud.

The police lodged a charge of manslaughter tonight against Salvatore Alfano, 19 years old, of 96 Nichols Street, one of two youths who brought Patsy Mazziello, 18, of 8 Nichols Street to St. James Hos pital suffering from a gunshot wound in the head. Mazziello died three hours after his admission to the hospital.
IF Spring is here, Summer cannot be far behind, and it becomes appropriate to mention the Lewisohn Stadium concerts, The Stadium Concerts Committee is planning a season this Summer, as usual.
A breath-holding feat, as reported by The U. S. Hoosier, ship's paper of the cruiser Indianapolis, cost Ensign Roy S. Thompson $82.
CHARLES PROTEUS STEINMETZ, whose electrical wizardry contributed much tothe renown of "the House of Magic" in Schenectady, was once quoted as saying, "the world belongs to the discontented."

There will be no traditional Easter bullfight in Madrid tomorrow. There was none today. Holy Saturday and Easter Sunday were gala occasions for Madrilenos before the war. They marked the first bullfights of the season.

THE loony this moonstruck--comedy. "Smirt - SmithSmire," this dream romance, this "Urbane Nightmare," this "Acceptance in the Third Person," that Mr. Cabell in his new incarnation has foisted on us, here comes to a close-or at least a temporary stopping place.

Problems confronting savings banks in the supervision of real estate management were described last week by Ralph A. Brooks, manager of the real estate department of the Union Dime Savings Bank, before the apartment house group of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Simon Glazer of 131 Riverside Drive have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Glazer, to Sidney G. Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Goldberg of Newark, F N. J. The wedding will take place on June 20.

British rearmament in the air, the extent of which is indicated by estimates recently passed which exceed [Pound]80,000,000, is based on the fact that only eight minutes would elapse from the time warning of an air raid was received from the coast until hostile raiders were over London.

Sam Gilpin and Gabe Lavine, both of Philadelphia, advanced to the second round of the Middle States indoor tennis championships today. Gilpin defeated W. T. Campbell, 6-1, 6-2, and Lavine won from Charles Gamble, 6-4, 6-2.

Secretary PERKINS has replied to the criticism made of her remark that the legality of the sit-down strike " has not yet been determined by the courts." She notes that this comment was made during the early days of the General Motors dispute. She describes it as "an aside in what was a rather long informal conversation."

Birobidjan, the Jewish autonomous region of the U. S. S. R., has become a positive force in Jewish life. In the former empire of the Czars, where the Jews were subjected to persecution and oppression, anti-Semitism has now, under the Soviet regime, been rooted out entirely.
Secret Service operatives are now handling over 400 forged government checks a month. The arrests show a sharp upward curve. Forged checks are cashed chiefly in chain and retail stores.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, in discussing the problem of old-law tenements before the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York last week, frankly admitted that no clear solution of the difficulty had yet been presented.

CONSERVATION of fuel, engine efficiency and predetermined range in the ninety-four completed crossings of the Pacific by the Clipper ships of Pan American Airways is shown in a recent dispatch by the company outlining the planned flight schedule of each flight.

An increased volume of foreign travel over the high 1935 total was predicted for the coming Summer season yesterday by John Schroeder, director of the Hapag Lloyd Line, on his return from a twentyfive-day tour of inspection of the offices of the company's agents throughout the United States and Canada.

A DISTINGUISHED London physician recently announced the discovery, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES, that the rereading of old novels is peculiarly efficacious for the man who cannot sleep; and, as if in answer to this suggestion, the American Book Company launched its American Fiction Series, in which will be reprinted,

Miss Petra Felisa Mufioz, daughter of Mrs. H. F. Uda de Mufioz of Havana, was married here yesterday afternoon in the West End Presbyterian Church to William W. Morrow of Boston, by the Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren.
Taking advantage of the Spring recess, several departments at Skidmore have organized field trips to show students the practical and applied sides of their respective fields.

Cobea scandens, Cup-and-Saucer vine or Cathedral-bells, is the only popular annual vine that cannot be planted in the open ground to produce mature plants by August. The large seeds must be started indoors during the latter half of March.

With 6,000,000 lambs consumed by New York residents and with only 385,000 sheep on the farms of the State, the Farm Bureau agents in Central New York are urging farmers this Spring to become sheep raisers.

Illinois' football warriors will be out there officially next Fall hustling for Coach Zuppke. Athletic Director Wendell S. Wilson announced today the 1937 campaign would be known as "Bob Zuppke's twenty-fifth anniversary season" to honor the wily mentor when he rounds out a quarter-century as head football coach.

If Tapan ever entertained any hope that, by bringing about the abolition of the naval treaties concluded at Washington and London, the Japanese Navy might be built up to equal those of the British Empire and the United States. such a hope is now definitely ended.

A new name took its place at the top of the list in the singles competition of the American Bowling Congress yesterday. Emil Gabarino of Middletown, N. Y., rolled a score of 699 and thus became the pacesetter.

There have been two contradictory responses here to the Pope's encyclical on Germany read in Catholic pulpits last Sunday. While the government and the National Socialist party resent it bitterly, church leaders and church goers, Catholic and Protestant, have a sense of foreboding.

The fourth and final free symphony concert for -the month of March, under the direction of David Mannes, was presented last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art before an audience of 2,400 persons.

ON the 14th of April, 1865, Jhn Wilkes Booth fired a fatal shot into the base of Abraham Lincoln's brain; on the 26th Booth--or was it Booth?--was shot in the Garrett barn; and a few weeks later the seven men and one woman convicted of complicity in the crime were either hanged or sent to prison.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. William R. Ward of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Meeker Ward, to Alvin Walck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Redman Walck of Weatherly, Pa.

Mgr. John M. Hilpert. pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Genoa, Albany Avenue and Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, was killed early today in a fire that swept the upper floors of the rectory, where he was sleeping.

IN many communities throughout the nation the Boy Scouts have "mobilization" plans ready for social emergencies. When they are needed to render aid to the victims of fire, flood or other disaster they may be summoned by a special siren. bell, whistle or bugle call.

The Eastern racing season, beginning as usual at Bowie in Maryland, will get under way on Thursday with bright prospects despite the fact that there is a conflict for the first time with the tail-end of the Florida season.

Senator Thomas of Oklahoma said today he had prompted the written statement of Judge Robert L. Williams of the Eastern Oklahoma Federal Court that he would retire at 70 if named to the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals.

Though union organizers have been enjoying a field day along the automotive front, none has been so bold as to claim sweeping gains in the Ford Motor Company. At the time of the General Motors strike union banners suggested that Ford was slated for trouble next.

Representatives of transatlantic steamship lines have complained to Police Commissioner Valentine about the activities of licensed porters who stand in front of the municipal piers and approach arriving passengers, representing themselves as the agents of express companies.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana was a sponsor of the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934. Now, asserting that he had been misled as to its real purposes, he wants the act repealed. In the current battle in Congress over the act both sides agree that the Indian should be developed as an American citizen, but the methods to achieve this end are sharply at variance.
Miss Grace J. Boggs of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Ruth Emily Van Olinda, to Dr. Eric Ponder of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.
Fellow Baptist ministers indicated tonight they would not unite with the Rev. Verdi Allen in his fight against the evolution theories of Hendrik Van Loon.
More than 22,000,000 words were carried over the navy's radio network in 1936, the Naval Communication Service recently informed the House Appropriations Committee.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today dated March 26: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Brady, R. C., Q. M. C., detailed with organized reserves at Philadelphia, Pa., in addition to other duties. Fletcher, A., Inf., Moscow, Idaho, to State College, New Mexico, July 1. Godfrey, S. C., Eng'rs., Panama. to office of Chief of Engineers, Washington, D. C.

Fifty years ago, as now, everybody was arguing about the Supreme Court. In the Eighteen Eightiesas a result of the nation's expansion and post-civil war problems--the court was so overwhelmed with work that cases remained on its docket for three or four years.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission, it was learned yesterday, will request city departments to set up schools to train their employes for better-paying city posts. Letters to this effect are expected to be sent to department heads this week.

In spite of Heavyweight Champion James J. Braddock's insistence it must have been "two other guys," the United States Marshal's office in Newark, N. J., declared last night he had been served with papers in Madison Square Garden's suit to prevent his fighting Joe Louis in Chicago on June 22.

With what is probably the strongest field ever assembled ready for action, the world's professional pocket billiard championship will be launched tomorrow night in a new amphitheatre built especially for the occasion at Ponzi's Academy on the sixteenth floor of the Bond Building, 163 West Fortysixth Street.
From the liquor that thirsty Americans consumed in 1935, the treasuries of the States that legalize the sale of alcoholic beverages derived a total revenue of $319,954,928.82.

The War Department ordered army engineers today to re-blaze the route followed by General Stephen W. Kearny in 1846-47 on his historic march from Fort Leavenworth to help wrest California from the Mexicans.
Visions of an endless stream of government employes crossing the eight-and-one-quarter-mile bay bridge free-while everybody else pays 50 cents a trip-worried the State Toll Bridge Authority today.

Revision of the Federal Social Security Act to provide more substantial benefits in the early years of its administration was recommended yesterday by the Non-Partisan Social Security Commission under sponsorship of the Hearst newspapers.

Foreign Minister Julio Alvarez del -Vayo said today he knew that sentiment in the United States was overwhelmingly in favor of the Spanish Republic. He made the remarks in accepting a Red flag presented by Sam Barton of New York in behalf of the Socialist party of America.

AN entirely new series of current postage stamps will be issued by Canada on April 1. These are non-commemorative and will carry the portrait of King George VI, all stamps being of the same design. The first values to appear will be the 1c green, the 2c brown and the 3c red. The 4c bistre, 5c blue and 8c orange denominations will be issued at a later date.
Greenwich House Music School will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Naughty Naught ('00)" the night of April 12 at the American Music Hall.

The 320-acre Elisha Waterman estate, on which is an eighteen-room house, on Colchester Road, near Norwich, Conn., and considered one of the largest dairy farms in New London County, has been purchased by Dr. K. J. Danziger of New York City.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 25: REAR ADMIRAL DuBose, W. G.. to duty as chief of Bureau of Construction and Repair, Washington, D. C., March 25:
The National Coffee Department will combat increases in the price of coffee, it was stated this afternoon by Jayme Guedes, president of the department.
Michigan stirred up a tidal wave in the University of Minnesota pool tonight and rode its crest to the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championship.

Miss Mary F. Leiper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Leiper of Chestnut Hill, was married today to C. Paul Denckla, a. Haverford graduate, member of clubs and sportsman, in a magistrate's office here.

THE Boston Symphony will give its last pair of concerts of the season at Carnegie Hall Thursday evening and Saturday afternoon. At the matinee performance the orchestra will be assisted by the Harvard Glee Club and Rulon Y. Robison, tenor.
Captain Harry Andrews of the Melbourne (Fla.) Sailing Club guided the newly built Moth type boat Blue Goose to victory today in a race for the world championship Anonia Trophy.

Attention of Bryn Mawr College students will be focused during the next five weeks upon social and economic conditions in present-day England through addresses, seminars and special lasses in connection with the Spring lecture series under the Anna Howard Shaw Memorial Foundation.

By the disaster in New London, Texas, through which hundreds of school children were killed in a gas explosion, attention is focused on American educational institutions of a recently developed and unusual type, the consolidated schools. Of them the ruined building was typical. In fact, the "Lone Star State" has the largest number of such schools in the Union.
A program of monologues and music will be presented under the auspices of the New York Women's Auxiliary Bible Society on the morning of April 26 in the ballroom of the Pierre.

TWO elder statesmen are included among Britain's more illustrious unemployed. Both these statesmen are devoting to literature those powers of expression which used to be consecrated to the perorations of politics.
Some striking changes in fields of student concentration at Radcliffe College in the year 1935-36 were revealed in the report of Mrs. Frances R. Jordan, dean of the college.

The existence of a bandit-controlled and convict-operated outlaw "State" encroaching on the territories of three important South American countries has grown in the last few days from the status of "bush rumors" traveling circuitously down the hinterland trails to an established fact.

An impetus unremarked by all but a few is carrying this country rapidly toward a reckoning on its population problems, Dr. Louis I. Dublin predicted yesterday. Vast social changes already impressed on the lives of average American women by the trend will be accelerated, he added, during the next generation, when population will have become stationary and then by all indications, begun to recede.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Emory Robertson of Cambridge have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Lee Henry Robertson, to Willard Goldsmith Rouse Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. W. G. Rouse of Easton, Md., which will take place on April 2 at Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here.

James J. Kenny, recently a copycutter in The World-Telegram composing room and formerly chairman of The Evening Telegram chapel of "Big Six" and assistant foreman of that paper's composing room, died yesterday at his home, 660 Riverside Drive, after a long illness, at the age of 61.

Nine men in crinoline will perform a dance feature at an entertainment to be given tomorrow evening at the Englewood Women's Club, under the direction of husbands of members. Supper dancing will follow at the clubhouse, formerly a conservatory of music, which was opened last month. Mrs. Lois Havrilla is in charge of arrangements.

THIS afternoon at 3 o'clock New York's only dance theatre will open its doors when the Dance Center of GluckSandor and Felicia Sorel takes up its life again, after an interval of four years, in its new home at 117 West Fifty-fourth Street.

IT is impossible to remain angry at the screen for long. Last week we had nothing but re proaches for it; this week there has been little but appreciation. Entertainment stock has been soaring and the canny filmgoer can attribute it to the fact that he is able to buy in an international market.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Bean of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Bean, to Robert Christian Lang, son of Henry Lang of Gillette, N. J., formerly of Newark, and the late Mrs. Lang.

After failing in seven previous starts this Winter, the 5-year-old gelding Chance Ray sprang a surprise today at Tropical Park when he proved a handy winner of the Coral Gables Spring handicap before 10,000 spectators.
Sharp contrast in exhibits, from the conventional to the bizarre, distinguishes the sixteenth annual Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries from its predecessors in the annual series.

Commodore George V. Smith of the American Yacht Club of Rye, N. Y., and William L. Crow, race chairman, yesterday announced the dates of that organization's cruise. The event, only a few years old, has come to be one of the most popular yachting events, and this time there are to be four squadron runs instead of three.

In one of the most exciting games ever played here the Springfield Indians tonight gained the right to meet the Philadelphia Ramblers for the Eastern division title of the International-American Hockey League by defeating the Providence Reds in a furious scrap before a packed house. 5-4.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 24, aggregated $10,451,000,000, or 4 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 35 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Barringer High of Newark successfully defended its New Jersey interscholastic fencing championship by capturing the annual title meet at Panzer College today. Barringer, which has held the crown since the event was inaugurated, scored 20 points.

All bu?? 650 shares of the recent issue of 100,000 shares of JohnsManville Corporation common stock were subscribed for by stockholders at $100 a share, Lewis H. Brown, president, said at the annual meeting on Friday, in reply to a question by Colonel B. F. Castle, a stockholder.

ON the invisible wave lengths criss-crossed through space as their far-flung checkerboard the radio showmen make numerous shifts in their program game during this week and next. April calls for new moves and new songs in a way that erases the general pattern of the Winter shows, providing lighter melodies for the dance of Spring.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Andrew Ryan of Coconut Grove, Fla., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Jean Ryan, to Spelman Prentice, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice of this city and Williamstown, Mass.

TWO of our smaller theatres, the Mercury and the Gate, have produced the most in teresting plays of the past week-one, "The Ascent of F. 6" by W. H. Auden and Christopher Isherwood proceeding from the extreme theatrical Left; the other, "Out of Sight," a narrative of an English convict prison, being by Leslie and Sewell Stokes, the authors of a play about Oscar Wilde which lately aroused and deserved discussion.

The boarrd of design of the World's Fair has formulated plans for its part in the annual exhibition of the Architectural League, which will e opened to the public April 22 at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Bobby Jones of Atlanta and Ed Dudley of Augusta scored a 1-up best-ball victory over Horton Smith of Chicago and Paul Runyan of White Plains, N. Y., today in practice rounds for the $5,000 Augusta national tournament next week.

A choice private home development in which the houses will range from $15,000 to $18,000 is being started in Montclair, N. J., by the newly formed building firm of Hinck Brothers, composed of Ernest C. Hinck Jr. and Edwin B.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company of Chicago, a parent company, reported today net income of $2,098,413 for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, last, against $2,143,791 in the preceding twelve months.

India's new Constitution is running into snags. B. C. Kher, leader of the Congress party and first Premier-designate for Bombay Province, has declined to form a government. He issued a statement saying the Governor of Bombay, Lord Brabourne, had declined to give the assurance contemplated in a resolution adopted by the All-India Congress Committee.
The cold weather of the past week decidedly dimmed the prospects of those who had hoped for a pleasant warm spell, prior to the opening of the trout season in New York State on Saturday.

Mrs. George Lane, Mrs. Albert Fishburn and Mrs. Nathaniel P. Davis have been named delegates to the D. A. R. Congress to be held in Washington. Mrs. Volney Brundage, vice State regent, will give a report on the Walter Hines Page Chapter.
The funeral services for William J. Wollman, stock broker and philanthropist, will be held at 2:30 P. M. today in the chapel of Temple Emanu-El, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

The School in the Forest, a unique educational enterprise sponsored by the Buffalo Museum of Science, will begin its eleventh year in Allegany State Park on July 4. Advance registrations indicate that the school will have a greater -enrollment in. 1937 than in any of its previous years.

Although the weather, to which the Insurgent command attributes the frustration of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's offensive on the Guadal?? jara front, has improved greatly, there has been no renewal of important operations there yet.

Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman is honorary chairman and Mrs. Leo Sulzberger active chairman of the Greater New York Woman's Division of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee which is aiding in the 1937 campaign of the organization to raise $372,000 for the relief and rehabilitation of needy Jews in Europe.
Colorful processions and the singing of Easter hymns marked the celebration today of the resurrection of Christ.
The fifth annual dance of the Veritas Unit of the Catholic Students Mission Crusade, of which Miss Kathleen Fleming is president, will be held April 10 at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

A record for "radio code" communication over long distances with low electrical power was claimed yesterday by Eric Palmer Jr., a Brooklyn amateur, who reported completing a two-way contact, emplaying a home-made transmitter of seven-watt power, with an amateur radio man in South Australia.

The Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor, 140 West Sixty-first Street, will be the beneficiaries of a supper dance to be held on April 9 in the Sapphire Room, 151 East Fiftyseventh Street, under the auspices of the Junior Friends of the Sick Poor.

Although the potential production capacity of a number of important industries actually decreased during 1936, the extensive construction and machinery programs undertaken by most companies this year will eliminate any possibility of a shortage of manufacturing facilities in most lines of merchandise, according to reports yesterday by trade associations, construction engineers and machine-tool builders.

The Metropolitan Opera completed its season yesterday as successfully as it began fourteen weeks ago. Capacity audiences heard a matinee performance of "Lohengrin" and an evening presentation of "Traviata."

Mrs. Osa Johnson learned yesterday from physicians that the injury to her knee received in the airplane crash on Jan. 13 in which her husband, Martin Johnson, was killed will not keep her permanently from carrying on the explorations which she had shared with her husband.
With Irby Wright pitching masterfully all the way, the University of North Carolina nine opened its season today by beating Springfield College, 4 to 1, before 2,000 fans.

ISOBEL STRONG hesitated about going to Samoa with her mother and stepfather. She was devoted to her family, but she had her own life; and both in Honolulu and in Sydney she had made herself happy, independent, and at home-against bewildering odds in Sydney, and in both places with vigor and buoyancy,

Students who have entered Barnard College in the last few years appear to be more experienced in the use of the library, according to a report presented yesterday by Miss Bertha L. Rockwell, librarian. Miss Rockwell attributes this gain in exprience to the high schools.

One and two family dwellings and apartment houses are among properties in Brooklyn reported sold by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn. Robert D. Barker, in charge of realty sales for the bank, said he had received bids for numerous other parcels in the borough.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-The movement recently launched by the Palm Beach officials and the Chamber of Commerce to "stay through April," and the unbroken succession of pleasant days of the last fortnight are apparently affecting the colony, for three-fourths of its members are planning to remain another month.

MANY years have passed since first Sir James Frazer became interested in the curious tradition of the King of the Wood, the priest of Diana at Lake Nemi "who slays the slayer, and must himself be slain."

Mrs. Beverley G. Mills of sunny Crest Orchards, Kinderhook, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Frances Lewis Gifford, to George L. Cummings of this city, son of Noah Cummings of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Louise M. Cummings.

Preliminary estimates by the National Board of Fire Underwriters put the 1936 fire loss 17 per cent above the final loss estimates for 1935, reports Curtis W. Pierce, vice president of the Continental Insurance Company.

Last year the Dodgers went through an entire season trying vainly to win four straight games. Eleven times they reached that barrier and just as often came a cropper. But the Grapefruit League is different.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were fewer than in the preceding comparable period. The calling of several large issues of public utility bonds was the feature of the week's calls.
The newly constructed Daniel Shays Highway past her lonely farmhouse in this town, over which New York buses now travel, gave Mrs. Luther H. Shattuck opportunity to satisfy a life-long ambition.

Economic and efficient methods have made the railways the lowest cost producers of man-made transportation in existence today, Dr. C. S. Duncan, economist of the Association of American Railroads, said in a recent address before the Pacific Railway Club of San Francisco.
The Democratic Governors of Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana and South Carolina, broadcast tonight a joint endorsement of President Roosevelt's bill to reorganize the Federal judiciary.

Crocuses stay closed on cloudy days; if today is bright those at Brooklyn Botanic Garden will make their Easter display. They will be found in the rock garden and strewn about the lawn. In the rock garden are, among others, Cloth of Gold and Crocus Korolkowii, the latter from the Black Sea region.
BROADS-HREISLER-Mr. Harry Kreisler of 100 Highland Av., Yonkers, N. Y., announces the engagement of his daughter, Carol, to Ralph D. Broads, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Broads of Yonkers.
Students in a wood-carving class at St. Mark's Episcopal Church will put their training into practice by making carvings for the new $40,000 church the parish is to build.
The silver anniversary dog show of the Mississippi Valley Kennel Club opened at the Arena today with an entry of 673 dogs, an increase of 125 over last year, representing forty-five breeds.

Miss Margaret Helen Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alva Johnston, was married here tonight at the home of her parents in Sherbrooke Park to Norman William Erlandson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil W. Erlandson of Arlington, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Edward C.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Kelley of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Kelley, to Clifford Hanwell, son of Mrs. Richard Hanwell of Montclair, formerly of East Orange, and the late Mr. Hanwell.

Savings bankers and trustees representing more than $10,100,000,000 deposited by 14,500,000 owners, will attend the annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, to be held here from April 28 to 30, inclusive.

Business boomed today at one of two main produce distribution markets here after some commission merchants had signed articles ending a one-day strike of produce handlers. Strikers continued to picket the Niagara - Terminal, but several trucks passed through the blockade.

The Tata Iron and Steel Company of British India is planning to erect a new blast furnace, a section mill for medium sizes, a strip, hoop and rod mill, and a semi-continuous wide-strip mill at its Jamshedpur plant, which will raise the annual ingot capacity to 1,250,000 tons.

Taking a cue from classical tradition, Hunter College will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary of student self-government with a school-wide silver jubilee Olympics festival to be held throughout April and May.
Wellington Vandeveer, a sophomore at Williams College, today was selected to manage the college glee club in his senior year as the result of a half year competition, just completed.

Among the varied functions with which the Securities and Exchange Commission is charged, that of looking after the safety and welfare of the investor is, of course, basic. Falling within this category is the prescribing of duties, powers and obligations of trustees under corporate bonds, mortgages and collateral trusts, commonly designated as corporate trust indentures.

In looking over his catalogues and reading the directions for planting seeds and bulbs, the amateur gardener frequently finds himself puzzled as to just when the plants should be started in order to obtain the best results.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Douglas C. Kahn of 545 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shirley Audrey Kahn, to Alfred March, also of this city.

The world's leading authorities in artificial fever, one of the most spectacular discoveries of modern medicine, will meet for the first time to discuss the latest discoveries in the field at the opening here tomorrow morning of the First International Conference on Fever Therapy.

BELIEVING that our American traditions and ideals need to be restated and reinterpreted in the light of new economic and social conditions, Harper's Magazine offers a prize of $1,000 for the best article on "The American Way" submitted before Sept. 15, 1937.

Final arrangements, which include plans for an "Ego Contest"-the time-honored popularity contest in a new guise-are being made for the Bassinet dinner dance in aid of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, which will take place on Friday in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador. The dance will be featured also by a program of divertissements by well-known entertainers.
The Giants encountered everything from chilblains to frostbite today as they grappled the Indians in the third game of their Spring series and strove heroically to keep warm.

LONDON. WHILE wars and rumors of wars are occupying so much prominent newspaper space day by day, one might have hoped that the world of letters. at any rate, would be enjoying uninterrupted peace and quietness.

OF Akiba, born about A. D. 50 and martyred about 132, a writer in the Jewish Encyclopedia says that "a full history, based upon authentic sources, will probably never be written, although he, to a degree beyond any other, deserves to be called the father of rabbinical Judaism."

AN entertaining divertissement has been produced at the Rene Gimpel Galleries, 2 East Fiftyseventh Street. The curtain is up and will not descend until April 5. They call it the Foire de Montparnasse, 1920, and the thespians whose attainments adorn the walls prove sometimes well known, more often performers in the gargantuan Comedie Moderne whose names have not yet become enwreathed in international renown.
Mrs. Robert Oldner Deyer of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ingram Deyer, to John Farrel Hughes, son of John Hughes, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Hughes.

The marriage of Miss Bertha E. Straus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Straus of this city, to Richard A. Page, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Page of North Branford, Conn., will take place in the Grand Avenue Congregational Church on April 3.

Joseph Wellington Shannon, an attorney, died today at his home here after an illness of three weeks. He was 70 years old. Mr. Shannon was a native of Bloomsburg and was educated at Danville Academy, Trinity Hall, Washington, Pa., and Trinity College, Hartford, Conn.

Mrs. Charlotte D. Hemingway of New York City and Mrs. Marjorie D. Rossiter of South Orange, N. J., are the principal heirs of the estate of their father, William H. Dunn, retired shoe manufacturer, who died here Tuesday.

A perpetual membership in the New York Society of Military and Naval Officers of the World War will be conferred on Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, wartime commander of New York's Twentyseventh Division, at the seventeenth annual reception and dinner of the society to be held April 7 at the Ritz-Carlton.

Aroused by complaints against drugging of horses, the government switched its fight against narcoticsto the field of horse racing yesterday. Warrants were issued here for two race track men and within a few hours one of them was arrested in San Antonio, Texas.

The tension in Anglo-Italian relations has perceptibly lessened over the week-end, and it is reported this is due to the fact that the British Cabinet at its meeting last Wednesday had before it an intimation from Italy that not only would no more troops be sent to Spain but in the not distant future Italy would be prepared to discuss withdrawal of foreign volunteers already fighting in that country.

THE National Symphony Orchestra has received $100 from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in its campaign to raise $110,000 for next season. Mrs. Roosevelt was hostess to the National Symphony Orchestra on the only occasions that a symphony orchestra has been heard in the White House.
Henry Pegram, the British sculptor who designed the great bronze candelabra in St. Paul's Cathedral here, died yesterday at his home in Hampstead. He was 74 years old.

A warning that the present building activity indicates the possibility of a building boom in the near future is voiced by Harold J. Rosen of the Rosen Construction Company. He calls attention to the urgent need for some definite method of control to preserve real estate stability and prevent a recurrence of the disasters following the speculative overbuilding period immediately prior to 1929.
Dr. and Mrs. Rufus Cole of 790 Park Avenue and Mount Kisco have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Hegeler Cole, to Alton Childs.

Dr. Laurence B. Chenoweth, Professor of Hygiene at the University of Cincinnati, declared today that better dietary and living conditions were making the present generation taller and sturdier than its predcessors.

MONOPOLY: Of Labor In the midst of fervent discussion always accorded any plan to control monopolies there is apparent danger that students of economics are ignoring a festering monopoly in the supply of labor.

The annual Easter holiday junior dance attracted 150 members of the younger set, home from colleges and schools, at the Milbrook Country Club tonight. Mrs. Curtis Sanford was chairman, assisted by Miss Jeanette Diefendorf, Miss Dorothy Baldwin, Miss Muriel Putnam, Miss Jane Creighton, also Galen Merrill, Harry Timmins and Daniel Bradley. The patronesses included Mrs.

Persons interested in the work of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children have arranged a special performance of "Miss Quiz" for the night of April 13 at the Henry Miller Theatre for the benefit of the organization.

THAT robin redbreast of rumors, the perennial about Katharine Cornell capitulating at last to the movies, popped up during the week gone by with just a shade more authenticity than usual. Beatrice Kaufman, Goldwyn story editor in the East, is now in Hollywood reporting to Samuel Goldwyn on conversations she has been having here in the last few weeks with Miss Cornell.

The Senators shut out the Cardinals, 2 to 0, today, winning their eighth straight exhibition game. Monte Weaver and Pete Appleton contributed air-tight pitching and only one Cardinal got as far as second base.

Miss Marion Elizabeth Hobbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Hobbs of Bronxville, N. Y., has chosen April 16 as the date for her marriage to Dr. Herbert H. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Smith of Brookline, Mass.

" Fish is cheap! Fish is cheap!" the dealers in Park Avenue market call to their customers, and they are right. For as milder weather creeps up the Atlantic Coast, and fishing smacks and fishermen follow in its wake, the fresh supply that enters New York City is growing in quantity and quality.'

The sacrifice of the lives of 455 school children and teachers in the London Consolidated School in Rusk County is a terrible price to pay to insure greater safety in the installation of equipment and in the heating of schools with gas.

New York City's population has gone "forum conscious." Its sidewalk controversialists, from the East Side's Seward Park to uptown Columbus Circle, have surrendered to the more comfortable but equally informal surroundings of forum centers established in neighborhood clubs, union halls and churches by WPA and the Board of Education. The Bowery is represented with its Y. M. C. A.; Central Park West with its Ethical Culture School forum.

The Class of 1929 of Fordham University will hold its annual dance on Saturday at the Hotel Plaza. Paul B. Carroll is chairman of the committee, which includes John F. Fitzsimons, Thomas J. Flattery, Joseph S. Murphy, Robert J. Purtell and Dr. Thomas Mulcahv.
The fourth anniversary of Thrift House, 7 East Fifty-seventh Street, one of the largest charity rummage shops in New York, will be celebrated with a bundle party on May 4 at the Commodore.

The marriage of Miss Doris Helen Symons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George K. Symons of Riverview Community, to Harold A. Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Mitchell of Jersey City, took place tonight at the Pompton Plains Reformed Church.

The problem of refugees from Germany in the various countries of Europe has been under discussion by leaders in organizations engaged in aiding these victims of Nazi persecution, it was announced yesterday by the Joint Distribution Committee.

Many educators have Joined a campaign, started by the Transcription Supervisors Association, to raise the standards of commercial education in the schools. This association is an organization of supervisors of transcribing, stenographic and typing departments of various business concerns throughout the city.

Delicate and undernourished children from the city streets who are given care and healthful surroundings at Save-a-Life Farm at Marydell, Nyack, N. Y., will be aided by a garden bazaar and bridge to be held the afternoon of April 8 at Sherry's.

Miss Kathleen Inez Lea, daughter of Mrs. Charlotte Howard Lea of Virginia, and the late Samuel D. Lea, was married today at noon to Dr. Luther Austin Heydon, son of Mrs. Eca C. Heydon of this city, and the late Dr. Clark A. Heydon.
The last two winners of the Hambletonian, top classic of harness racing, will meet in the feature trot of the New York State Fair's grand circuit meeting Sept. 5 to 11.

MANHATTAN Estate, less than $10,000. To Emily Amson and Blanche Eda Amson, sisters, executors, 161 W. 75th St., equal shares in residue. COLLETTE, FLORA L. (March 18). Estate, less than $5,000. To Nelson F. Collette, husband, executor, Minneapolis, Minn., life estate; Luclle Collette, daughter, 11 W. 69th St., remainder interest.

An ex-national amateur champion and .the man he defeated in the final round of the Metropolitan amateur event at Lido last year share a place at the top of the M. G. A.'s annual honor roll, released yesterday, with a veteran and a youngster who holds the State crown.

The holiday week just completed witnessed nervous security markets. Stock and bond prices moved in uncertain fashion, while commodities were generally firm. Trading in securities, however, was comparatively light. Industrial labor troubles contributed importantly to the unsettlement in securities, and the general topic of "inflation" received increasing attention.
The University of North Carolina tennis team made it two in a row over Yale today, blanking the Elis for the second consecutive day, 10-0.

Responding to a request for unrestricted funds, which Harvard can use in emergencies and for educational experimentation, a record number of 8,883 alumni last year contributed a total of $258,087 to the Harvard Fund, it was reported today by David T. W. McCord, '21, executive secretary of the fund.

The Hapag Lloyd Line announced yesterday the retirement on Thursday of Jacob Krive, who has served as landing agent in this port for twenty-eight years. Mr. Krive arrived in New York in 1906 from Odessa where he had been engaged in the steamship business, and became a member of the landing staff of the Hamburg American Line.

An inspired press campaign has begun here based on Japan's refusal to limit her naval guns to 14 inches. This decision, revealed recently in these dispatches, is attributed to a belief that Britain, in proposing the limitation, was trying, in collusion with the United States, to entrap Japan into a position of permanent naval inferiority.

NEVER before has feminine expression in interior decoration been so significant and widespread. It is true that in eighteenth - century France women were a powerful influence in the man-made decoration of rooms. but today they are doing much of the actual professional designing of fine interiors.

The government tonight ordered National Guard companies and the Sixty-fifth Infantry Regiment to remain "on the alert" in their barracks tonight because of reports that Nationalists planned independence demonstrations tomorrow.

The first world textile conference, sponsored by the International Labor Organization, will open a fortnight of deliberations here on April 2 for the purpose of discussing the possible stabilizatio of the textile

The annual supper dance under the auspices of the Almoners will be held on April 23 at Sherry's for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital. In charge of the arrangements are Mrs. Girard S. Wittson, Mrs. Francis Quillinan,

ONCE upon a time, long before Errol Flynn ever heard of Hollywood or thought of being an actor, he bought a little sailing ship. He was a roving young adventurer who had had a bit of luck with a gold claim in New Guinea just when his fortunes seemed to be at their lowest ebb

Catholic Young Women's Club-Tea dance, 4 P. M., clubhouse. Junior Guild of St. Mary's Hospital (Passaic, N. J.)-Tea dance, Jabberwock Club, West Orange.

Contributions of such articles as books, pictures, clothes, incomplete sets of china and glass, toys and bric-a-brac will be received by members of a junior committee headed by Miss Anne DeWitt Pell at the performances of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "The Grand Duke; or, The Statutory Duel," which will be given by the Blue Hill Troupe on April 7, 8 and 9 at the Heckscher Theatre.

Speaker Oswald D. Heck's personal budget was $8 out of balance tonight. Mr. Heck, who with other legislative leaders will confer Tuesday with Governor Lehman on the million-a-day State budget which they say is unbalanced by $40,000,000, reported to police that a "dime bank" containing $8 was stolen from his home last night.
Miss Marion Miley, star amateur campaigner from Lexington, Ky., defeated Miss Babe Didrikson, Beaumont, Texas, professional, 6 and 4, to win the seventh Augusta invitation golf tournament today.

During the Easter lull in German journalism, with Dr. Joseph Goebbels's Propaganda Ministry and other sources of official information closed for four days, two Berlin newspapers printed today symposiums on how best to safeguard the peace of Europe.

The 100th anniversary of the birth of John Burroughs, poet and naturalist, will be observed with a memorial meeting on Saturday evening in the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

Miss Helen Aust, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Aust of Zion, N. J., was married to Herbert E. Hundley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hundley of South Orange, this evening in the Presbyterian Church of Hillside by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John A. MacSporran.

Mr. and Mrs. Luther B. Anthony of Easton, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Sutherland Anthony, to John Thomas Carlisle Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., son of John Thomas Carlisle of Cincinnati and the late Mrs. Carlisle.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Vinton Parker Wilkinson of Silverholm, Little Silver, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Parker Wilkinson, to William James Hardiman, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cleveland Hardiman of Watertown, N. Y.

After four days of negotiations Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, were still deadlocked early this morning in their battle over the open versus the closed shop.

Alfred H. Haag, acting director of the division of research of the United States Maritime Commission, urged a comprehensive ship replacement program for the American merchant marine in an address broadcast last night by Station WBBC of the Brooklyn Broadcasting Corporation.

Miss Ebba C. Hartten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey F. Hartten, and Rufus King Weeks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Weeks of Elizabeth, will be married on April 24 in St. Lupke's Episcopal Church, Roselle.
The Catholic Boys Brigade of the United States will benefit from a supper dance to be held April 16 in the roof garden of the Hotel Pierre under the chairmanship of Miss Elizabeth Appenzellar.

Honus Wagner, high commissioner of the semiprofessional baseball congress, announced the appointment today of three former major league managers who will select the outstanding young ball player of 1937.

ORGANIZED labor as represented by the Committee for Industrial Organization today is Big Business and its leaders are becoming Big Business Men. They have millions of dollars at their command through the collection of initiation fees, dues and special assessments from hundreds of thousands of workers in mass industries and they use these vast resources of capital to expand into one industry after another.

THERE is every reason why MacLeish should say that "any one interested in the probable future direction of American poetry will do well to give thoughtful and appreciative attention to his [Archibald Fleming's] work."
The Securities and Exchange Commission again is considering possible steps for greater control over customers' men.

The revised uniform system of accounts for electric utilities and that for gas utilities which the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners recommended for adoption at their annual convention at Atlantic City in November has been published by the State Law Publishing Company of 30 Vesey Street, official reporter of the association.

Miss Jeanne Price, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence V. Price of this place, has completed plans for. her wedding on April 15 to A..Richardson Goodlatte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Goodlatte of Upper Montclair. The ceremony will take place at the Price home .in the presence of relatives and a few friends. The Rev. Lindsay S. B. Hadley of Cortland, N. Y., cousin of the brideelect, will officiate.
TRAVELER: Reports circulated last week that the man who last year "took a walk" was this year going to take a voyage.

THE title of Professor Haper's latest volume has been not inappropriately chosen, for its is rarely that one encounters a collection of eassys filed with such warm and yet discriminating literary appreciation.

When it comes to culinary concoctions, it is none of those fancy dishes with the even fancier names that win a husband's approval, but the plain old American dinners such as meat loaf, salmon loaf, baked ham and barbecued chicken, according to six of the nation's best cooks.

Champion Pillicoc Rumpelstiltskin, striking black standard poodle, owned by the Pillicoc Kennels of Mrs. Milton Erlanger of Elberon, N. J., and handled by Henry Stoecker, was awarded the highest honors tonight at the conclusion of the eighth annual bench show of the Manchester Kennel Club.

The Fenway Millionaires were grouped in chairs on the terrace of their hostelry here when out through the front door came Al Schacht wearing an "ice cream" suit, as Professor Moe Berg called it. And Professor Berg added:

The twenty-three-story loft structure at 59-65 West Thirty-ninth Street, northeast corner of Sixth Avenue, will be sold in foreclosure on Friday in the Vesey Street rooms by Henry Brady. The plot is 100 feet on the street and 98.9 feet on Sixth Avenue.

Representative Benjamin K. Focht of Lewisburg, Pa., died at Emergency Hospital here tonight. He was 74 years old. Hospital attendants said Mr. Focht was brought to the hospital in a taxicab and was dead upon arrival. He was stricken while dining at a hotel.

A recent suggestion by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. that the law permitting judges to commit mental detectives to the State Institution for Mental Delinquents at Napanoch, Ulster County, might be used in cases involving sexual crimes against children was sharply decried on Friday by County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn.

Thirteen hundred Boy Scouts, trained by Indians for such an emergency, made an organized search today for Robert W. Miller, missing 23-year-old Scout executive. Officers feared that he had been killed by a hitch-hiker.

THE second annual safety and economy test run conducted by Chevrolet under the official sanction of the American Automobile Association contest board has been completed after a 10,000-mile tour around the rim of the United States.

The near-end of the indoor swimming season will be marked next Sunday afternoon when three of the senior metropolitan championships will be held at the Women's Swimming Association. Most interest in the 500-yard free style race will center on two young ladies barely in their 'teens.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Miller of 210 West Ninetieth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alys-Pat Miller, to Howard A. Hirshfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hirshfield of Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif.

In a listless opening round of the National A. A. U. hockey championship, played before a very sparse crowd at the Boston Garden tonight, the Holzbaugh-Ford six of Detroit and the Boston Olympics survived and will meet tomorrow afternoon for the title.

Performances of the Mozart concerto in C minor, K. 491, and of Beethoven's G major concerto, were given by Myra Hess as soloist with the National Orchestral Association yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. In addition to these works Mr. Barzin led the orchestra in performances of Mozart's overture to "Cosi fan tutte" and Beethoven's "Fidelio" oyerture. The hall was packed for this occasion.

Exclusive of inter-company sales, business of stores and factories of Spencer Chain Stores, Inc., for the three months ended on Feb. 28, were $2,378,984, or 27 per cent correspondingly over 1935-36, the company reported yesterday. Store sales rose 35 per cent, reflecting the gain in their number from 54 to 58.
A 10-shilling New Zealand note arrived here as a belated response to a short-wave radio appeal for flood-relief funds.

Many newspapers, especially in the Danubian basin, have declared that the visit of Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, to Belgrade marks the decisive turning point in the political situation which has existed in Central Europe since the end of the World War.

Secretary of Agriculture Wallace will be among the speakers during a series of seven public meetings to discuss current social and po litical problems, beginning next Sunday, under the auspices of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

A revolutionary new process for extracting cellulose, one of the basic substances of modern civilization, from trees, plants and other products of the soil was demonstrated for the first time yesterday before a selected group of experts at the laboratory of the Island Lumber Company, 43-41 Thirty-second Place, Long Island City.
A dinner was given at the Mayflower Hotel tonight by Rear Admiral Robert Witthoeft-Emden, German Naval Attache.

The marriage of Miss Adele Justine Lay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Oscar Lay of this town, to John Geary Earl, son of Mrs. John C. Earl of Montclair, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

Westchester County's principal parkways will remain closed to automobile trailers this year despite mounting interest in that form of travel and regardless of the 600 current registrations of trailers in the county.

Reconstruction and modernization of outdated but latently valuable property virtually indicate the first stages of the building trades revival now underway as a part of the general business upturn throughout the country, points out Ely Jacques Kahn, chairman of the committee on allied arts of the American Institute of Architects.
Mr. and Mrs. A. P. Fairfield of Hanover, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Fairfield, to Emerson Day, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edmund E. Day of Bronxville, N. -Y.
Students will live in tents while attending the nature guide school to be opened at Massachusetts State College this Summer.

A Bible dictionary written by a Jewish scholar a thousand years ago, forgotten for eight hundred years and now published for the first time, clears the mystery of the Golden Calf and other disputed passages in the Old Testament and promises to settle many controversies long waged over cryptic wording in the English Revised Version.

NO city seen in our 2,500-mile journey from New York has preserved its historic sites as this one has. No need to shut your eyes to imagine the New Orleans of the past. You see it, rich in color, before your eyes as it has always been, made more romantic by bland and gracious decay; the deft, finishing touches of the master hand of Time.

Following Thursday's setback, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered 11 to 19 points yesterday under the influence of new high records in several commodity markets and few May contracts to supply mill demand.

The marriage of Miss Norma Bird of the Roosevelt, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Willard Bird, to Hale T. Shenefield of Toledo, Ohio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Shenefield of Pierceton, Ind., took place yesterday afternoon in Trinity Church.

Nome prepared today for a revival of its sports classic of gold days -- a twenty-six-mile dog sled race over the course which brought fame to many sons of the North.

The Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria was opened for the Spring season last night with a gala supper party for the benefit of the Opportunity Shop, which aids the support of several charitable organizations.

The Massachusetts Federation of Labor and the New England Committee for Industrial Organization tonight Questioned the good faith of Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell and six other Bostonians who demanded the government suppress sit-down strikes.
Weingarten Co. are opening a branch in the Wickersham Professional Building, 133 East Fifty-fifth Street. Estabrook Co. discuss the residential building industry in their current review.

Arizona newspapers gave notice today they will carry their fight against the 1 per cent sales tax on their gross income to the United States Supreme Court, having lost recently before the State's highest tribunal. Counsel for the American Newspaper Publishers Association will aid.

ONE of the first new apartment buildings to be erected in the Bronxville section of Westchester in several years is the Riverside, to be completed for Fall occupancy at Park View Avenue and Garrett Place, to accommodate eighty-two families.

Stocks closed steady and mixed; turnover, 531,590 shares, slowest trading since September. United States Government bonds rallied and closed higher, other loans mixed; transactions, $5,107,400.
Accidental discharge of a pistol being shown by playmates killed last night the 11-year-old son of a Federal public health officer.

PIONEERS are trekking into the ultra-short wave field in greater numbers now that the Federal Communications Commission has resumed issuing permit for new stations to operate in accordance with revised regulations.

After leaving Monte Carlo Casino, Mrs. George P. Wakefield, nee Sadie Baron of New York, told police she had lost a $15,000 necklace, comprising five large stones and sixty smaller ones.

WE are likely to remember for a long while, with delight, the present Spring season's opulent influx of nineteenth-century French art. No-table gallery events now on the list inlcude, of course, the superb Manet and Degas exhibitions, at Wildenstein's and the Durand-Ruel respectively, which no one can on any account afford not to visit.

With losses in four of its components and gains in three, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended March 20 receded to 106.6 from 106.9. It was 89.9 for the week ended March 21, 1936.

Among the leading field-trial events for pointers and setters in the Eastern section is the annual meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club, scheduled for April 10, 11 and 12, at Clinton, N. J. Four stakes will be contested: Open shooting dog, open all-age, open junior all-age and open Spring derby.

AT least ten "master points" issued by the American Bridge League are a prerequisite to entrance in that league's tournament for individuals and for teams of four which begins April 5 at the Park Central Hotel. The American Bridge League has been issuing these master points since 1934, and they have been very popular. A rivalry has developed among the leading players as to which can amass the greatest total of master points.

ASBURY PARK, Belmar and other North Jersey coast resorts are soon to bid for greater patronage from the PhiladelphiaCamden areas. Route 40, the Philadelphia-Camden-Monmouth County express highway, will give them the first modern highway direct from the lower Delaware River to the ocean.
Behind the five-hit pitching or Bill Calley, the Wake Forest nine opened its campaign by turning back Drexel Institute of Philadelphia, 4-3, today.

City College gave New York its first taste of college baseball this season as its varsity outscored the alumni, 9-2, in a jolly, carefree meeting at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The snappy Spring day brought out about 500 spectators for the eight-inning game.
Mrs. Harry C. Larter of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Susanne Larter, to Clarence Dickinson Long Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Dickinson Long of Fairfield, N. J.

Mrs. William J. Graham has taken over the Sapphire Room for a luncheon and bridge to be held Wednesday for the benefit of the Christ Child Society of New York. For twenty-five years the society has supplied outfits to destitute babies in New York.
Called from a party celebrating his fifty-ninth birthday, Mayor Jasper McLevy at City Hall this afternoon ended the city's first sitdown strike.

A definite undertone of concern about Fall price structures and business activity runs through the regular monthly report on general business conditions drawn up yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Shifting cross-currents in wholesale price developments are receiving close attention from retailers, but the consensus is that firm to higher quotations will rule on most merchandise lines during the months directly ahead and that consumers will begin to- feel the brunt of price advances next Fall.

The Works Progress Administration stated in a report made public today that production of goods and services would have to be increased by 20 per cent this year over 1929 to reduce unemployment to the level prevailing in the latter year.

" Les Amis" was voted the name of the permanent organization composed of American volunteers who served in the United States Army as ambulance drivers, the Mallet Reserves, the Norton-Harjes and field service units in either French or Italian commands during the World War.
Representatives of the railways and their 117,000 employes ended a wage negotiation meeting here this afternoon without reaching a final agreement on their pay dispute.

Miss Anne Bowen Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bowen Edwards, was married today to Richard Inglis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Inglis Sr. of Cleveland, in Taggart Memorial Chapel at McDonough, near Baltimore.

The Communist and Socialist parties will again participate in a joint May Day parade in this city Alexander Hoffman, temporary secretary of the Provisional May Day Committee, 125 West Fogty-fifth Street, announced yesterday.

The Governor General of Canada and Lady Tweedsmuir will arrive here late Tuesday afternoon for an official visit to the President and Mrs. Roosevelt in return for the visit paid them by President Roosevelt last Summer and will be received with full official honors.

Mrs. George J. Ferry 3d is chairman of the Spring supper dance which has been arranged by the New York Mount Holyoke Club. The event will be held on Friday at the Women's University Club for members and their friends.

The executive board of the Department Store Employes Union will meet today at the union offices, 80 East Eleventh Street, to consider the tentative agreement worked out between officials of the group and the F. W. Woolworth Company on Friday.
Boxer-Tulgey Wood Kennels' Lustig von Dom of Tulgey Wood. Newfoundland-Waseeka Kennels' Ch. Waseeka's Sailor Boy. Old English Sheepdog-Mrs. G. B. Huxtable's Peerless Roddy Sol.

An eighty-three-acre tract of land near Boonton, N. J., has been purchased from the Ball estate for development by the Intervale Lake Corporation, Charles M. Weber, president. Plans and specifications are being made by the developers for the erection of approximately forty-five houses of four, five and six rooms, to sell under $6,000.
With the thermometer near the freezing mark, Swarthmore College lost its opening baseball game to the Penn A. C. today, 10 to 5. The game was called in the sixth inning by agreement.
The nation needs no packing of the Supreme Court, but it does need, "and needs very much,"-a new Attorney. General, said Senator Wheeler of Montana in an address before the City Club Forum today.
The sale by the Central Savings Bank of the five-story apartment house at 475 West Fifty-seventh Street was announced yesterday by William G. Kohler, broker in the deal.
The Silver Brook polo team of Red Bank triumphed over the Essex Troop trio, 17 to 12 1/2, tonight in the feature of Essex Troop Armory's final program of the season.
A total of 5,600 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware have filed applications for this Summer's Citizens Military Training Camps, it was announced yesterday at Governors Island.

The engagement of Miss Carolyn Bartow Sherwood, daughter of Mrs. Arthur C. Sherwood of Englewood, N. J., and the late Mr. Sherwood, to David Ives Mackie Jr., son of Mrs. David Ives Mackie of this city and the late Mr. Mackie, has been announced by her mother.

When the last race at Tropical Park is run next Saturday it is estimated that the total amount of money wagered at Florida's two tracks this Winter will approximate $30,000,000. It has been the most successful racing season since 1925.
An entertainment and party on behalf of the West Sixty-third Street Community House will be held the afternoon of April 7 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

A great deal of uneasiness has been created at the Capitol over the probable fate of a considerable volume of New York City legislation now pending by the ease with which a series of bills, not wanted by the La Guardia administration and affecting salaries and working conditions in the city-owned and operated subways, slipped through the Democratic Senate this week with feeble opposition by Republicans.
President Luis Companys of Catalonia appealed tonight to the people's "sense of cooperation" in asking workers' groups to have confidence in the utonomous State's new government.

IT was Novemoer, 1878. A little over two years before, the "Nibelung's Ring" had been given to the world. The event had upheaved the musical cosmos like nothing else in its history, and as times passed, its repercussions became, if anything, louder and more insistent instead of dutifully subsiding, according to the traditions of the average artistic' sensation.
