AS Ernest Hemingway points out in a slightly mannered preface, the youthful short story writer seldom gets a break. Unless he has first produced a novel, few publishers are inclined to gamble on a book of his tales.

Many rare specimens of early United States gold and silver coins, in addition to fine collections of the large copper cents and halfcents, will be sold at auction by Thomas L. Elder on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

Staging a smart recovery following yesterday's defeat at Chelsea, Charlton Athletic conquered the Wolverhampton Wanderers, 4-0, today to draw within one point of Arsenal, leading the English Football League.

Dartmouth's trackmen easily defeated William and Mary today, 101 to 24. Lesner gave William and Mary its one first place with a javelin throw of 173 feet 2 inches. Scoring double triumphs, Geniawicz, in the shot and discus; Donovan, in the low and high hurdles, and Johnson, in the 220 and 100 yard dashes, led the men from Hanover in their one-sided victory.

An educational experiment begun five years ago with a small group of students at Temple University, known as the "X" group, is to be made available to all freshmen in the division of secondary education, effective next Fall.

The New York Yankees, world champions, are even-money favorites this season to repeat their 1936 pennant victory in the American League, according to the odds quoted yesterday by Jack Doyle, Broadway betting commissioner.

Albert E. Relf, 62, once a famous English cricket player, was found shot to death today on the cricket grounds of the college where he had coached for twenty-five years. A groundsman discovered Relf's body in the cricket pavilion of Wellington College at Crowthorne. A pistol lay near by.

Miss Sally Naugle Clough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Ambrose Cough of this place, was married here this afternoon to Philip W. Banker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Banker of Cherry Valley, New York and Palm Beach, in the First Presbyterian Church, by the Rev. Carl Hopkins Elmore.

Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Horner announced today the marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth L. Horner, to John E. Beer, managing editor of The Newark (N. J.) Sunday Call. The ceremony took place on March 15 in the rectory of St. James Episcopal Church, Newark.
Winning an exciting race against time, the New Zealand eleven forced a draw in a three-day match against the Marylebone Cricket Club touring team today.

The annual report of the Boeing Airplane Company and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, showed unfilled orders of $8,921,797, a high record, at the end of the year, compared with $6,141,203 at the close of 1935. Additional orders totaling $2,655,148 were received in the first two months of 1937.

ANY historical consideration of the movie villain in his serene evolution from the anonymous Biograph days to the present would be incomplete without a parallel review of the moral obstetrics of the changing times. Tradition may have drawn his outlines, but the temper of each generation was the catalyst that sped his substance.

They still wash dishes in the old way-glasses first, then silver, then china-but they stack them on a tray as they are dried, ready to be carried into the pantry or back to the dining room. Thus by the methods in use in the training schools for household workers which the government provides through WPA channels, one manual operation is saved.

Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, reported yesterday that 6,166 passenger cars and trucks were sold in the first twenty days of March, against 5,287 in the same period of 1936, a gain of 17 per cent.
Inspired by bruising Babe Siebert, the Montreal Canadiens swept to a 3-1 triumph over the world champion Detroit Red Wings tonight and kept in the hunt for the National Hockey League title.

Mrs. Carl Eggers, who heads the executive committee for the special performance of "Die Meistersinger" Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House in behalf of the German-American Charities, Inc., has announced that many boxes and seats have been purchased for the benefit.

THE OLD BUNCH" is a landmark in the development of the realistic novel. A decade ago the lost generation was intensively cultivating its lostness; today the next generation, deprived of the anchors of sentiment and tradition and disconcerted by the depression, struggles desperately to grow roots.

British diplomacy has been preoccupied for the past week with complications on both the western and Mediterranean fronts that illustrate the difficulties Britain faces in framing anything more than a provisional and makeshift foreign policy--difficulties which are legacies of her hesitation and uncertainty and her consequent setbacks since 1935.
Northampton's Chamber of Commerce started an intensive campaign today to raise $10,000 before Monday to save the PropperMcCallum Hosiery Company for its 800 workers.

MANY in Britain as elsewhere find a certain irony in the fact that exactly seventeen years after the foundation of a League of Nations to insure peace and disarmament the rearmament of Great Britain on an unprecedented scale should be widely accepted as a reassurng sign.

The fiftieth annual production of the City College Dramatic Society, "Don't Look Now," an original musical revue, will be presented April 1, 2 and 3 as the Spring varsity show in the Pauline Edwards Theatre of the College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Canadian pulp and paper production figures for 1936, although they will not be ready for several months, probably will show that newsprint production alone will be valued for the year at more than $150,000,000, a 16 per cent gain over 1935, according to reports received today at the Department of Commerce from Leigh W. Hunt, Trade Commissioner in Ottawa.

Staged with the lavishness of a Broadway production, the first performance of the 1937 international figure skating carnival was presented last night before a gathering of 16,000 hat jammed Madison Square Garden.

The success of the government forces on the Guadalajara front was a demonstration of their power, discipline and skill. Since people everywhere have come to regard the Spanish civil war as primarily a struggle of foreign powers on Spanish soil,

With Italian Riviera activities again at their peak and all hotels crammed with tourists, the Municipal Casino of Bordighera has reopened, after many years' closure, with a mounting of "Madama Butterfly."
Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Flanigan of 51 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Wilson Flanigan, to Henry Ernest Blagden of Montclair, N. J.
The thoroughbreds will gallop for more than $350,000 in prize money during Washington Park's thirty-day season, May 24-June 26, Walter L. Gregory, president of the Jockey Club, announced today.

Miss Edith Lisle, 11-year-old rider from Glendale, L. I., turned in a fine performance to capture the Good Hands Cup test at the Metropolitan Equestrian Club's third one-day horse show at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx yesterday. Handling her mount in expert fashion.

Ontario's gold mines produced bullion to the value of $6,895,604 in February, according to the Ontario Department of Mines. This compares with $7,120,010 in January. In February 622,276 tons of ore were treated by all the mines in production and the average grade of ore treated was $11.81 a ton. In January 691,

Are the Republican voters of New York in favor of re-electing the nominally Republican Mayor of this overwhelmingly Democratic city? To find out, Robert L. Levis, Republican leader of the Eleventh Assembly District on the upper West Side, conducted a poll; 60 per cent of the 600 votes recorded last week were against Mayor La Guardia.
The John Marshall College of Law of this city is sponsoring another oratorical contest in which students in all New Jersey high schools are invited to participate.

From a tomb in a garden, found broken very early in the morning on the first day of the week, the way to the Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue is very long and roundabout. That we still celebrate the feast of Resurrection--on the sidewalks of New York, in the trenches of Spain, in a rivalry of zeal over the Sepulchre in Jerusalem-must signify something profound and important.' It does;
A THIRD album of songs by Ernst Wolff, self-accompanied, contains a cycle fashioned by Max Knowalski from twelve poems out of Giraud's "Pierrot Lunaire" (Columbia Masterworks 278).

Military training, one of the most important features in the social and scholastic life at the University of Maine, has a coast artillery unit, after being concerned exclusively with infantry since military drill was instituted in 1868.

THE title of this book of Wythe Williams's, written from his experiences as a correspondent in Europe of several newspapers and magazines from 1910 to 1935, signifies the decline of empire in that continent as a result of the World War and the opportunity of the United States to function as the most powerful nation in the world east and west.

THAT growing army of wheeled nomads who have taken to the house trailer on America's highways do not appear to be faced with any very serious problem of restrictive legislation, at least for this year.

Speaking of the growing popularity of trailers, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, says that the best informed opinion leans to the view that while trailers may take some people away from apartments and hotels, they bring people into the State who would not otherwise come, and as far as real estate is concerned, they are a net gain from nearly every point of view.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday its opposition to a bill pending in Albany which would authorize the creation of two "block plant" commissions with authority to issue certificates for establishment of electric and steam plants within a city block.

The Catholic Seamen's Institute Auxiliary, of which Mrs. John R. Oulton is president, will give a card party and dance on April 22 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. The Proceeds will be used to help the Rev. A. M. Rickert establish an institute for Catholic seamen in the Brooklyn diocese.

The South African Government has a five-year defense plan to make the country's defenses as up to date as any in the world. This is revealed by a special correspondent of The. Cape Argus in the first of a series or articles to which Defense Minister Oswald Pirow contributes a foreword.

In his annual report as rector of Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie declares that America's determination to keep out of war is the most hopeful. sign in international life today and suggests that the church play a creative part in these efforts.

J. P. Morgan's yacht Corsair went aground in the harbor today as she attempted to leave for the United States during ebb tide. She was floated during flood tide this evening and went to an anchorage for the night.

Since Vermont adopted old-age aid the data accumulated show that the State has a high percentage of elderly people. This may mean that people live longer in Vermont or that a higher percentage of the young people have left the State.

The LeBrun Traveling Scholarship of 1937, amounting to $1,400, has been won by Mathew Lapota of Maywood, Ill., in a national competition for the design of a college library. Announcement of the awards in the contest was made yesterday by Oliver Reagan, chairman of the LeBrun scholarship committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
New England industrialists are practicing a policy of voluntary concessions to prevent strikes. They seek to forestall "trouble" by increasing wages and liberalizing conditions.
George Gray, completing work on a World War mural in a Troy hotel, has been spurred on by the praise of General John Pershing, commander of the A. E. F.

A dinner under the auspices of the New York Club of the Alumnae of Mills College will be held at Sherry's April 7 to mark the eightyfifth anniversary of the founding of the college. The occasion also will inaugurate a campaign for endowment and alumnae funds.

The Supreme Court reorganization plan of the President has split the Democratic South wide open. The solidly Democratic Senatorial bloc from the Southern States is divided into three camps, one for the President's proposition, the second against it, and a third "on the fence."

In recent months there has been a gradual but fundamental change in the factors influencing bank credit, which has a direct bearing upon the prospects for inflation about which official warnings have lately been issued in Washington and which also is linked with the recent decline in the market for government securities.

IT is hard to believe that, even in a short-lived furor over a very young American so prano, even in the brief vinous enthusiasm of a public dinner. there could have been a belief that American singers had ever lacked recognition.

ADELMAN-Lillian (nee Biren), beloved wife of Samuel and devoted mother of Leonard and Gloria, devoted sister of David, Harry, Bertha Felder and Elsie Goldberg. Funeral services Sunday, 2:30 P. M., Riverside Chapel, 76th St.

A full-scale two-story house, designed and erected by Irwin S. Chanin, will be a feature of the sixteenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries opening tomorrow at Grand Central Palace.
Postmaster General Farley dedicated Wilmington's new $1,400,000 Federal building today and paid tribute to the postal force.

BROOKLYN COLLEGE April 7, St. Peter's, away; 10, Manhattan, away; 11, St. John's, away; 15, New York University, away; 17, Savage; 21, Newark University; 23, Long Island University; 24, Alumni; 28, Nassau C. C. May 1. St. John's; 4, Long Island University, away; 8, City College; 10, Manhattan; 12, City College, away; 15, Columbus Council K. of C.. away; 19, Panzer: 29, Fordham, away; 30, New York A. C.

Charles F. Goodrich, chief engineer of the concern that built the superstructure of the San Francisco Oakland Bridge, pointed out to a dinner of alumni of the Pratt Institute last night at 2 Park Avenue that the world's largest overwater span contained a sample of every type of bridge-making except the arch.
Postal inspectors today examined the commissions of recently appointed postmasters in Massachusetts to determine how many had been signed by Postmaster General Farley in "disappearing" ink.

In 1916 Charles Evans Hughes resigned as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court to become the Republican candidate for President; he returned to the Supreme Bench in 1930 as Chief Justice. To Mr. Hughes's place in 1916 President Wilson appointed John H. Clarke, who resigned in 1922 to gives his time to the cause of world peace.
A. J. Maxwell, commissioner of revenue for North Carolina, explains in a pamphlet just issued by that State, the success of the plan to provide more equitable tax conditions for real estate.

Four prizes will be awarded in the annual essay contest of Fordham College to be conducted among the entire student body, according to an announcement by the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University.
NEXT Saturday is opening day. From a mere cheerless abstract point of view this means only that on that date, April 3, it becomes lawful to catch trout in the streams of New York State.

DOES the New York fire man need brains more than brawn? The Municipal Civil Service Commission recently raised the question. James E. Finegan, its president, declared himself in favor of a high-school training or its equivalent for the city's firemen.

Twenty-five volunteers, all carrying United. States passports, on their way -to Spain, were captured today-by the French control boat Cerbere and are being detained for investigation. This is the first "capture" made since international control of the Spanish coast was set up.
The administration re-emphasized tonight a "hands-off" policy respecting the sit-down strike situation and indicated that it felt there was no cause for immediate concern.

A request has been presented to Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, by the National Association of Real Estate Boards, asking that the FHA make a national study to determine the needs of a central mortgage bank system in the United States.
Vice President Garner showed anew today his determination to keep to the line of official silence, long adhered to by occupants of his office.

AIKEN, S. C.-The Aiken sports calendar still contains many sports events of importance. The second of the three major horse shows held annually will be given Sunday, sponsored by the riding clubs of Fermata School. Eight classes will be judged, including a hack class for those who do not jump, a bareback riders' class and the class for former students of the school.

ABRAMS-BLUMENTHAL--Mrs. F. Blumenthal, 917 Avenue K. Brooklyn, announces the marriage of her daughter, Sylvia Z. Blumenthal, on Friday, March 26, to Mr. Irving R. Abrams. son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Abrams of Manhattan.
Governor Hoffman declared today that it was his intention to prevent in New Jersey what he described as "virtual anarchy" in Michigan.

Miss Teresita de Palau, daughter of Mrs. Julia de Palau of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late Conrad Palau, has selected April 8 as the date for her marriage to A. Bruce Crane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Crane, also of Bronxville. The ceremony will take place at noon in the rectory of St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, and will be followed by a wedding breakfast at the Hotel Gramatan.

MY INDIA. By Lillian Luker Ashby, with Roger Whately. 12mo. Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown Co. $3. Recollections of fifty Years. PRESENT IINDICATIVE. By Noel Coward. Svo. New York: Doubleday. Doran Co. An autobiography.

CHARLES BENNETT, screen author of "The Thirty-nine Steps," "The Man Who Knew Too Much," "Sabotage" (which is currently showing in this country under the highly original title of "The Woman Alone") and most of the other Alfred Hitchcock thrillers for Gaumont British, is presently in New York headed for Hollywood and a long term with Universal.

Union steel workers of the Monongahela Valley, in their first district convention today, warned that they would seek to drive from public office all in Congress who fail to support President Roosevelt's plan for the Supreme Court.

To the Screen Editor: I deeply resent your gratuitous slur of Sunday last upon the patronage of the Rialto Theatre. The statement that four-fifths of our patrons are six-day bike riders is calculated to do us irreparable injury with the Taxi Drivers Proteetive Association and the fast-riding set of Meadowbrook and Southhampton.

The specter of inflation, ever a light sleeper in its shallow post-war grave, is abroad in the land once more. All through the early months of the Roosevelt administration it haunted the bedsides of conservative business men, bankers and economists,

To meet the criticism that college graduates are not trained to cope with unfamiliar situations, Princeton University will introduce on Monday a one-week "reading period" for upper class men in order to allow them more freedom to complete projects in their independent studies.

ON PAYROLL: A salary of [Pound]2,000 a year will be paid to Clement R. Atlee, leader of the Opposition in the British House of Commons, by the provisions of the Ministers of the Crown Bill made public last week.
The Minneapolis Millers of the American Association had an easy time with the No. 2 squad of the Browns today, running up a 15 to 1 score on the American Leaguers.

The six-story apartment house at the southeast corner of Haven Avenue and 177th Street, plot 90 by 161.2 feet, in the Washington Heights section, will be sold on Thursday in the Vesey Street auction rooms by B. Hollander Son.

FAREWELL SUMMER--Tomorrow evening at the Fulton Theatre. This is a comedy-drama-about a lady in search of a husbandby North Bigbee and Walter Holbrook. In the cast are Lois Wilson, Walter Gilbert, Linda Lee Hill, James Todd, Suzanne Jackson, G. Albert Smith, Richard S. Bishop, Ellen Love, O. Z. Whitehead, Virginia Campbell and George Spaulding.

Perhaps it was just as well that Winter was prolonged last week with snow flurries and icy blasts. At any rate, the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association, after originally setting the date of Sunday, May 9, for the annual Albany-toNew York outboard marathon, decided to delay the speed boat racing season one week.

Problems of the substitute teacher, long a smoldering issue in the New York City public school system, burst into the open last week when representatives of six important educational organizations joined forces to consider ways and means of giving the substitute a "square deal."

FEELING, it would seem, that some rather ample gesture was needed, not to counteract but in a way to balance the present profusion of nineteenth century French art, Marie Sterner has brought out a large group of work by Americans, which occupies all of the available wall space in her galleries at 9 East Fifty-seventh Street.

THIS ribald and outrageous story is so farcically funny that a statistical-minded English critic rated the laughs in it at five to every two pages It is hard to see how he could take time out from reading to make any sort of computation. But if he meant that the book provokes abundant and hearty chuckles and guffaws, he is qute right.

Dr. J. B. Mailer, the originator of a 100-item test for personal and social equilibrium, found that there was little or no relationship between superior intelligence and contentment when a research worker applied the test to 100 exceptionally bright and 100 normal school children and reported that more ot the bright pupils than the normal children admitted that they were despondent sometimes.

A comparison of the oppression of Jews in Germany and other European countries with the bondage of their ancestors in ancient Egypt was a general theme of sermons at Passover services in city synagogues and temples yesterday morning.

Although outhit, the University of Maryland nine squeezed home a run in the seventh inning to defeat the University of Vermont, 6 to 5, in its first diamond engagement of the season today. Maryland, winner of the Southern Conference title last year, took an early lead, but a four-run drive in the seventh enabled Vermont to deadlock the game at 5-all.

Members of the Dana Hall Alumnae Association will hold their annual luncheon April 5 at the RitzCarlton for Miss Helen Temple and Cook, headmistress of the school. Miss Constance Warren, president of Sarah Lawrence College, and Mrs. Faxton Saunders, a graduate of Dana Hall and editor of the Junior League Magazine,

An all-day meeting in observance of conservation week, under auspices of the National Life Conservation Soicety, will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Thursday on the theme, "Saving New York's Scenery." Mrs. Charles Cyrus Marshall of 2,239 Tiebout Avenue, president of the organization, is in charge of free cards of admission to those interested.

John Torrey Morse Jr., second oldest living Harvard alumnus and the oldest so far as graduation was concerned, died suddenly today at his home in Needham, where he had resided for more than thirty years. His age was 97. The funeral will take place on Tuesday.
A. S. Cornhill and J. Nida tied at 96 for the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the shoot-off Cornhill won by 24 to 22.

Former Mayor C. Nelson Sparks of Akron urged Governor Martin L. Davey by letter today to intervene in the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company strike, in which 10,000 employes are idle, as a new sitdown caused suspension of operations by the Enterprise Manufacturing Company, Akron fishing tackle concern.
By careful selection and planting it is possible, even on a place of moderate size, to have shrubs in bloom almost continuously from January until Autumn snows.
Spring came to Washington last week and the smell of fresh-cut grass attracted pedestrians and visitors who walked along Pennsylvania Avenue in front of the White House.
Governor Aiken announced today that President Roosevelt had approved a proposal to create a national park in Vermont as a memo rial to Ethan and Ira Allen of Colonial fame.

THE art of Arthur Dove has given rise to contention for quite a number of years. Now Alfred Stieglitz is showing a new crop of oils (a score in number) and water-colors (nearly two score) at An American Place, until April 16.

Bill Didie, former St. John's University athlete, has been appointed coach of the Richmond Hill High School baseball team to succeed Al Kunitz, it has been announced. Didie, who assisted in the coaching duties last Spring, has been the basketball mentor for the past two campaigns.

With the filing of plans last week for the erection of many groups of medium priced homes in various sections of Queens and adjacent Long Island areas and the purchase of several large tracts by building operators and investment syndicates, additional evidence was presented that the 1937 Spring season will witness a far greater volume of con ructio in Queens and Nassau County than was accomplished in the Spring of 1936.
EASTER trade failed to reach the proportions forecast earlier. To account for the smaller volume various reasons were assigned.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. Bement of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Bement, to Henry Bowditch Stone, son of Mrs. James S. Stone of Framingham, Mass., and the late Dr. Stone.
The Easter Ball at the Surf Club tonight was attended by many members of the college set here for the Easter vacation.

Holding fast to the sizzling pace they had set the day before, New York University's swordsmen slashed their way to three of the four team championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association yesterday on the Hotel Commodore strips and thus made good their early promise.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles David Kenny of Flushing have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Kenny, to George Haines Minor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brad Minor of Pierce City, Mo.
Reuben Fine of New York, winner of recent chess competitions at Zandvoort, Stockholm and Moscow, scored again today, capturing first prize in the Leningrad tournament.

The Spanish freighter Motomar, at present loading oil at Tampico in preparation for running the naval blockade-with Mexican war material for the Loyalists, is being armed with heavy guns and machine-guns, it was learned today. It is hoped thus that the ship will be able to beat off any attacks by Rebel auxiliary warships.
They used to be five little sisters, constituting the world's only quintuplets. They are beginning to sound more and more

Walter Fairchild, president of the Torrens Title League, will be the guest of honor at a luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania on Saturday in recognition of his thirty years of service in behalf of the Torrens system of land title registration, the Torrens campaign committee announced yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Harrison Ralph of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Spotswood Ralph, to Robinson Davis Bullard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph William Camp Bullard of Southport, Conn.

LONDON.-In expressing its concern over the falling birth rate and in adopting measures to combat it, the Fascist Grand Council in Rome is not alone. In other European countries, too, there has lately been some disquiet, even alarm, at the visible decline in fertility.

BAITELMAN-Mr. and Mrs. Max Baitelman (Rose Lawrence) announce the arrival of their daughter, Janis, March 22, 1937. BLUMSTEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Kyver Blumstein (nee Esther Lurie) announce the birth of a son, Wednesday, March 24.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 4 P. M.. March 27: SECOND GRADE DETECTIVES-Stephen P. DiRosa, from 18th Division, M. 0. D. D. to 32d Precinct, designation as second grade detective revoked. Robert Gilbert, from 18th Division, 6th Detective District to 28th Precinct, designation as second grade detective revoked.

A new Texas Gulf Coast oil field apparently was assured today. Glenn H. McCarthy's No. 1 Foley Land Company, a wildcat, one mile north of Palacios, Matagorda County, was washed into production last night.
The Piccadilly ball was held tonight in the rose garden of the BellevueStratford for the benefit of the Social Service Department of the Orthopaedic Hospital.

Bright children at the Speyer Experimental School who, as recently announced, need only half a day to accomplish the regular elementary school work, are not being allowed to skip grades and rush ahead toward high school.

Mr. and Mrs. Jacob S. Dreyer of Port Jefferson, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Hope Dreyer, to Charles Robert Schubert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Schubert of Douglaston, L. I.
Texas stands to get more than $5,000,000, possibly twice that much, is the legal residence of the late Colonel E. H. R. Green is found to be in this State.

New Hampshire is apparently prepared to get along with its present Constitution, in spite of suggestions from administrative sources that a revision in taxation provisions and a modernization to permit a type of aid to industry advocated by Governor Murphy would be in the interest of the State.
Scholarship awards amounting to $8,510 were announced by Lewis Perry, principal, at the closing exercises of the Winter term of Phillips Exeter Academy yesterday. Among the recipients were.
Paul L. Goudman, retired artist and lithographer of 561 West 141st Street, died on Friday night at the Park East Hospital after a short illness. He was 64 years old.

Miss Gloria Callen, 13-year-old representative of the Women's Swimming Association, last night captured the national junior A. A. U. women's 500-yard free-style championship at the Central Y. M. C. A. in Brooklyn.

The United Automobile Workers unexpectedly reversed its accustomed role of defendant today by seeking an injunction to compel the Chrysler Corporation to grant it sole recognition under the National Labor Relations Act.
IN the exhibition of nineteenth century French paintings at the Seligmann, which is scheduled to remain until April 17, more than a dozen artists are represented.

THIS is the first biography of Leon Blum, who has already made himself a place in history by fighting the battle of democratic forces. Richard L. Stokes has written not only a stimulating biography but also a lucid account of "le New Deal francais." The por.

In efforts to lead the textile industry to better days, Federal researchers have blazed the trail to many new industrial uses for cotton. Of the total consumed in the United States about three-fifths goes into clothing and household articles. The other two-fifths goes into industry, a field now regarded as offering the greatest promise for extending the use of the staple.

A contract for 3,835,779 pounds of steel plates was awarded by the Navy Department today to the Central Iron and Steel Company of Harrisburg, Pa., for $106,852.75. The steel is being bought for stock in the purchase program of 25,000, 000 pounds.

THE late Ottorino Respighi's posthumous opera, "Lucrezia" (otherwise named "Luorezia Romana"), set to a book in one act and three "moments" by Claudio Guastalla and completed in the orchestration by the composer's widow, Elsa Olivieri Respighi, had its world premiere at La Scala some days ago,

While unfavorable weather conditions and labor disturbances served to retard business activity in some sections of the country last week, the final surge of preEaster buying pushed retail sales figures to the high levels in most of the Federal Reserve districts.

Dr. George H. Shull, Professor of Botany and Genetics at Princeton University, and Wilbur F. Kerr, university registrar, were renamed president and vice president respectively of the Board of Education of Princeton, it was announced today.

WALTER DE LA MARE, one of the finest of English prose writers and, at the same time, a most subtle poet, is, in this eassay (the Warton Lecture on English Poetry, 1935), describing the relationship of the two great arts of prose andpoetry.
Eightyseven midshipmen attached to the French cruiser Jeanne d'Arc, now at Baltimore, were the guests of midshipmen of the Naval Academy today.

CINCINNATI will hold its thirty second Biennial Music Festival May 2-9, when five concerts will be given, enlisting the services of the May Festival Chorus of 300, a children's chorus of 600, a choir of 200 boys, the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, and an imposing array of soloists, under the direction of Eugene Goossens.

Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, declared tonight that support of President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court was "the only way to stand effectively and immediately for a liberalized court."

Venezuela needs a middle ground between the absolutely dictatorial government enforced a quarter of a century by the late General Juan Vicente Gomez and radical and communistic extremes, if a semblance of democracy is to be established in that naturally rich country.

The officers and general counsel of the Monroe Birthplace Memorial Association of Westmoreland County announced today that the association had entered into a contract for the purchase of seventy acres of the Westmoreland County plantation containing the site of the house in which President Monroe was born.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Polly O'Donnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Colgan O'Donnell of Walkes-Barre, Pa., to Joseph Nugent, son of James J. Nugent of 237 East Seventy-second Street, and Cedarhurst, L. I., and the late Mrs. Nugent.

More than half of the South American republics have declared an armistice in their economic war and begun tearing down their high tariff walls. This new policy has been adopted by six of the republics since the adjournment in December of the Pan-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

President William Mather Lewis of Lafayette College announces the gift of an antique desk and an oil portrait as part of the celebration of the Decade of Progress. The desk stood for many years in White's Tavern, formerly situated in the Center Square in Easton.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 26, unless specified: New York to New London, March 27: Badger, J. F. Talbott, Tattnall. At Pearl Harbor: Gamble, Nitro, Pamsay, Breese. At Puget Sound Yard: Louisville, Oklahoma. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Chaumont, Clark.

J. Howard Ardrey, New York representative of the Federal Housing Administration, and Frederick M. Babcock, chief of the underwriting section of the FHA, will speak to a group of New Jersey bankers, building and loan members and title mortgage company representatives at an FHA mortgage conference in the Essex House, Newark, Tuesday afternoon, April 13.

Seven-month-old Michael Hopkins Jr. nearly choked to death yesterday when a china doll, more than two inches long, became lodged in his throat. An operation performed a few hours later by a throat surgeon was credited with having saved his life.
Mrs. Grace M. Bingham obtained a divorce today from Harry Payne Bingham of New York City. She charged mental cruelty.

FROM down to midnight today Easter is the theme of broad casting. Sacred music, sermons, Spring songs and descriptions of Easter styles cause a shift in the routine of broadcasting as the microphone goes far afield to pick up its international program extended across the map from Italy to Hawaii.

For the first time in the history of the greater city, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, city ferryboats are to get feminine names. Three new boats, soon to be launched, will be called the Gold Star Mother, the Mary Murray and the Miss New York.

WASHINGTON. AN international aerobatic competition is to he held at St. Louis, Mo., over Decoration Day week-end, as a feature of a three-day schedule of air racing and flight exhibions by nationally known pilots. Minimum cash prizes of $15,000 for winners were announced last week, as was official sanction for the meet,
On the well-cropped lawn of Hyde Park, London, extremists mount the British equivalent of soap boxes and denounce anything they choose, including the government The English

Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward approved today a settlement between the trustees of the Chicago Great Western Railroad and representatives of five railway brotherhoods whereby the company agreed to pay approximately $50,000 to some of its employes.

Wage-earners and lower-salaried clerical workers in New York City earn more than those in any other city of the United States, according to a Department of Labor survey conducted in cooperation with the Relief Administration and the WPA. However, they also spend their earnings more freely.
A pergola should - either serve as an interesting pathway to some special point in the garden, or form a vantage point from -which an attractive part of the whole of the garden may be observed.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Ralph Condit of White Plains, N. Y., of the engagement of Mrs. Condit's daughter, Miss Marjorie Matthew, to Fred Howard Porter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Howard Porter of Beverly, Mass.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Louise McIntyre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William McIntyre of Demarest, to Morton Albertson Howard Jr., son of Mrs. John C. Hegeman of Larchmont, N. Y., and of Morton A. Howard of New York, took place here this morning in the chapel of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church.
The New York University College of Engineering will dedicate a new classroom building and power plant next Saturday in honor of Dean Emeritus Collins P. Bliss,

YEARS ago Dr. Rous of the Rockefeller Institute ground up chicken tumors, extracted the virus and passed it through a filer so fine that it could hold back even particles visible in the most powerful microscope. When he injected the filtrate into chickens they developed tumors.

In a swift move to capitalize on public interest in school safety following the school disaster in New London, Texas, the Bureau for Institutional Safety established temporary headquarters here last week in the offices of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT returns to the capital from Warm Springs for a fresh tussle with the foes of his judiciary reorganization plan, ready to press the fight to the enemy camp, apparently confident of an outcome agreeable to himself and to his program for the country.

Bootleg coal mining must be stopped by a rigidly enforced official proclamation and work must be found for the idle if the problems of the anthracite industry are to be solved, witnesses told members of Governor Earle's coal investigating commission at a public hearing here today.

Mrs. Douglas Gibbons of 430 Park Avenue will head a women's division of the special gifts committee in the Catholic Charities drive for funds to be held in the week beginning April 18, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, honorary and general chairman of Cardinal Hayes's Committee of the Laity, announced yesterday.

Two crack court stenographers took down more than 2,500,000 words in the restaurant-racket trial which followed a special inquiry. Containing the largest number of words at any recent criminal trial, the record ran to 10,000 typewritten pages of about 250 words a page. Average daily wordage approximated 45,000.

For a time today it looked as if the Bees were finally going to win a ball game from the Yankees. To the unconcealed joy of about 1,000 fans - natives and tourists are, strangely enough, violently proBees-they were doing all sorts of things to the feeble pitching of Johnny Broaca.

A child labor amendment, drafted in the hope of overcoming some of the objections which have led thirty-eight State Legislatures, in various tests, to reject the constitutional proposal adopted by Congress thirteen years ago, was completed today by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan. He intends to introduce it in the Senate on Monday.

With the stock markets and the bullion markets closed until Tuesday during the Easter holidays, overnight loans were in small demand at one-half of 1 per cent, and three-month bills were plentiful at nine-sixteenths of 1 per cent.

Harvard University undergraduates who are members of the cast for the ninety-first Hasty Pudding Club production "Come Across" are receiving the cooperation of many young women of society in this city, who are planning a reception and a cabaret performance to follow the presentation of the show here on April 9 at Mecca Temple.

Mrs. George H. Bostwick's aged gelding, Fugitive, a few years ago one of the best jumpers in the country, came back in his very best form today and scored an amazingly easy victory to capture the eighth running of the Carolina Cup.
New England members of Congress prepared today to expedite legislation enabling the Federa' Government to proceed with its share of the flood control plan approved by the Connecticut River States.
Three of the six-meter yachts that are to compete in the racing in Bermuda starting on April 7, were shipped yesterday on the Furness Bermuda liner Monarch of Bermuda.
The Good Friday processions in this capital of the Spanish Insurgent government were favored with good weather after a stormy spell. Advantage was taken of this fact by throngs.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--An early Easter means an early start for the Spring influx of visitors to Atlantic City. Thus this resort is looking forward to what is expected to be its best Spring in a number of years.

A Supreme Court ruling before June on the constitutionality of the Federal Social Security Act became possible today when the government joined an Alabama corporation in asking for an early ruling on the validity of the law.

Artur Schnabel, pianist, and Bronislaw Huberman, violinist, offered one of their occasional sonata evenings at Town Hall last night. The two celebrated artists had not been heard here in a program of the kind since last season, and in the interim their playing had not taken on any new aspects.

Joseph P. Day, foreseeing a strong effect on real estate values in Queens as a result of the World's Fair, has purchased a plot, 100 by 100, on the south side of Horace Harding Boulevard, adjoining the southwest corner of Main Street, Flushing, for the erection of an office to house his Queens and Long Island division.

Agitation in Westhchester over the matter of county reorganization during recent weeks indicates that a sizable audience will attend an all-day institute on the topic on Wednesday in the New Rochelle Woman's Club home. Sponsors are the Westchester County League of Women Voters, the Westchester County Taxpayers Association and other organizations of women.

A POWERFUL short-wave station on 29.8 meters, believed to be connected with the secret "Red" broadcasting transmitter of the German Communist party memtioned in last Sunday's TIMES as having been heard in Europe, was tuned in the New York area on Wednesday between 4 and 5 P. M.

The prospective candidacy of Mayor F. H. La Guardia for renomination on the Republican ticket has put the local leaders of that party "on the spot." The five county leaders, Kenneth F. Simpson of New York County, John R. Crews of Kings, John J.
Socialist leaders debated behind closed doors tonight their party's attitude toward the organized labor schism and a possible new farmers' and workers' party alignment.

In an encyclical addressed to the Mexican episcopacy under tomorrow's date, Pope Pius examines the situation of the church in Mexico and makes several practical suggestions for regaining -the ground lost in recent years.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that, in connection with its study of investment trusts and investment companies, hearings will commence on Tuesday on the Iroquois Shares Corporation of Buffalo and the National

Tnhe National Interscholastic Swimming Coaches Association elected John Miller of Mercersburg (Pa.) Military Academy, president today. Roscoe E. Dake of Phillips Andover Academy, Andover, Mass., was named vice president, and A. A. Newshaefer of Trenton, N. J., secretary.

Striking public school students throughout Mexico remained firm in their determination not to return to their classes tonight, although President Lazaro Cardenas gave an indication he was not sympathetic with their cause.

Manufacturers of patent medicines and druggists' preparations made 36.6 per cent of their sales in 1935 to wholesalers and jobbers and 23.6 per cent direct to retailers of all types, including chain stores, according to figures released by the Bureau of the Census.
Two national junior college track and field records were bettered today in a dual meet between Pasadena and San Mateo Junior Colleges.
Sitdown strikes do not offer a serious practical problem either to employers or authorities, owing to the special conditions prevailing in Mexico regarding labor.
A NEW and profitable division of the cinema has sprung up overnight devoted to such widely diversified themes as "sailing ships and sealing wax and cabbages and kings."

Dynamite blasts fired by Mayor F. H. La Guardia broke a peace of twenty years in Ulster County last Wednesday as New York City began her second invasion of Catskill drainage areas to tap still more water for her insatiable population.

The committee on legislation or the Citizens Union announced yesterday its opposition to the Doyle bill providing that if any multiple dwelling complied with the laws existing when it was erected it shall not be required to comply with the laws passed since it received a certificate of occupancy.

General Printing Ink Corporation common stock, New York Railways Corporation $7 non-cumulative preferred stock and McKeesport Tin Plate Company common stock, all of no par value, have been stricken from listing and registration by the New York Stock Exchange.

Maurice Zuckert, a Supreme Court referee, recommended today a reduction of $552,952 in the 1933 assessment of $2,030,050 upon the holdings of John D. Rockefeller Jr. in North Tarrytown. The report will be offered to the court for confirmation by counsel for the Rockefeller interests on April 1. Angelo E. Zingaro, attorney for the village of North Tarrytown, will opnose the move.

In the past three weeks the aspect of the struggle in Spain has greatly changed. Then there was a picture of General de Liano having captured the important port of Malaga and of General Franco's having driven his men onto the heights overlooking the strategic road from Madrid to Valencia, where he had the thoroughfare under gunfire, while strenuous efforts were being made to get the civilian population out of the capital.

Consumer views, as obtained by numerous polls and voluntary expressions of opinion, have been one of the prime factors in stimulating the repackaging of goods in the last year, according to comment last week at the packaging exhibit held by the American Management Association.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association and its sectional constituents are sponsoring a movement to develop a higher standard of play and propagate the principles of court sportsmanship and conduct among the younger players by the formation of junior Davis Cup squads throughout the country.

Taking issue with proposals of President Roosevelt's Committee on Reorganization, the Brookings Institution has recommended continuance of the office of the Controller General and the removal of the Bureau of the Budget from its anomalous position in the Treasury to an independent status under the President.

Mrs. Dora Toch, widow of Henry M. Toch, paint manufacturer and philanthropist, died on Friday night at her apartment in the Hotel Peter Stuyvesant, 2 West Eightysixth Street, after a five-month illness. She was 72 years old.

Comparing the British Sovereign to an office boy, James Maxton, Socialist Member of Parliament, attacked Britain's monarchical system today. In an address before the Independent Labor party's annual conference in Glasgow, Mr. Maxton said:

Columns of New York papers for the past year have been culled for the finest examples of news reporting and editing by women, the authors to be honored Friday night by their associates of the Newspaper Women's Club. Three awards of $100 each will be dispensed as the midnight feature of the club's fifteenth Front Page ball atop the Hotel Astor.

Net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income tax on one subsidiary, amortization, preferred dividends of subsidiaries and other charges, $38,669, equal to 99 cents a share on the 39,063 shares of $7 first preferred stock on which arrears at the close of the year amounted to $1,321,631. This contrasts with a revised net loss of $17,889 in 1935.

Broadcasting General Six years ago, in a Latin Quarter cafe in Paris, you would have' found a set of Spanish exiles, among them a tall, spare Castilian with a small dark mustache - a man in his middle forties perhaps, with the bearing of a general and the dignified manner of the true Castilian.

Ships in a wide area of the northeastern Pacific turned today to the aid of the leaking and. helpless American freighter, Volunteer, with a crew of about forty, which was fighting a losing battle against the sea 840 miles off the coast of Japan.
STOCKHOLM. DESPITE the buoyant triumph of Santayana's "The Last Puritan" in America, it seems to have been overlooked by critics here until a Swedish translation put in its appearance recently.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange dwindled at times almost to stagnation during the two-hour session. Prices, however, held steady to firm. The volume of transactions was the smallest in five months, being only $5,107,400, compared with $10,960,000 on Saturday the week before.

AN extended account of the difficult and involved work of the materiel division of the Air Corps is contained in the current issue of the Air Corps News Letter, and some of the problems attendant on the testing of equipment in use and for future procurement are discussed with criticisms of methods thinly veiled.
The Innis Arden Golf Club, Old Greenwich, will be the scene of an Easter subscription dance on Wednesday. More than 250 members of the younger set are expected to attend.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, sounded a cry of battle against C. I. O. rivals in an address here today and asserted that "no siren voice can ever persuade our loyal members to leave the ranks and experiment in some untried field."

Peace has at last been declared in the Adriatic. Improvement in ItaloYugoslav relations has been very slow. Thirteen years ago-five years after D'ANNUNZIO'S seizure of Fiume had outraged Yugoslav feelings--Premier MUSSOLINI and Premier PASHITCH coneluded the "Pact of Rome" and agreed " in principle" on a basis of cooperation.
Inspector Byron M. Jacobs of the Bureau of Air Commerce will conduct a hearing Tuesday on the cause of the wrecking of the Transcontinental and Western Airlines transport plant that killed thirteen
Mrs. Alfreda M. Bingham obtained a divorce today after testifying that Hiram Bingham, former Senator from Connecticut, had been "absolutely like a stranger" to her for the last four years.
Unlike other morning newspapers The Times today devoted its leading editorial not to an Easter message of cheer but to the grim possibilities of air raids in time of war.

The American Labor party, if it is to consolidate its position, as an independent political body, must nominate its own slate of labor candidates in the coming municipal and legislative elections, Louis Waldman, State chairman of the People's party, declared yesterday afternoon at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

THE its climax Conductors throughout the land stride out at concert time, acknowledge the applause of the audience and take their positions on the podium They give a signal, the musicians respond and an overture, a symphony or a tone poem begins. It looks simple.

The Dr. White Memorial Catholic Settlement Association in Brooklyn will benefit from a bridge and tea to be given April 27 at the Hotel Plaza. Mrs. W. Harry Sefton is president of the association and Miss Irene A. Farrell is general chairman of the benefit.

Twenty-one mechanics deemed to have shown outstanding skill in the erection of the new uptown office of the Dry Dock Savings Institution, at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and fifty-ninth Street, will receive craftsmanship awards in a ceremony to be held in the building on Tuesday under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

Restrictive rent legislation similar to that following the World War might be enacted as a result of an "unreasonable" attitude on the part of some owners, Joseph Milner of the brokerage firm bearing his name warns owners of residential real estate.

Judge and Mrs. Mortimer W. Byers of 188 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice W. Byers, to Allen K. Holding of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. C. Holding of Pittsburgh.

ROME.--During his recent illness Pope Pius received hundreds of letters from all parts of the world containing not only fervent wishes for his rapid recovery but the most heterogeneous recipes, which were guaranteed by their senders to have the power to restore him to health.

Starlight, 44-foot cutter owned and skippered by Albert Fay of Houston, Texas, was leading nine other racing craft about fifty miles south of Egmont Light tonight on the first leg of the eighth annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race.
Coach Dink Templeton's Stanford track and field team defeated the University of California at Los Angeles in a dual meet today, 88 to 43, on a windswept field.

WITH the opening of the annual Spring radiophone amateur contest during the past week operators all over the world were ready with new circuits and generally imprved "rigs" to contact as many foreign stations as possible.
Better business conditions have taken the "white collar" unemployed off the highways of travel, according to reports made at a meeting of the Travelers Aid Society at the Union Station here.

IN a compelling argument against the fairly common practice of corporations to put the best foot forward in reporting earnings, and a blistering condemnation of accounting firms that are parties to this procedure, Mr. Winthrop takes up the cudgels for the misinformed stockholder.

Twice as many farm boys in New York State are taking courses in vocational agriculture this year as four years ago. Six thousand of them are going to 240 high school centers straight through the school year. Another 4,000 are enrolled in short-term courses only.

IN the films, in the night clubs, practically everywhere except on the Broadway stage since 1930, Bill Robinson is now slated to bring his dancing feet home to a legitimate rostrum. Or so says his manager, Marty Forkins, defining the occasion as a Negro revue due in June, a month or so after his client is free of the pictures.

Well known members of society have purchased tickets for the recital to be given by Elisabeth Rethberg and Friedrich Schorr of the Metropolitan Opera the afternoon of April 12 at the home of James Speyer, 1,058 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of the New York Women's League for Animals.
Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Hupcher of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rose Hupcher, to Dr. Maxwell Schram, also of Brooklyn.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Maitland Houston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Houston 2d of Houstonia, Nether Providence, to Charles Stuart Brown, son of Mrs. Medford Jennings Brown of Merion and the late Mr. Brown.
A strike of wholesale grocery salesmen continued yesterday to paralyze the activities of six wholesale concerns. More than 600 retail grocers were indirectly affected.

During the past week, while the political atmosphere has been much disturbed by the discussion of the Clichy rioting and Communist influence among the workers, there has been some recurrence of partial and local strikes.

Announcement was made yesterday of the resignation of Robert Erskine Ely, director of the League for Political Education for the past thirty-six years, and the appointment of George V. Denny Jr., associate director to succeed Mr. Ely.

INDIA a medieval country. is slowly modernizing itself. Old customs and institutions that have survived their usefulness are yielding. New ones are taking their place. Recently the first national election was held under India's new Constitution.

Henry Greenberg, builder. is erecting a $35,000 residence with doctor's quarters at the southwest corner of Broadway and Cedarhurst Av., Lawrence, L. I., for Dr. Sidney Hirsch. Use of modern materials for remodeling homes or building new ones Is shown in the Johns-Manville talking picture,

APRONED, lathered and stretched out in what is probably the most exclusive barber chair catering to the people of the Stem-in a backstairs sanctuary the very existence of which is kept secret, doubtless on the theory that the public would storm the place with patronage if it only knew-the Man Who Owns Broadway gave himself up one afternoon last week to the twin luxuries of a shave and a movie interview.

Two Argus-eyed electrical testing machines, each said to be capable of grading 935 tests an hour, are expected to reduce "marker's cramp" among the teachers of certain New England sections when they are flooded this Spring with final examination papers.

A decision by Alberta's social credit government to hold up the budget now before the Legislature was disclosed today. The budget, providing for increased taxation, has drawn the opposition of an insurgent group in the Legislature which declared that under social credit increases in taxation were unnecessary.
The Philadelphia amateur champion, Jack Buchanan, was eliminated from the fifteenth annual Wildwood Easter invitation golf tournament in the second round today. Horace Williams Jr.,
Two sourdoughs, fresh from the musher's trail, recommended to the Far North today a new breakfast food-"mossolyte."

A new residential community rapidly is taking shape on the site of the old Morosini estate, in Riverdale. Fifteen air-conditioned dwellings in varied types of architecture have been erected in the development, now known as Riverdale Heights, overlooking the Hudson at 254th Street and Rivercrest Road.

No evidence of perjury, extortion or labor racketeering in New York County was found in the investigation here into the murder of Norman Redwood, sandhog union leader who was shot down in front of his home in Teaneck. N. J., on Feb. 19, Assistant District Attorney Ambrose J. Delehanty reported yesterday to District Attorney William C. Dodge.

Judging from the marked increase in applications for insured mortgages in New York State since the first of the year, home building operations are virtually assured of attaining a far higher volume in 1937 than was the case in 1936, declares Thomas G. Grace, New York State FHA director.

Unlike Angelo, the somewhat sophisticated East Side bootblack whose indifferent reception of the circus brought no cheers from the press agents, the children of Mayor La Guardia and Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey spent a thoroughly enjoyable afternoon yesterday at the Hippodrome.
War talk in Europe and elsewhere will put lumbeing at a peak of production in the Adirondacks, according to operators.

Teachers who nag or use sarcasm in the classroom tend to develop neurotic pupils, Dr. Emil Altman, chief medical examiner of the Board of Education, declared yesterday in announcing a new course for teachers on the problems of health and nervous diseases.

Mrs. Alice du Pont, widow of Senator T. Coleman du Pont, bequeathed $10,000 each to the Y. W. C. A. of Delaware, the Y. W. C. A. of Wilmington and the Protestant Episcopal Church of Delaware. Her will was admitted for probate today. The amount of her estate was not given.
Pompoon, the juvenile champion of 1936 and future book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, will make his first 1937 racing start in the Paumonok Handicap, which will be run April 15 at Jamaica.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey affirmed yesterday his faith in the members of the Police Department, and at a ceremony at police headquarters at which twelve men were promoted and six more recommended to the honor board he praised the "magnificent work" done by patrolmen and detectives assigned to his office.

Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, will discuss America's stake in world trade at a dinner under the auspices of the League of Nations Association of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on the evening of April 6.

During the last week many additional reservations were made for the sixty-eighth annual luncheon of the Brooklyn Woman's Club, to be held April 7, at the WaldorfAstoria. Mrs. Thomas Henry McClintock is president of the club. Mrs. S. Earle Saylor is chairman of the luncheon.

After living for three hours under his crumpled locomotive cab, Engineer Dan Horan, 40, died today of injuries suffered in a collision of his Colorado Southern passenger train' with a freight train near here.

Building and Loan Annals of 1936, its seventh yearly volume devoted to the work of savings, building and loan associations, is being distributed by the United States Building and Loan League of Chicago. Morton Bodfish is the editor.

Miss Mary Dolan of St. Paul raced to a surprise victory tonight in the senior women's 440-yard test, first event in the national indoor speed skating championship, beating Mrs. Dorothy Franey Drolson, a- more famous St. Paul star, in 46.8 seconds.

JUDY CLEMENT. 10 years old, with the independence of a born tomboy and the energy of a threshing machine. was all that the younger set needed to keep things stirred up. There were times, too, when Judy involuntarily stirred up practically the whole population of the little Illinois town in which she lived in the decorous days at the turn of the century.
Lawrence L. Quill, chemistry professor at Ohio State University, is in the midst of a four-year search into the mysteries of fifteen rare earth elements.

Lyman Ward, former Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, died Wednesday at Jacksonville, Fla., of injuries sustained last Sunday in an automobile accident near there. He was 60 years old and had lived at the St. Moritz Hotel.
David Suddeth, an 8-year-old inventor, of Fairfield, Iowa, polished off the manuscript of his lecture to the National Inventors Congress today.

Ground for the new Alumnae House of Smith College will be broken Tuesday morning. Mrs. Rudolph Zinsser of Great Neck, N. Y., chairman of the building committee will turn the first spadeful of earth for the foundation of the building at Elm Street and Bedford Terrace.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Noble, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Colton D. Noble of New Britain, Conn., to Charles Edwin Constantinides, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Lawrence Constantinides of Rutherford, was performed at the Noble home this afternoon by the Rev. Samuel Sutcliffe.

A council of some of Japan's foremost business men, bankers, economists and mititary leaders, called by the Tokyoi Chamber of Commerce, decided today that the Japanese economic mission to China had failed.

SPRING'S in, and the circus, on its 700-acre Winter camping ground here, is ready to move out. For four months whining buzz saws have turned out new grand stands, new rings. new wagon flooring. Five thousand new tent stakes were peeled and iron-banded:

With the actual arrival of Spring--according both to the calendar and to the weather-gardeners are turning their attention to the first work to be done in the open. In connection with some early Spring tasks, caution must still be exercised; but there are others which it is best to go ahead with immediately, regardless of what the weather may be from now on.

A claim for $249,711.94 as damages alleged to have been sustained by the government's failure to deliver Shipping Board vessels purchased in 1933 was filed by the Lyke Brothers-Ripley Steamship Company today with the Maritime Commission.
Three entombed miners shouted encouragement to rescue workers late tonight after being trapped by a rock fall in a clay mine. Speaking through a pipe driven down by rescuers. they said:

Strangest and most mournful relic of Maine's mining boom of the late Eighteen Seventies is a forty-room mansion set in a 6,000-acre tract of woodland in this town, a mansion never finished, nor ever likely to be, and inhabited today, as for sixty years, by two women, twenty cats and a swarm of rats.

The Congregational Church will include in its three-hundredth anniversary celebration this Spring, a Jenny Lind concert which will duplicate as nearly as possible a recital which the famous singer gave here many years ago.

The county grand jury today heard District Attorney Matthew A. Brady explain an asserted "obligation" to a central figure in the local vice investigation and then asked the State Attorney General, U. S. Webb, to take over the whole inquiry.
The Duke of Windsor cut his servant problem down by practically two-thirds tonight, preparatory to moving to a modest pension in Upper Austria.

Claiming a "property right" in their jobs, sit-down strikers continue earnestly to maintain that peaceful occupation, in good faith, of their employer's premises, without the employer's consent, is not illegal. It is a lawful method, they insist, to protect that "property right" in their jobs from "destruction."

All the certificated mortgages of the Mineola Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company and the Hempstead Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company have been placed under trustee control, the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York announced yesterday.

Organization of forty-one committees to work under the direction of the trade and industry division in the forthcoming $600,000 campaign said. of the Salvation Army was announced yesterday by Chalmers Wood, chairman of the drive. Oscar Cooper is chairman of the division.
THE word "electron" has now passed into the vernacular. Sir Joseph Thomson did not coin it, but his discovery of the particle that it designates is one of the very great achievements in science.
Mrs. Addie Bernheimer Seligman, widow of DeWitt J. Seligman, banker, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at her residence, 299 Park Avenue, in her eighty-first year.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Parsons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund S. Parsons of this city, to Charles Brown Dudley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Brown Dudley of Plaquamin, La.

The marriage of Miss Theodora Bates, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Moore Bates of Summit, N. J., formerly of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Rev. Mr. Bates, to Arthur Duncan Moir of Saranac Lake, N. Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Moir, took place here yesterday in the chapel of St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church.
A trim little filly named Jewell Dorsett and a Christmas gift horse, Dead Calm, drew the attention of form players in the $10,000 Louisiana Derby, which ends a 113-day racing meet here tomorrow.

An opinion recently given by Justice Keller in a suit tried before him in the New York City Court clearly puts the responsibility upon the tenant when moving from his leased premises to leave those premises in a reasonably clean condition for the landlord, points out Samuel R. Schneider of the New York bar.
Announcement of the selection of Hugh A. O'Donnell as treasurer of the Manhattan division of the City Fusion party was made yesterday by Dr. Moses Benmosche, Manhattan chairman.

Wheat and corn prices in North American markets today continued on the upgrade, with all deliveries selling at a new high for the season and since 1929. Corn took the lead and at the highest level it reached on the Board of Trade was virtually 4 cents a bushel above Thursday's

While President Roosevelt continued his holiday last week at Warm Springs (yesterday he returned to the capital) and official Washington awaited a Supreme Court decision on the Wagner Labor Relations Act, the sit-down strike occupied the attention of the nation. Attack upon labor's new tactic, defense of it also, was heard on public platforms and echoed in the press.

MOST of the fifty-seven examples of humor in this volume are from Punch, a statement which is at once a generalization and a classification. Punch is an institution, and all Englishmen take it seriously.

A government fleet returned safely to Cartagena tonight after heavily bombarding Insurgent-held Malaga and Motril. on the south coast of Spain, and Melilla, Spanish Morocco. Government airplanes put to flight an Insurgent plane that attempted to bomb the warships.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Austin Donnelly of 440 Riverside Drive of the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Mary Dorothy Donnelly, to John Peter McDonnell, son of Mrs. Robert Emmet McDonnell of 888 Park Avenue and the late Mr. McDonnell.

In pursuit of an ideal plan for the job training of youth, a dozen city school superintendents will set out early in May to visit nine cities, where such training shows distinctive and successful features. Starting in Minneapolis, they will spend a day each in Milwaukee, Indianapolis, Cincinnati, Providence, Buffalo and Newark, and two days each in Washington and New York City.

A healthy seven-pound baby girl only six hours old was found abandoned at 10 o'clock last night wrapped in a brown blanket and sheltered in an opened black suitcase on the doorstep of the town house of Mrs. John P. Tilden at 16 East Seventy-sixth Street.

The second concert in a series for the joint benefit of the Composers Fund of the League of Composers and the Scholarship Fund of the Neighborhood Playhouse will be presented under the auspices of the League of Composers the night of April 4 at the Town Hall.
The annual Spring dance arranged by members of the Wheaton College Club of New York to aid the Student Loan Fund of the college will take place next Saturday night in the garden of the Ambassador.

Fear that many members of Congress are more concerned with "denaturing" the merit system in the civil service than in extending it was expressed yesterday by Robert L. Johnson, president of the National Civic Service Reform League.

Mrs. Ingalls Sard will sail early next month for England where she will visit Sir Malcolm and Lady Robertson. Also sailing in the near future are Myron Hofer and Mrs. Charles F. Hofer, who have taken a house in London for some weeks.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Edwin Blaney of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor P. Blaney, to William Gibbs Bates of Hartford, Conn.

Many socially prominent women will serve as patronesses for the bridge party to be held under the joint auspices of the Welfare Committee and Junior Auxiliary of the Orphan Asylum Society of the City of Brooklyn on April 9 at the home, Kingston and Atlantic Avenues.

The announcement of President Manuel Quezon that he wants full independence for the Philippines in 1938 or 1939, seven or eight years ahead of the present legal schedule, will imperil the future of the islands only if Congress cuts them loose without special trade concessions.

Elaborate and colorful costumes of bygone eras as well as modern gowns from the salons of wellknown couturiers will pass in review at the unusual fashion show entitled "A Century's Looking-Glass of Fashion" during the luncheon hour at Sherry's Tuesday for the benefit of the West Side Thrift Shop.
Dr. Ira Warran Perry, retired dentist who for twenty-five years practiced in Peekskill, N. Y., died last night at his home here after a month's illness.

ALINE on the jacket of this book describes it as "a tale of Gallic lunacy, murder and mirth." That is a perfectly good description so far as it goes, but it neglects to say that there is a tender little romance tucked away between the covers of the volume, a romance only indirectly connected with the murders which engage the attention of Scotland Yard and the Paris Surete.
THE Societe Nationale, pursuing its annual series of concerts devoted to the presentation of new works, gave at the Salle de I'Ecole Normale another interesting concert.
With the legs severed near the hips, the body of an unidentified Negro, about 25 years old, was found yesterday morning in a bonfire in a lot at 234-242 West Sixtyfirst Street.
Mrs. Raymond H. Barnes of 90 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, gave a luncheon at her home yesterday in honor of Miss Eloise W. Lane, who will be married next month to Edwin Hicks.

Miss Rose Schneiderman, who for a number of years has headed the Women's Trade Union League, is the unopposed candidate for a new term as president in the election scheduled for tomorrow night. The business meeting will be held in conjunction with a celebration in observance of the thirty-fourth anniversary of the organization at its headquarters at 247 Lexington Avenue. Miss Schneiderman recently was appointed secretary of the State Department of Labor.

Ten "golden rules of the cancer examination" were offered yesterday by the American Society for the Control of Cancer as a "guide and aid to laymen who want a complete general physical examination" that would reveal the possible presence of early cancer, the stage when cancer is still a curable disease.
Bishop Frederick T. Keeney, for fifty years a minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church, said today he saw a "decided drift toward religion."

NEW YORK CITY'S new traffic code has now been in operation for five weeks. With one exception, its provisions have been praised generally by Observers and accepted with equanimity by the city's million motorists.
An American war hospital at Albacete barely escaped Insurgent bombs during an air raid Wednesday night, said reports reaching Madrid tonight.

A special meeting of the Board of Education will be held Wednesday afternoon at 500 Park Avenue. Building contracts will be awarded and the question of surrendering a portion of the New York Parental School site for college purposes will be considered.
The Columbia Daily Spectator is marking its sixtieth anniversary this year. It was founded in 1877 by Frederick W. Holls, who had been business manager of the literary magazine Acta Columbiana.
The Aknusti trio was forced into overtime to down Old Oaks, 11 to 10, in their Granniss Cups indoor polo game at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

Retailers in seeking the development of a national labor and fair trade practice policy for distribution have been weighing a number of questions that may exert influence on the program that will finally be evolved, it was pointed out in some retail quarters here yesterday.

John Francis Murray, a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority for the last eight years, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 169 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, after a prolonged illness. In a few days he would have been 38 years old.

The history of the Morro Castle disaster was closed yesterday with precise legal words in an order by Federal Judge John C. Knox. The effect of it was to fix liability at $890,000, or an average of about $2,225 for each of the 400 claimants.

Miss Elizabeth Powell Fenn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dean F. Fenn of Toronto, formerly of Montclair, N. J., was married to William Howard Kingston Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Kingston of Malone, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square.

Mrs. Helen W. Read and Fitz E. Dixon, prominent socially in Philadelphia, were married at the Baptist parsonage by the Rev. Brewster Adams today soon after Mrs. Read obtained a divorce from Charles N. Read on grounds of cruelty. Dixon was divorced last year in Philadelphia.

SERIOUS interruptions to automotive production caused by widespread strikes have raised some new problems for the motor industry. Car makers at the beginning of the year hailed a 5,000,000-car output for 1937, but prospects of attaining that goal are fading. General Motors declares it will take four months for it to catch up with back orders which piled up during its recent strike.
A steady return to normal business conditions in the flood areas was reported here yesterday by W. W. Orr, secretary of the New York Credit Men's Association.

Six of the best radio productions of the year, in the opinion of leaders of more than 10,000,000 women affiliated with the Women's National Radio Committee, will be acclaimed as winners of the organization's annual awards at a luncheon Wednesday at the Hotel St. Regis.

Shipping interests at this port had a scare this week when the Waterfront Employers Association notified the International Longshoremens Association that all dock activities would be stopped until pickets were withdrawn from the pier where there had been a jurisdictional dispute over four members of the crew of the Knoxville City.
Alfonso XIII, former King of Spain, is to become a grandfather for the fourth time in April or May. The baby is expected to grace the Rome Hotel home of Alfonso's second son, Don Jaime.

A fraud order was issued today by the Postoffice Department against the Atlantic City Vacation Fund Club, Inc., on a charge of "conducting a scheme or device for obtaining money through the mails by means of false and fraudulent pretenses."

J. Henry Nany, a retired horse trainer and real estate operator, died yesterday at his home here. He was 85 years old. Mr. Nay was born in Hartland, Me. He came to Boston as a young man and became a horse dealer. He bought the old Readville track and established a training school there.

A style show, iuncneon and bridge will be held under the auspices of the Cape Cod Institute of Music on April 20 at the Carlyle. Mrs. James Roosevelt is the honorary chairman and Miss Martha Atwood executive chairman.

A luncheon and bridge party will be held on April 13 at the St. Regis for the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children. Mrs. Peter McDonnell and Mrs. James F. McDonnell head the committee in charge of arrangements,

The main bar in the taproom of Syracuse's largest-hotel was closed last night after union bartenders walked out in what they said was a protest against the management's refusal to hire local bartenders.

President Roosevelt's veto of a bill to increase the allowance to $10 a day for expenses of United States district judges sitting temporarily in the Southern District of New York was blamed for the congestion in that district by Ira Jewell Williams of the law firm of Brown Williams, Philadelphia, in a letter to Senator Henry F. Ashhurst, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

The bill introduced in the British House of Commons this week to raise the salaries of all Cabinet members to a [Pound]5,000 level ($24,425) and the pay of the Prime Minister to [Pound]10,000 ($48,850), or double his present remuneration, represents a further step toward opening the highest political offices under the Crown to all, regardless of their personal fortunes. Incidentally,
