THE Chicago Council of Teachers announces its first competition for the best setting, for voice with piano accompaniment, of a given text. The poem chosen for the initial contest is Sidney Lanier's "Evening Song.

ONE of the things you soon find out about the Russians is that they are a nation of promisers. There is an English proverb: "A promise is like pie crust, made to be broken," but the Russians do not mean to break promises when they make them.

Miss Margaret Field Tilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Q. Tilson of New Haven, has selected May 8 as the date of her marriage to Brice Shafer of New York. Their engagement was announced last Summer at Lake Sunapee, N. H.

THE versatility of the American housewife and the wide range of native cooking are revealed in some 10,000 menus and recipes submitted in a contest of the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries opening in New York tomorrow.

A "world's fair" of scientific wonders has been opened at the Pennsylvania State College. It is a new exhibit, in which about fifty demonstrations have been assembled to illustrate fundamental principles of chemistry and physics.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:
Ninety persons have been indicted and nineteen convicted on charges of vote fraud in Kansas City and the Federal grand jury is still in session.

After two fires apparently of incendiary origin had been extinguished in the West End Synagogue at 160 West Eighty-second Street early yesterday morning, a third swept the interior of the building yesterday afternoon causing damage estimated by the synagogue officers at several hundred thousand dollars.

On Feb. 10 of last year ex-President HOOVER, acting as trustee of Stanford University, submitted to the California court a petition that the University be permitted to invest its endowment funds in stocks as well as bonds. The petition would not have attracted the nation-wide attention which it did, but for Mr. HOOVER'S statement of the reason for it.

The Central Ohio Light and Power Company has received permission from the Ohio State Utilities Commission to issue $750,000 of first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, and $600,000 in promisory notes to finance the construction of a new steam generating plant to cost $1,200,000.

Seventy-two girls at New York University were pledged to sororities at three branches of the university this term, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Dorothy McSparran Arnold, dean of women at the Washington Square College, Washington Square East.

As the development of new subdivisions is expected to play an important part in the construction gains during the coming Spring and Summer, Administrator Stewart McDonald of the FHA calls attention to the fact that when operative builders wish to obtain commitments to insure mortgages on houses, to be located in new developments, they are required to submit the subdivision proposal for approval.

Women who pride themselves on being stylish are supposed to have possessed themselves of the major pieces of their Spring wardrobes, and are now concentrating on accessories and trinkets to bring out the best in their new clothes.
Communism, which probably will receive its share of denunciation in the pulpits today, was attacked from a new angle yesterday-an egg hunt.

WINDING through much of the wild Everglades to connect the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico, Florida's new $17,000,000 canal, impressively christened a few days ago with a cruise of yachts, immediately becomes a waterway of major importance.

THE horse-and-buggy days have been superseded by the "speed age." but congestion in our streamlined city has increased to the point where only horse-and-buggy speeds are possible for the most modern motor vehicles.
The City College lacrosse team defeated a hard-playing New York Lacrosse Club squad, 11-9, in the opening contest of the season at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.
Arkansas, which enacted a ninetyday divorce law in 1931, has broadened it to permit severance of marriage ties without unpleasant charges.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. John W. Porte of Flemington, N. J., and Redland, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lillian Merril Porte, to Newton Clarence Bernheisel of New York.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Young of Mount Vernon, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Evans Young, to William Hall Ropes 5th of New Rochelle.

WITH no treaty restrictions upon the fleets of the world and each nation building warships accordneed, the United States Navy is entering upon a critical period in its development. At this juncture our navy has a new "high command."
Government food and farm experts said today that the food bill for the average family would increase during the rest of this year.

A concert of sacred music of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries will be given by the Dessoff Choirs, with Paul Boepple as conductor and Carl Weinrich as organist, the night of April 7 at the Church of the Incarnation for the benefit of the Bethlehem Day Nursery.

Thousands of persons from all parts of the nation are here for the Moravian Easter Sunrise services which will begin at 5 A. M. at historic Home Moravian Church and end in God's Acre, the burying ground, some minutes later.

The engagement of Miss Anne Louise Clifton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Clifton of Troy, N. Y., to Frank Gilbert Pfau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius W. Pfau of Yonkers, N. Y., has been announced by her parents.

Acquisition by New York state of the Holland Land Office Museum here for a historical building was suggested today by Chamber of Commerce officials who hope to interest Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, in the project.

The fifteenth biennial exhibition of contemporary American paintings was opened with a reception this evening at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. Beginning tomorrow it will be open to the public, the work remaining on view through May 9.

Official announcement was made today by the State Department of the designation by President Roosevelt of James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, as Special Ambassador and of General John J. Pershing, and Admiral Hugh rodman, retired, as the United States representatives at the coronation of King George VI at Westminster Abbey May 12.
A father's wedding gift to his daughter of about 28,000 lire worth of Treasury certificates has ironically started a bitter family court battle. [The lira was quoted yesterday at 5.2692 cents.]

Realty interests in Westchester County and especially in and around White Plains are practically unanimous in predicting that the White Plains Better Housing Exposition opening May 10 in the County Center will have a great stimulating effect in encouraging new home construction.
Captain Robert Rutherfurd Morris Emmet, U. S. N., and Mrs. Emmet will give a reception on Friday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Beulah Eaton Emmet.

Working in the costly media of gold, platinum and rare gems, two New York women, designers of precious ornaments, have in their brief careers created settings whose value if totaled would reach millions of dollars. Anonymous, like most designers, they nevertheless find much satisfaction in recognizing their finished work in the show windows of Fifth Avenue shops, and in the interest shown by passersby.
The mystery of the disappearance of William L. Adam, banker, who walked out of his home at 16 West Housatonic Street in the middle of the night on Sunday, April 9, 1933, is still unsolved.

A basketball double-header for the benefit of the Hospital of the Holy Family will be held at Arcadia Hall, Brooklyn, on Wednesday night. In the first game Barney Sedran's New York Whirlwinds will oppose the National City Bank five.

BARRIE portrayed his mother in "Margaret Ogilvie," Clarence Day immortalized his sire in "Life With Father," and Flannery Lewis has made a portrait of his grandmother that is worthy to hang in the same gallery.
The weekly secret conference of the Supreme Court justices furnished a prelude today to a possible decision Monday on the constitutionality of the much-disputed Wagner Labor Relations Act.

A new course in comparative Slavonic literature will be added to the curriculum at Vassar College next year. Nikander Strelsky, instructor in Russian, will conduct it. At present Harvard is the only other American institution offering a similar course.

Henry Egal, second in the 1937 national A. A. U. junior 1,000-yard run and third in the metropolitan 1,000, won both the mile and 880 in the fifth annual Military Athletic League handicap track and field meet before 2,500 spectators at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn last night.

Ten boys from this little village in the Lamoille Valley will start on Monday by automobile for Detroit, where they will present to Edgar A. Guest a supply of maple syrup made by one of the boys, Thomas Waterman, 15-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Waterman of Johnson.

A bill has been introduced into the Missouri Legislature providing for neighborhood protective and improvements associations, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Toward the government, in these hours of labor-capital travail, many distressed and well-meaning persons are turning and saying: "Why don't you do something about this awful labor unrest, these sit-down strikes and these demonstrations in our large cities?"
The Grand Ballroom of the Mosque Theatre in Newark, N. J., will be the scene of the seventh annual national open table tennis championship tournament starting on Thursday and concluding on Sunday.

SAN JUAN, P. R.-When a hundred people are wounded and a score are killed in a street battle, as at Ponce on Palm Sunday afternoon when Nationalists and police clashed, even a great deal of investigating may not clarify all the causes.

How to dramatize in a popular manner the most exacting scientific knowledge evolved by mankind is the ambitious undertaking of French savants who are planning an exhibit in the Grand Palais at the 1937 Paris exposition opening in the French capital in May.

Kid Chocolate, 127 pounds, former featherweight champion of the world, registered an easy triumph over Allie Todisco, 125 1/4, Jersey City, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Rockland Palace last night. A crowd of 2,500 persons saw the ex-ruler of the 126-pound division gain the decision over his courageous opponent.

Miss Elizabeth Larned Knight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert N. Knight of Westfield, was martried to John Morgan Sproul of Harrisonburg, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. William White Sproul of Middlebrook, Va., today, in the Westfield Presbyterian Church, by the Rev. Dr. William Kerr McKinney.
Westchester-in-Dartmouth will sponsor a dinner concert by the Dartmouth Musical Clubs and a dance on Tuesday evening at the Westchester Country Club here.

Essays eulogizing the contribution of American women to the progress of this country from 1825 to the present will be judged, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Kathmarine Bleecker Meigs, by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Dr. Eugene A. Colligan of Hunter College, Miss Fannie Hurst, Magistrate Anna M. Kross, and Dr. John H. Finley.
College women are more "peace conscious today than five years ago," according to a survey made by Miss Julia E. Blake, Professor of History at Georgian Court College here.
General Justin Tisseyre, 98year-old dean of French Army generals, died of pneumonia today at Sournia, a French village near the Spanish border.

Within recent weeks the local firemen have been called out for these reasons: To raise a ladder so that a resident could get into his locked home. To help bring down a little girl who had peevishly locked herself in her second floor room.

Laws governing savings, building and loan associations and cooperative banks were amended last year in seven States, according to The Building and Loan Annals for 1936, a publication of the United States Building an Loan League.

Mexican laborers and farmworkers are to be represented directly for the first time in the next Congress to be elected in June. This is the decision of President Lazaro Cardenas, and it means that he has definitely decided to forsake the course of moderation that he seemed likely to adopt two months ago and push Mexico further along its radical way.

Construction activity was 12.6 per cent greater in February than in January and 49.6 greater than in February last year, the Department of Labor announced today after a study of the number of permits issued.

Blazing wheels of fire will roll down hillsides, ancient religious processions will be revived, and eggs will be painted and eaten much as they are in the United States when Europe celebrates Easter Sunday.

A war by Japan against either Russia or China was called unlikely by Dr. Lin Yutany, Chinese author, in reply to a question at a luncheon forum yesterday in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

The 1937-1938 Citizens' Appeal for the Salvation Army will be launched at a meeting on April 6 at the organization's Centennial Memorial Auditorium, 120 West Fourteenth Street. Mrs. Robert H. Thayer of this city and Glen Cove, L. I.,

THIS book which was published in England under the title "Low Company," is the autobiography of a young man of 23 who recently completed a three-year term for burglary in Chelmsford prison Just why the publishers should be at pains to guarantee the authenticity of the book, or why English critics should join in a hallelujah chorus over it, one fails to see. Two or three such

Miss Eva Fleming, 42 years old, a former secretary, of Hackensack, N. J., was found dead at 8:20 o'clock last night in an apartment at 201 East Forty-seventh Street. Dr. Lawrence Dowd of 125 East Seventy-fourth Street said she had apparently suffered a heart attack.

P. Rogers Curtin, land and tax attorney for the Erie Railroad, died at his parents' home here on Thursday at the age of 34. His body will be sent to Corning for funeral services and burial Monday. A native of Corning,

Wielding a butcher knife like a cavalry sabre, Charles Granadno, proprietor of the grocery store at 228 West Twenty-fourth Street, near Eighth Avenue, routed four hold-up men at 11:30 o'clock last night. Two men were later arrested in hospitals, where they were seeking treatment for stab wounds, as members of the band. One was in a serious condition.

Miss Marie Dupuy Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lawrence of this place, was married here tonight in the First Presbyterian Church to William Thomas Miesse, son of Mrs. Clifton H. Miesse of West Orange and the late Mr. Miesse, by the pastor, the Rev. R. W. Sloan, who was assisted by the Rev. Raymond Lindquist of Orange.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Scoville Clarke, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. T. Wood Clarke of Cottage Place, Utica, N. Y., to Edward O'Hara of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred O'Hara of Norwhich, N. Y., has been announced by her parents.
The State of Louisiana is beginning to emerge slowly from the political control clamped upon it during the last few years of his life by United States Senator Huey P. Long.

While the economic upturn has stimulated a big volume of business for industrial and management engineers, rising labor and material expenses will sharply increase the demand for their services during the. second half of this year, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by executives of two of the leading companies in the field.

Argentine Army fliers tonight acclaimed Peru's crack army airman, Commander Armando Revoredo Iglesias, for his "daring and well-planned achievement" in making the first nonstop 2,000-mile solo flight between Lima and Buenos Aires.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee of John L. Lewis's C. I. O. increased its activities this week to sign up employes of independent steel concerns, using the non-strike clause of its contract with big steel subsidiaries as a particular appeal.

SALE of television receivers has increased rapidly in England since the price of the sets was reduced, according to reports from London. The British Broadcasting Corporation is conducting a symposium among tele-viewers to determine the type of entertainment preferred and the quality of reception.

IT was seventy years ago that Joseph Sabin projected his monumental "A Dictionary of Books Relating to America, From Its Discovery to the Present Time." In his Prospectus of Dec. 5, 1866, he announced his intention to include everything concerned with the political, governmental, military, economic,
Broad changes which . are expected to be a vital influence on the future growth of the city are being made in the zoning map of Manhattan.

Cut through the wildest area in New Hampshire, the new road from this town to the Canadian border is now about 50 per cent completed. Although the road opens a direct entrance into Canada, the type of construction does not make it a de luxe motoring highway, but drivers with a taste for adventure and a wish to explore new country wil be keen to try it out.

The broad acres where John D. Rockefeller Jr. played in his childhood are stirring with life again. Forest Hill, the historic Rockefeller estate in East Cleveland and Cleveland Heights, moved a step closer this week to the destiny planned for it.

Walter Holke, St. Louis Browns' scout, said today he was disappointed over the manner in which young baseball players avoided the catcher's mitt and mask. "Seems like they all want to play something besides catcher," he said.

More than 1,000 wine and spirit merchants, including representatives from leading distilleries, will embark here Thursday on the liner Ile de France, for a three-week "god-will" tour of wine and cognac producing sections of France.

THE Philharmonic Society of New Orleans, which last year celebrated its thirtieth anniversary, has just announced its program for next season, when it will present Kirsten Flagstad, Yehudi Menuhin, the Philadelphia Symphony (twice) and the Jooss Ballet in the Southern city.

PRO AND CON: "From the legal aspect of a [sit-down] strike, the law of trespass demands respect; yet no striker is a willful trespasser. Industrial and labor law must reflect mutual and not individual responsibility."-Senator Thomas.

Various dances in the near future have been arranged for younger members of society who are at home from colleges and schools for the Easter holidays. The majority of these parties are subscription dances of series that have been established for years, the subscribers including debutantes of next season or two or three years hence.

For the third time in less than two years, bandits robbed the Transcontinental and Western Air Line office at 70 East Forty-second Street yesterday and escaped with about $1,000 in cash and checks. Officials of the company announced that they had managed to stop payment on the $746 in checks.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Lorillard will return from Nassau, Bahamas, late this week and will be at the Pierre until going to their country home in Pomfret Center, Conn. Mrs. Edwards Spencer of 11 West Sixteenth Street has gone to Lenox, Mass., for Easter.

American farmers have boosted their income at least $66,000,000 a year by using disease-resistant varieties of important crops, G. H. Coons of the Department of Agriculture recently estimated. In 1935 disease-resistant varieties of plants were used on nearly 56,000,000 acres and the acreage is steadily gaining.

Paul Lukas, motion-picture actor, sailed last night on the French liner Paris to play in a film to be produced by the Phoenix Film Company of London. He said that he expected to be gone about seven weeks.
An augmented set of chimes constructed from discarded automobile brake drums will ring out the anthems of Easter tomorrow in the Baptist Church here.
Joseph G. Flynn renewed acquaintnn

For the benefit of members of the Mason-Dixon Track and Field Conference who plan to send teams to the forty-third annual University of Pennsylvania Relay Carnival, H. Jamison Swarts, manager of the two-day meet at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, April 23 and 24, is arranging a special championship race. The distance will be determined later.
MR. LANHAM'S third novel is about the post-war vagbonds of Montparnasse, their return to America, and their readjustment to life in New York and Texas.

To the Ridgewood Polo Club of New Jersey went- the first of the Eastern indoor polo championships last night when they nosed out the New York Athletic Club in a wildly exciting, extra-period final for the junior title at Squadron A Armory, 6 to 5 1/2.

Standard Tube Company Class B common stock, $1 par value, has been admitted to listing on the New York Curb Exchange. National Investors Corporation common and $5.50 preferred shares have been suspended from dealings on the Exchange.

AFTER a season as sterile as this one has been, perhaps it time to take stock of the American theatre again. Bad seasons are no novelty; we must be prepared for them without viewing the universe with alarm.
Vittorio Venturi, 147, of Italy, gained the decision over Ray Napolitano, 146 1/2, of Williamsburg, in the main bout of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove before 2,200 persons last night.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d and Joseph E. Widener were dinner hosts tonight at 11 Palmetto for Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio, Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Replogle, Prince and Princess Chlodwig Hohenlohe-Schillingsfurst, Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, Mr. and Mrs. Paulding Fosdick, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Waterbury, Mrs. Henry R. Rea, Mrs. William Randolph Hearst, Mrs. James P. Donahue and Charles A. Munn.

NEARLY one-fifth of motor vehicle fatalities in Maine in 1936 had liquor associated with them. This is the outstanding fact developed in a survey recently completed by the Maine Highway Safety Campaign. The fatalities attributed to this cause were fortytwo, or 19.5 per cent of the total of 215 deaths on the road.

THIS book's title is quite literal. The English author went into the high Himalayas on the Tibetan border and lived there for a season in a little hut, devoting himself to the religious meditation which was the purpose of his retirement from the world and when the publishers state on the book's jacket that Mr. Brunton "knows more about Yoga than any living Westerner" they probably are sure of their facts.
Branch Rickey, vice president of the St. Louis Cardinals, pulled the "Gas House Gang" back to earth today, terming the team the most overrated club in the major leagues.

Dr. and Mrs. George S. McLaughlin of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace McLaughlin, to Richard L. Snider of Washington, D. C., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Manning Snider of San Diego, Calif.

The engagement of Miss Catherine Creighton Cooke, daughter of Mrs. Mayme M. Cooke of. Bronxville, N. Y., and the late James Negley Cooke of Pittsburgh, to Alexander James Troy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander J. Troy, also of Bronxville, has been announced by her mother.

At a tea at their home this afternoon, Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Hoch of this place announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Donaldson Hoch, to Thomas C. Sheehan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Sheehan of Upper Montclair.
The Hershey Bears moved closer to the Eastern amateur icehockey championship tonight by nosing out the Atlantic City Sea Gulls in the third game of the playoff series, 3 to 2.

Virtual control of the financial management of the Boston Maine Railroad has been demanded by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as the only basis on which it will extend for two years a past-due note for $7,569,437 now held by the corporation, with accompanying collateral as security for past advances to the New England bridge line.

Miss Kathryn I. Young, daughter of Mrs. Leroy Mount Young of Babylon, L. I., and the late Mr. Young, was married here this afternoon in the First Methodist Church to George Emerick Brewer, son of Mrs. George Mellon Brewer of Spring Valley and the late Mr. Brewer.

Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander heads the executive committee for the performance of two one-act operas to be given by the Curtis Institute of Music under the direction of Fritz Reiner the night of April 11 at the New Amsterdam Theatre to aid the Henry Street Settlement Music School.
Preliminary arrangements are being made for the taking of the population census in 1940. Census officials estimate the job will require the services of more than 100,000.
A card party will be given for the benefit of the Brooklyn Home for Aged Men, 745 Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, on April 22, under the chairmanship of Mrs. J. Harry Alexander.

A 6-year-old boy, roused from sleep at 5 o'clock yesterday morning, gave the police information which ended a night long search for Joseph Vacirca Jr., also 6, who had been missing from his home in the Bronx since late Friday afternoon.

The fourth seeded team of Clifford P. Couch Jr. and Sumner D. Kilmarx and the third seeded pair of Charles M. O'Hearn and J. N. Hynson, both of the home club, gained the final of the national doubles tournament of the American Paddle Tennis Association at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club courts today.
The State Department figures that the Federal Government spends about fifty times as much on defensive equipment as it does for keeping out of war.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, owner of one of the largest racing strings in the world, is the man who will be elected next April 8 as the fiftieth member of the exclusive Jockey Club, for many years sole governing body for racing in much of the United States.

The Colgate UniversitY plan of having a group of social science students spend the first semester in Washington studying the government in operation will be continued. The plan was put into effect in the Fall of 1935.

ONLY a genius or a fool could hope to succeed in squeezig his impressions of New York--or even of an aspect of New York--into a paltry thousand words. Had I spent three days in New York I should have been too bewildered to write a line;

The Joseph-Pack bills calling for the creation of a system of mortgage banks under State supervision constituted one of the chief topics of conversation in real estate and mortgage circles here last week.

Improved business reported by many stores in the midtown and downtown business sections is, in a large measure, states the realty firm of Tankoos, Smith Co., being reflected in the revived activity in various neighborhood shopping areas throughout the city boroughs.
It is already evident that the thirty-six steeplechasers imported from France last January will have a marked effect on the cross-country sport in this country during the coming season.

Duke University Summer School will offer forestry courses this year for the first time. Students enrolled in the courses will be required to spend eight hours a day in the forest and in the laboratory.

THERE are many seasons of the year reflected by the issue of certain postage stamps, but none is more striking than the philatelic aspect of Eastertide. Each event commemorated during the Easter season has been honored by special postal adhesives. In 1926 Italy authorized the circulation of four stamps to aid in the propagation of the faith.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William T. West of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Emilie West, to John Ireland Howe McGiffert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian E. McGiffert of Easton, Pa.

Miss Sarah Jane Hood Webster, daughter of Samuel K. Webster of 2 Grace Court, Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Francis Thornton West 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. West 3d, of Brooklyn, formerly of Richmond and Norfolk. Va.
The West of Central Park Association, through its newly organized merchants' division, has started a drive to combat nuisances in the upper Broadway retail area.

American portraits and miniatures, rare silver by Colonial craftsmen, furniture of early New England and New York origin and early American glass from the collection of Herbert Lawton of Boston will be sold at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

An exhaustive but fruitless search by eighteen planes was made today for Lieutenant Robert C. Love of Los Angeles and Private Emory J. Parsons of Mineola, Texas, army fliers unreported since late last night on a sixty-four-mile flight from Glendale, Calif., to March Field.

Oklahoma has an excellent university, but sometimes we think that the people of the State are a better one. They are almost constantly engaged in what the medieval universities called disputations or determinations. The proponents set up a theme.

The Rev. Dr. Edgar Tilton Jr. surprised the congregation of the Harlem Reformed Church, East Eighty-ninth Street, yesterday at the close of his thirty-ninth consecutive Easter sermon there by announcing his intention to retire on Sept. 1.
Old-timers 'in this town where President Franklin Pierce was born recall a story about Pierce as a lad and his participation in what the oldsters now describe as a "sitdown." It seems that he became

The Department of Parks announced yesterday that the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park had agreed to release about 120 acres of land for the construction of part of an express highway link between the Triborough Bridge and Westchester parkways.
Shimshon Belkind, one of the founders of the Jewish colony of Rishon-le-Zion (First of Zion), died yesterday. He was 73 years old.

Floridas weather has cooled off tremendously, but Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers still are hot. Under gray skies and before a crowd of 1,100 fans, many of them in top coats and other snappy weather garb, the Flatbush boys ran their winning streak to five games by defeating the Reds today, 4-2.

An estimated 75,000 bundled and shivering spectators saw the eleventh annual Wichita Mountain Eastern Pageant, presented today in 22-degree weather at the base of wind-swept Mount Roosevelt, near here.

With the consent of Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Transportation, the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen has started a campaign to organize the motormen, conductors and trainmen employed on the city's Independent System, it was disclosed yesterday.

Opponents of the President's court reorganization program will resume their testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday. On that day Professor Erwin Griswold of Harvard, an authority on constitutional law, will be heard. On Wednesday Dorothy Thompson, writer and columnist, will appear for the opposition.

When the school at New London, Texas, blew up a little more than a week ago, and nearly five hundred children were killed at a single stroke, the whole nation was shocked and appalled by the extent of the disaster. The subject was on every tongue;

Prices of lard were depressed here early last week by liquidating sales of May contracts, only to rally later on moderate buying by shorts with offerings reduced. Packers' hedging sales were of fair volume. Cash trade was only fair.
Physicians in the last hours of life have been known to set down their dying symptoms for the benefit of science. But higher in the line of profession-

From back-of-the-scenes sources it is reported Japan is planning to cash in on the steamship business the Matson Line has built up between- the United States mainland and Hawaii. The Matson Lin{e and the Dollar Line heretofore have enjoyed a virtual monopoly under the law protecting inter-American routes for American ship companies.

Norm Smith, the Detroit Red Wings' ace goal tender, will be out of Tuesday's National Hockey League championship play-off game with the Montreal Canadiens because of an injury. Physicians said today the arm he hurt in a pile-up in front of the Detroit goal in last night's game would keep Smith out of action.

President Roosevelt braved a biting March wind in an open car today, to motor to Easter church services. At St. Thomas Episcopal Church, the President, with Mrs. Roosevelt, two grandchildren and Mrs. James Roosevelt, wife of his son, at his side, listened to the Rev. Howard S. Wilkinson preach an Easter sermon on the text, "Risen With Christ."

The Congress party refused today to form Ministries in three provinces-Bombay, Madras and the Central Provinces-in which the party had won majorities in the recent provincial elections. In a fourth province, Orisa, the Congress party leader informed the Governor that the chances of his forming a Ministry were remote.

Before a silver altar in front of the tomb of Christ the Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem celebrated today the Resurrection. A throng filled every point of vantage in the great church and hundreds, unable to gain admission. milled outside.
The vanguard of the experts in the fourth annual Augusta National golf tournament officially swung their clubs in practice rounds today.

The Yankees came out of a weird skirmish with the Bees at Waterfront Park today on the long end of a 6-5 score sweeping the seven-game series and maintaining an unbroken string of victories over the McKechnie clan for two years in a row.' They also added their eleventh triumph in fourteen bxhibitions this year in the citrus belt.

Cornelia Otis Skinner having arrived at the Lyceum, this is costurec drama week at that playhouse; which is to say that Miss Skinner last evening chose to begin her four-performance New York season with "The Loves of Charles II,"
The German wholesale price index on March 17 was 106.2, against 106.1 on March 10. Non-ferrous metals and rubber, rose sharply in the week.

The New York Rugby Club scored a surprising 6-0 victory over an allstar team from the Quebec English Rugby Union in the opening contest of a double-header at Randalls Island yesterday. In the other game Long Island University registered an even more startling upset with a 13-3 triumph over the French Rugby Club.
Brief personal testimonials instead of the traditional Easter sermon were given at the annual open-air services conducted by the Salvation Army in Washington Square yesterday morning.

Spring training in basketball will be inaugurated at Long Island University this year after the Easter holiday. The squad will drill outdoors as much as possible and practice will continue until the end of the semester. The sessions have been added to give the squad as much experience as possible before the next campaign.

Clarence Otis Bigelow of 133 West Seventy-eighth Street, pharmacist and banker, who was president of the West Side Savings Bank and for fifty-seven years proprietor of the drug store bearing his name at Eighth Street and Sixth Avenue, died yesterday afternoon in St. Luke's Hospital, after a fortnight's illness, at the age of 85.
Fred Perry defeated Big Bill Tilden in four sets tonight for his second straight victory in their professional tennis series. The scores were 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, 11-9.
The Law Department of the National Association of Manufacturers issued a twenty-nine page booklet today developing the contention that the sit-down strike is "clearly unlawful."

Albert Oscar Brown, former Governor of New Hampshire, died today after an illness of several months. His age was 84. A lawyer and a banker, Mr. Brown retired March I as president of the Amoskeag Savings Bank of Manchester. He was elected Governor in 1921 for two years on the Republican ticket.

It is "Farewell Summer," arriving tonight at the Fulton, that starts this lively week-lively, that is, for Broadway in the Spring. A couple of Texas newspaper men, North Bigbee and Walter Holbrook, are the authors of this comedydrama in which Lois Wilson, of the films, makes her New York stage debut.

Among the passengers due today from London via Plymouth on the steamship American Shipper of the United States Lines are Mr. and Mrs. Harry Ashworth, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Sowrey, Frederick J. Sowrey Jr., J. H. James and Miss Agnes Tennent.

Cardinal Hayes sang pontifical mass and at its close gave the papal benediction to almost 6,000 persons yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Every seat was filled and hundreds stood through the two-hour service.
Frank S. Mandel, widely known merchant and vice president of the Mandel Brothers department store, died today after an illness of several months in the Chicago Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old.

Two-year-old Virgin Islands rum, the first shipment of which is to be made within a week, is in such demand that the bottling plant is working twenty-four hours daily on three shifts, Boyd Brown, president of the Virgin Islands Company, who is en route to Washington, said here today.

It was Easter Sunday on the calendar today, but there was no Easter to be seen or felt in Madrid. Another Sunday has gone, and that is allwithout religious services, without [festivities, without color.

Offering will be made today by Lyon, Pruyn Co. and Stemmiler Co. of 40,000 shares of $1.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock of $20 par value, and 136,000 shares of $1 par common stock of the Eason Oil Company, Oklahoma.

President Roosevelt was informed yesterday by the American Labor party that it had obtained 30,000 signatures to a petition "endorsing in full the wise and essential proposals" for reorganization of the United States Supreme Court in the last three weeks.

Another young English writer has been killed. in action with the International Brigade in Spain, according to word just received here by Doubleday, Doran. He is C. St. John Sprague, who, although only 28 years old, had written several books on aviation, eight detective book-length stories, a novel and many poems.

The indoor polo season at Red Bank armory ended today with Silver Brook winning a round-robin with a total of 12 1/2 goals. The 112th Field Artillery trio finished second with 8 and Red Bank third with 7.

The stock markets were more cheerful at the end of their short business week on Thursday than at the outset. Continental European liquidation, which began at the end of last week, continued with disconcerting severity on Monday, but abated on Tuesday and then ceased completely.

It was bright and clear in the red hills north of Guadalajara as we stood on the rocky edge of a plateau, where a white road slanted down into a steep valley, and watched the Fascist troops on a tableland that rose sheer across the narrow valley.

Norman Bright, crack distance runner, oustepped Glenn Cunningham and Gene Venzke in the featured Cunningham Mile last night at the sixth annual Hill Military relay carnival. Venzke was second and Cunningham third.

A total of 2,585 boys in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx were aided in 1936 by the Big Brother Movement, Joseph H. McCoy, general secretary, announced yesterday. This total compares with 2,560 in 1935. he added.
The final opera concert of the season was given at the Metropolitan last night. A gala Easter program was presented, which was heard by a large and enthusiastic gathering. The offerings included

Mr. and Mrs. Marcus D. Richards of Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Fidelia Richards, to Oliver Gordon Stonington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar H. L. Stonington of this city. The announcement was made at a reception given yesterday at the Richards home in Winnetka.

Plans for a fifty-three-family apartment house in Brooklyn costing $154,000 have been filed by J. J. Millman, architect. The structure is to be located at 1,751-65 Seventy-fourth Street and will be six stories high. It will occupy a lot 79 by. 140 feet. H. Steinberg of 1,555 Fifty-fifth Street is the owner.

J. P. Morgan Co. and the National City Bank, as fiscal agents for the Argentine Republic 6 per cent bonds of May 1, 1926, have drawn for retirement on May 1 at par $204,500 of the bonds for the sinking fund. They have drawn also for retirement at par on the same date $204,500 of Argentine Government 6 per cent public works bonds of 1927 for the sinking fund.

Cornelius Van H. Erigert, former United States Minister Resident in Ethiopia, arrived here today from Cairo en route to the United States. The American legation at Addis Ababa has been placed in charge of a consul and is to be closed at the end of this month.
Three persons were killed and two others seriously injured in the crash of an automobile five miles south of York early today.

Disturbing messages to Germany from the United States, the new discord in the Spanish neutrality deliberations, and the Reich Government's intervention in favor of agriculture at the cost of industry counteracted this week a number of excellent corporation reports, and the Boerse languished as a result.

The labor situation in the United States is viewed here with great concern because each new labor victory strengthens the position of John L. Lewis and, it is believed, he is probably laying the basis for a complete social revolution and the creation of an influential labor party.

Eight matches, including five home encounters, have been scheduled this Spring for the Lehigh University varsity golf team of Bethlehem, Pa. The Lehigh linksmen are to begin their campaign on April 16 against the New Jersey State Teacher College squad.

Miss Marcella Hartman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Couvers Hartman of Columbus, Ohio, way married to David Albaugh Riehardson, son of William Payson Richardson, dean of the Brooklyn Iaw School of St. Lawrence University, and Mrs. Richardson of New York and Morristown, N. 3., yesterday in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman.

International intrigue coupled with plain ordinary theft, the skill of a master mind and the blunt hold-up methods of hoodlums. These are the forces that figured in the thefts of gold from the Homestake Mine at Lead, S. D., thefts now halted by the United States Secret Service. Some of the gold was transported across the Mexican border and back to facilitate its sale to the United States Government at $35 a fine ounce.

Snow shirts in ear-splitting colors dominated the Easter parade of grown-ups going to church in this tiny settlement on the shore of the frozen Arctic Ocean. As for the children, who have no illusions about the Arctic rabbit's egg-laying ability, choice bits of pickled whale hide made the day one of rejoicing.
With nearly perfect jumps of 199 and 196 feet for 229.9 points, Sigmund Ruud of Norway today won the Seattle Ski Club's annual tournament on the Beaver Lake Hill.

The sailing of the Hansa of the Hamburg-American Line, which was scheduled to leave for the Channel ports at 4 P. M. yesterday, was delayed six hours because of the heavy loadings of freight, Captain William Dreschel, the general superintendent, said.

Enthusiastic buying of all grains here and in Winnipeg last week carried prices to the best levels that the trade has seen in recent years, and virtually all the gains were maintained at the finish. May wheat on the Board

Henry F. McCarthy has been appointed passenger traffic manager of the Boston Maine and Maine Central Railroads and traffic manager of the Boston-Maine Airways. Frederick T. Grant, general passenger agent of the Boston Maine, is to hold the same position with

Although commodities in general continue to hold public attention, wheat again is occupying the dominant position. The Argentine Grain Board's warning that it may become necessary to restrict exports has given a fresh impetus toward the upward movement of prices, although it has been common knowledge that Argentina could not sustain exports indefinitely at the recent record rate without endangering domestic supplies.

Captain and Mrs. Peter Freuchen, in the Barbizon-Plaza, Central Park South. John 8. Melcher, Mrs. M. Leah Conrad, William V. Hawkins, William B. De Haven, in 410 Park Av.; Mrs. Margaret R. Tevor, in 823 Park Av.; Mrs. Grace A. Dwenger, in 145 E. 54th St.; renewals by Brett Wyckoff, brokers. Rltth Linda Hughes, Nathan Blank,

Governor Lehman observed his fiftyninth birthday quietly at the Executive mansion today, surrounded by members of his family. With the Governor and Mrs. Lehman were their three children, John, Peter and Hilda, home from school for the holidays, and Mrs. Lehman's mother.

A story of the phenomenal rise of Japan to a position of world economio importance is related by V. P. Copping of the Far Eastern Section of the Department of Commerce in a report made public today. It traces the political, social. scientific and economic progress of Japan since 1868.
Renee Wilde and Lora da Vinci made their first New York appearance as concert dancers in a joint recital last night at the Guild Theatre before an audience of fair size and marked friendliness.

Because pre-Easter trade gains, while substantial, were not entirely satisfactory, retail stores here next month will launch one of their most intensive April promotional campaigns in recent years, according to comment here.

The Fall fashion show of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers, Inc., will be held on June 2 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The fur exhibition is to be held June 2 to 4 at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 90 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in a week and 4 points in three weeks. The tonnage rate is the highest on record, passing that of June, 1929. Output then was at about 100 per cent of capacity, but a substantial increase in capacity has been made since then, largely from completion of -units begun before the depression started.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Huntington of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Blair Huntington, to Martin H. Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. B. Johnson of Lakeville. Miss Huntington was graduated from Vassar in 1934 and from the New York School of Social Work in 1936.

Morris E. Emory, '38, of Baltimore, outstanding 165-pounder, was unanimously re-elected to the captaincy of the Princeton wrestling team for next year at a meeting of lettermen held today before the annual wrestling dinner.

The annual Easter egg hunt by children of the colony was held this afternoon on the north lawn of the Greenbrier and was followed by a party in the terrace room. Louis de l'Aigle Munds, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis de l'Aigle Munds of New York, took first prize for finding the golden egg.

Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin is expected to arrive today on the Aquitania, and will be at the Ambassador before going to Providence, R. I. Mr. and Mrs. William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse will return to the Savoy-Plaza tomorrow from California. The Right Rev. Cameron J. Davis and Mrs. Davis are expected today at the St. Regis from Buffalo.

Mrs. Elizabeth Horton Hayward, 43 years old, wife of H. Gordon Hayward, vice president of the Nassau Union Bank of Glen Cove, and daughter-in-law of Harry G. Hayward, president of the institution, committed suicide this morning in the kitchen of her home on Vernon Avenue.

Turfdom will pause tomorrow in honor of its king-Man o' Warwho will celebrate his twentieth birthday anniversary. But to "Big Red," as he is affectionately known to owner Samuel Riddle, it will be just another day as he grazes peacefully on the Bluegrass farm near here. No observance is planned.

Four local unions organized under the banner of John L. Lewis in the Committee for Industrial Organization were suspended today from membership in the St. Louis Central Trades and Labor Union. ,The vote was 274 for suspension to 77 against, with 42 not voting.

A soccer game between Greek and Irish teams in the Bronx yesterday ended abruptly in a free-for-all fight in which the players and about 500-spectators joined. Two persons were taken to a hospital, four were

The money market here is featured by the fall in call money rates, which eased from 3 to 3 per cent last week to 13A to 2 per cent this week, due to the fact that the banks will retain until early April the money that was used to subscribe to the recent 4% per cent loan with exchange guarantee.

Florida pilots closed the ranks to outsiders today and captured all first places in the final races of the Moth Class regatta. In ideal conditions Don Hoeffler piloted Yellow Peril to first place in the suicide class for the Miami Yacht Club with 1,161 points.
Striking New England Transportation Company bus drivers tonight disrupted the firm's Boston-Providence, R. I., run and at least two tributary lines.

The pamphlet report of the General Electric Company for 1936, with earnings and balance sheet virtually as shown in the preliminary report issued early this month, says the International General Electric Company, Inc., had a profit of $6,302,597 available for interest on capital advances and for dividends. This compared with $2,458,079 for 1935.

The Cardinals snapped their six-game losing streak with major league clubs with a 7-6 triumph over the Tigers today. The Red Birds exhibited their best att of the Spring season in vanquishing the American Leaguers.

A cottage on the estate of Mrs. Charles D. Miller at mlithtown Branch, L. I., has been leased by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., to Mrs. A. N. Woody of Louisville. Ky. The Apartment Locating Bureau, Charles S. Welngart president, has opened an office for apartment renting, the first of a pro. posed chain of agencies, at 2,255 Broadway, at 81st St.
The annual Atlanta invitation tennis tournament will open tomorrow with a field including several highranked amateurs.

Subscriptions amounting to $10,497,500, or more than fifty-two times the amount of the offering, have been received for $200,000 of general mortgage bonds and accompanying common stock of the American Writing Paper Corporation, the company has announced.

Clarence W. Dolan, son of the late Thomas Dolan and executor of the Dolan estate, died of pneumonia today after a brief illness at his home in Narberth. He was 69 years old. Mr. Dolan was a member of the Philadelphia, Racquet, Radnor Hunt and Gulf Mills Golf Clubs here as well as several clubs in New York. He was graduated from Princeton in 1887.

The WPA Federal Symphony Orchestra at its concert in the Theatre of Music last night was conducted by Willem van Hoogstraten, who had not directed an indoor program in this city for more than a decade. For this event, which brought out a large audience, an interesting program had been arranged, containing Gluck's"Iphigenia in Aulis"

After a chase that lasted weeks and came to a climax in a gun fight, Alexander Pompeii, said to be wanted in the United States, was arrested here at 2 o'clock this morning. Announcement of the fact was made this evening by the Solicitor General of the republic.

The bondholders' protective committees for Vertientes Sugar Company's first mortgage sinking fund 7 per cent gold bonds, due in 1942, and for Camaguey Sugar Company's first mortgage sinking fund 7 per cent gold bonds, due in 1942, have extended, to June 15, the time in which holders of the bonds may deposit their securities in assent to the plans of reorganization of these corporations.

While many of the city's cliffdwellers were displaying their top hats in the Easter parade yesterday, keglers from Michigan, Illinois and Ohio were busily engaged in making places for themselves among the leaders in the American Bowling Congress at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

Outdoor Easter dawn services were held in many Northern New Jersey districts today with more than 40,000 persons attending, despite sub-freezing temperatures everywhere and snow flurries in some places.

The annual report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, which is to be sent to stockholders today, shows a consolidated net income for 1936 of $5,955,427, equal to 68 cents each on the 9,581,290 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of the year. This compares with a profit of $4,368,816 in 1935, or 50 cents a share on the common stock outstanding at the end of that year.

Miss Bessie Kadesh, 27 years old, injured in an attack in which her mother, Mrs. Celia Kadesh, 60, wife of Louis Kadesh, was murdered in their home, 324 Franklin Place, a week ago, died today in Muhlenburg Hospital without regaining consciousness.
So far as can be determined, capital does not seem to have been repatriated in any large volume during the last fortnight to subscribe to the 4 1/2 per cent loan.

With opportunities to meet the representatives of many governments in many capitals, the traveling correspondent learns to appraise and compare the diplomats of various countries as observers and sources of inside information. For diplomats, too,

After a two-cent rise in the last week, butter is now costing 6 cents a pound more than at this period last year, it was reported yesterday in the weekly Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets. Egg prices are normal for the season and there is a larger reserve supply than a year ago.

The Monarch Machine Tool Company, Sidney, Ohio, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for a proposed offering of 21,600 shares of no-par common stock. Of these, 12,000 are to be sold by the company to F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and Hawley, Huller Co., underwriters.

The following were the best ers for the week ended Satulway: NEW YORK Reported by the Ameeican News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanmaker's and Womrath's:

Prices of hogs here advanced to a new high level of $10.60 a hundredweight last week, the best in ten weeks and only 20 cents under the highest mark since last September. The closing price on Friday was $10.50. A year ago the best price was $10.80.

Worshipers who occupied all available space in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, heard the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector, present as a proof of the resurrection the transformation of character in Christ's disciples after that event.

An estranged husband turned his own unhappy Easter into a tragedy here today. He shot his two small sons in the head, wounding them so critically that they may die, and then fired one mortal shot through his own temple.
Eighty-two supply contracts under the Public Contracts Act, involving $5,279,848, were let by eleven government agencies in the week ended on March 25, the Department of Labor has announced.

The annual report of McKesson Robbins, Inc., for 1936, to be made public today, shows consolidated net earnings, after all charges, taxes and reserves, of $3,286,614, equal after preference dividends to $1.32 each on 1,282,983 common shares, compared with $2,029,359, or 34 cents a share, for 1935.

National Carloading Corp., space for its operating division in 136 Liberty St.; Charles G. Keller, broker; Hanford Henderson, Inc., agent. Anthony Angelides, furrier, in 109 W. 28th St.; Mrs. Amy Cunningham, beauty parlor, in 150 W. 58th St.; Brett Wyckoff, brokers.
New activity developed in the corn market last week, due to the taking-off of a fair sized line of hedges against the cash staple which was sold to consumers.

Bishop William T. Manning, addressing more than 5,000 persons who crowded the Cathedral of St. John the Divine for Easter services yesterday morning, called on all Christians to join in resisting the attack on civil and religious liberties which, he said, seeks to reject the teachings of Christ.

Michelangelo was found to be the most popular artist with the 1,108 art students participating in a survey conducted by the Grand Central School of Art, Edmund Greacen, president of the school, announced yesterday. Michelangelo's popularity rests not on his painting, according to the survey, but on his sculpture.

The golden opportunity of singing important roles at the Metropolitan Opera was awarded yesterday to Miss Maxine Stellman, soprano of Brattleboro, Vt., and Thomas Llyfnwy Thomas, baritone of Scranton, as winners of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air. They will sing during the Spring season, which will open May.
Chilling winds reduced the lower East Side's recognition that yesterday was Easter to a matter of individual fortitude rather then mass spectacle.
" Blind Justice" in Rome's legal circles now wears telescope glasses, and for the first time since childhood can see to read a newspaper.

Easter week in the New York galleries makes up in variety and in the unusual character of new exhibitions for a possible slight numerical decline. The French invasion, which has bulked so large on the season's calendar, continues, and several group exhibitions and annuals also appear on the roster of openings.

John D. Rockefeller's Easter automobile ride on the beach was cut short by a swiftly rising tide today. He sped back to his Winter home at fifty miles an hour. He was not endangered and could have left the beach for the highway, but apparently elected to ride the sand and watch the thundering surf throw spray and foam into the air.

In compliment to Miss Anne Benton and William Belden agyard of Pittsfield, who are to be 'rarried here on April 10, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Benton, will give a dance at the Hotel Wendell on April 9, the twenty-fifth inniversary of their marriage.

Leo Frei- and singer of Chicago, almost completely dominating the two-day pro- solo gram, captured the individual senior start men's title in the national indoor Th speed skating championships at the Chicago Arena tonight with four first places and one second, for a total of 140 points.

The Duke of Windsor formally bade farewell to Vienna and Enzesfeld Castle today. His farewell to Vienna took the form of reading a lesson in church; his farewell to Enzesfeld the form of a torchlight procession.

The Boerse was dull and slightly on the downgrade during this short trading week. Because of a premature leak in the news of the government's intended cut in nitrate and potash prices, stocks of the corporations affected began to fall early in the week and closed considerably lower.

Mrs. Sigmund Neustadt will give a luncheon April 6 at her home, 927 Fifth Avenue, for a group of women serving with her on the board of directors of the Travelers Aid Society of New York and others interested in the society's work. Mrs. James F. Shaw is executive vice president and chairman of the recently organized service committee of the society.

The National Labor Relations Board ordered today an election to determine whether licensed deck officers on vessels operated by the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company desire to be represented by the United Licensed Officers of the United States of America or by the national organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America for collective bargaining purposes.
Despite high winds at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday Z. G. Simmons finished with a card of 95 in the 100-target event. The score gave him the high scratch cup.
The wave mortality that started 1937 off with the poorest health prospects since 1933 has begun to decline, it was reported yesterday by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

The residence and two and one-half acres of land owned by Mrs. Jean P. Stanlaws on Riversville Road, Greenwich, has, been sold to Louis Cates of New York through Ladd Nichols. The property dates back to the Revolution and is assessed at $21,890.

Legislation ripping out of office the court-appointed members of the Fairmount Park Commission and the Board of City Trusts in Philadelphia will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow night, under the sponsorship of the Earle administration.

More and better trout streams available for New York anglers! That's rather welcome news and it's authentic, too. So this Saturday, besides being the opening day for trout fishing in the State, also will mark the opening of new areas to licensed fishermen.

When an Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females sold to Isidore G. Levine the flats at 172-174 W 81st St., at a price shown as $45,000, the buyer gave back a purchase money mortgage for $41,000, $2,500 to be paid next Sapt. 26 and the remainder on March 28 1942, at 4 per cent. Mr. Levine has conveyed this property to KC. M. . Estates Inc.

More than 1,500 worshipers, in heavy coats and mufflers, sang hymns and heard sermons at three outdoor Easter dawn services in Westchester today. Special musical programs featured indoor services in most of the Christian churches, while Passover ceremonies were conducted in Jewish synagogues throughout the county.

The truth of Christianity shall rise again in Russia and in Germany as it did upon Christ's resurrection even though that truth is badly crushed by the prevailing nationalism in these countries, the Rev. Edwin H. Rian declared yesterday in his sermon before the Presbyterian Church of America, worshiping at 310 Riverside Drive.

Gold imports continue on a large scale here, while exports are still mainly to the United States. An interesting recent movement has been the import of [Pound]3,200,000 of gold from Russia. This was immediately reshipped to the United States. however.

Tragedy marred today the first conquest of the hitherto unclimbed Mount Tren on the South Island of New Zealand. Three men of a party of nineteen slipped to death -from a height of 7,000 feet. One slipped on ice, dragging the others who were roped to him.

The marriage of Miss Kathryn M. Spiess, daughter of Mr. and AIw. Charles J. Spiess of New York, to Charles C. Reimer, son of Ms. Casper Reimer, also of this city and the late Mr. Reimer, took place last night in the Church of St. John the Evangelist in East Fifty-fifth Street. The ceremony was pew?? formed by the Rev. John V. Mechler.

The five-year dominance of New York University swordsmen on the strips and championship roster of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association appears at a temporary end. The Violet blade-wielders swept four of the seven crowns in the title tournament over the past week-end and what they missed Yale captured.

The four-story brick Building for nineteen families at 149-20 Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica, L. I., was sold by the Underwriters Trust Company, trustee, to an investing client of Sylvester F. Patte, broker. It is at the southwest corner of 150th Street and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $50,000.

On the ground that qualitative and quantitative limitation are inseparable, Japan has scrapped the last restriction on the competitive building of navies. On Saturday the Foreign Office in Tokyo announced it had notified Great Britain that Japan would not accept the 14-inch restriction on the size of naval guns, fixed in the London naval treaty of last year.

The cotton market moved within a narrow range last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange, prices of active contracts showed net changes of 15 to 30 points advance. The opening of the week brought active buying by foreign interests into the market and lifted prices sharply.

The financial report of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company for 1936, issued for publication today, shows consolidated net income of $15,881,829 after charges, taxes and depreciation, but before deduction for depletion of metal mines, equal to $1.83 a share on the 8,674,338 shares of capital stock outstanding. For 1935. the company reported net income of $11,180,087, or $1.29 a share.

Historians today misunderstand Christ because they can see Him only as a dead and not a living figure, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday in his sermon in the James Memorial Chapel of the seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, in an Easter message to the nation today, testified to his reliance on Christianity. General Chiang, who was baptized in the Methodist Church 1929, stated that during his captivity in Sian from Dec. 12 to Dec. 25, 1936, he read the Bible daily and "gained vital spiritual strength" therefrom.

The regional radio conference being held in Havana by representatives of the United States, Canada, Mexico and Cuba has reached an understanding on basic technical principles as a preliminary step toward calling an inter-American radio conference next November.

The Pennsylvania Railroad carried 64,617,913 passengers in 1936, the largest number since 1931, its annual report discloses. This total compared with 56,739,739 carried in 1935 and with 52,842,776 in 1933, the lowest total for the company in any year.
Betty Jean Hageman missed her father's Easter sermon today for the first time in her short life, but she spent the church hour baptizing two of her "babies."

Both the Catholic Bishop of Berlin and the Protestant Confessional Synod this morning issued Easter warnings to Christians in Germany to be on their guard and to protest the government's method of dealing with the churches.

Investment buying of housing properties featured real estate deals reported in Manhattan and the Bronx over the week-end. The building containing twelve apartments and two stores at 137 East Broadway was sold by Fannie Siegel to an investor who intends

The Montreal Maroons piled on the pressure after tying the score with a freak goal tonight and moved into the National Hockey League play-off semi-finals with a 4-1 triumph over the Boston Bruins. The victors in the second-place series will now continue against the New York Rangers, who won the play-off for the third-place teams.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed coregistrar for 4,379,819 shares of $5-par common stock of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation. Jules Bean, formerly of J. Arthur Warner Co., has become assistant vice president of the First New Amsterdam Corporation.

Miss Grace Slater of New York, who is the house guest of her brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Slater, assisted them in receiving at an Easter cocktail party they gave this afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Wyman Aldrich of New York were luncheon guests of Mr. and Mrs. Aldrich Dudley at the Bath Club.

The WPAreport on production and unemployment is more careful and sober than some of our new economists would like. It does not make one of those cocksure predictions that there will be a body of 5,000,000 or 7,000,000 permanent unemployed in this country-unless hours are sharply reduced, or a huge public works program is undertaken, or the Government takes private industry by the neck and "coordinates" and "plans" it.

While millions of dollars are being distributed to thousands of workers in this district in pay earned the first half of March, steel output will remain virtually unchanged at about 85 per cent this week.
A new course record for the St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race may be set tonight if the fresh northerly breeze which has blown almost continuously since the start holds for a few hours.
Far from London's crowds, King George VI and Queen Elizabeth attended Easter service today at the tiny church that Queen Victoria built for the tenants on the royal estate here.

T. D. Call is a banker by profession and a lender of money without interest to needy farm boys by inclination. Three years ago Mr. Call, executive vice president of the Bank of Cyril, decided to branch out from loans with cash interest to loans with the only interest the welfare of farm boys of this small community.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George C. Oakley of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris E. Oakley, to William R. Wright Jr., son of Mrs. William R. Wright of this city and the late Colonel Wright.

Twenty-five thousand persons, many of whom carried blankets and pillows and wore overshoes and earflaps, braved freezing temeratures and a biting March wind to attend an Easter sunrise service today at Temple University stadium.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Rentschler of Hartford, Conn., were honored at a dinner given by Colonel and Mrs. Harold A. Braman tonight. Other guests were Colonel and Mrs. William A. Bishop, Mr. and Mrs. George Stevenson Fenton, Prince and Princess Odescalchi, Mr. and Mrs. T. preston Davis, Mrs. Lawrence A. Furlong, Mrs. Hanna Carr and Miss Margaret Cidowley.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, left for New York this afternoon after another fruitless conference with Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, but Governor Frank Murphy announced that his conferences in the effort to settle the Chrysler strike would continue tomorrow.

The New York Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, and the Passon Club of Philadelphia played a 2-2 tie in a league contest at Starlight Park yesterday. A crowd of 2,000 watched the game.

As an observance appropriate to the season, and as the interpretation of a score superb in its coloring and extraordinarily communicative, even in a concert hall, of a mystical mood, the Prelude and abridged third act of Wagner's "Parsifal" were performed by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony
The National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday that the prevailing policy in industry today was to pay higher than the regular rate for overtime work.

Scammel St, 28, 27x95; William Weintraub to Emigrant Bank; consideration $1,000, foreclosure. 31st St, 172-174 W. 42x102.2 An Assocliation for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females to Isidore G. Levine. 263 W. 20th St. ($45). Same property. Isidore G. Levine to K. Md. Estates, Inc., 172 W R1stt t. mortgage S41.000 (51).

Introduction into the city schools of a revised edition of the classic McGuffey Readers, which contribute to the development of nineteenth century America, is being sought by a committee of forty-five parents, it was announced yesterday by Lester D. O'Dell, attorney and chairman of the group.

The Hinde Dauch paper Company has offered to holders of its $6 preferred stock the opportunity to exchange for each share held one share of its new $5 dividend preferred stock and $3 in cash, $1 of which represents accrued divi dends.

Mr. and Mrs. Manton B. Metcalf Jr. of New York entertained on a hay ride to Fassifern Farm for supper this evening. Yesterday's drag of the Bath County Hounds met at the Yard, home of Mrs. Fay Ingalls, the master. After the kill Mrs. Ingalls entertained at a hunt breakfast.
British trade activity is continuing at a high level. Its outstanding feature is the inability of the iron and steel industry to cope with the demand, although' it is working at full capacity.

Murray Armstrong played the hero role tonight to give the Syracuse Stars a 3-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Hornets in the third game of their International Hockey League play-off. The result put the Stars one game in the lead, with two victories on their home ice to one for Pittsburgh.

The State Department bowed today to the insistence of several unidentified "leading powers" that some of their secret diplomatic correspondence of recent years remain unpublished at this time. Dr. Cyril Wynne, chief of the Division of Research and Publication, said that the lapse of time between an event's occurrence and publication of the diplomatic papers in the State Department's volumes on foreign relations had resulted from objections by some foreign nations.

Formation of Schmidt, Poole Co., with offices in the FidelityPhiladelphia Trust Building, Philadelphia, to conduct a general investment securities business, is announced. Partners are SAimuel W. Parke, Donald W. Poole, Osborne R. Roberts and Walter A. Schmidt.
Rainbow, successful defender of the America's Cup in 1934, left Bath at the end of a tow rope today for Bristol, R. I., to be groomed for this Spring's cup defense trials.

Stocks irregularly higher in less active trading; turnover, 6,830,960 shares. United States Government bonds recovered after declines and closed irregular on the week, other issues mixed in trends; transactions $73,532,400.

The display of Easter flowers at the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx Park, was visited by more than 10,000 persons yesterday. Crowds pressed into the greenhouse doors in such numbers that when it came time to close at 4 o'clock officials decided to remain open longer to accommodate the people unable to get in. At 5:15 o'clock,
Marshall Eldridge, Class A record holder, rounded up 2,940 points as the inaugural power boat regatta on St. Andrews Bay ended today to capture the Walter Sherman Challenge Trophy.

An important factor in German economic opinion at this time is the United States business outlook. As the Wall Street collapse of 1929 was merely one facet of the universal depression, many believe that a new American crisis again would involve the whole world, including Germany.

" High Tor," Maxwell Anderson's fantasy of the Hudson Highlands, is "the best American play of the 1936-37 season," in the opinion of a majority of the New York Drama Critics Circle, it was announced yesterday.

In a report to its members on pending legislation, the Methodist Federation for Social - Service charged yesterday that the House Neutrality Bill giving the President power to embargo secondary materials of war at his discretion actually granted to him the power to bring the United States into another war.

Supreme Court decisions in public utility cases since the appointments of Justices Sutherland, Butler and Roberts have had the effect of "practically nullifying State regulation of utilities and Federal

Dr. Francis Ransom Lane, for many years a prominent educator, died here today at the age of 78. He was director of high schools in the District of Columbia from 1894 to 1902, after holding several other executive positions in the Washington school system.

Heavy coats, turned-up collars, woolen mufflers and furs were in vogue yesterday in what passed for Easter parades at the shore resorts in the metropolitan area. Chilly west winds discouraged most of the

The engagement has been announced of Miss Marie Eugenie Thebaud, second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Thebaud of White Plains, N. Y., to Douglass Mabee Compton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ranulf Compton of Madison, Conn.

Bond transactions of the Public Works Administration have brought an average of $187,912 a week into the Federal Treasury, the PWA reported today. This sum represents the profit Zrom bond sales and interest collected, and the average is based on the record of nineteen weeks.

More than 1,000 Negro men and women and a few white persons marched for two and a half hours yesterday afternoon in a procession on the East Side arranged by Fatheir Divine. It was cold, but the marchers did not seem to mind, in spite of their light garments.

Opposing President Roosevelt's proposal for enlarging the Supreme Court, Charles C. Burlingham, former president of the American Bar Association, declared last night that the fundamental question was not the New Deal, the size of the court or the age of the judges, but

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York, president of the American Jewish Congress, and Canon Anson Phelps Stokes of Washington Cathedral, president of the Educational Committee for Work Among Negroes, agreed tonight in a panel discussion at the Town Hall of Washington that knowledge and faith were the great requisites for combating religious persecution.
Walter Wanger's "History Is Made at Night," which the gentle week-end zephyrs wafted into the Rivoli, is as unreasonably likable a film as we have chuckled over and snorted at this season.

Making a clean sweep of their three-game series with the Baltimore Orioles, the New York Rovers tonight won the Hershey Cup, consolution trophy of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League. The fast attack the Rovers displayed throughout the Hershey Cup series carried them to an 8-to-3 umph tonight. It was the largest score of the series.

More than 3,000 Greek-Americans celebrated the 116th anniversary of their revolution of independence from Turkey last night at a mass meeting at the St. Nicholas Palace, Sixty-sixth Street and Columbus Avenue.

A change in tutorial instruction for Harvard College undergraduates "in recognition of the general opinion that all students are not equally capable or desirous of profiting by tutorial instruction as compared to course instruction" was announced tonight by Dean Hanford.

Walter Cantley, Whitemarsh Valley Country ClubPhiladelphia, won the fifteenth annual Eastern States Easter golf tournament today, deeating Clarence (Spike) Fisher, home club champion, 1 up, in the final.

The New York University College of Medicine will begin a comprehensive one-year study of self-inflicted deaths in the New York area under the auspices of the Committee for the Study of Suicide, Dr. John Wyckoff, dean of the College of Medicine, announced yesterday.
After a period of more or less diplomatic tension, Europe has spent one of the most placid Easters in recent years. This is not to say that nationalistic storms are over.

The United States market is puzzling to observers here. On the one hand, government authorities in the United States are regarded as clearly ready to take action to prevent the development of a boom, while the labor position is, to put it mildly, awkward.

Not often do the Sunday night benefit patrons witness an entertainment of as high a caliber as that presented last evening by the Friars Club at the Alvin Theatre. It was the group's first public Frolic in three years and brought out many leading lights of the amusement field.

NOEL COWARD is the Leonardo of the entertainers, a first-rate wit, pretends to be nothing else. Why it is that so many persons feel that they owe a duty, that of informing the public as each new Coward item appears that Mr. Coward is not a heavy thinker in the German style, and that he is primarily interested in the theatre and, so, unimportant, is mysterious.

Julius Manger, owner of hotels in New York, Boston, Chicago and Washington, died suddenly here today in his suite at the Hay-Adams House. He was 69 years old. Mr. Manger was born at Boonville, Mo., and was graduated from Tulane University Law School.

The Continental Oil Company has reported for 1936 a consolidated net income of $9,612,596 after charges, depreciation, depletion, intangible development costs and taxes, equal to $2.05 a share on the 4,682,614 shares of capital stock outstanding, exclusive of the 55,978 shares in the company's treasury.

Mrs. Sophea Black Pierrong of this city was married to Mayor Amos M. Kidder of Tenafly, N. J., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in the presence of Mr. Kidder's daughter, Miss Lucy E. Kidder; his son, Amos M. Kidder 3d, and a few friends.

More than $22,000 of the latest subscriptions to World's Fair debentures was subscribed by members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local No. 3, which has undertaken to sell $100,000 of debentures to its members by April 15, Richard Whitney,

For what is believed to be the first time since the days of the Legitimate Theatre Code, representatives of all stage groups will meet here the week of May 17 under the auspices of the American Theatre Council.

Newman Av. (14-3476), n. e. cor. O'Brien Av., 100x50; Roger F. Rlnn to Alfred Q. Elgar, 4,814 Osgood St. St. Ann's Av., 127 (9-2269), also St. Ann's Av., 131; Vito A. Miloscla to Giuseppe Miloscla, 127 St. Ann's Av. Edison Av., 1,254 (18-5336): Leon Goldenthal to Marie Casetta, 1.532 Leland AV.
