The rise in commodity prices is fully overshadowing all other economic problems and is being watched with growing interest in Holland because the Dutch colonial empire is large producer of commodities and on a rise in prices depends a considerable part of that empire's prosperity.

Alexander Kinderman, caretaker of the West End Synagogue which was the scene of three probably incendiary fires Saturday, was still being questioned yesterday by Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy in connection with the blazes, the last of which wrecked the entire south end of the synagogue at 160 West Eightv-second Street.

Pope Pius shared his joy for his reestablished health with 250,000 persons gathered today both inside and outside St. Peter's, from Rome and from the ends of the earth, to cheer him on his first public appearance since he fell ill last December.
A plea for strong individuality, against the "mass" trend of political and economic affairs, was made today by Dr. Charles Alexander Richmond, president emeritus of Union College.

A check-up of eight Barnard College girls who started this semester overweight revealed yesterday the success of an extra-curricular "course" in dieting with weight losses of from three to four pounds a week.

Up-State New Yorkers paraded in new Easter bonnets today but shelved the rest of their Spring ensembles in favor of warmer garments. Churches were jammed for Easter services, but those who came wore fur .coats and heavy suits instead of the traditional Spring frocks and topcoats.

The board of directors of the Juilliard School of Music announced yesterday the resignation of John Erskine, author and musician, as president of the school, effective July 1, and the appointment of Ernest Hutcheson, concert pianist and dean of the school, to succeed him.

The motor ship Heian Maru, bearing Prince Yasuhito Chichibu and his Princess on the first leg of their 10,000-mile journey to the coronation of King George and Queen Elizabeth, sailed into Canadian waters tonight as preparations were made on the mainland for an elaborate celebration when the imperial couple reach there tomorrow.

Dense smoke from a smouldering wood fire in Riverside Drive Park near Ninety-fifth Street early last night caused a major traffic tie-up for a mile in either direction along the Drive when motorists were compelled to drive slowly through the blinding smoke.

The coincidence of Passover and Easter Sunday yesterday prompted members of the rabbinate of New York City, among other things, to appeal for modernization of religion, emphasizing brotherhood, for more and not less religion, also for preservation of Palestine as the Jewish homeland.

The report of the Duquesne Light Company for 1936, made public today by F. R. Phillips, president, showed total operating revenues of $27,784,049.26, a gain of $2,002,138.76, or 7.77 per cent, over 1935. Net operating revenue, before appropriation for retirement reserve, amounted to $15,081,219,62.
Mr. and Mrs. John S. McKnight of Amarillo, Texas, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eula Lee McKnight, to William Pelton Wright Jr. of this city and Boston.

Germain G. Glidden of the Harvard Club, who recently retained his national championship, has been ranked first among the Class A players in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association for the past campaign, it was announced yesterday.

Emphasizing the importance of the City Planning Commission under the new city charter, the Merchants Association announced yesterday that it would seek to have members of the commission picked from a selected panel of names furnished by qualified civic, professional and technical organizations.

Sao Paulo's cotton exports of the 1936-37 crop, it is estimated, will be better than those in 1935-36 by 20 per cent, computing orders already booked and business on the way to be closed. While last year Great Britain led, it is believed that Japan will take the leadership this year.

Miss Suzanne Jeanne Searle, daughter of Clarence Eugene Searle of this place, has chosen April 23 for her wedding to Horace Brinton Passmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Hershey Passmore of Pelham. The ceremony will be performed at her father's home here and will be followed by a reception.

There has been little fresh evidence lately of any further return of British banknotes from the Continent of Europe, while because of the Easter holiday demand for currency the Bank of England's circulation this week recorded a sharp increase of f6,711,000.

Fearing to violate a village ruling which prohibits fire trucks from going outside the incorporated limits, Chief William Sinn ordered all apparatus parked inside the limits at 2 A. M. today and hose stretched to combat a fire in a two-story building about 100 feet over the village line.

Through their attorney, Louis Waldman, more than 3,000 employes of the Park Department asked Mayor La Guardia yesterday to meet a committee of their organization to consider a demand for a wage increase. Mr. Waldman told the Mayor in a letter that investigation had disclosed that "there is a widespread discontent among the employes by reason of the fact that they are receiving a sub-standard wage."
Five persons were killed here today when a Southern Railway passenger train struck their automobile at a crossing on the edge of the city.

About 1,000 persons braved a cutting wind at 7 A. M. yesterday to attend the sixteenth annual Easter dawn service on the steps of the Low Memorial Library at Columbia University. The program was under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.
Leading jurists of the New World will convene here April 5 to continue the work of international law codification and consider related problems, the Pan American Union announced today.

Joe J. Nelson, head starter for three years at the Alamo Downs race track here, disclaimed all conaection with narcotics and narcotic rings today as he awaited arraignment on a Federal drug charge. He was arrested on a Federal warrant esterday in a hotel room,

The Federal Reserve System has ample power to prevent the existing swift advance in commodity prices from developing into price inflation, provided the Federal budget can be brought under control, declares the Guaranty Trust Company in a discussion of the problem of world prices and business recovery in the current issue of its publication, The Guaranty Survey.

First International Conference on Fever Therapy begins at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this morning at 9 o'clock and continues Tuesday and Wednesday. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Everyday Mental Hygiene," David Seabury.

James Beriah Frazier, Tennessee statesman who for almost half a century was a leader in the affairs of the State which elected him twice as its Governor and once as United States Senator, died suddenly of a heart attack at his residence here this afternoon. His age was 80.

" The most precious value we know is human personality," Algernon D. Black declared yesterday morning in an address before the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixtyfourth Street.

The sit-down strike was branded as illegal and publicly disavowed today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor. He warned labor against this new weapon in industrial disputes and asserted that its use involved "grave implications detrimental to labor's interests."

Local Republican leaders sought unsuccessfully last week to learn from close friends of Mayor La Guardia whether he intends to run for re-election and if so, whether he wants the Republican nomination.

Joseph Stalin is fed up with the personal adulation that has been heaped upon him in increasing measure in recent years and he has decided to have it modulated, if not completely ended. This is according to many indications here.

JOHN BURROUGHS, Who began his journey of life a century ago this week, said when he was approaching the summit of his years that the longer he lived the more his mind dwelt upon the beauty and wonder of the world.

With weather conditions slowly clearing along the remaining 1,800 miles of our route to Auckland, New Zealand, the probabilities are that the Pan American Clipper, on its survey flight, will take off at dawn on Tuesday.

The scheduled arrival tomorrow of Norman Davis as chief United States delegate to the international sugar conference opening here April 5 occations mixed reactions, based on reports that he may wish to sound out sentiment on arms reduction.

High northwesterly winds today which had the waters of the harbor whipped into a frenzy made it unsafe for the Frostbite Fleet of the Larchmont Yacht Club, forcing the race committee to postpone the regular Sunday regatta for the second successive time.

The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday the three winners in this year's Rome Prize competition in classical studies. They are William T. Avery of East Cleveland, Ohio; Lester C. Houck of Port Huron, Mich., and Erling C. Olsen of Maplewood, N. J.

The award of 135 baccalaureate and advanced degrees to students of Cornell University who completed their work at the end of the first term on Feb. 10, was announced today by President Livingston Farrand.
Declines on the Bourse were accentuated on Monday, when sales of securities by subscribers to the government loan were accompanied by hasty Liquidation of bullish positions.

Miss Anne Sullivan was killed and her sister, Miss Veronica Sullivan, was injured this evening when a light roadster driven by the former overturned on Valley Road here. Police said the car ran off the concreate onto a soft shoulder and the driver apparently turned the wheel too sharply in the opposite direction, causing the machine to swerve back to the pavement and roll completely over, landing upright and facing the opposite direction.

Hundreds of bereaved relatives and friends stood solemnly with moist eyes in crisp, bright weather this Easter afternoon and heard comforting words in a memorial service for the estimated 455 who died in a school gas explosion ten days ago.

The drought and famine that have settled down on Szechwan Province have reduced 10,000,000 persons, a fifth of the province's population, to the verge of starvation, foreign missionaries here estimated today. The missionaries, trying to carry on relief work among the peasantry, are considered the best

Picturing a bright future for selfgovernment in the United States, but at the same time declaring that a broad understanding of economic facts is sadly lacking in America, Dr. Stanley High, founder and director of the Good Neighbor League, addressed a large audience gathered in Memorial Hall at the University of North Carolina tonight for the opening session of the fourth Human Relations Institute.

Germany's coal output for the first two months of 1937 was 29,150,000 tons, against 26,300,000 tons correspondingly in 1936. Steel ingot output in February was 1,519,600 tons, against 1,534,000 tons the month before. The home pigiron demand was active, and foreign demand again increased, with erratic and sometimes enormous price rises.

After three months of comparative inactivity by Congress, the Senate will busy itself this week with major legislation, including crop insurance and the Guffey-Vinson coal measure. The House has legislative and District of Columbia appropriation bills before it.

The "Strasbourg Strangler," one of Europe's most dreaded criminals, struck again tonight, spreading terror in this old Alsatian city. Screams in the poor quarter of the city led to discovery of the body of Marie Karcher, 23. The police said she was a victim of the mysterious killer.

Champion De Lou's Rea, smooth coated red dachshund owned by Mrs. H. D. Sims of Dallas, Texas, won the special for best in show tonight at the close of the twenty-fifth annual exhibition of the Mississippi Valley Kennel Club.

The Connecticut River Power Company, controlled by the New England Power Association, in the annual report it issued yesterday for 1936, shows a net income of $1,448,912, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.26 a share on the common stock outstanding at the end of the year.

More than two thousand persons attended the Easter services at Trinity Church at Wall Street yesterday, giving the festive air of an Easter parade to lower Broadway and the narrow streets of the financial district. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of the church, preached the sermon.

Appointment of Philip E. McIntyre as assistant general freight traffic manager of the International Mercantile Marine Company, effective May 1, was announced yesterday by Basil Harris, vice president in charge of freight.

Mrs. Lucretia L. Blankenburg, a leader in women's suffrage and civic reform movements, who had been known for years as Philadelphia's "grand old lady," died of pneumonia today in her apartment at the Beljevue-Stratford after an illness of three days. She would have been 92 years old on May 8.

Delegates to the special national convention of the Socialist party elected a national executive committee tonight, which, for the first time in more than ten years, did not include the name of Mayor Daniel W. Hoan of Milwaukee.

The split between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, together with the latter's recent rise, raises the question as to which of them shall represent American labor in the International Labor Organization, which is understood here to be causing concern now in Washington as well as in Geneva.

Grey Count, crack 3-year-old owned by Anthony Pelleteri, received a beautiful ride from Jockey Charles Corbett to capture the sixteenth Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds today. The victory brought $7,840 to the owner, the winner's share of the $10,000 added purse. Those who invested $2 on the colt's nose got $14.40 back.

Oliver Brothers, Inc., a hardware purchasing agency of 417-421 Canal Street, New York, and eleven buying and selling companies for which it acts as agent, were charged with violation of the so-called brokerage clause of the Robinson-Patman Act in a complaint which the Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had issued.
Fifty-nine of the passengers due to reach New York aboard the Aquitania Tuesday, after a cruise to South America, will have a tale to tell of stormy adventure off Montevideo.

An Easter nap was rudely awakened for Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Gooding today by an auto which crashed through the side of their house and into bed with them. Mrs. Gooding, 27, was injured. Her husband escaped. The autocame to rest on the bed.

A "small army" of Boy Scouts, reinforced by National Guardsmen, two Federal agents and CCC men, tramped through rugged wilds near here again today without uncovering "a single definite clue" to the disappearance of Scoutmaster Robert W. Miller, missing since Wednesday.

The Easter message, reduced to its simplest terms, is that there is a life after death, the Rev. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Commerce Department officials have laid the groundwork for a proposed $15,000,000 census of the unemployed which Congressional advocates say would "let us know where -we are when relief needs are considered." Several bills authorSizing a nation-wide count of the jobless are pending.

Weakened from lack of proper food and suffering from the illnesses of age, an aged couple were taken to Bellevue Hospital last night after they had been found lying weakly in bed in their threeroom apartment at 635 First Avenue, near Thirty-seventh Street, where they have lived for sixteen years.

Celia Adler has organized a company to present a number of plays in a limited engagement at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre and presented there on Saturday night "The Simple Woman," in a Yiddish adaptation of N. Constantinowitz, from the Russian of Igor Charadieff.
The National Labor Relations Board in the seventeen months of its active operations has averted 101 threatened strikes involving 30,067 workers, the board asserted in a report made public today.

An early goal by Frank (Junie) Stubbs gave the Boston Olympics a 1-to-O victbry over the Holzbaugh-Ford sextet of Detroit to win the National A. A. U. hockey championship before 500 spectators at the Boston I Garden this afternoon.
After another day of intermittent conferences, prospects of a settlement tomorrow of the general hosiery strike here developed this evening.
The announced German price of wheat for the crop year 1937-38 is unchanged, while the price of rye has been advanced 20 marks a ton.
Middle West residents observed the religious holiday and paraded their Easter finery today beneath clear to partially cloudy skies and with cold temperatures.

The body of Mgr. John M. Hilpert, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of Catherine of Genoa, Linden Boulevard and Albany Avenue, who was suffocated in a fire in the rectory at 520 Linden Bourevard early yesterday, a few hours before he was to have celebrated Easter services. will lie in state at the

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Smith of 941 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Alice Smith, to Gerald Hughes Phipps, son of former United States Senator and Mrs. Lawrence C. Phipps of Denver. The announcement was made yesterday at a tea given by Mr. and Mrs. Smith at their home.
Activity in the wholesale market here last week stressed coats and suits, in anticipation of continued demand through April. Coats were called for in dressy, untrimmed styles, in navy and black.

The Summer field training schedule for 21,000 members of the New York National Guard was announced today by Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander. The encampments, starting June 13, will be at Camp Smith, Peekskill;

BONAPARTE, by Eugene Tarle. (Knight, $4.50.) A new biography of Napoleon. JUAN IN CHINA, by Eric Linklater. (Farrar Rinehart, 2.50.) A racy novel of a young adventurer's career in China. DIABETES: A MODERN MANUAL, by Anthony M. Sindoni Jr. .Whit.tlesey House, $2.) Answers to questions about diabetes.

Archbishop John T. McNicholas, head of the Cincinnati Archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church, in an Easter sermon today counseled labor to unite, called sit-down strikes dangerous and foresaw government intervention.

Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta and Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, schoolgirl golfers, defeated Miss Marion Miley, veteran Lexington, Ky., campaigner, and Miss Babe Didrikson, Texas professional, by 2 up in an exhibition match today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,720,388,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 94.4, which compares with 93.7 a week before, 92.9 two weeks before, 91.1 three weeks before and 90.9 four weeks before.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, a sure harbinger of Spring, will leave Winter quarters here this week for New York. The first section, forty railroad cars, will rumble north on Thursday. It will carry performers, officials, wild animals and equipment needed for the opening performance in Madison Square Garden the Thursday following, on April 8.

The index for wholesale prices in France fell slightly to 533 on March 20, compared with 534 on March 13 and with 535 on March 6. The decline affected imported products for the most part, these falling to 504; Native products rose, foodstuffs were unchanged, and industrial materials declined slightly.

True religion means betting one's life that there is a God, and that is what Jesus Christ did on Calvary, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday morning in an Easter sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fiftyfifth Street.

The National Labor Committee for Jewish Workers in Palestine announced donations of $25,000 by the 2,000 that attended its third Passover Seder celebration, held last night in the Hotel Commodore. The money is to be used for the support of the Federation of Jewish Labor in Palestine.

Keen winds and vagrant sunshine quickened the pace of New York's Easter observance yesterday without entirely obscuring the recurrent brilliance of the joint festival of church and season. Only the more earthly aspects were affected by weather conditions, for, if the curtain rose and fell abruptly on the fashion promenade, it served to center attention on the magnificence of the religious services.

Charlie White and his new Little Red Book of baseball records should be credited with an assist for digging up a set of chuckle-provoking freaks that were overlooked in the batting records during the 1936 season, reports The Associated Press. White's annual publication is the baseball writer's accepted "bible" of standardsfor all diamond history.

After attending Easter services and the baptism of her three small daughters, Mrs. John Martin, 25 years old, was found hanged and the three children strangled to death in the bedroom of their home late today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his column of March 23 relative to Representative Wadsworth's proposal ior time limits-on constitutional amendments, Arthur Krock refers to the pending child labor amendment as a "textual blunder."

Invention of a machine with a memory, named the memnoscope, which stores up in a bit of "gray matter" made of aluminum foil and copper an electrical image that can afterward be recalled in its original likeness, was announced here today.

With only three days remaining before the expiration of the existing agreement in the bituminous industry, representatives of the United Mine Workers and operators of eight States, working through the Appalachian Wage Conference, will resume their negotiations this morning in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, in a final effort to reach an accord.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey will send the record of the restaurant racket trial to the Bar Association's grievance committee for scrutiny in connection with testimony concerning the law firm of Goldsmith Felix, 545 Fifth Avenue, it was disclosed yesterday.

Award of sixty-one fellowships with a total value of $130,000 to American scientists, scholars, writers, composers and artists for research in their fields during 1937 was announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, founded in 1925 by the

High gun honors in the first fifty at the North Jersey Gun Club's weekly shoot at Fairfield today went to A. F. Streelman with a score of 46 hits. W. N. Drake led on handicap with a card of 48 and E. H. Willis was next with 47.

242d St. (17-5115), n. s., 204 ft. e. of White Plains Rd., 25x100; Frederick Heine to Eastchester Savings Bank, 22 E. 1st ST., Mount Vernon, k per cent; $13,000. Fox St., 1,034 (10-2726); Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Max Brill, 2,548 Davidson Av., extends mtg. to Feb. 8, 1942, 5 per cent; $24,000.

Easter week parades to commemorate the insurrection of 1916 were held all over the Irish Free State this week-end. With the coming of these annual ceremonies, the proscribed Irish Republican Army, which had been quiescent for many months past, became galvanized into life, and public meetings with processions were scheduled to be held at Castlebar, County Mayo, and Birr, Tipperary, today.

A spiritual balance sheet to fore-' cast the state of the soul for twenty years was urged upon the Eastern Sunday audience in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, the rector.

The Philadelphia Sphas evened the American Pro Basketball League championship play-off series today with a 39-to-36 victory over the Jersey Reds. The Reds handed the Sphas a 36-to-31 setback at Philadelphia last night.

Twenty-eight prison guards, two from each of the fourteen State institutions, are to be trained in fire prevention and extinguishment at the Fire College in Long Island City, Queens, it was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott. The course probably will be started in a week.

John H. Barr, former Professor of Machine Design and trustee of Cornell University, died last night. He was 75 years old. He spent many years on the engineering side of typewriter development and had held some sixty American and many foreign patents for improvements in typewriter design during his years with the Smith-Premier, Union and Remington typewriter companies.

Navy officials declared today that oharges by Harry B. Ahrens, county commander of the American Legion at Brooklyn, -that the destroyers Mahan, Reid and Cummings had had to be reconditioned in the Brooklyn navy yard at a cost of $2,500,000 because of defective construction work in private shipyards were "absurd."

A new series of concerts, designed as a survey of music for small orchestra from the seventeenth century to the present, will be given by the Federal Music Project Chamber Orchestra, beginning April 23, in the WPA Theatre of Music. Among the guest condoctors will be Quinto Maganini, Otto Luening and Joseph Littau. Samuel Gardner, WPA staff conductor, will also participate. Soloists for the series will be announced shortly.

More than 500 Irish men and women attended a memorial meeting last night at the Hotel Astor for the men who lost their lives in the Easter rebellion of 1916. It was held under the auspices of the Clan-Na-Gael.
The conclusion of the Italo-Yugoslav agreement was warmly welcomed here as a step toward a better political atmosphere in the Eastern Mediterranean, for which Turkey has been steadily driving.

The Port of New York Authority and the New York City Tunnel Authority were criticized yesterday for failing to provide for a Manhattan crosstown tunnel to connect the midtown tubes under the Hudson and East Rivers. The criticism was contained in a report to be submitted to the New York State Chamber of Commerce on Thursday.

Radio dispatches picked up here today by Mutual Wireless said the steamship Fresno City was standing by the crippled freighter Volunteer, but at 11 A. M. [4:30 P. M. New York time] had not taken any one off.

Walter Huston's. award-winning performance in "Dodsworth" and pleasing box office testimonials have attracted renewed attention to him. Out of several rumors, the most likely seems to be that he may join R.-K.-O. during the coming week to appear with Ginger Rogers in her first romantic drama, "Vivacious Lady." R.-K.-O. hones to

The Waldorf-Astoria is setting 1,000 places for the Adolph Zukor testimonial dinner tonight, marking the veteran producer's twenty-fifth year in motion pictures. Hollywood technique will prevail, with traveling microphones picking up special speeches and comments for a broadcast over the Mutual chain, short motion pictures taking the place of some of the usual talking, and Hollywood talent contributing to the entertainment.

Higher government revenues last year made possible the advancement of Mexico's plan for land redistribution and the formation of land cooperatives as a part of the country's six-year program, according to a report issued here today by the foreign trade adviser of the Pan American Union.

The charity figure skating carnival will be repeated at Madison Square Garden tonight before another capacity gathering of 16,000. It was stated on Saturday that all seats had been sold for tonight's performance, but tickets are still available for the two remaining nights of the show-tomorrow and Wednesday.

Four men were held yesterday in connection with the theft of a truck loaded with fruit and vegetables valued at $1,600. The prisowners said "a man" had paid them to drive it to the old stable at 102 Twenty-first Street, .South Brooklyn, where suspicious detectives arrested them.

Short-wave broadcasting apparatus for producing high fevers in the human body will be shown among other exhibits at the First International Conference on Fever Therapy, opening this morning at Columbia University and continuing tomorrow and Wednesday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mrs. Albert Bruton Strange of Bernardsville, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Wiley, to Edwin Lex Bacon of New York, son of Marshall Chandler Bacon and the late Mrs. Bacon.

Announcement has been made of the' engagement of Miss Juae' Frelinghuysen York, daughter of Mrs. Edward Palmer York of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street and the Hill, Stonington, Conn., to Alfred Chappell Sheffield.

Joe Platak, the husky Chicago postoffice clerk who is seeking his third consecutive singles title, won his first-round match today in the opening session of the national A. A. U. handball championships at the Lake Shore Athletic Club.

Ed Fialkow of the home club was forced to three games by Arthur Weisenthal, unattached, before winning their first-round match which marked the opening of the New York State one-wall handball singles championship tournament last night.

Fire Chief John J. Towey, who retired last night as head of the Newark Fire Department after forty years of service, will be honored by members of the department, friends and fire chiefs from many cities in the East at a dinner and dance Thursday night at the Mosque Hall ballroom.

An explosion in a coal mine at Kramer, ten miles south of here, known for years as "one of the safest collieries in the world," killed two men last night. Seven members of a rescue squad lost their lives in a second blast forty-five minutes later.

Four unions affiliated with John L. Lewis's Committee on Industrial Organization withdrew last night from the Birmingham Central Trades Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, in the first rift in labor ranks in this Southern steel capital.

With the naming yesterday of the two referees who will officiate at all of the games, the stage was set for the launching of the world's professional pocket billiard championship tonight in a new amphitheatre on the sixteenth floor of the Bond Building, 163 West Forty-sixth Street. Special elevators from Ponzi's Academy, which is in the same building, will carry the spectators to the scene of action.

Although there has been no actual change recently in the British Government's policy with respect to exports of capital, a reminder has been given out that voluntary adherence to the Exchequer's wishes is considered more desirable now than ever.

Muffled in furs for protection against a biting north wind, participants in the Easter parade who shivered along Commonwealth Mall today were far more intent on warmth than on demonstrating Spring fashions.

Chief of Police George announced tonight that he was holding Clifton Dosher for investigation in connection with the theft of about $25,000 worth of jewelry from the Winter home here of Mrs. Lewis Price of Sewickley, Pa. He added that he did not believe Dosher, an Aiken resident, was actually connected with the robbery.

Picketing of the Consolidated Film Industries plant here continued today as strikers hastened to counteract alleged company efforts to get employes to return ?? work tomorrow morning by promising to provide transportation.
Events on last week's markets were at times bewildering. Except for the continued rise of commodity prices, it was occasionally difficult to make out exactly what was the trend of things.

On the ground it violates the principle of home rule, members of the City Manager Committee of Yonkers are organizing opposition to a pending Albany bill requiring that petitions for a change in the form of a municipal government must have names equal to 50 per cent of the number of votes cast in the last previous election.

A slayer who seemingly waited for his victims in their home beat and strangled to death a mother and daughter and fatally stabbed a man roomer early yesterday morning in a fourth-floor apartment at 316 East Fiftieth Street, a few doors east of Second Avenue.

The municipal elections concluded here tonight were preceded by hundreds of arrests in order to prevent any agitation against the dictatorship. Despite the precautions, thousands of leaflets were distributed demanding the restoration of the Constitution.

Ernest J. Hoffman, 45 years old, of 33 Delaware Avenue, Dongan Hills, S. I., a real estate broker in Richmond County for more than eighteen years, plunged to his death last night from a secondfloor private room at the Staten Island Hospital, New Brighton.

Dartmouth's nine outhit Virginia in the opening game of the season today, but lost to the Southerners, who registered five runs in the first two innings and were never headed. The final score was 7 to 5 in favor of the Cavaliers.

Four new naval destroyers have returned here with damages, ineluding cracked plates, from unusually rough weather met in "shakedown" cruises, naval officials disclosed yesterday, according to The Associated Press.
Cornell and Yale face each other tonight at 9:30 o'clock in the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, in the match which starts off this year's college indoor polo championship.

Winsome Too, 64-foot yawl skippered by her owner, Harkness Edwards of East Hampton, L. I., and the Devon Y. C. of Miami, reached Havana Harbor at 6:27:29 this morning to win Class A honors in the eighth annual St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race.

Fabien Sevitzky has been engaged as conductor and music director of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra for the next three years. it was announced yesterday by William H. Ball, president of the Indiana State Symphony Society.
Mrs. Sara E. Lamb, active for many years in local politics, died of a heart attack today while visiting her sister, Mrs. Ella Kilcourse, superintendent of the Kelso Home for Girls at Towson, Md.
Vivid in color, graceful and symmetrical in form, a denizen of swift, clean water and a fighter every inch of him, the native brook trout is one of the most prized of fresh-water angling trophies.

The second concert given in this city by the Loewenguth String Quartet, which made its American debut last week, took place yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, with a program of interesting contrasts and unities.

The report of the Plymouth Oil Company, including its subsidiary, the Big Lake Oil Company, issued yesterday, showed a net income for 1936, after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges of $1.739,681, equal to $1.65 each on 1,050,000 shares of $5-par capital stock. In 1935 net income was $736.056. or 70 cents a share.

An exhibition of French "Figure Pieces," twenty in number, opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, to remain until April 10. An attractive, fully illustrated catalogue has been prepared, containing a foreword by Lelia M. Wittier, librarian of the galleries.
Almost 200 Manchurians in Antung Province, the government disclosed today, have been executed or sentenced to long prison terms for plotting against the Japanese and Manchukuoan Governments.

Within a few hours after the annual poll of The Columbian, year book of Columbia College, on the preferences of members of the senior class had been made public yesterday, Thomas Merton, editor of the year book, expressed doubt about the authenticity of the poll.
A blazing last-round rally gave Maxie Fischer of Newark a draw with Ralph Hurtado of Panama in the feature eight-rounder at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 2,500.

Miss Lillian Merwin Wait, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. V. A. Wait of Kinderhook, N. Y., was married to Dr. Harrispn Betts Wilson of Hackensack, N. J., yesterday afternoon in the Flatbush Dutch Reformed Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Frederick Berg.

Internal Revenue agents have been sent to the larger income tax districts of the country to try to find out why so many persons and corporations have asked for extensions on filing their final income-tax returns this year, Secretary Morgenthau disclosed today.

Directors of the Bridgeport Brass Company, at a special meeting here today, set $15 each as the value of 185,398 shares of common stock offered to stockholders in the ratio of one new share for each four held, Ralph E. Day, president, announced. The new issue, approval for which is sought from the Securities and Exchange Commission, will be used to finance the company's $4,000,000 building program.
Following is the text of the opinion of the Supreme Court minority on the Washington State Minimum Wage Law for Women:

A bid of 75 cents on the dollar from Gimbel Brothers for the stock of the bankrupt James Butler Company was announced yesterday at the auction of the company's stock and fixtures in seventy-nine stores in the metropolitan area.
For the first time in its history, the city of New York was required yesterday to pay a fine of $1 for violation the parking rules.

In a bad spill that occurred shortly after the start, two jockeys were painfully if not seriously injured in the third race at Tropical Park todray, a four-furlong dash for maiden two-year-old colts and geldings.
Ira Fox, 37 years old, was found guilty in General Sessions yesterday of criminally receiving part of $4,000 in stolen Currier Ives prints.

George Washington University's baseball team hammered out a 6-3 victory over the Long Island University nine today as a crowd of 4,000 looked on. It was the Colonials' first victory in three starts. Vince De Angelis limited the Blackbirds to one hit, a smashing triple by Mark Lowe.

Carter Glass, oldest member of the Senate, assailed tonight President Roosevelt's plan for reorganization of the Supreme Court. He was speaking, he admitted, "from the depths of a soul filled with bitterness" against a proposition "utterly destitute of moral sensibility."
Mayor "Cy" La Maitre of the upper towpath called on Niagara River bass today to help redeem a campaign pledge made in his campaign for the leadership of the small river-side settlement.

Edward Neely Smith, 18 years old, son of Edward G. Smith, secretary and treasurer of the Union Pacific Railroad, was killed and four companions were injured late this afternoon when their automobile left Union Avenue, crashed along a stone fence for 336 feet, shattered its four wheels and overturned.

The Board of Education of Roslyn, which took under consideration at its last open meeting a plea from 941 taxpayers of the district to abandon the so-called progressive system of education in favor of the old-fashioned three R's method, has appealed to the State Department of. Education to assist in reaching a decision, it was learned tonight.

A group of employes of the National Tube Company of Lorain, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, obtained a charter from the Secretary of State today for an independent labor organization.

James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, questioned today some features of a proposal to recapitalize the International Paper and Power Company. H. R. Weaver, the company's vice president and treasurer, supported the plan.

The most pretentious schedule in Manhattan's six-year rowing history has been arranged for the Jasper oarsmen this Spring by Coach Allen Walz. Seven regattas for the varsity eight, five for the 150-pound varsity and six for the freshmen are on the program announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics.

Miss Margaret Winifred Dorrance, daughter of Mrs. John Thompson Dorrance of Woodcrest, Radnor, and the late Dr. Dorrance, was married this afternoon to George Strawbridge, son of John Strawbridge of Chestnut Hill and the late Mrs. Strawbridge.

Almost a hundred Nazis rose among the audience in the Yorkville Court yesterday morning and shouted "Heil!" with arms outstretched in the German Fascist salute as Fritz Kuhn, their national leader, walked down the center aisle after obtaining a week's adjournment from Magistrate Richard F. McKiniry.

More than 400 persons attended the annual charity ball of the AnnMay Foundation of the Fitkin Memorial Hospital, held in the crystal ballroom of the Berkeley Carteret Hotel here tonight. There was a buffet supper in the Mandarin Grill.
Within the next ten or fifteen years "heavy water" will be drunk by men and women over 60 years of age as a means of adding ten years to their span of life.
Eber Palmer of the American Association of the Blind at New York City has been recommended for the superintendency of the State School for the Blind at Batavia..

The first results of the attempt of the Committee for Industrial Organization to organize the textile industry were reported yesterday as a Rochester shop employing 800 persons signed a contract negotiated with the Textile Workers Organizing Committee.

Ky Laffoon, veteran Chicago shot maker, tied Bobby Jones's course record today by firing a sevenunder-par 65 as outstanding links stars played their second warm-up rounds preparatory to the fourth annual $5,000 masters tournament.

Jules S. Bache is the beneficial owner of 46,100 shares of the capital stock of Domes Mines, Ltd., and last year drew a salary of $26,500 from the company as its president, according to a report to the Secucities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

The executive council of the Pennsylvania Federation of Labor has sent a message to President Roosevelt praising "the efforts to aid labor" and attacking the judiciary for "opposing the expressed will of the people."

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: CUSTOMS 4011--United States v. F. W. Myers Co.., Inc.-Opinion by Judge Bland. The United States Customs Court judgment reversed. Judge Garrett dissents. Judge Lenroot did not participate in this case.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on March 24 shows decreases for the week of $138,000,000 in total loans and investments, $205,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, $64,000,000 in government deposits, $201,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $215,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Henry St., 168. 26.1x100; Patrick J. Walsh to Louis H. Pink, as liquidator of N. Y. Title and Mortgage Co., consid. $1,000, foreclosure. 119th St. 19 E.. 25x101; Arthur Devlin to Helen Yanover, 51 W. 110th St. (quit claim).

Paced by Mrs. K. F. Evans of the Short Hills Club, the top-seeded player, favorites advanced to the quarterfinal round today as play started in the first annual women's invitation squash racquets tourney at the Apawamis Club.

D Alan Dillenberg. in 791 Park Av. through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.; William B. Westphal, in 1,088 Park Av. for same agent: Charlotte Mays, in 227 E. 57th St.; Howard R. Schulze, in 65 E. 54th St. through Walter Samuels; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the Labor Relations Board, summoned yesterday Paul Warfield, director of sea-going personnel of the International Mercantile Marine Company, to reply to charges that he has discriminated against certain applicants for employment as engineers on the com pany's ships.

The Cedarhurst Grand National, chief event on the annual program of the Rockaway Hunting Club at Cedarhurst, L. I., Is drastically changed as to distance and conditions, according to an announcement yesterday from Fred Alexandre, secretary of the organization, which is one of the oldest in America. The former distance was three miles over brush for hunters.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was very slow In both the wholesale markets and slaughter houses. Btser hinds and ribs were higher, veal weak to lower, lamb slightly uneven but mostly weak to slightly lower. Fresh pork cuts were mostly steady but some smaller cut lower. Kosher beet and veal opened about steady, lamb higher.

Sol Reisinger, formerly assistant advertising manager, has been appointed executive advertising manager of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc., Brooklyn department store, in a realignment of duties in the advertising staff announced yesterday by Paul Murphy, sales manager.
The Washington State law establishing minimum wages for women, upheld today by the Supreme Court was substantially similar to the New York statute overturned on June 1.

President Roosevelt is expected to find a way to avoid discriminating between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization in naming a spokesman from "the most representative" American labor organization to the June meeting of the International Labor Organization, it was reported here today.

Holt Ross, Southern representative of the American Federation of Labor, charged in a broadcast address tonight that the Committee for Industrial Organization had Communist support and was organizing Southern textile workers "to instill its doctrine of hate and revolution."
Following is the text of Senator Glass's radio address this evening: The speaker this evening is Carter Glass, senior Senator of Virginia in the Congress of the United States.

The St. Nicholas Society of New York will award a medal to the citizen who it considers has done most for this city in 1937, it was announced at the annual paas festival of the organization at the Hotel Plaza last night.

The Borden Farm Products Company spent $12,400 to employ guards at its Elizabeth (N. J.) plant in a forty-one day strike in May and June of last year, the National Labor Relations Board was told yesterday by Joseph J. Quinn, who described himself as "the whole works" of the Joseph J. Quinn Detective Agency of Newark, N. J.

Plans were filed yesterday for several new apartment houses in Brooklyn and Queens. In the former borough, an eighty-two family house, on a plot 175 by 115 feet, to cost $275,000, is projected for 226-46 Park Place, and a fifty-four family house, to cost $190,000, on a 95 by 120 foot base, at 50 Lenox Road.

Dexter Fellows, chief of the department of understatement of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, arrived in town yesterday to herald the approach of what he fondly describes as "the greatest show on earth."
Reversing its original decision, the Foreign Office today granted the Dean of Canterbury-Dr. Hewlett Johnson, a liberal churchman-permission to lead a deputation of nine to Spain.
Motor traffic in the Holland Tunnel on Easter Sunday totaled 50,726 vehicles, the highest number for the holiday in five years, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.

The Pan American Clipper, pioneering a commercial air route of 7,000 miles between California and Australasia, landed in the harbor here today, completing the final leg in the journey, an 1,800-mile flight from Pago Pago, American Samoa.
A one-day sit-down strike which paralyzed the Fisher Body Corporation, General Motors Truck and Chevrolet Motors plants in Oakland ended tonight. The plants will resume operation tomorrow morning.

A relatively light volume of business on the Cotton Exchange yesterday reflected the protracted holiday in Liverpool, but the list ended with gains of 3 to 7 points due to trade buying in the face of limited offerings of contracts for either May or July delivery.

While trading in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday continued to feel the effect of the Easter holidays, with only one or two deals reported from these boroughs, realty interest turned again to Queens and the property within the zone of influence of the World's Fair of 1939.

Bryan Grant, Bobby Riggs and the other favorites in the Atlanta invitation tennis tournament breezed through the first round with little difficulty today. There wasn't an upset in sixteen matches. The mighty little Grant halted Burtz Boulware, Georgia Tech student from Florida, 6-0, 6-2. Riggs toppled Dr. Glenn Dudley of Atlanta. 6-0, 6-3.

A man who flagged down the Merchants Limited of the New Haven Railroad with a flashlight just as it hit a heavy chain bolted to the track was in jail today, charged technically with "idleness" and held in 15,000 bail.

Reports of dissension in the Insurgent ranks, both behind the lines and on the fighting fronts in Spain, are coming from many sources so persistently that neutral observers are beginning to believe them well founded. A German broadcast today even spoke of a "revolt" against Generalissimo Francisco Franco at Malaga and at other critical spots.

A group of fifteen pickets who had paraded, throughout the day in front of the Jeffersonian Democratic Club, 587 Hudson Street, in protest against the recent Aldermanic bill for an appropriation of $50,000 to investigate the Emergency Relief Bureau, were set upon last night by about twenty men who routed the pickets with fists.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin C. Fincke of 55 East Eighty-sixth Street and Locust Manor, Fair Haven, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Julia B. Fincke Humphreys, to Edwin Lewis Singleton, son of Mrs. Jouett Parker Singleton of Greenwich, Conn., formerly of Louisville, Ky., and the late Mr. Singleton.

Mr. and Mrs. William Sieben-Morgan of Westfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Sieben-Morgan, to George C. Worth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Worth of Plainfield, N. J.

In connection with the income statement of the Standard Gas and Electric Company for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, 1937, which was given out last Saturday and which showed a decrease of $45,378 in total net income compared with the preceding twelve months, Bernard W. Lynch, president of the company, made the following statement last night:

Duttons are hurrying into print a book called "The House of Windsor." It consists of nineteen pencil portraits of members of the British royal family. The collection was edited by the Marchioness of Aberdeen and Tremair.

United States COPPERSMITH, $1.056. $1,116, $1,176 per hour; DIE SINKER, $1.04, $1.64, $1.224. Navy Yard, Brooklyn, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the recorder, labor board, Navy Yard, Brooklyn, N. Y., not later than April 27.

Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, answered today the challenge of the Committee for Industrial Organization to the textile industry when he addressed a large audience at the University of North Carolina.
A capacity crowd attended the Lyric Theatre tonight for the opening presentation of the Metropolitan Opera Company's brief season here. There were more than 1,000 standees.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Kathleen Guthrie, daughter of Mrs. S. S. Guthrie of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Guthrie, to Allan Dean Converse of St. Louis, formerly of Greenwich.

Insignia have been awarded to nine members of the ski team at Wesleyan University, it was announced today. Those honored were: Frederick E. Fowler, Scarsdale, N. Y.; Irving J. Kotzer, Lowell, Mass.; Edward T. Krementz, Maplewood, N. J.;

The marriage of Mrs. Eleanor Barker Glenn, daughter of Mrs. John A. Barker of Baltimore and the late Mr. Barker, to Richard E. Nichols, son of Mrs. Romaine C. Nichols of Cozy Nook, Bernardsville, and the late Mr. Nichols, took place here this morning in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help.

Tenders for two series of the Treasury bills of approximately $100,000,000 to be dated March 31, which were offered on March 26, amounted to $301,729,000, Secretary Morgenthau announced today. Of this amount, $100.157,000 was accepted.
Edward B. King, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange and a sportsman, died here today at his home, Woodhill Farm, after a year's illness. His age was 51.

Strengthening of the State minimum wage bill, in view of the Su-. preme Court's reversal of its position on such legislation, was urged last night at the annual meeting of the New York Women's Trade Union League at the headquarters at 247 Lexington Avenue.

Hoe Av (11-2987), e s, 125 ft s of Jennings St, 100x100: Richard F. Weeks, referee. to New York State Teachers Retirement System, 152 Washington Av., Albany, N. Y. 240th St (12-3380), s s, 365 ft w of Katonah Av, 40x100; Albert B. Stone to John Guldner, 2,153 Chatterton Av.
Sections of the Railway Labor Act requiring railroads to engage in collective bargaining with their employes were unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court today in an opinion by Justice Stone.

The New York Rangers will be idle until Thursday night, even though their next opponents in the National Hockey League play-offs for the world's championship are known to them. The Blue Shirts have drawn as their rivals the Montreal Maroons, who, by eliminating the Boston Bruins, survived the competition between the teams that finished in second place in the league race.

Although the scholastic season is less than a week old, a one-hit performance was recorded yesterday when Jimmy McDermott twirled Flushing High School's nine to a 3-2 decision over the St. John's University freshmen in a seven-inning game at Flushing Memorial Field. The victory was the second in a row for the Queens nine. The battle marked the opener for the losers.

The annual report of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Inc., for 1936, issued today, shows a consolidated net income of $7,199,120, or $6.89 a share on the 1,045,278 shares of capital stock outstanding at the end of the year. This compares with a net of $5,258,078, or $5.03 a capital share outstanding in 1935.

Argument has just begun on the question whether the Supreme Court's reversal of itself in the women's minimum wage case today is a point for or against the President's judiciary proposals. That is a dispute over political effects. But there can be no dispute over certain facts in connection with the 5-to-4 decision today, and some of these are:

While the decision of the Federal Supreme Court upholding the constitutionality of the provisions of the Labor Railway Law attacked by the Virginian Railway strengthens the standing of the law, the decision would not seem to hold out the possibility of any important changes in the relations between railway managements and their unions, according to railway managers here.

White, Weld Co., as special agent, notifies holders of the State of Pernambuco 7 per cent external sinking fund loan, due in 1947, that funds have been remitted for the payment of the March 1, 1937, coupons at 22 1/2 per cent of the dollar face amount.

Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, prepared yesterday to seek the extradition of Alexander Pompez, arrested in Mexico, D. F., as a fugitive from New York, where he is charged with extortion in Harlem's rich policy racket.

An application for exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Act with respect to the issue and sale of $1,000,000 of 4 per cent firstmortgage bonds, Series A, due on June 1, 1966, to be sold at private sale to the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Wisconsin Power Company, a subsidiary of the Northwest Utilities Company.

The Supreme Court, among many decisions today, upheld the constitutionality of the Virginia Milk Control Law, sustained the perjury conviction of "Grocer" George W. Norris of Nebraska, upheld the validity of the National Firearms Act and assumed jurisdiction in lawsuits involving the unemployment tax section of the Social Security Act.
The chicken that crosses the road, regardless of reason, must make the journey pretty much at its own risk, under a proposal awaiting return of New York legislators April 5.

William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Citizens Union, wrote yesterday to members of the Board of Estimate asking them to deny a $50,000 appropriation requested by the Board of Aldermen for an investigation of public relief agencies.

Both sides rested yesterday at the trial of Captain Charles R. Morrison, supply officer of the 245th Coast Artillery of the New York National Guard, who is charged with conspiracy to defraud the government by presenting false vouchers for services and supplies for the regiment.

Miss Ethel du Pont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont of Owls Nest, Greenville, will be married to Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, on the afternoon of June 30.

Mrs. Osa Johnson, widow of Martin Johnson, the explorer and photographer, who lost his life in an airplane accident in which her right leg was broken, was wheeled onto the stage of Carnegie Hall last night and before more than 3,000 persons gave a brief review of the last exploration trip she made with her husband, which resulted in the filming of "Jungle Depths of Borneo."

Traffic in Forty-fourth Street between Times Square and Sixth Avenue was halted between 4 and 5 P. M. yesterday and one fireman was hurt when flames of undetermined origin swept through the shops of the National Souvenir Company on the second floor of a three-story brick structure at 140 West Forty-fourth Street.
The beauty parlors of America and England will provide the background for Merle Oberon's second Hollywood picture after her return from London, Samuel Goldwyn disclosed today.

Pointing to the regrowth of Russian-American trade, Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday that a very strong foundation for further development had been created.

Mayor Wilson today threatened to arrest union leaders unless they stopped alleged coercive tactics in soliciting employes of the city street cleaning bureau. He said men in automobiles were visiting homes of truck drivers and threatening them with injury unless they went out on strike.

Miss Catharina Dickinson Klein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rulof Klein of this place, will be married to Francis Joseph Muhling Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Muhling of Glen Ridge, on April 16 at the home of her parents by the Rev. Dr. Edmund A. Wasson, rector emeritus of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Newark.

Breeze Corporation, Inc., common stock, $1 par value; Electrol, Inc., voting trust certificates representing common stock of $1 par value; Mengel Company first-mortgage 4 1/2 per cent convertible sinking-fund bonds due in 1947, and Transwestern Oil Company capital stock, $10 par value, have been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange.

Frederick H. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, said tonight that the Supreme Court's reversal on the right to prescribe minimum wages for women was evidence that justices considered the social aspects of questions as well as the legal.

A tentative agreement covering the wages, hours and working conditions of more than 4,000 employes in 123 stores of the F. W. Woolworth Company in this city was worked out last night by representatives of the company and the Department Store Employes Union.
The Pictorial Photographers of America opened their fourth International Salon of Photography yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.
Strikes and rising prices are beginning to cause anxiety as Britain's defense program is being hustled into full stride.
Because Marian Anderson's recital next Friday evening at Carnegie Hall is already sold out, it was announced yesterday that she would make another appearance there on May 12.

After almost five years of bankruptcy, a plan for the reorganization of the United Cigar Stores Company of America was filed yesterday in the Southern New York District Federal Court, and Federal Judge Coxe set April 19 as a date for a hearing on the proposal.

J. S. Weed, president of the Grand Union Company, has addressed a letter to holders of preference stock setting forth that the management is soliciting their proxies for the sole purpose of electing four directors to represent the preference stockholders.

Everett W. Nourse, United States manager and president of the London Assurance, the Manhattan Fire and Marine Insurance and the Union Fire, Accident and General Insurance companies, issued yesterday their annual statements as of Dec. 31, 1936.

The striking employes of the Consolidated Film Industries plant in Fort Lee, N. J., variously estimated to comprise 40 to 100 per cent of the 600 workers, will hold a mass meeting this morning to determine whether they should return to work in the afternoon and continue production while a committee negotiates with the management.

Miss Erna Greenfield Linington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Howe Linington of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Edward Whiting Evans, son of Mrs. Henry Clay Evans of Brooklyn and the late Major Evans, in the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Dr. J. Frederic Berg.

More than 100 clergymen and laymen of the Brooklyn-Nassau Presbytery attended yesterday a farewell luncheon for the Rev. Dr. Frederic T. Steele, retiring executive secretary of the Presbytery, at th Central Y M. C. A., 55 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.

Dealings in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday slowed down markedly from the a pace of recent weeks and the volume of transactions, at $8,933,500, was the smallest in almost five d months.
Senator Vandenberg of Michigan proposed to Congress today a modification of the pending Child Labor Amendment to eliminate the objections raised against the proposal.

Earl Kitchener, elder brother and successor of the Field Marshal for whom the title was created, died in a hospital here at the age of 90. For the past decade he had lived the life of a recluse under primitive conditions resembling the Spartan life of the earliest settlers, attended only by two native servants.

Hanak Pazner, 52 years old, a linguist, who said he was a graduate chemist, was held without bail yesterday after pleading not guilty before Judge Streit in General Sessions on an indictment charging that he and two other men defrauded a physician of $54,000 last July through a bogus money-making machine.
Ranking players had little trouble today in advancing to the third round of the National A. A. U. handball tournament being played at the Lake Shore Athletic Club.
The Supreme Court was defended yesterday as "the bulwark of individual liberties" by former Governor Charles S. Whitman, who decried statements that it was tyrannical, hidebound and casebound.

The radio sleuths of Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Propaganda Minister, tonight finally got on the trail of the Communist who for a fortnight or more has been disseminating Red propaganda in Germany by short wave.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Arnold Austin of 228 North Walnut Street, East Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Austin, to Oliver Wills Tuthill, son of Mrs. Oliver Bailey Tuthill of North Caldwell, N. J.
The first public portrayal of the 1939 World's Fair, in dazzling colors and minute detail, took place yesterday afternoon on the ground floor of the Empire State Building.

Automobile production increased more thn seasonally last week, and the adjusted index moved up to 94.0 from 93.7 (revised). It was 102.6 for the week ended March 28, 1936. According to the estimate of Cram's Reports, output for the week was 101,805 cars, compared with 99,450 (revised) for the previous week and 105,415 (revised) for the corresponding week last year.

A plan of reorganization to take the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad out of bankruptcy should be ready by June 1, Howard S. Palmer, president, said in his report for 1936, issued yesterday. The company has been in bankruptcy since Dec. 7, 1935.
The Pedro Montanez-Lou Ambers lightweight bout will be held in Madison Square Garden next Monday. Approval of the new date was given yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission.
General Cornelius Vanderbilt of New York fell twelve feet into Biscayne Bay today when a gangplank slipped as he boarded his yacht, the Winchester.

Former Deputy Boxing Commissioner Charles Goodman filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday to collect his New York City Fire Department pension which was suspended during his service with the Boxing Commission. He contends that the city had no right to withhold pension payments.
Captain Frank W. Cannaday, retired United States Army officer from East Radford, Va., reported today his bomb-shocked hens had lost 25 per cent of their laying capacity after an air raid.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Board of Aldermen has under consideration an ordinance to end sales of stolen coal in this city, and to protect the consumer by making it as difficult as possible for dishonest dealers to take advantage of him. There has been some misrepresentation and considerable misunderstanding of the purpose and effect of the proposed law.

Preparing to lead his Yankees out of this sun-kissed land on a journey he hopes will end next October with another pennant, Marse Joe McCarthy today looked forward eagerly to an early answer to a problem which has been bothering him for the past three weeks.

The equity of the common stock of Best Co., Inc., on Jan. 31, with good-will carried at $1, was the highest yet recorded, Philip Le Boutillier, president, stated in his report to stockholders, issued yesterday.

Victor G. Bloede, for more than fifty years a manufacturing chemist and philanthropist, died Saturday at his home in Catonsville, near Baltimore, at the age of 88. Until a few weeks ago Mr. Bloede was active as the head of the ink manufacturing company which bears his name.

The Federal Trade Commission in a complaint made public today seeks to stop alleged international control of round grain, California-Japan type rice by California Rice Industry, a trade association with headquarters in San Francisco, and its milling members.

Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday that the unionization campaign of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen among employes of the Independent Subway system, now under way, had been undertaken at the suggestion of the union, and not of himself.
Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday that 2,500 technical WPA workers would strike tomorrow if the order for pay cuts ranging from 40 to 60 per cent were not rescinded.

Offering will be made today, of a new issue of $24,000,000 Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company first mortgage and first lien 4 per cent bonds, Series A, due on March 1, 1952, by a banking group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. The offering price is 97 1/2 and interest.

Three thousand striking students paraded the streets of this city today carrying the body of one of their number whose death, posters they carried charged, was due to "criminal negligence" of school authorities.

Letters subpoenaed from the files of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company revealed yesterday that the company had an "unsatisfactory list" for manufacturers who would not give the A. P. a price advantage of 4 per cent despite the prohibition of the Robinson-Patman Fair Trade Act.
Representative Lemke, co-autnor of the Farm Mortgage Moratorium Act, said today that if Congress would "take more pains" with laws it drafts fewer would be declared unconstitutional.

Following two days of disastrous skirmishing with the Indians in near-by Jackson and Vicksburg, the Giants returned to their training base today looking rather subdued and given once again to calm reflection.

William Morgan Butler, former United States Senator from Massachusetts, former chairman of the Republican National Committee and a textile corporation executive, died of a heart attack today at his home here. He was 76 years old, and although in poor health for some time, had visited his office within a week.

The congregation of Central Congregational Church, meeting in the church at Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, approved last night a contract merging into it St. Paul's Congregational Church.

Walter C. Hagen, noted golf professional, has been divorced from his wife, Mrs. Edna C. Hagen of Deal, N. J., it was learned today. The decree was signed by Francis Child, Advisory Master in Chancery, March 17, but was not made public until today.
Pope Plus, joyous over his participation in Easter services and the thousands of congratulatory telegrams sent him, rested tonight from the strain of the past few days.
Max Borges, prominent architect and contractor, was sworn in as the new Cuban Secretary of Public Works this morning at the Presidential Palace by President Frederico Laredo Bru.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, incorporated in Delaware, an operating subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company incorporated in New Jersey, has granted substantial increases, effective April 1, to clerical and other salaried employes, it was announced yesterday by Frank W. Abrams, president.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers and chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, yesterday denounced the stand taken against sit-down strikes by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, as "characteristically cowardly and contemptible."

Leasing of full floor and of additional space for expansion purposes featured the business rentals reported in various parts of Manhattan yesterday. Broadway and Fifth Avenue buildings figured in many of the contracts. The list follows:

Samuel J. Mitchell, former Sheriff of Queens County, whose tenure of office came near to establishing the necessity for a special election to fill that post after 1920, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 24-04 Ditmars Boulevard, Long Island City, after a short illness, at the age of 68.

Jim McMillen, 220, Chicago, threw Lilo Nardi, 220, Italy, with a back drop in 23:31 of the feature wrestling match at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw the bout. Nardi suffered a cut over his right eye when he came in contact with the canvas.
Alvah C. Frink, cited for bravery against the Sioux and Cheyennes during Indian wars in the old West, died here today. He was 82 years old.

Carmen Reuben, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, had the assistance of a quartet of women's voices for her presentation of Schubert's "Staendchen; Zoegernd leise." The guest artists were Veronica Harrison, Helen Bone, Laura McKenna and Margaret Barry.

Port of New York Authority purchased from William Kuenzler for $21,000 the twostory dwelling at 115 Cantelo St., Union City. Guttenberg Bank and Trust Co. sold to the Erco Co. the two-story factory building at 806-808 Palisade Av., and the twostory factory and one-story storage building, 339-341 24th St.. Guttenberg.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that inter-office messages showed that William E. Hutton 2d had tried to enter crossed orders to establish a new high price for Atlas Tack stock. Jacob Gruber, the commission's attorney, made this contention after the message had been described by Martin Smith, head order clerk for W. E. Hutton Co. of New York.

A guarded assertion came from Chairman J. Warren Madden of the National Labor Relations Board today that the failure of Federal courts to rule on the Wagner Labor Disputes Act was responsible in considerable part for present labor unrest.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey yesterday signed an order continuing the American Woman's Realty Corporation in control of its clubhouse at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, pending a reorganization planned under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Law.

At the moment when Britain is engrossed in rearmament and is grappling with dangerous international problems in Europe her imperial policy has just suffered in far-away India what may be a setback of the first magnitude.

The government announced tonight that its naval forces had obtrained revenge for the recent Insurgent air raids on Valencia and other coast cities by bombarding Insurgent forts in the Balearic Is-lands.

Evelyn Hudson, 28-year-old stenographer, claimed a special world record today for women's solo endurance flying, 19 hours 57 minutes 14 1-5 seconds. "I'd still be going if I had had more gas," she said. She took her light monoplane aloft Easter morning and landed it early today.

As the result of nine consecutive upward steps in the rate of steel activity, production this week is at a new top of 90.7 per cent of capacity, the highest rate since August, 1929, when the rate was 95.3 per cent.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today the issuance of a complaint against the Cast Iron Soil Pipe Association of Birmingham, Ala, its officers, and thirtyfive companies producing and selling 90 per cent of the cast iron soil pipe produced in the United States.

The Wheeler bill which would broaden the Federal Trade Commission Act to permit proceedings in the interest of the consumer as well as to restrain unfair trade practices was passed today by the Senate without a record vote. The bill now goes to the House.
Dr. James Chasey, who had practiced medicine here since 1875 except for an interval of eight years, died this afternoon at his residence, 864 Broadway, at the age of 84.

Mrs. Lauren Carroll gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for Mrs. Henry J. Mali, Mrs. J. Ellis Fisher, Mrs. T. J. Johnston Mali, Mrs. Felix E. Notebaert, Mrs. Lloyd B. Sanderson, Mrs. Butler Whiting and Mrs. Frederick Chauncey Tanner.

The marriage of Miss Rosemond O'Reilly, daughter of Mrs. Henry M. O'Reilly of this place, to Job Herbert Lippincott Jr., son of former New Jersey Commissioner of Motor Vehicles Job Herbert Lippincott and Mrs. Lippincott of Short Hills, took place tonight at the bride's home. The Rev. Michael J.

The Senators overcame an early lead to defeat the Montreal Royals. 4 to 2, today. Hitters got to pitchers in the first inning, Montreal scoring twice in their half only to have the Senators knot it with two. Tallies by the Senators in the fifth and sixth gave them the winning margin.
Dr. Charles Purdy Lindsley, a graduate of the Yale Sheffield Scientific School in 1875 and of the Yale Medical School in 1878, died today at his home here after a long illness.
There may be a man in the United States who has sold bread and butter and eggs over the same counter for more than seventy-three years, but the National Association of Retail Grocers doubts it.
Twenty-five delegates representing 10,000 teachers in seven locals in New York City, Buffalo, New Rochelle, Hudson and Katonah organized a New York State Federation of Teachers Unions here today.
Classes were resumed at Havana University this morning under the new autonomy system, with a total enrollment of nearly 6,000.

Mrs. George MacLeod Baynes of Hewlett, L. I., entertained with a dinner last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for her daughter, Miss Nancy Baynes, later taking her guests to the junior gettogether dance, which was held in the ballroom.

The Hershey Bears won the championship of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight for the second successive year by beating the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 4 to 3. This was Hershey's third victory of the play-off. The Gulls took only one game.
New high prices for the last eight years were recorded by wheat and corn in the leading North American markets today on heavy buying by specula tors and cash interests.

" Dishonor and disintegration stare the Republican party of New York City in the face" if it renominates Mayor La Guardia, Louis Davis Hopkins, leader of the Twelfth Manhattan Assembly District, North, declared yesterday in a letter to members of the New York County Republican Committee.

James T. Reid, professional from the Crescent A. C., gave a brilliant exhibition in subduing Tom Byrne, Downtown A. C. pro, by 15-2, 9-15, 15-1, 15-10, in the first round as play in the world's open squash tennis championship tournament got under way on the pent house court of the Hotel Shelton last night.

Representatives of the General Electric Company and the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union resumed their conferences yesterday for a collective agreement designed to cover 47,000 employes. The meeting was at the company's offices, 570 Lexington Avenue.

ABRAMS--On Monday. March 29, 1937, Anna J. Mead, beloved wife of Herbert T. Abrams of 218 Cleveland St., Orange, N. J. Funeral service in the Chapel (House of Prayer) of First Church of Orange (Presbyterian), Scotland Road at Main St., Orange, on Wednesday, March 31, at 1:30 P. M. Kindly omit flowers.

Mrs. Frances Robinson Biddle, widow of Algernon Sydney Biddle and great-granddaughter of Edmund Randolph, first Attorney General of the United States, died yesterday in her apartment at the Belgravia. Mrs. Biddle was a daughter of the late Moncure Robson and was prominent socially.

SO the Rangers are to play the Montreal Maroons in the semi-final scramble for the Stanley Cup. That brings the Odd Man from Ottawa very much to the front again, the Odd Man from Ottawa being Thomas Patrick Gorman, better known as Tay Pay, the manager of the mauling Maroons and a man of a few million words, all tinged with a bit of a brogue.

Details of a recapitalization plan for the Illinois Power and Light Corporation to provide a capital structure which will permit future financing through capital stock, and enable the company to accomplish a debt refunding program totaling possibly $116,000,000, are announced in a letter being mailed to stockholders today, signed by J. D. Mortimer, president of the company.

Mrs. George Forrest Butterworth gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for her granddaughter, Miss Isabel I. Butterworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Forrest Butterworth of Rye. N. Y.

Officials of the National Consumers League yesterday hailed the decision of the Supreme Court upholding the Washington minimum Wage Law as "the most encouraging event in the league's forty years of struggle to establish this principle."
Most standard brand patent and proprietary drugs are "fairly priced," George Gottesman, president of the Consolidated Brooklyn Retail Pharmacists, Inc.,

Governor Lehman will confer tomorrow with Republican and Democratic legislative leaders here concerning longrange budgetary problems, and, more particularly, the strife with the Republicans over his fiscal program.
One of the more encouraging developments noted as Easter trade reached its close last Friday and Saturday was the improvement noted in the demand for dresses.

Although twenty companies, either directly or through their New Jersey agents, obtained copies of the specifications, only one firm submitted a bid today for testing equipment to be used by the State for inspection of motor vehicles under the new law requiring semi-annual examination.

The recent award of 8 bolivars a day, plus an extra bolivar where free housing is not furnished, may have satisfied, at least temporarily, the Maracaibo oil-field workers, but it is having serious repercussions in other parts of the country where oil is not the dominating economic factor.

Another capacity gathering of 16,000 attended the charity figureskating carnival at Madison Square Garden last night and again the elaborate show won the wholehearted approval of all. When plans were made months ago the program called for only three performances. Following the opening one last Saturday, the carnival was to have been repeated only last night and tomorrow.
Representative Sabath of Illinois collapsed while speaking on the floor of the House today. Two colleagues went to his assistance and he was led, weeping, from the chamber.
