The first of a series of transfers in the American diplomatic service were announced today- when President Roosevelt sent nominations for Ambassadors and Ministers to the Senate for confirmation.

There was an atmosphere of tense expectancy in Grand Central Palace yesterday as of some great; event in prospect. All day young men and women could be seen entering the building with large packages under their arms and coming out empty handed.
By ROBERT FISHEL Grosvenor Av., 4,628, 2-story frame dwelling, 100x120x91.5xlrreg.: A. C. Holding Corp. against James J. Phelan; due, $32,683; to plaintiff for $15,700.
The Maritime Commission will open bids Thursday for construction of a new cabin liner for the United States Lines to replace the Leviathan.
The University of North Carolina and Yale brought their series of regular tennis matches to a close today, with the Tar Heels winning for the third straight time, 9 to 1.

On any tariff schedule worth a Congressman's while, "Farewell Summer," which was put on at the Fulton last evening, would be classified as a luxury. Candidly, it is not a necessity. Civilization has got on without it for years.

Endorsement of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization was voted by the convention of the Socialist party of America today in a resolution urging party members to support the new labor group.

Commenting on a report from Washington that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had clamped down unusual restrictions on the Boston Maine Railroad as a condition for extension for two years of the road's $7,569,437 loan from the RFC, Edward S. French, president of the Boston Maine, said today:
Mr. and Mrs. John Rowland Hill have come from Washington to the Waldorf-Astoria to join Mrs. Hill's mother, Mrs. George Hewitt Myers.

Due to the death on Saturday of John F. Murray, the firm of John F. Murray Co. has retired as a member of the New York Stock Exchange. The Owens-Illinois Glass Company has notified the Stock Exchange of a proposed change in authorized capital stock from 1,500,000 shares of $25-par to 3,000,000 shares of $12.50-par, each outstanding share to be exchanged for two new shares.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net profit, after all deductions, of $7,344,514, equal to 70 cents a share on the common stock after preferred dividends, compared with $2,798,860, or 24 cents a common share, earned in 1935.

Business failures in the United States totaled 189 for the week ended March 25, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 193 the week before and 194 for the corresponding week last year.

Burleigh Grimes's great Tiger killers proved to be just a lot of fellows being chased by Bears today after they had got inside the spacious park in which Colonel Jacob Ruppert's leading farmhands do their Spring training.

Miss Margaret Marie Ferry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Ferry of Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to Nicholas Joseph Healy 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Healy Jr. of Manhattan, by the Rev. John A. Ferry, a cousin of the bride, in St. Francis of Assisi Church, Brooklyn.

Eighteen thousand refugees camping on the banks of the Jaguaribe River in the interior of the State of Ceara are threatened with famine following a drought and have appealed to the government for immediate relief.
Pan American Airways announced today that four hundred pounds of special anti-smallpox vaccine was being flown to Montevideo, Uruguay.

Paul J. Cerny, Ernest A. Schade and Theodore Mayor bought plots from the Homeland Company on its development at Homefield, Yonkers. Houses were purchased by Elmer I. Cameron of Brooklyn and James J. Moore of Yonkers.
Connie Mack, manager of the Philadelphia Athletics, is expected to enter Medical and Surgical Hospital tomorrow after his arrival from Mexico City.

The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the constitutionality of the revised Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Moratorium Law, which was designed to extend to bankrupt agricultural proprietors the same aid provided for facilitating corporate reorganizations.

A movement by Presbyterian clergymen who are friends of the Rev. Dr. James A. Kelso, president of Western Theological Seminary of Pittsburgh, to elect him Moderator of the 149th annual general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States was reported here yesterday.

The Hon. Malik Sir Firozkhan Noon, High Commissioner for India in the United Kingdom; Herbert Morrison, Labor member of the British Parliament; Andre Philippe, Deputy of Lyons, France, and Henri Burquet, Secretary to the Paris Board of Aldermen, are among the passengers due to arrive tonight from Havre via Southampton on the French liner Ile de France.

For the second time within the month Oliver E. Sweet, director of the Interstate Commerce Commission's Bureau of Finance, has asked the New York Central Railroad for more specific information on details of the road's plan to issue $54,000,000 in fifteen-year convertible bonds, it was revealed today.
Formal notice that the price-fixing features of the State Milk Control Law become inoperative on Wednesday was given today to 4,350 licensed milk dealers of the State by the Agriculture Department.
Following is the text of the majority opinion of the Supreme Court on the Washington State Minimum Wage Law for Women:
The blotter at Police Headquarters contained today a man's tribute to a dog. Over the signature of Patrolman John Dubish there was inscribed:

The tale of a monster shark that frightened natives in a moonlit harbor of Haiti and gave cruise passengers a chance to see a thrilling primitive sea fight was told here yesterday as the Colombia of the Colombian Line arrived from southern ports.

Albert Russell Griffith, one of four defendants accused of mail fraud in the operations of the National Business Analytical Corporation, formerly of 11 West Fortysecond Street, testified yesterday in Federal court that the late Charles Steinmetz had complained to him about the direction of the corporation that bore his name.

Business activity in the wholesale dress market continued at a fair pace last week as the pre-Easter season came to a close, according to the survey issued yesterday by the Joint Board of the Dress and Waistmakers' Union.
A two-day exhibition of modern trends in printing and printing equipment was opened at the Hotel Astor yesterday under the sponsorship of the New York Employing Printers Association, Inc.
APthough ten of the navy's 7,050-ton light cruisers will become obsolete, or over-aged, before 1940, there are no plans at present to replace them, navy officials said today.
The government has prohibited further popular political meetings and broadcasts for the elections, which are to be held next Sunday.

Brig. Gen. Henry AlliSOn Ingans, who received citations in the Spanish-American and World Wars, including the Distinguished Service Cross, died here today. He suffered a stroke a year ago. His age was 68. He was wounded in the World War.

The leasehold on the property at 386-390 Fifth Avenue, improved with a nine-story building, 67.5 by 166.10 feet, irregular, and the adjoining eight-story building at 384 Fifth Avenue, 28 by 100 feet, irregular, was sold at auction yesterday to the plaintiff, Empire Trust Company, as successor mortgagee and trustee, in proceedings against the Fifth Avenue Realty Corporation.

Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, remained here today and participated in six hours of negotiations with auto union leaders on the sixth day of Governor Murphy's peace conference on the Chrysler strike, while John L. Lewis, chairman of the C. I. O., who left yesterday, was trying to settle the soft coal labor dispute in New York.

Snow fell in the "dust bowl" today. The snow extended from Western Nebraska and Eastern Colorado through Western Kansas and Western Oklahoma into Northern and Central New Mexico and the Texas Panhandle.

Five former employes of the WPA writers project are at work in offices on the sixteenth floor of the new Federal Building, looking over gazeteers and atlases so they will be able to answer questions about the nation's geography and subjects more or less related to it.
Officials of the Traffic Division of the Police Department at headquarters announced further revisions of the new traffic code of the city yesterday.
President Roosevelt participated in the Easter egg-rolling ceremonies at the White House, devoting his day otherwise to routine matters.

Adolph Zukor, chairman of the board of Paramount Pictures, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria by the Theatre Owners of New York on the occasion of Mr. Zukor's twenty-fifth anniversary in the motion picture industry.
The Adelphi Academy baseball team opened its Southern trip with an 18-5 victory over Greenbrier Military Academy today. Adelphi had a big inning in the sixth, when eight runs crossed the plate.

The Imperial Diet (Parliament) today completed final approval of the national budget for the fiscal year beginning.April 1, totaling 2,815,300,000 yen ($802,400,000), with more than half allotted to the army and navy.

By a 5-to-4 decision, the numerical division by which it struck down the New York Minimum Wage Law for Women and Children last June, the Supreme Court today held constitutional a similar statute of another State, the Minimum Wages for Women Act of the State of Washington.

American business spent slightly less than $500,000,000 in advertising through accredited advertising agencies in 1935, of which approximately 37 per cent went to newspapers, William L. Austin, director Bureau of Census, reported yesterday, in announcing publication of the first report on advertising agencies in 1935, a part of the current Census of Business.

The annual pamphlet report of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, submitted to stockholders yesterday by William E. Levis, president, calls attention to the acquisition in 1936 of certain properties by its wholly owned subsidiary, the Owens-Illinois Can Company.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Proceedings 80 JOHN ST. CORP., leasing and operating building at 80 John St.--Voluntary action for reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Laws indicates assets of $3,182,011 and liabilities of $2,945,310.

The Guggenheim Memorial Fellows for 1937 are more than twice in number the company of sundry folk whom CHAUCER brought together in fellowship as by chance on their way to Canterbury, at this season of the year.

Heavyweight Champion Jimmy Braddock today agreed to explain in Federal Court here next Monday why he should fight Joe Louis in Chicago June 22 instead of first meeting Max Schmeling in New York June 3.

Twentytwo Southern chess players opposed Jose R. Capablanca of Havana in his exhibition of simultaneous play arranged here today under the auspices of the Miami Chess Club at the Miami Biltmore Hotel.

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia bettered par and equaled the No. 3 Pinehurst course record today to lead sixteen qualifiers into the championship flight of the thirty-fifth annual North and South, women's golf tourney with a medal score of 72.

The War Department issued the following army orders today dated March 27: COLONELS Danford, R. M., F. A., detailed as a member of the General Staff Corps; from Hawaiian Department to duty as Chief of Staff. Sixth Corns Area. Chicago, ill.

The House Appropriation Committee today reported the 1938 Legislative Establishment Bill, carrying $24,001,734 for Congress and related activities. The amount was $1,413,724 less than for the present year and was $948,030 less than budget estimates.
Big Mike, a 300-pound chimpanzee, threw the monkey house at the Chicago Zoological Park in Brookfield into an uproar today with a vicious attack on the head keeper, Arthur Aitken.

North American Aviation Corporation, San Diego, Calif., was low bidder for contracts to furnish to the Army Air Corps planes classed as basic combat ships, a check of estimates by Wright Field engineers here today showed.

New York City has the lowest operating expense for the collection of sales tax of any city in the country, Milton Solomon, Deputy Controller, said yesterday in an address before the Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion, at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following order today, dated March 26: CAPTAINS Gaddis, W. P., command of the Mississippi to instruction at the Naval War College Newport, R. I., about June 5.

Stocks closed irregularly lower; turnover, 871,470 shares, smallest since Sept. 17, 1936. United States Government issues higher, corporate and foreign bonds irregular in slowest trading since November; transactions, $8,933,500.

Sir Alexander Seton is sending back to Egypt a bit of bone, supposedly from a Pharaoh's skeleton, because: Visitors complain about a ghostlike figure wandering through the house. Maids won't stay in the house more than one night, and each has complained about the figure.

The marriage of Miss Katherine H. Kerwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Kerwin of 835 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, to John L. Riordan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Riordan, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory, St. John's Place and Brooklyn Avenue.
The Manhattan Arrows easily defeated the New York Stock Exchange Brokers, 7-1, in the first game of the round-robin series for the Metropolitan Hockey League title at the Playland Ice Casino tonight.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Broadway in Review," John Mason Brown. Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Medieval Collection, General Tour, 11 A. M.; "Color: Near Eastern Textiles," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.;
Henry Munroe Rogers, oldest graduate of Harvard and the Boston Latin School, died here today in his home, 309 Beacon Street, at the age of 98.
P. W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said today that "if crude rubber continues to sell at present prices, further increases in prices cannot be avoided."
The Florida Supreme Court said today public officials could not interfere with newspaper reporters or cameramen engaged in gathering news information of public interest.
Manhattan BLEYER, ROSE M. (Feb. 11). Estate more than $5,000. To Mignon Schiele, daughter, Broadmoor Hotel. and Le Roy M. Bleyer, son, executor, 230 W. 79th St., one-half residue each.
Hereafter any man in Clifton Forge who uses relief money to get drunk, and is caught at it, will have to wear upon his back a placard proclaiming:
Diplomatic exchanges between Paris and London over the situation in the NonIntervention Committee on Spain are understood to have established a four-point understanding along these lines:

An "extraordinary proposal" for a loan of $5,000,000 to be used in a campaign to "put the Townsend plan over now" by promoting the General Welfare Act of 1937, now before Congress, was made 'by Dr. Francis E. Townsend today to his alleged 4,500,000 followers.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Paul Whitcomb Williams, Samuel A. McCain, Murry C. Becker, Sidney A. Wolff, and Robert Piza Well, of New York, were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:
Mrs. William Fox, wife of the former movie producer, was adjudged in contempt of court today by Federal Judge John Boyd Avis, sitting in this city.
Karol Szymanowski, greatest of contemporary Polish composers, died today at the age of 54 at a sanatorium near Lausanne, Switzerland. His sister, Stanislawa, was at his bedside.

Charles Edward Mitchell of 1,925 Seventh Avenue, who was United States Minister to Liberia from January, 1931, until February, 1933, died yesterday in the Harlem Hospital of an embolism which developed following an operation. He was 66 years old.
The capital and outlying provinces were shaken severely by earthquakes this morning, followed by minor tremors later in the day. No casualties or severe damage was reported.

Inclement weather and lack of heating caused postponement of school reopening today. Only a few of the 200 pupils who survived the March 18 explosion reported for a scheduled assembly. Superintendent W. C. Shaw said classes would be resumed tomorrow.
The financial statement for 1936 of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, whose chairman is Stephen Birch, was issued yesterday for publication today.

THE world has rolled along and left Branch Cabell in the sweet swamps and poppyfields of Poictesme and Branlon. Mr. Cabell declares very stoutly that he doesn't care, and writes books arguing that his dreamlands are more nearly real than anything the workaday world can offer. In so doing he protests a shade too much, and the measure of his protestation is probably the measure of his caring.

The engagement of Miss Ann Blaine Hays of Sharon, Carlisle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael S. Hays and a descendant of Ephraim Blaine, Revolutionary Commissary General, to Robert Lee Jacobs, Pennsylvania's youngest State Senator, was announced by her parents today.

The Sales Executives Club of New York put grocery store merchandising under a spotlight yesterday at its weekly meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt and with the aid of an actual grocery store layout, replete with national brands, showed members how manufacturers' salesmen should sell to retailers and how retail clerks should sell to consumers.

A further reduction in the Chesapeake Corporation's control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway was disclosed yesterday in a statement issued by the New York Stock Exchange concerning the amount of conversion of the holding company's bonds.

Wisps of what appeared to be smoke coming from the basement of the West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street, where three fires of probable incendiary origin occurred on Saturday, caused excitement in the vicinity yesterday morning.

President Roosevelt's policies with regard to labor arbitration and the Supreme Court follow closely those long in force here in Mexico, Vicente Lombardo Toledano, head of the Mexican National Labor Federation, declared today in an interview.

Brush fires on Staten Island were so numerous yesterday that additional apparatus and firemen had to be summoned from Manhattan. Firemen in Richmond were kept busy from 11 A. M. to 6 P. M. fighting twenty-seven such fires.
The first annual convention of the American Theatre Council will discuss all phases of the current theatre, from advertising to the WPA, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. F. H. La Guardia, wife of the Mayor, threw a bouquet of red roses at noon yesterday across the threshold of the four-room whiteshingled house erected in Grand Central Palace under the auspices of the Federal Housing Administration, and with this dedicatory gesture opened the sixteenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries.

Examination for Promotion The mental examination for promotion to the rank of deputy chief of department will be held at Room 1415, Municipal Building. Manhattan. at 9:30 A. M. Tuesday, March 30, and Wednesday, March 31. The following candidates shall be directed to report at the above time and dates:

By a vote of 8 to 2, the Republicancontrolled Suffolk County Board of Supervisors adopted a resolution today creating a Suffolk County Water Authority to safeguard and conserve the ground water resources of the county and to protect them from encroachment by New York City.
Governor Lehman vetoed tonight the Crawford bill which would have permitted putting into old law tenement houses in New York City sprinkler systems instead of fire retarding materials.

The new child labor amendment submitted by Senator VANDENBERG ought to command overwhelming Congressional support. Its phraseology removes any fears or doubts that reasonable men might have felt regarding the old amendment. Under the new proposal Congress would still be granted power to "limit and prohibit" child labor, but the more ambiguous power to "regulate" is removed.

Mrs. Henry P. Davison of Locust Valley, L. I., resigned today from membership on the Citizens Committee for a County College, declaring in a letter to the Nassau County Board of Supervisors that she did not approve of the establishment of a junior college in the county at this time.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday to the First National Bank of Boston a new issue of $4,000,000 of short-term notes, dated April 2, 1937, and due March 22, 1938. The notes were awarded at a discount of 0.79 per cent, plus a premium of $29.

James J. Walker, former Mayor, was the principal interrogator yesterday as a member of a General Sessions lunacy commission taking testimony on the sanity of Lawrence Mullens, former convict, awaiting sentence. Mullens recently pleaded guilty to participating in the hold up of Barney's clothing establishment on lower Seventh Avenue on the night of Jan. 2.
Trout angling in the center of New York City became a possibility yesterday when Art Neu, well known fisherman, started conducting classes at Wanamaker's Country Club Auditorium.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 27 unless specified: At New London: J. F. Talbott, Tattuall, March 28, Badger. At Portsmouth Yard: Perch, Plunger. At Pearl Harbor, March 28: Preston, Smith.
Jose Luis Alvarez, 28-year-old teacher of Spanish at Osaka, has arrived in Tokyo to become Spannish Charge d'Affaires and First Secretary on order of the Valencia government.
J. P. Morgan and five guests aboard his yacht Corsair disembarked here this afternoon after a

While receipts of hogs today were only moderate the demand was inclined to slowness and prices at the yards were steady to 10 cents lower. The end of Lent was reflected in an improved demand for fresh pork, but the shipping call for hogs from the East reflected no improvement.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS -- Frederick P. Bayer, from 34th Precinct to 5th Division, assignment changed from desk duty to duty as supervisor of patrol in uniform. John W. Fealey. from 5th Division to 34th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

Seldon Brook McLaughlin, for the last twenty-four years first assistant administration clerk in the Surrogates Court, New York County, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital of sclerosis of the liver. His age was 52.

In spite of the doubts expressed by Secretary PERKINS a few weeks ago, the illegality of the sit-down strike is now well established and generally conceded. Even Miss PERKINS has hastened to clear up the "misinterpretation" of her early remarks, and acknowledged that the Michigan courts were at least within their "competent jurisdiction" in ordering the evacuation of plants.

Wallace Benjamin Flint, retired member of the old shipbuilding firm of Flint Co., founded by his father, the late Benjamin Flint, died yesterday at is home, 74 Greenway Terrace, Forest Hills, Queens, at the age of 74. He had long been ill of arteriosclerosis and heart disease. Mr. Flint was a brother of the late Charles R. Flint, financier.

James Caras of Wilmington, Del., started the defense of his world pocket billiard championship last night with a 125-87 triumph over Fay Gainer of Vineland, N. J., as the competition got under way in a specially constructed amphitheatre on the sixteenth floor of the Bond Building.

Miss Lillian Elizabeth Van Wagner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Van Wagner of this city, was married to Francis Xavier Orofino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Frank Orofino, this morning in Holy Family Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John S. Coffey.
Governor Hoffman, it was learned tonight from a close political associate, will veto the bill diverting $7,900,000 of highway funds to relief purposes.

To the thousands gathered on Easter Sunday within the great sun-filled space enclosed by the spreading arms of Bernini's Colonnade, the appearance of the Pope on the balcony above the portico of St. Peter's was like a veritable resurrection, the return to life of one long close to death.

Magistrate Brough expressed surprise in the Homicide Court yesterday when informed that Floyd Smith of 2,754 Eighth Avenue, before him on a technical homicide charge in the killing of a woman by the automobile he was driving, had burglary and robbery convictions against him, as well as another for not supporting his wife.

Bishop William Fitzjames Oldham, long a noted Methodist Episcopal missionary, who served his church in Asia and South America and was formerly corresponding secretary of the church's Board of Foreign Missions with offices here, died of pneumonia on Saturday in Glendale, Calif.. the board announced yesterday. He was 82 years old.

Organization of a national honorary committee for the Knox College centennial in June was announced here today. Of the fifty men and women on the list, many have indicated that they will be here for the celebration.
Benjamin Towne Leland, for twelve years Professor of Industrial Education at the University of Maryland, College Park, died Saturday at the age of 56.

Several strands of short gray hair found under the fingernails of Veronica Gedeon, 20-year-old commercial model, offered virtually the sole remaining clue last night to the man who murdered the girl, her mother, Mrs. Mary Gedeon, and a roomer, Frank Byrnes, in their apartment at 316 East Fiftieth Street early Sunday morning.
The Supreme Court has reversed its position on an important point of law precisely at a time when the future of the court itself is the dominant political question before the country.
A reportedly unsuccessful attempt to steal state papers belonging to Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, took place here Saturday, but was kept secret until today.

James McMahon, 44 years Old, a night-club bartender, was killed by a northbound I. R. T. subway train at the Seventy-ninth Street station on Brodaway at about 11:30 o'clock last night, after he had jumped to the tracks apparently in an effort to recover something he had dropped.

Part of the investments of the Philadelphia Yearly Meeting of Friends have been switched during the last year "in order to be safe in the long run rather than earn an immediate profit," members of the society were told today by Howard Cooper Johnson, president of the trustees.

Several sales of residential properties in various parts of Brooklyn were reported yesterday by the Colonial Realty Company, Inc. The four-story apartment house at 221 East Fifth Street was sold for investment to the Willmul Realty Company, by the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation.

Organized Canadian railwaymen, 117,000 strong, won late today their battle for full restoration of a 10 per cent depression pay cut, as managements of the two Canadian railways yielded to union demands to end a long-drawn dispute.

Mr. and Mrs. Vinton Parker Wilkinson of this place have announced the betrothal of their daughter, Miss Lois Parker Wilkinson, to William James Hardiman, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cleveland Hardiman of Watertown, N. Y. The wedding will take place in the Autumn.
Amid mist and a storm of hail and snow that made the mountaintops white, the Duke of Windsor drove today to his new home here--Appesbach House. He arrived at 5:50 o'clock this afternoon.

Argentina's favorable trade balance for the first two months of 1937 was 359,775,000 pesos ($120,000,000 at. the official rate of exchange), the Argentine Information Bureau announced here yesterday. This figure compared with 84,838,000 pesos ($28,300,000) for the corresponding period of 1936 and set a high record.

The successful drive that keglers had waged against the leaders in the American Bowling Congress championships over the week-end was slowed considerably yesterday and it remained for the final group to take the alleys at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory last night to produce the lone change in the tournament standings.

Miss Marian Simons, 97 years old, died last night, less than three years short of the century mark set by herself and John D. Rockefeller Sr., four years ago. On her birthday anniversary on June 1, 1933, she and Mr. Rockefeller, who is also 97, expressed the hope the other would live to be 100.
When the American Federation of Labor denounces the sit- down strike as a menace to democratic government

Both branches of Congress designated today members of an official committee to attend the funeral of Representative Benjamin K. Focht of Lewisburg, Pa. The two Pennsylvania Senators, James J. Davis and Joseph F. Guffey, will represent the Senate. The House committee is composed of Representtatives Kinzer, Rich, Haines and Gingery.
Action on at least one of the five bills providing for an appropriation to continue milk advertising and pending in the New York State Legislature, is expected when both houses reconvene next week.
Ralph Norman Jr., 7-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Norman, will live without a jugular vein, his physicians said here today after an operation which they described as successful.

Insurgent gunboats carried the Spanish civil war outside Spain in two incidents reported tonightgrounding of a Spanish government freighter in French waters and an attack against a British steamer off Santander.
At least 50,000 children and grown-ups attended the annual Easter eggrolling held today on the South Lawn of the White House. They represented a record attendance for the ceremony.

Russell Forbes, Purchase Commissioner of New York City, is being mentioned here as a possible successor to C. A. Dykstra, City Manager, who has resigned to become president of the University of Wisconsin. Mr. Forbes and Mr. Dykstra have been on friendly terms for lec years.
A gift of $500,000 to Brown University to construct a new chemical research laboratory was announced this morning by President Henry M. Wriston.

Despite a sharp rise in traffic fatalities last week-end, figures compiled for the week compared to those for the corresponding week of 1936 declined, a report of the traffic division of the Police Department showed yesterday.

Steel ingot production in the United States is scheduled at 90.7 per cent of capacity, the highest level since August, 1929, and an increase of 1.1 points or 1.2 per cent, compared with the preceding week. A month ago the industry was operating at 85.8 per cent of capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Securities and Exchange Commission moved today to reduce speculative aspects of the combination of the functions of broker and dealer on Stock Exchanges by placing restrictions on the activities of "specialists."
New York State will have a new minimum wage law within a few weeks, according to forecasts made tonight as a result of the decision of the United States Supreme Court on the Washington State law.

Net premium income, assets and net surplus of the Lumbermens Mutual Casualty Company of Chicago last year set new high records, according to the report of the president. Net premium income rose $1,876,140 to $22,219,615, assets $4,018,905 to $26,630,204 and net surplus was up $512,333 to $3,594,766.

Beneficial results by the use of artificial fever in cases of St. Vitus dance, angina pectoris, certain types of rheumatic fever and neuritis, and several other serious diseases were reported yesterday at the opening sessions of the first International Conference on Fever Therapy, at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, and the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

Turpentine firm, 36 3/1 c; sales, 145 barrels; receipts, 112 barre; shipments, 60 barrels; stock, 20,124 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 359; receipts, 395; shipments, 1,820; stock, 43,369. Quote: B, $7; D, $7.40; E, $7.65; F, $7.95; G to N, $8; WG, $8.10; WW, X; $8.75.

Sales in February of reporting wholesale firms averaged 17.9 per cent higher than in the same month last year, a larger increase than that made in January, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Federal Reserve Bank.

THE DIALOGUES OF PLATO, translated by Benjamin Jowett. (Random House, two volumes, $5.) Complete and unabridged. DEEP SUMMER, by Gwen Bristow. (Crowell, $2.) A romance with a Southern historical background.

Robert Exton, 35 years old, a salesman of 322 West Eighty-ninth Street, was held on a charge of homicide last night as the result of a fist fight after which Joseph Johanson, 49, of 169 West Ninetyseventh Street, a doorman at 775 West End Avenue, died of a fractured skull.

With Prosecutor John J. Breslin Jr. of Bergen County, N. J., on a holiday in Florida, his assistants disclosed today that a revolver recovered from the bottom of the Hackensack River last Tuesday had been identified as one of those used by the murderer of Norman Redwood, leader of a sandhogs' union.

Leonard Schultze, architect who designed the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, conferred yesterday with Aldermanic President William F. Brunner on the latter's plan for a lowcost housing development on Jamaica Bay to house 11,000 families at an average monthly rental of $7.50 a room.
Brook Pemberton's third entry of the season, this one in association with the Theatre Foundation of America, opens tonight at the National Theatre.

MANHATTAN Gross assets $23,000. net $21,576. To Columba Aimone, widow, life estate in residue; Florence Aimone, daughter, $4,000 and remainder in residue; six varying bequests. Chief assets, real estate, $23,000. Alexander, Cone Sondheim, attorneys, 51 Chambers St.
Mrs. Elenore Van Houten Bolles of Harrison became entangled with speeding laws of two States today, and in doing so was prevented from answering a speeding charge in New Rochelle.

J. W. Thomas, president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, closed by a prolonged strike, informed the United Rubber Workers of America today that the company could not negotiate with the union on its demand for sole collective bargaining rights.

Jeannette L. Morse, daughter of Mrs. Herbert L. Morse, of West Haven, was married to Russell R. Camp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence L. Camp of West Haven, this morning in Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale University by the Rev. Jesse Lyons.
The House will be called upon on April 12 to act on the Gavagan antilynching bill. The 218th signature was placed on a petition today to bring the bill out of committee.

Leasing of the seven-story building at 147-49 Market Street, Newark, adjoining the present Ohrbach store, was announced yesterday by Ohrbach's Affiliated Stores, of which Nathan M. Ohrbach is president.

Federal Judge William H. Holly directed the Utilities Power and Light Corporation today to withhold payment of $900,000 in semi-annual interest on debenture bonds, pending a determination whether it is solvent.

Mrs. Georgette Gerard - Varet Hyde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Gerard-Varet of Semur, Cote d'Or, France, was married yesterday afternoon to Harris Fahnestock of 15 East Sixty-sixth Street and Lenox, Mass., at the home of the bridegroom's brother and sister-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Fahnestock, at 954 Fifth Avenue.
Frank R. Coutant, vice president of Brown Tarcher, Inc., addressed nearly 300 members of THE NEW YORK TIMES class in national advertising last night at The Times Annex.

The validity of the taxicab limitation ordinance approved by Mayor La Guardia early this month was challenged in a suit filed yesterday in Supreme Court by Charles E. Gunn as president of the L. C. M. Transportation Company, which operates a fleet of cabs. Mr. Gunn asserted that the provisions of the ordinance were null, void and unconstitutional.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, made public a report yesterday in which he said that although he was certain that graft had been frequently paid for engineers' licenses from the old boiler squad of the Police Department he had found only "one case in which we are reasonably sure that we have identified the receiver of the money."

Maternal deaths in the city for the week ending last Saturday numbered sixteen, the highest total for any seven-day period since the week ending June 8, 1935, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday in his weekly health survey.

The WPA Federal Art Project opened an exhibition of prints at the Federal Art Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, with a preview yesterday afternoon, and the work may be seen by the public, beginning today, until April 27. Fortyfive artists are represented, often by work of unusual excellence.
Supreme Court Justice Conway in Brooklyn denied yesterday a motion to dismiss a suit against R. Hoe Co., Inc., a group of its officers and stockholders and the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Producers of hogs and various consumers in the West were warned today by Guy T. Helvering. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, against persons reported representing to them that claims could be made successfully for refunds of processing taxes imposed during the effective period of the Agrcultural Adjustment Act.

The 30,000,000 boys, girls, young wmen and young women who compose the school and college population of the United States are to have a chance to win a free trip to the New York World's Fair in 1939 by drawing a design for a World's Fair poster, Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corportion, announced yesterday.

Twenty-one per cent of the students of the Columbia University School of Business plan to adopt accounting as a career, it is indicated in a survey made by the Columbia chapter of Alpha Kappa Psi, national fraternity of commerce, and the school's faculty committee on employment.
Stockholders of the Commercial Credit Company approved yesterday authorization of a new issue of $35,000,000 of convertible preferred stock, at a special meeting in Baltimore.

The stock market here reopened today after its long Easter week-end but business was restricted due to the fact that the present account will be closed after another three days. Conditions in general were quiet although movements were toward higher levels.
Employment in factories of the Pittsburgh district exceeded the pre-depression levels in February, the University of Pittsburgh's Bureau of Business Research reported today.

In the SuPreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 638-Hiram Steelman, trustee, , petr., v. All Continent Corp. Argued for both. 604-Reginald P. Ray, petr., v. United States. Argued for both.
The government has been informed of the safe evacuation of 400 Spanish citizens, mostly Rightists, who had taken refuge in the Netherland Legation in Madrid.

With the signing of a purchase voucher today, details of the government's purchase of the Ponce Electric Company, which for more than twenty-five years has been a Stone Webster property, were completed. The insular government will assume operating control on Thursday.
Meeting in Pittsburgh April 28, shareholders of the Gulf Oil Corporation will consider a bonus plan for officers and employes which has been prepared by the directors.

Captain Charles R. Morrison, supply officer of the 245th Coast Artillery of the New York National Guard, was acquitted yesterday by a jury in the Federal court in Brooklyn after trial on an indictment charging him with conspiracy to defraud the government by submitting false vouchers for services and supplies for the regiment.

ABRAMS-On Monday, March 29, 1937, Anna J. Mead, beloved wife of Herbert T. Abrmns of 218 Cleveland St.. Orange, N. J. Funeral service in the Chapel (House of Prayer) of First Church of Orange (Presbyterian), Scotland Read at Main St., Orange, on Wednesday, March 31. at 1:30 P. M. Kindly omit flowers.
Robert Moore Collins, Associated Press correspondent in Europe and the Far East for twentyeight years, died today after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
Store space figured in many of the commercial rentals reported yesterday, and many concerns were listed as taking new quarters for expansion; The list follows:

Following the lead of the University of Texas in granting longtime football coaching contracts, Indiana University decided today to entrust its football fortunes for the next ten years to A. N. (Bo) McMillin.
General Don Ricardo Burguente, for several years president of the Spanish Red Cross and a former High Commissioner in Morocco, died here today at the age of 66.
The engagement of Miss Jane Turner of San Diego and Claus Spreckels, grandson of the late John D. Spreckels, California capitalist, was made known here today.

Stricken with a heart attack while testifying at proceedings before Henry C. Frey, referee in bankruptcy, in the Federal court room in Postoffice Building at 88-40 164th Street, Jamaica, Queens, late yesterday afternoon, Frederick Schlobohm, 55 years old, of 60 Harvard Avenue, Baldwin, L. I., slumped forward in the witness chair and died.

Newspapers in foreign markets should carry the weight of any general consumer advertising campaign by American exporters, Harold N. Elterich, of N. W. Ayer Sons, Inc., yesterday told the Export Managers Club of New York at its annual "get-together" at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Other media must be considered as secondary and supplementary to newspapers, he added.
Washington matchmakers offered Freddy Steele $15,000 today to defend his middleweight boxing title at Griffith Stadium on June 21.

The Senate passed without a roll-call today the Wheat Crop Insurance Bill designed to insure wheat farmers against crop failures due to drought, hail, floods, tornadoes and other causes, maintain the buying power of such farmers and provide for stable supplies of wheat for domestic consumption and the orderly flow of the commodity in interstate commerce.
The annual National Achievement Award of the Chi Omega sorority was presented to Katharine Cornell, the actress, by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at a dinner at the White House tonight.
Former Assemblyman Erastus F. Post of this village, who was president of the Riverhead Savings Bank, in Riverhead, died aboard a train near Richmond, Va., this morning. He was 77 years old.

Frank Gray Griswold, sportsman and clubman, who had been a director of the Metropolitan Opera Company for many years and was one of the first stewards of the Jockey Club, died yesterday at his home, 783 Park Avenue, of a complication of ailments, at the age of 82.

The six-story apartment house at 2,105 Burr Avenue. northwest corner of 196th Street, on a plot 150 by 100 feet, has been sold through the Kemoner Realty Corporation to a client of Lep Kaplan, lawyer.
William H. Hatton, former State Senator and Republican Gubernatorial candidate, died at a New London (Wis.) hospital today. He was 81 years old.

President Roosevelt indicated today that he would push forward with his purpose to fix minimum wages of labor by Federal legislation, regardless of the impetus given to State action by the Supreme Court's decision yesterday upholding the Washington State Minimum Wage Law.

Eleven sales, amounting to $2,085,700. were reported yesterday as having been arranged through the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation on title company properties. Among the properties involved were the fifteen-story apartment house at 170 Second Avenue:
A critical, unexpected impasse has been reached in India. The program to make the new Constitution fully effective in the provinces on April 1 has been blocked.
The floor of the New York Stock Exchange, scene of the world's greatest feats in the art of finance, became a triumphant battleground yesterday afternoon for the Madison Square Boys Club.

Seventy --two candidates for promotion to the rank of deputy chief in the Fire Department were asked in a test by the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday to lay down a program of fire protection for the 1939 World's Fair to be held at Flushing Meadows.

Rice, one of the principal foods of Cuba, was eliminated today in a decree renewing minimum tariff treatment to various raw products. The decree specified that future importations of rice would be regulated by separate legislation.

Corn was the leader in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today, soaring 151 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel. with the May selling at the highest level since March, 1925, on general commission-house buying and short covering based on the continued limited country offerings to arrive and a growing scarcity of domestic corn at the leading terminal markets.
Claude E. Holgate, executive secretary of the New Jersey Automobile Trade Association for twentyfive years, died last night of pneumonia at his home here. He was 65 years old.

The dramatic circumstances in which Justice Roberts reversed himself-and with himself the Supreme Court majority-in yesterday's validation of the Washington Women's Minimum Wage Law naturally tended to divert attention from the coeval unanimous decisions in the farm mortgage and railway labor cases.

The Deep Run Hunt Club announced today W. B. (Bill) Streett of Warrenton, who rode What Have You in the Grand National at Aintree, had entered Gigolo from the Mill River Stables in the club's annual Spring meet to be run at Curles Neck Saturday.
To Christopher M. Morley Jr. of Roslyn Heights, L. I., a junior in the College of Arts and Sciences at Cornell University, has been awarded the Guilford essay prize of $15 for the year 1937.

Plans for a fifty-four family apartment house, costing about $185,000, to be built at 1,347-59 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, were filed yesterday. In the same borough a sixty-family house to cost $135,000 is contemplated for the site at 7,121-23 Colonial Road.
Jonson W. A., Engrs., Fort Belvoir, Va., to Baltimore. Md.., about Aug. 1. Gohn, J. F., Inf., Boston, Mass., to retirement, June 30.

Utica, N. Y., has invited tenders for a new issue of $1,000,000 of tax anticipation notes, award of which will be made on April 8. The notes will be dated April 8, and will become payable on Aug. 8, 1937.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was only fair to slow on most classes. Strictly choice and prime steer hinds and ribs were in demand, however, at strong to higher prices; other classes were weak to lower. Kosher veal opened weak and other kosher markets about steady.
The condition of Connie Mack, 70, manager of the Athletics, who arrived here today from Mexico for treatment of a leg injury, was reported as "very good" late today by dr. J. W. Goode.

Price advances ranging from 1 to 5 cents per pound on rayon yarns were announced yesterday by the rayon division of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. The increases, representing the first general advance to be made in somewhat less than a year, are effective today.

Because of a sharp rise in Pennsylvania. taxes during the last two years officers of the Curtis Publishing Company have been considering the advisability of moving the business into another State, where taxes would be lower.
The Giants went back to routine work today, and, in the circumstances, that appeared to be about the best thing they could do, with time hanging rather heavily on their hands.

The marriage of Mrs. Ethel Newsome Alexander, widow of Thomas Mackenzie Alexander and daughter of Mrs. William Newsome of New York, formerly of Boston, and the late Mr. Newsome, to Guy Ellicott Torrey of Bar Harbor, Me., took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride, 1,192 Park Avenue.
The special Detroit mediation committee, set up recently by Governor Frank Murphy's conference of labor, management and the public, asked tonight to be dismissed. The Rev. Frederic Seidenburg,...

Wilbur Henry appeared destined today to become the first winner of nine major letters at the University of Illinois since 1920. Henry is on the Illini baseball squad and virtually is certain of winning another major "I.

With Clarence (Buddy) Combs swinging a mallet that was more like a magic wand, Cornell's indoor polo team galloped into the semi-final round of the year's college championship last night, turning back a strong Yale team, 16 to 81/2, at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.

In a game as bruising as it was fast the Ramblers defeated the Springfield Indians, 3 to 1, tonight in the first test of the International-American Ice Hockey League's Eastern finals before 5,000 fans.

The 144 inmates of the Burlington County Almshouse one of them 114 years old and some of them bedridden, were saved early this morning by two young nurses from a slow-burning but stubborn fire that destroyed the interior of the institution from basement to roof.

Jewelry valued at $20,000 was stolen aboard the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania on March 23, it became known yesterday when the ship returned from a forty-oneday cruise to South America. A packet containing the jewelry, which belonged to Mrs. R. W. Higgins of Duluth, Minn., was taken from the purser's safe and recovered thirty-six hours later in the locker of John Cronin, 15 years old, a bellboy, of Southampton, England.

Leroy V. Porter has been appointed assistant vice president and controller of the New York Central Railroad, F. E. Williamson, president, announced yesterday. Mr. Porter has been in railway service since 1896 and has been controller of the New York Central since 1930.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday that no formal charge had been made against the International Mercantile Marine Company with respect to Its employment of engineers aligned with a faction of the Marine Firemen, Oilers and Watertenders Union.

Pausing in its tour, the Metropolitan Opera Association presented a post-season performance of "Die Meistersinger" at its Broadway home last night. The presentation was in aid of the German American Relief Organizations of Greater New York, and it was under the auspices of the German American Charities, Inc.

The first Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Award has been given to Dean Alfange, an attorney living at 285 Riverside Drive, for his book, "The Supreme Court and the National Will," it was announced yesterday by the committee.

National Distillers Products Corporation has notified holders of its ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures that the Chase National Bank, fiscal agent, has designated by lot for redemption on May 1, for the sinking fund, $147.000 of these debentures to be redeemed at 104 and accrued interest.
Brig. Gen. Sir Capel Holden, inventor of many instruments and apparatus for artillery and electrical science,, today at the age of 81.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company, for many years regarded as most determined in its opposition to labor union recognition, has let down the bars and will hold a referendum to determine representation for collective bargaining.

Appointment of public defenders whose duty would be the defense of indigent persons brought to trial in the Federal courts was proposed in a bill introduced in the Senate today by Senator Capper of Kansas. The bill, if enacted, would eliminate the "assigned counsel" practice in all Federal courts.

Charles Elmore Cropley, clerk of the Supreme Court, in reporting to the Senate Judiciary Committee today on the court's record in clearing its docket noted that the once familiar condition of cases being heard during one term but not decided until the next "disappeared beginning with the October term, 1929."
Estate, less than $10,000. To Arthur P. Carroll, son, 116 E. 58th St., one-hall residue; Anne E. Carroll, widow. executrix 116 E. 58th St., furniture, personal effects and one-half residue.

The University of Oregon rifle team registered a 961 to lead the college and university teams in the seventeenth annual William Randolph Hearst R. O. T. C. rifle matches, according to an announcement by the War Department yesterday.
Immediate legislation to help southern agricultural States of Brazil by permitting a larger influx of immigrants was urged today by Counselor Valentim Boucas before the Federal Trade Council.

Executive heads of thirty-four chain apparel stores, with an annual sales volume in excess of $100,000,000, met yesterday at a closed meeting in the Hotel New Yorker to discuss the advisability of the formation of a permanent trade group.

Comely Miss Virginia Guilfoil, a 19-year old Syracuse University sophomore, and Miss Mary Kuhn of Aspinwall, Pa., scored surprise vicstories in today's first round play of the north and south women's golf tourney but favorite players came really through safely in the six other matches.

A Syndicate recently formed by Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., has acquired the three-story building at 567 Seventh Avenue, between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets, adjoining the Bricken Textile Building.

The German delegation to the coronation of King. George in London on May 12 will be exclusively military. The government announced today it would be represented by Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, the War Minister; Admiral Otto Schulze, commanding the North Sea naval station, and Major Gen. Hans Juergen Stumpff of the air force.

Leonard Del Genio of Harlem enhanced his chances of becoming a leading welterweight by gaining a close decision over Irish Eddie Brink of Scranton, Pa., in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night.
Kingsbridge Rd. (11 - 3191), S.S., 82 ft. w. of Morris Av., 32x80: Herman L. Nelsson to Marmel Holding Corp.. 147 W. 42d St.

Proposals to decrease the actually issued and outstanding stock of Securities Corporation General by retiring all its outstanding preferred are to be considered by shareholders of the company at their annual meeting April 14 in Richmond, Va.

The Simmons Company of New York City filed a registration statement today under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $10,000,000 of debentures due in 1952, rights to be issued to common stockholders to purchase $9,941,000 of the debentures and an undetermined number of shares of no par value common stock to be reserved for conversion of the debentures.
The University of Delaware baseball team opened a training tour of the State here today with a 12-to-5 victory over the Medical College of

The thirty-six-story office skyscraper at 9 Rockefeller Plaza, in the lower block of Rockefeller Center, has been completed a month ahead of schedule and will be thrown open for its first tenants tomorrow.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st Grade George Treiber, Engine 25, died March 28. Funeral will take place from his late residence. 133 E. 32d St., Brooklyn, at 1 P. M., Wednesday. March 31. Interment at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx..

Metropolitan Museum of Art. The collection of paintings, general tour, 11 A. M.; "Introduction to the Language of Painting," Roberta M. Fansler, 4 P. M.; "Gothic Civil Architecture," Leopold Arnaud, 4 P. M.

Mrs. Ruth Carpenter V. Litt, a leader in women's organizations and formerly active in the Republican party in Suffolk County, died today at her home here after a brief illness. She formerly had homes in New York and East. Patchogue, L. I. Her age was 70.
From the end of 1930 to the close of 1936 expenditures of the United States Treasury were $39,560,688,831, exceeding receipts by $20,884,552,440, according to the 1937 year book of C. J. Devine Co.
A Federal Grand Jury today indicted seven persons, including three officials of R. Cummins Co., Inc., which operates a distillery at Battle Creek on fraud charges in connection with stock sales.

82d St., 122-128 E., 75x202.2 Harriet G. Brooks to Malcolm N. Crosbie. 39-22 49th St. Queens; mtg.. $200,000 ($30): same property. Malcolm N. Croshie to Aimee M. Wolf. 885 Park Av.: mtg., $190.000 ($10),.
Miss Nelva Van Druff has been appointed buyer of lingerie for Lord Taylor. Mrs. Frances T. Ashmore has been named buyer of women's neckwear.

Against the counsel of Dr. Albert B. Meredith, adviser to the State Board of Regents, the Appropriations Committee of the Legislature decided today to recommend that the $1,150,000 budget of Rutgers be reduced by $50,000 and the latter sum be set up as a fund for 200 scholarships.

Governor Earle's plan to wipe out the seven-member Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, controlled by Republicans, and substitute a five-member body to be known as the Public Utility Commission, was adopted finally today by the Senate after heated debate.

The Samuel J. Tilden High School baseball team, runner-up for the city P. S. A. L. crown last year, opened its season In successful fashion by halting Grover Cleveland, 5-1, at Remsen Field yesterday in one of the leading games on the scholastic program. George Sasko led the Tilden attack with a pair of safeties.
Britain sent General Francisco Franco, Insurgent leader in Spain, a sharp reminder today that the molesting of British ships off the Spanish coasts would be deemed acts of piracy.

Baxter Jordan, first baseman for the Bees, abandoned his holdout today and announced he would depart at once for the club's training ground at St. Petersburg, Fla. Jordan said he would accept the $8,000 contract offered him, the amount he received last year. He had demanded $12,00.

Columbia's football squad went outdoors for the first time in its Spring training yesterday and engaged in a thorough drill in fundamentals under the direction of Coach Lou Little at Baker Field. The Lions, in good condition after ten days of indoor work, went through their paces at top speed.

The KingFuller Company Chicago, makers of Top Hat brand food specialty products, has appointed the Chicago office of the Campbell-Ewald Company to handle its advertising. A campaign in magazines is being planned. Newspapers may be added later.

The Montreal Canadiens' defensive machine, bidding to make hockey history, forced the National League championship series to a crucial fifth game tonight by defeating the world champion Detroit Red Wings, 3-1, in the fourth game of their Stanley Cup play-off. The Forum was sold out for the contest, 13,000 attending.

It ought to be painful, even if it is sometimes amusing, to watch good men buffeted by adversity. Just now the struggles of Tammany Hall and the Republican organizations in Greater New York should stir general sympathy. If that fails,
Steel ingot output increased last week against a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index advanced to 122.5 from 120.4. It was 81.0 for the week ended March 28, 1936.

President Roosevelt today threw his influence behind efforts of Congressional and executive spokesmen to save provisions of the administration-sponsored Farm Tenancy Bill that would provide Federal aid to tenants wanting to become owners.

A supper dance was given last night at the Lombardy under the auspices of the Post-Graduate School for Nurses Alumnae of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital for the benefit of the hospital's endowment fund. Miss Helen Irene Hogan was chairman of the arrangements committee.
New York State was $40 richer today and a troubled conscience had found peace.

Rain today washed out the first of the two games scheduled here between the Yankees and Cardinals, and indications are that the field at Waterfront Park will be in such poor condition tomorrow as to preclude the possibility of play.

The principals of the Berlin Jesuit academies-one for boys and one for girls-have been ordered by the National Socialist authorities to refuse further applications for entrance into the lower grades. Jesuit school directors conferred today on the status of uppergrade students, who eventually will have to be transferred to nonconfessional, or State, schools.

James Gay Gordon, a former judge and a member of the bar for sixtyone years, died of a heart attack today at his home in Overbrook. He was 81 years old on Armistice Day. Although he had recently been ill for five weeks, he had returned to his office to resume his law practice more than a week ago.

The three buildings at 133 Maiden Lane, 156 and 158 Water Street, comprising the westerly blockfront on Water Street, have been purchased by Charles F. Noyes from the 133 Maiden Lane Corporation to extend his holdings in this downtown district.
Long Island University defeated Bridgewater College today 12-4, in the home team's second appearance of the baseball season. The Blackbirds got off to a good start, scoring three runs in the first.

The new Toronto Stock Exchange went into action today for the first time, trading starting at 10 A. M.. when the Exchange's siren was sounded by remote control from London. England. R. B. Pearson. chairman of the London Stock Exchange, pushed the starting button.

Twenty-five years ago the physician who clamped a pair of electrodes on a patient and passed an electrical current through the body either to heat tissues according to the principles of diathermy or twitch muscles or stimulate the flagging system was regarded either as a self-deluded enthusiast or as a quack who could not be restrained because he had a license.

No appreciable increase in trading greeted the reopening of the foreign exchange market here yesterday following the extended Easter holiday. Virtually all the foreign currencies, however, were firm to moderately better, the pound sterling closing up 1/4 cent at $4.88 7/8, while the franc showed a gain of 1/8 point to close at 4.59 3/8 cents.

M. C. Fergenson is with the local office of Nugent Igoe as a securities trader. Robert Lehman and John Hertz have been elected directors of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation. E. J. Thomas has been elected executive vice president and director of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. P. E. H. Leroy, formerly vice president and treasurer, was elected vice president of finance and Z. C. Oseland, assistant treasurer, was made treasurer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with a great deal of interest the diametric viewpoints of Edward P. Doyle and Arthur K. Burnam on our slum problems. While Mr. Doyle soft-pedals the perplexing housing problem, he betrays an unsympathetic viewpoint.

One of the gayest events of the late season was the Pirates' Ball with which Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Cheek entertained tonight at the Sailfish Club. Fish nets draped the walls and old ships' lanterns hung at either end of the long buffet table.

The preliminary report of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana for 1936, issued yesterday by Edward G. Seubert, president, shows a consolidated net income of $46,880,000 after chargers, reserves, and income and undistributed-profits taxes.

A special meeting of stockholders of G. R. Kinney Company, Inc. has been called for April 28 to consider a plan of recapitalization under which the holder of each share of present $8 dividend preferred stock, on which arrears at March 31 were $47.66 2-3 a share, will receive one and one-third shares of new $5 dividend prior preferred stock and one share of $1 par common stock.

Mystery, the 38-foot ketch sailed by E. V. Porter Pea of the Tampa Bay Yachting Squadron, arrived here at 6:15:30 this ST morning, the last of ten yachts to finish the eighth annual race from Mid St. Petersburg. Porter said he got off the course and was forced to beat back up the Cuban coast to the finish.

After ten hours of questioning by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott, Albert Kinderman, who hasbeen caretaker of the West End Synagogue at 160 West Eighty-second Street for more than twenty-four years, was arrested at about 2 o'clock this morning on a chrage of arson for two fires in the basement of the synagogue early last Saturday morning.

Two leading producers announced late yesterday an increase of 3/4 cent a pound in the domestic price of copper. The new price of 17 cents, which is the highest since early in 1930, when the price was pegged at 18 cents, followed continued strength in the price of metal abroad.

The Feld-Crawford "Fair Trade" Law has occasioned no advance in prices as far as toilet goods are concerned, H. L. Brooks, of Coty, Inc. and president of the Toilet Goods Association, told the "cosmetics luncheon" of the Fashion Group, Inc. at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

Class 1, Army Polo Ponies to Carry 165 Pounds, Performance 75%, Conformation 25%--First, Jigs, Major Gordan up; second, Little Alicia, Captain R. R. Selway up; third, Lady Love, Corporal Bumgardner up. Class 2, Middle and Heavyweight Army Polo Ponies-First, Guapo, Captain Selway up; second, Dandy, Corporal Bumgardner up; third, Lucky, Major Gordan up.

Asserting that 1936 was the best year American Rolling Mill Company and subsidiaries has had since 1928, George M. Verity, chairman, and Charles R. Hook, president, say in their annual report to stockholders that indications are that industrial activity in the United States may extend beyond all present levels before there is another marked recession.

United States JUNIOR ENGINEER (NAVAL ARCHITECTURE)-$2,000 a year. Navy Department. Applications must be on file not later than April 26, if received from States other than those named below; April 29, if received from the following States: Arizona, California. Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming.
Nine skiers were killed and ten were seriously injured by an avalanche yesterday near the Slovene village of Trzic, where they had been participating in slalom practice.

A single fingerprint on the inside of the bathroom door with a series of faint bloodstains beneath it and several crimsoned fingermarks on the sheets of the bed in which Frank Byrnes was stabbed have been discovered, the police divulged yesterday, in the hunt for the slayer of Byrnes, Mrs. Mary Gedeon and her daughter, Veronica.

A new mortgage loan of $380,000 for five years has been arranged by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., with the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of New Jersey on the fifteen-story apartment and store building at 100 West Fiftyfifth Street.

Thomas Smith, 18, who was arrested yesterday on his way home from church, confessed today that he was the slayer of Mary Ellen Babcock, Police Commissioner James W. Higgins announced. Mr. Higgins said Smith confessed also to having stabbed Francis Fitzgerald, 14, who lives in the same neighborhood, with an icepick in an automobile Sunday night.

Closer integration of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and the New York, Ontario Western Railroad was effected yesterday through the election of Edward G. Buckland, chairman of the New Haven, to the presidency of the other line.

While business failures showed increases in both the manufacturing and wholesale divisions in the week ended March 25 as compared with the previous week, there was a decline from 123 to 107 in the retail group, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders and administrative officials on the pending Farm Tenancy Bill, intimated at his press conference his intention to push forward plans to fix minimum wages by Federal legislation, and accepted the resignation of Raymond B. Stevens from the Federal Trade Commission. Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, and Lady Tweedsmuir arrived to be guests at the White House.
The Rev. Martyn Becker Keeler of West Orange, N. J., has been elected pastor of First Presbyterian Church, succeeding the Rev. Paul Silas Heath. A native of Madison,

The text of Senator Robinson's radio address tonight over the Columbia System was as follows: No other legislation coming before the Congress during recent years has caused so much discussion as that proposed by the President for the reorganization of the judiciary.

E. A. Lapointe, Minister of Justice, told Commons today that if he could find support for the idea he would organize a league of Canadian citizens of all classes to fight communism, fascism and other subversive movements in the Dominion by educating the people.

Resumption of trading in cotton abroad following the protracted Easter holiday brought a sharp rise in prices there which precipitated the most violent advance here and in New Orleans in several years.
Hogs were in slow demand today, especially from shippers, and the trade had reports that buying by the latter was restricted to some extent by heavy importations of foreign pork at New York.

The Polish Ambassador to the United States, Count George Potocki, and Countess Potocka, will come from Washington on Friday to attend the afternoon concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Artur Rodzinski,

A representative cross-section of the millinery industry had an average increase in sales covering all lines last year of 8.1 per cent, in comparison with 1935, with the gain ranging up to 17.8 per cent for hats selling over $24 per dozen, according to the results of a study issued yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.

Extension of the strike of wholesale grocery salesmen, which began last week in four companies, to all wholesale grocery houses in the Bronx was threatened last night by Harry Rosenzweig, business manager of the Wholesale Grocery Salesmen's Union.

The statement of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, excluding subsidiaries, for the twelve months through February, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $39,922,447 after Federal income taxes, retirement expense, interest, amortization and other charges. Total operating revenues were $46,730,936.
BERNARD SEGALL, jobber of thread and yarn, 1,107 Broadway-By Plymouth Thread Rayon Corp., for $835; Max Usdan, doing business as Perfect Thread Co., $1,064; Crown Thread Co., Inc., $346.

Union spokesmen for about 1,000,000 building mechanics affiliated with the American Federation of Labor adopted a resolution here today protesting against what they regarded as unnecessary delay in Congressional action on the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill.
The Society of Independent Artists felt yesterday that it had contributed something to astronomical revelation.

Increase of the New York City school budget by nearly $5,000,000 to provide for smaller classes and additional teachers is urged by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, in his thirty-eighth annual report, made public yesterday.
Albert S. Jones, managing editor of The Ansonia Sentinel and a member of its staff for thirty years, died at his home here today.

Newspaper readers were scandalized this morning to read of a quarrel between two eminent Japanese diplomats, as a result of which one of them was injured and has been ordered to bed by a physician for three days.

Government troops placed the rich Almaden mining district in Northern Cordoba Province out of danger today by capturing the towns of Alcaracejos and Villanueva del Duque, about three miles west of Pozoblanco.
President Roosevelt signed today a joint resolution making Joseph P. Kennedy eligible for appointment as chairman of the Maritime Commission. Mr. Kennedy,

The golfing greats of America, including Robert Tyre Jones Jr., one-time champion of the world and winner of thirteen major titles, invaded this resort city today to survey the battleground where the Augusta national tournament's fourth running gets under way on April Fool's Day.

Confronted by a slump in industrial production--which is frankly characterized as "alarming"- the government ordered today a 20 per cent increase in the total production of all sorts during the present year over last year.

Miss Kathleen Bagley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bagley of Chicago and Miami Beach, was married to Edward Charles Hogan of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Hogan of Chicago this morning in St. Patrick's Catholic Church by the Rev. William Barry, the pastor.

Captain Joseph H. Mode, drum major of the Seventy-first Regiment, died on Monday night at Veterans Hospital, the Bronx. He had been in the hospital for four weeks suffering with pneumonia. He was 66 years old and lived at 549 Riverside Drive.
Turpentine firm, 36 1/4c: sales, 51 barrels; receipts, 233 barrels: shipments, 596 barrels; stock, 19,761 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 922; receipts, 1,506; shipments, 614; stock, 44,261.

Dartmouth came back from defeat at the hands of Virginia yesterday and beat Roanoke College today, 7 to 1. The Indians took the lead with one run in the first and added four in the fifth to clinch the victory.

Mohammed Ali, British subject and chain store merchant during the rule of Haile Selassie, was reported ordered into exile tonight on the ground he had supplied information to the British Intelligence Service.
Mr. and Mrs. James Denison Sawyer are returning today from Boca Raton, Fla., and will be at the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. Timothee Adamowski of Boston are at the Ritz-Carlton.

The regular ticket for officers of Actors Equity Association has been announced, with some of the membership of Equity once again muttering of "nonrepresentation" and an opposition ticket. The regular officers, headed by Frank Gillmore, are on the ticket, and, while nothing is definite yet, an opposition ticket may be put into the field.

Another sinking spell by United States Government long-term bonds, attributed in trading circles in part to advices from Washington that the various governmental agencies virtually had exhausted their supply of excess funds for investment and that any further support of the market must come from the Federal Reserve Banks, featured trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
Walter Duranty's first novel, "One Life, One Kopek," will be the June selection of the Literary Guild. It will be published by Simon Schuster on June 1.

The first supper dance to be given by the committee of The Bachelors will take place on April 10 in the roof garden of the St. Regis. The dance has been patterned after the Bachelors Cotillon of Baltimore and is to be conducted by a committee of young men under the suspices of Miss Juliana Cutting.

Mrs. Bena Goldsmith Loeb, the mother of Gustavus A. Loeb of New York, assistant' treasurer of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died yesterday of a heart ailment at her home, 203 South Camilla Street, Memphis, Tenn., after a brief illness. Her age was 91.

One of the nation's most experienced and accomplished experts in the field of railroad signaling will retire today, the Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday. He is Alexander Holley Rudd, chief signal engineer of the system, who was 70 years old on March 8.
Fast Side realty in the Chelsea section and Yorkville and a parcel in East 106th Street changed hands in deals reported yesterday in which operators and investors were principals.

Governor Lehman announced this evening that before any action is taken by the Legislature to enact a State minimum wage law in consonance with the decision rendered yesterday by the Federal Supreme Court validating the Washington State Minimum Wage Act, a conference would be held, probably in New York City, to outline a course of legislative action.

Awards were made at the Quartermaster Depot here today on textile supplies, bids on which were opened here last week, as follows: Invitation 222, for the manufacture from government cloth of 446,250 coat-style khaki shirts-Hall-Hartwell Company, 90.000 at 42 1/2 cents each less 1 per cent, twenty days: Phillips-Jones Corporation, 261.562 at 48 and 206,250 at 58 cents each. nel.

Residential building in the metropolitan area for the first two months of this year was two and one half times as great as during the same period of 1936. according to the F.. W. Dodge Corporation. The figure for 1937 was $33.242,300, and for. 1936 $13,448,900.

Robert L. Studley, former president of the Boston and National Wool Trade Associations, died today at his home in Wellesley. He was 65 years old. Mr. Studley was the senior partner in the Bos; ton wool firm of Studley Emery and was president of the Wellesley Trust Company.
Loans to property owners for repairs and modernization which have been insured under the National Housing Act during the past three years no longer will enjoy this sponsorship after tomorrow.

A joint resolution to prohibit the export of arms, ammunition or implements of war from the United States, in time of peace or of war, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota and in the House by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York, both Republicans.

Defending the sit-down strike as simple, effective and virtually inevitable instrument in labor's struggle for "industrial citizenship," P. Raymond Walsh, Assistant Professor of Economics at Harvard University, asserted last night that labor unions had not gone half far enough in their fight against "industrial despotism."

Stocks rallied and closed higher; average gains were second widest of the year; turnover, 1,224,910 shares. United States Government issues sagged and closed lower, other bonds mixed; transactions, $11,666,500.

The Securities and Exchange Commission obtained yesterday a pro confess order from the clerk of the United District court here against the Centennial Consolidated Mines Corporation and James E. Martelton, its president, of Denver, Col.
The Interstate Commerce Commission will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary tomorrow. On March 31, 1887, the commisison was organized and five days later, on April 5, it started to function.

A fire that started shortly after noon yesterday in the rectory of St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church at 211 West 141st Street, did considerable damage to several valuable books and oil paintings, copies of old masters, collected by Father William McCann, rector of the church.

James J. (Paddy) Rooney, former welterweight boxer, pleaded guilty yesterday of possessing heroin. He explained to Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson that a blow in a fight about twenty years ago had caused a painful condition for which narcotics had been prescribed and that "I have made the sincerest fight of my life to overcome the habit."

MANHATTAN ANDERSON. CHRISTINA (June 4, 1936). Gross assets, $29.824; net, $26.738. To Otto S. Johnson, Hilmer R. Jaensson, brothers; Marie Roche, niece; Swedish Augusta Home for Aged, Swedish Evangelical Lutheran Church of Gustavus Adolphus and Immanuel Deaconess Institute of

William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, who has been in this country on leave of absence, during which he reported to officials on recent developments in France, went to New York today preparatory to sailing on Thursday on the liner President Harding to resume his post.
The international stock market indices for March 27. with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1924:
Webster Av., 1.68?. 3-st?? game tenement and stores, 25x90; North Side Savings Bank against Yetta Fog?? due $11,151. taxes, , $2.316; to plaintiff for $10.000.
Suspected by Federal officials of being the Boston head of a national bond theft ring, William J. Corcoran, disbarred lawyer and former District Attorney of Middlesex County,

The Fire Department conducted yesterday twelve-hour pumping tests on five new fire engines which were delivered last week. The tests were held at Fifty-third Street and the Hudson River. The pumpers sucked water from the river and pumped it back during the test period, the deck pipes of the engines also being thoroughly tested.

On the basis of a dying man's nod at a Rogues Gallery photograph, Michael Piccardo, 39 years old, of 335 West Thirty-fourth Street, Manhattan, was indicted by a Queens grand jury yesterday for first degree murder in connection with the killing last July 26 of Joseph Potter, 32, of 134 East Third Street, Brooklyn.
