The United States, through the application of Wayne C. Taylor as Acting Secretary of the Treasury, has been granted the right to intervene in the reorganization proceedings before the Interstate Commerce Commission of the Alabama, Tennessee Northern Railroad Corporation.
Movements of vessels follow: all dates are March 29. unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Antares, March 30; Salinas.

Benjamin F. Williams, banker and civic leader, died at his home here today of pneumonia. He was 64 years old. Mr. Williams was president of the Wilkes-Barre Deposit and Savings Bank, president of the National Register Publishing Company of New York, director of the Royer Foundry and Machine Company and member of the firm of Percy A. Brown Co.

Solly Krieger, Brooklyn middleweight, was awarded a technical knockout over Eddie McGuire of Ireland after the fourth round of the feature bout listed for ten rounds last night before 3,000 persons at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn.

Soviet Russia's de jure recognition of Rumania's annexation of Bessarabia will come about in the near future, according to the bestinformed circles here. Bessarabia has been the crux of SovietRumanian relations for the last eighteen years.

A group of investors purchased from David S. Meister the threestory business building on a plot 17 by 150 feet at 136 Main Street, White Plains. The property was bought by the seller in August, 1936, and the building was remodeled.

Tom Iannicelli, defending champion, advanced to the quarter-final bracket of the world open squash tennis tournament, a round ahead of the field, by subduing Barry Sullivan, Columbia University Club pro, 15-4, 15-6, 15-5, in a secondround encounter at the Hotel Shelton court last night.
Raymond B. Stevens of New Hampshire has resigned as a member of the Tariff Commission to campaign for the President's proposal for court reorganization and for tax revision in his own State.

Harry Cooke Cushing, banker, of this city and Oyster Bay, L. I., and Mrs. Frances S. Peters Holmes of the Pierre, formerly of Glen Head, L. I., will be married on June 30. Mr. Cushing said last night that he and his fiance had not decided where their marriage would take place.

Herbert Morrison, Labor Member of the British Parliament and President of the London City Council, said on his arrival on the French liner Ile de France last night that the British Government had "cringed to Fascist Italy" in its policy on the Spanish question. Foreign Minister Anthony Eden had not taken a stand, but a "lie-down" position in his attitude on the Spanish civil disturbance, he declared.
Mayor La Guardia's linguistic ability provided an agreeable surprise yesterday for B. P. Stoianovitch, consul general of Yugoslavia in New York, who called at City Hall to pay his respects.

Only one bowler was able to gain a place among the leaders yesterday in the twenty-first session of pin crashing at the American Bowling Congress tournament. Clarence Behrns of North Tonawanda, N. Y., cleaned off 681 pins at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory to go into a fourth-place tie with Jack Russell of Lyons, Ill., in the singles.
Eddie Blunt, Corona heavyweight who has knockout triumphs over Jack Trammell and Leroy Haynes to his credit, will face Jack Moran of Scranton in a ten-round bout at Rockland Palace tonight.

Word has been received here from China of the marriage of Miss Erica Joan Eames, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Eames of Twickenham, Middlesex, England, to Lieutenant Clark T. Abbott, Supply Corps, U. S. N. The ceremony took place on Feb. 27 in Christ Church, Shameen, Canton.

Frank Kemp, general manager of the Great Western Sugar Company, said today that representatives of growers' associations in Colorado, Nebraska, Wyoming and Montana had agreed with the company on terms for the 1937 beet contract.

TALL, blond and bland, Horton Smith is back at Augusta, Ga., again for the Masters' Tournament, a swanky golfing affair where admission is by card only. That Augusta course seems to be Horton's particular apple, and the big fellow from Joplin is an apple man from away back.
A mortgage held by St. John's Guild, Samuel S. Duryee, president, from the Ludin Realty Co. Inc., on 259 W. 34th St. 12, 1940. at 5 1/2 per cent.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 27: COMMANDERS Alden, C. S., Commander of Mobile Target Division 1, to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C., June 1. Thompson, R. R., the Cuyama, to instruction at Army Industrial College, Washington, D. C., June 11. Valz, E. G., Medical Corps, Philadelphia, Pa., to home, relieved from all active duty, about May 1.

Grant Fraser, 13-year-old son of Alexander Fraser, president of the Shell Petroleum Corporation, died of suffocation today in a fire which swept the rambling twenty-one-room family residence in suburban Clayton.

Republican leaders of the Legislature spent two hours with Governor Lehman this afternoon in a vain effort to obtain his cooperation in a fiscal reorganization plan submitted by Asemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the Assembly Committee on Ways and Means.

Nathan S. Jonas, president of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, yesterday failed in an attempt to have dismissed a $1,500,000 slander suit brought by officials of Local 171 of the Hospital Employes Union which recently staged a sit-down strike at the hospital. Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman ruled that the officials had a legal right to sue, except in the case of Morris Berlin, vice president, whose claim for $500,000 was dismissed as technically defective.

A mysterious motor car explosion, attributed by two scientists to a stick of dynamite wired to the ignition, dangerously wounded Mayor Gail H. Jacobs today in his own garage here. The 44-year-old executive apparently set off the charge unwittingly by turning the ignition switch of his car, preparatory to driving to his plumbing supply company office.

This was payday for several thousand employes of the Dodge Brothers plant, closed since March 8 by the Chrysler Corporation strike. By Friday evening paychecks aggregating about $2,000,000 will have been distributed among the 67,000 employes of Chrysler plants, for work done prior to the strike.
A committee to study the question of whether or not the government will resume payment on the public works bonds in default since 1933 was appointed at a Cabinet meeting this afternoon.

Mrs. K. F. Evans of the Short Hills Club, the top-seeded entrant, passed her quarter-final and semi-final tests to gain the final of the first women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Apawamis Club today.
Pearl White, heroine of the movie "Perils of Pauline," will be welcomed as "just a pal" when she visits two nieces here soon. The two girls,

Senator Desmond said today that he would introduce a resolution for a constitutional amendment to permit the Court of Appeals to reapportion Senate and Assembly districts if the Legislature fails to do so.

The charity figure-skating carnival at Madison Square Garden again proved to be a popular attraction last night when another capacity gathering of 16,000 attended. It marked the third evening that the Garden was "sold out" and, if anything, the spectators were even more enthusiastic than those at the first two shows.

Miss Marjorie Lucas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Lucas of Maplewood, has chosen April 17 for her marriage to Henry Leavitt of Bryn Mawr, Pa., son of Mrs. Harry Leavitt of Sharon Hill, Pa. The ceremony will be performed by the bride-elect's grandfather, the Rev.

Kirsten Flagstad, the Norwegian soprano, has signed with Paramount and will make her screen debut in "The Big Broadcast of 1938," planned for release in the early Fall. The operatic interlude in which she is to appear will be made in the Eastern service studio in Astoria.

The marriage of Miss Molly Flagg, daughter of Mrs. Harold Fowler of 1 East End Avenue and Far Hills and of the late Montague Flagg of Hartford, Conn., to Robert P. Gibb, son of Mrs. Lewis M. Gibb of 133 East Sixty-fourth Street and the late Mr. Gibb, took place here at noon today at Middlebrook, the country place of the bride's mother and stepfather.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal Court in Brooklyn, directed yesterday immediate payment of interest arrears of $50 on each bond of the Bush Terminal Company's 5 per cent consolidated mortgage bonds maturing in 1955 and the, payment of interest of $25 a bond due on April 1 on the Bush Terminal Buildings Company's 5 per cent bonds maturing in 1960.

Mrs. Helen Hartley Jenkins, whose philanthropies won her an honorary degree from New York University and many other decorations, left a gross estate of $3,090,056 when she died at Morristown, N. J., on April 24, 1934, according to a transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday. She was a resident of Norfolk. Conn.

The Socialist party Issued a warning today that "the democratic capitalist countries of the world are preparing a dictatorial military rule in the event of war," and called upon "the working class, progressive and revolutionary forces, to refuse to support all wars conducted by capitalist countries, whether they be democratic or Fascist."
Frank J. Centner. from 108th Precinct to 16th Division, assigned to duty as supervisor of plainclothes patrolmen. PATROLMEN-Thomas F. O'Brien. from 3d Precinct to 15th Precinct.
Appointment of a City Industrial Relations Board of three members to provide impartial assistance in labor disputes was announced yesterday at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia.

If you have a "ketcher's mitt" or a "first sacker's glove" or a baseball "backstop's mask," they are needed down on the lower West Side by some youngsters who dwell in the few houses which are wedged between the factories and warehouses which dot the waterfront.

Joseph Briggs of this place, president of the Louis C. Tiffany Studios Corporation of New York, makers of church decorations and memorials, died Sunday In St. Clare's Hospital in New York. He was 64 years old.

Pushed by one of his play-mates into the street, James Cavanaugh, 5 years old, of 294 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, was struck yesterday morning by an automobile. He died two hours later in the Cumberland Hospital of a fractured skull and internal injuries.

Joe Platak of Chicago and Sam Atcheson of Memphis, Tenn., favorites to battle it out in the title round of the national A. A. U. handball tournament, swept into the quarterfinals today by impressive victories.

RED HARVEST, a play in three acts, by Walter Charles Roberts, based on "pages from a Red Cross diary." Staged by Antoinette Perry; settings by John Root; produced by Brock Pemberton, in association with the Theatre Foundation of America. At the National Theatre.
An odd twist in Florida weather finally caught up with the Dodgers today, making them miss training for the first time since they reported a little more than a month ago.

Consignments of newly mined Russian gold to an estimated value of 38,000,000 are being shipped to Great Britain and reexported to the United States, according to The Daily Telegraph. Part of the bullion, it is assumed, will be used to pay for the Soviet's recent heavy purchases of rubber and metals.

About 4,000 employers of eight or more persons in New Jersey have failed to make their required contribution to the State's unemployment compensation fund up to the close of business today, according to the New Jersey Unemployment Commission. Unless they do so before tomorrow midnight it was explained,

The most elaborate schedule in recent years, including dual meets with three new opponents, has been arranged for Manhattan's varsity track and field forces this Spring by Brother Charles, faculty moderator. Altogether six dates are listed for the varsity athletes while the freshmen will participate in four meets.
Mrs. Mary Kennedy McLaughlin, wife of Thomas J. McLaughlin, newly elected Trustee of this village, died last night in Mercy Hospital here after a long illness. Mrs.

Emil Grunberg, through Frances Tilghman, in 888 Park Av.; Abraham A. Silberberg, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., in 885 Park Av.; Chester H. Roth, through Joseph Hart Co., in ISO E. 79th St.; Tishman Realty Construction Co., Inc., broker.

Renomination of Mayor La,.Guardia on the Republican ticket as the only alternative to returning control of the city administration to Tammany Hall was urged yesterday by Goodhue Livingston Jr. in a letter to members of the New York County Republican Committee.

Attorney General Fernandez Garcia made public today the results of the government investigation of the Palm Sunday killings in Ponce. A paraffin test applied to sixteen Nationalists to determine whether they had fired the guns showed fourteen positives.

The Fletcher Joint Stock Land Bank of Indianapolis, Ind., has called for payment on May 1, next, a total of $713,600 of 41/2 per cent bonds, representing all of the bank's bonds of the issue due on Nov. 1, 1937, and all of the bonds of the issue callable on May 1, 1937. and due on May 1, 1967.

Plans have been completed by Miss Florence Alice Morgan, daughter of Professor and Mrs. Jerome John Morgan of Maplewood for her marriage to William L. Hardham of Cynwyd, Pa., son of Mrs. John Stuart Hamilton of Newark.

The memorable climax of the concert given last night in Carnegie Hall by the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, a chorus of 250, and assisting soloists under the direction of Antonia Brico, was the performance, after an absence of some seasons from our concert platforms, of the superb score of Horatio Parker,

Although foreign copper prices have been maintained around 1 cent a pound above the domestic level for more than two weeks, the advance late yesterday in domestic prices of 3/4 cent a pound to 17 cents by two leading producers came as a surprise to the trade.

Two large multi-family dwellings, the sixteen-story house at 693-7 West End Avenue and the elevenstory apartment at 1,036-1.038 Lexington Avenue and 135-43 East Seventy-fourth Street, were sold at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms, together with ten other Manhattan properties, yesterday.

The Hackley School track squad of Tarrytown is slated to open its season on April 23, when several runners will participate in the Penn relays at Philadelphia. Four dual encounters and one triangular meet are also on the card.

Lord McGowan of Ardeer, chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, is sailing for England today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, accompanied by Lady McGowan. Others aboard will be Mr. and Mrs. Norman Thomas,

More than 1,000 persons, including civic and political leaders, attended the funeral service yesterday morning in Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church, Beverly Road and East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, for John F. Murray, a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority for the last eight years, who died after a prolonged illness Saturday at his home, 169 Rugby Road, Brooklyn.

Joseph B. Eastman, member of the Interstate Commerce Commission for eighteen years, appeared before the House Interstate Commerce Committee today to urge passage of the Lea bill, which would give the commission wide regulatory powers over air transport lines.

The Bankers Trust Company, as executors and trustees under the will of Charles A. Gould, sold the nine-story loft building at 75-77 Spring Street, northeast corner of Crosby Street, occupying a plot 50 by 112 feet.

For the first time in its history the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that an adopted child, incapable of self-support and in danger of becoming a public charge, may require its natural parents to contribute to its support when the foster parents are unable to do so.

The four-family dwelling at 531 Twenty-eighth Street, Union City, N. J., has been sold for occupancy of one of the apartments to Henry Henke. Henry Kaufman was the seller. The attorneys in the deal were Harber Freesman. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Captain James Barr, who commanded the Cunard liner Carmania when she went to the assistance of the burning Volturno in 1913, after responding to one of the earliest wireless appeals for help, died at Wallasey, Cheshire, today. His age was 82.

President Roosevelt today proclaimed April 6 as Army Day. On that day all army posts will be open to the public and special demonstrations and parades will be held by the army to give to the country a better acquaintance with its activities.

Richard Carman Sr., veteran turfman, died here today after a lingering illness. Mr. Carman formerly owned a well-known breeding farm at Silver Springs, Md., but this was wiped out in a disastrous fire in which he lost sixty brood mares. Mr. Carman's horse, Meridian, won the Kentucky Derby in 1910.

Miss Jean Osborn Thomson, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. W. K. C. Thomson of this city and Herbert Birch of Tenafly, N. J., were married tonight in the First Presbyterian Church here by the bride's father, who is pastor of the church. A reception followed in the chapel.
Brown Preparatory School of Philadelphia, defending champion, will meet Scarborough (N. Y.) School in the opening round of the annual Eastern States Basketball Tournament on Thursday night.
These orders were issued in the Northern New York Area: The following reserve officers. recently released to the Northern New York Reserve Area for assignment, are assigned as follows:
T. Roy Barnes, veteran stage and screen comedian, died at his home here today of a cardiac ailment. He was 56 years old and had been ill for many months.

The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Justice reported today that indictments had been returned in the United States District court at Detroit against seven individuals for alleged violations of the Securities Act of 1933 in the sale of stock of R. Cummins Co., Inc.

Not often in its long history has the Supreme Court handed down on a single day three major decisions of more immediate interest than those which were read on Monday, and part of this interest reflects the fact that each decision has helped in its own way to clarify some phase of the present controversy over the court itself.
The seventeenth annual dinner of the New York Society of Military and Naval Officers of the World War will be held next Wednesday at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton.

Efforts to get a meeting of the Tammany executive committee to depose James J. Dooling as leader on the ground that he is physically unable to conduct the Mayoralty campaign, now in its early stages, will be continued when James J. Hines returns from Hot Springs, Ark., today or tomorrow.

Spain's civil war has prevented the burial of the gypsy King, Matthias Kwiek, in his family vault in the famous gypsy cemetery in Seville. The war also ruined Kwiek financially, his family complains, for he sent the last of his money to his friend,

Speaking at the annual dinner tendered by the Hun School to athletic letter winners at the Princeton Inn tonight, Herbert O. (Fritz) Crisler, head football coach at Princeton University, warned the students not to "sell" their athletic abilities.

Jerome Straus defeated Edward Stewart, 175 to 51, and Howard Bergman vanquished George Hofmann, 175 to 33, in the Poggenburg Memorial Cup 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy last night.
Five college freshman teams are among the ten opponents listed by the Roxbury School baseball team this Spring. The Roxbury nine is to open its campaign at home on April 29 against Milford School.

Artur Rodzinski has been engaged to conduct the NBC Symphony Orchestra in a series of ten radio concerts supplementary to the ten which will be directed by Arturo Toscanini late this year, it was announced yesterday by Lenox R. Lohr, president of the National Broadcasting Company.

Representative Claude Fuller of Arkansas, denounced today what he termed the hiring of influential executives with strong political connections, and urged the House to adopt his resolution providing for an inquiry into alleged monopolistic practices in the liquor industry.

Mexico will call upon the League of Nations to back the Spanish Loyalists as a means of ending the "fratricidal" civil war in Spain and eliminating what is declared here to be an increasing danger of international war because of the participation of foreign elements in the struggle.

Thirty thousand members of Dressmakers Union, Local 22, of the International Garment Workers Union, have endorsed President Roosevelt's proposal for the reorganization of the United States Supreme Court, Charles S. Zimmerman, manager of the local, said yesterday in a statement issued through the State headquarters of the American Labor party.

Abe Coleman or Los Angeles defeated Rudy Dusek of Omaha in the feature wrestling exhibition at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 2,000 persons saw Coleman gain the award when Dusek, entangled in the ring ropes, failed to extricate himself before the count of ten. The bout lasted 38 minutes 3 seconds. Dusek scaled 217 pounds, Coleman 205.
Tinton Av., 1.249 (10-2663); A. R. Corp. to Central Savings Bank; installments, interest as per bond; .$28,500.

Many parties were given in conjunction with the style revue entitled "A Century's Looking-Glass of Fashion," which was held yesterday during the luncheon hour at Sherry's for the benefit of the West Side Thrift Shop.

The administration leadership struck back tonight at Senator Glass for his attack on President Roosevelt's court reorganization proposals. Senator Robinson of Arkansas, in a nation-wide radio broadcast, replied to the Virginian's address of last night.

Teaching methods in Roslyn, L. I., grade schools will be investigated "some time next week," Dr. J. Cayce Morrison of the State Education Department said today. The Roslyn Board of Education, Dr. Morrison said,

The wedding of Miss Adele Van Cott of Watertown, N. Y., to Dr. John A. Clarke of Greenwich took place this morning at the home of Miss Christine Devendorf of Watertown, with whom the bride had made her home.

Erection of a religious center and chapel for Catholic students and faculty members at Yale will be begun soon on the university campus at New Haven. William V. Griffin, Yale, '12, announced here yesterday.

In order to make the most of opportunities emanating from the upward business trend and the coming nationwide building boom, Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association,
The Governor General of Canada and Lady Tweedsmuir reached Washington today from Ottawa for an official visit of two days at the White House.
Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, will depart on Monday for Mexico, D. F., for a five-day visit of "no official significance." He will return to Washington on April 16.

The Mullins Manufacturing Company has notified the Exchange of a proposal to increase its authorized Class B common stock from 172,550 to 560,000 shares and to eliminate 57,550 shares of Class A common.

Compensation paid to E. S. Phillips, president of the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., during the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1936, totaled $72,426, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. E. D.

A promising St. John's University baseball team launched its 1937 season in an impressive fashion today on University Field, shutting out Bill Clarke's Princeton nine, 8-0, before 400 shivering spectators. It was also the home force's first game of the season.

While the Italian fleet, under Premier Benito Mussolini's direction, was recently making a test blockade of the Central Mediterranean, the British garrison at Malta, it is now possible to reveal, was secretly testing its own defenses in face of the possibility of some such menace.

A suit to enjoin the Literary Guild of America, Inc., from selling to non-members books published by Farrar Rinehart, Inc., was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by the publishing company. The complaint also asks $100,000 damages from the guild for alleged breach of contract.
Canadian coal production in February amounted to 1,292,002 tons, compared with 1,492,207 in February, 1936, and a five-year average of 1,160,082, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Dispatches received in London tonight from various points in Spanish territory tend to clear up rumors regarding dissension and discontent in the Insurgent ranks and also tell of unrest among the government forces.

A strike of 400,000 soft coal miners in a dozen States, effective tomorrow, loomed as a possibility yesterday as negotiations for a new agreement between the United Mine Workers and operators represented in the Appalachian wage conference appeared to be deadlocked.

" Minnie," a cat of undistinguished lineage, gets $3.20 a month for killing mice in a refinery laboratory here and is the only feline employee on the payroll of the Standard Oil Company, it was learned here today.
Senator Josiah W. Bailey, opponent of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan, declared here tonight that "the greatest danger in America today is inflation."
The seventh annual Tri-City Kennel Club Show opened today at the Moline Field House, where 268 dogs representing forty-one breeds were benched. It is a two-day show,

The Pere Marquette Railroad has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $1,940,000 of 234 per cent equipment certificates to be redeemed in ten annual installments, the first on May 1, 1938.

Frank Merkert, head bookkeeper in the title department of the Jamaica branch of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 160-08 Jamaica Avenue, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn to a complaint alleging embezzlement of the funds of the institution. Merkert was held in bail of $2,000 for a hearing on April 13.
The Pedro Montanez-Lou Ambers lightweight bout will be held in Madison Square Garden next Monday. Approval of the new date was given yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that sponsors of the Iroquois Share Corporation of Buffalo made a profit of $322,500 without assuming any obligations, while its stockholders lost heavily.

Arthru V. Gwynne has joined the Bulkley Horton Co., to be in charge of retailstore renting. George S. Horton reported yesterday that there had been a large increase recently in the demand for stores in Brooklyn and Queens.

Retirement annuities for all employes of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation and its subsidiaries are provided in a plan that will be presented to the annual shareholders' meeting on April 20. It is intended to supplement the annuities provided by the Social Security Act, especially for employes who receive more than $3,000 a year.
Two groups from the Fencers Club tied for the senior national epee team title at the Saltus Fencing Club last night, battling to a 41/2-to-41/2 deadlock in the final round.
Max Schmeling, German heavyweight contender, returned today from the United States, where he vainly sought to swing a deal assuring a title fight with Champion Jimmy Braddock here this Summer.

Filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, covering 988,971 shares of new $1 par value common stock of the company, reveals that the stock has been underwritten, subcct to the usual conditions, by a nation-wide group, as follows:

Thirty of the fifty-six classes in the two-day twentieth annual Pinehurst horse show were staged today, with an estimated attendance of 1,500. The three places in the Sandhills for qualified hunters were swept by the Sundown Stables, owned by Rufus Finch and Fred Wilmshurst of Red Bank, N. J., and Pinehurst.

A momentous decision confronts the Sinking Fund Commission, according to its schedule for today. This is whether to develop North Beach Airport, known since its lease by the city as Municipal Airport Number 2, into a terminal suitable for the rapidly approaching transatlantic and Bermuda air services, or, beyond this,- into an A-1-A airport to serve the greater city.

In a move to loosen the tongues of business men reluctant to discuss their dealings with racketeers, Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, "cracked down" yesterday on an officer of one of the largest dress-manufacturing companies in New York City.
Launcelot Packer, director of the EnglishSpeaking Union here and early supporter of workmen's compensation legislation, died late yesterday after a brief illness.
Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, the country's No. 3 ranking tennis player, defeated Vernon Marcum of St. Petersburg, 6-4, 6-4, in the second round of the Atlanta invitation tournament today.

Although the number or visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was well above the pre-holiday week, the total was slightly under the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals were 751, as against 623 in the previous week and 803 in the same period last year.

The two-story structure at 353 Broadway has been leased by the Bell Textile Company for ten years. It is to be used for the sale and storage of cotton goods, silks and rayons, Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., brokers in the deal, report that the adjoining building, 355 Broadway, will be reconstructed along lines similar to the new structure.

With WPA technical workers and engineers threatening sit-down strikes and walkouts on twentyfive major projects today, the Works Progress Administration served notice last night that it would dismiss, eject and have arrested any employee who refused to leave his place of employment when ordered to do so.
Patrolman William C. Stokes, one of the police assigned to guard Leon Czolgosz when he was executed for the shooting of President McKinley here, retired today after forty-three years' service.
Mayor La Guardia accepted an invitation yesterday to attend the fifteenth annual "Front Page Ball" of the Newspaper Women's Club at the Hotel Astor on Friday evening.

After a concert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra here this evening, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the orchestra, received an honorary degree of Doctor of Music from Rutgers University. The degree was conferred by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the university, before an audience of 3,200 faculty members, their wives, students of Rutgers and New Jersey College for Women and other friends of the university.

An inventory of equipment in the Roxy Theatre was ordered yesterday by Addison S. Pratt, Federal Special Master, as Howard S. Cullman, trustee for the theatre, continued his testimony in the proceeding to reorganize the Roxy Theatres Corporation under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

How the defeat of the Italian detachments before Madrid has affected the international situation and how the decisions of the Non-Intervention Committee for Spain are to be carried out, will be discussed tomorrow by the French Cabinet at a meeting that will be largely devoted to foreign affairs.
Eleven high school graduates, six of them girls, have won scholarships in this year's February-September division for freshmen at New York University's Washington Square College.

The Maritime Commission announced yesterday its decision upholding the recommendation of F. J. Horan, a commission examiner. that full membership privileges in the Adriatic, Black Sea and Levant Conference be granted to the shipping company of Phelps Brothers Co., of 17 Battery Place.

The conditional sale of real estate by mortgage trustees, with a possibility that the transaction might later be canceled, was disapproved today by Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme in one of four decisions affecting interests of Westchester investors in mortgage certificates originally issued by companies now in liquidation.

Fashioning an overlapping ring of old and new laws around its case in an effort to clinch convictions, the government indicted seven men yesterday on charges of defrauding several hundred persons in Georgia. Florida and the Carolinas out of $250,000 through fraudulent stock, sales.

WITH THE WEST IN HER EYES, by Kathleen Strange. (Dodge, $2.50.) A story of a modern pioneer. WILDERNESS WANDERERS, by Wendell and Lucie Chapman. (Scribner, $3.75.) Adventures among wild animals in the Rocky Mountains.
The horse show ball at the Pinehurst Country Club tonight was preceded by many dinner parties, one of the largest of which was a progressive event.

Three more men were arrested yesterday in the round-up begun by the police last Wednesday in an effort to stop sex crimes in South Brooklyn. The prisoners, locked up in Hamilton Avenue Precinct to await arraignment today, were: Anthony Rizzi, 52 years old,

The engagement has been announced of Miss Elsie Marian Bomhoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry James Bomhoff of 54 Tuxedo Road, Montclair, to William Ezra Cornell, son of Professor and Mrs. William Bouck Cornell, also of Montclair.

Romeo Tata, violinist, made his first New York appearance yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall. Mr. Tata gave evidence of his talent and seriousness and there were passages of fine straightforward playing, but he did not display the reserves of virtuosity and tone necessary for completely effective performance.

David Wesley Jarvis of Monmouth Beach, N. J., chairman of the board of the George A. Sloan Company of this city, textile mill agents. died yesterday in his New York apartment at 574 West End Avenue, in his sixty-ninth year of a complication of ailments.

Reconciliation between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and General Erich Ludendorff, who together faced the Reichswehr's bullets during the Munich Putsch of 1923 but whose ways parted afterward, was officially announced from Munich today in the following communique:
The Museum of Fine Arts announced today that it had found in Boston and acquired a fifteenth-century Venetian profile by Gentile Bellini, Italian painter.
There was a period some years ago in the development of the technique of game management when the idea of game refuges with an adjoining public shooting ground spread rapidly throughout the country.

With the total of prize money increased from $1,750 to $2,000, the annual metropolitan open golf championship will be played at the Forest Hill Field Club, Bloomfield, N. J., on May 13, 14 and-15, the Associated Press reported yesterday.

Harold D. Butler, director of the International Labor Office in Geneva, said today that the International Textile Conference, opening here on Friday, would discuss the possibility of expanding world markets for textiles.

World rearmament and a general improvement in economic conditions abroad are rapidly developing boom conditions in this country's foreign trade, executives assembled at the Hotel Pennsylvania for the annual get-together meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc.,

The annual financial report of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, of which Samuel W. Reyburn is chairman, showed a net profit of $1,701,433 for the year ended on Jan. 31, after depreciation, interest, expenses and Federal income taxes, including $500 surtax on undistributed earnings of a subsidiary and other charges.

Lieut. Col. Charles W. Ryder, infantry, now on duty here with the general staff, was named today to become commandant of cadets at the Military Academy, effective June 30. He will succeed Lieut. Col. Dennis E. McCunniff, who will report to the Army War College.

For outstanding skill in the erection of the new uptown office of the Dry Dock Savings Institution, at Lexington Avenue and Fiftyninth Street, twenty-one mechanics employed on the building received certificates and gold buttons yesterday from the New York.

Romeo Tata, violinist, made his first New York appearance yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall. Mr. Tata gave evidence of his talent and seriousness and there were passages of fine straightforward playing, but he did not display the reserves of virtuosity and tone necessary for completely effective performance.

David Wesley Jarvis of Monmouth Beach, N. J., chairman of the board of the George A. Sloan Company of this city, textile mill agents. died yesterday in his New York apartment at 574 West End Avenue, in his sixty-ninth year of a complication of ailments.

Reconciliation between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and General Erich Ludendorff, who together faced the Reichswehr's bullets during the Munich Putsch of 1923 but whose ways parted afterward, was officially announced from Munich today in the following communique:
Mrs. Mary Abbie Fessenden, whose husband, the late Major Joshua A. Fessenden, U.S.A. (retired), served as postmaster here prior to his death in 1908, died yesterday at her home. She was 95 years old.

Coming right on top of a bad spill yesterday, which had resulted in Joe Renick suffering a broken collar bone and Joe Rosen being badly stunned and cut over one eye, two horses fell with their riders at Tropical Park today in a jam shortly after the start of the third race, a six-furlong dash for maiden fillies and mares.

Affiliation of the "official testing laboratories" of the Retail Trading Standards Association of London and the National Retail Dry Goods Association was announced by the latter organization yesterday.

William T. Tilden, age-defying tennis star, tonight won the first of his professional matches with Fred Perry, agile Englishman. Tilden dominated the play in three sets, winning by 6-2, 8-10, 6-3, 6-3. Perry won the first two matches in New York and Chicago, taking three of four sets each time.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra will play the second Bach Brandenburg Concerto in F at its concert in Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening instead of the third Brandenburg Concerto, as originally announced.
A general reduction of 1 to 3 cents in the retail price of milk will become effective tomorrow with the termination of price fixing by the State Milk Control Board, it was indicated yesterday.

The use of artificial fever as an efficient preventive of several of the most prevalent causes of blindness was reported yesterday at the First International Congress on Fever Therapy at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, in which about 200 of the world's leading authorities are participating.
W. E. Hutton Co. today fought off attempts by counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission to show that it unlawfully obtained information from a stock specialist's book in 1935-36.

The Sanctuary of the Moon, ruined Moorish citadel in the Sierra Cordoba Range and scene of bygone Spanish struggles against invaders, fell into the hands of the advancing government troops in the Pozoblanco sector today.

Sullen gray skies that the sun vainly tried to penetrate and heavy mists obscuring all but the lower snowelad slopes of wooded mountains greeted the Duke of Windsor this morning when he awoke in hisbalcony room in the lakeside Appesbach House here.
The composing room equipment of The Brooklyn Times-Union, re cently acquired by The Brooklyn Eagle, was not included in the mechanical equipment purchased under lease,

The daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,431,300 barrels, compared with 3,448,150 in the preceding week, a decline of 16,850 the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

G. A. Tomlinson, a leading figure in affairs of the Van Sweringen companies since the death of the Van Sweringen brothers, said today that "propositions" had been made concerning the sale of Midamerica Corporation but "nothing of interest" had resulted.

Japan is not engaging in a naval construction race with the United States or any other nation, Hirosi Saito, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, said last night before 800 persons at the annual dinner of the Japan Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
A closed-shop agreement, providing a 10 per cent wage increase for 1,000 employes of eighteen Passaic County (N. J.) hatband manufacturers, was announced yesterday by Sidney Hillman,

Guaranty Trust Company of New York American depositary receipts for ordinary registered shares and 7 1/2 per cent cumulative participating preference registered shares of the London Tin Corporation, Ltd., have been removed from unlisted trading by the Exchange.

Emperor Augustus's altar of peace will be reconstructed as a symbol of Rome's regained glory, Premier Mussolini's Cabinet decided today. Excavations have been started forty feet beneath the Fiano Palace to recover parts of the marble monument.

This is the night they will be trying "Young Madame Conti" for the Murder of Her Lover, the samethe trial, that is-taking place at the Music Box Theatre. The play is from the German of Bruno Frank and was adapted by Benn W. Levy and Hubert Griffith.

Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis indicated today that the doubleheader of Tommy Henrich vs the Milwaukee Baseball Club and President Alva Bradley of the Indians vs. Billy Evans of the Red Sox would start promptly on Thursday.
Peace conferences in the Chrysler strike recessed here this afternoon until 11 A. M. Friday. Immediately afterward Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the corporation, left for New York.
Governor Carl E. Bailey vetoed today a bill passed by the Legislature to restrict the advertising of liquor, describing it as "grossly unfair and discriminatory."
Hugh M. Anderson, who headed one of the most ambitious real estate developments of the Florida boom, filed a bankruptcy petition today listing liabilities of $8,502,778.84 and assets of $400.

Offering will be made to the public soon by an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers of 198,800 shares of $1-par common stock of the Burlington Mills Corporation, according to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 247,911 common shares and stock-purchase warrants evidencing rights to buy 39,111 common shares.

The New South Wales Government has informed distributors of American films that they must honor the provisions of the film quota act requiring a quota of British films, even if it is necessary to undertake production in Australia to provide it.
The showing of the American Fox film "Charlie Chan at the Opera" has been forbidden by special order of the Reich censor. Just what its objection is is not clear.
Mrs. Nan Pierson Brooks Macy wore a ten-cent wedding ring in the Yuma (Ariz.) ceremony that made her the wife of William Hunsaker Brill, wealthy Los Angeles sportsman.

The pre-shrinking of woolens and worsteds as a current merchandising factor of "primary importance" was discussed yesterday at a luncheon conference held in conjunction with the sixteenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Grand Central Palace.
Sidney Wood's decision not to attempt to win a place on the United States Davis Cup team this year was confirmed yesterday.

Five charges against thirteen sitdown strikers in the plant of the Etched Products Corporation, 39-01 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, were withdrawn in the Long Island City magistrate's court yesterday by Albert Nierenberg, president of the company.

Europe and the Americas have changed places as "the Old World" and "the New World," and a united American continent must now teach its lesson of democracy to nations that have reverted to "one of despotism's old and outworn forms," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared yesterday.

The two-story brick taxpayer on the northwest corner of Pennsylvania and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Lincoln Savings Bank to an investing client of Henry Brinsley. The building covers a plot 107 1/2 feet on Pennsylvania Avenue and 21 1/2 feet on Atlantic Avenue.

Miss Elaine Evelyne Bassett, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Wallace Bassett of Dallas, Texas, and John J. Selig Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John J.Selig of 275 Central Park West, were married yesterday in City Hall by Mayor La Guardia.
Behind us today lie 7,000 miles of a new transoceanic airway never until now charted from the air for the purpose of converting it into a new aerial trade route, gaited to the speed of modern times.
Federal Judge George A. Welsh issued late today a temporary order that the Short Line, Inc., of West Chester must continue bus operations between Washington and New York City until April 5.

While another capacity turnout of 600 persons thrilled to his truly great performance Ralph Greenleaf, thirteen-time winner of the world pocket billiard championship, routed Marcel Camp of Detroit, 125 to 6, in 12 innings last night at the Bond Building, electrifying the crowd with an unfinished string of 63 points, which represents the highest run thus far.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace Hatch Tucker of this city and Greens Farms, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Tucker's sister, Miss Minnie Fox Hopkins of 55 East Seventy-second Street, to Dr. Charles Louis Gilbert of 151 East Eighty-third Street, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Pierce Gilbert of Richmond, Va.

The engagement of Miss Treve Wampler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Wampler of Miami, Fla., formerly of Greenwich, to Edward J. Lucke Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Lucke of Milbrook, Greenwich, has been announced. The wedding will take place in May.

Dunbar Bostwick, president of the Aiken Mile Race Track Association, announced today that the new course for trotting horses will be opened officially on April 8, when the Aiken Polo Pony and Hunter Horse Show is held.
The tranquillity in which the session of the House of Representatives was ending was shattered by the bombshell of dissolution, announced at 11 o'clock this morning.
One place where feelings over the Supreme Court do not run as high as they would have done in former years is the rural grocery store.

In sentencing a clothing cutter to serve five years in Sing Sing for second-degree manslaughter in the strangling of his wife, General Sessions Judge Freschi expressed the belief yesterday that the slain woman had "provoked him to the point of desperation." Irving W.

Gross operating revenues of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1936, as shown by the annual report issued today, totaled $96,739,231, against $78,004,081 in 1935. Operating expenses rose to $50,848,453, compared with $42,969,402 in 1935. The balance of consolidated income for 1936 was $7,748,913, against $939,526 in 1935.
Rents in Harlem River Houses, the $4,219,000 PWA low-rental apartment project covering a sevenacre site between 151st and 153d Streets on the Harlem River, will average $7 a room monthly.

" Marouf, Cobbler of Cairo," an opera in four acts by Henri Rabaud, former conductor of the Paris Opera-Comique, will be revived by the Metropolitan Opera Company for its first performance here in about twenty years, it was announced yesterday by Lee Pattison, director of the Metropolitan's Spring season.

Eleven companies and their trade association, said to dominate the production and distribution of blueprint paper and other paper and cloth used by engineers and building contractors, were accused of unfair trade practices today by the Federal Trade Commission.

B. E. Hutchinson, financial director of the Chrysler Corporation, late today issued the following statement: "The strike at our plants having interrupted the building and shipping of automobiles, and the receiving of material,

What is described as the most efficient telephonic information system devised is to go into service in the information bureau of the Grand Central Station today. The installation required five months' work.

The costs of manufacturing steel have been increased at the rate of nearly $215,000,000 a year by the recent wage advances and soaring prices for many raw materials, according to estimates by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Rutgers University football team will open its season against Susquehanna Sept. 25, George E. Little, director of athletics, announced today. This is an addition to the eight-game schedule previously reported.

The cloud of uncertainty enveloping the personnel of the Princeton University varsity crew dropped lower today with an announcement by Coach Gordon Sikes that thirtyone varsity aspirants have been requested to remain here during the annual Spring vacation for daily morning and afternoon workouts on Lake Carnegie.

The State Supreme Court upheld today the authority of the New Jersey Municipal Finance Commission in directing the city of Asbury Park to include an item of $861,253.86 in its 1936 budget for debt service.

James T. Reid, veteran Crescent Athletic Club professional, and Leo T. Collins, Harmonie Club pro, disposed of two of the nation's leading amateurs in second-round matches of the world open squash tennis championship at the Hotel Shelton last night.

The Japanese military continues to demonstrate its dominant power in the government of the empire. Without warning, the Cabinet of General SENJURO HAYASHI--from which, at the demand of the army, politicians had been excluded--yesterday dissolved the Diet and ordered new elections, it is said, " to "promote an awakening in the political "parties."

Vice Chancellor John 0. Bigelow washed his hands today of the New Jersey Fair Trade Act after vainly trying to interpret the meaning of Section 1-B. The vice chancellor got lost in a maze of ambiguity in a paragraph only thirty-five words long.
Three men and a corporation accused of swindling 2,000 stockholders of defunct corporations by collecting 10 per cent of their original investment on the promise

The Committee for Industrial Organization and its steel industry drive have now officially invaded Quebec. The first local of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers of North America has been organized in Montreal with affiliation to the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada.

Governor Lehman signed the Berg bill today changing the unemployment insurance system of the State. The new act eliminates the former differentiation between manual and non-manual workers and makes all workers in establishments where four or more persons are employed eligible to benefits if they receive less than $3,000 a year.
The University of Notre Dame, South Bend, Ind., received more than $8,000 for a load of prime fed steers that equaled the highest price in seven years in today's livestock market.

Twenty-five physicians from leading medical centers in this country and abroad testified yesterday at the closing sessions of the First International Fever Conference, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, that they had found artificial fever to be a specific cure for gonorrhea in both men and women.
Fred Perry of England clinched his fivematch tennis series with William T. (Big Bill) Tilden, veteran American star, by winning his third victory tonight in straight sets, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Bristol, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. S. Bristol of West Cheshire, to William Hathaway Shay, son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Shay of Fairfield took place this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here.

Mrs. Marie Josephine Makaroff of Palm Beach and Barclay K. Douglas, New York aviation executive and stock broker, were married today. The marriage license application listed the bride as 30 years old and Mr. Douglas as 26.

Strikers in two stores of the F. W. Woolworth Company returned to work yesterday after representatives of the company and the Department Store Employes Union had signed a six-month contract covering the wages and working conditions of more than 4,000 employes in all the company's stores in this city.

Thirty-nine awards in basketball at Long Island University were announced yesterday by Clair F. Bee, director of athletics. Three squads that saw action during the past season, the varsity, junior varsity and freshmen, were honored. Ten men were listed for major insignia.

Jacob B. Shale, a newspaper and magazine broker who was formerly president of The Publishers Press Association of New York, now The United Press, and formerly publisher of The Editor and Publisher, died on Tuesday in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, of a cerebral hemorrhage.

Governor Hugh White said today that "illegal occupation" of Mississippi property by sit-down strikers "will not be tolerated." "If any writ is presented to me I am going to see that the law and dignity of the State of Mississippi are upheld," the Governor said after being informed of a sit-down strike for higher wages at a West Point (Miss.) pajama factory.

MANHATTAN DE MARTINI, CHARLOTTE (Jan. 2). Estate, $7,100. To Victor De Martini, 90-21 199th St., Hollis. L. I.; Kathryn De Martini, 90 W. Houston St., and Louis De Martini, petitioner,-90 W. Houston St., one-third residue each; two specific bequests.

Shareholders of the EitingonSchild Company, Inc., are to be asked at their annual meeting April 16 to approve the action of the company's wholly owned subsidiary, the Eitington-Schild Fur Corporation, in contracting for sale of the Moscow Fur Trading Company (London), Ltd.

Schools, by failing to develop to the full the "creativeness" of all their students, are responsible in large measure for "countless not fully evolved humans," Dr. John L. Tildsley, retiring Assistant Superintendent of Schools, told 1,800 art teachers and students yesterday.

More than 150 paintings, prints, photographs and examples of sculpture and crafts, the work of physicians and surgeons, were being arranged yesterday for exhibition at the New York Academy of Medicine, 103d Street and Fifth Avenue. The show will open with a private view next Saturday night.
Unless President Roosevelt's court plan is adopted the nation will drift inevitably into economic depression as it did in the years before 1933, Secretary Wallace asserted here today.
Mayor La Guardia has been chosen for the 1936 American Hebrew Medal for the promotion of better understanding between Christian and Jew in America, it was announced yesterday.

It occurred, by melancholy coincidence, that Karol Szymanowski, the foremost Polish composer of this time, died at his country house at Zakopane on March 29, two days before his work, Inspired by legends and folk-music of that place, was given its New York premiere last night in Carnegie Hall by Artur Rodzinsky and the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra.

Arrangements have been completed to hold the fifth annual metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium Friday, April 30, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics at New York University.
British, French and Netherland warships patrolled waters off Spain tonight under firm instructions to protect their merchant shipping against interference or seizure by Spanish Insurgent vessels.

Plans were announced here yesterday for a conference of ship lines operating from the Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific Coast ports of the United States to the Far East, at which efforts will be made to draft a national agreement for the stabilization of freight rates.

The Westchester County Recreation Commission announced today a Spring festival of about twentyfive recreation events, to be presented in the County Center here, beginning Friday and continuing through June 11.

By unanimous vote the Pennsylvania Federation of Labor decided today to maintain a "hands-off" policy in the controversy between the American Federation of Labor and the John L. Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization.
Salary increases for seventeen members of the staff of Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, were disclosed in the City Record yesterday after they had become effective on March 16.
The remaining classes of the twentieth annual Pinehurst Horse Show were completed today with an attendance of 2,000.

The annual report of the United Gas Improvement Company for 1936, which is to be mailed to stockholders today, shows combined earnings of $29,116,226 applicable to the capital stocks of the company, a decrease of $98,033 from 1935.

Receipts, 13,000. including 4,500 direct; uneven, good and choice hogs steady to 10 cents lower; weights under 200 pounds, medium grade offerings all weights 10-25 cents lower than Tuesday's average; top $10.35; good and choice, 200 pounds up, $10 to $10.30; 150-190 pounds $9.50 to $10.15; packing sows steady $9.50 to $9.75. Shippers took 500 Estimated holdover, 5,000 head.

The financial statement for 1936 of the Shell Union Oil Corporation, released for publication today, shows consolidated net income of $22,494,364, including a net profit of $2,839,503 on the sale of its investment in the Flintkote Company, after all charges and taxes.

George M. Cohan Jr., 23 years old, son of the actor, of 993 Fifth Avenue, was exonerated yesterday by Magistrate Brough in the Intoxication Court of being intoxicated on the night of March 8 when the car he was driving at Madison Avenue and Sixty-second Street collided with another.
The new Roosevelt Raceway, redesigned since last Fall, will be the scene of the George Vanderbilt Cup motor race on July 5, it was announced yesterday. The prize money for the event will be $60,000.

Colonel Harriot Van Devanter Moore, acting brigadier general in command of the 155th Infantry brigade, Seventy-eighth Division, organized Reserve of U. S. A., and a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died in the Englewood Hospital today after an appendicitis operation. He was 58 years old.
The Warners stopped production of Marion Davies's "Ever Since Eve" today because of the illness of Robert Montgomery, the leading man.
Bishop Nathaniel Seymour Thomas of Bethesda-by-theSea Episcopal Church, died here at midnight. His age was 60. Ill for eleven days, he had been unconscious since last Thursday.

Walter Nelles, Associate Professor of Law in the Yale Law School, died today in the New Haven Hospital, after a short illness. He was 53 years old. Dean Charles E. Clark of the school said of him tonight: "We mourn the loss of a popular teacher and a deep student of American legal history."
Vioence broke out tonight in the war between factions of Seattle's Newsboys Union, sending five men to hospitals.

Rounding out Canada's plan to keep out of war entanglements that do not concern her, and supplementing the legislation of last week creating a complete check upon recruiting here for another nation, a measure was introduced in Parliament today by J. L. Ilsley, Minister of National Revenue.

The Rev. Dr. Edward P. Tivnan, S. J., former president of Fordham University and Superior of the Bellarmine Retreat House at Cohasset, Mass., died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack in the Cenacle of St. Regis, Riverside Drive and 140th Street. He was 54 years old. He served as head of Fordham from 1919 to 1924.

Apparently the oft-deferred "Driftwood," which most recently was mentioned to open this evening, has been called off altogether. No one could be reached for information yesterday at the Longacre Theatre, where it was scheduled to open, and the management was not available either.
Another severe break in values of United States Government bonds held the center of interest in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, as well as in overthe-counter dealings.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens gave notice yesterday that sit-down strikes would not be tolerated in that borough. In token of the sincerity of his warning Mr. Harvey appeared before a city magistrate and swore out a warrant for the -arrest of thirty-five WPA draftsmen employed on a Parks Department project who were entrenched on the top floor of his own building, the Queens Borough Hall.

Hearn Department Stores, Inc., and its subsidiary reported yesterday for the year ended on Jan. 31 a net profit of $571,293 after depreciation of fixtures and equipment, amortization of leasehold improvements and Federal income taxes.

Joseph Gedeon, the eccentric middle-aged man whose wife and daughter were strangled last Saturday night by a murderer who also fatally stabbed Frank Byrnes, a roomer in their apartment at 316 East Fiftieth Street, will be arrested on a formal charge some time before morning, the police announced last night.

Dr. George Walker, wartime surgeon and chief urologist of the American Army after the armistice, died today in Union Memorial Hospital, where he had been a patient for eighteen months. He was 68 years old.

The "first sacker's glove" and the baseball "backstop's mask" are the only present needs of the Beach Street Arrows, baseball team of youngsters who live among the factories and warehouses of the waterfront district of the lower West Side.

Miss Lois E. Wall of 152 East Fifty-third Street, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Jocelyn Wall of Davison, Mich., was married to Francis P. Heffernan, Staten Island attorney and former member of the New York State Assembly, yesterday morning in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, this city.

The National Dairy Products Corporation, through Goldman, Sachs Co., fiscal agents, has notified holders of 3 3/4 per cent debentures due in 1951 that it will redeem on May 1, at 100 1/2 and accrued interest, $955,500 face amount of the debentures, which have been drawn by lot.

The Museum of Modern Art will present as its major exhibition of the 1936-1937 season, a selection of 150 facsimilies of prehistoric rock pictures from the famous Frobenius collection of Frankfort-on-Main. It will be current from April 28 to May 30.
Robert Riggs of Los Angeles, the nation's fourth ranking player, defeated Malon Courts of Atlanta, 7-5, 6-4, in a delayed second-round match today in the Atlanta Invitational Tennis tournament.

All of the estate of Noyes D. Clark of this city and Bethany, except specific bequests of $64,000, has been bequeathed to the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University to set up a Dwight Noyes Clark and Noyes Dwight Clark scholarship fund, in memory of the donor and his father.
Lord Anthony Ashley-Cooper Ashley married Miss Francoise Soulier, daughter of a Neuilly manufacturer, in a civil ceremony at the Neuilly Mairie today. Only immediate members of the families attended.

The Transit Commission, according to reports current in financial circles yesterday, will hand down within the next week or ten days a report which will make almost certain the collapse of the $436,000,000 transit unification plan prepared by Samuel Seabury, and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr.
Senator Robert F. Wagner, of New York, speaking in the Senate today, declared that sit-down strikes had been "provoked by the long-standing ruthless tactics of a few great corporations."
Through tickets for trips around the world by air, completed in a little less than a month, were announced yesterday by Harold Crary, vice president of United Air Lines.

Insurgents, in precipitate retreat on the Cordoba front, abandoned late today the important railroad town of El Soldado. A troop train left standing in the station with steam up bore witness to the haste of the flight, which started yesterday with the Government capture of Alcaracejos.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Viking Gold Mines Corporation and six individual defendants, Carney Hartley, Sam J. Perrium, Emil L. Krushnic, J. L. Williamson, Fred Dorman and F. M. Day had consented to a decree before Judge J.

The La Follette administration's State power bill, modeled after the TVA, was introduced in both houses of the Legislature today simultaneously with the filing of incorporation papers for the Wisconsin Development Authority.

The engagement of Miss Victoria Corse Thorne to Bruce Matthews of Toronto, Canada, has been announced by her father, Dr. Victor C. Thorne of 322 East Fifty-seventh Street and Thornebrook, Greenwich, Conn.

Jesse L. Livermore, who has had a spectacular career in Wall Street, was revealed yesterday to be following a "come-back" trend through payment of more than $800,000 in back taxes to the Federal and State Governments.
A tornado swept a small area of Harbour Island, twenty minutes by plane from Nassau, at 2 A. M. today, killing a woman and injuring two others. Nine houses were destroyed.
The Curb Exchange Tickers defeated the Stock Exchange Brokers, 5-2, in the second game of the play-off series for the Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League title at Playland tonight.

The marriage of Miss Mary Bischoff, younger daughter of Mrs. Charles Bischoff of London and the late Mr. Bischoff, to Carroll L. Wilson, son of Mrs. Edna C. Wilson of Carmel, Calif., and of Louis W. Wilson of Rochester, N. Y., will take place today in Chelsea Old Church, London. The Rev. R. E.
The report yesterday that interest payments would be made on Bush Terminal Company 5 per cent consolidated mortgage bonds due in 1955 was in error.

Workers in the Federal Works Progress Administration are being called on again to contribute to a Democratic political fund. Hundreds of letters, it is said, are arriving at the homes of the relief workers, who are being told in effect that they are benefiting from the administration and should help pay the party's bills.

Miss Ella M. Sauer, head librarian at the Washington Heights Branch of the New York Public Library, died Tuesday of a heart attack in her apartment at the American Women's Association Clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. Her age was 72.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. O. Delnoce of Mount Vernon, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Rosina Delnoce, to Edgar Grey Persons, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Otis Persons of Scarsdale.

" The Second Hurricane," playopera specially composed by Aaron Copland to be performed by children and adolescents, will receive its world premiere on April 21 at The Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, under the auspices of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, it was announced yesterday.

A man accused of counterfeiting nickels was arrested here this afternoon and lodged in the Woodbridge Township jail for arraignment in Newark tomorrow. He is Joseph Hopta, 34 years old, of 869 Rayway Avenue.

Retiring after forty-six years of service in the New York Edison Company and its predecessor and affiliated companies, Joseph F. Becker, vice president in charge of sales, was guest of honor at a testimonial luncheon given at the Hotel Astor yesterday by the Electrical Association of New York. About 700 fellow-workers were present.

Calling attention to the twentieth anniversary next Tuesday of the entrance of the United States into the World War, Dr. James T. Shotwell expressed yesterday a need for cooperation among nations to guard against impending war.

President Roosevelt is "quite right" in his efforts to curb the powers of the Supreme Court, whose check upon social legislation and general attitude toward the authority of Congress to legislate have created an "intolerable situation," Herbert Morrison, Labor member of Parliament and chairman of the London County Council, said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Another bank building in midtown Fifth Avenue passed to new control yesterday when the Guaranty Trust Company bought the eleven-story structure at 522 Fifth Avenue which comprises part of the larger structure known as the Guaranty Trust Company Building at the southwest corner of Fortyfourth Street.

148th St., 429-431 E., two 4-story tenements; Central Savings Bank against Artsey Realty Corp.; due $32,172; taxes, , $165; to plaintiff for $2,000. Eastern Blvd., w s. 100 ft s of Buhre Av., 1OOx1OO; Jane A. Stokes against Glanmil Holding Corp.; due, $16,107; taxes, , $1,315; to plaintiff for $5,000.

Engagement of $13,202,000 gold abroad for shipment here was yesterday reported to the Federal Reserve Bank. Of the amount, $4,480,000 was engaged in Japan and $8,722,000 in England. The gold obtained in England, it was thought in banking circles, probably included some of the [Pound]38,000,000 of Russian gold reported as being shipped to London for re-export to this country.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt poked fun today at her own lecture efforts. In 'a talk to 150 Congressional wives who came to Washington with her in 1932, she related:

William H. Allen, Ernest Lyle Elsberry, Joseph G. Mahar, Charles H. Smith, William R. Heron; also Mrs. Clarence E. Clark, A line Goree, Mildred M. Stice and Billie Burke, Mrs. Cassandra T. Sinclair, London Terrace leases by Win. A. White Sons, broker.
Mrs. Susan M. Hoffman Watson, widow of the Rev. J. Henry Watson, died yesterday at her residence, the Belnord Apartments, Eighty-sixth Street and Broadway, of pneumonia at the age of 83.
Miss Gertrude Barrett, secretary to George A. Ball, said today it could be "authoritatively stated" that Mr. Ball "is not seeking a purchaser" for his equity in the Van Sweringen rail empire.
Romeyn Berry, secretary, today announced a forty-two-game Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League schedule for the 1937 season. Double-headers are slated for Hanover, Ithaca, New York and Princeton.

The City Fusion party, at a meeting last night at the Hotel Astor, unanimously adopted a resolution calling upon Mayor La Guardia to run for re-election, endorsing the record of his administration, and pledging itself to work against the return to power of Tammany Hall.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine clashed yesterday with Controller Frank J. Taylor over the latter's report to the Board of Estimate that 140 manufacturing concerns had left the city because of racketeering in business and labor.

Stocks eased and closed irregular in heavier trading; turnover, 1,662,770 shares. United States Government bonds weakened nearly a point to new low levels; other bonds irregular; transactions, $14,158,100.

Announcement was made today by Major William Valerie Andrews, commandant at Chapman Field, Miami, and Mrs. Andrews of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ashlyn Lowe Cannon, to Eben Draper, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. H. Bristow Draper of Hopedale, Mass.

The new Minister of Finance, Francisco Garces Gana, declared yesterday that the public must not be led to believe because of recent articles that the national budget was in such good condition as to allow any unnecessary expenditures.

The letter of Chief Justice Hughes to Senator Wheeler defending the Supreme Court against charges of inefficiency, was attacked by Senator Minton in the Senate today as made up of "facts, fiction and dictum."

Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. of the State Department of Labor said today that he planned vigorous enforcement of New Jersey's Minimum Wage Law in view of the e Supreme Court decision upholding the validity of the Washington State act.
Mrs. J. V. Dillon of Ardsley, seeded third, upset Mrs. K. F. Evans, top-ranking entrant, in the final today to capture the first women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Apawamis Club.

Charlton B. Hibbard has been elected a vice president of Swart, Brent Co., Inc. William W. Spring Co. announced that Walter Podolak is a general partner. William H. Griffith, who recently organized the Blue List Publishing Company, has rejoined Lord, Abbett Co., Inc., as vice president.
Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed. an increase of 20 per cent for the week ended March 27, against the corresponding week a year ago.

The price of milk in stores and delivered to homes was reduced 1 cent a quart generally throughout the metropolitan area, effective today, it was announced yesterday. On the lower East Side, in parts of the Bronx and Queens, and in the Williamsburg and East New York sections of Brooklyn, stores are expected to slash the price as much as 3 cents a quart.

Five hundred attended the dinner dance tonight at the Everglades Club, which marked the close of social activities there for this season. Mr. and Mrs. Messmore Kendall gave a dinner there for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert White of Paris.

Mr. and Mrs. James Lakeman Ward of the Sherry-Netherland will sail on Saturday on the Conte di Savoia for a tour of Italy and the Continent before going to London for the coronation. They expect to return here early in June.

Net operating income of 139 Class I railroads in the first two months of the year was $76,795,318, against $69,290,873 in the same period last year, a gain of 10.8 per cent, according to reports issued yesterday by the Association of. American Railroads.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: In the Southwestern great plains, Winter wheat was further damaged by soil drifting and dust storms, but in other portions of the Western belt additional moisture was decidedly favorable, though quite generally wheat made little or no growth because of low temperatures.

George F. Steele, who was general manager of the Canadian Export Paper Company of Montreal from 1917 to 1922 and a prominent figure in the newsprint industry in this country and Canada for the last thirty years, died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 1,155 Park Avenue, after a long illness at the age of 78.
The methods of combating the regular ticket in the forthcoming Actors Equity Association election drew fire yesterday from Equity officials.
Revival of an inter-city tennis feud of long standing loomed yesterday as members of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's executive committee looked forward to Saturday's meeting here.

This village has refused a new $97,000 postoffice on the ground that it is "short and squatty." An architectural duplicate of the Radcliffe Memorial Library at Oxford has been declined without even a "thank you."

Samuel Untermyer, New York lawyer and president of the AntiNazi Non-Sectarian League, returned yesterday on the Panama Pacific liner Virginia after spending three months at his home in Palm Springs, Calif.

New high prices for the season were established on May wheat and on May and July corn on the Board of Trade here today, but the upturn resulted in a marked weakening in the technical position and a sharp reaction from the best prices followed.
Following the rise on Tuesday to the highest levels for the last seven years, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were somewhat uncertain and ended with losses of 1 to 16 points.

Three persons were arrested in Pittsburgh yesterday in connection with the sale of one of the two revolvers used in the murder of Norman Redwood, leader of a sandhogs' union, who was shot and killed outside his home at Teaneck, N. J., on Feb. 19. Announcement of the arrests was made by William B. Mehler, Assistant Prosecutor of Bergen County.

Forty-eight candidates answered Glenn S. (Pop) Warner's Spring football call at Temple University today and indulged in a two-hour workout. Vincent Renzo of Long Branch, star halfback in 1935, who was out of college last Fall, was among the sixteen ball carriers who reported to Backfield Coach Chuck Winterburn.

Extensive deposits of olivine lying in the State of Washington may be utilized in the manufacture of fire brick and other refractory material as the result of experimental work conducted at the Northwest Experiment Station of the United States Bureau of Mines, in cooperation with the College of Mines, University of Washington.

Charged with the fatal shootlig last Deo. 13 of Mollie Starace, 28 years old, in her home at 20 Bay Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, John Cacopardo, alias John King, 28, of 1,822 Passyunk Avenue, Philadelphia, was arrested yesterday morning on the farm of Giuseppe Mastrella at Marlboro, N. Y., by detectives of the Bath Beach precinct in Brooklyn and State troopers.

Ricardo Castro Beeche, Minister from Costa Rica to the United States; Captain J. W. L. Crawshay, attache at the British Embassy in Paris, and Mrs. Crawshay, are among the passengers due to sail today on the French liner Ile de France.
Dartmouth's powerful track team experienced little trouble today in disposing of the University of North Carolina team, winning, 88 to 38, on Fetzer Field.

On the eve of golf's nearest approach to a world series, a field of fortysix, including thirty-eight ranking professionals, seven amateurs and business-man competitor Robert T. Jones Jr., prepared for the 72-hole test in the fourth Augusta national tournament. Cash prizes of $5,000 will go to the winning pros.

Although the volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March was slightly larger than in the previous month, the trading pace was slower because there were more business days than in February.
Dartmouth staged a big first inning to defeat the Hampden-Sydney nine, 24 to 3, today. Led by McLaughlin and Casey, the Indians scored ten runs in the opening stanza.

The moderate rise in short-term money rates in the last few months probably reflects, more accurately than does the rise of bond yields, the extent of the change in the money market situation, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in a discussion of the fall of government securities appearing in its April monthly review.

The German boxer, Lustig von Dom of Tulgey Wood, owned by the Tulgey Wood Kennels of Chicago and handied by Jimmie Sullivan, won the special for the best in show at the close of the seventh annual dog show of the Tri-City Kennel Club, Inc., tonight at the Moline Field House.

Francis Currie, since last June in general charge of regional offices of the Seourities and Exchange Commission, left that organization today to become associated with John J. Burns, former general counsel of the SEC. Mr. Burns resigned on Jan. 15 to enter private practice with offices in Boston and in New York at 30 Rockefeller Center.

Contrary to general opinion, war is more imminent in the Far East than in Europe, W. T. Wu, editor of the Association Press of China, declared tonight before the Human Relations Institute at the University of North Carolina.

Electric power production declined last week when seasonal and long-term trends pointed to an increase, and the adjusted index receded to 106.9 from 108.5. It was 96.1 for the week ended March 28, 1936.

Pensioned On Police Surgeon's Certificate: PATROLMEN-William J. Langdon Jr., slat Precinct, at $2,250 per annum. Appointed June 30, 1921. Peter J. Connolly, 19th Division, Raided Premises Squad, at $2,250 per annum. Appointed Aug. 4, 1916.

Lindsley Tappin of Wilton, Conn., who retired from the New York Stock Exchange in 1932, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital in his sixty-first year. Toward the close of his twenty-four years on the Exchange he was a member of Tappin, Rose Cammann.

Funeral services were held yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Genoa, Linden Boulevard and Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, for Mgr. John M. Hilpert, pastor of the church, who was suffocated in a fire at the church rectory, 520 Linden Boulevard, early last Sunday morning.

A queer-looking old macaroni box, containing a device made up of rubber bands, meat skewers, staples and wheels, was presented today to Dr. Charles G. Abbott, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, where it will repose.
Price advances of 3 and 4 cents per pound on "Acele" acetate yarns, effective today, were announced yesterday by the acetate division of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co.. Inc.

Appointments The following ununiformed firemen, having completed their probationary period of three months satisfactorily, are appointed as firemen, Fourth Grade, with compensation each at the rate of $2,000 per annum:
