Commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of Robert Ross McBurney, first general secretary of the New York City Y. M. C. A., more than 250 members of the Old Timers Club of the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C. A., 215 West Twenty-third Street, met there last night at a dinner.

Mrs. Mary G. Roebling, president of the Trenton Trust Company and a member of the State Unemployment Compensation Commission, was appointed by Governor Hoffman today to the Commission on Interstate Coopertion.
Congress was urged today by Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association, to "proceed slowly" in its legislation for further regulation of the airlines of the country.

Dial Lodge, Princeton upper-class eating club, has completed the mortgage payments on its club property at Princeton, made over a twenty-five-year period, according to T. H. McCauley, chairman of the board.

Jacob F. Loeb, a founder of and a special partner in the firm of Newburger, Loeb Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, died on Tuesday night in his home at 101 West Fifty-seventh Street after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

The largest importation of gold in the last five months was reported received here in March by the Federal Reserve Bank. Great Britain, the leading country shipping gold here this year, sent $75,841,100 of the $92,231,400 received at New York.

Two employes of the United States Customs Service, each of whom had rounded out nearly half a century of service with the government, retired yesterday. John Williams, 70 years old, of 73 South Arlington Avenue, East Orange, N. J., retired as an appraisal expert attached to the office of the United States Attorney.

The University of Vermont, scoring single runs in each of the last three innings, overcame a two-run lead of the Naval Academy today and won the opening game of season for the Middies, 5 to 4. The game was highly exciting and with only a moderate amount of the expected early season looseness.

Freight carloadings in the three months ending on June 30 will run about 7.5 per cent ahead of the total for the same period last year, according to estimates yesterday by the thirteen shippers' regional advisory boards. Estimates by districts are shown in the following table:
The formal presentation by the New York Drama Critics Circle of its plaque for the best American play of the year will take place this evening at the Hotel Algonquin.

Two Winter- campaigned horses, one from Florida and the other from California, are supposed to have at their mercy the $5,000 added Rowe Memorial Handicap that will feature the opening of the Eastern racing season here tomorrow.

A sensational upset victory for Miss Virginia Guilfoil, 19-year-old Syracuse University player, over Miss Kathryn Hemphill, the defeat of Miss Deborah Verry, defending champion, by Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., and the advance of two experienced players over less-favored opponents told the story of today's second-round play in the annual North and South golf tourney for women.
Miss Edith MacDonald, aunt of Premier Stanley Baldwin, died yesterday at Stourport, Worcestershire. Her age was 88.

John Wuest Hunt of Cleveland, an active worker in the religious movement founded by Father Divine, the Harlem evangelist, was sought yesterday by Federal authorities in connection with charges made against him by a 17-year-old girl, who also was a member of the sect. Both are white persons.

A warning that government ownership and operation of the nation's railroads is inevitable if legislation supported by the railway labor unions before the present Congress is enacted into law was issued yesterday in a statement by Frederick F. Bohman to shippers holding membership in the National Industrial Traffic League.
New York City's vast public education system, as depicted in the annual report of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, superintendent, still ineludes a typically rural one-room school.
Chicago's Joe Platak led a parade of favorites today into the National A. A. U. handball semi-final round.
Compositions of Bernard Rogers, faculty member of the Eastman School of Music, were heard in last night's meeting of the Composers' Forum-Laboratory at the WPA Theatre of Music.

Refunding operations declined in March, when the volume of bonds called for redemption before maturity was the smallest for any month since November. An outstanding exception to the almost general curtailment in prepayments was in the foreign group, where the total was the largest since September 1934.
Many younger members of society at home from schools and colleges for the Easter recess attended the Spring Dolphin Dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre.
In the oddest game of the grapefruit league season the Reds came to bat in the seventh inning trailing, 10 to ??, and rallied to defeat the Bees, 11 to 10, today.
The first quarter statements of condition of local banks and trust companies to be issued over the next few days may be expected to show a rather general decline in assets and deposits.

The Legislature completed action today on the bill repealinng the Teachers' Oath Law, and it is indicated that the Governor will sign it tomorrow. A last effort was made in the house to halt the measure but it was defeated by a roll call vote of 112 to 104.

A hustling nine wearing the lavender of City College of New York invaded University Field today and for the second time in two days the Princeton baseball team bowed in defeat to a superior metropolitan nine. Before 300 spectators the visitors rang up a 13-2 victory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The sit-down strike as a pressure technique of labor is illegal in the present state of the law. It is a trespass upon the employer's property. The decisions of Judges Gadola and Campbell in the General Motors and Chrysler cases were clearly right, as was that of Justice Miller in this State.
A business meeting of the recently reorganized Mineola Driving Club will be held Saturday evening at the Garden City Hotel, it was announced yesterday by John Parkinson Jr., secretary.

Preparations for holding a table tennis tournament among the leading houses of the financial district have reached the stage of choosing an arena for the proposed matches. It was understood yesterday that J. P. Morgan Co. have agreed to allow use of their counting room for the after-hours affair.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. has awarded a contract to the Bertwell Construction Co. for the rehabilitation of the "old-law', tenement at 336 East 110th St. from plans by F. P. Platt Bro., architects.

After having covered about 3,000 miles on horseback in four and a half months, during which she collected 125,000 marks for the National Socialist Winter Relief fund, Mrs. Friedel Schumann was officially welcomed at the City Hall here today.
The Ford Motor Company has awarded to the National Rubber Machinery Company a contract for tire-manufacturing machinery, The Beacon Journal said today.
General LUDENDORFF all this time has apparently counted for a good deal more in Germany than was generally believed.
Seymour M. Heilbron, Pennsylvania Securities Commissioner, has announced his resignation to enter the private practice of law with Wise, Shepard, Houghton Hoffman in New York.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Chalmers, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Clark Chalmers of 63 East End Avenue and the late Dr. Chalmers, to Thomas Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Lane of Hartford, Conn., took place yesterday noon at the Brevoort.

MANHATAN ALLEN, FREDERICK (Jan. 26, 1935). Gross assets, $103,964; net, $54,447. To Berthalin Osgood Alien, widow, books, furniture and one-third residue; Estelle Holland, niece, one-third residue; Blanche Warren, niece, $5,000 if residue is sufficient;

Mrs. Philip Lee-Warner of 41, Ovington Square, London, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Diana Vassall Lee-Warner, to Tobias Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wood Wagner of Chestnut Hill.

Places on an arbitration panel for the amicable adjudication of disputes on returned goods between manufacturers and retailers have been accepted by twenty-one retailers and buying office representatives in the New York market, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing directr of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Many units of commercial space on Madison Avenue, Fifth Avenue and in the midtown retail district were involved in the leasing activity reported by brokers yesterday. The list follows:

A 15-year-old high school girl was faced today with the alternatives of forsaking her parents or foregoing a modest fortune. "I haven't decided what I'm going to do," declared Vera Jean Howard, for whom the will of a great uncle established a $60,000 trust fund on condition that she does not live with her relatives.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York'City: General Conditions Trading continued at a very slow pace. Steer hinds and ribs held steady, but all other classes were weak to lower. Due to the Jewish holidays, there was practically no cattle slaughter and the calf and lamb kill was very light.
These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Paragraph 11, Special Orders 68, March 24, 1937, granting Ensign Josef Replogle, U.S.N.R., leave of absence for eleven days is revoked.

The Board of Education at a special meeting surrendered to the city yesterday forty-eight acres and the buildings of the New York Parental School in Flushing, clearing the way for the establishment of the Queens College which is expected to open in September.
The threeyear romance of the Queen's niece, the Hon. Cecilia Bowes-Lyon, ended tonight when she announced the termination of her engagement to Kenneth Harington, son of Judge Edward Harington.

The National Socialist press was jubilant today over the reconciliation between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and General Erich Ludendorff. The West German Beobachter summarizes the general view of the National Socialist camp in the following words:

From the mail bag: Art Flick, Westkill, N. Y.--"Being almost constantly out with hunters and fishermen, I was much amused by the comments on game protectors by one of your readers, particularly with reference to 'their relentless enforcement against nonresident sportsmen.'

The Polish Government will resume this week-end the negotiations with the Danzig Senate that were interrupted two months ago by the session of the League of Nations Council. This time, however the Poles will not act on the League's behalf to settle disputes between Geneva and the Free City of Danzig, but will try to defend their own interests and the rights of their nationals in the now virtually totalitarian area.

Firmer rates prevailed in the money market in March. Bankers' bill rates were advanced twice, making the fourth change since the beginning of the year. Commercial paper quotations were raised for the first time since May 24, 1934.

Fear of a world wheat shortage rapidly is pushing up the price of bread in Britain. London flour millers announced yesterday the sixth successive increase in the standard grade of flour in twenty-two days.

Awards for the six best radio programs of the year, as selected by the vote of more than 10,000,000 women affiliated with the Women's National Radio Committee, were presented at the organization's third annual luncheon at the Hotel St. Regis yesterday.
The State Assembly today adopted a resolution asking Governor Merriam to pardon Tom Mooney. The vote was 42 to 27. Concurrence by the Senate is necessary to give force to the resolution.

The New York Curb Exchange has filed application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for unlisted trading privileges in six more bond issues, five of which are now traded only over the counter and one registered on the San Francisco Stock Exchange.

Referring to the theatre of today as "a disease rather than an honorable profession," Paul Scott, 75year-old veteran of the theatre, who looks back upon more than fifty-four years as an actor, director, producer, promotion manager and stock casting agent, still predicts a rebirth of "the road" under the aegis of the Federal Theatre Project.

Gerald D. Reilly, acting solicitor of the Labor Department, said tonight that representatives of eight States would meet here tomorrow to discuss whether their minimum wage laws should be rewritten and reenacted. The States are New York, New Jersey, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Illinois, Connecticut and Ohio.
Bill Dickey's two-base drive into the overflow crowd in left field at Waterfront Park today gave the Yankees their second victory over the Cardinals this year in the Citrus Belt.

Peter Fick, New York A. C. star, who is national indoor and outdoor free-style sprint champion, bettered one of Johnny Weissmuller's noteworthy performance standards in a special race against time that was one of the features of last night's aquatic meet at the New York A. C.
Action to help producers overcome the shortage in materials employed in smelting high grade steels was taken last night by the government, which removed the [Pound]3 a ton duty on "common steel."

Legislation abolishing the Public Service Commission, controlled by Republicans, and setting up a substitute body to be known as the Public Utility Commission was passed by the House today and signed by Governor Earle.

After deliberating nine hours a jury in the Bronx County Court returned at 10:55 o'clock last night with a verdict of guilty of second degree manslaughter against six men as a result of the collapse last June 19 of a seven-story apartment house under construction at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, in which eighteen men were killed.

Henry Voorhis, treasurer of the New York real estate firm of Dwight, Voorhis Perry, Inc., 137 West Twenty-third Street, and chairman of the insurance committee of the management division, Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., died today of pneumonia at the Hackensack Hospital. Mr. Voorhis, who lived at River Edge, N. J., was 56 years old.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee will report favorably tomorrow on the New York World's Fair Appropriation Bill, which was amended in the committee. today in a manner to permit Congress to retain control of the $5,000,000 authorized to be appropriated for Federal participation in the exposition.

A man who used several names, accused of forging many checks, was saved from suicide early yesterday on the steamship Virginia and later was held in $5,000 bail for the Federal grand jury on a charge of fraudulently obtaining a United States passport from Panama.
We said last year when the illustrated report of the Board of Education appeared that a "perilous precedent" had been set, for it seemed that it would be impossible to live up to it.

A residential plot 87 by 160 feet on Murchison Place, Gedney Farms, adjoining the Gedney Farms golf course, has been sold by H. W. Munford to James Cooke, who will erect a Colonial residence there. Chauncey B. Griffen was the broker.

The strong Power Memorial Academy quintet, best in the school's history, added the metropolitan Catholic high schools championship to its imposing record this season by conquering St. Francis Prep, 27-26, last night at the Columbus Council Knights of Columbus.

Checking account plans of the "pay-as-you-go" type, requiring only a small balance, or no balance at all, are criticized in a study just published by the bank management commission of the American Bankers Association.

Francisco Flores, a Catholic priest, must spend more than a year in prison as a result of a Supreme Court decision today upholding his sentence "for having distributed written propaganda against Socialist education, which contained attacks against the government."

President Roosevelt talked with Mayor La Guardia on relief problems, Senator Norris on the court reorganization proposal, Representative Doughton on legislative matters and Sidney Hillman on the labor situation. With Mrs...
Colonel Bill Terry honed his Spring pruning axe to a razor edge today and with a few deft strokes raised such havoc among his Giants as to leave both players and experts practically agog.

Three more upsets were added to the list in the world pocket billiard tournament at the Ponzi Academy yesterday as James Caras, the defending champion, and Ralph Greenleaf and Erwin Rudolph, former titleholders, went down to defeat.

Mrs. Robert Todd Lincoln, widow of President Lincoln's son, died today at her home in the Georgetown section, where she had long lived with her husband prior to his death on July 25, 1926. She was 90 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Adrian A. Buck of Mount Vernon, N. Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Laura Frances Buck, to Charles D. Herb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Herb, also of Mount Vernon.

The Duke of Windsor today gave an indication of his future plans for the first time when he intimated that he would leave for France at the end of April. This intimation was contained in an answer to a press photographer's request for permission to photograph him.

President Roosevelt sustained his first major defeat of the present session of Congress today when seven Democrats joined with six Republican members of the House Agriculture Committee and struck from the Farm Tenancy Bill, by 13 to 11, a section providing $50,000,000 a year to finance farmers seeking to own farms they now operate for others.

Workers on the evening and night shifts at the Fisher Body plant here began a sit-down strike tonight. Police were guarding the gates. Men on the evening shift remained in the factory, a General Motors plant, when the midnight shift reported for duty and all sat down.

The four representatives of the Yacht Racing Association of Great Britain who came here to consult the New York Yacht Club on proposed changes in the rules governing the Class L sloops sailed for England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, with the prospect of more than their desires being fulfilled.

Schimmer, Kerner Feder have sold for Joseph M. May, Inc., the one-story taxpayer at2,215-23 Delamere Place, Brooklyn, to an investor. The building, which occupies a plot 100 by 30 feet, contains seven stores and is said to be completely rented.

Thirty candidates reported to Coach Lou Oshins as the Brooklyn College track team opened practice at the Wingate Field yesterday. Among the veteran Kingsmen on hand were Captain Vincent Motto, Ben Lander, Igor Storojeff, Metropolitan Class B champions;

Reports that have reached the French Government from both sides in Spain, that volunteers of all nationalities are thoroughly tired of the war and anxious to be repatriated, may lead to a new formal proposal by France before the non-intervention committee that steps be taken immediately to begin repatriation.

Norman H. Davis, President Roosevelt's principal "free lance diplomat," arrived today to make another periodic survey of the European situation and to attend, as chairman of the United States delegation, the World Sugar Conference.

Long Island University's baseball team loosed a barrage of base hits today and overwhelmed the Roanoke College nine by 21 to 10. The Blackbirds took the lead in the first with two runs, but Roanoke counted three in its half.
Amy Johnson, English aviator, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen with Miss Gloria Bristol of 480 Park Avenue. The flier plans a month's visit here.

The Ministry of Agriculture's second crop estimate forecasts a wheat production of 247,838,280 bushels. Flaxseed production is estimated at 72,827,000 bushels. Both crops are estimated at slightly lower figures than the first forecast in December, the wheat forecast being 2,000,000 bushels less and flaxseer 1.200.000 bushels less.

Walton Av. (11-2845), w s 120 ft n of 172d St., 80x100; Lena Flegler to Flegler Realty Corp., 142 Morton Pl.; mtg.. $90,000. Tlbbett Av. (13-3415-J), e s, 123 ft s of 252d St., 61x75; Agnea Desteian to Nishan H. Shimsllrian, 3,058 Godwin Terrace.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today a total of $2,812,000 of primary road refunding bonds of eight separate counties in the State of Iowa. Seven of the issues bear 2 1/2 per cent coupon rates and one a 2 1/4 per cent rate.
The city of Jersey City, N. J., will call today $1,000,000 of second class railroad tax notes due on Dec. 9, 1937, originally issued against 1935 second class railroad taxes.

Great Britain's budget year 1936-1937 ended tonight with a real surplus of [Pound]7,530,000. This was after a total of [Pound]186,072,000 had been spent on defense, which was [Pound]7,821,000 more than the last budget of Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain provided for and more than [Pound]49,000,000 more than was spent in the budget year 1935-1936.

A stoppage of 400,000 soft coal miners in twelve States tomorrow appeared dangerously near last night when operators of the Appalachian coal conference rejected a tentative agreement reached by a subcommittee of the owners and the United Mine Workers after another day of negotiation which had given hope that peace would continue.
Deals in which banks and institutions figured as sellers indicated a good demand for tenement houses in Harlem yesterday. Many of the houses were bought by investors.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized listing of 600,000 shares of United Electric Coal Companies common stock, $5 par value. Reliance Manufacturing Company common stock, $10 par value, has been admitted to the list.

A restaurant owner who had made false and evasive answers before the grand jury in the investigation of the restaurant racket pleaded guilty of contempt yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and was fined $100. Justice McCook suspended a 30-day sentence because the owner had since recanted.
Weakness in prices of seasoned bond issues, coupled with heavy selling of "governments" and the appearance of firmer money rates, had an adverse effect on new financing in March.

Attorneys planned an insanity. defense tonight for Tommy Smith, 18-yearold newsboy accused of stabbing to death Mary Ellen Babcock. The cool, sometimes gay youth pleaded innocent today when arraigned on a first-degree murder charge in connection with the slaying seven weeks. ago of the 18-yearold South Buffalo girl.

On the floor of the Senate yesterday Mr. WAGNER took the automobile industry to task for a policy of greed and repression which he described as fundamentally responsible for the present wave of sit-down strikes.
Mr. and Mrs. James Lee Kauffman of 911 Park Avenue, formerly of Tokyo, Japan, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Anne Kauffman, to William Charles Blind of this city.

Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, announced today the resignation of Professor Kenneth E. Olson, head of the Department of Journalism. Professor Olson will become director of the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University next September.

Adelphi and Augusta Military Academy battled to a 7-7 tie today, darkness halting the game in the tenth inning. Ken Pine, Adelphi pitcher, hurled beautifully in the pinches and he received good support.
The Nazi government is preparing to give to the German people a new conception of property rights, differing radically from the ideas of orthodox capitalism a high official disclosed tonight.

The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania announced today that Theodore N. Vail honor medals had been awarded to its employes in eleven communities for "noteworthy acts of public service" in the floods of March, 1936.

The railroad managements and employes of this State are to concentrate on the passage at this session of the Legislature o?? the Rapp bill for the regulation of motor trucking, the Associated Railroads of New York announced yesterday.

William R. Gray, dean of the Amos Tuck School of Administration and Finance at Dartmouth College, died at the Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital today at the age of 57. Dean Gray, who had been a life trustee of Dartmouth since 1926, had been connected with the Tuck School faculty since 1905 and had been dean of the business school since 1919.

With Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris filling the vacancy made by the withdrawal of Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba, and Reuben Fine of New York representing the United States, the international masters tournament at the annual Easter Congress of the Kent County Chess Association opened today at the Grand Hotel in Cliftonville, near here.

Andrew McLeod, secretary and treasurer of the Mullins Manufacturing Company, said yesterday that it is the intention of directors to declare a 100 per cent stock dividend to Class B stockholders following approval by stockholders at a special meeting on April 27 of a plan to increase the authorized Class B stock to 560,000 shares from 172,550 shares, of which 164,989 shares are outstanding.

A full-length study of child labor, with five chapters of actual case histories, will be published by Robert M. McBride on April 28. The book, entitled "Child Workers in America," is the work of Katherine DuPre Lumpkin and Dorothy Douglas.

Following the dissolution of the Diet, it was announced today that the elections for the new House of Representatives would be held on April 30 and that a special session would be convoked for early Summer.
Another article by Virginio Gayda in the Giornale d'Italia this evening protests what he terms the false news the British press is spreading about the situation in Ethionia.

Frederick Rex, municipal librarian, offered statistics today to show that New York was the windiest city in 1936. His compilation, based on Weather Bureau recordings in thirty-five cities in the United States, established that New York had 106 days with winds blowing thirty-two or more miles an hour, whereas Chicago had only seven.
New York Yearly Meeting of the Society of Friends begins at 10 A. M. at 221 East Fifteenth Street and continues to April 5. Morning, afternoon and evening sessions.

Coming from last place at the far turn, Mrs. W. T. Anderson's Carlovinian scored a thrilling halflength victory in the six furlongs of The Buccaneer, a test for 3-yearolds, today, at Tropical Park. T. D. Buhl's lightly backed Nad earned the place, a length before the Shandon Farm's Rainland.

Williams College at Williamstown, Mass., receives $579,419 as residuary legatee of Samuel Hopkins, retired cotton broker, it was disclosed in a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Hopkins, whose home was at 45 Park Avenue, died June 21, 1936.
This ancient city, the one-time proud head of the Hanseatic League and which had enjoyed independence since the twelfth century, was officially incorporated in Prussia today.

James Madison and Samuel J. Tilden were the victors in contrasting games yesterday, as Brooklyn P. S. A. L. nines continued their non-league contests. Madison beat Alexander Hamilton, 2--1, in a wellplayed battle at Commercial Field, while Tilden outscored New Utrecht, 16--8, in a slugfest at Bay Ridge Oval.

Henry W. Ohrbach of 1,552 Brooklyn Avenue, Brooklyn, an insurance broker, died yesterday at his home of a heart ailment at the age of 62. Mr. Ohrbach was a brother of Nathan M. Ohrbach, president of the Ohrbach Affiliated Department Stores.

General Francisco Franco's press bureau asserts 62,000 persons have been assassinated so far in Madrid by "Red terrorists." Photographs of 35,000 of these victims, who were merely charged with being "enemies of the proletarian regime," are said to be on file with the Insurgent press bureau.

With Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, both in New York, Governor Frank Murphy made plans today for an intensified week-end effort to get the Chrysler strike settled before next Monday's State-wide elections.

The marriage of Miss Virginia M. Slevin, daughter of Justice William Mrs. Slevin, to Thomas J. Galvin, the Borough of Manhattan and Mrs. Slevin, to Thomas J. Garvin, also of this city, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of All Saints, 129th Street and Madison Avenue.

Cambridge University senate decided today to decline an invitation from Goettingen University for a delegation to be sent to the bicentenary celebrations of the German institution on June 30, thus following the precedent established when a similar invitation from Heidelberg University was refused last year.

The sale last year of securities which cost $2,026,885 by the Delaware Hudson Company was disclosed in the annual report issued yesterday. Included in the sale were 18,500 shares of New York Central Railroad capital stock.

The semi-final stages of both the intercollegiate and interscholastic indoor polo championships will be contested at the Squadron A Armory tonight, with both defending titleholders making their opening appearances in this year's play.
Norman Thomas, chairman of the executive body of the Socialist party, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania for his first visit to. Europe in nearly thirty years.

The consent of present bondholders to an additional issue of $2,000,000 in bonds for funds with which to build a second vehicular level on the Henry Hudson Bridge has been asked by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, it was announced yesterday.

As realists in an illusory world we may as well regard "Young Madame Conti" as a vehicle for Constance Cummings. It gives us the first opportunity we have had in New York to appreciate her vibrant quality as an actress.
GEORGE RECTOR'S book, "Dine At Home With Rector" (Dutton, $2.50), is a labor of loving propaganda for dunkable doughnuts, inch-thick steaks smothered with onions, Irish stew served with the hair on.

The Supreme Court decision validating the Washington State Minimum Wage Law solves old problems only to pose new ones. With the States free constitutionally to enact minimum wage laws, they must now decide what precise form these laws shall take.

The domestic copper price advance to 17 cents a pound, which was announced late Tuesday by two producers, became general yesterday. The manufacturers of copper products also increased the prices of their products to conform with the higher Price of the metal.
A number of supper parties were given last night in the cert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, following the final performance of the International Skating Carnival at Madison Square Garden.

William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, returned to his post yesterday on the United States liner President Harding after spending three weeks here. Accompanying him is his 13-yearold daughter, Anne, who is returning to Paris to attend school.

A direct appeal to the Shah of Iran (Persia) Mirza Risa Pahlevi against the establishment in this city of a selling agency of the Iranian Carpet Company, Ltd., alleged government-operated monopoly handling Persian rugs, was cabled to Tehran yesterday by the Oriental Rug Importers Association, Inc.

George W. Barnum, a veteran actor of the American and English stage, died at the Edwin Forrest Home here yesterday in his eighty-fifth year. Born in Newark, he started his stage career at 29 after graduating from the Newark Military Academy.
Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday that real estate taxes for the first half of 1937 are due today. Payments may be made at the borough offices of the City Collector in each borough.

A program for the publication from time to time of opinions on accounting principles to contribute to the development of uniform standards and practices in major accounting was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Attention has been attracted, sometimes apprehensively, to the continuing rise of prices which has now brought the Labor Bureau's general average something like 10 per cent above this date last year.

A highly enthusiastic gathering bade adieu to the charity figureskating carnival at Madison Square Garden last night. Filling the arena to capacity, 16,000 spectators showed their unqualified appreciation of the show that ended with a fourth performance.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 655--Ben Reuben, petr., v. United States. Time within which to file rehearing extended to and including April 9th next on motion for the netr.

Senator Norris stated at the White House Executive Office today, after a conference with President Roosevelt, that he was planning to Introduce a bill authorizing crea??ion of an agency to build through??ut the country a system of flood control and power plants similar to ??he Tennessee Valley Authority.
At midnight tonight Title I of the National Housing Act expires, and with it ends the purely emergency phase of the Housing Administratlon's work.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn unanimously held yesterday that the City Chamberlain was responsible for investments made by the city for minors in mortgage certificates where a thorough and independent investigation of the mortgaged property had not been made.
Brig. Gen. John Philip Hill, former member of Congress from a Baltimore, City district, filed in Circuit Court here today an answer to Mrs. Suzanne Carroll Hill's recent suit for absolute divorce.

Having successfully cleared the first barrier blocking their path to the Stanley Cup, the New York Rangers will tackle a second and more formidable obstacle tonight when they face the powerful Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden in the opening contest of the semi-final two-out-of-three-game series for hockey's world championship trophy.
The fuel supply of Greater Boston's 2,000,000 population was cut off tonight as conciliatory conferences sought to end a strike of 1,200 truck drivers and helpers which started today.

Representative Wright Patman of Texas was named head of a steering committee of eighty House members today to push for enactment at this session of a measure for government ownership of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks.

Provincial autonomy, the first stage of governmental change under the new Indian Constitution, came into force at midnight without the cooperation of the All-India Congress party, which had obtained majorities in the Legislatures of six of eleven provinces.

48th St., 351 W., 20x100.5; Henry A. Uterhart to trustee will of Harriet Duer Potter, care of Bankers Trust Co.; consideration $10,000. foreclosure. 119th St., 347 E., 25x101; An Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females to Theresa Tinelli, 511 White Plains Rd., Bronx ($5).

George H. Rhinehart, senior vice president in charge of credits, was elected yesterday president of the Trust Company of North America. He will succeed Felix G. Langer, who resigned as president and director. The directors also elected Jacob Schapiro as chairman of the board, a new office.
The mill property, brands and good-will of the Dunlop Mills, Richmond, Va., have been sold by Joseph P. Day, Inc., to the DixiePortland Flour Company, Memphis, Tenn.

Jimmy Wilson's Phillies today won a ball game on four hits and did it in one hour and thirty-nine minutes. Coupled with the score of 1--0, these things were reminiscent of many another Philly-Dodger imbroglio because they were so different.

Mrs. Madeleine la Ferriere, known also as Miss Magda- de Fontanges, who shot and wounded the former Envoy to Rome, Count Charles de Chambrun, admitted today to the examining magistrate that she had practiced at a shooting gallery prior to her attempt to kill the diplomat in the Gare du Nord on March 17.

Jeannette Albert, a young pianist born and educated in Chicago, made her first New York appearance yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. She played the Bach Prelude and Fugue in E-flat minor; a group of Chopin containing the F minor Fantaisie, Op. 49,

With the filing of twenty-nine registration statements today under the Securities Act of 1933 for securities with gross proceeds of $50,643,512, the total for the first three months of 1937 reached $2,826,000,000.

New construction filed for yesterday included a set of plans for three tenement houses to be erected at Laurel Hill Terrace and 187th. Street in the Washington Heights section overlooking Highbridge Park. The houses will be erected by one owner and will cost $540,000. Plans filed yesterday are:
The National City Bank yesterday announced that it would continue to . make property modernization loans in spite of the expiration yesterday of Title I of the National Housing Act.

Original listing applications have been approved by the New York Curb Exchange as follows: 400 shares of Air Devices Corporation common stock, $1 par value, with authority to add 400,000 shares on notice of issuance; 239,049 shares of Beech Aircraft Corporation common stock, $1 par value, with authority to add 45,951 shares on notice of issuance;

The United States Conference of Mayors asked President Roosevelt today to recommend an appropriation of $2,200,000,000 to guarantee continuance of Federal aid for 2,800,000 employable relief workers they estimated would require aid during the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

A listing of 487 women's clubs in the metropolitan area is included in the thirteenth annual directory "Club Women of New York," published today with the endorsement of the City Federation of Women's Clubs. Compiled by Miss Rosaline C. Wren, the volume presents a picture of the manifold activities and objectives for which these feminine groups have been formed.

A conference to consider new steps in State minimum wage legislation to take full advantage of the recent Supreme Court decision will be held tomorrow morning in the office of Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

The Midtown Hudson Tunnel, 75 per cent completed and scheduled to be opened for vehicular traffic next year, was inspected from end to end yesterday by Arthur S. Tuttle, New York State PWA director, and a group of engineers and officials of the PWA and the Port of New York Authority, which will operate the tunnel when it is completed.

SIX years ago the Montreal Maroons asked waivers on Lionel Conacher and here he is bobbing up as the mainstay of the Maroon defense in the play-off battle with the Rangers in Madison Square Garden this evening.

Reductions in some Canadian automobile tariffs and upward revisions of furniture schedules were announced today by Charles Dunning, Finance Minister. The changes, retroactive to Feb. 25, put some automobile material formerly dutiable on the free list, both under the British preferential schedule and under the intermediate schedule applicable to the United States.
The bill to regulate interstate commerce in bituminous coal and transactions in or directly affecting such commerce was called up in the Senate today and is expected to be passed tomorrow.

Although recitals have followed one another in unbroken succession all season, organ soloists have been no more frequently heard in public concerts hereabout than during the darkest days of the depression.

The John Wanamaker department store presented yesterday a special program to mark the completion of the $200,000 renovation of the second, third, fourth and fifth floors of its south building, known as the "Home Store."

Quiet conditions prevailed on the stock market here today but the general tendency was firm. Gilt-edge issues were unchanged for the most part and foreign loans were without feature. International stocks showed all-around improvements, United States Steel and International Nickel shares going ahead.

The Pabst Blue Ribbon team of New York led by Ray Nolen, rolled 2,947 last night to gain the fourthplace tie-with the Bayonne Wheelmen among the five-man teams in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

When JOHN BUCHAN was here in 1934 speaking. at the opening of the great new library of Columbia University, he was welcomed in his own person and for his varied contributions, in both the written and spoken word, and especially to the English-speaking youth of the world.

Eddie Blunt of Corona, L. I., recent conqueror of Leroy Haynes, scored another knockout last night when he stopped Jack Moran of Pittsburgh in 1:55 of the first round in a scheduled ten-round bout featuring the card at the Rockland Palace. Blunt weighed 218 pounds and Moran 187 1/2.

John W. Smith, managing editor of The Brooklyn Times-Union, told the Federal Communications Commission today that a monopoly of news in Brooklyn by any single newspaper or organization was "impossible."
The Navy Department today awarded a contract to the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of Paterson, N. J., for 106 radial engines, at a cost of $1,042,484.

Many thousands of the 72,000 deaths here each year are from diseases for which there are now available effective control measures, about 100 health officers of the metropolitan area agreed here yesterday.

A copy of the first edition of James Fenimore Cooper's "The Last of the Mohicans," in the original boards, uncut, published in Philadelphia in 1826, brought $1,600 last night at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The buyer was Henry O. Keith.

The steel industry is entering the second quarter of the year with production almost equal to that of the record-breaking month of May, 1929, and with backlogs that, in some products, extend well into the third quarter, The Iron Age says this week.

Until Westchester residents are willing to consent to consolidation of local governmental units and to the dismissal of "Joe, the neighborhood policeman," they must continue to pay high taxes, Bert C. McCulloch, chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors' special committee on government reorganization, said this afternoon at the New Rochelle Woman's Club.

Films which will be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified have been recommended as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools; The list follows:
The six winners in the second national cookery contest conducted by the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries were announced last night at the Grand Central Palace.

After "measuring" Monday's unanimous Supreme Court decision in favor of the Railway Labor Act alongside last year's divided Guffey act opinions and the provisions of the Wagner act, attorneys and lay observers of the ways of the Supreme Court see reasons to believe that the forthcoming decision on the Wagner act may leave legally unsolved some of the issues that law has raised.

Luke E. O'Toole, Brooklyn Democrat, attempted to resign as principal examiner of Income tax returns in the Brooklyn office of the State Tax Department, but Mark Graves, State Tax- Commissioner, refused to accept his resignation pending the outcome of hearings on charges of official misconduct, it was disclosed yesterday.

Formation of an organization to promote legislation, curbing iron and steel scrap exports in the interests of national defense, was discussed at a meeting of steel mill executives yesterday at the Hotel Barclay. Announcement of the new association, together with details of its formation, spokesmen for the steel group said yesterday, would be made later this week.

Although the High Commissioner for Spanish Morocco tonight flatly denied there had been an anti-Insurgent plot there, reports persisted here that 1,000 Italian colonial troops had landed in the colony to prevent movements against Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, paid homage at American shrines today, honored the American war dead and talked with American newspaper men but avoided all discussion of public problems.

Miss Mary Alan Schaff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Alan Schaff of Beechwood, this place, was married here at noon today at the home of her parents to Edward Austin Byrne, son of Mrs. Vincent Byrne of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Byrne.

Contrary to the trend of recent years, the foreign trade of the United States expanded sharply in February, with increases from a month before and large gains over the import and export figures for February, 1936.
A new application of chemistry to make fabrics flame-resisting was demonstrated yesterday at the opening of a popular exhibit of this and other chemical contributions to better living.
The Piano Teachers Congress of New York will hold their regular monthly meeting this morning at 10 o'clock at Steinway Hall. Harry Spear will be guest speaker.
Simultaneously with satisfactory revenue figures, it is officially announced that the number of jobless has fallen to 1,601,201--the lowest figure in eight years.

The Republican party in New York State is on its way back to power after a decade and a half of ineffectiveness, William S. Murray, chairman of the State committee, told members of the Yonkers Republican organization at a dinner tonight.
A petition asking for judgments amounting to $1,027,000, with interest, was filed today on behalf of five southern railroad lines by Armstrong Machen Allen, attorneys, in the Federal court.

A. B. and B. B. Block have purchased the vacant plot, 70 by 100 feet, at the southeast corner of Woodside Avenue and Sixtieth Street, Woodside, one block from the subway and Long Island Railroad stations. A one-story taxpayer will be erected on the plot.

The chief need for intelligent sampling in market research or consumer polls is more complete data on income levels, Archibald M. Crossley, president of Crossley, Inc., yesterday told the luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association at the Advertising Club of New York.
Capital, surplus and undivided profits of the United States Trust Company of New York rose in the first quarter of 1937 from $30,510,824 to $30,615,161, according to the report, made public today.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today issued its valuation figures of the Sinclair Prairie Pipeline Company of Texas, as of Dec. 31, 1934. The report stated that the figures were "tentative."

Held without bail for grand jury action on an arson charge, Albert Kinderman, caretaker of the West End Synagogue, was committed to Bellevue for observation yesterday after his early-morning confession that he had set two fires in the synagogue, at 158 West Eightysecond Street, on Saturday morning.
The police announced today discovery of a secret arsenal containing twelve machine guns and 12,000 rounds of ammunition at a farmhouse near Waterstown, County Kildare.

A jury of three women and nine men today returned a verdict before a lunacy commission here declaring that Binny Woodward Earl of Edgewater Park, Palm Beach and Philadelphia is "not sane" and is "incapable and unfit to handle his personal affairs."

Charles J. Weaver, superintendent of RCA Communications central radio office until his retirement last January, died Tuesday afternoon in St. Petersburg, Fla., following an operation, it was learned here yesterday.

Forty policemen were rushed to the Central Courts Building in the Borough Hall area of Brooklyn at about 11 o'clock last night after a crowd in the street had threatened twelve jurors as they left a court where they had convicted two men of assault and robbery.

Details of four plans designed to give additional compensation to officers and executive employes became public yesterday. Tubize Chatillon Corporation shareholders will vote on May 3 on a plan to distribute options on authorized but unissued stock.

A decline of 3,461 employes of the executive branch of the government took place in February, the Civil Service Commission said today. The total of such employes dropped from 829,794 on Jan. 31 to 826,333 on Feb. 28.
C. Marshall Finnan, superintendent of national capital parks, estimated today that Japanese cherry trees in Potomac Park will make "a little showing" of blossoms Sunday, April 4.

Henry W. Bull was re-elected president of the Turf and Field Club at a meeting of the board of governors yesterday. This will be the fifteenth consecutive year he has served in that capacity and he was for many years vice president under the late Frank K. Sturgis.

A collection of 106 receipted bills for books, prints, objets d'art and other items supplied to Marie Antoinette during the years 1784-88 was sold for $800 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Mayor LA GUARDIA has made a constructive move by appointing a new City Industrial Relations Board to provide impartial assistance in the settlement of labor disputes. Its three members are Professor LLEWELLYN of the Columbia Law School;

Dr. Herman Goldenberg, dermatologist, died yesterday of a cerebral thrombosis at his office, 128 East Seventy-second Street. Dr. Goldenberg, who was 74 years old, was educated at Munich and Giesen Universities in Germany. He had been practicing in this city for almost fifty years.
Several days ago Charles A. Hendershot of Peapack, father of thirteen children, was notified he would be dispossessed from his small farm today unless he paid up some of the back rent.
None of the important items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached new high or low points for the year to date.

William F. Chinery, agent for the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission, was acquitted tonight of a charge of bribery and extortion after a jury had deliberated three hours and a half in Quarter Sessions Court.

Transactions in Bronx realty reported yesterday by brokers reveal a continuance of the current interest in large apartment properties by both operators and investors. The two six-story buildings at 2,910 Wallace Avenue and 2,911 Barnes Avenue, occupying plots 250 by 200 feet and 250 by 150 feet, respectively, representing an entire city block of twenty-two lots have been purchased by Charles Walzer.

With the assertion that "an obviously national need can be met only through obviously national action," President Roosevelt today injected the court controversy into ceremonies marking the semi-centennial of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A new Edgar Allan Poe mystery, almost as baffling as some the author wrote, was disclosed yesterday with the filing of a suit in Supreme Court by the Authors Club to recover four Poe letters from the New York Publio Library.
Jesse J. Ricks Jr., son of the president of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, faces possible grand jury action for unlawful possession of a pistol, and Patrolman Herbert A.

Mr. and Mrs. Laurance S. Rockefeller entertained with a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for her sister, Miss Elizabeth French, and Ethan Allen Hitchcock, who will be married this afternoon in the Brick Presbyterian Church.

Investors were attracted yesterday to the East Side, where sales were made from the Fourteenth Street area to Yorkville. Plans for altering the five-story building at 64 East Fifty-sixth Street were announced in connection with the sale of the property by Mrs. Elizabeth Harris to an investor.

Today, the fifteenth anniversary of former Emperor Karl's death, saw various memorial demonstrations by the Legitimists. Members of various monarchist organizations marched to St. Michael's Church, where a tablet was erected to the Emperor's memory some years ago, and attended a high mass.

The Merchant's Association of New York, feeling the need for a far-reaching study of unemployment in the State, has endorsed a resolution by Assemblyman Wadsworth at Albany to create a committee of business men to make such a study, it-was announced yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, president of the association.

In an atmosphere of post-prandial congeniality, the New York Drama Critics Circle presented last night its silver plaque for the best play of the year to Maxwell Anderson, author of "High Tor" and second-time recipient of the award.

Common stock issues intended for sale, registration statements for which became effective under the Securities Act of 1933 in February, totaled $131,507,000, including $126,437,000 to be sold by registrants and $5,470,000 by stockholders, the highest total for such issues in any month since the registration provisions of the act became effective in July, 1933, the SEC announced today.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

About 1,000 members of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Alliance and the Bartenders International League of America met yesterday afternoon at Palm Garden, 306 West Fifty-second Street,' and heard speakers tell of plans to organize the city's 100,000 hotel workers and bartenders.

Commodity futures were irregular in active trading on the local commodity markets yesterday. World sugar, rubber, silk and wool top futures advanced, while copper, tin, lead, zinc, hide, coffee, and cocoa futures declined. On the cash market, cotton, salk, rubber and corn advanced, but cocoa, sugar, butter, eggs, tins, wheat and lard declined.

Hogs 11,000 including 3,000 direct; good and choice hogs 200 pounds up, mostly 10 cents lower than Wednesday's average; medium kinds all weights 15-25 cents lower; pigs shared in the decline; packing sows, 10 cents lower; most good and choice 200-320 poundweights $10.10 to $10.20; top $10.25; practical top late $10.15; most Packing sows $9,25 to $9,60; shippers 1,000; estimated holdover 3.000.

The danger of war striking without warning at this traditionally neutral country and sparing no one and nothingnot even the world headquarters of the Red Cross and the League of Nations palace-was literally brought home to the people all through Switzerland today.

Brief particulars of the long-awaited reconstruction scheme of Cable and Wireless (holding), Ltd., a [Pound]46,000,000 concern which, through a subsidiary, controls nearly the entire cable and radio communications system of the British Empire, was announced tonight.

The annual meeting of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana will be held in Whiting, Ind., on April 29. R. H. Jonson Co. have opened an unlisted trading department un-' der the management of Jacques Scholle and Charles B. McAllister. J. Wheeler McGovern is with Ernstrom Co., Inc.

When was the first sit-down strike? It may have been among the Sumerians or Hittites, for all we know, or among Etruscan pottery makers, or among Spanish miners in Roman imperial times, who had the habit of rebellion. They fortified mountains. Mines may have been good places to hide in, but from a military point of view their seizure was hardly important.

Turpentine firm, 37c; sales, 43 barrels; receipts, 123 barrels; shipments, 353 barrels; stock, 23,498 barrels. Resin firm, sales, 219; receipts, 523; shipments, 527; stock, 43,629. Quote: B. $7; D, $7.10; E, $7.40; F to WG, $8; WW, X, 8.75.

W. J. H. Trott's six-meter yacht, Achilles, winner of the Prince of Wales competition in 1932, was badly damaged today and may not be repaired in time for the international six-meter series against the United States starting April 6.

Addressing a meeting of the Down Town Club tonight, which was described as the beginning of a movement to draft him for Governor, the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, State Senator from Essex County, said the interest shown at the meeting "sets up a challenge hard for any man to resist," but he added he could not "give any assurance at this time" that he would be a candidate.

District Attorney William C. Dodge declined yesterday to call a conference of anti-Nazi organizations to obtain their cooperation in gathering evidence to aid Frederick Sperling, Assistant District Attorney, in prosecuting a summons proceeding against Fritz Kuhn, national leader of the Pro-Nazi German-American League.

Statesmen and educators from many nations united yesterday to pay tribute to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, who will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday today. Their congratulations came to Dr. Butler in a flood of cabled messages from abroad and telegrams from many parts of this continent.
Dr. James John Quiney, a physician and roentgenologist here for thirtyfour years, died last night at the age of 55.

Under the most enjoyable auspices for the spectators, but with conditions not of the best for the competing dogs, the third annual Maryland retriever meet began this morning on the estate of R. R. M. Carpenter at Benton, to continue through Saturday, with a program of four stakes.

The marriage of Mrs. Lucy Eleanor Briggs Turner, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Ellis Briggs of Riverdale-on-Hudson, to George Carpenter Miles of Norfolk, Va., took place yesterday afternoon in the Riverdale Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. George Duff.

Colonel Bill Terry, having the previous day unloaded quite a bit of his choicest baseball bric-a-brac into the lap of his old pal, Travis Jackson, allowed his mighty Giants to try conclusions with his Jersey City farm hands today and happily discovered that in no way had he short-changed himself.

Mrs. Mark Garrison of 15 Claremont Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Beverly Brooke Bushnell, to Frederick ??. Robbins Jr., son of Mrs. Frederick O. Robbins of New Haven, Conn., and the late Mr. Robbins.

Youth triumphed in a brilliant duel on the alleys at the 212th Coast Artillery armory yesterday as 26-year-old Ernest Soest of Santa Monica, Calif., shaded the veteran Billy Knox of Philadelphia to gain the lead in the singles division of the American Bowling Congress championships.
College ring men ushered in the 1937 National Collegiate A. A. boxing championships tonight in a flurry of leather before several thousand spectators.

The testimonial luncheon for Walter Fairchild, president of the Torrens Title League, to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Hotel Pennsylvania, will have as its theme "putting the Torrens Law to work by registering city-owned property under the Torrens system."

A session of the Senate which was placidly considering the Guffey-Vinson bill to regulate interstate commerce in bituminous coal, and was about to pass it, was thrown into turmoil this afternoon by the sudden introduction by Senator Byrnes of South Carolina of an amendment which he frankly said would be tantamount, if passed, to a "declaration of public policy" against all sitdown strikes.

The Morris Plan Bank announces that it will continue to make loans to property owners for repairs and modernization without co-makers or mortgages, despite the expiration yesterday of government insurance of such loans.

A total of 3,014 establishments, engaged primarily in providing the general public with a warehousing service, gave employment to a monthly average of 32,785 persons in 1935 and paid out $37,715,000 in salaries that year, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of Census, said yesterday, in announcing publication of the Census of Business report, "Public Warehousing in 1935."

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had his sick leave extended today for another two months so he might recuperate further from injuries he suffered at the hands of rebellious troops at Sian last December.

Indications were received here that an attack on foreign correspondents was under way in Rumania. The representative of the semi-official Hungarian Telegraph Correspondence Bureau, a representative of the United Press and a German journalist were, all served with expulsion orders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What is the middle ground in the low-rent housing situation-a position fair to the tenant, the private real estate owner and the government? The tendency of the Housing Authority is to be too choosy about the people to be aided by low-rent projects and shows a lack of real intent to help.

Hazen (Kiki) Cuyler, who at 37 is the oldest player on the Reds' roster, suffered a fracture of the left cheekbone today during an exhibition game with Detroit which the Tigers won, 4 to 2. Cuyler collided with Second Baseman Alex Kampouris just as the latter caught a fly in short center field hit by Detroit's second baseman, Charley Gehringer, in the sixth inning.

Annual conference of the Eastern Public Speaking Association begins at the Hotel New Yorker at 9 A. M. and continues tomorrow. Dinner tonight at 7 o'clock. Meeting of the National Council of Naturalization and Citizenship, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Afternoon session 2 P. M. Dinner at 7:15.

Twice recently Senator Wheeler of Montana has intimated darkly that if he would-or, without breaching a confidence, couldhe has a tale to tell how certain of the administration's "bright young men" are the authors, and successful vendors to the President, of the Supreme Court plan.

Humane service to 26,929 sick or injured dogs, cats, horses and other animals was extended last year by the New York Women's League for Animals at its headquarters, the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals, 350 Lafayette Street, it is announced in the league's annual report.
The concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, -Serge Koussevitzky conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall was of superlative interest.

In a cash deal Frederick Brown has bought from the estate of Russell B. Burnside the business property occupying the blockfront on the north side of Rooseevlt Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, from Broadway to Seventy-fourth Street. The total frontage on the three streets is 146 feet.
Settlement of a strike of 1,200 fuel truck drivers of Greater Boston depended tonight upon a count of ballots ?? during the day on the question of accepting wage increases of about 10 per cent.
Government forces today continued to advance on three fronts. For the first time since the siege of Madrid started, the pressure on the capital was being relieved.

A rise of $130,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks to a total of $1,400,000,000 was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the Federal Reserve statements published yesterday. The gain in excess reserves was more than twice as large as the rise in actual reserves of the member banks, which amounted to $61,000,000 in the week.

Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis said today he didn't know just when he would decide about Outfielder Tom Henrich. Henrich, 21, asked the judge to tell him whether he belonged to the Zanesville, New Orleans, Milwaukee or Cleveland clubs or was his own boss.

Hearings in the arbitration proceedings on the wage demands of the Building Service Employes Union in the garment and fur area will begin at 11 A. M. today in the Garment Center Capitol, 498 Seventh Avenue.

The Reich Church Ministry today firmly denied reports that the Protestant elections had been put off indefinitely and indicated that they will occur some time before the first of June. A spokesman for Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, described the present situation, whereby church authorities are forbidden to make any changes, as intolerable for any length of time.

Following the jury's verdict yesterday in the Mosholu Parkway building collapse trial, Alderman Max Gross announced that he would introduce an ordinance in the Board of Aldermen Tuesday requiring the presence of a licensed construction superintendent on all building jobs in the future.

A veto by Governor Charles F. Hurley today killed two years' efforts to wipe from the statute book a law requiring teachers to swear that they will support Federal and State Constitutions. The House sustained the veto, making Senate action unnecessary.

Reduced holdings of United States Government securities were reported by almost all of the local banks and trust companies which yesterday made public statements of their condition as of the end of the first quarter of the year.

A favorable report on earnings of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation was read yesterday to Federal Judge William Bondy as the Irving Trust Company, trustee, and its attorneys applied for an interim allowance of $145,000 for services in the corporation's reorganization proceedings. The court reserved decision.
The annual water carnival at Barnard College was held last evening at the Barnard pool and was featured as the "Barnard Sea Fair," a farce patterned on Barnard's carnival last semester.
Three Bryn Mawr fellowships have been awarded to graduates of Barnard College for the following year. Miss Jane M. Martin of the class of 34 has received the fine arts fellowship for the second time.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Blanche Pattison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Pattison of Troy, N. Y., to Bayard Speyers, son of Mrs. James Bayard Speyers of 680 Madison Avenue and the late Mr. Speyers, which took place on Sunday in the Church of the Ascension in Troy.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt joined hundreds of capital socialites tonight in a trek to the Fort Myer society circus. They watched from a center box. The President, a loyal first-nighter since the shows began in 1922, was met at the entrance and saluted by a platoon of the Tenth Cavalry.

A leading citizen of Forty-second Street packs up today and moves away from there. Crosby Gaige, who guesses that he has occupied quarters in the Selwyn Theatre Building for twenty years, is going over to the RCA Building for a while and later, on May 1, to the International Building.

Pope Pius this morning emphasized his return to a state of comparatively good health, of which he had given first proof on Easter Sunday, by resuming his place at the desk in his private library which he had abandoned on falling sick almost exactly four months ago.

Proof that they don't often come back, once golfers get out of the hang of things, was furnished today when Bobby Jones, one-time monarch of the golf world, took 79 stroked in the opening round of the fourth annual masters' tournament at the Augusta National course.
Pre-tournament favorites advanced impressively today to the quarter-finals as the national badminton championships got under way at the Illinois Naval Armory.
Persistent reports at the Capitol that President Roosevelt intends to make a decisive intervention soon in world affairs in the interest of promoting peace reached a new high in definition today.

" Saving American Scenery" was the theme of the meeting of the National Life Conservation Society yesterday at its annual observance of Conservation Week in New York State. For sixteen years, by proclamation of the Governor, Conservation Week has been celebrated in the State in the first week of April.

The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports. Her passengers include Professor Paul Hindemuth, Dr. Heinrich Klas, Hans Schumberger, Max Komers, Rudolf Schillers, Dr. Hans Hartmann, Ahmed Abdil Latif, Mr. and Mrs. August Krueger, Douglas Claughton Fox, Mr. and Mrs. Roman Oberhummer, Henry N. C. Joostin, H. McKay Twombly, Mrs. Agnes Campbell and Mrs. Mabel Coard Franke.
Iver N. Lawson, brother of the late Victor F. Lawson, editor and publisher of The Chicago Daily News, died Wednesday night in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 72.
Retail coal dealers in this city began a drive yesterday against distributors of so-called bootleg anthracite and other competitors by announcing a slash of $2.50 a ton.

Lieut. Col. Charles H. Van Etten, in 375 Park AV.; John W. White, in 25 E. 86th St.; Robert H. Bowers, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., in 40 W. 55th St.; Mrs. F. W. Ellis, in 7 Part AV.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., broker.

Making his first appearance in the competition, Harry F. Wolf, eight-time national amateur titleholder from the New York A. C., met unexpected opposition from F. Barry Ryan Jr. and unexpected adversity in the form of an injured left ankle before he finally eked out
Miss Mary Frances Baker-Wilbraham, daughter of Sir Phillip Baker-Willbraham, and Elliot Perkins, a professor at Harvard University, were married today at Chelsea Register Office.

An invitation to high school graduate street sweepers--f whom there are said to be many--and all other employes of the Department of Sanstation to compete for a free university education in sanitary engineering disclosed yesterday that the city administration and New York University have undertaken a unique educational project.

Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N. C., a seasoned campaigner, and 19-year-old Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N. Y., playing in her first major tournament, defeated strong opponents in the semi-finals today and tomorrow will meet in an eighteen-hole match for the North and South women's golf championship.

A break in Treasury bond prices, the widest yet, that carried quotations down 16-32 to 1 5-32 points on the day, unsettled the securities markets generally. Nervous trading in stocks resulted in a lower closing, with many of the leading issues off 1 to 3 points.

Sir Philip Stott, industrial architect and founder of the ill-starred Stott College for Training Conservative Politicians, died today at 79. Sir Philip spent a considerable portion of his fortune, amassed by designing and investing in cotton mills all over the world, in furthering his plan for mass education of Conservative speakers and political agents.

With Strike leaders asserting that 3,000 WPA workers were engaged in sit-downs or walkouts yesterday, WPA headquarters counted only 254 away from their posts and Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, refused to recognize that a strike was in progress.
Counsel for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation have drafted a decree ordering stockholders of the Central Republic Trust Company to pay an assessment of $10,500,000 of their holdings.

Edgar Prochnik, Austrian Minister to the United States, and Mrs. Prochnik were guests of honor at a tea given yesterday by Baron Kurt Pantz at the Paul Reinhardt Galleries, where Mr. Prochnik formally opened an exhibition of his host's portraits.
The hardy anglers who annually make it a custom to go trout fishing in New York State on opening day have only a few hours left before they set out by motor or train to their favored spots tomorrow.

President Roosevelt told the leaders of a Congressional group today that he would not object to a two-year extension of the Public Works Administration, which expires June 30, but would object to any new approriations for the agency.

John Steinbeck, first editions of whose books are now being counted valuable on sight, has sailed from California and will be in New York about April 22. He is bringing with him the play version of "Of Men and Mice," which Sam Harris and George S. Kaufman plan to produce in the Fall.

The decision of the National Labor Relations Board of March 13 ordering reinstatement of 4,000 striking Remington Rand employes was condemned in a statement issued yesterday by a committee representing groups of the concern's employes in the plants at Ilion, N. Y., Syracuse, and Middletown, Conn.

The annual report of the Securities Corporation General for 1936 shows net income of $37,008, exclusive of net losses of $189,652 on investment securities sold, compared with net income for 1935 of $38,947 before net losses of $2,877 on securities sold.

Rutgers University defeated Montclair State Teachers College, 7 to 6, in the opening baseball game of the season for both teams on Neilson Field today. Trailing, 6 to 0, in the seventh, Rutgers tied the score and went on to win in the ninth when Gene Devereaux dropped a long. fly by Roy Lins with the bases loaded and none out.

The Mexican Government officially assured the United States today that its avowed policy of helping the Loyalist government in Spain would not involve any breaches of the United States Neutrality Law.

German and American speakers, regretting strained relations between this country and Germany, expressed hope for a better understanding between the two nations at a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, given by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., to three visiting groups of German industry and commerce, who arrived here last Wednesday.
Rudolf Hess, Deputy National Socialist leader, declared tonight during the festivities in celebration of the creation of Greater Hamburg: "The Fuehrer's work is blessed by God Almighty."
J. Renwick Hogg of Philadelphia was elected president of the Lafayette College board of trustees today at a meeting of the board here. Mr. Hogg, benefactor of the college, was graduated in 1878.

The Independent Steel and Iron Producers Committee on Scrap was organized yesterday, as a result of conferences held in the Hotel Barclay here on Wednesday, to discuss means of dealing with "the serious situation that has arisen with respect to the growth in export of iron and steel scrap."
The Securities and Exchange Commission extended today until April 1, 1938, the time within which the Buffalo Stock Exchange may apply for reinstatement as a national securities Exchange.

Max Schmeling renewed his offer yesterday of a guarantee of $350,000 to James J. Braddock to defend his world heavyweight championship against Schmeling in Germany in the Summer. In a cable from Germany to his manager, Joe Jacobs, Schmeling declared that he is willing to abide by most of the conditions named by Joe Gould, Braddock's pilot.

The retail price of milk dropped sharply yesterday, reductions in the city ranging from 1 to 6 cents a quart. A price war was on involving a conflict between the large distributors and the independents.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, reported to President Roosevelt today that the Commodity Credit Corporation had obtained such good prices for its loan cotton during March and February that there was a good chance of almost "breaking even" on the 3,000,000 bales held by the government under the cotton loan program.

Sol Schiff of New York and Jimmie McClure of Indianapolis, rated first and second in the domestic seeding of the national singles table-tennis championship, moved into the third round ahead of the field tonight.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works announced yesterday that it had received an order from the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company for the construction of twelve steam locomotives for use in Florida passenger service.

Despite American dominance in supplying Cuba with industrial and agricultural machinery, the percentage of the American exports to Cuba has declined steadily in the last three years and Germany's percentage has increased, the Department of Commerce reported today on the basis of a communication from the assistant American commercial attache at Havana.

All part-time employment has been eliminated by the Hearn Department Store, Inc., and full-time employment has been offered those part-time workers who wished such work, it was stated here yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, vice president of the store.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Bennett E. Siegelstein of New York was admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had: 12, Original-State of Texas. complainant, v. State of New Mexico et al. Ad interim report of the special master submitted.

The Works Progress Administration announced today that President Roosevelt has approved allotments totaling $2,345,840 for projects in thirty-eight States. The largest of the group was to Rochester, N. Y., $402,870, to repair school buildings and grounds.

Marshal Ahmed Izzet Pasha, former Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, who lived in retirement under the republic, died today at the age of 73. After completing studies at the Turkish Staff College, he spent some years in Germany, where he won the former Kaiser's high esteem.

The pamphlet report of the Virginian Railway Company for 1936 shows consolidated net income of $6,451,699 after taxes and charges, equal after preferred dividend re-quirements to $15.27 a share on the 312,715 shares of common stock outstanding.

The suggestion that the best way to preserve world peace would be for the United States and Great Britain to join and force their will on the rest of the world was made last night at a round-table discussion of "The Price of Peace" before the Young Women's School of Political Science at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.
Building projects submitted in the city yesterday included plans for a six-story tenement house to cost $500,000 at the southeast corner of the Grand Concourse and 161st Street, the Bronx.

Baron and Baroness Ernest von Schilling of Copenhagen, Denmark, have announced to friends and relatives here the engagement of their daughter, Baroness Cecilia von Schilling, to Marcus Wilson Acheson 3d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Wilson Acheson Jr. of Pittsburgh.

Further redistribution of educational activities of the Society of Friends to avoid overlapping and duplication was urged last night by Dr. John A. Lester of Philadelphia, secretary of the Friends Council on Education.

The low purchasing power of large numbers of people stands in the way of taking full advantage of new knowledge in the field of nutrition which can increase the average life span by at least seven years and ward off disease and senility, Dr. Henry C. Sherman, Mitchell Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University, declared last night in a paper read before the Academy of Medicine.

Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, made pleas to the Senate and House of Representatives today for effective cooperation between his country and the United States, and his address was received with prolonged applause in each chamber.
The engagement of $8,384,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $7,600,000 in England and $784,000 in India was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
American Public Service Company and Subsidiaries-Calendar years:

Miles Av. (18-5583), n. e. cor. Graff Av., 200x100; Urb Construction Corp. to Zerega Associates, Inc.. 1,727 Zerega Av. 178th St. (11-3157), n. e. cor. Anthony Av., 100x99; Arthur Silverman to J. H. Holding Co., Inc., 270 Broadway.

Several thousand WPA workers responded today to organizers' calls for a strike against "starvation" pay, but rain thwarted the leaders' plans to bring about an immediate walkout of 30,000 in the. Bay area as a prelude to a projected Statewide tie-up.

Miss Rose Schneiderman, former president of the Women's Trade Union League, was sworn in yesterday afternoon as secretary of the New York State Department of Labor by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.

Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended on March 31 showed an increase of $1,834,538 over the previous week, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today.

Governor Hoffman signed today the bill transferring a balance of $1,750,000 from the former Emergency Relief Administration to the State Financial Assistance Commission for Unemployment Relief, but announced he would veto the $7,917,660 Highway Fund Diversion Bill for relief.

Basil Murray, a journalist and son of Professor Gilbert Murray, British classical scholar, died today aboard the British hospital ship Maine on the way to Marseilles. Mr. Murray, until recently Valencia correspondent for The International News Service, was stricken with pneumonia five days ago.
