Phineas A. Seaman, former Nassau County Sheriff and former chief of the Hempstead police force, died today in his home in Garden City of pneumonia. He was 72 years old. A peace officer for nearly half a century, he was born in Roslyn and became a truant officer there.

In an effort to mitigate the steel shortage and curb rising prices the Departments of Commerce and Finance will recommend today that the Cabinet issue an imperial ordinance to take the place of the special legislation that the Diet session failed to pass.

Mucho Gusto, from the Araho Stable of Mr. and Mrs. Walter O'Hara, captured the $5,875 Rowe Memorial Handicap as the Eastern racing season began today before the largest opening-day crowd in the history of the Bowie course.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The deadlock in negotiations for extension of the empire flying boat service from Sydney to Auckland, New Zealand, between the British, Australian and New Zealand Governments points to the improbability of Australia's having an air link with the United States when the Pan American Clippers begin their service to New Zealand.

Onofrio Lauri of Brooklyn and Charles Seaback of Boston accounted for their second triumphs in the world pocket billiard championship at Ponzi's Academy yesterday. The former beat Fay Gainer of Vineland, N. J., 125 to 88, in 19 innings, and Seaback downed Marcel Camp of Detroit, 125 to 79, in 15.
Walter J. Swords has joined the residential department of Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc. Flaherty Associates. Inc.. report that the building at 602 West 157th St. is 100 per cent rented.

Assemblyman Phelps Phelps of Manhattan yesterday urged the enactment by New York State of a minimum wage law conforming to the State of Washington law upheld this week by the United States Supreme Court.

The two teams that met for the national A. A. U. handball doubles title last year reached the final of the 1937 tournament tonight. Joe Gordon and Andy Berry of Los Angeles. champions, and Joe Platak and Bob Weiller of Chicago were the winning pairs.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is not urging banks to retire the preferred stock which the government corporation bought to strengthen the capital structures of the banks, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, declared today.

Commander George Gardiner Fry, lawyer and yachtsman, died Wednesday in the Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, of a heart attack. His age was 74. He lived at his estate, Quarterdeck, at Westport, Conn.

The Duke of Windsor is having trouble again protecting his dog. He returned to his lakeside retreat after a six-mile walk today just in time to rescue his new Cairn terrier Schnooki. Two German shepherd dogs were getting the best of the small dog.
A nearriot sent a State Athletic Commission official to a hospital and one spectator to jail, ending what started as a wrestling match between Everett Marshall and Chief Osley Sanooke tonight.
Long Island University's nine bunched five hits for five runs in a big seventh inning to defeat Virginia Tech today, 6 to 1. The box score:

Francis Fleury Prentiss, chairman of the Cleveland Twist Drill Company, died of pneumonia at his Winter home in Pasadena, Calif., at the age of 78. Francis Fleury Prentiss began his career in 1876 as a bank clerk. After three years, however, he became a partner in Davies Prentiss of Cleveland, lock manufacturers.

If Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his troops ever invade Britain they should be welcomed like tourists and greeted in a friendly way, Bertrand Russell, well-known author and prominent pacifist, said today.

Miss Susan Badgerow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harve Gordon Badgerow of Winnetka, Ill., was married this evening to Winston Lewis May Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Winston Lewis May of New York. The ceremony was performed in Christ Church, Winnetka.

Washington Av. (9-2371), s. e. cor. 167th St., 75x90; Primlesh Realty Corp. to Bankers Trust Co.; extends mtg. to Feb. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $79,000. Valentine Av. (12-3307), n. e. cor. 201st St., 100x125; Dorsay Building Corp. to Institutional Securities Corp., 14 Wall St.; at 5 per cent until final advance is made and 4 1/2 Per cent thereafter, building loan; $163,000.

Three Americans have applied to the Governor in Council for permission to purchase Bermuda properties. They are Charles Markley Haddon of Camden, N. J., who is asking a permit for one acre on St. David's Island;

Action for a writ of habeas corpus was brought in the Mexican Federal Court today for Alexander Pompez, New York racketeer wanted by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey in the policy racket investigation.

Army and Cornell will ride together tomorrow night for the intercollegiate indoor polo championship. In last night's semi-finals at Squadron A Armory Cornell just managed to turn back Princeton by the slim margin of 6 1/2 to 5 and the Cadets from West Point had too much balance and strength for the Harvard team and scored, 17 to 5 1/2.

While the flood and strikes prevented first-quarter advertising volume from reaching the figures predicted for it, substantial gains by all media were registered in the last three months, according to estimates here yesterday. Newspapers were hardest hit by the various unfavorable developments, with weekly magazines next.

United States Government bonds suffered yesterday the sharpest break in values since the beginning of the current downward movement and one of the most severe declines for a single day in the memory of veteran bankers and dealers.
Samuel J. Tilden's nine registered its third victory in as many days by defeating James Madison, 5-4, and Richmond Hill vanquished Thomas Jefferson, 8-7, in nonleague school games yesterday.
A monoplane named Kamikaze (translatable as Heavenly Breeze) departed at 1:44 A. M. today in an effort to establish a record for the flight to England.

Suggestions that distribution of the relief fund of $1,500,000,000 which President Roosevelt is expected to ask soon from Congress might have an influence on the votes of Senators on the President's proposal to organize the judiciary were made by Senator Burke today at the hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Operations of the Aluminum Company of America and wholly owned subsidiaries in 1936 resulted in a net income of $20,866,936 after all taxes, depreciation, depletion and deduction of $1,228,313 loss from purchase and retirement of preferred stock.

Felix Garcia, Puerto Rico, defeated Joey Zodda, the Bronx, in the six-round feature bout at the Star Casino last night after having his rival on the floor for a count of eight in the first round. Both weighed 135 1/2.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that George A. Ball, Muncie, Ind., glass jar manufacturer, who owns the controlling interest of Mid-America Corporation, top holding company of the so-called Van Sweringen railroad system, had dropped in at the RFC a few days ago.

Why do manufacturing establishments leave New York for other towns and cities? The second report by CHARLES E. MURPHY to Controller TAYLOR on this question must be read in the light of the first report, submitted last December.

An application has been made to the Federal Communications Commission by the Columbia Broadcasting System for permission to construct combined television and sound transmitters at the top of the Chrysler Building, it was disclosed yesterday.

A combined Auckland and Wellington team hit 183 runs against the Marylebone Cricket Club in a match opened today. The M. C. C. players, who left for England at the close of the game, made 56 for no wickets when play concluded for the day.
Presenting a stanch defense that successfully hurled back the most intense drives directed at them, the New York Rangers, defeated the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night, 1 to 0.

Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., sprang the only upset so far in the Atlanta invitation tennis tournament by blasting Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., out in the quarter-finals while other seeded favorites advanced today. Sabin won, 6-2, 7-5.
The labor problem sat down today at the doorsteps of two of America's wealthiest men, Richard K. Mellon and Charles M. Schwab.

Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey Jr. dismissed here today the indictment charging first-degree asSault against Frank Walsh and John J. Corbett, State railway police assigned to the I. R. T., and Harold Wolinsky, a reporter, on charges of beating George Howard of the Bronx, who was accused of placing a slug in the Times Square station of the I. R. T. on Nov. 16, 1934.

William Alexander, secretary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, who died at Winter Park, Fla., on March 25, bequeathed to his daughter, Mrs. Frances Alexander Brooks of 410 Park Avenue, a life interest in his residuary estate.

If the present outlook for the Winter wheat crop is maintained to harvest, a yield of about 665,000,000 bushels would be secured, according to an average of the estimates issued by four leading Chicago statisticians today.

James J. Cain, former police sergeant, who had thirty-six years on the force to his credit when he retired in 1931, died yesterday at his home, 3,300 Bailey Avenue, the Bronx, at the age of 78. He had been ill for several weeks.

Fourteen hundred bags of flour, weighing 196,000 pounds, will be shipped to Spain this week to be made into bread for Loyalist refugees, according to an announcement yesterday by Bishop Francis J. McConnell, chairman of the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy.

Mayor La Guardia administered the oath of office yesterday in City Hall to the three members of his Industrial Relations Board and expressed the hope that the new agency would be useful in settling labor disputes.

Edward Campbell Mason, lawyer and an executive member of many New England corporations, died yesterday at his home in Winchester at the age of 72. He was secretary of the Dorchester Mutual Fire Insurance Company, attorney for the New England Power Association and vice president and treasurer of the Massachusetts Utilities Associates.

Howard Scott, director-in-chief of Technocracy, Inc., who gained wide publicity a few years ago with his economic theory, was the guest of honor at a dinner held last night in honor of his forty-seventh birthday at the Hotel Victoria, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Production of woven cotton goods last year reached more than 8,500,000,000 yards and was the highest since 1927, exceeding the 1935 figures by 20.7 per cent, according to the sixth annual survey of the industry released yesterday by the Association of Cotton-Textile Merchants of New York.
Mr. HERBERT MORRISON, the able and well-liked British Labor leader, is here on a visit and would not presume to interfere in affairs.

Former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, who propounded the "Westchester trustee plan" for rehabilitation of mortgage certificates and then supervised operation of the plan from the- bench for two years, will serve as attorney for trustees controlling more than $7,000,000 of the mortgages, it was announced today by Henry F. Freund.

Claims paid by railroads in 1936 because of loss and damage to freight shipments totaled $20,920,487, against $17,946,049 in 1935, the shippers' regional advisory board reported today. Claims paid last year were greater than for any year since 1931, when they amounted to $24,565,360.
Summary dismissal of a "bewildered" grand jury added another twist today to the already tangled charges and challenges hurled in San Francisco's tumultuous police graft investigation.

Former Colonel Joaquin Ibanez Alarcon, police chief when Manuel Azana, now President, was arrested at Barcelona during the Leftist uprising of 1934, was freed today of a charge of suspicion of having aided the Catalan Fascist-military rebellion of last year.

Those who had the privilege of attending the annual dinner of the American Institute for Persian Art and Archaeology on Wednesday night must have felt that they were for the moment inhabitants of the first of cities, sharing the archaeologist's thrill over the emergence of civilization.

THE plot in the great heavyweight drama thickens as it goes along. Champion James J. Braddock was packing his bag in a hotel room overlooking Central Park yesterday afternoon. Jersey James was allegedly preparing to leave for Chicago.

Six C. I. O. officials and organizers connected with the Lewiston-Auburn general shoe strike were arrested tonight on a warrant charging conspiracy to prevent shoe employes from working. The complaint named fourteen others.

Hec Kilrea, veteran speedster who made Detroit forget the loss of Larry Aurie, slashed home a goal early today to beat the Montreal Canadiens, 2-1, after fifty-one minutes of thrill-packed overtime action in the fifth and deciding game of the National Hockey League championship play-off.
Lumber production increased last week when a slight decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 83.6 from 81.5. It was 76.4 for the week ended March 28, 1936.

Victor Buerger, one of the five English representatives in the international chess masters' tournament, created a sensation today when, in the second round, he defeated Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the former world champion, in fifty-' four moves at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville.

The Monroe Smelting and Refining Works has leased the building at 90 Monroe Street through the Charles F. Noyes Company. The building at 397 Eighth Avenue was leased by H. V. Mead Co. for the estate of Anna G Van Riper.

Yesterday, when 400,000 coal miners stood teetering on the edge of strike, Florence Kathryn Lewis, John L. Lewis's 25-year-old daughter and private secretary, sat quietly smoking cigarettes and reading detective stories.

Mrs. Palmer C. Ricketts, widow of the former director of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, died here early today. The former Vjera Corine Renshaw of Baltimore, Mrs. Ricketts was long prominent in Troy's social and civic life.

Replying sharply to Senator Wagner's declaration in the Senate on Wednesday in defense of the recent sit-down strikes, when he declared that they had been provoked "by the long standing ruthless tactics of a few great corporations," the National Association of Manufacturers issued a statement yesterday charging the Senator with distorting the facts and confusing the issue.

Maurice Levin, president of Hearn's Department Store and one of the major backers of "The Eternal Road," received the fine arts award of the Manischewitz Foundation yesterday for his backing of the production.

After a reaction of $1 a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday to end with net gains of 5 to 9 points. With domestic consumption for March estimated larger than for any month on record and desirable grades of raw material reported becoming increasingly scarce in the South, mill buying of near month and foreign demand for the new crop exerted a steadying influence on the market.
Business activity in the Pittsburgh district improved a little more last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Harvard University was named today to receive the estate of Mrs. Sophia E. Williston of Rumson after the marriage or death of her daughter. Annie Louise.

Following the example of Cambridge University, the Northern English universities of Manchester, Liverpool, Leeds, Sheffield and Birmingham, in addition to the Royal Society, have refused to be represented at the bicentenary celebration at Goettingen University.

Miss Daisy Krey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Krey of 44 Palmetto Street, Brooklyn, was married last night to Arthur Richardson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Richardson, also of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Howard V. Ross in the Bushwick Methodist Episcopal Church.

The American Methodist Episcopal Church Mission in China, which has headquarters in New York, blazed a new mission trail today with a proposal that mission property be placed under Chinese ownershiD and control.

A sound moving picture, "Modern Christian German Martyrs," describing the oppression of non-Jews in Germany under the Nazi government, will have its premiere at the Riverside Church on Monday night, April 12, under the auspices of the American Committee for Christian German Refugees, it was announced yesterday.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: The leave of absence for ten days, effective March 20, 1937, granted 1st Lt. Howard A. Felding, Med.-Res., is extended sixteen days to terminate not later than April 15.

Sales of copper abroad were made yesterday between 16.925 and 17.225 cents a pound. c. i. f. the European base ports, compared with 17.25 to 17.45 cents on Wednesday. This is the first time in several weeks that the foreign price was lower than the domestic level.
Benjamin Charach, prominent in Patchogue business circles for the last thirty-one years, died in his sleep of a heart attack early today at his home here. He was 62 years old.

President Roosevelt told a House delegation that he was agreeable to extension of the Public Works Administration for two years, but was opposed to additional appropriations for it. He discussed his recent appointments to the Maritime Commission with Senator Black and Postmaster General Farley.
Mrs. M. Buckner Royall of Fieldston Old House, Riverdale, will give a supper and dance on Monday at the Plaza for Miss Dorothy Freeman, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Woolsey Freeman.

G. Everett Hunt, lawyer specializing in insurance cases, died last night in Doctors Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 48. Mr. Hunt, who lived at 16 Park Avenue and had offices in the Woolworth Building, had practiced here for twentyfive years.

Notifications of suggested minimum retail prices under the FeldCrawford "Fair Trade" Law were mailed yesterday to retailers by Parke, Davis Co. The price list covers a selected group of about thirty drug products of the company, officials said yesterday.

It is firmly believed here that control of the land and maritime frontiers of Spain will begin on April 10. During the past three weeks Italy has raised all kinds of subsidiary difficulties in order to gain time and extend the period where she could, more or less unobserved, send more men and war materials to Spain.

Senator Royal S. Copeland, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and Representative John J. O'Connor will speak at the Jefferson Day dinner of the National Democratic Club, to be held at the Hotel Commodore on April 10, the 194th anniversary of Jefferson's birth,

Following a visit to City Hall yesterday by officials of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, Mayor La Guardia said that no union on the independent city subway would be recognized for collective bargaining purposes unless it admitted Negroes to its membership.
The stock markets where extremely quiet today due to the approaching end of the account. Gilt-edged issues again improved, but most of the foreign loans were weaker.

A further slight advance in wholesale prices in the week ended on March 27 lifted the general level to the highest point in seven years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, is now 87.8, compared with 87.6 in the previous week and 79.3 a year ago.
During the week ended March 31 memberbank reserve balances increased $61,000,000.

The current canvas in the one-picture exhibition series at the Town Hall Club is "Delices Maternelles," by Jean Honore Fragona d, shown through the courtesy of the Wildenstein Galleries. It will remain on view there until April 12.

A "Mormon" back-to-the-farm movement will be begun shortly. Augmenting a security project to take 80,000 needy members off relief, the plan will be explained at the annual church conference April 4, 5 and 6.

Argentina's exportable surplus wheat has been reduced to 51,258,000 bushels, according to an estimate by the Bureau of Rural Statistics published today. The bureau estimates the exportable surplus of flaxseed at 35,150,000 bushels and corn of the old crop at 19,033,000 bushels.

Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato minimized reports yesterday that a crowd-had threatened a jury outside the Central Courts Building Thursday night after the jury had brought in a guilty verdict against two men who had been charged with robbery.

During a fifteen-minute stop at Melville, Sask., today, Prince Yasuhito Chichibu, brother of the Emperor of Japan, en route to the coronation in London, visited the crew of the engine pulling his train.
The University Fencers Club trio of Warren Dow, Jose de Capriles and Miguel de Capriles retained its national senior three-weapon team championship at the Fencers Club in Manhattan last night.

Petitions Filed-Against COLLAZO CLOTHING CORP., 34 W. 112th St., by M. Slavin, Inc., for $500; Sam. Schwartz, $500; Harry Wolfowitz, $500. Petitions Filed--By HENRY B. CONKLIN, unemployed, Suffern, N. Y.-No schedules filed.

Exports and imports of foodstuffs in February compared with February last year increased 53 per cent and imports 27 per cent, according to an analysis made public today by F. H. Rawls, chief of the Foodstuffs Division, Department of Commerce.

Advices from Oslo last night were that Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, member of the Democratic National Committee for the District of Columbia and a prominent figure in society and in philanthropic work, is to be appointed Minister to Norway to fill a vacancy caused by the forthcoming transfer of Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. to another post, presumably that of Ambassador to Poland.

David H. Clark, 39-year-old former Deputy District Attorney of Los Angeles, who disappeared mysteriously from his home there three months ago, arrived yesterday on the American Export liner Excambion from France, refusing to explain his secret voyages.

President Roosevelt's government reorganization program was analyzed here yesterday as a disguised reach for Fascist powers, in an address before the New York State Chamber of Commerce by John R. McCarl, who was responsible for the proper application of all the public funds of the United States when he was Controller General, from 1921 to 1936.

The Tri-Partite Preparatory Textile Conference, the first one convoked by the International Labor Organization since the United States became a member of it in 1934, will open here tomorrow with delegates from twenty-three nations present.
Paul W. Voorhies, president of the Kresge Foundation, said today S. S. Kresge has made a gift of about $12,500,000. in Kresge stock to the foundation, established in 1924 for charity work.

About 400,000 soft-coal miners in twelve States will stop work this morning as a result of failure last night of representatives of the United Mine Workers and operators to reach an agreement to replace the one that expired at midnight Wednesday.

Brig. Gen. Joseph A. Gaston, U.S.A. (retired), died at his home here yesterday at the age of 80. Born in Honey Brook, Pa., he was graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1881 and commissioned in the cavalry.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hardie Chalmers of this city and Florence, Italy, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vilma Flora Chalmers, to Alfred Hayes, son of Mrs. Alfred Hayes of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Hayes.

Five new fire engines from the apparatus division, 39-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, roared successfully through road tests at sixty miles an hour in the Bronx yesterday morning. They were accompanied by a motorcycle escort from the Police Department.

Residents of Manhattan feared they were sitting on a powder keg in 1687, according to a document found in the archives of the Hall of Records by research workers of the Historical Records Survey, it was made known yesterday. The matter is set forth in the original minutes of the Mayor's Court for May 12 1687.
The police at Canton were reported engaged today in a round-up of all lepers. A dozen lepers were shot last month at Samshui, a town twenty-five miles west of Canton.

The low bid of $37,755 for preliminary borings for seven dams planned as a part of the Hornell Valley channel improvement program was submitted by Sprague Henwood, Inc., of Scranton, Pa., it was announced yesterday by S. J. Leftoff of the First District Engineer's Office, War Department,

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, has sent a letter to stockholders entitled "The Story of the General Motors Strike." He seeks to give them an understanding of the steps taken and the present status of the United Automobile Workers of America as a bargaining agency for those of its members who are General Motors employes.

The annual report for 1936 of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., issued today, shows a consolidated net income of $4,749,846, an increase of $1,255,415 over the 1935 consolidated net of $3,494,430. The 1936 net was equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to $1.58 a share on the average number of shares of common stock outstanding in the year and compared with earnings of $1.32 a share for 1935.
Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities throughout the country amounted to $5,762,202,000 for the week ended on Wednesday according to Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

When Assistant District Attorney Della Paoli had called the last of 179 witnesses yesterday in the three-week Special Sessions trial of ten men and five women in an alleged misdemeanor conspiracy in the distribution of parish hymnals, church calendars and directories, all the defendants were pronounced not guilty, and discharged.

The Greek Government has increased the quota for certain United States imports for the first half of 1937 from $324.000 to $450,000, according to information received from the Acting Commercial Attache at Athens by the Department of Commerce, and made public today.

Two special agents sent to New York by Guy Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue in Washington; two Deputy United States Marshals armed with warrants, and an agent of the Intelligence Unit of the Treasury Department conducted raids yesterday on ticket agencies in two hotels and in several midtown offices in a drive to collect amusement taxes.

In recognition of his services to the Roman Catholic Church, John C. Kelly, president of Kelly, Nason Winsten, advertising agency at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, has been created a Knight of St. Gregory the Great by Pope Pius XI, it became known yesterday.
A $75,000,000 long-range, self-liquidating plan for providing Philadelphia with an unpolluted water supply from the Pocono watershed was proposed today by Mayor Wilson.

David Weinstein of 25 Central Park West, who, with eleven other defendants, was convicted of mail fraud two weeks ago, was sentenced yesterday to three and a half years in prison by Federal Judge John C. Knox.
Following a series of serious films, Barbara Stanwyck is. to return to the lighter side in "They Had to Save Charlie," which R. K. O. purchased today from M. John Bronson.
Two hundred striking employes of the Book-Cadillac Hotel left voluntarily tonight in the face of a police threat to "come in and throw you out."
Prospects for further improvement in all classes of trade between the United States and Britain were termed the best since 1929 in a report of the British Department of Overseas Trade today.
Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, visited the sixteenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Grand Central Palace yesterday afternoon.

The monthly average of commodity prices as of April 1, compiled by Dun Bradstreet, shows a rise during March of less than one-quarter of 1 per cent. It is below the Dun average of Jan. 1, but is 18 3/8 per cent above that of April 1, 1936.

Members of the Metropolitan Club of the Rosemont College Alumnae will have a card party and tea tomorrow in the Garden of the Ambassador to augment the fund for the building of a new chapel at the college.

The ballroom of the Pierre was the setting last night for the Spring Senior Get-Together Dance conducted under the direction of Mrs. Frazier Murray, who has succeeded Miss Edith M. Benjamin. These subscription dances are arranged for future debutantes and young men.

To dramatize the dangers that children face going to and from school, the New York City school system is preparing to make a fulllength motion picture that will emphasize the value of knowing how to cross the street properly and other phases of safety education, Dr. Joseph M. Sheehan, Associate Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.
The body of Mrs. Helen Mason, 31-year-old wife of Patrolman Thomas Mason of the Highbridge police station, who had been missing from her home since March 22.

Baldwin High of Long Island triumphed in the opening round of the eighteenth annual Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament tonight, turning back the Utica Free Academy five, 34-21. The victors held a 19-10 lead at half-time.

Governor Lehman gave his approval today to a bill, sponsored by Assemblyman Stephens of Putnam, which extends for another year the period during which savings banks may continue to invest in certain railroad securities not meeting the strict requirements of the Banking Law.

BREAD AND WINE, by Ignazio Silone. (Harper, $2.50.) A novel of Italy that has been highly praised in Europe. CRUISE OF THE CONRAD, by Alan Villiers. (Scribner, $3.75.) The story of a voyage around the world in a sailing ship.
A majority of the students at Johns Hopkins University voted against the plan for changing the Supreme Court, the poll being sponsored by The News-Letter, campus semiweekly.

The entire Chevrolet plant of General Motors Corporation here, employing 14,750 persons, was shut down at 10:30 o'clock tonight when union workers in all departments struck in sympathy with 1,285 who walked out in two units earlier in the day. This brought to 30,000 the number who have been made idle in General Motors plants here and in Pontiac in the last forty-eight hours.

Because Evaristo Garcia, 18-yearold Nationalist, was caught as a stowaway and locked in the infirmary of the liner Coamo, while she was on the way to Ciudad Trujillo, Dominican Republic, he started to burn the ship to seek his freedom, he admitted to United States Commissioner Ramon Julia today.
Engineering contracts totaling $888,556.31 were awarded by the War Department today as follows: Norfolk Dredging Company, Norfolk, Va., for dredging Washington Harbor, D. C.-$154,432.

About the only consolation traders could find yesterday in the severe drop in government bond values was that it brought that group close to the 3 per cent yield basis, a level which, since the decline continued unabated through the 2 3/4 and then the 2 7/8 per cent basis, has now been widely accepted as the halting point.

A K'ang-hsi peachbloom chrysanthemum bottle was sold for $2,400 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the collection of Chinese porcelains formed by the late J. Horace Harding. The buyer was Roger Norden.

The Morgan, Building, office structure at 39 Prospect Avenue, Mount Vernon, which has been in the hands of the Morgan family since 1898, has been sold to the Samjohn Realty Company, Samuel Kann, president, for investment.

It is not surprising to find the committee chairmen of Congress recoiling from the idea of more taxes. More taxes? The Federal Government has already imposed more taxes than ever before in its history.

A month ago the war in Spain seemed about to end in a Franco victory. Developments of the past fortnight, particularly the precipitate events of the past few days, have altered both picture and prospect.

Dartmouth staved off a ninth-inning rally by the William and Mary nine today and triumphed, 6-4. The home club had the bases crowded in the final frame but Relief Pitcher Clifford forced Metheny to fly out to third to close the ining.
Governor Allred urged today the immediate passage of a bill strengthening anti-narcotic laws, asserting he was advised that the narcotics condition in Texas is "probably the worst in the Union."
Mrs. H. Edward Manville is returning tomorrow to Hi-Esmaro, her home in Pleasantville, N. Y., after passing the Winter at Jekyl Island, Ga. Mr. Manville returned to Pleasantville March 20.

The appointment of William C. Campbell as passenger traffic manager of the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company and the New York and Puerto Rico Steamship Company and of John A. Hanssler as general freight traffic manager of the Anchor Line division of the Waterman Steamship Agency was announced here yesterday.
Dr. William W. Lazarus, World War hero and Republican State Committeeman, died at his home in Tunkhannock today at the age of 58. He was educated at the Medical School of Columbia University.

The second annual exhibition by artists of Palm Beach and vicinity at the Society of the Four Arts was opened tonight with a preview and reception at the salon, to which members of the art committee were hosts. They also selected the eighty canvases and sculptures from the 140 submitted. These represent sixty artists from sixteen Florida cities.

Frank J. Costello, 35, an attorney, was elected the seventy-sixth Republican member of the State Assembly today in a special election in Onondaga County's Third District. He defeated William Disque, Democrat, by 19,348 to 8,139, a plurality of 11,209. Mr. Costello succeeds the late Richard B. Smith, who died late in February.

John Sargent Newbold, an investment broker and member of a prominent old Philadelphia family, died at his home, Newbold Vernon, in Jenkiitown last night in his sixty-third year. He had been ill for about two years.

Joseph Stalin's speech of last month, published this morning, urging the Communist party to get in closer touch with the masses, made an enormous impression here, and conversations with individual Russians indicate it is evoking a very favorable reaction from a people shocked and bewildered by exposures of sabotage and treachery.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ending March 20 totaled 291,555,000 barrels, according to figures compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Section 1-B of New Jersey's Fair Trade Practice Act, declared "utterly meaningless" yesterday by Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow in Newark, has the identical wording of the same section in New York State's act, it was brought out today in a study of fair trade legislation in the several States.
Spanish Government airplanes began a vigorous bombardment of Insurgent-held Ceuta, Spanish Morocco, late today. The explosions were heard over this entire rock, across the narrow straits.

Mrs. Dorothy C. Bennett, formerly secretary to Judge Genevieve R. Cline of the United States Customs Court, was appointed yesterday a special attorney on the staff of Assistant United States Attorney, General Joseph R. Jackson of the customs division.

In charge of the best-conditioned squad of ball players he has taken out of this tropical training ground in years, Joseph Vincent McCarthy tonight led forth his champion Yankees on a Spring exhibition tour that will carry them through eight States. The first stop is Tallahassee.

Scovill Manufacturing Company of Waterbury, Conn., has filed a registation statement under the Securrities Act of 1933 covering 174,473 shares of $25 par value capital stock, installment subscription receipts and full and fractional subscription rights to buy shares.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of Newport News, Va., has offered to build a new cabin liner of the Manhattan and Washington type for $14,375,000, which was $620,000 below the bid of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N. J., according to bids opened at noon today by the Maritime Commission.
Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, one of the directors of the Maryland Jockey Club, was appointed today as general chairman of the Preakness Ball Committee following a dinner at the Southern Hotel.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin K. Gatins of 1,165 Park Avenue and Wyndyway, Rumson, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Hope Gatins, to James Freeman Curtis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Freeman Curtis of this city, Washington and Willowmere, Roslyn, L. I.

Broadway Department Store, Inc., will redeem on May 1 all of the issued and outstanding shares of both its 7 per cent cumulative first preferred and its 7 per cent non-cumulative second preferred stock, it was announced yesterday.

A barge captain, angered by boys who threw stones at him as he was towed along the Bronx River, shot one of them in the leg yestedray afternoon. He was arrested after a two-mile chase during which the police used an amphibian plane, an emergency squad, several radio cars, a Coast Guard boat and all available patrolmen and detectives.

With many women fliers and women active in other fields as her fellow-guests, Mrs. Louise Thaden of Bentonville, Ark., received yesterday the Harmon Trophy as the "outstanding woman flier in the United States in 1936" at a luncheon in her honor at the Advertising Club of New York. President Roosevelt sent congratulations through a telegram from his secretary, Marvin McIntyre.

Those rough and tough fellows from the other side of the river came rollicking into the Dodgers' private ball park today, and when the statistics of the day's doings were assembled. the totals were extremely embarrassing to. Burleigh Grimes.

The six-story apartment house at 295 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, running through to Waverly Place, has been purchased by David S. Meister from the Mopaul Realty Corporation. The house, on a plot 00 by 180 feet, accommodates seventy-six families.

The New York City Tunnel Authority received yesterday a check for $1,000,000, representing the second installment of PWA funds for use in construction of the Queens Midtown Vehicular Tunnel under the East River.
Passage of the Joseph-Pack Mort Albany, is urged by O. H. Cheney, former Superintendent of Banks and at present chairman of the committee on real estate securities of the New York Building Congress.
Three men boarded a well-filled B. M. T. subway train at 10 A. M. yesterday at Canal Street, held up a jewelry salesman and his assistant and escaped with gems valued at $10,000.
Turning from musical shows to the drama, Vinton Freedley tonight presented "Miss Quis," a modern comedy of Southern life by Ward Morehouse. The cast is headed by Peggy Wood and James Rennie.
Ridge Mor, a 6-year-old son of Morvich owned by Miss A. Doris, upset the form players today at Tropical Park in the featured Doubloon Handicap, which attracted five Class C horses.

The Niagara Hudson Corporation system took another step yesterday toward the simplification of its corporate structure, with the filing of a certificate of consolidation by three of the operating units of the system with the Department of State.
Turning from musical shows to the drama, Vinton Freedley tonight presented "Miss Quis," a modern comedy of Southern life by Ward Morehouse. The cast is headed by Peggy Wood and James Rennie.
Ridge Mor, a 6-year-old son of Morvich owned by Miss A. Doris, upset the form players today at Tropical Park in the featured Doubloon Handicap, which attracted five Class C horses.

The Niagara Hudson Corporation system took another step yesterday toward the simplification of its corporate structure, with the filing of a certificate of consolidation by three of the operating units of the system with the Department of State.

Rioting broke out in Rhode Island's House of Representatives this afternoon as a result of heated debate over a measure designed to place administration of Pawtucket's police, fire and public works departments in the hands of a commission.
Officials of Miami Beach, Fla., have invited tenders for a new issue of $1,938,000 of sewer, paving, bridge, water, police and fire station bonds, award of which will be made on April 26.

Trading showed some slight improvement. Veal and lamb continued to move slowly and fresh pork cuts were not very active except at weak prides. Toppy steer hinds and ribs were steady to strong, but others showed some weakness. Veal continued weak to lower. Lamb sold unevenly, strictly good and choice kinds were scarce and higher and others lower. Fresh pork sold steady to weak.

One of the most important conferences,in the history of the Little Entente began this morning among Foreign Ministers Kamil Krofta of Czechoslovakia and Victor Antonescu of Rumania and Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia.

The Federal Reserve Board and the United States Treasury, working together, have ample funds to keep the government bond market orderly, Secretary Morgenthau said today. He added that money flowed in and out of the Treasury all the time and there was sufficient for that purpose.

The General Telephone Corporation, constituting the largest group of telephone companies outside the Bell System, shows in its annual report for 1936 a consolidated net income of $1,299,911, after all charges and taxes. including undistributed profits tax. This is an increase of $313,961, or 31.8 per cent, over the preceding year.
The tanker Marajo; built in New England for the Brazilian Navy, is due here tomorrow. She is the first of three similar fuel ships ordered for the navy.

In a formal statement contradicting "statements and publications apparently emanating from those representing the city," the Transit Commission denied yesterday that it was in any way seeking to delay its decision on the $436,000,000 transit unification plan drawn by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr.

Certificates of deposit for New York Dock Company 5 per cent serial gold notes due in 1988 have been admitted to the list by the New York Stock Exchange. Tennessee Central Railway Company first-mortgage 6 per cent bonds, Series A and B, due in 1947, and Ohio River Railroad Company general mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds due in 1937 have been suspended from Exchange dealings.

MANHATTAN TRANSFERS Grand St., n. w. cor. Lewis St., 50x85; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co. to River Drive Apartments, Inc.. 570 7th Av., care of Fairing Bernstein ($40). exington Av., 318, 19x75; Victoria Bergles to Gilbert N. Parker and wife, 245 Martine Av., White Plains; mtgs., $25,000 ($8.50).
Directors of the Atlantic Coast Fisheries Company declared yesterday a cash dividend of 35 cents a share on the common stock, the first dividend paid by the company since June, 1930.

While the Raw Silk Price Stabilization Act technically went into effect in Japan yesterday, it was without effect in the local market. Leading executives in the silk trade here said they expected it would be a year or more before the act began to function.
The Supreme Court decision validating State minimum wage legislation set Labor Department officials today to studying the possibility of a model minimum wage law for all States.

The will of Dr. C. Purdy Lintisley, offered today for probate and disposing of an estate estimated at $1,000,000, contained a gift of $150;000 to erect and furnish a new church for St. Thomas Episcopal Church, of which Dr. Lindsley was a vestryman for forty years.

Defeat of the Esquirol-Hill bill in the Legislature, on the ground it would deprive Yonkers and other cities in the State "or virtually every chance" of having referendums on city manager charters and other governmental changes, was urged today by officers of the Yonkers City Manager Committee.

A marriage contract between Peter J. Bitterman Jr., an architect, of 106 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, and Miss Eleanor Andrus, artist, of Oswego, Ore., was acknowledged before Justice John E. McGeehan in Supreme Court yesterday.

A potpourri of mirth and melody was served up to a capacity audience last night at the Pauline Edwards Theatre, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, at the presentation of "Don't Look Now," an original musical revue, marking the fiftieth annual production of the City College Dramatic Society.

Robert Frost, twice winner of the Pulitzer prize for poetry, diagnosed the current ills of the world last night. He said we had lost sight of our inevitable progress forward between two opposites, in a myopic belief that we are only rushing sidewise toward one extreme or the other.

When the River Drive Apartments, Inc.. Charles Bernstein, president, bought from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co. the six-story tenement on the northwest corner of Grand and Lewis Streets for $40,000 the bank took back a purchase-money mortgage for $33,000, payable five years hence at 4 per cent.

The value of funds of the New York Community Trust rose to a new high of $8,764,712 at the end of 1936, compared with $8,419,742 in 1935, according to the annual report of the organization made public yesterday.

Optimistic over the outlook for the fine clothing business, Douglas J. Crawford, executive vice president of Rogers Peet Company, sailed yesterday on the Ile de France for his semi-annual visit to the European markets.

Wrapped in a blanket by a companion when the flame from an eyelash beading candle ignited her tulle ballet skirt, Miss Joan Bergere, 16 years old, of 3,495 Broadway, a member of the Allen K. Foster girls troupe, was saved from possibly serious burns at 9 o'clock last night in a dressing room at the Hippodrome Theatre.

Statutes compelling school children to salute the national flag and pledge allegiance to the government form no violation of constitutional rights in any matter of religion, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today.

If American railroad executives can induce employes to pay attention to such signs as "fragile" and "this end up," stop them from throwing packages and discourage trainmen from coupling freight cars with a crash, they hope to save millions of dollars this year.

George Fotheringhame, 57 years old, of 198 North Fifteenth Street, Newark, discovered fire late today in the residence of his son-in-law, Stanley Murphy, at 262 North Park Street here, ran a hundred yards to turn in an alarm and then fell dead.

The railroads paid $20,920,487 in loss and damage claims in 1936, the largest total since 1931, when it was $24,565,360, according to statement issued yesterday by the Shippers Regional Advisory Boards. Claims paid in 1935 amounted to $17,946,049.

Mayor La Guardia will be guest of honor tonight at Madison Square Garden for the performance of "Aida" to be given by the Hippodrome Opera Company under the auspices of Local 89, International Ladies Garment Workers Union for their membership.

The islands of Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard were cut off from the outside world today as members of the crews of the two steamers, New Bedford and Martha's Vineyard, went out on strike shortly before sailing time of the mid-morning boat, forcing both vessels to stay at their pier in this city.

Adam A. Stricker, a trial lawyer in this city for the last thirty years, died Wednesday night of heart disease at his home, 325 East Fiftyseventh Street. Mr. Stricker, who was 58 years old, had his office at 15 Park Place.
Two more milestones along Germany's rearmament road have been reached, it was learned yesterday. One of these milestones is being quietly passed now, it is believed.

While trading in wool goods was seasonably quiet during the past week, prices were strong, with an advancing tendency, and mills continued busy on the large contracts booked in the last six weeks, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Observing that the business upswing continued in March, the National City Bank in its monthly letter, published yesterday, says that the area over which "boom conditions" prevail is undoubtedly widening.
The Ontario Department of Labor today found a way out of the deadlock forestalling negotiations between General Motors of Canada and employes at its Oshawa plants.

Awards for engineering construction during the last week of March reached a total of $34,678,000, which represented a loss of 21 per cent over the figure for the same period of last year, according to the Engineering News-Record.

A diversified list of businesses was represented in the reports by brokers yesterday of commercial leasing. Most of the units taken were between Fourteenth and Fifty-seventh Streets. The list follows:

Contending that the city had no power to regulate fees charged for finding jobs, the Abbye Employment Agency, 112 West Fortysecond Street, asked Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer yesterday to restrain License Commissioner Moss from suspending its permit to operate. Commissioner Moss had ordered the agency closed Tuesday on the ground that it had overcharged a client.

Henry M. Bates, dean of the Law School of the University of Michigan, recited his piece to a former pupil when he testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee today in opposition to President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize the judiciary.

A one-family house will be erected at 31 Nottingham Road in Short Hills, Millburn, N. J., a vacant plot with a frontage of 125 feet sold by Arthur M. Seltz to the Leo Building Company. Leslie Blau, Inc., was the broker.

The examining magistrate at Ceret, a near-by town, today began hearing the cases of twenty-five United States and other volunteers who were arrested yesterday as they tried to reach Spain in an open boat from Port Vendres.

The Czechoslovak Government took action today to invoke wartime military field courts in time of peace-a powerful weapon for the safeguarding of the nation's democracy against possible attempts to overthrow it in its predominantly German borderland.

The eighth shipment of gold consigned to the Federal Treasury vaults at Fort Knox, Ky., was placed on a special train last night at Pennsylvania Station. This shipment of $180,000,000 brings the total of the series to $1,230,000,000.

Still defiant after thirty-three hours of almost continuous questioning, broken only by his attendance at the funeral of his murdered wife and daughter, Joseph Gedeon, 54-year-old upholsterer, was arrested at 8:15 o'clock last night on a charge of possessing a pistol without a permit.

Further widespread gains marked commodity prices in general during the week, and The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices accordingly advanced to 145.7 on March 30 from 144.6 on the Tuesday previous.
The first day of the new Constitution was marked as a day of mourning and a general stoppage of work was declared by the All-India Congress party in token of its pledge to wreck the new regime.
A nationwide movement to combat the sitdown strike was begun today by the executive committee of the National Automobile Dealers Association.

The Dickstein resolution proposing an investigation by a special House committee of "un-American propaganda" of alleged Nazi, Fascist and Communist origin was reported to the House today by its Rules Committee.

Mr. and Mrs. Wilder H. Ripley and Lloyd Aspinwall Jr. gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Eilzabeth Van C. Smith and William Gardner Mundy, who will be married next Friday in St. Bartholomew's Church.

The Embassy Suite of the Ambassador was thronged last night for the Bassinet dinner dance given for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, which cares for homeless infants until they are placed with foster parents.

As part of a plan for consolidating its commercial accounting work in Manhattan the Consolidated Edison Company has leased from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company the eleven-story building at 35-45 Irving Place and 111 East Sixteenth Street.

A fifth-inning home run by Jim (Rip) Collins, new Bruin first-sacker, gave the Cubs a 1-to-O triumph over the White Sox today in an exhibition game marked by mid-season form of pitchers for both clubs.

James T. Reid, Crescent Athletic Club professional, advanced to the semi-finals of the world open squash tennis championship tournament at the Hotel Shelton last night by beating Gerard T. Baxter, Crescent amateur, 15-11, 15-11, 13-18, 15-8, in a quarter-final engagement.

A protective committee for the common stockholders of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation has been organized, it was announced yesterday. It is represented by Hamilton Pell, Cecil P. Stewart, George N. Armsby and Aaron Colnon and, according to plans announced, will try to work out a situation on behalf of the common stockholders.

The first public portrayal of the 1939 World's Fair in the Empire State Building creates for the visitor the liveliest anticipations of a place of wonders and beauty, and blows away even the skeptic's doubts.

Because he intends "to pass about ten months of the year cruising in Southern waters," William B. Leeds, sportsman, has decided to auction off his fifty-four acre waterfront estate Kenwood on the North Shore of Long Island.

Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler ruled yesterday that trustees of defaulted mortgage certificate issues could withhold payments to the guaranteeing title companies on certificates owned by them and apply the funds so retained to making good their guarantees.

Miss Blanche Morrison Opp of this place, daughter of the late- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wellington Opp of Brooklyn and Plainfield, was married tonight to Daniel L. J. de Vlaming of New York and Amsterdam, Holland, son of Cornelius De Vlaming. of Amsterdam.

Several hundred union auto workers evacuated the main motor plant of the Chevrolet Motor Company here tonight, after having held possession for nearly twenty-four hours. They voted to evacuate soon after 9 P. M. and all but a handful of the men had left the building by 10:30.

Three recommendations designed to "prevent, so far as humanly possible, a recurrence of the conditions" which caused the Bronx building collapse of last June in which eighteen workmen were killed were contained in the presentiment of the grand jury which investigated the crash.

Frederick H. McDevitt of this city today announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Mary Joan McDevitt, to John Francis Whitehead, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Whitehead of New Haven. The wedding will take place in the Autumn.
The aftermath of Easter will be observed in the churches tomorrow with sermons, candle-light services, pageants, oratorios and cantatas. In almost every church the Easter music will be repeated.
President Roosevelt sought today to dispel conclusively the persistent reports that he is on the verge of making a peace move in Europe.

A four-way tie for first place was brought about today by the results recorded in the third round of the annual Easter chess congress in progress at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville. Reuben Fine, the only American in the competition; Jan Foltys of Czechoslovakia, Paul Keres of Estonia and Sir George Thomas of England, the leaders,

Chancellor Josiah O. Wolcott has issued an order giving Charles G. Guth authority to deposit certificates for 52,000 shares of Loft, Inc., with Laird, Bissell Meeds, a brokerage concern, for sale. The order directs that the proceeds go to George R. McDougall, sequestrator appointed by the chancellor.

Shiloh Tabernacle, historic house of worship in Zion, was razed by fire this morning, and the destruction was blamed tonight by Wilbur Glenn Voliva on "enemies" of his Christian Catholic Apostolic Church.

A funeral service for Frank G. Griswold, who had been a director of the Metropolitan Opera Company for many years, was held yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

Miss Helen Greene Clegg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Clegg of Chestnut Hill, was married this evening to John Stephen Peake, son of Mrs. Edwin Earnest Peake of Overbrook and the late Mr. Peake. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Ivan Murray Rose in the First Baptist Church.

While about 100 employes worked on advertising displays in the rear of a loft, four well-dressed young thugs, all armed, walked into the offices of the Superior Die Cutting Company on the fourth floor of 95 Morton Street late yesterday afternoon and escaped with a $2,600 payroll.

Weakness in stocks and commodity markets in general had only a temporary effect on grains on the Board of Trade here today, and, while there was considerable local pressure and also liquidation by scattered longs early, prices turned upward later on general buying which swept aside all opposition.

Several hundred workers, protesting what they called discrimination in selection of men to be laid off, closed the Ford assembly plant here with a sit-down strike late today in the first blow at the Ford organization in the current series of automotive strikes.

Rain early today put out forest fires that had been running along the western side of High Tor Mountain for several days. Since the New York dramatic critics selected "High Tor" as the best play of the season the mountain has been the center of attention here.

Miss Natalie M. Tait, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. B. Tait of this city, was married to Robert Davenport Bogert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Virgil Bogert of Demarest, N. J., this evening in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church here.

Poor propaganda techniques by the opponents of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals, unless modified in the near future, may prove the boomerang that will defeat their own purposes, Professor Clyde R. Miller of Teachers College declared yesterday.

National Distillers Products Corporation has filed an answer to the Federal Trade Commission's complaint of price-fixing which denies charges that its practices are in violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act, it was learned today at the office of the commission.

With six weeks of intensive training behind him and his machine already stripped for wartime action, Colonel Bill Terry moved his Giants into this seething metropolis of the South today to launch a final fortnight's drive that should bring his club to the starting mark on April 20 either marvelously conditioned or frightfully fatigued. The old Colonel is confident it will be the former.

President Roosevelt's statement at his press conference yesterday that the government would seek to divert its spending program from channels which lead to stimulation of the durable goods industries to those which lead to increased demand for consumer goods received a confused but generally unfavorable response in financial circles.

Three full-grown oriental plane trees, or sycamores, that for forty years have shaded the roadside at C. F. Hostetter's tobacco farm in Pennsylvania, were dug up, brought here on trucks and planted yesterday on the World's Fair site in Flushing Meadows.

Will H. Hays, in his annual report as president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, said yesterday that the marked improvement in the cinema during the last fifteen years had proved the efficacy of self-regulation-rather than imposed legislation-in developing the motion picture artistically as well as commercially.

FROM BRYAN TO STALIN, by William Z. Foster. (International Publishers, $3.) The autobiography of a radical leader. RESTORATION CARNIVAL: CATHERINE OF BRAGANZA AT THE COURT OF CHARLES II, by Maurice Bethell Jones. (Messner, $3.) A romantic biography.
Louis Torre, local C. I. O. organizer, told the Casco Corporation today that the voluntary wage increase and reduction in working hours, offered yesterday by the management, were unsatisfactory.
Ten thousand pilots, both active and reserve in the Italian air force, thronged Rome today in preparation for official ceremonies tomorrow before the Unknown Soldier's Tomb.
The Chamber Music Society of America will present the Maganini chamber symphony in a concert this evening at the Fifth Avenue Galleries of the Grand Central Art Galleries.

Brown Prep of Philadelphia and Morristown (N. J.) High School will play tomorrow night for the championship of the eighteenth annual Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament as both came through the semi-final round tonight.
Captain Robert Rutherfurd Morris Emmet, U. S. N., and Mrs. Emmet gave a large reception yesterday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Beulah Eaton Emmet.

Instead of the recession which usually accompanies the post-Easter period, many key cities reported substantial increases in retail sales this week over last week's figures, as a result of more favorable weather conditions, the gain for the country averaging around 2 to 5 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

When murder was committed within a few minutes of the rise of the curtain on Anthony Armstrong's "Mile Away Murder" the audience at the Duchess Theatre tonight soon found a dozen reasons for believing they had discovered the murderer.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 27 amounted to 761,109 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,840 cars, or 0.2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 166,320 cars, or 28 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 144,589 cars, or 23.5 per ce?? more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

The German battleship Admiral Scheer arrived at Algeciras this morning. The Netherland warships Java and Hertog Hendrik, patrolling off Gibraltar, are keeping a careful watch on the movements of several Insurgent armed trawlers in the Straits.

The parish house adjoining St. James Episcopal Church at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street will be demolished and a new fireproof building will be erected on the same site.

Championship racing dates for the member clubs of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound were set last night at a meeting of that organization in the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street, at which Clinton H. Crane, president, presided.
The seven-year saga of the new postoffice at Leroy, N. Y., was related today by a spokesman for the Treasury Procurement Division, which supervises the construction of such buildings.

The British, Australian and New Zealand Governments have agreed in principle to joint control of the Trans-Tasman air mail service. It is understood that the agreement was largely influenced by the British Government's intimation that failing agreement it would authorize the Imperial Airways to operate the service.
Judge J. Lank Supplee, member of the Supreme Court bench of Baltimore since 1934 and United States commissioner during the prohibition era, died of pneumonia today-at his home at the age of 59.

New England witnesses stood unanimously opposed tonight to an inland waterway from Montreal to New York, via Lake Champlain, as an international commission representing Canada and the United States adjourned a two-day hearing to Washington next Tuesday and Wednesday.

The Robert W. Hunt Company, international engineers, leased from the Charles F. Noyes Company the two-story Colonial-front building under construction at 59 Murray Street. The structure, a duplicate of a 1602 Salem (Mass.) dwelling, is being completed by G. Richard Davis Co., builders.

Sales increases of 15 to 200 per cent have been registered by the Town Tavern and Windsor brand of the National Distillers Products Corporation, as the result of the "spotlight" drive in a wide list of newspapers inaugurated three weeks ago.

The only winners of three straight games in the current National Hockey League play-offs, the New York Rangers will seek to make it four in a row tomorrow night when they carry on their quest for the Stanley Cup against the Maroons.
Bond Stores, Inc., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 155,000 shares of common stock of $1par. Of this stock, 105,000 shares are issued and outstanding.

James W. Sanders, owner of a chain of nine cotton spinning mills in the South, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, 2 West 106th Street, after a long illness. Mr. Sanders, who was 71 years old, had residences in Meridian and Jackson, Miss.

The political atmosphere in India is again charged. In a manner suggestive of the beginning stages of some of its earlier struggles against British rule, the All-India Congress party, by calling a day of mourning and general stoppage of work on April 1 when the new Constitution became legally operative, declared its purpose not to cooperate in the provincial governments on the basis of that document.
Mrs. Mary Murray Brown, who, as Marie Stanley, was an actress for forty years up to her retirement eighteen years ago, died yesterday at Community Hospital here. She was 76 years old.

Fred Coronado, 23, of New York City, a student pilot, was killed today in the crash of his training plane which spun into the earth at an isolated point four miles northeast of the Tulsa Municipal Airport.
Senator Norris advocated today that the people vote directly on proposed constitutional changes in the next general election after submission of an amendment.

Although the number of entrants at the thirteenth annual- pet show of the Kips Bay Boys' Club, 301 East Fifty-second Street, was smaller than last year, the noise, if anything, was greater. Of the eighty odd animals entered, some thirty were dogs.

James Martin Daly, rowing expert and Philadelphia lawyer, died of a heart attack today at his home here at the age of 50. Mr. Daly was a brother of former Civil Service Commissioner Thaddeus M. Daly Jr., with whom and another brother, Louis J. Daly, he was associated in the law firm of T. M. Daly, of which he was senior member.

President Roosevelt today approved the Navy Selection Board's recommendations for the promotion of 187 officers of the line to be elevated from the rank of lieutenant to lieutenant commander, and 270 lieutenants, junior grade, to be lieutenants.

Gertrude Bonime, pianist, and the Gordon String Quartet collaborated in a concert given last night at the Concert League Hall. It was the third event in the chamber music series sponsored by the Ernest Bloch Society.

A revival of the town meeting to facilitate education was advocated here today at a conference of adult education leaders from New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Delaware. The 1,000 delegates met in the War Memorial Building.
Merger of the Arnot Pine Creek Railroad with the Tioga Railroad has been approved by the State. The consolidated companies will operate as the Tioga Railroad Company.

Miss Peggy Reynolds, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry C. Reynolds of this city, and Robert Rowe Hertzler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver H. Hertzler of Lancaster, Pa., were married tonight in Blanchard Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church by the pastor of the church, the Rev. Dr. George T. Talbott.
The Minister of Education issued a decree today dissolving the militant anti-Semitic Nationalist students' organizations in Warsaw and Vilna Universities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of April 1, entitled "Explaining Sit-Downs," you advert to my statement concerning the unhealthy trends of profits, production, wages and hours in the automobile industry. In my Senate address of March 31 I said:

Contract awards on invitations opened at the quartermaster depot recently were made today as follows: Invitation 241, for 40,025 pairs of olive drab woolen gloves, went to the Gloversville Knitting Co. at 61 1/2 cents per pair, less 1 per cent 20 days.

Mr. and Mrs. George Emlen Roosevelt, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Poole, Captain and Mrs. L. R. Leahy, Dr. and Mrs. W. E. Weiss, Dr. and Mrs. Charles T. Martin, Archbishop J. C. McGuigan, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Morse and Mr. and Mrs. D. P. Hopkins are among those leaving today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian motorshin Conte Di Savoia.

Comes a lull in the day's occupations. The regular opera season is at an end. Mr. Anderson has again received the nice medal designed by Henry Varnum Poor, this time for "High Tor." Miss Cornell has been received with appropriate ceremonies at the White House.
Brazilian Treasury officials and representatives of foreign bankers here will re-initiate their parleys next week in an effort to find a formula for payment of Brazil's foreign debt.

ACKLEY, GRACE (March 21), Estate, more than $10,000. To Blanche Lawrence, 356 South First Av., Mt. Vernon, N. Y., and Lilly Dippel, 1,090 Stonewall Lane, Secaucus, N. J., sisters, one-third wearing apparel, jewelry, furniture and 15 per cent residue each;

Village Boy Rex was the winner of the junior all-age event sponsored by the South Jersey Field Trial Club on the grounds of the English Setter Club today. Despite a gale that rendered scenting extremely difficult, this white and liver pointer by Village Boy-Monroeville Lady turned in a creditable performance.

Employing the same deft touch that has brought him thirteen championships, Ralph Greenleaf climbed into a tie for the lead in the world pocket billiard title tournament at Ponzi's Academy yesterday by means of a 125-37 victory over Fay Gainer of Vineland, N. J.
Frank Jenkins, slender South Carolina youngster with a fine left jab, led college stars into the finals of the national collegiate boxing championships tonight.

The Museum of the City of New York opened yesterday a permanent room for the exhibition of manuscripts, which will offer opportunity from time to time to show some of the rare and unusual manuscripts in the institution's collection.
John Henry Lewis stretched his St. Louis winning stretch to six straight in two years tonight when he was awarded a technical knockout in the fifth round over Donald (Reds) Barry of Washington, D. C.

Trading was only fair to slow generally. Some steer cuts were higher and fresh pork cuts were steady to lower. Other classes were mostly unchanged. Due to the Jewish holidays, there was practically no cattle nor vealers slaughtered. There was only a light lamb kill in several houses. The balance were dark. There were no kosher markets, the Department of Agriculture reported yesterday.

American factory wages, in terms of buying power, are higher today than ever before in history, according to a statement issued by John W. O'Leary, president of the Machinery Institute, in connection with the publication of an institute pamphlet "Technology and the American Consumer."

Governor Elmer A. Benson tonight called "an outrage" the action of deputy sheriffs in breaking picket lines around the American Gas Machine Company's plant today, and said that a tear-gas attack on union headquarters had "no justification."

Adelphi lost to Staunton Military Academy today, 10-4 concluding its Southern trip. Staunton pounded the offerings of four Adelphi pitchers for twelve hits. Bill Laux led the attack with three safeties, two of them being home runs. Cadet Johnson and Griffin of Adelphi also hit circuit blows.

Net profit of the General Refractories Company for 1936 amounted to $1,576,255 after depreciation, depletion, interest, amortization, extraordinary charges, Federal and State income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings, it was reported yesterday.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Ellen McAdoo De Onate, 21, daughter of Senator McAdoo and granddaughter of Woodrow Wilson, obtained a divorce today from Rafael De Onate, 40, an actor, on a charge of non-support.

President Roosevelt expressed confidence In a message read at the opening today of the Technical Tripartite Conference on the Textile Industry that the frank interchange of discussions would have a far-reaching effect on the prosperity of the industry and the 12,000,000 workers who rely upon it for their livelihood.
Nadia Boulanger, head of the Department of Music Composition of the Ecole Normale in Paris and of the Fontainebleau School of Music, will arrive Monday for a brief visit to this country.

Though Samuel H. Collom of Philadelphia is expected to seek a transfer of the North American zone Davis Cup final from Forest Hills to the Germantown Cricket Club at today's Spring meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association executive committee, there were strong indications yesterday that the U. S. L. T. A. would not reconsider its earlier decision.

An aliotment of $892,470 for park development in Queens County was included in $7,229,177 released today with the President's approval by Works Administrator Harry L. Hopkins. New York State projects included in the total amount involve allotments of $1,245,262, New Jersey $124,158 and Connecticut $10,770.

Paced by Captain Carlos Rubio, the Culver Military Academy polo team defeated the Princeton junior varsity horsemen, 14 1/2--7, today in the riding hall. Rubio scored seven times for the Middle Western champions and accounted for two points of his team's first-period lead. The line-up:

A fight to regain control of Midamerica, top holding company for the Van Sweringen railroad empire, will be made in the courts in behalf of the estate of the brothers' partnership, it was indicated today.

ACKER, ALBERT W. Sr. (Feb. 23, 1935). Gross assets, $2,921; net, $2,219. To Albert W. Acker Jr., Chauncey H. Acker and Winifred A. Button, children, residue equally. Chief assets, real estate, $2,500. Charles E. Winslow, attorney, 423 Simpson Pl., Peekskill, N. Y.

About 100 delegates from typographical unions in New York State, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware are expected to attend the Empire State Conference of Printing Trades at the Hotel Plymouth, 143 West Forty-ninth Street, this morning, in a move to stabilize wages and working conditions in the printing trade, it was announced yesterday by William Ward, president of Typographical Union No. 6, otherwise known as "Big Six."
The stock markets continued quiet today, the principal influence seemingly being the end of the account. Gilt-edged issues were firm and the movements in the foreign list small.

An impression of one of the greatest of all etchings, Rembrandt's so-called "Hundred Guilder Print" or "Christ Healing the Sick," was sold for $10,500 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the print collection of the late Leonard L. Stein of this city.
A State-owned power authority, to provide cheaper electricity for consumers and higher wages for employes, was urged at a State League for Industrial Democracy conference here tonight.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $9,464,034, to be represented by one State and fifty-two municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $18,118,262 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $39,821,815.

Federal officers stood guard today over the $25,000 "throne car" of John Hunt, self-styled "St. John the Revelator," prepared to arrest the cult leader on immoral conduct charges if he returns to inspect his motorized chariot.
Bracebridge Hall, a ten-story apartment house on a plot 104 by 137 feet at 416 Ocean Avenue, corner of Caton Avenue, was sold by L. A. Pincus to the Alpine Management, Inc., for investment.

The 110-year-old schism of the Religious Society of Friends, commonly known as Quakers, was formally ended yesterday at the first business gathering of the 242d session of the New York yearly meeting, at the Friends Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.

The Delaware Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, comprising Negro congregations in New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware, Virginia, Philadelphia and New York City, went on record today in opposition to the proposed merger of Methodist denominations.

Mrs. Margaret Elizabeth Tayler Sutton, daughter of Lieut. Commander Robert Raleigh Yates, U.S.N., and Mrs. Yates of Portsmouth, Va., was married yesterday afternoon here at the Salisbury to Major Philip Nelson Bush, Air Corps Reserve, by the Rev. Frank Peer Beal.

Approval of the State Banking Department has been given to an increase of capital of the Empire Trust Company of New York, from $3,000,000 consisting of 300,000 shares par value $10 each to $3,500,000 consisting of 350,000 shares par value $10 each, it was announced today.

German shipyards are so clogged with work and the needs of the growing German submarine flotillas for mother ships so pressing that the German Navy is attempting to buy two commercial vessels for conversion into submarine tenders, it was learned today.

John J. McMahon sold for $12,500 to the Port of New York Authority a vacant parcel, 80 by 113 feet, at 200-204 32d St., northwest corner of Hudson Av., Union City. The Hoboken Bank for Savings sold to the Efar Co. of Newark, the three-story brick. and one-story frame store buildings at 679-683 Bergenline Av., northwest corner of 34th St., Union City.

87th St., 34 W., 20x100.8 1/2; Sophia Hershcovitz to Cecilia Greenberg, 34 W. 87th St.: mtg., $22,000. 106th St., 305 W., 20x101: excr. will of Walter D. Buchanan to Anna J. Burke, 302 W. 81st St.: consideration. $17,000. 11th St., 342 E., 35.10x69.11; Michael Veniero et al. to Pasqualina Veniero, 270 2d Av.

Frederick A. Alden, for twenty years headmaster of the Columbia Grammar School, the oldest preparatory school in this city, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner tendered him by the Alumni Association of the institution in observance of his anniversary.

Thousands of sportsmen from Virginia and throughout the East will come to this city tomorrow for the annual Spring race meeting of the Deep Run Hunt Club at Curles Neck Farm. Officials are looking forward to the best card since the club was organized in 1892.

With a hint of ultimatum, the General Motors Corporation served notice today on the United Automobile Workers of America that the epidemic of sitdown strikes which has curbed production in its plants since an agreement for industrial relations was signed three weeks ago "can not continue."

The candidacy of George H. Earle, Democratic Governor of Pennsylvania, for the Presidency of the United States, was urged last night at the annual dinner of the Williston Academy Alumni Association at the Midston House, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, by Malcolm R. Lovell, former financial adviser of the Federal Housing Administration.
Mrs. Alice O'Neill McCorry Myers, wife of John Caldwell Myers, a member of the law committee of Tammany Hall, died on Thursday at their home, 375 Park Avenue. Her age was 57.

If it lacks Bacardi rum, no bartender's concoction can be called a Bacardi cocktail, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday, affirming a similar decision of the late Supreme Court Justice John L. Walsh.

In the President's remarks yesterday it is necessary to distinguish between his announcement of a new governmental policy and his discussions of economic theory. The President remarked that the time has come for the Government to reduce purchases of durable goods-to slow down, for example, in its construction of steel bridges and permanent structures.

The Rev. James Clement Reid said today he had received a letter from Justice McReynolds of the Supreme Court, in which the justice said "it is not my purpose at present to retire from the bench in the immediate future."
