In the Supreme Court of the United States James F. Hart of New York City was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

Mrs. Harriette H. Dall Aldrich, widow of Spencer Aldrich, died at Orlando, Fla., on Thursday at the age of 81. Her husband, to whom she was married in 1878, was a lawyer and builder of commercial structures.

Contracts numbering 1,608 and aggregating $93,598,652 were reported by twenty-three agencies of the government as having been made with contractors throughout the United States during the six months in which the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act, has been effective, Secretary Perkins stated today.

The 124 W. 20 Realty, Inc., Samuel Cooper, president, gave to the Greenwich Savings Bank a purchase money mortgage for $68,000 when the bank sold 124-28 W. 20th St. for $77,000. Margaret St. John Mapes and two others of her family assigned to Sarah Kuhn a mortgage for $22,000 on 208 E. 60th St.
Seventeenth Annual Convention of the Eastern Osteopathic Association, Hotel Pennsylvania, 9 A. M. Afternoon session 2 -o'clock. Continues tomorrow.

Everett H. Brown, Germantown manufacturer for more than a quarter of a century, died yesterday at his home at the age of 71. A native of Philadelphia, he was the son of John Wilson Brown and Susanne Hare.

Miss Cynthia Kimball Nichols became the bride this afternoon of Harmon Augustus Harris. Dr. James Lee Michell of Attleboro, a cousin of the bride's mother, performed the ceremony here in the Leslie Memorial Chapel of Emmanuel Church.

During yesterday's debate in the Senate Mr. BORAH prophesied ultimate recognition of the principle that "labor has a right to a job." In a certain sense that is the principle on which the Government itself is already proceeding.

Marian Anderson faced the vast audience at her recital in Carnegie Hall last night with the humbleness of spirit and unaffected simplicity which seem invariably to accompany greatness in any field of endeavor.

J. G. Crowther's "Famous American Men of Science," published by W. W. Norton, has been made the April book of the Scientific Book Club. This is the third book by Mr. Crowther to be selected by the club, his "Science for a New World" having been chosen in 1934 and his "Men of Science" in 1936.

Work was going forward today to prepare the property and big steel hangars on Manhasset Bay owned by Pan American Airways so this could become an operating base of the over-ocean air services to Bermuda or even for the North Atlantic line now in contemplation.

Swimming in her first national competition at the R. C. A. pool tonight, 12-year-old Patricia McWhorter of the Newark Women's Athletic Club was an easy winner in the National A. A. U. junior 100yard free-style championship.

Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, representing the Georgia Power Company in its fight against the Tennessee Valley Authority, asked the Supreme Court to postpone a hearing by the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals until the power company could proceed with other litigation in the Fifth Circuit Court.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Those skeptics who delight in knocking an infant sport instead of giving it a helping hand are out in full force at the present time disclaiming the popularity of skiing, which, after a development that was unprecedented in sports annals last year, was curbed this Winter owing to the vagaries of the weather.

Despite the brilliant work of its star, Miss Maria Cerra, the Hunter College women's fencing team dropped a thrilling 5-4 match to New York University's representatives yesterday at the East Building of Washington Square College.

Entirely recovered from a severe cold which kept him indoors for a few days of his three-week vacation at the training camp of the Yankees at St. Petersburg, Colonel Jacob Ruppert returned home yesterday and let it be known that his Yanks "really look like world champions."

Thirty-four able-bodied law enforcement officials from cities and towns in twenty-five States will receive diplomas this morning in Washington certifying that they have completed a twelve-week course of training- at the National Police Academy, it was made known here yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, parent of the academy.

An attempt to attribute the prevalence of sit-down strikes to President Roosevelt's court plan was halted by the Senate Judiciary Committee today when a witness brought that subject forward as an argument against the pending reorganization bill. The witness was William S.

" Cracked Ice," the twenty-fifth annual ice carnival of the Skating Club of Boston, attracted more than 10,000 persons to the Boston Garden tonight, with Miss Melitta Brunner and Karl Schafer of Austria as the main magnets.

Although Bobby Jones, one-time monarch of the golf world, managed to do a little better today, he's still far back in the race for honors in the fourth annual masters' tournament now being stage on the picturesque Augusta National course.

Francis Leo Oley, 29, tonight became the second of six suspects in the 1933 kidnapping of John J. O'Connell to choose self-inflicted death. He was found strangled to death in his cell at the Oneida County jail, with a rope improvised from strips of torn sheeting bound tightly about his throat.

Miss Elizabeth French, daughter of Mrs. John French of 142 East Thirty-eighth Street and Woodstock, Vt., and the late Mr. French, was married yesterday afternoon to Ethan Allen Hitchcock of this city in the Brick Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill performed the ceremony.

It was not until twenty-one United States Government long-term issues had dipped to new low levels for the year-five to the lowest marks since their issuance-during the first hour of trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange that sufficient support appeared to give some steadiness to the list. The declines, at the early lows, ranged as much as 9-16 of a point from Thursday's closing.

Prince and Princess Chlodwig Hohenlohe-Schillingsfurst have returned from Palm Beach and will be at the St. Regis for the Spring. Dr. and Mrs. Fielding Lewis Taylor have returned to their home at 950 Fifth Avenue after passing the Winter in Florida.

The Irving Trust Company's report as trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Corporation, filed yesterday in the Federal Court for the Southern New York District, shows that funds held at Dec. 31 totaled $6,907,355, while funds held for the account of Continental Investment, A. G., a wholly owned subsidiary, were $2,355,636.
Major William Arthur Wills, a pioneer in the South African gold fields and one of the late Cecil Rhodes's "young men," died here today at the age of 73.

Although the City Fusion party has received no reply from Mayor La Guardia to its resolution "drafting" him for renomination, its officers and members are going ahead with plans for his re-election, Ben Howe, city chairman, said yesterday.

Ranger, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new America's Cup racer, is to be the opposite of Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee in sloop rig. Instead of extremely large mainsail and small single headsail, such as Yankee will have, Ranger will have an even smaller mainsail than Rainbow, defender in 1934, and she will rely to a surprising extent on a large fore triangle, with jib and staysail.
The United States Department of Agriculture issued the following report on the trading in livestock here today:

General Francisco Franco, the Insurgent commander, received several hundred Moslems from Spanish Morocco here today on their return from Mecca in a ship provided by him to enable them to make the pilgrimage.

A thief or thieves stole two goldplated church candlesticks and a gold-plated altar cross yesterday from the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street. The objects are valued at $3,000.
Mrs. B. D. Fidanque, Mrs. Anna Cloberidge, S. C. Wallace, in Bronxville Manor; John Birge Jr., in New Castle; Burnett Walker, in Scarborough-on-Hudson; Westchester leases by I. C. Totaling, broker.

Bids for Army Air Corps pursuit planes opened at Wright Field today showed the Seversky Corporation as low bidder, offering planes in lots of twenty-five at $18,500 each, exclusive of engines and at $15,900 in lots of 250.

" WE are not defeated nor silenced," says a character in Josephine Johnson's "Jordanstown" (Simon Schuster, $2)-"we are not defeated nor silenced, nor penitent and full of doubts. * * * We shall not stop talking and give you peace. We shall go on planning and protesting and building."

Legislative steps to remove the profit motive from traffic in war materials may be coupled with the power being taken by the government to control all such traffic by an order-in-council, it was intimated in the House of Commons today.

Miss Marjorie Louise Egbert, daughter of Mrs. Harry Drew Egbert of 249 Kimball Avenue and the late Mr. Egbert, was married to John Andrew Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Wallace, this evening in her mother's home.

A sharp rise was registered in Argentina's revenues for the first quarter of this year, with cash receipts totaling 262,529,019 pesos ($87,600,000, at the official rate of exchange), which is compared to 223,552,152 pesos ($74,650,000) in the corresponding three months of last year, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

The Rowe Memorial winner, Mucho Gusto, will be sent back for the Bowie Handicap, feature tomorrow on the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association's first week-end program. The Bowie is a run of a mile and seventy yards, and six have been entered.

Peter J. McGuinness stood at the door of the Brooklyn Labor Lyceum last night and welcomed by name virtually all of the 4,000 guests at the thirteenth annual ball of the Greenpoint People's Regular Democratic Organization.

A war between National Socialist Germany and Bolshevist Russia is being predicted by Field Marshal August von Mackensen in a series of identical speeches he is delivering in various places in Germany dedicating new homes for the Hitler Youth.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey protested today to the Interstate Commerce Commission a proposed upward revision in general freight rates by Class I railroads.

The one-day stoppage in the softcoal industry ended yesterday with the signing of a new two-year agreement between the United Mine Workers of America and operators of the Appalachian area granting wage increases totaling $85,000,000 a year to 300,000 miners in eight States.

The right of the Transit Commission to authorize the Bee Line, Inc., to operate buses in Queens as part of a through route to Nassau and Suffolk Counties even though the company had received no franchise from the city was unanimously upheld by the Appellate Division yesterday.

Mrs. John Heffron gave a tea at herapartment in Greenwich Towers this afternoon for. Miss Nancy Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Baker of Greenwich, whose marriage to Jesse Fleet Sammis of New York takes place here tomorrow afternoon.

FAN MAINTAINER (RAILROAD). Salary: 60 cents to 80 cents an hour; pension. Ages: 21 through 40, on April 15. Applications: Received to 4 P. M., Thursday, April 15, Room 1,400, Municipal Building, Manhattan. Vacancies: Occur from time to time; five appointments made from last promotion list. Subjects and Weizhts:

Philip James, conductor-composer, directed the Federal Music Project Chamber Orchestra last night at the WPA Theatre of Music in its weekly Mozart-Haydn concert. Mr. James led off with the Mozart overture to "Cosi fan tutte," and then conducted Haydn's symphony in D major, No. 104.

To speculate on the prospects for success of an American initiative to ease the international situation, it isn't necessary to credit reviving rumors that the President contemplates some positive step to promote world peace. It is enough to know that this is a lead Mr. Roosevelt has long been inclined to take.

Because of the natural fog of war it has always been difficult to gauge the course of a campaign actually in progress and it has become more difficult with the modern development of censorship and propaganda in creating artificial "smoke."

The Board of Tax appeals ruled today that the Commissioner of Internal Revenue erred in holding Christian H. Droge of New York City should have included in his gross income for 1933 the entire amount he won on the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes.

A speeding Southern Railway electric train packed with early-morningo ommuters on their way to Victoria Station plowed into another string of coaches temporarily stalled sixty feet in the air on a viaduct at Battersea Park today, killing eight persons and injuring forty.
Mrs. Del Barkhufi of Seattle, a pre-tournament favorite, entered the final of the women's singles division tonight in the national badminton championships at the Illinois Naval Armory.

Two gunmen waiting in a hallway at 449 Central Avenue here, held up today two girl clerks employed by Joseph Spiotta Co., clothing manufacturing firm in that building, and escaped with two packages containing the concern's weekly payroll of $4,629.

The decline in cotton mill activity last week was greater than seasonal and the adjusted index fell back one and a half points. The figure now is 136.9, as against138.4 (revised) in the preceding week and 103.0 for the week ended March 28, 1936.

Ted Snyder won his 250-point pocket billiard match with Vernon Whittle by taking the concluding block last night at Jack Doyle's Broadway Academy, 100 to 77. The score for the match was Snyder 250, Whittle 187.
Official confirmation of the reports abroad of the arrest of Christian Rakovsky, former Soviet Ambassador to Britain and France, who was named in the recent treason trial, is unobtainable here.

Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, is convinced the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn can build a first-class battleship. He made a statement to this effect yesterday afternoon upon completing a six-hour inspection tour of the shops, launching ways, foundries, mold lofts and drafting rooms.

Evidence piled up today to assure, beyond practically all doubt, that James J. Braddock will defend his world heavyweight championship against Joe Louis in Chicago June 22, notwithstanding renewal of the $350,000 guarantee for a fight with Max Schmeling in Berlin.

Total round-lot volume, member trading for own account and the percentage of member trading in relation to total volume increased on the New York Stock Exchange during the week ended on March 6, compared with the previous week, according to the summary of weekly transactions made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Judge Carroll C. Hinks of the Federal court authorized today trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to discontinue operation of their Providence Line steamboats. The railroad also was given permission to sell the steamboats New Haven, Mohegan, Hartford and Middletown.

President Roosevelt declared today that the price of steel, copper and other basic products had become too high and that, to counteract the trend, the government would curtail its purchases in the durable goods field and place emphasis on purchases in consumer goods lines.
Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth condemned the Communists, in a statement he?? tonight, for alleged attempts to halt passage of his bill to require annual financial reports from labor unions.
Early United States gold coins from an old Chicago collection brought excellent prices yesterday at the sale of numismatic material by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

Plans for altering numerous buildings in Manhattan were filed yesterday. They included plans for altering at a cost of $25,000 the West End Synagogue in West Eightysecond Street, which was swept by fire a week ago. The bulk of new construction filed for yesterday calls for new housing in Queens:
As a result of negotiations completed yesterday, Sheffield Farms Company will pay farmers $1.69 a hundred pounds for milk purchased in the State milk-shed during April, it was announced.

Top-seeded Sol Schiff of New York led the men's singles advance of the seventh annual United States table tennis championships into the round of sixteen tonight as play began in men's and mixed doubles and veterans' singles.

Style appeal was stressed in 166 of the total of 281 handbag advertisements appearing in leading daily newspapers here in March, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Authority for the Ladies Handbag Industry. Price appeal was featured in 115 advertisements.

An agreement affecting employment relations of 7,500 workers in all but one of Detroit's major hotels followed by less than four hours tonight the return to work of striking employes of the twenty-seven-story Book Cadillac Hotel.

John Rogers Dickey, former sales manager of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, died Wednesday in Presbyterian Hospital, of which his father, the Rev. Charles A. Dickey, was president for thirty-five years. Mr. Dickey, who was 72 years old, retired several years ago.

Sam Cohen, known to police as "Chowderhead" and a self-styled "gorilla," yesterday told Charles A. Woods, examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, about a period of employment during which he got $9 a day and sometimes more from the Borden Farm Products Company for his services as a "guard."
Under the heaviest selling pressure of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke nearly $2 a bale at one time yesterday but a partial recovery left the list with net losses of 19 to 23 points.

Faced with a demand from General Motors Corporation that the United Automobile Workers of America live up to its obligations and cease unauthorized sit-down strikes in the company's plants, officials of the union, defied by some of their followers, sought desperately tonight to regain control of the strike situation.

Net sales of the General Motors Corporation and subsidiaries last year were $1,439,289,940, the third highest in history, comparing with $1,155,641,511 the year before, a gain of nearly 25 per cent. Sales in 1929 were $1,504,404,472 and in 1928 they were $1,459,762,906.

Ships and cargo delayed by the maritime strike in the United States and released by the recent settlement apparently reached a peak here last month, with 536 ship transits, the highest since October, 1930.
The 105th Troy conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church denounced the New York Assembly by resolution today for refusing to ratify the child labor amendment.

An arrangement between five medical colleges in New York City and the city Health Department to train students in preventive medicine has been completed, Bailey B. Burritt, chairman of the committee on neighborhood health development, of the Welfare Council, disclosed yesterday.

Inspired by box-office returns, RKO has launched a campaign to make Victor Moore one of the screen's ranking comedy stars. Moore will be featured in "Strictly Accidental," acquired today from Richard English. With his story, English returns to RKO's contract list of writers.

It may be that Gordon Stanley Cochrane is trying to emulate that unfortunate old Roman who thrice was offered a Kingly crown and thrice refused. Three times his Tigers have had the Dodgers served up to them and just as often have the Detroiters completely lost their appetites.
The Brooklyn Trust Company in its report for March 31 shows deposits of $121,215,468, compared with $124,458,494 on Dec. 31 last. Total resources were $137,095,724, against $140,238,349.

Joseph Gedeon was freed in $1,000 bail obtained for him by his son-in-law late yesterday afternoon after a representative of the District Attorney's office who had previously sought high bail for him as "a possible suspect in the triple Gedeon murders" had consented to the reduction of the $10,000 bond originally fixed.

The engagement of $11,319,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gold was secured in London on Thursday and, inasmuch as it exneeded the amount that was available in the open market there on that day, it was assumed in banking circles here that it consisted of additional amounts of Russian gold.

Paul Hindemith, German composer and viola soloist, arrived yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland to give several concerts in this country. He will be soloist at two concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on April 15 and 16.

Miss Doris Whitfield Potter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Garwood Potter of this city, was married to Whitney Guerin Ball, son of Mrs. John Guerin Ball of Maplewood and the late Mr. Ball, tonight in the Forest Hill Presbyterian Church here.

The United States Government is constantly seeking to encourage the rubber-producing countries through their control system to keep the price of rubber at a reasonable level, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today in commenting on reports of the recent meeting of the International Rubber Regulation Committee in London, at which the United States was represented.

A verdict of guilty, with a recommendation for life imprisonment, was brought in at 12:39 this morning by a County Court jury that started deliberating at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon on a first-degree murder case against Novio Santoro, 24 years old, of 47 Post Road, Yonkers.
One of the four ex-convicts who were trapped by detectives on the night of Jan. 31 as they were about to loot a safe of $50,000 in the office of Gall Lembke, Inc.,

Mrs. Elsie Saltus Munds Domville, daughter of the late New York author and publicist, Edgar Saltus, and former wife of J. Theus Munds, New York broker, obtained a license today to be married to Gosta Tollius of Stockholm, Sweden.

Though told that death would be the probable outcome of her refusal to submit to surgical treatment for what physicians at Bellevue Hospital said was a ruptured appendix, Miss Yvette Cantwell, 23 years old, of 517 East Seventyeighth Street, who explained she was a Christian Scientist -and did not believe in operations, left Bellevue late yesterday afternoon, after having been taken to the emergency ward twice after collapses on the street.

In a court room of the Federal Building in Foley Square on April 19 D. W. Griffith, Inc., the pioneer motion picture company that produced many famous silent films, will come to its "fade-out" on the auction block for the benefit of creditors.
President Roosevelt will confer on unemployment relief problems at the White House on April 9 with Governor Lehman and Governors of other industrial States, it was announced here today.

Dr. Burdette S. Adams, a homeopathic physician in Connecticut for more than thirty-five years, died at his home here today after an illness of two years. He was born in Tariffville sixty-four years ago, son of Dr. Clifford B. Adams, a founder of Grace Hospital of this city. He was graduated from Hahnemann Medical College, Philadelphia, in 1898.
Fred Fuller Shedd, editor of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, died early today in Southern Pines, N. C., of a heart attack. He was 66 years old on Feb. 9.

Modest government successes on three fronts were reported in war communiques today. In the Cordoba sector in Southern Central Spain, Loyalists were reported to have occupied Villaharta and Ovejo, ten miles west and sixteen miles north of Cordoba, and gained the heights above Penarroya, the center of a rich coal-mine area twenty-five miles northwest of Villaharta.

The conference of the Foreign Ministers of the Little Entente-Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Rumania-ended tonight, and a communique was issued indicating complete solidarity in all important foreign political problems.

Housing properties in the upper West Side and Washington Heights sections formed the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday. The property at 226 West Seventieth Street, a modern nine-story apartment house on a plot 66.8 by 100.5 feet adjoining the Bradford Hotel, was bought by Melville L. Levy, president of the Morrow Realty Company, from Ada Van Tassel Billington, who had been the owner for many years.

The twenty-three-story loft and store building, at 1,040-8 Sixth Avenue, 98.9 by 100 feet, was sold in foreclosure proceedings yesterday by Henry Brady, auctioneer, to the Continental Bank and Trust Company, trustee, plaintiff in an action against the 680 Sixth Avenue Corporation,

A Japanese official described by defendants in Moscow's January treason trial as an agent plotting the war-time wrecking of the Soviet railway system left Moscow tonight, and with his departure sensational parts of the trial testimony became public.

R.H. Graham, president of Wallach's, Inc., will be among the important guests attending the twoday celebration in Chicago of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Hart, Schaffner Marx, clothing manufacturers, starting tomorrow.

A study of Negro life in the sharecropping region of South Carolina won recognition as a playwright for P. Washington Porter, 26-yearold member of a Civilian Conservation Corps camp near Columbia, S. C., who arrived yesterday to continue his dramatic work under the auspices of the Federal Theatre Project in this city.

Stocks closed steadier at lower levels after early weakness; turnover, 1,635,030 shares. United States Government issues rallied and closed higher, corporate bonds lower, foreign loans irregular; transactions, $18,866,400.

Retail trade was active on several ays this week, but sales volume offered in comparison with the figures for the same week last year, which was in the pre-Easter period. Department store executives reorted that up to yesterday volume ipped from 2 to 10 per cent under the corresponding 1936 week.

Reflecting the improvement in the demand for railway equipment, the American Car and Foundry Company resumed dividends yesterday on its 7 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock with a declaration of $4. This was the first distribution since 1932, when the full preferred dividend was paid. Common dividends ceased in 1931.
Thomas M. Hemy, painter of the famous picture "Wreck of the Birkenhead," which circulated in German barracks before the World War as an example of discipline, died today at the age of 86.
Governor Lehman announced today the signing of nineteen bills of a local or technical nature and the vetoing of four measures.

With Cornell standing closer to a title than it ever has been before, tonight's indoor polo play will see the closing games of four of the branches of the championships, with competition planned for both the Squadron A and Squadron C Armories.

The net income of twenty leading oil companies, so far reporting for 1936, amounted to $173,597,485, compared to $113,143,423 reported by these companies in 1935, an increase of about 53 per cent, according to a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.

Miss Catherine Barr Law, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Law of this place, was married to Charles Ernst Sherman of Knoxville, Tenn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst C. Sherman of Chattanooga, Tenn., tonight in the Woman's Club of Maplewood by the Rev. John Charleton, pastor of Morrow Memorial Church of Maplewood, N. J.

Repayment of part of the European war debts by providing scholarships for American students in foreign schools was proposed yesterday by Dr. Royal Bailey Farnum, secretary of the American committee for the 1937 International Art Congress, at the sessions of the annual convention of the Eastern Arts Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Senator Bone of Washington introduced today on behalf of virtually the entire Senate membership a bill to authorize the expenditure of $1,000,000 annually for cancer research.

Dr. Peter F. Amoroso, Deputy Correction Commissioner, announced yesterday that his department had completed plans for diagnosing and treating all men prisoners found suffering from venereal diseases on their admission to city penal institutions.

A committee headed by Professor John Dewey of Columbia University left New York last night for Mexico, D. F., where it will hold hearings at which Leon Trotsky will testify in his own defense against charges of anti-Soviet sabotage and terrorism made in the recent trials of Soviet officials in Moscow.
The Tallahassee Capitals of the Class D Georgia-Florida League gave the world champion Yankees quite a struggle today as the MoCarthymen opened their Spring exhibition tour.

Passenger revenues of the Great Northern Railway amounted to $4,977,601 in 1936, against $4,416,108 in 1935, an increase of 12.7 per cent, according to the annual report of W. P. Kenney, president. He remarked that since 1933 there had been a steady betterment in the volume of railway travel.

That the rush of modernity has not entirely driven out of New York the medieval spirit of meticulous craftsmanship is proved by an exhibition of sumptuous bookbindings by Marguerite Duprez Lahey, one of the foremost exponents of her craft, at the Pierpont Morgan Library.

President Roosevelt, faced with the fact that income-tax receipts for March were $100,000,000 below his estimates, is planning to recast his proposals for expenditures and receipts for both the current and the coming fiscal year in a message soon to be sent to Congress.

Propaganda against the foreignborn resident in "the current wave of alien baiting" was condemned and figures were cited to show the alien- population of the country was decreasing at "a tremendous rate" by speakers at the annual dinner last night of the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship in the Hotel Astor.

These orders were Issued in the Northern New York area: The following Reserve officers, recently released to the Northern New York Reserve area for assignment, are assigned as follows: 41st Infantry-2d Lt. William P. Baker, Inf.-Res., 606 University Av., Syracuse, N. Y.

Daniel W. Lave has purchased the business known as the Selected Apartments Service which was conducted by the late Violet E. Miller. Fay Wallace will manage the office at 724 5th Av. John Owen Dunn has been placed In charge of the management and leasing department of the Harland W. Meistrell Mineola office.

Scoring four runs in their final trip to the plate, the Dartmouth Indians scored a 13-12 victory over the University of Maryland nine today in an eight-inning contest. The final attack of the invaders was featured by a homer by Casey, with one on.

Attorney General Cummings was called upon today by Representative Raymond J. Cannon, Wisconsin Progressive, to start anti-trust proceedings against owners of organized baseball clubs on the ground they were operating a monopoly in restraint of trade.

The independent engineering survey of the properties of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation and subsidiaries, conducted by Sanderson Porter, shows that estimates of original cost of plant and equipment of the operating subsidiaries, owned as of Dec. 31, 1935, amount to about $100,915,000, excluding any allowances for cost of organization, franchises, patent rights, engineering development costs, all other intangible items, and physical property in process of retirement.

The chief interest in Madrid today concentrated on the Basque front. Messages from Bilbao, the Basque capital, state that the attack is the heaviest yet launched on that front, although it is still too early to judge whether it is a serious threat to Bilbao or a less ambitious localized offensive.

Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hayden of Brooklyn and Bayport, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catharine Patricia Hayden, to Arthur James Rykert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Rykert of Brooklyn and Brightwaters, L. I.

Factories of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation were closed today by a sudden sit-on-the-roof strike, and a five-hour conference by representatives of the company and the men broke up, as the company refused to negotiate until the strikers vacated the plant.

Unless preliminary signs are misleading, a rather formidable contingent of trout fishermen will be out on the streams in various parts of the Empire State today for the opening of the season. It's a red-letter day on the calendar of a vast number of sportsmen.

Stephen Adelbert Griggs, active in business and politics in Detroit and Windsor for more than a half century, died today at his home here at the age of 87. Mr. Griggs was a former president of the Common Council of Detroit and had been an Alderman for two terms.

Wayne Wright's remarkable spurt of the past few days finally found him tied with Hubert Le Blanc for the riding lead at twenty-three victories each when he won the mile and a sixteenth sixth race on Round Table today at Tropical Park. The latter- carried 125 pounds, broke last but was still good enough to rush into early contention and assume command.

Four newspaper women received prizes for professional achievement last night at the fifteenth annual party of the New York Newspaper Women's Club, known as the 1937 prize story edition of the Front Page Ball, held or the Hotel Astor roof. Many political, social and theatrical notables were among the guests.

Women who live in ground-floor flats have slimmer ankles and wrists than those who inhabit abodes higher up, according to Tade Styka, New York portrait painter, who is exhibiting paintings here with his brother Adam.

The sit-down strikers who held the seventh floor of Queens Borough Hall on Wednesday in protest against scheduled reductions of WPA wages and personnell were held guilty of disorderly conduct yesterday by Magistrate Anthony Savarese in Flushing Court.

A permanent legislative check on Executive budgets, on the receipts and expenditures of the State and on the conduct of its administrative departments would be established under a bill to be introduced Monday by Senator Desmond of Orange County.
The Vermont House of Representatives passed a bill today outlawing sit-down strikes, and sent the measure to Governor Aiken for his signature.

This year and next probably will witness the peak years in the present period of prosperity, General Charles G. Dawes, chairman of the City National Bank and Trust Company and former Vice President of the United States, asserted today.
President Roosevelt was hailed last night by Mayor La Guardia as the most sympathetic and understanding toward labor of any President in the history of the United States.
Control of police power was transerred from the anarchists to the more conservative Left republicans in formation of Catalonia's new Cabinet, the Valencia government revealed tonight.

Police thought today they could identify a hit-skip driver's automobile if they could find it. They said this all happened in a few seconds: The car broke down a power line pole, ripping light wires from poles and houses along an entire block;

Before 3,000 tennis fans Ellsworth Vines defeated Fred Perry tonight, 16-14, 3-6, 6-3, to win the thirtyninth indoor meeting between the two professional court rivals. The match left Vines with twenty victories to Perry's nineteen. Perry started strongly, but wilted after failing to take set point in the tenth game.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman will celebrate the twentieth anniversary of his ministry at the Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, tomorrow. He will preach at 11 A. M. on "The Challenge of Chance" and at the 5 P. M. vespers on "Link's 'The Return of Religion.'"

The annual report of the American Power and Light Company for 1936, issued today, shows a consolidated net income, after interest and other charges, of $10,398,806, as compared with $7,512,476 in 1935. Gross operating revenues of the company and its subsidiaries during the year aggregated $90,712,787, against $82,560,471 in the preceding year.

Frank D. Comerford, chairman of the New England Power Association, said yesterday in a letter to stockholders that business conditions throughout the territory served by the association had continued to improve and that preliminary earnings to date indicated "considerable improvement" for the first quarter of 1937.

According to word received at New York University from Washington yesterday, the Violet varsity rifle team has been declared the winner of the New England sectional championship in the national intercollegiate shoulder-toshoulder matches fired at New Haven on March 20.

To take effect 8 A. M., April 3, 1937: PATROLMEN-John F. Colton, from 20th Pct. to 23d Pct.; Max Bernstein, from 46th Pct. to 47th Pct. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Thomas T. Van Etten, from 18th Pct. to 18th Div., duty in D. A. Office, N. Y. County, for 5 days; Coleman P. Kovacs, from 45th Pct. to 18th Div., for 10 days; Timothy T. McGrath, 48th Pct.,

Mrs. Ida Rines Simmons of Pelham Manor and Albedor, Fourth Lake, N. Y., widow of Colonel Edward Alfred Simmons, was married to Branch P. Kerfoot, also of Pelham Manor, here last night in St. Agnes Chapel of Trinity Parish on West Ninety-second Street.

Acceptance by the Apparel Industrial Inter-Trade Bureau of the "anti-returns" program in the form prepared by the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association was indicated at a meeting of representatives of both bodies at the offices of the retail association yesterday. Another meeting will be held next Tuesday.

A general strike was called tonight by the Wilmington Central Labor Union and Building Trades Council for 6 o'clock tomorrow morning, following the breakdown of efforts to reach an agreement in a nineteen-day-old strike of truck drivers and helpers.
Philadelphia has won the 1936 Interchamber Fire Waste Contest conducted by the National Fire Waste Council in cooperation with the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, it was announced today.

The women's committee of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity for 1937 has set as a goal $150,000 for the annual appeal for Catholic Charities, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Douglas Gibbons, who has been appointed by Cardinal Hayes as the chairman.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler has given a special pardon to 200 Saar miners recently arrested for infringement of German currency regulations.

An East Bronx deal involved the five-story flat for twenty families at 669 Prospect Avenue, which was sold by Fannie Siegel to a client of Myers Sherwin, attorneys. The house occupies a plot 37.6 by 100 feet and is assessed at $35,000. Schimmer, Kerner Feder were the brokers.

Foreign copper quotations and domestic lead prices were lowered yesterday. Sales of copper were made at 16.40 to 16.50 cents a pound c. i .f. European base ports, compared to 16.90 to 17.225 cents on Thursday.

Cram's Reports, Inc., estimated today that this week's automotive output would total 99,425 passenger cars and trucks, compared with its revised figure of 101,046 units last week and 108,426 in the corresponding week of 1936.
The mystery of the fate of the Duchess of Bedford was solved today by John Hales, a fisherman. Walking along Great Yarmouth Beach, he found among the driftwood a broken airplane strut four feet long.
The former Sultan of Morocco, Moulay-Hafid, is ill at his villa in a Paris suburb. The three doctors attending him state that his condition is the result of high blood pressure.
It is singularly appropriate that our first women Ministers Plenipotentiary should go to the Scandinavian countries.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday that further applications for taking the examination for the post of Board of Education Examiner, with an $11,000 annual salary, would be received from next Monday until 4 P. M. on April 26. The date of the examination has not yet been announced.

A permanent exhibition of memorabilia of John Burroughs, the poet-naturalist, at the American Museum of Natural History,-Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West, will be dedicated tonight, the 100th anniversary of the birth of John Burroughs, it was announced yesterday.

To the letters and other messages that have come to President BUTLER from around the world we would add a postscript of pride that he belongs especially to us of the United States, of this State and of this mightiest of cities.

The Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Esperanza, 524 West 156th Street, west of Broadway, will begin tomorrow the celebration of a double jubilee. the golden anniversary of the ordination of the pastor, the Rev. Adrian Buisson, and the silver anniversary of the church itself. The parishioners chiefly of Spanish descent.
American upholders of democracy who have ventured to criticize conditions in Germany were told pointedly today to take a little more intelligent interest in their own affairs.
Any ambition that Germany may have had of winning back her former colony of Southwest Africa was scotched today by a proclamation published by the South African Government.

For five hours the Senate wrangled today over the amendment to the Guffey Coal Bill condemning the sit-down strike. Senator Byrnes of South Carolina, stolidly insisting upon his amendment as a "declaration of Federal policy," was supported by a bi-partisan group.

A full military funeral was held here today for Colonel H. V. D. Moore, acting brigadier general in command of the 155th Infantry Brigade of the Seventy-eighth Division, United States Organized Reserve, and member of the New York Stock Exchange, who died at Englewood Hospital on Wednesday.

J. Edward Lumbard Jr., a member of the firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton Lombard, was appointed yesterday counsel to the Society for the Prevention of Crime at a meeting of the board of directors of that organization at the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

Business leases reported yesterday by brokers reflected expansion by a number of stock brokers, and by chain store concerns in the food and flower businesses. A large outof-town business training school also took space for a New York City branch. The list follows:

An accounting for the Guarantee Mortgage and Title Insurance Company of Passaic was filed today with Vice Chancellor Vivian M. Lewis by Carl K. Withers, New Jersey's Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, as trustee, for the period covering June 17, 1935, to Oct. 31, 1936.

The Royal Dutch Airlines announced today its first profit360,000 guilders for 1936-on the Amsterdam-Batavia route since its inception. The increases in passengers, mail and freight amounted, respectively, to 68, 47 and 62 per cent, as compared with 1935. Nearly 3,000 passengers were transported on the route.
Mortgage certificates for a principal amount of $2,380,500 were liquidated through refinancing operations during March, according to -the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York.

This should be a pretty nostalgic evening up on West Fifty-fourth Street, where the Gay Nineties Club is to clip back the calendar to the departed age of minstrelsy. For in the new "Spring revue" there will be starred the Eddie Leonard whose minstrel days date back to Primrose West.

Production of distilled and electrolytic zinc at zinc reduction plants in the United States in 1936 amounted to 534,341 short tons valued at $53,434,000, representing increases of 19 per cent in quantity and 35 per cent in value over the 1935 production of 449,284 short tons valued at $39,537,000, according to a report today by the United States Bureau of Mines.

William J. Leonard, 46 years old, an Assistant Corporation Counsel, of 75 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, was arrested on a charge of disorderly conduct at 2 P. M. yesterday near Joe's Restaurant, 330 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, by Police Captain Michael Richter.

IN the bickering over the site for the United States-Australia tennis matches in case these teams go that far in the current Davis Cup campaign, President Holcombe Ward of the United States Lawn Tennis Association exhibited a cable from the Australian Lawn Tennis Association reading:

Morris Nelkin, 32 years old, a diamond cutter at 71 Nassau Street, was freed yesterday by Judge Streit in General Sessions on a first-degree grand larceny indictment in connection with the theft of $30,000 in jewelry on Jan. 18, 1936, from Marcus Co., jewelers, at 671 Fifth Avenue.

Rights for the new Series O bearer shares of L'Air Liquide on which the Guaranty Trust Company had received no instructions have been sold in the. Paris market, the trust company reported yesterday to the New York Curb Exchange.
Dr. Max Wallerstein, industrial chemist, who made many contributions to the technique of brewing, died on Thursday at his home at 33 East Seventieth Street after a long illness.

Municipal bond issues aggregating $10,018,412 were approved during March by voters of 139 municipalities located in thirty-four States, as compared with $6,736,400 of bonds approved during February, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.
Passenger rates will be increased this month by three intercoastal steamship lines to meet higher cost of operations in recent months, it was announced yesterday.

Anti-war sculptures, depicting the horrors of conflict, will be shown at the exhibition of the work of Anita Weschler which will open April 12 at the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue. The exhibition will close early in May.

Two more stakes were completed today in the third annual Maryland retriever trials, held under the auspices of the American Chesapeake Club on the estate of R. R. M. Carpenter at Benton, thirteen miles from this city.

The marketing of $24,000,000 of Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due 1952, lifted the volume Ro of new bond financing this week to $33,212,000, compared with $20,382,000 placed last week.

Miss Peggy Best, a bride-elect, the daughter of Admiral Sir Matthew Robert Best, commander-in-chief the America and West Indies Station, and Miss Ruth Backhouse, daughter of Admiral Sir Roger Backhouse, commander-in-chief of the British Home Fleet, were injured in a bicycle accident here Thursday, both suffering concussion of the brain.
Reorganization of the State Department of Social Welfare neared completion tonight with the appointment of ten executives and six regional directors.

President Roosevelt signed the bill amending the Marine Act to permit continuation of private operation of government- owned steamship lines, announced that the government would curtail purchases in the durable goods field as a move to check rising prices and possible credit inflation,

Jacob Wilson Humbird, retired capitalist, died today. He was born here Christmas Day, eighty-six years ago, a son of Jacob Humbird, contractor of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and Chesapeake Ohio Canal, who also built railroads for Dom Pedro, Emperor of Brazil.

Stephen N. Brennan will manage the new branch office of Reynolds Co. at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N. Y. L. L. Warringer, general manager of Master Electric Company, was elected a director to succeed J. A. Wortman, and H. E. Kline was named secretary to succeed Mr. Wortman.

The reaction to the statement by President Roosevelt that copper prices were too high was a substantial decline in mining shares. In this connection those in the trade said the price of copper abroad in the last few months had been from one-half to 1 1/2 cents a pound above the domestic level and that the price here was marked up to insure an adequate supply of the metal for home industries.
A reduction in vegetable prices caused by increasing supplies from all parts of the country was reported yesterday by the Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets.

After one of the most bizarre performances on record, "White Horse Inn" late yesterday afternoon decided to stick around a while longer. On Thursday it was scheduled to close its run tonight at the Center Theatre.

Despite determined resistance by administration leaders, the tide of opposition to sit-down strikes surged forward in both houses of Congress today toward definite action in some form by the Federal Government.

Anthony Caserta of the College of the City of New York gained a firstround knockout in his semi-final bout as the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference boxing championships began at the Penn A. C. tonight. C. C. N. Y. is competing as a guest team.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is brisker, especially in the West, where newclip purchases have become more general.
A ventilating system has been installed in the vault of the Northern Westchester Bank here, where officials and employes have been imprisoned in two recent hold-ups. No one will suffocate now.
Governor Lehman announced yesterday afternoon that a new minimum wage bill for women and minors would be introduced in the State Legislature early next week.

224th St. (17-4826), n s, 105 ft e of Carpenter Av., 50x114; Allenville Construction Co., Inc., to Anna Goldstein, 633 E. 220th St. Bronx Blvd. (16-4649), e s, 600 ft n of 216th St., 133x100; 3,764 Bronx Boulevard, Inc., to Anna Goldstein. 633 E. 220th St. White Plains Rd. (16-4666), s e cor 219th St., 64x80; Friedgold Realty Corp. to Jacob Solomon, 675 E. 223d St.

The auditor's report for 1936 of the Wisconsin Bankshares Corporation, shows total assets on Dec. 31, 1936, of $18,384,969. Total reserves amounted to $8,075,428, compared to $8,385,686 on Dec. 31, 1935, a decrease of $310,258.

The Rev. Dr. Fred E. Mayer, a professor in Concordia Lutheran Theological Seminary, Springfield, Ill., has been elected as president of Concordia Collegiate Lutheran Institute, Bronxville, N. Y., it was announced yesterday by the board of trustees.
The two grand juries to which Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey has been presenting racketeering evidence since last August, handed up reports yesterday in which-they asked to be discharged.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary yesterday quietly. While educational and political leaders from all parts of the world continued to send their congratulations and the Columbia University Alumni Club of Union County dedicated a bronze memorial tablet on the lawn of his birthplace at 210 West Jersey Street, Elizabeth,

Although the Federal program helps to develop eventual social security for children, it is the private social agency which makes this program really effective, the Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart, director of the Division of Child Care of Catholic Charities, declares in his annual report issued today.

Darkhaired Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., who stands No. 17 in the national tennis rankings, blasted young Bobby Riggs, national clay courts champion, from the Atlanta invitation tournament in straight sets today.

The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday that stockholders had bought 90 per cent of the $52,670,700 of fifteen-year 3 1/4 percent debentures offered to them as Feb. 6. The issue was under written by Kuhn, Loeb Co.

Paul B. Adams, advertising man and former collegiate and scholastic track star, died Thursday night at the Harkness Pavilion in the Medical Center after an illness of several months. Mr. Adams, who was 46 years old, lived at 142 East Thirty-ninth Street.

The opera "Martha" by Flotow was presented by the Westchester Little Opera Company tonight as the opening event of a Spring series of activities at the County Center. Five hundred persons attended and applauded the melodies "The Last Rose of Summer," "Good Night Quartet" and "Spinning Wheel Quartet."
One hundred and eight employes, members of the International Upholsterers and Carpet and Linoleum Layers, occupied the Weiman Company furniture factory tonight in this city's first sit-down strike.
Miss Helen T. Kracke of 11 Kenmore Place, Brooklyn, was re-elected president of the Junior Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Home for Children at the meeting and tea held yesterday at her home.

The two-story frame Long Island Colonial farmhouse, said to have been erected in 1780 by Allan Mitchell, one of the first settlers in Flushing, Queens, with the tract fronting on Whitestone Avenue, Bayside Avenue and Myrtle Avenue, has been sold by Gardner B. Perry of Minneapolis, Minn.

Although no date yet has been fixed for the opening of the Paris 1937 exposition, it was stated today by Commissioner Paul Leon that the work would, without question, be far enough advanced to permit the inaugural ceremonies on May 1.

A conceded putt on the final green gave Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page her second women's North and South golf championship today. The Chapel Hill woman, who won the title two years ago in a final match with Miss Charlotte Glutting of Orange, N. J., and who captured the medal last year in the national, was 1 up with Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N. Y., needing to sink a twelve-foot putt to square the match.

The long-established series of Metropolitan Dances was concluded for this season last night with a supper dance in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The dances are given in the Winter and Spring for debutantes of the following season.
With the air full of rumors of anti-Franco moves, fresh contingents of Spanish Insurgent infantry are arriving at Algeciras and La Linea from Cadiz.

The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation declared yesterday initial quarterly dividends of $1.25 a share on the company's first preferred, second preferred Series B and second preferred Series A stocks. The dividends are payable on May 1 to holders of record on April 15.
Louis Buchner of 95-15 Forty-second Avenue, Elmhurst, died yesterday at the Parson Hospital following a short illness. He was 75 years old.

By a vote of 312 to 278, Chicago was chosen yesterday as the scene of the thirty-eighth annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress in 1938 at the convention of delegates in the Majestic Theatre. The only other city seeking the competition was Cleveland.

Announcement was made today of the marriage of Miss Edna Elizabeth Baldwin, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Baldwin and sister of Mrs. John Arringdale of West Point, N. Y., to Colonel Frank Powell Stone, which took place here Wednesday at the home of th bride.

United Stores Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange of a proposal to decrease its authorized Class A stock from 918,000 to 916,000 shares and its common stock from 2,090,000 to 1,522,200 shares.

The last for this season of the Knickerbocker Assemblies, an annual series of subscription dances for debutantes of former years, took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The guests were received by members of the committee, headed by Mrs. Frederick W. Longfellow.
Maurice Podoloff, president of the International - American Hockey League, announced today a schedule of play-offs for the league championship.

WITHOUT mention of intentions as to the first of the series, Columbia has lost no time in giving general American circulation to the second album of the English Delius Society's collection, listing it as Volume II, with a society label, in Masterworks Set No. 290.

STANDARDIZATION has become the trend in commercial air transport. Like planes, instruments and radio aids to navigation as well as intermatched schedules with equalized fares are rapidly being adopted by the major airlines.

Time Flies, the new airplane of Frank Hawks, landed at North Beach Airport yesterday morning after flying against a head wind of more than thirty miles an hour from Washington in forty-eight minutes-airport .to airport-at an average air speed of 300 miles an hour.

The report of the Spicer Manufacturing Corporation and subsidiaries, issued yesterday, shows a net profit for 1936 of $1,488,760 after depreciation, idle plant expense, Federal income taxes and $15,872 provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

The war Department released the following orders day, dated April 2: COLONELS Baltzell, G. F., Inf., Fort McClellan, Ala., to home and await retirement. Walthall, H. L., Adjutant General's Department. to retirement.

In conformity with plans for mutualization and reorganization for the four National Investors companies, dividends will be paid on April 23 to the holders of shares in the old concerns. The new National Investors Corporation, a Maryland company, commenced operations on April 1, as successor to the four old companies.

Led by Olympian Sam Francis, Nebraska's great ace, and Al Tolmich, sprint star from Wayne University of Detroit, track and field athletes cracked six meet records and tied two others at the Texas relays today.

CHARLESTON, S. C. SYNCHRONIZING the blossoms and the tourists is this Spring the South's chief worry in regard to hospitality. Months ago the Southeastern States, individually and collectively, plotted to break all records with their 1937 flower shows, floral festivals and garden weeks.

THE genesis of this novel is unusual enough to be worthy of comment. Its author, Richard LaPiere, is an Assistant Professor of Sociology at Stanford. He had never-and this itself is a distinction in these literate days--entertained any notion of writing a novel.

A survey of the real estate license laws in twenty-eight States has been compiled by Robert W. Semenow of Pittsburgh for the National Association of Real Estate Boards and the National Association of License Law Officials. It consists of 183 pages and has been distributed to all officers-charged with the administration of State realty license laws, to all State real estate associations and all local boards belonging to the national association.

S. S. Kresge of Detroit, a director of the S. S. Kresge Company, made in February a gift of 450,000 shares of the common stock of that company, which at the current market value of about $25 a share aggregated $11,250,000, according to the summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stock holders published today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Godmothers League, which maintains a day and night shelter for the babies of the poor, at 115 East 101st Street, will give a luncheon at the nursery on Friday in honor of the Amelia Relief, a pioneer organization out of which the Godmothers League has grown, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Zion de Frece Bernstein, president of the league.

Although Army Day falls on Tuesday, which is also the twentieth anniversary of the declaration of war of the United States against the central powers, members of the Veterans Corps of Artillery and the Military Society of the War of 1812 will not celebrate the event until Saturday when a reception to be followed by a dance will be held in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre after the Army Day parade.

An assertion that unnamed "hired help" sent to the Capitol by Attorney General Cummings was trying to choke off the hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee on President Roosevelt's Court bill, was made today by Senator Wheeler, one of the leaders in the fight against the proposal.

Any change in the American system of government, regardless of its nature, must be accomplished solely by means of a constitutional amendment after "calm and deliberate" consideration by the electorate of the nation, Presiding Justice Edward Lazansky of the Appellate Division, Second Department, declared last night.

APRIL'S first week gives the cue for shifting the scenery on the broadcasting stage. Some shows seek a more favorable hour as other acts change time or disappear for a seasonal vacation, while others, in an effort to add zest to the program pattern, enlist new talent.

Dr. and Mrs. Reginald Burbank gave a supper dance last night at their home, 6 East Seventy-eighth Street, for their daughter, Miss Marion Burbank, who was formally introduced to society by her parents at a reception given at their home on the afternoon of Thanksgiving Day.
The East Texas oil field, rocked by mass tragedy only sixteen days ago, today silently awaited John L. Lewis's drive to unionize the world's most prolific petroleum sector.

Jury service for women in New York State, as yet only a prospect, will not find them unprepared. The League of Women Voters, anticipating legalization of the measure in the near future, has opened a course of instruction in the duties of veniremen,

WHY stress night accidents? Consider these facts: In 1917 only one-third of the total fatalities occurred at night. Since then, while the rate of deaths from day accidents has fallen off slightly, the rate of night fatalities has sky-rocketed until today they represent very nearly twothirds of the total.

Five thousand persons, among whom were Postmaster General James A. Farley and Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York, witnessed the amateur boxing show for the sick-and death benefit fund of the New York Postoffice Clerks Association at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

CARACAS, Venezuela. THE government of Venezuela has just started an airplane tourist service from Caracas to the cataracts of the Orinoco River, into a picturesque and primitive land seldom seen by a traveler. About 300 miles by airline directly south of Caracas a modern airport, El Jobito,

The first commercial air charter for the North Atlantic has been given to the Oiley- Air Service. Ltd.. of Croydon which will provide the pilot and crew for he airliner now being built as ?? at Britain's entry in the New York-Paris international air race next August.

The marriage of Miss Aimee Virginia Bisgood, young daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Bisgood of this community, to Dr. Harrison L. McLaughlin of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Patrick McLaughlin of Ottawa, Ont., took place this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church. The rector, the Rev. H. E. Covell, officiated.

MEN called him "the learned blacksmith" and with reason, for he belonged to that age, strange in retrospect, when men educated themselves in the belief that knowledge was indeed the key to a power that could be used for the improvement of humanity.

Opposition to the proposed RogersRapp amendment to the State Constitution reducing from 2 to 1 3/4 per cent the tax limit on real property exclusive of funded debt service was voted yesterday by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union.

Behind the superlative five-hit hurling of Dick Bell, veteran right-hander, Princeton University's baseball team staged a complete reversal of form today on University Field and turned back an aggressive Villanova nine, 7-2, for its first triumph in three starts. The contest opened the Pennsylvanians' 1937 season.

THIS week will see the start of the big Spring exodus to Europe and the coronation. For months travel companies and steamship lines have been hard pressed to meet the demands of travelers fishing to include ooronation festivities with European tours.

GRIM Aran Islands off the entrance to Galway Bay. on the west coast of Ire land. One does not have to go back to Synge and "Riders to the Sea" to realize the heroic temper of the ocean-girt fisherfolk who for centuries have eked out a scanty living on windswept barrens and snatched a hazardous pittance from the swirling waters. A recent film.

THE mothers who have been taking their broods to the Cameo to see "Beethoven Concerto" on their Easter invasion of Broadway have been asking how the Soviets train musical prodigies to act like veteran troupers.

THERE is nothing haphazard about Arturo Toscanini. Known as "the perfectionist" among orchestra conductors, he brings that same musical perfection to radio. He is one man who can make the-broadcasters toe the mark of high standard, else he will have nothing to do with "the ether." His word is law; the broadcasters respect it.

FOR the second time in the two years of its history the New York Drama Critics Circle has selected a play by Maxwell Anderson as the best of the season. Last year it was "Winterset." This year it is "High Tor," the Hudson Highlands fantasy that has been playing at the Martin Beck Theatre since Jan. 9.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: The following officers are detailed as ?? unit instructors of the Organize Reserve units listed after their names, addition to their other duties, for the purpose of training those Reserve officers who may be assigned to these units, and to assist in the conduct of a Command Post Exercise, to be conducted for these units from July 25, 1937 to Aug. 7, 1937, inclusive.

Commodity futures moved irregularly in lessened activity on the local markets yesterday. Cocoa, coffee, world sugar, hide and tin futures gained, while rubber, copper, lead and zinc futures declined. Domestic sugar and cottonseed oil contracts were steady.

Spectators, among them many military men, will search memories to find the title of the marching music the United States Army Band plays when it passes the Presidential reviewing stand in celebration of Army Day next Tuesday.
Martin E. Greenhouse, a retired real estate operator, died at his home here last night of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

A recent survey of apartment house rentals by a Northwestern life insurance company disclosed the fact that approximately $18 a room per year is paid by the average apartment house tenant, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards. The survey comprised statistics from 354 apartment buildings and 1,165 one and two family houses in forty-eight cities in the Northwestern States.
Miss Deborah scull Lippincott of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Guy Currier, son of Mrs. Guy W. Currier of Boston and the late Mr. Currier.

A search has been started by the police for a man whom Mrs. Mary Gedeon introduced to friends within the last two years as "my new husband," it was disclosed yesterday by detectives seeking the murderer who strangled Mrs. Gedeon and her daughter, Veronica, and fatally stabbed Frank Byrnes, a roomer in their apartment.

Death today halted the transatlantic voyage of Margaret.Wilson of Philadelphia. En route to Drimgormily, County Donegal, Ireland, to visit relatives, she was found dead in her cabin aboard the Anchor liner Cameronia as that vessel put into port here.

Former President Hcrbert Hoover arrived tonight by train from California to be the guest of George F. Getz, former treasurer for the Republican National Committee, on a fishing cruise in the Florida Keys.

Underprivileged children who are cared for by the Society for the Relief of Half Orphan and Destitute Children will be the beneficiaries of a performance of "Miss Quis," a new play with Peggy Wood in the leading role, the night of April 29 at the Henry Miller Theatre.

The New York Junior League "Follies," a production to be presented by members of the Junior League on April 28 and 24 at the New Amsterdam Theatre, is now in rehearsal with a cast of league members and their friends chosen at a recent "casting party" in the organization's clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.
For the first time in several years a regiment of infantry will be among the ten to twenty thousand soldiers taking part in Summer manoeuvres at Pine Camp, the army's proving grounds.

A monumental 1,500-page report on American medicine, containing 5,000 contributions by 2,100 leading physicians and surgeons throughout the country, who were called in "consultation" to diagnose the "ills" of their own profession and to "prescribe" remedies, is made public today by the American Foundation, established by Edward W. Bok.

Miss Margaret Chalmers Hawley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Bronson Hawley of this city, was married this afternoon to Arthur Holroyd Moore Jr., son of Mrs. Arthur H. Moore and the late Mr. Moore. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Chauncey B. Brewster, assisted by the Rev. Ralph D. Read, in St. John's Episcopal Church.

More than 200 companies with funds tied up in Spain had responded up to yesterday to the National Foreign Trade Council's questionnaire asking for details of blocked balances.- The questionnaires sent out early this week are preliminary to a move by the council to negotiate for the liberation of American money in Spain after hostilities cease.

TWO weeks before his death on March 9. Paul Eltner More delvered to the Princeton University Pres the revised manuscript of a little book entitled "Pages From an Oxford Diary." This diary wirten originally about a dozen years ago while be was living in Oxford, si really Mr. More's confession of faith.
When rain today washed out the scheduled Red Sox-Dodger game, one member of Burleigh Grimes's squad did not know whether to be disappointed or glad.

For the first time in the six-year history of the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference, Bucknell University boxers came through with a team championship tonight, scoring 18 points in the finals of the annual tourney at the Penn A. C. before 1,500 persons.

ALONG with that other noted prima donna, Martha Raye, Kirsten Flagstad will contribute to the next annual Paramount potpourri, the 1938 version of the "Big Broadcast" dries. Miss Flagstad, engaged last veek in a coup comparable only to that in which Sarah Bernhardt was induced to enact "Queen Elizabeth" for the films in 1911, will provide an operatic interlude, just as Leopold Stokowski presented a symphonic one in the last "Big Broadcast."

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Hazen McChesney of Cynwood, Pa., and Skaneateles, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance McChesney, to Carl Frederik Brauer of this city, son of Mrs. Carl Wilhelm Brauer of Danbury, N. H., and the late Mr. Brauer.

The wedding of Miss Elizabeth Anne MacGregor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. MacGregor of this city, and Franklin Houston Martin, son of Mrs. James Martin, also of East Orange, took place today at the rectory of Holy Name Church. The Rev. Eugene F. Sullivan performed the ceremony.

Elusive S. J. Scarborough, hitchhiking killer, made his sixth prison break in twelve years today, with eight other convicts. Two of the others were convicted slayers serving life terms like Scarborough, who only Thursday was returned from Hobart, Ind., after an escape Feb. 8.

HUTCHISON, FRANCES CAMPBELL (March 19). Estate, less than $10,000. To William J. Hutchison, husband, 444 Central Park West, residue. JACOBS, RALPH J. (March 25). Estate, $10,000. To Mount Sinai Hospital, 5th Av.

John G. Winant, president of the Tripartite Technical Conference on the Textile Industry, addressing the delegates today, strongly endorsed the American policy of removing barriers to international trade through reciprocal trade agreements and urged upon the meeting the vital importance of expanding international trade if living standards were to be raised so as to permit a larger consumption of textile goods.

History and Biography SHIPS AND WOMEN. By Bill Adams. 8vo. Boston. Mass.: Little. Brown Co.. an Atlantic Monthly Press Book. $2.50. The memoirs of a youth at sea. CLAUDE KITCHIN AND THE WILSON WAR POLICIES. By Alex Mathews Arnett. 8vo. Boston. Mass.: Little. Brown Co. $3.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

Representatives of several New York architects' and sculptors' societies yesterday came to the defense of the design approved by the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission for a $3,000,000 memorial to Jefferson to be erected in the Tidal Basin at Washington.
A newly created Board of Home Missions of the Congregational and Christian Churches will take over Tuesday the work which has heretofore been carried on by seven national boards or "societies."

An endowment fund to establish a collection of books in the Princeton University Library in memory of the late Dr. Paul Elmer More, who died here last month, has grown steadily in the last year, according to the current issue of Biblia, the publication of the "Friends of the Princeton Library."

The hard-hitting Long Island University nine had little difficulty defeating the Quantico Marines today, 16 to 8, as the Blackbirds closed their Southern trip. Errors by the Marines contributed to the one-sided score.

Investors played a prominent part in real estate activity yesterday when properties changed hands in scattered sections of three boroughs. A Yorkville deal involved the fivestory apartment house at 120 East Eighty-second Street, which was resold by the Rimsovo Corporation,

Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar signed today an agreement granting Pan American Airways and the British Imperial Airways operating rights for twenty-five years for the proposed transatlantic air service.

SPRING comes to Washington in a breath-taking pageantry of loveliness when the Japa nese cherry trees burst into bloom, and at this season the nation's capital entertains its greatest crowds. A cold Easter week-end made necessary the lighting of smudge pots to keep the prized trees from freezing, and the next two weeks are expected to show the blossoms at-their best. Tomorrow begins official Cherry Blossom Week.

More than two-thirds of the two acres of space to be occupied by the North American Homes Exposition at Madison Squate Garden, May 12 to 23, has been sold or reserved, report L. Porter Moore and R. L. Pardon, directors of the event.

" Marked progress" in the campaign to put the so-called Torrens law for the registration of land titles in this State into more general use was reported yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania to honor Walter Fairchild, president of the Torrens Title League.

Mr. and Mrs. S. Winston Childs Jr. entertained with a dinner last night in the Mirror Room of Le Coq Rouge, later taking their guests to the supper dance at the River Club for the benefit of the Big Brother Movement.

An SOS repeated throughout the day yesterday caused ships to head for a point in mid-Atlantic where the 3,670-ton German freighter Borkum was foundering in heavy weather, with her steering gear gone and her plates opening to the seas.

The sit-down strikes in the automobile industry showed signs last week of getting out of the control of the union organizers who had started them. At Flint, Mich, scene of the fortyfour-day occupation which paralyzed General Motors production last January and February, the contract which the United Automobile Workers Union won as a result of that strike did not prevent new sit-downs. William S.
As the first six days of competition in the world's pocket billiard title tournament closed late last night at Ponzi's Academy, Onofrio Lauri of Brooklyn was in first place.

A small flying figure, Miss Claire Isicson of the Eastern Women's A. C. of Brooklyn, turned in a sterling performance in winning the women's metropolitan A. A. U. 50yard sprint championship, feature event of the athletes' development meet sponsored by the A. A. U.
The Yankees conquered the weather today, ignoring a rainstorm which greeted their arrival to play an exhibition game against the New Orleans Pelicans on soggy Hartwell Field.
The annual bridge tea under the auspices of the Ursuline alumnae of New Rochelle will be held on April 24 at 'the Plaza. Proceeds will be devoted to the Ursuline Novitiate benefit fund.

Brambly on Wicomico, a 500-acre farm situated between the Wicomico and Potomac Rivers in St. Mary's County, Md., has been sold by Joseph F. Crew to Joseph J. Tunney of Philadelphia, Pa. Leonard Snider, broker of La Plata, Md., negotiated the deal.

Epicurean customs associated with fashionable entertaining during New York's "elegant Eighties" will be revived at a "New-York-ofFifty-Years-Ago-Dinner" to be given at the Museum of the City of New York by that institution's trustees on Tuesday evening.
WHAT every one has deemed a Theatre Guild entry for next season, "Jane Eyre," ended its long pre-Broadway tour last night in Baltimore. It has been a distinct financial success.

Setting of a retail price of $3 for the novel "Gone With the Wind," has caused some immediate drop in sales, but the book continues the outstanding "best seller" in the country, it was reported yesterday by A. J. Blanton, sales manager of the Macmillan Company, which about ten days ago established the retail price for the book under the Feld-Crawford law.

The 1937 White Plains model home to be given away as a climax of the White Plains Better Housing Bureau's third annual exposition at the county center May 15 was opened for public Inspection at 3 P. M. today.

A total of 34,500 German Jews settled in Palestine during the fouryear period since the beginning of the Hitler regime, according to a report from the Jewish Agency for Palestine, received here yesterday by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal.

Superior stroking carried the well-mounted Ramapo Valley indoor polo trio to a 12-to-101/2 victory over Squadron C in the Eastern final of the Sherman Memorial competition at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.
A total of sixty-four members of the Tanners Council of America will participate in the officialopening of leathers for the Fall season, starting tomorrow at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Reports reaching here today said Insurgent fliers had bombarded Ceuta, Spanish Morocco, held by their own troops. The attack, said to have been made Thursday, strengthened persistent reports of revolts against General Francisco Franco in the area where he started the revolution against the Spanish Government.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELTS determination to effect a reorganization of the Federal courts through legislative action rather than through a consititutional amendment has dramatized as could nothing else the problem of adjusting our constitutional system to the changing needs of democracy.

Today Carroll Club-Spring tea dance, 4 P. M., clubhouse. Maplewood (N. J.) Woman's ClubMonthly concert. Hazel Burleigh and Marion Shoudy, artists, clubhouse. New York League of Girls ClubsTea, auspices Industrial Society, 4 P. M., clubhouse. Pen and Brush--Reception. Ford Madox Ford, guest of honor, 4 P. M., clubhouse.

A policy of militant pacifism was adopted yesterday by the Society of Friends following the report of the Quakers' Peace and Social Order Committee at the 242d session of the New York yearly meeting. A letter will be presented soon to President Roosevelt demanding that his "good neighbor policy" toward Latin America be extended to the rest of the world as a means of insuring world peace..
Mrs. E. Chandler Walker, widow of the eldest son of the late Hiram Walker, died today at her home in Washington, D. C., where she had lived for the last twenty years.
The city manager form of government in Cincinnati seems to be as firmly entrenched with the average man in the street today as it was when the experiment was first tried in 1926.

Leaders in the educational and engineering fields paid tribute yesterday to Collins P. Bliss, dean emeritus of the New York University College of Engineering, at ceremonies on the University Heights campus where a new engineering building and power plant was named in his honor.
THE art of the camera is decidedly to the fore at the moment, with material enough on exhibition to please all varieties of photographic taste and keep devotees of the lens busy for some time.

Mrs. Adele Rivero, winning for the sixth time in succession, assumed the lead yesterday in the women's open championship tournament being played under the auspices of the National Federation at the Marshall Chess Club.

Paintings by Turner, Constable, Corot, Hobbema and other artists, comprising property of Mrs. Marion B. Nellis and other collectors, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., Thursday evening.
