THE person who has the largest stake in American broadcasting is the listener, Dr. Irvin Stewart, vice chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, asserted in a recent address at Duke University, pointing to improvements necessary to give the listener more for his money.

Advocating a- housing policy that would have as its core decent housing for every family rather than slum clearance, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, urges that a study be made by the Federal Government of the mortgage situation in all localities of the country.

Miss Muriel Terry King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lewis King of this place, was married to Rowland Frank Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Smith of Southampton, this afternoon in the Westhampton Presbyterian Church on Quiogue. The Rev. Thomas Coyle, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.
St. John's University conquered the Wagner College nine in the latter's opening game of the season yesterday at Wolverine Oval, Staten Island, 13 to 1.

Celerating the completion of a quarter of a century of service to American childhood, a distinguished group of men and women from all parts of the United States will assemble here for a dinner on Thursday in honor of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

The reopening of classes at the University of Havana, center of all revolutionary activities since 1927, cannot be considered as an indication that a state of normalcy has been attained in the island, but it does show that idealistic, hot-headed students are willing for the first time to compromise on the points at issue.
Georges Bonnet, recently appointed French Ambassador at Washington, repeated yesterday his denial made in a recent radio broadcast that his country would seek financial aid in the United States.

American medicine stands divided in two strongly opposing camps on the question of group practice. This is brought out in answers by 2,100 doctors, representing a cross-section of the American medical profession, to a comprehensive inquiry on the problems of medical care for the American people, made public today by the American Foundation.
Number One holdout Red Ruffing settled himself more firmly in his chair today, as determined as ever to "sit it out" unless the Yankees meet his demand for a $16,000 contract.

The Florida Bar Association adopted a resolution today, 124 to 37, opposing President Roosevelt's Judiciary revision bill. In an address to the association on the final day of its annual convention President Frederick H. Stinchfield of the American Bar Association predicted an all-powerful central government should Mr. Roosevelt's proposal to increase the membership of the Supreme Court be enacted.

CEDRIC BELFRAGE'S amusing definition of an escapist as a person "who looks the facts of life squarely in the back of the neck" has more than its usual application to Hollywood these romantic days. It used to be that the cinema's unrealists were content to be escapists in their selection of subject matter; now, and for some time past, they have been following escapist procedure not merely in theme but in their treatment of it.

A new service, believed to be "the first merchandising plan of its kind ever established by a bank in this country," will be inaugurated on Wednesday by the Morris Plan Bank of New York whereby persons may obtain funds from the bank for the purchase of merchandise for cash from R. H. Macy Co., Inc.
Wesleyan University opened its baseball season with a decisive 8-4 victory over the Stevens Tech nine at Castle Point Field today.

The only performance of Richard Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" scheduled for Philadelphia this season will be given at the Academy of Music next Tuesday evening by the Civic Grand Opera Company of Philadelphia.

The recovery in United States Government bonds was extended moderately during the two-hour trading session yesterday, net gains ranging from l/32 to 1/2 point. The turnover in those issues on the Stock Exchange was fairly large for a Saturday, amounting to $4,010,900, compared with sales of only $875,400 the week before.

Hundreds of bills affecting real estate and particularly mortgage problems are before the State Legislature, with the prospect that quite a few will be adopted before adjournment. State Legislators and real estate interests are studying the proposals, which have a direct bearing on sales of property and on future methods of mortgage financing.

Sinking fund operations last week involving many small amounts of bonds brought an increase over the preceding week in the number of announcements of bonds called for redemption before maturity. The calls covered a wide variety of issues, with those for industrial corporations predominating. Payment dates were mostly for future months, only some small amounts of municipal bonds being called for April.

Foreign traders and domestic manufacturers are looking forward eagerly to the arrival in this country next month of a Japanese economic mission composed of leading industrialists who are coming here to repay the visit made to Japan two years ago by American business men.

The President of the United States, like his predecessor and distant kinsman, Theodore Roosevelt, knows how to coin and apply a telling phrase. He has done so on many occasions. One item in the steadily growing collection is the war term "no-man's land," with which the President described the situation that arose after the Supreme Court last year had ruled against the New York State Minimum Wage Law.
Five members of New York's street-cleaning force are soon to begin a free course in engineering at New York University

REPORT has it that the Elffel Tower, one of the world's best-known landmarks, will be demolished. Started in 1887, the slender steel spire was formally opened for the 1889 Paris Exposition. Since that time bitter controversy has raged around its spiderweb network.

A brief price war that sent the cost of milk to consumers below 5 cents a quart was reported yesterday among a few neighborhood stores on the lower East Side. It ended a short while after it began and prices rose to 7 cents and 8 cents a quart in the neighborhood. Independent companies sold at 8 cents.

Threading her way from Hobart, Tasmania, through the South Seas, the fifteen-ton Norwegian yacht Ho Ho arrived in Callao Bay a short time age and after undergoing repairs here will continue to New York on the last lap of her round-the-world voyage. The crew of the Ho Ho are, contrary to the ways of men at sea, all skippers.

Amicable settlement of the crisis arising in the ranks of the Junior Woman's Club of Bergenfield, N. J. over the mandatory age limit of 29 imposed by a ruling of the State Federation was effected last week. Ninety of the membership,

Hartwick College celebrated today the centennial of the birth of John Burroughs, naturalist and author, and set aside for him first place in its proposed hall of fame. "It seemed fitting that in launching this new hall of fame we should give first place to one of the most illustrious sons of this section," Dr. Charles W. Leitzell, president of the college, asserted in a memorial service in the college chapel.
AMINATURE retrospective exhibition of paintings by Georgia O'Keeffe is accomplished in the group of pictures assembled in the Lounge Gallery of the American Woman's Association (through April 16).
Elza Evans, Pottawatomie County's "lie-down" striking Sheriff, today accepted his March salary after a successful mandamus action, and shouted, "Well, boys, we've won our fight."

Miss Margaret Gage Crofut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Crofut of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and granddaughter of Mrs. Harlan Hoge Ballard of Pittsfield, was married to William Augustus Whittlesey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Whittlesey of this city, at the First Congregational Church tonight.

The Rev. Frederick P. Houghton, for six years a member of the staff of the National Field Department of the Episcopal Church, has been made executive secretary of the Diocese of Pennsylvania by Bishop Tailt and the diocesan executive council.
A PORTRAIT from life is, of course, a definite--and difficult-thing. It is not a mere personal remniscence. It is not a professionally critical appraisal.

The third anniversary of the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, formed in 1934 to aid families in this city in solving their mortgage problems, will be celebrated at noon tomorrow at City Hall.
Anatole Kalichevsky, retired general of the White Army of Russia and a court officer of the last of the Czars, died here on Thursday at the age of 66.
William G. Rice, for thirty years chief engineer of the Philadelphia Bourse, died today in his penthouse atop the Bourse Building after an illness of two days. He was 71 years old.

It's hard to keep Texas out of the limelight in any golf tournament these days because when one of the representatives of the Lone Star State slips there's always another to step in and take his place.

Miss Dorothy Devereaux, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clement Devereaux of 175-02 Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, was married to William Henry Ryan, son of Dr. George J. Ryan, former president of the New York City Board of Education, and Mrs. Ryan of Flushing, Queens, yesterday in the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Jamaica.

Leptosyne is one of those flowers ignored by many gardeners because the name looked unprepossessing. Yet the long known Leptosyne stillmani has the common name of Golden Daisy, and the flowers are of the ever popular daisy form.

An experiment in centralized police control will be started here tomorrow under the direction of Police Chief William H. Funston when city precincts are to be abolished and newly designed and tested twoway radio auto patrols will go into operation.

SEVERAL new courses have been added to the curriculum of the music education department of the Juilliard Summer School. Hazel Kinscella will conduct classes in methods of teaching piano to children; Irving Cheyette will hold classes in orchestral instrument instruction, and Mortimer Browning and Blanche Witherspoon will Inproduce courses dealing with the children's theatre.

MIAMI, Fla. GAZING over blue Biscayne Bay from the sun deck of the glaring white Pan-Amer ican Airways Building, the flier compared the world to a sponge; said that fast planes had "squeezed the water out of it." He pointed due South.
A steady stream of money today flowed into the Gonzales Warm Spring Foundation's "living memorial" to the children who died in the New London school explosion, March 18.
An appeal for Federal aid to public schools was made today by the South Dakota Department of Public Instruction and the South Dakota Education Association.
Pratt Institute lost the opening game of its 1937 baseball schedule today, dropping a 9-3 decision to Rhode Island State.

JINX: Last year Sir Alexander Seton's wife took to her home in Scotland a bit of bone said to be part of an entombed Pharaoh's skeleton. Since then ghosts have been reported in the house, sudden illnesses have stricken the family, twice the house has caught fire, servants have had hysterics. Last week Lady Seton left for Egypt to restore the bone to its tomb.

Even the tiniest of city or suburban backyard can be made into a bit of paradise. Money is not the "limiting factor," although man people assume that the expense will be so great that they do nothing about it.
With the reopening of school tomorrow, the second edition of "All the Children," annual report of the Department of Education, City of New York, will be mailed to educators th roughout the country.

Real estate holdings of the late William o. Allison, consisting of approximately 700 acres of vacant land in Bergen County and valued at $3,500,000 have been placed on the market with Joseph P. Day acting as sales agent.

Democratic and Republican political leaders and office holders were among the 2,000 persons who attended a testimonial dinner in the Hotel Commodore last night in honor of Deputy Controller Milton Solomon.

FEW realize how much American ingenuity and inventiveness have accomplished in cheapening the prices of books. Linotypes, highspeed presses, intricate machines for folding, sewing and casing have had their share in placing books within the reach of every one.

Announcement last week that mayonnaise dealers in California have availed themselves of the fair trade act there and sent out price maintenance contracts created widespread interest among members of the grocery industry.

Better medical education is the key to the solution of the problem of better medical care for more people, according to the views of eminent teachers In leading medical schools, as well as of many leading practicing physicians.

One of the most controversial issues of the 1936 Congress session came suddenly to life again today when Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, Chief of Army Engineers, reported that the Federal Government would be justified in spending $197,921,000 to construct a ship canal across Florida.
The Corn Belt farmer starts another crop year with three chief worries-drought, the chinch bug and the grasshopper, and the greatest of these is the grasshopper.

AMERCANS have proved again that they like to take a chance. Hundreds of them held winning tickets in this year's Irish Sweepstakesfor the Grand National Thousands scanned published lists of winners in the hope of finding their names. For gambling is a mania which persists.

The Giants played baseball today with vim, vigor and an air of finality that looked utterly superior to anything the Indians had to offer, when suddenly their air gave out, causing them to lose much of their vim and vigor and almost the ball game as well.

Steel union forces of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization asserted today that they had obtained recognition from forty-six steel companies in the United States and were negotiating for collective -bargaining contracts with eighteen other producers.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Charles Milner Jr. of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Evergreen Lake, Onondaga County, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lillian Harris Milner, to Daniel McCabe, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. McCabe of Baltimore.

Twenty years ago tomorrow, the United States Senate passed the resolution declaring war against Germany. Only six Senators ventured to vote against the measure, La Fallette of Wisconsin, Norris of Nebraska, Lane of Washington, Stone of Missouri, Vardaman of Mississippi and Gronna of North Dakota.

LIKE other lands, Canada, despite her favorable position from the point of view of protection and defense, is increasing her air armaments. The budget proposals for this year and next show an increase in excess of 150 per cent for the Royal Canadian Air Force. In number of airplanes the force is to be augmented by more than 100 and personnel is to be enlarged to 195 officers and 1,498 enlisted men.

The Johns Hopkins University's new faculty clubhouse, following a formal opening last week, is starting to function as a recreation center for members of the faculty, alumni, graduate students and their guests.

Mortgage financing in the future will stand on sounder and safer foundations than was generally the case prior to the depression period declares Philip W. Kniskern, president of the First Mortgage Corporation of Philadelphia. This strange situation he holds is being achieved as a result of a better knowledge of the factors upon which the real values of income properties depend.

In a room hung with oil paintings, water colors and miniatures executed by their members, the New York League of American Pen Women will hold a "celebrities breakfast" tomorrow at 12:30 P. M. in the National Arts Club, Gramercy Park South.
EDELSTEIN-ALBERT-Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Albert announce the engagement of their daughter, Frances Claire, to Dr. Samuel Edelstein, son of Mr. Joseph and the late Anna Edelstein, Jersey City.

Members of the Maryland Society of New York will hold their annual founders' dinner on Friday at the Beekman to mark the anniversary of the founding of the Colony of Maryland on March 25, 1634. Herbert R. O'Conor, Attorney General of Maryland, will speak.

For the three months ended March 31 the average price of real estate bond issues advanced 1.8 per cent, according to the Amott-Baker Realty Bond Averages, based upon 200 selected issues of properties in New York, Buffalo, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and other Eastern cities.

David O'Donnell, 18 years old, a freshman chemistry student at the University of Illinois, was killed tonight and Rodger Shields, 18, also a freshman chemistry student, was seriously injured when a home-made bomb with which they were experimenting exploded prematurely.
If the fate of Spain's civil war could have been settled in the air, the government probably would have won a cleancut victory several months ago. It must now be obvious

Rotary International was violently attacked here today by one of the smaller neo-pagan journals, the Blitz, in a six-page "expose." Rotary is linked with Free Masons and with a general antiNazi point of view. The author of the article, Friedrich Hassenbacher, demands that Rotary introduce an "Aryan clause" into its statutes.

A chance to receive a reward "without any questions asked" for the return of $3,000 worth of church ornaments was lost yesterday by a burglar when detectives recovered the stolen pieces, obtained a description of the thief and promised an arrest shortly.

Governor Hoffman, who formerly was Motor Vehicle Commissioner and was instrumental in promoting safety programs throughout New Jersey, will speak at the graduation exercises of the Rutgers University Traffic Officers Training School the evening of April 16.
IT is indeed a long span in the career of a single artist that Dr. Schaeffer has undertaken to indicate. at his gallery in Fifty-seventh Street, with the assistance of but four paintings.
A strike by 150 cadides at the Chickasaw Golf Club lasted thirty minutes today. At exactly noon the caddies walked out of the "bullpen" and demanded 75 cents for eighteen holes instead of 60 cents.

New York's Mayor receives from his public 1,000 letters a day, and whether the expressions of opinion are written on penny-pad paper or engraved stationery they are read carefully. People write the Mayor about almost every Epic in the news, particularly about tabor troubles, the noise campaign, traffic problems and relief. Over 3,000 letters were received during the recent anti-Nazi episode.

CAMERAS licked steadily during a recent visit of some 200 rail "fans" to the Bald win Locomotive Works at Philadelphia and the Pennsylvania shops at Wilmington, Del. Vestpocket cameras, large folding cameras, candid cameras, cameras of all sizes and shapes were turned on an equally varied assortment of locomotives. It was a field day for the engine-picture fans.

LONDON.-In the next few uncommonly eventful weeks, which will be marked in London by the coronation of George VI and the meeting of the most important Imperial Conference in many years, Britain will acquire a new Prime Minister and a somewhat altered Cabinet.

In the opening tennis match, of the local season Navy was defeated by Yale today, 7 to 2, taking one match in singles and another in doubles. Captain Grantham of Navy led off by winning a well-played match with Dalrymple, Yale ace, taking two of three close sets.

ALTHOUGH this Tuesday marks the twentieth anniversary of America's entrance into the World War, A. E. F. veterans now resident in the United States still cherish the memory of their service in France and maintain their interest in things French, judging from the correspondence files of Paris Post No. 1 of the American Legion.

FOR the first time in the history of the cinema, there is a shortage of scenery. In what is regarded as a renaissance of the Western, the eleven leading exponents of the brave and the true are tumbling over one another on the two favored locations for horse operas, Kernville and Lone-Pine, at the base of the Sierras.
State Department officials announced today that Cuba's nomination of President Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Nobel Peace Prize had received official backing from seven other countries.
Development operations are proceeding on some 160 gold mining properties in the Province of Quebec, according to a survey made this week.

Supplied with food and bedding by relatives and friends, 108 sitdown strikers at the Weiman Company furniture plant prepared today for a long siege. Homer Grossman, president of the company, said he would take no action to remove them.

Mrs. E. Roland Harriman and a group of prominent women actively interested in the maintenance of the Boys Club of New 'York have taken over the performance of "Babes in Arms," Dwight Deere Wiman's new musical play with a score by Rogers. and Hart, on the night of April 19 at the Shubert Theatre as a benefit for the club. The play is scheduled to open here next week.

Lord and Lady Ashburton of London, who have been at the Pierre since their return from visits in California and Arizona, will sail Wednesday for home on the Queen Mary. Mrs. De Lancey Nicoll is expected at the Westbury today from Middleburg, Va.

Dwellings reported as having been sold recently by members of the Bay Shore (L. I.) Brokers Association include the following: At Brightwaters, the Hart O'Brien houses on Windsor Avenue, the Shields house on Concourse East, the Barrett, Lohse, Ruppe Bermingham houses on Bay Way Avenue,

Plans for the erection of a seven-story factory building at 344-56 Wallabout Street, at the corner of Harrison Avenue, Brooklyn, were filed with the Brooklyn Department of Buildings yesterday by Charles Pfizer Co., manufacturing chemists, of 11 Bartlett Street.
RIDING high, on top of the air waves, because the Women's National Radio Committee awarded them parchment scrolls as radio's "best" for 1936-37, are the six following programs:

" Ride a Cock Horse," by Robert York and George Bruhl, opened at the Royalty Theatre tonight after postponement of a few days due to the leading player, Laura Cowie, having strained a leg muscle during dress rehearsal.

Stocks improved slightly and closed steady in quiet trading; turnover, 643,050 shares. United States Government bonds steadier and closed generally higher; other bonds irregular; transactions, $8,410,900.

When the question of the weight of patronage and public largesse in behalf of President Roosevelt's judiciary reorganization plan was raised before the Senate Judiciary Committee this week, one Senator remarked privately that the public hearings had better be closed.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-Because the season, lengthened by several weeks during the last two years. shows every sign of continuing until late Spring, hotels and clubs are postponing their closing dates. Although colonists are still entertaining frequently and with large affairs, these will become smaller and less formal as the days pass, until the end of this month will be given over entirely to impromptu events.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being April 2 unless specified: At Pearl Harbor: Breese, Gamble, Montgomery, Ramsay. At San Diego: Neches, Partridge. LaHaina to Mare Island Yard: Preston, Smith.
IN November a year ago an interesting chapter in local history was written by the widely publicized sale at the Rains Galleries of books from the William D. Breaker library.

Striking with sudden force in the second period, the New York Rangers staggered the Montreal Maroons with a trio of goals, and then went on to score a knockout over the favored local sextet tonight. Led by the sharp-shooting Neil Colville,

Public Service Company of Colora do and subsidiaries - For 1936: Net income after interest, amortization, Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, $3,182,325, which, after dividend requirements on company's 7 per cent, 6 per cent and 5 per cent preferred stocks, was equal to $12.08 a share on 208,000 common shares outstanding at end of year.

THE exhibition of prints by artists working in the Graphic Art Division of the WPA Federal Art Project enjoyed a well deserved enthusiastic send-off by John Taylor Arms last Tuesday afternoon at the Federal Gallery in East Thirty-eighth Street.

Problems and experiences of the institutions which they head in many parts of the country will be the theme of the three-day assembly of members of the National Federation of Day Nurseries here this week.

HOBOVITZ-Mr. and Mrs. Moe S., announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Robert Sigmund, on Saturday, April 10, at 10 A. M., Temple Beth-Emeth, Brooklyn. Reception at home, 1,015 East 10th St., Brooklyn, Sunday, April 11, after 3 P. M. No cards.
Pitcher Thomas halted a ninthinning rally today by fanning two batters, with the bases filled and four runs in, enabling Ohio Wesleyan to defeat West Virginia, 12 to 9, in a loosely played game.

A one-story taxpayer will be erected on a plot 80 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Nostrand Avenue and Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, by Roth Gould, who have taken a long-term lease on the property. The three 40-yearold houses on the site are being demolished.
Winning for the third straight year, the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute day school rifle team retired the second St. John's rifle trophy when it captured the eighth annual

Stanley S. Tumbridge of 141 Willow Street, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Dorothy Olcott Tumbridge, to William McCarroll Mark, son of Mrs. Henry A. Mark and the late Mr. Mark of Manhattan.

With the opening of the International Sugar Conference in London tomorrow, attention in sugar circles is centered on the possible developments and the probable outcome. The aim of the conference is to arrive, if possible, at a scheme for the control of production and marketing of world sugar.

Capturing every one of his thirteen bouts, Paul Riccardi of Barringer High School of Newark won the annual open interscholastic foils fencing championship at the Salle d'Armes Vince in Manhattan yesterday.

Indications that a larger number of homes will be erected in many of the popular residential communities of New Jersey this season than was the case last year are shown by the announcement from the New Jersey FHA office that within the past two weeks twentyfive prospective developments in the three counties of Essex, Morris and Union were presented for subdivision approval. In several of them improvement work is already under way.

Miss Carol Marion, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Marion of Shippan Point, Stamford, was married to Edwin Brightman, son of Professor Charles Lewis Brightman and Mrs. Brightman of Syracuse, N. Y., at the Marion home this afternoon by the Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church.

ROLE: "The Americas have become the old world, with a lesson to teach to a new world that does not realize how very old, how discarded by human experience, is the backward and reactionary path."--Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

A large committee of Brooklyn women will assist Mrs. Raymond V. Ingersoll tomorrow and Tuesday when she opens her home at 380 Clinton Avenue for an exhibition and sale of handicrafts made by the refugee women of the Near East, under the supervision of the Near East Foundation.

Mrs. O'Donnell Iselin will open her home at Davenport Neck here on Monday for the first of a series of bridge parties to be held throughout Westchester County to aid the Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help,

A rummage sale for the benefit of the Yorkville-Speedwell Unit, which provides care for convalescent children, will be held on April 14, 15 and 16, the location to be announced later. Donations are being received by Miss Cordelia Bookwalter, chairman of the committee.

Many tenants occupying offices in the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street, are protecting their future requirements by renewing their leases and in several cases by expanding their quarters, according to Henry I. Chanin of Chanin Management, Inc. Although several of the leases have some time to run, the tenants have extended their tenure, he said.

A large reception will be given for members of the English-Speaking Union and their guests Thursday night to mark the official opening of the organization's new national headquarters, occupying a large part of the fifteenth floor at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
Dr. Hagop H. Rejebian, a leader in Armenian circles here for a number of years, died yesterday at the age of 72. His home was at 127 East Twenty-eighth Street.
Miss Mabel Webster Beiser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rufus W. Beiser of Brooklyn, was married last night to Harry Edwin Hamilton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lee Hamilton of Maplewood, N. J.

Philadelphia's battle for Germantown as the venue of the finalround Davis Cup match in the American Zone came to naught yesterday and the Forest Hills stadium of the West Side Tennis Club was established beyond revocation as the scene of the all-important tie in which the teams of Australia and the United States are expected to meet May 29, 30 and 31.

IN these days, when so many persons regard poetry as one of the twinkling superfluities of life, it is refreshing to read so sturdy and so serene a vindication of the poet's place as one finds in the present volume. "Philosophies, histories, treaties are forgotten," declares Dr. Dinsmore, "but the poets abide."

A NEW chapter in faster and more luxurious railroad travel in the West has been opened with the inauguration of Southern Pacific's new streamlined train, the Daylight, between Los Angeles and San Francisco.

Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, will discuss his program for the school at a dinner, sponsored by the New York City committee on the president's program, Princeton University, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Friday at 7:30 P. M., it was announced .yesterday by Gordon S. Rentschler, chairman of the committee.

Exports of finished and semi-finished products from the United States will show a gain of approximately 20 per cent for the first quarter of this year compared with the corresponding period of 1936 and an even more substantial increase in the following quarter, trade authorities forecast here yesterday.

Most of Europe feels a thrill of new confidence in these early Spring days that it will be able to avert another war. It is as though a nightmare of fear were ending and sanity were returning to international life.

Paul E. Stark, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards will discuss phases of the national housing policy and the needs for a sound home building system at the Central Atlantic regional convention to be held at the Hotel Biltmore in this city May 14 and 15.

The Pacific Coast League officially opened the 1937 professional baseball season-and its thirty-fifth campaign-before about 40,000 fans in four California cities today. Portland, 1936 champion; Seattle, San Francisco's Seals and Los Angeles were the victors.

THE ineffective State," according to Mr. Hessler, "is in the modern world, a State ready and waiting for seizure by ruthless political realists. It is prime for conversion into dictatorship and despotism. no matter how deeply wedded to democratic ideas the population may be."

Mayor La Guardia has ordered the police to put an end to the penny candy "racket," it was announced yesterday. This "racket," it was explained, is the practice of selling penny candy or gum to children through the lure of prizes to lucky purchasers. The prizes range from pennies to pennants.

With only one case of seasickness reported, a group of 1937-model Noah's Arks docked in swift succession last night at the Harlem River railroad yards at 135th Street and Willis Avenue and debarked inembers of the four-legged cast of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

Dartmouth, after winning five out of six games on its Southern baseball trip, bowed to Temple University nine in the latter's opening contest today, 8-7. Johnny Kovacevics, sophomore third baseman, starred for the Owls with three hits, including a triple, with Charley Tesreau, son of the Dartmouth coach, had three singles for the Indians.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wasserman of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claire Wasserman, to Sidney E. Barnard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Barnard, also of this city.

The engagement of Miss Carol Van Velsor Hibson, daughter of Mrs. Albert Van Velsor Hibson of this place, and the late Mr. Hibson, to J. Dwight Bridge, also of Cranford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Bridge of Sauthold, L. I., has been announced Jy her mother.
Thirty-two of the 173 seniors at the College of New Rochelle were singled out by their classmates in a class poll last week prior to the departure of the students for the Spring recess.

Studies of influenza have established that it follows travel lanes and that the velocity of its spread has been increased by the growth of travel habits in the last halfcentury, Dr. Edward A. Ward of Saginaw, Mich., said yesterday at the opening of the seventeenth annual convention of the Eastern Osteopathic Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Miss Margaret Crozer Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Errington Martin of Elkins Park, was married this afternoon to Joseph Coleman Bright, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bright of Cedar Hill Farm, Reading.
SOVIET REPRESENTATIVE: It is going on four years since the longclosed Russian Embassy in Washington was reopened and refurbished for Alexander Trove.

After registering successive victories over Dartmouth and Vermont, Virginia's nine was swamped by Maryland today, 18 to 5. Three Cavalier pitchers who received wretched support throughout were touched for twenty hits, including two home runs, a triple and double.

For their annual May Day Festival this year the students of Sweet Briar College are planning an Elizabethan celebration which will convert the campus into an English village and transform the student body into country boys and girls, villagers, soldiers, county gentry, strolling musicians and players and other citizens typical of the many-sided life of Elizabethan England.

LONDON is celebrating the advent of cheaper television. The English and American tele systems being quite parallel scientifically, it is believed in radio circles that what is taking place in London's air will eventually spread to New York.
Through the activities of the Jones. Beach Surf Fishing Club, brown and brook trout have been planted in certain streams and ponds of Nassau County.

Spring, the running tide and the call of adventure conspired yesterday to lure three boys out upon the East River aboard a make-shift raft, but when their clumsy paddles proved both tiring and inadequate they accepted a lift to shore aboard a Department of Sanitation lighter.
The Screen Actors Guild, which has a membership of more than 5,000 players-both stars and extras--will make another attempt to win union recognition from the motionpicture producers.
A Spring snowstorm swept North Dakota and Southwestern Minnesota today, isolating at least one Southern Minnesota town and hampering communication and travel in others.

Through the generosity of Dr. Gustavus W. Cook, a photographic telescope will be added to the equipment of the Flower Astronomical Observatory of the University of Pennsylvania. The telescope, which is now being constructed, will have a four-inch Lundin-Fecker lens of twenty-eightinch focal length.

The three-story studio building at 744-748 Madison Avenue, plot 75 by 95 feet,. adjoining the southwest corner of Sixty-fifth Street, will be sold under foreclosure proceedings on Wednesday by Edwin J. McDonald in the Vesey Street rooms. The action is brought by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company against First National Realty, Inc., and others. The approximate amount of the lien is $452,619.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 1: CAPTAINS Jones. C. A., Groton, Conn.. to duty as manager, Navy Yard. New York, in July. Mathewson, R. W., Washington, D. C., to command the Louisville in May.

Philadelphia's governmental set-up is undergoing some deftly executed plastic surgery in the operating room of the Pennsylvania Legislature. Generally speaking, the Republicans are shocked and irritated at the changed aspect, but the Democrats, responsible for the operative work, with Governor Earle as a consulting specialist, are highly pleased with their efforts.
Activity on the Boerse declined again today and again approached stagnation. It appeared as if the strength received by the market from the April coupon-cutting had been exhausted.
Two veteran peace officers stood "toe-to-toe" today and "shot it out" in front of a downtown cafe. City Marshal J. D. Shelbburne was killed and Chief Deputy Sheriff

UP the river is a place New Yorkers hardly ever think of going unless they are sent, but Fay Bainter lives on a farm near Ossining from choice and commutes back and forth even when she is appearing in a Broadway play.

That the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is recruiting its students from an ever broader territorial base, without the introduction of a definite campaign in that direction, is revealed by figures showing the geographical distribution of the student body this year.

Miss Lois Adeline Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Wise of this city, was married to Harrison Gray Otis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Gray Otis of Rutherford, this evening at Grace Episcopal Church, Rutherford,

The annual card party and Spring fashion show under the auspices of the Associate Alumnae of Hunter College will take place Saturday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for carrying on the charitable enterprises of the organization. Mrs. Robert E. Draddy heads the group in charge.

Mayor La Guardia's recently appointed City Industrial Relations Board met briefly at City Hall yesterday afternoon with striking employes and owners of twenty-seven Brooklyn laundries. About 1,500 laundry workers are involved In the strike.

ITS awfully easy, in a squirrel cage," says william M. Strong, "to get into the habit of being a squirrel" Get out of it, he says. Get away from your own country. Liven up your mind. You haven't time? Vacation too short? Not enough money? Well, you'll know better than that when you've read this book.

The marriage of Miss Emily Adele Gibson, daughter of Colonel Adelno Gibson, U. S. A., and Mrs. Gibson of Governors Island, to Robert Murray Field, son of Major Robert Baxter Field, U. S. A., and Mrs. Field of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Cornelius the Centurion, Governors Island.

A survey of residential and business occupancy just completed by the Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood, N. J., showed a vacancy of only 3 per cent in all types of residential housing units, reports Donald W. Willett of of East Orange, chairman of the survey committee.

Under bright skies and before 6,000 socialite followers of the turf, Paul Mellon's fast-stepping Welbourne Jake took the Deep Run Hunt Cup at the tenth annual Deep Run Hunt Club meeting over the Curles Neck course today. The success of his gelding gave the Pittsburgh sportsman permanent ownership of the $500 trophy, as twice before, in 1934 and 1935, his Drinmore Lad had won the event.

The Spanish Government issued a statement today declaring large quantities of poison gas were being loaded at Hamburg, Germany, for shipment to the Insurgents. The government declared its information came from "official sources."

THIS year's National Academy itself is a puzzling side-show to the lively collection of contemporary prints John Taylor Arms has assembled in what used to be called the "morgue." The print committee announces that those entrusted with the selection "recognize no distinction

The editors of nine metropolitan college papers met yesterday in Hartley Hall, Columbia University, and formed the Metropolitan College Newspaper Association. The conference was called by Thomas M. Jones, editor of The Columbia Spectator, and Albert Sussman, editor of The City College Campus.
The sitdown strike went into reverse today when seventeen girl clerks stayed all night in the Scott 5-and10-cent store to. make sure that they would have work.

A service in memory of the Rev. Dr. Warren H. Wilson, secretary in charge of rural work of the Presbyterian Board of Home Missions, who died on March 2, will be held tomorrow at 4 P. M. in the James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

Sunny days, crocuses and the chatter of the first migrant birds have combined to make hordes of amateur gardeners dreamy-eyed with visions of glorious bloomings on their own little plots of land. This form of Spring fever accounts for the signs of renewed life in shops where garden tools are sold. Here the gardener finds gadgets that will help him make the "perfect garden."

Of the $3,939,249 in allotments which Administrator Harry L. Hopkins announced today had been approved by the President, $159,962 were for New York State communities, $123,082 for New Jersey, and $247,475 for Connecticut.

" Students in a Changing World" has been announced by Miss Louise Harman of Northfield as the theme for the Middle Atlantic Regional Conference of the National Student Federation of America. Miss Harman is chairman of the conference and a senior at New Jersey College for Women.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard George Auspitzer of Lawrence, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Clare Auspitzer, to Bernard H. Fee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Fee of Far Rockaway.

The prevention of littered streets, ugly billboards and unsightly conditions along the highways is a responsibility of the art teachers in the schools of the country, it was said at the closing session yesterday of the annual meeting of the Eastern Arts Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Girls of the Florida State College for Women are studying family life from many different aspects this semester, in a course introduced as part of the new curriculum.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lafayette Ray Chamberlin of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Wentworth Chamberlin, to Eliot Butler Willauer, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ebbs Willauer of Rye, N. Y.

Luis Companys. President of autonomous Catalonia, announced the formation of a new Cabinet today to replace the government of Premier Jose Tarradellas, which resigned March 26 over political differences.

DETROIT. IN the past few months the country has been brought face to face in sudden and dramatic fashion with a deep and underlying social problem, the inner significance of which the general public is just beginning to comprehend.

MARIO LABROCA, the new general superintendent of the Teatro Comunale and dependent "Maggio Musicale Fiorentino," discloses some details illustrating the plans for Florence's "Third Musical May" (April 27-June 8), rated Italy's major lyric event of the year and which promises to be fully as attractive as its justly celebrated predecessors of 1933 and 1935.

Miss Kathleen Meehan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Francis Meehan of Montclair, was married this morning to Edward Lester Heywood, son of William Henry Heywood of Brattleboro, Vt., and the late Mrs. Heywood.

THE preparations that are under way at the University of Pennsylvania for the cultural Olympics soon to be held there direct attention to the man who for years has advocated artistic competitions similar in character to athletic contests and who persuaded the university to stand sponsor for this novel protect in education.

Canadian Government, Provincial and municipal financing for the first three months of 1937 amounted to $340,211,637, the largest volume for a similar period in any of the last five years, according to figures compiled by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd. Of the 1937 total, $328,257,950 was issued for refunding purposes and $11,953,687 for new money.

For the protection of Americans who own real estate in Germany, acquired either during the inflation period or by inheritance, an organization has been formed in Berlin known as the Berlin Credit Investment Company. In Berlin alone, 5.7 per cent of the foreign-owned real estate

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Barbara Hetzler of this city and New York, daughter of the late Walter L. Hetzler, to Robert Brentlinger, son of J. B. Brentlinger, also of Dayton. The prospective bride attended Ohio State University.

This week will be the most important of the Spring field-trial season for pointers and setters in this section of the country. The two leading meetings, both giving large cash prizes, are scheduled during the next eight days, each having arranged four stakes.

One of the most eagerly awaited boxing bouts of the indoor season will take place tomorrow night when Lou Ambers, holder of the world lightweight championship, engages the sensational Pedro Montanez of Puerto Rico in a ten-round battle at Madison Sauare Garden.

The Federal Government wishes to put a little of the romance of the sea into the nation's fish markets. Fisheries specialists would have all fish emporiums called "sea food markets" and have the window displays of denizens of the deep replaced with miniature seascapes, replete with tiny flashing lighthouses, rocky coast and aquaria.
An administration leader said today that President Roosevelt had expressed the hope that the House Agriculture Committee would restore a land-buying proposal to farm tenancy legislation.

A new index of rents is being prepared by the Bureau of Statistics of the United States Department of Labor, states Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards. It will be, he adds, a revision of the bureau's present plan of reporting rent costs.

Increasingly large numbers of spectacles on the college campus with figures compiled by ophthalmologists to show the partnership existing between light and sight have aroused an interest in home illumination which transcends the efforts of commercial propaganda.
Edward Laemmle, film director and nephew of Carl Laemmle, pioneer motion-picture producer, died of a heart attack last night. His age was 49.

Mrs. Clyde R. Place, who heads the group in charge of the arrangements for the dinner dance in behalf of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital to be held April 13 in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center, will give a luncheon Wednesday in the Rainbow Room for her aides.

QUINTO MAGANINI has composed an opera-cycle called "The Argonauts." It is a Californian tetralogy based on the days of Forty-nine. The opening section is a prologue, with the first scene devoted to the discovery of gold and the second to the departure for the mines.

The fortyeight Civilian Conservation Camps will hold "open week" in celebration next week of the fourth anniversary of activity of the "Federal forest army" in this State. The camps, which at one time numbered seventy, will be open to visitors.

One of the two racing rule decisions gained by Gerard B. Lambert with his America's Cup yacht Yankee over Harold S. Vanderbilt and the defender Rainbow last Summer was changed, the committee on racing appeals of the New York Yacht Club reversing itself, it was learned yesterday.
Members of the swimming, basketball and wrestling squads were among the New. Yorkers who received athletic awards at Wesleyan for Winter sports activities during the past season.

The difference between a horse staying near the rail and another running out, away from the rail, decided the issue in the Bowie Handicap today before 20,000 persons who wagered approximately $430,000 on the seven races run under a warm sun and over a fast track. Calumet Dick, recent victor in the Mardi Gras Handicap at New Orleans,

Retail food costs rose between February 16 and March 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-25 average, was 85.4 on March 16, compared with 84.5 a month earlier, and 79.5 on March 10. 1936.

Mr. and Mrs. P. T. Seibert of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lorraine Elizabeth Seibert, to Henry R. Heeren of West New Brighton, S. I. Miss Seibert, a graduate of West Chester State Teachers College, is on the staff of the Lincoln School here.

Revised plans for Manhattan College's new library building were announced yesterday by the Rev. Brother Patrick, president of the college. The principal change is the selection of a new site on the eastern fringe of the campus.

The Department of English Literature at Wellesley College has extended the laboratory method of study to include the course in the Ballad. The classes, under the direction of Miss Evelyn K. Wells, always sing instead of saying the ballads they are studying, and thus learn them as did the Scottish highlanders and American mountaineers with whom they originated.

AIKEN, S. C.--With the drag hunts and golf tournaments out of the way, attention of the Winter colony here and at surrounding resorts turns toward the race meets and horse shows to be held at the new Aiken mile race track, where the first trotting races of the season will be run on April 5 and 10.
Reports from Yeungkong, in Southwest Kwangtung, give details of the massacre of an entire hamlet of lepers by soldiers on Easter Sunday.

The increase in construction costs during the last four years is exerting an important influence upon insurance, report the Continental, Fidelity-Phenix and other fire insurance companies of the America Fire Insurance and Indemnity Group, following an analysis of structural costs in various parts of the country.

The engagement of Miss Mary Melinda Thompson, daughter of Mrs. William A. Thompson of Evanston, Ill., and the late Mr. Thompson, to Arthur Robert Meares, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Meares of Mount Vernon, N. Y., has been announced by her mother.

A Recorder's Court jury convicted two alleged Black Legionnaires today of conspiring to kill William W. Voisine, village president of suburban Ecorse, thus increasing to forty-six the number of convictions since the terrorist society was unmasked ten months ago.
The joint choruses of the Harvard Glee Club and the Radcliffe Choral Society gave their annual concert in Town Hall last night, under the direction of G. Wallace Woodworth.
The socio-economic problem raised by coal bootlegging, now before Governor Earle's Anthracite Coal Industry Commission, has proved to be most difficult of solution.

Mail orders slackened in the wholesale market here last week, due in part to the post-holiday lull and to the fact that many buyers arrived to obtain Summer merchandise, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. The report continues:

Miss Edith Moira Kavanagh, a descendant of Samuel Adams, Revolutionary leader of Massachusetts, and of Governor De Witt Clinton of New York, was married to Joseph Andreae Mosenthal yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Mediator in Kingsbridge, this city.

Frederick Charles French of 142 East Twenty-second Street, in charge of the inspection of building construction in the city parks, died yesterday morning in the Beth Israel Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 63.

The 781 Big Brothers who were active last year helped 2,585 boys in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, it was reported yesterday by Joseph H. McCoy, general secretary of the Big Brother Movement, Inc., 315 Fourth Avenue. He will present a detailed report on the work at the organization's thirty-third annual dinner Thursday night at the Hotel Ambassador.
Miss Josephine McLaughlin of Easton, Pa., has been elected editor-in-chief of Campus News, semi-weekly student newspaper at New Jersey College for Women.

Guests from New York, Baltimore and other cities were at the marriage this evening of Miss Martha Page Wroth, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peregrine Wroth, to John Vincent Jamison 3d, son of John Vincent Jamison Jr.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles Kisselman Imbrie of Newburgh, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Imbrie, to Reinald Werrenrath Jr., son of Mrs. Ada Werrenrath of this city and Reinald Werrenrath, American baritone.

The annual Rockne Memorial communion breakfast of the Notre Dame Club of New York will be held at 10 A. M. today at the Centre Club, 120 Central Park South, with more than 250 alumni of the university attending.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court today ordered Clinton L. Bardo, trustee of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company, to show cause why efforts to reorganize the railroad should not be terminated.
A great celebration is being arranged for May 15 to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the reign of King Christian X.
With over three feet of snow still in the Green Mountains, the traditional sugaring-off party at Middlebury College scheduled for tomorrow promises to be the most colorful in years.

The marriage of Mrs. Paula M. Graham, widow of George S. Graham, former District Attorney of Philadelphia, to Jules S. Vatable of New York and Islip, L. I., took place this afternoon at Poinciana Chapel. Dr. William Edward Biederwolf, the pastor, officiated.

The many weddings planned for this month include three taking place in England that are of wide interest in this country. One of them-that of Miss Constance Masirevich to Count Hans SeherrThoss, which will occur on April 22 in London, is of particular interest in New York, where the bridegroom-to-be has many relatives.

The busiest man of the theatre is Charles Landstone, the author of "Behind Your Back," staged earlier in the year at the Strand, who is presenting three plays next week. At the Arts on Sunday he will show "Peter Petrous," a satirical three-act comedy by Robert Victor and purporting to demonstrate how disastrous it is for politicians to have ideas.

Florida's most successful racing season since the sport was legalized in the State six years ago was brought to a close at Tropical Park today. Eighteen thousand saw I. J. Collins's Bernard F. score a striking triumph in the Tropical Special for 3-year-olds at a mile and a furlong. Par, the favorite, was second and Maecloud third, with Robber Baron completing the small field.

Before the agreement for reopening the Chevrolet Motor Company plants at Flint, scene of a sit-down strike Thursday, the number of temporary idle in the automobile industry had reached 137,000, comparable to the highest point of the nation-wide General Motors shut-downs of January and February.
The long-heralded move of the Department of the Interior into its new $13,000,000 building across New York Avenue from its present location got under way this afternoon. The moving period.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Alden Gibbs, daughter of Arthur Stanley Gibbs of this place and the late Mrs. Gibbs, to Joseph John Du Bois, son of Mrs. Hattie H. Du Bois of South Orange, took place this afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Robert W. Trenbath, rector, performed the ceremony.

The engagement of $24,050,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $18,900,000 in England and $5,150,000 in Belgium, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gold, although reported only yesterday, had been purchased at some previous date.
Citations of German factories in the race for high productivity within the FourYear Plan will be made May 1, the Third Reich's national labor holiday.
Governor Allred declared today that he would not tolerate sit-down methods of "taking or holding property in Texas, and would use all the powers at his command to enforce laws and court orders.

DALLAS, Texas. was fourteen years ago March 26 that Mme. Sarah Bernhardt, grown tired of life and love, slipped away into death. Coincidentally, it was thirty-one years ago, on March 26, that the darling of the Comedie Francaise played for the first and almost the only time in a tent pitched in an old cornfield in a raw little city splintering up out of the Texas prairie.

The effectiveness of the mailfraud statute in prosecutions ot business frauds is indicated in a report submitted by John F. Dailey Jr., Chief Assistant United States Attorney, to his chief, Lamar Hardy. It shows that in the fifteen months since Jan. 1, 1936, defendants charged with using the mails to defraud were convicted in fortyone out of forty-two cases.
The issue of whether tickets to amusements are the "instruments and tools of trade" of a ticket broker was placed before Magistrate Overton Harris in West Side Court yesterday.

San Francisco officials looked today to a showdown in the fight with the Interior Department over methods of distributing electric power generated at the municipal Hetch Hetchy water project high in the Sierras.

Plans have been completed by Miss Josephine Turney Brown, daughter of Albert Turney Brown of this city, for her marriage to George Ellsworth Currey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Currey. The ceremony will take place on May 7 at Trinity Congregational Church.

The Rev. Daniel J. O'Connor, associated with St. Patrick's Church here for nearly twenty years, first as assistant and later as pastor, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital, Hartford, following a heart attack at the rectory Wednesday night. His age was 72.
Alfred Luke, Harrow house painter, today won a judgment for $341. He would not have done so if George VI had not succeeded to the throne last December.

A course in medicine and hygiene for missionaries and mission workers will be given here in July under the joint auspices of the Catholic Medical Mission Board and the Guild of Catholic Physicians, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Edward F. Garesche, director of the board.

The thirty-third annual dinner of the Big Brother Movement will take place Thursday at the Ambassador. The speakers will be Sanford Bates, former director of the United States Bureau of Prisons at Washington, and Robert L. Ripley. Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d will be toastmaster.
ARBETTER--ECKSTEIN - Mr. Sigmund Eckstein of Los Angeles announces the marriage of his daughter. Bertha to Mr. Louis Arbetter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Arbetter of St. Louis. March 28.

Two months after it received a 580page report of a special commission on reorganization of the State government, the General Assembly next week will vote on the first of the bills to "modernize" the State government.

Dartmouth easily defeated the University of Maryland on the track today, the score being 89 to 37. With a pair of firsts apiece, King and Geniawicz starred for the Indians. Frank Cronin set a new record for the Terrapins in the 440, being timed in 0:49.2.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Sandberg of 670 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Sandberg, to Dr. Frank L. Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rosen of Brooklyn.

A new wage agreement entailing increases ranging from 50 cents to $2.50 weekly for coal miners in South Wales was accepted today by their federation after a card vote of the members. ThP vote was 65.250 to 23.550.

Two persons were killed and five student nurses of the Middletown State Hospital were injured critically early today in an automobile accident. The dead were: Thomas D. Trial, a 21-year-old factory employee of Middletown.
The early American furniture, paintings and silver sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries realized $102,245.

On his own application: To take effect midnight, April 3: PATROLMAN-Alfred R. Radeck, Traffic Precinct F, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 28, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., April 5: PATROLMEN--Edward C. Hoffman, from 19th Precinct to 4th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur; Harold King, from 19th Precinct to 4th Division, assigned to duty in plain clothes.

ISAAC NEWTON, who sat beneath an apple tree, watched the golden fruit come tum bling down, and thereafter evolved the law of gravity, may have been the inspiration of Dr. C. J. Lynde of Teachers College, Columbia University, who likewise demonstrates the effectiveness of simple experimental apparatus.
Invitations have been received here for the marriage of Lieutenant John Pearson Sherden Jr. to Miss Catherine Frances James, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Warren W. James of Berlin, N. H.

George Sargent of Lucas Point, Old Greenwich, entertained at a cocktail party today for Miss Shirley Ludlam Woodward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cedric Rainey Woodward, and H. Fletcher Eggert Jr. of New York at the Greenwich Country Club.
About 1,000 youths between the ages of 16 and 25 will attend the United Christian Youth Conference in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church and neighboring churches from April 23 through 25.
The tenth annual exhibition to be sponsored by the New York Physicians Art Club was opened last night at the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

Miss Marion Lloyd, one of the foremost women fencers in the world, and Joseph Vince, founder and director of the Salle d'Armes Vince of this city and himself a noted fencer, were married yesterday at noon in Chatham, N. J., at the residence of Magistrate Roy S. Tinney, who performed the ceremony.

Sentiment expressed and plans made tonight by more than 200 members and prospective members of the Nassau Driving Club at a dinner at the Garden City Hotel, presided over by Cornelius N. Bliss Jr., gave assurance that harness racing, which has been an active sport in this community for many years, will receive further impetus this Spring.

Prompted by the Federal Government's encouragement of corporations to declare stock dividends in avoidance of the undistributedprofits tax, the State of New York recognizes such dividends as affording a new source of revenue

More than 10,000 graduates of Cornell University living in the metropolitan area will have an opportunity this week to cast their votes for the office of alumni trustee of their alma mater. The world-wide poll of Cornell graduates will reach more than 34,000 men and women.

Lehigh University will entertain debaters from four colleges and universities at its annual intercollegiate forum on Wednesday evening. Delta Omicron Theta, debating society, will sponsor a discussion on "National Administrative Reorganization."
EXPECTATIONS of the size of the crowd at London's coronation on May 12 verge so close upon the fantastic that the mind sags under the burden.

The Hudson Motor Company in a letter to employes today stated that the union had "refused to bargain further" after a demand for sole bargaining rights was refused. T. M. Doll, president of the United Automobile Workers' Hudson local, charged that the company "misrepresents the situation."

Five new world air records, four of them set by Crystal Mowry, were marked to the credit of the United States today by the International Aeronautic Federation. All were established at Miami, Fla., last December.
Judicial authorities have opened an investigation of a Reuters News Agency correspondent here, H. A. Kauranda, an Austrian citizen.

The Pan American Clipper, returning to Alameda, Calif., after a pioneering trip to Auckland, New Zealand, arrived at Pago Pago tonight at 9:15 o'clock, Pacafic time, Pan American officials here reported.

JOSEPH SCHUSTER, 'cellist, and Jose Iturbi, pianist, will be soloists this week with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Other events of the week include a benefit concert by the League of Composers at Town Hall tonight and a performance of Mendelssohn's "Elijah" by the Oratorio Society Tuesday.

SENATOR WALLACE WHITE of Maine, co-author of the Radio Act of 1927, and one of the veteran radio legislators in Congress, has endorsed the move in the House of Representatives for a broad inquiry into the broadcasting industry

Mrs. Dorothy Harvey Thompson Cobb, wife of Augustus S. Cobb, a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company committee suicide early yesterday morning in their eighteenth-floor suite at the St. Regis Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Far removed in time and space from California and the days of the "Forty-niners," a gala dinner at Sherry's on Wednesday will celebrate the eighty-fifth anniversary of the second oldest institution of higher learning for women in this country-Mills College,

Last week's stock market continued to reflect the nervousness felt in the weeks immediately preceding. THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks was off 0.45 point on the week. The principal topics of the week, marketwise, were the Supreme Court's reversal of its former

AIR travel has increased tre mendously in the first three months of 1937, and the planes of airlines have flown nearly 10,000,000 miles, carrying some 300,000 persons. Yet the recent series of accidents, on lines with reputations for thoroughness in operation, stand, in the minds of spectators and the Bureau of Air Commerce, as a blot on the record.

The committee for the first supper dance of The Bachelors, which will take place on Saturday night in the roof garden of the St. Regis, has announced that the net proceeds from the dance will be given to Hope Farm, a community and school for children at Verbank, Dutchess County.

Predictions of an exceptionally active selling market for mediumpriced homes in Queens and the popular residential communities of Nassau County during April and May are being voiced by brokers and builders, and already many evidences of an active buying campaign are being seen.

First returns in Representative Edward L. O'Neill's poll of sentiment in New Jersey's Eleventh Congressional District on President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal showed 56 per cent definitely opposed.

The Italian public is only vaguely aware of what is going on in Spain. Newspapers here give only very one-sided accounts of events, speaking of nothing but an unbroken chain of victories for General Francisco Franco's forces and attributing Madrid's unexpectedly long resistance wholly to the impossibility of carrying on large-scale military operations while unfavorable weather conditions continue.

A selected list of 100 first editions by American authors, one for each year during the past ten decades, will be on display in the Mount Holyoke College library during the May Centenary celebration. The books, owned by the college or borrowed for this occasion, will include novels, essays, poetry, history and other typical American literary works.

Officials of the Socialist and Communist parties a well a representatives of more than 100 trade unions and approximately eighty fraternal organizations gathered yesterday afternoon at a United May Day Conference at Webster Hall, Eleventh Street between Third and Fourth Avenues, and formulated plans for the traditional May 1 labor-day demonstration and parade.

Despite some slackening in demand in recent weeks, dry goods jobbers for the first quarter of the year sold their retail customers 25 per cent more goods than they did in the corresponding period of 1936, they reported here yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Van Mater of Plainfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Van Mater, to George Billingsly Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Morgan of this city.

Although totally blind, Mrs. Prudence Patterson, 38-year-old widow who is attending the evening session of New York University's Washington Square College, is employed by the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities during the day.

EXCEPT for some sections of the country which continued to have Winter or unfavorable weather, post-Easter trade showed less than the usual let-down after that holiday, according to reports received here.

Mr. and Mrs. Haddon Ivins of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Ivins, to Konrad W. Valentin, also of Englewood, formerly of Berlin-Dahlem, Germany, son of Mrs. Wilhelm J. Valentin and the late Major Valentin.

The Azione Coloniale, a weekly specializing in colonial news, breaks into the Anglo-Italian discussion today with a delicately worded but unmistakable suggestion that Great Britain may have had something to do with the bombing attempt on the life of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, the Viceroy of Ethiopia.
Miss Superior, an 8-year-old bay mare owned and ridden by Norman Baetjer Jr., won the junior cross-country steeplechase today in as breathtaking a contest as the six-year-old race has known.
THE Malkin Conservatory Scholarship Fund, which has been established at the Malkin Conservatory of Music, Boston, Mass,, promises to be of benefit to talented and needy music students.

More than 2,500 teachers, administrators and school officials of New York City will participate in the educational conference on "School in Contemporary Society," which will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania next Saturday, Charles J. Hendley, president of the Teachers Union, announced yesterday.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased - for the all-Stravinsky program to be presented by the American Ballet the nights of April 27 and 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the ballet.
THE author of this book has been a detective attached to the District Attorney's office in Los Angeles and he has told of his experiences there in his autobiography. "Me, Detective."

Breaking 95 out of a possible 100 targets. J. M. Schirmer took the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. T. H. Lawrence defeated 0. Agathon for the Class A handicap honors after a tie at 97. In Class B. A. Trahan triumphed with a full score.
The opening of the Little Entente conference in Belgrade was under the shadow of a series of recent political surprises in the Danube basin.

1. GONE WITH THE WIND, by Margaret Mitchell. June 30. (Macmillan.) $3. 2. WE ARE NOT ALONE, by James Hilton. March 12. (little, Brown.) $2. 3. BREAD INTO ROSES, by Kathleen Norris. Feb. 19. (Doubleday, Doran.) $2. 4. THEATRE, by W. Somerset Maugham. March 3. (Doubleday. Doran.) $2.50.

Plans are being drawn for the construction of a "tent city" on a 350-acre tract in Washington for the National Scout Jamboree, to be held from June 30 to July 9, it was announced yesterday at the national headquarters of the Boy Scouts of America, 2 Park Avenue.

Although vacancies in loft buildings have been greatly reduced, this condition has not caused a commensurate increase in revenue due to low rents and increased operating costs, according to Leon R. Spear, vice president of Spear Co.

THE interesting announcements of the repertory of the Spring season of opera at popular prices at the Metropolitan give promise of some new ideas and some fresh activities in that field of public entertainment. It looks as if the sheer pressure of events and the reactions of public opinion would clearly differentiate between the Winter and Spring seasons, with benefit to each series.

Sweet are the uses of adversity, Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous, Wears yet a precious jewel in his head. This bit of Shakespearean observation might well be carved on a stone in the garden wall-for the toad, ugly but not venomous, is one of the gardener's best friends.

The nation will observe Army Day on Tuesday and at the same time mark the twentieth anniversary of its entrance into the World War. In hundreds of cities and towns throughout the country, veterans, patriotic, civic and fraternal organizations all this week will honor the armed forces of the United States.

Problems of old age dependency, unemployment and health insurance and social security will be discussed by leaders in these fields at the tenth anniversary national conference of the American Association for Social Security, Inc., Friday and Saturday at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday.
Mrs. Helen Collord Taylor, widow of Dr. William H. Taylor and for many years active in civic, religious and charitable work here, died at her home here today. Her age was 83.

The police here today arrested four Protestant pastors, members of the directing board of a church congress at which two Swiss churchmen had been allowed to speak. The congress was given to understand that the active participation of foreign Protestant spokesmen would not be tolerated.

A walkout called by the Worcester locals of the Amalagamated Meat Cutters and Butchers Workmen's Union at the three Brockelman Brothers markets in this city to enforce demands for wage increases of 10 to 15 per cent, shorter hours and union recognition, caused a complete tie-up of business and the closing of the stores today.

Henry G. Yagoda, at one time acting chief of the Ogpu, or secret political police, and then Commissar of Internal Affairs, has been dismissed from his new post as Commissar of Communications for "criminal activities in connection with his office," it was officially announced tonight.
Seven plays will be presented during the third season of the Mohawk Drama Festival, July 6 to Aug. 14, sponsored by Union College on its campus.

A choral and orchestral spring festival will be given on the night of April 22 at Carnegie Hall by the People's Chorus of New York for the benefit of the organization's maintenance fund. Mrs. John Henry Hammond, chairman, and Mrs.

Miss Marion Fountain has enlisted the aid of several young women in the arrangements for the Twilight Tea Dance to be held Wednesday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for the benefit of the West Sixty-third Street Community House.

More than 300 Columbia College sophomores and their guests participated last night in the annual Sophomore Easter Promenade in John Jay Hall, Morningside Heights. The dance was the first class social function of the current year.

ANY introduction is a confession of weakness. This one is no exception. It is written because I am anxious to persuade American poets to experiment with verse plays for radio and because I am quite certain the radio verse play I have written will not persuade them of itself.
At a moment when an unmistakable change has appeared in Japan's China policy, the dissolution of the Tokyo Diet last week, under military pressure, brings new uncertainty.

Deputy Fernand Bouisson pinned the decoration of the Legion of Honor today on Mr. Dame, manufacturer of the new propellers that enabled the French liner Normandie to recapture the Atlantic speed mark.

A luncheon and forum to discuss the work of child-care institutions will be held Tuesday at the headquarters of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, under the auspices of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

EDWIN ARUINTON ROBINSON was Rollo Walter Brown's neighbor for many Summers at the MacDowell Colony-from 1923 until the poet's death-and though Robinson was naturally solitary and reserved, the two came to have long talks, to be real friends.

The Florence Nightingale Federation - of the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, will hold its annual benefit Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Dorothy Flexer, contralto of the Metropolitan, and the Russian Choir of Sixty Voices of the Art of Musical Russia will sing.

The cottage type of home, averaging between 18,000 to 19,000 cubic feet with four or five rooms has been the dominant type in the home-building revival of the last two years, according to the homebuilding and home-owning committee of the United Stater Building and Loan League.

LOS ANGELES-On the basis of the annual population figures supplied by the California Taxpayers Association and recent computations by the Western Statistical Association, Los Angeles expects the 1940 census to give her third rank among American cities; she expects to be surpassed in population only by New York and Chicago.

More than 200 students of the classics representing forty-four metropolitan high schools will compete for two team trophies and six medals next Saturday in the third annual Interscholastic Latin Sight-Reading Contest at New York University's Washington Square College. Washington Square East.

The first use of Floyd Bennett Field for regular air passenger and express service will start tomorrow, when American Airlines, Inc., will open daily service to and from Boston with its new twenty-one-passenger Douglas flagship club planes.

Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Ambassador of the Soviet Union, said today he would not transmit to his government an invitation to send a representative to a commission hearing at Mexico, D. F., on treason charges made by the Russian Government against Leon Trotsky, exiled former Bolshevist leader.

The Palmetto Players, now a group of seventy enrolled in the dramatic department of Converse College, have just marked their tenth anniversary with a production of "Pride and Prejudice." On April 17 they will give "Inga," a Russian play, and at Commencement, T. S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral," which won success as a Federal Theatre presentation in New York.

More than 1,000 residents of Long Island, from the East River to Montauk Point, paid tribute to Robert Moses as "dreamer-plannerdoer," in a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night. Before and after speeches of praise by former Governor Alfred E. Smith,

One of the largest fashion show benefits of the season, a revue entitled "Styles From Dawn to Dusk," will take place at a luncheon in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria on April 15. The Generosity Thrift Shop at 1,237 Third Avenue will be the beneficiary.

individual bargaining: Discussion between management and a single employee, determining the latter's wages, hours or other working conditions. collective bargaining: Discussion between management and a group of organized workers, the latter usually represented by agents who may or may not be employes of the management, to determine the conditions that shall apply to the group.
Joseph Stalin in recent days has set a new ferment to work in the Russian Communist party which seems destined to have a great effect both on the party and on the Soviet State which it rules.
Among the presents that Norway's new-born Prince Harold received at his christening last Wednesday was a large and ornate beer mug.

The Associated Swimming Clubs, twenty-three strong, staged their first annual interclub championship carnival before 1,000 spectators at the Columbia University pool last night. They presented a varied and interesting program that included relay races, diving exhibitions, water polo and a water ballet.

A concept of library science which aims at selecting the right book for the reader, rather than on increasing circulation figures, will be emphasized when the School of Library Science at Syracuse University celebrates its fortieth anniversary on the campus May 28.

Dr. John A. Miller, a student of solar eclipses, will be co-leader and technical director of the Hayden Planetarium Grace Expedition which will travel to Peru to see the total eclopse of the sun on June 8, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Clyde Fisher, leader of the expedition and curator of the planetarium.
Annie Oakley has her counterpart in four Syracuse housewives. Break into their homes and they might write the illegal entry law in bullets all over the wall back of the intruders.
