James J. Braddock, with Manager Joe Gould, traveled nearly 300 miles by motor today inspecting prospective training camp sites near Chicago preparatory to the world heavyweight champion's departure tomorrow for the Wisconsin north woods.
Roscoe Crary, former Chicago tannery executive and one of the organizers of the Texas Corporation, died yesterday afternoon in his suite at the Congress Hotel. He was 70 years old.

The charity ball to be given for the benefit of the New York Osteopathic Clinic on April 26 at the Waldorf-Astoria will be featured by a varied program of entertainment and a midway of side shows and carnival attractions.

Herbert S. Chapman, 64 years old, who commuted 1,250,000 miles in forty-seven years before ending his career as a New York insurance executive last February, didn't even look up from his early morning garden tasks today when the 6:30.

Displaying a fast-breaking attack, the strong Mount Washington Lacrosse Club from Baltimore scored its second straight triumph today on Goldie Field, repulsing Princeton, 8-3. It was the first defeat for the Tigers in two starts.

SPAIN'S civil war has brought about an unprecedented demand for special delivery mail service and consequently the Rebels suddenly found themselves facing an acute shortage of stamps for that purpose.

Slightly more than half of each tax .dollar collected by- the State during the last ten years has been used for improvements in the localities from which the taxes have been derived, Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, declared yesterday in an address at the Rand School of Social Science, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

American handbag manufacturers who leave for Europe next month to view the new style offerings will carry their own sample lines for the purpose of booking orders. This was done last year with excellent results, manufacturers calling attention yesterday to the fact that handbag exports in 1936 were more than double the 1935 total.

Representative Beiter of Williamsville, N. Y., made public today a letter to Governor Lehman urging immediate construction of works to preserve the beauty of Niagara Falls. He suggested that the power issue involved in such works be set aside for the present.
The Eastern branch of the American Psychological Association held its Spring meeting at Vassar College today.

Miss Anne Chandler Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Sherman Baker of Greenwich, was married to Jesse Fleet Sammis Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse Fleet Sammis of New York, at St. Bede's Chapel, Rosemary Hall, Greenwich, this afternoon. The Rev. John H. Chapman of Round Hill, Greenwich, officiated.

The Republican "strategy of silence," which has been a more or less spectacular feature of the Supreme Court struggle since its inception in February, has one definite limitation. It does not apply to Congressmen on the home front.

Mr. and Mrs. Somers Marshall Rutledge of this place have announced the engagement of their, daughter, Miss Jane Fife Rutledge, to Charles Edward Richardson of East Orange, son of the late Mr, and Mrs. Albert Edward Richardson of Coventry, England.

The Minneapolis St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway (Soo Line) has ordered 550 freight cars for use on the Wisconsin Central. The Pullman-Standard Manufacturing Company will build 450 of them and the American Car and Foundry Company 100.

Miss Barbara Kaley of this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Haley, was married here this afternoon to Edward C. Treat, also of Summit, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Erastus B. Treat of New York, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Waterman.

BROLI--Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Brolln (nee Frances Feingold). 1,865 University Av., Bronx. joyfully announce the birth of a son on March 31, 1937. CORRIGAIN-A daughter to Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Corrigan. on April 1, 1937, at Park East Hospital.

An entertainment to be known as a "Bazaar of All Nations" will be held next Saturday afternoon under the auspices of the Church School of All Angels in the parish house of the Church of All Angels, 251 West Eightieth Street.

Prince Chichibu, younger brother of the Emperor of Japan, and his Princess were officially welcomed to Canada this afternoon when they arrived in the capital en route to London to represent Japan at the coronation.
The 2-week-old strike at the plant of the American Gas Machine Company was settled today after twenty-four hours of violence.

The unusual manner in which sound effects were handled by engneering students in the University of New Hampshire, at a recent production of the University Dramatic Society, has won high commendation here.

A memorable performance of Liszt's "Faust" Symphony after Goethe, by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor; the Harvard Glee Club and the solo tenor, Rulon Robison, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, constituted the only adequate observation in this season of 19361937 in New York, of the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Frank Liszt, which occurred July 31, 1886, at Bayreuth.
The White Sox pounded Larry French in the early innings today and went on to defeat the Cubs, 6 to 3. It was the tenth victory for the Sox in their last eleven starts against their Chicago rivals.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jonas W. Federman of 875 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caryl J. Federman, to Martin H. Newman of Brooklyn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Newman.

NOT this week a discussion of any one play, but a list of events with comments. Yesterday morning W. Graham Browne died. By midday London was streaming with placards: "Death of Marie Tempest's Husband," and nothing else was spoken of in the clubs.

A daily increasing shortage of iron ore, due to unprecedented steel operations, has caused the Lake Carriers Association to charter the ice-breaking ferry Chief Wowotan to try to break ice jams and permit bulk freighters to start moving ore from the northern iron ranges.

Hazel Hedge Hiker's Gadden was the winner of the members shooting dog stake in the eighth annual Spring trials of the South Jersey Field Trial Club today. A field of thirty pointers and setters competed.

Business men in the Ligonier Valley intervened today in the dispute between farmers and Richard K. Mellon. Hoping to keep the Mellon fox hunts and steeplechases in Pennsylvania, the Ligonier Board of Trade circulated a petition pledging owners of farms near the 12,000-acre Rolling Rock estate to permit use of their property by sportsmen.

Time out for cheering was a luxury denied last week to proponents of a minimum wage for women in New York State. One eye triumphantly on Washington and the Supreme Court's reversal of its former stand, the other warily on Albany and the impending end

Miss Shirley Lowenhaupt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Lowenhaupt of Montclair, will be married on May 15 to Franklin J. Koehler, son of William F. Koehler of Montclair. The ceremony will be performed in St. Cassian's Church.

Operating on the theory that charity begins at home, Columbia handed a baseball game to City College at Baker Field yesterday and then began to repent as the fray progressed. Finally the Lions made a complete about-face, rallied for seven runs in the seventh and thus made off with their first victory of the new season, 11 to 6.

Fifty Western Union messenger boys who began a strike yesterday afternoon kept police squads busy today when they paraded through the "Loop," visiting several of the company's branch offices and trying to induce other messengers to join their ranks. No arrests were made.

The Feld-Crawford law and its effect upon the retail drug trade here will be the outstanding topic for discussion at the New York Pharmaceutical Council convention to be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania April 13 and 14, Sol Fierer, chairman of the convention committee, announced yesterday.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John M. Spangler of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Spangler, to David H. Trott, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Trott of Montclair.
Gus Moreland of Peoria, Ill., shot a 149 for thirty-six holes in the Midwest amateur golf championship today to top his nearest rival, Don Armstrong of Aurora, by two strokes.
MEXICO, so frequently called the land of manana, with its yesterday covering cen turies, today gives every sign of progress, evidencing its determination to become a country with a future.

Joe Platak "stole the show" in the finals of the National A. A. U. handball championships today. The speedy Chicago postoffice clerk captured his third consecutive singles title by defeating Sam Atcheson of Memphis, Tenn., a former champion,

In the Court of Claims of the United States today the following calendar for Monday, April 5, was announced: Call of the April Calendar Rule to show cause. Plaintiff to show cause Monday, April 5, why the following case should not be dismissed: 43246-Elwood C. Madsen.
HERE is a book that seems to have fallen from heaven One had hardly hoped to meet with such a book again in our present interregnum of the literae humaniores. A rich.
TWO ballet companies, both Russian in their origins, divide the lion's share of the news this week, the one because it is a novelty and the other because it is not.

A peace pact designed to end labor disputes in Detroit's leading hotels encountered a stumbling-block today. New objections and new demands cropped up to prevent signing of the agreement by a three-man board of arbitration and halted negotiations until Tuesday.

Drastic enforcement of the "threeday cancellation clause" as a means of checking any increase in returns is recommended in a special report being filed by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.,

California is the sixth State in the Union in the amount of liquor tax revenues collected annually, according to the best available information. This is reported in a survey of State liquor incomes made by the Bureau of Public Administration of the University of California at the request of a number of members of the California Legislature.
Jay W. Smith, president of the strike-closed Chris-Craft Corporation, boat builders, said today that the plant would remain closed indefinitely and that employes had been advised to seek new jobs.

ABELES-Henry, beloved father of Irma Abeles Feldstein and husband of the late Camille (Blum) Abeles, brother of Jacob, Frederick, Paul; Esther Wachtel, Elsie Wachtel, Minnie Levene. Funeral services Sunday, April 4, 11 A. M., at Midtown Memorial Chapel, 171 West 85th St.

A campaign of poisoning Mormon crickets in nine Western States was begun here this week by the United States Bureau of Entomology in the hope of quelling at its start what threatens to become the second major outbreak of the insects since 1848, when crops of the Mormon settlers in Utah were saved by a timely invasion of sea gulls from the Pacific Coast.

Freddie Bartholomew, child screen star, was -adopted today by his aunt, Miss Myllicent Mary Bartholomew. "It's what I've always wanted," the 13-year-old actor said. "I'm very happy." "Aunt Cissie" said "this is quite the happiest day of my life."

SHORTLY after midnight on Dec. 7, 1815, the Chamber of Peers of France voted sentence on Marshal Ney. The gallant Duc de Broglie alone voted not guilty on the man whom Napoleon had called 'the bravest of the brave." Five members shstained, seventeen proposed deportation and 137 voted for the death penalty, including five Marshals of France.

Suggested minimum retail prices on more than 1,100 nationally branded items have been - announced by producers or wholesale distributors acting for them in this State since the State Court of Appeals reversed itself and validated the Feld-Crawford "fair trade act" early last month, according to data available here yesterday.

Frank M. Ledwith of the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York, and who has been Named president of the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation, said yesterday that the hardest part of the commission's problem lies in the financial restoration, so far as possible, of those mortgages, small in number in comparison to the total, but aggregating about $50,000,000, which are not bringing in enough money to foreclose or promulgate reorganization plans.

The Greater New York Safety Council will hold its eighth annual convention at the Hotel Astor from April 13 to 15 inclusive. Afternoon sessions will deal with safety instruction as a part of the course in homemaking, safety in athletics and a safety program in the elementary school. Members of the New York school system will speak.

It has been contended, in regard to the Supreme Court's rejection of its own precedent in the Washington State minimum wage case, that the action was actually taken prior to the President's proposal to enlarge the court. The argument in this case, it is pointed out, was completed in December, 1936. Within a week after completion of an argument the court's custom prescribes that the judges shall record their individual ballots.
The curtain dropped on the third and last performance of the Boston Skating Club's "Cracked Ice" at the Boston Garden tonight. A crowd of 13,000 saw the figure skating carnival end.
May be a "sudden death" pamphlet would head off daredevils who think. they can ride over Niagara Falls in a barrel or swim the Niagara Whirlpool, according to John A. Curry, Police Superintendent.

An automobile owned by Mrs. James Roosevelt of Hyde Park N. Y., mother of the President, and driven by Louis Depew, her chauffeur, struck and injured Fred J. Grewen, 47 years old, of 46 Van Guilder Avenue, New Rochelle, at Park Avenue and Eighty-third Street, at about 10:20 o'clock last night.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended March 27 remained unchanged at 106.6. Five gains among its components failed to offset two losses. The combined index was 91.6 for the week ended March 28, 1936.
The marriage of Miss Helen Elise Levin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barton Gumpert Levin of Overbrook Hills, to Charles Clancy Warren, son of Mrs. A. Lloyd Gliem of Wynnewood, took place this afternoon.

VIENNA. INSTINCTIVE and fundamental as was Brahms's respect for Wagner, his regard for Bruckner was proportionately small. When in 1891 he heard that the University of Vienna had conferred upon Bruckner an honorary doctor's degree, he could hardly contain his amusement.

Walter P. Chrysler and John L. Lewis resumed their conferences on the Chrysler automobile strike today in Governor Murphy's offices, the eighth day of negotiations, in an atmosphere charged with the remembrance of the "quickie" sitdown strikes in General Motors plants this week, the union's drive to "purge" Communist and other trouble-makers from its ranks, and the State elections to be held on Monday.

MATCH-BOOK collecting is riding on the crest of the hobby wave right now and maker of matches are becoming ever more cover conscious. At New York's Hobby Show last year only one frame of match-books was shown; this year, at the one now being held at the Pennsylvania Hotel, a considerable assortment indicates the present scope of the fad.

In a reorganization of the general religious work among students of Yale University, Dwight Hall, center of the Christian Association Unit, begins its second half-century of existence with a new program formulated by E. Fay Campbell, '18, general secretary of Dwight Hall since 1922.

The Coast Guard in the New York area, which extends from New London, Conn., to Cape May, N. J., is pressing its annual Spring enforcement of the navigation laws. Small boats in the area are being boarded for inspection.
Exercises marking "Parents' Day," May 9, will be held by the city schools on the preceding Friday, a circular issued by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, revealed yesterday.
A plucky Irish squad finished as runner-up to the all-conquering English fifteen
The Rev. Vittorio Aghetto, pastor of the First Italian Baptist Church of Rochester, died here today after a short illness. He was 44 years old.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy Barbara Monaghan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Monaghan of 835 Riverside Drive, to James Francis Keleher, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Keleher, also of this city.
Dr. and Mrs. Carl Eggers gave a supper dance. last night at their home, 5 East Sixty-sixth Street. for Miss Elizabeth Marie Bartner and Ward Henes Bolter, whose marriage will take place in June.

MARSEILLES. THE way that Europe has gone mad over canoeing must be a puzzle to most Americans, and especially to those who are themselves canoeists. That there should be enthusiasm for the sport is Understandable.

A national student fast, in connection with the national student strike against war, is being called for April 22 by the National Intercollegiate Christian Council. The council includes student Y. M. C. A.'s on 770 campuses and Y. W. C. A.'s on 570.
SOUTHERN PINES, N. C. THERE is full warrant for an intercommunity movement in the Carolina and Georgia resorts to obtain public recognition of the health - giving contributions of the long-leaf pine.

After the performance of "Miss Quis" by Vinton Freedley's company at the Shubert Theatre this afternoon, Miss Jessie Royce Landis, who, with Peggy Wood, shares leading role honors in the new comedy, was married to Rex William Daniel Smith Jr. of New. York, one of the editors of News Week.

Miss Doris Osborne Frantz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Frantz of Sans Souci, Davenport Neck, this city, was married to Robert Winslow Carrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. RObert Edward Carrick of Larchmont and Hillsdale, N. Y., this afternoon at the Trinity Episcopal Church here.

Samuel P. Atkinson, Civil War veteran and one of the oldest living graduates of Dartmouth College, died on Thursday after a stroke of paralysis at the age of 93. He took his usual daily two-mile walk a week before.

Books about aviation and aviators are always exciting and nearly always good. "I Wanted Wings" is one of the best. And it is decidedly different. It is, in particular, the story of an army airman's training at Randolph Field and Kelly Field in Texas.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poiems and their souces, the names of authorrs, c., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

The marriage of Miss Olivia Edgerly Frick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edgeworth Frick of this place, to William Champlin Robinson, son of Mrs. Champlin Robinson of Baltimore and the late Mr. Robinson, took place at noon today in St. James Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair.
Behind locked doors a man named Owen Eugene Moore was held today in the psychopathic ward of General Hospital. He is believed to be the former screen actor, first husband of Mary Pickford.

The engagement of Miss Nancy Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes of Montclair, N. J., and Fishers Island, N. Y., to Alfred Faris King Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Faris King of Dongan Hills, S. I., has been announced by her parents.

Skilled machinists in the Southern New England jewelry industry today awaited the decision of a special committee named to decide a date for a strike voted last night for higher wages and a closed shop.
The Chicago Kennel Club opened its thirty-sixth annual dog show this morning in the Coliseum on Wabash Avenue with the largest entry in eight years. A total of 1,006 were entered.

Miss Kathryn Rising, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard, BradleyRising, was married in St. James Episcopal Church here tonight to Lieutenant Selden Gain Hooper, United States Navy, son of Mrs. Rosa Hooper, miniature artist, of New York.

The net asset value of the Phoenix Securities Corporation at the end of February was $15,046,205 after provision for normal Federal income taxes of $598,063 which would be payable on realization of the appreciation in the company's investments, it was announced yesterday.

Immediate removal of Governor Blanton Winship is demanded in a resolution adopted by students of the University of Puerto Rico. The Governor and Chief of Police Enrique de Corbeta are blamed for "irresponsible and savage attacks carried out by the armed forces," resulting in the death of eighteen persons in recent rioting at Ponce.

Miss Alice A. McCutcheon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Charles McCutcheon of Lawrence Park, this place, was married to Edward Folk, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Folk of White Plains, here this morning in the Reformed Church of Bronxville by the Rev. John H. Powell, the pastor.

A surrealist film directed by Rene Clair, a film based on themes by Edgar Allan Poe, and an animated cartoon in a new technique, will be presented by the Museum of Modern Art Film Library at 8:30 o'clock tonight in the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History.

A MOVEMENT is on foot to create a "world-center for Jewish music in Palestine." According to a recent article in the Pariser Tageszeitung, the movement is being launched by a committee in Jerusalem, consisting of Dr. Salli Levi, Jehuda Shertok and Hans Elsenstaedt.
The foreign copper market dropped rather sharply in the unofficial trading yesterday. London reported a drop of 30 points in electrolytic prices to about 16.075 cents a pound. Sales abroad,

The leading women swimmers of the district will compete for three Metropolitan A. A. U. senior titles today at the Women's Swimming Association pool, 204 East Seventyseventh Street. The championship races feature a water carnival which is scheduled to start at 2:45 P. M.

Brown Prep of Philadelphia retained the honors in the Eastern States interscholastic basketball tournament tonight by defeating Morristown (N. J.) High, 46 to 34. Baldwin (L. I.) High won the consolation trophy by defeating St. Peter's High of Worcester, Mass., 34 to 21.

Mr. and Mrs. Abraham S. Phillips of 888 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Phillips, to Frederick Lampke Isaacs, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Isaacs of 129 East Seventy-third Street.

GOVERNOR WILBUR L. CROSS of Connecticut approaches his seventy-fifth birthday, April 10, in excellent health and humor. His sturdy body may be slowed down a bit; he has to case his ankles in spats against the New England frost, and he says: "At my age you look to see if the walks are slippery."

Peace returned to the industrial scene here tonight with the nnouncement that more than 15,000 workers in General Motors plants would return to their jobs Monday morning, ending a strike which has paralyzed all operations of the Chevrolet Motor Company since Thursday night.

Miss Elizabeth N. Lawrence heads the debutante committee working on arrangements for a special performance of "Naughty-Naught," the Krimsky musical drama of life at Yale, to be given the evening of April 12 in the American Music Hall for the benefit of Greenwich House Music School.

The military defense plan of the Philippines was vigorously defended yesterday by Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Commonwealth, in the face of a "protest" that it endangered the democracy envisaged for the islands and might destroy their economic security.

While Reuben Fine of New York was unable to finish a long, drawn out game with P. S. Milner-Barry of London, Paul Keres of Estonia moved into first place in the international masters tournament at the annual Easter Congress of the Kent County Chess Association today.

The newest type of Russian bombing planes used by the government forces made a raid here today. It was remarkable for the great death and destruction caused during only a few minutes. The bombers, about fifteen in number, swept low over the city, dropped their high-powered bombs and then sped away at an astonishing speed.

ONE exasperated, tobacco-chewing gentleman sat down in great anxiety not long ago, took pen in hand and wrote the customer research staff of the General Motors Corporation to ask why in heck they didn't build cars with cuspidors set in the floor.

Mrs. Edgar Scott and J. Hunter Lucas, members of the Radnor Hunt Club, were injured today when their mounts were in collision and fell near the finish of a cross-country event during a race meeting at Happy Hill, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Custis Harrison 3d at White Horse.
IN doing "Peruvian Pageant" Mrs. Niles longed for some character who had carelessly forgotten to die-one who could recount the chronicles of Peru from the days of the Incas down to our own.

Plans to stabilize wages and working conditions in the commercial printing trades throughout the East were discussed here yesterday by 100 delegates from locals of the International Typographical Union.

Three fellowship awards, each providing for a year's study in the American School of Classical Studies at Athens, Greece, were announced yesterday by Dr. Edward D. Perry, secretary of the school's managing committee and Jay Professor Emeritus of Greek at Columbia University.

Discussing the heavy taxation burden placed upon real estate in New Jersey from the administration of former Governor Stokes in 1907 to the present year, John O'Brien of the New Jersey Real Estate Commission cited the following example to the members of the Teaneck-Bogota Real Estate Board at a recent meeting.
American film companies are abandoning their attempt to amount to anything in the German market and are beginning to transfer their German synchronization abroad.

Studies by a board of experts as a sequel to the Morro Castle and Mohawk disasters have brought a report to the Senate by its Commerce Committee outlining in minute detail recommendations for making ships of all kinds "absolutely fireproof." Embodied in the report is the draft of a bill to bring the recommendations into effect.

Gerald Richard Dairymple, football star of Tulane University in 1930 and 1931, has been named Brown varsity end coach by the athletic council, it was announced today. He will take up his work when Spring practice opens Wednesday.

Plant labels of several years' permanence can be fashioned simply by any gardener. The ordinary wooden label may be written on with black ink, then dipped in varnish or shellac, and drained and dried before being set in place in the garden.

A Village President and three Trustees will be elected April 13 at Peekskill, second largest village in the.State. Port Chester, the largest, will have its annual election April 27. Its candidates will be nominated Tuesday or Wednesday.

ANOTHER Spring season of social activity is in bud at the White House. Invitations have gone out for a series of post-Lenten dinners; luncheons. teas, receptions and musicales also will be given Entertaining will increase through April and culminate in the famous Roosevelt garden parties in May and June.
A corps of 2,800 men, many of them CCC workers, fought more than forty forest and slashings fires in West Virginia tonight.
Corn again held the spotlight in the grain markets today, all futures advancing to new high marks for the season and the May into the highest ground since 1925 and selling at $1.29 1/4 a bushel.

MIAMI, Fla.-In honor of six Latin-American countries, a pageant, "Six Americas," will be presented here in connection with Miami's seventh annual observance of Pan American Day on April 14. A number of colorful episodes in Latin-American history will be dramatized for the first time.

The promotion and appointment of 129 cadet officers, members of the college unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps enrolled in advanced courses in military science at the City College, were announced yesterday by Colonel Oliver P. Robinson, chairman of the Department of Military Science and Tactics.
A pair of field goals by Woolsey Wheeler gave the St. Andrews Rugby Club of East Orange, N. J., an 8-3 victory over the favored Nassau-Hofstra College of N. Y. U.

A dinner in honor of the alumnae committe which is working with the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund Committee of Barnard College will be given by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve next Tuesday in Brooks Hall. Mrs. Edward M. Earle is chairman of the alumnae committee which is selling subscriptions for square feet or square yards of the Riverside quadrangle, the block purchased last Fall by the college for an academic building.

More than a year of investigation is sometimes required in accumulating data necessary to obtain naturalization papers for immigrants of years ago. Details of the tracing of dates of arrival, name of the ship on which the individual journeyed,

Mrs. Nan Pierson Brooks Macy Brill, New York heiress, declared today that she would "bring my exhusband and half of New York society" to fight an annulment suit brought by her second husband, William Brill Jr., in Los Angeles.
Noel Z. Ledger, an 82-year-old R father, who did not like the conduct of his 51-year-old son, Placide, had him haled into court today on a charge of drunkenness.

The new Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam, which will be launched next Saturday at Rotterdam, will carry the largest air-conditioning system afloat, according to L. R. Boulware, vice president of the Carrier Corporation of Newark.

A smashing finish in his third string enabled Ernest Bolle of Detroit to hang up a 682 and roll into a seventh place tie with Andy Varipapa of Brooklyn in the singles race of the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress championships yesterday at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.
The candidacy of Mrs. Walter W. Seymour of Chicago for the post of first vice president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at the triennial in Kansas City, Mo.,

The situation created in India by the refusal of the leaders of the Congress party to accept office under the new Constitution seems to be disappointing all round, and not least to the leaders themselves, who had evidently expected the provincial governors to throw up their hands and accept a Deadlock.

ST. MARTINVILLE, La. S0, through a land of exquisite beauty-bayous, great oaks and green levees-lulled into deepest peace and contentment; into the great Southern Eden, the romantic land where Evangeline ended her wandering.

Records of a strike which occurred in New York City in 1684 among the licensed "carmen," or draymen, have been uncovered by research workers of the Historical Records Survey in the archives of the Board of Aldermen and City Clerk's office, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Commissariat of Heavy Industry announced today it would reduce pay scales and increase production "norms"namely, the individual worker's standard daily output, above which higher pay per piece is given-in order to fulfill-the government's demand for higher labor productivity and lower production costs.

John Biggs Sr., son of the fortysixth Governor of Delaware and father of Judge John Biggs Jr. of the United States Circuit Court, died today. He was 81 years old. Mr. Biggs, widely known as an attorney, had been in ill health for several months.
Louis Pagliaro of New York featured the seventh annual national tennis championships tonight by upsetting fourth-seeded Bud Blattner of St. Louis, Mo., in the round of sixteen.

No contrast could be more striking than that which presents itself between the rapid industrial recovery, nearly or quite to the pre-depression level, and the visibly present spirit of financial hesitation and perplexity. As recently as 1934, the prospect for revival of American industry to normal was widely considered doubtful.

Nine years of highly successful formal organization life, antedated by a tradition of several years of informal gatherings at International House, will be commemorated in the Spring dance and bridge of the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization on Saturday at the Hotel Ambassador.

Machine-gun fire, instead of bugles, broadcast from the Victor Emmanuel monument facing the Piazza Venezia during the conferring of banners upon air squadrons today, was believed by officials to have been the cause, of rumors abroad that Premier Mussolini had been assassinated.

President Lazaro Cardenas says that he wants "public peace cemented in satisfaction of the needs of the people" and not re-election. In a speech delivered to 300 peasants yesterday at Chila Puebla but obviously directed to the nation, Cardenas said:

Mrs. Arthur.B. Walsh of this city and Green Valley Farm, Princeton, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Walsh, to Richard John Ach, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Lewis Ach of Brooklyn and Falmouth Heights, Mass.
One department of Conde Nast Press voted here today for union representation in dealing with the company and two other departments voted for individual representation.

Swimmers of Columbia University, St. Francis Prep and Trenton High School, won the majority of honors yesterday in the first annual invitation swimming relays held in the Morningside Heights pool. An afternoon filled with competition ranging from 150 to 1,000 yards in eight events saw each of these teams win two races, while other victors were Ohio State and the Rutgers freshmen.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Warner Allen of 309 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Allen, to Richard Zellner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl P. Zellner, also of Brooklyn.

Mrs. Jessie Harris, 27 years old, was shot and killed at the door of her second-floor apartment, 172 Conklin Avenue, Brooklyn, at about 10 o'clock last night by a man who escaped before the police could be summoned by neighbors. Mrs. Harris's two children, a girl 5 years old and a boy 3, were asleep in the apartment at the time of the shooting.

Cardinal Hayes heads the list of honorary patrons for the joint concert to be given tomorrow by the combined music organizations of the College of New Rochelle and Holy Cross College of Worcester, Mass., at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York, Miss Margaret Sullivan of Stamford, Conn., president of the New Rochelle Glee Club, announced here today.

Tonnage movements. in and out of this port were back to normal this week for the first time in more than six months, according to Chamber of Commerce data. The tonnage of the ships coming and departing was about 3,000,000 tons and included vessels in the foreign intercoastal and coast-wise services.

Another traditional sign of Spring came today with the opening of the trout season in New York State. By far the largest gathering of fishermen in recent years responded to the first opportunity to test their luck and skill in the icy waters of streams and lakes in Westchester and Putnam Counties.
THE title of this book is a characteristic jet of Gogarty's gayety. It is the first line of a larky lyric which he and Joyce picked up in the Dublin of their student days

THE easiest way in which to indicate the sort of book this is would be to say that it is not like other books about Haiti. As the publisher correctly states on the jacket, "the people of Haiti have usually been described as hysterical paranoiacs, their entire life revolving around the mysterious 'voodoo' cult, while a few writers have described them as happy, childlike primitives'"

Hardly ten days after the close of the radio meeting here, at which radio's mission of peace was much discussed, a particularly sharp skirmish in the German-Soviet radio battle has again demonstrated that in a world of bellicose ideologies the most ultra-modern plowshares promptly become swords.

Miss Emily Louise Slocum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester G. Slocum of this place, was married to Theodore B. Luerssen of Watchung and New York this afternoon in the Westfield Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. William K. McKinney, the minister.

Melville A. Kelsey, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, in expressing his regret yesterday that Governor Lehman had vetoed the bill providing for the installation of sprinklers in the old-law tenement houses, said that the board would be represented. in Albany on Wednesday, when a hearing will be held on the measure introduced by Senator Twomey providing certain relief for owners of such buildings.
Georgetown University's weekly newspaper, Hoya, is planning to publish this month an innovation in college journalism, a four-color process supplement to the Founder's Day issue.

DETROIT. THE motor car industry continues to move toward decentralization of manufacture. General Motors Corporation has done more than any other company to distribute its production around the country, although its operations, aside from assembly plants, are still highly concentrated in Southern Michigan.

Army's brilliant string of polo victories reached its end in Squadron A Armory last night and three redshirted youngsters from Cornell walked out of the ring carrying the towering silver trophy with them that goes to the winner of the intercollegiate indoor championship.

Miss G. Elizabeth Oelbermann, daughter of Mrs. Julius Oelbermann of Chestnut Hill and of the late Mr. Oelbermann, was married this afternoon to Dr. Chalmers E. Cornelius of Jenkintown, son of Mrs. Chalmers E. Cornelius of Mooresville, N. C.

Amid reverberations of yesterday's storm in the Senate, it became apparent today that an expression of policy declaring against the sit-down strike would be adopted in some form or other after the chamber reconvenes on Monday.

POINTING a distinct relationship between safety and taxation, especially diverted taxes from automobile owners, Truman H. Preston, vice president of the Automobile Club of Syracuse, said last week that engineers and traffic experts have agreed that no one can correct all the faults of driving, but says in another breath that safer highways will make the probability of accident less.
Four hundred persons attended the annual supper promenade of the junior class of New York University's Washington Square College last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Plaza.

THE great new highway which Mussolini has just inaugurated across Libya, the Italian North African colony, linking it with Tunisia to the west and Egypt to the east, is not only a great feat of engineering but also of the highest strategical importance.
A marital situation involving Albert Marzano, 17 years old, and his wife, Concetta, 15, was likened to "a scene from a comic opera" today by Judge George Gowen Parry.

Miss Heddy Brauns, 17-year-old John Adams High School performer, representing the Turn' Verein Vorwaerts, captured the metropolitan junior A. A. U. allaround gymnastic championship with a total 181.8 points at the home club last night.

Relations between the United States and Canada have been brought sharply to public attention through the official visit this week of the Governor General and Lady Tweedsmuir to the President and Mrs. Roosevelt and the recent informal visit to the White House of Prime Minister Mackenzie King in the course of a vacation trip to Virginia Beach.

University of Maine alumni have started a scholarship fund campaign to honor the fifty years of service to the institution given by Dean James N. Hart. A special book of tribute, which will include the signatures of every contributor, will be presented to Dean Hart at commencement.
Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Z. Smith of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabelle Marie Smith, to Arnold E. Mooz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Mooz of Essex. Conn.

Contending they are weary of criticism and abuse from "professional" consumer groups, price-cutting retailers and large organizations that demand special discounts, grocery manufacturers of nationally advertised brands will open a counter-offensive against such elements shortly.

Recently one of our columnists closed an article with the words: "Our menace is not communism but confusion." This certainly is an accurate description of the situation prevailing today in the realm of moral standards and moral sanctions in our industrial life.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 31, which included five business days in some of the reporting cities, aggregated $9,365,000,000, or 10 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 11 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

TO the list of current exhibitions of nineteenth century French art, such as the Manet show at Wildenstein's, the Degas at Durand - Ruel's, the "Courbet to Seurat" at Seligmann's and the group of Post-Impressionists at the Bignou, it is a pleasure now to find added an exhibition called "Figure Pieces" at Knoedler's, which opened last Monday and will remain until April 10. Most of the canvases have been lent.

As a generic term, applied to politics, the word "fusion" means a coalition of parties or factions. In New York the word has been taken over by the City Fusion party, formed by. independent Democrats, who fused successfully with the Republican party in 1933 to beat Tammany and elect Fiorello H. La Guardia as Mayor.
" A demonstration of what boondogglingg' has been worth to the taxpayers" was given today by Harry L. Hopkins, the WPA Administrator.

The bill "to protect the artistic and earning opportunities in the United States for American actors, singers, dancers, solo instrumentalists and orchestral conductors, and for other purposes" will meet its crucial test before an executive meeting of the House Immigration Committee next week, from present indications.
TO tour the model rooms newly opened in metropolitan shops is one of the easiest and pleasantest ways of acquiring a knowledge of the trends in furniture and interior decoration.

Crowded between tall commercial buildings at 47 West Forty-fourth Street is a small red-brick, twostory structure, one of the few examples of an earlier New York architecture remaining in the Times Square district.

Marguerite Stanton, 38 years old, was killed instantly at noon yesterday when she fell or jumped from her apartment on the ninth floor of Essex House, 325 East Forty-third Street, to the roof of a one-story extension. She had been alone in the apartment, which she shared with her mother, Mrs. Madeline Stanton. Mrs. Stanton was visiting friends in Houtzdale, Pa.

Two thousand four hundred and ten junior Civilian Conservation Corps prospects will be enrolled throughout the United States Army Second Corps Area, comprising New York; New Jersey and Delaware, beginning Tuesday, it was announced yesterday at the corps headquarters, Governors Island.

Mrs. Dunlap Hopkins, founder and president of the New York School of Applied Design for Women, heads a committee in charge of the arrangements for an entertainment to be known as "Around the World Costumes With Music and Song and Modern Fashions," next Friday afternoon at the headquarters of the school, 160 Lexington Avenue, for the benefit of the institution's library fund.

Two well known astronomers will change academic places this Summer when Dr. Frederick C. Leonard chairman of the Department of Astronomy at the University of California at Los Angeles, will go to the University of British Columbia and that. institution's Dr. Daniel Buchanan will come to the Los Angeles university.

AN important novelty in Turin's public symphony season at the Teatro di Torino was "Psalm IX," for chorus and orchestra, by Goffredo Petrassi. It is worth noting that Malipiero rates Petrassi as one of the two most gifted composers of the youngest Italian generation, the other being Luigi Dalla Piccola.

Newspaper reading habits apparently change radically during four years of high school, according to a survey made in the Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn. A comparison of 200 students who had just entered with 200 who were about to graduate showed marked differences.

Prince Pu Chieh, heir presumptive to the orchid throne of Manchukuo, was married today to a Japanese commoner, 23-year-old Hiroko Saga, in the first of two ceremonies to solemnize the dynastically important marriage.

Already embarked on the task of finding "the sweetest girl in Wyoming County," maple syrup festival planners were looking today for the champion pancake eater-of the world. The title will be bestowed after a championship contest at the Wyoming County Maple Festival here April 30 to May 2.

THE Loyalists and Rebels were still blowing Tone another apart in Spain. Germany was going ahead with its plan of building the largest warships the world ever had seen. Russia was adding to its enormous airplane fleet. France was looking at England hopefully and at Italy suspiciously.

A general strike which went into effect in this city at 6 A. M. today in support of the twenty-day-old walkout of truck drivers was called off conditionally by the Central Labor Union and Building Trades Council soon after noon, when a conference was held that brought announcement that the truck operators had agreed to peace negotiations.

AN individual tournament, in which the players change partners every round, is scored by match points. The measure of success is in large part an ability to adapt one's self to the habits of many different partners.
Dr. Ernesto Lattes, noted publisher, died here today of a heart attack while motoring in a park. His age was 51.
A high Japanese official said today that there was evidence that Nanking was attempting, with some success, to strengthen its authority over the North China administration.

The logging camps of Oregon and the docks of Puget Sound, in the past the scenes of some of America's hardest fought labor struggles, have become far-flung battle fronts in the clash between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Al Reid of the Bronx outpointed Nicky Jerome of Greenpoint in the feature eight-round contest at the Ridgewood Grove before 2,500 persons last night. Jerome was on the floor for a count of nine in the first round, but arose to fight a desperate battle. Each boxer scaled 127 pounds.

Mrs. Henry F. Wolff of 15 East Sixty-ninth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nathalie Miner Wolff, to John Lee Marsh, son of Arthur M. Marsh of Southport, Conn., and the late Mrs. Marsh.

Convinced that the recall of volunteers and all foreign interventionists from Spain is the surest further step toward obtaining peace in Spain, the French Government is continuing active conversations in London and other centers on this subject. Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos received Charles Corbin, French Ambassador to London, and it is expected that another official attempt to open the subject will soon be made before the Non-Intervention Committee in London.

SALEM, Ore. BICYCLES were a traffic problem when women's skirts swept the ground and William McKinley was in the White House. They are still a traffic problem in places, with an ever-increasing number of young people using them as an inexpensive means of conveyance.

FERRUCCIO BUSONI'S opera, "Doktor Faust," was given here by the B. B. C. before an audience which included most of the notabilities of the town who were obviously keen to discover something about the genius, the personality, the philosophy of its composer.

An agreement calling off the sit-down strike of employes of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation and providing for immediate evacuation of the big factory here was signed tonight by officials of the company and organizers of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Lucy Estelle Doheny, granddaughter of the late Edward L. Doheny Sr., oil company head, was married this afternoon to Waldeman Van Cott Niven, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Crombie Niven of Los Angeles, in the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Leigh McMaster Battson.

The steady advance of the machine age has lessened the necessity for teaching spelling, according to Mrs. Jane Dorsey Zimmerman, president of the Eastern Public Speaking Association, who urged teachers yesterday to have children devote less time to repeating "C-A-T spells cat" and more time to instruction in pronunciation.

An atmosphere of the island for which it has been named will prevail at "Capri Night," the dinner dance sponsored by La Margherita Society, which will take place Thursday at the Ritz-Carlton. An Italian dinner will be served and decorations will consist mainly of margherites and Spring flowers.

ANOTHER retail outlet at 4,286 Broadway, at 183d Street in Washington Heights, has been opened by the Nash Motor Company of New York, according to R. H. Israel, president. John Jensen will be in charge under E. B. Shumate, sales manager for the New York district.

WASHINGTON. IN response to a resolution adopted by the Senate last April, Secretary Ickes has submitted to Congress a twentyyear program for expediting the topographic mapping of the United States. His recommendations, based upon studies by the various Federal map-making agencies, call for expenditures of $5,000,000 a year, or $100,000,000 in all,
Fred Perry squared at 20-all his series of professional tennis matches with Ellsworth Vines when the Englishman won easily, 6-3, 6-3, tonight.

As the site for a sixteen-story loft building designed primarily for the garment trade, the property at 233-5 West Thirty-fifth Street has been leased from Hell's Kitchen, Inc., to the 235 West Thirty-fifth Street Corporation, of which David Zuckedman is president.

Annual communion breakfast of the United States Customs Holy Name Society, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Speakers: Joseph P. Martin, the Rev. Robert P. Dugan, the Rev. John J. C'Donnell, the Rev. Patrick J. Temple, Jerry B. Sullivan and Francis A. Nugent.
The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $149,963,858 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange.

Ernest Bloch's "Voice in the Wilderness, " symphonic poem with 'cello obbligato, had its local premitre last night at Carnegie Hall at the concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting. Joseph Schuster, first 'cellist of the orchestra, was the soloist in this work, as in the Saint-Saens A minor concerto for 'cello and orchestra.

VISCOUNT CECIL says in his preface to this book: "At a time when every decent citizen should be striving his utmost to maintain peace there exists a great industry with branches in every country and having a capital running into hundreds of millions of pounds whose interest it is to promote war."

Eliminating of the customary graduation diploma in favor of credentials listing each student's special achievements and qualifications is one of three "marked" departures from standard practices to be put in operation next Spring by the Rochester Athenaeum and Mechanics Institute.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Rhodes of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rebecca Rhodes, to Dr. Henry Dows Stebbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Ledyard Stebbins of New York and Seal Harbor, Me.

Virginia's newest hotel, the Williamsburg Inn, built by Williams burg Restoration, Inc., in connec tion with the restoration of this historic city by John D. Rockefeller Jr., was opened this afternoon with a reception and informal inspection.
SAN SALVADOR.--Porfirio Canales, 35, was attacked and instantly killed by a fighting cock at the village of La Caridad in Honduras, according to reports brought here.

A charming suburban garden laid out successfully on a curiously shaped plot is that arranged by Mrs.-Nellie Allen for Frank E. Bliss of New Rochelle. It lies behind the house, thus assuring privacy, and consists of a small "courtyard garden" in a space formed by an angle of the building, while beyond this lies an intimate walled garden of formal design.

New light was shed last week on the whys and Wherefores of the decision of the Board of Education to move its central headquarters from 500 Park Avenue to Brooklyn. It came from two independent sources. One is the thirty-eighth annual report of the board, just published; the other, striking studies of population and physical trends recently completed by the Regional Plan Association.

Seed beds soil has long been a problem-often the limiting factor n the growing of plants from seed. Either it was such heavy clay that it caked and packed and prevented adequate germination; or being clay, once it was overwatered stayed so wet that the seeds rotted.

Miss Bernadine Wingert, daughter of Mrs. Charles Wingert of this city and the late Mr. Wingert, became the bride of James Mansfield Downey, son of Mrs. Edward Downey of St. Louis, Mo., and the late Mr. Downey, at St. Catherine's Catholic Church this morning.

Earle Meadows of the University of Southern California equaled his Olympic championship mark of 14 feet 4 inches in the pole vault as the powerful Trojans swamped Fresno State, 90 to 41, in a dull track meet today.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Fink of Pelham Manor, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beverly Dorothy Fink, to George J. Carmichael Jr. of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Carmichael of Brooklyn and Milwaukee.

Persistent little Bryan Grant Jr., vestpocket tennis ace, was extended to overcome an off day and a good opponent for a berth in the Atlanta Invitation final today. Getting off to a bad start against Joel Hunt of Los Angeles, Grant quickly dropped two sets but he steadied and finally won, 3-6, 6-8,6-2, 10-8, 7-5.

Miss Anita Rockwell Farrington, daughter of Mr. and Mr. Walter Leavenworth Farrington of Kew Gardens, L. I., was married yesterday to Philip Earl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Earl, also of Kew Gardens. The Rev. Joseph McLaughlin performed the ceremony in Our Lady, Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church, Forest Hills.

DOWN at Washington the Cor coran Gallery of Art has opened its fifteenth biennial of contemporary American painting. It is, by some thirty or so canvases, bigger than ever. Better as well? That must depend, I suppose, upon your point of approach.
A delegation headed by Premier Mustapha Nahas Pasha left here today for Montreux, Switzerland, for a conference of the powers having extraterritorial rights in Egypt.
The Maryland Senate voted tonight to legalize bookmaking on horse races in approving taxes designed to raise $5,360,000 annually for relief purposes.

Some of the best jumpers in training for the past two months in the Carolinas will get their next test in the Middleburg Cup, which will feature the opening day of the seventeenth Spring meeting of the Middleburg Race Association over the Glenwood Course at Middleburg, Va., on Saturday.

Herbert Walsh, 7 years old, of 107-50 139th Street, Jamaica, Queens, was killed in an automobile accident about 10 o'clock last night as he was crossing Van Wyck Boulevard at 109th Avenue, under circumstances that were so puzzling to the police that, instead of making any arrests, they decided to let the Queens Felony-Court in Ridgewood fix the responsibility next Friday.

A card party and tea dance has been arranged by members of junior committees of the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization for next Saturday at the Ambassador for the benefit of the organization's philanthropic fund.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The eighth annual Atlantic City Horse Show will be held in the Convention Hall here, May 11 to 15. The Atlantic City show, due in part of the tremendous amount of space available in the huge hall, is fast becoming one of the best in the country. About 90,000 persons witness the affair each year.
Mrs. Mabel Hobart Page, assistant treasurer of the Chicopee Falls Savings Bank, will celebrate the completion of a half-century of banking activities May 1 by ending her.

Landlubbers have been far fewer among the Girl Scouts during the past two years, and will be still further reduced under the plan of expansion outlined for the Girl Mariners section of the organization, after analysis by sociologists of the program of activities.
Music Hall of the Air presents a conceit version of the first two acts of Wagner's "Siegfried," with Erno Rapee conducting the symphony orchestra (Act III next Sunday): WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M.

The quick and dramatic success of the Committee for Industrial Organization in organizing the mass-production industries has surprised even John L. Lewis and his associates at the head of this new labor movement.

DURING Winter evenings reception of European short-wave stations near 19 meters is seldom satisfactory, possibly because of lack of heat and light over the northern regions through which signals from Europe to America must pass.

Some of the best jumpers in training for the past two months in the Carolinas will get their next test in the Middleburg Cup, which will feature the opening day of the seventeenth Spring meeting of the Middleburg Race Association over the Glenwood Course at Middleburg, Va., on Saturday.

Herbert Walsh, 7 years old, of 107-50 139th Street, Jamaica, Queens, was killed in an automobile accident about 10 o'clock last night as he was crossing Van Wyck Boulevard at 109th Avenue, under circumstances that were so puzzling to the police that, instead of making any arrests, they decided to let the Queens Felony-Court in Ridgewood fix the responsibility next Friday.

A card party and tea dance has been arranged by members of junior committees of the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization for next Saturday at the Ambassador for the benefit of the organization's philanthropic fund.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The eighth annual Atlantic City Horse Show will be held in the Convention Hall here, May 11 to 15. The Atlantic City show, due in part of the tremendous amount of space available in the huge hall, is fast becoming one of the best in the country. About 90,000 persons witness the affair each year.
Mrs. Mabel Hobart Page, assistant treasurer of the Chicopee Falls Savings Bank, will celebrate the completion of a half-century of banking activities May 1 by ending her.

Eight pickets were arrested about 7:30 o'clock last night after they refused to budge from tables in the Garfield Cafeteria, 881 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, which has been having labor trouble for the past ten months. All were charged with disorderly conduct.

Millions of dollars are saved annually by railroads and industry through joint efforts in improving the packing and loading of freight in order to reduce losses and damages according to the Association of American Railroads.

Declaring that "the real issue" in the controversy over President Roosevelt's proposal for reorganization of the judiciary should be understood by the people, the New York State Bar Association today cited as making the issue clear an address delivered at the 1912 meeting of the association by Elihu Root, at that time its president.

A considerable body of opinion among American medical men is in favor of State medicine, in the sense of complete governmental control over the provision of medical care, it is revealed today in a comprehensive report on American medicine published by the American Foundation.

MRS. ELIZABETH SPRAGUE COOLIDGE has accepted the dedication of the American Spring Festival of Chamber Music, which will offer three concerts of chamber music by American composers, to take place on Tuesday evenings the 13th, 20th and 27th of this month, at the Fifth Avenue galleries of the Grand Central Art Galleries, 1 East Fifty-first Street.
Events of the last few days stimulated activity at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue as well as in administrative circles generally on the problems of minimum wages and child labor.
King George VI will make history at his coronation by being the first monarch to address his subjects throughout the world within a few hours of his crowning.

Obsolete school buildings, triple sessions and a high pupil teacher ratio in the New York City school System are menacing the welfare and health of thousands of children, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, charged in his thirty-eighth annual report, "All the Children," made public last week.

Douglas Claughton Fox of Plandome, L. I., who for the last four years has been making studies of ancient paintings and engravings found in the African deserts, returned Friday on the HamburgAmerican liner Deutschland. The work was under the direction of Professor Leo Frobenius.

The Fernando Wood Martin Hall of Sciences, which will provide adequate and thoroughly modern accommodations for the departments of biology, chemistry and physics and release the old science building for additional classrooms and offices, is under construction at Randolph-Macon Woman's College.

A "Mother's Day" luncheon meeting will be held under the auspices of the Maternity Center Division of the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association and the Committee on Maternal Welfare of the Medical Society' of the County of Kings,

Frederick M. Babcock, chief of the underwriting section -of the FHA, and J. Howard Ardrey, deputy administrator, will be among the speakers at the mortgage conference of bankers, building and loan representatives to be held at the Essex House, Newark, N. J., Tuesday afternoon, April 13. Garret A. Denise of the New Jersey Bankers' Association will preside.

Dilwyne Montauk Pilot, owned by the Dilwyne Kennels of R. R. M. Carpenter of Montchanin, Del., and handled by Harry T. Conklin, today won the open all-age stake, the most important event of the third annual Maryland retriever trials sponsored by the American Chesapeake Club and conducted on the estate of Mr. Carpenter at Benton Md.

Seventeen-year-old King Farouk of Egypt became a locomotive engineer today. He piloted the electric engine of the Red Arrow Express from Geneva to Berne. His mother and sisters rode in a special car attached to the train.

ATTEMPTS to combine information with a story more often than not prove unsuccessful. That Mme. Samaroff succeeds in constructing an entertaining fairy tale and at the same time in presenting musical information in a compact and interesting form proves that she has both imagination and in a high degree. the ability to condense and clarify.

Andrew Ross, retired railroad executive, died at his home here today at the age of 69. Mr. Ross was born in Mauch Chunk, Pa., and at the age of 14 began his long career on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, starting as a messenger.

Douglas Claughton Fox of Plandome, L. I., who for the last four years has been making studies of ancient paintings and engravings found in the African deserts, returned Friday on the HamburgAmerican liner Deutschland. The work was under the direction of Professor Leo Frobenius.

Frederick M. Babcock, chief of the underwriting section -of the FHA, and J. Howard Ardrey, deputy administrator, will be among the speakers at the mortgage conference of bankers, building and loan representatives to be held at the Essex House, Newark, N. J., Tuesday afternoon, April 13. Garret A. Denise of the New Jersey Bankers' Association will preside.

Conklin, today won the open all-age stake, the most important event of the third annual Maryland retriever trials sponsored by the American Chesapeake Club and conducted on the estate of Mr. Carpenter at Benton Md.

Samaroff succeeds in constructing an entertaining fairy tale and at the same time in presenting musical information in a compact and interesting form proves that she has both imagination and in a high degree. the ability to condense and clarify.

Andrew Ross, retired railroad executive, died at his home here today at the age of 69. Mr. Ross was born in Mauch Chunk, Pa., and at the age of 14 began his long career on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, starting as a messenger.

Pope Pius resumed today public audiences, which were interrupted early in December, and received a group of 400 newly married couples. Because the attendance was so large the audience was not held in the Consistorial Hall as usual, but In the larger Ducal Hall.

The First Cleveland Cavalry won the Western indoor polo championship in the Sherman low-goal division when it defeated the Chicago Shamrocks, 8 to 7, tonight. The Cavalry will represent the West in the lowgoal class in the nationals in New York next week.

The Interstate Commerce Commission upheld today, with four exceptions, rates on carload shipments of coal from the Pennsylvania antharcite regions to destinations in the eastcentral part of New York State.

One of the largest fields of the season followed the Meadow Brook hounds this morning from the gates of the Henry F. Atherton estate in Brookville to a fox hunt over Syosset, East Norwich and Oyster Bay estate lands.

IF Japan has one national characteristic above all others, it is dogged singleness of purpose. It tried to manufacture wool tops and found its costs far above those of British producers. But it kept on, year after year, absorbing the losses, until it learned the trick, cut its costs below the world average.

Six labor and professional organizations, claiming a total membership of 75,000 in the local Works Progress Administration, laid plans yesterday for a common offensive against Harry L. Hopkins's order to cut the number of WPA workers drawn from non-relief sources or receiving wages in excess of the security scale.

Foremost among the conditions causing anxiety in the nation are rapidly rising prices and sit-down strikes. The applications of the one to the national economy, and of the other to respect for law, are direct. In his rapacity as head of the American government, the President on Friday took such official cognizance of prices as to shake down the stock markets. But no word on the sit-down strikes has come from him.

One of the long-established entertainments of the Spring, the Butterfly Ball in behalf of the House of Rest, will be held Friday night in the main ballroom and Oval Restaurant of the Ritz-Carlton. Now given earlier in the evening as a dinner dance, the party, as in past years, will be featured by several diversions and a floor show program.

Wilbur Glenn Voliva charged today that time bombs were used to start the fire which destroyed the Shiloh Tabernacle in Zion yesterday. In his own private investigation, Mr. Voliva said, he has learned that the conflagration originated in seven different places, almost at the same moment, and that one of these was the store-room in which the scenery for the Passion Play was kept.

Repetition of the extremes in economic depressions and booms probably can be avoided in the future if the government is allowed to use its taxing and spending powers to stabilize business, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, said in an address here tonight at the closing session of the fourth Human Relations Institute, held this week at the University of North Carolina.

Brooklyn Botanic Garden's six outdoor Spring courses present opportunity to gain a first-hand acquaintance with plants in the New York neighborhood. Subjects range from studies of ornamental plants for the home gardener to field work on the wildflowers and trees for the amateur naturalist and teacher.

Loel Guinness, M. P., and Lady Isobel Guinness have returned to England in their yacht Atlantis after a four months' wedding trip, passed chiefly at New York and Palm Beach, Fla. Lady Isobel is the younger daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Rutland.

A group of British and United States shipping lines today announced an increase of approximately 10 per cent in transatlantic freight rates to ports on the Eastern seaboard of the United States and Canada.

Railroad "irons," or rails, upended in the earth, and other obstacles, mine traps and special concealed antitank guns now plug the gaps between the steel and concrete casements of the Maginot line, it was learned yesterday.
BREAD AND WINE," by the author of "Fontamara," is a quiet ahrewd, humorous, and bitter book of the Italian peasantry under fascism, just before the Ethiopian war.

Jail bars tonight kept Geraldine Murphy, 14year-old school-girl bride, from accepting her sympathetic mother-inlaw's offer of a home. Reaffirming their love in messages exchanged through an attorney, Geraldine and her husband, Joseph R. Murphy, 20, remained in Charles Street jail, she facing a stubborn child complaint and he a charge of abducting his bride.

New York University's varsity baseball team, 1937 edition, was unveiled to the public eye for the first time yesterday. The consensus among the 1,000 spectators at Ohio Field who watched the Violet nine swamp an alumni combination, 14 to 1, was that a promising season lies ahead.

Ed Hall, second vice president of the United Automobile Workers of America, announced settlement tonight of the strike which closed the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here yesterday. Strikers will return to work Monday "without any discrimination whatsoever," he said after a conference with Ford officials tonight.

The neighborly charm of the old row of private residences occupying the block in Washington Square North, just east of Fifth Avenue, is to be preserved. When long-held ground leases expired last year on many of the sites and families long identified
The second day of the conference on "Current Problems in Community Coordination" began yesterday at New York University's Washington Square College.

Two British correspondents representing The Daily Express of London and the Reuters News Agency in Insurgent territory were expelled today and The Daily Express was barred from Insurgent Spain as a result of a dispatch that recently appeared in that paper reporting that several officers and men, including some volunteers in the Foreign Legion, had been executed following discovery of a plot against General Francisco Franco's life.
Anerosion combatant borrowed from Italy is being develped experimentally in Gilmore Valley, near here, with a view to its possible application on a nation-wide scale.

With the expiration of Title I of the National Housing Act on April 1, the emergency phase of the Federal FHA activities came to an end, and henceforth, according to Administrator Stewart McDonald, the Housing Administration will be free to concentrate its efforts on the long-range objectives of its program. These, he points out, are improvement in housing standards and conditions, and the maintenance of a sound system of home finance.

Hunter College has an acute library problem, Dr. Joseph K. Reilly, librarian and Professor of English, said yesterday. The present quarters, he said, are insufficient to meet the needs of the more than 5,000 students who use the library daily.

The significance of last Monday's decisions of the Supreme Court, particularly that in the minimum-wage case, it is already being recognized, extends beyond their immediate important results and their timely relation to the present controversy over the court and its past decisions.

The wedding of Miss Anna Marie Spottiswoode, daughter of Mrs. William J. Spottiswoode of this city, to Thomas Clifford Macauley, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Macauley, also of Orange, took place this evening in St. John's Church.
The engagement of Miss Eleanor Bodwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Bodwell of this place, to Gordon B. Pepion of Hartford, Conn., has been announced by her parents.

A MAN who in the midst of a gracious, familiar room suddenly sees the walls lengthen and foreshorten, the floor and ceiling meet, would not be more puzzled than is many a medical man of today trying to keep his accustomed foothold in a world changing its dimensions under his very nose.

MORE than 100 musicians will play in the municipally endowed Milwaukee Young People's Orchestra at its concert this Tuesday in Milwaukee, Wis. The orchestra, which was founded ten years ago, consists of youthful performers who have finished high school and college musical careers, but who are unable or unwilling to try for positions with professional symphony orchestras.

It was with joy that I listened in on several scenes of the splendid rendition of the "Tragedy of Man" by Imre Madach, translated from the Hungarian by Evan Roberts, managing director of the WPA Federal Theatre Radio Division, and broadcast over Station WQXR.

A luncheon meeting will be hel? on Saturday in the Rainbow Gril under the auspices of the Vocations Service for Juniors in connection with its second annual career con ference for high school graduates Percy S. Straus will preside ove: the meeting, the principal topic o which will be "Youth and the Firs Job."
THERE was an expectant hush in all the right places when word got around that Noel Coward, placidly touring the seven seas by freighter. was writing his official autobiography.

Penn State turned back the Naval Academy nine today, 6 to 1. The Navy did almost as well as the Nittany Lions at bat, getting nine hits to ten, and their game in the field also was sparkling, but most of their safeties came when one or two were out, and they only managed to put one runner across the plate, Matheson scoring the lone run in the fifth.

Freshmen at the University of Pennsylvania who aspire to roles in future Mask and Wig Club productions are whipping into shape the dances, songs and skits which will comprise their first annual revue, to be given the night of April 16 in Irvine Auditorium.

Two new titleholders are certain to be crowned in the intercollegiate and interscholastic outboard championships at Saratoga Lake on June 26-27. Paul B. Sawyer Jr, of Yale, the college men's champion, will be in France that week-end, rigging and testing his outfits for the Spreckels race, and Gar Wood Jr.. the interscholastic winner of a year ago, has been graduated from schoolboy ranks and as a consequence cannot defend.

The championship of the Aiken Kennel Club show was awarded today to Village Mister Bill, a white English setter owned by Fitch Gilbert of Gilbertsville, N. Y. Diana, a black and white smooth-haired terrier, owned and handled by Mrs. Katherine Owen Austin, Great Neck, L. I., was judged the best puppy.
Mr. and Mrs. William Alsop Bours of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Mercy Bours, to Robert B. Archibald of Jacksonville, Fla.

The annual Spring party sponsored by the board of managers and others interested in the Mariners' Family Asylum, Home for Aged Women of the Sea, will be held on Thursday afternoon at the home, 119 Tompkins Avenue, Stapleton, S. I.

Mexico's voters, their ranks swelled by thousands of women who will cast ballots for the first time, tonight studied last-minute appeals of nearly 2,000 candidates for 173 Congressional seats in tomorrow's primaries.

" The World Challenge to Democracy: How Can America Meet It?" is this year's theme for the Summer Institute for Social Progress, to be held on the campus of Wellesley College on Lake Waban for two weeks, July 10 to 24.

The Fulton Savings Bank of Brooklyn moved its main office yesterday into temporary quarters at 205 Montague Street, which will be occupied while the bank's new building is being erected on the site at 375 Fulton Street, where the institution has been doing business for almost seventy years.
BOOKS about Spain may soon be falling as thick as bombs on Madrid. They come so fast that in "Unhappy Spain" Pierre Crabites quotes from E. Allison Peers's "The Spanish Tragedy,"

Miss Irene M. Gerbracht, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gerbracht of Grantwood, N. J., was married yesterday to John M. Plante of Huntington, W. Va., by the Rev. Dr. Richard Pressey, in the Trinity Episcopal Church, Grantwood.

Sentenced to be shot as a deserter from the Irish Brigade of the Spanish Foreign Legion, but finally pardoned after weeks in jail at Caceres and Burgos, Hugh A. McDaniel, 26 years old, unfolded a colorful tale of his experiences in Rebel Spain here last week.

Attempts to combine programs for slum clearance and low-cost housing are fallacious in plan and execution, according to Wallace W. True, Chicago appraiser, writing in the current issue of the Society of Residential Appraisers' Review.

HALF a century ago when Professor Arsene d' Arsonval told the medical world that the day was coming when diseases would be treated by electricity, heat, light and other agencies still undiscovered he was looked on as a romantic dreamer.
Oxford and Cambridge, appearing in foreign waters for the first time, today defeated two French crews in special two-mile races on the Seine.

ALTHOUGH "Nights of an Old Child" is published as a novel, it actually is an autobiography in the form of a fantasy. It has the dream-like quality that distinguished much of German literature of the Twenties--a quality that represented the recoil of sensitive minds from the chaos of a world in process of disintegration.

An opinion recently rendered by Justice Mitchell May of the Supreme Court holds developers of -residential tracts strictly responsible for all improvements and installation of home facilities originally promised to purchasers of lots. The opinion held that Nathan Horowitz and Dr. Aaron Forelick were entitled to receive from the developing company all payments of principal, interest and taxes from 1926 to May, 1933.

Augustus Strong Mapes, lawyer, died here yesterday after an illness of several months. He was 71 years old. Mr. Mapes, -who maintained active practice at his offices at 2 Rector Street until his illness, specialized in estate law.

Battering his opponent with heavy body blows, Roy Petragallo of Washington State became the 1937 national collegiate 115-pound boxing champion tonight. He scored a three-round decision over Frank Jenkins of South Carolina.

Miss Helen Elliott Belding, daughter of Mrs. Albert G. Belding of this place and the late Mr. Belding, was married here this afternoon in the Sage Chapel of Cornell University to Henry P. Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Smith of North Tonawanda. The Rev. Paul C. Payne performed the ceremony.

THE twentieth anniversary, this week, of the entrance of the United States into the World War finds General John J. Pershing returning for a brief moment to the stage of world events on which, two decades ago, he played a mighty part.

CURIUM (Kourion in Greek), an ancient city of Cyprus which flourished in the Mycenaean period (1400-1100 B. C.) and was shaken down by an earthquake in the sixth century, has yielded several important finds to the spades of American archaelogists working under University of Pennsylvania sponsorship.

Brilliant performances that left a combined attendance of more than 100,000 enthusiasts with no doubt as to their superiority today sent Celtic and Aberdeen, two of this country's mighty soccer machines, to the Scottish Cup finals at Hampden Park, April 24.

The Veterans of Future Wars, who a year ago today were enjoying nation-wide notoriety in their efforts to satirize the Harrison Bonus Bill, have officially terminated their sporadic career as a "veterans' movement," according to a bulletin issued today by Robert G. Barnes, '37, of Philadelphia, and Thomas Riggs Jr., '37, of Washington, present joint commanders of the organization.

Remodeled in a number of important respects, the latest draft of the bill to revise the Bankruptcy Act will be presented to Congress this week, Brace Bennitt of the National Association of Credit Men reported here yesterday.
