Residential sales in many sections of Westchester County showed a decided upward trend last week This early Spring demand, combined with a growing shortage in medium-priced dwellings in some of the popular home centers, has -led several of the leading brokers to predict that a rise in asking prices for good homes will be seen before the Fall season, and in many areas rent rises may also be looked for at that time.

The lot at 10 Norfold Av., Maplewood, N. J., has been purchased by Michael Warnitzke, builder, for resale. W. H. Schoner. the broker, also rented the bakery at 1,226 Springfield Av., Irvlngton. to Max Schrott for Mrs. Elsie Lemke. and the store at 1,292 Springfield Av. to Harry Jack for John Ernst. for a tailor shop.

Agriculture, told an audience here tonight that repetition of the extremes in economic depressions and booms probably could be avoided in the-future if the government were allowed to use its taxing and spending powers to stabilize business.
Germany has begun to punish her citizens for crimes committed abroad. Such crimes are now classed as "attacks on the reputation of the German people."
Business movements in general continued steady last week, except in those sections of the country affected by labor troubles and unfavorable weather conditions.
Two landlords agreed today that the Home Owners Loan Corporation did a good repair job on a house--but said that it was the wrong house.
NOVELS of divorce are many, but those worthy to be compared with this new one by Margaret Kennedy might be counted on the fingers of one hand.

John A. Leverty, president of Leverty Drug Company, local drug store chain and president of the Municipal Board of Apportionment and Taxation, died at his home here today at the age of 68. He was a native of Bridgeport, a son of James Leverty who came here from Ireland in 1830.

England's cricketeers concluded their tour of Australasia today with a victory over a combined Auckland and Wellington eleven. After the match the players were given a hearty send-off as they boarded a liner bound for England.

AGIBE once current at the expense of the typical Oxford undergraduate alleged that his idea of the working claes was a generalization from his scout-the college servant who cleaned his rooms and prepared his meals.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Piel of 30 Fifth Avenue and Salisbury, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Scott Piel, to William Evans, Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans Ward of Port Chester, N. Y.

Robert E. Chaddock. Professor of Statistics at Columbia University, today was elected chairman of the advisory committee of the Bureau of the Census, succeeding Edmund E. Day of the Rockefeller Foundation.
The seventh annual national masters' individual championship tournament under the auspices of the American Bridge League will be held tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday at the Park Central Hotel.

Fordham began another chapter in its long and colorful baseball history yesterday and did it in a manner highly pleasing to followers of the Maroon. In the opening game of the season the 1937 Ram nine contrived to score a 7-to-2 triumph over St. Peter's College on windswept Fordham Field.

Walter Kramer of Detroit won the men's singles title in the first national badminton tournament before 3,000 fans at the Illinois Naval Armory tonight, defeating Hock Sim Ong of Berkeley, Calif., 15-10, 15-4.

THIS year is the sesquicentennial of the ratification of the Amer ican Constitution, which is to be commemorated by a special stamp issue. Although no definite plans have been made, it has been suggested that a complete set be issued, picturing various scenes which occurred in formulating the document.
A couple of dabs of iodine and a black eye remained the only visible reminders of "The Battle of Tampa" tonight as Frankie Frisch dismissed the matter with a wave of the hand.

Fordham began another chapter in its long and colorful baseball history yesterday and did it in a manner highly pleasing to followers of the Maroon. In the opening game of the season the 1937 Ram nine contrived to score a 7-to-2 triumph over St. Peter's College on windswept Fordham Field.

Walter Kramer of Detroit won the men's singles title in the first national badminton tournament before 3,000 fans at the Illinois Naval Armory tonight, defeating Hock Sim Ong of Berkeley, Calif., 15-10, 15-4.

THIS year is the sesquicentennial of the ratification of the Amer ican Constitution, which is to be commemorated by a special stamp issue. Although no definite plans have been made, it has been suggested that a complete set be issued, picturing various scenes which occurred in formulating the document.
A couple of dabs of iodine and a black eye remained the only visible reminders of "The Battle of Tampa" tonight as Frankie Frisch dismissed the matter with a wave of the hand.
German settlers in the former Reich colony of Southwest Africa, angered by a decree outlawing Nazi political units, boycotted courts and mapped a protest to the League of Nations today.

Communism, once illegal in Canada, later legalized and still later benefited by the deletion from the Canadian Criminal Code of a drastic "antiRed" clause known as Section 98, is again to be driven underground in the second largest Canadian Province.
Michigan will choose two State Supreme Court justices and several minor State officials on Monday in an election which would ordinarily attract little outside interest.

A period of change such as the present crisis in organized industry often marks the birth of a new way of organizing the habits, the patterns of thought for a nation, the Rev. John Walter Houck said at the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx, yesterday.

A cabled message of congratulation from Pope Pius XI to the Rev. John R. Mahoney of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rose of Lima, 165th Street near St. Nicholas Avenue, was read yesterday at the golden jubilee of Father Mahoney's ordination. The Most Rev. John J. Mitty, Archbishop of San Francisco, read the message.

Labor's application for a forty-hour week has accentuated the rise of prices in France. While industrial leaders note a falling-off in consumption resulting from the higher prices, workmen are demanding still further increases in their wages. Thus the social situation continues rather uncertain.

Miss Elizabeth June Sumner, daughter of Mrs. Amelia Sumner of Bronxville, N. Y., and of G. Lynn Sumner of New York, will be married here to George Sidney Birdsong, also of Bronxville, on the afternoon of April 16 in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

George Ade, Hoosier humorist and author, assailed President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan today in a statement released here. "We are headed for a virtual dictatorship, and such a finish was never contemplated by the founders of our government," Mr. Ade said.

Negotiations with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra having failed, Paramount is searching frantically for some other nationally known orchestral unit to appear with Kirsten Flagstad in her sequences of "Big Broadcast of 1938."
The Chrysler automobile strike, four weeks old, appeared to be on the verge of settlement tonight on the ninth day of peace conferences in Governor Murphy's office.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., speaking at the communion breakfast of Woodhaven Council, Knights of Columbus, in the church hall of St. Thomas Roman Catholie Church, Eighty-eighth Street, Woodhaven, criticized the presentation of crime news in "some newspapers."

James Talcott, Inc., textile and general factors, report a business volume for-the first three months of this year of $26,969,000, as compared with $19,594,000 for the corresponding period in 1936,.an increase of 37 per cent.

Two hundred and fifty young men in the uniform of cavalrymen of the United States National Guard stood in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Ninetieth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon in the annual memorial service for members of Squadron A who died during the year.

Margaret S. Kingsford, in 116 E. 63d St, through Samuel A. Herzog. Ruth Corby, in 14 E. 44th St.; Semyon Canter, in 34 W. 47th St.; Cushman Wakefield, Inc., broker. Willis R. and Elizabeth S. Harrah, in 140 E. 28th St.; Roy M. Moskowitz, William P. Rogan, in 230 E. 73d St.; S. Richard Lemberg, in 39 5th Av.; through Bing Bing, Inc.

Dr. L. Morgan Chambers, Methodist clergyman, today advised women in his congregation to honor their mothers-in-law. "Let the wife remember that she also may become a motherin-law and learn to practice the Golden Rule," he said in his sermon.

Four Japanese delegates to the Conference of Textile Producing Nations will have a story to tell when they get home of how a member of President Roosevelt's Cabinet took them on a sight-seeing tour of Washington.

The Regional Plan Association declared yesterday that the Storm King by-pass between Bear Mountain and Cornwall, as planned by the State Department of Public Works, was not suitable for general traffic and offered an alternative route through the Popolopen Creek Valley several miles to the west.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 4.--The rare spectacle of a State Gov ernor naming best-in-show brought the Union County Kennel Club' all-breed exhibition to a conclusion in the local armory tonight where George H. Earle 3d, Pennsylvania's chief executive, selected the wire haired fox terrier, Ch. Edgemoore Everest of Wirehart. for the pre mier award.

Passage of the Feld bills giving permanent tenure to associate superintendents and enlarging the Board of Education would undermine the integrity of the city school system, the New York City League of Women Voters declared yesterday in a message to Speaker Oswald D. Heck.

Carl Owen Hubbell, foremost pitching master of his time, came to grips with baseball's latest mound marvel, Bob Feller, in a soul-stirring duel of five innings today and demonstrated to an overflow crowd of 13,000 that the old has not yet been overshadowed by the new.

An agreement was reached at 4 A. M. today in the strike of fortyeight seamen of the New England Steamship Company, which halted all steamer communication with Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard Thursday.
Harry C. Turner, veteran Missouri newspaper man, died here today. His age was 68. He had been a figure in Missouri newspaper and political life nearly half a century.

Jesse Stuart, the Kentucky backwoodsman whose writings have won him a Guggenheim Fellowship, will use the grant to go to Scotland to study. His autobiography, "Beyond Dark Hills," has been postponed until the. Fall, Dutton's, his publishers, announce.

Dress business was irregular in the wholesale market here last week. Prom, graduation and party dresses were called for, and there were requests for bridal ensembles for window-display and promotion purposes.

Taxpayers of the Oyster Bay School District will be asked to vote at the annual meeting May 4 on whether or not the old gray schoolhouse at Cove Neck, where the children of President Theodore Rosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt learned their three R's, shall be sold at auction to cut expenses.

The Mordkin Ballet made its bow to New York last night at the Majestic Theatre when it presented the world premiere of "The Goldfish," based on a poem of Pushkin, and a revival of the classic "Giselle" after a quarter of a century's sleep.

Class X dinghies gathered today in a group of eight at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Sam Wetherill, in his new craft, Wench, led the others through seven contests with 134 points to 121 points for George Isdale in his Queen Mary.

Dinghy skippers in both the B and D classes had to bow to the skill of the brothers Romagna in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club series today. Victor Romagna Jr., sailing Tom and Jerry, scored In class B and his younger brother, Leonard, in Jenny, won in the ten-foot division.

Dr. Frederick C. Langenberg, vice president in charge of research of the United States Pipe and Foundry Company, arid a widely known metallurgist, died suddenly at his home here today from a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 47 years old. Dr. Langenberg was born in Beverly, Ohio.

George Orr, consul and secretary of the United States Legation here, died yesterday at his home of apoplexy. He was 50 years old. He had been playing tennis, and shortly after returning to his home he collapsed. Mr. Orr was born in Philadelphia and assumed his post here in 1936. His widow survives.
Councilman and Mrs. Everett B. Sniffen of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabel Gertrude Sniffen, to Harry Leslie Brown, son of Mrs. Alice May Brown of Fairfield.

States which attempt low-cost housing projects must at least partially exempt such properties from taxation or they will be "forced to fill their projects with tenants who do not need public aid and will thus encroach upon the field of legitimate enterprise," Howard A. Gray, housing director of the Public Works Administration, asserted in an article published today in the magazine American City.

Longfellow Av., 1,810 to 1,812 (11-3011); Longfellow Equities, Inc., to Syndicate Estates, Inc., 535 5th Av.; mtg., $246,000. Edison Av., 1,914 (15-4234); Commercial Trust Co. to Teresa Poidomani, 1,916 Edison Av.; mtg. $5,000. Jerome Av. (12-3322). n. e. cor. 205 St., 90x 100; Nesor Service Stations, Inc., to Pickwick Garage, Inc., 3,150 Jerome Av.; mtg., $35,000.

The Highview Real Estate Co., represented by J. W. Kera, attorney, was the buyer of the two apartment houses at 652-6 W. 160th St., sold recently by a client of Charles M. Rosenthal. C. Willis Griffen, son of Chauncey B. Griffen, has joined the Chauncey B. Griffen Organization.
Two of the seven championships were won tonight by Miss Ruth Hughes Aarons of New York as the seventh United States table tennis tourney ended.
The economic effect of the Chrysler strick has aroused concern among business leaders.

The blundering tactics of Japanese militarists in Inner Mongolia have lost them the respect of the Mongol population, which is becoming growingly sympathetic to the Sovietized Outer Mongolia, according to the opinions of qualified foreign observers just returned from that region.

Byron Nelson, 25-year-old Texan who quit railroading for golf eight years ago, today justified his change in occupation by winning one of the most important honors that golf has to bestow on one of its devotees.

Members of the old guard captured two of the three women's senior metropolitan A. A. U. championships at stake yesterday in the Women's Swimming Association pool. However, these so-called "old-timers" had to put forth their best efforts to stave off strong challenges by younger entrants.
Word of the death in London yesterday of Mrs. A. Augustus Van der Poel, the former Gertrude Welling of New York, has been received by relatives here. She died after a short illness at the age of 41.

The German press has been forced to take notice of the storms of applause interrupting every performance of Schiller's drama "Don Carlos" here and throughout Germany at the passage in which the Marquis Posa demands of King Philip of Spain: "Sire, give us freedom of thought."
Their skulls crushed with a brick, the bodies of Mrs. Edna A. Worden, 48, and her daughter, Marguerite, 12, were found today in their small apartment.

In 2,002 Civilian Conservation Camps throughout the United States proper and on American possessions, 350,000 healthy and weather-beaten young men and war veterans tomorrow will climax a three-day "open house" celebration in honor of the fourth birthday of the CCC.

Three members of the last Olympic squad were among the eight swordsmen who survived the metropolitan district's qualifying round for the senior national foils individual fencing championship tournament at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

The sale of milk at from 5 cents to 8 cents a quart in the more congested sections of the city continued yesterday. It was indicated on the lower East Side and in other congested sections that the price war would continue today.
A flight between Boston and Floyd Bennett Field will be made today by a regular airliner of American Airlines, operators of the scheduled service to Newark Airport.
More than one-half of the william L. Blanchard estate here, considered on of the residential show places in this area, will become a suburban real estate development.

Thomas L. Forbes, father of Russell Forbes, New York City Commissioner of Purchase, died in West Middlesex, Pa., on Saturday, after a long illness, at the age of 79. Services will be held today, with burial in the family plot alongside the grave of his wife, who died four years ago.

The Screen Actors Guild, representing film actors and extras in movie studios, most of them on the Pacific Coast, will not shrink from calling a strike if its demand for recognition by the producers and collective bargaining is rejected, it was said yesterday.

Retail sales in Great Britain in February were 7.1 per cent larger than in the corresponding month of 1936, when there was a similar gain over a year before. In January there had been an increase of only 2.4 per cent over a year before, due to seasonal slackness.

Dejay Stores, Inc.--Year to Jan. 31: Net profit, after deducting reserves and after provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes and $45.500 surtax on undistributed earnings, $267,885, equal to $1.87 a share on outstanding common stock.

Preliminary figures on the production of tractors, combines and grain threshers in the United States for 1936 show a sharp rise over production in the previous year, the Department of Commerce has announced.

Efforts are being made to get Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, to intervene in the Tammany situation with a view to electing a new leader in place of James J. Dooling today or tomorrow before his return from Washington.

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, making a short visit here today to award prizes at a dog show, told interviewers he was "not thinking" of seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1940.

Funeral services for Frederick Charles French of 142 East Twentysecond Street will be held at 11 A. M. tomorrow in the Funeral Church, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street. Mr. French, who died Saturday at the age of 63, is survived by his widow, the former Helene Goodrich; three sisters, Mrs.

Demanding that the city stop work on the Delaware-Roundout water supply project, the Community Councils, through a statement by Edward T. Russell, chairman of its water committee, predicted yesterday that another increase in water rates of at least 20 per cent would be required to meet the deficit caused by the project if the water system is to be made selfsustaining.

The Los Angeles Times is the winner this year of the Francis Wayland Ayer Cup, offered annually to a daily newspaper for typographical excellence. The award was announced today by N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., advertising agency.

Joseph E. Davies, United States Ambassador to Russia, will arrive today from Moscow on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary accompanied by Mrs. Davies. Others on board the ship are Sir Alfred and Lady Booth, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Miller, Arthur L. Halmi, Mile. Naida Boulanger, Norman Marshall and Sandon Incze.
Sir Robert Cassels, commanderin-chief of the army in India, left for the northwest frontier today following reports of growing unrest in that area.

Miss Evelyn Warnock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Warnock of Wistaria Court, Westport, will be married to William K. Zinke, son of Mrs. William K. Zinke of Brooklyn, N. Y., on Saturday at Sherry's in New York by the Rev. Herbert H. Field. A reception will follow the ceremony, which originally was planned for June 12.

Dowager Lady Linlithgow, mother of the Marquess of Linlithgow, Viceroy of India, died here yesterday. The Hon. Hersey Alice Eveleighde-Moleyns, daughter of the fourth Baron Ventry, and a Lady of Grace of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem in England, married the first Marquess of Linlithgow in 1886.

Pedro Montanez, the Puerto Rican sensation, will trade punches with Lou Ambers, the world lightweight champion, at Madison Square Garden tonight in a tenround non-title bout that is expected to draw a crowd of 12,000.

The second annual interclub golf tournament for the Arthur Lehman Memorial Trophy, sponsored by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, will be staged this year on Sunday, June 13, at the Century Country Club, Purchase, N. Y.

The Foreign Policy Association said today that pending legislation to take profits out of war contained a legal basis for establishing "a dictatorship bearing much more severely on the press and labor than on industry."

Two Bronx detectives were engaged yesterday in a search for a large bronze figure. It was such a bronze figure as even a resourceful group of thieves must have difficulty in concealing, being that of an eagle, about 6 feet tall and with a wingspread of 6 1/2 feet and weighing 700 pounds.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Berry of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Gibson Berry, to Thomas Gregory Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gregory of Westfield. Miss Berry attended the Katharine Gibbs School in New York. Mr. Gregory was graduated from Clarkson College of Technology.

The two-year contract signed Friday in New York between the United Mine Workers and the bituminous coal operators of the Appalachian area will increase the nation's annual fuel bill by about $100,000,000, J. D. Battle, executive secretary of the National Coal Association, said today.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 87.2 on March 31, which compared with 85 on March 10, 82.3 on Feb. 24, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
Gold mines described as the most ancient in the world, which may have furnished the mysterious Scythians

Starting a ten-run rally. with two out in the fourth inning, the St. John's University baseball team turned back the Columbus Council K. of C. nine of Brooklyn, 11 to 5, in a five-inning game at Dexter Park yesterday.

Miss Alice Kingsbury, a member of one of Waterbury's oldest and most prominent families, died early this morning of pneumonia after a brief illness. Her age was 78. Miss Kingsbury died in the house on Prospect Street in which she was born.

Even a few years ago when political surrealists talked of the "new Europe" they were still thinking of the abstract composition produced by the war treaties. Mr. Agog didn't hang together very well, but the bones of the loose-jointed structure were knitting;

Four hundred model airplanes, constructed by 102 youthful contestants, tried their wings this afternoon at the eighth annual miniature aircraft meet held under sponsorship of the Westchester County Recreation Commission and the Westchester Advanced Aircraft Modelers.

Alexander Pompez, New York policy racketeer, who is wanted by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, has refused an offer to return to the United States and testify before a grand jury in return for "some consideration," Charles P. Grimes, assistant to Mr. Dewey, announced tonight.

An extensive itinerary has been mapped out for the combined Oxford-Cambridge lawn tennis team which will meet the joint representatives of Harvard and Yale in the eleventh biennial international intercollegiate match for the Prentice CuD.
Errol Flynn, film actor and adventurer, early today was reported to have received a minor bullet wound on his face when he was caught in machine-gun fire yesterday on Madrid's University City front.

Miss Isabel Morrison West Jackson of New York will be married to Dr. Thorborn S. McGowan of New London; Conn., in the First Congregational Church, Pittsfield, on April 17. Miss Jackson is the daughter of Mrs. William Benjamin Jackson of Pittsfield and the late Colonel Jackson, formerly of Scarsdale, N.

The Hudson Coal Company produced 4,574,275 net tons of anthracite coal in 1936, an increase of 5.3 per cent from 1935, according to the annual report. The 1936 output of the company was 8.8 per cent of the total produced by all collieries in 1936. Sales of the company last year aggregated 4,571,866 net tons, against 4,408,391 net tons in 1935, an increase of 3.7 per cent.

Further rezoning and planning of the West Side waterfront area to develop "an imposing gateway to the city" from the piers between Forty-eighth and Fifty-seventh Street has been proposed to the Mayor's Committee on City Planning by the Merchants Association of New York.

Army officers in charge of Civilian Conservation Corp- camps have been directed to turn over for investigation by their superiors "all magazines and publications containing subversive material," M. B. Schnapper, editor of the magazine Champion of Youth, charged yesterday in a letter to Senator Robert M. LaFollette, chairman of the Senate sub-committee on civil liberties.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler has promised General Erich Ludendorff he may carry on his neo-pagan propaganda unhindered, according to a statement mailed by the general to members of the Tannenberg League throughout Germany. General Ludendorff writes:

The body of Lieutenant William D. Meurlin, 40, of Brooklyn, was found today in the ruins of the officers' barracks of the Breeze Hill CCC camp near. Fire of an undetermined origin swept the barracks late last night, while other officers were attending a farewell dinner dance at Camp Wawayanda of the CCC, several miles away.

The rise in prices of goods in France has been caused in the first place by an expansion in the demand by consumers and a shortage of production, but has been accentuated by purchases of a more or less speculative nature.

The S. G. S. B. Realty Corporation (Sol Brenner and S. Gluek) bought from Jack L. Fein and Nathan Bernstein the six-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1,065 Manor Avenue, siuthwest corner of Watson Avenue, the Bronx.

Twelve government agencies let 147 supply contracts valued at $10,119,044 under the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on April 1, the Deapartment of Labor has announced. This total is more than double the weekly average to date.

The church has for years been afflicted with spiritual "sit-down strikes," the Rev. John Brett Langstaff, rector of St. Edmund's Church, Morris Avenue and 177th Street, told his congregation yesterday.
The feeling here is that the financial markets probably will not be lively before the budget, although they should maintain a confident tone without being affected by Spanish developments.

Champion Hertzville Headstone, sable and white collie owned by C. J. Casselman and Thomas Halpin of Chicago and shown by Casselman, was named best in show as the thirtysixth annual two-day Chicago Kennel Club exhibition closed at the Coliseum tonight.

George Grubee, 28 years old, a truck driver, was a prisoner in Kings County Hospital yesterday charged with the fatal shooting of Mrs. Jessie Harris, 27, mother of two children, following a quarrel at her home, 172 Conklin Street, in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.
News of the degradation and presumable arrest of Henry G. Yagoda, leader for twenty years of the Soviet political police, was received today by Moscow with shock.
The work of the Customs Service in suppressing traffic in narcotics was praised yesterday by Joseph P. Martin, Assistant United States Attorney.
For the first time since Wilmington truckmen went on strike three weeks ago their representatives will meet a committee representing the employers tomorrow.

White the much-discussed project of a Northern European defense pact, including Finland, is meeting opposition in leading Socialist quarters of the Scandinavian countries as impracticable, the Finnish Labor party today approved the proposal.

The art collection of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, will be sold on the premises of Inisfada, Mrs. Macaulay's mansion at Manhasset, L. I., from May 10 to May 15.

The first in a series of afternoon gatherings in behalf of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will be given tomorrow by Mrs. Francis Oakey at her home, 24 Gramercy Park. Acting as hostess with Mrs. Oakey will be Mrs. William O'D. Iselin, chairman of the membership committee. During the afternoon tea will be served.
ALBANY, April 4(AP).--Roy S. Smith, director of the Albany district of the Federal Housing Administration, predicted tonight a Spring building boom in up-State New York.

Henry Goldman, former senior partner of Goldman, Sachs Co., bankers. died yesterday at his home, 998 Fifth Avenue, surrounded by the paintings and objects of art to the collection of which he had devoted many years of his life. He would have been 80 years old next September.

Miss Florence Meachem Hyde, daughter of Mrs. Dana Cheney Hyde of 122 East Seventy-sixth Street and the late Mr. Hyde, has chosen the afternoon of May 15 for her marriage to Henry John Wynkoop 3d, also of this city,
Defense of Hawaii and tests of new "vest-pocket cruisers," new sky

In a statement emphasizing the growing importance of arbitration in legal practice the Association of the Bar of the City of New York announced yesterday formation of a panel of its members who have agreed to act as arbitrators when called upon. The panel is composed of more than 200 lawyers.

Dr. Nathan Birnbaum, writer, scholar and a leader and theorist of several important Jewish nationalist and cultural movements, died last night in Scheveningen after a long illness. He would have been 73 years old on April 25.

The official campaign against independent craftsmen, handworkers and small industrial concerns has begun. Owing to bureaucratic complications in obtaining rations of raw materials, these small workers already had been in difficulties.

Passenger revenues of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway amounted to $15,629,081 in 1936, compared with $13,451,494 in 1935, an increase of 16.1 per cent, S. T. Bledsoe, president, disclosed in his annual report.

A four-point program designed to stabilize wage and working conditions and eliminate unfair competition in the commercial branch of the printing industry was adopted yesterday at a conference of representatives of 40,000 members of the International Typographical Union, held in the Hotel Plymouth, 143 West Forty-ninth Street.

Central Park West, s. cor. 88th St., 125, 10 1/2 x 160; central Park-88th St. Crop. to Jonas D. Lissberger, 541 Isham St. ($1) 121st St., 207-209 E., 34-10x71.9 x irreg.: Mary Goldberg to Morris L. and Mary Goldberg, 209 E. 121st St., in trust for grantee and her children.

An airplane for experimental work in the stratosphere will probably be completed within two weeks in the Lockheed factory here. Although secrecy has surrounded the construction, the plane, it is understood, will be delivered to the army.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's, and Womrath's:

The Tigers, who paid the White Sox $75,000 slightly more than a year ago for Al Simmons, sold the hardhitting outfield veteran to the Senators today. The transaction was completed soon after the Washington team arrived for an exhibition game with the Tigers.

The Society of the Four Arts Gallery was filled for the twilight recital given today by the Palm Beach String Quartet, making its first public appearance here this season. Members are Mary Miller Trownsell, Nell Vivian, Marjorie Byrum and Henrietta Olhaber.
Pointers, English setters, Irish Setters, cocker spaniels and bulldogs were judged at the final session of the fifth annual Pinehurst Kennet Club show today.

Playing in surroundings that more closely approached big league standards than any they have encountered since starting their 1937 training campaign, the Yankees looked like champions today as they swamped the Houston Buffaloes of the Texas League, 14-0, for their eighth straight exhibition conquest and their fifteenth triumph in eighteen games.

A poodle, ch. Marquis De Fumerol of Stonywall, owned by Dr. and Mrs. F. R. Sanborn of Jackson Heights, N. Y., was declared best in the show tonight at the annual bench show of the Birmingham Kennel Club.
More than 200 clothing dealers from all parts of the country assembled here tonight at a jubilee dinner in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of Hart, Schaffner Marx, clothiers.
The week's markets were dull and featureless, with interest concentrated on United States and European movements in the primary commodities. Views in this field vary greatly locally.
Twenty-nine Americans, the second such group of Spain-bound volunteers to be stopped in France since the law against volunteers went into effect, were lodged in the Toulouse jail tonight.

There is a bill before the Vermont Legislature to restore the original seal of the State, which declared its independence in 1777. IRA ALLEN, one of ETHAN'S brothers, a subtle-minded politician, became the first Treasurer of the State in 1778.
Hundreds of Osaka geisha, encouraged by the success of their sitdown strike a month ago, were selling shares today in Osaka Geisha, Inc., a joint stock company and a strictly business organization.

April finds the New York art galleries displaying all the vitality of the early season. Far from any sign of a falling off in- the number of exhibitions, the Spring curve is sharply upward. More than a score of shows are on the calendar for today and tomorrow, and with those opened over the week-end and others later this week, the total of new exhibitions approaches two-score.

Contrary to general expectations, the Bank of France has not lowered its official discount rate, which remains at 4 per cent. Adjournment of the decision is due more to the confused money-market position.
Navy Department officials disclosed today the development of a "radio spy" by which enemy warships can be located or tracked long distances at sea.
A runaway market developed in corn here last week, with business on the Board of Trade the heaviest and offerings of cash corn and futures the lightest in several years.

Fifty representatives of the newly formed Textile Workers Organizing Committee headed out of Atlanta tonight into the eight Southern States from North Carolina to the Gulf of -Mexico to open their organization drive.
The Reds ran their winning streak to three today with a 2-to-1 triumph over the Red Sox in eleven innings in the final game of the Tampa training season. The Reds start north tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Considerable popular uncertainty regarding my attitude toward sit-down strikes has arisen because my Senate remarks of March 31 were incompletely reported in the press.
The League of Composers presented a program of contemporary music in Town Hall last night at a concert for the benefit of its Composers Fund and the Neighborhood Playhouse Scholarship Fund.

State Trooper Herbert Berglund, 28 years old, of Bay Shore Barracks, was taken to Meadowbrook Hospital in East Hempstead soon after 4 o'clock this morning for treatment of a fractured skull suffered in a night club row.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 94.7, which compares with 94.4 the week before, 93.7 two weeks before, 92.9 three weeks before and 91.1 four weeks before. The present average is the highest of the year to date;

Talcott Williams Powell, author, of Glen Avon Road, Riverside, Greenwich, died at the Greenwich Hospital this morning, following an operation for a ruptured appendix. He was 36 years old. Mr. Powell was born in Lansdowne, Pa. He was graduated from Wesleyan University and in 1932 he became editor of The Indianapolis Times, retiring in July, 1935.
Walter H. Powers and Alwyn Monroe captured the club trap-shooting championships, while Mrs. P. J. Fuller and P. J. Fuller Jr. annexed the mixed doubles paddle tennis title at Manursing Island today.
Ralph Greenleaf of New York turned in a brilliant run of 84 last night to move into a three-cornered tie for first place in the world's pocket-billiard championship at Ponzi's Academy.
The death toll of Friday's railway crash near Battersea Park rose to ten tonight when two of the forty persons injured in the suburban train collision died in a hospital.

The WPA Federal Music Project announced yesterday that the attendance of adults and children at its free classes in 128 music education and social music centers of Greater New York during the period from July 20, 1934, to April 1, 1937, totaled 7,689,406. At the present time the weekly attendance is more than 60,000.
If the present trend continues, practically every State in the union will have inaugurated some type of advertising campaign before the end of the year, according to comment among agency executives.

The Federal Government moved today to protect the market for its securities and at-the same time to carry a step farther the easy-money policy which it believes necessary to continue expansion of industrial production and increased employment.

Active buying of home loans and converted dollar bonds developed today as the main feature of the week on the Boerse. Stocks generally were neglected. Bond buyers particularly sought the mortgage bank issues.

Many reservations have been made for the annual dinner dance in behalf of St. Vincent's Hospital which will be held tomorrow at the Plaza. The benefit has been arranged by members of the Ladies Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital, of which Mrs. Jose M. Ferrer is president.

Byron W. Austin, 45, Democratic Mayor-elect of Danbury who was to have been sworn into office tomorrow, was found dead tonight at his hunting lodge near Ball's Pond, New Fairfield, several miles north of Danbury.
The New York Americans battled to a 1-1 tie with Brookhattan in an American Soccer League contest at Starlight Park yesterday afternoon before 2,500 fans.
Commenting editorially on the American Foundation's survey of medicine in the United States.
William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company devoted his Ford evening hour radio address tonight to replying to this question from an Eastern State listener:

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,770,530,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

Bishop Pierre Fallaize, Catholic prelate of the Arctic, whose diocese comprises 600,000 square miles, arrived in New York yesterday and participated in a radio program broadcast specially to a member of the Royal Northwest Mounted Police at the northernmost point of entry in Canada.
Mrs. Frank J. Bersbach of suburban Winnetka, will announce tomorrow morning the engagement of her daughter, Helen, to Robert Hall McCormick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hall McCormick.

After a twenty-four-hour search of the Atlantic, within a radius of 300 miles northwest of the Azores, had been made by three ships which picked up her S O S call early Saturday morning, the North German Lloyd freighter Borkum, which had reported her steering gear disabled and her plates opened up, admitting water into her forward hold, was located by the Exeter of the American Export Line and the British freighter Pontypridd.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Ellmore gave a tea this afternoon in honor of Miss Mildred Smith, fiancee of their son, Wilbur A. Ellmore. Miss Smith is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Smith of this place. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Frank Braun, Mr. and Mrs. George Reischmann,

Dr. Nahum Goldman of the executive committee of the World Jewish Congress said today that representations were being made to the League of Nations against a law the Rumanian Government now is drafting for the protection of national labor.

BERLIN, April 3.--The official index of industrial activity, with the 1936 basis as 100, was 100.7 in February, against 100.4 for January. Owing to the decline in building, the capital goods branch was unchanged, whereas consumption goods showed substantial revivals, also the average working time in this category increased. Only cottonspinning, woolen activity and radio, and part of the electrical industries were depressed.

The Baltimore Soccer Club today defeated the league-leading Brooklyn Hispano Club, 1 to 0. With fifteen minutes remaining in the first half, Brandolini, leftback for Hispano, fell across the goal to save a shot and knocked the ball out with his hands.

Mankind defeats its own purpose by resorting to war, quarrels and bickering to achieve the ends of peace and is, in turn, blind to the things that actually do bring peace to the world, the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge said yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

An unenthusiastic reception was given "Peter Petrolus," by Robert Victor, which opened tonight. This gave Esme Percy the role of a demagogue who rose to the highest political post in England and aspired to create first the United States of Europe, then the United States of the World.

From records of solar activity gathered by astronomers in the last 200 years, a rule has been devised that may make it possible to forecast world-wide radio receiving conditions five or six years in advance, according to A. L. Durkee, engineer of the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

Norman P. Gaynor, president of the Bridgeport City Trust Company, announced today the marriage in Port Chester, N. Y., on Friday of his sister, Mrs. Marion Gaynor Jackson of Bridgeport and New York, to Frank Carley Hunt, Bridgeport broker.

Paddy, a 3-year-old German shepherd dog, owned by Mounted Patrolman Patrick Conroy, caused his master's death by shooting early yesterday morning when he playfully leaped at him, knocked him down and discharged a service revolver that the policeman held in his hand.

A conflict between the idea of a 30-hour week for industry and the hope for a better standard of living for all families in the United States was emphasized yesterday in the annual report of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered four large electrical manufacturing companies to cease pricefixing with respect to sales of turbine generators, directed eight concerns to halt price-fixing in sales of condensers and dismissed a proceeding against the Heat Exchange Institute.

Eighteen British sociologists, who are members of Le Play Society of London, will be entertained by New York University tomorrow afternoon during one of a series of visits to American universities. Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university, and Dr. Marshall S. Brown, dean of the faculties, will greet the visiting sociologists. Dr.

Postmaster James A. Farley eschewed politics for the night as he presided at the induction last night of the newly elected officers of the United Irish Counties Association in the ballroom of the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Scientific excavations and research by the University of Chicago and the University of Illinois are throwing further light on the Mound Builders, the lost race which inhabited Illinois long before the Indians.

After the long Easter recess the Bourse was quiet this week. At first there was a tendency for prices to harden, but Thursday saw a sharp reaction, French and international securities falling considerably. Quotations hardened again at the end of the week, but little business was done.

Leon Trotsky's trial here to decide whether he is guilty of an attempt to overthrow the Soviet regime promises some strange and possibly amusing developments if remarks by his attorney, Albert Goldman of Chicago, are to be taken seriously.

Imposing funeral ceremonies for the composer Karol Szymanowski-regarded as Poland's greatest musical genius since Chopin-were begun today when the train bearing his body crossed the Polish-German frontier to the tune of his Stabat Mater.

The National Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association, Local 33, is the exclusive representative of all licensed chief and assistant engineers employed by the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, Inc., of New York, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.

Dr. Charles Henry Smith Jr., emeritus Professor of Geology at Princeton University, died today in Princeton Hospital from pneumonia and complications resulting from a fractured hip received in a fall two weeks ago. He was 71 years old.

Rain kept Bitsy Grant from testing Wayne Sabin's improved game today and the two were slated tentatively to play the Atlanta invitation tennis final April 18. The doubles final also was prevented by rain.

Dr. Robert E. Wilson, former vice chairman of the boards, has been elected president of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company, the American Oil Company and their subsidiaries, succeeding Jacob Blaustein, resigned. E. G. McKeever was made executive vice president and C. F. Hatmaker, elected vice president in charge of sales.

Intent upon annexing the intercollegiate chess championship, seven student players representing Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Dartmouth began play yesterday in the annual tournament of the H. Y. P. D. League at the Marshall Chess Club.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine gave departmental recognition in a general order issued at midnight last night to 361 policemen recommended by the honor committee for meritorious conduct in line of duty.
Approximately $300,000 in additional subscriptions for World's Fair 4 per cent debentures was announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the Fair's Bond Sales Committee.

The interesting program given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting, yesterday afternoon included the performance of Ernest Bloch's most recent instrumental work, his symphonic poem, with 'cello obbligato, "Voice in the Wilderness."
Sir John Henry Luscombe, a member of Lloyd's since 1870 and five times elected chairman, died at Crawley, Sussex, today at the age of 88. He retired in 1931 after sixty-one years as an underwriter.

Harry Goldstein of Trinity Club, second seeded player, defeated Edward Fialkow of the home club, 21-17, 21-16, in the second round of the New York State A. A. U. one-wall handball singles tournament at the East Flatbush Jewish Community Centre last night. Three other second round clashes were held.

Detective William Barrett, 46 years old, of 375 East 199th Street, the Bronx, attached to the West 100th Street station, was killed at noon yesterday when the car in which he was riding swerved into an elevated pillar at Eighth Avenue and 134th Street.

Within a week or two the President is expected to present to Congress his message asking for relief appropriations for the coming fiscal year. In anticipation of that message the nation's organized Mayors recently asked for a huge appropriation, and Mr. HOPKINS has just published a new list of the useful projects completed by his WPA.

An appeal to President Roosevelt and Congress to balance the budget in the coming fiscal year by reducing expenditures or stabilizing them at present levels, by additional taxes if necessary, by turning back to States and local communities the "main responsibility" for unemployment relief and by "firmly" resisting new demands by World War veterans and other special groups was contained in a petition made public today by the National Economy League.

Kaname Wakasugi, newly appointed Japanese Consul General in New York, arrived here yesterday from Chicago to assume his post. He came as no stranger to New York City, although he came all the way from Manchukuo and China.

Meeting for the first time since the defeat of the child labor amendment in the Assembly, the trustees of the National Child Labor Committee announced yesterday through its secretary, Courtenay Dinwiddie, that it would urge the Legislature to make possible a referendum on ratification at the regular election in November.

Work will be resumed at the Ford Motor Company's plant here tomorrow after a one-day sit-down strike, settled last night to at least the temporary advantage of the United Automobile Workers of America, one of the C. I. 0. unions.
The police moved early this morning to break up a new Shinto sect called Hitonomichi-literally "the human way"-accused of lese-majeste. The chief priest, Tokuchika Miki,

If the world has twenty years more of peace education the armed truce of today can be transformed into real and lasting peace, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said yesterday. Dr. Sockman's sermon marked the twentieth anniversary of his pastorate at Christ Church.

The general increase of freight and passenger rates ordered on several important trade routes in the last ten days and proposed on others reflects the return of traffic in some instances to a point beyond the record pre-depression years, F according to observers of maritime affairs.

Another Monday brings with it the possibility of a decision by the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Act, perhaps better known as the Wagner act. Five cases arising under this law have been argued before the court.
The Milan civil tribunal today granted legal separation to the Marchesa Stefano d'Amico, the former Olive Elizabeth Perkins of New York, from her husband.

Eternal values can be brought into the life of man during his transitory existence, Rabbi Israel Goldstein said yesterday at the Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eightyeighth Street. west of Broadway. The eternal values were named by Rabbi Goldstein as truth, goodness, beauty, faith, love, charity, loyalty, justice, peace and brotherhood.
Seventeen - year - old Herman Hoffberg of Newark today won the five-mile street run conducted annually by the Margate Athletic Association.

Mrs. William Henry Parkinson of Brooklyn and Pinehurst, announced at a tea dance given yesterday at the Country Club here, the engagement of her niece, Miss Emma Arline Bliss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard John Bliss, to Robert Mauldin Pearse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilford Ashley Pearse of Cleveland.

Along First Avenue early yesterday afternoon children clustered to see Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey circus that was here once more and on its way to Madison Square Garden. Last year, over the same cobblestone route, Dexter Fellows convoyed some of his placid elephants, but this year he decided to ride on a scarlet truck hauling property wagon No. 57.

When he signed the Quinn bill, which permits juries to recommend life imprisonment for accomplices in felony murder cases, Governor LEHMAN secured one more of the measures recommended in his anti-crime program.

Thousands of Akron union members paraded through the business district today and then gathered at a huge outdoor mass meeting to hear speakers urge support of the United Rubber Workers' strike at the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

A meeting between Mohandas K. Gandhi and the Marquess of Linlithgow, the Viceroy, is being suggested here as a possible method of ending the constitutional deadlock caused by the refusal of the All-India Congress party to form Ministries in the six provinces where it won majorities at the last election.

If some of the so-called-saints of today were admitted into heaven their noise and hysteria would spoil everything, Dean Milo H. Gates of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine said yesterday at the cathedral Describing the present time as "a hysterical age, an emotional age, an age of high lights," he declared that what religion needs now is more "walking with God," after the manner of Enoch.

The Rev. Aloysius Pfeil, S. J., for twenty-three years chaplain at St. Anthony's Hospital, Woodhaven, L. I., and former rector of Canisius College, Buffalo, died at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday following an operation. He was 75 years old.
A too-enterprising newspaper reporter today found himself a prisoner for half an hour when he tried to interview Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

The international sugar conference opening tomorrow is generally viewed here as a renewed test of whether international cooperation can be applied to regularizing production of essential world commodities without causing future shortages.

William J. Budd Sr., former Controller of Jersey City, died last night at his home, 165 Belmont Avenue, of a heart ailment. He was 77 years old. Mr. Budd, eulogized today by Mayor Frank Hague as a "financial genius," retired two years ago after serving Jersey City for twenty years.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson, who announced on Thursday a $75,000,000 longrange, self-supporting plan for supplying Philadelphia with an unpolluted water supply from the upper Lehigh Valley Pocono watershed, said tonight that he would discuss the program with both New York and New Jersey authorities.
Thus Polish border town was the scene today of another series of frontier rallies which have been going on for some weeks. The local National Socialist regional chief declared:

Admiral Seizo Kobayashi, Governor General of Formosa, will visit American, Netherland and British territories and dependencies in the South Seas this Summer, to establish friendly contacts, reports the newspaper Asahi.

Leinster defeated Ulster by 10 to 4 in the opening Gaelic football game of the season before a crowd of 2,000 at Innisfail Park yesterday. It was an inter-provincial contest, and the players were stars of the local clubs from which the New York team will be picked to play Ireland's champion Mayomen in the opening game of their tour, at the Yankee Stadium on May 16.

A joint meeting of dentists, optometrists and physicians whose practice deals with parts of the head was held in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday under the auspices of the inter-professional relations committee of the New York State Optometrist Association.

Cotton prices last week continued their upward movement which, subject to only brief interruptions, has been under way since last November. Net advances in prices of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange for the week were from 27 to 35 points.
The engagement of Miss Alta Frances Judy of New York to Harold N. Graves Jr. of Washington, D. C., was announced here today by Miss Judy's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Judy.
The Gourmet Society put aside its taste for Continental cooking yesterday afternoon and went native, with a dinner composed entirely of delicacies from Maine.

The interlocking issues of the sit-down strike, the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act and the Roosevelt Court Reorganization Bill combined today to provide Washington with a week-end of expectant tension.

Dr. Leo S. Rowe, Director General of the Pan-American Union, said today that President Roosevelt would deliver his annual Pan-American Day message personally to the Governing Board of the Union on April 14.

Lawrence Wood Robert Jr. of Atlanta, Ga., secretary of the Democratic National Committee, was elected on Saturday as chairman of the board of directors of the Standard Commercial Tobacco Company, it was announced yesterday by Ery Kehaya, president of that company and chairman of the Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company.

Stocks irregular with trading slowest since week ended Sept. 19, 1936; total sales, 7,245,000 shares. United States Government bonds recovered slightly from lows, but prices were sharply off on the week; corporate and foreign bonds also lower; total transactions, $79,257,800.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise called on members of the Free Synagogue, Carnegie Hall, yesterday to co-operate in obtaining Federal enactment of a uniform marriage and divorce law to remove the "shameful" competition between States.

Thomas Hennessy, 15 years old, of Maple Shade, is dead, and a chum, David Preston, 17, of Herwood, is in the Camden County jail on a seconddegree murder charge as the result of some by-play with a .22caliber rifle while the boys were hunting in Delaware Township, near Preston's home, this afternoon.

Dr. Lewis Edwards, president of the Board of Commissioners of Luzerne County and Republican leader, died at his home in Kingston today at the age of 68. He was educated at Wyoming Seminary and at Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia.

The Supreme Court issue was discussed by a clergyman and a layman at two religious services here yesterday. The Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventyninth Street, condemned President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize the Federal judiciary.

Political and industrial leaders get into difficulties because they lack the ingenuity of God's guidance, the Rev, Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty first Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.
A good reason for believing that Germany is not yet ready for war is that she has two technical battle problems still to work out.

The Chinese Ambassador will announce today his government's offer concerning service on the bonds of the Imperial Government Hukuang Railway loan of 1911, a sterling loan offered in that year in the amount of ??6,000,000 in four equal parts as British, French, American and German shares, according to the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc.

The names of Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, and Robert Moses, New York City Park Commissioner, entered tonight into discussions of the possible successor to City Manager Clarence A. Dykstra.

To insure fulfillment of the three-year road-construction program, announced by the President of the Republic of Peru in his inaugural address last December, the government will float an internal loan of 5,000,000 soles bearing interest at 6 per cent.
Wheat operators are reported to be nervous on the expectation of sharp bull movements developing from crop scares in the next month or two. Further decreases in reserve supplies also are feared.
Travelers from Spanish Morocco said tonight demonstrations against the Insurgent regime of General Francisco Franco were growing in intensity in Tetuan and Ceuta.
The New York racing season, which opens at Jamaica April 15, will be a highly successful one, in the opinion of Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the State Racing Commission.
British industrial activity is being vigorously maintained, March's employment increase exceeding the 55,000 February gain, excluding agricultural labor.

Joseph Gedeon paid a brief visit late yesterday afternoon to theapartment at 316 East Fiftieth Street where his wife and daughter were strangled and their roomer, Frank Byrnes, was fatally stabbed eight days ago; but before he could much more than glance inside he was ejected by the police.

Swinging around the Insurgents' left flank in a surprise move, Loyalists this morning captured Valsequillo, on the Cordoba front about eight miles northwest of Penarroya and forty-five miles northwest of Cordoba city.

The investigation of the desperate and now successful efforts of the Reich radio to drown out the so-called secret station of the German Communist party revealed that the effect of its broadcasts on Pan-German propaganda was resented as much as its possible influence on public opinion within the Reich.
Mayor La Guardia and Senator Robert F. Wagner joined last night in a radio appeal for popular support for the $1,000,000,000 WagnerSteagall housing bill now pending in Congress.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 91 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in the week and a rise of 7 points from the low point of the last six weeks, when recovery from the flood influence was virtually complete.
Secretary of State Cordell Hull gave formal notice today of the intention of the United States to negotiate a reciprocal trade agreement with Ecuador.

Senator Royal S. Copeland was the principal speaker at a dinner given last night by the Young Men's and Women's Hebrew Associtation of Washington Heights in honor of its president, Benjamin F. Schreiber.
Prices of lard broke early last week on the Board of Trade on liquidating sales and lower prices for hogs, but they rallied on short covering and a little new investment and consumptive buying.

Pope Pius spoke for ten minutes today to 3,000 French pilgrims in his first reception to a pilgrimage since he became ill last December. Carried into the hall of Pope Benedict XII on his portable throne,

The Dodgers beat the Newark Bears, 9--7, today in the farewell game on the Brooklyn training grounds. Runs were scored in peculiar ways, including errors, wild pitches, passed balls, one double steal engineered by Woody English and Buddy Hassett, and another odd play on which no error was made, and neither was the run batted in.

State medicine was attacked yesterday by Dr. John Rogers of Oshkosh, Wis., president of the American Osteopathis Association, who declared that independence in practice was essential to the advancement of scientific medicine and the well-being of doctors.

In last week's statement of the country's foreign trade during February the Commerce Department lays particular stress on its very large increase in total money value. The figures amply bear this out.

Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia joined yesterday in paying tribute to the memory of Henry Moskowitz, New York civic leader and for many years political associate of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, at exercises at Town Hall. Mr. Smith also was present, but he did not speak.

After a two-year survey directed to the improvement of the nation's tax system, the Twentieth Century Fund made public yesterday as its major recommendation the extension of Federal and State income taxes to lower levels.

WASHINGTON, April 4.--The Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore, builder of the China Clipper, pioneer transpacific passenger plane, has completed plans for a huge flying ship for transatlantic service between New York and the Continent, the Bureau of Air Commerce announced today.

The annual report of Stone Webster, Inc., for 1936, issued today, shows a consolidated net income, after operating expenses, taxes, interest and other charges, of $1,772,937, equal to 84 cents a share on the 2,104,391 shares of capital stock outstanding at the end of the year.

British financial opinion is reported as being in favor of the continuation of cheap money and its effect on commodity prices. The fiscal year's revenue figures, while failing to meet the more sanguine expectations, are satisfactory.
Heavyweight Champion James J. Braddock almost tied up Loop traffic today when he took off for a north woods camp to hike himself into condition for his title bout against Joe Louis here June 22.

Mrs. Grace Ellery Channing-Stetson, poet and essayist, died on Saturday at her home, 520 East Seventy-seventh Street, after a short illness. She was 74 years old. Mrs. Channing-Stetson was born in Providence, R. I., the daughter of Dr. William Francis Channing and Mary Jane Tarr Channing.

Poisoned food caused the death of a schoolboy in Northeast Philadelphia today and the illness of four other members of the same family. Walter Barron, 14 years old, died in Northeastern Hospital this afternoon, a few hours after eating Sunday breakfast prepared by his mother, Mrs. Anna Barron, 36.

An unidentified woman, about 45 years old, died in Harlem Hospital late yesterday afternoon of injuries she received Saturday night when she was struck by a southbound Third Avenue trolley car at Broadway and 116th Street. The car, according to police, was operated by Thomas Keons of 1,789 Tenth Avenue.
Title to twenty-three properties in the metropolitan area has been given to purchasers by the State Department of Insurance, Louis H. Pink, superintendent, announced yesterday.

Rolling a score of 2,975, the Prager Beer quintet of Chicago won a place among the leaders in the American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory last night. The Windy City keglers, with games of 1,009, 1,006 and 960, went into third position in the five-man competition.

Random impressions gathered on the opening day of the trout season: The first anglers sighted shortly after,7 A. M. at Crestwood, fishing the Bronx River. ... Another at White Plains the same stream. Further on, at the Kensico Reservoir, a nimble angler balancing himself on a rock close to shore.

Members of the ladies and junior auxiliaries of Columbus Hospital have arranged a primavera entertainment for the night of May 1 at the Plaza to raise funds for the hospital. Honorary patrons and patronesses of the benefit include the Italian Ambassador, Fulvio Suvich, and Mrs. Suvich;

The colonial exhibition here opened today with the declaration that "there is no longer a German colonial problem. There is simply the righteous demand of the German nation that its colonies be returned."

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals announced yesterday the winners in the poster contest it recently conducted in the Roman Catholic high schools of the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn.

Bishop William T. Manning confirmed fourty-four persons yesterday morning in St. Agnes's Chapel on Ninety-second Street near Columbus Avenue, where he formerly was vicar and rector of Trinity Parish. "The chief thing in your confirmation is not something you do, but something that God does for you," Bishop Manning told the group.

OLIVER ST. JOHN GOGARTY'S "As I Was Going Down Sackville Street" (Reynal Hitchcock, $3.50) is the book of a Dublin wit and, appropriately, a whirl of dissolving views, of cut-backs and facts and fancies, a story of poets and pretty women, bombs and bullets, ghosts and pubs, hospitals and politicians.

The Federal Child Labor Act of 1916, which the Supreme Court held unconstitutional in a five-to-four decision on June 3, 1918, will be reintroduced, in somewhat modified form, in the Senate tomorrow by Senator E. C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado.

A requiem mass for Emperor Karl at St. Stephen's Cathedral today was attended by 5,000 persons, including Archdukes Anton and Eugene, Prince Max of Hohenburg, Baron Mirbach, head of the so-called Black and Yellow legitimists and officials of the Fatherland Front.

First of this week's four new entertainments is "Bet Your Life," dropping in tonight at the John Golden Theatre. It is a farce comedy by Fritz Blocki and Willie Howard (but without Mr. Howard in the cast), and the title is practically the story;
Minto Cato, Negro soprano, supervisor of the WPA Federal Music Project's opera school in Harlem, has been engaged to sing the title role of "Alda" at the Hippodrome on April 16.

Scheduled curtailment of commuter train service on three branches of the Erie Railroad, serving Northern New Jersey and Rockland County in New York State, brought protests yesterday from Mayors and civic groups in the towns affected.

Wheat prices the world over are the highest in years, with close adjustments of supplies to demand and traders in leading markets extremely nervous as to how high prices will go, especially if there should be serious damage to the growing crops in the countries that produce surpluses.
Eight persons were missing tonight aboard a giant Douglas DC-3 plane bound for Kansas City and New York, unreported since it left Union Air Terminal at 10 A. M. yesterday.

The Dartmouth Outing Club took all the honors today in the Eastern slalom championship race, run on Mount Washington under near-perfect conditions. Waiter Prager, Dartmouth Winter sports coach, took the open championship, covering the 3 1/2-mile course in 6 minutes 49-10 seconds,
Peter Garino was the major winner at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He began his good work by taking the high scratch cup at singles with 96 out of 100 targets.
Excited villagers of Saint Saens, undaunted by denial of reports that the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson would wed there, began a polish-up campaign today, just in case.

R. M. Lindley an insurance man of Newark, N. J., foiled a hold-up man who had hidden in the rear seat of his automobile tonight by turning the machine across a busy street and causing a traffic jam. The robber, startled, opened a door and fled.

Last week's outstanding incidents on the markets were, first, resumption of the decline in United States bonds and next, the President's public statement that production and prices in the "durable goods industries" had risen too fast, and that government purchases of such goods must be reduced.

Moulay Hafid, former Sultan of Morocco, died today at his villa in Enghien-lesBains, at the age of 61. He had been suffering from arteriosclerosis. With him were the Moroccan envoy, the director of the Moslem Institute and the Iman of the Paris Mosque.

Officials of the Near East Foundation, 2 West Forty-sixth Street, announced yesterday that King George II of Greece had conferred the Order of the Redeemer on Dr. W. E. Doughty of Roslyn, L. I., field worker for the foundation, in recognition of his twenty-five years of service to the Greek people.
The New York Rangers, having swept everything in their path, entrained for home tonight to await the call that will send them into battle again.
The Marshall Chess Club took a 3 1/2 to 1 1/2 lead over the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday in the final match of the annual series for the Metropolitan League championship.

Diplomats here said today they had reecived reports that an Italian general named Bergozzoli had committed suicide at Salamanca after receipt of a letter from Rome condemning him for the defeat of Italian troops on the Guadalajara front.

The annual report of the Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsidiaries for 1936, which will be mailed today to stockholders, shows a consolidated net income of $8,932,769, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $3.88 a share on the common stock outstanding at the end of the year.

The German wholesale price index on March 24 was 106.1, against 106.2 the week before. In the last two months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index ranged between 105.8 on Feb. 24 and 105.2 in the first week of January.
Banford B. Langill, Thomas E. King, Charles J. Cullen and Edward F. Newell announce the formation, with themselves as partners, of a new Chicago investment firm to be known as Langill Co.

William E. (Biil) Daughtrey of Suffolk, a star athlete at HampdenSydney College in the early Nineteen Thirties, was stabbed to death on the Portsmouth-Norfolk ferry tonight by a man who, Police Captain James Talbot said, believed Daughtrey and his party were laughing at him.

The movement of capital into the United States continued in the last three months of 1936, bringing the total for 1935 and 1936 to $2,606,749,000, according to an analysis reported today by the Treasury Department. For the twenty-one months through Sept. 30, 1936, the figures for which were published previously, the total was $2,281,650,000, leaving $325,099,000 for the last three months of 1936.

Theodore D. Gottlieb, Newark attorney, who has amassed a quantity of documentary evidence that the designer of the American flag was Francis Hopkinson of New Jersey, not Betsy Ross of Philadelphia, is preparing to demolish the Ross "myth" once and for all, he hopes.

Take it from the New York State Employment Service, the jobs have begun to look for the men. Webster W. Eaton, manager of the Elmira office of the service, said today that "times have changed," and that "we can't find enough employable people to fill the openings we have."

Alexander Thiede, conductor of the WPA Commonwealth Symphony Orchestra of Boston, was guest leader of the Federal Symphony Orchestra at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. His program contained three American works, one of which was new to New York.
AS I WAS GOING DOWN SACKVILLE STREET: A PHANTASY IN FACT, by Oliver St. John Gogarty. (Reynal Hitchcock, $3.50.) Memoirs and commentary on the current Irish scene.

Reuben Fine of New York tonight won his adjourned game with P. S. Milner-Barry of London from the fourth round of the international masters' tournament in the Easter Chess Congress of the Kent County Chess Association.
The Uruguayan driver, Bazet Cantoni, today won the first stage of the automobile race from Montevideo to Rio de Janeiro, a distance of 3,200 kilometers, or about 1,920 miles.

Candidates for Manhattan's varsity football team will report to Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan today for the opening drill of a threeweek session of Spring practice. A turnout of approximately forty players, the majority of whom are veterans, is expected.
Three Czechslovak round-the-world fliers received hospital treatment for cut laces tonight after they had made a forced landing in Riis Park, on the northwest side of the city.

The French Rugby Club scored the most surprising upset of the current season with a well-earned 12-3 triumph over the previously unbeaten and unscored on New York Rugby Club at Randalls Island yesterday.

The resignation of Gordon G. Sikes, '16, as head rowing coach to take effect at the conclusion of the current season, was announced tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the Princeton University Council on Athletics.

Limited medical facilities have made it necessary for relief officials in up-State rural districts to spend twice as much proportionately on medical care for home relief recipients as have city authorities, Dr. H. Jackson Davis, medical director of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, disclosed, yesterday in his annual report.

The first step in the final stage of our survey flight to explore a new air route over the Pacific between the United States and Australia is now completed. Our arrival here at dusk yesterday from Auckland, New Zealand, was like ,the return to a group of old acquaintances and familiar scenes.
Organizers of the Committee for Indetrial Organization were gathered in Texas tonight prepared to start tomorrow a drive to unionize the oil field, pipe line and refinery workers of the State.
New maximum rates for suicide and automobile fatalities in the State were noted in February, Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of vital statistics of the State Department of Health, reported today.

Rear Admiral A. W. Marshall, commandant of the Fifteenth Naval District, announced today that a jail sentence of five years has been imposed on Edward W. Eaton Jr., a Negro messman on the U. S. S. Wright, for manslaughter.

ALBANY, April 4.--The triumph of the Republicans in the special election in the Third Assembly District of Onondaga County by which a constitutional majority was restored to them in the lower house gives the party a new chance to gather political ammunition for use against the Democrats in the election of Assemblymen and delegates to the 1938 constitutional convention this Autumn.

Limited medical facilities have made it necessary for relief officials in up-State rural districts to spend twice as much proportionately on medical care for home relief recipients as have city authorities, Dr. H. Jackson Davis, medical director of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, disclosed, yesterday in his annual report.

The first step in the final stage of our survey flight to explore a new air route over the Pacific between the United States and Australia is now completed. Our arrival here at dusk yesterday from Auckland, New Zealand, was like ,the return to a group of old acquaintances and familiar scenes.
Organizers of the Committee for Indetrial Organization were gathered in Texas tonight prepared to start tomorrow a drive to unionize the oil field, pipe line and refinery workers of the State.
New maximum rates for suicide and automobile fatalities in the State were noted in February, Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of vital statistics of the State Department of Health, reported today.

Rear Admiral A. W. Marshall, commandant of the Fifteenth Naval District, announced today that a jail sentence of five years has been imposed on Edward W. Eaton Jr., a Negro messman on the U. S. S. Wright, for manslaughter.

ALBANY, April 4.--The triumph of the Republicans in the special election in the Third Assembly District of Onondaga County by which a constitutional majority was restored to them in the lower house gives the party a new chance to gather political ammunition for use against the Democrats in the election of Assemblymen and delegates to the 1938 constitutional convention this Autumn.
The enactment of a strong, adequate and effective anti-lynching law by the present Congress was advocated yesterday at the third annual Catholic Interracial Conference held in the Woolworth Building.

The activities of the 214 agencies affiliated with Catholic Charities of the New York Archdiocese will be discussed on Saturday at a conference at the Commodore Hotel. More than 1,600 representatives of these agencies will be present.
Lights flickered feebly and went out, electric trains and street cars coasted to a stop and elevators ceased to run in the Philadelphia tri-State region at 3:23 A. M. today.

Sixty-three uniformed cadets of the Catholic Chapel Choir and Acolyte Squad of the United States Military Academy participated yesterday morning for the third successive year at high mass in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street and Broadway.

Hans Goebel, 25-year-old waiter, an alien illegally in this country, was being held at Ellis Island yesterday by immigration authorities for deportation to Germany. His case has been taken up by the Committee for the Protection of Foreign Born, 100 Fifth Avenue,

The closest battle ever waged in the Midwest golf tournament today brought the title to a Peoria (III.) salesman, Gus Moreland, who was forced to play a fifty-fifth hole before proving the master of Don Armstrong of Aurora, Ill.

The transit commission reported yesterday that. 286,975,746 passengers were carried into and out of the city by railroads and ferries in 1936. The total represented a gain of 15,388,451, or 5.7 per cent over the 1935 traffic.

" Unrestrained attacks" on the Supreme Court by President Roosevelt and his followers are responsible "in no small measure" for the illegal sit-down strikes and other manifestations of growing disregard for law in the United States, Senator Burke of Nebraska said this afternoon in an address at the Old South Meeting House Forum.

Final selection of the Brooklyn College varsity baseball team, which will open its drive against St. Peter's College at Jersey City on Wednesday, will be made by Coach Arthur Musicant at the conclusion of practice at the Oakland Field this afternoon.

The decision of the Federal Reserve authorities to make open market purchases of United States Government securities is a partial retreat from their recent policy of reducing the surplus reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, in the view of. bankers who could be reached last night for comment on the plan.

Mrs. Earle Perry Charlton entertained today with luncheon and contract at Qui Si Sana for Mrs. Herbert E. Gale, who will soon depart for Boston. Other guests included Mrs. Nathan D. Bill, Mrs. Frank-B. McQuesten, Mrs. Chester Milton Williams, Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Mrs. Zenas Sears, Mrs. Frank Osgood Butler, Mrs. James H. Kennedy, Mrs. J.
