Edson Andrews, Miss Margaret Crowley, Miss Ruth Talbott, Miss Dorothy Nagle and Miss Emilie Leming.

Dr. Ernest Fahnestock, 60 years old, an honorary police surgeon and the donor of park lands to the State, was killed by a bullet wound in the head some time between 6 and 6:30 o'clock last night in his home at 954 Fifth Avenue.

Colonel Francois de la Rocque, Deputy Jean Yarnegaray and three other members of the French Social party were indicted today on a charge of "inciting to riot" and of reorganizing the outlawed Croix de Feu organization.
The Fred F. French interests, builders of Tudor City and Knickerbocker Village in Manhattan, have extended their holdings by the purchase of two properties in Jamaica, Queens.
Gordon Duncan Davie, a prominent figure in shipbuilding and shipping circles here for more than forty years, died today at the age of 64.

George Peck, who managed the world tour of Mr. and Mrs. Tom Thumb for P. T. Barnum, died Saturday at Tampa, Fla., at the age of 87. He had been associated with the Columbia Amusement Company and was a former president of the Burlesque Club.

Governor Frank Murphy put more pressure on Walter P. Chrysler and John L. Lewis today in an effort to bring about an early settlement of the strike which has closed all the Chrysler automobile plants in Detroit and kept 65,000 men out of work for four weeks.

Let's pretend that "Bet Your Life" did not open at the John Golden last evening. Let's pretend that Fritzi Block and Willie Howard, who are nominated on the program as the authors, had nothing to do with this sweepstakes aberration, and that all the actors were a couple of other fellows.
The hope of the administration to get through the remainder of the present fiscal year without borrowing "new money" appears to be blasted.

Jerome Strauss and Samuel Swenerton were among the winners in five games held in the semi-final round of the Poggenburg Memorial 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night.

The Giants and Indians began their long hike from New Orleans to New York today, but only the Tribe got away on the right foot. For in the eighth inning the National League champions, with Harry Gumbert on the mound, became entangled knee deep in difficulties, most of which were of the luckless Harry's contrivance.

The State of New Mexico has invited bids for a new issue of $2,000,000 of highway debentures, award of which will be made on April 20. The debentures will be dated May 1, 1937, and mature on May 1 and Nov. 1, 1946 to 1949. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.

Most of the editorial employes of The Long Island Daily Press, at Jamaica, went on strike yesterday. The strikers, members of The Press unit of the New York Newspaper Guild, are demanding recognition of the union, higher wages and a five-day, forty-hour week, established by contract.

Four street sweepers and four Sanitation Department truck drivers were among the 229 members of the department who applied yesterday for scholarships in New York University providing four years of training in sanitary engineering.

All big stores and a great many little ones in Paris closed today because of the application of the forty-hour week, and instead of showing its usual Monday animation the city gave the appearance of continuing a somewhat gloomy Sunday.

With the arrival in the city yesterday of the pony. string and some of the players from the West, the climax of the indoor polo. season, the East-West matches, which start tomorrow at Squadron A Armory, came closer.

More than 250 persons attended a testimonial dinner to the Rev. Adrian Buisson, pastor of Our Lady of Esperanza Catholic Church, 624 West 156th Street, last night at the Hotel Biltmore. The dinner marked the fiftieth anniversary of Father Buisson's ordination to the priesthood and the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Our Lady of Esperanza.

Veterans from Chicago mage the twenty-seventh session of kegling their own yesterday as they caused major changes in the standings for the various divisions in the American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

President Roosevelt asked Congress today to enact legislation making permanent the Civilian Conservation Corps, and to fix the maximum enlistment at 300,000 young men and war veterans, 10,000 Indians and 5,000 enrollees in territorial and insular possessions. A greater number, he said, would adversely affect the financial position of the Treasury.

Miss Shirley Newkirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Warren Newkirk of Old Greenwich, will be married to John Hamilton Tyson 2d of Milbrook, Greenwich, on April 27 in the First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, by the Rev. Alden S. Mosshammer. A small reception at the bride's home will follow the ceremony.

Paul V. McGinnis, steeplechase rider, died suddenly here yesterday. He complained of having an earache and died a few hours after being admitted to a hospital. His age was 25. Surviving are his widow, his mother and a brother and sister.

Several East Side houses and a midtown business building figured in the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday. Some of the properties sold had been held in one ownership for many years. In the East Bronx a large apartment building also changed hands.

Bids on two offerings of $50,000,000 each in Treasury bills opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today showed that the 72-day issue was oversubscribed slightly, while there was a considerably larger oversubscription for the 273-day bills.

Forfeiting 60 points because of scratches, which included three penalties that cost him 45 points, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia suffered his second setback in the world's pocket billiard champion ship last night at Ponzi's Academy.

Manuel Quiroga, the Spanish violinist, who has appeared here this season with the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra and the Beethoven Association, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night.

Noisier than ever, the Yankee championship caravan boomed deeper into the recesses of the Lone Star State today, feasting on Texas League pitching. Under a seventeen-hit shower that included five home runs the McCarthy men buried the Galveston Bucs before 2,300, 13 to 2, lengthening their winning streak to nine straight and boosting their total for the exhibition swing to sixteen out of nineteen.

Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican lightweight sensation, scored the most important victory of his American invasion when he defeated Lou Ambers, holder of the world 135-pound championship, in a tenround bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

Mrs. M. Buckner Royall gave a supper dance last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Dorothy Freeman, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Woolsey Freeman of Wave Hill, ltiverdale-on-Hudson.

John M. Davis and Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bowden gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mr. Davis's daughter, Miss Mildred Davis, and John Bradley Gates, who will be married today in St. James's Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.
A document filed here today disclosed that the German Government has agreed to pay $22,474,736 on claims growing largely out of war-time explosions at Black Tom and Kingsland, N. J.
Removal of the Trust Company of Northern Westchester as a trustee in a $99,000 mortgage rehabilitation case was asked today by Miss Marie Mertin, owner of a $1,000 certificate in the mortgage.

Eighty Russian pursuit planes, some similar to the single-seaters now in use by the United States Army, are one of the chief reasons for the Spanish Loyalists' recent successful offensives on the Cordoba and Guadalajara fronts, it was learned from reliable sources here today.

Changes shortening the coronation service by a full hour were announced today. The Westminster Abbey ceremony will take two hours, as compared with three at the coronation of King George V in 1911. No sermon will be delivered.

A few hours after their marriage in New York, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Dudley Nolan of that city were killed tonight near South Langhorne in a highway collision involving two automobiles and a motor truck.

Professor Leopold Alas, rector of the University of Oviedo, has been executed at Oviedo, according to government information. He was accused principally of having been a Left political leader in the past.

Private and church educational institutions can ill afford any tampering with the United States Supreme Court, Dr. George B. Cutten,' president of Colgate University, 4 said last night at the annual dinner of the Colgate University Alumni Association at the Hotel Commodore.

Soaring leather prices, created by a shortage of skins resulting from the use of the material abroad for army shoes and gas masks, greeted shoe manufacturers and retailers, who attended the official showing of leather for Fall, opened yesterday by the Tanners Council of America, in conjunction with the style forecast conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

General Hugh S. Johnson, former head of the NRA, has been engaged as adviser for the silk textile printing industry, it was announced here today by Samuel Neslin, president of the Textile Printers Guild, and William Alexander, spokesman for a group of larger printing firms known to the industry as Group A. General Johnson's duties will be to recommend a method of eliminating unfair trade practices.

Making his first ring appearance since his defeat at the hands of Jimmy McLarnin last Fall, Tony Canzoneri, former world's lightweight champion, scored an impressive technical knockout victory over Georgie Levy of Trenton in the seventh round of their scheduled ten-rounder last night at the Laurel Gardens.

More than 100 clergymen and laymen of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island attended the monthly luncheon yesterday of the Long Island - Clerical League, a diocesan organization for ministers of the denomination, to pay a farewell tribute to the Right Rev. Frank W. Creighton, Suffragan Bishop, who will leave this month to become Bishop Coadjutor of the Diocese of Michigan.
When a dashing Londoner named Edward Windsor registered at a Paris de luxe hotel, the management congratulated themselves on having the former British monarch as their guest.

Henry Ohl Jr., president of the Wisconsin State Federation of Labor, resigned today from the Socialist party, of which he had been a member forty years. Mr. Ohl pointed out in a 1,000word letter to Socialist party leaders that he was resigning in his personal capacity and not as president of the State federation.

Frank F. Sister, chairman of the board, and formerly for twenty years president and treasurer of the Q. C. Company, railway supplies, 90 West Street, Manhattan, died yesterday at his home, 567 Third Street, Brooklyn, after a two months illness, at the age of 64. He left a widow, Julia B. Kister; two daughters, Mrs. Bernice Devin and Mrs. Maryon Byrnes, and a son, Frank F. Kister Jr.

Assemblyman Moffat said today that he had amended his bill prohibiting sale in New York State of products made by child labor, lowering the age limit from 18 to 16 to conform with the Wheeler bill in Congress instead of the Bacon bill.

John A. Moore, Harvard, '38, Whose home is in Clayton, Mo., captured the lead in the annual Easter tournament for the individual championship of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

Abington Electric Company of Philadelphia, subsidiary of Republic Service Corporation, a registered holding company, filed an application with the SEC today under the Holding Company Act for exemption of the issue of a $590,000 five-year 5 per cent promissory note dated March 8, 1937.

The proposal to deport aliens as one way of curbing unemployment was criticized as unfair yesterday at a meeting of the National Committee on Naturalization and Citizenship. About 150 women attended an all-day meeting of the committee under the auspices of the National Council of Jewish Women at the Essex House.
Whopper, who set a track record in the Hialeah Inaugural, is top weight with 126 pounds, for the Paumonok Handicap, opening day feature of the metropolitan racing season at Jamaica on April 15.
Senator John J. McNaboe was the center of a sharp debate tonight in which he attempted to resign as chairman of the Senate Civil Service Committee.

Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page, who won the North and South title at Pinehurst last week, gained a fourstroke margin over her nearest competitors in today's eighteen-hole round of the annual thirty-six-hole Mid-South medal play tourney for women. The second eighteen holes will be played tomorrow.

The estimated cost of building work for which plans were filed in Queens last month totaled $10,623,975, about three times the total for the same month last year, Building Commissioner Frank C. Keller reported yesterday.
Van Norman Machine Tool Company common stock, $5 par value, and Weisbaum Brothers-Brower Company capital stock, $1 par value stock, have been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange.

General business in Panama in March was at the highest level since the visit of the United States fleet about a year ago, according to a report of the Division of Regional Information of the Department of Commerce. made public today.

Fred Perry gained his fourth victory in five starts against Big Bill Tilden tonight, 3--6, 6--2, 8--6, 6--3, before 5,000. The British star was a bit wild at first, but he regained control early in the second set.

IT is a rank injustice that the name of Ralph Bates is not as well known as is that of Charles Morgan or J. B. Priestley or even Margaret Mitchell. I am not trying to compare Mr. Bates with these authors; such comparisons are generally inexact and of no particular value.

Sir William J. Berry, who was Director of Naval Construction at the Admiralty from 1924 to 1930, died today at the age of 72. During the World War, as assistant to Sir Eustace d'Eyncourt, he was largely concerned with the unprecedented output of naval war material, including 842 vessels ranging from eighteen battleships to eighty-three coastal motor boats.

Four of the city's most daring gang of yeggmen were found guilty in Judge Cornelius F. Collins's part of General Sessions late yesterday afternoon of attempting to loot a safe of nearly $50,000 in the early morning of last Jan. 31 in the office of Gall Lembke, Inc., meteorological instrument dealers, on the ground floor of 7 East Fortyeighth Street.

THE only thing the Rangers have lost so far in four play-off games is M'sieu Lestairre Patrick's voice. He wore out his vocal equipment cheering his young players and shouting instructions as they went weaving down the rink to victory. M'sieu Lestairre is now speaking in hoarse whispers.
In sympathy with a rise in the outside markets, new crop deliveries on the Cotton Exchange advanced into new high ground yesterday under a general improvement of about $1 a bale.

Renewed strike difficulties caused automobile production to decline last week when an increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index slumped to 85.1 from 93.3 (revised). It was 104.7 for the week ended April 4, 1936.

The Senate, by a vote of 48 to 36, refused this afternoon to approve an amendment to the Guffey-Vinson Coal Bill declaring it to be the sense of Congress that sit-down strikes are "illegal and contrary to sound public policy." Passage of the bituminous coal control measure followed within an hour.

Workers' delegates from eight nations to the World Textile Conference today favored establishment of the forty-hour week in textiles, and advocated having such a proposal carried to the June meeting of the International Labor Organization and ratified there for submission to the governments by I. L. O. members.

Stockholders of the Phoenix Securities Corporation at their annual meeting on April 21 will be asked to approve recommendations of the directors for the extension for three and a half years of the profit-sharing employment arrangements with Wallace Groves, who recently was named chairman, and with Walter S. Mack Jr., who was elected president.

In the outdoor freedom of the Northern Wisconsin woods, James J. Braddock, world's heavyweight champion, settled down today for five weeks of roughing it in preparation for the defense of his title against Joe Louis, the Brown Bomber, scheduled for Chicago June 22.

Mrs. Woodrow Wilson has come from Washington to the Biltmore. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Markey Egan of Fox Chapel, Pittsburgh, have joined Mrs. Egan's parents, Major General and Mrs. William N. Haskell, at 975 Park Avenue.

Irving M. Felt, vice president of the Adams Express Company, has been elected a director of General Realty and Utilities Corporation. Ralph T. and E. G. Dimpel have formed Ralph T. Dimpel Co., 60 Wall Tower, to deal in over-thecounter securities.

After his propeller flew off and ripped into the left wing of his plane, a pilot glided over the New Fairchild Funeral Home here this morning to a threepoint landing in a 400-foot-square field at Franklin Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

An offering to the public will not be made of Hinde Dauch Paper Company $5 convertible preferred stock, as the 36,000 shares have been sold. Holders of the company's $6 preferred stock, which is being retired, were given the privilege of exchanging their shares for the new issue.

The Spanish civil war was tried out last night as the ground for motion picture publicity. Today Madrid does not know whether to be resentful or to be amused. In any event American radio fans may be assured that one of their idols-Errol Flynnwas not wounded.

Lawrence Tibbett was re-elected president of the American Guild of Musical Artists at its second annual meeting at the Hotel Plaza yesterday afternoon. Others renamed were Richard Bonelli and Alma Gluck, vice presidents, and Frank LaForge, treasurer.

With the question of studio recognition of the Screen Actors Guild and its right to collective bargain ing still in abeyance despite the statement Sunday of the Guild's spokesman that the organization was prepared to strike to gain both points, a committee of motion picture producers meeting here yesterday granted pay increases of 10 per cent to all the other screen crafts.

Reuben Fine of New York, representing the United States in the international, masters tournament at the Easter Congress of the Kent County Chess Association, today achieved one of the most important successes of his career by defeating Dr. Alexandre Alekine of Paris, former champion of the world.

Joseph E. Davies, Ambassador to Russia, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He was accompanied by Mrs. Davies. He expects to return to his post in Moscow on June 1. He was abroad three months, ten weeks of which were spent in Russia.

The Order of the Golden Rose, a rare distinction that the Pope confers on reigning Queens as a sign of special good-will was delivered to Queen Elena of Italy today by a delegation headed by the Papal Nuncio to Italy.
After an absence of five years, Dr. Joseph Wood Krutch, literary critic and an editor of The Nation. will return to the Columbia University faculty next September, it was announced yesterday.

Henry Jayne Mills, Mayor of this village, died yesterday in the Albany Hospital. He suffered a fractured hip in a fall on the steps of the State Office Building in Albany two weeks ago. He had lived here since 1915 and was active in village politics, a director and vice president of the National Union Bank of Kinderhook.

Finding means of checking the spread of venereal diseases is the most serious health problem now facing the city, Dr. Jacob Goldberg, member of the social hygiene committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, declared yesterday at the-third annual Institute of the New York Counties Registered Nurses Association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Heavy calendars in both Senate and Assembly faced legislators upon their return to the Capitol tonight after the tenday recess.

The gasoline tax has become the largest source of State revenue in all but fifteen States, and in three of those motor-vehicle license fees are the only large item of income, and the two combined constitute the largest source of revenue in all but a few of the forty-eight States, according to a study, "Borrowing for Highways," by Dr. Edna Trull, just published by the municipal service department of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Committee for Industrial Organization was pictured today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, as directed at making the labor movement the means to realize "the consuming ambition" of John L. Lewis and the "instrumentality through which one may promote his personal or political welfare."

Three jurors were chosen at the perjury trial of Louis Luckman, which began yesterday before Justice Erskine C. Rogers in an Extraordinary Term of Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The court then directed that they be locked in a hotel for the night to "avoid public contact." The trial will be resumed today.
The Rev. James F. Farrell, organizer of the Church of the Blessed Sacrament here, was found dead today in bed in Bombay, India. He had attended the Eucharistic Congress in Manila. His age was 57.

Mayor La Guardia participated yesterday morning in the opening of the sixteenth annual week's campaign of the American Merchant Marine Library Association to obtain 50,000 books for distribution among merchant seamen, Coast Guard crews and keepers of lighthouses.

More than half of the $22,000,000 estate of Cyrus Hall McCormick, chairman of the board of the International Harvester Company, who died on June 2, 1936, is to go for illinois and Federal inheritance taxes.

Mr. and Mrs. Melville G. Steinhardt of 1,100 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Steinhardt, to E. Henry Sondheimer, son of Mrs. Henry Sondheimer of 601 West End Avenue and the late Mr. Sondheimer.

Gathered around a luncheon table yesterday instead of the old-time cracker barrel, "nine old men" of the grocery trade exchanged anecdotes of fifty to sixty years ago, when grocery-keeping was often stepping-tone to politics and "maybe a little sand went into the sugar sometimes."

" It is a terrible thing to lead a people into war," said President Wilson in his message to Congress twenty years ago. But it would have been a cowardly and dangerous thing not to lead us into war in defense of those sacred liberties which were so dearly won by the founders of the Republic.

A delegation of lobbying sit-downers estimated to number nearly 1,000 took possession of the State House here tonight with a declaration that they would remain three months unless the Legislature met their demands for enactments to aid labor, farmers and needy persons.

The Superior Electoral Tribunal took under consideration today the question whether the Sao Paulo Governor's election is lawful. The case is the outcome of the resignation of Governor Armando Salles de Oliveira, who was elected Sao Paulo's Governor by popular vote and who recently resigned to qualify himself as a Presidential candidate.

Christopher J. Dalton, confidential attendant in the Brooklyn Supreme Court and widely known of ficial in amateur athletics, died yes terday at his home, 51 Madisor Street, Brooklyn, of a heart attack He was 66 years old.

Mrs. Helen Stenger Stamps, daughter of Mrs. Arthur D. Stenger of Houston, Texas, and the late Mr. Stenger, was married yesterday to Henry R. Stern Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Stern of 115 Central Park West, in the Pillement suite of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Rev. Charles F. Divine of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church.
The address of Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, upon receiving the Woodrow Wilson Medal at the Biltmore Hotel last night follows: Mr. Chairman, ladies and gentlemen:

A movement was started in the House today to force consideration there of President Roosevelt's Court Reorganization Bill. It was sponsored by members who are impatient at the delay the measure is encountering in the Senate.

The Great Lakes Utilities Company, a registered holding company and successor to the bankrupt Great Lakes Utilities Corporation, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a declaration and amendment covering its assumption of the obligations of the predecessor company and subsidiaries, the SEC announced.

The Bellanca Aircraft Corporation said today that Air France, a French Government supervised airplane transportation company, had bought twenty airplanes costing about $800,000, now under construction at the Bellanca factory near New Castle.
The Harvard University rugby team, opening the Bermuda Rugby Week today, forced the Bermuda Athletic Association to a 3-3 tie. The score was tied, 0-0, at the half time interval.
The Works Progress Administration here was accused yesterday by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, of attempting to' cripple the completion of the city park and playground program.

Six children were burned to death today in a fire that swept the frame home of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Sweezy, one and a half miles from Port Allegany. The children ranged in age from 5 months to 13 years. Their father repeated their names and ages to Miss Ruth McNally, superintendent of the hospital where he and his wife were taken, seriously burned.

Governor Hoffman vetoed tonight the bill divesting $7,900,000 from highway funds to relief purposes. He returned the measure to the Senate without his signature, accompanying it with a lengthy message reiterating his objections to use of road money for other than highway maintenance and construction.
With the peak of the Spring renting season in the business building field approaching, brokers yesterday reported long lists of contracts for space in the midtown district and elsewhere in Manhattan.
Members of the Amherst Club, 273 Park Avenue, have been advised that the club is "hopelessly insolvent" and that they should consider liquidation or reorganization, it was learned yesterday.

While an armed robber stood guard in the lobby over the doorman and elevator operator of the 13-story apartment house at 310 East Fifty-fifth Street, near Sutton Place, two confederates held up the renting agents in their ground floor apartment-office at 1:35 P. M.

Indiana Service Corporation-For 1936: Net income after provision for retirements, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges, $107,982, which after cumulative preferred dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock was equal to 72 cents a share on the 6 per cent preferred stock.
MARCONI: THE MAN AND HIS WIRELESS, by Orrin E. Dunlap Jr. (Macmillan, $3.50). A portrait of Marconi that is also a history of radio, by the radio editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Sanford Blackinton Pomeroy, American-born artist, who passed more than fifty years in Paris, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Charles Warren Lippitt, at the age of 83. He returned to the United States last October.

Mayor La Guardia told a committee of Jewish Hospital strikers from Brooklyn yesterday that he would ask Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater to make every effort to settle the labor troubles that resulted in the recent strikes.

Prediction was made here today by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York that the Republican party would not even carry Maine and Vermont in the next election unless it is liberalized in leadership and policies.
A general upward movement in prices of both rugs and carpets began here yesterday with the announcement of price advances averaging 5 per cent by two major rug mills.

Renomination of Mayor La Guardia on the Republican ticket was opposed yesterday by the Independent Young Republicans Committee for Public Safety in Central Manhattan, which adopted a resolution calling upon the party leaders to nominate a "loyal, patriotic and non-Communist citizen" or the committee would urge Republicans to vote for the Democratic nominee for Mayor.

Dr. William Brash, a dentist, who had practiced in New York since 1908, died yesterday in City Hospital, Welfare Island, where he was taken in the morning after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage in the vestibule of 342 Madison Avenue. His age was 55. Associated with Dr. W. B. Short, he practiced at 342 Madison Avenue.

Resumption of common dividends by the United States Steel Corporation may not be far off, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the corporation, hinted to the corporation's stockholders yesterday.

Although Republicans were running ahead out-State for all offices but State Highway Commissioner in yesterday's biennial election, Democratic party leaders claimed early today that complete returns would sweep their entire ticket into office.

Alexander M. Fairlamb, assistant treasurer of the Air Reduction Company, died suddenly here yesterday at his home at the age of 61. He had just returned from a motor trip to West Point, where he had visited his son, Charles R. Fairlamb, a cadet.

Andrew E. Smith, president of the Grolier Society, publishers, 2 West Forty-fifth Street, died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 412 Cathedral Parkway, after two years of failing health. He was 64 years old.

The work of thirty-one photographers, selected from prints submitted from all parts of the nation and twelve foreign countries, are included in the Princeton University Camera Club's fifth annual photographic salon, which opened this morning.

The Queen Mary arrived yesterday from Southampton via Cherbourg with 943 passengers, under the command of Captain J. C. Townley, who is relieving Commodore Reginald V. Peel for the voyage. The liner made the passage of 3,162 miles in four days eighteen hours and thirty-six minutes, at an average speed of 27.59 knots.

A new effort to realize effective international cooperation in the control of sugar production, which, it is hoped by many governments, may point the way toward a broad field of negotiations looking to the insurance of world peace and economic stability, began today.

Holders of the Vanadium Corporation of America ten-year 5 per cent convertible debentures, due April 1, 1941, have been notified that on May 1 next the debentures will be convertible into the company's no par common stock at the rate of 26 2-3 shares of stock for each $1,000 debenture.
Commuter travel into New York showed an increase of only a trifle over 2 per cent last year compared with 1935.

After having held the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League for three years in succession, the Manhattan Chess Club surrendered its supremacy to the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, when two of the five games adjourned from the final round were decided.

" Kiki," that sturdy memento of the heyday of Lenore Ulric, is to be revived by Jesse L. Lasky as a vehicle for Lily Pons. The Belasco success was filmed in 1926 by First National and produced again in 1931 by Mary Pickford.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. McGough of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Mullin McGough, to Dr. Joseph A. Ryan of Chatham, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Ryan of Philadelphia.

Opening of the new account today in the stock markets was marked by a cheerful tendency, although there were only few substantial gains. Gilt-edged issues were firm, but the foreign loan list lacked feature.

O. P. Robinson, works manager of the Electric Boat Company's Groton, Conn., plant, told a House labor subcommittee today that ejection of sit-down strikers from the factory recently was undertaken partly to protect confidential navy submarine plans.
The old Grand Atlantic Hotel was destroyed today by fire which spread to two adjoining buildings and for a time threatened an entire block.

George M. Lott Jr., former member of the American Davis Cup team and now on tour with Fred Perry and Ellsworth Vines, has been engaged to work with the United States team in preparation for the anticipated match with Australia at Forest Hills May 29, 30 and 31.

Mrs. Clara Louise Westinghouse of New York, widow of Henry Herman Westinghouse, was married here today to John Franklin Miller of Pittsburgh, in the First Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. George E. White.
This morning's Loyalist bombardment of Ceuta, Spanish Morocco, it is now known, was the severest the Rebel stronghold has suffered since the civil war commenced.

Our Albany correspondent reports the curious fact that "Republican extremists" in the Legislature have let the strong wine of "victory" go to their heads. A Republican district in the Onondaga reservation showed itself Republican again last week and restored to the Republicans their "constitutional majority" in the Assembly.
A cocktail party was given at the yard today by Mr. and Mrs. Fay Ingalls in honor of the Harvard Hasty Pudding Club members before their performance of "Come Across" in the Homestead Theatre.

In announcing, through its "open market committee," that Federal Reserve Banks are prepared to purchase United States Government bonds in the open market, the Reserve Board stated that it had in mind maintenance of "orderly conditions in the money market" and "orderly readjustment of "member banks to the increased re"serve requirements, effective May 1."

For improvement with a sevenroom dwelling, a two and one-half acre site in the Groton Farms section, between Croton Falls and North Salem, has been purchased by Mme. Tamara Daykarhanova, Russian actress and make-up specialist.
Reflecting the improvement in general business conditions, the earnings of department stores are substantially higher than those of the previous year.

Mrs. Dwight V. Monroe, mother of Lucy Monroe, opera and radio singer, and herself a musical comedy star twenty-five years ago, committed suicide by gas yesterday morning in her apartment at 310 West End Avenue after writing a rambling, three-page note in which she said that her daughter had "forsaken" her.

Into the wide open spaces on the thirty-third floor of the Squibb Building, thirty-nine American "abstract artists" have ventured, each of them bringing examples of hiss own special ingenuity, each arguing in some degree his endowment as a raconteur of tales from over yonder on the Rive Gauche that have begun to assume, by this time, a sly patina of age.

Ochandiano, a key town on the Basque front in Spain, has fallen to the Insurgents after one of the bitterest engagements of the civil war. General Emilio Mola's Fourth Army, which received large reinforcements during the week-end, has thus broken for the first time into the province of Vizcaya.

Once more the Supreme Court's decisions on the Wagner National Labor Relations Act were postponed today while the President and Congress anxiously awaited the outcome and the crowd nearing the record of 12,000 a week ago was drawn to the court building.

The behavior of the market for United States Government obligations following the decision of the Federal Reserve authorities to enter the open market for purchase of those securities when deemed necessary held the center of interest yesterday in the bond market.

Refunding of the $26,936,000 outstanding bonds of Atlantic City, N. J., defaulted in February, 1933, was announced yesterday by Henry Bruere, chairman of the protective committee for holders of the bonds. Holders of more than 94 per cent of the bonds, he said, have assented to the refunding plan and it is expected that the remainder will be presented for exchange soon.

The forthcoming inquiry into charges that Leon Trotsky was guilty of treason against the Soviet Union will in no sense be an attempt to "whitewash" the Russian revolutionary leader, John Finerty, Washington (D. C.) attorney, who will act as counsel to the American Committee for the Defense of Leon Trotsky, said yesterday.

A six-story apartment house to cost $600,000 will be erected on a plot of 23,000 square feet on the north side of Sterling Place, 125 feet west of Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, by Shampan Shampan, architects, who have purchased the property.

Sales of copper were made yesterday at 15.90 cents a pound c. i. f. the European base port, or more than 1 cent below the domestic price of 17 cents. Other sales were made abroad as high as 16.375 cents. This compares with 16.375 cents on Saturday.
In English Rugby League matches played today, the Broughton Rangers gained a 17-8 decision over St. Helen. on the latter's ground, and Warrington, also playing away from home, overcame Oldham 13--5.

William Percy Lipscomb, British playwright and scenarist, and Miss Florence Taub, an American, were married here today at Caxton Hall. The couple planned to depart soon for Hollywood, where Mr. Lipscomb has engaged in motion picture writing for several years.

William Risko of the Catholic Youth Organization outpointed Joseph Lubin of the First Avenue Boys Club in the heavyweight special bout which featured the amateur boxing program at the New York Athletic Club last night.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, in a booklet to be issued today, discusses the problem of selecting in advance an investment policy to govern effectively trust funds which may be administered a generation later.

Adolf Deissmann, former theologian at the University of Berlin and known throughout the Christian world for his work for international church unity, died today at the age of 70. A leading figure in international church councils, he visited the United States several times:

Supporters of the Presidential candidacy of Eduardo Santos won a majority in the national House of Representatives and probably majorities in most of the State Legislatures, according to present returns from yesterday's elections.
Blind workers in two shops have submitted through their organization, the Blind Workers Union, demands for increased wages and better working conditions, it was learned yesterday.

The Timm Cap Company, Inc., 302 Fifth Avenue, and the Manhattan Soap Company, 441 Lexington Avenue, both of New York, have stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to stop certain unfair methods of competition, the commission announced today.

The Nassau County grand jury refused today to indict Jesse J. Ricks Jr., son of the president of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation of Plandome, L. I., who woke up last Wednesday morning with a policeman's revolver in his pocket after having been on a drinking party with Patrolman Herbert A. Taylor of the Plandome Police Department.

The administration has been exerting pressure on members of the House Agriculture Committee to reverse themselves when they meet tomorrow and restore to the Jones bill the appropriation whereby farm tenants may purchase their land.
Sir Laurence Philipps's The Hour today was made favorite at 10 to 1 for the Derby June 2 at Epsom Downs. William Woodward's Americanbred colt Perifox was second in the callover at 100 to 9.

George Washington's baseball team, city P. S. A. L. champion in 1936, opened its season with an 8to-1 victory over Bryant at the Washington Stadium yesterday. Phil Goldstein and Lefty Zografas set the Queens nine down with two safeties.
Passers-by in one of Copenhagen's busiest streets were alarmed today when they saw King Christian's horse suddenly rear and fall, pinioning the monarch's leg underneath.

The profit-and-loss deficit of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway rose from $26,536,711 to $41,470,211 in 1936, according to the annual report issued yesterday. This increase resulted largely from the net loss of $13,118,589 incurred by the company last year, which total was reported previously. The net loss in 1935 was $15,024,425.

Miss Eloise Wentworth Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Loring Lane of 895 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Edwin Willis Hicks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hicks of Westbury, L. I., which will take place on the night of April 17 in the Clinton Avenue (Brooklyn) Community Church.
Business failures in the United States totaled 185 for the week ended April 1, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 189 the week before and 221 a year ago.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at his home in Searsport, Me., of Captain Charles M. Nichols, who had commanded many vessels of the American Hawaiian Steamship Company before his retirement in 1916. He was born in Searsport eighty-six years ago.

The small, independent milk dealers continued their price war yesterday. Milk was sold as low as 5 cents a quart in stores on the lower East Side, in the Bronx and in Brooklyn. The advertised brands were sold for 11 cents a quart.

Paddy, the German shepherd dog who caused the accidental death of his master, Patrolman Patrick Conroy, on Sunday afternoon, was killed by the S. P. C. A. yesterday. Relatives of the patrolman requested that the dog be destroyed.

Picturesque wide brims, opencrown effects, poke-bonnet tilts, contrasting grosgrain or belting ribbon trimmings and off-the-face lines will characterize the new hats for late Spring and Summer selling, according to the collection of fortyeight new models displayed by the MillineryCreators Guild at a cocktail party held yesterday afternoon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

A banking group headed by Cassatt Co., Inc., and including A. G. Becker Co., Inc.; Lawrence Stern Co., Inc., and Stern Brothers Co., Inc., will offer today 126,000 shares of Western Auto Supply Company $10-par value common stock at $28.75 a share.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would like to see extensive development of one and two-family houses outside of Manhattan when he spoke at exercises in City Hall marking the third anniversary of the formation of the Mayor's Committee for the Relief of Home Owners.

Playing by invitation, thirty-six of the country's leading bridge experts started play yesterday afternoon at the Park Central Hotel for the national masters' individual championship under the auspices of the American Bridge League.

Trailing two games to one, Rowland Dufton, New York A. C. professional, rallied to beat Leo T. Collins, pro from the Harmonie Club, in a thrilling quarter-final round match of the world's open squash tennis tournament at the Hotel Shelton last night. The scorewas 15--10, 10--15, 13--15, 15--10, 15--5.

Dr. Eleanor Bridge Kilham, formerly of New York, who had been honored with the French medal of honor for services in France during the World War, died here today at her home after a long illness at the age of 80.

All six seeded handball players advanced as play in the annual men's senior national A. A. U. 4wall, hard-ball championship got under way last night on the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. courts. Arthur M. Anderson, defending titleholder of the home club, went ahead when Patrick Tarmey of Boston defaulted.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today it had bought 8,345,000 dozens of eggs100,140,000 in 278,188 cases-at a cost of more than $2,000,000 through a surplus purchase program intended to prevent a decline in Winter farm egg prices.

A new program calling for expenditures of $1,750,000 a year and designed to harness the "Black Blizzards" rising out of the ever-expanding "dust bowl," leaving ruined lands and impaired health in their wake, was announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

The principal foreign exchanges continued yesterday to rise against the dollar. The pound sterling went to $4.90 13-16, the highest price since Jan. 26, and closed at $4.90 11-16, up 11-16 cent net from Saturday's final price.

Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Senate and Assembly tonight urging the passage of a new minimum wage bill, drafted after week-end conferences between the Governor and individuals and groups interested in labor and social security legislation.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Brig. Gen. Charles D. Herron to be major general to succeed the late Major Gen. Henry W. Butner. General Herron at present commands the Sixth Corps Area, Chicago.

Today was the first open date the Dodgers have had since the exhibition schedule opened on March 20, and Burleigh Grimes had planned a twelve-inning practice game to give four of his pitchers a good workout. But last night it rained.

Justice McReynolds departed today from his dissenting, written opinion in a District of Columbia case to repeat in a sarcastic tone some words used by Justice Stone last year in dissenting in the New York Minimum Wage case.

Little Egypt, the dancer who entertained the crowds at the Chicago World's Fair of 1893 as Sally Rand did forty years later at the Century of Progress Exposition, died today in the Cook County Hospital. She was 65 years old.
Speaking at the annual meeting yesterday of the Home Insurance Company, Wilfred Kurth, president, told the shareholders that the concerns was not adding now to its holdings of common stock.

Officers and attorneys of the Colombian Steamship Company of New York conferred with the Maritime Commission today concerning adjustment of the company's ocean mail contract as required by the new Merchant Marine Act.

Princeton University's baseball team unlimbered its heavy artillery today on a windswept University Field, thumped seventeen solid hits and batted around in three different innings to set back Panzer College, 20 to 7, in a contest called in the eighth in the teeth of a driving rain. It was the second Nassau triumph in four starts.

The efficient service performed by Eric C. Wendelin as third secretary of embassy in Madrid and in Valencia, representing the United States in the emergency of the Spanish civil war and directing the work of promoting and safeguarding American lives and property, was rewarded today by promotion.

President Roosevelt, in a letter read yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral, praised the existence of religious. toleration in the United States and pledged himself "with all the resources at my command" to work for the achievement of permanent harmony among the various religious elements of the nation.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on March 31 shows decreases for the week of $287,000,000 in total loans and investments, $210,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $124,000,000 in deposits credited to

Twenty years after we entered the European war there impends over the Continent the threat of a new catastrophe. The tension grows and relaxes, but it is there. Americans today are earnestly studying ways and means to keep this country from being embroiled a second time in a quarrel not of our making.

All German national comrades, irrespective of origin, class or situation, have been declared "satisfaktionsfaehig"--that is, entitled to demand and give satisfaction in duel for insults to personal honor-under new regulations for student duels framed at a conference of student leaders at Oberursel near Frankfort on the Main.
Fifteen thousand new toys that will delight youngsters next Christmas morning were put on display yesterday at the American Toy Fair at the Hotel McAlpin and the Toy Center, 200 Fifth Avenue.

Fears that a Douglas transport plane, missing since Saturday with eight persons aboard, had fallen in the mountains of Eastern Arizona were strengthened tonight by a report of a forest ranger's 11-year-old son that he had heard a plane crash near Alpine, Ariz.

Funeral services for Fred Fuller Shedd, newspaper editor, who died last Friday at Pinehurst, N. C., after an operation, were held here today. Mr. Shedd, a native of New Boston, N. H., was editor of The Haverhill Evening Gazette and The Boston Herald before becoming editor-in-chief of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin in 1911.

Charles P. Grimes, assistant to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, who is here to obtain the return to New York of Alexander Pompez, policy racketeer wanted by Mr. Dewey, said today that he did not authorize any statement to the effect that Pompez would receive special consideration "to return to New York to testify."

Nearly 1,500 men and women attended a dinner to William Solomon last night at the Hotel Astor on the tenth anniversary of his election to the Tammany leadership of the Seventeenth Assembly district. The dinner was given by the Owasco Democratic Club.

Increase in loans and discounts, but sharp reductions in holdings of United States Government securities and moderate declines in deposits and total assets were shown by the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank, the two largest national banks in the country, in their statements of conditions as of March 31, issued yesterday.

The corn market again was the leader among grains on the Board of Trade here today, with the May opening as much as 4 cents a bushel higher, the maximum permitted for one day under Exchange regulations, and reaching $1.33 1/3, a new high level since 1925.

In your editorial of March 31, referring to the decision by the Supreme Court on the Minimum Wage Law, you stated that the court has ruled that "the reasonableness of the exercise of governmental powers can be determined only in the light of conditions currently prevailing."

B. Altman Co., yesterday announced the opening of a completely new linoleum section of the store's rug department. Beginning next Monday night the Silk Travelers Association, Inc., will begin a series of forums devoted to various divisions of the textile industry.

The usual concise, comprehensive and authoritative review of the baseball season of 1936 is provided by the annual Spalding Baseball Guide, which has made its appearance on the newsstands. In addition, the publication, always admired for its pictorial displays, is this year most notable for its presentation of leading players and team pictures in both major and minor leagues.

The entrance of the United States into the World War twenty years ago today will be commemorated here in various ways by patriotic and anti-war organizations.- The day has been designated by President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman as Army Day.

Reporting that retail trade in England was excellent, with the demand for American-made merchandise growing, Philip Halperin, managing director of the Houndsditch Warehouse Company, Ltd., London, arrived here yesterday on the Queen Mary with a party of four buyers to purchase $300,000 or more worth of American goods.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it had filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission, on behalf of itself and several trade groups, a brief urgihg that proposed new rail rates on automobiles which have been filed by the railroads be made effective between the Middle West and Atlantic Coast ports.

Robert Bruns, 217, Germany, was declared the winner over Ed Virag, 205, Hungary, in 31 minutes 4 seconds when the latter fell to the floor after missing a flying tackle in the feature finish wrestling bout before 2.000 persons at the New York Coliseum last night.

The impressive play of Bobby Kamrath of Austin marked today's matches in the seventh annual River Oaks tennis tournament. Kamrath turned back Bob Allen of Houston in two sets with the loss of only one game and then disposed of Max Campbell, Rice co-captain, losing only two games.
Secretary Perkins said today that the sitdown strike was "not a good technique, nor a useful one," and described it as "a vogue which is now passing over."

William B. O'Toole, president of the Brooklyn Audit Company, Inc., will not have to produce the company's books for the State Tax Department, which has been investigating the official conduct of his brother, Luke E. O'Toole, former principal examiner in the Brooklyn State Income Tax Bureau, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

Federal registration of labor unions was proposed in a bill introduced in the House today. It was considered the first tangible evidence of a growing sentiment in Congress which may eventually result in the regulation of labor organizations and compulsory arbitration of trades disputes.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ruth Eleanor Garthwaite Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ellsworth Crane of this city, to John Ballantine Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Young, also of Newark.

Activity in the women's wear lines at wholesale here yesterday was rather spotty, reflecting the similar condition which prevailed in retail trade in many sections last week. There was fair activity in women's coats, with fill-ins and specials outstanding.
Friends of James J. Dooling expressed the belief yesterday that no meeting of the Tammany executive committee would be held until after the leader's return from Florida.

Changes in the city's school administration that would strip the Board of Superintendents of many of its powers and centralize more authority in the Superintendent of Schools were recommended yesterday by the law committee of the Board of Education.

The arrival here today of President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia and Mrs. Benes on a state visit was marked by tremendous popular enthusiasm, which was reflected only formally in the official arrangements.
Twenty years ago tomorrow, at 1:18 P. M., the United States formally declared a state of war existed between this nation and Germany.

Spring football practice opened at Manhattan yesterday, a squad of forty-one candidates for the 1937 varsity eleven reporting to Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan. Twentysix veterans were in the group, which was sent through a two-hour drill on fundamentals in Van Cortlandt Park.

The Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation plans soon to reopen its plant at Holyoke, Mass., it was announced yesterday. The plant has been closed since 1922, and it is expected that between 400 and 500 persons eventually will be employed there.
The government is going into the elections on a platform of orthodox economics at home and a conciliatory policy toward China, according to official utterances yesterday evening.
Trout caught in the opening days of the current season averaged less than half a fish each for those known to have whipped New York streams, the Conservation Department said today.
Prince Chichibu, brother of the Emperor of Japan, and his consort, Princess Chichibu, with their imperial suite, left Ottawa yesterday for New York and are expected to arrive here this morning.
Syracuse University started Spring football practice today under the direction of its new varsity coaching staff, headed by Ossie Solem, formerly of the University of Iowa.

Not only did the fresh water anglers respond to the opportunity to go fishing again over the past week-end, when the trout season in New York State opened, but judging from the number who traveled out to Peconic Bay on Sunday salt water anglers were equally anxious for the happy fishing days to start.
Despite the severity of Greek censorship, the Prager Tageblatt's Athens correspondent reports a series of demonstrations against the Metaxas dictatorship.

After an adventure in New York, a venerable Virginia document is going back home. It is the marriage bond of Thomas M. Randolph Jr. and Martha Jefferson, daughter of Thomas Jefferson, allegedly stolen from the archives of Albemarie County, Va.

Miss Rosemary Maloney, daughter of Mrs. Josiah Van Kirk Thompson of this city, was married here to Donald McLoughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett McLoughlin of New York, this morning in St. Paul's Cathedral.

A major event of the Spring, "Babes in Arms," will make its Broadway bow on Friday night, April 16, instead of next Tuesday evening, April 13. There are no cast changes and no particular difficulties, the Wiman office saysthey simply want a few more days to polish the show, as is the way with musical offerings.

Sliding out to sea this morning, the United States fleet started its final three-day limbering-up exercises for the Pacific war games, which will begin April 16 with departure from the San Diego-San Pedro area and extend to the far corners of the California-Alaska-Hawaii triangle.

Ed Linke, Senators' hurler, led his team to a 4-3 victory over the Cardinals today, winning his own game in the last inning. Relieving Newsom in the seventh, Linke let the Cardinals get to him for two runs and a 3-3 tie in the eighth. In the ninth, however, Linke rifled a triple to deep center, scoring Millies from first with the winning run.

New Yorkers sailing today on the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Australia for a cruise to the West Indies include Mrs. E. R. Stettinius, Mr. and Mrs. W. Herbert Davis, Mrs. Julian Strauss, Mr. and Mrs. Hat-old N. Henry, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin P. Adams, Miss Elise Bonwit, Mrs. I. D. Haines, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Braun, Mr. and Mrs. J. Everett Sparrow and Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Seaman.

The Cincinnati Reds, seeking to spread the gospel of baseball, today invited every schoolboy from 9 to 16 years of age within a radius of seventyfive miles of Cincinnati to join their Knot Hole baseball club. To join this club a boy needs to sign a pledge to be eligible for admittance to Crosley Field on twelve free days.

Sliding out to sea this morning, the United States fleet started its final three-day limbering-up exercises for the Pacific war games, which will begin April 16 with departure from the San Diego-San Pedro area and extend to the far corners of the California-Alaska-Hawaii triangle.

Ed Linke, Senators' hurler, led his team to a 4-3 victory over the Cardinals today, winning his own game in the last inning. Relieving Newsom in the seventh, Linke let the Cardinals get to him for two runs and a 3-3 tie in the eighth. In the ninth, however, Linke rifled a triple to deep center, scoring Millies from first with the winning run.

New Yorkers sailing today on the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Australia for a cruise to the West Indies include Mrs. E. R. Stettinius, Mr. and Mrs. W. Herbert Davis, Mrs. Julian Strauss, Mr. and Mrs. Hat-old N. Henry, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin P. Adams, Miss Elise Bonwit, Mrs. I. D. Haines, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Braun, Mr. and Mrs. J. Everett Sparrow and Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Seaman.

The Cincinnati Reds, seeking to spread the gospel of baseball, today invited every schoolboy from 9 to 16 years of age within a radius of seventyfive miles of Cincinnati to join their Knot Hole baseball club. To join this club a boy needs to sign a pledge to be eligible for admittance to Crosley Field on twelve free days.
In the first test within this jurisdiction, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday, by a unanimous decision, upheld the constitutionality of the Home Owners Loan Act.

Employing the expression "a voice of warning," Germany directed a protest note to the Union of South Africa today for a recent proclamation against alleged National Socialist activities in former German Southwest Africa.

Charles R. Aikman, retired police lieutenant, who was for many years assigned to the waterfront area, died yesterday at his home, 4,120 Amboy Road, Great Kills, S. I., after a brief illness. He was 73 years old.

Robert Irwin, 29-year-old sculptor, former theological student and insane asylum inmate, was being sought throughout the nation last night as the police definitely named him as the man who murdered Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter, Veronica, and their roomer, Frank Byrnes, on the night before Easter.

Howard S. Eckles, a manufacturing chemist, died at his home in Wyncote today at the age of 72. Mr. Eckles was president of H. S. Eckles Co., which he founded more than thirty years ago. Born at Mechanicsburg, he was a graduate of the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science.

New York is a pagan city, the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington, declared in an address at the annual Spring luncheon of the Board of Domestic Missions and of the Women's Board of Domestic Missions of the Reformed Church in America, held yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

William Forbes Morgan, president of the Distilled Spirits Institute and former Democratic National Treasurer, was named defendant in a $10,000 suit filed in Supreme Court yesterday by William T. Starr, a former associate in the defunct brokerage firm of Morgan, Livermore Co.

Lionel Brown has written a witty comedy in "Constant Sinner," staged at the Q Theatre tonight. He has taken for his story the familiar situation of a young wife, stricken by what she calls her husband's "impersonal behavior," who nearly burns her wings in an attempt to provoke his jealousy.

Plans were filed yesterday for a $125,000 six-story apartment house, to be erected at 50-56 Manhattan Avenue, Manhattan, and for a sixstory apartment, to cost $175,000, on the west side of Morris Avenue, 100 feet north of 167th Street, the Bronx. The list follows:

With business conditions in Australia forging ahead rapidly, advertising volume there is also making substantial gains, R. S. Maynard, president of the advertising agency bearing his name and also head of the Advertising Association of Australia, said here yesterday.

The Cleveland Stock Exchange, in the first proceeding of this character, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to delist shares of the North American Securities Company.

The new Kings County grand jury, which will delve solely into racketeering, was sworn in yesterday by Kings County Judge George W. Martin, who said that "these are serious times when business men are forced to pay protection in the orderly and proper conduct of their business."

Charles G. Macri of 25 Pilling Street, Brooklyn, died late Sunday night near Toms River, N. J., of a heart attack while traveling on a bus from this city to Washington, D. C. He was 38 years old. Mr. Macri was traffic manager for Oldetyme Distillers, makers of Green River and Three Feathers whisky, with offices in the Chanin Building.

The publication of Captain Henry Landau's complete story of German sabotage in the United States in the World War has finally been set for June. Putnam's will bring out the book under the title "The Enemy Within."

Haw Branchwilling, a white and orange pointer dog owned and handled by Fritz Sitterding Jr. of Richmond, Va., today was awarded the first trophy in the Members' DerbyStake, opening event of the annual field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America.
The Cheney Chemical Company, Cleveland, is introducing a tobaccoless "cigarette" under the name "Breathers" and will develop distribution in selected areas one by one.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that at the request of the applicants it had consented to the withdrawal of the following registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933:

The executive committee of the Central Labor Union voted this afternoon to postpone indefinitely the general strike called Saturday in sympathy with the three-weeks-old strike of truck drivers and helpers.

Pressident Roosevelt sent to Congress a message asking the establishment of a permanent Civilian Conservation Corps of 315,000 men. He also sent to the Senate nominations for promotions in the diplomatic corps and the army.

What is the greatest single asset of the police? It is the certain knowledge on the part of the criminal that the man in blue will keep coming no matter what the odds may be against him. Organization, equipment, physical condition, training, intelligent direction are all required to make an efficient force, and here we have them all.
Mrs. Mildred E. Agness, whose sitdown strike for back alimony made the news several weeks ago, lost her Supreme Court fight today to place her husband in contempt of court for nonpayment.

Steel ingot production in the United States is scheduled at 89.9 per cent of capacity this week, compared to 90.7 per cent last week, a decrease of .8 point, or .9 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Ending of a three months' feud between Governor Hoffman and Senator Winant Van Winkle, Bergen County Republican, over patronage was indicated tonight when the Governor submitted more than a score of nominations to the Senate for confirmation, including appointments to two judgeships in that county.
The State Legislature carried out its pledge tonight to pay the $25,000 reward to the persons giving information leading to the arrest of the kidnapper and slayer of the Lindbergh baby.

The amazing New York Rangers, who have thus far confounded all critics by breezing through two rounds of the National Hockey League play-offs, will start their 1937 bid for the Stanley Cup and its attendant honor, the world's hockey championship, tonight.

George T. Dunlap Jr. shot a sparkling 70 in the qualifying round of the North and South amateur golf tourney today to begin the defense of his title against 171 rivals. But his brilliant effort went for naught because a soaking rainstorm caused a postponement of

The Rev. Dr. Samuel J. Greenfield, long prominent in the Northern New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died today at his home here. His age was 80. He was field secretary of the permanent fund of the conference for eighteen years and for twenty-three years was treasurer of the board of trustees and also registrar.
Following is the text of Governor Lehman's message sent to the Legislature concerning a new Minimum Wage Bill: To the Legislature:

The Federal Reserve System's retreat from its policy of cutting down excess bank reserves, indicated by its announcement that it was prepared to purchase government securities in the open market, illustrated the conflict which monetary management inevitably faces when it seeks to reverse an expansion program.
Italy may withdraw from the twenty-sevennation accord for neutrality in the Spanish civil war on the basis of charges that France has violated the agreement, a government spokesman said tonight.

A Committee on Good-will and Peace to plan an exhibit for the New York World's Fair, 1939, has been organized, it was announced yesterday after a meeting at the offices of the fair in the Empire State Building.
Many of Henry Ford's Kansas City employes went to work today wearing union buttons on their overalls for the first time in the quarter century of the plant's operation.

While the twenty-nine Americans arrested Saturday on suspicion they were volunteers bound for Spain were still being held in jail here, examining Magistrate Signoret announced tonight that he intended to inform the United States about their arrest through the French Foreign Ministry.

An arrangement to have the State take title to the Bronx River Parkway and assume all its future maintenance obligations was disclosed today by the legislative committee of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday a net gain of telephones in service for March of 18,961, as against a net gain of 9,408 units in March, 1936.

Mrs. Henry Leroy Finch will give a reception this afternoon at her home, 46 East Seventy-fourth Street, for members of committees working toward the success of the Butterfly Ball to be held Friday night at the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge.

The Civilian Conservation Corps has been the least criticized and perhaps the most popular of all the New Deal measures. The President's proposal that it now be made into a permanent agency is therefore likely to receive a very favorable reception in Congress.

Mahlon Brewster Smith, the Erie Railroad's oldest commuter, who for seventy years had been on the payroll of the Seamen's Bank for Savings in New York, died today in his home here at the age of 89. "Retire?" he recently said with impatience, "I've never given it much thought. In a few years perhaps I'll think it over.

The second program of a series of five, for laymen, illustrating phases of motion-picture technique will be presented on Friday evening at the Pauline Edwards Theatre, Twentythird Street and Lexington Avenue, by the Film and Sprockets Society at the City College.

Students going into business were advised yesterday by Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, to quit their jobs as soon as they discovered that "the boss is a boob." Opening the tenth annual occupational conference at Columbia University, Mr. Hoving outlined a fivepoint program for the guidance of young persons in -business. The points were:
That Alexander Pompez, New York policy racketeer wanted in the Dewey rackets inquiry, would leave here within a few hours for New York appeared likely tonight.
The rather sharp decline in commodity prices this week, which is ascribed in part to heavy selling by Europe, is the subject of much conjecture in the financial community.

The 1,404 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $46,993,975,903 par value as of April 1, had a total market value of $44,115,628,645, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

The Committee for Industrial Organization union which recently attempted to invade the building and general construction field here consented yesterday to the issuance of a permanent injunction restraining it from claiming to have any sanction from the American Federation of Labor for its actions.

Mr. and Mrs. G. Harlan Miller, who passed the Winter in Paris, are expected to arrive Monday on the Normandie, and will be at the Pierre for a month before going to Whimsy Farm, their country place in Arlington, Vt.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, according to well-informed quarters, is expected to delay for some time final determination whether actual segregation of members on the floor of the Stock Exchanges is advisable and essential in carrying out its program to eliminate speculative member-trading for own account of a type which accentuates price trends, excites public participation and tends to create a disorderly market.

A directed verdict freed four defendants today from a Federal indictment charging mail fraud and conspiracy involving the closing of the Commercial National Bank of Bradford with a $1,300,000 shortage.
Passage of a bill to spend $400,000 to extend a State campaign to combat pneumonia seemed likely tonight as Governor Lehman indicated his approval.

A "jury" of twelve fashion editors and a "supreme court" of nine leading- retail executives passed judgment yesterday on the Fall and Winter shoe styles, materials and lasts in a "court of shoe style opinion," at the closing session of the semi-annual meeting of the National Shoe Retailers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Following are the texts of the addresses of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick delivered tonight under the auspices of the Emergency Peace Campaign:

Miss Natalie Couch, clerk of the State Assembly, was appointed police judge of this village today by the new Mayor, Dr. Charles Vetter. Miss Couch will be sworn in Friday when she returns from Albany. She succeeds Dr. Vetter,

A description, with partial specifications, of the Russian singleseater pursuit biplanes now being used by the Loyalists in Spain, is contained in the German publication, "Handbuch der Luftfahrt," for 1936 published by J. F. Lehmanns at Munich.

Martial law is expected to be declared in Brussels from Thursday to forestall any trouble arising over the elections next Monday. Even now the capital's streets have an aspect somewhat like that of an armed camp, with soldiers much in evidence and an increased number of policemen on patrol.

Attorney General Cummings today gave an opinion that the District of Columbia Minimum Wage Law became once more effective, without further legislative action, when the Supreme Court last week reversed its decision in the Adkins case, in which the law was found unconstitutional in 1923.

The defeat in the Senate of the Byrnes amendment condemning the sit-down strike, now renewed in Michigan, creates a situation that will be dangerously ambiguous unless Congress itself acts immediately to make it clear. The amendment declared it to be the sense of Congress that sit-down strikes are "illegal and contrary to sound public policy."

Miss Mary Nash Uihlein, daughter of Herman A. Uihlein, Milwaukee financier, was married to Robert Seymour Cunningham in this city yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Judge Paul A. Jones of Benton, Ill., sitting in the marriage court.

The Panama Pacific Line will discontinue calls at San Deigo by its westbound ships effective with the sailing of the liner California from New York on April 17, it was announced yesterday. The change will not affect schedules at Los Angeles and San Francisco.

When the Rural Electrification Administration makes its final allotments from 1936 funds within two weeks, it will have a balance of about $3,000,000, of which $467,484 will represent funds for New York State which the law requires the administration to retain for future needs. No REA loans have ever been made in New York State.

More than 1,000 Methodist women attended a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the New York Branch of the Women's Foreign Missionary Society of the Methodist Church to prepare for the seventieth anniversary, which will occur in 1939. Only one man was among the guests and he left in the middle of the program.

The number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday reached the thousand mark for the first time in five weeks. This total was also well above the figures for the pre-holiday week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Colonel and Mrs. H. Murray Jacoby gave a dinner last night at their home, 1,165 Fifth Avenue, for Sir Albion Banerji, former Prime Minister of Kashmir, India. Other guests included Mrs. Murray Whiting Ferris, Mrs. John T. H. Mitchell, Mrs. Bertram Chase Hinman,

There is an old adage in sporting circles that to be honored with gifts before a contest usually proves a jinx to the recipient, and last night at Ponzi's Academy, where the world's pocket billiard championship is in progress, Benny Allen, Kansas City (Mo.) veteran, was the unhappy victim.

The turf belief that young horses are up against it in the Spring when competing with older horses was upset today when E. K. Bryson's Louisiana flyer, Honey Cloud, won the Leonardtown Purse through deep mud.

While business failures increased in the retail division to 115 in the week ended April 1 from 107 in the previous week, the total was under that of the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

Nathaniel D. Lancaster, a director and former vice president of the New York Trap Rock Corporation of 230 Park Avenue, New York, died here yesterday at his home, Blind Brook Lodge. He was 71 years old. Born in Richmond, Va., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lancaster, Mr. Lancaster was graduated from the University of Virginia in 1886.

Mrs. Henry Howard, president of the American Merchant Marine Library Association, made public yesterday a letter from President Roosevelt in connection with the sixteenth annual Book Week the association is conducting for books to be distributed on merchant and Coast Guard ships and in lighthouses.

A definite platform for the proposed new association of dress chain apparel stores was drawn up at a meeting here yesterday of the committee of eight headed by Sidney M. Netzorg, president and treasurer of the Virginia Dare Stores, Inc. The committee was appointed last week at a meeting of representatives of thirty-four specialty dress chains doing an annual volume of business in excess of $100,000,000.

Henry H. Bacon, 58 years old, of 309 Ninety-fifth Street, Brooklyn, an inspector of the alcohol tax unit of the Internal Revenue Bureau, died suddenly at 2:30 P. M. yesterday in the offices of Ronson Products Company, Inc., at 347 Fifth Avenue.

The annual report of the Alabama Power Company, controlled by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, for 1936, which is to be mailed to stockholders today, shows a consolidated net income of $3,633,614, against $3,023,383 in 1935. Total operating revenues of the company and its subsidiaries last year were $18,712,810, against $16,794,482 in 1935.

The Irving Trust Company, as depositary, received word by cable from London yesterday that the Roan Antelope Copper.Mines, Ltd., had declared the third interim dividend with respect to the year ended on June 30 at the rate of ls 6d on each English share, less British income tax at a rate still to be determined.

Passengers leaving today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for Cherbourg and Southampton are Giovanni Martinelli, opera singer; Lord and Lady Ashburton, Sir Henry and Lady Bunbury, Sir James and Lady Calder,

Paul W. Dieter, patentee of several inventions used in railroad locomotives and cars, died early yesterday morning of a heart attack in his apartment in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street. He would have been 53 years old on April 26.

Elmer De Witt Brothers, lecturer on medical and dental jurisprudence and an attorney here since 1892, died of a heart attack today while swimming in the pool of the Hamilton Club. Born in Decatur, Ind., seventy-seven years ago, Mr. Brothers at one time was superintendent of schools at Council Grove, Kan.

With preparations completed yesterday, the stage was set at the Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, for the opening tonight of the major events of the indoor polo season, the first games of the East-West matches that decide the national championships.

A conference which opened this morning in an effort to settle the truck drivers' strike broke down tonight when the employers rejected a union proposal to call off the strike if they would recognize the union.
Princeton University's rugby team, making its first visit to Bermuda, finished on the losing end of its game with the United Services fifteen today, bowing by 6--3 in a wellplayed contest.
Apparently feeling the pinch of the shortage of raw materials, Germany has notified Brazilian importers to withdraw all present quotations and make future ones subject to confirmation.

The Chrysler automobile strike, now in its thirtieth day, was settled at 9:05 o'clock tonight by an agreement between Walter P. Chrysler and John L. Lewis on collective bargaining and related issues. The agreement was signed at 11:15 P.M.

Canadian wheat in store on April 3 was 82,365,779 bushels, compared to the revised figure of 83,780,624 the week before and 204,435,080 the year before, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Major Gen. Robert Alexander, commander of the Sixty-third Brigade in the second Battle of the Marne, told members of the Hammer Veterans Club in an Army Day speech that "neutrality cannot be maintained by protests."

A vagrant Negro youth suffering from an attack of claustrophobia or something worse in a Valley Stream (L. I.) police cell, embarked early yesterday morning on an adventure which, for the rain of bullets, a stolen automobile, screaming patrol cars, a collision and clanging ambulances, would put to shame the creators of the old-time movie thrillers.

A tract of fifty acres known as Cargain's Point, a peninsula in Boyd's Corners Reservoir, near Carmel, Putnam County, has been sold by Leland Ryder and associates to an investor. Located on the tract is a peak 1,100 feet in height. Herbert J. Gebing was the broker.
