Officials of Utica, N. Y., awarded yesterday to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation an issue of $1,000,000 tax-anticipation certificates of indebtedness, dated April 8, 1937, and due Aug. 8, 1937, at a rate of 0.73 per cent plus a premium of $19. The securities will be reoffered today at a price to yield 0.60 per cent.

The Allied Stores Corporation and subsidiaries showed a net profit of $3,406,448 after depreciation, interest, subsidiary preferred dividends, Federal taxes and $21,500 surtax on undistributed income, according to the annual report for the year ended on Jan. 31, 1937.

Louis P. de Luze, a retired civil engineer who was formerly on the staff of the New York Transit Commission, died here this morning at his home, 660 Pelham Road, where he lived with his sister, Miss Sarah F. de Luze.

American Equities Company and Subsidiaries-For 1936: Consolidated net profit, after depreciation, depletion, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes, $490 surtax on undistributed profits, subsidiary preferred dividends minority interests and other charges, $476,129.

Circuit Court Judge Wilfred H. Jayne has declared that William C. Hunt, Republican member of the State Senate from Cape May County, is not entitled to a certificate of election, and has ordered set aside the election of Nov. 3, 1936, at which Mr. Hunt was declared elected, it was learned here today.
Arthur Shaw, workers' delegate from Great Britain to the World Textile Conference, made a "friendly but frank" statement today concerning Japanese competition in the textile industry.
Two madly determined Insurgent officers were reported today to have set up a reign of terror over 1,500 slowly starving men, women and children on top of El Cabezo, a mountain in Southern Spain.

Pedro Montanez, the Puerto Rican lightweight who beat world's champion Lou Ambers in an over-theweight fight at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, is eager to get the titleholder into the ring at the class weight, Lew Burston, Montanez's manager, revealed yesterday in the office of James J. Johnston, Garden boxing promoter.

Dr. Ernest Albert Farrington, psychologist, physician and president of the Bancroft School here, a private institution for mentally retarded children, died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home here yesterday. His age was 56. Dr. Farrington was an authority on specialized education for handicapped children.

Benjamin P. Treacy, lawyer, died last night in St. Francis Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 52. Mr. Treacy was graduated from New York Law School in 1907. He was a United States Supreme Court Commissioner and a special master in chancery. He never held any public office.

Frank A. Vanderlip Jr. and a group of associates who own collectively 500 common shares are asking for proxies to be voted at the annual meeting of the Reo Motor Car Company on April 20 for the purpose of electing a majority of the directors.

Paul Keres, representing Estonia in the international masters tournament, regained the lead in the sixth round at the Grand Hotel in Cliftonville today. Sir George Thomas of London was Keres's opponent and, although the former British champion had the choice of opening and selected the Ruy Lopez, he made a poor showing and lost in 25 moves.

Western Auto Supply Company common stock, $10 par value, has been admitted to listing by the Curb Exchange. Each share of Class A and Class B common stock, no-par value, is exchangeable for three shares of the new common. The Class A common has been removed from unlisted trading.

The net earnings of the American Smelting and Refining Company in the first two months of this year were at the rate of $8.37 a share annually on the old common stock, F. H. Brownell, chairman, informed stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.
Harvard's baseball team pounded the offerings of three George Washington pitchers for sixteen hits, including seven extra base blows, to rout the Colonials. 15--3, today.

Citizens of this old town who have been riding free on the railway to neighboring Buechen since 1852 will have to pay in the future. The Reich government will pay 60,000 marks as compensation to the municipality for the suppression of the privilege.

The gold medal of the Holland Society of New York was presented last night to Dr. Frank P. Graves, New York State Commissioner of Education, at the fifty-second annual meeting of the Holland Society at the Hotel Astor.

Wright L. Gilbert, retired New York building contractor and an uncle of S. Parker Gilbert, former reparations commissioner to Germany, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was born in this town eighty-two years ago.

By a strict party vote of 76 to 74 today, the Assembly passed the bill of Assemblyman Brownell, Republican, of New York, providing for a recanvass of the vote in elections in every city direct from the voting machines.
Scores of American tourists from the world cruise ship Reliance today joined a crowd exceeding 50,000 in watching the public execution by shooting of six narcotics peddlers.

Michigan's biennial election of yesterday which party leaders on both sides had asserted would prove something of a test of the Roosevelt Court program and Governor Murphy's handling of recent labor troubles, developed races so close that those who raised the question hesitated to interpret the result.

A 184-page brief citing various reasons why the Appellate Division should set aside the conviction of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania for compulsory prostitution was served yesterday on Thomas E. Dewey. special prosecutor.

The first week of the strike of WPA technical workers ended yesterday, with WPA officials still refusing to recognize its existence. The Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians said that 2,250 were on strike, but reports to Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, showed only 239 out.

Thirty-five blind men and women employed by the Community Craft Weavers Auxiliary, a philanthropic organization, began a sit-down strike yesterday to emphasize their demand for a 100 per cent pay increase and union recognition.

Arthur M. Anderson of the home club, defending champion, progressed to the semi-final round of the men's senior national A. A. U. 4-wall hard-ball handball championship tournament at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night.

James G. McDonald, honorary chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, said tonight that neutrality legislation probably would not be a guarantee of keeping America out of conflict. He spoke before 200 persons at a meeting of the College Club of White Plains, in the auditorium of the Contemporary Club here.

The baseball teams of Columbia and New York University will meet this afternoon at Baker Field. Theodore Atkinson is scheduled to pitch for the Violet while the Lions have selected Jack Moller to do the twirling. The probable line-up:

Having adopted the catapult mothership as a basis for its proposed transatlantic air-mail line, Lufthansa took a complacent view today of the monopoly landing rights obtained in the Azores by the United States and Great Britain.

Two men were named yesterday by Rhea Whitley, chief of the Fedaral Bureau of Investigation, as those who held up the Northern Westchester Bank of Katonah, N. Y., last March 12,. escaping with ?18,402 in the second robbery of ?hat institution within a month.

The International Business Machines Corporation in January and February, this year, had the best two months in its history from the viewpoint of earnings, Thomas J. Watson, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting. Despite increased wages, material costs and taxes and without increased prices, the company also had in 1936 the largest earnings in its history, Mr. Watson added.

Jacob Omansky, in 1,033 Park Av.; John J. Kelly, in 151 E. 83d St.; Robert D. O'Callaghan, through Duff Conger, Inc., in 162 E. 80th St.; Culver, Hollyday Co., broker. Clarence D. Wimpheimer, through Pease Elliman, Inc., in 480 Park Av.; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., broker.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic W. H. Stott of Andover, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Binkerd Stott, to Lovett Chase Peters, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Peters of Amherst, Mass.

Maryland's Legislature legalized horse-race bookmaking today. The State is looking to this activity, formerly conducted under cover, to furnish $400,000 annually in tax money to help provide relief for needy persos.

Commodity futures were generally lower in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, silk, copper, tin, hides, coffee, cocoa, world sugar, cottonseed oil and wool top futures lost ground, while lead and domestic sugar futures were mixed.

New Idea, Inc., manufacturers of agricultural implements, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 68,000 shares of common stock, the proceeds of which are to be used to increase working capital and for other corporate purposes.

The Long Beach City Council passed tonight an ordinance by which the entire city waterfront will be converted into a beach park, to be operated under the jurisdiction of the council. Admission to the beach, which in the past has been free, will be granted only to persons holding season tickets, priced at $1.
Relief conditions in Jamaica, Queens, were protested yesterday by ten adults and twenty-two children from that section who picketed in City Hall Park during the noon hour.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, and Dr. Marshall S. Brown, dean of the faculties, yesterday welcomed eighteen British sociologists, many of whom were visiting New York for the first time, at the Washington Square center of the university.

The Mexican public awoke this morning to read in the newspapers that President Lazaro Cardenas had decided to make Mexico "non-alcoholic" three days a week and to prohibit entirely the manufacture and sale of alcoholic beverages in the Indian regions.

The first prize of the Little, Brown novelette contest has been awarded to Wallace Stegner of Salt Lake City. The prize amounted to $2,500 in advance on royalties. The manuscript, entitled "Remembering Laughter," was selected from more than 1,300 manuscripts submitted.

The four-story apartment house at 122 Kenmore Place, Brooklyn, on a plot 62 by 100 feet, was sold by Thomas M. Graham Co. for Alfred Boser Jr., assistant treasurer of the Congregational Boards, to Embassy Estates, Inc.
Movements in the livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, seeded favorite to repeat for his River Oaks tennis title, won his third-round match today from Melvin Lapman, University of Texas star, 6--3, 3--6, 6--2.
There is an impression here in quarters frequently well informed that the relations between Paris and Moscow are undergoing a change.

Furious batting of the Yankees against Texas League pitching went even beyond the amazing at Steer Stadium today as the world champions beat the pennant-winning Dallas Steers, 15-4, before some 3,000 persons.
Mrs. Helen Walker Homan obtained a divorce today from Dominique A. Homan of New York City. An agreement was made as to property matters.

Twenty years ago Londoners beheld the unprecedented spectacle of the Stars and Stripes flying beside the Union Jack on Victoria Tower of the Houses of Parliament to mark the entry of the United States into the World War.

The output of 14,390,787 gross tons of open-hearth and Bessemer steel ingots in the United States in the first quarter of 1937 was the highest first-quarter output in the history of the country and represented a gain of 54 per cent over the 9,352,983 tons produced in the first three months of 1936, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Mrs. Terry Cramer Quimby has been named advertising manager of the Elizabeth Arden organization. Mrs. Quimby has concentrated in the retail field, having been associated with Stewart Co., Bonwit Teller Co., Bruck Weiss, Oppenheim Collins Co., and also Blum's Vogue, Chicago.

Horses and mules whose ancestors helped build the great Western American empire are going back "home." On the wheat farms where they once pulled combines in twenty-horse teams horses have found themselves replaced by tractors and as a result eastward shipments have become big business.
A 28-monthold girl, whom a Washington University psychologist described as "the most remarkable child I've ever seen," knows that King Edward "abdicated for Mrs. Wallis Simpson."

The Giant-Indian educational expedition, designed to enlighten the folk of America's vast open spaces on the arts and wiles of major league baseball, swept through the Lone Star State in full stride today, unloaded in this quaint place and forthwith paid off handsome dividends.

Pension payments to retired employes of the General Electric Company for 1936 totaled $2,548,275, according to the annual report of the company's pension board. On Dec. 31, 1936, there were 3,292 persons on the pension rolls.
The blue skies over Spain today belong to Chato and Katioushka. They are newcomers in the acrid humor of man

The Harvard freshmen defeated the Tome School nine, 14--2, today in the initial contest of the season for both teams. The yearlings had the edge all the way, reaching the offerings of three Tome pitchers for eleven safeties, including four home runs. Woodward, hurling for the freshmen, went the route and yielded only four hits. The score by innings:

While sales of furniture will expand from 15 to 20 per cent this year, profits will not keep pace with the rising volume, according to the annual review issued yesterday by Arthur Fertig Co., accountants.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank will celebrate today the one-hundredth and tenth anniversary of its founding as the first savings bank on Long Island. Its original site was the building that housed the beginning of Brooklyn's library system, the old Apprentices' Library Association building, at Henry and Cranberry Streets.

Four naval fliers plunged to death in the sea today after two fast scout bombing planes crashed headon during manoeuvres over the fleet drill grounds, forty miles off shore, naval authorities reported. The dead: Ludwell R. Pickett, lieutenant, junior grade, Coronado, Calif.

The nation's largest citizen, according to medical authorities quoted by his father, spent his first day in New York yesterday by touring Central Park in a taxi, visiting the liner Queen Mary at her slip, and entertaining a steady stream of gaping interviewers in his room at the Hotel Astor.

The F. W. Woolworth Company reported sales of $24,814,741 for March, an increase of 26.1 per cent over the $19,676,649 in March, 1936. For the first three months sales were $63,223,012, against $55,675,527 a year ago, a gain of 13.5 per cent. Figures of other companies announced yesterday follow:

The committee for Roosevelt Water Conservation District (Ariz.) 6 per cent bonds, headed by C. F. Herb, announced yesterday that a plan of liquidation and settlement as revised on Sept. 31 had been declared operative and that the Reconstruction Financ Corporation had issued an order for the purchase of bonds deposited with the committee and the district.

During these days of searching memories and dark forecasts it is heartening to observe that rumors of peace are beginning to creep in among the crowding prophecies of war. Suddenly, by an impulse no one Government acknowledges, suggestions and tentatives in a new direction begin to appear.

AIKMAN--Charles R., retired Lieutenant, New York City Police Department, at his residence, 4,120 Amboy Road, Great Kills. S. I. Funeral Mass Thursday. 10 A. M., at St. Claire's Church, Great Kills, S. I.

Aristotle's ancient dictum that the drama serves as a catharsis for the soul. purging the spirit of any ills that may beset it, is finding experimental confirmation in the psychiatric wards at Bellevue Hospital, where the "Psychiatric Theatre" is proving itself a new aid in the diagnosis and treatment of mentally ill and socially maladjusted adolescent girls.

Golf's touring professionals came near the end of the Winter trail today, the $5,000 Tournament of the Gardens. Seeking the last prize money before the rest between now and the national P. G. A. tournament, about thirty salaried players and ten amateurs entered the seventytwo-hole firing that gets under way tomorrow and continues through Saturday.

The States Electric and Gas Corporation of Philadelphia has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Act of 1935 and filed an application for approval of the acquisition of securities in several companies from the General Water, Gas and Electric Company and the American Equities Company, both of Wilmington, Del.

Republicans in the Assembly today, in effect, served notice on Governor Lehman that unless he lined up the full Democratic strength of 74 votes in the lower house in favor of his bill raising the State tax on gasoline to 4 cents, that measure will go down to defeat.

After a long debate the Senate passed today the bill introduced by Senator Joseph of the Bronx which prepares the way for the organization of mortgage banks throughout the State. This bill was adopted by a vote of 34 to 7 after it had been subjected to rapid-fire attacks from several members of the Senate.

Ernst F. S. Hanfstaengl, who is reported to have been exiled from Germany, is paying a quiet visit to London, it was learned today. He arrived a week ago and has been staying at Claridge's Hotel, under the same roof as Norman Davis and the American delegation to the sugar conference.

The movement for Congressional condemnation of sit-down strikes, halted temporarily yesterday by an adverse vote in the Senate, is expected to culminate in the next few days in adoption by Congress of a threepoint resolution denouncing this and two other practices contributing to the present labor strife, spying by employers on employes, and refusal of employers to bargain collectively with workers under the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

Operations in 1936 of the Ingersoll-Rand Company and subsidiaries resulted in a net income of $6,402,306 after depreciation, loss on foreign exchange, Federal income taxes, write-off of investment in Spanish subsidiary and other charges, according to the report issued yesterday.

William (Dutch) Cliffe, Utica's ace kegler, marked the halfway point of the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress championships by taking third place in the all-events division at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday. Other members of the Utica delegation also were outstanding rollers during the twenty-eighth session of the pin classic.

Under the impetus of President Roosevelt's New Deal program, the United States is witnessing for the first time a nation-wide campaign against venereal diseases, Anna L. Tittman, vocational secretary for Public Health Nursing, told 500 nurses at the third annual Institute for the New York Counties Registered Nurses Association.

AFTER years of digging around in reference books, listening to informal conversation and reading with an eye out for odd usages. Eric Partridge has compiled a "Dictionary of Slang" (Macmillan, $12.50), which contains about all one needs to know of unconventional English plus a good deal that, according to the prevailing mores, one is better off not to know.

For the first time since the initial trotting of the Hambletonian, Southern racing fans will get a glimpse of five candidates for this historic race when the new Aiken mile track holds its inaugural meeting on Friday and Saturday.

Net asset value of the capital stock of the Lehman Corporation on March 31, at market or fair value of investments on that date, was $102,866,951, equal to $149.44 each on 688,355 outstanding shares, according to the report of Robert Lehman, president, for the nine months through March 31, issued yesterday.

A covert invitation to Russia to discuss armament limitation may be concealed in the redefinition of the purposes of Japan's armament expansion policy given by General Gen Sugiyama, the War Minister, at the annual conference of divisional commanders today.

The price of heavy cream, commonly used in homes, was reduced from 22 cents a half pint to 19 cents by Borden's Farm Products Company and Sheffield Farms Company. Prices on larger quantities were reduced accordingly. Milk continued to be sold at 5 cents a guart in some sections of the city,

Scoring two goals in- the third period and presenting an airtight defense, the Philadelphia Ramblers defeated the Syracuse Stars, 2 to 0, tonight in the opening final play-off for the International-American Ice Hockey League championship.

Dutch interests increased their holdings last year in the Pennsylvania, Baltimore. Ohio, Southern Pacific and Kansas City Southern railways, their reports for 1936 to the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed yesterday. The large holdings of Paine, Webber Co. and associated interests in the Kansas City Southern are noted, but the list does not give effect to the recent transfer of some or all of these holdings to Harvey C. Couch.

The Department of State reported today that 1,811 new stock corporations filed in March, or 130 more than in the same month last year and 243 more than in February. Of the total, 911 were capitalized at $17,999,082, an increase of more than $500,000 over March, 1936.

Heelfly, the Three D's nominee for the Kentucky Derby, showed his mettle today when he ran six furlongs in 1:13 3-5 to win the feature race at Arlington Downs. The brown 3-year-old colt of Royal Ford was hustled away from the post in front, establishing a comfortable lead of three lengths.
Standard Brands, Inc., and the Royal Baking Powder Corporation were merged by action of the directors of both companies at a meeting today, incorporating under the name of Standard Brands, Inc.
Prime Minister J. B. M. Hertzog today gave the Germans a last chance to resume cooperation as settlers in Southwest Africa.

Every cause which brought about America's participation in the World War has been lost and the United States stands today without guarantees against involvement in another European conflict, Senator Gerald P. Nye said last night at an anti-war dinner of the American League Against War and Fascism at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 East Seventy-third Street.
Outfielder Floyd (Babe) Herman, National League veteran, sought the counsel of Manager Charles Dressen today in his effort to win a place on the roster of the Reds for 1937.
Joe Louis came home from his barnstorming tour today so unconcerned over plans for fighting James J. Braddock that he flopped right into bed for an all-day nap.

Abe Coleman of Los Angeles threw Ed Meske of Akron, Ohio, with a flying tackle and bodyspread to win the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The time was 37 minutes, 2 seconds. Coleman weighed 205, Meske 218. A crowd of 2,000 saw the match.

In special session yesterday, the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange adopted a recommendation of the committee on stock list that the old common and preferred stocks of the American Writing Paper Company, Inc., be stricken from listing and suspended from dealings at the opening of business on April 12.
Paul Maury, 26 years old, committed suicide today at the grave of his dog. The dead dog had been one of a pair with which Mr. Maury used to hunt.
Bernie (Schoolboy) Friedkin of Brownsville last night outpointed Joey Wach of the East Side in eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn. A capacity crowd of more than 4,500 attended.

Because no attempt had been made to try Pasquale Caffre, Tammany election board chairman in the polling place of the Twentysecond Election District of the Second Assembly District in the November, 1933, elections, Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday dismissed the indictment against him alleging violations of the election laws.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William F. Wall of this city and Scarsdale of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Panchita Wall, to Joseph Fowler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Coolidge Fowler of Bronxville.

THERE is more to making ready for a race Meeting than currycombing the racing strip, painting the fences white, cutting the clubhouse shrubbery and oiling up the turnstiles. Belmont Park doesn't open its gates until May 10, but getting ready is a matter of weeks and months, and even years.

The threat of new taxes inherent in the failure of government revenues to meet Treasury estimates brought about today the formation of a Congressional bloc which will insist that President Roosevelt revise his indicated recommendation for a $1,200,000,000 work relief fund to a lesser amount in order to avoid additional levies.
Roger Peckinpaugh and Lew Fonseca, ex-American League stars and the circuit's baseball salesmen, visited West Point today and showed the cadet nine how it's done in the big leagues.

Week from hunger and penniless after a fruitless six-day search for a job, Harold Kleenman, 53 years old, of 16 Latonia Street, Worcester, Mass., collapsed yesterday afternoon in front of 3,120 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx.

Entry into the foreign field by the Glenn L. Martin Company in 1936 and a corresponding shrinkage of domestic commercial sales were revealed in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. For the last three years the airplane company reported sales as follows:

Sitdown strikers resumed their posts inside the Hershey Chocolate Corporation's plant here tonight as negotiations between company officials and union organizers ended abruptly. Fears of strife grew as 400 nonstrikers formed their own union to oppose the United - Chocolate Workers, a C. I. O. affiliate.

Secretary Morgenthau's uneasy remarks about government revenues yesterday have aroused deep suspicion in Congress that, despite several inspired statements by its own leaders to the contrary, Congress will be asked for new taxes at this session.

Because of the trend away from humanism and the didactic in letters today and the stress on practical education, Dr. Rafael Ernesto Lopez, recently appointed Minister of Eduction by Venezuela, will leave next week to revise the educational system of that country.
The United States is best equipped among nations to defend itself against air attack, Major Herhudt von Rohden sets forth in a survey of world aerial powers.

Mrs. Frances Marcosson, wife of Isaac Marcosson, publicist and writer on political and economic affairs, died at 9:30 o'clock last night after a long illness at their home in the Lowell, 28 East Sixty-third Street. Mrs. Marcosson was 43 years old.
The National Association of Raiiroad and Utilities Commissioners advocated today Federal regulation of air carriers operating in interstate arid foreign commerce.

An official announcement regarding future plans for the World Two-Way Trade Fair, exhibit of foreign and domestic products scheduled for May 10 to 22 here, will be made today, Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants' Association and head of the corporation of civic and foreign trade group officials sponsoring the project. announced yesterday.

Samuel Bornstein, 44 years old, manipulator of a ring of lawyers, doctors and "stooges" that in eight years defrauded insurance companies of hundreds of thousands of dollars in fake accident claims, was sentenced to the penitentiary yesterday in Special Sessions for an indeterminate term of not more than three years.
Five of six Hawaiians who competed in the national A. A. U. junior boxing tournament tonight, won their way into tomorrow's semi-finals, two of them by knockouts.

Trial of suits brought by the State Banking Department against fifty-five individuals to collect assessments aggregating between $175,000 to $200,000 on Bank of United States stock is scheduled to start today before Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon. The actions will be tried without a jury.

The Fourth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in a decision today declared the "windfall tax" constitutibonal, affirming dismissal by the District Court at Salisbury, N. C., of the White Packing Company's suit to enjoin the collector of internal revenue from collecting the 80 per cent under Title 3 of the Revenue Act of 1936.

Space for publishers, printers, restaurants and food shops figured in the contracts for commercial quarters reported yesterday in various parts of the city. In the Gotham National Bank Building at 1,819 Broadway, the National Council of Jewish Women took space for administrative offices from the Manufacturers Trust Company, owners.

Funeral services for Talcott W. Powell writer and former newspaper man who died at his home in Riverside on Sunday, were held here today in Christ Episcopal Church. The services were conducted by his father, the Rev. Dr. Lyman P. Powell.

Jacob Einstein, a retired insurance broker, father of Izzy Einstein, the prohibition agent, died yesterday at his residence, 167 Ridge Street, of pneumonia, at the age of 86. His widow, another son, Edward, who lives in Tampa, Fla., and two daughters, Pauline Einstein and Mrs. Ethel Ansel, both of this city, survive.

The Board of Higher Education, through the administrative committee of Hunter College, will ask for $4,100,000 in the capital outlay budget for the construction of new college buildings, Mark Eisner, chairman, disclosed last night after a meeting in the City College School of Business.

Assets of all banks in the country on Dec. 31, 1936, amounted to $70,114,791,000, an increase of $12,869,660,000 in four and a half years, J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

Floyd Bennett Field, New York's $5,000,000 municipal airport, became a regular stop on the route of American Airlines yesterday and the first passengers were landed and flown from it over the commercial air lanes of the country.

August Hafner has purchased from Malba Investors, Inc., a plot on Malba Drive, between Center and North Drives, Whitestone, Queens, upon which he intends to build a home. Malba Investors, Inc., was organized pursuant to a Supreme Court order for the benefit of certificate holders in an issue of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company.

Charles Di Avanzo, 27 years old, of 55 Delancey Street, who said he was a physician when he was arrested Sunday afternoon on the complaint of Mrs. Tillie Culumbia of 236 East Twenty-fifth Street on a charge of impairing the morals of a minor, was discharged by Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in Homicide Court yesterday when Mrs. Culumbia refused to press the complaint.
All reports that General Erich Ludendorff will return to the army or that Chancellor Adolf Hitler has accepted his brand of Nordic paganism are categorically denied in a semi-official statement.
Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature urging enactment of a measure declaring it as State policy that all State officers should pay State income taxes.
A blue-ribbon jury and one alternate were chosen late yesterday to try Louis Luckman, 50 years old, on a perjury indictment before Justice Erskine C. Rogers in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

James Benny, City Attorney here for twenty-five years and one of the oldest members of the New Jersey bar, died last night at his home. Mr. Benny, who was 81 years old, was a lawyer for fiftyeight years and was widely known in the State as a student of municipal law.

Gluck-Sandor, one of the directors of the WPA Federal Dance Theatre, will take over the stage and dramatic direction of "The Romance of Robot" at its first performance next Monday evening in the Theatre of Music, Chalmers Clifton, New York City director of the WPA Federal Music Project, announces.

This evening the theatre will devote itself to the affairs of that small-town maid-of-all-work, "Miss Quis," who inherited a fortune and spent it in the interests of the community. Ward Morehouse, theatrical writer for The Sun, is the author of the play, and Miss Quis herself is represented by Peggv Wood.

Mayor La Guardia and John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, agreed yesterday at City Hall on pay increases for about 5,000 employes on the operating division of the Independent City Subway which will aggregate $1,400,000 a year.

Forty-five grave-diggers and laborers staged a sit-down strike in Holy Cross Cemetery here today. With their spades andpicks lying beside them on the greening lawn, they passed a pleasant afternoon playing cards, pitching horseshoes or sleeping in the April sun.

Two new sit-downs today closed three General Motors plants, two of them here and one in Saginaw. A sit-down in the Olds Motor Works tonight caused the closing of that factory and the Fisher Body plant here, which assembles bodies for Olds.
Advertising of a contract for steel alteration work on the Manhattan Bridge brought a low bid of $279,700 yesterday from the Taylor-Fighter Steel Construction Company of 570 Seventh Avenue.

Parents who give their children "odd-sounding names and those of ambiguous meanings" endanger the youngsters' personality development throughout life, according to W. E. Walton, University of Nebraska psychologist.

The Polish Government today signified its acceptance of Anthony J. Drexel Biddle, now Minister to Norway, to be United States Ambassador to Poland. He will succeed John Cudahy, who became Ambassador to Poland in 1933.
Luigi Freddi, chief of the film division of the Italian Propaganda Ministry, has arrived here to arrange an alliance between the German and Italian film industries.

The Electric Bond and Share Company and other public utility company co-defendants, which lost the first round against the government over the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act of 1935, filed an appeal yesterday in Federal court in an effort to reverse Judge Julian W. Mack's opinion upholding the registration provisions of the statute.
Paul Winthrop Brown, one-time editor of the old St. Louis Republic, publisher and historian of river and railroad transportation, died in a hospital here today. He was 67 years old.
The wedding of Miss Anne Benton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Benton of this city, to William Belden Hagyard, Son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Hagyard, has been postponed for two weeks.
The Spanish Government announced tonight a shipload of refugee Spanish children had arrived in Crimea, on the Black Sea, where they will be cared for by Russian authorities.

Judge and Mrs. George W. Smyth of Crestwood, Westchester County, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Grace Smyth, to Carl Joseph Weisenbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Weisenbach of Wayne, Pa.

Steel-ingot production continued its upward movement last week when a decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 125.1, a high for the year. It was 122.5 for the previous week and 86.1 for the week ended April 4, 1936.

The market for United States Government securities, unsettled by the recent sharp decline and by the recovery on Monday induced by the announcement of the plans for the Federal Reserve Banks to make open-market purchases, was confronted yesterday with a new problem in the announcement of Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau that additional borrowing would be necessary before July 1.

The factory of the Caterpillar Tractor Company in East Peoria was closed tonight by a combination sit-down and walk-out strike. Eleven thousand five hundred employes were reported idle. A superintendent in the assembly room and a workman were injured in a scuffle which accompanied the walk-out

Supplementing what has been said about the opening of the trout season in this State, Sparse Gray Hackle contributes a few words about the Catskill streams. "The Catskill streams are in the best shape in several years," writes the angler. "Water level is normal and stones are brown with moss, showing that they have not been recently disturbed by storms.

This city was without a Mayor today. Mayor Hitch was en route to New York; Council Chairman Harry Fulenwider, next in line, was in Birmingham; Vice Chairman H. Lee Fulton Jr. was in Chicago and Alderman Edgar L. Wortsman

Miss J. Isabelle Sims, long prominent in civic affairs here, began serving today as foreman of the April term Federal grand jury. She is probably the first woman in the United States to serve in that capacity. Miss Sims was chosen by Judge William Clark, senior judge of the New Jersey District Court, from among six women and seventeen men who had been called for service.

Heavy profittaking developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today and while there was an advance or around 1 cent a bushel on wheat and corn early there was a notable lack of aggressive buying on the upturn and later all grains receded.

Deaths, injuries and the total of vehicle accidents declined last week and week-end in New York City, compared with similar periods of 1936, according to figures issued by the traffic division of the Police Department.

Practical functioning for the Fall wholesale season of the anti-returns program for the women's apparel industry was foreseen here yesterday after a meeting of the committee of the Apparel Inter-Trades Bureau, with Irving C. Fox representing the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the offices of the retailers' organization.

Further reports of the patrol boat Larrakia's encounter with Japanese pearling and fishing luggers were given today. When the luggers attempted to escape from Australian waters, where they were operating, the Larrakia pursued, firing machine guns across the bow of one lugger. The fugitives immediately stopped.

A suit to compel Cardinal Hayes to turn over to Mrs. Mary F. Stannard one-third of the $200,000 estate left by her uncle, the late Auxiliary Bishop John J. Dunn, was dismissed on technical grounds yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo. The Cardinal is executor of the Bishop's will.

Residents of the town of Randall were determined today to do something about their pressing financial problem-involving a surplus of $16,000. Perhaps, said Town Chairman George Dean, . the voters, at their annual meeting, will be able to figure out how to get rid of the accumulated funds.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage in Honolulu on March 10 of Miss Kate Leilani van Heemskerck Duker, daughter of William Frederick van H. Duker, to Dr. Hugo Peter Kortschak of this city.

After being hauled up at Gosport for the Winter, the America's Cup yachts, Endeavour I and Endeavour II, have been put in the water. Their outfitting, now in its later stages, is being pushed forward as fast as possible. Both vessels will set sail for America on May 1.

Members of the Tammany executive committee, whose views were said to coincide with those of a majority, decided yesterday to oppose any attempt to hold a meeting during the absence of James J. Dooling, the leader, in Florida. Mr. Dooling's return has been set tentatively for April 26.
The name of Heinrich Heine, German poet, has been banished from Viennese municipal buildings by order of Burgomaster Richard Schmitz.

Richard Anthony Strong, a retired woolen manufacturer who was formerly president of the Metropolitan Opera Club, died yesterday morning at his town residence, 945 Park Avenue, after an illness of less than two days. He was a bachelor, 73 years old.
Harvard's lacrosse team overwhelmed Penn State today, 11 to 1. It was the season's opening game for both teams. George Cushman, second defense for the Crimson, was leading scorer with four goals.

The annual Spring meeting and dinner of Group VII of the New York State Bankers Association, comprising member banks in the counties of Kings, Queens, Nassau, Suffolk and Richmond, will be held next Wednesday at the Bethpage State Park Clubhouse on Long Island, it was announced yesterday by Daniell Schmeidler, chairman of the group.

Several dinner parties have been arranged by subscribers to precede the three performances of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, "The Grand Duke; or, The Statutory Duel," to be given tonight, tomorrow and Friday nights at the Heckscher Theatre by the Blue Hill Troupe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The waste of 200,000,000 gallons of water into the sewer system every day, as officially reported by the Water Department, is responsible for the scare of a water shortage, the avoidance of which causes us to start work on the New Delaware-Roundout project.
In the Customs and Patent Appeals Court of the United States, Samuel D. Spector of New York City was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

J. M. Hutton of Cincinnati, senior partner in W. E. Hutton Co., told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he understood his company had sold stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation in November, 1935, to investment buyers, not to speculators.
Residents of Pelham voted by slightly more than 11 to 1 tonight at an "oldfashioned town meeting" against President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize and enlarge the Supreme Court.

Vermont's Legislature tonight became the first in the nation to vote to outlaw sit-down strikes. The Senate sent to Governor Aiken a bill providing a maximum sentence of two years' imprisonment or not more than $1,000 fine for violation.

Farmers Estates Corporation, which recently filed building plans for a number of multi-family dwellings in Forest Hills, yesterday placed on record specifications for the construction of thirty-three sixstory apartments in Rego Park, Queens, close to the World's Fair grounds, to cost $4,125,000.

Administration forces lost today in a second attempt to have the House Agriculture Committee provide in the Farm Tenancy Bill $50,000,000 a year for Federal purchase of land to be sold to worthy tenants. The vote was 12 to 12.

Sumner Simpson, president of Raybestos Manhattan, Inc., said at the annual meeting yesterday that earnings for the first two months of 1937 were about 70 cents a share, as compared with 39 cents in the 1936 period, and that first-quarter earnings may be 95 cents to $1 a share.

Prince Chichibu, eldest brother of Emperor Hirohito of Japan, and Princess Chichibu, his consort, arrived in New York-from Montreal yesterday morning with their imperial suite for a brief visit en route to England.
The youngest Bishop in America, the Rt. Rev. Henry Wise Hobson, 45, of Cincinnati, won approval today of a plan to make the lone cathedral in his Protestant Episcopal Diocese an automobile trailer.

Three government airplanes, one of Russian design, dropped several high explosive bombs on Algeciras this morning, some exploding in the vicinity of the Hotel Cristina, where it is understood that officers of the Insurgent general staff and German technicians are quartered.

Helen Frederick, who gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall last night, is a young American pianist. Born in Indiana, she received all her training in this country. She has made public appearances in the Middle West, in the East and in Canada.
The British destroyer Gallant was reported tonight to have opened fire with anti-aircraft guns on an airplane that dropped a bomb near her in the Mediterranean.

Everglades farmers said today that bean and tomato crops on 50,000 acres had been "90 to 95 per cent" destroyed by rain and hail. Luther Jones of Belle Glade said the' damage in the rich Winter vegetable bowl was "greater than that of the 1928 hurricane."

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today twenty-nine additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, including one by. Monogram Pictures Corporation of New York City covering 1,000,000 shares of $1 par value common stock.
Five young men will join the Society of Fellows at Harvard University In September as junior fellows, devoting themselves to independent research and study for three years. They are Orville T.
Deliveries of Pontiac cars to dealers in March set a new high record of 25,609 units. The best previous showing was 23,750 cars delivered in April, 1929.

Burleigh Grimes and his Dodgers had lunch at Sarasota today, but engaged in no contest with the Red Sox, because when it rains in these parts it really lets go. So the final game prior to the campbreaking ceremonies may be dismissed along with the weather, and a much more Interesting subject, Van Lingle Mungo, taken up.

County Judge Martin in Brooklyn directed a jury yesterday to acquit Michael De Pasquale, 27 years old, of a charge of first-degree manslaughter in connection with the fatal shooting of his father, Salvatore De Pasquale, 59 years old.

The Legislative Committee on Legal Affairs ordered the Massachusetts Racing Commission today to produce its books and records at an executive committee meeting April 16. If the commission refuses to produce the documents, the committee will issue a summons, Senator Thomas Burke (D., Boston), a member of the committee, said.

A gift from C. B. Winslow of $315,000 to the Building Fund of the White. Plains Hospital was announced today by John W. Appel Jr., president of the board of governors of the institution. Mr. Winslow, a resident of White Plains, is a member of the board of governors of the hospital and a former vice president of the F. W. Woolworth Company.

The Salvation Army opened a campaign last night to raise $600,000 to meet deficits expected for the year 1937-1938 and, in a pageant, reviewed the Army's activities in the last twenty years. The ceremonies were held in the Centennial Memorial Auditorium, 120 West Fourteenth Street.

A strong army and navy are the best guarantee of a country for safety and peace, Lieut. Gen. Robert Lee Bullard, retired, declared last night in an Army Day address over the radio from Station WOR under the auspices of the National Security League.
The government discovered today that the Lutheran Council and the Confessional Synods were calmly ignoring its recent decree for the temporary administration of the Protestant church.

Attendance of buyers yesterday at the American Toy Fair being held at the Hotel McAlpin and the Toy Center, 200 Fifth Avenue, was again heavy, bringing the total registration of merchants for the two days thus far to more than 1,000, or from 15 to 20 per cent above the same days of the 1936 fair.

Tom Iannicelli, defending titleholder, and Rowland Dufton, New York Athletic Club professional, scored semi-final victories to gain the title bracket of the world open squash tennis tournament at the Hotel Shelton last night.

The conferring of the Medal of the Holland Society upon Dr. FRANK PIERREPONT GRAVES (who as Commissioner of Education for the State of New York has under his official care two million, more or less, school children, high school youth and college and university young men and women) not only gives him deserved recognition and honor, but offers occasion for recalling the early Dutch contribution to democratic education in this city and State.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that it had informed legislative leaders of its endorsement of the bill introduced by Assemblyman Rapp to restore to municipalities power to determine the salaries of all officers and employes except judges and teachers.
Strong agitation continues in the Italian press against alleged violations of the non-intervention agreement by countries with Socialist or Communist leanings, particularly France.

A plot of about two acres in Joseph P. Day's residential development on Old Short Hills Road and South Orange Avenue in Short Hills, N. J., has been purchased by David Lobdell of Lobdell Co., stock brokers, who will erect a large residence for his own occupancy. The Frank Hughes Company, in conjunction with Mansfield Swett, negotiated the sale.

Four pickets were arrested about 8:30 o'clock last night in front of the Globe Theatre, on Broadway between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, after the manager had accused them of interfering with patrons entering and leaving the theatre.

Having increased its sales volume sevenfold since it entered the Summer clothing manufacturing field in 1931, the Goodall Company will launch its most extensive advertising campaign for men's and boys' Palm Beach clothes at the end of this month.

An automobile, started by a 9year-old boy after the owner had left it parked at the curb, fatally injured Mrs. Lena Mayer, 56 years old, of 502 East 142d Street, the Bronx, just after 10 o'clock last night, when the car got out of the control of the young driver. The boy, James Glennon, of 172 St. Ann's Avenue, was charged with juvenile delinquency.
Both Arabs and Jews are receiving very coldly persistent reports from London predicting that the Royal Commission will recommend either cantonization or a geographical division of Palestine.

Ida Krehm and Jorge Bolet, pianists; Pauline Pierce, mezzo soprano, and Morris Bialkin, 'cellist, have been selected as winners of the annual Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation's competition for young artists, it was announced yesterday. Their prize will constitute debut recitals in New York City next season.

The Dominion government, faced with the impossibility of passing social reform measures without invading provincial jurisdiction, is planning to call a conference of political leaders similar to those which preceded confederation in 1867, to obtain amendments which will give the central government more power. It is believed that all political parties will be represented.

The William Sloane House of the Y. M. C. A. at 356 West Thirtyfourth Street was declared exempt from municipal real estate taxes in a decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman. It is expected that the ruling will apply to other branches where a large number of rooms are rented.

GovernorLehman signed today the Milmoe bill, which includes income from broadcasting and motion picture rights at boxing bouts or wrestling matches in gross receipts subject to the 5 per cent State tax.

Bail of $2,000 each, given by three former officials of Massapequa Park, Nassau County, in General Sessions last Summer when they were indicted on second-degree grand larceny charges, was quashed yesterday by Judge Nott.

A revised plan for reorganizing the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company and its twenty-seven underliers into one $132,819,028 corporation, thus wiping out the 999-year leases to the underliers, was filed today in the Federal District Court here by Frederic L. Ballard, chief counsel of the P. R. T.

Miss Anne Beatrice Kliegl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Kliegl of 322 Central Park West, was married to Lieutenant James Francis Byrne, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Patrick J. Byrne of Lowell, Mass., and the late Mr. Byrne, yesterday morning at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in West Eighty-second Street by the Rev. Eugene A. Duggan.

Nearly 1,500 persons listened to several pleas for continued peace yesterday afternoon at a ceremony observing the twentieth anniversary of this nation's entry into the World War on the steps of Brooklyn Borough Hall. The event was planned by the Kings County American Legion.

Undesirable manufacturing tenants are being kept out of the area surrounding Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, Leo S. DePinna told the Plaza district conservation committee of the Fifth Avenue Association yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Plaza.

The first annual ball of the Staff lub, asocial organization recently bunded and incorporated by the utlers of New York City, was held ast night in the grand ballroom of ne Hotel Commodore. Harry J. :eney, butler to Herbert L. Sattere, heads the club.

A special police detail of a sergeant and ten patrolmen was distributed in the audience in Yorkville Court yesterday to prevent an expected clash between pro-Nazi and anti-Nazi forces at a hearing scheduled for 2 P. M. before Magistrate McKiniry.

The fate of WPA workers on Park Department projects remained somewhat in doubt yesterday despite a conference between Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, and statements by both Mr. Moses and Colonel Somervell.

Fifteen tenement buildings were involved in the seven auction sales held in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday. Nine of the ten houses which occupy the block front on the west side of Eighth Avenue, Fifty-first to Fifty-second Streets, were among the properties sold at foreclosure. The list follows:

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer denied yesterday an injunction sought by the owners of the Holmes Airport in Jackson Heights, Queens, to restrain the city from proceeding with the development of North Beach Airport. The plaintiffs had argued that the Proposed expenditure of $8,444,300 would be a waste of money,
Four nephews of the Insurgent leader, General Francisco Franco-Jose, Luis, Fernando and Juan Suarez-Avila-all students from Oviedo, have been arrested at the village of Carballar in Asturias.

Claude Trevine Symons, adviser to the government on scientific aids in crime detection, died suddenly today while conferring with authorities here on the establishment of a new police laboratory for the Midlands.

With hearty shouts of "Banzai !" New York and the country yesterday welcomed the brother of the Japanese Emperor, His Imperial Highness Prince CHICHIBU, and his wife, Princess CHICHIBU, who are here for only a short visit en route to attend the coronation of GEORGE VI.

President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia and Mrs. Benes, Regent Prince Paul and Princess Olga, together with Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and other Yugoslav Cabinet Ministers, visited King Alexander's mausoleum at Oplenac this morning.

Thomas Mann, the novelist, will speak on Wagner in the first of three lectures, to be given April 19 at 5:20 P. M., in the New School for Social Research. The Dessoff Choirs, Paul Boepple conductor, will be heard in concert tonight at the Church of the Incarnation for the benefit of the Bethlehem Day Nursery.

Governor LEHMAN'S special message to the Legislature yesterday recommending " legislation to place the State "officers named in the Constitution on "the same basis as all other State of"ficers and employes with respect to "the payment of State income taxes" will relieve a very general soreness in the minds of persons who have to pay every year their share of those steep taxes.
The Senate passed by a vote of 25 to 11 today a bill by Senator Waldvogel of Hamilton County, which would provide State aid for parochial and private schools. It now goes to the House.

The engagement of $4,788,000 gold in England yesterday for shipment here was reported to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought the total of gold secured in London for American account since Sept. 26, 1936, to $381,600,000.

George A. Tomlinson, 71-year-old shipper and a prominent figure in the railroad empire amassed by the Van Sweringen brothers, was elected today chairman of the Missouri Pacific Railroad to succeed the late O. P. Van Sweringen.

Charles H. Thompson, 25 years old, of 89-07 Eighty-eighth Street, Woodhaven, Queens, an undertaker, was injured critically at 6:30 o'clock last evening when thrown from his horse as he struck the limb of a tree while riding on the Forest Park bridle path near 108th Street, Richmond Hill.

The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained a large number of guests at dinner tonight. After dinner the company and additional guests were entertained by a program of old ballads and folk songs by a chorus from the Pine Mountain Settlement School from Harlan County, Ky.

Continuing along the successful road that few critics expected them to travel, the New York Rangers rang up their fifth straight playoff victory last night, when they toppled the Detroit Red Wings by a score of 5 to 1.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Radio Corporation of America, held yesterday afternoon in one of the National Broadcasting Company's spacious studios, took a rather disorderly turn with considerable heckling of David Sarnoff, president, who presided over the meeting.

The annual meeting of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., is to be held in New York. The management is asking for proxies in the names of Charles E. Fox, lawyer; Daniel Gimbel, vice president of the company; Ellis A. Gimbel, chairman of the board;

The twenty-first exhibition in the series at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee opens today, with all four floors devoted to oil paintings by groups formed, as before, of compatible artists organized for the purpose of exhibiting their works at the Municipal Galleries.

Dapper Don Collins, noted in the underworld and in police circles as a first-class confidence man, was in custody yesterday with five other men, the victim of too great trust in a Secret Service agent who he had thought was corrupt.

Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., was not represented today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission on the company's application to withdraw its stock from trading on the New York Curb Exchange. Counsel for the commission and the Curb Exchange asked that the application be dismissed. Their request was taken under advisement.

Miss Martha Byrne, Register of New York County, and Walter Fairchild, head of the Torrens Title League, headed a delegation which went to Albany yesterday to urge passage of the Rossi bill, now before the State Legislature, calling for the creation of a State assurance fund to encourage registration of real property titles under the so-called Torrens law.

Intensive training in fashion work, and practical experience as well, will be furnished a specially qualified student body through the School for Fashion Careers, Tobe informed a press group at a luncheon held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A move to end the prolonged Senate hearings on the President's Supreme Court reorganization plan drew sharp opposition from friends and foes of the proposal today.

Acquitted of a robbery charge in Kings County Court Yesterday, Emmanuel Petrovsky, 48 years old, of 2,810 Olinville Avenue, the Bronx, collapsed four blocks from the court house in the company of his attorney and died a few minutes later as he was being assisted into Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn. Death was attributed to natural causes.

Governor Lehman called upon the Legislature today to enact a measure fixing it as State policy that all State officials be required to pay State income taxes. The Governor sent a special message to the Legislature, remarking that certain officials, including himself and the other three State-wide

Isaac Muss of 415 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, former builder and contractor, now unemployed, filed yesterday in the Federal court in that borough a voluntary petition in bankruptcy. Muss listed his liabilities as $1,604,149 and said he had no assets.

The Hospital Department, after three years of rehabilitation, is now definitely on the march to proper standards, Commissioner S. S. Goldwater informed Mayor La Guardia yesterday in his annual report for 1936.
A survey of the less usual professions followed by women college graduates will be the subject of the third annual conference on fields of work for women to be held at Cornell.University on April 17.

Copies of the adjustment plan for Republic of Poland 7 per cent external sinking fund bonds of the stabilization loan of 1927 are available at the Bankers Trust Company and the Chase National Bank, special agents. They will accept coupons-due on April 15 from devalued dollar bonds for payment in cash or new bonds, as provided by the plan.

The Republican Assembly turned its back on Mayor La Guardia and his Fusion administration today by passing two Tammany bills which take control of the Board of Superintendents out of the hands of the Board of Education.

Reflecting further declines in prices abroad and a reduction here by some custom smelters, the leading copper producers lowered yesterday the domestic price of the metal 1 cent a pound to 16 cents. This is the first decrease in the domestic price since the price of copper started upward last Summer.

G. M. P. Murphy Co. received an underwriting commission of $279,230 on the recent issue of the Ludlum Steel Company, the latter has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to the Stock Exchange.

H. W. Warley, vice president and general manager of the Calmar Steamship Company, has been nominated to succeed himself as president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Warley is serving his first term in that office.

James T. Hunter, veteran golfer of North Adams, Mass., led a field of thirty-two qualifiers into the first round of match play in the North and South amateur tourney by shooting a fine 71 today to win the medal from a field of 171.

The parents of Helmut Hirsch, young man under sentence of death in Germany, where he had been described as a "Stateless Jew" in an official announcement that he had been condemned for high treason and possessing explosives, revealed today that they had been unable to obtain further details of the case.

Operation of aircraft at Lake George for commercial purposes would be a misdemeanor under a bill approved today by the Legislature and sent to Governor Lehman. The Assembly concurred, 141 to 9, with the Senate in approving the measure sponsored by Senator Benjamin Feinberg, Republican of Clinton.

Under the bewitching spell of costumes, cookery and reminiscence, something of the New York of fifty years ago returned last night at the Museum of the City of New York, 103d Street and Fifth Avenue, at a dinner given by the trustees to a group of distinguished New Yorkers, including former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Mayor F. H. La Guardia and Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University.

Jack J. Boyle, manager of the media department of McCannErickson, Inc., addressed the 300 members of THE NEW YORK TIMES class in national advertising last night at THE TIMES Annex on the subject of buying advertising space in newspapers.

The United States cannot escape the consequences of another great war no matter how much it may seek to isolate itself from the rest of the world and, in common with other nations, it can find peace and security only through international economic cooperation.

The convention of the American Theatre Council will be held at the Astor Hotel on May 24-27 instead of the week before. Luise Sillcox, Sidney Howard, Frank Gillmore, Paul Turner, Marcus Heiman, Lawrence Langner and Warren P. Munsell have been chosen as temporary directors of the council, with Mr. Turner and Mr. Munsell acting as executive directors for the convention.
President Roosevelt led the nation today in commemoration of the twentieth anniversary of America's entrance into the World War and in celebration of Army Day, which he designated by proclamation.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for March 31, issued today, showed that the ratio of the gold reserve notes in circulation had declined from 135.34 per cent on March 15 to 132.75 per cent on March 31.

Anne O'Hare McCormick, foreign correspondent, speaking last night at a dinner meeting of the Women's City Club, 20 West Fifty-first Street. said that she did not believe there was such a thing as "fireproof" neutrality legislation.

The cost of tin cans-including the kind beer comes in-went up today. The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corportion announced an increase of 50 cents a base box on coke tin plates and special-coated manufacturning terns.

Stocks eased and closed generally lower; turnover, 1,251,540 shares. United States Government bonds steadier at slightly lower levels, corporate and foreign issues irregularly lower; transactions, $11,112,400.

Walter J. Loughran, with offices at J. K. Rice Jr. Co., has been elected to associate membership by the New York Security Dealers Association. The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for the common stock of the Weyenberg Shoe Manufacturing Company.

Semi-Annual Meeting of the Academy of Political Science, Hotel Astor. Morning session, 10 A. M. Afternoon session, 2:15 P. M. Dinner session, 7 P. M. "Foreign Policy of the United States-Political and Economic," William L. Ransom, James Grafton Rogers, Senator Elbert D. Thomas.

A statement that strict impartiality would be the keynote of the investigation of Leon Trotsky by the preliminary investigating commission was made today by Dr. John Dewey, noted educator and chairman of the group, on his arrival here.

For the first time, today the Spanish Government brought its new "chatos" pursuit aircraft [swift, snub-nosed Russian planes] into action on the Basque front. Officials reported later that the planes, of the type that have given the Loyalists superiority in the air on other fighting fronts, had stemmed the Rebel bombing force, which had dropped 4,000 bombs on Sunday.
About 200 members of the "People's Lobby," who staged a sit-down in the Senate chambers of the Capitol last night, gave up their siege today at the request of Governor Benson.
With a home-made lethal gas chamber, Leroy Irish, 40-year-old mailman, ended his worries over debts at the cost of his own life and that of his invalid wife, police said today.

A reversal in commodity prices generally canceled most of Monday's gain in cotton prices and, in sympathy with a decline in the outside markets, quotations on the Cotton Exchange lost $1 a bale at one time yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Carson of Stoneleigh, near Baltimore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Knighter Carson, to Donald Frederick Proctor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Proctor. The wedding will take place in June.

A red sun was setting and the shadows were lengthening over the covers when the judges reached a decision late today in the Members' All-Age Stake at the annual field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired; Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick stressed the need for effective international action to prevent war in radio addresses tonight, marking the opening of a nation-wide "No-Foreign-War Crusade" sponsored by the Emergency Peace Campaign.

Adrienne Ames's story that her actor husband, Bruce Cabot, drank to excess, threatened her, swore at her and broke furniture won her a divorce today. It was her second decree from Mr. Cabot in a year. She received an interlocutory decree last July, but Mr. Cabot flew to her in New York and there was a reconciliation.

A residential plot at the corner of Hampton and Whig Roads, in Fox Meadow, Scarsdale, has been purchased from Fox Meadow Estates by Luigi DiScala, who Will erect a stone residence in Italian style there. Chauncey B. Griffen negotiated the sale.

Mrs. Susan Matilda Watson, widow of the Rev. J. Henry Watson, who died on March 31, bequeathed most of her estate to religious, charitable and public institutions. Her will was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson told the Market Street Business Men's Association tonight that he was "having a private feud" with President Roosevelt. "He is peeved at me," the Mayor said, "because he wants to take the Liberty Bell to New York, to be placed in the Empire State Building there as a special display in connection with the New York World Fair in 1939.

Benjamin Gassman, executive secretary of the recently incorporated Loyal City Democracy, announced yesterday that a committee had been appointed to see former Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial and ask him to run for Mayor. If Mr. Prial consents, he will be nominated at a city-wide convention and his name will be placed on the ballot by petition.

Fifty-one of the best 3-year-olds in the country, including J. H. Louchheim's Pompoon and E. R. Bradley's Brooklyn, the joint choices for the Kentucky Derby, remain eligible for the Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park on June 5. This number remains from 349 nominations of weanlings and yearlings following the final declarations March 30.

Norman Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, and Walter Runciman, President of the British Board of Trade, tonight had their first opportunity to talk over general economic subjects since Mr. Davis came to London as chairman of the American sugar delegation.

Another chapter in the story of the New York Community Trust tells of the appropriation of "more money "from more trusts to more beneficiaries "than in any prior year." And with such a record it concludes the chapter with this advice to those who are seeking a channel through which to make their charitable gifts and bequests enduring:

While dusting off the marquee over the entrance to the Hotel Woodstock, 123 West Forty-third Street, yesterday afternoon Garabed Belian, 35 years old, of 310 East Thirty-second Street, a handyman, fell through the glass top to the sidewalk fourteen feet below.

The speed of German rearmament, although not its potentialities, has been exaggerated, experts here said today. Despite contrary reports, Germany was not ready last year to fight a major war when her troops marched into the Rhineland;
Emile Pathe, president of the board of PatheMarconi Company, was buried today in the family vault at St. Mande, near Paris. He died on Saturday in Pau at the age of 77.

Thomas C. Campbell, vice president of the Fred F. French Management Company and managing director of Tudor City, will sail today on the Queen Mary for a month's visit to London, where he will act as consultant to the House of Costain, builders, in the management and operation of the new Costain housing development near the Thames, London.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 95,120 additional shares of Vanadium Corporation of American capital stock, no par value; 4,492 additional shares of General American Transportation Corporation common stock, $5 par value; 185,398 additional shares of Bridgeport Brass Company common capital stock,

The stock markets here continued firm today, although there was little increase in the volume of business. Giltedge issues made new gains, but foreign loans were irregular. International shares were lower for the most part and United States Steel and International Nickel showed weakness.

For the first time in eighty-two years this village today was in the complete control of officials elected on the Republican ticket. The village board, all Republicans, held its organization meeting yesterday.

The first public estimate given by Marshal Ferdinand Foch, commanderin-chief of the allied and American Armies during the World War, of the service of the A. E. F. was recalled here today in connection with the twentieth anniversary of the entry of the United States into the conflict.

A plea by the United States for a rehearing on a case in which the court had held that the owner of a Liberty bond was not required to surrender it on call by the government was denied today by the Fourth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

A man clad in shorts sprinted a block through the pouring rain to the West Forty-seventh Street police station shortly after 3 A. M. yesterday and shouted that he had been robbed. "Took your clothes, eh?" said the lieutenant on the desk.

Barred from amateur competition by the Metropolitan Golf Association, Charles H. Mayo Jr. is determined to stick to his job as a golfequipment salesman, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Mayo, Long Island amateur champion, said the only indication he has had of his disbarment came when the M. G. A. omitted his name from its Spring handicap list.

Mr. and Mrs. Michael Phipps gave a dinner today at Casa Bendita. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. John S. Phipps, Mrs. William Thomas Lane, Miss Frances Munn, Miss Mary Munn and Miss Grace Munn Amory, John Guest, Charles A. Munn, John Hemingway and Herbert Scheftel.

Theron C. Bennett, musician, composer and one-time owner of a chain of music stores, died in the county hospital today. His age was 57. He was widely known as the publisher of the famous "Memphis Blues," and he composed "Around Her Neck She Wore a Yellow Ribbon," "St. Louis Tickle," "Fireflies on Parade" and other songs.

Several luncheons will be given before the Garden Bazaar and card party in behalf of Save-A-Life Farm in Nyack, N. Y., tomorrow afternoon at Sherry's. Among the prpspective hostesses are Miss Frances Coleman, chairman of the benefit committee; Mrs. Frank X. Sadlier,

President Roosevelt reviewed the Army Day parade, sent to Congress an opinion of the Attorney General that the District of Columbia Minimum Wage Law is in effect in view of the recent decision of the Supreme Court in the Washington State minimum wage case,

Real Spring weather arrived yesterday, sending the mercury to 70 degrees, the highest since Nov. 3, and bringing forth a post-Easter fashion array of vivid apparel. But the balmy weather is not here to stay, the Weather Bureau warned.

Vladimir Golschmann, Fritz Reiner, George King Raudenbush, Willem van Hoogstraten and Alexander Smallens will direct the Stadium concerts of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra in its coming Summer season, it was announced yesterday.

Daily average crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,422,350 barrels, compared to 3,431,300 in the preceding week, a decline of 8,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 15,800 in the daily average output of Texas and a gain of 8,200 in Oklahoma were the important changes.
President Roosevelt today remarked that he felt more peaceful than he did twenty years ago, when the United States entered the World War.
The American Merchant Marine Library Association is virtually a Book-of-the-Seas Club, selecting books with which to furnish and replenish the libraries on board American ships for seamen.

Marin Marie, French marine artist who crossed the Atlantic alone last year in twenty days in the 42-foot motor boat Arielle, is to be awarded the Blue Water Medal of the Cruising Club of America at the dinner of that organization tomorrow night in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. He is to be a guest at the dinner.

The Senate ladies entertained Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt at their regular Tuesday sewing bee and cooperative luncheon today. While most Senators' wives sewed and folded bandages, the day's hostesses prepared the luncheon table in a kitchenless committee room in the Senate office building.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Frederick J. Lind of New York City, Paul Speer of New York City, John Jerome Manning of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:
Charles C. Harvey of Boston took the lead in the national masters' individual contract bridge championship at the end of the third round yesterday at the Park Central Hotel.

Ruling that a sit-down strike is a violation of the law, City Magistrate Jacob Eilperin in the municipal term of the magistrate's court in Brooklyn yesterday held twenty-eight draftsmen and engineers employed on technical jobs in the Park Department for the action of the Court of Special Sessions.

The importance of boys' clubs as character - building agencies was stressed yesterday afternoon by Sanford Bates, new director of the Boys Clubs of America and former director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

Mrs. Edith Hopner, widow of Robert H. Hopner, one of the original members of the New York Curb Exchange, yesterday filed suit in the State Supreme Court to have herself declared the real owner of the Curb seat held by her husband and now registered in the name of Eugene J. Mitchell.

Westchester County's Summer Theatre activities for 1937 will be launched Saturday night, when a new troupe known as the Manhattan Players will present "Biography" at the Westchester Woman's Club auditorium here. The company will open an eight-week engagement.

The Port of Philadelphia last month established new high records for March in the number of ships entering and leaving and in their total gross registered tonnage, according to David Tempest, statistician of the Board of Commissioners of Navigation.

Almost at the same time that Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy was declaring during his Libyan visit that he was the "protector of Islam," it is learned here, the Vatican, backed by the Italian Government, was 'sending a Roman Catholic mission to Ethiopia.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana, today launched its Spring motor oil advertising campaign with full page color advertisements headed "Sprig readyHas Cub." The opening insertion is appearing in color in many large metropolitan newspapers and in readysmaller space in the balance on the company's list of 1,596 daily and weekly newspapers.

Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill won her second golf championship of the Spring season today by scoring an easy victory in the annual Mid-South tourney with a sub-par 78, 79--157 for the 36-hole medal play event. Last week she won the North and South at Pinehurst.

East Side properties figured in most of the Manhattan sales reported yesterday. Apartment houses in University and Grant Avenues, in the Bronx, also changed hands. The five-story building at 446 East Eighty-eighth Street, on a plot 27 by 100 feet, was sold for cash by the estate of George Fennell to Raymond C. Smith through Joseph Goldsmith and Ernest I. Reichfield, brokers. Henry Schoenherr represented the sellers.

Two deaths from diphtheria were reported in the week ending last Saturday, bringing the total of deaths from this disease to sixteen for the thirteen weeks since the first of the year, as Compared with five deaths in the similar period last year, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.
The Rev. John J. Thompkins, S. J., who for the last year was attached to the Philippines Mission Bureau at St. Ignatius Loyola Church in this city, died early yesterday morning. He was 70 years old.

Westchester County's Summer Theatre activities for 1937 will be launched Saturday night, when a new troupe known as the Manhattan Players will present "Biography" at the Westchester Woman's Club auditorium here. The company will open an eight-week engagement.

The marriage of Miss Mildred Davis, daughter of John M. Davis of 1,035 Fifth Avenue, and the late Mrs. Davis, to John Bradley Gates, son of Albert Oscar Gates of New Haven, Conn., and the late Mrs. Gates, took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Ocean vessels using the Panama Canal paid tolls amounting to $2,355,149.04 in March, the Acting Governor of the Panama Canal reported today. There were 536 essels in this class, an increase of ten over the corresponding month in 1936, and a gain of $61,274,53 in tolls collected.

Lewis Fairbrother Burrough, who fought in the Spanish-American War as an ensign in the fleet naval reserve, died here today after a long illness. During the World War he was a personal aide to Admiral James Brennan, commandant of the Third Naval District, receiving the rank of lieutenant.

Flashing a strong rally in the last two rounds, Lew Feldman, 133 1/2, Brownsville veteran, earned a surprise draw with Freddie Miller, 128, Cincinnati, in the star eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 10,000 persons watched the contest.
