Senator Minton of Indiana has been receiving a lot of mail in the last S few days as a result of a "Dear General" letter, addressed to "General Arthur St. Clair, care Mrs. Clyde Wands Chapter D. A. R., Indianapolis, Ind."

Despite dozens of reports that Robert Irwin had been seen at various places in the Northeast, the police asserted last night they were without a definite lead in their search for the man they have accused of the murders of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter Veronica, and their roomer, Frank Byrnes, on the night before Easter.

Mr. EDWARD MORGAN FORSTER has an unfortunate habit of thinking, and perhaps a little tendency to the lugubrious. In The Spectator he has a piece written in the mood of an atrabilious coroner. It is called "Coronation Nightmare." He summons a procession of masked and goggled figures. Female of sex they seem.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion-Pioture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in private and public elementary and high schools. The list follows: Rialto-"Elephant Boy."

The first Japanese cherry blossoms burst into bloom overnight, and thousands of visitors got their first glimpse of the pinkish-white buds today. Weather forecasters predicted warmer and cloudy weather, thus assuring a beautiful scene over the week-end.

Professor Walter B. Pitkin's criticism of French-Canadians, written in a letter to a reader and published in a Toronto newspaper, was stamped "reprehensible" today by the Quebec Legislature, the only French-speaking legislative body in North America.

The new arrival this morning over at the Radio City Music Hall is RKO Radio's picturization of Sir James M. Barrie's "Quality Street," played by Katharine Hepburn, Franchot Tone, Fay Bainter, Eric Blore, Cora Witherspoon, Bonita Granville and Estelle Win-wood.
The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University presented its ninety-first theatrical production, a musical show entitled "Come Across," tonight in the ballroom of the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel.

An uncirculated specimen of the Panama-Pacific commemorative $50 gold coin issued in 1915 brought $290 yesterday at the sale of United States and foreign coins at the Morgenthau Galleries, 1 West Forty-seventh Street, conducted by Wayte Raymond and J. G. Macallister.

C. M. Coate resigned as a vice president of the General Printing Ink Company yesterday. J. F. Devine and L. S. Allstrum were elected vice presidents. The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent in New York for the stock of the Reliance Manufacturing Company.

While Art Sattler and George Aiken kept Seton Hall's batsmen at bay yesterday at Fordham Field, the Rams garnered eight hits from two of the three twirlers fired at them by the charges of Al Mamaux, one-time major league moundsman, to triumph, 7-0. It was Fordham's second victory in as many starts.

A vigorous movement to convert bonds into stocks, resulting in large savings to the New York Central Railroad, was revealed today in a ruling by the Interstate Commerce Commission in connection with a proposed bond issue by the road.

The interstate facilities of the Port of New York Authority were used by 4,386,671 vehicles in the first quarter of the year, representing an Increase of 1,016,928 or 30.2 per cent over the corresponding period last year, it was announced yesterday. All five facilities participated in the increase.

President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia left the Yugoslav capital this afternoon after receiving another tremendous ovation from the crowds assembled at the station to which he had been accompanied by the principal regent, Prince Paul, and his wife.
The East led the West, two victories to one, when the opening games of the East-West series for the national indoor polo championships ended at Squadron A Armory last night.

During my two terms of office the State has lived well within its income. We have had in these years more than a balanced budget. In addition, the accumulated deficit of approximately one hundred million dollars which existed when I took office has been reduced to an estimated deficit of only twenty-one millions.

After hearing the reading of a special message sent in by Governor Lehman, in which he put responsibility for balancing his $370,000,000 executive budget upon the Republican majority in the lower house, the Assembly Republicans today permitted the budget to be thrown out of balance by withholding votes which it was within their power to furnish.

Ward Morehouse, the peripatetic theatre itemizer for The Sun, has sat him down and spun him a yarn, "Miss Quis," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening. For Mr. Morehouse is a bustling fellow who can appear in several Times Square places simultaneously and rush away with whatever he needs.

A $5,000 tax exemption on Trinity Cathedral rectory here was denied to the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey in a decision today by the State Board of Tax Appeals, which ruled that the dwelling was not occupied by the "officiating clergyman," as required bylaw.
N. H. Coit, vice president and general manager of the Broad River Power Company, announced yesterday that the company's name had been changed to the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company.

Emphasizing the importance of immediate immunization of children against diphtheria, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday that almost half as many deaths from the disease had occurred here in the first thirteen weeks of 1937 as in all of 1936.

A charge of disorderly conduct against Assistant Corporation Counsel William J. Leonard, 46 years old, of 75 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Malbin in Bay Ridge court, Brooklyn, at the request of the complainant, Police Captain Michael Richter of the Poplar Street station, Brooklyn.

The average price of real estate bond issues for the three months ended March 31, 1937, advanced 1.8 per cent, according to the April 1 Amott-Baker Realty Bond Averages, which are based upon 200 selected issues of properties in New York, Buffalo, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and other Eastern cities.
Officials of the World Two-Way Trade Fair voted yesterday to defer until Monday their decision as to continuing plans for the exhibition scheduled to be held here May 10 to 22.

Details of options to buy 13,500 shares of the common stock of the Grand Union Company were containted in the report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The report covered the fifty-three weeks ended Jan. 2.

Lady Houston, eccentric millionaire and imperialist, left an estate valued at [Pound]1,528,083, it was shown today when her will was made public. The estate was much smaller than had been popularly believed. When she died, on Dec. 29, it was unofficially estimated that she was worth [Pound]5,000,000.

Mrs. Emily Howell Cooper, widow of Frank C. Cooper, died at her home here last night after a long illness in her seventy-third year. She was the daughter of Benjamin F. Howell, late postmaster of Riverhead.

It was officially confirmed today that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economics Minister and president of the Reichsbank, would go to Brussels next Tuesday for what is described in the official formula as a return visit to the Governor of the Belgian National Bank.

Federal Judge William Clark gave final approval today to reorganization of the Cuba Railroad Company, a New Jersey Corporation, under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Under the plan, the maturity date of $3,000,000 of bonds was advanced ten years from Dec. 1, 1936.

The expected general release within the next few days of copy thanking the public for its -patience and waiting for Chrysler cars will be the first gun in an intensive advertising and selling campaign by the Chrysler division, which will get under way as soon as sufficient production has been released, officials and the Lee Anderson Advertising Company announced today.

Alexander Pompez, wanted in New York on extortion charges in connection with that city's rackets investigation, obtained an injunction today temporarily restraining Mexican authorities from returning him to the United States.

The Glasgow .Rangers were returned Scottish Football League champions today for the - twentythird time since the -organization was formed in 1891. The Light Blues made certain of the honor by defeating the Hamilton Academicals, 5-1, on the latter's ground, while Clyde and Aberdeen struggled ninety minutes to a scoreless draw.

Taking the lead in the first inning, the Williams College baseball team gained an 8-4 victory over Haverford today. Led by Bill Stradley, who made three hits in five times at bat, the visitors scored twice in each of the first, third and fifth innings and once in the fourth and eighth.

Lee Pattison, manager of the Metropolitan Opera Spring season, will talk this afternoon at 2:15 o'clock at a meeting of the National Opera Club, at the Waldorf-Astoria. An all-Schumann program will be heard tonight at the WPA Federal Music Project Midtown Community Center.

A stroller on Twenty-third Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues saw a white Russian wolf hound gasping in a parked sedan with windows shut, released the animal and started a rather odd series of incident about 6:30 o'clock last night.

Jerome Av (11-2856), w s, 120 ft s of 170th St, 50x125; 1,375 Jerome Av. Corp. to Theological Seminary of the Presbyterian Church, Princeton, N. J.; 4 per cent; $35,000. Nelson Av, 1,715 (11-2876), Macray Realty Corp. to Solgreen Realty Corp., 384 E 149th St, 4 years; $12,000.
An open break between teamsters and longshoremen over which of two international unions shall have jurisdiction over warehousemen started in Oakland today.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has become a volunteer fireman at the Hill Top Engine Company's fire house here. The membership privileges include use of the player piano and all recreational facilities, according to Oscar Bodelsen, president of the fire company, who announced Mr. Rockefeller's election today.

Latest developments in the tangle of affairs of the Utilities Power and Light Corportion, Chicago's $400,000,000 utility holding company, were the approval today by Federal Judge William H. Holly of a request for $15,000 to finance an investigation of the company and an announcement that Harley L. Clarke had retired as chairman of the board of the Indianapolis Power and Light Company,

ALBERT--Margaret, on April 7, beloved daughter of the late Louis and Lavina. Albert (nee Heath). Funeral from her late residence, 8 Parkview Drive, Pelham, N. Y., on Friday, April 9, 9:30 A. M. Requiem Mass at St. Catherine's Church, Pelham, N. Y., 10 A. M. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery.

A complete new board of directors was elected yesterday at the annual meeting in Jersey City of the Isle Royale Copper Company. The new board is composed almost entirely of interests affiliated with Paine, Webber Co. and the Copper Range Company.

In view of the distressing series of accidents with which aviation, both on scheduled airlines and in miscellaneous operations, has been bedeviled of late, it is particularly gratifying to note that recognition is to be paid to remarkable records of air safety which have been set up.

67th St., 32 East; to 5-story light manufacturing and showrooms; Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av., owner; Rene C. Bragnoni, architect; cost, $5,000. Bronx Colden Av., w. s., 250 it. s. of Allerton Av.; seven 2-story brick dwellings. 21x45; Migjos Realty Co., Inc., Joseph Migliori, president, 2,556 Radcliffe Av., owner;

Governor Elmer Benson today censured "conservatives" in the State Senate who criticized him in a proposed resolution as the "inspiration behind the 'peoples lobby' seizure of the chamber" Monday night.

An underwriting group headed by Cassatt Co., Inc., and including Burr Co., Inc.; King, Crandall Latham, Inc., and G. H. Walker Co., will offer today 30,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $50 par value and 15,000 shares of common stock of $2 par value of Edison Brothers Stores, Inc.

The strike of WPA technical workers in this city ended last night, after Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, had promised to transmit to Washington "with appropriate comments" a brief drawn up by four organizations of relief workers, detailing their grievances and objections to proposed cuts in wages and non-relief personnel.

Arthur DePersia, 29 years old, a political writer for The Long Island Daily Press, most of whose editorial employes went on strike Monday, was served with a summons for disorderly conduct yesterday after he was accused of assaulting Warren Bennett, who was on a picket line in front of Jamaica police headquarters.
Effects play an important part in the Walter Hackett formula and in "London After Dark," presented at the Apollo Theatre here tonight, he introduces a realistic display of familiar London scenes.

Thirty men, headed by Ben Gray, Ohio leader of the Worker's Alliance, a WPA organization, occupied Governor Davey's office tonight after parading with signs appealing to the Governor to see that they did not "starve."

Cannon St., 54, 25x100; ?? Brandt to executor of will of Harmon W. Hendricks, care of City Bank Farmers Trust Co.; mtg., $20,000, held by executor. 110th St., 130 E., 18.9x101; Leonhard Realty Co. to Reginald Thomas, 30 W. 128th St.; mtg., $20,000.
Mrs. James Reynolds McCafferty of Deal, N. J., gave a luncheon yesterday in the terrace room of the Plaza for Mrs. Harold G. Hoffman, wife of the Governor of New Jersey.

Blasting 3,028 pins into the pits, the Reinhart Radio Reserves of Philadelphia gained third place in the five-man-team race of the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress championships last night before a cheering gallery of 3,000.

The election of four members to the board of trustees of the Rockefeller Foundation was announced yesterday. The new trustees are President Harold Willis Dodds of Princeton University; Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman, editor, of Richmond, Va.;

Ask any Senator on the Judiciary Committee if he believes the testimony on the President's Supreme Court Bill has changed any votes. If he is candid he will answer in the negative. Both sides have merely been fortified with arguments in support of positions previously assumed.

Here and there: An unusual fishing trip in which boat owners will join is planned for Florida next month. The cruise will start May 1 from Miami and after a dinner at the Key Largo Anglers Club the party will go up the West Coast to Fort Myers and then back to Stuart and Miami on the east coast during the sixteen-day expedition.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals set aside yesterday in a unanimous decision the conviction of William F. Warms, acting captain; and Eben S. Abbott, chief engineer of the Ward liner Morro Castle, Who had been found guilty of: negligence that resulted in the loss of 134 lives when that vessel burned on Sept. 8, 1934, off Asbury Park.
Last month witnessed the broadest and strongest industrial advance in Canada of the present economic revival, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Leila Peoples, daughter of Rear Admiral Christian Joy Peoples, U. S. N., and Mrs. Peoples of Washington, D. C., to Lieutenant Homer B. Wheeler, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. P. Wheeler of Asheboro, N C.
Any church containing a Bishop's chair is a cathedral. If the Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Cincinnati wishes to make an automobile

The 390 Fifth Av. Corp., Max Weinstein, president, gave to the Empire Trust Company, as trustee, a trust mortgage for $1,287,500 on the southwest corner of 5th Av. and 36th St., 95 1/2 feet on the avenue and 166.10 on the street, covered by the nine-story Russek's Fifth Avenue, Inc., building.

Meeting of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Republican Problems and Opportunities," William R. Castle. Metropolitan Museum of Art, "The Art of Italy," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "The Egyptian Collection," general tour, 2 P. M.;

Since this country's steel production has never entirely relinquished its distinction as the "barometer of trade," the statement for March, just published by the Iron and Steel Institute, is interesting. It shows that last month's output of 5,229,431 tons had been exceeded only once on the past monthly record-by the 5,286,246 of May, 1929.

Wilbur Hess of Houston supplied the first major upset of the seventh annual River Oaks tennis tournament today by eliminating Joel Hunt of Los Angeles, 6--1, 6--3, in a fourth-round match. Hunt was seeded third. Hess was not seeded.

Navy scored its first baseball triumph of the young season today, conquering Harvard, 12-10, in a loosely played but exciting game. The contest went seven and a half innings and was called because of darkness after more than two and a half hours of play.

The activities of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, which started an organized campaign in 1908 to cut down babies' "sore eyes," has reduced the number of children in the schools for the blind in the United States by 75 per cent, according to the annual report of the society.

Results of a mock election by the proportional representation system, conducted under auspices of the League of Women Voters last week at the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries, were made public yesterday.

Gabriel Amand, secretary general of the Paris Exposition, died here today at the age of 62.. He was a pioneer in aviation and a former director of several airplane companies. In 1911 he was chief official of the Paris-to-Rome air race.

Philadelphia Electric Company first lien and refunding mortgage gold bonds 4 1/2 per cent series, due in 1967, and first and refunding mortgage gold bonds 4 per cent series due in 1971, which have been called for redemption, have been suspended from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange.

GOLDMAN, HENRY (April 4).Estate, more than $20,000. To Babette Goldman, widow, executrix, 998 5th Av., real and personal property and one-third residue in trust; Florence G. Vogel, daughter, Sherwood Av., Greenwich, Conn.; Robert Goldman, 35 E. 76th St., and Henry Goldman Jr., 21 E. 69th St., sons, executors, twoninths residue each and remainders in one-ninth residue each;

Word has been received here of the marriage on Monday in London of Miss Kathleen Winifred ArcherShee, daughter of Lady ArcherShee of Ascot, to Captain Christopher Dudley Miller of the Tenth Royal Hussars, which took place at the Brompton Oratory..

Representatives here of the Bellanca Aircraft Company of New Castle, Del., denied yesterday reports that twenty fast airplanes recently sold to Air France, the French Government-controlled air transport system, were destined for Spain.

B. J. Becker of Philadelphia won the individual masters' contract bridge championship yesterday afternoon in the tournament conducted at the Park Central Hotel under the auspices of the American Bridge League.

Frank Parker, the country's second ranking netman, departed for San Francisco yesterday, where he will make his bid for one of the singles berths on the United States Davis Cup team which is to face Japan in the first round of the American Zone play at the Olympic Club on April 30-May 2.
The Hershey Chocolate Corporation is a $20,000,000 enterprise which nets about $5,000,000, year after year, and pours practically all these earnings into philanthropies in and around Hershey, Pa.

Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., defending the world's pocket billiard championship in the tournament at Ponzi's Academy, defeated young Irving. Crane of Livonia, N. Y., by 125 to 68 in twenty-five innings last night.

Twelve grand larceny indictments which had been on file in General Sessions since May, 1930, against Abraham Rayman in the failure of the Columbia Finance Corporation were dismissed by Judge Allen yesterday on motion of layman's lawyer, Joab H. Banton, former District Attorney.

Factory sales by members of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, which includes all producers except the Ford Motor Company, amounted to 350,078 cars and trucks in March, the local office announced yesterday.
The city-wide strike of truck drivers and helpers which brought twenty-four days of disorder and tension and a two-day general strike ended at noon today in an agreement for a fifteen-day truce.

Mrs. Leonides J. Calvoceressi has arranged the bazaar to be conducted by five Greek girls in costume which will be a feature of the bridge and tea to be held this afternoon in the garden of the Ambassador.

Six defending champions and twelve United' States 1936 Olympic swimmers are among the 107 entries inthe ten-event National A. A. U. indoor swimming championship meet that. will open tomorrow in the Payne Whitney gymnasium pool at Yale University.
Isaac Liberman, president of Arnold Constable Co., told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that he was "optimistic as to the prospects of the retail business for the current year."
The decline in prices in virtually all classifications of bonds continued in varying degrees yesterday in moderate trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

President Roosevelt's court reorganization proposal was assailed tonight by Frank 0. Lowden as the forerunner of a centralized government, destroying local self-government and having the power to determine all prices and wages.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: Planting cotton was somewhat more active during the week in the southeastern portion of the belt, but cold weather delayed seeding in the West. In general, much soil has been prepared in nearly all portions, while progress of seeding is near normal in eastern districts.
Real estate transactions in the Bronx reported yesterday comprised properties of varied types, located in widely scattered sections of the borough.

A determined campaign is under way, it was stated today, by leaders in the movement to induce Congress to reconsider its action in approving a site and design for the $3,000,000 Thomas Jefferson Memorial in Washington and appropriating funds for its construction.

In a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, the Federated Department Stores reported that the board of directors and F. R. Lazarus Co., a subsidiary, had voted to Robert Lazarus a salary of $75,000 a year, commencing on Feb. 1, 1937.
Liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here early today, with wheat and corn futures generally declining 2 cents a bushel before the selling ran its course.

Clyde Beatty sulked in the squad room of the West Forty-seventh Street police station at about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon while associates arranged to free him in $500 bond on a charge of cruelty to animals.

Demands of the Workers Alliance, composed of beneficiaries of the WPA relief program, for an immediate 20 per cent increase in rates of pay and a $4,000,000,000 relief program for the next fiscal year were rejected today by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

One run in the eleventh inning broke a tie that had endured since the sixth inning and gave the Milwaukee Brewers of the American Association a 7-6 victory over Jersey City, the Giants' International League farm team, today.

The sit-down strike of forty gravediggers and helpers in Holy Cross Cemetery went into its second day today and five more coffins were placed in receiving vaults, bringing the number awaiting burial to twelve. Four coffins were placed in vaults yesterday and three were put temporarily in other cemeteries.

Not even a duststorm could interfere today with the victory march of the Yankees as they feasted for the last time this year on Texas League pitching. Manager Joe McCarthy's champions made the Fort Worth Cats victims of their eleventh straight triumph and their eighteenth in twenty-one starts. The score was 6 to 3.

Martin Schlossman and Harry Weiss, each 27 years old, received mandatory sentences of twenty years to life imprisonment yesterday for kidnapping Paul H. Wendel in a plot to compel him to "confess" the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

Forty husky firemen were delighted yesterday at the chance to compete in an elimination spelling bee to pick a team of fifteen, which will engage the Chicago Fire Department team in a radio spelling bee on Saturday afternoon over WJZ.

Legislation to remove the "gold clause" from contracts binding Canadian debtors to pay in gold was introduced in the House of Commons today by Charles Dunning, Minister of Finance. It is called the Gold Clause Act, 1937.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the American Tobacco Company at 75 Exchange Place, this morning, Paul M. Hahn, vice president, attribute a 25 per cent decline in profits for the last year in part to a sales-promotion campaign.

International 6-meter yacht racing, which will be carried on here through April 20 with the Prince of Wales Trophy, the Governor Cubitt Cup and the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Challenge Trophy as prizes, opened today with an initial victory for Eldon H. and Kenneth F. Trimmingham's Norwegian-built Saga, the Bermuda entry that was the victor last year and now is defending.
Walter P. Chrysler and John L. Lewis posed in a long handshake at the request of photographers after last night's Chrysler peace pact was signed at Lansing.

The Estonian Ministry of Social Affairs has completed a project for the organization of labor camps in which Estonia proposes to confine persons who refuse to provide for their families or try to escape taxes or for other reasons are considered errant citizens.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When Governor Martin signed the Washington State Social Securities Bill, which provides a pension of $33.33 a month for disabled tuberculosis patients as well as other handicapped citizens, he helped to place the final quietus upon one of the cruelest scourges that has ever afflicted mankind.

The Manufacturers Trust Company has sold the garage occupying the block front on Third Avenue, between Warren and Baltic Streets, Brooklyn, to the S. E. Motor Hire Corporation through a subsidiary company.

Movements In the livestock markets here today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 18,000 including 7,000 direct. Market uneven, steady to 10 cents lower than Tuesday's average, mostly steady to 5 cents lower; late top one load $10.30;

State banks which are not members of the Federal Reserve System and their employes are subject to the old-age pension and unemploymentinsurance provisions of the Social Security Act, even though such banks are depositories of postal savings or may be able to meet the requirements for these deposits, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.

The body of Samuel Wittlin, 38 years old, a former Assistant Corporation Counsel and later connected with the Department of Labor in Washington, was found in the debris of his tenth-floor apartment at 245 East Twenty-first street shortly after 2 P. M. yesterday, following an explosion.
Chester T. Lane, assistant- general counsel to the Securities and Exchange Commission; John S. Linen, vice-president, Chase National Bank; Colonel Henry W.

One of the great fallacies of the retail business today is the "loss leader" promotion of merchandise, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., declared last night at a dinner meeting of the Housewares Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania. People who respond to "bargains" at no profit are too shrewed to buy articles at a long profit, Mr. Collins said.

THE YEARS, by Virginia Woolf. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50.) A new novel. BUCKSKIN BREECHES, by Phil Stong. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A historical novel. MODERN BUILDING, ITS NATURE, PROBLEMS AND FORMS, by Walter Curt Behrendt.

The eighty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Mills College, at Oakland, Calif., second oldest women's college in the United States, was celebrated' last night at a dinner of the Mills College Club of New York at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

In a decision yesterday Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in the Federal court in Brooklyn held that jewelry estimated to be worth from $50,000 to $250,000 purchased by John M. Phillips, known at the time of his death on July 3, 1928, as the "Sewer Pipe King" of Queens County, is the property of Mrs. Marion Phillips Cassidy, his widow.

Stocks fell 1 to 6 points on rumors of gold price change; turnover, 2,289,590 shares. United States Government bonds steadier at fractionally lower levels, convertible issues off sharply, other groups irregular; trans actions. $12,157,200.

Under the heaviest selling pressure experienced in several months, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke $2 a bale yesterday to end with losses of 29 to 38 points. A combination of foreign and domestic liquidation carried both old crop positions below 14 cents a pound, May selling 70 points under last week's high record for the season.

Surrogate Foley reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on a motion attacking the constitutionality of an amendment to the New York State Tax Law which permits the State to tax "limited powers of appointment."

Three subway loiterers, who had been called for trial last Tuesday in General Sessions on a first-degree murder indictment in the strangling of Edgar L. Eckert, 54 years old, a director and assistant treasurer of the Rogers Peet Company, in the Forty-second Street Eighth Avenue subway station last May 14, pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder.
New York City's tax collections for 1937 will exceed substantially those of 1936, on the basis of taxes collected since they became due last Thursday, the Finance Department reported yesterday.

Bombarding five pitchers for twenty hits, including five doubles and a triple, Long Island University registered its sixth straight baseball victory of the season yesterday when it routed the City College nine, 20 to 10, in a free-hitting game at Lewisohn Stadium.

Victor Scharf, through Huberth Huberth, in 36 Central Park South; Jerome Herskowitz, through Pease Elliman, in 983 Park Av.; James J. Buttridge, in 414 E. 52d St.; Miss M. S. Winn, in 17 W. 67th St.; Selected Apartments Service, broker.

Miss Mary W. Dewson, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced yesterday the appointment of Mrs. Thomas F. McAllister of Grand Rapids, Mich., as head of the women's division of the committee.

Extradition proceedings to bring General Plutarco Elias Calles, former Mexican President, back here from exile in San Diego, Calif., are likely to be instituted by the Mexican Government, according to newspapers here.

By the overwhelming vote of 75 to 3, the Senate passed today and sent to the House a concurrent resolution intended as a rebuke by Congress to both sides in labor controversies. The three negative votes were cast by Senators Borah, Frazier and Lundeen.

Clicking off a high run of 43, Anthony LaVia triumphed over Richard Goldsticker, 175--68, in twenty-seven innings in one of four contests in the Poggenburg 18.2 balkline billiard tournament last night at the Lawler Manhattan Academy. The loser's best run was 13.

Mrs. Edwin S. Townsend of Center Island, Oyster Bay, is at the Savoy-Plaza. Miss Jacqueline Godwin has returned to 125 East Fifty-seventh Street from a trip to South America. Mrs. Charles Eliot and Mrs. Eliot Dudley have come from Chestnut Hill, Mass., to the Weylin.

Representative Kenney, New Jersey Democrat, asserted today that the Postoffice Department went "beyond its authority" in a recent ruling prohibiting publication of Irish sweepstakes results in newspapers having privilege of the mail.

Edward FitzGerald, veteran of the World War and a reporter for The Evening Bulletin, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital after an illness of two days. Death was due to complications resulting from an infection of the arm.

An 18-year-old grandfather and a 5-year-old father enjoyed the sun in Central Park yesterday and strove to outdo each other in displaying justifiable pride. The cause of the rivalry was a thirty-ninepound female baby bison, born at 1 A. M. Tuesday in a sandy enclosure south of the zoo's seal pool.
Harpers have just received the manuscript for a new volume of poems by Edna St. Vincent Millay. It is hoped that the volume may be published early in June. The title is "Conversation at Midnight."

The fourth victory of the meeting for the Detroit-owned Bomar Stable was scored under a hot sun and over a rough track today when Benjam captured the eleventh Kindergarten Stakes. This is the Jean Valjean colt which was campaigned in Florida with only medium success.

FIVE straight for the Rangers in the hockey play-offs! Come what may along Grand River Avenue in Detroit in the concluding clashes of the big rink riot, the Rangers have bewildered not only their opponents but many innocent bystanders by their play in the past two weeks.

Fire destroyed one and one-half square miles of flimsy residences in the Tondo section of Manila today, leaving an estimated 25,000 persons homeless, one dead, eleven injured and property damage estimated at $1,000,000,.

Mrs. Wilfred H. Winans was elected president of the Woman's Club of New Rochelle at a meeting today in the auditorium of the clubhouse. Other officers chosen were Mrs. Luman T. Thurber, first vice president; Mrs. Hubert A. Hagar, second vice president; Mrs. Harold B.
A Spring clean-up drive to improve the appearance of Broadway and the adjacent streets has been started by the Broadway Association with the cooperation of the Department of Sanitation.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas for the week ended April 3 showed a decrease of 20 per cent under the same calendar week last year, which, however, was in the active pre-Easter trade period, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

Weary searchers found eight burned and broken bodies late today at the mountain spot southeast of McNary where a luxurious skyliner crashed Saturday with eight persons aboard. Bodies of Pilot Glen Moser and Co-Pilot Joe Wolfolk, half-burned, were still strapped to their seats in the smashed and charred wreckage.

City inspectors are watching the milk-price war closely for any attempts by cut-rate dealers or retailers to adulterate the milk or give short measure, it was learned yesterday. Milk continued to be sold for as little as 5 cents a quart in a few sections, and at 6 and 7 cents in many others.
The Mitchell Anti-Lynching Bill was sidetracked by the House today on a roll-call vote of 257 to 122, through a coalition of Southern Democrats and Republicans.

Hoping to make it three straight over the Detroit Red Wings, and bring the Stanley Cup back to this city for the first time since 1933, the New York Rangers left, the Grand Central Station last night in a confident mood.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 6 unless specified: Manila to Hong Kong: Isabel, August. At San Pedro: Bushnell, Saratoga. At Mare Island Yard: Boggs, Lamberton, Preston, Smith. Badger, 52d St., Brooklyn, to sea, April 7. Brazos, at San Diego.

New York University defeated Columbia, 5-2, yesterday at Baker Field in their annual baseball contest. The Lions outhit the Violet, 11 to 5, and in eight. of the innings. the Blue had men stranded on the bases. Therein lies the reason for the downfall of the Morningsiders.

The Columbia rowing squad will make its only official competitive appearance on home waters on May 1, when it meets Yale and Pennsylvania in the Blackwell Cup regatta on the Harlem, it was announced yesterday by Manager William Davenport.
St. John's Prep and St. Augustine's High turned in victories in Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. inaugural games that marked the heavy scholastic baseball program yesterday.

PHIL STONG hints his intentions and his method in the title of his new novel, "Buckskin Breeches" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50). It is a book made up of the most durable stuffs of American history, filled with the neglected, intimate details of pioneer living.

Preliminary figures of the electric output of subsidiaries of the North American Company indicate an increase of approximately 12 per cent for the first quarter of 1937, compared with the corresponding period of 1936, J. F. Fogarty, president, announced yesterday.

It is not unfair to say that the settlement which Mr. LEWIS has obtained from the Chrysler Corporation, after a month's strike, with its loss of wages and production, is not greatly different from the one he might have obtained without calling a strike at all.
Manhattan had the advantage over Columbia yesterday in a twohour scrimmage at Baker Field, the first actual contact work of their respective Spring football drills.
Governor Lehman sent a message to the Assembly demanding that branch vote the fourth cent of the gasoline tax or else come forward with an alternative revenue-raising plan.

As a further adjustment of openmarket rates to the rise in yields on government securities, leading banks here yesterday advanced from 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 per cent the rate of interest charged by them on four to six months' loans on Stock Exchange collateral.
A revival of rumors that the Treasury might reduce its buying price for gold was responsible yesterday for a sharp drop in foreign exchange rates here.

David W. Peck, attorney for W. E. Hutton Co., charged today that counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission was guilty of "unconstitutional and unwarranted search and seizure" of private records.

A General Motors official commented today that the "joke" strike in the Olds Motor Works at Lansing last night was a costly one for 4,500 employes on the night shift. They lost, he said, $30,000 in wages.
Injuries suffered in a fall in his home here several weeks ago resulted early today in the death of Justice Robert F. Thompson of the Appellate Division, Fourth Department. He was 66 years old.

Miss Maudmary Spellane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Spellane of Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, was married to Dr. Vincent J. Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Murray of Elm Avenue, Flushing, yesterday afternoon.

As a result of speech training at Fordham College, such mispronunciations as "dese," "dem," and "dose" are almost never heard, but the students insist on dropping the final "g" in such words as "running," "talking" and "speaking," according to a survey at the Manhattan division of the college in the Woolworth Building, it was announced yesterday.

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Edwin Levisohn and Isidor Ninor of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: 539--Ohio Bell Telephone Co., applt., v. Public Utilities Commission of Ohio. Argument continued and concluded for appellees.
Second New York Recital Given at Barbizon-Plaza Concert Hall A good-sized gathering heard Leslie Frick, mezzo-soprano, give her second New York recital last night in the Barbizon-Plaza Concert Hall.

Harrington Putnam, former Supreme Court justice, official referee of the Supreme Court, Second Judicial District, and noted longdistance walker and mountain climber, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 404 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 85 years old.

The diplomatic intervention of Germany on behalf of Germans in Southwest Africa has given to a relatively minor issue an importance transcending the borders of that former German protectorate, now administered as a mandate by the Union of South Africa.

Diplomats' molars ached unchecked today, for the police had arrested, for the third time in three years, Vasili Samoilovitch Yudelovitch, the dentist who has been taking care of virtually the whole foreign colony.

Bids on the first two contracts on the Northern State Parkway in Nassau County will be opened by the State Department of Public Works on Tuesday, April 20, it was announced yesterday by the Long Island State Park Commission.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals. Arthur L. Tallman and Isidor Niner of New York were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4051-The United States v. International Graphite and Electrode Corporation. Argued.

Proposed neutrality legislation as outlined by Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, yesterday before 500 members of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor was denounced immediately from the floor by two proponents of peace by collective security as a national shirking of moral responsibility.

Dwellings and a lot in Westchester County were disposed of by banks yesterday. The Bowery Savings Bank sold to Gladys B. McNear the eight-room dwelling at 21 Vanderbilt Avenue; Scarsdale, through Chauncey B. Griffen, broker.
Mr. and Mrs. Carl Churchill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Churchill, to Harry Broadbent Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald A. Rose of East Kingston, N. Y.

Stockholders of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., have authorized the directors to sell the company's holdings of 20,868 shares of stock in the Colombian Petroleum Company on the basis of a price not less than $2,050,000.

Turpentine firm, 37 1/4c., sales 97 barrels, receipts 171 barrels, shipments 316 barrels, stock 23,590 barrels. Resin firm, sales 800, receipts 449, shipments 350, stock 45,008. Quote B, $7.00; D, $7.10; E, $7.50; F to M, $8.12 1/2; N, $8.15: WG, $8.20-30; WW, X, $9.00.

While rumors are circulating with increasing insistence that Colonel General Hermann Goering, the German Air Minister, will return to Rome toward the end of the month to discuss recent developments in the Spanish situation with Premier Benito Mussolini, the Italian press has thrown itself with redoubled vigor into a campaign intended to prove that the powers supporting the Valencia government are guilty of gross infractions of the nonintervention agreement.

Opposition will be shown by retailers to the lowering of discounts on boys' and students' clothing from the previous basis of 10 per cent -or more to large buyers to a maximum of 7 per cent for the Fall season, it was learned here yesterday.

Apparent consumption of finished steel in the United States last year amounted to 2,350 pounds for the average family, compared with 1,700 pounds in 1935, according to the American Iron Steel Institute.
Miss Mary A. Curtis of 16 East Ninety-sixth Street, who was principal of Public School 20 in the Bronx for thirty-three years, died yesterday of pneumonia in St. Vincent's Hospital at the age of 80.
Purchases of fuel, material and supplies by the Class I railroads were greater in 1936 than in any year since 1930, according to a statement issued by the Association of American Railroads yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the following additional applications for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market had been received from New York City (symbols-S, Sole Proprietor; P, Partnership; C, Corporation):

Many who knew the liner Majestic when she was the largest and proudest vessel flying the British flag will look on sadly as she sails tomorrow from Southampton harbor into "exile" off Rosyth Scotland.

Prince Chichibu, eldest brother of Emperor Hirohito of Japan, and his consort, Princess Chichibu, sailed for England yesterday afternoon after a twenty-nine-hour visit in New York City. They will represent the Japanese Empire at the coronation of King George VI.

Kenneth Thomson, executive secretary of the Screen Actors Guild, who failed in recent negotiations with producers here to obtain recognition of the Guild and collective bargaining rights, will return today to Hollywood, where he will hold a conference with producers within the next two weeks, he said yesterday.

J. Halperin Co., Inc., has arranged a first-mortgage. loan of $175,000 for ten years for Fox Levick on the new apartment house on- the northeast corner of Austin St. and Payne Pl., Forest Hills, Queens. The house contains 59 apartments.

The Baltimore Athletic Club, in the opening game of its lacrosse-season today, was forced to the utmost in defeating Princeton 8 to 6. In the final quarter the Tigers had everything their own way and tallied four times, while holding the club men scoreless. Frank S.

A demand for American athletes from abroad that presages a very busy Summer campaign in foreign fields was announced yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union. Five countries have sent invitations for teams of track and field athletes, the latest arriving yesterday from the Amateur Athletic Association of England.

Mrs. Florence E. Roberts, wife of City Councilman George I. Roberts, died at the New Rochelle Hospital last night. She was 42 years old. Flags on municipal buildings were lowered to half-mast and City Court was adjourned in her memory today.

Beating Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, former world champion, in twenty-three moves, Paul Keres, the young expert representing Estonia in the international chess masters' tournament at the Grand Hotel in Cliftonville, held first place at the close of the seventh round today.

The Superior Electoral Tribunal today validated the election by the Sao Paulo State Assembly of Cardozo de Mello to the post of Governor. The election was contested by the Opposition on Constitutional grounds, it being contended that the Governor should have been elected by popular vote.

William A. Schick Jr., retired partner of Scovell, Wellington Co., accountants, and an intercollegiate track champion while at Harvard in the class of '05, died today of a heart ailment at his home in Brookline, at the age of 55.

The Hawaiian Islands and St. Louis won three championships apiece, leaving one each to Bloomington, Ill., and the Chilocco (Okla.) Indian School, in the final bouts tonight of the National A. A. U. junior boxing tournament.

Six charitable, religious and educational institutions are to receive legacies totaling $30,000 under the will of Julia Jay Pierrepont, a member of one of the oldest families of Brooklyn. The will was filed for probate yesterday. Miss Pierrepont, who lived at 1 Pierrepont Place, died on Feb. 8.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, asked the Congressional sugar bloc today to amend the administration's new sugar bill so as to prohibit importation of refined sugar from Cuba.

Plans to reorganize the Wabash Railway should take definite shape this year, according to the annual report of the protective committee for its stockholders, which was issued yesterday. Winslow S. Pierce is chairman of the committee.

A measure aimed at preventing strikes and lockouts in industry and providing penalties for interference with the rights of employers and employes was moved for second reading by W. R. Clubb, Labor Minister, in the Manitoba Legislature today.

With one of Oklahoma's celebrated dust storms enveloping the scene to give it genuinely local coloring, the good folk of near-by Meeker joined forces with those of Shawnee today to give Carl Hubbell, the Giants' celebrated left-hander, a rousing homecoming.

Laconia Av. (16-4364), s w cor of Waring Av., 200x100; D'Agosttna Holdings. Inc., to Schapowal Construction Corp., 1,721 Hobart Av. Crotona Av. (11-3103), w s, 170 ft s of 187th St., 87x80; Antonio Cattano to Jaypol Holdings, Inc., 1,475 Broadway, mtg. $70,000.

Continuing its drive against theatre ticket agents who fail to stamp prices properly on the backs of tickets, the Internal Revenue Bureau arrested six of them yesterday. United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter held them in $500 bail each for a hearing Wednesday.

Two cases affecting the Alabama Unemployment Insurance Law, which is dependent upon existence of the Federal Social Security Act, were argued for three hours in the Supreme Court today and the way was cleared fort another debate tomorrow to end the Alabama cases and take up a direct challenge of the law.

A total of 39,157 tons of iron and steel valued at $1,671,272 was imported into the United States during February, according to figures made public today by the Metal and Minerals Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Utica, N. Y., has invited tenders for a new issue of $300,000 of emergency relief and public improvement bonds, award of which will be made on April 15. The bonds are to be dated Feb. 1, 1937, and mature Feb. 1, 1938 to 1947. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.
As the result of negotiations with Canada, the final diplomatic obstacle to joint operation of a transatlantic airline by British and American companies has been removed.
A complaint has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission charging unfair competition against Chanel, Inc., of 35 West Thirty-fourth Street, New York City, dealers in toilet articles.

All commodity futures declined sharply yesterday in the most active trading in many weeks. Continued profit-taking and hedge selling caught stop-loss orders as the markets continued downward. Rubber, copper, hides, lead, coffee and zinc futures were the heaviest losers.

Characterizing them as "hypocritical scoundrels" who posed as "respectable professional and business men and honest union leaders," Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook imposed prison sentences yesterday afternoon on the seven men convicted of conspiracy and extortion in the restaurant racket trial.
Speedy enactment of Governor Lehman's new minimum wage bill for women and minors in industry was forecast today when the measure was reported in the Senate by the Labor and Industry Committee.

The Federal Grand Jury Association went on record unanimously yesterday in opposition to the President's Supreme Court plan, declaring that "so fundamental a change" should be submitted to the people as a constitutional amendment.

Madrid celebrated the fifth month-end of the Rebel siege by rejoicing today over an important victory last night on the Cordoba front. Next to the victory last month on the Guadalajara front, it was the greatest thus far achieved by the Loyalist arms, and, like the one at Guadalajara, it was won in the open country by outmanoeuvring and outfighting the Rebels.

The warning that "soda fountain orgies" and other "dietetic busts" may cause serious health hazards, and in extreme cases even death, to diabetics and persons who must observe strict food habits was made yesterday at the third annual Institute of the New York Counties Registered Nurses Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Honors of the third day of the annual Spring field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America went to Dr. Harold E. Longsdorf of Mount Holly, N. J., who swept first and second places in the junior open stake, completed this afternoon with a field of nineteen.

Bids were opened yesterday for the construction of the World's Fair Administration Building. The lowest, including the foundation contracts previously let, made a total of $514,981, or $385,019 less than the $900,000 allowed in the fair's budget.

Wilfred Taylor, president of the Stonecraft Homes Corporation, bought 278 lots in Garden City, L. I., from George L. Hubbell of the Merillon Corporation. Joseph P. Day negotiated the sale of the lots, which were held at $150,000 and front on Willow Street, running east from Clinton Street to the Garden City boundary line.

Meredith P. Snyder, four times Mayor of Los Angeles and for many years prominent in State and national Democratic politics, died suddenly of heart attack today at his apartment. His age was 78. The Los Angeles wartime Mayor was known as the originator of municipal ownership in California.

Dizzy Dean was "sorry" tonight, he said, "about what happened last week" in a Tampa hotel lobby-a fight with two baseball writers. "It's the first time I ever had any trouble with a sports writer," declared the vociferous Cardinal hurler, "and you take it from ol' Diz, it'll be the last time.

Money in circulation at the end of March amounted to $6,376,861,656, the Treasury announced today. This was a decrease of $22,145,389 from the total on Feb. 28, but an increase of $500,060,537 from March 31, 1936. The average per capital circulation was $49.39, compared with $49.59 Feb. 28 and $45.84 a year ago.

David Mackenzie, the 20-year-old son of a British rear admiral, described yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln some of the adventures he had during the three months he commanded the first British Lewis gun section in the international column fighting for the Spanish Government outside Madrid.

The Namm store in Brooklyn, beginning on April 19, will return to the NRA forty-hour week, it was announced yesterday by Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the store. The employes have been working on a forty-five-hour schedule.

Joseph H. Leib of South Bend, Ind., acknowledged by the Democratic national chairman as founder of the first Roosevelt-for-President club, in 1930, announced yesterday upon his arrival here his intention to organize large groups in opposition to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal.

Officials of the American Federation of Labor, appraising the result of the settlement of the Chrysler strike in Michigan, came to the conclusion today, as they stated it, that organized labor had gained nothing.

The stock market here was unsettled today by rumors of a reduction in the price of gold in the United States and, although the tendency became firmer after official denials were issued, most issues closed lower on the day.

Sales of the J. C. Penney Company in March were the largest for that month in the company's history, aggregating $19,822,685, it was announced yesterday. This compared to sales of $16,282,558 in March, 1936, and represents a gain of 21.7 per cent.

The place and date of the next National Shoe Fair will be selected within a month by the newly elected committee, which includes representatives from the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association and the National Shoe Retailers Association.

Former Mayor Joseph V. McKee requested yesterday an allowance of $50,000 for his work as one of three appraisers named by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan to evaluate the assets of Eitingon Schild Company, Inc., dealers in furs. He said he spent 892 3/4 hours on the case, on which basis his fee amounts to about $55 an hour.

Three Catholic priests and four laymen stood before the People's Court here today charged with high treason. The indictment, covering 154 typewritten pages, charges a vast conspiracy between the Catholic priests and Communists to undermine the National Socialist government.

Gasoline prices in New York State are either controlled by one large company or fixed by agreement among large companies, the joint legislative committee investigating oil and gasoline prices reported to the Legislature today.
A preliminary application by parents of a child bride for an annulment of her marriage was denied today by Advisory Master Dougal Herr in Chancery Court here,

The biological results of celibacy within the Catholic church forms the theme of an article by Dr. Wilhelm Hartnacke in Neuen Volk, monthly organ of the National Socialist party's Racial Political Department.

Oliver C. Hutchinson, former general sales manager of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, died Tuesday night in Cottage Hospital, Grosse Pointe, where he had been taken Saturday when he suffered a stroke in his home at the Whittier Apartments. He was 74 years old.

If the women's coat and suit industry attempts to put into effect the proposal to eliminate customary free deliveries to freight forwarders, package consolidating companies and resident buyers on orders of out-of-town stores there will be endless confusion and controversy between retailers and manufacturers, it was declared yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry. Goods Association. According to the present plan, out-of-cty retailers would be assessed the cartage charges.
Governor Lehman signed today the Feld Bill which will insure a position as Assistant Superintendent of Schools for Dr. Joseph M. Sheehan in New York City.

O. Max Gardner, former Governor of North Carolina and American Employers' delegate to the World Textile Conference, told the conference today that government, employers and workers in this country were substantially in agreement on these points:
Investors acquired a variety of buildings in scattered sections of Manhattan yesterday when trading included housing and business properties.

Thea Behrens, a mezzo-soprano of New York, gave her first local recital last night in Steinway Hall. Most of her musical education was attained in this country, but she has also studied in France and Germany.

A proposal for the sale of the stock in North American Aviation, Inc., and Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., that was segregated in a voting trusteeship in compliance with the Air-Mail Act of 1934, will come before shareholders of the Aviation Corporation at a meeting to be held on April 20 in Wilmington, Del.

A movement to pay bonuses to Canadian veterans of the World War of a kind similar to those granted in the United States has begun in Canada, but according to a statement made in the House of Commons today by C. G. Power, Minister of Pensions, it will not be heeded by the government.
Capturing eleven first and seven second places in fourteen events today, Princeton's powerful track team defeated North Carolina for the second time this season, scoring 82 to 44.

A copy of the first dated edition (Rome, 1493) of Columbus's letter addressed to Ferdinand and Isabella announcing his discovery of America was sold for $4,350 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries,' Inc., at an auction of Americana and American and English first editions collected by William D. Breaker of Brooklyn.

Jane M. Bolin of 61 West 130th Street became the first Negro woman to hold the position of Assistant Corporation Counsel yesterday when she received an appointment from Corporation Counsel Paul Windels.
Several firms in the stock brokerage and investment security business were numbered among the concerns taking new quarters for commercial purposes yesterday, according-to brokers reports.

President Roosevelt conferred with Works Progress Administrator Hopkins on relief needs in prepaparation for his forthcoming message to Congress and discussed Pennsylvania relief problems with a delegation from that State.

Nearly $87,000,000 was the cost, unofficial figures showed today, of the Chrysler strike affecting about 85,000 automotive workers, most of them in Detroit. In addition, the 11,000 Hudson strikers have lost in wages close to $1,540,000.

Alexander Munk, vice president and a founder of the Platt Munk Company, Inc., 200 Fifth Avenue, publishers of children's books, died suddenly of a heart attack Tuesday on a train at Las Vegas, N. M. He was on his way from Los Angeles to New York. He lived at the Hotel St. Moritz here and was 43 years old.

The Interstate Commerce Commission published today a ruling calling for a downward revision of rates on refined sugar moving from Southern territory into the "official territory" bounded by a line marked on the west by the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railroad and on the east by the Buffalo Pittsburgh Railway.

Mayor WILSON of Philadelphia, one of the briskest and most versatile of contemporary statesmen, is a happy child of nature. He never hides his feelings. When he smiles the sun breaks out on the cloudiest of days. When he is angry he speaks like Mars. This week he is Martian.

Harry Cohen of the Harry Cohen Dress Corporation was elected chairman of the board of the National Dress Manufacturers Association at the annual meeting of the association last night. Other officers chosen were:

The service of the Morris Plan Bank of New York, whereby persons may obtain funds from the bank for the purchase of merchandise for cash from R. H. Macy Co., Inc., was officially inaugurated yesterday. A representative of the bank was located adjacent to the furniture department on the ninth floor of the store.

Pickets reinforced sit-down strikers today in a labor dispute which closed the big Caterpillar Tractor Company plant. The pickets gathered around the factory in East Peoria while the sitdowners barred the doors and 11,500 employes were forced into idleness.

The Granby Consolidated Mining, Smelting and Power Company has entered into a contract with Mitsui Co., Ltd., and the Mitsubishi Trading Company, Ltd., to deliver its entire output of copper concentrates to them for three years, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's prospectus for the sale of $750,000 of convertible debentures.

Miss Carol Rossin, daughter of Alfred S. Rossin of 40 East Sixtyeighth Street and the late Mrs. Rossin, was married at her home last evening to Charles S. Rosenthal of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max Rosenthal of Dixon, Ill.

The request by Representative Raymond J. Cannon, Democrat, of Wisconsin, for an investigation to determine whether major league baseball violates the anti-trust statutes has been referred to the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice, Attorney General Cummings said today.

Price reaction in the commodity markets had been foreseen by most industrial purchasing agents and they were protected against the turn, George Renard, secretarytreasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, asserted yesterday.
Though Coach Garrison H. (Gar) Davidson again will be in charge of Army football for 1937, army orders have necessitated several changes among his assistants.

In one of the fastest Rugby football games seen in Bermuda in recent years, a combined Harvard-Princeton team played to 9-9 draw with and All-Bermuda fifteen today. Sayer of Bermuda scored the first try within ten minutes of the start. Just before the interval Tagg of Princeton dropped a field goal to give the collegians a one-point lead.
The House passed today a bill embodying one of the corollary recommendations which President Roosevelt sent to Congress in his message of Feb. 5 calling for reorganization of the Supreme Court.

The Pulitzer Prize choices in letters and journalism for the calendar year 1936 will be announced on Monday evening, May 3, at the Hotel Biltmore, it was disclosed yesterday by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, whose advisory board determines the nominations.

A Treasury deficit of $4,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000 for the fiscal year was predicted today by Senator King unless, he said, there is an increase in taxes or drastic curtailment of Federal expenditures.

How an antique china tea set became successively an antique dinner set and than a banquet set was described to Justice Edgar J. Lauer and a jury in Supreme Court yesterday by Clinton I. Nash, retired Boston business man. The witness said that he paid $51,126 in all for the set and was overcharged $50,000.

Sites in Flushing, Jackson Heights and Woodside yesterday were reported sold for immediate improvement with apartment or store buildings. Several industrial property deals were closed in Long Island City.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh were resting here today after their long flight from Zagreb, Yugoslavia, on the way to London. They landed at the local airport at 8 o'clock last night after a sevenhour flight, largely over mountainous territory. They will take off for London tomorrow.
Sam Snead of West Virginia, sensational newcomer to golf's professional ranks, gave the veterans something to shoot at today in the opening round of the $5,000 Tournament of Gardens.
For the first quarter of 1937 net assets of General American Investors Company, Inc., rose S2,071,137, or 5.6 per cent, the company reported yesterday.

Mrs. C. O. Hubbell watched her famous son, King Carl of the Giants, pitch in a professional baseball game for the first time today. "It's the first time I've seen Carl pitch since he was in high school," said Mrs. Hubbell, blushing as photographers pointed cameras at her.

The 15,000 employes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company were notified yesterday that the election to determine how they would be represented in future collective bargaining with the management was to be held under the supervision of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

The proposed merger of the Methodist Episcopal Church, the Methodist Episcopal Church South and the Methodist Protestant Church was supported by a vote of 159 to 16 at the eightieth session of the annual Newark conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which opened today at St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church.

Maurice Wertheim, investment banker and principal financial backer of The Nation as a liberal weekly, revealed yesterday his public dissent from its editorials in support of the President's Supreme Court program.

Henry Ford today announced a short-lived "sit-down" strike in his St. Louis assembly plant and said his company had no intention of recognizing the United Automobile Workers union as a bargaining agency.

A crowd estimated at 25,000 automobile workers, friends and sympathizer, crowded the Coliseum at the State Fair Grounds to capacity tonight cheering John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization;...

Twelve women and six men, members of Local 2 of the Blind Workers' Union, continued their sit-down strike yesterday at the plant of the Community Craft Weavers Auxiliary, on the sixth floor of 708 Broadway. They had spent the previous night listening to a radio, talking, and sleeping fitfully on chairs and tables.

Alexander Semmler is a pianist who is known to a much more extensive public than the audience that heard him last night in his debut recital at the Town Hall. He is indebted for such fame as is his to the radio; perhaps the radio owes him something as well.

With this week marking the sixth anniversary of the first installation of its product in a retail store, the Frosted Foods Sale Corporation is planning a sharp expansion of distribution facilities in five major cities, Donald Barr, advertising manager, reported yesterday.
Billboards and other road signs along the main highways and avenues in, and around the capital will be subject to heavy taxation in the future, according to a, resolution adopted yesterday.
Three city concessions were let for two-year periods beginning May 16 by the Department of Plant and Structures yesterday after they had been offered at public auction in the department's offices.

Miss Emily Hawley died at her home in Brookfield Center last night at the age of 84. Miss Hawley, Brookfield historian, wrote and published in 1907 "Neubery-Brookfield." In 1911 she compiled and published "The Skidmore Genealogy."

Dust, snow, rain and chill winds blew over Western States today. A Spring blizzard swept across the Rocky Mountains, interrupting plane and highway traffic. Airplane schedules out of Denver were canceled as the snowfall reached three inches.

Two bills outlawing the sit-down strike as a weapon in labor disputes were passed by the State Senate today. Sit-down strikers would become liable to fines of $2,500 or five years in prison under the terms of one. Both were passed by a vote of 17 to 12 and sent to the House.

Leaders of the Democratic party began today to formulate plans to push to the limit their advantage gained by the decision of Circuit Court Judge Wilfred H. Jayne, in which he set aside the election of State Senator William C. Hunt, Republican.

The British Imperial Conference group headed by Lord Phillimore and composed of members of the House of Lords and Commons, who arrived here on March 17 for an unofficial survey of American social and economic problems, sailed yesterday for London on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of Spiegel, Inc., yesterday, Charles J. Fogler, Reuben Don, Walter A. Gatzert, H. G. Meinig, Howard J. Sachs, Frederick W. Spiegel, M. J. Spiegel Jr., and E. L. Swikard were elected directors.

After a trial lasting a month a jury before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard returned a verdict of guilty yesterday against the Empire State Paper Corporation, Morris Seltzer, its president, and Emanuel Goldberg, its treasurer, for evading income taxes. The jury acquitted Emanuel Fass, an accountant, of 60 East Forty-second Street.

George C. Smith Jr. of 3 East Seventy-seventh Street, president of the publishing house of Street Smith, 79 Seventh Avenue, died yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Hospital, after a brief illness, at the age of 45.

The Cardinals downed the Reds in an exhibition game today, 7 to 2. Dizzy Dean settled down after the Reds scored two runs off him in the fifth, when he took over the pitching. Lon Warneke started and held Cincinnati hitless the first four innings.

Commodities Decline Further The selling movement in commodities, which started on last Saturday in London, assumed greater proportions yesterday and enveloped the stock market, on persistent rumors of a pending change in the gold-buying policy of the United States Treasury Department.

John B. Swinney has been ap pointed managing director of the Uptown Retail Guild, it was -an nounced yesterday by Adam L Gimbel of Saks Fifth Avenue and president of the guild, which has a membership of 300 specialty shops in this city located above Forty second Street.

While the sugar conference got off on an uncertain course today because of disparate statistics introduced by the different national delegations, Norman Davis, United States Ambassador at large and head of the American delegation, continued his unofficial friendly conversations with a private group of Members of Parliament and junior government officials gathered at a luncheon by Lady Astor.

A net profit of $4,604,908 for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 30, 1937, which compared with one of $2,753,901 for the preceding twelve months, was reported by R. H. Macy Co., Inc., in its annual statement given out today by Percy S. Straus, president.

Dwindling receipts from endowment funds and increased competition from publicly supported institutions confront the privately endowed colleges and universities of the United States with problems so grave as to menace their continued existence as important educational factors, Trevor Arnett, former president of the General Education Board, declared in a report of that organization, published yesterday.

John G. Livingston, who has had an active interest in amateur racing for many years, was elected president of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association to succeed John E. Cowdin, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Cowdin, who is president of the Queens County Jockey Club, resigned because he felt he could not handle the duties as head of both organizations.

Although Leftist Liberals polled only 20 per cent of the total votes in last Sunday's Congressional election, they announce that they are holding a rump convention next month which probably will nominate Dario Echandia for president in the next election.

Measured in terms of 1929 prices, the weekly earnings of workers in most of the major industries in February represented a purchasing power of from 1 to 30 per cent more than the weekly wage a year ago, according to computations released today by the American Retail Federation.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Ray Goodrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Goodrich of 170 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, and Monmouth Hills, N. J., to John Hardie Karrh Jr. of this city, formerly of Carbon Hill, Ala., which will take place here on April 21 in St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Mrs. Clyde R. Place, who heads the committee arranging the dinner dance to be given on Tuesday in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, by the Ladies Auxiliary of the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, entertained with a luncheon there yesterday for the other members of her group and also for the junior committee.
Electric power production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 105.5 from 106.9. It was 99.8 for the week ended April 4, 1936.
The status of the Sanjak of Alexandretta was again hotly discussed in the National Assembly today when Shukru Kaya, Minister of the Interior, reported on his recent tour of inspection.

Mr. and Mrs. James C. Kennedy Jr. of New York and Kennedune, Quogue, L. I., who are now visiting Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bennett at their home here, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janice Chrystal Kennedy, to John Homer Winters Jr. of New York.

Yesterday was rumor day in the security and commodity markets, and prices fell sharply. Favorable industrial news, such as the settlement of the Chrysler strike, the promise of a continued high rate of activity in steel, and electric power production 15 per cent better than a year ago, was ignored in favor of rumors.

A surprise witness at the Louis Luckman perjury trial testified yesterday in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to having twice seen Luckman in the company of former Assistant District Attorney William W. Kleinman after the murder of Samuel Drukman.
The cast of youngsters who will take leading roles in "Second Hurricane" play-opera by Aaron Copland to a libretto by Edwin Denby, has been selected, it was announced yesterday.

Many of the golfing sensations of the past Winter, young as well as old, were passed over, at least for the present, by the P. G. A. selectors of the American Ryder Cup team which will meet the British pros at Southport, England, June 29-30.

C. V. McLaughlin, vice president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, said today strike ballots already in his hands gave the needed majority to call a strike on coast wide Southern Pacific lines.

The three-story brick office and store building at 740-8 Madison Avenue, 75 by 95 feet, was sold at auction yesterday in foreclosure proceedings brought by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company against the First National Realty, Inc., for an indebtedness of $453,099 and taxes and other liens of $33,576.

According to The Daily Express, "Slippers," Mrs. Wallis Simpson's Cairn terrier, died today as the resuit of snakebite received in the grounds of Mrs. Charles Dedeaux's chateau, where Mrs. Simpson is staying.
The Twomey bill to provide for a one-year moratorium on criminal penalties for failure to comply with the Multiple Dwellings Law was debated today at a turbulent public hearing.

The nonferrous metal markets had yesterday their worst break in several years. The price of copper abroad dropped to 14.90 cents, a loss of 85 points, but the domestic price was unchanged at 16 cents.

While Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley prepared yesterday to tell the Board of Estimate tomorrow that the administrative cost of relief in Chicago was 7.5 per cent, against New York's 15.53 per cent, relief officials and social welfare groups marshaled their forces to oppose his demand for a $50,000 appropriation to finance an Aldermanic investigation of relief here.

A crowd of 3,000 or 4,000 angry Central Pennsylvania farmers, bred in the tradition of a seven-day week and a dawn-to-sundown day, descended today on this model industrial town armed with clubs and improvised weapons, and put a pretty severe crimp in a C. I. O. sit-down strike in the mammoth Hershey chocolate plant.

The New York University women's fencing team ended one of the best seasons in its .history last night by conquering the Scafati Club of Elizabeth, N. J., 5-4, at the Salle Santelli. The Violet finished with a string of five straight triumphs and a record of seven victories in eight clashes.
Blows from James J. Braddock's two-bladed axe resounded for two hours through the forest wilds surrounding the world's heavyweight champion's training camp today.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, wartime commander of the Twentyseventh Division, was decorated with the War Governors' Perpetual Membership Award of the New York Society of Military and Naval Officers of the World War at the society's seventeenth annual dinner last night in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
The German Government issued today a semiofficial but rather earnest warning to Poland through the Foreign Office organ, the Diplomatische Korrespondenz.
Physicians may give birthcontrol information to patients, under the terms of a bill passed in both houses and now before Governor Blanton Winship for his signature.

The defending champion, the medalist and all the other favorites got their men in the first round of match play today in the North and South amateur golf tournament. George T. Dunlap Jr., who won his fifth championship last year, had trouble off the tee, but eliminated Robert Lowry of Shamokin, Pa., 4 and 3. James T. Hunter,

Robert Irwin is believed to have been in the vicinity of Stroudsburg, Pa., late Tuesday afternoon and the New York police made every effort yesterday to push what they said was the most promising lead yet developed in the nation-wide hunt for him.

The New York World-Telegram signed a contract yesterday with the Newspaper Guild of New York, marking the culmination of collective bargaining negotiations lasting more than two months. It is the first contract. signed by the paper with the guild. Lee B. Wood,
The Presbyterian Hospital conveyed yesterday to the City of New York a plot 71 by 85 feet, at the southwest corner of Broadway and 168th Street, adjoining the Vanderbilt Clinic.

Preliminary plans for a new city court house to replace the Criminal Courts Building were discussed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan and General Sessions Judges John J. Freschi, George L. Donnellan and James G. Wallace at a City Hall conference.

No important let-down is in sight for the steel industry, which has broken all first-quarter production records, according to Iron Age. Output of open hearth and Bessemer ingots for the first three months of the year was 14,390,787 tons, gaining almost 3 1/2 per cent over the first quarter of 1929.

The teaching of the "facts of life" before the three R's, lack of discipline, report cards that do not "report" and a general attitude of experimentation were among objections voiced tonight by Roslyn residents against the so-called progressive education methods in the local elementary schools.
Captain William J. Maidhof died suddenly today at his home here after a heart attack. He was 85 years old. Born in New York he had served in the National Guard in that State for many years.

Passengers arriving today on the Italian liner Rex include Mr. and Mrs. Armand Dreyfus, Mrs. Olaya Herrera, Eduardo Bonitto, Dr. and Mrs. Norbert Einstein, Dr. Irwin Schwenk, Mr. and Mrs. Franco Ghione, Professor Gerolamo Ippolito and Miss Frieda Salber.

Lord Auckland has withdrawn his $10,000 suit for slander against Mrs. Arthur Woolley-Hart scheduled to be heard at Grasse Thursday. Lord Auckland has left for Italy aboard his yacht Lanatana and it is understood that he does not intend to return for some time.
