If Van Lingle Mungo wants Randy Moore behind the plate when the Dodger fireball ace is pitching, he can have him. That and some other statements just as frank if not so definite came from Manager Burleigh Grimes as the Dodgers bade farewell to their Clearwater camp and headed toward Ebbets Field.

St. Peter's College registered its first victory of the season at Lincoln Park today, defeating Brooklyn College, 11 to 1. Edward O'Brien twirled seven-hit ball for St. Peter's, going the route. Every player on the St. Peter's team aided in a six-run rally in the fifth inning.

John B. Clark, on Hillaire Circle, Saxonwoods, White Plains, Westchester; Howard A. Schlieder, in 36 Gedney Park Drive, White Plains: E. S. Tewksbury, in 101 Woodcrest AV., White Plains; Dr. Dorothy Worthington, on Chadwick Road. Westminster Ridge, White Plains; Rudolph Snyder, on Woodbrook and Topland Roads, Haviland Manor, White Plains;

Representatives of the traffic departments of the chemical and drug industry in Eastern States will meet tomorrow at 10 A. M. in the rooms of the Traffic Club to consider action in protest against the proposed increase of freight rates by the United States Intercoastal Steamship Freight Association.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has set down for oral argument on April 14 applications by the San Francisco Curb Exchange for extension of unlisted trading privileges in the following securities:

Mrs. Beta Bijur, daughter of the late Samuel Lionel (Roxy) Rothafel, New York theatre owner, received' a divorce today from George Bijur of New York on grounds of mental cruelty. A separate agreement gives her custody of their child.

Captain E. C. Whitwell, Coliseum promoter, went before the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday with a proposal to post $20,000 in prizes for an outdoor wrestling tournament during the Summer in an effort to break the so-called wrestling trust.

A hardening in time money, four to six months' maturities, was the most significant development of the money market. The new rate was 1 1/2 per cent, an advance of 1/4, and marked the first change since May 11, 1936.
Dr. James Seymour Luckey, for twenty-nine years president- of Houghton College, died at his home here late today after a six months' illness. He was 69.

Propelled by two aircraft engines, Ab Jenkins of Utah hopes to "fly" to- a new land speed world's record over a measured mile in his superpowered automobile next Fall, he made known yesterday. Sir Malcolm Campbell of England holds the present mark at 301.337 miles per hour, made in 1935.

The British destroyer Garland tonight was steaming to Palma, Majorca, to lodge a protest with the Insurgent authorities against yesterday's two bombing attacks on the destroyer Gallant between Valencia and Alicante.

Ariel and Caliban-and, if you've followed your newspapers diligently, you'll know who else-are said to have inspired "Hitch Your Wagon!" the new comedy by Bernard C. Schoenfeld, which will arrive this evening at the Fortyeighth Street Theatre under the guidance of the Messrs. Pearson and Baruch.

Sit-down strikes are "directly in conflict" with the law-observance program of the American Legion, according to an editorial yesterday in the current issue of The New York State Legionnaire, published by the New York State Department of the Legion.

Predicting a building boom in the New York and northern New Jersey area, the New Jersey State Planning Board advocates a wider use of governmental control to insure the unified growth of that section. It urges that full advantage be taken of building codes and zoning ordinances, and that comprehensive plans be made for future municipal, county and State development.

The five-story dwelling at 638 West End Avenue, on the southwest corner of Ninety-first Street, has been leased to Max Berkowitz by M. A. Bannon. The sale of the furnishings of twenty-one rooms was included in the lease. The Sharp Nassoit Management Corporation acted as broker.

An intimation that organized railroad labor had discontinued efforts to obtain national legislation for a six-hour day in their industry was afforded yesterday following a meeting of the heads of most of the important Eastern railroads in the Pennsylvania Station.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden gave a dinner tonight at their home. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. D. Terry West, Mrs. Harold Wilson Sweatt, Miss Belle Gurnee, Dr. Edmund Leroy Dow, John Hale Brelsford and Harold Lihme.
Vital statistics being what they are, we can be quite certain that Sir James M. Barrie did not have Katharine Hepburn in mind when he wrote "Quality Street" some thirty-five years ago.

The purchase by Abraham Weinstein of the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 160 Riverside Drive, northeast corner of Eighty-eighth Street, featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

The Chrysler Corporation began calling its 65,000 men, who have been on strike since March 8, back to work in large numbers today, as a result of Tuesday night's settlement. It announced that Chrysler, Dodge and Plymouth plants would resume operations on almost normal lines by Monday, the De Soto plant by Tuesday. All are in Detroit.
To fall into the cadences of Mark Antony's oration, but yesterday the sit-in strike was on top of the world; today it is more sat

The Welfare Council of New York City, the League of Women Voters, the Citizens Union and the Women's City Club are all urging the Board of Estimate not to grant the sum of $50,000 requested by the Board of Aldermen for its Special Committee on Relief Investigation, recently set up.
State Forester Charles P. Wilber has called attention to some of New Jersey's many streams that will be ready for the trout anglers of our neighboring State when the season opens Thursday.
The Bezbojniks-the Godless League-set in motion today a plan to rebuild their organization through the establishment of anti-religious schools.

A shabbily dressed young man with a four-foot long gold-plated candlestick under one arm was arrested yesterday afternoon as the thief who has been taking valuable articles from three churches and selling them to junk dealers.
William Leary, treasurer of the Port of New York Authority, observed his eighty-third birthday yesterday by working at his desk at the offices of the Authority, 111 Eighth Avenue.

Jacob Hurwitz, 34 years old, insurance broker who trained a cast of men and women for roles through which he defrauded insurance companies of about $250,000 yearly in faked accident claims, was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge Koenig to three and one-half to six years in Sing Sing.

Ferdinand Franklin Hobby, an assistant general counsel for the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, died yesterday at his home here after a brief illness. Mr. Hobby had been with the company for fifty years. He was 64 years old.
Manager Burleigh Grimes returned tonight from the washed-out game with the Cardinals at Daytona Beach to find another blow has been struck at his already wounded Dodgers.

Jack Citron, a driver for the H. Feuerstein Coal Company at South and Roosevelt Streets, was found guilty by Magistrate Curran in the Tombs Court yesterday of violating the short-weight coal ordinance. He was charged with delivering 71,400 pounds of coal to the Central Hotel in West Forty-third Street last March 3 under representation that it was 80,000 pounds.

A painting by J. M. W. Turner, "Blois, on the Banks of the Loire," was bought by Nicholas Acquavella for $4,100 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of pictures, that included property of Mrs. Marion B. N. Nellis, the estate of Charles Melville Dewey, the late Mrs. Hugh A. Murray, Rosemarie Durig and others. The sale brought a total of $40,275.

Engineering construction awards for the week ended yesterday reached the second highest volume of this year with a total of $50,778,000 and exceeded the total for the same week of last year by 68 per cent, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Claiming to represent 12,000 shares of preferred stock of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, a new protective committee is circularizing other holders, asking authorization to represent them in negotiations for a plan of reorganization in order that the preferred "may not be squeezed out between the $50,000,000 of outstanding debentures and the 4,900,000 shares of Class A, Class B and common stock."

A dinner dance entitled "Capri Night" was given last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton under the auspices of La Margherita Society. The entertainment marked the first anniversary of the founding of the society, which aids sick and needy children. The ballroom was decorated with Spring flowers. Entertainers appeared in a special program.

A brief announcement at the office of George A. Ball, fruit jar manufacturer, told today of donation of his common stock holdings in Midamerica Corporation to a religious, charitable and educational foundation bearing his name and that of his wife, Mrs. Frances Ball.

Mrs. Edmund Borgia Butler of Riverdale has been appointed chairman of the women's committee of the Cardinal's Conference on Charity, to be held at the Hotel Commodore tomorrow. At the request of Cardinal Hayes, more than 1,600 trustees,

The five-story apartment house at 534 East 150th Street, the Bronx, has been sold for alteration to an investing client of Charles Kaufmann, attorney. The Julius Trattner Company, brokers in the deal, arranged a new first mortgage.

Governmnent troops were less than three miles from Penarroya and Fuenteovejuna on the Cordoba front at 3 o'clock this afternoon and were still advancing, according to reports from Andujar. One Madrid newspaper, the Claridad, says Villaharta has been captured, but there is no confirmation of this.

Recounts of votes cast for three State offices in last Monday's election seemed inevitable today, as unofficial returns from all but a few precincts left winners and losers closely bunched. On the basis of the unofficial figures Thomas F. McAllister, Democrat, and Walter H. North, Republican, were elected supreme court justices, although Mr. North's margin was less than 2,000.

Just as other defending champions have done through the long history of the American Bowling Congress championships, the Falls City Hi-Bru keglers of Indianapolis relinquished their five-man team la els before more than 2,000 spectators at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory last night.
For alleged "medieval barbarities" and "outrageous offenses against civilization," Nazi Germany was bitterly arraigned in the Canadian House of Commons today.

A floor show will feature the Butterfly Ball dinner dance to be given tonight in the main ballroom and Oval Restaurant of the Ritz-Carlton in behalf of the House of Rest, a hospital at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers, N. Y., for the treatment of men, women and children afflicted with pulmonary tuberculosis.

Mrs. J. Duncan Spaeth, wife of the president of the University of Kansas City, died at her Sarasota Beach cottage tonight after a long illness. Accompanied by her physician and a nurse, she came here in January for her health. Her daughter Janet was with her.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The conception of private property seems to be in for a housecleaning. Certain things should be said to clear the air. First, no instructed person has ever believed that absolute private property can exist except in an absolute monarchy-and then only for the monarch.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated nervously over a 20-point range yesterday, but the break of more than $3 a bale from last week's high levels attracted sufficient buying to offer a greater degree of resistance and the list improved 13 to 22 points.

Bert Lahr, Billy House and Jimmy Savo have been signed by Universal for "Four Black Sheep," together with Mischa Auer, and negotiations are under way to obtain Beatrice Lillie and Fanny Brice, it was announced today.

William A. Dalton, former president of the New York Athletic Club, will be honored Sunday night at a testimonial dinner at the club, Seventh Avenue and Central Park South. The dinner is to be given in appreciation of Mr. Dalton's services to the club during the four years he was president.
The United States Legation was closed here today at almost the same hour that the Consulate was vacated at Tripoli, Libya, in another part of Italy's African empire.

A 15 to 20 per cent increase in cooperative newspaper advertising by manufacturers and retail stores this year was predicted yesterday at the annual Toy Fair, being held here. National magazine volume, which was said to range between $400,000 and' $500,000, will also be increased substantially.

SEVERAL months ago the United States Golf Association passed a rule, effective Jan. 1, 1938, limiting the clubs to fourteen in a bag when a player sets out to do battle with par, bogey or any other opponent, real or imaginary. It was expected that the Royal and Ancient body at St. Andrews would follow suit in this child-labor amendment to the golf code, but now there is some doubt.
At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Schenley Distillers Corporation in Wilmington, Del., yesterday, the following members of the board of directors were re-elected:

H. P. McClure, formerly Dallas district manager, has been appointed Western division manager of the toilet articles department of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company. Philip Kalech, formerly Western division manager, was recently named manager of the Central division.
Bookshops did a thriving business today because five words were omitted from the prayer for the King in an edition of the new Book of Common Prayer.

Charles C. Hemenway, editor of The Hartford Times, said in delivering the annual Isaac Bromley lecture at Yale University this afternoon that the press can today adequately meet demands of leadership placed upon it only by maintaining its independence and preserving its influence because its prestige and character have been sustained.

Elden Auker took a long stride along the come-back trail today by pitching the Tigers to a 5-to-1 victory over the Montreal Royals. Auker became the first Tiger hurler to go the route this Spring. He allowed only five hits.

Dr. Henry John Harp, practitioner here for the last thirty years and former chief surgeon of the Alexander Linn Hospital, was found dead in his home, 78 Fountain Square, yesterday afternoon. Sussex County Coroner George H. McCloughan Jr.. said that death was due to a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

Medley G. B. Whelpley, chairman of The Lautaro Nitrate Company, Ltd., announced yesterday that $30,453,000 of the company's new first mortgage income bonds were ready for distribution at the offices of the Bankers Trust Company in exchange for old first mortgage 6 per cent convertible bonds or certificates of deposit representing such bonds.
Mrs. Marie de Rothschild, widow of the financier, Leopold de Rothschild, and a leading London hostess for many years, died at her home in Hamilton Place, Piccadilly, today at the age of 75.

Tears poured from the eyes of many spectators who gathered at Southampton docks .today to witness the departure of the old Atlantic liner Majestic on her way to the Firth of Forth, where she will be moored as a naval training school.

Support developed today for a bill introduced by Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee for repeal of the two-yearold law requiring the Treasury Department to make public all salary payments of more than $15,000 annually.

The sharp upward trend in prices is creating a "consumer consciousness" which may result in a strong buying resistance and temporarily check the recovery movement during the later months of this year, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declared last night at a dinner meeting of the New York Chapter of the National Institute of Credit at the Hotel Astor.

Morris Wadley gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for his sister, Miss Melissa Wadley, and Thomas S. Childs Jr., who will be married today in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. Guests included Mrs. Thomas S.
Announcement has been made of the marriage in Elkton, Md., last Saturday of Miss Eleanor Perry Herrman, daughter of Mrs. Eugene Wells Waterbury of Waterbury Manor, Peekskill, N. Y.,

Miss Adelaide Ferry Hooker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elon Huntington Hooker of 620 Park Avenue and Chelmsford, Greenwich, Conn., and John Phillips Marquand, author, also of this city, whose engagement was announced in February, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building.

William Monk, an etcher principally known for his studies of New York, died yesterday at his home in Chester at the age of 73. He was a fellow of the Royal Society of Painters and Etchers and was prominent in the Society of Graver Printers in Color.

In the presence of Vice President Garner, four United States Senators and other well-known persons, Howard W. Jackson, Mayor of Baltimore, today presented to W. J. (Big Bill) Norton the victory trophy in the featured race.

Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday that he was "reasonably sure" of the early capture of Robert Irwin, 29-year-old sculptor and former theological student who is wanted for the murders of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter Veronica and their roomer, Frank Byrnes, on the night before Easter.
Owing to the two-day shut-down of bituminous coal mines, business in the Pittsburgh district reflected a severe drop last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
The government press is showing some sensitiveness over the question of whether Yugoslavia is being forced by Italy into the anti-democratic bloc of States controlled by Germany and Italy.

Meetings of the Screen Actors Guild and of local unions of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America have been called for Sunday to hear reports on negotiations with motionpicture producers for recognition of the unions. Both are A. F. of L. organizations.
Cadillac Hawkins, Raleigh Negro who has served four previous road terms for stealing chickens, asked a Wake County Superior Court jury to acquit him "on account of my past record."

The Salvation Army will have a new chief of staff, it was announced tonight at the International Headquarters here. Commissioner Henry Mapp, who has been second in command to General Evangeline Booth in charge of the Salvation Army's world-wide organization, has received an "extended furlough" on grounds of ill health and will not return to his post.

With stores curtailing orders on dry goods throughout the country, wholesalers placed comparatively little business in the market during the week. Jobbers, however, were not particularly worried about the raw cotton fluctuations, pointing out that the heavy backlog of mill orders would prevent any serious decline.

The "slogan" that will be used by the Morris Plan Bank in promotion of its arrangement to finance customers' purchases of durable goods for cash at R. H. Macy Co., Inc., will be "Buy Money on Time to Buy Merchandise for Cash," it was learned yesterday. This phrase. ing will be used at least temporarily, but may be changed later if an improved and more compact wording is developed, it was said.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced tonight that it would summon W. E. Hutton 2d and Jerry McCarthy, customers' man of W. E. Hutton Co. in Detroit, to appear early next week at its hearing to determine if Hutton Co. manipulated stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation.

Argentina has appointed a national commission for the codification of international law in accordance with a resolution adopted at the Pan-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, which President Roosevelt inaugurated here in December.

A fusillade of questions was directed from the Supreme Court bench today as lawyers began argument on vital aspects of the Federal Social Security Act. William Logan Martin, speaking for the Charles G. Steward Machine Company of Alabama, and Charles E. Wyzanski Jr.,

Magistrate Burke in West Side Court dismissed yesterday a complaint charging cruelty to animals against Clyde Beatty, animal trainer of the Cole Brothers-Clyde Beatty Circus, which will close its engagement at the Hippodrome on Sunday night.

A movement to end the public hearings on President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan at the end of next week, with a view to getting the pending bill before the Senate within three weeks, gained momentum today.

This greenswarded community was in a state of great excitement tonight as the battered C. I. O. strikers and their opponents, farmers, nonstrikers and sympathizers, sought breathing time to consolidate their strength for a further test of power over the week-end in the strike of Hershey Chocolate Corporation employes.

In recognition of his feat incrossing the Atlantic alone last year in the 42-foot motor boat Arielle, Marin Marie, Frenoh marine artist, last night was awarded the Blue Water Medal of the Cruising Club of America.

The body of Dr. Enrique Olaya Herrera, former President of Colombia and before that Minister to the United States for nearly eight years, was brought here yesterday on the Italian liner Rex accompanied by the widow and Miss Maria Olaya Herrera.

Tre Fontaine was the setting today for a tea and cocktail party given by Mr. and Mrs. Marion Sims Wyeth as the first large entertainment there since his return from Honolulu where he went as architect for Mr. and Mrs. James H. R.

Flavia Arcaro, musical comedy singer and actress of the legitimate stage, died yesterday morning in the House of Calvary, Featherbed Lane and Macombs Road, the Bronx, after a long illness. She was 61 years old. Her last professional appearance was in "Roberta" on tour four years ago.

A pair of upsets that had a farreaching effect on the world pocket billiard championship astounded a capacity gathering at Ponzi's Academy last night as two of the three men then deadlocked for the lead went down to defeat.
The strike-bound Louis Sopkin Co. plant here will remain closed until picketing is stopped, Nate Niederman, vice president, said today.

The Princeton Rugby team won the Bermuda Trade Development Board Trophy today, defeating Harvard, the 1936 winner, 8 to 3, in the concluding match of the fifth annual Bermuda Rugby Week tournament at the Bermuda Athletic Association field.

Mrs. Jeannette Horlick Simmons of this city and Greenwich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander James Horlick of Racine, Wis., was married to John F. Bowles Jr. of 2 East Eighty-second Street yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

Critics wondered tonight why the trouble was taken to produce "Thou Art the Man," which opened at the Arts Theatre tonight. Taking the biblical story of King David's love for Bathsheba, the author, Arthur Hood, reduces the simplicity of the biblical statement to a burlesque level.

Led by the de Capriles brothers of the University F. C., eight local fencers qualified for the national epee championships to be held April 25-28 at the New York Athletic Club, where last night's matches were staged.

William Conrad, contrabassoon player in the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society for the last eleven years, died yesterday in the lobby of the Subtreasury Building at 20 Wall Street, where he had gone to inquire about a passport.
Mayor La Guardia extended the city's welcome yesterday to seventeen members of the Le Play Socity of England who arrived on Monday on the Queen Mary.
The annual report of the Italian Superpower Corporation for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $587,763 after Federal income taxes, interest and other expenses and charges.

The Giants got their third look at Bob Feller today, and while this time nobody was cracked in the skull the headache that Hank Leiber has been nursing ever since he was struck by the youngster last Sunday took on the proportions of an epidemic.

Displaying a strong attack behind excellent twirling, the Jamaica High nine, Queens P. S. A. L. titleholder, opened its campaign with a 10-3 triumph over Adelphi Academy in a non-league game yesterday at Jamaica Stadium.
Next Monday night the New Jersey Senate will convene. The Democrats are in high feather. Circuit Court Judge JAYNE decided Tuesday that WILLIAM C. HUNT, Republican Senator for Cape May County,

Two tiny slips of smudged and crumpled paper found by detectives in a Third Avenue rooming house provided a clue that led to the arraignment yesterday of three young men in Felony Court on a charge of homicide.
Its siren shrieking, a car occupied by Deputy Chief Inspector Joseph R. Reynolds yesterday afternoon chased a speeding sedan, which had passed a red light, for five miles through the West Bronx.
Members of the Legislature left the city today for the week-end without any apparent effort on the part of Republican leaders to reach an understanding with Governor Lehman over balancing the budget.

President Roosevelt received a group of delegates to the World Textile Conference and subsequently conferred with Attorney General Cummings and Donald Richberg, former NRA Administrator, on wage and hour legislation.

Charges by the Mayor's crime commission, composed of clergymen, linking crime and politics and hinting at "perhaps the downright corruption of some of the courts," led today to the possibility of a grand jury investigation.

A further advance in wholesale prices in the week ended on April 3 lifted the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics to 88.3, Commissioner Lubin announced today. For the preceding week the index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 87.8, and the year before it was 79.2.

Moving swiftly to carry out its plan for supporting the government bond market, announced on last Sunday night, the Federal Reserve System purchased $28,819,000 of government securities in the first three days of this week, it was disclosed in the weekly report of the system, issued yesterday.

Leading brewers and representatives from industries allied with brewing will attend a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Wednesday, at which aims and purposes of the United Brewers Industrial Foundation will be officially announced. Colonel Jacob Ruppert will preside at the gathering.
Sixteen brace have been run in the $1,000 free-for-all stake, the leading competition in the annual Spring field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America.

The Brooklyn Trust Company sold to the Ovington Avenue Building Corporation the six-story apartment house on a plot 110 by 118 feet, at 495 Eighth Avenue, corner of Fifth Street, Brooklyn. The house, which contains suites of two to eight rooms and was held at $150,000, was sold through Irving Judis, broker.

The disclosure late yesterday that Federal Reserve purchases of United States Government securities in the first three days of this week had totaled $28,819,000 overshadowed all other points of interest in the weekly bank statement.

A complete severance of relations be tween organized labor's rival factions appeared nearer tonight after John P. Frey, an official of the American Federation of Labor, reported that he had received a death threat.

A formal reception last night preceded by a tea for members of British societies marked the opening of the new national headquarters of the English Speaking Union at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Lord Godfrey and Lady Elton were guests of honor at the reception.

Following a conference yesterday at City Hall with city and Port Authority engineers, Mayor La Guardia emphasized the "absolute necessity" for proceeding immediately with construction of the Midtown Tunnel connecting the East and Hudson River Tunnels.

August William Kolehmainen, who used to be a marathon runner and ski jumper, but now devotes most of his time to bricklaying and managing the finances of a fiftythree-family cooperative apartment house at 828 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx, was bewildered yesterday when he learned that the United States Government had begun an action to revoke the citizenship he obtained in 1934, citing a proclamation issued by President Lincoln.

Eighty-five nominations, an increase of eleven over last year, have been made for the fortyseventh renewal of the historic Preakness, to be run May 15 at the old Pimlico course near Baltimore, according to an announcement yesterday from M. L. Daiger, secretary of the Maryland Jockey Club.
The State Department of Law was practically self-sustaining in 1936, said Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., in his annual report filed with the Legislature today.
Lumber production held up well last week when a decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 85.3 from 83.6. It was 72.4 for the week ended April 4, 1936.

Miss Constance Hanf, a junior at Washington Square College and captain of New York University's women's swimming team, has been named to lead the 1937-38 Violet basketball sextet, according to an announcement yesterday.

Henry Schade, honorary vice president and a trustee of the Bushwick Savings Bank, Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 266 Hooper Street, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. Mr. Schade, who had been associated with the bank for fifty years, was 93 years old and a native of Germany.

Rearrangement of assignments of alcohol tax unit officials, announced today, included William D. Moss, field inspector at large, to succeed John H. Flynn, resigned, as supervisor for the Second District in New York;

George F. Wilder, head of the mathematics department of John Adams High School in Richmond Hill, Queens, for the last seven years, died Wednesday at his home, 94-13 Hollis Court Boulevard, Queens Village, after an illness of four months.
President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth will study Mexico's agrarian program, he announced on his arrival here tonightby special train from Laredo, Texas.

For some time it has seemed obvious-that certain Democratic splits could be mended by strong reminders from the party leadership that the present policy of the Republicans in.Congress is to encourage and profit by Democratic dissensions without themselves taking a front position on the issues.

Criticism, implied but sharp, of officials of investment trusts who paid large salaries to themselves, while their companies were losing substantial sums features a letter to shareholders from the new management of the General Investment Corporation.

Harry Balsamo, hard-hitting Harlem boxer, advanced a step along the comeback trail by knocking out Mickey Bottone of Newark, N. J., in the third round of the feature ten-rounder at the Star Casino last night.

Dr. Tyler Dennett, president of Williams College, denied last night that he had insulted preparatory schools by saying recently that Williams had too many "nice boys" from these schools. He spoke at the annual dinner of the Williams College Club of New York at the Hotel Plaza.

Dates of the annual A. A. U. track and field games, listed to be held at Milwaukee on June 25 and 26, may be switched to July 2 and 3 so as to give the Big Ten and Pacific Coast athletes an opportunity to compete, Secretary Dan Ferris of the national Amateur Athletic Union announced yesterday.

James Lewis Malcolm, member of the Greene County bar and president and editor of The Greene County Examiner, died suddenly at the Memorial Hospital of Greene County late last night of coronary thrombosis.

Following eighty employes into the building, more than 200 pickets, reported to be members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, today took possession of the dress factory of the Interborough Sewing Company of Dickson City and prevented any work being done.

In order to protect the light of the thirty-five-story business building which he owns at the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Fortyfourth Street Colonel Jacob Ruppert has purchased the nearby fivestory apartment house on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 712 Third Avenue.

The Australian starting barrier which has been under consideration for several months was adopted for the metropolitan tracks yesterday by the stewards of the Jockey Club in their final meeting before the opening of the New York State racing season at Jamaica next Thursday.

Members of the Board of Estimate will be confronted at their meeting today with a strongly worded report of the Mayor's Advisory Committee on the Foreign Trade Zone declaring that municipal operation of the zone on Staten Island would be unsuccessful and recommending that private interests operate the development.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel R. Rosenbaum of Germantown of the engagement of Mr. Rosenbaum's daughter, Miss Rosamond Margaret Rosenbaum, to Lewis Adams Riley Jr. of Mexico, D. F., son of Lewis Adams Riley of Los Angeles and the late Mrs. Riley.
The Board of Superintendents approved yesterday the application for a "maternity leave" of a married teacher who desired a year's absence without pay to devote to rearing an adopted child.

The chief need of the American air industry is "sympathetic regulation" and the proper regulating agency is the Interstate Commerce Commission, Senator Patrick F. McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, told the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today at a hearing on his bill to give the Interstate Commerce Commission greater regulatory powers.

At exactly 4 P. M. yesterday the outgoing patrol of policemen in the First Precinct--better known as the Old Slip station house--came rigidly to attention with nightsticks sharply raised at salute. Police Captain William J. Kent, with a large silver loving cup and a pocketbook in his hand, walked up to Philip Cestaro, the official bootblack of the station house.

Carl Zeisberg, president of the United States Table Tennis Association, said today that the suspension of Miss Ruth Aarons of New York, undefeated world champion, by the English association means the withdrawal of the American body from the International Table Tennis Federation.

The proposed Trans-Florida Canal could accommodate 90 per cent of all Gulf of Mexico traffic and prove of high value to light cruisers and destroyers in time of national emergency, Major Gen. E. M. Markham, chief of army engineers, told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today.

Through Its refusal to back Mayor La Guardia in his plans for a $400,000 electrical power plant for Brooklyn College, the Board of Estimate may have lost a grant of $180,000 from the PWA, originally intended for this purpose, the board has been informed by Harold L. Ickes, Federal Public Works Administrator.

Maryland's lacrosse team swamped Harvard today, 12 to 2. Coach Faber of the Terps used his entire squad of twenty-three. The two goals of the Crimson came in the final period when the second squad was on the field. George Cushman scored both of the points for the invaders.
Former Mayor John P. O'Brien was guest of honor last night at a dinner given by more than 2,000 of his friends at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He was lauded by speakers for his career in public life.

Letters from a new protective committee for common stockholders of the United Cigar Stores Corporation were mailed last night from the office of Archibald Palmer, counsel for the group. Interested common shareholders obtained permission from the referee in the bankruptcy proceedings to form the new committee, which will be represented April 19 before Judge Cox at the general hearing on the plan.

Johnny Morris, slightly built righthander, limited the Williams batsmen to two scattered hits today and the hustling Princeton baseball team concluded its vacation stand on University Field with its fourth consecutive triumph, disposing of the New England nine, 5 to 1.

The milk price war continued yesterday on the lowest East Side and in the congested sections of Brooklyn and the Bronx. Retailers who obtained their supplies from the socalled Independent dealers continued to sell milk as low as 5 cents a quart.

Christopher A. Gough, Deputy Commissioner of Banking and Insurance of New Jersey, was chief guest at a dinner given last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 1,500 insurance officials were present.

IT is now customary, and almost compulsory, to approach a new work by Virginia Woolf with awe, reverence and something like piety, for Mrs. Woolf has long been regarded as one of the most gifted of Englishwomen and one of the chief ornaments of the English literary scene.

The sit-down strike begun Tuesday by members of the Blind Workers Union in the shop of the Community Craft Weavers Auxiliary on the sixth floor at 708 Broadway spread yesterday to the Bourne Workshop at 338 East Thirty-fifth Street, maintained by the New York Association for the Blind.

Satte and municipal financing for March amounted to $88,215,593, compared with $119,995,256 in March, 1936, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This type of financing for the first quarter aggregated $357,388,986, against $308,160,764 last year.

HITCH YOUR WAGON! a comedy in three acts, by Bernard C. Schoenfeld. Staged by Garson Kanin; settings by Watson Barratt; produced by Malcolm L. Pearson and Donald E. Baruch. At the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

Plans for a "Paris International Week" in New York City, May 2-8, to call attention to the Paris Exposition of Arts and Techniques, which opens officially May 2, were announced yesterday by the FrancoAmerican Committee.

An expansion program involving $26,000,000 was announced today by the Aluminum Company of America Plants and additions in various localities to make shapes and tubing will go forward at once. One of the new plants will be located at Lafayette, Ind.

Arbitragists in the old preferred shares of the American Writing Paper Company, Inc., and the new common stock of the American Writing Paper Corporation so far have discovered no way out of their tangled position.

Trainer Frank Kearns, in charge of William Wright's Calumet Farms Stable, said today Privileged would not be pointed for the Kentucky Derby May 8. Kearns said the Calumet colors would be carried in the derby by Galsun and Gosum. Both, he said, have trained well this Spring.

Miss Teresita de Palau, daughter of Mrs. Julia de Palau of this place, was married today to A. Bruce Crane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Crane, also of Bronxville, in the rectory of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here. The Rev. Joseph McCann performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Ethel Putnam Wagner, widow of Franklin Allan Wagner, New York lawyer, died today at her home here on Colonial Avenue. She was 60 years old. Mrs. Wagner, whose husband died on March 23, had served for twentysix years as secretary of the Women's Association of the Dobbs Ferry Hospital.

Benjamin J. Solomon, owner of the Dispatch Collection Agency at 154 Nassau Street for the last twenty-five years, yesterday criticized District Attorney Dodge's office and the New York County grand jury for not permitting him to testify under waiver of immunity in an inquiry in which he alleged he had been arrested wrongfully.

Dr. Milton Jay Greenman, director of the Wistar Institute of Anatomy at the University of Pennsylvania for thirty-two years, died in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital yesterday at the age of 70.

While the actual business transacted was light, there was a firm tone in the wool goods markets this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Stocks of spot goods are virtually nonexistent and buyers find near-by deliveries difficult to arrange.
Commodity prices were generally lower last week, and The Annalist weekly wholesale price index declined 0.5 point to 145.2 on Tuesday from 145.7 (revised) the Tuesday previous.

Jules Verne's "Michael Strogoff" will be presented this morning at the Roxy under its new RKO Radio title-"The Soldier and the Lady." Anton Walbrook portrays the title character of the book and is assisted by Elizabeth Allan, Akim Tamiroff, Margot Grahame, Fay Bainter, Eric Blore, Edward Brophy and Paul Guilfoyle. George Nicholls Jr. directed from a screen play by Mortimer Offner and Anthony Veiller.
Governor Lehman made public an exchange of communications with Major Robert Fechner, head of the Civilian Conservation Corps, protesting against the barring of Negro enlistments in New York State.
Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, was elected associate superintendent to succeed Dr. Joseph M. Sheehan, at a special meeting called yesterday by the Board of Education.

Police Recorder Anthony J. Casale took it upon himself to declare part of a local ordinance unconstitutional today and thereby gave Mayor Arthur H. Jones, sponsor of the measure, and Town Counsel John H. Cooper one of the surprises of their lives.

A movement to organize city park employes into a labor organization to fight for higher wages was begun last night at a meeting at the Julia Richman High School, Sixtyseventh Street and Second Avenue.

The programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Artur Rodzinski continue to have variety and interest which are exceptional. Jose Iturbi was soloist in the interpretation of Mozart's piano concerto in D minor.

Properties in Staten Island reported yesterday as having been sold by the John A. Lynch Company, Inc., included the 100 by 100 feet plot on the southwest corner of Metropolitan Avenue and Crosshill Street in the City Park section.

Invincible for three seasons and acknowledged king of the world's back-stroke swimmers, 18-year-old Adolph Kiefer of the Lake Shore A. C. tonight thrashed his way to his third successive national A. A. U. 150-yard indoor dorsal championship as the biggest aquatic show of the campaign opened in the pale green waters of the Yale University pool.

Dudley F. Sicher was appointed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to a thirty-day term as justice of the Domestic Relations Court, to sit for Lawrence B. Dunham, who is ill. Mr. Sicher is a member of the firm of Davidson, Moses Sicher of 160 Broadway.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Redden of 720 Riverside Drive have announced the marriage of Mr. Redden's sister, Miss Rita R. Redden, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John J. Redden of New York, to Joseph M. McAuliff, son of Mrs. Patrick McAuliff of Kingston and the late Mr. McAuliff.
Some custom smelters lowered yesterday the price of copper in the domestic market 1/2 cent a pound to 15 1/2 cents. The primary producers, however, held their price unchanged at 16 cents.
A delegation of thirty unemployed men and women decided tonight to continue indefinitely their occupancy of Governor Davey's office until their demand for a $50,000,000 poor-relief program is met.

Senator Copeland said today that the Senate Commerce Committee had voted to hold a public hearing on Saturday, at which opponents of some of the nominations of members of the Maritime Commission will be heard.

The text of the draft of a bill to revive Federal control over wages and hours in industry, one of two such proposals officially submitted to President Roosevelt by the Council for Industrial Progress, was made public today in the course of the hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the administration bill for reorganization of the Supreme Court.
Heavy showers late today drove thousands from the cherry blossom festival and caused the postponement of the coronation pageant, festival climax, until tomorrow night.

Three proposed constitutional amendments, one providing for a four-year term for Governor and Lieutenant Governor, another for two-year terms for Assemblymen and a third to permit Sheriffs to succeed themselves, along with Governor Lehman's new minimum-wage measure, were reported today by the Assembly Rules Committee.
John Albert Thorne, who was associated with the Paramount Pictures Corporation before his retirement, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home at the age of 68.

Leila Stott, director of the extension division of the City and Country School, will give the fourth in a series of lectures sponsored by the Art Teachers Center of the WPA Federal Art Project this afternoon at 2 o'clock at the Project design laboratory. She will speak on "Behavior of the Young Child."

After three Cistercian monks, sworn to silence for life, but speaking from the witness stand by special permission of superiors, had testified. in Providence County Superior Court, a $15,000 damage suit against the monastery of Our Lady of the Valley at Cumberland, R. I., was discontinued today by Judge Herbert L. Carpenter.
Mrs. Elsie Saltus Domville, daughter of the late New York author and publicist, Edgar Saltus, was married to Gosta Tollius of Stockholm, Sweden, here this afternoon in the Baptist Church.

Bert S. Michell, leading trainer of the Florida racing season and winner of the 1928 Kentucky Derby with Reigh Count, was ruled off the turf today when the Racing Commission said a saliva test showed a narcotic had been administered to one of his horses.

In an uproarious session, with hundreds of Spring visitors looking on, the House today killed by a vote of 236 to 149 the Dies resolution calling for an investigation into sit-down strikes and their causes and the measures being taken by local communities to handle such situations.

The Transamerica Corporation may distribute to its stockholders part of the stock of the Bank of America, L. M. Giannini, president of the bank, announced today. Mr. Giannini said his father, A. P. Giannini, head of the Transamerica board, and John M. Grant, president of Transamerica, were discussing plans for the distribution, but had not decided how much of the 2,000,000 shares to distribute.

President McConaughy of Wesleyan University today joined the opponents of President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court, but expressed the belief that the adoption of the plan would not endanger democracy. He stated his stand in a letter to Talcott M. Banks Jr. of the Volunteer Citizens Committee of Boston.

The Rev. O. A. Keller, Jonesboro minister, said tonight that he had performed a marriage last Tuesday for Alexander W. Biddle, 18 years old, of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Miss Elizabeth Simms, also 18, of Garden City, L. I.

The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University will close its tour tonight when it presents its ninetyfirst theatrical production, "Come Across," at Mecca Temple. More than 2,000 seats have been sold for the performance.

Seventeen-year-old Bobby Dunkelberger again played the role of "giant killer" today when he ousted the favored Texas star, Jack Munger, from the North and South amateur golf tourney, 2 up, in their second-round match, recalling his upset victory a year ago over the veteran Francis Ouimet in the same event.

James J. Braddock, world's heavyweight champion, took his first gymnasium workout today in preparation for his fifteen-round battle with Joe Louis in Chicago June 22. A sudden switch in plans, due to a pair of blistered hands, decided Braddock to take a workout e quivalent to six rounds of boxing.

The statement of condition of the Discount Corporation of New York as of March 31, shows holdings of United States Government obligations, including those bought under resale agreement of $38,539,708, compared with $61,494,682 on Dec. 31, last. Acceptances discounted were $11,328,705, against $7,974,556. Cash and due from banks amounted to $3,051,165, against $3,678,146. Capital and surplus were unchanged at $5,000,000 each, while undivided profits were $2,304,469, compared with $2,604,745.

The marriage of Miss Emmy Lou Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Richard Parker of Greenwich, Conn., to Norman Shannon Illges, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Illges of Columbus, Ga., took place here last night in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Clarkson of the Ritz Tower are visiting friends in Bermuda. M. Lopez Pumarejo, the Colombian Minister, and Mrs. de Pumarejo have arrived at the WaldorfAstoria from Washington.

The campaign preceding Sunday's by-election, in which Premier Paul Van Zeeland expects to show the world that his government truly speaks for Belgium and that young Leon Degrelle, leader of the Rexist party, represents only a negligible minority, is approaching a climax amid more excitement than usually attends a lone electoral contest in this country.

Under the supervision of Charles W. Rochester, engineer of the Police Department, a new system of road marking was applied for test purposes yesterday at the Seventh Avenue entrance of Central Park and on the Henry Hudson Parkway. The marking material is said to be 2,000 times as luminous for night driving as any type of marking paint and more visible and lasting by day.

The budgetary situation may make necessary a curtailment of work relief, Senator Robinson warned today. The Democratic floor leader, like President Roosevelt, is opposed to increasing taxes at the present session.
The engagement of Miss Esther Julia Manning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hiram T. Manning of Unionville, N. Y., to Ira Koenig of this city has been announced by her parents.

Wisconsin voters returned Joseph Martin to the State Supreme Court bench and John Callahan to his fourth term as State Superintendent of Public Instruction, incomplete returns from Tuesday's election showed today.

Carroll Trow Runyon, a brother of the late Federal Judge William N. Runyon, this city, died today in St. Michael's Hospital, Newark, N. J., at the age of 57. He was born here, the -son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Runyon.

John T. Hancock, member of the law firm of Peck Hancock of 32 Liberty Street, Manhattan, and prominent in civic affairs in his home community, Nutley, N. J., died at 12:10 this morning after he had jumped in front of a Hudson tube train in the Journal Square station here yesterday morning.

Victor Wolfson's "Excursion" is this evening's first-night fare, andthey are calling it a fantastic comedy--properly enough, it seems, for this is the tale of the 125th StreetConey Island skipper who throws off inhibitions and takes his craft right out to sea.

The largest field that ever faced a starter in the Kentucky Derby is expected to go to the post for the renewal of the Blue Grass classic at Churchill Downs May 8. This is the opinion of Colonel Matt Winn, president of the Kentucky Jockey Club and promoter of the Derby, who stopped off in New York yesterday and talked racing in his suite in the Waldorf-Astoria.

The annual shareholders report of Libby McNeill Libby and subsidiaries for the year ended on Feb. 27 shows a profit from operations of $3,941,267 after depreciation, interest, amortization, loss on disposal of fixed property, Federal income taxes and $87,000 Federal surtax on undistributed income.

Copies of a resolution favoring prompt action on slum clearance and endorsing the Wagner-Steagall Public Housing Bill now before Congress were sent yesterday to President Roosevelt and members of Congress by the National Public Housing Conference.

Montgomery Ward Co. reported yesterday that sales for March totaling $34,931,168 were the best for that month in its history. They are compared to $24,844,596 in March, 1936, an increase of 40 6 per cent.

Calls for statements of condition by national and other member banks of the Federal Reserve System as of March 31 were issued today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, and M. S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Increased demands for vacant stores for retail and display purposes and for office space in the downtown district characterized the reports by brokers of commercial leasing yesterday.

Less than twenty-four hours after he had been cleared of negligence in connection with the destruction of the liner Morro Castle, which burned at sea, Captain William F. Warms applied yesterday for permission to return to the sea as a ship's master.

The "excellent stock" represented in many of Boston's older families is one of the most hopeful influences in the development of a distinct "American race," said Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, curator of the division of anthropology at the National Museum, in an address today before the women's Republican Club.

The high treason trial of three Catholic priests and four laymen, which started yesterday in an attempt to prove before the People's Tribunal that the Catholics are allied with Communists, threatens to become a boomerang.

B. C. Heacock, president of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, announced tonight settlement of the strike which closed the plant on Tuesday and threw 11,500 men out of work. Mr. Heacock said the plant would reopen tomorrow.

The Washington Arms Apartments, on the southeast corner of Thirty-fifth Avenue and 147th Street, Flushing, Queens, a six-story building, have been sold by the Aronrose Realty Corporation, Robert Benenson, president, to the Theodore Realty Company through Burt Franklin.

Sales of General Motors cars to dealers in the United States in March set a new high record for any month with 216,606 units. They compared with the previous high mark of 197,065 in December, 1936, and with 176,510 in March, 1929, the best previous record for the month.
Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta and Wayne Sabin of Hollywood won the Atlanta, Ga., tennis doubles championship today by defeating Robert Riggs and Joel Hunt of Los Angeles, 4--6, 6--3, 6--3, 12--10.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage were hosts tonight at a dinner at the Piping Rock Club for their daughter, Miss Margaret Smith Salvage, and James Potter Polk, whose marriage will take place tomorrow afternoon at the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown.

Paul Niepold of Brookwood Labor College at Katonah, N. Y., a recruit in the International Brigade fighting on the Spanish Government's side, was killed today while attempting to rescue a wounded comrade at suburban barricades.
Raymond R. Donges of Merchantville, N. J., who had practiced law in Camden, N. J., for forty-two years, died today in Northeastern Hospital in this city. He was 65 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Harden Lake Crawford of this city and Rumson, N. J., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julia Lake Crawford, to William Irving Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Budington Harris of East Orange, N. J.

The Bagdad Copper Corporation, after a hearing today before the Securities and Exchange Commission on a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933, consented to entrance by the commission of a stop order.

The Newmont Mining Corporation, a United States operating company, has completed a deal by which it takes over a large interest in the Cyril Knight Prospecting Company, according to Fred Searls Jr., vice president of Newmont.

Whether Germany will pay to the United States $22,474,736 or any other amount on claims, arising from the wartime munitions explosions at Black Tom and Kingsland, N. J., in 1916 and 1917, is still to be decided by the German-American Mixed Claims Commission.

Bank clearings in the principal cities registered an abrupt upward turn in the week ended on Wednesday, which period included heavy first-of-the-month settlements. The total increased 15.2 per cent to $6,659,751,000 from $5,782,402,000 in the same week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In the preceding week there was a percentage loss of 10.7 per cent in a similar comparison.

While the rayon industry will continue to experience difficulty in meeting the growing demand for yarn during the current year, no runaway price situation is expected, according to The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

The Burly Amusement Company and the manager of its Abe Minsky's Gotham Theatre in East 125th Street were found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of giving an indecent performance last Aug. 27 in the theatre. The evidence was that five young women went through "strip-tease" acts to the accompaniment of soft music and softer lights.

At the direction of Justice Edgar J. Lauer, a jury in Supreme Court found yesterday that Clinton I. Nash, retired Boston business man, had been cheated to the extent of $50,000 in the purchase of an alleged old Lowestoft china dinner set from William W. J. Cooke, a former antique dealer, now a patient in Middletown State Hospital. Mr.

The Roosevelt Administration must encourage the making of profits so it can collect heavy taxes to pay the enormous debt being created, Representative Wright Patman (D.) of Texas, co-author of the Robinson-Patman Fair Trade Act, said in an address today before the twentieth annual convention of the American Brush Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Traymore, here.

Payment of the State income tax is due Thursday. The payments may be made through the mails or in person. The normal tax payment may be made in full or installments. The emergency tax must be paid in full.

Fred W. Clements, cashier of the Union National Bank, has been promoted to vice president; Frank J. Koetzel, from assistant cashier to vice president, and S. Beach Parker, from assistant cashier to cashier. The annual report of the Kildun Mining Corporation will be issued on Monday. The annual stockholders' meeting has been called for April 28.

Miss Dorothy Flagg Leet, director of Reid Hall, the American University Women's Center in Paris, was the guest of honor at a tea given by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve and the Department of French at Barnard College yesterday.

Reports from Salzburg that a pensioned Austrian official and his wife had been fined about $60 for depositing a wreath at the graves of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's parents at Leonding near the Austro-German frontier have evoked indignant comment in the Berlin press.

An American boat swept to victory today in the international racing for the Prince of Wales Trophy. It was the second contest, and Indian Scout, which led on points for the defeated team from the United States last year, won by a margin of 44 seconds over the second finisher, Herman F. Whiton's new Light Scout, his successor of Indian Scout, from Oyster Bay, L. I.

Mrs. Christine Marie Voss Lumsdon, painter, art instructor and lecturer on art, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. Mrs. Lumsdon had her studio and residence in Carnegie Hall. She was born In Brooklyn and educated at Adelphi Academy and the New York Normal College.

After a closed meeting tonight of Local 83, United Rubber Workers of America, a branch of the Committee for Industrial Organization, John R. Marchiando, C. I. O. organizer, said employes of the Thermoid Company, here, would continue on strike pending further negotiations.

In two pronouncements made today Germany in effect reaffirmed her determination to continue her present economic policy and to join the Western powers in efforts for a reduction of international trade barriers only if these powers were willing to meet her price.
John L. Lewis, leader of the Committee for industrial Organization, stopped here long enough today to attack Henry Ford for the latter's statement that he would never recognize a labor union.

Governor Lehman made public today an exchange of messages with Major Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, protesting against an alleged ban upon Negroes being enrolled in the CCC in New York State.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a new low figure for the year.

Canadian war veterans tomorrow will recall once more that achievement which twenty years ago rang through the world as one of the most brilliant of the great war--the storming and capture of Vimy Ridge.

Prevention of crime by providing better opportunities for potentially delinquent boys was stressed by several speakers last night at the thirty-third anniversary dinner of the Big Brothers Movement, at the Hotel Ambassador.

" Dapper Don" Collins, underworld character, and four other men held with him on Tuesday on a charge of conspiracy to violate the Gold Reserve Act of 1934. were uncontitionally freed by the government yesterday for lack of evidence.

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University Graduate School of Jouralism, informed the Canadian Press yesterday that the opinions of Professor Walter Pitkin did not represent the viewpoint of the graduate school.

Additional notifications of suggested minimum resale prices under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Law were received here yesterday, the list for the first time including such housewares as heaters and stoves.

Four bridge teams reached the semi-final round of the masters' team-of-four contract bridge championship yesterday at the conclusion of the qualifying rounds in the tournament conducted at the Park Central Hotel under the auspices of the American Bridge League. The semi-final round will be held today.

Premier Leon Blum reminded Italy tonight that France was "insistently" asking the withdrawal of foreign volunteers in Spain and maintained that his government's attitude of neutrality "gives the lie" to Italian charges of French intervention in the civil war.

Once more the New York State Republicans are demonstrating their complete political ineptitude. Last year they made the huge blunder of opposing the Governor's social security program. In addition they had the bright idea of " saving " the State some money by providing revenues for only nine months instead of a full year's debt service.

While the International Sugar Conference followed an uncertain course, Ambassador Norman H. Davis took out time for a possibly significant talk today at a luncheon given by Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, whose growing stature in the British Government may lead to the post of Chancellor of the Exchequer and eventually to the Prime Ministership.

Henry Gilbert Picard, the "Hershey Hurricane," overhauled- golf's professional brigade today to assume command at the half-way stage in the $5,000 Tournament of Gardens. Cracking par wide open in the face of adverse weather, the tall shot-maker, who started his professional career on the course here, moved in front for thirty-six holes with a total of 135 after shooting a 67 today.
The British Government made cautious overtures to Mohandas K. Gandhi today to seek an interview with the Viceroy, the Marquess of Linlithgow, and end the present constitutional deadlock in India.

Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg told The Associated Press tonight that restoration of the Hapsburg monarchy would have to wait for many years and he registered his belief that world rearmament was preparing the way for disarmament.

For the third successive year Tom Iannicelli won the world open squash tennis championship last night. In the final round at the Hotel Shelton the 29-year-old professional from the Short Hills Club defeated Rowland Dufton, veteran coach of the New York A. C., 7-15, 15-3, 15-10, 15-2.

Three additional surprise witnesses appeared yesterday at the Louis Luckman perjury trial in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, and testified they saw Luckman in the company of former Assistant District Attorney William W. Kleinman soon after the murder of Samuel Drukman.

Francis Brady, former deputy police inspector in charge of the Third (Broadway) district, died Wednesday night of heart disease at his home, 335 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Brady, who was 69 years old, had been retired from the Police Department for three years.
Grain markets advanced rather sharply at the opening on the Board of Trade here today with corn rising as much as 2 cents a bushel above the previous close.

Professor Gilbert Chinard of the University of California, formerly of Johns Hopkins University, was appointed Meredith Howland Pyne Memorial Professor of French Literature in Princeton University by the board of trustees at its Spring meeting today.
C. I. O. representatives pressing a national campaign to organize the petroleum industry met for several hours today with H. O. Wiess, Humble Company president, and other executives.
From the dust-laden atmosphere of Fort Worth the Yanks today came to the oil-soaked terrain of Oklahoma and a warm reception by an old pal of Marse Joe McCarthy, Jack Brillheart, veteran southpaw.

Trinity Church was the scene of the marriage this morning of Miss Marjorie Van Schaick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Van Schaick of Sasco Hill, to the Rev. Sewall Emerson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Kendall Emerson of New York.

National headquarters of the Distilled Spirits Institute have been opened here at 511 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday. The offices will be used by W. Forbes Morgan, head of the institute, and his staff, and by Norman W. Baxter in charge of public relations for the organization.

The New Friends of Music, Inc., concluded its 1936-37 season of sixteen chamber music concerts at Town Hall with a deficit of only $407.95. Eight hundred and ninetyfour subscribers paid a total of $16,024.75, the sole income of the enterprise.

Jesse Grabowsky, 49 years old, an unemployed civil engineer, ended his life yesterday morning at the Hotel Times Square by shooting himself in the head with a small rifle. He was found slumped in a chair by Rose Bodisch, a housemaid: He registered at the hotel on Wednesday.

The need for Federal legislation "to provide a means for industry to work out some of its problems by legal voluntary cooperation, subject to governmental supervision," was urged in the report of a committee of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association, received at its fifth annual dinner last night in the Biltmore Hotel.

Coincidentally with Thomas Mann's visit here next week, Alfred A. Knopf will publish in pamphlet form the correspondence between the author and the dean of the University of Bonn, consisting of the dean's announcement that the university was withdrawing the honorary degree it had once bestowed on Dr. Mann and the latter's long reply defining his attitude toward Nazi Germany and its culture.
Arthur Carron, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, and Helen Traubel, soprano, making her debut, will take the main roles in the world premiere of Walter Damrosch's opera, "The Man Without a Country,"
With preparations well advanced for the celebration of the centenary of Mount Holyoke College on May 7 and 8, details of the full and varied program were made known today.

What happened on Wednesday in the town of Hershey, Pa., emphasizes from a new point of view the dangers involved in the use of such a weapon as the sit-down strike. In an attempt to force an employer to meet their terms, a minority of employes followed the now familiar practice of seizing the plant in which they worked.

Luke Vincent Lockwood, chairman of the executive committee of the Greenwich Trust Company, has leased an apartment of thirteen rooms and four baths in 33 East Seventieth Street from the Tishman Realty and Construction Company.

Word of the death in China of Brig. Gen. Thomas H. Jackson, former president of the Mississippi River Commission, was received by relatives here today. The retired officer died Wednesday while on a world cruise with Mrs. Jackson. He was 63 years old.

Emil Kirdorf, Nestor of National Socialism and the first wealthy industrialist to support financially the present regime, was decorated today with the Eagle Shield, the highest honor of the Third Reich.

Miss Ruth Florence Craft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd L. Craft of Woodmere and John Walker Fulcher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Walker Fulcher of Far Rockaway were married Wednesday morning at St. Mary Star of the Sea Catholic Church, Far Rockaway, by Mgr. John J. F. Robinson.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Clifford Moore of Southern Pines, to Arthur Bynum Patterson of Boston took place at the home of the bride this evening. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. F. Craighill Brown, rector of Emanuel Episcopal Church of Southern Pines.

Dr. R. P. McClellan, president of the Jersey Cereal Company, has announced that the plant at near-by Cereal would be moved to Chicago. A strike closed the factory March 21 and Dr. McClellan said pickets had refused to permit company officials and office workers through their lines.

As a strike for union recognition called by the United Automobile Workers of America, and involving 3,700 workers, went into effect today in the Oshawa plant of General Motors of Canada, Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario gave warning to the Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate that Ontario would tolerate no such "chaos" and near "anarchy," as he said the John L. Lewis forces had brought about in the United States.

Test trains will begin operation tomorrow over the new section of city subway line from Kew Gardens to 169th Street, Jamaica, the local office of the PWA announced yesterday. The section will be opened to the public in about two weeks, completing the Queens branch of the Independent Subway System.

The decline in the foreign exchanges, which began on Wednesday, following the circulation abroad of rumors that the United States Treasury planned to reduce Its buying price for gold, continued with redoubled force yesterday.
The government has appointed Mr. Jazerzetski, Under-Secretary of State in the Ministry of Labor, as Price Commissioner.
Winged Victory, from the Milky Way Farm, finished two lengths in front of the field to win the featured fifth race today at Arlington Downs. The victor traveled the six furlongs in 1:13 2-5.

Formal request for a conference to discuss the announced intention of boys' clothing manufacturers to reduce discount terms on volume orders to 7 per cent off, ten days, was made yesterday by the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in a letter sent to Abraham Landau, president of the Boys' and Students' Clothing Manufacturers Association and treasurer of Julius Schwartz Sons, Inc.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported today that, of disbursements of $6,434,588,331 for activities of the corporation other than advances to other governmental agencies and for relief, made since its establishment on Feb. 2, 1932, through March, 1937, $4,537,252,003, or about 71 per cent, already had been repaid.

Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada during the week ended April 7 showed an increase of $2,657,263 over the previous week, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued, today.

A 292-pound marlin, measuring ten feet, was landed today by P. J. McIntosh of New York in a twohour battle in the Gulf Stream. It was one of the largest marlin ever caught on this section of the Florida East Coast.
Governor Earle issued this statement today in ordering an investigation of the strike riot at Hershey: "The bloodshed at the Hershey plant was a disgrace to the Commonwealth.
President Anastasio Somoza today decreed nationalization of the Pacific Railroad of Nicaragua, formerly incorporated in the State of Maine.
An appeal on behalf of a Hindu idol to establish its claim to property in India was dismissed today by the judicial committee of the Privy Council, ending twenty years of litigation.

Following a breakdown of negotiations with jewelry manufacturers, about 350 tool, hub and die workers went on strike today in fifty Providence jewelry plants, according to David Clydesdale, Grand Lodge representative of the Jewelry Toolmakers and Hub and Die Cutters Lodge.

The secret political police confiscated a pamphlet entitled "We Summon Germany to God," written jointly by the Rev. Martin Niemoeller and Superintendent Friedrich Dibelius, Confessional Synod spokesmen.

Twelve civic and labor organizations combined yesterday with thirty-one individuals prominent in civic affairs in an effort to block the proposed $50,000 investigation of relief agencies by the Board of Aldermen, which will come before the Board of Estimate at today's meeting in City Hall for action.

Miss Frances Coleman gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's in advance of the garden bazaar and bridge there for the benefit of Savea-Life Farm. Among her guests were Mrs. Albert L. Hoffman, Miss Margaret Skinner, Mrs. George E. Coleman, Miss Ida Guerin, Mrs. William Pendleton, Miss Yvonne Gourd, Miss Agnes Finn, Mrs. James E. Barney and the Misses Katherine and Mary Strong.

A quick apology for two attempts to bomb the British destroyer Gallant on Tuesday came today from the Insurgent authorities at Palma, Majorca, in contrast to the continuing absence of any expression of regrets for the attacks on the destroyers Gypsy and Havoc in February.

A group of the Forty-niners and their immediate followers (when scarcely 2 per cent of the population were women), becoming concerned about the education of their daughters, established (in 1852) a young ladies' seminary in the temporary capital of the State of California--Benicia.

Railway shipments of commodities in New York and near-by States in April, May and June are expected to increase 4 per cent from the level of the same period a year previous, according to estimates submitted at a meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board in Elmira. N. Y., yesterday.

The Frederic A. Juilliard fellowship to the American Academy in Rome has been awarded to Frederick Woltmann of New York as the result of the annual competition March 30, it was announced yesterday. He is 28 years old.

Having shaken off all other rivals, including Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, former world champion, and with only one more round to be contested, Reuben Fine of New York and Paul Keres of Parnu, Estonia, were tied today for first place in the international masters tournament at the Kent County Chess Association congress.
A drive for $400,000 for a new home and workshops was begun last night by the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind at a dinner at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

Joseph R. Johann and Anthony La Via scored in the Poggenburg 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night. Johann defeated John Hutchins, 175 to 69, in 26 innings, and La Via conquered Howard Bergman, 175 to 158, in 36. Johann had a high run of 33, Hutchins 11, La Via 22 and Bergman 34.
Steel Workers Organizing Committee leaders today ended a four-hour unauthorized sit-down strike affecting 3,800 employes at the Mesta Machine Company's plant in West Homestead.

Rushing an emergency bill through both houses of Parliament today, the government proscribed a strike of 70,000 workers scheduled for Saturday. The government, as in an earlier industrial crisis, accepted the award of its mediator and made it law. On this occasion, the workers accepted the award but the employers rejected it.

A House obviously weary of investigations tabled by a vote of 184 to 38 today the Dickstein resolution calling for an inquiry into alleged un-American activities and propaganda in this country after it had been denounced as likely to engender race and religious feeling.

The government regrets very much that the employes of General Motors have seen fit to follow the suggestions of the C. I. O. paid propagandists from the United States and to desert their posts at a time when both the employes and the industry itself were in a position to enjoy a prosperity not known since 1929.

The Treasury announced today that its issue of bills on April 14 would amount to about $50,000,000, or enough to meet the maturity on that date of $50,052,000, instead of the $100,000,000 that it has been issuing for the last six weeks.

Frank M. Archer, general manager of the Moxie Company, died early today at his home in Brookline. He was 74 years of age. He was also chairman of the board of the beverage firm which has sold more than $140,000,000 worth of Moxie.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told at a dinner commemorating the 25th anniversary of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor here tonight how she had been described in a letter she received today as "America's First Nuisance."

Bishop Louis Shvoy, emissary from the Catholic hierarchy of Hungary, arrived last night on the Italian liner Rex with an official invitation to American Catholics to attend the Eucharistic Congress in Budapest in May, 1938.

There was a fresh, new tingle to the air spreading through the city last night, starting from a corner on Eighth Avenue and reaching right out to the heart of every young boy or girl, or man or woman.
Coach Andy Kerr called out the Colgate football squad for the first Spring practice this afternoon. Some fifty candidates reported, although several were kept away by afternoon classes.

Ten men and two women were arrested in a series of battles 'yesterday between picketing strikers and groups of young women and strike guards, who were escorting them into the plant of the Etched Products Corporation at 39-01 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, where about 300 employes have been on strike since March 22.

Nine directors, including the president, of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation have sent a letter to stockholders asking them to elect at the annual meeting on May 4 a group of directors who will not be dominated by the American Metal Company, Ltd.
The North German Lloyd liner Europa arrives today from Bremen and channel ports. On board are Orestes Ferrara, former Cuban Ambassador to the United States, with Mrs. Ferrara;

President Roosevelt, in a message tonight to 600 friends of the Children's Bureau upon the occasion of a dinner celebrating the twentyfifth anniversary of the bureau's founding, praised the work of the organization and its founders and administrators.

The march of the New York Rangers to the Stanley Cup was checked tonight. The Detroit Red Wings, holders of the cup and the world hockey championship, snapped the sensational post-season streak of the, amazing men of Manhattan in the second game of the teams' series 'by the score of 4 to 2 in an exciting battle that was witnessed by a capacity crowd of 14,000 persons.

Automobile trailers to suit nearly every fancy were placed on exhibition at the County Center today when the Southern New York and Connecticut Trailer Show opened. It was the first indoor show in the United States devoted chiefly to trailers, according to R. L. Fox, assistant show manager.
Japan undertook today to limit her exports of hosiery to the United States to 18,000,000 pairs annually for the period Jan. 1, 1937-Dec. 31, 1939.

Mayor La Guardia added the role of book salesman to the many others he has filled in his public career, when he appeared yesterday before more than 1,000 prospective customers in the book-shop of R. H. Macy Co.

A list of nations of the world where true democracy is still functioning, chiefly notable for its omission of Great Britain, was presented yesterday-at the opening session of the biennial conference of the National Federation of Day Nurseries at the Hotel Commodore.

The executive committee of the World Jewish Congress announced today that it had been informed that the Danzig Senate had decided to introduce there the same racial legislation as that in force in Germany. The committee has taken several steps to prevent "this projected violation of the Constitution guaranteed by the League."
Jacob L. Schwarz, wholesaler and banker in Newark, died. last night at his home here. He was 64 years old. Mr. Schwarz was president of Schwarz Son, wholesalers of candy, tobacco and liquor.
