Moscow's birth rate for the first three months of 1937 was reported today virtually double that of the corresponding period last year.

Gifts of a valuable jade collection and five paintings to intimate addition friends of the late Charles Hayden were announced yesterday by J. Willard Hayden of Boston, his brother, to whom they had been willed.

The Ambassador of Cuba, Peter Martinez Fraga, announced tonight that he had been instructed to invite authorized representatives of American groups holding approximately $84,000,000 of public works bonds of the Machado administration to a conference in Havana to discuss settlement of the debt. The bonds have been in default since 1933.

Captain Martin F. Callagy, oldest firefighter in the city in point of service, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday following a heart attack. He is 75 years old and has been in the department fifty-three years. He was stricken while at his post at the foot of West Thirty-fifth Street, where he has been in command of the fireboat James Duane since 1925.

Two extortion indictments against Alexander Pompez, fugitive policy racketeer under arrest in Mexico, D. F., were handed up yesterday by the special grand jury to Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

Two divisions of the American Bowling Congress championships in progress at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory received new pacesetters yesterday as a pair of New Jersey keglers took the lead in the doubles section and a Michigan quintet forged ahead in the fiveman team standing.

Miss Rosamond Harris Dryden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Dryden, and John Paulding Farnham of New York, son of Mrs. Pauline Farnham and the late Mr. Farnham of New York, were married here this evening in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer by the Rev. Harold Arrowsmith, Canon of the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

High school students who desire to succeed were advised to follow the example of leaders of business and industry who do not observe a forty-hour week, in an address given by F. E. Searle, superintendent of the Henry Ford Trade School, Dearborn, Mich., at the second annual career conference, which opened yesterday at the R. C. A. Building, Rockefeller Center.

The organized onslaught from the German press in the case of a railway official Franz Brueckner, who had been fined a small sum and deprived of his pension for a political demonstration, was answered tonight in a sharply worded communique that Colonel Walther Adam, head of the Federal press service, broadcast personally.

Piercing gale-like winds with his whistling drives and excelling with his approach shots, Sam Snead, the 24-year-old golf rookie from White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., regained the lead today m the seventy-twohole $5,000 Tournament of Gardens.

With the Spanish civil war at the end of its ninth month, it is a constant cause of wonder here that the Rebel government can go on fighting month after month without a gold reserve and without suitable foreign loans. The truth is that neutral Britain, with her great volume of imports and her growing purchasing power,

Fourteen out of nearly 100 entrants were eliminated from further competition tonight in the national A. A. U. wrestling championship tournament at the Baltimore Y. M. C. A. When the opening program ended at midnight the second round was still unfinished.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Denckla Howe of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss May Denckla Howe, to George Roberts Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy H. Clark of Willoughby, Cynwyd.

The nation's automotive industry, strikeless for the first time in five months, headed for high production levels again tonight. The Chrysler Corporation, pushing its plans to resume 6,000-a-day capacity operations next week after a month-long labor dispute, issued calls for all workers in plants of its Dodge division to report for work on their regular shifts Monday.

James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, and Charles W. Culkin, leader of the Third district, have gone to Miami to see James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, and to advise him to resign, it was reported yesterday in local Democratic circles.

Soldiers armed with machine guns were standing guard today in the textile factory town of San Martin Texmelucan, State of Puebla, after a battle between members of two rival labor unions in which eight were killed and twenty wounded.
Georgetown defeated Harvard, 16 to 15, today in a ten-inning game featured by the relief pitching of Mike Petroskey and hard hitting on both sides.

As a result of a new coolness that has developed between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Field Lord Erich Ludendorff since their recent reconciliation, the Field Lord's seventy-second birthday passed today without his receiving any of the honors that had been expected for him.

The sit-down strike of gravediggers in Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington, spread this afternoon to Holy Name Cemetery, Jersey City, and in the latter burial ground one coffin lay in an open grave for three hours in the rain while cemetery authorities sought to persuade workmen to cover it with earth.
Laughing at the Dodgers still may be a favorite outdoor sport, even in Florida, but frequently the Flatbush boys get the final chuckle and enjoy it most.

Convinced of the insanity of Robert Irwin, sculptor and former divinity student whom they accuse of the Easter Sunday killing of Veronica Gedeon, artists' model; her mother and their roomer, Frank Byrnes,
One cent was "saved" by the American Federation of Labor when it . obtained an injunction which tied up funds of the rebellious aluminum workers' local at New Kensington.

If the old-age pension systems of the country are to be kept from "degenerating into a racket," the "stranglehold" of politics on them must be broken and the Federal Government "must assume a firmer control and insist on honesty and intelligence in administration," social security leaders asserted yesterday.

Following is the argument against the President's court proposal presented to the Senate Judiciary Committee today by Frederic R. Coudert in behalf of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York: TO THE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE OF THE UNITED STATES SENATE:

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May in Queens granted yesterday an order restraining striking members of The Long Island Press from picketing the Food Show in the 104th Field Artillery Armory in Jamaica, pending argument Monday on a permanent injunction.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George B. Gibbons of Rye, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Gibbons, to Miller P. Longbotham, son of Mrs. Bertram Longbotham of Brooklyn.
Reports were current today that the Justice Department was about to drop its investigation into charges by Representative Cannon that big league baseball was guilty of illegal "monopoly."

Unanimously reversing a lower court ruling, the Appellate Division held yesterday that the Florida East Coast Railway Company was not a beneficiary of a $17,000,000 trust fund created in the will of Mrs. - Mary Lily Flagler Bingham, late wife of the American Ambassador to England.
The body of Harry Waldfogel, 50 years old, of 118 Trowbridge Street, Cambridge, Mass., was found yesterday morning in his room on the fifth floor of the Hotel Edison, 228 West Forty-seventh Street.

Nothing quite so refreshing as "Excursion" has turned up in this neighborhood since Spring settled down over Broadway. It is Victor Wolfson's beguilingly fantastic comedy of a Coney Island steamboat that shows her heels to Manhattan and starts jubilantly south for the warm Caribbean Sea.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frederick Zeltner of Scarsdale, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anita Louise Zeltner, to Thomas Vail Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stanford Brooks of Ardsleyon-Hudson and Woodstock, Vt.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Van Cortlandt Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Mahlon Smith of Newark, to William Gardner Mundy of New York, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George P. T. Sargent, the rector.
Creation of what would be virtually an international raw cotton cartel was proposed today before the International Textile Conference by Sir Firoz Khan Noon, government delegate from India.

For ten innings yesterday Jimmy Caras, the defending world pocket billiard champion, was neither hot nor cold, and the possibility of an upset at the hands of Charles Seaback of Boston was far from remote.

Numerous increases in salaries were made last year by the Northern Pacific Railway, its report to the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed yesterday. The salary of Charles Donnelly, president, remained unchanged at $42,000. Among the changes were the following:

Cardinal Hayes Conference on Charity begins with mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 9:30 A. M. and continues at session at Hotel Commodore at 10:30 A. M. Luncheon 12:45 P. M. Afternoon session 2:30 P. M.
Working under miserable weather conditions, the Long Island Beagle Club began its fourth annual three-day field trial meet today with a fair entry in the trio of events on the opening program.

Five persons were killed and eleven critically injured today when an electric train plowed into a crowd of persons who had taken shelter in a tunnel when sirens warned of the approach of Insurgent war planes.
David P. Millar, in business here for sixty-three years, died today at the age of 82. An active Republican, he served terms as County Commissioner and County Road Director.

Jacob Amron of Jack Dempsey's restaurant turned over to Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday an envelope containing $3,900 in cash which had been left with him by Paul N. Coulcher, convicted extortioner, two days before the restaurant racket trial started.

Harry Pringle Ford, for forty years Secretary of the Board of Publications of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, died yesterday at his home in Norwood, after an illness of two weeks. He would have been 81 years old tomorrow.

Sir Henry Hadow, pedagogue and writer, died today at his home here. He was 77 years old. Sir Henry followed the teaching profession for more than half a century and in addition wrote many books on musical topics and early in his career composed a sonata for piano and a string quartet.

The shriek of a 12-year-old girl who had just been stabbed spurred her 11-year-old sister to her aid yesterday afternoon. Disregarding the knife, the younger child drove a boarder whom the family had befriended to the street and pursued him three blocks to the apartment of his estranged wife.

Although peace still prevailed in this city of 28,000 inhabitants tonight, on the second day of the General Mctors strike, violence was feared if the company proceeds with its announced intention of reopening its closed parts department tomorrow morning, and if the United Automobile Workers of America is unable to prevent its rank and file from attacking workers whom it regards as strike-breakers.

Mrs. Audrey Wupperman Brooks was married to William Melhuish Byam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy H. Byam of Yonkers, N. Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Edward Wupperman of Calhoun Drive, Greenwich, tonight.
The Italian press completely forgot Spain today, its attention having been distracted by attacks made against Italy by some foreign newspapers for the expulsion from Ethiopia of a number of missions.

If the experience of Chicago hotels during the World's Fair there can be taken as a criterion, hotel advertising in this city during the 1939 event here should rise anywhere from 24 to 450 per cent over the preceding year. Needham Grohmann, Inc., which handles a number of hotel accounts yesterday reported the Chicago figures in their bulletin, "The Hotel Advertiser."

The marriage of Miss Margaret Smith Salvage, second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage of Rynwood, to James Potter Polk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lyon Polk of Syosset and New York, took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown at Locust Valley.

President Stanley King of Amherst College does not mind bailing errant students out of jail on Sunday mornings. "It happens," he explained to Amherst alumni at a dinner here, "that I own a piece of real estate in Springfield which is good Sunday bail. So on Sunday mornings,

Ward's Reports, Inc., today estimated the current week's output of motorcars at 100,470 units, compared with 97,710 last week and 110,190 in the like week of 1936. Cram's Reports placed this week's assemblies at 98,910, compared with 95,827 last week and 112,815 in the corresponding week a year ago.

Officers of the Ohio National Guard have been sent to thirteen counties indicated by the Relief Commission as areas where the hungry must be fed by the Guard after April 15. The State has no money, says the Governor. Local subdivisions have none or are too mean to use it. Governor DAVEY is an extraordinary person.

An "anti-war poll" conducted among students of Columbia College by The Spectator, campus daily, revealed yesterday that the 486 students who cast ballots stood almost equally divided on the question, "Do You Regard All Wars as Unjustifiable?" While 238 answered this query affirmatively, 284 voted no.

Eleven clubs already have filed entries for the Arthur Lehman Memoral Trophy golf tournament to be held at the Century Country Club, Purchase, N. Y., on June 13, according to an announcement yesterday by V. Theodore Low, chairman of the tournament committee.

Pope Pius XI has conferred upon Mrs. Thomas J. O'Neill of Yonkers the medal "Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice" in recognition of her work for the Catholic Boys Brigade, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the brigade, 316 West Eighty-fifth Street.

Miss Mary Drane and Miss Virginia Drane, violinists, and Miss Leone Pettigrew, harpist, presented a musical at the annual meeting of the Greenwich Travel Club in the Masonic Temple this afternoon. Mrs. Douglas A. Milward, assisted by Mrs. Minot C. Morgan, arranged the program.

The Dalhousie Club of New York, which has a membership of more tan 500 alumni of Dalhousie University, Halifax, N. S., will hold its annual dinner and dance at the Hotel Gotham on Saturday evening, April 17.
The Junior League Coronation dinner dance was attended by more than 1,000 guests tonight in the BellevueStratford ballroom.

Closer cooperation between private and public welfare agencies for the good of the entire community was urged yesterday by the Rev. John J. Donovan, director of the Division of Families of Catholic Charities, in making the annual report of activities in his division for 1936.

When the shocked signatories of the Locarno treaty met in London a year ago to decide what they would do with the remains after Hitler had smashed the pact by marching into the Rhineland, Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium did not sleep for seventy-two hours.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag yesterday ordered Bruns Brothers, Inc., coal dealers, to change their name within fifteen days so that it will not be confused with Burns Brothers, Inc., also coal dealers. He held that the first named company was "obviously" attempting to trade on the reputation of the second.

A crowded house which included many standees greeted the DeBasil Ballet Russe last night upon its return to New York for a brief engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House before its annual departure for Europe.

The marriage of Miss Janet Pallen Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Clinton Noyes of 23 East Seventy-sixth Street and Sharon, Conn., to John Preston Potts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Rockhill Potts of this city and Hewlett, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon at the Carlyle.
A Winter wheat crop of 656,019,000 bushels, the largest since 1931, was forecast for this year in the April 1 estimate of the government Crop Reporting Board made public today.

The Hershey Chocolate plant opened here today with at least half of the workers back at their posts. But many others, either avowed participants in the C. I. O. strike or sympathizers, joined a formidable picket line in front of the plant while the strike leaders conferred fruitlessly all day with company officials and Federal and State mediators.
The government market specialist predicted today that domestic wool prices would continue at high levels in the first few months of the new marketing season, starting this month.

With no more effort than is ordinarily expended on a cold day trying to keep warm, the Yankees today breezed through to victory over the Tulsa Oilers, Texas League pennant winners of last year and victors in the Dixie Series, before a gathering of 5.000 chilled natives.

President Roosevelt, at his press conference, denied reports that the government contemplated lowering the purchase price of gold, reiterated his hope for no legisnation for new taxes at this session of Congress, and said he would send his relief estimates to Congress next week.

The Federal Trade Commission frowns on the label "Made in the U. S. A." Unless this is entirely true of the article even to the raw materials, it was indicated at the twentieth annual convention of the American Brush Manufacturers Association in the Hotel Traymore today.
The Drama Study Club yesterday afternoon gave its medal to Paul Green as the author of the club's favorite play of the year, "Johnny Johnson." During the ceremonies,

The mystery of the unclaimed $15,000 diamond brooch, which had Mme. Ginette de Paris, dress designer in whose shop the ornamental clasp was found, and her staff of assistants frantically trying to find the owner for a week,

Zion de Frece Bernstein, president, treasurer and founder of the Norton Retail Stores, Inc., a women's and children's apparel store at 34-42 West Fourteenth Street, and long a leader in Jewish charities, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 450 West End Avenue, after a ten-day illness. He was 55 years old.

Miss Charlotte Irving Noyes, daughter of Mrs. D. Grinnell Noyes of 1,120 Park Avenue and of C. Reinold Noyes of 53 East Sixtysixth Street and St. Paul, was married to William Raymond Driver Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Driver of Milton, Mass., yesterday afternoon in All Souls Unitarian Church by theRev. Dr. Minot Simons.

The role of government as "the great adjuster of conflicting interests under popular control" was described last night by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, as "a task of vast proportions imperfectly performed as yet."

Details FIREMAN--Patrick Kearney, Engine is to the 2d Division, on light duty. FIREMAN-Joseph p. Dugan, H. L 105, to Brooklyn Headquarters, as elevator operator. Name Change The name of Ununiformed Fireman Thorwald C. Finkelson, H. L. 131, is corrected to read: Thorvald C. Finkelson.

Declaring that it "is not improbable that some day the safety of the United States" may depend on the oil in the Elk Hills Naval Oil Reserve in California, the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs reported to the Senate today an amended Naval Oil Conservation Bill to vest the President and the Navy Department with greater control over the Elk Hills and other oil deposits now held in reserve by the navy.

Rose Titus, 31-year-old unmarried mother, who is said to have confessed throwing her 2-monthold daughter into South River April 1, will be examined by allenists next week and a charge of murder will be lodged against her if she is found sane.

President Roosevelt denied today reports that the administration planned a change in its gold-buying policy to set the price below the present level of $35 an ounce. His denial was made at a press conference.

Some of the vicissitudes of a President's wife among friends were described last night by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at a dinner In the Biltmore in observance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Girl Scouts in the United States.

Weakness in French exchange disturbed prices on the Cotton Exchange in the early trading yesterday and a decline uncovered stoploss limits to an extent that carried July below 13 3/4 cents a pound and October to 13 1/4 cents before the selling ran its course.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,007,000 bales, against 1,020,000 a week ago, 969,000 two weeks ago, 943,000 three weeks ago and 732,000 a year ago, of which American 439,000 bales, against 443,000 a week ago, 423,000 two weeks ago, 420,000 three weeks ago and 341,000 a year ago.

Medals and awards for distinctive merit for the outstanding examples of advertising art in various media were given yesterday to advertisers, agencies, art directors and artists who competed in the Sixteenth Annual Exhibition of Advertising Art, sponsored by the Art Directors Club.
Paul A. Monahan, brother of Alderman Joseph J. Monahan of Brooklyn, died on Thursday night at his home, 61 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of two months. He was 51 years old. Mr.

Bert S. Michell, ruled off the turf on a charge that a horse he trained was stimulated artificially, moved for a hearing today, while his attorney and his employer voiced suspicion the case was a frame-up.
A government decree today set the national elections for the States General-on May 26 for the Lower House and on May 27 for the Upper House. Parliament will be dissolved on April 17.

New bond financing this week consisted exclusively of State and municipal loans, with seven taxexempt issues placed on the market, aggregating only $4,443,000, the smallest volume since the week ending Nov. 6, last year, when offerings amounted to $450,000.

The coincidence of the Spring season and a new show in the Rainbow Room offers a fit opportunity for a few quick observations upon this most extraordinary of local supper clubs-for one, because the Spring has always brought in the best business there and, too, because the present show is, on the whole, just what the doctor ordered for it.

Fully 5,000 members of the Transport Workers Union, most of them employes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, voted last night for a resolution asking Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Regional Director of the National Labor Relations Board, for a system-wide election on the Interborough before May 1 to choose a single union to represent all employes in collective bargaining with the management.
Blind persons as well as lepers were believed doomed to death tonight as civil and military authorities continued hunting down and executing the lepers.

The newly formed Non-Partisan American Committee for Spanish Relief, which will launch shortly a nation-wide appeal for funds to help relieve distress occasioned by the civil war in Spain, is planning to establish branches in all the principal American cities soon, Joseph F. Moore, its secretary, announced last night.

Thirteen Americans and twelve others were sentenced to twenty days in jail today for attempting to cross the French frontier into Spain to join the Loyalist forces. The men were captured March 27 on the fishing smack Sanspareil off Port Vendres.
The Rev. Creighton SpencerMounsey of Kings Park, L. I., retired Episcopal clergyman, died yesterday at St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn.

Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, extended his series of private conferences with international leaders here to France today in a conversation with Charles Spinasse, Minister of National Economy.

Wilmerding, Pa., defending champion, advanced to the semifinal round of the national Y. M. C. A. basketball tournament tonight by defeating Kokomo, Ind., 76 to 21. Wilmerding will play Williamsport in one semi-final tomorrow, while Jersey City and Harrisburg meet in the other.
With the return here today of John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, the bitter rivalry between the C. I. O. and the American Federation of Labor entered another phase.

Since 6 o'clock this morning I have been watching the government attack on a large scale that is designed eventually to link up the forces on the heights of the Coruna road with others advancing from Carabanchel and Casa de Campo, cutting the neck of the salient that Rebel forces have thrust toward University City and thus lifting the Rebel pressure from Madrid.

Reports of the early fishing this season in the trout streams of the State--especially those which lie on the fringes of the metropolitan area--bring no tales of full creels. But there is no dearth of fishermen, even though the catch is sparse. This is not hard to understand.

A tornadic windstorm accompanying a severe electrical disturbance surprised sleeping residents of Miami's southwest section before dawn today, toppled trees and unroofed their houses and injured a dozen persons.

Eleven women, 70 years old and over, all members of the Amelia Relief Society, a pioneer nonsectarian charitable organization, were honored at a luncheon yesterday by the Godmothers League at the league's Shelter for Babies, 115 East 101st Street.

Retail trade here improved its comparative showing this week and department store executives estimated gains in this area ranged around 5 per cent above the same week last year, which was the week immediately- before Easter.

Blind workers continued sit-down strikes in two charitable workshops for the blind yesterday while directors of the organizations refused to negotiate with the strikers until they evacuated the places.

James T. Hunter, 45-year-old golf veteran of North Adams, Mass., and 17-year-old Bobby Dunkelberger of High Point, N. C., battled successfully through two rounds today to provide the annual North and South Amateur Tournament with a final matching the oldest qualifier against the youngest.

Senator Frederick Steiwer of Oregon proposed today an amendment to the Constitution which would provide for a nation-wide primary every four years in which the people would vote their - preferences for nominations of President and Vice President.

Frank Kingdon, actor on the Broadway stage for forty years, died this afternoon of pneumonia at the Actors' Fund Home here, where he had been living for a year. Mr. Kingdon, who was 72 years old, was born in Providence, L. I.
The Federal Trade Commission today approved trade-practice rules for the covered button and buckle manufacturing industry along the lines proposed by Covered Button and Buckle Creators, Inc.,
The Butterfly Ball dinner dance, for several years one of the most popular entertainments of the Spring season, took place last night in the main ballroom and Oval Restaurant of the Ritz-Carlton.

Rumors that the United States would lower the price of gold were largely responsible for erratic fluctuations in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today. An early break of around a cent a bushel in wheat and corn futures was followed by an advance of 2 cents when the rumors were denied, but the volume of trade was light.
Constantine Stronghilos, a New York pianist of Greek and English extraction, made his local debut in a recital at Town Hall last night. Mr. Stronghilos displayed inherent talent in his performances.

THIS reviewer thought he was sick of tales of circumnavigation and of men who, in an age of steam, hanker for the good old days of sailing ships. But Alan Villiers has cured him, and the "Cruise of the Conrad" (Scribner, $3.75), although it is exactly that sort of 'tale written by exactly that sort of man, is gladly prescribed for other sufferers from this form of mal de mer.
Clarence Birch Stoner, secretary and treasurer of the Hotels Statler Company, Inc., died today of heart disease at his home on Hobart Avenue here after an illness of several months.

Captain William F. Warms, who was in command of the liner Morro Castle when she was burned and wrecked in September, 1934, regained his status as a shipmaster yesterday. A new..license was issued to him by Captain Karl C. Nielsen of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation' after he had ' passed physical' and mental examinations.

The entire forty-seventh floor, comprising 16,000 square feet of space, in 30 Rockefeller Plaza, the new building in Rockefeller Center, has been leased by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., to Allied Products, Inc., specialists in the production of perfume, cosmetics and toilet preparations.

The New York Stock Exchange has received notification that Leslie Wink will retire as a partner in Maloney, Anderson Block on May 1 and that William G. Finucane will retire from Tefft Co. on April 30. Mr. Finucane is a member of the Exchange.

Assurances that the Erie Railroad was ready to eliminate some of the objectionable features of its North Branch train curtailment schedule, recently announced, were received tonight at a meeting of Mayors and trustees of five New York villages served by the railroad. The meeting was held in the Nyack Village Hall.

Friends of Cecil Miracle, for ten years a prominent lumberman of Bell County, rallied to his defense today against charges that he is an escaped convict from Alabama. Miracle's Jean Valjean story came to light when two men appeared at his Clear Creek home and took him in custody after displaying a circular which they said bore a likeness to him.

Three games of indoor polo at Squadron A Armory tonight may bring the 1937 season to its close. Starting at 8 o'clock, the second games of the East-West championships will get under way, and the same results tonight as those of Wednesday would bring the national championships to a close.

Edgar T. Appleby defeated Lester Fisher, 300 to 137, in twentyfour innings, in one of three games in the Poggenburg Memorial 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night.

Administration forces in the Senate rallied today to prevent the passage of a resolution offered. by Senator Gerald P. Nye, Republican, of North Dakota, to ask Secretary of State Cordell Hull whether existing neutrality laws should be applied against nations participating in the Spanish civil war.

United States Government bonds reflected a decidedly better undertone yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, although on a sharply reduced trading volume. The improvement in the Treasury list went hand in hand with moderate recoveries among the better grade corporate issues.
A Japanese sportsman has written to me as follows: "The Japanese are looking forward to 1940, when we shall be the hosts to thousands at the Olympic Games.
Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, favorite, and Wayne Sabin of Hollywood fought their way into the semi-finals of the River Oaks tennis tournament today.

The Dauphin County Court dismissed today a suit brought by Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti seeking to revoke the charters and franchises of the corporations underlying the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company.

Long Island is to have a new tuna club this year, and perhaps some day it will rank with many of the other famous organizations of this type that are to be found in various sections of the world where deepsea fishermen gather.

The fate of the Social Security program, regarded by the Roosevelt administration as one of its greatest achievements, was left in the hands of the Supreme Court today as arguments were completed on a test of the law.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Wiggins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph St. Clair Wiggins of: this city, to Randolph Underwood Stambaugh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Stambaugh of Hanover, Pa., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Flatbush, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold Summerfield Olafson, a cousin of the bride.

The completed Queens branch of the city's Independent Subway will begin passenger service the afternoon of April 24, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. Completion of the branch will add four new stations to the line and mark the beginning of express service on a rush-hour basis.

The first hint that our own epidemic of sit-down strikes threatens to spread across the border into Canada has brought a plainly spoken warning from the Premier of Ontario. He does not intend it to be taken as indicating hostility to labor, for he insists that his Government has enacted much legislation in the interest of labor and that it proposes to enact more.
New Yorkers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex include Mrs. Lowell Thomas, Mrs. A. L. Konta, Mrs. T. J. Hickey, Count von Franken Sierstopff and Mrs. Ada Candioli Uberti.

Many headliners of the stage, screen and radio appeared in the entertainment at the eighth annual dance of the Press Photographers Association of New York at the Hotel Commodore, last night. More than 2,000 persons were present. Well-known cartoonists and columnists contributed to the fiftyfive-page souvenir program.
The Feld bill, providing for employment from appropriate civil lists of custodians in New York City school buildings, together with assistants and cleaners, will go before the Governor soon.

Flats in scattered sections of Manhattan were acquired yesterday by buyers who intend to alter them. The purchase by Rosenstock Bachrach, operators, of the three four-story and one three-story tenement houses at 2,004-6-8 Third Avenue and 173-5 East 110th Street, the northwest corner, was announced.

The milk price war that many predicted would develop with the end of State price-fixing April 1 has not yet materialized, Fred H. Sexauer, president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., said yesterday.

Tickets for box and reserved seats for the New York Yankees' opening baseball game of the league season at the Stadium on April 20 will go on sale Monday at the club's downtown office, 55 West Forty-second Street, and also at the Yankee Stadium, it was announced yesterday by Edward G. Barrow, club secretary.
The Vassar College Choir will give a concert tonight in Irvine Auditorium in Philadelphia under the sponsorship of the Philadelphia branch of the Associate Alumnae of Vassar.

Joseph A. Judd, a magazine publishers' consultant, died suddenly today at his home, 11 Manhattan Avenue. He was 54 years old. Mr. Judd was employed by The Literary Digest for fifteen years and was advertising manager when he left the publication in 1920 to become owner and publisher of Arts and Decoration Magazine.
Major oil companies announced today millions of dollars in pay increases for thousands of workers, and reliable sources predicted that similar steps would be taken throughout the industry.

Under the lea of the famous levee where only a few months ago the natives were staging a heroic struggle here against the raging tide of the old Mississippi, the Giants made an equally noble stand today against a surging mass of Indians.

A one-story house built of steel sections and containing five rooms was opened to the public yesterday at 107th Street and Riverside Drive by National Houses, Inc. It will be on display until June 1. William Van Alen is the architect.

The suit of Ernest Aldrich Simpson, charging slander by a British society matron in a sequel to the divorce nisi granted to Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, was postponed today until the next court term, opening May 16.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn in a decision yesterday disbarred two attorneys for subornation of perjury and unprofessional conduct in connection with the trial of a negligence action.

The famous Healy portrait of Abraham Lincoln, reproductions of which adorn homes and public buildings throughout the country, will become the property of the government on the death of Mrs. Charles Isham, granddaughter of President Lincoln, if the government sees fit to hang the portrait in an appropriate position in the White House.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The passage of the Pittman resolution by our august Senate is certainly a heroic piece of business. After settlement of the General Motors and Chrysler crises, after the national wave of sit-downs, flouting the law of the land and of respective locality, our Federal fathers in an amazing burst of virile indignation have seen fit to record an almost unheard of unanimity of opinion.

The Pan American Clipper alighted on the waters of Pearl Harbor at 1:30 P. M. (7 P. M. Eastern standard time) today after a 1,100-mile flight from tiny Kingman Reef, in mid-Pacific, completing next to the last leg of our round-trip trade-survey flight from San Francisco to Auckland, New Zealand.

Although the rumors of a possible reduction in the gold-buying price of the United States Treasury provided the impulse for the fall of the franc, the real basis of its decline in the opinion of bankers here was the decision of the French authorities themselves to cheapen the exchange.

While Premier Leon Blum celebrated his sixtyfifth birthday today by addressing members of the Socialist party on the political situation, it became known that yeggs had visited the office of his three brothers, downtown silk merchants, and taken $2,000 in cash from a safe opened with an acetylene torch.

Arline Judge, screen actress, and Daniel Reed Topping, wealthy New York sportsman, were married late today at Virginia City by Judge Thomas F. Moran a few hours after her marriage to Wesley Ruggles, film director, was ended in divorce here.

The report of Trusteed Industry Shares for the first quarter of 1937 shows net assets of $4,337,882 on March 31, equal to $1.61 a share on 2,690,000 shares. This compares with $3,533,088, or $1.55 a share on 2,276,000 shares, on Dec. 31, and with $1,761,329, or $1.41 a share, on March 31, 1936, when 1,250,000 shares were outstanding.

The marriage of Miss Frances Ross Hyde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Harrison Hyde of Boothbay Harbor, Me., to Henry Wilson Beardsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sterling S. Beardsley of this city, will take place on the afternoon of April 21 in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas.

Round lot purchases and sales by members on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 13 aggregated 6,874,405 shares, or 21.25 per cent of volume, compared with 7,066,272 shares, or 21.39 per cent, in the week ended on March 6, according to the weekly summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University, very old hands at this sort of thing, put on its Spring show last evening at Mecca Temple. For the records, it was the ninetyfirst annual production--the club being a little younger than the college--and the name was "Come Across."

President Federico Laredo Bru today counseled the people to give no credence to rumors of the instability of his administration and strained relations between Cuba and the United States. He charged such reports were inspired by a desire to injure the government.

With allowance made for the early date of Easter this year, department store sales showed less than the usual seasonal increase from February to March, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Adjusted for seasonal variation these sales were 92 per cent of the 192325 average in March, compared with 95 per cent in February, 93 per cent in January and 84 per cent in March, 1936.

Contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday featured leases taken by paper products, millinery and office supply firms. Many leases also were made to garment concerns. The list follows:

Can Calumet Dick pick up additional weight and defeat the Araho Stable horses that finished back of him in the Bowie Handicap? This is the question in the $5,000 added Southern Maryland Handicap, closing- day feature tomorrow, for which seven are named.

The International Longshoremen's Association was recognized last night as the bargaining agency of longshoremen employed by the Seaboard Terminal and Refrigeration Company after a one-day strike due to a. jurisdictional dispute between the association and the Brotherhood of Railway. Clerks.
FuriotNiclot claimed a new world speed record of 484 kilometers--302 miles an hour--over a 1,000-kilometer course today.

A report by the Social Service Commission of the Newark Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church endorsing the campaign of the C. I. O., warning against fascism and calling for a "planned economy" was received at the eighteenth session of the conference in St. Luke's Church here today.
In this country they call them "sitdowns" in China they are "walking cow" strikes. Chu Hsueh Fan, Chinese work:er's delegate to the International Textile Conference, explained this today.

A $250,000 store improvement program will be started about May 15 by James McCreery Co., it was announced yesterday by Neil Petree, president. The construction planned includes the installation of new escalators and elevators, and the moving and expansion of a number of departments.

Lawless Boy, a white and lemon pointer dog, owned by Dr. H. E. Longsdorf of Mount Holly, N. C., today was awarded first place in the $1,000 free-for-all stake in the annual field trial meeting of the -English Setter Club of America.

Major Gen. Edwin M. Markham, chief of army engineers, told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today that he informed President Roosevelt some months ago that the Florida Canal would cost $200,000,000 to build, and that Mr. Roosevelt replied it would be. all right if there was some way of getting back the money.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that at the request of the applicants it had consented to the withdrawal of the following registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933:

Albert Bigelow Paine of West Redding, Conn., author and biographer, died here tonight after an illness of four weeks. His age was 75. A member of the Pulitzer Prize committee for many years, he had just finished reading a novel which may bring its author the award next month.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Nineteen couples in Rio das Pedras, State of Minas Geraes, want to get married, but they can't find a justice of the peace to perform the ceremonies.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to ask the State Legislature to readjust the boundary line between Queens and Nassau Counties from Sunrise Highway at Rosedale to the vicinity of McNeil Avenue between Far Rockaway and Inwood.
The Reichsbank's statement as of April 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

J. E. Wayne, president of the York Railways Company, has requested holders of the company's $6,116,000 thirty-year 5 per cent gold bonds, due at the end of this year, to extend the maturity of the issue for an additional ten years.

A bill for a special enrollment by Mail of members of the American Labor party, introduced by Senator Julius S. Berg, Bronx Democrat, was denounced yesterday by Alex Rose, secretary of the Labor party, as an attempt by Tammany Hall to control the party's nominations for offices to be filled at the city electionss next Fall.
Tennis stars from Japan and Australia reached North America today in quest of the Davis Cup, their hopes buoyed by abdication of Fred Perry of England as amateur king.

Deposits in the 134 savings banks of the State increased $35,543,000 in the first quarter of this year to a total of $5,278,441,015, according to the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

Dr. John Studebaker, Federal Commissioner of Education, told the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today that there were more than 2,000,000 children, some crippled, some otherwise incapacitated, who need special schools and specialized teaching.

Mrs. Douglas Gibbons of 430 Park Avenue, whom Cardinal Hayes has appointed to head the women's division of his special gifts committee for the 1937 appeal for Catholic churches, will be at the headquarters which have been established in Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue, every day from 10 A. M until 5 P. M. until the campaign closes.
Non-striking employes of the Titan Metal Works today drove four pickets several miles from the factory after ripping down union signs and burning a shed in which strikers had set up headquarters.

The ensign of Japanese aviation was hoisted high this afternoon when the monoplane Kamikaze (Divine Wind), owned by the newspaper Asahi and bearing Masaaki Iinuma and Kenji Tsukagoshi with Tokyo's coronation greetings, swooped into Croydon airfield.

High political figures, lawyers, jurists, Boy Scouts and civic officials gathered here in a throng of 1,200 today for the funeral services of Justice Robert F. Thompson, noted Jurist, who died on Wednesday.
Two opponents of the Roosevelt court reorganization plan declared before the Senate Judiciary Committee today that the bill pointed the way to "dictatorship."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for April 26 on an application by Central Ohio Light and Power Company, a subsidiary of the Crescent Public Service Company, a registered holding company, for exemption of the issuance of $750,000 of first mortgage 4 1/ent bonds, Series B, and $600,000 of serial notes to be issued and sold for financing the business of the company.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $8,402,795, to be represented by two States and fifty-one municipalities, as compared with the revised total of $10,454,034 for this week.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in March totaled $32,233,110,561, a gain of 23.6 per cent over the preceding month and 11.4 per cent over March, 1936. Excepting last December, the total was the largest for any month since October, 1931.

Francs dropped almost 3 points in terms of the pound sterling and were off 55 centimes against the United States dollar on the Bourse today, creating some stir, but not affecting the securities markets. Rentes actually rose, and French industrial securities were firm and even progressive.

The Continental Securities Corporation reported yesterday that estimated net assets on March 31, after $91,949 Federal normal income tax and $9,915 management compensation, both computed upon unrealized appreciation, were $5,037,643, equal to $1,813 for each $1,000 of debentures,

Worried by the work of a new and masterful criminal engraver who has cheated the public in the metropolitan area out of $200,000 in the last two months, the Secret Service yesterday warned 25,000 small storekeepers to guard against a cleverly executed counterfeit $5 bill.
The Catholic high-treason trial before the People's Court is demonstrating the extent to which that bench can on occasion be exploited for the dissemination of Nazi propaganda.

The text of the statement issued here today by Hugh Thompson, C. I. O. organizer, was as follows: In view of the position reportedly adopted by Premier Hepburn of Ontario, to the effect that he would throw all the resources at his command behind General Motors,

Disappointed with their showing against the Detroit Red Wings, to whom they lost by the score of 4 to 2 in the second game of the competition for the Stanley Cup and the world hockey championship, the New York Rangers, nevertheless, are confident of ultimate success.

In making its report on 1935 operations to the Securities and Exchange Commission, CongoleumNairn, Inc., omitted to list salaries paid officers of the company, adding a note that they were being sent the commission "under confidential cover."

Anti-Hitler propaganda, despite the secret police, is beginning to circulate again in Germany. Today's mails contained a manifesto of the "German Liberty party" summoning loyal Germans to free the German nation from National Socialist rule and demanding a plebiscite on the question of German participation in the Spanish civil war.

About 180 employes of two furniture companies here were out on strike today in this Grey County town forty miles south of Owen Sound. Nearly 100 workers at the Peppler Brothers Furniture Company walked out yesterday, joining about 80 of the Speisz Furniture Company who struck Wednesday mornin.

City Commissioner Carlos de Castro, a former New York physician, today denied the Nationalist request for a parade April 16, the birthday of the late Jose de Diego, independence advocate, poet, former Speaker of the Legislature and sponsor of the formation of a State of the Antilles, composed of former Spanish colonies.

Miss Elizabeth Ingram Deyer, daughter of Mrs. Robert Oldner Deyer of the Towers, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Deyer, was married to John Farrel Hughes, son of John Hughes, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Hughes, yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Charles Borromeo in Brooklyn Heights.

Thursday's Reserve Bank statement covered a weekly period of which only three days followed Sunday's announcement by the board that the Reserve Banks would be willing to purchase United States bonds from the open market.

Miss Margaret Hermes, daughter of Mrs. J. George Hermes of this city and the late Mr. Hermes, was married this afternoon to Harold James Mold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Mold, also of Mount Vernon, in the Church of St. Peter and Paul, in Fleetwood, by the Rev. John B. Delaney.
The monarchist system in Europe tonight was poorer by yet another member of royalty, whose downfall, at least ostensibly, was caused by the direction taken by his affections.

Recent studies made of the effects of a new synthetic drug, which has been found to stimulate the activity of the brain cells and to enhance their functioning, furnish new experimental proof that the human brain in ordinary circumstances does not "run on all cylinders," Dr. William Healy, director of the Judge Baker Guidance Center, Boston, said in a lecture last night at the New York Academy of Medicine.

IT is the opinion of Hank Gowdy-Old Goldenrod of the Boston Bees--that the Explorers Club can't be on the level because Walter Hapgood isn't president or chairman of the board. Hank thinks that in breaking trail for strange places "Hap" was right on Marco Polo's heels and far ahead of Captain Hubert Wilkins, Roy Chapman Andrews, Bob Bartlett and other footloose fellows of modern times.

An international dinghy fleet, including a strong Scandinavian representation, will come to Rochester next July. Commodore Edward J. Doyle of the Rochester Yacht Club announced today that plans for a three-day regatta on Lake Ontario over July have been approved.

"Good Shepherd Sunday" will be observed tomorrow, it being the annual Sunday when the Gospel for the day to be read in the ritualistic churches will be the parable of the Good Shepherd. The sermons and the music will be about the Good Shepherd.
Governor EARLE has declared in no uncertain terms that mobs will not be tolerated in Pennsylvania. It is a position which will become
The National Labor Relations Board has not had a fair chance to function, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board, declared in a radio address last night.

House leaders pressed today for early action on the Senate resolution rebuking both sides in labor controversies, and meanwhile Senator McAdoo introduced another measure in the Senate, creating a special committee to confer with leaders of industry and labor in an effort to devise measures to promote better relations.

Because of a possible legislative conflict on the proposed Aldermanic investigation of relief, the Board of Estimate deferred action for one week yesterday on the resolution of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens appropriating $50,000 from accruals for the inquiry.
A service of thanksgiving for the coronation of George VI will be held at 11 A. M. on Coronation Day, May 12, in historic Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 3 totaled 726,687 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 34,422 cars, or 4.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 113,106 cars, or 18.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 181,231 cars, or 33.2 per cent, more than in the corresponding week two years ago.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market continues moderately active. The spot demand is chiefly for the foreign descriptions, and sales of Australian, New Zealand and South American wools, both merinos and crossbreds, have been made at prices which usually are about on an import parity.
Pinemax Properties, Inc., purchased from David M. Meister, Inc., the five-story walk-up for twenty-seven families at 1,360 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx.

Coincident with the declaration of a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share on its capital stock instead of 25 cents as previously, the Union Oil Company of California announced yesterday that net income for the first quarter of this year was about $2,200,000 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to 47 cents a share on the 4,666,270 capital shares outstanding.
Miss Elise Minshall Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wilson Robinson of Overbrook, was married this afternoon to Leighton Howe Mcllvaine, son of Charles Lee McIlvaine of Bryn Mawr.

Edward Lasker of the Marshall Club, which won the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League earlier in the week, yesterday drew his adjourned game with Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State champion, thereby gaining the additional half-point needed to swing the match with Manhattan into the Marshall column in the league table.

William C. Orr, lawyer, who died April 4, 1986, left a gross estate of $1,018,365, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. His net estate, after allowing for funeral and administrative expenses and debts. was $912,670.

The best field of junipers in amateur racing thus far this season will face the starter tomorrow in the renewal of the Middleburg Cup, which will feature a program of six races at the first session of the two-day meeting of the Middleburg Race Association.

Only 18, or 4.4 per cent, of the 405 representative industrial companies included in a survey reported they had made it a definite policy not to hire male workers 40 years old or older, the National Industrial Conference Board disclosed yesterday in announcing the results of the study.

A dance dedicated to Professor T. H. Harrington, who resigned last year after a half century as a member of the Columbia University faculty, will be held by the Columbia Engineering School tonight in John Jay Hall on the campus.

The Eighth Biennial Festival of chamber music opened tonight very propitiously for performances of the kind, which Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge persuaded the legislative powers to allow to be presented in the Library of Congress for the glory of that province of the tonal art which so deeply engages her interest.

Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday that his department would start no drive against the city's strip-tease dancers. As in the past, however, investigations will be made of any theatre or cabaret against which complaints are received, and reports will be turned over to Second Deputy Commissioner John J. Sullivan, in charge of licenses.

Rudolph Hermann Kissel Jr., member of a family socially prominent in New York, died yesterday at his home in Denver. He was 40 years old and was educated at Taft School and Harvard, where he was captain of the freshman hockey team.

Traffic executives of the steel and iron industries added their protest to that of the drug and chemical industries against new freight rates which the intercoastal ship lines propose to establish at hearings yesterday at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

The Commerce Department said today that business showed "marked improvement" during the first quarter of 1937. Industrial production was one-fifth greater than for the comparative period last -year, it said, with slight advances in January and February being extended in March.
Maynard W. Brown, Professor of Journalism at Marquette University, died today of a heart attack. He was 41 years old.
Construction of new links in two vital arterial highways in Brooklyn and Queens, involving expenditures of about $2,600,000, was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

A cowboy on snowshoes came in from his traplines today, loaded down with furs, and told how to hunt with a lariat. "Texas Red" Shaw bags moose in the Skwentna district as a Texas cowboy ropes a steer, substituting snowshoes for a pony.

Meeting yesterday at the Aldine Club, the members of the Boys and Students Clothing Manufacturers Association "reaffirmed" its policy already announced of establishing a maximum discount of 7 per cent for the Fall season, this basis comprising the extra discount for volume purchases ranging up to 5 per cent, and the regular 2 per cent discount, it was stated following the meeting.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh flew back to England from Munich today, ending a ten-week aerial tour of Europe and the East. The couple landed at Gatwick Airdrome and went immediately to their home to see Jon, their little son.

A jury in Federal Court, Brooklyn, returned a verdict of guilty early this morning against six men, three of them Malays who were acused by the government of conspiracy to smuggle opium into the country.

An exhibition of paintings by Spanish masters will open to the public tomorrow at the Pennsylvania Museum and remain current for one month. Much of the material has been lent by American museums and galleries and from private collections. A long period is spanned, beginning in the fifteenth century and ending in the nineteenth.

Cotton mill activity last week increased, counter to the usual downward trend, and the adjusted index spurted four points to 140.9. In the preceding week, the figure was 136.9 and 107.9 for the week ended April 4. 1936.
Arthur William Foote of Newton, widely known composer and organist, died in Massachusetts General Hospital today. He was 84 years old.

A frank statement on the Spanish Loyalist Government's child refugee problem was given to the writer today by one of the persons most directly concerned in its solution. The government has on -its hands the enormous problem of caring for nearly 250,000 children up to 16

Simon Lake filed suit in Common Pleas Court today to prevent a Sheriff's sale of his submarine, the Explorer, said to be the only privately owned submarine in the world. His action names the Forsberg Manufacturing Company and Sheriff Maurice Hocheiser, both of Bridgeport, as defendants.

Brooklyn and Queens were active centers of new construction projects yesterday when architects filed plans for numerous one-family dwellings in those two boroughs. The plans were submitted as follows:

Copper markets were little changed abroad yesterday. After selling as high as 15.725 cents a pound c. i. f. the European base ports, the price declined to about 15.50 cents when an easier tendency developed on the London Metal Exchange. On Thursday, copper sold abroad at 14.80 to 15.50 cents.
The Department of Commerce reported today that gold imports totaled $154,370,956 in March, an increase of $34,000,000 over February and $147,000,000 over March, 1936.
The course of international exchange was greatly disturbed yesterday as foreign markets gave increasing credence to the reports that the United States Treasury might lower its buying price for gold.
Robert Charles Norman, one of the first importers of broomcorn into the United States, died yesterday morning at his home, 404 Riverside Drive.

The newspaper Tevere, which has always occupied a prominent place in the anti-Jewish campaigns that make their appearance every now and then in Italian newspapers, gives a whole page today to what purports to be the completest existing list of Italian Jewish surnames.
The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered further hearings today on revisions of freight rates on heavy basic commodities.

Concentration of 244 combat airplanes in California during May was ordered by the War Department "for the purpose of testing the strength and organization of the flying combat units of the army." The personnel necessary for the manoeuvres will include 430 officers and 2,500 enlisted men.

In New York City and other communities lobar pneumonia is the principal cause of death in young and middle-aged adults. It is the most devastating of the respiratory ailments. For generations, of every 100 persons ill with lobar pneumonia, about 25 have died, according to the United States Mortality Statistics.

A crack quartet of sprinters from the University of Michigan smashed the world 400-yard relay record in the Yale pool tonight, pushed the Wolverines into the lead for the team title and forthwith ended the six-year reign of the New York A. C. as relay king as the national A. A. U. swimming championships moved into their second day.

Coupling a denunciation of the Nazi "program of spiritual destruction" with a declaration that the future of world peace and freedom lies in the Americas, Erika Mann, daughter of the self-exiled leader of German literature and Nobel Prize winner, Thomas Mann, announced here yesterday her Intention of becoming an American citizen.

Richard Dana Skinner, vice president of Pell, Kip Skinner, Inc., has completed a book, "Seven Kinds of Inflation, and What to Do About Them," which Whittlesey House will publish late in May. Mr. Skinner discusses four kinds of "absolute"- and three kinds of "relative" inflation, and supplies methods with which the layman can determine for himself the facts about inflation at any particular time.
Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-Frank J. Madden, from Traffic B to 60th Precinct; Bernard Murray, from Emergency Service Squad 15 to 75th Precinct.

New York State will undertake legislation to prevent industrial or other encroachments on the banks of streams which tend to bottle up the flow of water at densely populated points, according to Ogden J. Ross of Rensselaer, chairman of the New York State Flood Control Commission.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Horace Conner of 130 East Sixty-seventh Street, and Rye, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Conner, to Dr. Howard G. Bruenn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Bruenn of 320 West Eighty-ninth Street.

Miss Gertrude May Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Edward Howe of this place, was married to Gilbert Saltonstall Carpenter of Montclair, son of Dudley Saltonstall Carpenter of Santa Barbara, Calif., tonight in St. James's Church here.

Sailing on a boisterous sea kicked up by a twenty-five-mile southerly wind, the six-meter yacht Saga, owned by Eldon H. and Kenneth F. Trimingham of Bermuda, today won the third race in the international series for the Prince of Wales Trophy. Saga triumphed by 51 seconds in duplicating her victory in the opening contest of the group of four.

The racing cutter Endeavour I, a trial horse for challenger Endeavour II in this Summer's America's Cup yachting series, was put overboard today without ceremony, while final preparations are being rushed on the Endeavour II for launching next Thursday.

The modern day nursery now has a "unique" opportunity to strengthen family life and to prevent marital breakdown, the twentieth biennial conference of the National Federation of Day Nurseries at the Hotel Commodore was told yesterday.

"Marked Woman," Bette Davis's first film since her return to the Warner fold after a self-imposed exile in England last Summer because of a contract row, opens this morning at the Strand. Supporting Miss Davis are Humphrey Bogart, Isabel Jewell, Eduardo Clannelli, Rosalind Marquis and Lola Lane.

Coupling a denunciation of the Nazi "program of spiritual destruction" with a declaration that the future of world peace and freedom lies in the Americas, Erika Mann, daughter of the self-exiled leader of German literature and Nobel Prize winner, Thomas Mann, announced here yesterday her Intention of becoming an American citizen.
Paul Waner, three-time National League batting champion, signed his contract today, ending his prolonged holdout with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Sailing on a boisterous sea kicked up by a twenty-five-mile southerly wind, the six-meter yacht Saga, owned by Eldon H. and Kenneth F. Trimingham of Bermuda, today won the third race in the international series for the Prince of Wales Trophy. Saga triumphed by 51 seconds in duplicating her victory in the opening contest of the group of four.

The racing cutter Endeavour I, a trial horse for challenger Endeavour II in this Summer's America's Cup yachting series, was put overboard today without ceremony, while final preparations are being rushed on the Endeavour II for launching next Thursday.

The modern day nursery now has a "unique" opportunity to strengthen family life and to prevent marital breakdown, the twentieth biennial conference of the National Federation of Day Nurseries at the Hotel Commodore was told yesterday.

"Marked Woman," Bette Davis's first film since her return to the Warner fold after a self-imposed exile in England last Summer because of a contract row, opens this morning at the Strand. Supporting Miss Davis are Humphrey Bogart, Isabel Jewell, Eduardo Clannelli, Rosalind Marquis and Lola Lane.

Mrs. Arthur Courtlandt Ely of 135 East Seventy-fourth Street, who has been in New Orleans for the Winter and early Spring, is at the Mayflower in Washington. Mrs. Paulding Fosdick has arrived at the Savoy-Plaza from Newport.
Mrs. Laura Barnard Corlies, daughter of the late Rev. Dr. and Mrs. George B. Draper of New York, died here today at her home in her seventysixth year.

France banned gangster films from theatres today as responsible for a crime wave in the nation. Marx Dormoy, Minister of the Interior, said he would refuse permits to show films that portray "cynical or violent scenes, gangster raids and shootings of 'American' type, or pitched battles between the underworld and the police."

Youngest of all the competitors engaged in the international masters' tournament of the Kent County Chess Association, Reuben Fine of New York and Paul Keres of Parnu, Estonia, today tied for first place when they drew their encounter in the ninth and final round at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville.

Expansion of the plant of the Acme Steel Company this year may be financed through the sale of additional common stock, R. H. Norton, president, says in the annual report, issued yesterday. The company is planning additions that will cost about $1,500,000 to meet increased demand for its specialty products, he said.

A bequest of $500,000 by H. Ford Behrens of Wheeling, W. Va., to Washington and Jefferson College was announced today. The bequest, the largest ever made to the college, will become available for a new building on the death. of Mrs. Behrens.

The official head of this Federal bureau, whose twenty-fifth anniversary is being celebrated this week, has been called "the second mother of everybody's children." And these children must by now number well toward 50,000,000. There were 43,000,000 three years ago, counting all up to the age of 18.

An attempt to start a measles scare here by artificial tinting failed this afternoon when the nurse at the Mountain Lakes High School rubbed a little cold cream on the face of a 13-year-old junior high school youth, who was the leader of the. "measles movement."

Upper Fifth Avenue will resound today with the rumble of artillery and tanks, the clatter of horses and the tread of 22,000 soldiers, sailors and civilians participating in the Army Day parade, the city's annual demonstration for an adequate national defense for the nation.
A grand jury returned a firSt-degree murder indictment today against Thomas Smith, 18-year-old Buffalo newsboy accused of the slaying of Mary Ellen Babcock, 18.

President Roosevelt reiterated today his hope that new taxes might be avoided at this session of Congress. The President's attempt at reassurance, made at his press conference, did not, however, quiet fears of some Congressional leaders that they may be faced with the necessity of levying additional taxes If present budget trends continue.

Judge Ardra Hodgins of Yarmouth, Me., said to be Maine's only woman judge and one of the youngest jurists in the country, was married at City Hall here on Wednesday to William Lardner Ogden of Deadwood, S. D., and Batavia, Java, it was learned last night. Mrs. Edward Gohr of Summit, N. J., was matron of honor, and Dr. George M. Maverick of Elizabeth, N. J., was best man.

Stocks rallied on gold rumor denial and closed steady and mixed; turnover, 1,733,250 shares. United States Government bonds recovered and closed higher in less active trading; transactions, $12,200,200.

Cain's legendary horses will be dropping in their traces by this time tomorrow, for six shows already are definite about leaving tonight for the storehouse or Chicago and there may well be others after the evening's receipts are counted.

Meeting behind closed doors at the State House for nearly seven hours today, Republican members of the Senate failed to reach an agreement as to the attitude to be taken toward their Cape May County colleague, William C. Hunt, whose election was set aside as "fraudulent" by Circuit Court Judge Wilfred H. Jayne in an opinion handed down on Wednesday.

Miss Edna C. Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Alfred Chapin of this place, was married tonight to Howard Tantum Jr., son of Dr. Howard Tantum and Mrs. Tantum, also of Nutley, in Grace Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Peter Deckenbach of Belleville.

E. B. Christopher, president of the Swallow Aircraft Manufacturing Company of Wichita, Kan., and E. A. Grumm, 41, Pasadena attorney, were killed today in the crash of a small plane piloted by Mr. Christopher, near Gorman, Calif.

Adopting the unionization technique of the Committee for Industrial Organization, the American Federation of Labor today openly declared war against the militant electrical union of John L. Lewis in the Pittsburgh district.

Deputy sheriffs, swinging clubs, forcibly ejected late today seventyfive men and women who had staged a two-day sit-down in the office of Governor Martin L. Davey in a demand for a $50,000,000 poorrelief appropriation.

The report of the Tradesmens National Bank and Trust Company, Philadelphia, as of March 31, showed total deposits of $43,525,757 and total assets of $56,138,316, compared respectively to $47,114,101 and $58,790,168 on Dec. 31, 1936.

What seems like a final blow to any Rexist prospects for beating Premier Paul Van Zeeland at next Sunday's election was dealt to the Degrelle party tonight by Cardinal Van Roey, Archbishop of Malines and Primate of Belgium.

Joseph Rose, 64-year-old diamond hoarder who is serving a sentence on Rikers Island for failing to support his family, was termed a psychopathic liar yesterday by County Judge Nova in Brooklyn, who directed a jury to acquit Louis Gorelick, 30, of 2,311 Avenue Y, Brooklyn, of a charge of stealing $100,000 worth of diamonds from Rose.

Mrs. Mary Ridgely Preston Kelly, daughter of Alexander Preston of Baltimore, was married here at noon yesterday to Gordon Arthur Smith of 16 West Seventy-fourth Street, son of Mrs. Arthur Cosslett Smith of Rochester, N. Y., and the late Mr. Smith, in the chapel of the Riverside Church by the Rev. C. Ivar Hellstrom, assistant pastor.
The government's first great effort to raise the siege of Madrid began at 4 o'clock this morning with combined attacks on the Aravaca sector to the south and the Casa de Campo sector to the west.

The House took two steps today to make rehabilitation loans available to sufferers from floods and other disasters. It first passed the Senate bill permitting the Federal Housing Administration to insure rehabilitation loans by financial institutions through June 30, 1939.

Eighty-nine awards have been made to members of the basketball, wrestling, boxing, fencing and handball squads by the Brooklyn College Athletic Association, according to an announcement by Louis R. Oshins, business manager of athletics, yesterday.

The marriage of Mrs. G. Luke de Bustamante, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Keith Luke of this place, to William Reginald Gough, son of Mrs. William Thomas Gough of 139 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York, took place here this afternoon at Devon Hall, the home of the bride's parents.

Frederick M. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, said today that adoption of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan "would mean a change to a legislative from a constitutional form of government." Mr. Stinchfield's statement, along with those of several other lawyers, appeared in the April issue of the American Bar Association Journal.
James Bonnyman, president of the Blue Diamond Coal Company, died early today at his home here. He had been in ill- health since Wednesday and suffered a heart attack today. He was 57 years old.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired its first examples of Cambodian sculpture, which will be placed on display this morning in the room of recent accessions.

Edwin Goodman, president of Bergdorf-Goodman, has accepted the general chairmanship of the department store, ready-to-wear and resident buyers' division of the New York campaigns of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the United Palestine Appeal, it was announced yesterday.

Protesting against being laid off on June 30 for possibly a year, with no guarantee of being taken back, about 400 cigar makers and strippers, out of a total of 700 employes of the De Nobile Cigar Company, said to be the largest manufacturers of Italian cigars in New York City, began a peaceful "sit-down" strike in the company's plant at 3,511 Ninth Street, Long Island City, yesterday afternoon.

The report of the Tradesmens National Bank and Trust Company, Philadelphia, as of March 31, showed total deposits of $43,525,757 and total assets of $56,138,316, compared respectively to $47,114,101 and $58,790,168 on Dec. 31, 1936.

Donald E. Bates, president of the Reo Motor Car Company, is at present the holder of 2,000 shares of common stock in the company and has owned virtually this number of shares for five years. Ray A. DeVlieg, who resigned as vice president and works manager on Aug. 15, 1936, held 300 shares at that time.

Five probable entries from this country for the international Star class racing in Bermuda starting on April 27 and lasting through May 3, were named last night at the dinner of the Star skippers along the Atlantic Coast, held in the Hotel Lafayette, University Place and Ninth Street.

The marriage of Mrs. G. Luke de Bustamante, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Keith Luke of this place, to William Reginald Gough, son of Mrs. William Thomas Gough of 139 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York, took place here this afternoon at Devon Hall, the home of the bride's parents.

Frederick M. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, said today that adoption of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan "would mean a change to a legislative from a constitutional form of government." Mr. Stinchfield's statement, along with those of several other lawyers, appeared in the April issue of the American Bar Association Journal.
James Bonnyman, president of the Blue Diamond Coal Company, died early today at his home here. He had been in ill- health since Wednesday and suffered a heart attack today. He was 57 years old.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired its first examples of Cambodian sculpture, which will be placed on display this morning in the room of recent accessions.

Edwin Goodman, president of Bergdorf-Goodman, has accepted the general chairmanship of the department store, ready-to-wear and resident buyers' division of the New York campaigns of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the United Palestine Appeal, it was announced yesterday.

Protesting against being laid off on June 30 for possibly a year, with no guarantee of being taken back, about 400 cigar makers and strippers, out of a total of 700 employes of the De Nobile Cigar Company, said to be the largest manufacturers of Italian cigars in New York City, began a peaceful "sit-down" strike in the company's plant at 3,511 Ninth Street, Long Island City, yesterday afternoon.

TODAY Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra, chorus and soloists, under the direction of Erno Rapee, present in concert form the third and final act of Wagner's opera "Siegfried": WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M. The cast:

A new section, comprising twenty acres, of the Montfort farm in Port Washington, L. I., has been opened for home development. It marks the expansion of the original tenacre community of suburban residences known as Montfort Hills,

The weather was cold, but Bernard Pearlman was "hot" as he struck out fourteen Savage batters and allowed only two scratch hits as Long Island University won, 7-0, at Manhattan Beach yesterday. By mutual agreement of the shivering teams, the contest went only seven innings.

Last week the rumor got started that the Government was planning to lower its price for gold. After a flurry in the foreign exchange, commodity and securities markets, the President remarked that there was no truth in the rumor. But it drew what plausibility it had from the former statements and actions of Administration leaders.

The Merchants Association of New York, acting on recommendations of its committee on building laws and regulations, is opposing three bills which it believes would add to the burdens of the building industry in New York City.
Certificated mortgages and bond issues will not soon if ever again find any marked degree of popularity with the investing public according to Robert H. Armstrong of the firm of Armstrong Armstrong.

Officials of the Hamilton College library are planning to open its new unit for the inspection of the board of trustees of the college when it convenes for the annual Spring meeting on April 24, according to Lewis F. Stieg, librarian.

Those who control society's institutions must strive to close the gap which exists between school and work if either is "to resist the pounding pressure of modern maladjusted youth seeking its opportunity," Dr. M. R. Trabue, director of the division of education of the University of North Carolina, warned yesterday.
Mrs. Mathilda C. Parsons, author and lecturer, died on Friday night in the Doctors Hospital after a short illness. She was 63 years old and lived at 7 Bayard Street, Larchmont, N. Y.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morris Posner of 717 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of Mr. Posner's daughter, Miss Esther M. Posner, to Hyman L. Berry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Berry, also of Brooklyn.

Members of the Alumnae of St. Mary's Hall for Girls in Burlington, N. J., are aiding in the campaign to raise $100,000 for reendowment of the institution, a preparatory school of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey.

Alabama's 20,000 union coal miners, who began a "holiday" when their work contract expired a week ago, rejected today an offer of 30 cents a day wage increase and time and a half for hours above thirty-five per week. The miners asked 50 cents a day increase and time and a half for overtime.
