SO firmly is Nat Pendleton established even in the British public mind as a tough guy, a punk, a mobster, a mug, a gorilla, , that-a kind of economic Fuzzy-Wuzzy-he has succeeded in breaking the "Buy-British" square, and getting himself imported to play an American gangster in the next Jessie Matthews picture, "Gangway."

The German Labor Office today announced the number of registered unemployed had decreased by 366,000 during March, bringing the total reduction since the Winter peak to 608,000. The remaining total is now 1,245,000, which equals that at the middle of last year.
Riot charges were filed today against four men and two women combatants in Friday's battle between Sheriff's deputies and relief demonstrators in Ohio's Capitol Building.

The Hispano team strengthened its lead in the American division of the American Soccer League by defeating the Brookhattan eleven, 1-0, at Hawthorne Field yesterday. A crowd of 1,000 saw the former Maccabee player, Herman, now on the Hispano eleven, score his first goal since joining the team.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Secor Couzens of Yonkers, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Pearce Couzens, to John Bell Thurston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Royal C. Thurston of Rochester, N. Y., and Dennis, Mass.

RAIN drummed all night against the windows of our room in St. Martinville, La. When we awoke the unpaved streets were inches deep in the gummy mud the natives call "black jack." Trying to manoeuvre the car near the house to load bags, I slid it into a three-foot ditch. No traction in the Louisiana soup, and I kept sinking my wheels deeper and deeper.
Five days on the municipal woodpile will be the penalty for men convicted more than once for drunken driving in Lakewood under a resolution adopted this week by the Township Committee.
Eighty-four churches of all denominations in the city's five boroughs will participate in the Choir Music Festival to take place April 17 to April 30.

Thomas F. Garrity of 888 Union Street, Brooklyn, since 1918 president of the regular Democratic Club of the Eighth Assembly District, died Friday in the Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital, after a year's illness. His age was 50. He was a bachelor.

The 50-year-old Ackerly Building, a village landmark, is about to be torn down and on its site will be erected a taxpayer structure containing five stores. The building has been purchased by the South Ocean Avenue Corporation, which nine years ago purchased the land on which the Ackerly Building stands.

The Spring choral concert of the Chaminade Society of Brooklyn will be held on Wednesday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in Music Hall. The program will include old classics, folk songs and modern compositions. Mrs. William A. Phillips is president of the organization, Mrs. Amelia Gray-Clarke, conductor, and Miss Wilhelmina Muller, accompanist.

Samuel Horwitz, operator, has purchased from the builder the sixstory elevator apartment house at 95 Northern Avenue, northeast corner of 181st Street, in a deal arranged by Nehring Brothers, brokers.

Movie salaries took a substantial lead over industrial pay checks today in early filings of 1936 corporation reports at the Securities Commission. The salary of $227,500 paid to Kay Francis, film star, by Warner Brothers, compared with the $85,000 top business salary reported to date, which went to Harvey S. Firestone, chairman of the tire and rubber company which he founded.

Nothing tires the French people so much as the display of too much zeal. It was Talleyrand who made the phrase famous, if he did not invent it, when he declared that the first maxim of success in diplomacy was "Surtout, pas de zele."
Effects of the Spanish civil war on the direct imports of American products into Spain were shown in figures made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Neopaganism, which has been in eclipse in the Third Reich for some two years, is coming to the fore again. Adolf Hitler has publicly promised the most noted of the neopagan prophets, General Erich Ludendorff, that no further hindrances will be put in the way of his propaganda.
Miss Ruth C. Paine, daughter of Mrs. Walter Paine of this place, and Frederick Dunn of West Orange were married this afternoon at Incarnation Episcopal Church, East Orange, by the Rev. Carolus Webb.

A dinner dance at the Innis Arden Golf Club tonight was attended by about 150 members and guests. Those who had reservations for the dinner and entertained guests included Mr. and Mrs. Archie Graham, Mr. and Mrs. H. J. Welch.

Donkeys plodded lazily through Brussels streets today, bearing signs which said: "I vote for Degrelle." They were sent on their "electioneering" misisons by Premier Paul van Zeeland, who is opposing the Fascist Leon Degrelle for a Chamber of Deputies seat in tomorrow's elections.

Class 5, Bridle Path Hacks-First, C. V. Rich Jr.'s ch. g. Mallow Boy; second, Miss Margarieta Noble's ch. m. Hallie S.; third, Joseph Aubrey Hale's ch. g. Tommy Lindsay; fourth, Mrs. J. J. Farrell's ch. m. Judy.

The marriage of Miss Mariesta Dodge Howland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Giles Wilson Howland of this place and Scituate Harbor, to Elmer Jacques Bloom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Bloom of Peoria, Ill., took place here this afternoon in the First Congregational Church, where the bride's great-grandfather, the Rev. Freeman Parker Howland, once preached.

The February factory employment report of John J. Toohey Jr., State Labor Commissioner, shows that in 701 industrial plants of this State the number of workers employed last month was 243,493, a gain of 12.7 per cent over February, 1936.
Werner Janssen's third visit to Helsingfors since 1934 as guest conductor of the municipal orchestra further enhanced his reputation here as a profound and original interpreter of Sibelius's music.

ARKIN-Mr. and Mrs. -Leonard Arkin of 180 Riverside Drive announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Andrew J.. at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th St., Saturday, April 17, 10 A. M. At home 3 to 6; no cards. BACHMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Sydney B. Bachman, 204 5th Av., Bradley Beach, N. J., announce bar mitzvah of their son, Irwin, April 17. At home after 4 P. M.

A categorical official denial was made here concerning an allegation by the Giornale d'Italia of Rome that four Soviet planes had landed at an airdrome near Prague recently, leaving the following day for Madrid and Valencia accompanied by ten Czechoslovak planes.

While it is yet a bit early for planting most of the vegetables, some other. things can be done at this time in the vegetable patch. The tightly folded crimson rhubarb shoots, looking somewhat like gigantic peony buds, have pushed up well above the soil and are ready for the application of a mulch of thoroughly decayed manure or of a complete plant food.

ANNA LOUISE STRONG is a well-known protagonist of the Soviet Union. The reader of her most recent book, "The New Soviet Constitution," will not be surprised therefore to find in its pages not a critical and impartial analysis but a carefully thought out, if perhaps not very original, panegyric of this creation of the "genius of Stalin" (to quote the Izvestia of Nov. 26, 1936).
The fifteenth annual dog show of the Toledo Kennel Club, Inc., was opened this morning with an address of welcome from Mayor Roy C. Start of Toledo.
Mr. and- Mrs. Henry L. Herring of Kenston, N. C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Ella, to Helmer Petersen, principal of the Amityville public school.

Evander Childs recorded its fifth straight victory to win the annual championship tournament of the Interscholastic Chess League of Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday, defeating the George Washington quartet, 3 1/2--1/2, in the final round at the Manhattan Chess Club.

Members of the Junior League are now engaged in one of the most ambitious projects of entertainment they have yet undertaken-a theatrical production entitled the New York Junior League "Follies," which will be presented in three performances, on the night of April 23 and on the afternoon and night of April 24 at the New Amsterdam Theatre.

Miss Claire Pilger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leonard Pilger Jr. of this place, was married this evening to Byron Orme Dimmick of Montclair, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Dimmick of Mountain Top, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Montclair by the Rev. B. Haas of Harrisburg, Pa., assisted by the Rev. Victor G. Mills.

The ninth annual championships of the Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association, which take place at the Washington Square East Building of New York University next Saturday, have drawn entries from all six member colleges, namely Hunter College, N. Y. U., Brooklyn, Cornell, the College of William and Mary of Williamsburg, Va., and a new team from Hofstra College, N. Y. U.'s supplementary institution located at Hempstead, L. I.

SAMUEL JOHNSON created a mild sensation on his first day at Oxford by quoting from the Latin poet, Macrobius. James Boswell records the incident, but he fails to record the quotation--one of the few lapses of this really great reporter.

Industrialists are to make an intensive study of six major phases of agriculture through a committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, headed by Warren W. Shoemaker, vice president of Armour Co., Chicago.

Elections in Kansas rural towns this week were evidence to Kansas Legislators that their hopes of putting a quietus on the beer question by giving legal status to 3.2 beer were ill-founded. Beer bounced right back into the center of political discussion and the worst is yet to come when county elections are held in 1938.

Peter Alonzo Elliott, a Civil War veteran and. one of the oldest Masons in the United States, joining the Columbus (Ohio) lodge in 1868, died yesterday at his residence here. His age was 91. He long had been active in Republican affairs.

As the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress became one month old yesterday a number of changes were recorded among the leaders. Throughout morning and afternoon contestants in the singles and doubles fired away at the figures chalked up by their predecessors on the alleys at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory, and when these divisions checked out for the day a quick inventory showed that quite a little damage had been done.
The fishing-goods department is a man's world. Right now, at the beginning of the trout season, the angler's jargon is to be heard in the sports shops, a sure sign of Spring.

Tomorrow 368,000 Brussels voters are to register their preference either for democracy and parliamentary-government or fascism in its Belgian manifestation known as Rexism. The name is an abbreviation of Christus Rex, the title given the newest political party by its youthful leader, Leon Marie Joseph Ignace Degrelle.

The Daughter of the American Revolution said today that their Continental Congress, convening April 19, will pick seven vice presidents general from a field of eleven candidates. The candidates listed are: Mrs. George Baxter Averill of Milwaukee:

SOMETHING like eight decades ago--in 1855, to be exact--a young Weslhman, deciding that he would like to be an American, said good-bye to all his friends and all his relatives and took ship for New York.

The Woman's Club of New Rochelle will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary Thursday with a tea for new members. Mrs. Lawrence E. Van Etten, founder of the club, recently was elected honorary president.
Negroes occupying the Alexander County Emergency Relief offices here were ejected today by a detachment of National Guardsmen and a force of Sheriff's deputies.

Edmund G. Stalter, an attorney and Past Exalted Ruler of Paterson Lodge 60, Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, died here today of a heart attack at the Alexander Hamilton Hotel. He made his home at the hotel and at Greenwood Lake, N. J.

For the last two decades the sight of a woman climbing the scaffolding of a half-completed house has been no novelty, yet a survey of New York's women architects discloses that small homes rather than skyscrapers are still their specialty.

RECENT afternoon and evening tuning of European short wave stations has brought to light several changes in the wave lengths and programs of stations in a number of countries including Soviet Russia, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Spain.

Dr. and Mrs. Francis Tweddell of the Shore Drive Colony of this community were hosts tonight at a supper for Miss Doris Dautrich of Port Washington and their son, Anysley Tweddell, whose marriage will take place next Saturday.

Vassar alumnae who once romped in bloomers and middle blouses on the basketball court of Ely Hall would not recognize the scene today. Workmen this week completed the conversion of the gym into new headquarters for the Geology Department.

Captain J. Jarvis Reybert, retired owner of the three-masted schooner Robert Felter, which was crushed in the ice of the Great South Bay twenty years ago, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home, 9 Bay Shore Avenue. His age was 86.
A commutation by Governor Browning today made Mrs. Daisy Alexander Root, convicted of killing her husband in a jealous rage over a night club "cigarette girl," eligible for parole in fourteen months.

Sixteenth Annual Communion Breakfast of the New York Postoffice Holy Name Society. Hotel Astor, 9:15 A. M. Speakers: Postmaster General James A. Farley, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen. Postmaster Albert Goldman. Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.. Justice James T. Hallinan, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle Mgr. Francis A. McIntyre, the Rev.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-To concentrate on the collection and preservation of historical data of Southeastern Florida, members of the State Historical Association in this county have organized the Historical Society of Palm Beach, naming Judge C. E. Chillingworth of West Palm Beach president. Dr. George A. Waterman,

Dublin's bid to become an important port in transatlantic passenger traffic made a notable advance today when the Cunard White Star Line inaugurated the first regular service between Dublin and New York.

INDUSTRIAL warfare is today a major I menace to the welfare of all the people of the United States. There is a rapidly rising flood of big and little labor conflicts that may wipe out in a few months all the gains of the last four years.

ROME, April 10.--Premier Benito Mussolini made a start in the Cabinet Council over which he presided this morning toward fulfilling the promises in his Tripoli speech of March 18, in which he said a new era was about to dawn in Libya's history and special measures would be taken in favor of its Moslem population as a reward for the attachment to Italy they showed during the East African campaign.
An increase in chain-store leases at higher prices in retail locations is one of the features of the present real estate market, states I. Jerome Riker, president of Riker Company. This applies,

TARDILY and reluctantly, but with what has at last become a firm determination, this pacific nation is rearming on a greater and more expensive scale than it has ever done before in order to be prepared to defend itself.

THE physiological laboratory at Wright Field in Dayton, Ohio, is practically completed and in service to deal with problems affecting the manifold experiences of flight under new high speeds, extreme altitudes and other phases in which the physical reactions of pilots become variable quantities.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Fassitt of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Matilda Fassitt, to William Reese Scott 3d of Swarthmore, son of Mrs. William Reese Scott and the late Rev. William Scott.

The up-and-coming New York State Golf Association, which in its short span of life has done much for the golf clubs of the Empire State, has decided to become a guinea pig in an experiment to help solve the much-discussed stymie question.

Twenty-seven events are on the program announced by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday. The season will start on May 4 with a one-day tournament at the Essex County Country Club and continue until Oct. 19 when the
Telegrams to Governor Lehman protesting his reported intention of appointing Lester M. Herzog of Albany a member of the State Civil Service Commission to succeed William Gorham Rice, Its chairman,

Conferences seeking a settlement of the General Motors strike in Ontario broke down when Premier Hepburn refused to treat with "any foreign C. I. O. agitator." Homer Martin, president of the U. A. W. A., threatened another General Motors strike in the United States if the Canadian demands were not met. Page 1.
Members of the Seventy-eighth Division will celebrate the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the organization next Saturday at a reunion in the Hotel Paramount, Forty-sixth Street off Broadway.

Miss Evelyn Irwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Irwin of this place, was married this evening to Edwin B. Bachman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Bachman of Upper Montclair, in Watchung Congregational Church by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Travis.

A HUNDRED years ago Sir Charles Wyndham was born. He married Mary Moore. His son, Howard Wyndham, and her son by a previous marriage, Bronson Albery, now jointly control the New, Wyndham's and the Criterion Theatres. Two nights ago,

Tiger Jack Fox, 177 1/2, Spokane, Wash., stopped Lou Poster, 188 1/2, Yorkville, in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round feature at the Rockland Palace last night. Referee Artie McGovern halted the action in 1:11 of the sixth to save Poster from further punishment.
Officials and employes of the Maryland Silk Mills recently demonstrated how a sit-down strike could proceed without acrimony.

Three hundred and seventy-eight boys and girls from about ninety high schools in the Metropolitan area will be tested next Saturday afternoon in the Fourth Annual Interscholastic Mathematics Contest at the Washington Square Colllege of New York University.

President Harold W. Dodds of Princeton University will be the guest speaker at a testimonial dinner to be given by alumni of Rutgers University in recognition of the fifth anniversary of the presidency of Dr. Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers,

Four airplanes and a new th hangar were destroyed in a $30,000 fire at the Toronto Flying Club today. Only the fact that a strong wind was blowing saved the entire airport from disaster. The planes destroyed were a customs Waco, valued at $13,000, and four Cubs, worth about $2,000 each.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation now has its New Jersey headquarters in this city, the Newark Field Division having been installed on the ninth floor of the RaymondCommerce Building early this week. The division covers the whole State.

Fanciers of the pointer and setter in the field will have an opportunity to see them in action for the first time north of the city this Spring when the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club opens next Friday in the covers of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club at Verbank, N. Y.

An explosion believed by police to have occurred in underground passages linking grist storage tanks of the Charles A. Krause Milling Company plant killed at least three men late today and sent thirty-two to hospitals.

Edward C. Blum, president of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn, was guest of honor last night at a dinner in the Montauk Club, Lincoln Place and Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn. About 200 persons, including members of the bench, the bar, the professions, commerce and industry, were present.

Federal agents held the Italian liner Rex at anchorage off quarantine for an hour yesterday while they inspected a full muster of most of the ship's crew, which numbered 874 members. in a futile search for a conspirator in an attempt to smuggle narcotics ashore.

Miss Eleanor Wallace Kavanagh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Kavanagh of 14 East Ninetieth Street, was married to George Joseph Healey, son of Mrs. George Healey of 434 East Fifty-second Street, and the late Mr. Healey, yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, pastor of Holy Cross Church.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Fannie Fellows, daughter of Lester Fellows of this city and the late Mrs. Fellows, to Arthur Philip Henricks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Henricks of East Orange.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg arrived yesterday carrying one of the largest cargoes of birds and animals brought to New York in many years. There were eleven camels, eight polar bears, nine antelopes,

Preparing for the parade of cruisers now returning from the Winter in Florida, Victor Gelineau, director of the New Jersey State Board of Commerce and Navigation, has assigned his State maintenance boats to work on the Inland Waterway this month.

Seventy State police will go to school in Troy this month to brush up on highway traffic control, Major John A. Warner announced today. The course, which will be conducted from April 19 to 24, will include these topics: "Approach to Driver."
RIVERA'S politics are reder than the rose. Nearly every one is aware of that; if you have doubts, look in this book. His rebel boiling point is low and the water around him is perpetually scalding.

Declaring there can be no social security without spiritual security, Cardinal Hayes, speaking with unusual emphasis, asserted yesterday that the government should not attempt to take over the administration of all relief and charity.

The Princeton Engineering Association, which has been closely associated with the development of engineering in the university, has adopted as one of its cardinal aims the maintenance of "a living bond between engineering education and engineering practice" in connection with the twenty-fifth anniversary of its foundation.
Michael H. Donahoe, founder and treasurer of the Shetucket Worsted Mills, Inc., here died in his home today after a short illness at the age of 79. He was a native of Ireland.
For their heroism in rescuing a dog from drowning on Dec. 31, two men will receive honor awards from the American Humane Society Association here.

Flower beds everywhere in this vicinity bear mute evidence that the mild open Winter from which we have just emerged has not been kind to plants. Lacking the usual protection of snow, perennials in general, and particularly the bearded iris, have suffered considerably from "heaving" due to the alternate freezing and thawing of the ground in the Winter.

Two more evidences of recent labor difficulties in the automobile industry disappeared today. The thirty-three-day possession of plants of the Hudson Motor Car Company by striking members of the United Automobile Workers of

Marking the end of a long period of ill-feeling generated by this country's restrictions on fruit imports from South Africa, 10,000 cases of South African grapes of a luxury variety rarely found in this country are due to arrive here early next month, it was announced yesterday.

IF it has happened before, we cannot recall the occasion, but certainly it is not often that two companies elect to issue the same major work at the same time. Coincidentally, both Victor and Columbia decided that this was the proper month for a new version of Beethoven's Eighth symphony,

Florida is divided and confused as Congress turns to consideration of the Atlantic-Gulf ship canal. Battle lines are more sharply drawn because it is believed that the final test has arrived, and contradictory statements by experts make it impossible for the average citizen to decide whether the 195mile waterway would be a good thing.

When ALBERT BIGELOW PAINE arrived at the age of 70 he dwelt upon the importance of a sense of humor. He held that its possession tended to make for a long life. If a man looks sourly at life, he said, thinking how hard it is to die, it must affect his health.

Hamilton House Settlement will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Babes in Arms" Thursday night at the Shubert Theatre. Hamilton House, which is affiliated with the Henry Street Settlement, was founded in 1902 and proyides a recreational and educational program for 400 children and 200 adults daily.

THE principal novelty at the Metropolitan Opera next season may turn out to be a 170-year-old opera. At any rate, it will be one of the novelties, for it has not been performed at the Metropolitan in the fifty-odd years of that institution's history. The work is Gluck's "Alceste." It is understood to be definitely on the agenda for the next regular season.

Clearing the difficult in-and-out course in a flawless manner, the 8-year-old bay mare Matinee last night captured the $200 Jumper Stake, feature of the forty-eighth annual Brooklyn Spring Horse Show.

Thousands defied cold weather tonight to see the capital's famous cherry trees floodlighted for the coronation of a tiny Japanese queen. Visitors from many States thronged about the Tidal Basin for the Spring cherry blossom festival, postponed twice because of rain.

Led by James Connors and Walter Curphey, the Hofstra College of N. Y. U. scored an upset victory over the New York Rugby Club today, winning 17-0. Curphey opened the scoring by picking up a loose ball and running fifty-five yards for a try, and Connors converted.

The contention of Richard C. Murphy, contestant for the Tam?? many leadership of James H. Torrens in the Twenty-third Assembly District, Washington Heights, that his legal residence was 605 West 179th Street, was upheld yesterday in a report by James A. O'Gorman official Supreme Court referee.

Mrs. William Cravath White of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth P. White, to Warren Hastings Miller, son of the Rev. Everard Miller of Scarsdale and the late Mrs. Miller.

The Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, rabbi emeritus of the old Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York, will be 85 years old on Tuesday, but any celebration of the event will be officially a "surprise" to him, he said in a prebirthday interview.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Rose Farwell Whitman, daughter of Mrs. Chatfield Whitman of Boston and Hendricks H. Whitman of Greenwich, Conn., to Channing Frothingham Jr.. son of Dr. and Mrs. Channing Frothingham of Boston.
THOUSANDS of stamps enthusiasts in this country and abroad will have a new "first-flight" cover to add to their collections when the China

A vein of whimsy ran through developments in the New Jersey strike situation today, what with the estranged wife of an industrialist joining a picket line of his employes and a crew of gravediggers calling off a sympathetic strikeout

Declaring that a high rate of industrial construction is necessary to meet the demands of improved business and to compensate for accumulated obsolescence during the depression, H. K. Ferguson, president of the industrial engineering company of that name,

More than 400 members of society of the north country colonies attended the annual dinner dance of the Buckram Beagles at the Piping Rock Club tonight. The dinner was accompanied by a floor entertainment.

" Let's Build a Town," a musical play for children; by Paul Hindemith, the German composer now on a visit to this country, will be presented at the MacDowell Club next Sunday afternoon under the auspices of Heida Hermanns and Ruth Moltke.

Almost daily some observer on the ground in Spain sends a dispatch refuting a story sent out by some other observer or dissipating an impression held by partisans outside, the non-observers who have the advantage of collecting their " facts " from a safe distance.

Even when a great deal of thought has been given to planning the garden in the beginning, usually more or less remodeling must be done to bring it around to just what the owner wants. If-as is often the case-the garden has, like Topsy, "jis growed," then a great deal of remodeling is likely to be required.
The Stevens Tech baseball team scored its first victory of the season by defeating the alumni, 3-1, in a close seven-inning contest at the Castle Point field today.
Prices on the Boerse were firmer today, with trading relatively active. Heavy industrials were stronger throughout, with other leading industrials fairly active.

The National A. A. U. swimming championships wound up as a debating contest in the Yale pool tonight as the disqualification of the Princeton University 300-yard medley relay trio in the final event on the program wrenched away the team championship from the University of Michigan and gave it to the Lake Shore Athletic Club of Chicago.
In winning from the Naval Academy netmen, 7-2, today, Harvard took five of six matches in the singles and two of the three in the doubles.

THE new game-fishing season will afford greater opportunities than ever before for the nation's 12,000,000 amateur anglers. Eighty-five Federal fish hatcheries, 400 State hatcheries and some 200 private ones have restocked hundreds of streams and lakes to meet the demands of sportsmen.
A GENERALLY modern flavor pervades the twenty-first exhibition by groups of New York artists at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee.
An aver age wage of $30.25 and $40 a month with and without board, respectively, "the highest wage since 1931," was reported today for farm labor in New York.

Profiting by a lucky break in the ninth inning, City College's baseball team proceeded to bag two runs and record a 6-to-5 victory over one of its oldest rivals, New York University, at Ohio Field yesterday, before 300 fans, who shivered and stamped their cold feet all during the game.

With the potential threats to this British naval base resulting from the fortification of the Italian Island of Pantelleria and the establishment of airdromes in Sicily and Libya, the authorities have undertaken detailed plans to make the defense force as mobile as possible.
Steadily rising governmental expenses and the detrimental effect which increasing costs are exerting and will continue to exert upon bonds, mortgages and other forms

With the issuance by the United States Bureau of Fisheries recently of the first whaling license under the act of May 1, 1936, the Coast Guard adds another to its multifarious duties-that of enforcing the Whaling Treaty Act, passed after the Senate had ratified the 1931 Geneva convention for the regulation of whaling.

Sales last month of the first twenty-five chain store organizations to report, which aggregated $251,018,035, set a new record for March according to figures released yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.

The Essex County Country Club here will be decorated to represent a cabaret next Saturday for the "Red and Blue Whirligig" dance and entertainment to be given by the University of Pennsylvania Club of Suburban New Jersey.

Citing the fact that a steady and progressive expansion of housing facilities is needed in the United States, Preston Delano, Governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, sounds a warning against excess enthusiasm which would lead to a recurrence of boom coneditions.

America's flotilla of super-yachts, powerful seagoing craft which spend most months of the year cruising the Atlantic, Pacific or Great Lakes waters, are now being fitted out for a Summer season afloat.

Clifford Wayne Hartridge, who was chief counsel for Harry K. Thaw until shortly after his first trial for the murder of Stanford White, died yesterday after a long illness in Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 70.

The twenty-six registered voters of this place will hold a special election Wednesday to decide whether to change the name of the borough to Bendix, in honor of Vincent Bendix. The latter, in announcing he would erect a $1,000,000 airplane instrument plant here, said the name of the borough would be changed to Bendix. Few of the voters object, but the election must be held as a formality.
THIS is the longest novel Phil Strong has yet written, and one has little hesitation in calling it the best. As the title aptly suggests, "Buckskin Breeches" is a story of the frontier.

Showing in her first Good Hands event, Miss Nancy Selinger, 9-yearold member of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, scored a signal triumph in capturing the A. S. P. C. A. horsemanship test for children at the Round Hill Club Stables' tenth annual one-day Spring exhibition today.

THE reason that one seldom if ever hears jokes over the radio about the Supreme Court, the Duke- of Windsor, Mrs. Simpson and the war in Spain is revealed by Ed Wynn, veteran comedian of stage and radio, who has' been stringing together all sorts of gags for thirty-odd years.
