NEW BERN, N. C.--Governor Clyde R. Hoey of North Carolina hsa pledged his active leadership in a plan to restore the historic old Tyron Palace here as one of the major historical objectives of his State administration.

Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the United States who will be 75 years old tomorrow, took part today in the usual secret weekly conference of the nine justices, four of whom are older than their chief.

A dinner was given last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria by Mrs. Blanca Lazo Steinman of this city, Antonio Lazo of Greenwich, Conn., and Carlos Lazo of Locust Valley, L. I., to celebrate the eightieth birthday anniversary of their father, Dr. Antonio LazoArriaga.

Retail stores in general reported decreases for last week because of comparison with the holiday figures of a year ago, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. However, many retailers found dress business better than before Easter.
Professor Auguste Picard, stratosphere pioneer visiting in Denmark yesterday announced he was planning a new flight when he hopes to reach a height of thirty kilometers.
CERTAIN age-old celebrations come with Spring in the Alps, but they are so integrally Swiss, so rarely staged for the benefit of foreigners, that they often pass unnoticed.

While cleaning up under his Summer bungalow at the rear of 2,966 Ocean Parkway in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn yesterday, Frank Taylor, 28 years old, discovered the body of an unidentifed woman about 40 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Walker MacDonald of 858 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Lewis MacDonald, to Philip Faxon Mygatt, son of Mr. and Mrs.

GIBRALTAR, April 10.--With every evidence of haste the 46,200 ton battle cruiser Hood sailed from Gibraltar tonight in a westerly direction, supposedly for Bilbao, where the Rebel blockading warships are reported to have forbidden the landing of foodstuffs from British ships.
A model home contest for amateur architects will be one of the features of the North American Homes Exposition in Madison Square Garden, May 12 to 23, the management announced yesterday.
Belgium's most notable by-election in years, the result of which will be known a few hours after this is read, already has shown itself more important outside the country than within.

Two crack North of England teams will battle in the final for the English Football Cup at Wembley Stadium, May 1. In rousing semi-final tilts today, Sunderland emerged winner, 2-1, over Millwall, while Preston North End trounced West Bromwich Albion, 4-1. Sunderland, league champion last season, is shooting for its first cup.
PROFESSOR OVERSTREET writes interestingly of the social changes which have taken place in ths country in the last half-century or so, and of the questions which they present for answer.

Twenty-five of the best boy checker players in the city emerged from the Gramercy Boys Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street, yesterday after a contest that had kept the place almost incredibly quiet for a Saturday afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clothier Jones of Valley View, Ardmore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Cramp Jones, to Robert Butcher Parker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Butcher Parker of Haverford.

The metropolitan racing season of 171 days, which will continue through nine race meetings until Oct. 30, will get under way on Thursday at the Jamaica course, with new and expanded facilities available for patrons. The seating capacity of the grandstand and clubhouse has been substantially increased and numerous lesser improvements have been made, such as removing the officials from the track level to the roof of the grandstand.

Subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday shipments of 1,414,399 tons of finished steel products in March, an increase of 280,675 tons over February and a gain of 630,847 tons compared with March, 1936.

There are many gray-haired tales concerning that which was not done when a boat went into commission. Of course the familiar one is about the non-replaced drain plug and the prompt sinking of the boat.

THE big-league baseball players are returning. Where have they been? Or rather, where haven't they been? For weeks they trained in far places, in foreign lands, under topic skies, on palm-fringed diamonds.

A fashion show and luncheon in behalf of the Cape Cod Institute of Music will be held April 20 at the Carlyle. Proceeds will be used in providing an addition to the school where instruction will be given blind students.

Importers here last week looked for early action by Congress altering administrative features of the Tariff Act to put that statute more in harmony with the reciprocal trade program of the administration. Several bureaus of the Treasury Department are ready to make recommendations for alterations in the act and will include in the suggestions a number of proposals made by foreign trade groups to the department.

Formation of the Harvard Traffic Associates was announced today, following sanction by .the university authorities. It has a membership of more than fifty present and past fellows and graduate students,

Ambassador Sir Ronald and Lady Lindsay have as their guests at the British Embassy Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Outram and Mr. and Mrs. George Saber of London. The Ambassador and Lady Lindsay entertainted last evening, and tonight they gave a dinner for their guests.
A luncheon was given in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle yesterday by Miss Josephine Amend for Miss Kathryn Quinlan, who will be married to Edward Robert Amend on Tuesday.

Only Germany, Italy and Great Britain are observing the Spanish neutrality accord, the Diplomatische Korrespondenz; German Foreign Office' mouthpiece, charged today. "Relentless energy," it stated, should be used to -suppress any organization formed along the Spanish border to help either of the civil-war belligerents.

Two marks which are likely to prevail for the remainder of the competition were recorded by Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia at Ponzi's Academy yesterday as he defeated Onofrio Lauri of Brooklyn, 125 to 7, and deadlocked the loser for third place in the world's pocket billiard championship.

The influence of the World's Fair is being seen, reports the realty firm of Tankoos, Smith Co., in the increasing demand by chain store organizations for good locations in Flushing, Jamaica, Hempstead, Forest Hills, Jackson Heights and other near-by communities.
THE carillon and an empire service from St. Paul's Cathedral, London, will be on the air today at 6:30 P. M., Eastern standard time, over these sttaions: GSF, 15.14; GSD, 11.75; GSB, 9.51 megacycles.

Recovery is bringing a new consciousness in many quarters of the role of the family as "the most dynamic of social forces," Stanley P. Davies, general director of the Charity Organization Society, said in his annual report made public yesterday.

For the fourth year in a row the New York Athletic Club stands as champion of indoor polo. Last night in the final game at Squadron A the Winged Foot trio of Buddy Combs, Billy Nicholls and Arthur Borden just managed to come from behind in the final period to turn back the gallant bid of the Chicago senior team, 11 1/2 to 10, and win the senior title in two straight games.
Webster lists fleas and ants as insects, but no such simple definition suffices for Uncle Sam.

Students in Hebrew religious schools throughout the East will make a pilgrimage to the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and Yeshiva College, Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street, this morning, to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the institution.

WITH that insatiable ogre, the double feature, gobbling up his rations, quickies and all, faster than they can be manufactured, Hollywood's producers are busily searching through the scrapheaps for more food for the fellow. Last week Jesse L. Lasky dug out "Kiki" and prepared to garnish it with Lily Pons;

Despite the recovery in industry throughout the world since 1932 and the added impetus to heavy manufacturing by the broad rearmament programs of the leading European powers, international trade in iron and steel has recovered only moderately and Is still far below the level of 1929.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. - Reservations are being made at hotels and taverns for the opening of the Berkshire trout season on Thursday. Yellow perch also may be caught after the same date in all lakes and ponds except Onota Lake, Pittsfield, where the opening Leg date is May 30.

It was Mayor Ellenstein's turn to chuckle today. Last week Mayor La Guardia chuckled when American Airlines announced that two of its Boston-to-Newark planes would stop every day at Floyd Bennett Field on their way to Newark.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Berry of Spring Lake, formerly of Westfield, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Gibson Berry, to Thomas Gregory Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gregory of Westfield.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Holland Drury of Newport of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Linton Drury, to Robert H. I. Goddard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. R. H. Ives Goddard of Providence, R. I.

The election of Miss Julia Grant, '38, of Governors Island, N. Y., as president of the Undergraduate Association of Bryn Mawr College was announced today. Students are holding their major elections early this year to release senior officers for a longer period of concentrated work before their comprehensive examinations in May.

Hawaiian members of the Amateur Athletic Union protested today the reported exclusion from Canada of a Hawaiian boxer en route to the amateur championships at Boston. A. A. U. officials asked Delegate Sam King at Washington to protest to the State Department.

Pennsylvania opened its Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball season by winning a spectacular thirteen-inning game from Cornell on Franklin Field today, 3-2, while snow fell part of the time. Not a run was scored by either team until the eleventh.

After forty-nine years as a full-sized newspaper The Item was published here yesterday in tabloid form. Since 1888 The Item, serving ?? and Short Hills, has been in eight-page, large-sized weekly newspaper.
Mrs. James B. Duke, Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson and Mrs. Eugene V. R. Thayer sailed last night on the Europa. Colonel and Mrs. H. Anthony Dyer and Miss Nancy Dyer have come from Providence to the Weylin.

HOT SPRINGS, Va.-This is the week anglers have been waiting for. The trout season opens on Thursday and continues through June 15, and prospects are considered good because of the number of trout emptied into local streams during the Winter season.

With craft unions in the American Federation of Labor rapidly changing their old policies in order to compete with the Committee for Industrial Organization in many fields, the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, once strictly a craft guild, is taking in sawmill and lumber workers in the Northwest.

Divertisements by professionals will be a feature of the annual dinner dance of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital on Tuesday in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. Proceeds of the dance will be given to the institution for its care of needy patients.

The perjury charge against Louis Luckman was still in the hands of a blue ribbon jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court early today. The jurors, who received the case at 4:23 P. M., following the charge of Justice Erskine C. Rogers,

Surprised by an unidentified assailant, Mrs. Gussie Dishler, 61 years old, proprietor of a rooming house at 1,681 Richmond Road, in a residential section of Dongan Hills, S. I., was beaten to death at about 9:45 o'clock last night at the top of a flight of stairs she had been ascending to reach her apartment on the third floor of the house.

Edsel Ford has bought an estate on Jupiter Island, with 130 feet of frontage on the Atlantic Ocean. a deed disclosed today. The property runs a quarter of a mile across the island to the Indian River, where it has 330 feet frontage.

WELLINGTON, N. Z. AUSTRALIAN film production, long concerned with revuestyle comedies and dramas of ranch life, seems now to be moving into a wider field. This is the outcome of the efforts of Charles Chauvel, president of Expeditionary Films, and he has been giving the movement point and impetus by making a film of the Australian blacks.

A revolt by eight Western and Ontario Liberals against the high tariff policy of their own government, particularly the recent increase in tariffs against furniture from the United States, delayed for a time the closing today of this year's session of the Dominion Parliament.

MANHATTAN KIRSCHBAUM, GEORGE (March 30). Estate, more than $10,000. To Lester M. Kirschbaum, son, 118 W. 79th St., $5,000 or stock in Kirschbaum Bros., Inc.; Sadie Kirschbaum, widow, executrix, 118 W 79th St., residue.

The War Department announced today the award of a contract for seventythree basic training airplanes and spare parts to the North American Aviation, Inc., Inglewood, Calif., at a total cost of $903,380.99.

Proponents of the so-called Model Wage Bill, which would amend the State labor laws in relation to the payment of wages, declared yesterday that if the Senate emulated the favorable action of the Assembly and passed the measure,

In an attempt to standardize the descriptions of criminals and reduce to a minimum the opinions of the observer, the Bureau of Criminal Identification of the Police Department has just prepared seventy-one questions which must be checked on a form provided for that purpose when a prisoner appears in the line-up.

The editorial "Sit-Down Philology" was intriguing, but I am sure that there are many of us who would welcome a definite answer to the question, When was the first sit-down strike? I nominate Mahatma Gandhi as a pioneer of the "sit-down" philosophy.

The faith of Wilbur Glenn Voliva and his devoted flock has refused to become disturbed over the incendiary fire which last week, in Zion, twentyfive miles north of Chicago, destroyed Shiloh Tabernacle, for nearly forty years the center of their religious activities.

Armour Heath, '38, of Hillside. was elected this week manager of the undergraduate press bureau of Stevens Institute of Technology. Richard Tarallo, '39, of North Bergen, was elected assistant manager.

Juvenile Worcester skaters are out of luck. First of all the weather man did them a poor trick by sending a Winter that was practically iceless, not to mention snowless, so that skating, sliding and skiing were out of the question.

Henry Ford broke into the oil business today when the General Petroleum Corporation, which is developing forty acres surrounding the Ford automobile assembly plant at Los Angeles Harbor, brought in Ford Well No. 2.

Robert F. Potts, for thirty-nine years a member of the composing room staff of The New York Sun and formerly well known as a track runner and ice skater, died on Friday in the Caledonian Hospital after an illness of six weeks. He was 62 years old and resided at 355 Monroe Street, Brooklyn.
Death by heart disease struck down the veteran James N. Evans as he watched his horse, Stipulate, run in the third race at the Bowie race track this afternoon. He age was 65.

The Josephine Home, an institution in Peekskill, N. Y., providing shelter and care for undernourished girls from 8 to 14 years old, will be the beneficiary of the Spring Fever Frolic to be held Saturday night at the New York Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Turpentine firm: 36c: sales 91 barrels; receipts 314 barrels; shipments 186 barrels; stock 23,634 barrels. Resin firm: sales 750: receipts 584; shipments 534: stock 44,964. Quote: B, $7; D, $7.05; E, $7.45; F, $8.071/2: G. H. I, K, M and N, $8.10; WG, $8.20: WW and X. $8.80.

Wives are indulgent in the Spring of the year. They have to be. In thousands of seaboard homes this April Sabbath morning husbands will bolt down a hurried breakfast and make an early start for their yacht club or shipyard. It is the fitting-out season. It is here in earnest at last.
Thomas M. Paterson, well known in oast banking and investment circles, died of a heart attack last eight while on a business visit at an Diego. He was 54 yea old.
Wilmer Allison, Davis Cup veteran, and Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, Atlanta flash, will battle for the River Oaks tennis championship tomorrow.

Percy Sullivan, a member of the Australian military contingent to the coronation here next month, was knocked down last night by a bicyclist outside Wellington Barracks, facing Buckingham Palace, and later died of his injuries.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Elder of this place have announced the engagement of Mrs. Elder's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Miller Rochester, to Albert Robert Erda, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Erda of New York.
A call for 250 students who have shown aptitude in music or art was issued last week by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to fill the Fall quota for the High School of Music and Art.
Few events recent Soviet history have made more profound-and happier-impression on Russians generally than Dismissal under criminal charges of Henry G. Yagoda, Commissar of Communications.

THE annual tournament of the Long Island Bridge League, which begins tomorrow night at the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn, is sandwiched in between two tournaments, both of which are held to decide national championships.

THE Spring returns! In spite of war and the national debt hovering black on the horizon; in spite of the Winter's toll of deaths, of last year's withered hopes--it comes on, shouldering the sullen earth away, waving green flags and chanting bird canticles as mile by mile and day by day it conquers old surly North. carrying victory past your garden gate and over the hill. It will not stop until,

Safety, in transportation by land and air, in the home, the factory and the school, in industry and in private life, will be the theme -of three days of crowded sessions of the eighth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council that opens on Tuesday morning at the Hotel Astor.

Members from New Jersey, Long Island, New York City, Westchester, Brooklyn, New Rochelle and Connecticut attended the annual luncheon and card party of the Alumnae of St. Mary's of the Lake College, Notre Dame, at the Carroll Club yesterday. Mrs. James B. Clark of Jersey City was the chairman in charge of the luncheon.
Nicholas Mastropasque, 14, needed a license for his dog Rex, and his parents refused to help.
New Jersey had in 1936 the lowest infant mortality rate during the twenty years that records have been kept, State Health Director J. Lynn Mahaffey said today.
The annual junior promenade of the University Heights Colleges of New York University was held last night in the Jade Room of the Waldorf -Astoria. Three hundred and eighty persons attended.

ASSEMBLED mainly from two collections-that of John F. Braun in Philadelphia and of the Washington University in St. Louis-more than sixty prints by Joseph Pennell have been placed on view at the Keppel Galleries, where they will be shown until April 17.

Oh, Abner of the Doubledays in far-off fields Elysian, Your claim to fame is called a foul by later-day decision. Some prying archeologists have gone and found some traces Of baseball footprints ages old in sundry English places.

New Yorkers arriving today from Mediterranean ports on the Italian motorship Vulcania include Mrs. Bryan Ball, the Rev. Peter B. D'Connor, Mrs. Mary Ansko, Miss Kathryn Ansko, Mr. and Mrs. Tames Seligman, Miss Maria Babcock, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Allen and Mrs. Charles Delano Hine.

The recent explosion in the Consolidated School at New London, Texas, has created renewed interest among school authorities in the use of self-inspection blanks prepared by the National Board of Fire Underwriters and endorsed by the National Association of Public School Business Officials, it was said yesterday.
AFTER roaming genially over the far regions of the earth, Bob Davis now reports on his wanderings in Canada, and gives us a gallery of Canadian pictures and people.

FROM mid-May, when Danube steamers get under way, until late Fall, this river of romance becomes one of Austria's busiest tourist thoroughfares. While the waterway extends from Germany's hills to the Black Sea, its most renowned scenic stretch perhaps is between Passau and Vienna.

More than 10,000 persons ap peared yesterday at the incometax offices in the State Building, 80 Center Street, and filed returns. The returns are due on or before next Thursday and may be filed in person or through the mails.

CONCERTED efforts are being made to put a stop in New York to the practice of "packing" the finance charges on the purchase of automobiles on time, which has reached serious proportions in this area as it has in other cities.

Several prominent British scientists and psychologists have decided there is no mystery in fire-walking, although there is "something to learn about the hardness of the human foot," as Professor J. C. Flugel said.

PROPHECIES of overproduction in the automotive industry heard even in the days when car output was "puny compared to later development" have proved false, in the opinion of A. vanDer Zee, general sales manager of the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation.

CHILDREN'S drawings as art, we have trustingly believed, are a brand-new discovery of our times. When before have youngsters' bright splashes on yards of brown wrapping paper adorned the walls of Fifth Avenue galleries, been gravely studied by critics, psychiatrists and educators and even been purchased by museums?
The third annual conference of Trustees of College and Universities will be held at Lafayette College on April 22, with forty-five Eastern educational institutions represented.

Rid of the Indians for a brief spell, the Giants moved into historic Russwood Park today to help Lou Chiozza celebrate his homecoming and between toasts they also made off with the ball game, defeating Billy Southworth's Memphis Chicks by a score of 5 to 0.

A benefit bridge and fashion show will be held on the night of April 20 in the ballroom of the Three Arts Club, 340 West Eightyfifth Street, to raise funds for the Jane Harriss Hall Scholarship Fund, which enables young women from all parts of the country to live at the club for one year to study music, drama and the fine arts.

IN his recent book, "American Prisons," Blake McKelvey traced the evolution of correctional philosophy, institutional techniques and administration in this country from the close of the Revolutionary War until 1915.

A showdown drew near tonight as Cleveland interests declined to enter into a bidding contest against New York interests in negotiations for purchase of Midamerica Corporation, controlling the vast Van Sweringen railroad and real estate empire.

THE collector is taking to the trail again. Spring and warm, sunny days may spell trout or deep-sea fishing for the angler, rambles up hill and down dale for the hiker and nature lover, an endless variety of good "shots" for the camera ehthusiast.
For the first time since 1931, horsemen in the Bluegrass believe the stables of C. V. Whitney are set for a big season.

Committees of debutantes of this season and former years have been organized to assist with ticket sales and entertainment plans for the White Horse Ball, to be held in the grand ballroom of the Astor on April 27 in aid of the Stage Relief Fund.
Drew lost its opening home game for the third season in a row, bowing to the Staten Island division of Manhattan College at University Field today, 9 to 7. The score by innings:
St. Mary's Church in Newton Lower Falls was the scene of the marriage this afternoon of Miss Lorraine Young and Robert Livingston Hollins of New York and East Islip L. I.
Dr. Francis G. Miniter, ear and throat surgeon, died today in Carney Hospital after an appendectomy. His age was 53. He was noted for his work among poor children.
The world's first film treaty between high contracting parties was initiated here today and for the first time photoplay relations entered the official realm of international diplomacy.

Newark debutantes, matrons and children will pass in review Friday in a "Parade of Nations" to be staged at the home of Mrs. Edgar W. Heller of this city for the benefit of the Newark Exchange for Woman's Work.
A Primavera supper and entertainment in aid of Columbus Hospital will be held May 1 at the Plaza under the joint auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary and the Junior Auxiliary of the hospital.
The Senate's two-year investigation of cotton marketing produced today ten recommendations for legislation, including one to eliminate or curtail government crop estimates.
TWENTY-FIVE years ago next Wednesday, on April 14, 1912, from mid ocean the S. S. Titanic flashed an historic CQD-SOS and sank on her maiden voyage to America with 1,517 lives lost.

MANY a time and oft, innumerable moons ago, has this reviewer passed through portentous portals which bore the legend, "For Readers Only," and entered a great rotund room lined with books under a vast dome.
AMYTH in the form of a "frustreating fantasy" hovers over broadcasting, according to William D. Boutwell, director of the Educational Radio Project of the Office of Education.
In a week crowded with important meetings in New Jersey, the State conference of the Committee on the Cause and Cure of War at the McCarter Theatre in Princeton on Thursday holds a double interest.
The week In the markets was characterized by nervous trading and generally lower prices. In stocks the week's best prices were reached on Monday and the worst on Friday. At the low point,
A member of the road patrol of the Keystone Automobile Club saw a man make a flying leap from an automobile today and land sprawling in the highway at Village Green, near here.

THE annual music festival of the Eastman School of Music will be held from Monday, April 26, through Friday, April 30, in Rochester, N. Y. The full program arranged by Howard Hanson, director, includes the usual American Composers' concert, a "Founder's Day" concert, chamber music and band programs and ballet.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ruth Helen Marschalk, daughter of Mrs. Katherine S. Marschalk of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Harry C. Marschalk of this city, to Dr. E. Edward Napp also of this city.

Miss Frances Dee Shanahan, daughter of Mrs. Mary Franoes Shanahan of this place and the late William A. Shanahan, was married to Charles Lester Manning, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Timberlake Manning, also of Waterbury, this morning, in the Blessed Sacrament Church here.

A. W. A.-Lecture. Salvador de Madariaga, speaker on "Theory and Practice of International Organization," 8:30 P. M., clubhouse. Catholic Young Women's Club-Reception and tea. Program by Madeline McNamara and Julia Mahoney, 4 P. M., clubhouse.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

The first hint of open weather has brought new life to the lake and shore developments within commuting distance of Manhattan. In a thousand quiet, sheltered spots close to the water new cabins and Summer houses are springing up to lure city dwellers away from the crowded centers of population.

Miss Rhoda Hermine Wuensch, daughter of Mrs. Everett Raymond of Palmer Hill, was married to Robert E. Phillip, son of Mrs. Walter Blauvelt and the late James Phillip of New Milford, N. J., this evening.

Vegetable prices, already started on a downward trend, will be cheaper for the next few months, government market observers predict. But there will be higher prices, the experts say, on all fresh fruits except strawberries, which will be unusually plentiful as the warm weather advances.
VAMP or Southern belle? It's up to the girl to decide. She can be slinky as a Cleopatra or a hooped beauty like her grandmother. It's a catholicity of style that the Summer is ushering in.

In a frigid setting, Harvard's baseball team toppled Columbia, 14-2, yesterday at Baker Field in the teams' opening game in the Eastern Intercollegiate League. As the afternoon wore on, the weather became colder and the Harvard score soared higher, so that when the game was called at the end of the seventh, this decision was welcomedy.

Miss Lola M. Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Lee of Jamaica, Queens and Idlewood, Adirondack State Park, was married yesterday afternoon in the First Baptist Church, Jamaica, to Ross M. Turner, son of Mrs. Ross Miller Turner of this city, formerly of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Turner. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John C. Wiley.

Transferred to WPA, the Passamaquoddy Dam Federal project will be used by WPA as an instructional center, if plans now under consideration are carried out. In refusing last session to approve an appropriation to continue the original experiment for harnessing the tides of the ocean to create a vast reservoir of

Thomas Watson of 505 Main Street, 35-year-old, 215-pound waiter, was reported recuperating at New Rochelle Hospital today after undergoing an operation by which his "upside down" stomach was righted. Watson became ill several months ago, but his ailment was not diagnosed until April 2, when he was removed from his rooming house to the hospital for X-ray examination.
Lord Portal's Remember II today won the Newbury Spring Cup, important early season handicap over Newbury's mile straightaway, finishing a head in front of R. Middlemas's Fairplay.

The annual charity tea dance, sponsored by the St. Mark's Juniors, will be held on Saturday in the Sapphire Room, 151 East Fifty-seventh Street. Founded as an auxiliary of the St. Mark's Ladies Emergency Society, the Juniors give aid to needy persons without regard to race, color or creed, and gifts and personal service to recognized charitable institutions.
A new air-conditioned house has just been completed by Frank A. Vanderlip in his Scarborough home community, Westchester County, adjoining his estate on the Hudson River.
A huge racing motor, with a pilot's cockpit built in front, will be the newest thing in speed creations on the track for the annual 500-mile automobile race to be run here May 31.

At the tea under the auspices of the Joint Distribution Committee, Junior Division, on April 25 at the home of Miss Beatrice Sulzberger, 1,045 Park Avenue, Mrs. Edward Popper, chairman of the Junior Division, will speak of the work of the committee, often referred to as the "Jewish Red Cross."
Week-end evening-up operations held fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange within rather narrow limits yesterday and although a rally occurred at one time, the list ended with losses of 3 to 7 points.

EVEN were we not informed by the publishers that the author and artist of this book have lived among the Navajos, there is a feeling of authenticity, a simplicity like that of the life it depicts, which bears witness to a close association with its subject.

The four-story building at 1,960 Park Av. and the four-story building at 1,936 Lexington Av. will be offered at auction tomorrow by Henry Brady. Irwin H. Steinman has completed a Cape Cod Colonial dwelling at 38 Parkway Boulevard, Bryn Mawr, Westchester County,

EDWARD DORO'S poetry has always been that of fancy rather than that of the imagination. He has spun fantasy after fantasy obviously in an effort to re-create for the reader some mystic or spiritual adventure. But he has never had the power to add new elements to poetic vision. Elaboration and strange ornamentations have been his way of dressing up some old myth or legend.

Senator Bridges of New Hampshire asserted here tonight that President Roosevelt wants a "subservient" Supreme Court. "He wants the power to appoint justices who will decide favorably for his policies of social and economic reform," he told the Indiana Republican Editorial Association.
The Committee for Industrial Organization began a campaign yesterday to organize the 270,000 employes of the nation's largest corporation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Columbia and Villanova battled through nearly three hours of football yesterday at Baker Field as part of their Spring training campaign. With football weather prevailing, coaches Lou Little and Maurice Smith ordered a regulation game, with the exception of kickoffs. Substitutions were frequent.

Announcement has been made of th engagement of Miss Helen Devine, daughter of Mrs. J. Frank Williams of Douglaston, L. I., and Joseph P. Devine of Caldwell, N. J., to Bruce Currie, son of Mrs. Juanita Dey Currie of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and William Currie of Montclair, N. J.

Answers to a recent questionnaire issued by ManhattanCollege's placement bureau showed that thirtyfive occupations were listed as the preferences of the 200-odd students and young graduates who have applied for whole or part-time jobs.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lennon gave a dance and buffet supper tonight at their villa. Before the dance Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer entertained With a dinner for thirty-five at their villa and Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld had sixteen for dinner at Mrs. Margaret Emerson's Villa, where they are guests.

The women's national A. A. U. indoor swimming and diving championships will be decided at a fourday carnival in the pool of the Lake Shore A. C. in Chicago from Wednesday through Saturday and speculation is keen in aquatic circles concerning the probable outcome. So closely matched are the leading candidates that in one event only, the 400-yard relay, can the winner be named with any assurance.

ASKENASE-Philip, father of Joseph, beloyed son of Rose and Nathan, brother of David, Irving, Sadelle, Esther, Jeanette, Florence. Funeral Jewish Memorial Chapel, 1,406 Pitkin Av., Brooklyn, Sunday, 12 o'clock. BALDINGER--Max, beloved husband of the late Jennie, devoted father of Michael, Irving, Jonah, Esther, Sid Sinenberg. Services today, 2 P. M., Jeffer Funeral Home, 452 New York Av., Brooklyn.

IN a majority opinion rendered by the readers of The Colophon, Sinclair Lewis was voted the one member of his profession most likely to succeed, in the long run. That is to say, of all the American authors now living he has the best chance of being considred a "classic" in the year 2000.

Mrs. Irene Wentworth Nicol, former actress, died on Friday at the Manhattan State Hospital. She was 70 years old. Mrs. Nicol, who was born in Chicago, made her first appearance on the stage in 1888 in "Evangeline." She next appeared with Fanny Davenport and was a member of the Francis Wilson Opera Company in "The Lion Tamer."

Walter Hatterer, 8 years old, who confessed last week that he beat Leroy Bonner, 6, and locked him in a closet in a vacant house for twentyfour hours, was sent to the Camden County detention house for an indefinite period by Judge Gene Mariano after a hearing in the Juvenile Court here yesterday.

United States Commissioner of Education The future of democracy is topic number one in the animated discussion going on all over-America. In the Legislatures, over the radio, at the luncheon table, in the drawing rooms, at meetings of forums and in all kinds of groups of citizens everywhere, people are talking about the democratic way of life.

The most unique strike in this district involves the Mellon family, a large section of the Ligonier Valley in Westmoreland County, the International Gold Cup Steeplechase and a series of annual fox hunts.

Referee Al Koogler, Southern California representative of the American Motorcycle Association, reported today that Fred Ham of Pasadena had established a new record yesterday at Muroc Dry Lake, Mojave Desert, for 24 hours' motor-cycle riding. Ham rode 1,825 miles in 24 hours, including time for fuel stops, averaging 76 miles an hour, Koogler reported.

HAVING a Wonderful Time," a 10-minute sketch sliced from a Broadway show as an act on a recent Vallee Varieties, apparently caused considerable astonishment and eye-brow raising among listeners, who the next day inquired "what is radio coming to."
The Cunard White Star Line will begin its most ambitious excursion program in ten years with the departure of the liner Berengaria on Thursday for Southhampton.
WASHINGTON. SLOWLY but surely a trend toward an ideal is emerging from the competing movements and opinions among the agencies of American transportation and travel.

FOR its next to the last Sunday concert of the season, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, in cooperation with the League of Composers, will give the first performance in New York of Aaron Copland's "A Dance Symphony."

THE production this week, by the WPA Federal Music Project, of Giovanni Pergolesi's "La Serva padrona" in English translation by Marion Jones Farquhar, with a stage setting designed to suggest the period when the opera was composed, and some appropriate dances, should be an event of uncommon interest.

The existence of a free press continues to be the greatest guarantee of personal and political freedom, James G. McDonald of THE NEW YORK TIMES tonight told the members of the Intercollegiate Newspaper Association of the Middle Atlantic States. He was the chief speaker at the closing session of the organization's Spring convention.

Fourteen editors of campus newspapers belonging to the Metropolitan College Newspaper Association, established on April 3, met yesterday in Hartley Hall, Columbia University, and unanimously adopted a resolution urging their staff members to join the American Newspaper Guild as "unemployed newspaper men."

The world premiere of Rachel Crothers's latest comedy, "Susan and God," starring Gertrude Lawrence, was enthusiastically received here tonight in McCarter Theatre by a capacity audience of 1,000 persons.

The problem of Federal unemployment relief is again facing Congress. It has grown less acute, with the dropping off of Federal relief expenditures from their depression peaks, but new uncertainties have risen to cause observers to wonder how far the administration will go in its recommendations on the subject expected next week.

One of the novel features of the "Dawn to Dusk" fashion revue and luncheon to be held Thursday in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria in behalf of the Generosity Thrift Shop will be the appearance of several champion dogs which will walk with the manikins.

Marty Cogan permitted only five scattered hits and fanned four in hurling Samuel J. Tilden, BrooklynQueens P. S. A. L. baseball titleholder, to a 1-0 victory over Adelphi Academy on the latter's field in Queens Village yesterday.
Mayor Stanley Davis announced today that "outsiders" will not be allowed in Scranton to aid the unionization drive of the Committee of Industrial Organization in the textile industry.

Burleigh Grimes had several items that demanded his deep consideration today after his Dodgers, alleged to have had all daffiness extracted from them, had trounced the Jacksonville Tars, 13 to 3, running their winning streak to four.

James Speyer will give a luncheon today at his home, 1,058 Fifth Avenue, for Elisabeth Rethberg and Friedrich Schorr of the Metropolitan Opera, who will give a recital for the benefit of the New York Women's League for Animals tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mr. Speyer.

Safeguards required by the Fed eral Housing Administration a protection for the mutual mortgage insurance fund, explains Fredericl M. Babcock, chief of the under writing section, automatically ac as a protection to the borrow himself.

One of the oldest and most famous buildings in Bergen County, N. J., and which for more than a century has been the most interesting landmark in Hackensack, has just been sold and will soon be torn down for commercial improvement.

Lord Nuffield, the British motor magnate, is reported to have told a Cambridge professor that he sleeps only about one hour in each month. He goes to bed and rests, he says, but remains conscious of everything around him.

United States Government bonds extended their recovery yesterday during the two-hour trading period. Values throughout the government list were lifted from 1-32 to 22-32 point on a turnover of $1,235,400 on the Stock Exchange, compared with sales of $4,010,900 on Saturday a week ago.

Two Oriental pearl necklaces were sold yesterday afternoon for a total of $22,300 at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, The pearls were from the estate of the late Alice W. Emmet and they were sold by order of the United States Trust Company of New York.

MIAMI, Fla.--Officials in charge of the annual Metropolitan Miami Fishing Tournament, which began on Jan. 15 and will close next Sunday, estimate that 50,000 persons from all parts of the United States have participated.

Applications from choruses, glee clubs, orchestras and bands for the current Catholic school music contests will total twice those of last year, it was predicted yesterday-by Isabel Lowden, president of the Music Education League.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to make public within a few days its opinion on applications by the Pittsburgh Stock Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in twenty-three stocks and debentures that are registered on other Exchanges under provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
Mathew F. Boyd, former Philadelphia and Washington newspaper man, died today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Boyle Jr. He was 52 years old.

Grain markets were on the upgrade today as the result of general commissionhouse and professional buying. While the upturn inn wheat on the Board of Trade here was checked by profit-taking sales, net gains were 7/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel, with July leading. Corn advanced 3/4 to 2 cents, the latter on July, while oats were 1/4 to 3/4 cent higher and rye was up 1 1/2 to 2 5/8.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lewis o 45 Gramercy Park o the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claire Josephine Lewis, to Martin Fuld Ehrenberg, son of Mrs. Etta Fuld Ehrenberg of 1,075 Part Avenue and the late Sydney P. Ehrenberg.
United States Ambassador William Phillips tonight informally asked Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano for information on the expulsion of three American women missionaries from Ethiopia.

A note of relief was sounded in the camp of the New York Rangers today when it was definitely revealed that Ott Heller and Alex Shibicky will be ready for action tomorrow night. The news was joyfully broadcast by Manager Lester Patrick after he himself had been apprised of the athletes' condition by examining physicians.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. James Markoe Robbins of Mount Kisco, N. Y., on March 21. Mrs. Robbins is the former Miss Jane Brooks, daughter of Mrs. Ellwood Wilson Brooks of South Nyack, N. Y., and the late Mr. Brooks. The child, whose mother is a well known golfer, will be named Barbara.

The Boston University nine scored an easy victory over Upsala as the Vikings opened their baseball season today, winning, 13-0. Besides outhitting the local team, the visitors capitalized on the wildness of Elk Graef, Upsala pitcher, who issued eleven bases on balls.

IF you want to become substantially au courant with what is being done by our American abstractionists, go to the thirtythird floor of the Squibb Building, where, until April 17, a large group show is current, and to the Reinhardt Galleries, where four artists-A. E. Gallatin, Susie Frelinghuysen,

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Jean Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Brown of this city, to Richard Edson McGraw, son of Mrs. Louis W. McGraw of Newark and the late Mr. McGraw, took place this afternoon in the Church of St. Andrew, South Orange. The Rev. Karl C. Kumm performed the ceremony.

On the small home place there are few parts of the landscaping so important as the hedge. Often it must serve the double purpose of providing privacy, if not actual physical protection from without, and of serving as a background for beds and borders within.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of author, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Charles H. Haupt, an engineer and an executive of the Standard Oil Development Company for many years, died this morning at his home, 777 Salem Avenue, following an illness of five months. He retired from business four years ago. His age was 67.
THOUGH it does not profess to be a textbook, Dr. Taylor's "World of Science" possesses some of the qualities of the simple texts that are used in teaching.
Henry Picard, the calm, gracefulstroking professional from Hershey, Pa., stood off a serious challenge today to win the Tournament of the Gardens for the third straight year.

ALAMEDA, Calif. DEFINITE plans for the early completion of an important link of the projected International Pacific Highway from Alaska to South America were made at the recent meeting in Mazatlan, Mexico, of officials of California auto clubs, the Governors of four Mexican States and representatives of the Mexican Federal Government.

BERLIN.--German rearmament has reached a stage, it has been learned, where the Reich is now exporting considerable quantities of munitions and manufactured products to Central Europe and South America.

Connecticut, along with New Jersey, will formally usher in another trout season on Thursday. New Yorkers who fish the waters of the Nutmeg State are not apt to be out in large numbers on opening day, but they will form a part of the regular contingent in the weeks to come.
The Banco di Roma, Italy, in its report for 1936 showed deposits of 982,348,882 lire in current and savings accounts at the end of the year an increase of 317,619,430 lire in the year.
IT would be interesting to know just what sort of picture the title of this book brings up in the mind of the average fairly well-read American.

Leroy Staubs, 44 years old, who told the police he had been a member of the Baltimore Police Depart ment and a guard at the Baltimore City Jail, is charged with murdering his 39-year-old wife. Mrs. Ann?? Marlin Staubs, about 2 o'clock this morning in a beauty shop at 342 Main Street, this city. He has confessed, according to Acting Detective Captain James Smith.

The New York State Horseshoe Pitchers Association, reorganized at a recent meeting at the old senior high school on Main Street, plans to rejuvenate the ancient rustic sport by holding a State championship tournament in New York City between Aug. 20 and Sept. 15, it was announced today.

The plan adopted when sanctions collapsed to have the League of Nations study that experiment with a view to avoiding the repetition of mistakes and doing better next time has been quietly shelved to ease Italy's return.

The problem of the unbalanced national budget was thrust into greater prominence last week when the Federal Reserve authorities made known their intention of coming to the support of the faltering government bond market and Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, promptly followed up the news with the announcement that he would soon have to borrow again.

New savings for more than 800 New York families occupying two large apartment houses under the cooperative tenancy plan were reported yesterday by the Cooperative League of the United States. In the Amalgamated Housing Corporation's building facing Van Cortlandt Park, in the Bronx,
Mr. and Mrs. Harmon Lewis of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Read Lewis, to Robert Thrun of Eagle River, Wis.

The wedding of Miss Louise Jane Geyer, daughter of Mrs. Louis Geyer of this city, and Thomas Philip Heiss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Heiss of Newark, took place this morning with a nuptial mass in St. Rose of Lima's Church here.

One of the most serious problems in the stimulation of home ownership, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, is the difficulty of reducing the financial sums which must be paid annually for home ownership.

WITH the eyes of the motoring public sharply focused on safety, the first annual Metropolitan Automotive Maintenance Show, which is to be held in Commerce Hall, Port Authority Building, on April 21, 22 and 23, will be dedicated by its sponsors, a group of metropolitan wholesalers and manufacturers' representatives, ...
The imminence of war and the attitude to be taken by this country will be discussed at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, to be held here Friday and Saturday.

ALANTIC CITY, N. J.--A barnstoring group of outstanding professional tennis players will stage exhibition matches in the Municipal Convention Hall here next Saturday for the entertainment of the visitors to Atlantic City.

THOSE whose recreation is bird study are lured to many strange lands by their hobby. For them travel and ornithology form a happy union. They voyage -mostly to tropical or subtropical countries, for there birds are not only numerous, but appeal to the eye with their colorful plumage.

President DODDS in his address at the Princeton alumni dinner gave authoritative use to a word which has found only bottom-of-the-page recognition in our American dictionaries but which is given full acceptance by the New England Dictionary in a meaning that has made obsolete the definitions of earlier centuries.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 7 aggregated $9,967,000,000, or 6 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included five business days in some of the reporting centers, and 19 per cent above the total for the corresponding week. of last year.
ARTISTS of the WPA proposed recently to do something esthetic about those gloomy, depressing caves, the subway stations of New York City.

Mrs. John H. Elliott of 1,834 Caton Avenue, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Elliott, to Howard Chamberlain Moore, son of Mrs. William C. Moore, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Moore. The wedding will take place on June 5.

AN intimate exhibition entitled "Modern Art, Old and New," has been arranged at the Georgette Passedoit Gallery to continue through April 24. Carlo
Wherever he may be, in the skyscraper cities of the New World or in a village school in a Brazilian jungle, the radio hearer can switch in and become a member of the German world community.

Mayor La Guardia is scheduled to speak at a conference on the Prevention of crime, sponsored by the civics and politics committee of the Baptist Ministers Conference of Greater New York and Vicinity, on Thursday at the Metropolitan Baptist Church, 128th Street and Seventh Avenue.

For the first time this season a Class C gunner won the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The nimrod was Al Trahan, who generally competens in Class B.

Plans for the Spring supper-dance to be held on April 23 at Sherry's for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital will be discussed by members of the Almoners at their regular monthly meeting tomorrow at their headquarters, 300 Park Ave.

David Kantrovitz of New York gained a 10-yard victory over fast-closing George Durgin of Beverly today in the twenty-seventh Cathedral Club 10-mile road race. The winner, who led almost from the start, was timed In 55 minutes 48 seconds.

Miss Hazel M. Bantel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Bantel of Crest Acres, Summit, was married to Lewis L. Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis L. Smith of Bellerose, L. I., here this afternoon in St. John's Lutheran Church by the Rev. William S. Hinman, a member of the faculty of Wagner College in Staten Island.

Paul Mellon's veteran jumper, Welbourne Jake, who appears to have come back to his best form, scored his second victory of the season today when he captured the Middleburg Cup, leading the Northwood Stables' Indigo by two lengths after a stirring battle through the stretch in a grueling four-mile race.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were the smallest in volume for any week in two months. The major portion, as in the preceding period, was for parts of issues called to satisfy sinking-fund requirements.

THERE are several reasons to be grateful for Ralph Bates, but the sad state of British fiction today is chief among them. As critics of every disposition have agreed, too many young British novelists write like nonagenarians, and too many older ones like professional and unwearying cynics.

THIS is about the best month of the year for cookbook circulation. It is the end of a trying season for housewives. The children have probably had the average number of colds from wet feet and deceptive weather; husbands are inclined to acid dispositions, the result of a series of inclement Sundays; income-tax reports have cast a sour light on the domestic scene.

With a special race for Hambletonian candidates featured, the new mile harness racing track recently completed by Dunbar W. Bostwick and his associates was officially opened today. The feature trot, third on a card of four events, was won by Hollyrood Audrey, a bay filly owned and driven by Bostwick. Her times were 2:16 3/4 for the first heat and 2:15 1/4 for the-second.
The Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Labor laid new strategy today in their battle for employee leadership at the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.
F. Louis Van Gilluwe, well known in music and religious fields and a founder of Ephiphany Lutheran Church in New York, died last night at his home here. He was 88 years old.

Captain Lionel Rees, holder of the Victoria Cross, has exchanged his 24-foot yacht May, in which he made an Atlantic crossing and other long cruises, for a 20-foot Nassau cabin cruiser, in which Maurice Barbes made a trip to South America and the Pacific last year.

The so-called mandate given Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium to investigate the possibilities of increasing international trade and, if possible, pave the way to a resumption of the 1935 economic conference appears to have given rise to high expectations throughout the world.

A policy forbidding the summary killing of prisoners captured by the Loyalist forces in the Spanish civil war and assuring restoration of all rights and property to combatants in the Rebel armies who can show their true loyalty to the Valencia government is contained in a communique made public today by the Spanish Ambassador, Fernando de los Rios.

The annual Gift Horse Party under the auspices of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work will be held the afternoon of April 22 in the Viennese Room of the St. Regis. The party will take place during the membership drive now under way.

C. S. FORESTER is the English adventure novelist of "The General," "The African Queen" and "The Gun." Like Conrad, he is a psychological novelist, but, unlike Conrad, there is nothing either tortuous or tortured about either his prose or his plots.
Dr. Christian Gauss, dean of the college, Princeton University, will be the speaker at the initiation meeting of the Gettysburg College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa on April 30.

Three men were held here today in the theft of gold from the Irvington Smelting and Refining Works at 374 Nye Avenue. Detectives said the gold was sold to a New York "fence" for about $7,500. Its value was estimated at $15,000.

SEVERAL one-man shows of interest have been placed upon the local art calendar. At the Rehn Gallery, for instance, may be seen, until April 24, paintings by a Philadelphia artist, Elizabeth Sparhawk-Jones. She is by no means a newcomer, although not for a good many years has work by her--save for an occasional canvas--been shown in New York.

Modernization and rehabilitation of existing structures on a large scale should be hastened in order to cope with the demand for low-rent housing instead of depending upon the fruition of plans for this type of dwelling construction by means of public projects, Harry D. Phillips, director of the sixth annual Building Modernization Exposition,

LONDON. THAT diminutive but dynamic film magnate, Max Schach, looks as though he may rival Alexander Korda in making British films which will interest world audiences. A Viennese journalist, he was for twelve years dramatic and literary critic to one of Berlin's largest newspapers.

The Chase National Bank will open a new branch in London on April 19, in historic Berkeley Square and will move its main London office on May 3, from 10 Moorgate, City, to more spacious quarters at 6 Lombard Street, in the center of London's financial district, it was announced yesterday.
The increase in daily allowable of 49,000 barrels a day, which on April 1 raised the total from 551,000 to 600,983 barrels,

Eight prizes will be awarded in a competition for the design of a hotel interior, open to advanced architectural students and sponsored by the Illuminating Engineering Society and the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design, on Tuesday flight, it was announced yesterday.

Speaking of the general recovery in New York City real estate during the past year, Edgar Cadmus, vice president of the firm of Slawson Hobbs, points out that ample funds are ready for investment in desirable mortgages.

ALMOST parenthetically, in the course of his annual report for the industry, Will Hays mentioned the increased use of classical music in the cinema and hinted that an experimental grand opera in film was being considered by one of the studios.
The engagement of Miss Elsa Hilger, only woman 'cellist of the Philadelphia Orchestra, to Dr. Willem Ezerman of this city, has been announced.
Eighty-one students have been pledged by twenty-three sororities at Hunter College, according to an announcement yesterday by Ruth Ginsberg, president of the PanHellenic Association at the college.

When the widening of the Henry Hudson Parkway and the doubledecking of the bridge over the Harlem Ship Canal are completed, a bronze statue of Henry Hudson will be placed atop the Henry Hudson Memorial column in Spuyten Duyvil, opposite 227th Street, north of the bridge, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, announced yesterday.

The fourth and final yacht race of the Prince of Wales Trophy series, scheduled for today, was postponed until Monday. The yachtsmen were tired after three days of heavy going and as squalls were expected today Eldon H. Trimingham, Bermuda's star skipper, suggested the postponement.

Recognizing the fact that many new homes in Bergen County and the northern part of Hudson County, N. J., have been equipped wita air-conditioning devices, the Hackensack Water Company has made a survey to obtain information regarding the various types of air conditioning so as to enable the company to estimate the water
Lehigh and St. joseph's College of Philadelphia scrimmaged for more than two hours in a Spring football drill today. A total of 110 players saw action.

Yale rallied in the eleventh inning today and with one out, pushed three runs across to defeat Springfield College, 9-8. After Sophomores Bill Albinger and Eddie Collins Jr. had produced timely hits, Captain Larry Kelley, the Elis' man of athletic magic, was intentionally passed by Cliff Mantor.

With unfavorable weather conditions and labor disturbances continuing to retard the movement of Spring merchandise in some sections, trade results were spotty last week. In most of the Federal Reserve districts, however, the volume of buying continued heavy, with gains reported over the corresponding.period last year, which was the week immediately preceding Easter.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 10.--Youthful Lyndon B. Johnson, who shouted his advocacy of President Roosevelt's court reorganization all over the Tenth Texas district, was elected today to the seat in Congress which the late James P. Buchanan held for twenty-four years.

The examination of the Rev. Joseph Rossaint, chief defendant in the Catholic trial before the People's Court, today was carried to the point where he began to break off his relations with the Communists in the Spring of 1934.
A possibility of a peaceful settlement of the hitherto bitterly contested demands of strikers in the Hershey Chocolate Corporation's plant here appeared likely today.

An eavesdropper at the Capitol could hear some very disconcerting things these days. In fact, if he listened at the right doors and tuned in on little groups of conversationalists around the cloakrooms of the House and Senate he might readily conclude that the long-drawn-out "honeymoon" of Mr. Roosevelt and his Congress is fast coming to an unromantic close.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday the new wage schedules adopted by the Board of Transportation, granting pay rises, aggregating $1,120,910 a year, to employes in the operating and maintenance divisions of the city's Independent Subway.
WHAT makes this yeaar's Society of Independent Artists exhibition at Grand Central Palace an anniversary is the fact that it is the twenty-first. The Independents have come of age.

An exhibition of contemporary American silver will be opened to the public today in Gallery E 15 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and will continue through May 23. The Associated Traffic Clubs of America, which comprise ninety members, will hold their semi-annual meeting at the Commodore Hotel on April 20 and 21. The Traffic Club of New York will act as host to the other clubs.

AHRENS-Mr. and-Mrs. George Ahrens announce arrival of a son, at Jewish Hospital, April 10. BLUMENFELD-Mr. and Mrs. Irving (nee Alice Frankfurt), announce the birth of a daughter on April 7, at Sydenham Hospital, N. Y. CANEDARI-Mr. and Mrs. August Canedari announce the birth of a daughter April 2, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital.

Movements on the chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follows: HOGS Receipts 5,000 head, including 4,500 direct. The market closed nominally steady. With the top $10.30. Shippers took none and the estimated holdover was 500 head.

A story that the life of Abraham Lincoln's late son, Robert Todd Lincoln, was saved by Edwin Booth, actor and brother of John Wilkes Booth, was told here by persons close to the Lincoln family who asked that their identity not be disclosed.

Inspired by the Supreme Court issue and other recently proposed constitutional changes, Harvard students of the social sciences will hold a Student Constitutional Convention on the 150th anniversary of the American Constitutional Convention of 1787. They will consider possible alterations in our form of government to fit it to modern economic conditions.
First copies of one of the major undertakings of the Federal Writers Project. "Washington: City and Capital," reached Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, this week.
Gold mines in Ontario and Quebec recorded substantial increases in production in February, in comparison with the same month last year. In Ontario production was $6,895,604, compared with $6,111,006.

The fifteen largest banks in this city reduced their holdings of United States Government securities $394,873,000, or 9.17 per cent, in the first quarter of this year, a compilation of their condition statements as of March 31 shows.

The League of Nations slavery committee concluded today its fourth session by confirming its position as the League's only secret organ. Not only is the public excluded from its meetings, but it issues no communiques.
More than 14,000 supporters of President Roosevelt's proposal to change the Supreme Court tonight heard Mr. Ickes sharply assail the conservative members of the nation's highest tribunal.

Nineteen new apartment houses have been erected in the Jackson Heights and Elmhurst sections of Long Island since October, 1936, according to Frank S. O'Hara, president of the realty firm bearing his name.

James C. Clark of New York obtained a decree of divorce today from Lady Irene Cubitt Clark, daughter of the Marquess and Marchioness Camden. The divorce, which was granted on grounds of desertion and cruelty, was uncontested.

Brown University's baseball team defeated Lowell Textile, 9 to 1, in its opening game today. Dan Hicks, second baseman, paced the Bruins' twelve-hit attack with three doubles in four trips to the plate. Dye,

" Big Pete," a full-grown dog of terrier ancestry, rescued "Little Pete," a terrier pup, from drowning in the Patterson Park boat lake yesterday. How the pup came to be twentyfive feet from shore was not known, but the larger dog jumped in to save him.

David S. Milford, British schoolmaster, won the world racquets championship today, defeating Norbert Setzler of New York, 15-4, 15-4, 15-9, 15-12, at the Queen's Club. Milford is an amateur, Setzler a professional.
A further decline in the French franc featured the brief trading period in foreign exchange yesterday, although the loss was slight in comparison with that on the preceding day.
