NICHOLAS II, the last of the Romanoffs, and his consort are undoubtedly entitled to a place among the most tragic figures of history. Essad-Bey, in his biography of the late Autocrat of All the Russias, seems to be unduly impressed by the fact that Nicholas II was born on the day when the Russian Orthodox Church honors the memory of "the sufferer Job," a coincidence to which he refers over and over again.

Mrs. Florence Burnhome, 37 years old, of Boston, died in Highland Hospital here today, the second victim of an automobile collision in which two others were injured. Joseph E. William, 29 years old, of Beacon, with whom Mrs. Burnhome was riding,
First mortgages aggregating $372,800 have recently been placed on several business and residential properties in Hudson and Bergen Counties, N. J., by J. I. Kislak, Inc.

RARE manuscripts, such as the Columbus letter of 1493 addresssed to Ferdinand and Isabella and sold for $4,350 here last week, are fascinating game for collectors and often bring high prices at auctions or private sales.

Stuyvesant maintained its position at the top of the Division 1 standings, while Erasmus Hall emerged as the undisputed leader of Division 2 as a result of yesterday's competition in the P. S. A. L. fencing tournament at the Washington Irving gymnasium.

The Structural Clay Products Institute, of Washington, D. C., has announced a home competition with prizes aggregating $5,000. The purpose is to disseminate to the building public the latest ideas evolved since 1928, toward increased beatty and utility in the construction of fireproof homes.

THE Gabrilowitsch Scholarship Fund of the National Orchestral Association has more than reached its objective of $10,000. The committee in charge, which was organized last Fall to establish an annual scholarship in the National Orchestral- Association in memory of Ossip Gabrilowitsch, conductor-pianist,
Dr. Walter Scott Grant, for more than forty years a practicing physician in Brooklyn, died in his home at 378 McDonough Street, yesterday at the age of 65.

The Rutgers University baseball team was routed by the University of Maryland. today, 15 to 2. All of the victor's runs came in the first four frames, with six being made in the second-and six in the third. The box score:

STROUDSBURG, Pa.-On Thursday the trout fishing season will open in the Poconos. Hotels have announced a large advance booking of fishermen. The State Fish Commission has completed its program of early Spring stocking of streams. Several of the larger resorts have their own private trout streams, many miles in length.

WE have had a number of studies of primitive psychology of late, and a number of books dealing with backwoods communities of sixty years ago. "Windless Sky," however, is not a realistic or a dramatic novel.

ANDREA MAJOCCHI is Italy's foremost surgeon. His father was a physician who died at 32 as a result of an infection received while performing an autopsy. To his wife his dying words were: "I commit our children to your care. I would rather have them peasants than doctors."

Strikes in Edmonton increased to five today as picketing started at the Burns Company packing plant. Officials said that between fifty and sixty workers were on strike and that the plant continued operations.

Re-election of Mrs. Lionel Sutro as chairman of the Manhattan division of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom is anticipated at the annual meeting tomorrow afternoon at 150 Fifth Avenue, the first of a series of events in which the local unit is especially interested.

Two national junior college records were bettered and one tied today as San Mateo's powerful track team defeated Sacramento, 66 1/2 to 56 1/2. Cecil Cole of San Mateo ran the mile in 4:20.4 to better the mark of 4:23.5 set by Warren Dixon, former San Mateo athlete.

The Westchester Summer theatre season was launched tonight when the Manhattan Players, a cooperative group of young Broadway actors, raised the curtain on their production of the Theatre Guild success, S. N. Behrman's "Biography," at the Westchester Woman's Club.

The indications are for partly cloudy and continued cold weather today. Tomorrow will be fair and somewhat warmer, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

Commodity futures were generally firm in lessened activity on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, copper, tin, zinc and hide. futures gained, while coffee, sugar, wool tops and cottonseed oil futures held steady. Cocoa and lead futures eased. On the cash market, rubber, tin, wheat, corn, rye and oats advanced, but cotton and cocoa declined.
Stocks steady and mixed; turnover, 480,360 shares, slowest Saturday trading since August. United States Government bonds stronger, closed higher; other issues firm; transactions, $6,095,400.

The 1937 edition of the New York University Varsity Show, "In Praise of NYU," will be produced on April 29 and 30 at the Manhattan Opera House, it was announced yesterday by Jess Kimmel, production manager.
Subscriptions have been received from several hundred patrons of music, including many persons prominent in society, for next season's Town Hall Endowment Fund concerts.

The newly organized American Committee for Spanish Relief, with headquarters at the Hotel Vanderbilt, denied last night that it had been formed to send relief to General Franco and the Insurgents as charged by the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, 381 Fourth Avenue.
IT is good news that aviation is to be stressed at the New York World's Fair. Appointment of Howard Hughes, speed flier extraordinary and serious scientific student of air problems at.the same time,

The sit-down strike issue has stimulated members of Congress to thoughts of curbing labor unions. Nothing has yet resulted except the introduction of a bill seeking to force the incorporation and regulation of labor groups.

Burleigh Grimes had several items that demanded his deep consideration today after his Dodgers, alleged to have had all daffiness extracted from them, had trounced the Jacksonville Tars, 13 to 3, running their winning streak to four.

Outskating the Philadelphia Ramblers from start to finish, the Syracuse Stars won the third game of the final play-off series for the International-American League ice hockey championship tonight, 4 to 1. A crowd of 6,500 saw the home team scored on before the contest was two minutes old.

Vice Commodore John J. Warsaw and Frederick L. Kraemer, acting as a moorings committee at the Knickerbocker Y. C. at Port Washington, are confronted with the problem of providing anchorage for a number of new craft which have been added to the club's fleet since the beginning of the year.

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house the vacant plot 120 by 150 feet, at 310 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Skolnick Building Corporation from the Manufacturers Trust Company.
Federal prosecution of State bank officers under provisions of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Law gained the approval of Federal Judge Robert C. Baltzell here today.
The General Motors Corporation will have its own police force for its new $5,525,000 assembly plant, nearing completion here.

The marriage of Miss Alyce Pressprich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald W. Pressprich of Purchase, N. Y., to Samuel Lord Brookfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Brookfield of this city, will take place on June 11 in Christ's Church in Rye.
Albert T. Rogers, former Mayor of this borough and active in Democratic politics here, died at his home, 1,008 Main Street, this morning. He was 78 years old.

Invitations to an international radio conference to be held in Havana beginning Nov. 1 will be sent, as a result of a resolution approved by the Cabinet yesterday afternoon, to all Central and South American countries and to Mexico, Canada and the United States.

Army recruiting sergeants throughout New York City are seeking 247 highly trained workers for service in the garrisons of the Panama Canal Department, it was announced yesterday. Men from thirty-six trades or occupations are sought.
In a special practice shoot of the North Jersey Gun Club today D. P. Earle won the trophy in the first fiftybird event, the laurels in the second fifty going to A. E. Cooper.

The performance of "Babes in Arms" tomorrow night at the Shubert Theatre has been taken over to augment the scholarship fund of the Junior Society of Congregation Emanu-EI. Mrs. Albert Frankenthaler heads the group that has in charge the sale of tickets.

The marriage of Miss Epsie Phelan Dallis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Ellington Dallis of this city, to Harry William Buice, also of Atlanta, took place here tonight in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

Miss Lucille Simmen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Simmen of Port Chester, was married to John deLong Moomaw, son of Dr. and Mrs. William C. Moomaw, also of this place, this morning at the home of her parents by the Rev. Stanley S. Kilbourne, rector of St. Peter's Church here.

THE DeBasil Ballet Russe will bring its Spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House to a close on Tuesday night after four more performances. The repertory for the remainder of the engagement is as follows:

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William R. Kennedy of White Plains, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Violet Kennedy, to Arthur Howard Blight Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Howard Blight, also of White Plains.

MEXICO, D. F., April 10.--Leon Trotsky implied under questioning today that all his correspondence since his exile from Soviet Russia was not in Mexico and explained that some documents here consisted of copies of originals.

As a result of a rise in the prices of engineering materials because of Britain's rearmament rush, the London Passenger Transport Board postponed consideration of vast subway extension and electrification schemes.

DR. WALTER GROPIUS, 54 years old, with a record of four years' service on the Western Front during the World War (he was decorated with the Iron Cross, First Class, and his experience as observer over the French lines was punctuated by a shot which brought him down to earth with his airplane), has come from Germany, by way of England, to be Professor of Architecture at Harvard.

Higher education is celebrating in New York this week the fourth completed year of a challenging academic enterprise. What will ever be known by its earliest and most significant description-the University in Exile-has justified the faith of its founders and is now a recognized school.

Pope Pius today named Archbishop Giuseppe Pizzardo as Papal Legate to the coronation of George VI in London May 12. The legate will be accompanied by Mgr. William Godfrey, rector of the English College in Rome, and Noble Guard Giulio Pacelli, a nephew of Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State.

Six British officers were officially reported killed and five wounded est today in a skirmish with tribesmen on the northwest frontier. Unconfirmed reports placed the casualties at twenty-five killed and forty wounded in the remote territory where spasmodic guerrilla warfare recently has cropped out again.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Richardson, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Willard Samuel Richardson of Montclair, to Lewis William Ray, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Murray Ray of Toronto, Ont., took place this afternoon in the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father.

A plan to provide a clearing house for handling mortgages on homes made through the FHA insurance plan in the New York area was announced yesterday by Donald K. Vanneman, formerly head of the Jamaica offices of the FHA.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 9: MAJOR GENERAL Gibbins, H., the Quartermaster General, 5 days' leave, April 12.

BERRY-POSNER-Mr. and Mrs. Morris Posner of 717 East 7th St., Brooklyn, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mr. Posner's daughter, Miss Esther M. Posner. to Hyman L. Berry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Berry, also of Brooklyn.. ESKIN-WEIGERT-Mr. and Mrs. Louis Weigert of 659 Ocean Av., Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Louise Pauline, to Mr. Albert Eskin, son of Mrs. Dora Eskin.
George Zengaras, East Side lightweight, outpointed Charley Gomer of Baltimore in the feature bout of eight rounds before 2,500 spectators at Ridgewood Grove last night. Each weighed 135 pounds.
The coronation season International Opera at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden will open on April 19 under the direction of Sir Thomas Beecham. The London Philharmonic Orchestra will accompany.

Government troops smashed ahead today in their offensive just outside Madrid, further narrowing the now virtually useless Rebel line of communication into University City. They continued to batter in vain, however, at two houses and a cemetery just north of the lake in the Casa de Campo, west of the city, that were their main objectives yesterday.

By the practical work in a course in educational testing the Department of Education at Franklin and Marshall College contributes a service to surrounding communities and at the same time gives its students actual experience with tests and testing techniques through field work.

COMPARISONS for last week's trade with a year ago were particularly difficult for the reason that 1936 sales were those just before Easter. Reports from various sections of the country described fair results, however, except where weather conditions continued unfavorable.

On the radio is no place to mimic the voice of the President of the United States, according to the rules of WMCA, which promptly cut Arthur Boran, professional imitator, off the air at the Press Photographers Association dance late Friday night at the Hotel Commodore.

Westchester County Horticulture and Agricultural Association will conduct a gardening school at the County Center, White Plains, April 27 and 28, to which all amateur gardeners are invited.... Tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. at its headquarters, Rockefeller Plaza, Federated Garden Clubs will hold an executive board meeting. . ..
Four old houses at 540-48 Central Avenue, East Orange, N. J., are being demolished to make way for a new store building to expand the shopping facilities of that community.

IF the heirs of Edmond Rostand were less exacting with their musical rights, not a few composers would have materialized the temptation to set music to his plays. After Massenet and Walter Damrosch, Arthur Honegger is one of the many who have strongly felt their charm.

AN earthquake shocks and excited the people. It has punch. Few acts of nature are as dramatic and spectacular as a hurricane. In a flood something can be done, there is escape, and restoration. But when the dust rises and storms across the land, as it has begun to doagain in the Middle West, it numbs and paralyzes and obliterates.

Michigan citizens who read New York newspapers and nationally syndicated columns were surprised to learn that the eyes of the country were directed upon their State election of last Monday and that it would be interpreted as the verdict of the people of Michigan on the sit-down strikes,

The marriage of Miss Muriel Lillian Baunach, daughter of Mrs. Julia B. Baunach of Newark and the late Mr. Baunach, to Charles Banks Hamburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hamburg of Irvington, N. J., took place this afternoon at St. Stephen's Evangelical Church here. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Edward Fuhrmann. It was followed by a reception for the bridal party and families at Essex House.

LIVING AMERICAN ART, INC., has just completed, and very successfully, its scheduled 1936-87 portfolio of forty-eight reproductions in full color. The first installment of twelve prints appeared on the market last Autumn and was followed in due course by two more sets. The final installment has now been brought out,

James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York City and now a resident of Northport's colony on the Long Island Sound shorefront, will become a yacht owner this Summer. He has placed an order for a new 50-foot cruiser, which he will moor at the Northport Y. C.

More than 500 delegates representing 99 units of the Y. W. C. A. in Eastern States are arriving today and tomorrow in New York for participation in a conference to evaluate progress made on four fronts since the biennial of one year ago.

On the basis of student testimony gathered by The Engineer, yearbook of the Columbia University School of Engineering, in connection with its annual senior poll, the composite graduating engineer at Columbia is characterized as a 22year-old bon vivant, 5 feet 10 inches tall, whose favorite drink is Scotch and soda and whose favorite hobbies are photography and dates.

Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont today suggested to United States Senator James F. Byrnes "that Congress legislate more Vermont practices." In response to a request by the Senator for the information, the Governor telegraphed that Vermont's indebtedness March 14, 1933, was:

The entrance of the United States in the World War twenty years ago this week was recalled yesterday as more than twenty thousand soldiers, sailors, veterans and members of patriotic societies paraded in upper Fifth Avenue in the ninth annual observance of Army Day.

English eighteenth century furniture as well as French and American pieces, tapestries, arms and armor, Oriental rugs, and appointments for interiors, comprising property of Mrs. Leo F. Wormser of Chicago and the late A. Mitchell Palmer and Mrs. Palmer and other owners, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., Friday and Saturday afternoons.

The premiere of Frederic Hart's satiric opera, "The Romance of Robot," and Pergolesi's opera bouffe, "La Serva Padrona" to be presented in a twin bill tomorrow evening at the WPA Theatre of Music, will open the Federal Music Project's season of popular-priced opera.

George Caster and Bud Thomas hurled shutout ball today as the Athletics scored a 7-to-O victory over the Phillies to take the lead in a five-game series for the city championship. Cold weather held the crowd to a few hundred.
FIRST RACE--Purse $700; claiming; 4year-olds and upward; six furlongs. Little Son, 115.. (Dauron) 4.40 3.60 2.80 Jessie Cloud, 115. (Young) .... 4.00 3.40 Can Ele. 107...(Summers) ........ 4.20

Recrudescence of terrorism in Palestine in the past twenty-four hours has cost two lives. Haj Ibrahim Musa, a Damascus Arab on a business visit to Nazareth, while resting in the municipal garden there yesterday, was fatally shot by an Arab who escaped.

Coach Bert Daniels took the wraps off his seventh and highestpowered Manhattan College baseball team long enough for the Jaspers to rout Brooklyn College, 13 to 1, in their first start of the season at Manhattan Field yesterday, and then hastily bundled up his charges again as a heavy snow flurry necessitated the calling of the game at the start of the eighth inning.
First editions and other literary material from various consignors will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., Wednesday and Thursday evenings.
HAMILTON, Bermuda.-Following one of the greatest "in vasions" of American tourists ever recorded during an Easter season, Bermuda this week returns to normal.
James Braddock, world heavyweight boxing champion, today had a cinder removed from an infected eye and began treatments with a view to resuming training Monday for his fight with Joe Louis.
THE two years of the Soviet Governments "new spiritual policy"-a policy char acterized by a more liberal attitude toward old Russia's cul-

When Justice McReynolds recently reemphasized the fierce clash of thought between the liberals and conservatives of the Supreme Court bench he echoed a cleavage of opinion running through every phase of Washington life as a result of President Roosevelt's proposal to remodel the Supreme Court.
Governor Murphy advocated today the establishment of a unicameral Legislature in Michigan.

Despite Borough President George U. Harvey's recent warning that sit-down strikes would not be tolerated in Queens, 300 men and women continued to sit yesterday in the strike-bound plant of the DeNobili Cigar Company at 39-11 Ninth Street, Astoria. The strike began at the close of business on Friday.

Stockholders of Neisner Brothers, Inc., at a meeting in Rochester, N. Y., approved yesterday a recapitalization plan calling for immediate issuance of 25,000 shares of 4 3/4 per cent convertible preferred stock, out of 35,000 authorized, and for conversion of the 400,000 shares of no par common stock into $1 par shares.

Athena will be the patron goddess of the annual Greek Games at Barnard College, which will be held next Saturday in Barnard Hall. A Panathenaic festival was held every year by the people of Attica in honor of the goddess and every fourth year there was a greater Panathanaea, an extended and more magnificent performance.

Miss Louise Robinson Risley, daughter of Mrs. Samuel D. Risley of 126 Van Pelt Street and the late Dr. Risley, was married this afternoon to John Hyatt Wight, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Wight of Baltimore.
DURING the past ten or a dozen years several compilations have been made of transplated British folk minstrelsy as preserved and handed on orally in the Southern mountains of the United States.

The German propaganda authorities issued today to the foreign press a semi-official explanation from the government's point of view of yesterday's declarations by the German Liberty party. Government spokesmen assert the declaration was printed abroad, "probably by Communists."

BABES IN ARMS-Wednesday Nevening at the Shubert Theatre. The week's only arrival is a musical comedy by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, and while it probably doesn't matter, the story is about a group of children who put on a show of their own. Most of the players are under 21, some of the names being Mitzi Green, Ray Heatherton, Duke McHale, Grace and Ray McDonald, Rollo Pickert, Wynn Murray,
FUNDAMENTALS: "When I speak of labor legislation, I do not mean laws to outlaw this or that as much as to remove the underlying causes of unrest." -Governor Murphy of Michigan.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, will be the guest speaker at the testimonial luncheon tendered to James P. Warren, principal of Bryant High School, at the Hotel Pierre, Saturday, April 17. Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, will be the toastmaster. The luncheon marks Mr. Warren's tenth year as principal of Bryant High School.

Creation of national workers' schools to bring about a closer alignment between teachers and organized labor was proposed yesterday by Francis J. Gorman, international president of the United Textile Workers of America, in an address before 1,200 educators at

Props and Paint, the dramatic society of the College of New Rochelle, will present its freshman members in "The Witch's Doll," a three-act mystery play by Helen Monsell, in Chidwick Auditorium on campus, Thursday evening.

Franklin medals, awarded to physicists or technologists whose efforts "have done most to advance a knowledge of physical science or its applications," will be presented this year to Dr. Robert A. Millikan of the California Institute of Technology and Dr. Peter J. W. Debye, director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute of Physics in Berlin.

A survey of the choice shopping areas on Madison Avenue from Forty-second to Sixtieth Street and on Park Avenue from Fortysixth to Fifty-ninth Street reveals, states Loring M. Hewen, vice president of the realty firm of Wm. A. White Sons, an almost complete scarcity of stores available for rent.

Real stabilization of the world's currencies is possible only if creditor nations are willing to make great sacrifices to stabilize the international balance of payments, Professor Noell von der Nahmer of Breslau University told the Economic Science Society in Berlin today.
HERE is an outdoor book with a difference. It is a puppet book with a difference, too. For thepuppets which embody Walter Wilkinson's professional acticity have only a small place in these pages.

A WHITE-HAIRED lady who smokes cigars and describes herself as a "hardbitten old hellion" engages Perry Mason to undertake a delicate mission for her, with the result that Mason finds himself so deeply involved in a murder case that his secretary and the detective who handles his sleuthing despair of even getting him out of the mess he is in.

Mrs. Carter Hammett of Chestnut Hill has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julia Anne Hammett, to Charles Ellis Halcomb, son of Charles Halcomb of Malvern and Mrs. Ellis Halcomb of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of the National Association of Science Writers I ask the privilege of replying to Dr. Francis Carter Wood's letter on cancer research. At the outset it must be pointed out that the Science Writers had nothing to do with the editorial to which Dr. Wood refers.
Bill Sefton hung up a new world pole vault record of 14 feet 7 3/8 inches today as his Trojan team-mates of the University of Southern California overpowered the Bears of California, 79 to 52.
Edward A Knight of 64 West 104th Street, Manhattan, an official of the Miller Casket Company of Scranton, Pa., died last night at the Alexian Brothers Hospital here at the age of 72.

Kentuckians have stolen a march on the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association, which annually has been ushering in the speed boat racing season with its Albany-to New York marathon, and have scheduled an elaborate regatta on Sunday, May 2, two weeks earlier than the Hudson River test.
When in 1661 Samuel Pepys wrote in his diary of having seen a woman conducting an orchestra "keepng time to the musique while it plays," he added, "which is simple, methinks.'

A card party and dance under the auspices of the recently organized Catholic Seamen's Institute Auxiliary in the Brooklyn Diocese will be held the night of April 22 at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn. Bishop Thomas E. Molloy is honorary president of the organization and Mrs. John B. Oulton active president.

This season's selections of hardy asters make new colors available. It is now possible to possess a complete color range within a blooming season that extends from Spring to the time of devastating frosts.
Private lending institutions have made more than 1,500,000 individual loans for home financing and modernization under the FHA program, reports Administrator Stewart McDonald.

It was a field day at My Lady's Manor today for Mrs. Francis P. Garvan, Victor P. Noyes and Morgan Macy. By the triumph of her brown gelding Tertius in the twenty-ninth My Lady's Manor point to point, Mrs. Garvan obtained permanent possession of the challenge cup offered by the Hartford Hunt.

THIS book is a clear and detailed presentation of the Zionist movement by one of its strongest and most active advocates. And it is not only well written and interesting in its specific consideration of that subject, but informative in its connotations as well:

The following foreign service changes since March 13 were announced today by the State Department: George Orr of Atlantic City, second secretary of legation and consul at Helsinki, Finland, died at his post on April 3. Alan N. Steyne of New York City, who has been assigned to the Department of State, assigned to London, England, as consul.

Convenient to Manhattan residents. the colony of yacht clubs and shipyards along the Hudson between 140th and 155th Streets has developed its own unique method of hauling out boats for Winter storage. With the high, steep banks and with land made available by the city department, only in small plots, the turn-table system was devised.
With Navy trailing by only one run, Princeton hit Frank McKay freely in the ninth today to vanquish the Midshipmen, 7-2. McKay went the route for the losers.

Apparently set upon his first, second and third beatings, Coach Gordon Sikes concluded a week of intense vacation practice for his Princeton varsity crews on Lake Carnegie today with an informal, handicap regatta in which Hun School was invited to compete.

Mr. and Mrs. Max Rosenfield of 300 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcelle Rosenfield, to David J. Rosenheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Rosenheim of 225 Central Park West.
The development of a national policy toward sit-downs is slow to appear, despite prolonged public debate. Few signs of such a policy were apparent last week, and even those were contradictory.

Miss Anne Randolph Gray, daughter of Mrs. Philip Brewerton Ricketts of Madison, N. J., formerly of this city, and the late Thomas Tarvin Gray, will be married on June 26 to Oliver Hazard Perry Cabot of Boston, son of George D. Cabot of Meadville, Pa., and the late Mrs. Helen Perry Cabot.

Presenting a marked contrast with the red ink on the Federal ledgers elsewhere, the United States Patent Office during the past three years has shown a surplus of half a million dollars. As a money-maker it stands with the Philatelic Agency of the Postoffice Department.

Hambleton Slingluff of Ferndale, Md., member of a well-known old Maryland family, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was the son of the late Dr. Frank Slingluff and Mrs. Slingluff. Surviving are his widow,

Two amendments to the real estate license law are approved by the Real Estate Association of the State of New York. According to Herman A. Acker, president, the proposed bills will give greater protection to the public in its real estate dealings.
IN an hour and a half broadcast, Max D. Steuer, noted trial law yer, will go on WMCA, Wednesday night, at 9:30 o'clock, to discuss President Roosevelt's proposed changes in the Supreme Court.

E. S. Idol, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, recommended today the dismissal and denial of twelve applications for authority to act as common carriers by truck and two to act as brokers in interstate truck operations, made by members of the Visceglia family of New York and Jersey City.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn Warnock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Warnock of Westport, Conn., to William K. Zinke, son of Mrs. William K. Zinke of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Zinke, took place here last night in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Herbert H. Field.

LONDON. EVERY one who is acquainted with the pictures of Wagner knows the portrait by Renoir in the Bibliotheque de l'Opera in Paris: a benign old gentleman, with an almost baby face, as different from the famous portrait by Lenbach (reproduced in Grove) as is Landseer's Queen Victoria from her statue in front of Buckingham Palace.

The names of the five men President Roosevelt nominated to compose the Maritime Commission were unanimously recommended for confirmation today by a subcommittee of the Senate Commerce Committee, assigned to hold public hearings on their fitness. It was taken for granted that the full committee would accept the recommendation and that the Senate would confirm the appointments without further delay.

A general WPA strike in New York City was threatened today by a delegation which came here in an effort to see Harry L. Hopkins, administrator, unless demands for pay increases and a cessation of pay cuts for supervisory employes were met within two weeks.

Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Edgar Hall Thompson of South Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emmy Winslow Thompson, to Jones Lanier Jordan of Philadelphia and Wyndblough Farm, Delaware County, Pa.

COMMODITY prices having climbed, the new 1937-38 radio sets to be introduced in May and June will carry higher price tags, according to a survey by O. H. Caldwell of Radio Today. *The forecast is for prices to be 10 to 15 per cent above those of last season.
The National Council of Young Israel will present a concert and pageant at Madison Square Garden May 23, as a part of its twentyfifth anniversary celebration, it was announced yesterday.

To widen into a speedway the scenic Bronx River Parkway, as the State is said to plan after Westchester County transfers title to the State under proposals approved this week, would not be wise and would result in "tremendous destruction," Hermann W. Merkel, superintendent of the Westchester park system, said today.

Miss Evelyn Beryl Blenheim, daughter of Mrs. William J. Blenheim of East Orange and the late Mr. Blenheim, was married today to Edward Cady Marsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Capron Marsh, also of East Orange, in Grace Episcopal Church, Orange, by the Rev. Dr. Charles Thomas Walkley, rector of the church.

The popularity of so-called business trusts suffered a major setback in December, 1935, when the United States Supreme Court in each of four distinguishable proceedings held that the income therefrom was subject to the Federal income tax as the income of an associtation rather than as the income of a trust. Thus by operation of the Revenue Acts these trusts became taxable as corporations.

Seton Hall College, playing its first home game of the season, defeated Montclair Teachers today, 5-1. Berie Coyle held the visitors to two hits and connected for triple, the only extra base hit of the game.

The Architectural League of New York will open its annual exhibition on April 22 at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. It will close May 15 Edgar I Williams, chairman of the committee states that features of the exhibition will be sketches,
Temple University suffered its first baseball setback of the season today when the Penn A. C., rallied with five runs in the eighth inning and won, 9-4, before a chilled crowd at the Owls' Field.

About 1,900 firms in the United States issue seed, nursery, bulb, plant or other horticultural catalogues. Thus there are nearly four times as many in this country as in the rest of the world combined. New York State leads with 330 firms, more than the total in the British Empire.

About 2,000 chemists from the country's universities and industrial laboratories will participate in the ninety-third meeting of the American Chemical Society, which opens at the University of North Carolina Dean Fdank C. here Monday. Nearly 400 papers dent-elect.
Sixty thousand persons gathered here today cheered as Queen Wilhelmina severed a wire that launched the 36,000-ton liner Nieuw Amsterdam, the second of the name.

EVER since she won the Pulitzer Prize with "Now in November" the speical qualities of Miss Johnson's style and vision have been commented upon so exhaustively that there are few adjectives left. She is a writer of subtle and extreme sensibility--one whose response to the world is so nakedly fresh that in all of her prose one finds the starting imagery of poetry.

A colony of beavers, said to be the first seen in this part of Essex County in half a century, has been discovered in the meadows west of the Curtis Essex Airport in Caldwell. The colony, discovered by Game Warden J. R. Hugg of West Caldwell,

The election of 127 student officers to posts in twenty-seven undergraduate student clubs was announced yesterday by Dr. John Roscoe Turner, Dean of Men at the City College. The student officers, chosen during the club organization period at the beginning of the semester, will hold office through the Spring term.
Gerhardt Stoeck, Olympic javelin-throw champion, and Miss Annette Johanna Thorndike, descendant of a prominent Boston family, were married here today.

Reorganization meetings were held by Boards of Trustees this week in twenty-one Westchester villages which had annual elections on March 16. The elections brought politicalupsets in only two of the villages, Croton-on-Hudson and Irvingtonon-Hudson, and upheavals within ranks of public employes of those communities were begun when the new boards were organized.

Norman Skelly, 28-year-old rink proprietor of Pawtucket, R. I., was in town yesterday with reminiscences of a trip across the country by roller skate, and return as a hitch-hiker. At noon Ont. 2, 1936, Skelly said he and John Shefuga, 27, started gliding along Route 20 out of Boston. At noon on Dec. 4, he added,

Announcement has been made by Mrs. George A. Shepard of 15 Park Avenue, formerly of Scarsdale, N. Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Shepard, to Francis P. Alles Jr. of Buffalo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Alles of Philadelphia.

HOLLYWOOD. ELABORATE preparations are under way for the filming in the South Seas and in Holly wood of "Hurricane," which Samuel Goldwyn will produce. A troupe of eighteen has sailed for Samoa to record the episodes involving scenery and natives,

Cuban residents dedicated today in the city park a monument to Jose Marti, one of that country's greatest patriots. It was here that Marti and a group of exiled Cubans formed Cuba's revolutionary resolutions on April 10, 1892. Here too he obtained funds to finance filibustering expeditions to Cuban shores.

The winners of two fellowships awarded by the Somerville Societyof Swarthmore College were announced today. Miss Mina Waterman, '37, of Rochester, is the recipient of the Lucretia Mott Fellowship and Miss Mary Fairbanks, '34, the winner of the Martha E.

The defeat of the Dickstein resolution for investigation of Nazi and Communist propaganda in the United States is hailed by the Berlin press. The Boersen Zeitung remarks that this shows an overwhelming majority of Americans reject the attempts of a small minority to stir up trouble. The Voelksischer Beobachter jubilantly exclaims:
Mrs. Charles T. McClintock of Princeton has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Monroe McClintock, to George Prior Woollard, son of Mrs. Frank Woollard of Demarest, Ga.

WASHINGTON. THE last diplomatic obstacle to commencement of transatlantic service by airplane has been removed. Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, announced several days ago that an agreement had been reached with Canada over the perplexing question of whether Montreal or New York is to be the

About 200 high schools in the metropolitan area will enter competitions in architecture, interior and industrial design, water-color, drawing and modeling next Saturday at the annual high school day of the New York University School of Architecture and Allied Arts.

Through the customary hubbub at Albany, scheduled to explode this week into the final burst of oratory and action preparatory to adjournment of the Legislature, keen scrutiny has convinced large groups of women that they will emerge with only one major objective gained, and others of almost equal importance lost.

PARADOXICALLY, a modern setting is used by many decorators to bring out the best points of antique Colonial furniture. It is surprising how advantageously a simple pine and hickory settee with a chintz cushion can be made to fit into a sophisticated background. Modern paintings
The Smith College Dance Group will begin rehearsals this week for its annual Spring recital, to be presented the last week in May. In contrast to the modern atmosphere of the performance last Spring.

Commuting by air between New York and Washington almost three times weekly during 1936 won yesterday for Jesse Briegel, lawyer, of 120 Broadway, the presidency of Eastern Air Lines' 80-Minute Men Club.

Seventeen-year-old Bobby Dunkelberger of High Point, N. C., defeated the veteran James T. Hunter of North Adams, Mass., 5 and 3, today and became the youngest golfer ever to win the North and South tournament.

FAREWELL: The Gourmet Society of New York held a dinner last week. Walter Damrosch, composer and guest of honor, informed the diners: "I have two hatreds in food; one is spinach and the other is prunes." Learning that the society had recently held a farewell dinner to spinach he said: "I will write a funeral march to spinach."

The Nolde Horst Co., largest hosiery manufacturer in this district, asked the Berks County Court today to evict employes who have been on strike six weeks at its main factory here and at the branch mill in Womelsdorf. The two plants employ more than 2,500.

An apple blossom festival, the feature of which will be an "Apple Blossom Ballet" to be presented by Miss Teresa McCall, a former pupil of Rosina Galli, will be held on April 23 in the Astor Roof Garden under the auspices of the Cenacle Giuditta Guild for the benefit of the Catholic Action and Youth Movement.

Enterprises supported for sightless men and women by the Vacation Camp and Dormitory for the past fifteen years will be reviewed at the annual open meeting and tea on Friday at the Hotel Plaza, when an attendance of hundreds is anticipated.

Declaring that the talk of the socalled decentralization of industry is unfounded, W. Gerald Holmes, head of W. G. Holmes Co., engineers of Boston, said yesterday that the current widespread activity in industrial construction and the shifting of some operations away from main centers is merely an effort by manufacturers to fit their facilities to the needs of the consumer.

With gains in four of its components more than offset by three losses, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended April 3 receded to 105.9 from 106.6. It was 94.6 for the week ended April 4, 1936.

Moving eastward after a couple of years in the Midwest and Southwest, the national outboard championships will be held near Richmond, Va., this season, as the result of a decision last week by the American Power Boat Association and the National Outboard Association.

DAUER--GRAY-Mr. and Mrs. Ivor Gray announce the marriage of their daughter, Violet, to Mr. Sawley S. Dauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dauer, on Thursday, April 8. FAGENSON-KRAKOWER--Dr. and Mrs. Tobias B. Krakower announce the marriage of their daughter, Josephine Helene, to Bertram F. Fagenson. son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Fagenson, to take place Sunday, April 11, at Hotel Pierre.

President Roosevelt today received a delegation of English Masons here in connection with a celebration of the 200th anniversary of the establishment of the first Masonic lodge in this country at Charleston, S. C.

IT was the man with the red face aboard the Bay Ridge Ferry that bleak January morning who conveyed to Alan Villirs the starting information. "The schoolship's on the rocks and full of water and all the boys have been taken to the hospital frozen to death."

LONDON. ENGLAND is expecting many visitors from foreign countries, particularly the United States, for the coronation ceremonies in early May, but despite the fascination of old London there are many other places in the countryside which will attract travelers.

Belgium's economist Premier, Paul van Zeeland, has agreed to try to find a remedy for excessive trade barriers, and Prime Minister Baldwin told the Commons on Thursday that the Imperial Conference next month would discuss improvement of international trade so strongly urged by Secretary Hull.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that it had advised its members of its support of the proposal of Borough President Levy of Manhattan to construct an underpass in Second Avenue, to relieve Queensboro Bridge traffic congestion.
Jack Pearl, stage and radio comedian, underwent an operation for an intestinal complaint yesterday afternoon at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, Madison Avenue and 124th Street.

The marriage of Miss Helen P. Mullen, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Mullen of this city, to Edward J. Norris, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Norris of Holyoke, Mass., took place yesterday morning in Holy Trinity Catholic Church.

The record high cost of foodstuffs has moved the government to adopt severe penalties against speculation, hoarding and excessive exportation. President Arturo Alessandri publicly asserted it was unfair of the opposition to make a political issue of economnic conditions beyond the government's control.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Lazarus, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Frederick Lazarus of 555 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, to Donald Edward Swahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav E. Swahn, also of Brooklyn, took place last night in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Flatbush. The ceremony was performed by the rector, Rev. Harold Summerfield Olafson.

Concerned about the activity of nationalistic organizations combating reciprocal trade through buy-at-home movements, foreign traders had under consideration last week the formation of a World Reciprocal Trade Association, aimed at reaching average citizens of the country with facts concerning the importance of foreign trade.

The annual New York State intercollegiate men's singles and doubles championship tournament will usher in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's 1937 program, accoring to the card announced yesterday by the sanction and schedule committee.

The engagement of Miss Aldean Catherine Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Davis of Scarsdale, N. Y., to David Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Brown, also of Scarsdale, has been announced by her parents.

The possibility that Robert Irwin, sculptor, hunted as the murderer of Veronica Gedeon, her mother and a lodger in their home, had committed suicide in Utica, N. Y., was being investigated early today on the basis of a note picked up on a Utica street.

Material for a monumental bibliography of exploration is being assembled by a staff of thirty-five WPA workers assigned to a project which, guided by members of the Explorers Club, will cover the globe from prehistoric times up to the latest issue of current publications.
With $180,000 already raised for their proposed students' union. Colby College alumni are confident of obtaining the remainder of the needed $300,000 by commencement in June.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 10 unless specified: Amoy to Shanghai: Alden, Barker, J. D. Edwards, J. D. Ford, Paul Jones, Parrott, Peary, Pillsbury, Stewart, Whipple. San Pedro to San Diego, April 9: Bushnell, Tern. San Diego to Mare Island Yard, April 9: Cachalot, Cuttlefish. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Va., April 9.

Mrs. Robert P. Smith will give a tea Tuesday at her home in Colonial Road, White Plains, for Mrs. Valentine Everit Macy, president of the Westchester Music Festival Association. The guests will include the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs, the presidents of member clubs throughout Westchester and members of -the White Plains Committee for the annual Westchester Music Festival to be held next month. Mrs. Leslie B. Gillie heads the latter committee.

Whenever anything of importance happens in the world beyond our borders it is the job of the State Department to keep our government officially in touch with what is going on. Right now its most difficult task is to report what is taking place in Spain.

Japanese electors, with the polling twenty days away, received tonight two competitions in abstractness described as political platforms. The government's platform, which has been in the process of preparation by the Cabinet for three days, bears the marks of a fierce struggle toward concreteness, but still leaves much to the imagination.
ON the accession of Victoria, great-grandmother of King George VI, to the crown of England a century ago, New Yorkers "were all in a swivet," or flurry. In its issue of July 7, 1838,

The bridge team headed by Phil Abramsohn, which eliminated the strong Four Aces team in the semifinal round early yesterday morning, trailed by 3,340 points at the end of play last night in the Masters team-of-four championship at the Park Central Hotel. Sixty boards had been finished.
The debating team of the College of Mount St. Vincent will hold a debate with the team of Princeton University in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium on April 17.
PAGANISM: A native New Yorker, born more than seventy years ago in what is now Times Square, came back to his birthplace last week and found it "a pagan city." The Right Rev.
THE White Plains Better Housing Bureau, which is sponsoring the White Plains Better Housing Exposition to be held in the County Center May 10 to 15, is preparing to care for large crowds

The former John A. Morehouse estate of 229 acres on Merryall Road, South Kent, Conn., has been sold by Mrs. Julia M. Morehouse to Myer Lesser, of the Blaine-Thompson Advertising Agency, who will improve the old twelve-room Colonial homestead for his own occupancy.

BUENOS AIRES.-Pan-American Day this year (April 14) finds the American nations bound together in a real Pan-American spirit for the first time in their history. For more than forty years Pan-Americanism was little more than an idealistic aspiration and there were many times when it seemed impossible that that aspiration could ever be realized.

Two members of a family of four died of suffocation when they were trapped in their top-floor apartment at 710 East 148th Street, near Jackson Avenue, the Bronx, at 2 o'clock this morning by a fire of suspicious origin which spread through the three-story frame structure.

Two tuition scholarships for 19371938 in memory of Sir James Butler will be offered by Marymount College here, it was announced today. Girl students now in their senior year in high school who can meet the entrance requirements of the college are eligible for the awards.

ALWAYS searching for "a new art form" definitely characteristic of radio, the Columbia Broadcasting System believes it is approaching such a "significant milestone" in Archibald MacLeish's poetic drama, "The Fall of the City."
Charles Briggs of this city has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Elizabeth Briggs, to Arthur S. Laundon, son of Mortimer H. Laundon, also of Cleveland.

A warning that countries with high working standards should protect themselves from the competition of "backward" nations which refuse
The legislative committee of the Citizens Union announced yesterday its approval of the Brownell bill to extend the time for New York City to levy emergency taxes.

The Department of Justice announced today that "all facts indicating violation" of Federal law in the Remington-Rand strike at Middletown, Conn., in June, 1936, would be presented to a Federal grand jury convening in New Haven Monday.

BY far the most significant, the most deeply moving art it was my privilege to see lastweek is by Kaethe Kollwitz, some thirty of whose prints and drawings have been placed on view at Hudson Walker's, 38 East Fiftyseventh Street.

Renewing his attack on labor unions as "the worst things that ever struck this earth," Henry Ford declared today that the Ford Motor Company would soon "demonstrate wages, production and competition such as never seen before."

Former President Herbert Hoover returned today from a week's cruise in the Florida Keys with a new stock of fish stories and a healthy sunburn. Lounging in a deck chair on the yacht Virago, Mr. Hoover contentedly puffed at an enormous pipe as he related his fishing luck, which included seven elusive bonefish in one afternoon and a 185-pound tarpon.
The Southwestern Teachers College of Weatherford, Okla., tonight won the team title in the national A. A. U. wrestling championship tournament by half a point.

A. A. Grill, a State policeman, planned a fallen tombstone today for the death of John Collins. Grill said the 38-year-old truck driver apparently stumbled and knocked were the 500-pound monument while

The Swarthmore College Debate Board ended its forensic activities of the season last week when two Swarthmore speakers debated six colleges on the annual Spring vacation tour, which took them as far West as Chicago.
Starting Monday morning all regular classes, lectures, laboratory exercises and extracurricular activities at Russell Sage College will be omitted for an entire week.

While in complete agreement with the fundamental principles of the Mortgage Bank Bill before the Legislature which was passed by the State Senate last week and is now before the Assembly, it contains,

The 80-foot tugboat Radiant, with an oil barge in tow, listed suddenly and sank without warning in the Delaware River below this city shortly before last midnight, carrying with it all except two of the ten persons aboard.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Anne Mulligan of Westfield, daughter of John A. Mulligan of Brooklyn, to Walter Pierre Wells of Coudersport, Pa. Miss Mulligan, a graduate of L'Ecole Francaise de Westfield, is vice president of the Junior Woman's Club of Westfield.

A drive by the White Plains Hospital to raise $1,200,000 for construction of "a modern suburban medical center" received an auspicious start this week when C. B. Winslow, a former vice president of the F. W. Woolworth Company, contributed $315,000.

The government's intention to curb the rapid spread of the Nazi movement here was evidenced today by an Interior Ministry ban on mass meetings, uniforms, insignia, badges and other emblems revealing group activities.

This principality is having to cope with a strike for the first time in its history-and it is a sit-down strike. Disregarding the wishes of Prince Louis II, the sovereign, as well as the fact that strikes are strictly against the principality's laws,

Paul A. Brokaw, publicity agent for the Committee for Industrial Organization, was flown back to Detroit from here today because he lacked identification papers, thereby failing to comply with immigration regulations.

THE meeting of 7,000 safety delegates from all parts of the country at the annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council, to be held here from Tuesday through Thursday, will be something of a celebration of the city's recent citation for having come in 1936 "nearest to doing for traffic safety the maximum that practically could be done in that city."

A final decree has been entered closing the proceedings to reorganize the Cuba Railroad Company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, the company has notified the New York Stock Exchange. Allen Industries, Inc., common stock, $1 par value, will be admitted to the Exchange list tomorrow.
A housing project limited to dwellings of an exclusive and moderately expensive type is being started on the old Slater estate in the Colonial Heights section of Yonkers, Westchester County.
A new development of two-family houses between Forest and Seneca Avenues in the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn has been started by the Talmon Building Corporation,

A large part of the membership of the Junior Woman's Club of Orange and their husbands will participate in the club's musical presentation, "The April Frolics of 1937," on Friday and Saturday nights at the Woman's Club of Orange.

The New York Fire Department's orthographic experts earned a-lastsecond tie with Chicago's best yesterday in a radio spelling bee which earned $10 for each of ten smokeeaters and $5 extra for one of them.
The rural South contributes more than its share of the nation's babies, a government economist said today.

An appeal has been made by Walter R. MacCornack, chairman of the Housing Committee of the American Institute of Architects, to the sixty-eight chapters of the institute throughout the country urging their cooperation with the Federal Housing Administration
Share prices moved narrowly yesterday and closed steady and mixed in the slowest trading since Aug. 22. The half day's turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to but 480,000 shares.
AMERICANS are subject to a recurrent, vernal urge to "go abroad," and the call of the Old World seemingly becomes more compelling and alluring.

A "browsing room" containing 1,000 of the world's most important books will be housed in the new library planned for Good Counsel College, it was announced today. Another innovation will be an outdoor reading room on a large porch surrounding the building.

With the defeat in the Republican Assembly on Wednesday of Governor Lehman's bill to increase the State tax on gasoline from 3 to 4 cents a gallon the armed truce which had created a semblance of peace on Capitol Hill since the Legislature has been at work has come to an end.

Intimations that the Pure Oil Company may resume dividends on its common stock were made here today by L. S. Westcoat, vice president and secretary, who was chairman of the annual meeting of stockholders. No dividends have been paid since 1930.

Miss Margaret Parker Mather, daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. John Mather, was married tonight to Walter Lucas Clark, son of Mrs. Walter Lucas Clark and the late Colonel Clark. The ceremony was performed in St. Alban's Church the Rev. Charles T. Warner.

THE relationship between Canada and the United States is exceptional; in fact, there is nothing quite like it anywhere else in the world. In the first place, Canada does not love the United States On the contrary, she fears her neighbor because she is determined to develop her own political entity. This feeling, latent but very real, is shared by all Canadians. It is apparent among

Depositors and creditors of the old Baltimore Trust Company are assured, it was said today, of the disbursement of a new dividend of $1,000,000 to $2,000,000 by decisions of the State Court of Appeals affirming a lower court's decision in favor of receivership.

When the John Dewey Soviet committee in Mexico puts Religious LEON TROTSKY on the Revival grill there is one question it must not overlook. TROTSKY will no doubt be asked to say whether he really plotted with HITLER and with Japan against the Soviet Union.

Announcement was made here yesterday of a gift from Rockwell Kent, the artist, to the Library of Congress of a design for a bookplate to be used as the official symbol of the library's rare book collection. It is believed to be the first time that a special bookplate has been designed for the library.

Haddon Harris MacLean, eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Haddon MacLean of Chicago and Miss Isabel Alvarez Bravo, of a notable Mexican family, will be married here Thursday. Mr. Mac Lean is vice president of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago.

As might be expected, the. first entry posted for the Albany-to-New York outboard marathon on May 16 was -that of Fred Jacoby Jr. of North Bergen, N. J., national high point champion for the past two years.

Four Spanish Government military planes were confiscated by the French Government today after landing in Southern France. The fliers, who said they were en route to Bilbao, in Northern Spain, from Valencia, were held for questioning.

Because the danger of street car and highway accidents to children are many, special courses dealing with safety problems will be introduced into the school system this Fall, according to Charles J. Kraft Jr., assistant director of Health Education.
Senator Walsh, co-author of the Walsh-Healey act, proposed today "blacklisting" of industrial concerns which fail to comply with the National Labor Relations Act.

Several hundred younger members of society attended the first supper dance of The Bachelors last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis. The committee for this new subscription series of dances is composed of several young men who have patterned the entertainments after those given in this city several decades ago by The Patriarchs.

Henry Searing of this place, retired textile commission merchant, former head of the firm bearing his name at 72 Leonard Street, New York, died yesterday of pneumonia in Wilmington, Del. He was born in Brooklyn seventytwo years ago.
Wounded in a pistol battle with four hold-up men, Detective Michael J. Foley of the East Fifth Street station died in Post-Graduate Hospital last night.

Beginning with the opening of the next school year in September, a program in religious education will be included in the curriculum of the Henry W. Saxe Junior High School, which includes the seventh, eighth and ninth grades.

Charles A. Johnson, one of Pennsylvania's best known Republican leaders, who headed the party in Montgomery County for thirty years and served in two Cabinet positions under former Governor John S. Fisher, died of a heart attack this evening in the Montgomery Hospital here. He was 83 years old.

A new course opened last week in the Radio Workshop, now emerged from its experimental period and established in permanent quarters at New York University. Professional technique has arrived in educational broadcasting.

AMERICAN broadcasters must discard the old-fashioned non directional aerials and "megaphone" their waves to Europe by the use of modern directional aerials if they wish to be heard, according to Consul George P. Waller in a report to the Department of Commerce from his post in the Grand Duchy of Luxemburg.

This town claims the oldest active fiddler in the State. He is Edward Wakefield who recently celebrated his ??5th birthday. In his day, he was one of the most popular fiddlers of the section, and has scraped his bow at thousands of house and barn raising, as well as husking bees and other assemblies.

TELEVISION over New York, which for almost a year has been a one-man "race" under the colors of the National Broadcasting Company, found a new entry in the contest during the past week when the Columbia Broadcasting System pranced out upon the wave-lengthed race track.

The inflow of gold, the maintenance of the fixed price of $35 an ounce and the general domestic price level combine to face the President with one of the most acute problems he has ever been obliged to meet. There is no doubt of this, and the absence of the doubt is what has permeated Wall Street with a set of rumors of action.

City College could make only spasmodic headway against the tenacious defense of Rutgers's veteran lacrosse team, and as the Scarlet attack functioned smoothly, the Beavers lost, 17-5, yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium.

Concrete houses erected by the Billner vacuum process, which permits the erection of all standing elements of a one-story dwelling in a single day, and the installation of floors and permanent waterproof concrete roofing within three days,

Mrs. Payne Whitney, who for years has been a stanch supporter of steeplechasing, is once more preparing for an active season with Sailor Beware, a successful racer on the flat, as the headliner among her jumpers.

Miss Elizabeth Butler, daughter of Gilbert Butler of this city and the late Mrs. Grace Spratt Butler, was married this morning in St. John's Church here to Captain Everard Radcliffe, eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. Everard Radcliffe of St. Trinian's Hall, Yorkshire, England.

Striking changes in the contours of the Potomac Park Tidal Basin are among the chief artistic and landscaping effects promised Washington through the projected Thomas Jefferson Memorial, on which construction is scheduled to begin as soon as plans have been accepted by the Federal Government's art agencies.

THE English biscuit-making town of Reading, near Oxford, has figured tenuously in various literary affairs. It was the Albrickham of Hardy's "Judge the Obscure," where Sue and Jude lived for a few months, and it was the scene of a literary crime as well:

John Derenga, 17 years old, a high school student, hanged himself yesterday afternoon in his home at 2,755 Mickle Avenue, the Bronx. He was discovered by his mother, Mrs. Catherine Derenga, after she had returned from shopping.

Miss Suzanne B. Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Smith of Waterford, near here, was married at noon today to Ensign Richard C. Latham, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard W. Latham of Crestwood, N. Y., in St. James Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Frank S. Morehouse.

Four yachts, including a 60-footer for Commodore Eugene A. Canalizo, are to be launched by members of the South Shore Y. C. during the coming month at Randall's Bay in Freeport. Next week William F. Latus and Harry -L. Sarles, coowners of a 33-foot cruiser, which they have named Sprindrift, will launch her at George Christensen's yard.

Misericordia Hospital, founded by six Roman Catholic Sisters of Miser??corde with a capital of $1, will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary this year. Established in a tumble-down old residence on Staten Island, the hospital, which specializes in the care of unmarried mothers and their infants, has grown into the modern and well equipped institution which now provides many types of hospital care at 531 East Eighty-sixth Street in the German-American Yorkville district.

Fairfield County Public Forums, which is sponsored by the United States Office of Education and which serves Norwalk, South Norwalk, New Canaan. Darien, Stamford and Greenwich, had a change in directors this week.

ALTHOUGH this column has acquired through the years a Substantial distaste for the atrical memoirs, an exception must now be made in the case of Noel Coward's "Present Indicative," which Doubleday Doran have recently published.

Driven into 9-10 favoritism, the Bowie Handicap winner, Calumet Dick, added the Southern Maryland Handicap to his string with a decisive victory before 15,000 persons today. It was the final program of the meeting, and a record betting figure for the session was set, as an estimated total just short of $500,000 was wagered on the seven races.

AND now it seems that Thornton Wilder really meant it when he said, almost two years ago, that he would abandon the writing of novels and devote himself to plays. "All my life," he told a reporter then, "I have written plays and torn them up."

SPURRED by the interest shown in the trailer exhibit at the re cent New York Automobile Show, dealers in Southern New York and Connecticut have combined forces at the Westchester County Center, White Plains, in the Trailer Show, the first event of its kind to be held in this part of. the country.

A GREAT deal of American history is disclosed in American stamps. And a great deal of the part that women played in the development of this country from pioneer days to the present is also told on adhesives. In fact, more than 100 stamps--including newspaper and periodical stamps, special delivery adhesives and postoffice seals--are devoted to the telling.
Mrs. Elizabeth Sturges Field, wife of Henry Field, assistant curator of the Field Museum, filed suit for divorce in Superior Court today, charging desertion. Mrs. Field.

With the weather clear in contrast to yesterday's downpour, but with conditions still not at their best, the second session of the fourth annual Spring field trial menet of the Long Island Beagle Club was held today.
Newell Lorenzo Mead died today at the home of his father-in-law, Oliver D. Mead of Field Point Park, Belle Haven, Greenwich, following a long illness. He was 62 years of age.

The efficacy of the foster-mother plan of caring for children of working parents was stressed yesterday as a satisfactory means of augmenting the work of the regular day nursery by Mrs. Berthold Strauss, president of the Montgomery County Trustees of the Mothers Assistance Fund, Old Age and Blind Assistance, and vice chairman of the Pennsylvania Emergency Child Health Service.

Dr. Henry T. Moore, president of Skidmore College; Mrs. Moore and George Foster Peabody will be guests of honor at the annual dance of clubs of the college in the metropolitan district next Saturday night at Sherry's for the benefit of the college scholarship fund.
Canada's international trade in securities bounded upward in the two months ended on Feb. 28 from the corresponding period in 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics has reported.

Speaking last night before 6,000 of his Socialist constituents, Premier Leon Blum faced 90 per cent applause and 10 per cent boos, the latter including shouts of "Resign!" He gave members of his party an outline of the political situation with relation to the party.
The Westchester County Girl Scouts will be the beneficiary of the cinema "The Jungles of Borneo" to be presented by Mrs. Martin Johnson Friday night at the County Center here.

Developing and investing syndicates played an important part in contributing to the realty activity of Queens County and adjacent I Long Island areas last week. Several hundred acres passed into the hands of large building interests and in practically every case plans are under way for immediate improvement of the properties with medium priced homes.

Six parcels totaling 152 acres, in Queens and Nassau Counties, L. I., will be sold at auction on Saturday by J. Edward Breuer. The Lewis Land Company is the owner. Practically all have been cleared and planted with evergreens, trees and shrubs.

After a week's virtual silence, during which he has concentrated twelve hours a day on his monumental book about Lenin and on other literary undertakings, Leon Trotsky again steps out upon the Mexican and world stage.
Dr. Osvaldo Aranha, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, made reservations today for a flight to the United States on Monday's Clipper. He will be accompanied by Mrs. Aranha.

William J. Kelly, known as "the human adding machine" during his thirty-eight years in the State Department of Banking and Insurance, died here Wednesday at the age of 68 and was buried today in St. Mary's Cemetery. At his death he was cashier in the department.

Mortgages accepted for insurance by the FHA during the first quarter of this year totaled $102,997,500, an increase of 64 per cent over the corresponding period of 1936. About 59 per cent of these mortgages were for newly constructed homes.

IT has taken nearly a year and has cost $1,000,000 to turn the Central Park Casino into a playground. This little enclosure near the center of the park, with its wading pool and its shining apparatus, soon to be opened to the public, will be one more link in the long, bright chain of play grounds and recreation areas that Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, is flinging through the five boroughs.

Four prospective brides of this place will be entertained within the next few days at several parties. Miss Ann Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Crane, who will be married on Sunday, April 18, in Christ Church to Carl Johan Michaelsen, was honored today at a tea given by Miss Virginia Reed of Bronxville.

Mrs. Myron I. Borg will give a tea April 20 at her home, 270 Park Avenue, for the chairmen of the Social Service Auxiliaries of the various hospitals in Greater New York and Westchester County cooperating with Irvington House. A discussion of mutual problems with the group, has been planned by .Mrs. Borg, who heads the Irvington. House Hospital Social Service.

Duke University's Southern Conference champions displayed surprising strength today to tie Princeton's fine track team, 63-all. Princeton, which placed second in the I. C. A. A. A. A. meet and scored an 82-44 victory over the University of North Carolina earlier in the week, was the victim of a couple of upsets.

The fourth annual Junior Bal Masque was given tonight in the BellevueStratford Rose Garden by members of the sub-debutante set. All guests were requested to wear costumes, and judges who awarded prizes were Miss Maida Dale Williams, Mrs. John Shipley Dixon Jr. and Mrs. McMullan Richards.

Under auspices of the Bryn Mawr Club, the first women's intercollege club bridge tournament will be held on Wednesday evening at the Women's University Club, when a permanent trophy will be offered. Among organizations which have accepted an invitation to enter a

The Aluminum Company of America today announced a wage increase of 5 cents an hour for 7,000 workers at its three Pittsburgh district plants. The increase, the third in five months, will become effective Friday at the New Kensington.

Elimination of employee contributions to old-age insurance reserves, direct taxation to finance the plan, uniform State laws and consolidation of all phases of relief into one program were urged yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
A splendid field in two events helped the Hauppauge Gunning Club to get off to a nice start today in the staging of its tenth annual field trials on liberated quail.
Nearly 800 young children and adults watched the two puppet shows put on yesterday by Walter Wilkinson. the English puppeteer, at Wanamaker's department store.

Civilization long since unbound the feet of Chinese girls, but tradition kept them furtive little figures on the streets of Chinatown until six years ago. Then Mrs. Theodora Chan Wang waved the charter of the Chinese Women's Association, and a social revolution materialized in the tight little community around Chatham Square.

Canadian sections adjacent to New York State will send representatives to Utica for the fifteenth annual convention of the National Council of Jewish Women opening there today, and which is expected to attract a delegate group of several hundred.

Theatre performances are among the most popular ways of raising funds for charitable organizations that depend largely upon voluntary contributions for their support. Several such benefits have been arranged for this month, performances of well known plays being taken over by the officers of the institutions.

BOSTON. YACHT-BUILDING yards are busier than at any time since the World War. Even the boom years preceding 1929 did not produce so much activity here, because more building was done in yards at New York and southward. Now the craft is returning to the region where it had its beginnings.

Three of six University of Michigan students injured in an automobile accident near Grantville were reported in "unsatisfactory" condition today at a Harrisburg hospital. The three are Julian Malinsky of Brooklyn, N. Y., fractures of the skull and nose and bruises of the scalp; Morton Nathanson of Brooklyn, fractured skull and jaw, and Irving Klein of Ozone Park, L. I., fractured jaw and thumb and cuts on the face and leg.

Preliminary choices of major fields by this year's freshmen at Harvard, announced today, disclosed a continuance of the trend toward the social sciences which President Conant has termed a dangerous tilt in the intellectual balance of the college.

Pensioned ON HIS OWN APPLICATION. To take effect 12 midnight, April 10: PATROLMAN-Alfred G. Rummage, 120th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 6, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., April 12: PATROLMEN-Harry Rosenstock, from Motorcycle Precinct 1 to 8th Precinct, assignment to motorcycle duty discontinued.
Marked by heavy advance purchasing and a buyer registration in excess of the 2,000 mark, the American Toy Fair last week achieved new records for the initial week of the event.

Russell Page, director of the Easy-to-Own Homes Organization, which has been disposing of a large number of properties held by a large insurance concern in Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau and Westchester Counties,

AFTER three years without the ort of surcease that a Hollywood writer calls a real vacation, Robert Riskin is off to Europe with the prospect of months of long Spring days with never a qualm about one of those loosely bound paper-covered things that Hollywood is pleased to call, in its uncertain fashion, "final incomplete" scripts.

Problems confronting the air-conditioning industry and owners of office buildings were discussed by Walter L. Fleisher, consulting engineer, in a talk before the operating forum of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York at the Town Hall Club last week.

Dr. L. B. Capehart, Harlem Negro physician, is a candidate for Tammany leader of the Nineteenth Assembly District, and will make a primary contest against Harry C. Perry, the present leader, he said yesterday.

The six-story apartment house at 134 Haven Avenue, northwest corner of 172d Street, has been purchased from the New York Por Authority by a syndicate operating under the name of the 134 Haven Avenue Corporation. Purchase was for cash above a mortgage of $190,000.

The wave of "wildcat" sit-down strikes, unauthorized by the United Automobile Workers of America, which has swept through General Motors plants since the union signed its agreement with the company, has raised the question whether the new, young unions which the Committee for Industrial Organization is organizing in the mass-production industries can control their members and make them live up to their contracts.

Members of the Graham Alumnae Association, of which Mrs. Lewis Mercer Borden is president, have arranged their annual meeting and luncheon for Wednesday at the Pierre. After luncheon Miss Mabel Rowland will present groups of monologues.

SEA ISLAND, Ga.-Drum, which range from 40 to 85 pounds in weight; cobia, known for their fighting spirit; sheepshead and other smaller fish will be sought by fishermen forming the party for a deep-sea fishing trip which will leave the Sea Island Yacht Club on Wednesday.

Important visits by Austrian statesmen to Berlin are in prospect for the immediate future. Yesterday's Prager Tagblatt announced that Dr. Edmund Glaise-Horstenau, Minister of the Interior, was going to Berlin on the invitation of Marshal Werner von Blomberg, the German War Minister, to take part in a celebration connected with the official German archives department.
Talk of a possible split in the Democratic party through the pressure of political and social groups was dismissed as "idle chatter" last night by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.

Misfortune came in double dose to the world champion Yankees today. The observance of Bill Dickey Day in the home town of the Yankee backstop was spoiled when a home run over the right-field wall by Leo Nonnenkamp gave the Little Rock Travelers of the Southern Association a ninth-inning victory

These are days when neutral observers in Madrid have to lean over backward in order not to be swept forward on the wind of optimism that is blowing like a gale across Loyalist Spain. With the siege of the capital entering its sixth month and the civil war approaching the end of its ninth month, there is not a Spandard here unconvinced that the tide has turned in the government's favor.

The Summer home of the Rabbi Joseph Jacob School at Deal, N. J., will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance to be held tonight in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. Mrs. Harry W. Golding is chairman for the event, which will be featured by a program of entertainment by stars of the stage and screen.

Wellesley College alumnae throughout the country have inaugurated a drive for a fund of $200,000 needed to erect an indoor swimming pool on the college campus and in the interests of this project a Spring dance will be given under the auspices of a special alumnae committee the night of April 30 in the Astor Gallery of the WaldorfAstoria.

AT last our detective writers have themselves been detected. The News-Chronicle has discovered a mysterious Detection Club--to be distinguished from the Crime Club, a book society for the circulation of thrillers--of which Chesterton was president.

Syracuse University undergraduates and alumni paid annual tribute tonight at the Block S. dinner to the Orange athletes. More than 1,200 attended the affair in Archbold Gymnasium, at which 259 letter awards were made by Acting Chancellor William P. Graham.
Miss Fannie Edytha Thomson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Thomson of Upper Montclair, was married this afternoon to Douglas Donald Masten of Clifton.
