WITH the strong possibility that one or more car makers will adopt a fully automatic transmission as standard or optional equipment in 1938, special interest attaches to recent reports before the Society of Automotive Engineers by Austin M. Wolf, consulting engineer, on the, operation of 100 rear-engine automatic transmission buses in regular service in Chicago the past few months.

Representatives of 100 universities, colleges, junior colleges and normal schools have been invited to attend the annual conference on April 24 at Adelphi College here of the American College Publicity Association, District 2. The persons attending will represent educational institutions in New York State, New Jersey and Canada.

As Prince Nicholas ceased to be a member of the royal family last midnight, his aides de camp and military guard of honor were withdrawn this morning by a special order issued by General Paul Angelescu, Minister of War, his personal antagonist.

The second concert of the eighth Washington Festival of Chamber Music presented a program of recent compositions of Paul Hindemith, all of them, with the exception of his unaccompanied viola sonata, heard for the first time in America. Mr. Hindemith himself "in person," was a solo performer.

THE chorus of the University of Helsinki, Finland, composed of fifty male singers, under the direction of Martti Turunen, will make its New York debut early next January in a program of music by Finnish composers.

Three men were drowned in three and a half feet of water here early this morning when the coupe in which they were riding plunged over a steep embankment into the Bound Brook and landed on its top, crushing it in a manner to prevent the occupants from escaping.
After escaping injury in a motor crash Miss Kay Stammers, ranking Brith ish tennis ace, was beaten by Miss Mary Hardwick in the final of the Surrey women's championship today. 8-6. 7-5.

A program for better wages and working conditions was adopted by members of the Eastern Brokers Division of the Commercial Telegraphers Union at a special meeting in the Pulitzer Building on Park Row yesterday afternoon.
Life sentences for adults who corrupt the morals of children were recommended here today by George W. Smyth, Children's Court judge of Westchester County.
In rehearsal since the beginning of the present semester, the Gilbert and Sullivan operatta "The Mikado" will be given by Bryn Mawr College students on April 23 and 24 in Goodhart Hall on the campus.
Frank A. Duggan, borough police recorder for the last two years, and long active in affairs of the American Legion, died at his home here today after an illness of two weeks at the age of 42.

Minnesota is in a great state of excitement over the march on the Legislature last Monday of a so-called people's lobby. The demonstration was organized by Governor Elmer A. Benson to furnish moral support for his legislative program, but, observers declare, he overplayed his hand.

Consolidated net income of Poor Co. and subsidiaries in 1936 amounted to $418,497 after depreciation, interest, premium on 6 per cent notes refunded, expense in connection with liquidating subsidiaries, normal Federal income taxes and after deducting $58,280 for surtax on undistributed earnings.

WHILE the Boy Scouts of America are preparing for their first National Jamboree at Washington, D.C., from June 30 to July 9, their brother Scouts of the Netherlands are making ready to play host at the fifth World Jamboree, from July 29 to Aug. 13.

Nine government agencies let 128 contracts for a total of $6,332,560 under the Walsh-Healey act during the week ended April 8, the Labor Department announced today. Of this total, New York contractors obtained $2,289,495.75; New Jersey,

Where former Prince Nicholas will live in the future is still uncertain. According to the newspaper Curentul, Vice Premier Ion Inculetz visited the former Prince yesterday, handing him King Carol's decree expelling him from the royal family and from his army and air force posts.

A group of Midwestern keglers rolled into leading positions at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday as the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress recorded one of the most interesting sessions since it started more than a month ago.
The Museum of the City of New York was visited last year by 148,920 persons, received 209,572 gifts, bequests and loans, and through its educational department served 339,748. Extending its work,
Leaders of the Hershey Chocolate strike bent their efforts today toward assembling a heavy picket line to demonstrate their strength when negotiations for a settlement are resumed tomorrow.

The Agence Espagne (official Spanish Government news agency) says in a dispatch from Bilbao that President Juan Antonio Aguirre of the autonomous Basque Republic has protested to Pope Pius against "assassination of a great number of Priests" by Insurgents.

Apparently the Warners meant it when they invited the runaway Bette Davis to "come home; all is forgiven." In "Marked Woman," which celebrates the prodigal's return, they have offered up-fortunately not for sacrifice-a dramatically concise script, a shrewd director and an extremely capable supporting cast.

Three were shot in an electoral affray in the center of the city as primaries were held here to select the candidates of President Lazaro Cardenas's National Revolutionary party for the June Congressional elections. Ten thousand women voted in this city for the first time in Mexican history.

Faced with eviction from their apartments at 252 Rivington Street on the lower East Side so that owners can make repairs, fourteen families and fellow-members of the East Side Tenants Union held an outdoor protest meeting yesterday at Rivington and Sheriff Streets.

New York's chances of becoming the home of the world hockey champions flamed brightly tonight. That amazing sextet from Manhattan, the Rangers, upset the dope once more and scored a 1-to-O victory over the Detroit Red Wings in the third game of the Stanley Cup round at the Olympia.

The annual gala of the Manhattan Figure Skating Club took place at the Ice Club last night with almost every member of the club performing in the group numbers and specialty skating which kept a large crowd of visitors and friends entertained for over an hour and a half.

What gave every indication of being one of next season's outstanding events-the revue by George S. Kaufman, Moss Hart and the Gershwin brothers and slated to open at the Music Box-has been erased from next season's schedule. Apparently the Gershwins could not be released from their film commitments to write the songs.

The Chinese Government will announce today through its Ambassador in Washington an offer for resumption of service on the Republic of China two-year 6 per cent treasury notes of 1919, following nearly a year's negotiations between the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., and that government. About $5,500,000 of notes is outstanding.
The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin predicted today an "inflation of prices" by next April and another depression as a result of President Roosevelt's spending policies.

Although twenty of the best detectives of the New York Police Department were still hunting for Robert Irwin, the police confessed yesterday that temporarily, at least, they were completely baffled in their efforts to capture the 29year-old sculptor and former theological student.

Republican leaders of the Assembly are expected to take steps this week for a conference with Governor Lehman in an effort to break the deadlock on balancing the budget, which developed when the Assembly defeated the Governor's bill to increase the tax on gasoline from 3 to 4 cents a gallon.

Jacob Janos, builder, purchased from the Esdo Building Corporation, Samuel Minskoff, president, nine lots at the northeast corner of Bronxdale and Cruger Avenues, the Bronx, for improvement with two six-story elevator apartment houses containing 297 rooms.
Veronica Secker, 20 years old, of 60-34 Linden Street, Ridgewood, Queens, died in a doctor's office yesterday after receiving a local anesthetic administered for a tonsilectomy.
The uncertainty over the United States dollar and the upsetting of the gold market contributed to cause the franc to fall this week in foreign exchange.

Mrs. Duer McLanahan and Mrs. Ellery S. Husted will give a luncheon Wednesday at Le Coq Rouge for Mrs. Edward W. Saunders and her aides serving in behalf of the performance of "Miss Quis" the night of April 29 at the Henry Miller Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Society for the Relief of Half Orphan and Destitute Children.

Frank E. Agar has joined Reynolds Co. Allyn C. Donaldson is with Eastman, Dillon Co. in their Rockefeller Center office. The Chase National Bank, as trustee, has invited tenders for the sale to it of City Stores Company ten-year 6 per cent general collateral convertible notes due on Oct.

Horace S. Wilkinson, financier, industrialist and GreatLakes shipping operator, died in his suite in the Blackstone Hotel this morning at the age of 68. He had been ill since last Tuesday, when he suffered an acute heart attack while on his way with Mrs. Wilkinson from the West Coast to their home in Greenwich, Conn.

An increase of $263,095,494 in the resources of State-chartered banking institutions in Pennsylvania in 1936 was shown in a report made public tonight by Governor Earle. Total resources on Dec. 31 were $3,090,475,000, including loans of $739,628,778. The increase in loans was $6.813.085.
Taking six races out of seven, Frank Campbell had the next thing to a clean sweep with his Class B one-design boat Felix in the Larchmont Yacht Club's dinghy racing today.

A group headed by Hallgarten Co. and including Paine, Webber Co., Stern Brothers Co. and Granbery, Safford Co. will offer today an issue of $4.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock of $100par value of the Katz Drug Company.

Vitriolically attacking the present Cuban military dictatorship, the executive committee of the Republican party, headed by former President Miguel Mariano Gomez, issued a manifesto to the public last night declaring the present administration a complete failure.
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Pan American Day," Conrado Traverso, Consul General of Argentina, and Blair Niles.

Men of the Gloucester fishing fleet learned early this afternoon of a large mackerel school moving slowly northward far offshore and within an hour on sixty power sloops, mooring lines were cast aside for the annual race to a phosphorescent fortune.
The authorities bowed tonight, though only a bit, to irate collectors after the police had confiscated the latest issue of German stamps bearing Chancellor Adolf Hitler's image.

Plans for a county-wide Holy Name Society rally to be held May 16 were discussed at the parish house of the Corpus Christi Church here today by delegates of the society of the thirty-five Roman Catholic churches in Nassau County.

Charles Joseph C. Davol, president and treasurer of the Davol Rubber Company in Providence, R. I., died in Post-Graduate Hospital here yesterday after an illness of three weeks. He had been stricken in Miami, being removed to New York a week ago.

The Rev. Matthias A. Sheridan, pastor of St. Michael's Catholic Church here for twenty years, died today. His age was 75. He was appointed to the pastorate here Feb. 2, 1917, succeeding the late Rev. Patrick Dempsey.

A negotiating committee empowered to call a general strike of 20,000 truck drivers in this city was appointed today at a nieeting of the Teamsters' Joint Council 53, representing unions interested in the strike of laundry wagon drivers.

The general endowment fund of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University has been increased $2,000,000 to a total of more than $8,000,000, it became known today with the publication of an institute bulletin listing staff appointments and student enrollments in the various schools.

The powerful new warship Neptuno, whose keel was laid by the government, made her debut with the Insurgent fleet today by shelling Santander and the road to Bilbao, reports to this Insurgent naval base said.

Frank Hunter Simmons, president of the John Simmons Company, 110 Center Street, dealers in steel and iron pipe and fittings, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 116 East Fifty-eighth Street, at the age of 62. He was also treasurer of the Powhatan Brass and Iron Works, vice president of the Simmons Realty and Construction Company, secretary and treasurer of the Vulcan Rail and Construction Company.

Mrs. Sarah Phoebe Taber Willets, a pioneer settler of this community, died today at her home, Old Brick, in the incorporated village of East Hills. Her age was 89. She was the widow of William Willets.

Purchases of grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade last week were larger than in the previous week and were greatly in excess of those a year ago, except rye, which was slightly reduced for the week.

The nation's automobile makers, heading for peak production again, are ready to throw their giant industry into high gear next week. With recent strikes now settled, assembly lines will be speeded up as some 90,000 employes-idle dur-l ing the Chrysler, Hudson and Reo strikes-resume full-time work schedules.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Gilbert E. Jones of this city and Morristown, N. J., of the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Leila Ingersoll Jones, to Niels Kampmann, only son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Peter Georg Kampmann of Aarhus. Denmark.

The Countess of Suffolk, who has been spending the Winter in Tucson, Ariz., will return in two weeks to New York and. will be at the Pierre before sailing for England. Mrs. Richard T. Wilson will give a dinner in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador on Friday.

With Frank Weynand, sophomore southpaw star, allowing only one hit, the St. John's University baseball team shut out the Brooklyn College nine, 9 to 0, in a seven-inning game at Dexter Park yesterday. It was the fourth straight victory for the Redmen, who have yet to taste defeat this season.

In London a. few weeks ago the writer met a delegate to the Spanish Non-Intervention Committee, who was also a political philosopher. In a world that moves like a rotary press, too fast for a man in public life to stop and read, too fast for anything but a smear of passing impressions,

The report of the German Conversion Office for March shows for the first time the dollar funding bonds among liabilities of the Reich, but the amount is only 18,000,000 marks, although the issue amounted to $69,000,000.

Julius H. Susmann, treasurer and a director of Adolph Lewisohn Sons, 61 Broadway, New York, died here today in the Hotel Suburban, where he had resided since 1927. He was 80 years old. A daughter, Mrs. Amy S.Hogue of Providence, R. I., survives.
Gerald W. Knight, executive secretary of the Interstate Sanitation Commission, died at his home here last night of heart disease. He was 58 years old.

Declaring that there was just as much sentiment throughout the country for President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize the Federal judiciary as there was for his reelection last November, Postmaster General James A. Farley reiterated yesterday his prediction that Congress would pass a bill putting that plan into effect.

The annual Catholic Charities campaign, which opens this week, is not merely a drive for money, but "a drive to enlist the hearts and minds of Catholic people in one great corporate act of devotion and faith, which we call charity," the Rev. Henry F. Hammer declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Mrs. Rachel A. Wallhauser, who was active in welfare work for many years, died yesterday at her home here. She was 67 years old and the wife of Dr. H. J. F. Wallhauser.

The speculative element in the price movement, particularly of metals and rubber, is emphasized by the Reich Statistical Bureau, which predicts a new fall in prices of these commodities whenever purchases decline to the level of actual consumption.

The price of copper is likely to decline over a period, it is believed here. It is now recognized that the recent rise was exaggerated, as the general desire of copper producers is to keep production just a little ahead of consumption.

Automatic S 0 S equipment, designed to eliminate static, a deterrent in ascertaining the locations of distressed ships, is being manufactured here by the Federal Telegraph Company for 600 cargo vessels of United States registry, it was learned today.

The annual card party and fashion show for the benefit of St. Elizabeth's Hospital will be held next Saturday afternoon in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the hospital, of which Mrs. Robert E. Draddv is president.

The battle over President Roosevelt's proposal for the reorganization of the Federal judiciary bids fair to overshadow all other issues in Congress during the coming week, with the general tempo of the court fight expected to increase as the moment of decisive action approaches.

Arthur M. Wickwire, a corporation lawyer formerly for some years a member of the firm of Guggenheimer, Untermyer Marshall, died Saturday of pneumonia in the Columbus Hospital, 227 East Nineteenth Street, to which he was removed a week ago from his home at 81 Irving Place.

An increase of $1,475,274,062 in the assets of the fifty-six legal reserve life insurance companies authorized in New York State is reported for 1936 in advance of a report to be issued soon by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.
Roland Drew, who returned to Hollywood two weeks ago for a part in "The Great Gambini," with Akim Tamiroff after an absence of eight years, will be back in the ranks of Hollywood's leading men.

Dr. Thomas Mann, Nobel Prize winner in literature in 1929, is to arrive today on the French liner Normandie to lecture on the activities of the American Guild for German Cultural Freedom. Others due on the Normandie from Havre and Southampton include:

The Loyal City Democracy, which seeks to put forward former Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial as a candidate for Mayor, was endorsed yesterday by David Hirshfield, president of the Allied Civic League, in a letter to Benjamin Gassman, its executive secretary.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "one of the most urgent needs in the Protestant world of today is teaching ministry."

The engagement of Miss Helene Lillian Solomon, daughter of Mrs. Myer Solomon of 353 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Solomon, to William E. Arnstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Arnstein of 120 East Seventy-fifth Street and Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., has been announced by her mother.

Milton S. Hershey, the 79-year-old founder and head of the $100,000,000 Hershey Chocolate enterprises centered in this model industrial community, discussed in an interview with this correspondent tonight his industrial and social policies in the light of the sit-down strike started in his plant on April 2 by the Committee for Industrial Organization.
Great political importance is attached to the visit here of the Turkish Premier, Ismet Inonu, and his Foreign Minister, Tewfik Rushdu Aras.

Van Lingle Mungo's fire-balling right arm is ready for the National League wars. Today. as Burleigh Grimes and his Dodgers closed their exhibition season in Florida in the same manner in which they opened it-by a shutout victory-the big South Carolinian dominated the show.
Pressure for third-quarter bookwings has become so insistent that It is intimated some steel makers may announce prices soon for delivery in that period, the magazine Steel says today.

THE Italians keep Haile Selassie's crown in a red plush hat-box. Marshal Graziani shows it to visitors. It is of silver-gilt and the cross at the top is loose and hangs askew. All the stones, precious and semi-precious, have been pried out of it. The crown was never either valuable or beautiful, yet in the opinion of Evelyn Waugh,

Members of the Roosevelt Hospital Social Service Committee have arranged a Spring sale of useful articles in behalf of their charitable work which will take place April 20 at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue.
The consolidated net profit of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., and subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 amounted to $882,

L. F. Sanman won the majority of the prizes at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He captured the shoot at 100 singles targets by breaking 99, won a leg on the doubles scratch prize with 28 out of a possible 30 targets, and finished the day by taking both the scratch and the handicap legs in the 155-target event with a score of 148-1-149.
Soy beans for May delivery had a range of 10 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here last week, but trade was light. Prices were bid up at times by shorts and processors, as offerings were light.

Frank Traeger of Montclair, member of the American skeet team, 1938 to 1935, and Dr. Charles W. Scranton of East Orange, captain of the B unit in 1935, won the third annual New Jersey State two-man team skeet championship at the Roseland Community Gun Club today with a score of 96, 94-190. They competed for Roseland.

Whether France is to be pulled farther Left by Communists and extreme Socialists or is to abide by the moderate program of Premier Leon Blum and the present Popular Front, which includes the mild Radical Socialist party, will be in large part decided on April 18, when the Socialist party will hold its congress at Marseilles.
Harry Goodrich Currier Sr., for fifty years a member of the general staff of J. P. Morgan Co., until his retirement in 1925, died today at his home, 161 Quitman Street, at the age of 78.
Mrs. Woodward Vietor entertained with tea and cocktails today at Southwood, where her portrait, just completed by Bernard Boutet de Monvel, was shown for the first time.

The Cadet Chapel Choir of the United States Military Academy, 165 men in dress uniforms, took part yesterday in a special evensong service in Trinity Church. It was the first time that a West Point choir had sung at Trinity Church, and the crowd attending the service overflowed into the street.

Proceedings that may have an important bearing on the fate of rapid transit unification will start before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack today. He will hear arguments on proposed formulas for measuring and allocating earnings of the subway and elevated lines of the Interborough system, now in Federal receivership.

Offering will be made today by means of a prospectus of 123,400 shares of new convertible preferred stock of $2-par value of the United States Casualty Company, New York, by Robert Garrett . Sons, Baltimore, and Paine, Webber Co.
President Roosevelt's announcement this week of his intention to check the rise in the prices of raw materials helped to weaken their upward tendency.

The index of French wholesale prices on April 3 was 539, compared with 536 on March 27 and 533 on March 20. Higher prices for native foodstuffs were largely responsible for the advance in the general average.

The program for the fourth annual Princeton invitation track meet, which will be held in Palmer Stadium on commencement Saturday, June 19, was made public today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

Mrs. Irene Brown McKnight of 600 West 115th Street, who retired in 1929 as a teacher in the Chicago public schools, died yesterday morning in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center of post-operative complications. She was born in St. Louis seventy-three years ago, a daughter of Professor Isaac Hinton Brown of the University of Missouri.

Public works projects estimated to cost $371,731,000 in New York City, for which plans have either been made or are under preparation, are in cluded in the recommendations of the Water Resources Committee of the National Resources Committee, details of which were announced today.

Robert Ford, seeded third entrant from the New York Athletic Club, conquered John Corbett of the Bronx Union Y. M. C. A., 21-13, 21-8, In one of five matches that marked the beginning of the annual metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall handball singles championship tournament at the Pastime A. C. in the Bronx yesterday.

Subscriptions of $95,200 to New York World's Fair 4per cent debentures, including one subscription of $32,000 by the Hotel Lexington, were announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the bond sales committee, which is distributing $27,829,500 of debentures.

Egbert Moxham Jr. and L. E. Stiles were the winners in the Manhasset Bay frostbite dinghy racing today. Moxham won three out of four races in the Class B one-design class with Stingaree and Stiles did equally well in the ten-foot.division of the fleet with Golly.

The wage increases on the city's Independent Subway will become effective on April 25 without requiring action by the Board of Estimate, it was disclosed yesterday. The Board of Transportation has the exclusive right to fix these wages, under -the legislation controlling municipal operation.

THE dreadful suspense is over. Through the courtesy of Ford C. Frick, president of the National League, among those present at the opening game at the Polo Grounds this season will be "Mr. Ike Falk and one" as stated on National League Pass 180, now on display by the overjoyed recipient.
Ancient Egypt, gradually regaining national sovereignty, hopes to free herself from what she has called "the shackles of the capitulations," at an international conference beginning here tomorrow.

President ROOSEVELT has announced that he will send to Congress this week a message outlining the Government's relief program for the forthcoming fiscal year. In so doing he will set the stage for an inevitable debate on the question of balancing the budget.

The congregation of the Brick Presbyterian Church, which has stood for seventy-nine years at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, will ask the Presbytery of New York for permission to sell its site and rebuild on the west side of Park Avenue between Ninety-first and Ninety-second Streets.
Plans to start a ten-State drive to have railroad freight rates in the South reduced have been announced by Governor E. D. Rivers.

Thomas J. Mooney will hear tomorrow in the Supreme Court final arguments on his new plea for freedom from a life sentence. In a sense, the case will be new to the seven justices, for it has- outlasted the Supreme Court careers of those who nineteen years ago decreed he should die on the gallows.

Because of the sit-down strike by seventeen blind workers, the board of directors of the Community Craft Weavers Auxiliary, on the sixth floor of 708 Broadway, announced yesterday that the shop would be discontinued.

By finishing second in today's fourth and final race for the Prince of Wales Trophy, the American sixmeter yacht Lulu carried off the cup. Briggs S. Cunningham's boat compiled a total score of 34 points for three seconds and one third place.

Japan's economic advance in North China, which a year and a half ago threatened to sweep through five provinces, has been slowed almost to a standstill by the growing resistance of Chinese along all fronts.

The savings of 1,425,138 persons in 1,661 savings and loan institutions of the country were insured up to $5,000 each by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation at March 31, it was announced yesterday.

Buying activity increased in the wholesale market here last week. The majority of purchases stressed merchandise for sale through the Spring and Summer months. Formals were in steady demand in the better lines of dresses, bridesmaid and graduation types being called for in sheers. Reorder activity in street wear was concentrated on sheer black and navy dresses with lingerie trimming for immediate sale.
Florida music lovers plan an amphitheatre on the banks of the Suwannee River in memory of Stephen Collins Foster, who immortalized in song the stream he never saw.

Ralph Greenleaf of New York outsteadied Benni- Allen of Kansas City, Mo., to w.n a long eleven-inning encounter in the world's pocket billiard championship at Ponzi's Academy last night. The final count was 125 to 75.
Muffin, owned by Henry R. Sears, captured dinghy racing honors at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today, with George Lauder's Apparition second.

The Morris Management Corp., Abraham Weinstein. president, gave a demand mortgage for $35,000 at 6 per cent to the Merit Factors Corp. on the north corner of Riverside Dr. and 88th St. The Manufacturers Trust Co. assigned to the 550 Park Av. Corp. a mortgage for $52.500 on 550 Park Av.
Mrs. Catherine Pingree Dawes, widow of Henry L. Dawes Jr. and member of an old Pittsfield family, died today of angina pectoris at Villa Passerini, Florence, Italy.

A field of fifteen, headed by Whopper, Aneroid and Jay Jay, is named for the $5,000 added Harford Handicap, six-furlong opening-day feature tomorrow at Havre de Grace, which will stage the second of Maryland's Spring race meetings.

The committee acting for the first mortgage and the 5 per cent non-cumulative income bonds of the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway Company, the Gulf Coast Lines, has sent a communication to owners of these equities requesting deposits of such bonds.
The Shady Lake Beagle Kennels of Walkill, N. Y., owned by Harvey Low, dominated the third and final session in the fourth annual Spring field trials of the Long Island Bea- r gle Club today.

A first mortgage of $295,000 at 41/2 and 5 per cent has been placed by Jacob Emil Leitner. Inc., as broker, with the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank on the apartment being completed on the north side of 167th St., from the Concourse to Sheridac Av., the. Bronx. Francis J. Kleban and Milton Leader are the builders.
The Yankees transferred their scene of operations from Little Rock today without appreciable change in their relations with Southern Association baseball.
Mrs. Elsa Soentgerath Schmidt, 15-year-old bride of George Schmidt, 20, of 750 Second Street, Dunellen, has received her parents' permission to live with him as soon as he gets a job.
Although the food-buying power for employed industrial workers is still 10 per cent above the level of 1929, the general cost of living for wageearners is advancing sharply,
Having received word from Central Idaho that golden eagles were killing lambs, State Game Warden Amos Eckert today proposedintensification of a month-old campaign against the big birds.

While Premier Mitchell Hepburn insisted here today that the next move was up to the union if it wished his aid in settling the General Motors strike, labor leaders denounced the Premier as trying to "dictate" to labor and' defied him to "drench the workers in blood."

The nineteenth annual tennis tournament for the United North and South championships will start tomorrow, on the courts of the Pinehurst Country Club with a field of men and women players gathered from all parts of the country.

District officials of the Brotherhoods of Railroad Firemen and Trainmen today backed demands made on the Southern Pacific Company with what they declared was an almost unanimous strike vote by 9,000 employes.

The season in the art galleries continues its pace as mid-April approaches with a number of unusual exhibitions on the calendar for the current week. Group shows are much in evidence and many familiar names appear on the roster of exhibiting artists.
Pope Pius's German encyclical has wrecked the German premiere of the much advertised cooperative film "Condottieri."

The reorganization plan for the seventeen-story penthouse apartment building at 101 Central Park West, for which bonds for $3,500,000 are outstanding, has been approved by the Prudence Bondholders Protective Association, it was announced yesterday by John Kadel of Kadel, Van Kirk Trencher, counsel to the association.
Business sentiment here has improved. Concerns executing the four-year self-sufficiency plan find -banks increasingly inclined to finance them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES Thomas F. Daly states that the increase in hydroelectric plants since 1923 has decreased the annual consumption of coal by at least a hundred million tons. He foresees a continued reduction in the use of coal if the government continues its present power policy,

As part of the celebration marking the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and Yeshiva College, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 2,000 students of Hebrew religious and parochial schools made a pilgrimage there yesterday morning.
Houghton P. Metcalf, sportsman of Providence, R. I., has bought 32,000 acres of land near here for development of a game preserve.

The contract bridge team of Waldemar von Zedtwitz, Theodore Lightner, Samuel Fry Jr. and Edward Hymes Jr. won the masters' team-of-four championship in the tournament. conducted under the auspices of the American Bridge League.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, will meet Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, at St. Petersburg tomorrow morning to spend a few days on an Inspection tour of the site of Everglades National Park, the nation's first tropical park.

The Tangerine Room at the Casino was crowded today and scores of luncheons were given there and in surrounding lounges. Among the hosts were Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lawrence Taylor, Mr. and Mrs. Edward C.

Eleven more small refuges for migratory waterfowl have been established. in North Dakota by the United States Biological Survey, thus bringing the number of such projects in the State to sixty-eight. The acquisitions complete this phase of the program which supplements larger Federal refuges by a total of 103.000 acres.

If the General Motors strike at Oshawa, Ont., continues for long, it was said here today, nearly 1,000 Canadian firms, mostly in Ontario, will be affected by loss of business from the automobile company.

A rose by any other name may smell as sweet, but when " psychic research" becomes "parapsychology" we no longer pinch our nostrils. We seem to breathe the bracing air of the laboratory rather than the sticky incense of darkened rooms in which frauds hold forth.

Stocks lower on the week in moderately active trading; turnover, 8,651,410 shares. United States Government bonds recovered, in part, irregularly; other issues steadier and mixed in trends; transactions, $67,964,300.

The Athletics reached Bucky Walters and Wayne LaMaster for thirteen hits to defeat the Phillies, 7 to 4, and take a 2-0 lead in the city series today. The Mackmen broke a scoreless duel with two tallies in the fourth inning, ending a string of twentytwo runless innings pitched by Walters this Spring.

Several dozen cats and dogs had their day yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt, which, appropriately enough, is decorated with murals depicting the happier moments of the life of Cinderella.

In the presence of one of the greatest galleries that has witnessed a pointer and setter trial in the East, Lawless Boy today continued his unbroken series of brilliant victories as an all-age dog when he captured first money of $275 in the Free-For-All Stake,
The union of the Committee for Industrial Organization at the Wagner Electric Corporation today authorized its executive committee to call a strike at its discretion.

Mohandas K. Gandhi, in a bitter attack on Great Britain's "imperialistic designs," has ignored an invitation to confer with the Viceroy, the Marquess of Linlithgow, but has suggested the creation of a three-man tribunal to decide whether the Governors of the six Congress-controlled provinces have the right to give the noninterference pledges demanded by the Congress party.

Five brick dwellings will be erected at the northwest corner of Calamus Avenue and La Forge Street, Woodside, L. I., sold by Charles Green to the Dunwell Contracting Corporation. The site is 100 by 86 feet and was acquired through Edwards Co., brokers.

Activity in the world's wheat markets, with prices covering a range of 6 to 8 cents a bushel last week, combined with uncertainty as to what the government's crop report would show, kept traders in all markets, especially here and in Winnipeg, in a nervous state.

The report for 1936 of the Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company, Ltd., issued today, shows net income of $3,693,074 after expenses, taxes and depreciation, but before depletion of mine reserves. The net, equal to $1.34 a share on 2,757,973 capital shares outstanding, compared with $3,215,187, or $1.17 a share in 1935.
Coincident with the issuance of its report for 1936, which is to be made public today and which shows an increase of 48 per cent in net profits from those of 1935,

The index of German wholesale prices stood at 106.2 on March 31, against 106.1 on March 24. In the first three months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index ranged between 106.2 on March 17 and 31, and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Marion Av. (11-3022), w. s., 197 ft. n. of 184th St., 50x81; Michael J. Murtha to Kerstan Realty Corp., 1,431 Broadway. 167th St. (9-2496), s. e. cor. Cromwell Av., 125x100; Esspee, Inc., to Arlen Realties, Inc., 122 E. 42d St.

The movements in the commodity markets here this week have confirmed the German opinion that the recent rise in prices, although partly speculative and partly due to rearmament, represented primarily an automatic adjustment of prices to depreciation of world currencies.

The T. V. P. Corporation, a subsidiary of the Petroleum Conversion Corporation, has obtained a contract to construct an oil-shale retorting unit with a capacity of 1,000 tons daily in Tasmania for the Adelaide Oil Exploration Company, Ltd., of Adelaide, Australia, according to Petroleum Conversion.

Thomas F. Burns, a florist in Flushing, Queens, for the last thirty-two years, died yesterday in the French Hospital after a three weeks' illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 143-18 Forty-first Avenue, Flushing.

The WPA Federal Music Project will begin its season of popularpriced opera tonight at the Theatre of Music with a double bill, Pergolesi's "La Serva Padron" in English and Frederic Hart's "The Romance of Robot," a premiere.

Constabulary reports to Major Gen. Paulino Santos today said 300 soldiers attacked the powerful Moro Stronghold on Mindanao Island, and put the Mohammedan defenders to flight into surrounding forests.

Prime Minister BALDWIN, acquainted though he is with the classics, ancient and modern, often finds his illustrations, his parables and his metaphors in the fields, in the orchards or along the roads or lanes of his England. It was said by PLATO of SOCRATES that his words were " like the images of Silenus

ASTOR-Abraham M., 1,337 Carroll St., beloved husband of Gertrude, devoted father of Phoebe-June, Steward Lloyd. Brother of Lena Shapiro, Leo and Ben. Funeral services at Congregation Shaarl Zedek of Brooklyn, Kingston Av. and Park Place, today, 2 P. M. Interment New Mount Carmel Cemetery. Kindly omit flowers.

Reuben Fine of New York; sole representative of the United States in the international chess masters tournament which began today at the Ostend Casino, made an unpromising start by losing in the first round to Paul Keres, champion of Estonia, who on Friday divided first and second prizes with him at Margate, England.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, estimated today that the Federal works program was falling short by at least 1,000,000 jobs of providing for unemployed families where health and morale are in danger.

Winter visitors and homefolk wagered a record $50,121,647 and the State of Florida reaped a record tax harvest of $1,833,719 during the racing season just ended, Chairman Joseph R. Stein of the Racing Commission announced today.
Max Baer, the playboy ex-heavyweight champion, wound up his heavy training today for his fight Thursday with British titleholder Tommy Farr, and announced himself "in the 'pink."

World interest will focus on the church in the next twenty-five years as "one of the three or four major concerns of our time" the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick predicted in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

James Cameron Clark, sportsman and son of the late J. William Clark, Newark thread manufacturer, who obtained a decree of divorce from Lady Irene Cubitt Clark in Reno on Saturday, married yesterday afternoon Mrs. Marion Taylor Gibson of this city, daughter of Mrs. Moses Taylor of New York and The Glen, Newport, R. I., and the late Mr. Taylor.
For last week's decline in stocks, which at one time brought. the "averages" down to the lowest since last August and 15 points below last November's highest, there were varied explanations.

In line with the trend in the market, the Viscose Company will put price advances into effect today on rayon and acetate yarns. Advances on the rayon yarns range from 1 to 5 cents per pound, with the bright first quality 150 denier 40 filament type being moved up to 63 cents per pound.

With the report of the nominating committee, the naming of new committees and the announcement of the appointments of ministers tomorrow afternoon, the eighteenth Newark Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in session at St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church since Wednesday, will be brought to a close.

On Saturday it was reported that the C. I. O. union at Hershey had made two chief proposals to the chocolate company: 1. That the 2,600 employes ballot as to support of the C. I. O. union and, if a majority favors it, the union be. vested with sole bargaining rights.
Pope Pius's return to his normal daily routine was marked this afternoon by an automobile ride in the Vatican gardens. He rode in the gardens, rain or shine, before he became ill in December.

Immature minds, obsessed with fears and conceit, stand in the way of promoting fellowship politically, socially, industrially and in religion, the Rev. Dr. John Howland Lathrop said in his morning sermon yesterday at the Unitarian Church of the Saviour, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn.

A third detachment of the hospital unit of the American Friends of Spanish Democracy arrived in Valencia today. There were thirteen persons in the group, headed by Dr. Donald S. Pitts of Elk City, Okla.

French banks having transferred to the Treasury at the end of last week the funds arising from subscription to the recent defense loan with guarantees of foreign exchange rates, their withdrawal from the money market resulted, as had been foreseen, in an immediate rise in the rate for call money from 11/2 or 2 per cent to 3 per cent, then to 31/2 and 33/4 per cent.

Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy said yesterday that a preliminary investigation of a fire at 710 East 149th Street, early yesterday morning which took two lives indicated that it probably was not incendiary.

Falvey, Waddell Co., investments; W. A. Fine Co., stock brokers, in 1 Wall St., and- additional space in same building to Russell Maguire Co., underwriters; Bear, Stearns Co., F. I. Du Pont Co.; Fahnestock Co.; Mackey, Dunn Co. and William M. Mericka Co., bond dealers: Cruikshank Co., broker.
The Baltimore Soccer Club defeated Brookhattan, 3 to 2, in an American Soccer League contest at Starlight Park yesterday before 3,000 fans.

Honored by the presence of the author himself, the amateur actors of the Henry Street Settlement brought distinction to themselves on Saturday evening by presenting the first New York performance of Ernst Toller's notable poetic drama,

Bishop William T. Manning, presiding yesterday morning at the confirmation services for thirty-two young boys and girls at the Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Riverdale Avenue and 252d Street, the Bronx, urged them to make their parish "a living sentinel of the power of Christ in the lives and in the homes of all whom we are able to reach."

The news that King Boris had decided again to postpone the reconstruction of the government and plans to replace the present Minister of the Interior, Mr. Krasnovsky, with a business man, Mr. Obriekoff, has increased the hostility of the political parties to his present regime.

The Shamrocks of St. Louis, Western champions, accounted for their twentysecond triumph in twenty-three starts when they shaded the New York Americans, Eastern champions, by 1 to 0, today in a bitterly contested soccer battle. The attendance was announced as 5,083.

Catholic opposition to the child labor amendment was defended yesterday by James V. Hayes, chairman of the Catholic Affairs Committee of the Knights of Columbus, at the annual communion breakfast of Corrigan Council, Knights of Columbus, at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx.
The keel of the new 28,000-ton passenger motorship Stockholm of the Swedish American Line was laid on Saturday in Trieste, according to G. Hilmer Lundbeck,
Simple procedures have been devised by the Social Security Board for the filing of claims for the payment of lump sums under the Social Security Act.

State Solicitor General Henry Epstein said tonight that the "Constitution will be construed eventually as an institution of 'living law' and not a parchment stored away for ages." He spoke as "keynoter" for the New York State Conference National Council of Jewish Women, opening a three-day session here.

" The Eternal Road," the most expensive legitimate theatrical production New York ever saw, will end its engagement here on May 15, it was announced yesterday. After more than three years in preparation, involving expenditures of about $500,000, the biblical spectacle staged by Max Reinhardt opened at the Manhattan Opera House on Jan. 7. Between then and lasts Saturday night, it is said to have grossed $355,000.
Two men told last night a story of being shipwrecked on a lake for fourteen hours, and at one time crowding a water moccasin off their floating island perch.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 91 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week. For a month production has been at a rate of about 63,000,000 tons a year.

Paced by Dr. John R. Huffman, holder of the national three-weapon and outdoor saber crowns, six fencers qualified yesterday at the New York A. C. for the national senior indoor saber championship semifinals to be contested there two weeks hence.

A new measuring rod for the infinitesimal, which measures "thicknesses" of molecules of the order of one ten-millionth of an inch, together with a new sort of "supermicroscope" which enables man to penetrate further into the behavior of the protein molecules, the most important building blocks of living matter, will be described here this week by Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel Prize winner, of the General Electric Company's Research Laboratories.

Herbert Morrison, Labor member of Parliament and president of the London City Council, criticized Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn of Ontario last night for "declaring war" on the United Automobile Workers of America.

When the annual report of th Rockefeller Foundation is issue within the next few days it will ad mit error in proclaiming the defea of yellow fever and will present "new and darker picture," accord ing to part of the report made public yesterday.

Augusta Scheiber, New York pianist, made her debut in a recital at Town Hall last night. Her program began unconventionally with a Mendelssohn dispensation including two of the "Songs Without Words," the "Scherzo a Capriccio" and the etude in F. major.

New Yorkers are the most neighborly people in the world in the presence of need, the Very Rev. Robert F. Keegan, secretary to Cardinal Hayes for charities, declared yesterday in his sermon at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, of which he is pastor, at Seventy-first Street and Broadway.

Last week was lively in Aberhartian Alberta. The Government gave up for good its one-dollar bonds or prosperity certificates. On each of these bits of scrip the holder was to stick a onecent stamp every week.

J. B. Whitten, scheduled to be executed in the electric chair tomorrow for, the murder of his former sweetheart, was found strangled to death with a bed sheet in his "death row" cell at the State prison today.

General Jose Maja, government commander, announced tonight the Franceses Bridge over the Manzanares River, the Insurgents' means of communication with their University City forces, had been dynamited.

A minister can cry out against the evils of the world, but he should never be a propagandist, the Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, said yesterday morning. It was Dr.
S. Algernon B. L. Ashton, whose thousands of letters to London newspapers earned him even more fame than his many musical compositions, died yesterday at the age of 77.
This resort municipality counted $2,292,531 in building permits today for the first 100 days of 1937 and set its sights on a new postboom record. Last year's figure at this date was $1,809,084.
The Workmen's Circle Chorus, 120 working men and women under the direction of Lazar Weiner, gave its annual concert at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

The Board of Trade's index number for British wholesale prices of all commodities in March, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 107.3, which compared with 103.9 for the preceding month and 91.7 for March, 1936.

More than 350 delegates from the forty-two Manhattan, Bronx and Westchester County councils of the Knights of Columbus, at a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, heard Michael H. Carmody of Grand Rapids, Mich., Supreme Knight of the order, launch the organization's local drive against communism.

Employment in the non-durable goods industries in February this year was at approximately the 1929 level, according to a-report issued by the National Industry Conference Board. Weekly earnings and total payrolls, however, were from 8 to 9 per cent below the 1929 figures.

The semi-final for the New York State Cup at Bay Ridge Oval, Brooklyn, yesterday, between the Hakoah and Gjoa teams resulted in a 3-3 tie after two extra periods. Hakoah led by 2-1 at half time, Raab and Wortman scoring. Peterson tallied for Gjoa.
The April meeting of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing was held yesterday morning at the Hotel Astor with Roderick C. Grant of Yonkers, president, presiding.

The secret political police have opened another campaign against Jewish institutions in Germany. Several Jewish sport clubs were suppressed indefinitely and. last night the Berlin Jewish school that was preparing emigrants for life abroad was closed for two months.

Arm-folding caddies of the Forsyth Country Club won a moral but not immediately effective victory today in a strike for more pay. More than 100 of the young Negroes selected the day of the opening of the season's most important golfing event, the Donkeys and Camels Tourney, to demand 15 cents additional pay for eighteen holes.
Three persons were killed and two critically injured about 6 o'clock this evening in a head-on crash of two automobiles in front of the State Home for Feeble-Minded Boys on Route 41 here.
Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes became 75 years old today, but the three-quarter century milestone in his eventful career passed virtually unnoticed by him.

Championphip honors in the second Alken hunter horse show were awarded today to Pomeroy, a gray gelding owned by S. H. Knox of East Aurora, N. Y. Louis Smith was up. The reserve ribbon went to Manite, a black mare, listed by Mrs. Louis E. Stoddard Jr. of New York and ridden by Miss Betty West.

With feasting and song the 500 employes of the Nobile Cigar Company plant at Ninth Street and Thirty-fifth Avenue, Long Island City, continued their sit-down strike yesterday. Relatives and friends participated and the police looked on with nothing to do.

The Trustees of Dartmouth College today made public several important appointments, including two new life trustees, a dean for the Tuck School of Administration and Finance, and at the same time degrees were awarded to twelve midyear graduates.

Residents of Pearl River and Nauraushaun are considering a proposal to withdraw from the town of Orangetown in Rockland County and establish a .separate town or village government because they feel they are not receiving benefits under the present system commensurate with recent local development.

If men and women were swayed by the influence of God as much as they are led by other people there would be less evil and conflict in the world, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church of America, said yesterday in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
Serious doubt has arisen as to the proper functioning of the two-payment tax plan for Suffolk County, a bill for which was recently passed by the Legislature and signed by Governor Lehman.
The cotton market underwent last week the sharpest reaction in many months. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures at the close on Saturday showed net losses of 40 to 53 points.

Verdi's "Rigoletto" was presented by the Opera League at the Adelphi Theatre last night. The opera, which was the second staged by the organization this season, was given in a revised version by a cast of youthful vocalists under the baton of Emerson Buckley, the young American conductor who directed the league's initial performance last month.

The marriage of Miss Norma Rubenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob A. Rubenstein of 12 West Seventy-second Street, and Park Hill, Yonkers, to Benedict I. Lubell of Tulsa, Okla., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Lubell of this city, took place yesterday noon at the Pierre.
The Rev. John Brett Langstaff both praised and criticized the New York City stage in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Edmund's Episcopal Church, Morris Avenue and 177th Street, the Bronx. He said:
Ralph W. Ince, noted film director and actor, who came to England three years ago, was killed in an automobile accident in Kensington today.

Plans to celebrate the fourth anniversary of Thrift House, 7 East Fifty-seventh Street, by holding a bundle party on May 4 at the Hotel Commodore were announced yesterday by Mrs.. Herbert Pollack, president of the organization.

A fresh break in South African gold mining securities unsettled financial mar- Ur kets this week, and the likely result will be selling of industrials and other equities to meet heavy losses for the April 22 settlement.

Changing over from the spelling bees of other years, and the "definitions bee" of last year, the members of the Town Hall Club, at 123 West Forty-third Street, amused one another last night with a "difficult questions bee."

Mr. and Mrs. William Bouldin 3d of West Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Maulsby Bouldin, to Frederick Martin Blaicher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Blaicher of Orange. Miss Bouldin is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bouldin Jr. of East Orange.

The Division of International Law of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. which for twenty years has administered awards of fellowships in international law established in 1917 with stipends varying from $750 to $2,000,

The church and the public school should "stop playing with religious education," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning. He advocated "released time for weekday religious education," and added:

The land of the Pharaohs hopes soon to free itself from one more of the remaining stigmas of inequality. Today in Montreux, Premier MUSTAPHA NAHAS Pasha meets the representatives of twenty countries, twelve of which, including the United States, still exercise capitulatory (extraterritorial) rights in Egypt.

Professor Leopold Arnaud, who has served as acting dean of the Columbia University School of Architecture since Feb. 17, 1936, was recently elected dean of the school by the university's board of trustees, it was learned yesterday.

The smooth-coated dachshund Helmi Flottenberg, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Dan R. Hanna of Willoughby, and handled by William Lang of Elyria, won the special for best in show at the fifteenth annual exhibition of the Toledo Kennel Club, which closed tonight at the Civic Auditorium. The judge was M. H.

The Quartermaster Corps has awarded contracts on cotton threat, including the following items: Machine cotton, Type 1 C2, 3-cord, mercerized, vat-dyed, left twist, (1) "A" 6,000-yard cones, olive drab, 10,000 cones; (2) "A" 6,000-yard

A protest against orders allegedly sent to army officers in charge of Civilian: Conservation Corps camps, directing them to turn over for investigation all publications containing "subversive material," was sent yesterday to Robert Fechner, director of the CCC, by Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union.

A play written almost three-score years ago was produced last night at a party honoring its author, who will be 85 years old tomorrow. It was "The Eternal Problem," produced first on March 1, 1880, and written by the Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, rabbi emeritus of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Seventieth Street and Central Park West.

Puerto Rico's best citizens must adopt the pressure-group methods of the small band seeking independence for the island, Miguel A. Garcia Mendez, Speaker of the House of Representatives, said today in a published call addressed to all responsible persons who would preserve the island from the dark future he sees impending, should the will of a "minute minority" be imposed through more constant propaganda.

In an effort to reduce consumer cost, the Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures will encourage greater diversion of the daily delivery of fruits and vegetables to Wallabout Market in Brooklyn and the Bronx Terminal Market, Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. disclosed yesterday.
A hard soccer battle was fought at Celtic Park yesterday when the St. Mary's Celtics and Paterson Caledonians met in an American League game which it ended without either side scoring.
The Bureau of Standards said today the camera is probably a better instrument than the human eye for spotting the winner in a close horse race.

Although Federal Fevenues have increased by nearly $85,000,000 a month in the first three quarters of this fiscal year over the corresponding period of last year, the national government has increased its budget deficit by $115,762,291 in the same time,

More than 2,000 of the 3,600 employes of J. P. Coats (R. I.), Inc., voted today to authorize C. I. O. leaders and an employes' committee of fifteen to sign an agreement on wages and working conditions with the management at a meeting in Providence tomorrow.

Louis Bromfield, who recently visited Rome to lecture on fundamental differences between the life and culture of America and that of Europe, has returned to his home in Senlis, France, where he is completing a novel called "The Rains Came." He writes to Harpers, his publishers, that the book should be ready for publication in the Fall. It was postponed from this season. The material is said to be of a controversial nature.

A jury which after ten hours and thirty-five minutes of deliberation was still at odds on the guilt or innocence of Louis Luckman, accaused of perjury, was dismissed early yesterday in Brooklyn. by Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers.

Half a hundred relief demonstrators, put out of the office of Governor Davey, huddled in the bare second story of a little Negro church tonight, voicing intention to try again to see the Governor. Nelson Meagley, State secretary of the Workers Alliance, said:

Eight-month-old Mickey O'Connell proved to be the best "demonstration object" yesterday afternoon at a class in elementary baby care at the Manhattan center of the Catholic Youth Organization, 353 West Seventeenth Street.
THE SPECTACLE OF A MAN, by John Coignard. (Jefferson House: Morrow, distributors, $2.50.) The story of a year in a man's life during which he was treated by analytical psychotherapy. An actual case.

The cream of this year's amateur boxers, 221 of them from twenty-five States, the District of Columbia and Hawaii, will perform in two rings during tomorrow's opening National A. A. U. boxing program at the Boston Garden.
The Central Executive Committee today removed Moises Kalmonovich as Commissar of State Farms and named Nikolai Demchenko to succeed him. Mr. Demchenko has been Vice Commissar of Agriculture.
It might be said of the late KARL MARX that his name is great in the world today because he guessed wrong so completely.

Striking WPA workers in the Bay area relinquished a demand for a 10 per cent wage increase and voted today to end a strike which began eleven days ago. All workers who have remained on strike will return to work tomorrow, said an announcement from the joint strike committee and W. H. Day, representing State WPA Administrator W. R. Lawson.

Rising discontent in the ranks of British labor, with prospects of large-scale strikes in several industries in the near future, confronted the British Government today with the severest test in years of its extensive labor arbitration machinery.

The rise in new pulp mills in the South is expected soon to make the United States independent in production of kraft paper, according to a survey made public today by the American Chemical Society. Ten new mills are in operation or being erected, the report stated.

Labor troubles, including the sitdown strike, which have spread from the United States and Canada, were discussed in many New York City pulpits yesterday. Members of the clergy and the rabbinate variously condemned the sit-down strike or appealed to employers to consider the viewpoint of employes trying to support -families on meager wages.

The weather played the gamut of variety yesterday, turning from faint traces of snow to a sprinkling of rain and from ominous clouds to bright Spring sunshine. The snow was too faint to leave a mark at the United States Weather Bureau, but was seen several times during the day at places throughout the metropolitan area.

Millions of dollars of waste in terms of "unnecessary deaths, preventable illness and disrupted homes" was charged today by Dr. Robert E. Plunkett to "penny-wise and fencestraddling public policies" in fighting tuberculosis.
The 108th anniversary of the birth of General William Booth, founder of the. Salvation Army, was observed in seventy-five Protestant churches at two -special commemorative services here today.

The Summer home of John J. Melady, a three-story frame structure on a hill overlooking Pine Road opposite the Briar Hills Country Club, burned to the ground tonight, with the loss estimated at more than $75,000.

Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut has accepted an invitation to become the first president of the recently organized American Guild for German Cultural Freedom, the aim of which is to preserve and develop the life and spirit of German culture outside of the Reich.

A study of racial intolerance in this country with particular reference to anti-Semitism, is to be made by the Good Neighbor League with the cooperation of several other organizations, Dr. Stanley High, president of the league, announced yesterday.

24th St., 239 W.. 20x98.9; Extel Realty Corp. to Ella Kelsch, 835 8th Av.; mtg., $8,500. Block bounded by 41st St.. 42d St.. 1st Av. and East River; Consolidated Edison Co. of New York, Inc., to City of New York; consideration. $1,230.000.
Dr. Allan Fulson.Odell, chemical director of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours plant at Arlington, N. J., died Saturday at his home in Essex Fells, N. J. He was 51 years old.
Two more victims of terrorism in Palestine were added today, one of whom was Ibrahim Youssef, lawyer and Vice Mayor of Tiberias, a man of moderate views.

The modern experiences of Jews throughout the world proves again that the Jewish people must return to the ideals of the Jewish faith and that they must again be at one with the Jewish God, Rabbi Joachim Prinz of Berlin said in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eightythird Street.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, as president of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, 633 West 155th Street, announced yesterday that next November the academy would be sponsor of a memorial exhibition of the works of Elihu Vedder.

The world needs practical Christianity and the practice of Christian virtues, the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman asserted in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

The Giants' scoring machinery congealed very badly on this bright but chilly afternoon. They froze up at other points as well and the result of all this was that the Terrymen had to go all of twelve innings to bring down the Nashville Volunteers, 3 to 2, a two-bagger by Sambo Leslie and a single by Harry Danning ending a long deadlock.

Due to the demand from the European Continent and erroneous reports that Great Britain's wheat supply would last only seventeen days, July options this week reached their highest level since 1928. Plenty of wheat is now on ships bound for England, so no serious shortage of supplies is expected. The potential demand, however, should absorb the offerings.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 94.5, which compares with 94.7 the week before, 94.4 two weeks before, 93.7 three weeks before and 92.9 four weeks before.

Staten Island police requested the police of Hoboken and Perth Amboy yesterday to look for Canwell Leitch, 29 years old, an odd-job man, who is wanted for questioning in connection with the murder Saturday night of Mrs. Gussie Dishler, 61, a rooming-house keeper of 1,681 Richmond Road, Dongan Hills.

The foreign exchange market last week was milled about in a manner reminiscent of the unsettlement which struck it last Fall upon the occasion of the devaluation of several European currencies. The immediate cause of the current reaction, most of which centered in the French franc, was the report that the Treasury would cut the buying price of gold from the $35 level set by the Gold Act of 1934.

Henry Ford was elected president of the Quito Chauffeurs Union at the last general meeting. The union commissioned Captain Colon Eloy Alfaro, Ecuadorian Minister to the United States, to present to Mr. Ford a document testiflyinx to his election.

The report of the Bank of Montreal Trust Company as of March 31 showed total deposits of $293,637 and total assets of $1,863,858. The bank showed cash on hand and due from banks and bankers of $584,561 and holdings of United States Government securities of $1,266,180.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

The World War generation does not wish to feel detached from other men, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fiftysixth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. William Torrey Baird, residents of this place for nearly forty-seven years and both prominent leaders in the philanthropic and social life of the Oranges, will celebrate tomorrow their golden wedding anniversary with two parties.

The railroad excursion season began in earnest yesterday when 3,200 locomotive enthusiasts from twenty States took the New York Central's third "wonder trip" to inspect the American Locomotive Company's plant at Schenectady.

A bronze plaque in memory of Henry Pennypacker, former chairman of the committee on admission to Harvard College and at one time headmaster of the Boston Latin School, will be unveiled in the Harvard Union tomorrow afternoon.

The universal interest in pictures, as evinced by the popularity of movies, tabloids, and picture magazines, should be recognized by ministers and utilized by bringing before the people visions and pictures of Jesus Christ, the Rev. Karl Tiedemann of the Order of Holy Cross said yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street.

Given up for dead after being entombed twenty-seven hours in a bootleg coal mine, Andrew Vinscavage, 52 years old, was rescued apparently unharmed this afternoon at the bottom of a forty-five foot shaft a mile west of Tamaqua.

Angelo De Bacco of the Belleville Bicycle Club defeated a field of 120 cyclists today to win the fifth annual Eastern road championship over a fifty-mile course from Newark to Somerville and Union. His time was 2 hours 12 minutes 82-5 seconds.

A police raid in the early hours of this morning broke up a wellplanned and well-attended cockfighting exhibition staged in a barn at Wantagh, on the Merrick Road. Police Captain Frederick Stuhler said it was the first exhibition of its kind to find its way into the police records of Nassau County in many a year.

Nine men were shot down this afternoon in Main Street here in front of the headquarters of the International Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, as a climax to a day in which 4,000 triState district miners ruled this lead and zinc mining district with pick handles in a demonstration to thwart C. I. O. organization in the Field.
George Adrian Breeman, holder of the Congressional Medal of Honor, died of embolism at the home of his brother John here last night. He was 60 years old.
Bob Feller, sensational young Cleveland hurler, today fell a victim to the bane of all pitchers when he was touched for a home run with the bases full.

The Rev. W. D. Harvey, who has testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal, declared yesterday that "communism exists openly in the committee's inquiry room and in the State Department."

The Brussels electorate expressed Its preference for democracy, parliamentarism and Premier Paul van Zeeland's policies in figures so decisive today that a neutral observer is left wondering what all the shooting has been about and what was the occasion for the alarm and excitement of the last few weeks.

The faithful gathered for the final concerts of the Washington Festival of Chamber Music, which took place this afternoon and evening, in large numbers and with great good-will for those composers, old and new, young and old, who ministered to their edification.

Defending the old-fashioned home against the ridicule of "today's supercilious and cynical ultramoderns," the Rev. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that the home was "earth's foremost fundamental institution."

Edward J. Karr, traffic manager of the Calmar Steamship Company, announced yesterday the appointment of a committee of twenty steamship and railroad traffic executives to study freight problems of the North Atlantic ports of the United States, particularly those which involve the diversion of commerce to other ports in the country and Canada.

The Rev. Dr. Addison B. Lorimer in a sermon yesterday morning at the Chambers Memorial Baptist Church, 215 East 123d Street, ridiculed the idea that the life of a saint, of a man close to God, was devoid of pleasure. According to Dr. Lorimer, the opposite is true.

If this country is to prosper, independent business must be protected and preserved, Representative Wright L. Patman of Texas, co-author of the Robinson-Patman act, said yesterday afternoon at the sixteenth annual convention of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore.

Philadelphia's Curtis Institute of Music came to town last night bearing the gift of two contemporary operas in their New York premieres. They were Amelia al Ballo," an opera buffe in one act, by Gian-Carlo Menotti, and "La Pauvre Matelot," a sardonic oneact work by Darius Milhaud.

With retail prices rising so sharply, both manufacturers and retailers of men's clothing will have to put greater emphasis on quality and fashion in their advertising copy, according to one advertising agency executive, who handles a number of clothing accounts. Copy should also be patterned more after that of other products, in which the idea of what they can do for consumers rather than the products themselves is promoted, he said.

Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia University said yesterday in an address at the Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street, that passage of the present Neutrality Bill in Congress will mean the end of America's peacetime foreign trade.

Virginia Russ, a young dancer from San Francisco, gave her first New York recital last night at the Guild Theatre. That Miss Russ has had training in various styles of movement and that she has worked seriously at them are evident in a body that is able to respond to all the requirements made of it.

General price increases on shoes will be put into effect today in the 654 Thom McAn and twelve John Ward stores, as the result of higher leather costs, it was announced by the Melville Shoe Corporation. In the Thom McAn line, men's shoes, which since last August have retailed at $3.15, will sell at $3.45,

The General Capital Corporation in its report for March 31 shows net asset value at market prices of $5,637,655, equal to $45.33 a share, compared with $5,366,493 on Dec. 31 last, which was equal to $43.84 a share.

Alexander Budson, counsel for Leather Fabrics Creations, Inc., announced tonight an agreement had been reached with the firm's 400 employes who went on strike Friday and that operations would be resumed tomorrow afternoon.

Everett Chase Brown of Chicago, former president of the National Livestock Exchange and for many years a member of the executive committee of the American Olympic Committee, died at his Winter home here today at the age of 73.
Written communications delivered to airplane pilots as they speed at 200 miles an hour were seen today as a likelihood soon by James T. Flynn, chief of communications for American Airlines.

A 17-year-old thug, held with two others for the fatal shooting of Detective Michael Foley Saturday morning, made two ineffectual attempts to escape yesterday after hearing Magistrate Michael Ford predict that he and his companions were "on their way to the electric chair."

Warren C. Giles, Reds' general manager, announced today he had released Gillie Campbell, third string catcher, to Syracuse of the International League subject to twenty-four hours recall. Campbell has been with the Reds two years.
The week's stock market opened on an irregular note, with some buying in the chemical, rubber, linoleum and bank shares.

Homer Martin, president of - the Automobile Wrorkers of America, declared today that Premier Hepburn of Ontario was a bungler who had "made the biggest political mistake of his career." In an address to union automobile workers he criticized also Henry Ford and the American Federation of Labor.

William Rowland, a retired hat manufacturer, died early this morning in his sleep at his home, 15 Morris Crescent, at the age of 82. Born in England, he came here as a child with his father, John Rowland, with whom he was associated for many years in the hatmanufacturing firm of John Rowland Sons of Yonkers.

Oats are reported scarce on farms and at interior points. Minneapolis is shipping oats to Texas and other points in the Southwest, and the Middle West is being drawn on to supply near-by and Eastern consumptive points.

The principle of self-defense is incompatible with the teachings o Jesus, so Christians must decide whether to adhere to this practical policy or to follow the admonitions and example of their Savior, the Rev. Edmund Melville Wylie, minister of the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, declared yesterday morning.

Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, third ranking tennis player in the nation and long a Davis Cup question mark, annexed Hu his third successive River Oaks tournament title today by defeating Wilmer Allison, retired cup and international tournament star. The count was 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, 6-4.

Tris Speaker, who managed the Cleveland Indians to the world series championship in 1920 is in critical condition to night in Lakeside Hospital here with a skull fracture received in a fall from the second story porch of his home.

Seeking to avoid a grave international from the Insurgent blockade of Bilbao, Spain, the British Government today instructed four British merchant vessels bound for the besieged Basque capital to remain at St. Jean-de-Luz, France, until additional warships arrive and warned them that afterward they may enter Spanish territorial waters at their own risk.

Munster defeated Connacht by 8 to 4 in the semi-final inter-provincial Gaelic football game at Innisfail Park yesterday and will battle Leinster in the final next Sunday. Munster led at half time, 5-1. Tommy Armitage and Joe Connors starred for the winners.

A committee of the Boston Chamber of Commerce declared today that the Federal undistributed profits tax was injuring business, "eating the seed corn," and that "famine" was sure to follow if the measure was not soon altered.
Paul Peter Gunther von Kanitz, 59, self-styled former agent of the German Kaiser, was bound for New York today on a special six-car deportation train bearing about 200 aliens.

The body of Benjamin Buchlazer, known on the lower East Side as "the Miser of Madison Street," was found yesterday under a heap of rags on his iron bed, which, aside from a battered phonograph and an antique trunk containing evidence of hoarded wealth, was the only furniture in the dark, squalid cellar that served him as office, warehouse and dwelling place.

Dean Arthur D. Whitman or Hofstra College, New York University's educational affiliate at Hempstead, L. I., announced yesterday the appointment of four new faculty members, effective next September. They are Dr. Younghill Kang, assistant Professor of Comparative Literature; Dr. Roland Warren,
The tenth annual two-day field trials on liberated quail staged by the Hauppauge Gunning Club ended today. Improved conditions brought out a large gallery and produced keen competition.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that the city's credit consultation service for city employes began yesterday evening when Louis E. Yavner and Louis M. Weintraub advised prospective borrowers in the office of the Commissioner of Accounts at 2 Lafayette Street.

Governor Lehman, accepting the challenge of Republican leaders of the Legislature, who charged that he had fallen $27,000,000 short in his executive budget of providing adequately for unemployment relief during the next fiscal year, recommended in a special message tonight an additional relief appropriation of $24,000,000.
Earl F. Reed, counsel for the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, said tonight that the Supreme Court decision on the Wagner Labor Relations Act was one which "cuts both ways."
