Robert Lincoln O'Brien, who has been chairman of the Tariff Commission since Dec. 1, 1931, announced today his intention of resigning about June 30.
The S. C. Daugherty family of Jeannette, Pa., lays claim to possessing the largest. number of diplomas from the University of Pittsburgh of any one family, the university reports.

Fifteen members of Princeton University's 1936 football squad, including four lettermen, reported to Head Coach Fritz Crisler on Fitzpatrick Field today to launch the fortnight of intensee practice that will conclude the annual out-ofseason training periods.

Police yesterday placed the time of the murder of Benjamin Buchlazer, "the Miser of Madison Street," as between 6 and 11 o'clock Sunday morning, but reported little progress otherwise in their search for the slayer or slayers who stabbed the 57-year-old man to death.
Brig. Gen. Winthrop S. Wood, retired, former assistant to the Quartermaster General, died at Walter Reed General Hospital here last night, the War Department announced today.

" Angelica," by the late Leo Ferrero, produced by the Stage Society last night, is a politico-poetical play whose protagonists, Angelica and Orlando, are employed as symbols portraying the forces of freedom and those of tyranny.
Senator McKellar of Tennessee said tonight the Supreme Court should "stop this foolishness of declaring acts unconstitutional by a 5-to-4 decision."
Captain Samuel Gilman Harding, oldest master mariner on Cape Cod, died here last night at the age of 96 in the home of William Rich. Captain Harding was born in Chatham April 2, 1841.

Retail prices in March continued the uninterrupted advance which began on Aug. 1 last year and reached the highest levels since 1931, according to the Fairchild retail price index, issued yesterday. The increase last month was 0.9 per cent, bringing the composite index to 94.5 on April 1, compared with 93.7 on March 1.

A slight improvement in prices at the opening on the Cotton Exchange yesterday failed to hold and a resumption of the liquidating movement which was in progress last week carried the list off $1 a bale or more at one time.

Mayor La Guardia was asked yesterday by the United May Day Committee of 1,265 Broadway to reverse the ruling of Edward F. Kenny, acting borough director of the Parks Department, denying the committee permission to build a platform and install a loudspeaker system in Union Square.

A luncheon and card party, under the auspices of the board of managers of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children, will be held today in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of the shelter.
Workers who attempted to sabotage construction of the second link of Moscow's subway already have been "liquidated," the organ of the Commissariat of Heavy Industry disclosed today.

Automobile production last week increased more than seasonally over the revised total for the previous week and the adjusted index advanced to 84.4 from 84.1 (revised). It was 108.0 for the week ended April 11, 1936.

Colonel T. Bentley Mott, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Mott have returned from Paris and are at the Savoy-Plaza. Mrs. Alfred Anson, who has been in Aiken, S. C., is at the Westbury. Mrs. Edward A. Hubbard has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from South Natick Mass.

Martin M. Spellacy, brother of Mayor Thomas J. Spellacy, died today at St. Francis Hospital, where he had been a patient since Feb. 27. He was born in Hartford and for twenty-two years had been a building department inspector.

Ten automobile manufacturing and sales companies and three financing companies have entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission not to make certain statements in their advertising in relation to the so-called "6 per cent" financing plan, the commission announced today.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 7 shows increases for the week of $83,000,000 in total loans and investments, $41,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $97,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $46,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, and a decrease of $15,000,000 in deposits credited to foreign banks.

The Federal Land Banks have decided to call a part of their 4?? per cent bonds dated May 1, 1927, for payment on May 1 this year, W. I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration. announced today.
Officials of the United Paper Board Company have announced a 5 per cent wage increase at its plant here. The increase affects 300 workers in the plant, officials disclosed.
Major Gen. Garnet Hughes, son of Sir Samuel Hughes, Defense Minister during the war, died in a hospital here this afternoon. He would have been 57 years old on April 22.

An old carriage house and stable on the 100-acre estate of William Mathews Sullivan, New York lawyer, is being remodeled into a small opera house for the Summer performance of intimate operas and chamber music, it was learned here today.

Victory today in decisions upholding the Wagner Labor Relations Act brought the New Deal box score to nine victories and eleven defeats since 1933. This does not include the Washington minimum wage decision. Here is the record since the Roosevelt administration came into power:

Objectives of the recently formed Committee on Scrap of the Independent Steel and Iron Producers were explained to thirty-five steel executives who attended a luncheon meeting of the committee at the Hotel Commodore yesterday. R. W.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in a two-to-one decision yesterday found that the Packard Lektro-Shaver made by the Dictograph Products Company, Inc., did not infringe upon the patent rights of the product of Shick Dry Shaver, Inc., and Schick Industries, Ltd.
The Wall Street rumor that our Government's price for gold, which in 1934 was advanced arbitrarily by the Administration from $20.67 per ounce to $35, might be reduced, has been denied at Washington.

Joseph Edward Taylor, for thirtyeight years a locomotive engineer and motorman on the Fulton Street Elevated line in Brooklyn, died on Sunday at his home, 104 Sumpter Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 78.
Embezzlement became a capital offense in Hopei and Chahar Provinces today under the ironfisted rule of Sung Cheh-yuan, along with tomb looting, narcotic peddling and smuggling.

The twenty-fifth floor of 369 Lexington Av. was leased by the Savings Banks Trust Co. to the Willfor Realty Corp., William F. Chatlos, president, for five years from April 1, 1937, at the annual rental of $1, the floor to be used as a real estate office.
The Yale freshmen opened their season today by defeating Branford High, 4--1. The three Yale pitchers, Gardner from Andover, Stevens from Choate and Jackson from Milford, were effective.

Unless the World Textile Conference now in progress succeeds in achieving a degree of stabilization in working hours and wages of certain foreign countries, American exporters will be compelled to renew their demands for an equalization fee or cotton tolerance on exports, Samuel C. Lamport, head of the Lamport Manufacturing and Supply Company, said here yesterday, prior to leaving for Washington, where he will address the conference today.

Lazard Freres Co., Inc., has prepared a pamphlet tabulation, listing 300 callable railroad, public utility and industrial bonds of general market interest, bearing 4 1/2, 5 per cent and higher coupons which have sold over their call prices this year.

THE Harvard Advocate, an undergraduate publication appearing monthly, is--or should be--out today with a long article by John A. Day, '37, on the endowment policy in athletics that Fair Harvard is pursuing. The word pursuing is used advisedly. They are going after it, but they haven't nearly caught up with it yet. It looks like a long chase,
With the traditional Spring "moving day" in the business world less than three weeks away, commercial leasing in Manhattan yesterday continued to show the effects of expanding trade in many lines.

The volume of bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States on March 31 totaled $396,471,668, a decline of $4,636,092 from the end of February, 1937, but an increase of $37,467,161 over March 31, 1936, according to the monthly report of the Acceptance Analysis Unit of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.

President Roosevelt conferred with Mayor La Guardia, discussed the Supreme Court's decisions in the Wagner act cases with Attorney General Cummings and sent to the Senate the nominations of William J. Sears to fill the unexpired term of Raymond B. Stevens on the Tariff Cammission and Harry M. During to succeed himself as Collector of Customs of the Port of New York.

With the vital issues of the fivecent fare and unification of the city-wide transit system at stake, Federal Judge Julian W. Mack was asked yesterday to decide upon a formula for working out the net earnings of the Manhattan elevated lines during the four years of the Interborough's receivership.

The marriage of Miss Elsie Wise May, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. May of 103 East Eightyfourth Street, to Albert Philip Gross. son of Mrs. Edward Gross of this city and the late Mr. Gross, took place last night at Sherry's.

Stockholders of the old National Investors Corporation and of the Second, the Third and the Fourth National Investors Corporations have been notified that the plan of mutualization and reorganization of the four companies was completed on March 31, and that the new National Investors Corporation commenced operations on April 1.
The death of Sister Caroline Louis Tate, 77-year-old convert of the Society of Believers, today left a dwindling Shaker colony of less than a half dozen followers of Mother Ann Lee.

Angelo Trullo, unattached and undefeated champion, defeated Jack Weitz of the Castle Hill Sport Ing Club in the first round of the metropolitan four-wall singles handball tournament at the Pastime Athletic club last night.

The Decorators Picture Gallery, 554 Madison Avenue, gave a preview yesterday afternoon of its third exhibition, which will be opened to the public tomorrow. The show includes four rooms arranged as settings for pictures by American artists and two murals, which their designer, Annot, calls "collages."

Roy L. Humphrey, 41 years old, a former Washington, D. C., lawyer and for the last five years an inspector in the United States Customs Service, stationed at the Barge Office in Manhattan, was killed instantly when struck by a Philadelphia-New York express train at the Pennsylvania Railroad station here today.
Tony Canzoneri, former lightweight champion, will meet Frankie Wallace of Cleveland tonight in the main bout of ten rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn.

A proposal that New York City schools use ferryboat trips to supplement classroom instruction in the teaching of civics, geography and foreign trade, was made yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the committee on buildings and sites of the Board of Education.

Mayor La Guardia conferred briefly with President Roosevelt today on what he said were "routine matters concerning the problems of the cities." Mr. La Guardia, who is president of the United States Conference of Mayors, refused to discuss the conference further.

James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., and Pearl L. Bergoff of New York were indicted tonight by a Federal grand jury for violation of the Byrnes act by bringing strike-breakers to the Remington Rand plant at Middletown.
The Yanks ran against some Washington farm pitching from the Chattanooga Lookouts today at Engel Stadium and didn't look so impressive. But they managed,

The Southern Railway has ordered 1,250 gondola cars from the American Car and Foundry Company, 2,000 box cars and 250 gondola cars from the Pullman-Standard Manufacturing Company, 500 automobile cars and 500 box cars from the Mount Vernon Car Company and 1,100 hopper cars from the Pressed Steel Car Company.

Two games at Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, bring down the curtain on the indoor polo season tonight. The feature match will be the one between the Cleveland Riding Club and the Ridgewood Polo Club to decide the East-West junior title series, the only branch of the championships requiring the limit of three games.

Two Olympians, the Misses Mavis Freeman and Elizabeth Ryan, and the Misses Elizabeth Kompa and Elsie Petri will represent the Women's Swimming Association of New York in the national senior A. A. U. title meet to be held at the Lake Shore A. C. in Chicago beginning tomorrow and concluding Saturday.

Principal actuarial mathematician (pensions), $5,600 a year; senior actuarial mathematician (pensions), $4,600; actuarial mathematician (pensions), $3,800; associate actuarial mathematician (pensions), $3,200. Railroad retirement board applications must be on file not later than the following dates:
An offer for purchase of Camden's $10,000,000 City Hall has been made by brokers representing the Curtis Publishing Company, Mayor George E. Brunner of Camden announced today.
The presence in the court room of Mrs. Charles Evans Hughes, wife of the Chief Justice, was the first real intimation that the long-delayed Wagner act cases would probably be handed down today.

A track record was made today in the second heat of the aged trot, the feature event on the second day of harness racing at the new Aiken mile track, when Brogan, brown gelding, driven by J. C. Andrews, of West Point, Ind.,

Government employes in Pomerania were ordered today to wed by Nov. 1 or lose their jobs. The order was handed down by District Leader Franz SchwedeCoburg. Explaining the measure at a meeting of Pomeranian officials, he said:

At the end of one of the happiest days in his public career, Senator Wagner broadcast an appeal to industry and labor to pick up the step, under his labor act as upheld today by the Supreme Court, and march along together "toward a clearer atmosphere of mutual understanding and good-will."

No. 365-October Term, 1936. The Associated Press, petitioner, v. National Labor Relations Board. On writ of certiora?? to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Mr. Justice Roberts delivered the opinion of the court.

More than' 600 high school students, members of the Pan-American Student League, celebrated Pan-American Day yesterday in McMillin Theatre at Columbia University, where they listened to Latin-American music, witnessed Spanish dances and heard two educators and a consul general plead for greater amity between the North and South Americas.

Mrs. Mildred Reubin and her interlocked twins, two daughters whose manner of birth is rare in medical history, made satisfactory progress today, hospital attendants said. A delicate obstetrical manoeuvre was necessary to save the twins, because they were lying in opposite directions but locked together, chin against chin.

Stanton St., s e cor of Allen St., 8.94x75x irreg.; Savings Banks Trust Co. to Bank for Savings; same property, City of New York to Savings Banks Trust Co.; consideration, $17,500. Henry St., 200-02, 47.6x100; 118 Suffolk Street, Inc., to Miriam Nieberg, 2 Elwood Place ($1).

Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, Atlanta, teamed with Wayne Sabin, Hollywood, today to beat Bob Kamrath, Austin, and Karl Kamrath, Houston, 6-1, 6-3, 10-8, and annex the seventh annual River Oaks tennis tournament doubles title. Grant previously ousted Wilmer Allison in the singles final.

An application for a summons against Colonel John R. Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, charging violation of the Donnelly act in forming a conspiracy in restraint of trade, was denied yesterday by Magistrate Anthony F. Burke in West Side Court.

Stocks closed steadier after declining on Supreme Court's decision upholding Wagner act; turnover, 1,135,240 shares. All groups of bonds firm and mixed in slowest trading since August; transactions, $7,964,500.

Colonel Tillinghast L'Hommedieu Huston, once the partner of Colonel Jacob Ruppert in ownership of the New York Yankees, revealed in an interview at his Butler Island headquarters last night that he had offered $1,700,000 for the Brooklyn baseball club thirty days ago. He thought the deal would go through, but it did not.

Carl R. Gray, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, will resign that position on Oct. 1, W. A. Harriman, chairman, announced yesterday. Mr. Gray, who has headed the Union Pacific seventeen years, will reach the company's retirement age of 70 a few days before the date of his retirement.
James Alexander Henderson, retired building contractor and former Bronx Superintendent of Buildings, died suddenly today of a heart attack at his home, 42 Crestwood Avenue. His age was 61.

Plans for eighty-eight new buildings estimated to cost $8,892,800 were filed during the first quarter of 1937 with the Manhattan Department of Buildings, as compared with sixty-four new projects estimated at $6,187,150 for the same period last year.

A long essay on "Collectivism: A False Utopia," has been written by William Henry Chamberlin, author of "The Russian Revolution, 19171921." He analyzes the new Soviet Constitution, which has been interpreted as hailing the birth of democracy in Russia, and finds that it leaves the fundamental bases of the one-party dictatorship unshaken. The book will be published by Macmillan on April 27.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Schmelzel and Mr. and Mrs. J. Fearon Brown gave a dinner last night in the Jade and Basildon Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Schmelzel of 1,120 Fifth Avenue and Great Oak, Ardsley-on-Hudson, parents of Mr. Schmelzel and Mrs. Brown.

tary Hull told the World Textile Conference today that the improvement of labor standards had a great bearing on the international trade situation and that the improvement of working standards would remove one of the artificial barriers to commerce.

The majority opinion on the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act as applied to the Jones Laughlin Steel Company was as follows: SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES. No. 419--October Term, 1936. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, vs. Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, on writ of certiorari to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The American Bowling Congress was relatively serene yesterday-if serenity and the thunder of pincrashing can go hand in hand-as the leaders held fast to their positions atop their divisions.

Canwell Leitch, 29-year-old handyman, who was seized last night for questioning in connection with the killing Saturday of Mrs. Gussie Dishler, 61, a rooming house keeper of 1,681 Richmond Road, Dongan Hills, S. I., confessed the crime early this morning, according to the police, and was booked on a homicide charge at St. George.

James V. Ryan and William Ryan, defending champions, advanced to the semi-finals of the national A. A. U. four-wall hardball handball doubles championship tournament by halting Joseph Ascuitto and George Morabit of the home club, 21-3, 21-7, in one of four quarter-final tests on the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. courts last night. The Ryans represent the Brooklyn Handball Club.
The price of bread in New York City was increased 1 cent a loaf yesterday by the larger baking companies. Brands that retailed for 10 cents last week now are sold for 11.

Mayor La Guardia of New York, speaking as an aviation enthusiast and "America's worst flier" in the World War, urged today that aviation be subjected to regulation by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Arthur C. MacMahon, Lewis B. Young, in 230 E. 73d St.: Bertha Waring. Lester H. Schreiber, in 150 W. 79th St.; H. Hayward Christensen, in 45 Christopher St.; through Bing Bing, Inc. Lewis Davis, in 233 W. 99th St., through Sidney Hahn, broker.

J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N. J., led the field into the second round of the United North and South tennis championship today as the nineteenth annual tournament started on the clay courts of the Pinehurst Country Club.

The strike in the Hershey chocolate plant, which last week roused some 4,000 farmers hereabouts to the wrathful expulsion of several hundred sit-down strikers who blocked the farmers' milk market, was settled late tonight.

Here are the texts of the opinions of the Supreme Court majority in Labor Board cases, involving the Fruehauf Trailer Company, the Friedman-Harry Marks Clothing Company and the Virginia and Maryland Coach Company:
Thirty-one out of thirtyeight players in a geography game at Town Hall did not know where is Thirteenth Avenue.

Although Fred Doenig limited the opposition to three hits and fanned fifteen, the Bayside High nine bowed to Flushing High, 4-1, at Memorial Field, Flushing, in one of the three games that marked the opening of the Queens Division P. S. A. L. race yesterday.

Plans to modernize several houses figuring in Manhattan deals yesterday were announced by the new owners. Among the properties involved in the trading was the fivestory tenement at 629-31 East Fifth Street,

The House voted 281 to 108 today to consider the Gavagan Anti-Lynching Bill tomorrow. The vote was upon the question of discharging the Rules Committee from consideration of the measure sponsored by Representative Joseph A. Gavagan of New York to make it a Federal offense for an officer to permit a mob to take a prisoner and injure or kill him.

Captain Anthony Linquota brought the former submarine chaser Natalie II alongside the dock here today with the Gloucester fleet's first load of mackerel. It weighed 4,000 pounds and is expected to bring 35 cents a pound retail.

Arthur M. Cathcart, law professor, predicted at the annual Stanford University alumni conference that the Supreme Court would "in a short time be aligned with the liberal and advanced views of the power of the State to regulate private business."

D'ANTONA, ATTILIO (Nov. 26, 1935). Gross assets, $428,956; net, $403,720. To Adelina d'Antona, widow, life estate; James d'Antona, son, remainder interest in one-half residue; Julia d'Antona, Marie d'Antona Melano, daughters, remainder interest in one-fourth residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $272,105. Gallert, Hilborn Raphael, attorneys, 521 5th Av.

A blistering third and last round rally enabled Gilbert Murakani, sturdy little Honolulu flyweight who won the national junior title at St. Louis last week, to beat rugged Robert Piegler, of Greenville, S. C., and move into the quarter-finals of the National A. A. U. boxing championships at the Boston Garden tonight.

SEVERAL years ago it fell to this reviewer to show an earnest young Englishman the sights of New York. The main building in Radio City was then nearing completion, and we stood on a Fifth Avenue corner staring up at the towering height. "What does it all mean?" asked the visitor finally. with a disdainful wave of his hand; "what do any of your ugly up-ended cubes mean?

The Spring dress sale at Everybody's Thrift Shop will open today at the shop, 112 East Fifty-ninth Street. The Wayside Day Nursery, the Maternity Center Association, the Association to Promote the Proper Housing for Girls, the Bryson Day Nursery, the Vanderbilt Clinic Auxiliary and the Woman's Auxiliary of Union Settlement are beneficiaries of the shop, of which Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell is president.

Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday appointed George W. Alger, lawyer, of 50 Broadway, special master to conduct hearings in the proceeding to reorganize the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

A picture of two pilots striving desperately up to the last second to save a doomed plane and the eleven persons on board, was disclosed today in the Bureau of Air Commerce accident board's report on the San Francisco Bay accident on Feb. 9.

Carrying the fight on behalf of his suspended trainer, Bert Michell, right to Florida racing officials present at this course, Emil Denemark arrived today from Chicago and announced that he would retire from racing and disperse his entire thoroughbred string, one of the largest in America, if Michell should not be completely exonerated of the doping charges leveled against him.

During a lull in the sugar conference today, while delegations from twenty-three countries worked on suggestions for the control of production and distribution for discussion beginning tomorrow, Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador-at-Large, Earnest A. entertained delegates from Britain and American countries at a private luncheon.

Trading was fair on most classes. Beef prices were steady, lambs higher, other classes steady to higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb prices to be higher. Veal about steady, beef steady to strong, as reported by the U. S. Department of Agriculture.
Twenty-five scientists staged and won a sit-down strike today in a bus taking them from Durham to the meeting of the American Chemical Society at the University of North Carolina here.

R. Bernard Crispell, an attorney with offices at 48 Wall Street, Manhattan, was in the Lawrence Hospital here today with serious internal injuries received yesterday afternoon when a horse fell on him at the Bronxville Riding Club. He has a fracture of the pelvis.

The handling of the prison labor problem demonstrates the "failure of political government in the field of business administration," the National Committee on Prisons and Prison Labor was told yesterday at its annual meeting in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

Following is the text of Governor Lehman's special message to the Legislature this evening: To the Legislature: On March 26 the Assembly passed the executive budget. It failed, however, to provide $20,000,000 of revenue to meet expenditures which its members authorized.
Industrial consumption of electric power increased 19.4 per cent during January, according to a detailed summary issued yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

During 1936 the United States supplied 8 1/2 per cent of about 83,974,000 pounds of old and over-issue newspapers imported to China, according to a report to the Department of Commerce by C. E. Christopherson, American Trade Commissioner, made public today.

Mrs. Howard L. Hughes, wife of Trenton's city librarian, received word today of the death at Monrovia, Calif., of her father, the Rev. Edward P. Rankin, Princeton University's oldest graduate. His age was 92.

It is a reportorial duty to record the fact that, so far as Washington is concerned, the Supreme Court conclusions today in the Wagner act cases were assayed exclusively on the scales of politics and not on the scales of law.

South Oak Drive (16-4603), s s, at s e s of Wallace Av., 110x58: Giuseppina Marzrano to Gaetano Failla, 784 South Oak Drive. Bryant AV. (11-2998), w s, 268 s of 176th St., 112x100; 1,821 Bryant Avenue, Inc., to 222-223 Riverside Drive Corp., 122 E. 42d Et.; mtg., $141,000.
After a week-end of private skirmishing on their own account the Giants and Indians collided here today with such terrific force as to produce no end of startling results.

Associate Justice John V. McAvoy of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department, died of heart disease yesterday morning in his home at 1,120 Park Avenue after an illness of a little more than a month. He was 58 years old.

The six-story apartment at 140-10 Franklin Avenue, on the southeast corner of Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Charles Walzer through Flushing Equities, Inc., to the Tansara Realty Corporation.

Announcement has been made by Dale Carnegie of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of his niece, Miss Josephine Dale Carnegie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Homer Clifton Carnegie of Kansas City, Mo., to Gerard B. Nolan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Nolan of Long Beach, L. I.

Wild Bill Cummings wheeled his two-man racing car around six dizzy laps at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today and climbed out to claim a one-lap record of 123.5 miles an hour for the two-and-ahalf mile course.

Although gross revenues of the Northern Pacific Railway gained substantially in March, compared with March, 1936, larger expenditures on equipment held the increase in net operating income to a small percentage, Charles Donnelly, president, said yesterday.

Protecting his grip on first place, Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., the defending world pocket billiard champion, recorded an easy 125--45 victory over Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland last night at Ponzi's Academy as he hung up his sixth triumph in seven starts.
A rare bottle of brandy donated by King George VI was sold at auction today for the benefit of Queen Charlotte's Hospital and brought [Pound]30.
Eighth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council begins at the Hotel Astor at 10 A. M., and continues tomorrow and Thurs day.
The stock markets, after opening today on a strong note, developed fresh weakness and most sections eventually lost ground.

Five more coal truck drivers pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday on misdemeanor indictments obtained recently by John B. McDermott, assistant district attorney, in his investigation of coal bootlegging.

Salvatore Ossido, 26-year- old Brooklyn barber, accused of crimnally assaulting and murdering 9year-old Einer Sporrer, German??orn parochial schoolgirl, in the back room of his barber shop three weeks ago, was declared sane yesterday in the report of a threemember commission appointed to study his mental condition.

Miss Constance Jacobsen, daughter of Mrs. Carl Labiaux Jacobsen and the late Mr. Jacobsen of this place, was married tonight to Robert William Cade. son of Mrs. William James Cade of Clifton, Bristol, England and the late Mr. Cade.
Fredric March will return to the swashbuckling school of acting, which he deserted in 1932 after completing "The Sign of the Cross," as pirate Jean Lafitte in Cecil B. De Mille's "The Buccaneer."

The "Children in American Folk Art" exhibition, arranged for the benefit of the Little Red School House scholarship fund, opened at the Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street, with a preview reception yesterday afternoon. Tickets were sold at $5 a pair. Beginning today, the show will be open to the public, price of admission being 25 cents. This work is to be on view until May 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a daily reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and as a member of the Committee for the Defense of Leon Trotsky, I want to protest the article on the "Trial for Trotsky" in your issue of April 5.

Net income of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company was $9,853,014 for 1936, after deducting depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges. This is equal to $2.56 a share on 3,840,000 no-par shares of capital stock and is compared to $7,468,017. or $1.94 a share, earned in 1935.
" Nothing can stop us now," was the keynote of the New York Rangers today, as they realized that they are only a step away from possession of the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship.
The American six-meter yachting team defeated a Bermuda group twice today and captured the Cubitt Cup, the gift of Sir Astley Cubitt, former Governor of the island. The score was 231/2 points to 19.

P. R. Bacon, director and president of Cutler-Hammer, Inc., owned 1,260 shares of its common stock at the end of last year, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. H. F. Vogt, director and vice president, owned 3,225 shares; J. C. Wilson, director and vice president, 3,230 shares, and W. C. Stevens, director, vice president and secretary, 3,160 shares.

Miss Katherine Cheney will be married Saturday at noon in St. James's Church here to George Fiske Hammond, who has arrived in his plane from Santa Barbara, Calif. Only near relatives will be present at the ceremony, which will be performed by the Rev. William P. Reidy.

A brief criticizing the Department of Justice for a statement in connection with a lawsuit between the Federal Trade Commission and the Standard Education Society has been filed in the Supreme Court by Henry Ward Beer of New York City, counsel for the society.

The Browns broke their threegame 'losing streak today, taking an 8-to-7 victory from the Cubs in ten innings. Clay Bryant's wildness helped the Browns to four runs in the seventh, but in the ninth the Cubs tied the score on Frank Demaree's homer with Rip Collins on base.
With only occasional, casual references to the Supreme Court's decisions in the Wagner act cases, the Senate Judiciary Committee gave over its entire hearing today to a Texas delegation
A delegation of 1,800 relief workers from New York City appeared at the Capitol tonight to back the Neustein bill, which, they declared, would aid them in retaining their jobs.

The possibility of the United States reversing its policy on gold, despite reassuring statements from Washington to the contrary, formed the chief topic of informal talks today among the - governors of the large European central banks, here for the monthly meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, denied in a formal statement to the Harvard Board of Overseers today, that Dr. J. Raymond Walsh and Dr. Alan R. Sweezy, instructors in the Harvard Department of Economics, were discharged because of liberal sentiments and sympathies with organized labor.

Governor Martin L. Davey barred the State House today to a band of nearly 100 relief demonstrators whom he called "Communists." The demonstrators paraded around the building this afternoon and found its doors locked and guarded.

LONDON--Foreign Secretary Eden predicted a long war in Spain and said, in the end, the Spaniards would rule the country. Meanwhile Britain would pursue no spectacular policy and so "lead Europe over a precipice." British ships were warned to avoid Bilbao and the battlecruiser Hood avoided that port.

Lexington Av., 1,936, 4-story tenement, 20x64.10; Shercoop Corp. against Pierce Manufacturing Corp.; due, $7,602; taxes, , $40; to plaintiff for $5,000, Park Av.. 1.960. 4-story tenement and stores, 20x75; Central Savings Bank of New York against Peter Ourakian: due, $6,221; taxes, , $27; to plaintiff for $1,000.

President Roosevelt has made a posthumous award of the air mail flier's Medal of Honor to Ted N. Kincannon, pilot for American Air Lines who was killed near Dallas on Jan. 29, 1936, while attempting to land a plane in a snowstorm.

To provide customers with essential information on merchandise, Bloomingdale Brothers announced yesterday that a general order has been issued to merchandise executives and buyers of the store requiring them to see that correct and more complete data on goods be furnished by manufacturers from whom they are purchased.
There were no reversals of expected form as six local foilswomen qualified at the Fencers Club last night for the national championships which will be held on the same strips April 23.

Denouncing the Nazi regime in stronger terms than ever before and prophesying its end sooner or later, Thomas Mann, German writer whom the Third Reich recently deprived of his citizenship, said yesterday that dictatorships in Europe in general and Nazism in particular were doomed.

With seven officials of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union already under charge of conspiracy and with a "padlock" law in force giving the Provincial government power to suppress any movement which it wishes to call bolshevistic, labor circles here fear a drive against C. I. O. organizers in Quebec similar to that initiated by Premier Hepburn in Ontario.

The Beethoven Association closed its nineteenth annual season at the Town Hall last night with a well made program that was stirringly performed. The guest artists were Josef Hofmann, Yella Pessl, George Barrere and the Curtis String Quartet, consisting of Jascha Brodsky, Charles Jaffe, Max Aronoff and Orlando Cole.
Members of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service will hold a reception this afternoon in the Candlelight Room at 14 East Sixtieth Street.

Labor leaders of the State and city, backed by State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews, attorney for trade unions and others interested in problems of labor relations, yesterday hailed the series of decisions by the United States Supreme Court upholding the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Disputes Act as paving the road for "industrial democracy" and ushering in an "era of economic peace."

THE WOODROW WILSONS, by Eleanor Wilson McAdoo. (Macmillan, $3.50.) An intimate account of the Wilsons' family life. DANCE OF THE QUICK AND THE DEAD, by Sacheverell Sitwell. (Houghton Mifflin, $4.25.) An "oblique survey of Life and Art."

Lending major league aid to the development of semi-professional baseball, Ford Frick, National League president, yesterday approved selection of the veteran arbiter, Ernie Quigley, as umpire-inchief of the national semi-pro tournament this Summer, according to The Associated Press.

The War De partment released the following orders to day, dated April 10: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Crowley, F. C. V. Cav., Washington, D. C. detailed with the organized reserves, De troit, Mich. Brown, S. G., Inf.. Fort Benning. Ga., de tailed with National Guard Bureau a Washington, D. C.

Queen Mary will wear a gown of supple cloth of gold for the coronation ceremonies May 12. The gown, designed by Reville of London, will be hand-embroidered with silver and diamante in a cascading design of roses and fuchsias. Small sleeves of gold lace will be edged with tiny rose leaves.

Harper Av., 3.811, 33x100; Home Owners Loan Corp. against John H. Wall; due. $5.478; taxes, , $283; to plaintiff for $500. University Av., 1,494, 5-story tenement, 54.10x137.1, Irregular; New York Life Insurance Co. against Haru Realty Corp.; due, $67,503; to plaintiff for $16,000.

There can be no rest at present for Premier Paul van Zeeland. Experts of the Oslo group of nations arrived here today for a four-day session of the Scandinavian powers, reinforced by the Netherlands and Belgium, with the British and the French in close contact if not actual participants.

In the hotel where in July the West agreed to return the Dardanelles Straits to Turkey there opened today a conference to abolish the capitulations in Egypt. The conference opened with virtually no doubt as to the outcome. Every one agrees the capitulations will go, the only question being how, with what transition.

Keres of Estonia, who opened the international chess masters' tournament at the Ostend Casino with a victory over Reuben Fine of New York, was again in brilliant form today as he defeated P. O. List, Germany's representative, in 33 moves.
News of the long-awaited Supreme Court decision with respect to the Wagner Labor Relations Act caused little more than a ripple in the markets yesterday.

The committee of savings banks and insurance companies headed by John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, is nearing an agreement with the management of the Missouri Pacific Railroad on a plan of reorganization for that company, according to a statement to bondholders of the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway (Gulf Coast Lines) by a committee headed by G. H. Walker.

As the Dominion Government in Ottawa offered its mediation in the automobile strike at Oshawa and Premier Mitchell Hepburn made public concessions in behalf of General Motors of Canada, Ltd., designed to end the strike, it was learned today that a crisis had arisen in the Ontario Cabinet over reported opposition to the Premier's position in the situation.

Following is the text of the opinion of the Supreme Court minority dealing with the Jones Laughlin, Fruehauf and Fried man cases: SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES. Numbers 419, 420-21, 422-23-October Term, 1936. 419, National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, vs. Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation on writ of certiorari to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Pomp and circumstance of Britain's Tower of London were transplanted in New York City at noon yesterday as an exhibit of reproductions of the crown jewels was opened to the public in Bloomingdale's.

Lord and Lady Revelstoke, Sir William Wiseman and Jascha Heifetz are among the passengers due tonight from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others on the ship include Mr. and Mrs. W. P. Lipscomb, Captain and Mrs. C. D. Miller, Mr. and Mrs. George P. Dunn, Mrs. L. C. Enright, Mr. and Mrs. Eric Stanley, Colonel G. H. Walton, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Noble, Mrs. P. S. Comstock and Peter Macdonald.

Harry H. Levey, an advertising agent who formerly had an office at 1,328 Broadway, went on trial before Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday on a indictment of two counts of mail fraud whereby he was alleged to have defrauded newspapers and a bank.

A plan to reorganize the closed $24,000,000 Lawyers Mortgage Company, with the cooperation of creditors and stockholders, was submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler by James A. Martin, who had been appointed as referee to determine what should be done with its assets and liabilities.

Jennie Wernick assigned two mortgages, each about 30 years old, on 447 Water St., to Garland Galloway as trustee. A mortgage for $12,000 on 430 W. 56th St. was assigned by the Presprop Corporation to the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church.

ABELES, HENRY (April 2). Estate, less than $10,000. To Irma A. Feldstein, 895 West End Av. BURKHAM, CAROLINE TOUSEY (March 4). Estate, more than $20,000. To Anna P. Burkham, niece, Cincinnati; Kathleen Burkham Sullivan, niece, Lawrenceburg, Ind.; Lucie Burkham Read, niece,

Donald E. Bates, president of the Reo Motor Car Company, has addressed a letter to stockholders asserting that the company has more unfilled orders on its books than it has had at any time during the last seven years, and urging that proxies be signed in favor of the management and not of any other group.

At Ettore, Philadelphia's high-rank. ing heavyweight, soundly trounced Freddie Fiducia of Newark to win a decision in the feature ten-round boxing bout at Laurel Garden tonight. Ettore weighed 193 1/2 Fiducia 184.

Most of the concessions at. the World's Fair in 1939 will be auctioned off to the highest qualified bidders to insure high standards and to obtain the best income for the fair corporation, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the corporation.

The Securities and Exchange Commission received today evidence intended to show that, while an investment trust lost about one-third of its $6,500,000 assets in the 1929 crash, its organizer and controlling figure drew almost $500,000 for his services.

Marking a departure from its previous policy, the State Department, in announcing impending negotiations for a trade agreement with Ecuador, has listed the specific products on which possible duty concessions will be granted to that country.

Holders of common stock of the G. C. Murphy Company have received a letter from J. S. Mack, president, advising them that rights to subscribe to one share of common stock at $60 a share for each thirty shares held on April 5 will expire at 2 P. M. on May 10.

Representative heavy industries were in a wholly philosophical mood with respect to the National Labor Relations Act decisions handed down yesterday, since most of the companies have learned to live with the modern labor leaders and most of the agreements reached are of such nature that labor hardly will be in the position of looking to the provisions of the act for relief.

Otto Karl Ludwig, a German, was charged today with violation of the Official Secrets Act. He had been arrested early Saturday morning when he landed at Harwich from a British steamer aboard which he had come from the Netherlands.
The pre-season announcement from New Jersey's Board of Fish and Game Commissioners is exceedingly optimistic.

Getting away from Florida and minor league opposition wasn't healthy for the Dodgers, Today John Lanning set them back on their heels with three hits in nine innings, while the Bees fell upon George Jeffcoat and Jim Peterson for ine to win, 8-1.

Federal Judge Leibell signed yesterday a consent injunction under which Connor, Leach Co. and others promised to refrain permanently from selling the common stock of the American Consolidated Tin Mines Corporation.
The Senate Committee on Commerce voted unanimously today to recommend confirmation of all five nominees to the Maritime Commission.

The annual report for 1936 of the Standard Oil Company of California, released for publication today, shows consolidated net income of $23,310,223 after all charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation and depletion, equal to $1.78 a share on the 13,102,900 shares of common capital stock.

Expansion of the Weather Bureau service to provide "up-todate and modern methods of forecasting floods" was announced here today by Merrill Bernard of Washington, chief of the River and Flood Division.

Rumors of impending changes in the Group Theatre came to a head yesterday with the announcement that Cheryl Crawford and Lee Strasberg have resigned from its board of governors. They had been associated with the organization since it was founded six years ago, and were co-directors of its first Broadway production, "The House of Connelly," in 1931.

Officials of the New Haven Railroad announced the death today in Daytona Beach, Fla., of Herbert J. Reynolds of Pelham Manor, N. Y., assistant superintendent of the New York division. He had been ill since September. His age was 69.

A warning that the government had almost exhausted the sources of taxation to which it was "willing and able to resort," and that unless drastic retrenchments in Federal expenditures follow it would be necessary to enact new tax legislation, was given in the Senate today by Senator Robinson of Arkansas, administration leader.

Leon Trotsky produced strong evidence this afternoon before the subcommission of inquiry headed by Professor John Dewey to prove he had never had meetings in Copenhagen in 1932 with those convicted by Moscow of having plotted a terrorist campaign in the Soviet Union.

The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has reversed a plan of reorganization of the Louisiana Oil Refining Corporation of Shreveport, which had been approved in November. 1936, by Federal Judge Ben C. Dawkins of the Western Louisiana District Federal Court.
More than 300,000 persons are enrolled in the three-cents-a-day plan of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, it is announced in the current issue of the Hospital Service News.

Dr. and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Sophie Kilbreth and Ernest Patrick Bernuth, whose marriage will take place next Saturday in Trinity Church, Hewlett, L. I.
Government troops fought desperately but successfully today to keep the Insurgents in University City bottled up after destroying their only bridge last night.

The marriage of Miss Bernice Rentner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Rentner of 55 Central Park West and Larchmont Manor, N. Y., to Arthur Jablow, son of George Jablow of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Pierre.

Morris Glaser, 34 years old, of 326 West Hudson Street, Long Beach. L. I., pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to usury after investigation by James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, into the so-called garnishee racket, in which city employes were alleged to have been victimized of more than $1,000,000 in recent years.
A message from Governor Lehman congratulating the Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes on his eightyfifth birthday, which occurs today, was made Public yesterday.

Thanks less to diplomatic negotiations than to trade revival, which is easing all economic problems and relaxing international tensions, Japan now has not a single important trade dispute open, said Eiji Amau, the Foreign Office spokesman, today.

In a circular letter issued today in connection with the Prince Nicholas affair, Prince Charles Adolp Cantacuzinu, leader of the Fascist Iron Guard, sharply attacked not only Premier George Tatarescu, but King Carol and Mrs. Magda Lepescu. The letter was distributed among Iron Guard commanders. The letter says:

Patrolman Solomon Goldstein, who rescued a duck with an injured wing, and 180 other policemen who made rescues of animals or assisted in them in the past year, received certificates of honor yesterday from the Humane Society.

John Corson Blair, New York lawyer, and Miss Cynthia Ann Wills of 179 East Seventy-ninth Street, obtained a marriage license at the Municipal Building yesterday and said they would be married on April 21 in the Church of the Ascension.

Bond prices held within an exceptionally restricted range yesterday in the slowest trading since Aug. 26, last year. Compared with the activity and price fluctuations of the last four weeks or so, the market came virtually to a standstill as traders took to the sidelines to await some definite indications of the next major movement. Total transactions in all bonds on the Stock Exchange amounted to $7,964,500, compared with $12,200,??00 on last Friday.

Exports to the United States from China in 1936 were valued at $77, ??19,386, compared with $66,864,838 ??n 1935, according to a report today to the Department of Commerce from L. H. Gourley, United States Consul at Shanghai.
Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, will be the guest speaker at the luncheon of The Associated Press members at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel next Monday.

Mrs. Lionel Sutro was re-elected chairman of the Manhattan division of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom at the annual meeting held yesterday afternoon at 150 Fifth Avenue. Other members presented by Miss Caroline Singer, chairman of nominations, were approved.
Commissioner John McMillan, territorial commander of the Salvation Army in Canada, was promoted today to the organization's No. 2 post, that of chief of staff to General Evangeline Booth.

Control of all the outstanding stock of the United Broadcasting Company of Delaware has been acquired by the Phillips Petroleum Company, according to the latter concern's report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May, in Special Term, Jamaica, reserved decision yesterday on a motion to vacate a temporary injunction granted last Friday against the American Newspaper Guild and its subsidiary organizations in the New York area, including the Long Island Daily Press unit of the guild, which is on strike against the Long Island Daily Press.

William F. Marshall, 40 years old, of 111-42 203d Street, Hollis, Queens, former assistant cashier of the Kingsboro National Bank at Sixtyninth Street and Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, who is alleged to have embezzled $45,000 in bank funds with which he pyramided stock market deals until he had a paper fortune of $1,000,000, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn Federal Court to serve eighteen months in a Federal penitentiary.
Alexander Meyer, nineteen-yearold dairy farmer, was sentenced to death in the electric chair by two judges of the Chester County Court today for the murder of Helen Moyer, 16.

The eightieth session of the Newark Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church came to a close at St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church today with the reading of pastoral appointments by Bishop Francis J. McConnell.

Retired Captain Daniel Donovan, formerly a member of Engine 247, residing at 647 Warburton Av., Yonkers, N. Y., died April 8. Retired Fireman Eugene A. O'Brien, formerly a member of Engine 238. residing at 241-14 138th Av., Rosedale, Queens, died April 8.

Shampan Shampan are drawing plans for a $50,000 business building containing ten stores, to be erected on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of 63d Drive and Austin St., Rego Park, by the Long Beach Equities, Inc., owner.
Traffic accidents, fatalities and the number of persons injured on the city streets all declined sharply last week and week-end, compared with figures for the corresponding periods of last year.

Since Pan American Airways announced the opening of passenger service on April 28 across the Pacific, thus closing the last airline gap, its traffic department has been flooded with mail from prosspective passengers who want to go around the world by air.

President Roosevelt is perhaps the "outstanding salesman" in the country today, and if he had not gone in for politics could have made his fortune in the selling field, George R. Lightowler, personnel consultant, declared yesterday at a symposium on "How to Pick Good Men," held by the Sales Executives Club of New York, at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Aldous Huxley, British novelist and essayist, arrived yesterday from London on the French liner Normandie, on his third visit to America. He was accompanied by Mrs. Huxley and their 17-year-old son, Matthew. After a few days in New York Mr. Huxley will motor to Colorado for a three-month stay.
The Federal Music Project of the WPA presented last night in the Theatre of Music its most recent experiment in chamber opera, and this with conspicuous success.
Resolutions ranging from birth control to discretion in deportation of aliens of good moral character were approved this afternoon by the State conference of the National Council of Jewish Women.

Announcement has been made or the marriage Sunday of Miss Marguerite Harris Jacques, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jacques of 431 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, to Sam La Barba, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony La Barba of Brooklyn.
The House completed Congressional action today on the Guffey Soft Coal Bill, approving a conference committee report which adjusted Senate and House differences on the legislation.

Contracts for $18,000,000 of work on the Thirty-eighth Street Midtown Tunnel to Queens will be advertised by the New York City Tunnel Authority tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by A. B. Jones, chairman.

Suit has been instituted in the Supreme Court seeking to hold the National City Bank of New York responsible for non-payment of interest and amortization of a $30,000,000 issue of bonds issued by the United Steel Works of Germany, for which it is trustee, it was disclosed yesterday.

Captain H. T. (Dick) Merrill, pilot employed by Eastern Air Lines, set a new commercial record for the distance yesterday when he flew a twenty-one passenger plane of his company from Newark to Miami in 5 hours and 26 minutes. The scheduled time for the 1,192. mile trip is 7 hours and 40 minutes.

General Francisco Franco's intelligence service has in its possession evidence it considers accurate that French aviation schools train fliers for the Valencia government's air force with the French Government's full knowledge and tolerance.

An improvised celebration of the Supreme Court decision in The Associated Press case was held last night at the Ritz Theatre after the performance of "Power" produced by the WPA Living Newspaper, which Morris Watson has headed since his dismissal by The Associated Press.
The victory for the government in the Wagner act decisions was hailed by opponents of President Roosevelt's plan for reorganization of the Federal judiciary as a "death blow" to his hopes.

The annual convention of the Fiftieth District, Rotary International, opened in the Convention Hall here today with 1,200 delegates attending. After lengthy discussion it was voted to have the subject of dividing the district reopened.
A 14-year-old boy held up his mother in gangster fashion with an army pistol in an East Side flat yesterday when the mother was unable to produce 10 cents which the youngster wanted to see a movie.

Gross premiums of the Maryland Casualty Company for the first quarter of 1937 were $8,129,653, a rise of $491,886 over the corresponding period in 1936, according to Silliman Evans, chairman of the board. Net premiums rose $667,676,

With the same dramatic earnestness and in the same startling circumstances under which he denounced the goldclause decisions two years ago, Justice McReynolds sharply dissented today from the majority opinion of the Supreme Court in the Jones Laughlin and two other manufacturing cases involving the Wagner act, and assailed the views expressed in the prevailing opinion.

Twenty-eight State prison guards were taken directly into the city Fire Department yesterday for an Intensive two weeks of training designed to equip them to handle fire prevention and fire fighting in their institutions.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will leave on his first trip to Europe on May 15, it was learned yesterday. Reservations for his party have been made on the Conte di Savoia of the Italian Line.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 9: CAPTAINS Atkins, A. K., Navy Yard, New York N. Y., to duty as Naval Inspector of Machinery and Inspector of Navigation at Materiel, New York Shipbuilding Corporation, Camden, N. J., about July 1.
Charles Henry Meyer, assistant vice president of the Bronx County Trust Company, which he had served for forty-three years, died today in the Mount Vernon Hospital. He was 59 years old. Mr.

Villanova College lost to the Phillies in a charity game today, 15--2, before a crowd of 5,000. The National Leaguers pounded Bill McLoughlin out of the box in the second inning by bunching five hits, including a three-bagger by Claude Passeau.

The block bounded by First Avenue, Forty-first and Forty-second Streets and the East River, title to which has been transferred to the city by the Consolidated Edison Company, will be utilized in the construction of the new vehicular tunnel to Queens. The indicated consideration was $1,230,000.

Hugh Thompson, organizer for the Committee for Industrial Organization, dedared tonight that the United Automobile Workers of America will be the sole collective bargaining force for General Motors employes in both the United States and Canada as a result of the United States Supreme Court's decision on the National Labor Act.
stock, $1 par value, has been admitted to listing by the New York Stock Exchange.

Robert A. Wheeler, in charge of publicity for the International Nickel Company, was elected president of the Technical Publicity Association, Inc., at the group's annual meeting last night in the Arkwright Club.
Movements on the Chicago livestock markets today. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Princeton's hopes for its most successful baseball season in recent years rose to new heights today as the veteran Dick Bell set down the hitherto undefeated Penn State nine with two hits and aided the Tigers to turn back the visitors, 3 to 1, for their sixth consecutive victory.

Upholding the District Court, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here rejected yesterday the suit of Norman C. Norman, retired jeweler, who had sought as a stockholder to prevent the Consolidated Edison Company from paying taxes under the old age provisions of the Social Security Act.

John C. Koons, vice president of the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company, died here today while attending a meeting of the board of directors of a savings and loan association. He was 64 years old.

Stanley H. Rolfe, City Superintendent of Schools, ordered today an inquiry into the school standing of Mrs. Leroy Steinbach, 14 years old, who as Margaret Waldron was a freshman in Westside High School.

Jack Tabata, 29 years old, a Japanese, was pummeled by a crowd of fifty persons at noon yesterday after an attempted attack upon Sigmund Leder, 30, manager of a butcher shop at 130 Moore Street, Brooklyn.

The annual report of the Philadelphia Company and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, depreciation, taxes and other charges, of $8,597,766, compared to $8,004,608 in the preceding year.
G. M. Hubbard has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that he has resigned as a director of the General Reinsurance Corporation.

Vincent J. McMann of New York lost today in the Supreme Court in his protest against an effort by the Securities Commission to obtain records of his stock market transactions held by his broker, Engel Co.

The State of California has invited tenders for an issue of $2,241,596 of registered warrants, it was announced yesterday. Award of the issue will be made tomorrow. Ramsey County, Minn. Tenders will be considered on May 3, by officials of Ramsey County, Minn, for a new issue of $400,000 of public welfare bonds, to be dated May 1, 1937, and maturing from May 1, 1939 to 1947.

District Attorney William C. Dodge declined to say yesterday whether he would seek the indict ment of Robert Irwin, 29-year-old sculptor and former theological student, who has been accused by the police of the murders on Easter Sunday of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter, Veronica, and their roomer, Frank Byrnes.

William C. Hunt, Republican, of Cape May County, whose election in November was set aside last week by Circuit Judge Wilfred H. Jayne as a result of ballot box frauds, resigned tonight from the State Senate instead of facing an impending ouster by a coalition of Democratic and Republican colleagues.

Jacob C. Morse, member of The Boston Traveler sports staff, pioneer baseball writer here, former secretary of the old New England League and a founder of Baseball Magazine, died today at his home in Brookline, in his seventy-seventh year.

The eagerly awaited decisions of the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act have now resulted in a sweeping victory for the Government. Five test cases were involved.

Scraping the fence from the break to the top of the stretch, the bay colt, Aneroid, at last got racing room and whipped around the leaders to capture the $6,825 Harford Handicap before an opening day crowd of 12,000 today.

Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that the tenders for $50,000,000 or thereabouts of 273-day Treasury bills, dated April 14, 1937, and maturing on Jan. 12, 1938, which were offered on April 9, amounted to $126,121,000, of which $50,022,000 was accepted.
On of the real surprises of the Easter season came today in the award in the junior all-age stake of th?? annual meeting at the Jockey Ho low Field Trial Club.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Federal Social Security Board, estimated yesterday that 42,770 persons in this State would be entitled to lump sum payments under the old-age benefit title of the Social Security Act in 1937.

A new method which makes it possible for the first time to create millions of new synthetic chemicals out of sugars, starches and cellulose was reported here today at the opening sessions of the annual Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society at the University of North Carolina.

Ephraim Mead died at his home, 240 Milbank Avenue, Greenwich, today, after a long illness. He was 81 years old. Mr. Mead was born here, oldest of seven sons of the late Isaac Howe Mead and Mary E. Mead.

The propaganda trial of seven Catholics before the People's Court opened a new week today with the presiding judge still employing every opportunity to heckle the defendants and laud the National Socialist point of view.
Jubilant over the Supreme Court's decisions, leaders of organized labor were confident today that the opportunity was at hand to build, within a year, the most powerful labor movement in the world.

The Presbytery of New York voted yesterday to hold a special meeting April 26 to consider the recently announced plans of the Brick Presbyterian Church to move from its present location at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street to Park Avenue between Ninety-first and Ninety-second Street.
Fritz George Schmidt, an optician with offices at 49 West Forty-sixth Street, New York, died here today at his home. He was 73 years old.
The Belgian election was as clean-cut a fight between a democratic government in power and aFascist leader seeking power as has been waged anywhere since the triumph of HITLER in Germany.

Commodity futures were lower in active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber futures broke severely, and silk, copper, tin, lead, cocoa, hide, coffee, world sugar and cottonseed oil futures also lost ground. Domestic sugar and wool top futures ruled steady.

Endorsement of Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn is expected at a meeting of the Kings County committee of the City Fusion party Thursday evening. The meeting will be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

A settlement of the Keelung, Formosa, incident of last Autumn, in which three sailors from a British warship were abused by a Japanese policeman and a British officer was rudely treated, was reached yesterday.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,820,623,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

Tibor Eckhardt, leader of the Agrarian party, who more than any one else is responsible for the revelation of a Fascist conspiracy in Hungary, with the formation of cells within the armed forces and official bodies, again warned yesterday of the continued danger of a Fascist revolution and declared the Fascist party was receiving foreign support.

The former Amy Dakin residence in New Castle. Westchester County, has been sold to N. H. Garrett through the office of James F. Greene. The same broker negotiated a lease to Harold T. Gavitt of a new Colonial residence in Bedford Ridge.
B. F. Avery Sons Company common stock, $5 par, and Clark Controller Company common stock, $1 par value, have been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange.

For the first time in American history, industries organized on a national scale, though their products are locally manufactured, were held by the Supreme Court today to come specifically within the regulatory powers of the Congress.
President Roosevelt's sentiments on the Supreme Court decision were made known in a telephone call to Speaker Bankhead congratulating him on his sixty-third birthday.

A resolution appealing to Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin to intervene and prevent the public ox-roasting ceremonies proposed for various centers in Britain during the coronation festivities was adopted today at a public meeting composed largely of Hindus and Jains here.
Former King Alfonso's 73-year-old aunt demanded tonight that he be restored to the Spanish throne in reward for financial aid to the Insurgent General Francisco Franco.

By unanimous vote, the Assembly tonight passed three concurrent resolutions proposing amendments to the State Constitution to provide four-year terms for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Controller and Attorney General, and two-year terms for Assemblymen and to permit Sheriffs to succeed themselves.

Representatives of the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union conferred again yesterday with William R. Burrows, vice president of the General Electric Company, on the union's demand for a pay increase of 10 cents an hour for 47,000 of the company's employes.

Mrs. Johanna Christensen of East Orange again joined the picket line in front of her husband's plant--the Button Corporation of America--for a time here today, posed with a sign declaring "Button King Unfair," encouraged the strikers and bought hamburgers, cake and coffee for all.

Eight new governors for the New York Stock Exchange were nominated yesterday, indicating that the election on May 10 will see the greatest turnover on record. Only four of the retiring governors were renominated.

SERGEANT-James J. Fox, 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector, designated as acting lieutenant. PATROLMEN-John J. Meehan, from Borough Headquarters Squad, BrooklynRichmond to 80th Precinct, assignment to clerical duty discontinued.

Weakness in the wheat markets abroad and a decline in commodities in general started a liquidating movement in grains on the Board of Trade here today which continued until the close. Final sales were within small fractions of the lowest levels of the day with wheat futures 2 1/4 to 3 cents a bushel lower.

Four Princeton University juniors studying in the School of Public and International Affairs have received scholarships for study in Europe this Summer, it was announced today by Professor Dewitt Clinton Poole, director of the school.
Head officials of the United Automobile Workers Union who were in Detroit today expressed their gratification over the Supreme Court's decision on the Wagner Act.

Trls Speaker, one of the greatest players in baseball history, was fighting for his life today in Cleveland's Lakeside Hospital. He suffered a fractured skull yesterday when he fell sixteen feet to a stone walk while putting up a flower box at his home.
Tense peace hung over this zinc and lead mining area today as county officials sought to fix responsibility for shootings and floggings which brought an inter-union feud to a bloody climax yesterday.
Federal Judge Philip Forman of New Jersey married Miss Pearl Karlberg of Trenton, his secretary, here today.

The efforts of more than 7,000 persons who signed petitions urging Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College to waive an agelimit ruling which would force the 65-year-old Professor William H. Kilpatrick to retire from active service after the present college session were finally frustrated yesterday.

Mrs. Junis Ambrose Rawlings of El Paso, Texas, has announced to friends here the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Mary Jeannette Rawlings, to Karl Emory Robinson of New York. son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Robinson of Greenburg, Pa.

The National Industrial Traffic League yesterday distributed to its members throughout the country the report of a special committee opposing the proposed reorganization of the Interstate Commerce Commission and its assignment to the supervision of the Secretary of Commerce.

The story of WALTER REED, CARLOS FINLAY, JESSE LAZEAR and ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE and the American soldiers who permitted themselves to be inoculated by stegomyia mosquitos has been so deeply impressed on the public mind that yellow fever, once a scourge, was supposed to be conquered. Havana, which had never been free from the disease for two centuries, became a veritable health resort after GORGAS cleaned it up.

James H. Edwards, New York financial expert, who has contracted with the Nicaraguan Government to straighten out financial and exchange difficulties, arrived here yesterday by airplane from Panama. He is accompanied by his wife.
In the eight months ending Feb. 28, 11,208,338 proof gallons of imported distilled liquors entered into American domestic consumption, James H. Moyle, Commissioner of Customs, reported today.
Comment in official and Congressional circles on the Supreme Court's decisions upholding the Wagner Labor Relations Act included the following:

The National Industrial Traffic League yesterday distributed to its members throughout the country the report of a special committee opposing the proposed reorganization of the Interstate Commerce Commission and its assignment to the supervision of the Secretary of Commerce.

Havana, which had never been free from the disease for two centuries, became a veritable health resort after GORGAS cleaned it up.

James H. Edwards, New York financial expert, who has contracted with the Nicaraguan Government to straighten out financial and exchange difficulties, arrived here yesterday by airplane from Panama. He is accompanied by his wife.
In the eight months ending Feb. 28, 11,208,338 proof gallons of imported distilled liquors entered into American domestic consumption, James H. Moyle, Commissioner of Customs, reported today.
Comment in official and Congressional circles on the Supreme Court's decisions upholding the Wagner Labor Relations Act included the following:
A crowd of 4,000 saw Salvy Saban, Greenwich Village welterweight, win a hard fought bout from Frankie Cavanna, of the East Side in the feature eight-rounder at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Extensive local newspaper advertising, radio broadcasts by the Federal Housing Administration and the free distribution of 1,000,000 copies of Small Homes Magazine will be used around June 1 to launch the drive for the erection of 450,000 new low-cost homes this year.

Arthur Friedman, 20 years old, of 444 Claremont Avenue, the Bronx, one of the three suspects being held in the fatal shooting of Detective Michael J. Foley early Saturday in the hold-up of the Boulevard Restaurant at 144 Second Avenue, was examined yesterday by Dr. Perry M. Lichtenstein on his charge that the police beat him after the holdup.
Frank H. Lee, 70-year-old hat manufacturer, died last night at his home here after an illness of several months.

For a great many years the American people have been searching for the right answer to the question which the Supreme Court discussed on Monday. Under a Federal system of government, in which power is deliberately divided between the States and the

John Henry Lewis, Pittsburgh, Negro holder of the world's lightheavyweight title, scored a technical knockout over Harold Murphy, Springfield, Mo., in the fourth round of their scheduled ten-round, non-title bout tonight.

The New York City Bar Association adopted a resolution last light condemning the practice of judges of lending their names to various charities, benefit dinners and similar enterprises, and recommended to its members that they refuse to yield to any such solicitations either by or in behalf of any judge.

Northern New York Area The following prospective R. O. T. C. graduates of the University of Michigan, recently released to this headquarters for assignment are tentatively assigned as indicated, effective upon acceptance of appointment in the Officers Reserve Corps:

The final concert of the season by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski conducting, was conspicuous, as may be assumed in advance when this masterly conductor appears, for the superb playing and for an innovation, where symphonic concerts in New York are concerned, in the form of an

More than $6,000,000 in losses to the oyster crop during the 1936-37 season have been caused by small marine snails known as oyster drills, Frank T. Bell, Commissioner of Fisheries, said today. In Delaware Bay more than $1,000,000 worth of oysters have been killed.

Rudy Dusek of Omaha defeated Abe Coleman of New York last night in the feature wrestling bout at the St. Nicholas Palace. Dusek, weighing 218, pinned his 205-pound rival in 31:29 with a flying tackle and body press. Scotty McDougall, 218, Canada, threw Bobby Roberts, 207, Dayton, in 21:16 of a scheduled half-hour bout. In another listed for the same distance Charley Santon, 220, Omaha, pinned Sandor Vary, 215, Hungary, with a body slam.

Research into the production of fish for angling in the lakes and streams of the country by improvement of waters rather than by artificial planting is asked of the American Wildlife Institute by its technical committee, headed by Dr. Aldo Leopold, Professor of Game Management, University of Wisconsin.

Miss Martha Fuller Stamford of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Boyd Stamford of Pittsburgh, Pa., has chosen May 1 as the date for her marriage to Ralph Herbert Teichert, son of Mrs. Otto Teichert of Clifton, N. J., and the late Mr. Teichert.

As an aftermath of the tenement house fire at 710 East 149th Street, which took two lives early last Sunday morning, the Board of Aldermen adopted a resolution yesterday calling for an increase in the number of inspectors in the Tenement House Department.

Henry methods Ford declared today that his employes were "free to join anything they want to." "They have always been free to join any church, any lodge or any huge union they want to," he said in his first interview after the Supreme Court decision upholding the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

George Alexander, former president of the local Board of Education and an executive of the old Nairn Linoleum Company here and in Scotland, for many years, died suddenly of a heart attack in his home here this afternoon. He was 72 years old.
Five paintings by well-known American artists have been bought for the permanent collection of the University of Nebraska, according to announcement made here yesterday.

Writing of new life insurance last month was 19 per cent higher than in March a year ago, and the total for the first quarter of this year was 8.8 per cent more than for the same three months of 1936, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

In a day of continued active leasing of commercial space, brokers reported yesterday two leases to agencies of the Federal Government in the midtown area-the Social Security Board and the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department. The contracts generally
Dr. E. B. Castle, attending physician, said tonight Tris Speaker, baseball immortal whose skull was fractured Sunday in a sixteen-foot fall from a porch, "is getting along pretty well."
Abdulhak Hamid Bey, the poet who was called "the Turkish Shakespeare," died last night. His age was 86.

President Roosevelt ordered a resurvey of departmental expenses with a view to reduction for the 1937 fiscal year and indicated at a press conference that he would insist upon adoption of his courts reorganization plan despite recent Supreme Court rulings.

John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization has started a drive to form the 8,000 workers at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn in a C. I. O. unit, it was disclosed yesterday. The United Shipbuilders

Transfers of two Manhattan properties bought many years ago . were filed yesterday in the Register's office. One of the deeds covered the property at 31 West Seventeenth Street, on which the date of the deed was Jan. 25, 1910. The other,

The Bernese mountain dog was admitted as a breed into the Stud Book of the American Kennel Club yesterday by the board of directors at the regular monthly meeting. At the same time a standard of perfection was approved thus enabling the breed to compete in shows held under the rules of the A. K. C.

Rochester, N. Y., awarded yesterday to a banking syndicate headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago, a new issue of $2,000,000 of public welfare bonds, dated March 1, 1937, and maturing serially from March 1, 1940 to 1944. The price paid was 100.347 for 21/4 per cent bonds.

Two gunmen who carried a pair of handcuffs in a paper bag locked a payroll-bearer to a washroom pipe yesterday and escaped with $1,542. The victim, Ralph Freedman, 22 years old, is the son of Alex Freedman, proprietor of the A. F. Dress Company, 347 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Education today must fit graduates to cope with shifting demands for jobs of various kinds, Dr. Arthur E. Bestor, president of Chautauqua Institution, told the graduating class of the Mechanics Institute last night at the exercises at the Town Hall, 123 West Fortythird Street.

Miss Edith Eyre Schippers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Schippers of 219 Melbourne Road, has completed plans for her marriage to Paul Phillippi Huffard Jr., which will take place on the night of May 14 in All Saints Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Alexander
