Inspite the railroad representatives of the railroad management and employes and the Treasury Department to agree as yet on the rates of assessment to be contained in the new railroad retirement act, Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that Congress would "go ahead' in drafting the legislation.

Letters, telegrams and cablegrams from many parts of the world arrived today at the home here of the Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, rabbi emeritus of the old Spanish and Portuguese synagogue in New York, on his eighty-fifth birthday. Among those who sent

By a unanimous voice vote the Connecticut House today passed a bill creating a Legislative Council. The measure was the second to win approval of the Republicancontrolled House in a program to reorganize the State's 300-year-old governmental structure.

The attempt of a majority of the City Affairs Committee and the board of governors of the New York Young Republican Club to have the club endorse Mayor La Guardia for renomination on the Republican ticket will be resisted at a meeting to be held tonight in the National Republican Club.

Sheriff St., 124, 24x100; Bowery Savings Bank to Joseph Genovese, 40 Hampton St.. Elmhurst ($11). Stanton St., 188. 24.6x70; Cufasa Realty Corp. to Louis Halpern, 227 E. 2d St. ($2). Laight St., 36, and 15 Vestry St., 23 on former and 20.5 on latter; trustees will of Samuel Weil to Louise H. Archibald, 42 Perry St.; mtg. $20,000, consideration $1.

The third annual two-day dog show of the Tri-State Kennel Association opened this morning in the Auditorium with an entry of 341 dogs, representing thirty-three breeds, the largest exhibition ever given by the club. Most of the judging was handled by Alfred Delmont of Wynnewood, Pa.

Total shipments of all types of hosiery in February amounted to 11,473,837 dozen pairs, compared with 8,662,068 dozen pairs in the corresponding period last year according to figures issued yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

In an effort to increase Greece's revenues the Greek Government is preparing to extend the State monopolies to include gasoline, kerosene and other fuels. When the Turkish Government recently introduced a fuel oil monopoly Athens manifested great interest in the financial results.
The Prussian Geological Society has declined an invitation to attend the International Geological Congress in Moscow at the end of July.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest your recent editorial dealing with cancer research and Dr. Francis Carter Wood's letter printed in your issue of April 4.

Argentine's exports for the first quarter of 1937 established a record at 840,006,117 pesos ($280,100,000 at the official rate of exchange), according to the Argentine Information Bureau. The previous record

Captain Archibald Magill Fauntleroy, Medical Corps, U. S. N., retired, died yesterday afternoon at the Harkness Pavilion of the Presbyterian Medical Center, after a short illness. He was 60 years old.
Larz Anderson, one-time Ambassador to Japan, died today at the Greenbrier Hotel, where he had been ill for five weeks.

To provide an adequate highway link between Brooklyn and the World's Fair site in the Flushing Meadows, Queens, Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, suggested yesterday that part of the proposed Borden Avenue, Queens, approach to the Thirty-eighth Street Tunnel be built before the fair.

Fred Apostoli, California middleweight, rules a slight favorite over Solly Krieger of Brooklyn for their twelve-round bout at the Hippodrome tonight. This is a return match, Apostoli having gained a decision over Krieger in ten rounds in their last meeting. He is quoted at 8 to 5 to get the verdict again.

Racketeering by physicians in fake accident indemnity claims, reveaied in the last year by the inquiry conducted by Bernard C. Botein, Assistant District Attorney, led yesterday to a move by Attorney General Bennett and District Attorney Dodge for more certain punishment for crooked doctors.

The entire West Side improvement from Seventy-second Street to Dyckman Street will be open to traffic in September, Park Commissioner Moses announced yesterday. There will be no piecemeal opening of the new express parkway, it was explained because the resulting traffic would interfere with park restoration and cause congestion at the parkway entrances at Seventyninth and Ninety-sixth Streets.

Trading was fair to slow. Lamb had a tendency of slowing up at recent price advances and the demand for veal was considerably lighter than the past several days. Prices showed little change throughout. Early trading in kosher meats Indicated beef prices to be steady to strong, veal weak, lamb about steady, as reported by

Registrations of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday were slightly under the preceding week but were considerably ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Births reported in the four weeks ended last Saturday totaled 8,127, an increase of 289 over the similar period in 1936 and of 327 over 1935, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, said yesterday in his weekly review.

A report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the American Hide and Leather Company and made public yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange shows that 581,850 common shares were outstanding on April 8, reflecting the conversion of 13,370 shares of 6 per cent $50-par preferred stock into 66,850 shares of $1-par common stock. There were 86,630

Mrs. T. Ellwood Allison of Connymeade, Wallingford, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Meredith Allison, to William B. Hubbard Jr., son of Mrs. William B. Hubbard of Cornwall, Conn., and Portsmouth, N. H., and the late Mr. Hubbard.

Mrs. Frank A. Rowsey of 1,111 Park Avenue and Sands Point, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sally E. Rowsey, to James V. McFadden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. McFadden of Bethlehem, Pa.

The use of sulfanilamide as a "more pleasant" antiseptic for kidney and bladder infections "opens a new field in the fight against infectious diseases," Dr. Russell D. Herrold of the University of Illinois College of Medicine said tonight.

It has just been revealed that the arrest, April 3, of twenty-nine Americans suspected of planning to enter Spain to volunteer for service with the Loyalists, was the result of a police tip that must have referred to some other group of volunteers.

Alfred J. Johnson, who was the first City Chamberlain under Mayor Hylan, died yesterday of bronchial pneumonia in the Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 66. He resided in the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Steel ingot production was unchanged last week when a rise was seasonal, and the adjusted index receded to 124.1 from 125.1. It was 90.3 for the week ended April 11, 1936. According to the estimate of THE NEW YORK TIMES, production remained at 91 per cent of capacity, compared with 66 per cent for the corresponding week last year.

Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario mustered in 200 special constables today and asked the Dominion Government at Ottawa for additional forces from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, on the ground that the strike situation in Oshawa was becoming more tense because of the activity of Communist agitators.

Governor Lehman sent a sharp letter tonight to Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, notifying him that he would veto a bill providing for a fiscal survey by a temporary commission which had been introduced earlier in the day by Irving M. Ives, the Republican floor leader.

Seven new appointments to the faculty of Teachers College, Columbia University, were announced yesterday by Dean William F. Russell. The appointees and the positions they will assume next September were as follows:

Morris Watson, whose job as a reporter with The Associated Press was restored to him by the Supreme Court in one of its rulings upholding the Wagner labor act, returned to duty at the offices of the press association yesterday.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, told 2,000 persons at a Jefferson Day dinner tonight that the "necessity" for passage of President Roosevelt's court bill was "as compelling today" as it was before the Supreme Court upheld the Wagner Labor Relations Act in yesterday's decisions.

Led by guides, forty members of the Blind Workers Union marched down Broadway to City Hall yesterday in an effort to persuade Mayor La Guardia to intervene in the sitdown strikes conducted by the union at the Community Craft Weavers Auxiliary, 708 Broadway, and the Bourne Workshop, at 335 East Thirty-fifth Street, operated by the New York Association for the Blind.
The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 355,132 shares of $1-par common stock of the Reynolds Spring Company, Jackson, Mich.

COOKE, HOWARD DEW (April 16, 1936). Gross assets, $32,673; net, $29,523. To Anna L. Cooke, widow. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $28,491. Stern Reubens, attorneys. 551 5th Av. COURTNEY, ROBERT W. (Jan. 9, 1937). Gross assets, $37,078; net, $35,262. To Marian H. Courtney, daughter. $23,746; Bertha H. Courtney, widow, $11,505; one other bequest. Chief assets $32,409.

The Dodgers rolled into this Virginia town more than an hour behind time today and if it hadn't been for the rapidly convalescing Cookie Lavagetto they'd have ferried back to Norfolk tonight at least one run behind the Portsmouth Cubs.

Trading in sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday reached a volume that made trading so far this year larger than that for the entire year 1936, when 2,827,750 tons were turned over. Introduction

Liquidation was under way in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here early today in sympathy with the weakness in other commodities, the continued slow export demand for wheat and the sharply lower prices for wheat in foreign markets.
The Red Sox got busy in the latter frames of an exhibition game today and defeated the Reds, 6 to 1. Home runs by Left Fielder Gaffke and First Baseman Jimmy Foxx featured the attack.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 12 unless specified: At Shanghai: Alden, Barker, John D. Edwards, John D. Ford, Paul Jones, Parrott, Peary, Pillsbury, Stewart, Tulsa Whippl?? At Boston Yard: Vincennes, April 13; Tillman.
A mother was killed and her son fatally injured today when a pot stove in the basement of their home at 1,444 Lexington Place exploded, blowing out a score of windows in the two-family dwelling.

Attorneys for heavyweight champion James J. Braddock will ask Federal Judge Guy Fake in Newark today to dismiss Madison Square Garden's action for an injunction against a Braddock-Joe Louis fight, slated for Chicago. The Garden asked Braddock on March 29 to show cause why he should not be restrained from boxing Louis or anybody else until he keeps his contract with the Garden to fight Max Schmeling in New York June 3.

BRAHAM--Theresa Rich. suddenly, on April 11, 1937, at Hollwood, Fla., widow of Alfred Abraham, and beloved monther of Mrs. Benjamin H. Kaufman, Mrs. Sidney F. Kenton, Mrs. Florence Harris and Mrs. victor B. Zeman. Funeral at convenience of family.

Judge J. Whitaker Thompson of the Federal Circuit Court granted a temporary injunction here today preventing the scheduled trial in Newark, N. J., next Monday of Detective Ellis H. Parker and his son, Ellis H. Jr., on a charge of conspiracy in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.

Arguing for an even larger Federal work-relief program than we have at present, WILLIAM GREEN, president of the American Federation of Labor, tells us that there are now 9,722,000 unemployed, and that therefore "we "cannot possibly count on reducing

The contest for proxies between the management of the Reo Motor Car Company and the group headed by Frank A. Vanderlip Jr. was terminated yesterday following a meeting of Mr. Vanderlip with the entire Reo board in Detroit which resulted in an amicable agreement to give the Vanderlip group representation on the board.

The first strike settlement effected by Mayor La Guardia's new industrial relations board was ratified yesterday in the Mayor's office. By its terms fourteen drug stores of the Silver Rod chain, closed for nearly two months, will re-open and 150 employes will receive wage increases totaling about $20,000 a year.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,426,300 barrels, compared to 3,422,350 in the preceding week, an increase of 3,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 40,400 barrels in

Dr. and Mrs. Morley Currie of Picton, Ontario, Canada, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clara Madeleine Currie, to Dr. Lawrence Coleman Kolb; son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kolb of Lexington, Ky.
Miss Grace A. Reavy, Executive Deputy Secretary of State, was named today by Governor Lehman as a member of the State Civil Service Commission, to succeed William Gorham Rice.
Germany's anti-Semitic government struck another blow at Jews today. An unexplained police order banned all Jewish meetings, except the gatherings of worshipers in synagogues, for sixty days.

Drastic changes strengthening the rules concerned with the taking of saliva tests of thoroughbreds at all Illinois race tracks were made today by the Illinois State Racing Commission. The new rules, designed to protect the public as well as the owners and trainers themselves,

Two conflicting points of view on the working hours of certain city employes were expressed in the Board of Aldermen yesterday, when Alderman Charles E. Keegan of the Bronx, sought to give them a fiveday week, and Alderman Samson Inselbuch moved that those who observed a Saturday Sabbath be required to make up the time they took off.
Josef Lhevinne, American pianist born in Russia, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria after giving a series of twelve recitals in Continental Europe and England.

Patrick Kevin Foley, better known as P. K. to thousands of book lovers, collector librarians and auctioneers, who often frequented his quaint book shop here in the Phillips Building, died today after a long illness. His age was 81.

BATEMAN, ANDREW A. (Jan. 23). Estate, not more than $2,000. To W. Bateman Cullen, executor, Smyrna, Del., residue. BERNSTEIN, ZION D. (April 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Helen Stroock Bernstein, widow, executrix, 450 West End Av., household furnishings and 50 per cent residue in trust; Peggy L.,

The mill men whose discharge from the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation led to the Supreme Court's validation of the Wagner Labor Act met today to calculate how much back pay they will receive under the court's decision and to press for their reinstatement.

Claims of a million dollars for damage resulting from sit-down strikes are reported to have been filed against insurance companies here, which may pay this time, under the scope of a "riot and civil commotion" clause of the policy, but will move to have that clause cover more specifically what was the original intent.

William Roe Bull, a real estate expert who was well known as an appraiser of properties, died here today at his home, 391 Irving Avenue, at the age of 70. Born in Goshen, N. Y., Mr. Bull had been in the realty business in Westchester County for half a century.

The Senate Judiciary Committee heard a defense of the Supreme Court today from a Federal judge who had been overruled by that tribunal in its unanimous decision invalidating the National Industrial Recovery Act.
21st St., 158 W., 3-story loft building, 20.3x91.10; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Edward L. Bang: due, $7,928; taxes, , $210; to plaintiff for $1,000.
Mathias P. Moeller, owner of the M. P. Moeller Organ Works, died at his home here today of complications following an attack of pneumonia last Autumn. He was 82 years old.

Miss Kathryn Marie Quinlan, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Quinlan. was married yesterday morning to Edward Robert Amend, son of Mrs. Alfred J. Amend and the late Mr. Amend, in the Church of St. Philip Neri, the Bronx. Th ceremony was

Marked improvements occurred in the domestic bond market yesterday under the leadership of the rails, with the turnover at $12,104,100, considerably higher than the $7,964,500 total on Monday. Corporate bonds comprised $9,645,000 of the total, against $6,529,000, and trading in United States Government issues was $1,497,100, against $354,500.

Two apartment houses in Queens to cost $250,000 and $140,000 were among the projects for which building plans were filed yesterday. The list follows: Manhattan Hudson St., 168 and 170, and Laight St., 48; 54x24, for 1-story gas station; Hudson Light Service Station, Inc., 2,260 Bedford Av., Brooklyn, owner; Lama Proskauer, architect; cost, $4,500.

The police of Queens expressed the hope, after they had arrested a shabbily dressed old man in Whitestone, L. I., early yesterday morning, that they were close to a solution of the long series of "phantom pocket-book" burglaries committed along the north shore of Queens and Nassau Counties for some four and a half years.

A luncheon bridge party and fashion revue will be given on May 4 in the Park Lane Gardens as the annual Spring benefit for the New York Diet Kitchen Association. The occasion will mark the opening of the outdoor garden.

Two Negroes, accused of murder, were put to death by a mob here today after its members had seared their flesh with blasts from gasoline blow torches. A third Negro was flayed mercilessly, then released and told to quit the State. The Negroes were charged with the murder of George S. Windham, country merchant, Dec. 30.

In two weeks the directors' meetings of the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation will be held, two days apart, with interest already attracted to the sessions by the statements made at the annual meetings of the companies hinting that common dividends are not far off for the former and that a distribution is likely to be made by the latter.

Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland dimmed the world's pocket billiard championship hopes of Ralph Greenleaf of New York last night, staging a sensational rally to upset the thirteen-time winner, 125 to 118, in a tense fifteen-inning match before 600 persons at Ponzi's Academy.
Mr. and Mrs. Hans Bernstorff of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leila Ammon Bernstorff, to Dr. Hans. Joachim Grauert of New York and Hamburg, Germany.

J. H. Louchheim's Pompoon, equal favorite with E. R. Bradley's Brooklyn in the Kentucky Derby, is almost sure to start May 8 at Churchill Downs, despite the recent lameness which developed at Columbia, S. C., and which threatened to keep the colt out of the race.
Governor Lehman sent a sharp letter to Speaker Heck condemning a Republican bill to set up a special commission to study the budget. He said that such a commission was not needed.
Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Minister, has arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.

The Republic Steel Corporation issued last month 383,940 common shares in conversion of $8,532,000 of general mortgage 41/2 per cent Series A bonds and 250 common shares in conversion of $10,000 of purchase money first mortgage convertible 51/2s, making 4,753,535 common

Stocks of refined copper in the United States at the end of March, excluding consumers' stocks at plants or warehouses, were 121,448 tons, a decrease of 14,673 tons in the month, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks

The Town Council of this little Mobile Bay shore resort community today had "kicked over the traces" and adopted the first business license and excise tax in its fortythree-year-old history. And thus Fairhope lost its single tax distinction.

Lieut. Gov. Frank Hayes and Speaker Wayne N. Aspinall, presiding officer of the Colorado General Assembly, said today they had received threatening letters in connection with a pending old-age Pension Bill.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, who arrived here by special plane from Berlin this morning, has been cordially received without thus far making any considerable progress toward attaining the object of his mission.

The official French mission which arrived in this country three weeks ago at New Orleans for a commemorative visit to the territory explored 250 years ago by Robert Cavelier de la Salle spent yesterday in New York preparatory to sailing today for France on the Normandie.

WITH a flourish of her long black eartrumpet the old lady asked benignly, "Well, Tommy, what are you doing now?" The man said, "I've been elected President, Aunt Janie." "What ?" "President." "Come, come," the old lady replied in a nettled tone, eager to get to the point, "president of what?"

The six-story apartment house, on a plot 137 by 100 feet, at 36-08 29th Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold to Netter Netter, attorneys, by Acadington Builders, Inc.; Morris Schwartz, president, who erected the structure in 1929.

Two buildings containing stores and lofts, one of twelve stories, on a plot 50 by 98.9 feet, at 28-30 West Thirty-eighth Street, and the other an adjoining structure of sik stories, on a plot 25 by 98.9 feet, at 26 West Thirty-eighth Street, have been leased by Isadore B. Geller for twenty-one years.

A railway conciliation board of the Labor Department recommended unanimously today that basic wage rates be restored by April 1, 1938, to 10,000 Canadian National Railways workers affiliated with the Canadian Brotherhood of Railway Employes.

The British Government's policy to maintain the status quo for currency and foreign exchange was strongly affirmed today by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, when questions of major interest to the United States were brought into open parliamentary discussion.

For the first time in the history of the game a national indoor polo title went to the Ridgewood Polo Club of New Jersey last night when its team won the third and deciding contest of the East-West junior championship from the Cleveland Riding Club, 10 1/2 to 5, at Squadron A Armory.

A woman was injured critically and a child less seriously at 6 o'clock last evening when they were struck at Webster Avenue by a runaway, driverless automobile that had rolled from its parking place down a steep hill on 184th Street, the Rronx.

Alexander Calder, president of the Union Bag and Paper Company, reported a net profit of about $330,000 for the first quarter at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday, and said that with earnings running far above previous figures and prospects increased as new units were brought into production, stockholders were likely to receive materially increased dividends.

One of the most interesting activities of college sport continues along the commerce-studded shores of what was once a recreation center of New York, the Harlem River, as the crews of Manhattan College head into the sixth season of the sport.
Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Bayley Riker of South Orange will entertain this evening at their home with a reception in observance of their golden wedding anniversary.

Marty Barry kept the Detroit Red Wings in the Stanley Cup play-offs tonight by lashing home a goal that beat the New York Rangers, 1 to 0. The rangy sharpshooter came through with the only counter midway in the third period to send the packed house of 14,000 enthusiastic fans into frenzies of joy and force the championship series into a fifth game.

Commodity futures were mixed yesterday in fairly active trading on the local markets. Copper, silk, tin and domestic sugar futures gained, while cocoa, rubber, lead, coffee and hide futures fell. World sugar, zinc and wool top futures ruled steady. On the cash market

Italy took a noncommittal position in the conference to abolish Egyptian capitulations today when she got down to business with the interest centering on Italian policy. Because the Fascist empire is at the end of a long line of communications which can be cut at Suez, the Italian policy at this conference is expected to be determined by general political considerations instead of financial and juridical ones governing the other capitulation powers.

John F. Powers, a director of the F. W. Woolworth Company of France, died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage on Sunday at the Hotel Park Central. Mr. Powers, who lived in Paris, was here on a visit. He was 66 years old and a native of Hoboken, N. J.
Sales of several home sites in the Scarsdale section, and of residences in Crestwod and Larchmont, were reported by Westchester brokers yesterday.

The German Government today delivered a note of protest to the Vatican in reply to Pope Pius's encyclical read in German Catholic churches March 21, accusing Germany of having violated the 1933 concordat.
Discovery, isolation and synthesis of a new male hormone was announced today before the meeting of the American Chemical Society at the University of North Carolina.
The Polish Army revealed yesterday that the horse, the dog and the carrier pigeon-particularly the horse-still play a considerable part in the nation's defense scheme.

Mrs. William Kent Dupre gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 126 East Seventy-third Street, for her cousin, Miss Isabel Hoey, daughter of Governor and Mrs. Clyde R. Hoey of Raleigh, N. C. Among the guests were Mrs. William MacRossie, Mrs. George Stanley

Germany and Sweden Alone Failed to Show Gain in Last Quarter Merchantt shipping under construction by the principal nations of the world was increased by 200,830 tons during the first three months of this year, making a total of 2,452,051 tons, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Registry of Shipping, issued yesterday. All nations except Russia
The estate of Ina Claire, stage and screen star, consisting of sixty acres in Greenwich, Conn., has been sold to a New York lawyer whose name was not revealed. George Howe, Inc., negotiated the deal.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., had issued $12,502,800 of new 31/4 per cent convertible debentures by March 31, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange.

Alexander Silverblatt, Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A., defeated John Lehrner, West Side Y. M. C. A., 15-21, 21-4, 21--9; Henry Perkins, Bedford Y. M. C. A., beat Lou Colman, Pastime A. C., 13-21, 21-4, 21-12; and Kenneth Schifferson, Pastime A. C., vanquished Roy Fee, White Plains Y. M. C. A.,

Lieut. Commander Frank M. Hawks, speed flier, badly damaged his plane when he landed last night at Newark Airport at the end of two flights to prove he could breakfast in Hartford, Conn., lunch in Miami, Fla., and dine in New York, all in one day.

Briggs S. Cunningham's American six-meter yacht Lulu took the first race today in a series of three for special Royal Bermuda Yacht Club trophies. Most of the yachtsmen here for the team events preferred to rest today and only five boats competed, three American craft and two representing Bermuda.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 10: CAPTAINS Ingram, J., Destroyer Squadron 6, Battle Force; to duty as Captain of the Navy Yard, New York, N. Y., about June 14. Warner, R. A., Medical Corps, Chelsea, Mass., to duty as medical officer in command of Norfolk Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, Va.

Some $24,000,000 of debts to banks, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Railroad Credit Corporation must be repaid before the resumption of dividends on the Erie Railroad's two issues of preferred stock may be considered, C. E. Denney, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday.
A Mexican divorce was granted today to James Hilton, British author of "Good-bye, Mr. Chips," and other popular novels, from Alice Helen Brown Hilton of London.

Mrs. Frederick R. Hattersley and her house guest, Mrs. Earl P. Mallory, who will depart Friday for Chicago and then for her home in Santa Barbara, Calif., entertained tonight with a dinner at Brazilian Court, taking the party later to Mrs. Hattersley's villa for backgammon.
Mrs. Alice Whitney Hutchison, for forty-two years secretary to the late George Eastman, died here this morning. She had been ill three months.

Tony Canzoneri moved a step closer toward gaining the lightweight title for the third time by outpointing Frankie Wallace of Cleveland in eight rounds last night before a capacity crowd of 5,000 fans at the Broadway Arena. The victor scaled 1343/4 to 1381/4 for the Clevelander.

Before the inquiry commission of liberals here Leon Trotsky testified today that the French police had refused to give his friends access to their records in regard to the exile's movements in the latter part of July, 1933, the period during which,

Rejecting $500 each offered as compensation for their temporary dismissal, the 500 sit-down strikers in the plant of the De Nobili Cigar Company, 35-11 Ninth Street, Long Island City, Queens, decided yesterday to remain in the plant indefinitely.

The fireworks were long delayed tonight when the survivors in the national A. A. U. boxing championships clashed in the quarter-finals at the Boston Garden. Almost five hours of tame boxing preceded the first lusty action in a 160-pound bout waged by James Lindsay of Pittsburgh and Pat Devine of Cambridge, Mass.
Delegates assuming to represent 12,000 aluminum workers broke with the American Federation of Labor today and aligned themselves with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Joseph Chuisano, 17 years old, was sentenced yesterday by County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn to serve twenty years to life in Sing Sing prison on his conviction for second-degree murder in the slaying of Henry Antico, 27.

Roman Holiday," by the actress Thea Holme, was produced by the Manuscript Theatre Club tonight. It is a guileless little comedy about a vague young mother-pestered archaeologist who went off on a tandem bicycle to search for Roman remains and found romance.

The stage today is suffering from too much cleverness and not enough humor, comedy and sentiment, Daniel Frohman, dean of American theatrical producers, told more than 200 Brooklyn women yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the senior guild of the Colony House at the settlement headquarters. 297 Dean Street. Brooklyn.

The Collins Aikman Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $4,991,659 for the year ended on Feb. 27 after all charges including depreciation, provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes and $187,000 provision for surtax on undistributed earnings. The net income

With the Hershey Chocolate Corporation's plant operating once more at full capacity, and with peace restored in this erstwhile strike-torn community, sympathizers and opponents of the recent C. I. O. sitdown strike in the chocolate plant awaited the forthcoming balloting of employes under the Wagner act.

With all of the late coming ranking players checking in from the Wes and South except Wayne Sabin who is due tomorrow, the United North and South tennis champion ships got under way in earnest to day on the- courts of the Pinehurs Country Club. By nightfall sever players had taken their places in the quarter-finals of both the men's and women's singles.

A strike of 5,000 employes in Loft, Inc., chain of restaurants and candy stores, was threatened yesterday by the Cooks, Countermen and Assistants Union, Local 325, an A. F. of L. affiliate, unless demands for wage increases, improved working conditions and recognition were granted.

The Diesel-engined fishing schooner Taiyo, out of a California port for Luna fish, reported by her shortwave wireless to Mackay Radio here at 12:50 A. M. today that she had run aground on Danaide Rocks, about four miles from Bilboa, Canal Zone, at the Pacific entrance to the Panama Canal.
Contributions totaling $900,000 in 1936 are reported by the Rockefeller Foundation for biological research in "relatively new and important factors in man's struggle to become a rational animal."

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Kitchel, daughter of Cornelius Porter Kitchel of Englewood, N. J., to Alexander Lincoln Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lincoln of C Brookline, Mass., will take place on May 17 at the home of Miss Kitchel's father and stepmother.

In one of the largest recent sales of East Side properties, an investor acting through John T. Javasile has purchased in the name of the 1,192 Park Avenue Corporation the fifteen-story apartment house at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street.

With the coming New York City Mayoralty campaign an obvious background for the action, the Democratic Senate passed today six election bills aimed in the general direction of the American Labor party.

The annual basketball dinner tendered by the Manhattanville College Athletic Association to this year's undefeated team took place at the Benziger Building on the campus last evening. With over seventy-five .guests attending, there were speeches and presentations to the. intra-mural teams as well as the varsity, to mark the end of an unusually satisfactory season.

Joseph Kelban, business agent and delegate for Local 306 of the Motion Picture Operators Union, was convicted yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions of endangering the safety of persons in a public place. The union representative, who is 45 years old

Movements on the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts-23,000 head, including 7,000 direct: generally 10 to 15 cents lower than Monday's average; packing sows, 15 to 25

Michael S. Asch, in 60 W. 68th St.; Dr. Ricardo Almeda, Harold L. Springer, Charles Russo, in 170 W. 79th St.; Bing Bing, Inc., broker. H. G. Hotchkiss, through Pease Elliman, in 1,165 5th Av.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., broker. Dr. Helman Schwarz, through Tishman Realty Construction Co., in 1,095 Park Av.; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., broker.

A Cabinet crisis that brought a threat of resignation from J. F. Hofmeyer, Interior Minister, ended today when the government decided not to place on the parliamentary calendar a bill to prohibit the employment of white women by Asiatics.

Naval aviators completed today the third "route transfer" of fighting airplanes from the mainland to Honolulu with the arrival of twelve flying boats bearing seventy-eight men on a non-stop flight from San Diego, Calif.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Aileen Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Eugene Reynolds of Larchmont, N. Y., to Cornelius Earle Rumsey Wells, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jonathan Godfrey Wells of this city.

Representatives of Spain's two regimes are engaged in a bloodless war for possession of the Spanish Legation here. The Rebels still hold the fort and a 27-year-old teacher who possesses the Valencia government's commission has hung his shingle outside his hotel room.

Democrats in the Senate rejected today a Republican resolution condemning sit-down strikers. The measure was tabled after a warm debate. The vote was 30 to 17. G. Mason Owlett of Tioga asked the Senate to commit itself against sit-down strikes as "an unlawful
The Great Lakes navigation season formally opened today with the clearing of the John Gehm first ship out of Duluth, with 2,500 tons of scrap iron for lower lake ports.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Brooks Wood of 68 Beechmont Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Wood, to James Edward Tatnall Gummere, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Gummere, also of this place.

Former President Hoover declared here yesterday that "the whole country should be grateful" for the validation of the Wagner Labor Act by the Supreme Court. The court's action, he said, "opens the way for constructive solution of many problembs."
This city, where the Titanic was built, will observe a period of mourning tomorrow, the twenty-fifth anniversary of the sinking of the liner on her first voyage.
Fred W. Lyon of Milford, Conn., owner and publisher of The Milford Citizen, a weekly, died at the Milford Hospital last night after three days of illness.

A son of Man o' War, the chestnut colt, Over the Top, gave Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Kentucky Derby hopes a heavy jolt today when he won the Mayfield Purse from Tedious, main hope of the young master of Sagamore Farm. Over the Top carried the famous Glen Riddle Farm colors to a head victory at the end of a mile and seventy yards.

Guessing about decisions of the Supreme Court, especially when a majority in that body is moving to new positions, is a risky business. It is particularly hazardous for Presidents, Congresses and lawyers arguing cases because they have a more immediate stake than the public

The Police Department is making a survey to determine the number of automobile accidents on streets with elevated railroad pillars, as compared to casualties on other streets, Commissioner Valentine disclosed yesterday.

The Dartmouth Athletic Council announced tonight the appointment of Edward J. Jeremiah of Boston as varsity, and freshman hockey coach for next season. Jeremiah, in the Dartmouth class of '30, starred in baseball, football and hockey. He has also had wide

According to The Daily Telegraph's Berlin correspondent, it was rumored in usually well-informed. Nazi quarters last night that General Francisco Franco, the Spanish Rebel leader, had been urged by Italy to give up the military direction of the civil war and to confine himself to duties as head of the Insurgent government.

More than 2,000 druggists from all boroughs of the city massed in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night for a fourhour meeting at which speakers explained the business benefits they can expect from the Feld-Crawford act. The meeting was
Prices on the Cotton Exchnage here broke sharply under Far Eastern liquidation at the opening yesterday. only to recover $1 a bale and end with losses of 6 to 10 points. The early weakness dropped
Mayor La Guardia gave the proposed aldermanic investigation of relief a severe setback yesterday when he vetoed an appropriation of $50,000 sought by the Aldermen.

Enthusiasm and belief in the product they are advertising are what make advertising writers produce good copy, Harford Powel, vice president of Kimball, Hubbard Powel, Inc., told 300 members of THE NEW YORK TIMES advertising class last night in the Times Annex.

Take the word of Dr. Howard J. Crum, coffee and doughnuts is proper fare for seekers of slenderI ness. Years of experimenting with reducing diets have proved the time-honored combination to be "most satisfactory," he told the Southern Beauticians Association.

George Washington High began the defense of its city P. S. A. L. baseball title by conquering Commerce, 6-3, in the opening Upper Bronx-Manhattan division test for both teams at Washington Stadium yesterday. Another battle in the same section found Morris a 10-9 victor over Monroe on the loser's diamond. In the lower ManhattanRichmond group Curtis crushed Textile, 10-5, at Prospect, Park, Brooklyn.
The Assembly bill of Jane Todd, Westchester Republican, to bar hasty marriages in the State, was passed by the Senate today and sent to Governor Lehman.

Stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company empowered its directors today to add $95,000,000 to the company's indebtedness whenever the additional financing is needed. Their action will be submitted to a formal stock vote April 17.

Notice was served yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange on its members and member firms that they must not be associated in any way with three investments trusts: Business Recovery Trust Shares, Selected Managements Trustee Shares and Twentieth Century Fixed Trust Shares.

Trapped inside a Miami-New York bus when it overturned in a creek twenty miles south of here today, twenty-two passengers, eight of them from New York City and vicinity, saved themselves from death by smashing windows, then standing in water up to their necks until rescuers arrived.

The Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that District Judge Merrill E. Otis at Kansas City must hear on its merits a suit of the Missouri Pacific Railroad's trustee to recover $3,200,000 paid

The American Bar Association announced tonight that its final tabulation of more than 71,000 lawyers' votes disclosed about a 4-to-1 disapproval of what it described as a "proposed increase in the number of members of the Supreme Court of the United States."

A proposal for a Federal tax on broadcasting companies, the rate to be based on the amount of power used, is to be introduced in the House by Representative Boylan within ten days. The plan is proposed by George Henry Payne of the Federal Communications Commission.

A first mortgage loan of $62,000 at 5 per cent has been placed on the six-story apartment house recently completed on the east aide of Seaman Av., 46 feet north of West 215th St., Bronx, by Samuel Kronsky, Inc.

Facing the possibility of an operation for the removal of his tonsils, Joe DiMaggio, sensational 1936 rookie of the world champion Yankees, may miss the opening game of the baseball season in New York next Tuesday.

For more than an hour yesterday afternoon two dozen women applied the sit-down technique in a vain attempt to prevent the eviction of two of their neighbors in a 54-family apartment house at 2,802 Olinville Avenue, the Bronx.
The battle along the Manzanares River, on the western border of Madrid, reached what amounted to a deadlock today.

A registration statement covering $45,000,000 of twenty-five-year 31/4 per cent debentures of the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company of Atlanta was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today under the Securities Act of 1933. The bonds are due on
Dr. Hawkling Yen, Professor of English at National University here, died yesterday after a paralytic stroke. He was 54 years old.

Switzerland took a commanding position today in the international chess masters tournament at the Ostend Casino when her representative, H. Grob of Zurich, won two games, one in the regularly scheduled third round and the other in an adjourned match.

Under the headings, "Disgraceful agitationfilm about Germany in New York's biggest church" and "Speech of hatred from altar; with the cooperation of the notorious cabaret performer, Erika Mann" Berlin newspapers created another "incident. "
President Roosevelt today ordered a resurvey of the expenditure requirements of all departments and other government agencies for the fiscal year 1937, ending June 30.

Contrary to-general predictions, reduction in hours of textile workers did not bring about proportionate increases in labor costs or decreases in profits, according to Robert West, employers' adviser of the American delegation, in an address to the World Textile Conference today.

Miss Ellen Dexter Fales and David Arms Lomasney, both of this city, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said they would be married in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church on April 27.

The first step toward formal organization of the new city college in Queens was taken yesterday with the appointment of a Board of Higher Education administrative committee, headed by John T. Flynn, writer and economist.

Holding grimly against the insurgents' repeated attacks and against the inroads of starvation, the populace of Bilbao, now swelled by refugees to about 400,000, learned today that all hope had vanished of receiving aid from British food ships.

Salaries derived from funds supplied to the State by the Federal Government which are paid to employes of the Pennsylvania Unemployment Compensation Commission are subject to the Federal income tax, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.

Death Announced Retired Lieutenant Thomas H. Carson, formerly a member of Engine 215, residing at 53 Apollo St., Brooklyn, died April 12. Funeral will take place from his late resi?ence, at 2 P. M., Thursday, April 15. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 11th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen, as funeral escort.

The six-story apartment house, on an irregular plot 121x112 feet, at 2,101 Westbury Court, Brooklyn, has been sold for cash over a first mortgage of $250.000, at 4 1/2 per cent, to an investing client of David S. Meister, broker.

The Holland Furnace Company, Holland, Mich., has announced that it will use approximately 400 newspapers in its 1937 advertising campaign. Full pages will be used in principal cities and smaller space in other communities.

The Republican party won control of the Village Board in today's election here, breaking the Democratic rule of the last six years. The Republicans elected a village president and three trustees to the seven-man board. The old board was Democratic by 5 to 2.

Mr. and Mrs. Fritz Reiner depart today for London, where the conductor will direct opera performances in Covent Garden as part of the Coronation festivities. The chorus and string orchestra of Washington Square College, New York University, Martin Bernstein director, will give their Spring
THOMAS MANN told the reporters that he is 62, but that he hopes some day to go back to Germany, from which he is an by his own will, seconded by Nazi decree.

The United Shoe Corporation of Boston held today an injunction against the O'Donnell Rubber Products Company of Cincinnati and the Irving Drew Company of Portsmouth, Ohio, restraining them from infringing on patents on folding sheet materials used in shoe manufacturing.

In verdicts directed by Federal Judge George A. Welsh, a Federal jury today found Frank P. McGlone, labor organizer, and Emanuel Romm, an attorney, innocent of a charge of conspiracy to violate the Anti-Racketeering and Anti-Trust Acts. They will be tried tomorrow
The reported discovery of a comet at Sydney, Australia, April 6, was called at Harvard University Conservatory today apparently erroneous.

Britain's new [Pound]3,000,000 aircraft carrier Ark Royal, which Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, said proudly will be "the most up to date in the world," was launched today at Birkenhead.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that the "outlook of the Niagara system is, at present, better than at any time in the history of the company." He said he did not share

Fred Sherry of Carbondale, Pa., broke into the circle of leaders in the American Bowling Congress championships yesterday at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory. Registering a magnificent tally of 710, Sherry took fifth place in the singles division. Among five shifts of maple crashers in singles and doubles competition, he was the only one to turn in an unusual mark.

At the opening of court in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday, Presiding Justice Francis Martin, after announcing the death of Justice John V. McAvoy, sketched his career in a memorial address.
The first clue to the esthetic tendencies in the new reign was given tonight with the issuance of examples of the George VI coinage, which show a reversion to the ornate styles of Victorian days.

The annual dinner dance in behalf of the charitable activities of the Ladies Auxiliary of Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital attracted a large gathering last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center.
A declaration in favor of a strong policy of neutrality for the United States marked a peace forum today at the final session of the State conference of the National Council of Jewish Women.

By the overwhelming majority of 132 to 15, the Assembly this afternoon passed the Moffat bill, which would prohibit the sale of child-labor products in this State. Mr. Moffat's bill was drafted to conform with provisions contained in a bill introduced at Washington by Senator Wheeler to regulate the interstate transportation of merchandise manufactured wholly or in part by child labor, subsequent to Jan. 1, 1938.

Action by the book publishing industry on the standard resale price contract under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act is expected before the end of the week, it was learned here yesterday. The final form of

The most enthusiastic bidding for foreign-language rights of Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind" occurred in Germany, Macmillan, the publisher, reports. The German rights have been sold to a Hamburg firm and Baronin Wangenheim is making the translation.

On the eve of his retirement from public life next month, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin tonight called upon British industrialists to shorten their working hours and improve working conditions still further so that the British people might remain sane and healthy in the years to come.

Irene Dunne, who stepped out last year in the well-received modern comedy, "Theodora Goes Wild," after a career of costume dramas and roles that required her to age from 'teens to grandmotherhood within one feature-length picture, has decided she prefers the lighter moods. As a result, Universal is considering the substitution of I. A.
PEOPLE ON THE EARTH, by Edwin Corle. (Random House, $2.) A story of the Southwest. ROARING TOWER AND OTHER STORIES, by Stella Gibbons. (Longmans, Green, $2.50.) Satiric stories.

A permanent injunction restraining members of The Long Island Daily Press unit of the New York Newspaper Guild from picketing the Long Island Food Show now in progress in the Jamaica Armory, Inc., 168th Street and Ninety-third Avenue, Jamaica, was granted yesterday by Justice Mitchell May in the Supreme Court in Jamaica.
Cottonseed crushed in the eight months from Aug. 1 to March 31 was reported by the Census Bureau today as 4,100,301 tons, compared to 3.537,196 in the corresponding period a year ago.

A seaman who swallowed a dental plate containing three teeth has refused to undergo an operation despite a surgeon's warning that his life was in danger, it became known yesterday when the captain of his ship refused to allow him to sail.

While business failures in the retail division in the week ended April 8 showed a decline from 115 to 107, as compared with the previous week, there was an increase of ten defaults in the manufacturing division, according to the report issued

Motorists using the Holland Tunnel to New Jersey will no longer be required to take the receipt handed to them at the ticket booths and then hand it on to the collector about a dozen yards farther on.
Brightly bound in green velour, the 1937 edition of the Official Directory of the City of New York makes its first appearance today with Mayor aL Guardia scheduled to buy the first copy for 50 cents.
The path of Joseph Barney, Civil War veteran who for seventy years sought an honorable discharge from the army, led to his grave today without fulfillment of that hope.
The Chamber Music Society of America inaugurated its first New York Spring festival with a concert last night at the Fifth Avenue Galleries of the Grand Central Art Galleries.

Thirty-nine original paintings by old masters are bequeathed to the Corcoran Art Gallery, under condition, in the will of Mrs. Mary Griffin Walker, widow of Edward Chandler Walker, filed for probate today in the Federal court for the District of Columbia. Mrs. Walker died in Boston. April 2.
Harry Gutschow, 27, relief client, went to jail because, it was charged, he could support a big, fine car, but not his wife and their six children.

The Dunbar National Bank reported that its statement of condition as of March 31 showed total resources of $3,908,886, an increase of $183,135 from Dec. 31, 1936. Its total deposits on March 31 were $2,987,308 and its capital funds $902,387.

Organization of a new trade association comprising women's apparel chain store concerns with annual sales in excess of $100,000,000 is in progress, following a meeting yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker at which the report of a committee, headed by Sidney

J. Hal Steffen, for thirty-five years a newspaper photographer in this city, died of lobar pneumonia yesterday morning at the PostGraduate Hospital, 303 East Twentieth Street, after an illness of a week. He was a news photographer

Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank of New York, spoke today before the Economic Club of Detroit at a luncheon in the Book Cadillac Hotel. He .took for his subject "Technological Progess, the Stability of Business and the Interest of Labor."

State income tax returns which are postmarked by midnight tomorrow will be received without penalty, Wesley M. Dawson, district income tax supervisor, said yesterday as he warned that only two days remained for filing the returns on time.
Mr. and Mrs. William Crane Ivison entertained with a dinner last night at their home, 417 Park Avenue. Among their guests were

Daylight saving time will be extended this year into eighteen States and will be observed also by Nova Scotia, Labrador, Newfoundland, Ontario and Quebec and by ten other countries or territories, five in Europe, according to an annual survey made by the Merchants Association of New York.

While government witnesses were on the stand yesterday at the trial of Harry H. Levey on charges of using the mails to defraud newspaper advertising departments, Federal Judge Bondy threatened to use "drastic" powers to discipline Levey's attorney, Archibald Palmer.

Governor Lehman asked the Legislature in a special message today to appropriate $400,000 for a campaign against pneumonia. A good share of the funds would be devoted to production of additional serum.

In turning down the extra cent gasoline tax recommended by the Governor, the Assembly Republicans charged that the Governor's budget was not balanced anyway, as it fell short by $27,000,000 to provide adequately for unemployment relief.

Appointment of a national coordinator for traffic, with powers similar to those of Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis in baseball, to provide a clearing house for traffic safety organizations was advocated yesterday by Michael A. Connor, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles in Connecticut.
Before the national committee of the French Labor Federation, its secretary, Leon Jouhaux, today made a mixed appeal and warning to the workers not to abuse the strike weapon.

A $5,000 mortgage on 689 9th Av. was assigned by Giovanni Bertoncello and two others to the Esperia Realty Corp. The Brico Realty Corp., George H. Nieberg, president, gave a blanket second mortgage for $12,500. due as per bond, to the Mastan Co., Inc., on the plot on the north side of Jane St., 68.4 west of Greenwich Av., 62x25x irregular. and on the

A verdict of $15,000 for the loss of her right eye was awarded yesterday to Andrea Shaw, 9 years old, of 349 East Thirty-second Street, Brooklyn, by a Jury in Supreme Court, Brooklyn. The jury's sealed verdict, opened by Justice Thomas C. Kadien, also awarded $2,500 for medical expenses to the child's motherr. Mrs. Ruth E. Shaw.

In an effort to simplify traveling in the Borough of Brooklyn, a group of city officials will convene at the Brooklyn Borough Hall next Monday afternoon to begin the elimination of confusing duplications in street names.

Charitable, educational and scientific institutions or corporations will eventually inherit the estate of William J. Wollman, securities broker, estimated to be worth between $4,000,000 and $5,000,000, it was revealed. yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

The Seattle Chapter of the American Newspaper Guild urged today the reinstatement of Frank M. Lynch by the Post-Intelligencer as a result of the Supreme Court's the Wagher Labor Relations Act appliedx to the Association Press. The Guild said the two cases were alike.

The Inland Steel Company will offer to stockholders rights to buy additional shares on the basis of one new share for each twenty shares held, involving the offering of 74,950 shares, to finance improvement of the company's plants.
The House bloc that is pressing for government ownership of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks drafted a 7-point program today to be embodied in legislation soon to be introduced. The bloc is headed by
Five large tobacco companies have given ground in their efforts to have the Securities and Exchange Commission treat as confidential their data concerning gross sales and cost of sales,

While cons employers were assuring Federal officials that they were ready to bargain collectively, and unions' officers were deluged with inquiries about the import of yesterday's Supreme Court decisions on the National Labor Relations Act, Secretary Perkins gave out a list of representative persons in bor, industry and government circles who will meet next Tuesday then to discuss stabilization of industrial relations under collective bargaining.
Mrs. Edward Atkinson St. John gave a luncheon here today at her home on Brixton Road for Mrs. Frank W. Creighton, wife of the former Suffragan Bishop of the diocese of Long Island.

The various counsel associated in the bondholders' proceeding to try to force the Associated Gas and Electric Company system to reorganize under the Bankruptcy Act, which resulted in an out-of-court settlement last Jan. 11, requested yesterday a total of $875,009 for fees and disbursements.
A new injunction suit in the row between "New Deal" and "Old Guard" factions in the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union of the Atlantic and Gulf was filed yesterday. The "New Deal" faction

BY HENRY G. WALTEMADE 151st St.,255-257 E., 6-story tenement and stores, 50x118.1 irregular; Dollar Savings Bank of New York - against CappeeloFusco Holding Co., due, $34,746; taxes, , $975; to plaintiff for $32,400. BY THOMAS J. LUNNEY Hughes Av., 2,424, 3-story brick and frame tenement. 26.8x87.6; Charleton H. Upson against Mary Badalamente; due, $6,305; taxes, , $807; to plaintiff for $3,000.

Charging fraud in the promotion of memberships in the "London Curb Exchange" among New York brokers, Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall obtained yesterday a Supreme Court order directing Edward John Harrison, the London Curb Exchange and others to appear in court for examination on April 23.

It was indicated today that Congress soon would be asked to consider legislative proposals for control of the activities of protective committees in reorganizations, the corporate trustees under indentures and foreign bond defaults, following a visit to the White House by James M. Landis, chairman of the SEC and Commissioners Douglas and Healv.

News leaked out today that three intrepid husbands here had been mapping a program to promote an organization known as the Westchester Home Conservation Movement, with a view to improving household efficiency and economy.

Stressing the necessity for the smaller Exchanges to establish, in their vicinity, substantial distribution of and trading in securities registered on other Exchanges for which they seek the unlisted trading privileges, the Securities and Exchange Commission today granted ten applications by the Pittsburgh Stock Exchange and rejected thirteen.

Leaders of the annual Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army reported yesterday the receipt of $174,350. The goal is $600,000, needed to defray expenses for institutions and services during the next fiscal year.

Senators McAdoo and Johnson of California have each written to the Interstate Commerce Commission, it was revealed today, to inquire why the commission ruled against the extension of the Transcontinental and Western Air System to San Francisco.

Buying of United States railroad stocks by Europeans was disclosed yesterday in railroad reports for 1936 to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The lists showed European interests as being among the most important stockholders of these companies.

A possible obstacle to relations of complete friendship between Mexico and the United States was removed today when Secretary Hull and Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, signed a treaty providing for the termination of Article VIII of the Gadsden treaty, 1853.
Senator and Mrs. Eugene Charabot of Paris, Count and Countess Rene de Chambrun and the Count and Countess de Prevoisin are among the passengers sailing today for Europe on the French liner Normandie.

Because of the constantly changing media picture, close cooperation between advertising manager and space buyer is necessary to avoid "bad buys" of advertising space, Lee H. Bristol, vice president in charge of advertising of BristolMyers Company, declared

With the critical eyes of 4,000 Romans, mostly all of Georgian extraction, intently following his every move, Prince Hal Shumacher today stepped nine innings to pace the Giants to a handsome 5-to-1 victory over the Indians and put the National League champions in front in this roving series by a margin of seven games to six.

Through the arrest of two men in Brooklyn yesterday it was revealed that the Postoffice Department and the police in various parts of the country have been working for more than six months to discover the source of thousands of obscene letters that have been sent through the mails.
Arthur M. Horey of 1,776 Castle Hill Avenue, the Bronx, a detective of the Wadsworth Avenue station, died at his home yesterday of a heart ailment.

With declarations of faith in the "universality of the spirit" and of opposition to present-day doctrines of "blood and soil," the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science (the University in Exile) began yesterday the three-day observance of its fourth anniversary.

President Roosevelt was holding fast today to his plan to reorganize the Federal judiciary, despite the action of the Supreme Court yesterday in upholding the Wagner Labor Relations Act in five cases.

Mr. and Mrs. Hiram Tuttle Folsom of Hamilton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Folsom, to Francis P. Clark, son of Mrs. J. Francis A. Clark of Newport, R. I., now at the Pierre in this city, and the late Mr. Clark.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith joined Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, last night in an attack on communism as the enemy of the church, of human liberty and the well-being of the working men and women of America.

The Senate resolution condemning sitdown strikers was favorably reported today by the House Labor Committee voting, 11 to 4. It had previously tabled, by a vote of 8 to 7, a motion to delay consideration until members had further time to study the Supreme Court's decision on the Wagner act.

Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, Community House of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, 10:30 A. M. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M., "World Affairs," Mrs. Jackson Fleming.

The committee on the regulation of athletics at Harvard today voted to make basketball a major sport at the university beginning with the 1937-38 season. As a result basketball becomes the sixth major sport at the local institution, the others being in the order of their approval rowing, baseball, football, track and hockey.

The State Senate today passed finally, 42 to 8, the McGinnis bill setting up a State Labor Relations Board and guaranteeing the collective bargaining right to Pennsylvania workers. A companion measure

Mr. and Mrs. Hiram Tuttle Folsom of Hamilton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Folsom, to Francis P. Clark, son of Mrs. J. Francis A. Clark of Newport, R. I., now at the Pierre in this city, and the late Mr. Clark.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith joined Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, last night in an attack on communism as the enemy of the church, of human liberty and the well-being of the working men and women of America.

The Senate resolution condemning sitdown strikers was favorably reported today by the House Labor Committee voting, 11 to 4. It had previously tabled, by a vote of 8 to 7, a motion to delay consideration until members had further time to study the Supreme Court's decision on the Wagner act.
Turpentine firm, 353/4c; sales, 146 barrels; receipts. 352 barrels. shipments. 25 barrels: stock 23.408 barrels Resin. firm; sales. 531; receipts, 1.583; shipments, 1,599; stock. 44,201.

Coincident with the opening of the eighth annual convention on safety of the Greater New York Safety Council yesterday, a mobile safety unit made its appearance in Times Square. It is the safety special of the Aetna Life Insurance Company, a tractor and trailer unit thirty-four feet long, which in a few days will begin a tour of the United States.

As Police Commissioner Valentine expressed conviction yesterday that Robert Irwin was being sheltered by some one within the limits of New York City, the nature of the evidence that led the police to attribute three murders to the young sculptor and theological student became known for the first time.

The engagement of $3,310,000 of gold abroad for shipment here, $1,611,000 in England and $1,699,000 in Canada, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank reported the arrival here yesterday of $5,437,800 from England and the release of $2,250,600 from earmark for foreign account. At San Francisco,

Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, Community House of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, 10:30 A. M. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M., "World Affairs," Mrs. Jackson Fleming.

The committee on the regulation of athletics at Harvard today voted to make basketball a major sport at the university beginning with the 1937-38 season. As a result basketball becomes the sixth major sport at the local institution, the others being in the order of their approval rowing, baseball, football, track and hockey.

The State Senate today passed finally, 42 to 8, the McGinnis bill setting up a State Labor Relations Board and guaranteeing the collective bargaining right to Pennsylvania workers. A companion measure
Growing friendship among Western nations and auguries of continued peace were hailed today in Pan-American Day ceremonies in all Argentine schools.

Norfolk St., 38, 5-story brick tenement and stores and 4-story brick rear tenement, 25x100; Chase National Bank of N. Y., executor, against Earltrice Realty Corp.; due, $17,283; taxes, , $712; to plaintiff for $15,000.

-Mrs. G. H. Bosowick's veteran timber topper, Fugitive coasted home the winner by fifteen lengths today in the three-mile Glenwood, feature race on the second and closing day of the Middleburg Racing Association's Spring meet.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York authorized its legislative committee yesterday to oppose the Wheeler-Ramspeck bill which would lodge control of rates on port-toport ship lines in the hands of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler agreed yesterday to name a referee to evolve a plan for reorganization of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, the largest of thirty-seven title companies taken over by the State Insurance Department in 1933.
Nassau Hofstra College, a branch of New York University, defeated Yale, 13-6, at Rugby today. Early tallies by McKean and Backheil gave the visitors the lead, and Connors scored later.

In the view of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, expressed at a gathering of the international and Belgian press here today, no real improvement in European economic conditions can occur without political improvement preceding it.

Testifying before Justice Mitchell May in the Supreme Court in Queens yesterday, T. Harold Forbes, publisher of The North Shore Daily Journal in Flushing, told of severe advertising losses of his paper as a result of a strike of employes begun last November.

LONDON--In a heated Commons debate during which the Opposition charged that the government had "run up the white flag" in its policy on the Bilbao blockade and that Britain was helping the Spanish Rebels starve women and children, the Cabinet was upheld, 345 to 130.

According to the newspaper Az Est, former Prince Nicholas of Rumania, brother of King Carol, will leave Bucharest tomorrow morning accompanied by his wife and secretary In conformity with Carol's wishes that he go into exile.
After a halfhour battle of tear gas and lead weights, more than 300 policemen and sheriff's deputies arrested 150 sit-down strikers, mostly women, at the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company plant today.
Faith in the Loyalist cause was expressed last night by 2,000 members of Spanish societies here who crowded a meeting at the St. Nicholas Palace, Sixty-sixth Street east of Columbus Avenue.
A favorable report was given by the House Ways and Means Committee today to the Doughton bill to repeal the statute permitting publicity on incomes of more than $15,000 a year.

Fred Apostoli of California gained a technical knockout over Solly Krieger of Brooklyn at the end of the fifth round of their scheduled twelve-round fight at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 6,000 was present.

Four new films will have local premieres today. The Radio City Music Hall will receive "The Woman I Love," an adaptation of Joseph Kessel's story of the wartime French escadrille, "L'Equipage," directed by Anton Litvak and played by Paul Muni, Miriam Hopkins, Colin Clive, Louis Hayward, Mady Christians and Minor Watson.

The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers Association signed tonight an agreement relat ing to the handling of collective bargaining, grievances and seniority as a supplement to the strike settlement compact they signed at Lansing on April 6.
A SONG CATCHER IN SOUTHERN MOUNTAINS, by Dorothy Scarborough. (Columbia University Press, $4.50.) Folk songs and ballads sung in the South, and Miss Scarborough's adventures in recording them.
The Athletics came from behind today to win the city championship by beating the Phillies, 4 to 2, for the third straight time.

Films to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local, public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
The Sunshine-Radio System, Inc., operating 2,400 of the 13,600 taxicabs in the city, attempted yesterday afternoon to put into effect a surprise one-third reduction in fare.
Yale's crews went out from the Bob Cook boat house at Derby late this afternoon, and finding the best rowing conditions thus far this season, put in a strenuous workout.

Milwaukee was named the winner of cities of more than 500,000 population yesterday in the eighth annual city and rural health contest of the American Public Health Association and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Army's lacrosse team conquered Hobart today, 17 to 6, as the Cadets opened their season in the rain and a sea of mud after Hobart had taken the lead in the first quarter, 3 to 2. The Cadets came back with six goals in the second.

The two five-story apartments at 525 and 527 West 134th St. were sold by the Vardhom Realty Corp., Joseph Melcer, president, to the Calvert Realty Corp., Annie Gruber, president, for a consideration shown as $8,000 over a first mortgage for $20,000, a second for $80,000 and a third for $2,500. The buyer then gave another mortgage thereon to the Montrose Industrial Bank of 781 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn,

The Yanks met up with their Binghamton farm club of the New York-Penn League at Duncan Park today and continued their winning ways. Playing on almost unchartered ground, a dust-blown field located in a gulley, the world champions downed the Triplets, 7 to 4, in seven innings.

The purchase of 800 shares of Chesapeake Corporation stock for $67,200 since Feb. 28 was reported by the Alleghany Corporation yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission. This brought total purchases in recent months to 28,200 shares, at a cost of $2,598,800.
Medals were awarded last night by the National Safety Council to three American airlines which, in more than 225,000,000 passenger miles of operation, never have incurred the death of a passenger.

FICTION knows no more enduring plots than those Dorothy Scarborough tracked down and made record of when she was, as her book's title says, "A Song Catcher in Southern Mountains" (Columbia University Press, $4.50).

Members of the Graham Alumnae Association held their annual meeting and luncheon yesterday in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. At the luncheon a tribute was paid to Mrs. Walter F. Murray, who has served as treasurer of the organization for twenty-five years. A program of monologues was presented by Miss Mabel Rowland.
The Columbia-Stanford football game next Nov. 27 will be played at Baker Field instead of at the Polo Grounds, as was originally scheduled, according to the current issue of The Columbia Alumni News.

The Soviet is ready to come under a naval treaty with Western powers and is considering building the two battleships it would be permitted to construct if it did so, according to information in reliable quarters here.

Fellowship House, an affiliate of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of its work in the field of after-care for dependent children at a dinner at the Town Hall Club last night.
A strong rally in its two final trips to the plate enabled the Pratt Institute nine to overcome a 7-5 deficit and triumph over Stevens Tech of Hoboken, 13-9, yesterday at Pratt Field in Brooklyn.

Lindell T. Bates, international lawyer and writer, died of a stroke Tuesday in London, England, according to a cable received here yesterday by one of his New York associates, Joseph Quittner, a lawyer with offices at 36 West Forty-fourth Street. He was 47 years old.

A strike ultimatum by representatives of 8,500 Southern Pacific employes brought quick action today from President Roosevelt, who appointed an emergency mediation board and thus staved off a walkout for at least sixty days.

Miss Carol Ann Morehouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Morehouse, has chosen June 19 as the date for her marriage to William French Jones, son of Mrs. Frederick H. Jones and the late Mr. Jones, also of Darien. The ceremony will take place in the Congregational Church here.
The decision of the Supreme Court on the Wagner Labor Act as applied to The Associated Press raised three broad issues:

Several galleries, because of unusual interest shown by the public, are extending their exhibitions. Nathaniel Dirk's water-colors will stay on exhibition at the Guild Gallery through April 24; paintings by Paul Emile Lecomte will remain at the Camilla Lucas Galleries, 22 West Twenty-sixth Street, until April 29;

Cessation of further action by the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission on the disputed Jefferson Memorial project was demanded today in a resolution introduced in the House by Representative Wearin, Democrat, of Iowa.

R. B. White, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that the company's gross income for the first quarter of the current year would be about $2,465,000 larger than in the corresponding period of last year. He estimated that the net income would be about $412,000 higher than in the first quarter of 1936.

The executive council of the American Bankers Association will hold its customary Spring meeting at the Arlington Hotel, Hot Springs National Park, Arkansas, from next Monday to Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

Their hopes of keeping the Stanley Cup in this city revived by their fine showing against the New York Rangers last night, the Red Wings are confidently awaiting tomorrow night's fifth and final game for the trophy and the hockey championship of the world.

Commodity futures were irregular in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, hide, cottonseed oil and Rio coffee futures lost ground, while copper, tin, lead, cocoa, Santos coffee and sugar futures gained.

A 12-year-old schoolboy was fatally injured yesterday afternoon when he grasped a high tension wire while climbing a steel pole beside the tracks of the Rockaway division of the Long Island Railroad in Richmond Hill, Queens, and fell twenty-five feet to the ground.

The sit-down strike at the plant of the De Nobili Cigar Company, at Ninth Street and Twenty-fifth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, was settled last night and the 500 men and women who had been encamped in the building went home.

Yesterday in all the twenty Latin-American countries and in the United States Pan-American Day was celebrated more generally and under happier auspices than in any recent year. No war nor threat of armed conflict marred inter-American relations or discourage the wider popular participation in the celebration through special t programs and pageants in thousands of schools.

Charles P. Grimes, assistant to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey; Detective Sergeant Grafnecker and Detective Carnovan of New York left here tonight for that city without Alexander Pompez, whom they came to get for questioning by the Dewey Investigating Committee.
J. Vincent O'Brien of Great Neck, L. I., died on Tuesday night in St. Vincent's Hospital following an appendicitis operation. He was born in Brooklyn thirty-nine years ago.
The Glen Riddle Farm's War Admiral today qualified impressively for the approaching Kentucky Derby by turning in a brilliant race and a fine workout all in the same motion.

Miss Frances O'Connor Becker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude M. Becker of this place, was married here this morning to Joseph A. Keenan Jr. of Washington, D. C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Keenan of Brooklyn, in St. Joseph's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward C. McManus, assisted by the Rev. Frank Ryan.

Jamaica High, defending champion, launched its Queens P. S. A. L. baseball campaign with an impressive 10-3 triumph over Richmond Hill yesterday at Jamaica Stadium. A crowd of 1,000 saw the battle, featured by Al Raman's two doubles and a home run for the victors.

The slogan "Smash Fascism" ended a manifesto with which the Shakai Taishuto (Social Mass party) opened its election 'campaign today. Laborers and other members of the populace stood in queues three hours awaiting the meeting and then heard eleven speeches and saw a film of the new Diet called "The Palace of Constitutionalism."

A bill has been approved by committees of Congress providing for a 20 per cent increase in duties on wheat and wheat flour. It also requires that all wheat bread shall contain a percentage of Brazilian wheat, to be fixed yearly by the Minister of Agriculture.
George A. Schiller, an actor for I more than half a century, died Tuesday night at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 80 years old.

Mrs. Myra Grace Wickwire of 81 Irving Place, widow of Arthur M. Wickwire, corporation lawyer, died on Tuesday night of pneumonia in Columbus Hospital, 227 East Nineteenth Street, after a week's illness.

A routine tour of the Yorkville Magistrate's Court, 153 East Fiftyseventh Street, by members of the State Commission of Correction, led yesterday to the revelation that prisoners awaiting arraignment get no lunch, even if they have money to pay for it.
