The model of the United States pavilion of the Paris International Exposition, which has been on exhibition for the last week at 647 Fifth Avenue, was inspected yesterday afternoon by Thomas J. Watson, commissioner general of the American section of the exposition; Frederick A.

Senators, weary of what they regarded as repetition of arguments against the Roosevelt Court Reorganization Bill, led a movement in the Judiciary Committee today to try to force the closing Saturday of the public hearings on the measure.

Sale of the controlling interest in the Midamerica Corporation, top holding company of the Van Sweringen rail and real estate empire, now held by a charitable foundation established by George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., was the subject of conversations today between Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, and Donaldson Brown, a director of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and
Judge Engert, who is presiding over the People's Court in the trial of seven Catholics for high treason, expressed pain rather than anger tolay at reports of the case in cerain Austrian papers.

Miss Kathleen V. Mulcahy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Mulcahy of this place, has chosen May 3 as the date for her marriage to Arnold Rogers Storrs, son of Mrs. F. Rogers Storrs of Hartford. The ceremony will take place in St. Joseph's Cathedral.

Following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of March: Total imports [pound]82,690,000; exports of British products [pound]43,460,000; re-exports [pound]6,710,000; total exports [pound]50,170,000; excess of imports [Pound]32,520,000.

Charles F. Noyes Co., Inc., has arranged a first mortgage loan of $220,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for 5 years to finance the erection of a 2-story building, 113x80 feet on the southwest corner of 52d St. and Sixth Av., for the 100 W. 52d St. Corp.. J. L. Fisher, president. Jerome Eisner was attorney for the borrower.
Units of the Spanish Government fleet were reported tonight heading for the north coast of Spain, the scene of an Insurgent blockade, and hence a naval battle in the Bay of Biscay is expected.

Federal Judge Guy L. Fake, somewhat confused by the legalistic high jinks of the fight world, deferred judgment tonight on Madison Square Garden's request for an injunction against the James J. Braddock-Joe Louis fight.
Following are the prepared texts of Pan-American Day addresses delivered by President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull today before the governing board of the PanAmerican Union:

A divorce was granted here today to Edwin C. (Alabama) Pitts, former star of the Sing Sing prison football team by Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich. Mrs. Cathryn Kruse Pitts of 74 Freeman Street, Brooklyn, the wife, was accused of misconduct while Pitts was serving a prison sentence for robbery.
The Fordham freshman baseball team opened its 1937 season yesterday with a 2-to-1 triumph over the Snyder High School nine of Jersey City at Fordham Field.

In a meeting which lasted from 11 A. M. on Tuesday until 3 A. M. yesterday, the management slate of directors of R. Hoe Co., Inc., was elected, with the exception that a minority group elected one of the eleven members of the board, according to Allen W. Lishawa, secretary of the company.

Stanley Galowin, City Athletic Club star, has been honored with the No. 1 position in the Group 1 ranking of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association for the 1936-37 season, according to the ratings released yesterday.

A further indication of the activity of general business in the United States was seen yesterday in the report of the Census Bureau placing the consumption of cotton in this country in March at almost 780,000 bales, the largest consumption in any single month.

Reports of business leasing yesterday reflected an easing of the active seasonal interest in new space which has characterized the last several days. The bulk of the contracts r ported were with manufacturers and retailers of garments and allied lines. The list follows:

Reports from ninety-four Class 1 railroads, made public today by the Association of American Railroads, show that in March these roads had an estimated operating revenue of $311,356,969, compared to $265,188,710 in March 1936, and $373,310,257 in March, 1930.

A resolution opposing the most-favored nation principle of the reciprocal trade agreements was passed yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Board of Trade in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The resolution declared that the principle had the effect of "granting tariff concessions to nations which do not grant substantially equivalent concessions."

A plot of 10,000 square feet on the northwest corner of Austin Street and Sixty-third Drive, Rego Park, Queens, has been sold to Long Beach Equities, Inc., for early improvement, by Roman-Caswell Company, broker.

Pompoon, 1936 Juvenile champion and Kentucky Derby future book favorite, will make his first start of the year this afternoon when New York racing begins its 171-day season at the Jamaica course. He is in with 116 pounds. but since he is a 3-year-old, Pompoon will carry top impost in the field of ten when the scale of weights is considered.

Faced with a shrinkage from the expected revenues which, it appears now, may run as high as $500,000,000 by June 30, and consequent dislocations of budget plans for the fiscal year 1938, the administration moved today toward an important decision.

The East and West divided eight national A. A. U. boxing championships as the Philadelphia and Detroit teams each provided three new titleholders during the third and final program at the Boston Garden tonight.

Arthur Arnow, insurance broker and former president of the General Brokers Association of the Metropolitan District, died yesterday in the Polyclinic Hospital here after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage in Albany on Tuesday.

Operations of A. I. Namm Son in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 30 resulted in a net profit of $65,503 after deductions of $168,672 for interest on funded debt, $199,042 provision for depreciation and $33,412 Federal normal income tax and surtax on undistributed earnings, according to the annual stockholders report submitted by Benjamin H. Namm, president.

The flood of new magazines, which at the present time is the outstanding development in the field, was augmented yesterday by announcement of four new publications, two of which will be in the increasingly popular pocket size. Re-Vue will be the name of a new monthly news magazine from the Enrey Publishing Corporation, 45 West Forty-fifth Street, of which Fillmore Hyde is president.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., and subsidiary companies had a consolidated net profit of $4,067,696 for the year ended on Jan. 31 after $96,000 Federal surtax on undistributed profits, according to a report issued yesterday. After deduction of minority interests in.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. was granted today an income tax refund of $37,695 by the Internal Revenue Bureau. The bureau found that Mr. Rockefeller's income taxes for the year 1929 had been overpaid.

In oral argument today before the Securities and Exchange Commission on applications for unlisted trading in seven securities registered on other Exchanges, the San Francisco Curb Exchange stressed the contention 'that this privilege was important if the Exchange was to remain in existence.

Water St., s. w. cor. Burling Slip, 24.10x 63.2; trustee, will of Sarah A. P. Fay. to Martin A. Ingram, Penwarne, Falmouth, England (conveys 1/8 interest, in distribution). Broome St., 156. 25x100; Frieda lltis to Morris Testa, 941 Intervale Av., Bronx; mtg., $10,000.

William E. S. Griswold Jr., also Mrs. Lila James Roney, in 157 East 72d St.; Alice Frank Merriam, also Charles V. Stehlin, in 308 East 79th St.; Duff Conger, Inc., brokers. Seymour Finn, in the Majestic, 115 Central Park West; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.
Mrs. J. Addison Woolley gave a dinner last night in the Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza, followed by bridge in her apartment at the hotel.
Boston University subdued Harvard, 9-7, to spoil the Crimson's home baseball opener at Soldiers Field today. The Terriers played steadier ball, although fielding on both sides was weak.

Harold B. Butler, director of the International Labor Organization, told the World Textile Conference today that if the conference report should point out the need of considering the problem' of extra-territoriality in China in relation to bettering conditions for textile employes in China's foreign settlements, the organization would be able to approach the governments involved and attain the end desired.

At torney General Cummings and Secretary Wallace emphatically challenged today the view that the Supreme Court's validation of the Wagner Labor Act had removed the need, as the administration sees it, of reorganizing the Supreme Court.

Captain Eric Erskine Loch, leader of the Andes-Amazon Expedition under the auspices of the Museum of the American Indian (Heye Foundation), returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Rita after sixteen months in Ecuador.

Paul Green, who received a Pulitzer Prize for his play "Abraham's Bosom" and who has also published novels and short stories and worked in Hollywood, will be on the staff of the Bread Loaf Writers Conference at Middlebury, Vt.. this coming August.

Miss Alison Williams Coe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Coe of Stamford, has planned her marriage to Theodore K. Hess of New York for June 5 in the First Congregational Church here, with the Rev. Allen Hackett officiating. A reception will follow at the Coe home.

Still in conflict with Governor Lehman over his proposal for a one cent a gallon increase in the tax on motor vehicle fuel, Republican chiefs in the Legislature reached a decision today to propose next week a substitute levy designed to bring in $20,000,000, the same amount which the Lehman plan would yield.
The last member of the original Bronx detective squad, Detective Thomas Sullivan, died at his home, 2,400 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, early yesterday of erysipelas. His age was 65.

Edward G. (Foxy Ned) Hanon, pioneer of modern baseball and manager of the celebrated Baltimore Orioles of the Nineties-including the late John J. McGraw and Uncle Wilbert Robinson-died in a hospital here late tonight.

In a report departing radically from recommendations made by President Roosevelt and his special committee on farm tenancy, the House Committee on Agriculture submitted to the lower chamber today a $450,000,000 program for aiding tenant farmers on the road to ownership and retiring submarginal lands that many of them now operate.
Arthur Williams, retired vice president of the New York Edison Company, died at a hospital here late today of a heart ailment. His age was 68. He had been here since January.

The Boys and Students Clothing Manufacturers Association stands pat on the previously announced "agreement" of its members to adhere to a maximum 7 per cent volume discount on merchandise for Fall, it was reported yesterday after a meeting here of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Associtation, at which the refusal manufacturers to change their policy was discussed.

Joe DiMaggio, Yankee outfielder who has been troubled with a lame throwing arm during the training season, will be operated on tomorrow for the removal of his tonsils. This was decided on yesterday following an examination by Dr. Girard Oberrender, personal physician to Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the club.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John M. Allen of Gladstone of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn A. Allen, to the Rev. Richard D. Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Jones of this city.

Albert H. Wiggin has offered to pay $2,000,000 in settlement of stockholders' suits alleging that he was responsible for huge losses suffered by the Chase National Bank and the Amerex Holding Corporation, formerly Chase Securities Corporation, on loans and investments made while he was their chief executive officer, it was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is the confident expectation of the advocates of the Wagner act, which has just been sustained by the Supreme Court, that it will prevent strikes in industry, at least until after disputes have been subjected to "collective bargaining." Strikes may occur, of course, in consequence of the failure of that method of adjustment.

Sir James Jeans, British astronomer, and Lady Jeans are among the passengers sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others departing are Princess Jennie Chikhmatoff, Viscount Traprain, Lord Riverdale, Marchesa Carignani, Mme. Stella Andreva, Miss Patricia Johnstone, Gwen Farrar, actress;
David F. Guiney, retired mathematics instructor at George Washington High School, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday at his home, 145 Seaman Avenue. He was 55 years old.

Three veteran employes, discharged twenty months ago for union activities, were reinstated today by the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company of Yonkers as a result of the Supreme Court decisions upholding the National Labor Retations Act.

Former Representative Charles G. Bond of Brooklyn announced last night that he had decided to enter the Republican primaries as a candidate for Mayor. Mr. Bond at one time was the Republican candidate for Borough President against the late James J. Byrne.

After nearly a week's discussion as to whose business it was to do so, the Red flags, tricolors and People's Front symbols have been removed by the police from the top of the entrance gates and other buildings of the Paris exhibition.

Passage of the Brownell bill to remove flaws in the titles of many millions of dollars' worth of waterfront property in New York City was urged today at a hearing before the Senate Committee on the Affairs of the City of New York.

A collection of 119 letters by Elizabeth Barrett Browning and ten letters by Robert Browning was sold at auction last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., for $4,700. All the letters were addressed to Mrs. Browning's sisters,...
Ilya Ilf, who with his collaborator, Eugene Petroff, was the Soviet Union's best known satirical writer, died today of tuberculosis. He was 40 .

Miss Marcia Stranahan was married today in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here to Howard Lewis Jr. The bride is the daughter of Robert A. Stranahan of Toledo and Westport, Conn., and Mrs. Lester Scott of Los Angeles. Mr. Lewis is the eldest St. son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lewis of Toledo.
Governor Hoffman signed today the legislative bill making $20,000 available to pay the reward offered by the State for the arrest and conviction of the slayer of the Lindbergh baby.

Another lawyer was arrested yesterday on an indictment in Assistant District Attorney Bernard C. Botein's accident fraud investigation. He was H. Lee Kanner, 34 years old, of 1,710 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, with an office at 299 Broadway.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 13: BRIGADIER GENERAL Warfield, A. B., assistant to the quartermaster general, three days leave, April 13.

Thomas Owen of Louisville, Ky., and Ira Kitzmiller of Camden, N. J., bowling in the final shift of singles and doubles keglers, put on a grand finish to a hitherto uneventful day as they accounted for major changes in the standings of the American Bowling Congress championships yesterday at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.
Movements on the Chicago livestock market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:
The Park Department and the Municipal Art Commission have approved plans for a statue of Peter Stuyvesant in Stuyvesant Square, Second Avenue and Sixteenth Street, it was announced yesterday.

Ninety-two lots in Huntington, Balcom, Graef and Dewey Avenues, in the Bronx, have been sold to the Hanlyn Realty Company for improvement with private homes. Joseph P. Day made the sale for the Kent Road Realty Company.

Jimmy Caras, 26-year-old holder of the world pocket billiard championship, failed to retain a 79-point advantage which he had amassed early in his meeting with Onofrio Lauri of Brooklyn at Ponzi's Academy last night and eventually fell before the latter's brilliant rally in one of the most thrilling exhibitions witnessed here.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Luff Carman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence M. Carman of Quogue, L. I., to Alanson N. Rogers, son of Mrs. Alanson P. Rogers of Westhampton.

Steadfast pacifism expressed by Lord Riverdale at a luncheon given for him yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, brought applause from many American industrialists at the luncheon.

Slender Miss Katherine Rawls of Miami Beach, Fla., retained her 300-yard medley championship with the greatest of ease at the opening of the women's national swimming meet in the Lake Shore Athletic Club pool tonight to account for a new record total of twenty-two A. A. U. titles.

W. E. Hutton 2d, testifying today at hearings on the Securities and Exchange Commission's charge that W. E. Hutton Co. manipulated Atlas Tack stock, said he had told several customers and friends he thought Atlas " a good speculative buy." Mr. Hutton is the manager of the firm's Detroit office.

The marriage of Miss Anna Gisondi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gisondi of Cos Cob, to Arthur LaMorte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank LaMorte of New York, will take place on May 15, in St. Catherine's Church, Riverside.

William C. Hunt, whose Senatorial election was set aside by a Circuit Court decision and who subsequently resigned, issued a statement today calling on Republican Senators to seat his Democratic opponent Jesse D. Ludlam.

Miss Elizabeth Burnet Glover, daughter of Mrs. Bryce Metcalf of Ardsley, N. Y., and the late Dawson Coleman Glover, will be married to Fanshawe Lindsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Sinderen Lindsley of Lawrence, L. I., on May 6, in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, here.

The marriage of Miss Genevieve G. Brady of 14 East Eighty-ninth Street and Gladstone, N. J., to Anderson Fowler of New York will take place on April 23 in the chapel of Hamilton Farm, Gladstone, the Summer home of the bride-elect's stepmother, Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting, and Mr. Cutting.

The nation's safest bus drivers have been selected after a year of exhaustive examination of the records of more than sixty men, Carl W. Stocks, editor of the magazine Bus Transportation, which made the safety awards, said yesterday.

The Pettengill bill to repeal the "longand-short-haul" clause of the Interstate Commerce Act was passed today by the House, 268 to 120, after a spirited debate which was prolonged by successful efforts of opponents of the Gavagan antilynching bill to prevent that bill from being considered.
The Manhattan College freshman nine launched its campaign under its new coach, Charles Barkaus, by dropping a 6-4 decision to the High School of Commerce team yesterday on the loser's diamond.

The government submarine C-3, which sank in Malaga Harbor last December after a terrific explosion of undetermined cause, has been raised secretly by the Insurgents and towed to port in Northeastern Spain to be rehabilitated as a new unit of General Francisco Franco's navy.

Ten Persons were injured, five seriously- when part of the wooden floor of the cathedral collapsed during he services at the installation to-day of Archbishop Martinez, the nominal head of the Catholic Church in Mexico.

Charged with violation of Interstate Commerce Act rate provisions, the Howard Trucking Corporation of 550 West Twenty-fifth Street was fined $20,000 by Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday but he suspended payment on all but S3,000 of this.

The increase in bread prices recorded in several large cities this week was termed by W. M. Quinlan of the American Bakers Association today "a natural and long-overdue reaction" to rising production and distribution costs.

Accepting the argument that the only issue in the coming municipal campaign is between "decent and indecent" government, the New York Young Republican Club endorsed last night the candidacy for re-election of Mayor La Guardia by a vote of 114 to 19.

The Board of Education has approved the following appointments and transfers of teachers and others in various branches of the school system: APPOINTMENTS High Schools STRAUBENMULLER TEXTILE - Jeanne Greenberg.
Juan March, Spanish millionaire, has been staying at a hotel here for several days, but has refused to see newspaper men or give any indication of the nature of his mission.
Nearing 70, and the end of his career as Prime Minister, Mr. STANLEY BALDWIN in his recent speeches has the air of a man musing in public on the lessons life and experience have taught him.

J. Davis, Lawrenceville School pitcher, turned in a no-hit, no-run game today against Chestnut Hill Academy of Philadelphia, winning, 4-0, in seven innings. With R. Davis catching, he struck out seven men and permitted five bases on balls.

A reception will be given by tne American Merchant Marine Library Association this afternoon at its book-week headquarters, 680 Madison Avenue, for authors who assisted the organization in its sixteenth annual Seaman's Book Week, April 5-12.

The firmer tendency in the stock market here continued today and most sections went ahead. Gilt-edge issues were quiet on the whole, but were fractionally lower where changed. Among the foreign loans, German securities did well. International stocks suffered from profit taking. United States Steel, for one, had a setback.

Belmont Av., 2,130 (11-3083), Chiarina Imitato to William Cohn, trustee, 15 E. 58th St., three years, 5 per cent; $35,000. Boynton Av., 1,119 (14-3740), Bennie Axelrod to State Mortgage Commission, extends mtg. to March 1, 1938, at 5 per cent: $10.250.

The outstanding occurrence in the fourth round of the international chessmasters' tournament, contested today at the Ostend Casino, was the defeat of Paul Keres of Estoniahis second in two days-by H. Grob of Switzerland, leading in the competition.
Robert R. Lansburgh, a member of the New York Curb Exchange, has been admitted to the firm of Bear, Stearns Co.

The Italian delegation to the conference for the abolition of Egyptian capitulations worked today with the French against the Egyptian and British groups. This indicated Italy would seek only to protect her material interests in Egypt, which would tend to force her to the French side.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered 10 points in the early trading yesterday on the strength in the stock market and a let-up in the pressure to sell but a setback in the last hour left the list with losses of 1 to 4 points.

Both because of what it says specifically, and because of what may fairly be read between the lines, there will be widespread approval of President ROOSEVELT'S letter to his department chiefs on the subject of finances.

The city will spend $584,000 on direct relief for the needy blind from May 1, when Federal and State social security funds become available for the first time, until Dec. 31, William Hodson. Commissioner of Public Welfare, estimated yesterday.

Well-informed circles admitted today the likelihood that visits by prominent German personalities to Italy might take place in the not very distant future. Some of the visits, they said, will be private and will be followed by visits of a more official character.

Charles E. Wharton of Kenton, Ohio, 78-year-old president of the National Farm Council and Federated Farm Clubs of Ohio, declared yesterday in an interview here that "the feelings of the farmers- of America in regard to sit-down strikes were expressed at Hershey, Pa."

Southern New York Area. Each of the following Signal Corps Reserve Officers is relieved from his present assignment or attachment to the organization indicated, and is released for assignment to the New Jersey and Delaware Reserve Area:

The First and Merchants National Bank of Richmond, Va., in its report for March 31, showed total deposits of $67,986,380 and total assets of $75,100,500, compared, respectively, with $74,924,017 and $81,908,050 on Dec. 31.

Harley Jackson of the Yale freshmen held Ansonia High to four singles and fanned ten in seven innings today in a baseball game partly played in showers as the yearlings won, 14-3. The Ansonia pitchers gave eight passes and the fielding was marred by the muddy diamond.

New steel business declined last week, according to the Iron Age summary, which declares that the contraction was natural in view of the heavy tonnages ordered in March, together with the facts that the mills have little steel to sell and that consumers are generally well covered. Incoming business remains fairly good when compared with February but is considerably below the extraordinary volume of late March.

The Central Vermont Public Service Corporation in 1936 had a net income of $339,965, against $361,839 in the preceding year, the report just issued shows. Gross operating revenues were $1,996,413 against $1,833,177.
The report for 1936 of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $10,217,928 after charges, taxes and reserves.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company announced today that it would construct in its works at Altoona, Pa., 2,800 steel freight cars and the chassis for eleven electric passenger locomotives at a cost of slightly more than $10,750,000. Electrical parts for the locomotives will be supplied by manufacturing companies.

An English-type home, containing eight rooms and three baths, on Vanderbilt Road, Scarsdale, Westchester County, has been sold to G. R. McNear by the Bowery Savings Bank. Chauncey B. Griffen negotiated the deal.

The speaker at the luncheon meeting of the management division of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx today in the East 148th St. Restaurant will be Arthur V. Sheridan, chief engineer of the Bronx. Monroe Miller Co., Inc., will move their offices on May 1 to 270 Broadway.

Despite a late-hour effort to build up a case for Tommy Farr, British heavyweight titleholder, Max Baer, former world champion from California, today remained the 3-to-1 choice to beat the Welshman in their twelve-round non-title bout tomorrow night.

Dr. Armgaard Karl Graves, selfstyled former German spy, who was put aboard the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines at 10 A. M. yesterday for deportation to Germany, obtained a last-minute stay half an hour later and was sent back to Ellis Island.

Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, denied tonight reports from the East that he was planning to relinquish his post to accept the chairmanship of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, which became vacant with the death of Elihu Root.

It's easy to tell that things are popping all along the fishing fronts. Most of the mail has a trouty flavor, fellow-passengers on the commuters' trains are going down to work with leather rod cases under their arms (bound for the repair man) and enthusiasts like Harry Bruno call you up and rave for thirty minutes about a fifteen-anda-half-inch steelhead trout that fell for a bucktail in Gypsy Trail Lake on opening day.

The Metropolitan Golf Association announced yesterday that the sectional qualifying play for the United States open championship will be held on the Essex County Country Club course, West Orange, N. J., on Tuesday, June 1.

It is gratifying, if rather unexpected, to see moral pressure win at last in the New Jersey Senate. Late last week Senator HUNT of Cape May, to whom a circuit judge had denied a certificate of election on account of election frauds, was still clinging to his seat and most Republican Senators were clinging to him.

Demand was very uneven. Steer hinds and ribs and veal moved slowly. Lamb business improved in slaughter houses but most cuts moved slowly in wholesale markets Fresh pork cuts showed a tendency of slowing up. Demand for kosher meats opened slowly, with beef and lamb about steady and veal somewhat stronger as reported by the United States Department of A priculture.

Max Yergan, a Negro, has been recommended for appointment to the faculty of City College to conduct a new course in Negro history. If he is appointed, Mr. Yergan will be the first of his race to hold a post on the City College faculty.

Pleas for peace within and beyond the boundaries of the Western Hemisphere were made today by President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull in addresses at the Pan American Union on the occasion of the seventh annual observance of Pan American Day.

-By the unanimous vote of twenty-five of the twenty-six registered voters. of this borough, the borough's name was changed tonight from Teterboro to Bendix in honor of Vincent Bendix, whose corporation is planning a $3,000,000 plant here for the manufacture of airplane instruments. Why the twenty-sixth voter remained away from the polls was not learned.
Charles Ferdinand Coyne, a building conractor in the Oranges for more han half a century, died last night Lt his home here of a heart ailment Lt the age of 77.

Plans for a new apartment building in upper Broadway, Manhattan, a $400,000 garage and office building in South Jamaica, Queens, and for two multi-family houses in Brooklyn, featured the construction projects filed in the city yesterday.

Factory employment in the State increased 2.5 per cent and payrolls 5.8 per cent from the middle of February to the middle of March, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today. A year ago the percentage of employment was identical, but the payroll increase was only 4.2 per cent.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kessler of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ethel Kessler, to William H. Ackerman, son of Mrs. Bertha Ackerman of Millville. Miss Kessler attended Columbia University.
The Rev. John Francis Maxwell of St. Mary's Catholic Church in Hackensack, N. J., died in a hospital today after a short illness. His age was 54. Father Maxwell came here two weeks ago.

The original notes of Dr. Charles S. Taft, an army surgeon who saw Abraham Lincoln shot and helped care for him during his last hours, are included in an exhibition opened today by Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach on the seventy-second anniversary of Lincoln's assassination.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States on April 3 amounted to 297,374,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today.

The social service department of the Lincoln Hospital will be the beneficiary of a bundle tea tomorrow at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Brice Armistead Frey, 520 East Eighty-sixth Street. Each guest is the requested to bring a bundle of clothing or discarded household articles.
A particuJarly poor set of examination papers inspired Professor John Madigan, head of the department of physics at St. Thomas College, to mete out punishment in an odorous manner.

The United Brewers Industrial Foundation, dedicated to maintaining cordial relations between the industry and the public and to preventing a repetition of practices of the days before prohibition, was officially launched yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

With the title "The Scepter of Freedom" the Schwarze Korps, the journal of the secret political police, publishes an article deriding Americans for arming policemen with clubs. With National Socialism this "barbaric custom has been abandoned." the German police carrying pistols.

Mayor La Guardia and Democratic Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan engaged in a sharp verbal encounter yesterday after the Senator had denounced the Mayor's new city Power Plant Bill in Albany as a piece of insincere political legislation.

Imports of gold totaling $30,308,400, of which $22,318,800 arrived late on Tuesday and $7,989,600 came in yesterday, were reported yesterday in the daily gold statement of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank received reports during the day from commercial banks of the further engagement of $7,266,000 gold in England for shipment here.

Statements of the presidents of nine New England colleges and universities in opposition to the Roosevelt plan to reorganize the Supreme Court were filed with the Senate Judiciary Committee today by the Volunteer Citizens Committee, with headquarters at Boston.

The pleasant business of scoring a 15-5 victory over the Norfolk Tars today had Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers feeling as if they had reached the end of a treasure hunt trail in Bain Field. More lost batting eyes were found than the boys could have expected in their most optimistic moments.

Max D. Steuer, speaking on the radio 1 hour and 54 minutes last night, urged the voters of New York City and the United States to bring pressure upon their Representatives and Senators to pass President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan. Mr. Steuer's address was broadcast over Station WMCA.

Governor Frank Murphy took issue today with Henry Ford's reported attitude toward labor unions. Mr. Ford has been quoted to the effect that he considers it "foolish" for his employes to enroll in labor unions.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are April 13 unless specified: At Hongkong: Canopus, Isabel, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 40, 41, Sacramento. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Jacob Jones, April 14: Conyngham.

The Rev. Dr. Alexander Lyons, rabbi of Congregation Beth EIohim, Eighth Avenue and Garfield Place, Brooklyn, is about to relinquish his pulpit duties, but will continue as minister - at - large, it was made known yesterday.

Patrick Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, declared at the installation of Bishop John A. Duffy today that modern man apparently had become "lost in labyrinths of his own creation." Cardinal Hayes preached a sermon at colorful ceremonies in St. Joseph's Cathedral.

An extra-curricular program of study of United States history, open to both college students and the general public, with competitive examinations and prizes, will be started by Harvard University this Spring.

Governor Lehman considered some of the many bills the Legislature has sent him in the last few days. He wrote a letter to Colonel William Gorham Rice, retiring president of the State Civil Service Commission, congratulating him on his services to the State.

Francisco Garces Gana, Minister of Finance, has outlined Chile's finance position. His statement says that, although this year's budget is balanced, the year-end results will not be so satisfactory if expenditures beyond those contemplated are voted in the next few months.

In the Dail Eireann this evening, Sean MacEntee, the Minister of Finance, introduced the Fianna Fail government's sixth budget before a packed chamber. Since this was the government's general election budget, many expected that it would include several spectacular surprises, but Mr. MacEntee disappointed them. With a moderate "clear surplus" of [pound]464,842 available, he took the conservative course of affording relief in the prices of essential food commodities.

Dr. Leroy Wiley McCay, Emeritus Professor of Chemistry in Princeton University and former chairman of the Chemistry Department, died late last night at his home here after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

Mrs. Helen R. Valden of Norwalk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Robinson of Danbury, was married to Sidney N. Terry of Bethel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isah Terry of Bethel, Monday morning at the residence of the Rev. John Maurice Deyo in Brookfield Center.

Yale overwhelmed Columbia, 17-2, today in the Elis' opening game of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League season. Rain fell immediately before play opened and during the second and third innings, the final frames being played in gathering dark on a heavy field.
Plans for establishment of a "council of members of the dress industry" were launched last night at a meeting of the National Dress Manufacturers Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

Paul Dean's sore arm is worrying him again. With the Cardinals' 1937 pennant hopes pinned largely on him, Paul's announcement today that the arm had become stiff following five innings of work at Birmingham Monday came as a severe blow.

Following his demand for "solidarity" in his Cabinet, Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario forced the resignation today of David Croll, Minister of Labor, Public Welfare and Municipal Affairs, and of Attorney General Arthur Roebuck because they opposed his fight against the C. I. O. "and communism in general" in the General Motors strike at Oshawa.

Hard hitting and good pitching were combined by City College at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday in defeating the Panzer College baseball team of East Orange, N. J., 16-2. Arky Soltes and Johnny Mauro, pitching for the Lavender, allowed nine hits.

Edgar Harrison Foster, who was Village President of Amityville from 1904 to 1908 and who served as Mayor of the village from 1931 to 1935, died last night at his home in West Islip Road, aged 71 years.

A rifle volley sounded and a wreath was thrown today upon the spot where twentyfive years ago tonight the liner Titanic wrote in frantic SOS signal the first lines in history's worst iceberg disaster.

The Federal Power Commission refused today to permit counsel for six affiliates of the Associated Gas and Electrio Company to examine all correspondence exchanged by the commission, the Governor of Pennsylvania and the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission.

A total of $495,500 of Kingdom of Belgium external loan thirty-year sinking fund 7 per cent gold bonds due in 1955 will be redeemed on June 1 through the sinking fund, it was announced yesterday by J. P. Morgan Co. and the Guaranty Trust Company,

The Federal grand jury today indicted two of the Marx brothers, Groucho and Chico, on charges of violating the National Copyright Laws, a misdemeanor. They are accused of broadcasting over the radio last September a skit (Mr. Diffle and Mr. Daffle) without permission of the writers, Garrett and Carroll Graham.

MANHATTAN BARNARD, JOHN HALL (March 31, 1936). Gross assets, $47,184; net, $39,872. To Agnes O'Connor Russell, niece, Robert B., and Gerald W. O'Connor, nephews, one-fourth residue each; Anne H.. Emily G., Frances B., and Elizabeth O'Connor, grandnieces, one-sixteenth residue each;

The President Roosevelt of the United States Lines, scheduled to sail at noon yesterday for Europe with 217 passengers, was held at her pier last night by a sit-down strike of sixty-five members of the deck and engine crews.
A revolution of the masses in the Soviet Union to overthrow Joseph Stalin and end his "bureaucracy" is necessary, Leon Trotsky declared today before the subcommission of inquiry headed by John Dewey.

Two officers of the Empire State Paper Corporation, who were convicted last week of defrauding the government of between $20,000 and $30,000 by their failure to turn in true income tax returns, received prison sentences when they appeared yesterday before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

Fifteen thousand persons filed income, tax returns yesterday at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, where today clerks and auditors 'of the State Tax Commission will remain on duty until 9 P. M. to help taxpayers wishing to file before the deadline at mid-night.

The California Railroad Commission has approved the merger of the Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation into the Southern California Gas Company in the manner asked by the companies in an amended petition.
Major UIiseno Franco Granero, chief of the Presidential aides, died this mornng in the Military City Hospital Af cancer of the stomach after a rolonged illness. He was 56 years lad.

The Tri-Continental Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $59,438,509 on March 31 before deducting bank loans and funded debt but after provision for normal Federal income tax on unrealized appreciation. This indicated a net coverage of $5,185.73 for each $1,000 of bank loans and debentures, $314.96 for each share of preferred stock and $13.47 for a share of common stock.

Stocks eased slightly, but closed irregularly net higher after early gains; turnover, 1,480,100 shares. United States Government issues strengthened and closed higher, corporate bonds also advanced; foreign loans mixed; transactions, $14,574,400.

A Rhodes graduate of Oxford from Nashville, Tenn., and an undergraduate from the University of North Carolina shared the spotlight in the united North and South tennis championships today as they eliminated two favorites on the clay courts of the Pinehurst Country Club.

Mrs. C. A. Van Duzee of Redding, Conn., and Cairo, Ga., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Hawthorne Deming, to Paul Willard Howe, son of Mrs. Willard D. Howe of Pleasantville, N. Y., and the late Mr. Howe.

Jac Gorodetzky, 23-year-old Russian-born violinist, made his local debut yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. He played the Beethoven sonata in G, Opus 30, No. 3; the Bach solo sonata in G minor; Chausson's "Poeme," and shorter items by Corelli-Busch. Paganini, Boulanger and De Falla.
Fred Perry and Ellsworth. Vines will bring their tennis tour back to the metropolitan district when they meet at the County Center in White Plains tonight.

The sale by the Delaware Hudson Company of the Champlain Transportation Company to H. W. Corbin of Burlington, Vt., for $100,000, was disclosed in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday. All the 2,950 shares of the subsidiary's common shares were transferred under the terms of the sale.

Isolation at last of vitamin A in pure crystalline form, with an increase in potency of 1,000,000 vitamin units above the best present concentrates, was announced today before the meeting of the American Chemical Society at the University of North Carolina.

The cornerstone for the nine-story glass brick building which Lilly Dache will erect at 78-80 East Fiftysixth Street will be laid at 11:30 A. M. today. Among those invited to take part in the ceremony are Charles Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General in New York;

Since no modification of Harry L. Hopkins's order to cut the number of WPA workers drawn from nonrelief sources or receiving wages in excess of the security scale has been received from Washington, local officials of the Works Progress Administration prepared last night to put the first of the cuts into effect today.

Chilean officials welcomed today reports that the first group of Spanish refugees had left the Chilean Embassy in Madrid. The difficulties encountered over the refugees' evacuation had caused anxiety.

Jurists, attorneys and others joined yesterday in honoring the memories of Chief Justice Frederic L. Kernochan and Justice Thomas J. Nolan, both of the Court of Special Sessions, who died early this year.

Keeping an unofficial promise made last month by Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, to Senator Burton K. Wheeler, chairman of the special Senate committee to investigate holding companies, the Stock Exchange yesterday amended its rules to control its govornors in matters of listing.

Dr. Victor Mildenberg, since 1925 director of the Queens Bureau of Preventable Diseases of the New York Board of Health, with which he had been connected for thirtytwo years, died on Tuesday night, after a brief illness, at his residence, 148-17 Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, queens.

T. O. M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger, Endeavour II, was relaunched amid cheers of an enthusiastic crowd today. The racing yacht, winner of many events after its launching in 1936, had a full crew when she entered the water.

A syndicate composed of the American Trust Company, AngloCalifornia National Bank and the Bankamerica Company purchased yesterday an issue of $2,241,596 of State of California registered warrants as 13/4 s at par plus a premium of $1,096.54.

The Census Bureau reported today the domestic cotton industry established an all-time consumption peak in March by using 779,302 bales of lint. The previous high month was June, 1933, with 697,261 bales consumed.
A bill to amend the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act of 1936 was introduced in the House today by Representative Healey, Massachusetts, Democrat.
Payment of six years' arrears in preferred share dividends of the Hudson's Bay Company was announced at the company's annual meeting here today by P. Ashley Cooper, governor.

All records of the New York Curb Exchange were broken yesterday when the board of governors approved twenty listing applications in a single day. These covered twenty stock issues and one bond issue, one company having filed for two stock issues. Previously the record was held by April 8, 1936, when fifteen applications went through.

Thomas J. (Scratch) McCarthy, 62 years old, one of the most notorious check forgers in the country, who in the last thirty-six years had been convicted of ten previous offenses in this and other cities, was found guilty yesterday in General Sessions on a first-degree forgery indictment.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 12: REAR ADMIRAL Neal, G. F., commander of mine craft, Battle Force, to duty as senior member, Board of Inspection and Survey, PacifiC Coast Section Long Beach, Calif.

A strong westerly gale lashing the gray seas off the Basque coast to fury and shrouding the mountains of Guipuzcoa with driving rain squalls has temporarily halted the battle for Bilbao and reduced the activity of the Insurgent naval forces to a minimum.

Westchester County's proposed new charter, as outlined in the bill of Assemblyman Gamble, Westchester Republican, went through the Assembly today by unanimous vote. Senator Garrity, Westchester Democrat, is sponsoring the proposal in the Senate, where approval seems assured.

Although Lambros Demetrios Callimahos, the Greek-American flautist, gave his first public concert two seasons ago in Munich, he had not been heard on this side of the Atlantic until last night, when he appeared in a recital at Town Hall. Glowing accounts of his abilities had preceded his American debut.

Reports from abroad that the wife of Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff had been "exiled to the Urals" were officially denied here today. She is now at Sverdlovsk University where she is teaching Basic English, which she has long been promoting in Russia.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and including the Commercial Investment Trust, Inc.; A. G. Becker Co., Inc.; Hallgarten Co. and R. S. Dickson Co., Inc., has offered for subscription by the public 188,800 of the 198,800 shares of common stock of the Burlington Mills Corporation purchased by this group. The stock has been priced at $18 a share.

Three Larchmont husbands who were motivated by a desire to introduce "business efficiency and economy" in their homes abandoned today all plans to promote an organization they had christened the Westchester Home Conservation Movement.

175th St. (11-2878). s e corner of Montgomery Av., 148x110; New Deal Associates, Inc., to Lillian Cotkin, 1,895 Belmont Av.; mtg., $172,000. 181st St. (11-3083), n e corner of Belmont Av., 41x80; William Cohn, trustee, to Chiarina Imitato. 1.900 Lexington Av.
Electric power output increased last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 107.3 from 105.5. It was 100.4 for the week ended April 11, 1936.

Champion Wolvey Noel of Clairedale, sealyham terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. W. O. Penney of Riverhead, L. I., and handled by Leonard Brumby of Hicksville, L. I., tonight won the special for best in show as the third annual dog show of the Tri-State Kennel Association came to a close.

Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, and Mrs. Russell will preside tonight over the Dean's Reception, a traditional social event at the college. They will receive faculty members and students in Dodge Hall.
American universities and colleges must train youth for "a new and graver social responsibility,". Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, said last night.

The Legal Gazette announced today the names of ninety-seven more Germans deprived of citizenship on the ground that "through their attitude they have violated their duty of loyalty toward the Reich and people and damaged Germany's interests."

Several hundred men and women of prominence in society have made reservations for the gala luncheon and fashion show entitled "Dawn to Dusk" which will be held today in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The engagement of Miss Clara Jaffray Reese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Mesier Reese of Yonkers, N. Y., to Dr. John Ellis Knight of West Roxbury, Mass., has been announced by her parents.

Without waiting for the American Federation of Labor formally to expel unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, the Lewis organization will continue to organize the basic industries and will issue certificates of affiliation at once to eligible organizations among the 300 which have applied for charters, Mr. Lewis announced today.
Designed for the susbstratosphere more than 30,000 feet above the earth's surface; a huge transport plane was within two weeks of completion at the Lockheed Aircraft Company plant today.

Resolutions opposing Federal fi nancial aid for retail "co-ops" and condemning the practice of some manufacturers in making "discrim inatory" sizes of products available to variety stores were adopted yes terday at the closing session of the two-day convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania of the New York Pharmaceutical Council, Inc.
Mayor La Guardia lashed out yesterday with a strong condemnation of the bill passed by the State Assembly Tuesday night which is designed to eliminate use of the "third degree" by the police.

The Aircraft Year Book for 1937, published by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America in Rockefeller Center, is out today. The book, nineteenth of its kind, has 526 pages and gives a comprehensive survey of the development of aviation here and abroad in 1936.

With a five-minute lead at the start of the final stretch, the Bermuda six-meter yacht Saga, owned by the Trimingham brothers, today beat Briggs S. Cunningham's American boat Lulu in an exceedingly close race, triumphing by one length.

Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine, District Attorney Dodge and many other officials attended yesterday the funeral of Detective Michael J. Foley. Foley died on Saturday from bullet wounds received in a battle with four thugs who tried to hold up the Caf Boulevard Restaurant at Second Avenue and Ninth Street.
Norman Thomas, American Socialist leader, vigorously led the singing of the International at a meeting in London tonight organized in his honor by British Laborites.

Mayor Alex Hall issued an ultimatum today to Homer Martin, international president of the U. A. W. A., demanding a general sympathy strike in all General Motors plants in the United States in support of the 3,700 strikers here.
Making a clean sweep of the three doubles, Columbia downed New York University, 6-3, as both squads opened their campaigns at the Fleet Hollow. Tennis Courts yesterday.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-second Street and Fifth Avenue. "The Art of Italy," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "The Art of Egypt," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 11 A. M.; The Print Galleries, General Tour, 2 P. M.; "Life in Ancient Times: Greece and Rome," Stuart M. Shaw, 4 P. M.

Chairman Sumrnners of the House Judiciary Committee telegraphed to Governor White of Mississippi today that the State could not escape being an accessory after the fact to the Duck Hill lynchings, unless it meted out quick punishment to the lynchers and officers.

Net income of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company for the twelve months ended on March 31 was $16,708,349, a 25 per cent increase over the previous twelve months, the company reported today at the annual meeting of stockholders.

More than 500 present and former members of the Twelfth Regiment, N. Y. N. G., now known as the 212th Coast Artillery, attended the ninetieth anniversary dinner of the regiment last night at the Hotel McAlpin. Speakers included Major Gen. John J. Byrne, N. Y. N. G.

Many business men these days are complaining of Government competition and Federal curbs on trade, but reports from Chicago reveal that the Government, without any intention whatever of doing so, has stimulated one dying industry into a genuine little boom which bids fair to sweep the country.

United States Ambassador William Phillips called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, again today in connection with the American missionaries who were expelled from Ethiopia, and was told that detailed information concerning their case had not been received from Addis Ababa, but every effort was being made to speed it as much as possible.

In a vital decision, Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, today ripped the lid off the alleged practice of major league clubs in "covering up" promising young stars to block their entry into the big leagues through the selective draft.
Attorney General Cummings said today the Justice Department would not investigate charges. of possible violation of anti-trust laws by major league baseball clubs.

Japan's cardinal weakness as an industrial power-a lack of iron and steel resources-is being exposed by the world steel shortage. Extraordinary measures to meet the situation are being introduced today.

RAIN or shine, they'll be off at Jamaica today. Hoofbeats on the track. Wild cheers from the grand stand. The Paumonok. Probably Walt Whitman was not a regular along the rail during his Long Island days. The writing of that stalwart, gray-bearded poet didn't check with the information in the Metropolitan Jockey Club stake book.

A $12,000 payroll intended for the 100 persons employed in the liquidation of the defunct Bank of United States, 111 Duane Street, was stolen at 1:30 P. M. yesterday by two gunmen who held up two men who were delivering the money from a near-by bank.

Dealings in Manhattan real estate, as reported by brokers yesterday, were concentrated in the upper West Side district. The four five-story tenements at 247-53 West 116th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, have been sold by Nellie V. McCarthy to Rosenstock Bachrach, operators.
tion of the union, the 40-hour week largest manufacturer of rayon yarn in the country, with the Textile Worlters Organizing Committee, an affiliate of the C. I. 0.

Rear Admiral Richmond Pearson Hobson, a naval hero of the Spanish-American War, who died on March 16, left an estate of less than $5,000, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence B. Naramore of Newtown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary B. Naramore, to George K. S. Connolly of South Charleston, W. Va., son of James W. Connolly of Dundee, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Connolly.

Drew won its first baseball game in two starts by defeating Cathedral, 6-2, at University Field today. All runs for both teams were scored on errors. Last year Everett Stannert, who played center field for Drew today, pitched a no-hit, no-run game against Cathedral.

The British Government warned in the House of Lords today that the Johnson Act would bar the floating of loans in the United States if another war forced Britain to depend principally on American food supplies.

A special meeting of creditors of the International Match Corporation has been called before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, for May 6 at 10 A. M. to consider whether the court shall direct the Irving Trust Company, trustee, to settle suits against the United States Government for recovery of income taxes and by the government for tax claims.
Life has been none too easy for the military expert these last two years in Ethiopia and Spain. When the fighting began in East
American Steel Foundries' rights have been admitted to dealings on the New York Stock Exchange when issued. Pfeiffer Brewing Company rights have been admitted to "when issued" dealings.
Manhattan BIGELOW, CLARENCE OTIS (March 28). Estate, more than $10,000. To College of Pharmacy City of New York, 115 W. 68th St., $25,000, for establishment of a fellowship;

G. H. Whigham, chairman of the board of directors of the Celanese Corporation of America, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that earnings for the first quarter of 1937 were approximately $1.10 a share on the common stock after all prior deductions, compared with 46 cents a share earned in the corresponding period of 1936.

177th St.. 1.974 E.. s. s., 34 ft. w. of Pugsley Av., 21x73.9 to n. s. Ellis Av., 24.6x86.5 to beg.; Society for the Relief of Destitute Children of Seamen against James Moran. due. $11,759, taxes, , 31,902; to plaintiff for $7.500.

At the annual meeting of the Junior League of the Oranges today at Essex County Country Club Mrs. Anne Marshall Rice of South Orange was elected vice president to succeed Mrs. Theodore Steers of Maplewood. Mrs. John W. Woodward of South Orange was elected secretary. Mrs. Franklin Ryan Fort of East Orange will be city editor.
The annual report of the activities of Catholic Charities in the Archdiocese of New York was made public yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Kleegan, director.

Three robbers brandishing sawed-off shotguns and automatic pistols obtained about $35,000 from the Hall Street branch of the National Bank of Grand Rapids today after holding up a dozen employes and customers.

Three out of four new high school principals recommended by the Board of Superintendents for appointment by the Board of Education yesterday are women. The appointments are expected to be approved at the board's next meeting.
Loyalist Spain observed today the sixth anniversary of the establishment of the Spanish Republic as a day of redoubled labor for victory in the civil war.

Work will begin soon on two bridges over Grand Central Parkway Extension at the World's Fair site, Grover A. Whalen announced yesterday . A low bid of $103,261 was submitted by the James P. Rice Building Company of 11 West

The wireless set of THE NEW YORK TIMEs correspondent here picked up early this morning a presumably clandestine station operating on a wave length of 31 meters, calling itself "Libertad, Milan," and describing itself as Communist.

Dudley Place, the estate of Mrs. Muriel Vanderbilt Phelps in Middletown, just over the Newport line, is to be divided into eightyone lots for the erection of small homes to meet the demand for such dwellings here, it was learned today.

The Four Aces bridge team has sent its entry for the Grand National team-of-four championships to be played under the auspices of the United States Bridge Association beginning next Tuesday at the Hotel Montclair.

Edwin S. Gleason, lawyer, who was secretary to Lewis Nixon when Mr. Nixon was Public Service Commissioner in 1919-20, died yesterday after a brief illness at the home of a sister, Mrs. William Heuer, in Westerleigh, S. I. He was 61 years old. Lately he had been living near Greenwich, Conn., after many years of residence on Staten Island and in Manhattan.

The Federal Government's case against Ellis H. Parker Sr., the Burlington County (N. J.) detective, took a new and unexpected turn yesterday when the Department of Justice in Washington authorized United States Attorney John J. Quinn to seek new kidnapping indictments against Parker in Brooklyn, apparently in a move to evade the technical obstacles which his attorneys have raised in the courts of New Jersey.
Amid charges that labor. legislation was going "too far," the Senate took action today on a series of measures affecting labor.

A reception to welcome the Rev. S. Tagart Steele Jr. as the new vicar of the Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession was held last night at the parish house, Broadway and 155th Street. More than 600 members of the congregation were present.

Because, it seems, George Abbott has got into the habit of offering his Broadway premieres on Wednesday nights-having done it with "Boy Meets Girl," "Sweet River" and "Brother Rat"--his new production of "Room Service" is now slated to open here on May 19 instead of May 17, as previously mentioned.

Members of a joint preparatory committee of American and Philippine experts to study trade relations between the United States and the Philippines and to recommend a program for adjustment of Philippine national economy in preparation for the termination of preferential trade relations between the United States and the islands were appointed today by the Interdepartment Committee on Philippine Affairs.
The final tabulation of the men in the Sanitation Department who applied for five scholarships at New York University in sanitary engineering showed 319 applicants yesterday.

Improvement in the maritime industry is reflected in the 102d annual report of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, which was issued yesterday. Men were sent to sea in larger numbers and deposited their wages in 1936 in greater volume than in the previous year, the report showed.
Famine conditions in Szechwan Province are much exaggerated, according to two qualified American observers who have just returned to Peiping after having passed through the affected area.

A sitdown of 115 employes of the Yahr Lange Drug Company was settled this afternoon when the workers' single demand was granted with the resignation of Fred E. Yahr as general manager, after a long conference between company officials and spokesmen for the strikers.

The German Government is expected to make an official protest in Washington against further exhibition of the film known here as "Modern German Christian Martyrs," shown Monday in the Riverside Church, New York.

Stockholders of the Lehman Corporation will vote on May 14 on a proposal to divide the corporation's 690,123 outstanding shares of capital stock three for one. Included in these are 1,768 shares held in the treasury.

High-grade investments assumed leadership in the bond market yesterday, advancing over a broad front on the New York Stock Exchange in a heavier trading volume. United States Government loans were conspicuous in the general upswing on a turnover of $3,904,900 for the group, compared with sales of $1,497,000 on Tuesday.

The Giants, with a gathering of 5,000 applauding both their perseverance and temerity, went eight innings against the celebrated Bob Feller today and proved, to their own satisfaction at least, that Cleveland's 18-year-old mound marvel is not quite invincible and his stuff not altogether invisible.

Arthur F. Egner or South Orange has been appointed first vice president of the Kresge Department Store of Newark, the Kresge Deapartment Stores, Inc., and the Steinbach-Kresge Company of Asbury Park, it was announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. William S. Gubelmann and their son, Walter S. Gubelmann, entertained today with cocktails on their yacht. They will leave next week for a cruise in the Bahamas before returning to Morristown, N. J.
Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area showed another decrease in the figures reported yesterday by the United Parcel Service, covering the week ended April 10.

BABES IN ARMS, a musical comedy in two acts and fourteen scenes. Book by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart. Lyrics by Mr. Hart. Music by Mr. Rodgers. Staged by Robert Sinclair; choreography arranged by George Balanchine; scenery by Raymond Sovey: costumes designed by Helene Pons; produced by Dwight Deere Wiman. At the Shubert Theatre.

Shareholders of the Republic Steel Corporation at their annual meeting, held in Jersey City yesterday afternoon, elected R. J. Wysor, formerly executive vice president and general manager, president of the company.

Transfer of the New York Curb Exchange membership of Bert B. Kopperl to Robert R. Lansburgh of Bear, Stearns Co. and that of Robert E. Horton to C. V. Quayle of White, Knipe Quayle was approved yesterday by the board of governors.

The American Metal Company, Ltd., in a letter to the stockholders of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation, said yesterday that the former had no intention of allowing itself to be drawn into a proxy contest for the coming annual meeting of the latter company.
No great amount of outside attention appears to have been directed toward the valiant purge that is now being effected in the political corporation of kansas City.
Turpentine firm, 35 3/4c; sales, 68 barrels; receipts, 246 barrels; shipments, 135 barrels; stock, 23519 barrels.

Rudolph M. Klein, partner in the McGrath Shoe Company of 137 West Broadway, Manhattan, died suddenly today while driving through the business section of this village. Death was attributed to a heart attack.
President Roosevelt addressed the governing board of the Pan American Union at Pan American Day ceremonies and conferred with Senator Guffey and John L. Lewis on labor questions.

The Illinois Central Railroad has asked for bids by April 28 for the purchase of $7,050,000 of 3 per cent equipment trust certificates to be dated March 1. The certificates will be secured by equipment to cast at least $8,410,487.

The existence of an underworld syndicate held responsible for circulating about $300,000 in counterfeit $10 and $5 bills was revealed yesterday when three alleged distributors were held for the Federal grand jury.

Mr. and Mrs. Truman H. Newberry, who passed the Winter in Belleair, Fla., are expected to arrive at the Plaza on Saturday from Hot Springs, Va. Princess Margaret Boncompagni has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.

Secretary Ickes told the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today that a long-range slum clearance rand low-rent housing program was needed and that the program should be a permanent and not an emergency relief undertaking.

Frank Lowell Kennedy, Associate Professor of Engineering Drawing at Harvard University from 1913 until his retirement in 1931 and member of' many scientific societies, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 66 years old. -He had been a member of the Harvard faculty for thirty - two years, retiring in 1931 because of ill health.
With international peace as the keynote, Hunter College celebrated Pan-American Day yesterday morning at a chapel assembly in the Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

New York State, Illinois and California accounted for 37 per cent of the hotel business in the country in 1935, the Bureau of the Census reyealed today in announcing publication of the census of business refort on hotels.
Guy T. Warfield, for many years president of the Warfield-Dorsey Company, Inc., insurance brokers, died at his home here today at the age of 60.

Frederick P. Struckman, 41 years old, of 628 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, described as a former city detective of the gangster squad, who resigned under charges. and Irving Willen. 37 years old, of 4,209 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn, were held yesterday in $500 bail each for the Federal grand jury on charges of impersonating Federal officers.
Invalidation of the ringless hosiery patent startled the local market yesterday, but, inasmuch as an appeal from the Philadelphia decision will be made, executives here were unwilling to comment.

Mrs. Edna C. McCullough, Alexauder L. Patterson, Ralph F. Stewart, Charles E. Gray and John Gray, George J. Thornton, Mrs. Margaret L. Anderson, Lucille W??liams Raymond P. Thomson, Walter Buck, Jack Wirenius Charles E. Taylor, Mrs. Irene Boudreau; in London Terrace, 435 W. 23d St.; Wm. A. White Sons, broker.

Finally shattering the reserve of 5-year-old John Woods and his twin brother. James, a reporter obtained the information that it "feels good" to be on the verge of celebrating one's fifth birthday. This will be on Sunday, in the case of the two youngsters.

Germany's shipping business has become so good, her shipyards are so crowded with naval and commercial construction and her iron shortage at the same time has become so acute that she has begun to buy up both old and new foreign ships, partly to enlarge her merchant fleet and partly to break them up for scrap.
Charles Poletti, counsel to Governor Lehman, is slated for appointment as Supreme Court justice to fill the place left vacant by the death of Justice John V. McAvoy, it was learned today.

The Nourmahal, Vincent Astor's yacht, sailed at dawn today from Cristobal after a fast transit of the Panama Canal Wednesday night in order to save tropical fish collected in the Galapagos and the Pacific waters of Central America.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended April 15 were announced today: COLONEL Smith, H. M., detail as assistant adjutant and inspector revoked. LIEUTENANT COLONEL Fassett, H. C., Quantico, Va., to Mare Island, Calif.
The Rt. Rev. Patrick Thomas Ryan, Catholic Bishop of Pembroke, died today at I the age of 72. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Ryan, he was born in Ireland in 1864. His father came to
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 13: CAPTAIN Lofquist, E. A., to War College, Newport. R. I.

The District Attorney's office received word yesterday that Berton Tucker, 32 years old, had been arrested at Topsfield, Mass., on an abandonment indictment handed up by the New York County grand jury last March 16 on the complaint of his wife, Gussie O. Tucker.
A fourman team, headed by the veteran Henry W. (Bunny) Austin, today was invited by the British Lawn Tennis Association to go into training for England's defense of the Davis Cup.

Increased activity was indicated by world economic developments last month, according to the monthly review of foreign conditions in the current issue of The Annalist. Commodity prices made further sharp advances, although some of the more speculative excesses were wiped out at the end of March.
No one could possibly have imagined that the waves of industrial unrest, spreading out from Detroit, Mich., would

Failing to extract damaging evidence from Bertha Karg, described as a Communist agent in the trial of seven Catholics for high treason, produced sharp warnings by the presiding judge and prosecutor in People's Court here today.

Cornelia Otis Skinner, American disease, peopled the stage of the Little Theatre tonight with her uncanny creations, which began a fortnight's season. She adapted herself with such astonishing virtuosity and rapidity to so many diverse roles that the audience could enjoy, but at the same time forget the fact that the crowd she built up was an illusion.

The Soviet intention to build two battleships, as hinted by their diplomats in several conversations with foreign representatives here recently, was received in diplomatic and naval circles today with general reservations, if not disbelief.

The defeated Vincent Richards today, 6-0, 3-6, 6-2. The match was played on the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club courts where eleven years ago Richards, then an up and coming youngster, turned back Tilden, the national champion.

Field Lord Erich Ludendorff, who only a few days ago, on his seventy-second birthday, was greeted by Chancellor Adolf Hitler, was again the subject of flattering remarks today at his home in Tutzing. The occasion was the

Seventeen former employes of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital and the president of their union local went on trial yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn on a five-count information embracing charges of endangering lives of patients in a conspiracy to prevent internes and nurses from working.

When the Picket family of 39 Stagg Street, Brooklyn, visited the Bronx Zoo monkey house on June 2, 1935, a chimpanzee and a gorilla escaped from their cages and mingled with spectators. Three suits seeking to recover a total of $75,000 for fright and personal injuries resulting from this experience were filed in Supreme Court yesterday.

The Yankees today neared the end of a trail they cut across seven States and through seventeen cities, marking the approach to New York with a blaze of home-run hitting, but Lou Gehrig, the king-pin fourmaster stroker of them all, was missing from the game.

New York Stock Exchange members will ballot April 29 on proposals to transfer the membership of W. Wallace Lyon to Edward R. Whitehead Jr., and that of William Stix Friedman to William H. Frank, who will become a general partner of Smith, Frank Co. The first seat sold for $106,000, the latter for a nominal consideration.

The names of forty-eight doctors involved in the accident-fraud investigation conducted by Assistant District Attorney Bernard Botein will be referred for disciplinary action to State Attorney General John C. Bennett Jr. and the medical grievance committee of the State Education Department, it was announced yesterday.
Trading was mostly fair. Some steer cuts were higher and some fresh pork cuts lower. Prices otherwise were mostly unchanged. Thursday being an off kosher

Fear of a clash between the government and the Nationalists over the observance tomorrow of the birthday of the late Jose de Diego, advocate of independence, was freely expressed today with the publication of a Nationalist program for the day and of a statement from the Executive Council, composed of goverent department heads, in the form of a resolution condemning "defiance of constituted government."

Mrs. Fermine DuBuisson Baird Hawley, wife of Samuel B. Hawley, retired lawyer, and active for years in philanthropic work, died yesterday at her residence here of a heart ailment. Her age was 73. She was a patron of art and literature. Mrs.
Stricken with a heart attack as he was about to go to bed, Police Lieutenant John R. Hanken died yesterday morning at his home, 1,946 Tomlinson Avenue, the Bronx. His age was 56.

The dying words of GOETHE might have been the motto of ARTHUR WILLIAMS, for he was one of the Edison Pioneers working with THOMAS A. EDISON to "apply electricity for the use of all "-urging always "more light, more light." Cities became as dreams of the apocalyptic city.

High school students were warned yesterday that participation in peace demonstrations outside school buildings during the national antiwar strike, called by the United Student Peace Committee for next Thursday, may lead to a recommendation that their diplomas or school honors be withheld.
Sales of General Motors cars and trucks to dealers in the overseas markets during March totaled 32,172 units, a decrease of 1.9 per cent from March, 1936. The figures

Miss Eunice Dean of san Antonio, Texas, the defending titleholder, defeated Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York. 6-4, 8-6, today to gain the final round of the United North and South tennis championship at the Pinehurst Country Club.

Villa Sonia was the setting for a dinner and bridge given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Kaufman for Mr. and Mrs. Laurence C. Fuller, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lennon, Prince and Princess Odescalchi, Mr. and Mrs. Henry K. Harding, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Major, Mrs. Charles Lewis Harding and Frederick R. Sears Jr.

Mrs. Josephine Whetstone Conwell, wife of Walter L. Conwell, died yesterday at her home, 80 Lloyd Road, Montclair, after a short illness. Her age was 61. Born in Philadelphia, Mrs. Conwell was educated at Friends School, coming to Montclair in 1901.

Results in the fifth round of the international chess masters' tournament today at the Ostend Casino brought about no changes in the relative positions of the leaders. H. Grob of Switzerland and S. Landau of the Netherlands remained first and second respectively. Dr. S.

More than 20,000 State income tax returns were filed yesterday at the local offices of the State Department of Taxation and Finance, 80 Center Street, and the offices were kept open by Wesley M. Dawson, district supervisor, from 5 P. M., the customary closing hour, until 9 P. M.
Sedden St.. 1,753, w. s., 95.8 s. Walker Av., 25x100: Fulton Trust Co. of N. Y., executor, against Pasquale Zazzarine, due $7,254; to plaintiff for $6,000.

Harold Halleck Johnstone of this place has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Madeleine Kelleher Johnstone, to Lieutenant (Junior Grade) Joseph Warford Williams Jr., U.S.N., son of Judge and Mrs. Joseph W. Williams of Martinsville, Ind.

Called together by representatives of manufacturing and labor interests at a meeting at the Hotel Governor Clinton last night, leading groups in the cloak and suit industry agreed upon a program to strengthen the work of the recovery board's program.
George Graham of 20 Shawnee Road, Scarsdale, N. Y., executive vice president of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Regent Hospital. He was 55 years old.

The synthesis of one-half of the fundamental structure of the red coloring matter of blood and the green coloring matter of plants, the two most important pigments on earth, was announced here today before the closing session of the meeting of the American Chemical Society of the University of North Carolina.
One of the most interesting and able figures of recent rowing history is finishing his coaching career down here on the placid waters of Princeton's Carnegie Lake.

The text of the preliminary draft of rules of fair practice of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., for over-the-counter markets was made public today with the text of the preliminary draft of procedure for handling complaints against members of the conference. The text-s follow.
The Assembly passed today and sent to Governor Lehman four Democratic bills designed to put new legal obstacles in the path of the American Labor party in the coming Mayoralty campaign.

A general strike of radio operators on all ships of the International Mercantile Marine Company was called yesterday by the American Radio Telegraphists Association, threatening to tie up the operations of the company in transatlantic and intercoastal services.

Theodore J. Lewis, a retired steel manufacturer, died yesterday in his eighty-second year. He retired thirty years ago as secretary of the Standard Steel Company, a subsidiary of the Baldwin Locomotive Works. Born at Altoona, he studied

Formation of an organization to comprise the leading associations in various wholesale fields, with the aim of protecting the wholesalers' position in the distribution scheme and of combating "fallacious propaganda," was announced here yesterday by Henry Matter, secretary of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute.

Three more lawyers who were involved in an investigation of crookedness in accident litigations resigned as members of the bar yesterday on the "suggestion" of the prosecutor. The resignations were filed with the justices of the Appellate Division by Bernard C. Botein, who is head of the Accident Fraud Bureau.

During the week ended April 14 Member Bank reserve balances increased $217,000,000. Additions to Member Bank reserves arose from increases of $105,000,000 in gold stock, $35,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, and decreases of $163,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $4,000,000 in money in circulation and $11,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by an increase of $102,000,000 in Treasury cash.

Miss Katherine Rawls, the 19-year-old aquatic marvel from Miami Beach, Fla., successfully defended her women's national indoor A. A. U. 100-yard breast-stroke title tonight and set a new record in doing it.
