Under government encouragement the migration of girls to the Soviet Far East has begun in such volume that the railway administration has ordered two extra cars daily attached to Transsiberian trains.

President Federico Laredo Bru today sent a message to Congress asking that body to appoint a committee to work out a plan for the resumption of the payments on the Public Works bonds, which have been in default since. 1933, in collaboration with a committee recently named by the Chief Executive.
Federal Land Banks have called about $62,000,000 of their 4 1/4 per cent bonds for cash payment on May 1, William I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, announced today.

Pompoon won like a champion at Jamaica yesterday when he came from behind to take the twentyeighth Paumonok Handicap by a neck in a bitter finish with Tintagel, thus clearly demonstrating that he is at his fittest.

A former waitress was declared today to be the heir to the $100,000 estate of L. Arthur Richards, Atlantic City hotel man, in a decision by Judge Robert L. Warke Jr., who said it had been proved to his satisfaction that the woman had been Mr. Richards's secret wife for seventeen years.

Bainbridge Av.. 3.300 (12-3343D): Jay B. Realty Corp. to Bank of N. Y. Trust Co., five years, 4 per cent. $24,000. Matilda Av., 4,617 (17-5079): Vincent Gasparini to Harrison G. Otis. trustee, 131 Woodward Av.. Rutherford, N. J., extends mtg. to March 1, 1940 at 5 per cent, $10,000. Gun Hill Rd. (12-3344); n. a., 52 ft. east of Tryon Av., 157x109; Lessen Realty Corp. to Dollar Savingsbank; $30,000.

Three men and a woman, all Negroes, were held without bail on a murder charge today as Mayor S. Davis Wilson and police declared that the mystery of the slaying, five years ago, of Norman R. Bechtel, a Mennonite church worker, had been solved.
Senate police noticed suspicious bulges today under the left armpits of several shaggy-haired Kentucky mountaineers who had come from Harlan County to attend the Senate civil liberties investigation.
Dick Shikat, former world heavyweight champion, was declared the victor over Robert Bruns in 52 minutes 13 seconds of the finish wrestling match at the New York Hippodrome last night.

The marriage of Miss Frances Loring Abercrombie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Abercrombie of Greenfield, to Malcolm Knifton Cameron, son of Mrs. Angus Cameron and the late Mr. Cameron, took place here tonight in The White Church, where the bride's paternal grandfather, the Rev. Robert Crawford, was minister for twenty-five years.

Dr. Alfred Harrold Thomas, surgeon on Staten Island for thirty-five years, died yesterday in Staten Island Hospital of pneumonia. Dr. Thomas, who was 62 years old, lived at 33 Westervelt Avenue, New Brighton. He was graduated in 1898 from Yale, where he was a member of the football team.
The Philadelphia Orchestra Association, in an effort to fill hundreds of seats usually empty at the orchestra's Saturday night concerts, announced today two innovations for next season.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Bernadette Cavanagh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Stewart Cavanagh of Brooklyn and Bay Shore, L. I., to George L. Le Blanc Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Le Blanc of 125 East Seventy-second Street, took place yesterday morning in the Church of the Holy Innocents, Brooklyn.

Continuing their search for Robert Irwin, 29-year-old sculptor who is wanted for the Gedeon murders, the police were pursuing several new lines of activity yesterday in line with Commissioner Valentine's expressed belief that the suspect is in this city.

H. Paul Shanik of 26 Court Street, Brooklyn, a minority stockholder in the Carib Syndicate, Ltd., yesterday brought an action in Supreme Court to have the value of his holdings judicially determined and the company ordered to pay him this amount. The suit is an

Members of the United Automobile Workers of America slowed the rate of production today in the big Ternstedt Manufacturing Company plant, a division of the General Motors Corporation employing 12,000 workers here.

A conflict in major track meet dates was averted last night when secretary Dan Ferris of the A. A. U. announced that the national A. A. U. track and field meet had been set for July 2 and 3 at Milwaukee instead of June 25 and 26, as originally scheduled, according to THe Associated Press

The officers and directors of the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants Association, Inc.. at a special meeting yesterday, adopted resolutions of sorrow over the death in Florida Wednesday of Arthur Williams., a founder member of the association.

The Senators made a last-inning rally that netted four runs today to defeat the Bees, 5 to 4, in an exhibition game. The Bees scored three runs in the fifth and led 4-1 as the Senators came to bat in the ninth. Two walks, an error and three singles accounted for four runs.

Eighteen acceptance have been received by Secretary Perkins to her conference Tuesday which will bring together industrialists, public officials and trade union executives to discuss "next steps" with relation to the implications in the Supreme Court's decision upholding the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

The first drop in the wholesale price index of the Labor Department since late January occurred in the week ended on April 10, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The decline was attributed largely to falling prices of farm products and foods.

Albert Salle, defense lawyer for the spy Bolo Pasha, died in a clinic here this morning at the age of 76. Known as a capable corporation lawyer, he was of counsel for the Bank of France and was appointed batonnier of the Paris bar in 1921. He was admitted to the bar in 1882.
Amy Evans, soprano; Fraser Gange, baritone, and Hans Barth, pianist, will participate in a musicale tonight at the MacDowell Club in honor of Edward Arnold Robinson.

A copy of the first edition of Thackeray's "Vanity Fair" in the original parts was sold to Walter M. Hill, Chicago dealer, for $2,500 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of rare books and manuscripts from the collection of Christopher Schwab and others.

Miss Eleanor Mendelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Mendelson of 167 Westminster Road, Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning at the home of her parents to Carl Albert Strauss, son of Mrs. Albert Strauss of Cincinnati, by the Rev. Dr. Sidney S. Tedesche.

Robert W. Bonynge, American Government agent handling war-time claims against Germany, filed a statement today with the Mixed Claims Commission, holding in effect that Germany was responsible for payment to Americans of $20,000,000 in settlement of sabotage cases.

The Insurgents besieging Madrid sought today to shift the battlefront by attacking government lines along the road southward to Valencia in an apparent effort to lure Madrid defense troops away from the Casa de Campo sector, just west of the capital.

Americans are mistaken in their belief they are the greatest peace-loving people in the world, Dr. Emily Hickman of the New Jersey College for Women declared today in a talk before 600 women delegates to the ninth annual conference of the New Jersey Committee on the Cause and Cure of War in McCarter Theatre here.
The fourth International Hydrographic Conference opened here yesterday under the presidency of Prince Louis II of Monaco. Delegates from nineteen nations are attending.

Awards for engineering construction work for the week ??nded yesterday totaled $46,927,??0, representing an 8 per cent gain over the average of the preceding week in 1937, but a loss of 14 per cent over the corresponding week for 1936, according to the Engineering NewsRecord. The figure for private
J. G. White Co. hold the largest stock interest in the Philippine Railway, according to a report to the Securties and Exchange Commission issued yesterday.
Brooklyn College was routed by New York University, 13 to 2, at Ohio Field yesterday, seven errors and thirteen bases on balls making the Violet nine's task singularly simple.

The Navy Department was urged today by a delegation of Brooklyn officials and citizens to build one of the new 35,000-ton battleships in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The request was taken under consideration after the groups had presented their request to Assistant Secretary Edison.

A blue-ribbon jury was completed yesterday before County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn to try Salvatore Ossido, 26-year-old barber, on an indictment charging murder in the first degree. The taking of testimony was put off until Monday.
Major R. W. Schroeder, assistant director of the Bureau of Air Commerce, has resigned to become vice president in charge of operations of United Air Lines.

The Federal Reserve System bought $27,537,000 of.United States Government bonds in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly reports of the system published yesterday. Following purchases of $28,819,000 of government obligations in the preceding week, the increase lifted the system's total holdings of "governments" to $2,486,583,000, a high record.
All schools in the State, including private schools, will be required to establish courses in highway safety and traffic instruction under the terms of a bill signed by Governor Lehman today.

Richard E. Cochran, a retired wholesale produce merchant, died on Thursday of pneumonia at his home, 315 Central Park West, after a brief illness. His age was 88. Born in Middletown, Del., he came here in 1870 and entered the wholesale fruit and produce business with John Nix Co.

In the year 8118 A. D. a group of archaeologists will apply their eighty-second century equivalents of picks and axes to the stainless steel walls of a crypt buried in the ruins of what was once Oglethorpe University, Atlanta, Ga., United States of America.

George H. Church of 112 East Seventy-fourth Street, who died July 27, 1935, left a net estate of $1,380,216. according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. He had held more than sixty trustee ships in estates and corporations.

The Supreme Court's decision upholding the Wagner act in the Jones Laughlin case resulted in an agreement today by the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company here to negotiate terms with 2,000 strlking union employes.

E. J. Carson has been named superintendent of the Webster Avenue division of the Sheffield Farms Company to succeed J. H. Tiedemann, who has been appointed district sales manager of Long Island for the organization.

Ministers and lay delegates from parts of this State, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts registered yesterday for the 138th annual session of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Grace Church, 131 West 104th Street.

ABOUT the best that can be said here of Archie Binns's "The Laurels Are Cut Down" (Reynal Hitchcock, $2.50) is that it is a perfectly readable story-which is more than can be said of most novels and considerably less than was said by reviewers of the author's first book, "Lightship." As a piece of writing it is

The prospective resignation of Colonel Philip Fleming, Deputy Resettlement Administrator and directing head of most New Deal construction programs, was made known today by officials of the agency, who, under orders to reduce expenditures, have been surveying Resettlement Administration activities for possible saving.

A possibility developed today that the State Senate would join three other agencies in looking into conditions and administration of the Windham County Temporary Home for Children. Two men are under arrest as a result of a two-day investigation.

On option to Lee Shubert are the' American rights to "Three Waltzes," and the prospect is of a Fall production of this Viennese operetta, with book by Paul Knepler and Armin Robinson and music arranged by Oscar Straus. That is,

County Judge John Cadman Tracy died last night in City Hospital here,' after a week's illness, at the age of 52. Judge Tracy, former president of the New York State Conference of Children's Court Judges, served three terms as Columbia County District Attorney before becoming county judge in 1925.
Movements on the Chicago Livestock Exchanges today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

A "preview" of the Model League of Nations Assembly, to be held at Cornell University the end of this month, will be broadcast this afternoon at 4:45 o'clock over Station WNEW. The topic to be discussed,

The New York State Traffic Commission hopes to create a "model highway" on which to test proposed new traffic controls, Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, told delegates to the annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council and cooperating agencies at its closing session in the Hotel Astor yesterday.

Under the La Guardia administration there has been a reduction of 20 per cent in major crimes, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday at a crime prevention conference held at the Metropolitan Baptist Church, Seventh Avenue and 128th Street.

The Globe and Mail in a dispatch from Brampton today quotes Ian Mackenzie, Minister of National Defense, as saying: "Canada will fight its own battles in future in traditional British manner, instead of depending on the Monroe Doctrine for its protection."
Lumber production increased less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index declined to 85.0 from 85.3. It was 72.8 for the week ended April 11, 1936.

Movement of vessels follow, all dates are April 14, unless specified: San Diego to San Pedro: Rail, April 15. At San Pedro: Cuyama, Sonoma. San Diego to San Pedro: Brazos, Neches. Acushnet, Norfolk, to Washington Yard, April 15. Antares. Guantanamo Bay to Norfolk, April 15.

James H. Crowley, head football coach at Fordham University, was chosen "most prominent senior" in the annual preference poll conducted among members of the graduating class of Fordham College and printed in today's issue of The Ram, weekly undergraduate newspaper of the college.

Mrs. Sophia Laurie Hodge of 102 West Fifty-seventh Street and Jonathan T. Lanman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan T. Lanman of 823 Park Avenue, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building. They will be married on May 1 in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The fifteenth engagement of this roving series between the Giants and Indians, played today before a banner crowd of 5,000, ended in a shower of rain and base hits, with the forces of Colonel Bill Terry getting no great amount of relish out of either. For Steve O'Neill's Tribe,
The license of the New Gotham Theatre, a burlesque house at 167 East 125th Street, was revoked yesterday by License Commissioner Paul Moss after a two-hour hearing.
New York's public employment offices filled 46,039 jobs in private industry during the first quarter of 1937, "a record-smashing" figure 70.7 per cent higher than the 26,974 in 1929.

IT was Joe DiMaggio's luck to be out when the phone rang in his room yesterday. By this narrow margin he missed a thrilling surgical lecture by what is known as Columbia's Inadvisory Board on Tonsillectomy, the same being composed of Professor Lou Little, Ralph Furey and Herb Kopf.

A police court here today found six Americans. arrested April 9 guilty of having tried to smuggle themselves across the Franco-Spanish frontier to enlist in the Spanish Government Army. France recently passed laws to prevent the transit of such volunteers. Each was sentenced to one month in prison.
The dissolution of the Keystone Container Car Company on March 25 has been disclosed by the Pennsylvania Railroad in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The subsidiary was organized

Metro is going ahead with plans for next season and today announced "The Return of the Thin Man," a second sequel to "Thin Man"; "Rendezvous With Love," an operetta by William Anthony McGuire, and "Hats in the Air," which will be an Eleanor Powell musical. As with the previous

Miss Mary H. Chadwick, daughter of Mrs. James A. Chadwick of Mayfair House, entertained with a diner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mr. and Mrs. Edwin B. Dickinson, Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Moore Robinson, Dr. and Mrs. Irving H. Pardee, Mr. and Mrs. E. Winthrop Rossiter, Mrs. M. Buckner Royall, Mrs. Orville Davies, Theodore L. Bronson, John C. Milne and Irving Beebe.

Just a big man from the South is Burleigh Grimes. The old spitball pitcher, making his debut as a major league pilot, brought back to New York last night and will present at Ebbets Field today a team of Dodgers only two of whom are hitting under .300.

Helen Keller is arousing the Japanese people's sympathy and enthusiasm as hardly any other visitor has ever done. This evening's newspapers devoted pages with pictures to her. Morning papers treated her as greater than visiting royalty.

Scenes of modern shipping in New York harbor, painted in bright colors and adhering to technical accuracy, will be the subject of eight mural panels soon to be applied to the dome of the rotunda in the New York Custom House.

Leaders in politics, education and the judiciary united yesterday with students and- faculty members of the City College to mark the completion of ten years of service by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson as president of the college.

The Moscow charges that he had plotted against the Soviet in conjunction with Germany and Japan are "completely false from beginning to end," Leon Trotsky asserted this noon when he finished his four and one-half days' presentation of his side of the case before a subcommission of inquiry.

A large reception for members of the cast of the New York Junior League "Follies" will be given in the Netherland Cafe of the SherryNetherland this afternoon by one of the assisting committees for the show, which will be presented at the New Amsterdam Theatre on April 23 and 24.

To Medical Chief The following members of the department shall be directed to report to the chief medical officer, at these headquarters, at 12 o'clock noon, Wednesday, April 21, for examination to determine their physical fitness to operate motors and pumps on apparatus:

The annual brief services in memory of the officers and crew of the lost liner Titanic were conducted at noon yesterday on the wind-swept roof of the Seamen's Church Institute at 25 South Street in the presence of about 200 seamen and staff members.

Completion of a debt-reorganization program for Tennessee designed to enable the State to pay all bonds in cash at maturity, to release immediately upward of $2,500,000 annually for current purposes, and to provide for a possible yearly reduction after 1944 in both gasoline and tobacco taxes, was announced yesterday by Governor Gordon Browning.

The Metropolitan Building, a twostory taxpayer at 1,847-59. Mott Avenue, Far Rockaway, Queens, has been sold by the Wilbeth Realty Company to Samuel Reznick. The structure covers a plot 130 by 92 feet, and contains seven stores, reported to be fully rented, and offices on the second floor.

Prince Nicholas, stripped of all royal rights by his brother, King Carol, ostensibly because of his refusal to renounce his marriage to a divorced commoner, is proving less tractable than Britain's Edward.
The California Senate passed a bill today which would exclude sit-downs from the definition of "strikes" and class them as misdemeanors punishable under the criminal code.

The prevalent talk of emergency measures to prevent a business boom and increased Federal powers to check commodity price advances is "a kind of locking of the stable door before the family horse has even been acquired," says Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company in the current issue of the bank's business bulletin.

While some Republicans in the Assembly are still holding out for defiance of GovLehman, parleys last night and today appear to have prepared the way for a more peaceful and speedier finish of the legislative session than seemed possible only twenty-four hours ago.

The consolidated report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the three months ending Feb. 28 shows a net income, after operating expenses, interest deductions and other charges, of $53,597,104, or $2.87 a share on the company's 18,686,687 shares of common stock outstanding during the period. This compares with...

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports, bringing among her passengers several groups of special tourists aggregating 231 persons, the largest number to arrive on a single ship this year. Included are twenty-one

When the cornerstone of the Lilly Dache Building was laid yesterday at 78-80 East Fifty-sixth Street, there were sealed into it copies of the first and latest hats created by Mme. Dache, both wrapped in cellophane; a live horned toad, current fashion news items concerning millinery and a parchment scroll signed by the notables present. The nine-story structure is to be of glass brick.

Many of those who differ with Attorney General CUMMINGS about the merits of the President's Supreme Court plan will agree with him that there ought to be no "compromise " on the issue. If the President's plan is as

Yesterday a thinly attended Assembly passed four of the six election bills introduced by Senator BERG of the Bronx and passed by the Senate. The plain purpose of these four bills is to make independent movements more difficult and to hamper the American Labor party in the municipal elections in this town next Fall.

" Where can I go to try for a trout?" is the question asked most often by fresh-water anglers of New York in these early-season days. For those who wish to venture as far as the Catskill region, six of the most famous streams in the East are available.

Under pressure of liquidation in the May in preparation for first notices on April 27 and in sympathy with the action of outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined $1 a bale for the old crop months yesterday and closed with losses of 12 to 23 points.

New York City school teachers who are illegally dismissed cannot collect back pay when reinstated by court order, Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller ruled yesterday after he had directed the Board of Education to re-employ thirty-nine teachers and principals in evening schools.

Hugh McDowell Pollock, Minister of Finance in Ulster and Deputy Premier, died today. Mr. Pollock became a Companion of Honor last year. He was the first Minister of Finance for Ulster and a member of the Northern Ireland Parliament since 1921.
William H. Smathers officially entered upon his duties in the United States Senate today, abandoning his seat in the upper house of the New Jersey Legislature.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to turn over to trustees of thirty-seven New York Title and Mortgage Company certificate issues $248,620 which he had reserved to meet the expenses of Federal receivership of Land Estates, Inc., and Liberdar Holding Corporation, two wholly owned subsidiaries of the title company.

Senator Walsh of Massachusetts introduced in the Senate today a bill to provide that individual income tax returns may be made without the formality of an oath. The bill is patterned after the Massachusetts law and has the approval of Secretary Morgenthau.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended April 14 were announced today: Borromey, Lieut. R. J., the Escanaba, to the Modoc, for engineering duty. Natwig, Chief Boatswain S. B., the Active, to Coast Guard Academy. Pederson, Chief Boatswain P. M., Base Six, to the Atalanta.

Judge John P. Nields in United States District Court has permitted two affiliated concerns, the Southwest Telephone Company and the Southwestern States Telephone Company, to file reorganization plans under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.

The Central Information Bureau proposed in the governmental reorganization plan submitted to Congress by President Roosevelt "would be a dangerous innovation" in the field of propaganda, America's Town Meeting of the Air was told last night by Anne O'Hare McCormick.
Pedro Montanez knocked out ?? die Ran of Poland in 1:15 of ?? sixth round before 4,000 at the San Casino last night. The Pua?? Rican scaled 1371/2, seven ?? less than Ran.
Archaeologists discovered today rich and valuable examples of Fifth Dynasty art in an ancient Egyptian tomb for which they had conducted a twenty-year search.
The MurrayNeustein bill to establish municipal funeral authorities to conduct funerals for poor persons at low prices is still awaiting action in Senate and Assembly committees.

Negotiations started months ago for the purchase of several United States warships for the Brazilian Navy may reach a successful conclusion with the return tomorrow of Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, the Brazilian Ambassador, to Washington.

Simen Artemowsky's operetta, "Zaporogetz Za Dunayem" ("Cossacks Beyond the Danube"), will receive its American premiere performances May 8 and 9 at the Venice Theatre in a production by the Ukrainian Theatrical Company of New York. The work will be

Partly cloudy skies, mild Spring temperatures and ideal stream conTitions provided a pleasant setting that drew a large number of Connecticut's 30,000 licensed sportsmen to the fishing brooks today. The occasion was the opening of the 1937 trout season.

The National Retail Credit Association announced today that 12,926 retail stores in forty cities reported increases in March, as compared with March, 1936, averaging 6.2 per cent in collections. 12.3 per cent in credit sales and 13.4 per cent in total sales. Thirty-four cities reported

Formation of a police force for the New York World's Fair of 1939 was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation. John O'Brien, retired chief inspector of the Police Department, has been appointed chief of police for the fair. Richard J. Sheridan,
Three men were held today in $500 bail for the June term of court, charged with aggravated assault and battery growing out of the strike riot at the Hershey chocolate factory April 7.

Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser, prominent clubwoman who celebrated her 101st birthday on March 24, was the guest of honor yesterday at a reception given by the Women's Health Protective Association at the home of its president, Mrs. Ralph Trautmann, 333 Central Park West. Mrs. Fraser,

Approximately 1,000 employes of the National Can Company, 50-26 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, went on strike yesterday for higher wages and improved working conditions. They represented about 90 .per cent of the plant's working force.
President Roosevelt, a husky right-hander, reported his pitching arm in great shape today and promised to toss the first ball of the major league baseball season here Monday.

Investment buying of housing property along the upper West Side featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday. A Dyckman section deal involved the five-story walk-up apartment building at 9-11 Vermilyea Avenue, north of Dyckman Street, which was resold by Walter A. Baron, operator, to an investing client of Low Gross, Inc., broker.

Representative Merritt of Flushing, N. Y., asked Congress today to appropriate $2,500,000 to dredge a channel from the East River in New York City through Flushing Bay to the city boat basin at Flushing Meadow Park.
The Gavagan Anti-Lynching Bill was passed by the House, 277 to 118, today after a six-hour debate marked by sectional bitterness.

Commodity futures were generally lower in active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, silk, copper, tin, hide, cocoa and world sugar futures declined, while lead, zinc and domestic sugar futures were steady and coffee advanced.
Mayor La Guardia told the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today that more than 40,000 tenements in New York City exist in violation of State laws.
Dominion Government expenditures reduced Dominion deposits in the Bank of Canada in the last week and. created a nearly equivalent increase in deposits by the chartered banks.
Governor Hoffman today signed a foreign corporation tax bill designed to prevent departure of foreign corporations from New Jersey.
American fleet will sail from the West Coast tomorrow for manoeuvres in the Pacific inside the vast triangle running from Panama to Hawaii and northward to Alaska.
BOY IN BLUE, by Boyce Brier. (Appleton-Century, $2.50.) A novel of the Civil War concentrating on a soldier's adventures on the battlefield. DENMARK: KINGDOM OF REASON, by Agnes Rothery. (Viking.

Stockholders of the American Rolling Mill Company at their annual meeting yesterday in Middletown, Ohio, authorized the issuance of $60,000,000 of preferred stock, of which $45,000,000 of cumulative convertible stock is proposed to be issued to retire present outstanding debt, to increase production facilities and add to working capital.

Stocks closed irregularly lower in slowest trading ,f the month; turnover, 940,900 shares. United States Government bonds continued to advance and closed higher, corporate issues also improved; foreign loans mixed; transactions, $11,746,100.

The report of the First National Bank of Boston for March 31 showed total deposits of $639,830,621 and total assets of $744,264,217, compared, respectively, with $652,386,954 and $756,201,927 on Dec. 31, 1936.
New York's Senate inadvertently passed a "barbering" bill today when it meant to approve a baking measure. The reason was a misprint in the measure which put the letter "s" before the word "having."
The six changes Head Coach Dick Harlow recommended for his 1937 Harvard football staff were approved today by the committee on the regulation of athletic sports.

Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities of the nation for the week ended on Wednesday totaled $5,837,681,000, against $5,072,985,000 in the corresponding week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The increase was 15.1 per cent.

A protest was filed in Federal court yesterday by Benjamin J. Friedkass as a stockholder against the offer of Henry L. Doherty to settle a stockholders' suit against him and Cities Service Company interests. To end the action, which
The Trust Company of Northern Westchester was removed today as a trustee in a $99,000 mortgage rehabilitation case by Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme.

The Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., which has been setting up a nation-wide self-regulatory organization, has sent to its 1,710 members proposed rules of fair practice which have received the tentative approval of its executive committee. The rules, the conference

51st St., n. s., 143.6 ft. e. of 9th Av.. 56.6x 100.5; Samuel H. Rosenberg to Dry Dock Savings Institution: consideration. $1.000, foreclosure. York Av., w. s., block from 79th to 80th St.; 179 ft. on former and 125 ft. on latter; Murray Kaufman and wife to Chal Associates, Inc., 31 Union Square Vest.
There has been disagreement as to the source of the signal that was sent when the Persians were quitting Marathon in order to attack Athens before it could be reached by MILTIADES.

Stockholders of the Crane Company will vote on May 3 on a plan to create a new lower-rate issue of convertible preferred stock to permit the retirement at $110 a share of 145,889 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock, to increase working capital and to make possible resumption of common dividends as earnings may permit.

Herbert Lighthipe died today in a sanitarium in Cedar Grove at the age of 77. Mr. Lighthipe was a member of an old New Jersey family and for many years was a leader in political and civic activities in the Oranges. He was born in Orange

Miss Jeanne Roe Price, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence V. Price of this place, was married tonight to A. Richardson Goodlatte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Goodlatte of Upper Montclair, formerly of Passaic. The Rev. Lindsay S. B.
Foreign traders here yesterday welcomed reports from Washinginton that Congress will grant a $75,000 increase in the appropriation for gathering and compiling foreign trade statistics.

Liquidation by tired holders of grain futures in the world's leading markets showed no evidence today of having run its course, and closing trades on all grains were around the lowest levels of the day and on the current downturn.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, and Lady Lindsay gave a dinner at the embassy tonight. Those invited were the Japanese Ambassador and Mrs. Saito, Senator and Mrs. Key Pittman, Senator and Mrs. Warren Austin, Otto Wadsted, Danish Minister;

Thomas Mann, exiled German author and Nobel Prize winner, declared last night that the "moral discipline" of Christianity must be maintained in the face of presentday attacks, and voiced his conviction that writers today must take a political stand as a matter of direst necessity" for the defense of freedom of the spirit.
Meeting of the Woman's Forum, Hotel Roosevelt, 10:45 A. M. "Education for Everyday Living," Mrs. Isabel Graham Turner, Mrs. Harry Lilly, Mrs. Irma Lederer, Mrs. Anne Morse, Anne Frances Hodgkins.

The Equity Corporation's report for the first quarter of 1937, issued yesterday, shows net assets on March 31 equal to $9,754.74 for each $1,000 of assumed debentures outstanding, compared to $8,249.12 a year before. After deducting

Government statistics show that heart disease is forging steadily ahead as the principal cause of death in the United States. A total of 312,333 deaths were attributed to heart disease in 1935, as compared with 303,724 the previous year and 286,360 in 1933.
Dressmakers went on strike today for union recognition and higher pay in the expectation that their walkout would paralyze the industry here and spread repercussions into three other cities.

Out of 3,500 potential victims, 1,500 to 2,000 Harvard students were hoaxed today by the distribution of cards, apparently from the Department of Hygiene, directing them to attend a lecture on "Scientific Aspects of Birth Control."

At the annual meeting of stockholders of Russek's Fifth Avenue, Inc., all directors were re-elected, Max Weinstein, president, announced yesterday. He also said that Walter H. Weinstein, his son, and Harold Russek, son of Frank Russek, vice president, were both elected vice presidents of the corportion at a meeting of the board. All other officers were re-elected for a year.

The Christlische Staendestaat, weekly paper founded in 1934 by friends of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of strongly Clerical and Monarchist a leanings to support his corporative State, was confiscated by the police yesterday under curious circumstances.

A freakish accident on the collier William C. Atwater at dawn yesterday off Sea Girt, N. J., almost cost a seaman his life, but he was rescued ninety minutes later by a passing freighter which had sighted him drifting seaward on the Atwater's hatch cover. The seaman,
More than 1,000 faculty members and students of Teachers College, Columbia University, were greeted last night by Dean and Mrs. William F. Russell at the annual Dean's reception.
Mr. and Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart have returned from Palm Beach, where they passed the Winter and early Spring, and are at the Ambassador.

Representatives of scores of business, civic and real estate organizations pledged themselves last night at Cooper Union not to vote next November for any candidate now holding city office who does not work whole-heartedly for the repeal of the 50 per cent increase in water rates adopted in 1933.

At the height of one of the most remarkable comebacks in the history of the game, Ralph Greenleaf of New York assumed the lead in the race for the world pocket billiard championship last night when he beat Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, 125 to 76, in a thrilling fourteen-inning encounter.

The war partment released the following orders today, dated April 14: COLONELS Desobry, E. C.. Adjutant General's Department, 1 month's leave, July 26. Freeman, C. E., Med. Corps, 4 months' leave, April 30; to retirement on Aug. 8.

A warning that the rising cost of living in Britain was creating a dangerous situation for the export trade was sounded today by Sir Geoffrey Clarke, president of the Associated Chambers of Commerce of Great Britain, in addressing the organization's annual meeting.

The Massachusetts Supreme Court, in an opinion requested by the State Senate, ruled today that the Legislature had authority to regulate parking through the use of fees charged by means of parking meters. But, the court warned,

Tommy Farr, stolid, unimaginative 23-year-old Welshman, sprang into the front rank of the world's heavyweights tonight with a clean-cut victory over Max Baer before 14,000 wildly cheering fans in Harringay Arena.

It can now be stated with certainty that Premier Benito Mussolini will visit Chancellor Adolf Hitler in Germany at the end of the Summer or early in the Fall unless something happens to disturb Italo-German relations.

The American Can Company and the National Biscuit Company have withdrawn suits in the Federal courts and have agreed to the publication of data concerning gross sales and cost of sales and salaries of executives, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. This reduces to twenty-one the number of such suits pending.
15.-Dr. Darwin Oliver Lyon of 111 Crary Avenue, rocket expert and physician, died yesterday at Grasslands Hospital, Valhalla, after a long illness. He was 50 years old.

Philip Chaleff, 26 years old, of 33 Canal Street, walked into the District Attorney's office yesterday, accompanied by an attorney, to submit voluntarily to questioning in connection with the fatal shooting Saturday of Detective Michael J. Foley.

Miss Sylvia Seymour of San Francisco, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Seymour, will be married to John P. Cluett, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Harold Cluett of Troy, N. Y., and Washington, D. C., on Monday afternoon at the Washington home of the prospective bridegroom's parents, 2,400 Sixteenth Street, N. W.
Miss Kathryn C. Binder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Binder, was married here tonight to E. Harlan Whitehead, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Whitehead.

The Central Park Zoo became host yesterday noon to the second new buffalo calf of the season. No more are expected this year. Buffie, who was born in the old zoo, was the mother this time, and both she and the youngster were looking fine a few hours after the event.

D. Stewart Iglehart, president of W. R. Grace Co. and of the Grace Line, announced last night that the company would grant three yearly scholarships to Chilean engineering graduates to acquaint them with American standards and practices and, incidentally, to enhance commercial relations between the two nations.

Orders received by the General Electric Company for the first quarter of 1937 amounted to $105,747,030, the largest first quarter in the history of the company, compared to $59,569,879 for the 1936 period, a gain of 78 per cent.
Church and secular newspapers today censured Crown Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard, just returned from their honeymoon, for "desecrating the Sabbath."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The deficit in income and payroll tax collections, it seems to me,- grows out of an error on the part of the administration in estimating the tax income, because they might have based such estimate on the increased volume or business turnover rather than on the prospects of the profits resulting from such increased volume.

Reflecting a continuing improvement in business, operating revenues of the New York Central Railroad Company last year amounted to $361,063,872, an increase of $51,033,100 over the figures for 1935, according to the company's pamphlet report, issued yesterday.

At the meeting yesterday of the directors of the Consolidated Laundries Corporation the calling for redemption on June 15 of $403,500 of the company's convertible 61/2 per cent sinking fund notes was authorized. Upon the retirement of these

Leadership in the singles division of the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory almost changed hands yesterday as Paul Crane of Montclair, N. J., scored 725 to feature the tourney's thirty-seventh session.

With the murder this afternoon at Haifa of Khalim Basta Effendi, assistant superintendent of police, by three Arab terrorists, the Palestine police force lost one of its ablest officers, a master brain in criminal research.

The award to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd of the medal of the Explorers Club was announced yesterday by Dr. Vilhjalmur Stefansson, president of the club. The award was made in recognition of Admiral Byrd's "achievements in Arctic and Antarctic exploration."

The Senate passed today the Fischel Minimum Wage Bill advocated by Governor Lehman. The vote was 43 to 1, Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Orange, voting in the negative. His proposal to include men in the measure was defeated, 22 to 13.
Offering will be made today by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and Hawley, Huller Co. of Cleveland of 21,600 of no-par value common stock of the Monarch Machine Tool Company of Sidney, Ohio.
The piano industry continued to report large increases in its business when the quarterly statement was issued today by the National Piano Manufacturers Association.
For more than a half century the Charity Organization Society, whose abbreviated name has become dear to thousands upon thousands of families,

Resumption of "new money" borrowing to meet a deficiency in the Treasury's working balance caused by failure of revenues to come up to expectations, was announced officially today by Secretary Morgenthau. Simultaneously, various

Mrs. Alexander Lamport of Mount Vernon, N. Y., national membership chairman of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization, announced yesterday the organization now has a total of 60,000 members in its senior and junior divisions.
Arguments at the present term of the Supreme Court will be suspended during the week beginning May 3, according to tentative arrangements made today.
The University Glee Club of New York, Channing Lefebvre, conductor, gave its annual members' concert last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria before a large audience.

Successful completion of a campaign to raise $650,000 for a new out- patient department building was announced last night at the thirty-first annual meeting of the Hospital for Joint Diseases at Madison Avenue and 123d Street.

Viking, William Miller's Bermudian six-meter, today won the final race of the open yachting series. She took the lead on the third leg of the ten-mile race, gaining an advantage in a luffing match with Henry S. Morgan's Indian Scout and Briggs Cunningham's Lulu, both American craft, and kept ahead till the finish.

Mrs. Emil Denemark's Singing Slave, educated by Florida racing last Winter, bounded through the stretch to win the Shenandoah Purse, feature event, today. With Charlie Kurtsinger, the veteran pilot, doing the urging, Singing Slave scored by a length over Miss Oak, owned by J. P. Jones and the favorite in the field of nine juvenile fillies.
Chalmers Wood, chairman of the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, announced yesterday that this year's gifts to the campaign were ranging from 15 to 25 per cent more than the gifts of last year.

Completion of an arbitration agreement to settle disputes on the return of merchandise from retail stores to manufacturers in the wash-frock industry was announced jointly yesterday by the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers.

The thirty-fifth presentation of Greek Games at Barnard College, dedicated this year to the Goddess Athena, will take place tomorrow afternoon in Barnard Hall. The games are a contest in athletics, lyrics, costumes, music and dance and an attempt is made to reproduce, as nearly as modern conditions permit, a classic festival.
Dr. Max Poll, Professor Emeritus of the German department, University of Cincinnati, died at his home here today. He was 78 years old. Dr. Poll was born in Germany.

Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee introduced today a compromise taxing act that. would enable railroads and their employes to pay joint taxes into the Treasury. A companion measure would permit the roads to pay pensions to their employes.

Frederic Bowne, former member of the Stock Exchange and a member of one of Long Island's oldest, families, will be buried tomorrow after a funeral service in Trinity Chapel, Twenty-fifth Street, west of Broadway, at 10 A. M. He died on Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital after a short illness.

Mrs. Mary Flanagan, 45-year-old mother of ten children and the winner of the essay contest on "Why President Roosevelt Must Be Reelected," conducted during the last campaign by the National ProRoosevelt Association of Women Lawyers, Inc., arrived here yesterday to collect her reward, a sightseeing cruise.

Thomas Jefferson High School's nine began its Section A, Brooklyn Division P. S. A. L. drive yesterday by downing Bushwick High, 8-4, at Farmers Oval, Glendale. A fiverun outbreak in the seventh frame enabled the Orange and Blue to triumph. A feature of the rally was a double by Fred Baktis, which sent three scores across the plate.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
The Sunshine-Radio System abandoned yesterday an overnight attempt to operate its 2,400 taxicabs with a fare reduction of one-third. Even the weather was against it.

The general argument being made by moderates to the President for withdrawal of his Supreme Court Bill can be briefly summarized as follows: "The new court majority, having made two broad concessions to government, should be given an opportunity to proceed logically along the liberal path by the submission of well-drawn laws on wages and hours, crop controls and unfair trade practices.

An amendment to President Roosevelt's Court Reorganization Bill, designed to offer a compromise solution to members of Congress who regard the pending measure as too drastic, but believe some court change is needed, was offered to the Senate today by Senator McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada.
The size of the week's purchases of government securities by the Reserve Banks was again a surprise yesterday to most bankers and dealers. Although this week's

Herman S. Helander of Noroton Manor, president of the H. S. Helander Auto Supply Company of Stamford, died suddenly last night from acute indigestion and a heart attack in a cottage he owned in Imperial Park, Westport. He was in his forty-fifth year.

With a cast of 3,000 students of the Herman Ridder Junior High School, Boston Road and 173d Street, the Bronx, five WPA employes yesterday began production at the school of a three-reel movie which when completed will be shown at schools throughout

C. Edward Rowe of Orange was appointed today trustee of the PropperMcCallum Hosiery Company of Northampton by Federal Judge George C. Sweeney. He will take possession of the company and operate it, his bond being -laced at $100,000. He was ordered to

The final Thursday concert of the 1936-37 season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was given last night in Carnegie Hall. Paul Hindemith appeared as composer and soloist, performing his concerto for viola and small orchestra for the first time in this city.

Grand Av. (11-2867), e. s., 140 ft. n. of 176th St., 37x100; Bertha Schwartz to Rosalie S. Lederer, 1,722 Grand Av. East Bay Av. (10-2773), n. w. side, 50 ft. s. w. of Sacrahong St., 75x100 ft.; Consolidated Edison Co. of New York, Inc., to Benjamin Haskell, 1,335 Morris Av.
More than 300 entries have been received for the thirty-three classes listed for the first annual two-day Squadron A Spring Horse Show, which begins this afternoon at Squadron A Armory, Manhattan.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman yesterday dismissed a stockholders' suit which charged former officers and directors of the United Founders Corporation, once rated the largest investment trust in the United States, with wasting and squandering assets.

Another leading shoe chain joined the movement to raise prices yesterday, when the A. S. Beck Shoe Stores advanced their quotations 47 cents a pair, effective May 3. The Beck rise marks up the price from $3.98, which has been in effect for several years, to $4.45 and follows

Contracts for new space for commercial uses reported yesterday involved a number of locations on Broadway for stores and for units on upper floors. Among the businesses represented were investment security dealers, hardware, bakery products, woolen and dry goods dealers and men's furnishings. The list follows:

Plans for the construction of a $2,000,000 steam-power auxiliary plant here were disclosed by the Tennessee Electric Power Company today as the State Railroad and Public Utilities Commission announced that, as the result of a hearing late this month, it may order the utility to purchase power from the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Miss Emma Frohman, a sister of Daniel Frohman, dean of the American stage, and of the late Charles Frohman, also a producer, died on Wednesday night at Mount Sinai Hospital of pneumonia after a brief illness.

John S. Struyk, architect, died here this morning of a heart attack at his home, 138 Haledon Avenue. He was 57 years old. Mr. Struyk was born in Passaic County, the son of Adrian Struyk, the first Mayor here. He was educated at Columbia University.

The Hollywood guild of lily-gilders, having mulled long over Joseph Kessel's "L'Equipage" and having weighed the possible title of "Escadrille," finally displayed its customary originality by rechristening the opus "The Woman I Love."

The gallant bid of the New York Rangers for the Stanley Cup failed tonight. Detroit's Red Wings, holders of the trophy and the world hockey championship that it symbolizes, repulsed the Manhattan skaters in the fifth and deciding game of the series by 3 to 0.

The general committee of the World Textile Conference adopted the draft of its report on economic problems in the textile industry today, after amending it to state "that, in the interests of enlarged trade as well as of improved social conditions, governments should seek every opportunity to reduce unreasonable trade barriers."

The arrest of thirty Nazis who were wearing uniforms under ordinary clothes despite a government prohibition has once again brought to the foreground the activities of the Nazi party here, which has been growing unchecked in the face of government opposition.

A hint to the municipal authorities to clear away rusty old war trophies before the coronation was given today by King George, who ordered the removal from the east terrace of Windsor Castle of two large captured German guns that had stood there since 1918.

Because of the heavy mortality in promotion examinations for city employes, the Municipal Civil Service Commission suggested to all city departments yesterday that . they establish training courses for subordinate employes seeking promotion.

The six-story apartment house at 114 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, on a plot 150 by 100 feet, has been sold by the Home Life Insurance Company to Property Dealers, Inc., an investing syndicate of which Max Sollar is secretary.

Miss Jane Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent B. Smith of Westfield, N. J., was married yesterday in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria to John Arthur Hillier Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hillier of Braintree, Mass., by the Rev. John C. Poland.

Recognition of the United Automobile Workers of America by Henry Ford's big assembly plant at Richmond, across the bay from San Francisco, has been accomplished, Frank Slabey, union head in the East Bay area, said tonight.

Norman H. Davis is considering canceling his former plan to attend the meeting of the Disarmament Conference Bureau in Geneva early in May and sailing for the United States at the conclusion of the International Sugar Conference here, which is expected ten days hence.

The Flintkote Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for their three periods, or twelve weeks, ended on March 27, a net income of $193,585 after depreciation, Federal income, State and capital stock taxes and other deductions, but before Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

A gala luncheon and style pageant entitled "Dawn to Dusk" was held yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, drawing an attendance of more than 1,000 persons, many of whom were hosts and hostesses for luncheon parties at tables taxing the capacity of the ballroom floor and of the two tiers of boxes encircling the room.

The stock markets were weak today, with business on a small scale owing to the approaching end of the account. Gilt-edge issues were steady. Foreign loans were featureless. International stocks, including United States Steel, sagged.

After a short chase which zigzagged back and forth across East 122d Street early yesterday morning, Frank Becker, 34 years old, a WPA worker, of 243 East 124th Street, was arrested and charged with setting fire to rubbish under the staircase of a six-story tenement house at 254 East 122d Street.

BEGG, ALEXANDER (March 14). Estate, not more than $1,000. To Annette Dorothy Peel Begg. widow, executrix, 354 W. 18th St., residue. William Clement Foster Farnell, 9 Governor PI., Rutherford, N. J., executor.

Engagement of $15,177,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gold was engaged, it was said, at some previous date. It brought to $417,300,000 the total of gold obtained in England for United States account since Sept. 26, 1936.

American Gas' and Electric Company and Subsidiaries --Twelve months ended Jan. 31: Net income after interest; depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses, $12,057,660, which, after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to $2.21 a share on the common stock, comparing with a net of $10,626,789, or $1.89

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., and including Wells-Dickey Company, and Wheelock Cummins, Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,010,000 of public relief and permanent improvement bonds of Minneapolis, Minn., on a bid of 100.08 for 21/2s. The bonds,
Joe DiMaggio, Yankee outfielder, had his teeth examined and X-rayed yesterday in an effort to determine whether their condition is in any way responsible for his lame throwing arm.

Changes in amounts of reacquired stocks have been reported by the Curb Exchange as follows: Since the last report, American General Corporation's holdings of its own $2 preferred have risen from 12,806 to 19,338 shares and the common from 19,609 to 28,272; Equity

Stockholders of the Certain-teed Products Corporation have elected Robert L. Moore, Thomas H. Dugan and Edward G. Roos to the board of directors. Harold S. Maddock retired. Because of lack of a quorum, the meeting was adjourned until May 14 to vote on change in amendments.
The recovery in bond values continued yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange over a broad front but on a smaller trading volume.

Plans for changes and enlargement of Town Hall, at 113-15 West Forty-third Street, to include an additional five stories on the building, were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings by Louis E. Jallade, architect, who estimated the cost of the work at $800,000.

Walter Justin Sherman, civil engineer and historian, died here today at the age of 82. A graduate of Cornell University in 1877, Mr. Sherman took an important part in the railroad building boom of fifty years ago, putting down 300 miles of track in 300 days for the Gulf, Colorado Santa Fe. He served more than a dozen roads.

The engagement of Miss Helen Marion Touzel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. J. Touzel of Ottawa, Ont., to Dr. Robert Clyatt Kimberly, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Kimberly of Baltimore, has been announced.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Flora Flicker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Flicker of Brooklyn, to Jessie Schiffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Schiffman, also of Brooklyn.

Richard. Butler Glaenzer, poet, editor and writer on art, died yesterday at Far Rockaway Hospital of a stroke suffered a week ago. Mr. Glaenzer, who was 60 years old, lived at 34 West Tenth Street. When he was taken ill, he was visiting his brother, Georges Brette Glaenzer at Atlantic Beach L. I.

With two of the eight classifications registering a decline, total newspaper advertising in fifty-two cities measured by Media Records registered an increase of 8.3 per cent for March. Linage was 126,133,602 as against 116,443,051 for March, 1936, and 103,092,209 for February.

Theodore R. Middleton, Sheriff of Harlan County, Ky., admitted today that a group of coal operators had signed his bond, that he made about $2,400 a year from his investment in a coal concern's "company store," that he owned stock in a coal company and that of the 370odd deputies he has appointed in three years most were paid by mining companies.

The United Automobile Workers of America agreed in Detroit tonight to settle the General Motors strike at Oshawa on a "Canadian" basis, without recognition of the C. I. 0. as an "international" labor organization.
Assemblyman Ira Holley, New York Democrat, took Mayor La Guardia to task on the floor of the Assembly today for criticizing the Holley bill designed to end the use of "thirddegree" methods by police.

BERNHEIM, CHARLES H. (Sept. 11, 1935.) Gross assets, $767,347; net, $752,778. To Lillian Bernhelm, widow, $50,000, life estate in residue with right up to $5,000 of principal each year; Joseph Yagard, chauffeur, $2,000; Lily Swan, employee, $1,000. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $705,374. Stroock Stroock, attorneys, 141 Broadway.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiary companies, including the Midvale Company, reported yesterday that unfilled orders on March 31 were $33,181,836, compared with $30,531,416 on Jan. 1, and $9,868,856 on March 31, 1936. Orders taken

The American Artists Congress will open with a private view this evening and to the public tomorrow its first annual membership exhibitton in the Mezzanine Galleries of International Building, Rockefeller Center. The large group show will be current until April 29.

The American Artists Congress will open with a private view this evening and to the public tomorrow its first annual membership exhibitton in the Mezzanine Galleries of International Building, Rockefeller Center. The large group show will be current until April 29.

The British Government, unmoved by the taunts of cowardice and distortion of international law flung by the leaders of the Labor Opposition, refuses to modify its Spanish policy to give other Governments any pretext for "tearing non-intervention to pieces."

Mme. CHIANG KAI-SHEK is not only a picturesque but a powerful figure in the turbulent drama of resurgent China. She disproves the legend of the Oriental woman by playing a more open and active part in the Chinese revolution than is permitted to her most audacious contemporaries in the West. Far from being the power

The 1937 campaign for the defense of the America's Cup really got under way today when Commodore Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee had her first the spin on Massachusetts Bay under the new sloop rig which Frank C. Paine designed for the Marblehead boat this Winter to make her a real contender against the new Ranger and Rainbow 1934 defender.
LONDON-Italy abandoned her refusal to discuss withdrawal of foreign fighters in Spain. In consequence the Non-Intervention Committee held its most friendly meeting.

When the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. conveyed to John T. Javasile the 15-story apartment on the southwest corner of Park Av. and 94th St.. at a valuation shown as $1.200,000 Mr. Javasile gave back a purchase-money mortgage for $1,000,000. payable Aug. 1, 1947, at 4 per cent, $10,000 to be paid off semi-annually beginning Aug. 1. 1939. Mr. Javasile has conveyed

Walter Justin Sherman, civil engineer and historian, died here today at the age of 82. A graduate of Cornell University in 1877, Mr. Sherman took an important part in the railroad building boom of fifty years ago, putting down 300 miles of track in 300 days for the Gulf, Colorado Santa Fe. He served more than a dozen roads.

The engagement of Miss Helen Marion Touzel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. J. Touzel of Ottawa, Ont., to Dr. Robert Clyatt Kimberly, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Kimberly of Baltimore, has been announced.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Flora Flicker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Flicker of Brooklyn, to Jessie Schiffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Schiffman, also of Brooklyn.

There was an unenthusiastic response on the Clydeside today to a call for a general one-day strike of shipyard workers and engineers in support of 1,300 apprentices who have gone out for a better and uniform scale of wages.

Acting Captain William J. (Billy) Raftis, who in his twenty-two years on the pickpocket squad has probably known and arrested more "dips," grafterss" and "confidence men" than any other police officer in the country, announced yesterday his retirement, effective Sunday midnight.
And now comes Death: the final peak of all Experience! So shall I go, despaired; Or shall I go, my soul's stark forehead bared Before such majesty, while thin shades fall

Everett E. (Hooks) Mylin today became the third football coach in three years at Lafayette College. He was appointed to succeed Ernie Nevers, who resigned March 15 to become back-field coach at the University of Iowa. Nevers replaced Herb McCracken at the end of the 1935 season.

Cyril J. C. 'Quinn, in 530 E. 86th St.: Lucius H. Miller, through Culver. Hollyday Co., in 192 E. 75th St.; Stockwell Marling, brokers. Edward T. McLean. in 47 E. 88th St.; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker.

Nature has been unusually kind to both trout and trout fishermen up to this early stage of the angling season, and with prospects of balmy weather this week-end should witness a general exodus to the streams.
Employes in two cigar manufacturing plants continued their sitdown strikes yesterday, demanding higher pay and union recognition.
Flowers were placed on the grave of Jose de Diego, independence advocate, today but there was no Nationalist demonstration in defiance of municipal and insular authorities as announced.

Mayor La Guardia warned his colleagues on the Board of Estimate yesterday that if the city's practice of giving awards to the survivors of persons killed accidentally by policemen was abused, the granting of any awards easily could be blocked by a taxpayer's action.

The marriage of Miss Gladys B. Smythe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Richardson Smythe of 1,900 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, to John Colegrove Sims, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Sims of New Haven, Conn., took place last night in the Church of the Neighbor, Brooklyn. The Rev. William F. Wunsch performed the ceremony.

Joan Haslip, British biographer of: Charles Stewart Parnell, the Irish leader, and of Lady Hester Stanhope, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the liner Manhattan for a visit of several months in America.

A collective agreement for the 9,000 employes in the four rayon plants operated by the du Pont interests is the next objective of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, it was announced yesterday by Sidney Hillman, chairman, and president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden will return today from Palm Beach to the Plaza, where they will be until they sail for Europe on April 27. Mrs. Marshall Russell has returned to the St. Regis from Aiken, S. C. Her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Shevlin of Pasadena, Calif., are also at the St. Regis.
The Princeton freshman baseball team opened its season with a 15to-1 victory over the Tome School nine on Brokaw Field today. The score by innings:

The Trip Realty Corporation, rep resented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, bought from Petmon Equities, Inc., the apartment house at 2,917 Grand Concourse, southwest corner of 199th Street and immediately resold it to Shulman Brothers, operators.
Though it is touch-and-go with one or two plays, only three thus far are scheduled to end their runs after this evening.

Hopes for a compromise of the fight of steel companies to restrict exports of scrap steel essential to steed production appeared to have risen this week despite a series of regional meetings of independent steel and ron producers and their retaining of Donald Richberg, former head of the NRA, as legal counsel.

Shareholders of the Michigan Bumper Company are to meet on April 26 to ratify the action of the board of directors in applying to the New York Curb Exchange for listing of 305,000 additional shares of $1 par value common stock and in reserving 50,000 shares of common for purchase by officers, directors and employes over a three-year period.

208th St., 106 E. (12-3336); Ray Siegel to Bowery Savings Bank, extends mtg. to April 1, 1942, at 41/2 per cent; $13,500. Grand Concourse, 1,362 (11-2831); Max Nisnewitz to C. V. J. Corp., 2,804 3d Av., 4 per cent; $34,000. Beach Av., 1,460 (15-3899); Lillian Cotkin to Felix A. Muldoon, trustee, 164 Bush St., 3 years, 4 per cent; $68,000.

Mrs. Beatrice Schaefer, 33 years old, of Glen Ridge, wife of Everett G. Schaefer, a New York insurance broker, died tonight in a fall from the roof of a four-story apartment house. Mr. Schaefer brought his wife home last night from a Hartford (Conn.) hospital.

Governor W. I. Myers of the Farm Credit Administration told the House Agriculture Committee in an executive session today that a boom in land might result if artificially low interest rates were continued for purchasing farms. He voiced opposition to a bill which would extend through 1938 and 1939 the present 31/2 per cent interest rates on Federal Land Bank loans.

R. C. Tackett, elderly Kentuckian, who told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee of his participation in attempted dynamiting of a Harlan County union organizer, today charged that Ted Creech, a mine superintendent, had threatened him with a jail sentence in conversation at the door of the Senate hearing room.

The eighth annual robbery of the Shelton Delicatessen, 808 Third Avenue, was carried out last night but a suspect was seized. The police arrested Nicholas Selvaggio, 37 years old, a laborer of 124 East 115th Street, after a chase along East Forty-ninth Street. The store has been robbed once a year for eight years.

That her automobile might be available whenever her 4 1/2-year-old son, who is subject to convulsions, required emergency treatment Mrs. Mary Larkin ignored 29 tickets for overtime parking, she told Magistrate Ford yesterday in Washington Heights Traffic Court.

Leon Trotsky wrote into the records of his hearing his belief that the defendants of the Moscow trials should have been executed if they actually were guilty of assassinations, sabotage and conspiracy with foreign governments.

WHETHER he knows it or not, President Ford Frick of the National League is about to receive a little gift. It's something of a museum piece. Mr. Si Goodfriend, who owns it at the moment, was around exhibiting it yesterday.

The proposal of Representative WRIWHT PATMAN and the "House block" for which he speaks, that the Federal Reserve System be purchased from its present stock ownership by the Government and thenceforward be operated in all its branches as a Government bureau, will excite no great interest.

The increase in cotton mill activity last week was slightly less than seasonal and the adjusted index dropped back 1 point. The figure now is 138.9, as compared with 139.9 (revised) in the preceding week and 107.4 for the week ended April 11, 1936.

Miss Elizabeth June Sumner, daughter of Mrs. Amelia Sumner of Bronxville and of G. Lynn Sumner of this city, was married to George Sidney Birdsong, son of Mr. and Mrs. Silas A. Birdsong, also of Bronxville, yesterday afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the WaldorfAstoria. The Rev. Dr. Owen R. Lovejoy of Washington performed the ceremony.
No royal family of recent times will compare with the house of Rumania for the amount of newspaper copy furnished,

Turpentine firm, 36 1/2c: sales. 96 barrels; receipts, 169 barrels; shipments, 5 barrels; stock, 23,535 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 177 barrels; receipts, 693 barrels; shipments, 443 barrels; stock. 46,006 barrels.

Several hundred persons of prominence in society and the artistic world thronged the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for a "Red, White and Blue Burlesque Ball," a dance and entertainment given for Miss Elsa Maxwell.

DONALD CULROSS PEATTIE'S "A Book of Hours" (Putnam, $2.50) ought to please nearly every one who liked "An Almanac for Moderns," for it is another example of Mr. Peattie's honesty, perception and skill with wordsa tender, serious and, on the whole, unpretentious book that deals boldly with great matters and charmingly with small.

Quoting from a publication entitled "Man's Best Friend," a eulogy on dogs, Magistrate Brodsky in Homicide Court yesterday dismissed a charge of homicide against Robert Exton, 25 years old, of 322 West Eighty-ninth Street.

The Louisiana Society in New York, meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, elected the following officers: Mrs. Gertrude Aldrich, president; Mrs. W. L. Morse, first vice president; Mrs. Paul de G. Prickett, second vice president;
An offer to settle a contemplated $100,000,000 suit for $1,000,000 was reported today to the United States District Court by the Standard Gas and Electric Corporation, now in reorganization.
The First Circuit Court of Appeals of the United States here today ruled the Social Security Act unconstitutional, both in regard to unemployment insurance and its provisions for old-age assistance.
Organization of a new Cabinet for autonomous Catalonia, with the anarchists having the strongest representation, was announced tonight by President Luis Companys.

Jacob and Emil Leitner, Inc., have placed with the Dollar Savings Bank a permanent mortgage for $205,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for five years on the six-story apartment on the northwest corner of Gun Hill Road and Kings College Place. the Bronx, for the Leseen Realty Corp., Samuel Rubin, president. The new loan replaces a building loan made by the Sterling National Bank and Trust Co.
The Peddie School tonight honored its undefeated Eastern Private School Basketball League champions. A dinner was held at the school, with Headmaster Wilbour E. Saunders acting as toastmaster.
Officials of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers and owners of seventeen hosiery mills in this vicinity reached an agreement tonight ending the strike which began seven weeks ago.

Municipal Court Justice Daniel V. Sullivan yesterday refused to set aside a $3.85 verdict against the New York Telephone Company recently awarded by a six-man jury in the court to James J. McCoy, a "public utility consultant," who had brought suit charging the telephone company with overcharging him on toll calls made last September.

John Masefield, Poet Laureate of England, today made public his contribution to the approaching coronation celebrations, a "Coronation Prayer." It was written for the coronation program of the King George V Memorial Trust. The poem, in sonnet form, reads:

The Fidelity Fund, Inc., reported yesterday a net asset value of $29.31 a share on 165,424 shares outstanding on March 31, compared with $28.61 on Dec. 31. On March 31, 1936, net assets value was $26.23 on 133,962 shares then outstanding, before the special dividend of $2.50 a share paid on Dec. 10, 1936.

Lord Marley, British Laborite, advised Americans today to stay away from the coronation of King George VI unless they want to be "overcharged for hotels, overcharged for seats to view the coronation, and generally exploited."

President Roosevelt plans to leave Washington on April 28 for a fishing cruise of two weeks off the Texas coast, he told his press conference today. He will board his yacht, the Potomac, at New Orleans.

There is still $125,819,756 due to depositors in Pennsylvania's Statechartered banks, according to a report by Dr. Luther A. Harr, State Secretary of Banking. The closed banks had on Dec. 31 assets appraised at $46,327,888 to meet the depositors' credits,
William Bates, conductor, 75, began the first day of his retirement today after traveling hundreds of thousands of miles in fifty-four years of railroading by making plans to do more traveling. "Mrs.
An attempt to commit the World Textile Conference to the pronouncement that the meeting had disclosed the need for reducing hours in the textile industry failed today.
Following a hearing on the plan of reorganization for the Prudence Company, Inc., yesterday, Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal court in Brooklyn directed counsel for interested parties to

Leading copper producers yesterday reduced the price of the metal in the domestic market from 16 cents to 15 1/2 cents a pound. For more than a week, the primary producers have been quoting copper at 16 cents in the domestic market, while the custom smelters have been at 15 1/2 cen,.

The Netherland freighter Sarkana was seized by a Spanish Insurgent warship as she attempted to run the Insurgent blockade in the Straits of Gibraltar, it was reported today, while a Netherland cruiser stood by, refusing aid.
Member trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 20 was 20.43 per cent of the total volume, compared with 21.25 per cent in the previous week,

Premier Hepburn instructed Colonel W. W. Denison, Inspector of Legal Offices, today to take necessary steps to collect $219 said to be owing to the Province by, Mayor Hall of Oshawa out of legal fees collected before his dismissal as Crown Attorney of Ontario County in 1934.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 15: BRIGADIER GENERAL Tyner, G. P., General Staff Corps, now on duty in office of the Chief of Staff; to duty as Assistant Chief of Staff G-3, effective April 16.

William J. Graham, vice president in charge of the group insurance department, was elected a director of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States by the board of directors yesterday. He entered the service of the company in 1911 and became an officer in 1920.

New trials were ordered by the Appellate Division yesterday for two men who were convicted in Bronx County Court of kidnapping and holding for ransom Battisto Salvo, reputed policy banker. The court ruled unanimously that the two had not received fair trials.

Action on a plan to provide approximately $2,600,000 of new capital for the Hupp Motor Car Corporation was deferred today until tomorrow, when a meeting of stockholders was adjourned because of the failure of expected proxies to arrive.

Miss Dorothy Ruth Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel C. R. Palmer of this city, was married to Clifford N. Pascoe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman C. Pascoe, also of New Rochelle, this evening at her parents' home here.

Harry Chancer, 39-year-old president of the New York and Brooklyn Coat and Suit Trucking Company, Inc., was arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy and coercion as Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey pushed his investigation of racketeering in the garment industry.

Philologians have followed with interest the discussion in Books of the Times as to the origin and correct text of such phrases as "the or the real Mackay, McKaye, McKie, McCoy." The last spelling seems authoritative, since the English or Scottish variants are thought to be derived from the American model.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 10 totaled 716,044 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,643 cars, or 1.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 94,201 cars, or 15.1 per cent,

Despite the improvement in bond prices and investment sentiment general this week, new bond financing was again restricted largely to tax-exempt flotations. Total new offerings amounted to $7,650,000, of which State and municipal issues accounted for $5,710,000.

Apparently feeling that today might be the last day devoted to public hearings on President Roosevelt's court reorganization bill, the Senate Judiciary Committee sat for nearly eight hours listening to various witnesses, without even taking a recess for luncheon.

The State of New York has Just collected its first (and most painful) installment of the income tax, and perhaps 500,000 people have now made a direct personal contribution toward the upkeep of the State's institutions. This would be about one person in every sixteen of voting age.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Emily Van Olinda, niece of Miss Grace J. Boggs of 425 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, to Dr. Eric Ponder, son of Mrs. Charles F. Ponder of Awliscombe, Devon, England, and the late Dr. Ponder, took place yesterday morning in Christ Church, Bay Ridge.

It must be disheartening to many Germans to hear Nazi district leaders ordering officialdom to marry and reproduce itself. In the double drive to increase the population and encourage farmers to stay on the soil and work it as a family enterprise, the National Socialist Government, pays special premiums to farmers with large families.

Belgium's American-educated Premier, Paul Van Zeeland, trying to find a way to break down world trade barriers, will go to the United States soon to get some pointers from President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.
Negotiations by stockholders for a merger of the Aircraft Plywood Corporation with the United States Plywood Company of New York were under way here today.

M. Eitingon, president of the Eitingon Schild Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that sales for the first four and one-half months of the current fiscal year were $7,400,000, and that the estimated net income for the period was $527,000.
Officially sanctioned by the San Francisco Labor Council, a strike of more than 3000 employes of fifteen large hotels was ordered tonight for 5 P. M. tomorrow.

Sentences of fifty years to life imprisonment were imposed yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions on three vagrants who, on the night of May 1 last, strangled and robbed Edgar L. Eckert, 54 years old, a director and assistant treasurer of the Rogers Peet Company, in the station of the city subway at Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The list of the Hamburg-American liner Hansa, due today from the Channel ports, includes Dr. and Mrs. Karl W. Gebhard, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Kiers, Dr. Felix Pincus, Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Stroebel, Mr. and Mrs. William Kuhlman, C. S. Hedges, Mr. and Mrs. Ricardo Seipmann, Dr. and Mrs. Johannes Clasing, Arnold Keller, Mrs. Auguste Bolte, Ernest Letter and Christoph Diener.
A jury in Supreme Court found yesterday that the city was the owner of about two-thirds of a block of East River waterfront which Wilson Co., the meat packers, have occupied more than twenty years.

Adding complications to an already complicated situation, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia and Irving Crane of Livonia, N.
