Y., completed their eleven-game schedules in the world pocket billiard championship last night at Ponzi's academy with respective triumphs over Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Dell., and Joe Diehl of Rockford, Ill.

Raymond E. Korte, Lynn Craig and Roland H. Weir, Southern Indiana banker-business men, were sentenced to eight years imprisonment and fined $5,000 each in Federal Court today for violations of the National Banking Laws.

Sunned turned in his first victory of the 1937 season today in the Hampton Roads Purse, a sprint of six furlongs which drew seven better-than-average horses. The 5year-old gelding drove to a length victory. In a photo finish for second, the Glen Riddle Farm's War Emblem- got the call over the Bomar stable's Billy Bee.

The projected strike by 8,500 employes of the Southern Pacific Railroad was postponed here tonight by officials of the Brotherhoods of Railway Trainmen and Railroad Firemen pending the meeting of an emergency mediation board appointed by President Roosevelt.

The "flying fortress" military plane, which is more formidable than anything ever constructed in any country in the world, according to Army Air Corps officers, is near completion at the Boeing factory in Seattle and will have its first test flight within the next two weeks.

Ted, the last remaining horse in the service of the city, has been going on a sit-down strike daily since he was brought out of his Winter quarters two weeks ago. He appears to have only one demand-no work.

Trading was mostly fair. Steer hinds and ribs and veal hindsaddles were higher. The lamb market was steady to lower and fresh pork cuts steady to weak. Early trading in kosher meats indicated some beef sales to be higher. Veal and lamb weak, as reported by the United states Department of Agriculture.

Shareholders of the Northern Texas Electric Company have been notified that the protective committee representing holders of its funded debt is heavily in favor of the reorganization which will be considered by the court on April 26.

Responding to the continued heavy offerings of gold in London, the pound sterling yesterday rose ?? $4.92 3/8, the dearest price since Oct. 5, last, and closed at $4.92 1/4, up 15-16 cents from the previous day.
The petition of a Negro seeking admission to the School of Pharmacy of the University of Tennessee, now attended only by white students, was denied today by Chancellor Lois D. Bejach.

The annual Evening of Columbia University Music, offering compositions and arrangements by students, faculty and alumni, will be held tonight at the McMlllin Theatre on the campus. Professor Seth Bingham will direct the program.
The Rev. Elias Brown Van Arsdale, pastor emeritus of the North Paterson Reformed Church of Hawthorne, N. J., died Thursday at his home, 201 Vreeland Avenue, Paterson, N. J.

Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Barnes Hiscock, wife of Frank Harris Hiscock, former chief judge of the Court of Appeals and chairman of the board of trustees of Cornell University, died at her home here today. She was 80 years old.

The annual field day of the Bond Club of Philadelphia will be held this year on Friday, June 11, at the Philmont Country Club. Activities of the day will be under the direction of Edward Blyd Jr. of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., chairman of the field day committee.

The sit-down strikes called in strategic key plants by which a small group of workers causes idleness for thousands was condemned last night by Judge John Clark Knox, senior judge of the Federal court in the Southern District of New York.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn unanimously reversed yesterday a man's conviction for driving an automobile while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident on the ground that he had inadvertently taken an overdose of a drug and
Else Brems, mezzo-soprano of the Royal Opera of Copenhagen, aroused interest and enthusiasm at her local debut in Town Hall last night.

When Mr. Winston Churchill, certainly its most wide-awake member, day-dreams in the House of Commons; when Mr. Eden announces publicly that he "does not regret" this public dreaming, and the French press takes it seriously; when it is followed by a comtest in concession and recession between the Italian and Russian delegates in the Non-Intervention Committee--an act of withdrawal from previous positions in the best Alphonse and Gaston
Another Colorado decathlon star emerged today at the Kansas relays as the probable 1937 occupant of Retiring Champion Glenn Morris's shoes-but he fell far short of filling them.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $8,103,957, to be represented by one State and thirty-five municipalities, compared with the revised total for this week of $12,944,754. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $36,072,159..
Plans for new buildings and alterations in existing ones in scattered sections of the city were filed by architects yesterday. Details of the plans follow:

Realty contracts reported in Manhattan yesterday included the sale by banks of walk-up apartment houses in scattered sections. The Metropolitan Savings Bank sold to a client of Bachrach Bachrach the six-story walk-up at 233-35 East Ninth Street subject to a first mortgage of $30,000 at 4 to 5 per cent interest.

Proxies to be voted at the forthcoming annual meeting of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, now under proceedings in reorganization before Federal Judge Holly in Chicago, are being asked by a new "general protective committee" for security holders of the corporation headed by Harry Reid, an executive of the Associated Gas and Electric System.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company has been appointed transfer agent of the capital stock of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, and the Manufacturers Trust Company ns registrar for 425,000 shares of $1 par capital stock.

William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, attempted unsuccessfully yesterday to bring about a settlement between the blind strikers of the Community Craft Weavers Auxiliary and the organization's board of directors.

Mme. Lilly Dache's short-lived courtship of elusive Lady Luck received a set-back yesterday whenthe A. S. P. C. A. stepped in and ordered her to remove the "good luck" live-horned toad from the cornerstone of her new building.
United States Senator Robert F. Wagner vigorously defended his National Labor Relations Act last night against the charge that it unduly favored the employee against the employer.
The government armies seized the offensive on a new front tonight and swept through three villages north of Teruel City, about 150 miles east of Madrid.

Pensioned For physical disability: Fireman First Grade William C. N. Pedersen. H. L. 148, retired on an annual pension of $1.500. Fireman First Grade Lawrence Murray. H. L. 37, retired on an annual pension of $1,500.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will open today an exhibition of work by and about Thomas Paine, the English author whose writings helped further the American Revolution and who later, as a prisoner in France during the French Revolution, wrote "The Age of Reason."
Stocks sagged and closed irregularly lower in quiet trading; turnover, 1,069,210 shares. United States Government issues irregularly higher, other bonds firm and mixed; transactions, $9,523,400.
The Fedial Home Loan Bank of Chicago announced today that its first quarer's net earnings this year amounted to $122,987, or $20,958 more than for the same period in 1936.

Squadron A inaugurated its first Spring horse show at the Madison Avenue Armory yesterday. The two-day show began with an afternoon session, and last night the exhibitions were presented in a colorful setting.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 14:. CAPTAINS Helm, S. F., the Richmond, to Headquar ters, 3d Naval District, New York, N. Y., about June 19. Reed, T. W., Medical Corps, Pensacola, Fla., to the Relief.

The general collapse in the commodity markets yesterday carried cotton off almost $2 a bale under the heaviest selling movement of the year. Owing to pre-notice day liquidation of May contracts, pressure was heaviest in near months and the May-December spread narrowed to 40 points at one time, compared with 88 points a month ago.

J. E. Crawford, vice president in charge of operations of the Norfolk Western Railroad, was elected president of the Cincinnati Union Terminal Company at the annual meeting yesterday, to succeed C. D. Brooke.

The sons of Rutgers, who have been singing for years of the "Banks of the Old Raritan," may find, before June tapers off into Summer, added significance to their alma mater hymn. For there is evidence here that the appealing enthusiasm which has brought Rutgers into rowing is beginning to

Ditmas Estates, Inc., representing Max Gelles and Irving Honigsberg, purchased the three four-story apartment houses at 2,203 to 2,217 Ditmas Avenue, northeast corner of East Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, for cash over a mortgage of $140,000 at 41/2 per cent.

Two armed men, objects of a nation-wide hunt as suspects in the recent Katonah (N. Y.) bank robbery, were captured here tonight after they had shot their way out of a trap set by Federal agents at Topeka today, founding a Federal agent and a bystander. The capture was by the local Sheriff and a deputy.

In a formal statement on behalf of directors of the World Two-Way Trade Fair. Inc., Louis K. Comstock, president of the organization, yesterday announced indefinite postponement of the exhibit which was to have opened here May 10.

Grand Concourse (11-2831);' e. s., 215 ft. S. of 170th St., 100x100; Max Nisnewitz to Henthel Realty Corp., 384 E. 149th St. Webster Av., 1357 (11-2887): Nathaniel Kaplan, referee, to William F. Schneider, 851 Columbus Av. Grand Concourse (12-3319); s. w. cor. 199th St., 115x100 ft.; Petmon Equities, Inc. to Saha Realty Corp., 203 W. 145th St., mtg., $165,000.

Reports in the boys' and students' clothing market here yesterday indicated that large-volume purchasers are planning a "buyers' strike" as the result of dissatisfaction with the decision of the Boys and Students Clothing Manufacturers Association to limit volume discounts for the Fall season to 7 per cent instead of the 10 per cent basis which formerly prevailed.

It is entirely proper that any one who wants to should be able to organize a mass meeting to condemn communism or any other doctrine with which he does not agree. But those who attend such meetings should recognize the value of temperateness of speech.

THE GREAT POETS AND THE MEANING OF LIFE, by Charles Allen Dinsmore. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.75.) Dr. Dinsmore considers the ancient poets-Homer, Aeschylus, Lucretius and Virgil-and Shakespeare and Dante.

Miniature yachts will fling their sails to the breeze this morning on Conservatory Lake, Central Park, as they vie for prizes in the semiannual model sail and motor boat regatta sponsored by the city Deapartment of Parks and R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has amended its original order in the alleged manipulation of Lakey Foundry and Machine Company securities on the Detroit Stock Exchange by Dart Co. of Detroit to strike out the names of Herbert La Vinge and George Blumenthal as partners.

Surveying a re-arming world, with incidents growing in "pace and intensity," with dictators seeking to save face and a democracy such as ours assertedly "lacking a clear understanding of our own national objectives," speakers at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science today put their fingers on danger spots and spoke cautiously of the hope of averting another general war.

Supporting the one-hit pitching of Joe Dooley with a strong attack, Jamaica, defending titleholder, crushed Bayside, 15-0, in a Queens P. S. A. L. game yesterday, the contest being among the features of the tournament battles in the metropolitan area. Ed Hansen got the only hit off Dooley.

The election by the board of trustees of Dr. Eugene Staley as associate professor of international economic relations in the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy has just been announced by Dean Halford L. Hoskins.

The first conviction under a new law forbidding truck drivers to remain at the wheel of their vehicles for more than ten hours in any consecutive fourteen occurred yesterday in Flushing Magistrate's Court.
Dr. George Gallup told the American Society of Newspaper Editors today that the "newspaper of tomorrow" would carry more pictures, have wider news columns and be printed in larger type.
W. Va., April 16 Al Marshall of Cincinnati and Richard D. Lunn of Washington won today in the semi-finals of the Mason-Dixon amateur golf tourney.
A study of the anti-trust laws and the court decisions affecting them will be laid before the President soon, Attorney General Cummings said today. It may be the basis for new legislation.
Bernard J. McPhillips, retired ship builder and designer, died on Thursday at his home, 34-22 Eightyfourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

Before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today the William Filene's Sons Company of Boston charged that the Fashion Originator's Guild, Inc., of New York, was a monopoly and fostered a business in restraint of interstate commerce.
Cram's Reports, Inc., tOday estimated that this week's output of the automobile plants would total 124,970 cars and trucks, compared with its revised estimate of 99,196 units last week.

" Outstanding Problems of Labor and Industry" is the subject for discussion at the fourth and last dinner meeting of the season for the Economic Club of New York, which will be held at the Hotel Astor on Thursday, April 29, with George E. Sokolsky as the leading speaker, and Paul D. Cravath presiding.

Captain David ("Potato") Jones, skipper of the small British food ship Marie Llewellyn, has returned here in a white rage without breaking General Francisco Franco's blockade of government ports on the northern Spanish coast.

More than half a dozen members of the Twelfth Kings County Assembly District Republican Club, including the first and second vice presidents, the secretary and a member of the board of governors, joined last night in condemning Mayor La Guardia and expressing opposition to his renomination.

Leases of commercial space reported by brokers yesterday were featured by the interest shown in store locations on the upper West Side and in the Bronx. The principals in several of the contracts closed will operate food stores and retail apparel and accessory shops. The list follows:

The Soldier's Medal has been awarded to Mike Barsosky, private, Headquarters and Military Police Company, First Division, the War Deapartment announced today, for heroism displayed at Battery Park landing, New York, Sept. 8, 1936.

Senator Copeland of New York, in an address to the students of Dartmouth College today, declared that President Roosevelt may have no intention of establishing a dictatorship, but that his Supreme Court plan puts him under suspicion.

Miss Dorothy Baird Turner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Turner of this place, was married tonight to Beverly Wilson Robertson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Robertson of Orange, in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here. A reception at the Turner home followed the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Dr. Luke M. White, the rector.

Liquidation engulfed the wheat market today and prices dropped in a manner which reminded the trade of the collapse of the bulge in July, 1933. The May deliveries of wheat, rye and barley on markets in this country and all deliveries of the three grains in Winnipeg declined 5 cents a bushel, the maximum permitted for one day,

The directors of Armour Co. (Illinois) voted today to pay a dividend of 20 cents a share on the common stock on June 15 to holders of record of May 25. Last March, 15 cents was paid, the first common stock dividend of the company in ten years.

President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Morgenthau and Budget Director Bell on fiscal matters; announced that Premier Van Zeeland of Belgium would be a White House guest when he visits this country in June and revealed plans to leave April 28 for a fishing cruise off the Texas coast.

Peter Morris Close, descendant of one of the oldest families in Greenwich, died last night at his home, 1,620 University Avenue, New York, at the age of 77. Mr. Close was born in the original homestead here.
Five students from the Greater New York area and neighboring States were among those elected to the Oberlin College Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa.

The Rev. Harris A. Darche, World War hero, who was national chaplain of the American Legion in 1932, died suddenly of acute indigestion today in his home here. He had been pastor of St. Joseph's Church for fourteen yars. His age was 49.

Leaders in many fields were among the 150 persons who attended funeral services for Captain Archibald Magill Fauntleroy, U. S. N. (retired), this afternoon at Shadow Lake, Yorktown, where he had lived.

The Board of Tax Appeals disclosed today that it had dispatched subpoenas for service on Pierre S. du Pont and John J. Raskob in connection with the Treasury's suit for recovery of alleged deficiencies in their income taxes.

A conference on the proposed commercial standards for colors for bathroom and kitchen accessories will be held under the auspices of the Bureau of Standards of the Department of Commerce on April 30 at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

It has just been announced that a complete catalogue of John Singleton Copley's American works in oil, pastel and miniature is being compiled in connection with the bicentennial celebration of the author's birth.

Coupons should be a definite step and an integral part of the selling plan, Walter E. Thwing, head of the company bearing his name, declared yesterday at a symposium on coupons in advertising, held by the Advertising and Marketing Forum of the Advertising Club of New York.

Shedding the metaphoric sable wraps and the star-banded neckpieces which have been encumbering it recently, the movies went out to meet the Spring yesterday in an attractively light-weight fabric called "When Love Is Young."

Strike-breakers invaded Toronto and Hamilton docks today for jobs as stevedores loading ships ready for the 1937 navigation season. Pickets patrolling the waterfront paid no attention to them and the single policeman on duty reported no incidents.

With a score of distinguished guests in attendance, the eighteenth annual ball and reunion of the Father Duffy Chapter of the Rainbow Veterans Association was held last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The chapter is composed of veterans of the 165th Infantry (Old Sixty-ninth) N. Y. N. G.

The court hearing of a complaint against Fritz Kuhn, national leader of the American Nazis, was postponed for the fourth time in Yorkville Court yesterday, until April 30 at 2 P. M. The special detail of policemen assigned to each hearing made a disorderly conduct arrest of one anti-Nazi among the disputing partisans afterward in the street.

The Appellate Division, in a unanimous decision, confirmed yesterday a permanent injunction restraining Park Commissioner Robert Moses from building playgrounds in Stuyvesant Park at Fifteenth Street and Second Avenue.

The report circulated last month and verified in part by Secretary Morgenthau that the various investment accounts of the Treasury were "fully invested" and had only a limited amount of funds available for further purchases, was explained yesterday in the report showing that these agencies of the Treasury had purchased in March $119,553,000 of government securities.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The market for wool is quieter. The slower movement is apparent both in the East and in the West.

Mortgages guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration were recommended as investments for banks by J. Howard Ardrey, assistant FHA administrator, at a mortgagee's conference held yesterday at the Crescent Athletic Club, 129 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, under the sponsorship of the Kings County Bankers Association.

The Giants' stupendous Spring training tour, which began eight weeks ago today in Havana, came simultaneously to an end and a lot of grief today when, before an overflow crowd of 5,000, the Indians routed Clydell Castleman in the eighth and rushed four runs across the plate to win the sixteenth game of the series, 8 to 4.
Cooper Square, 31, 3 and 4 story loft and store building, 24x100; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Julie L. Cullen; due, $9,937; taxes, , $1,236; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Dr. Charles Sumner Benedict, former president of the Westchester County Medical Society and former New York Health Department official, died yesterday of heart disease at his home here. Dr. Benedict, who was 80 years old, had offices at 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, until illness forced his retirement last May.
Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Broun of 330 East Forty-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Almeda Broun, to Malcolm C. Petrie of Scarboroughon-Hudson, N. Y.
Major Ference Szalassy, with twenty-five members of the Fascist organization, Party of National Will, was arrested here last night and will be prosecuted for "activities disturbing public order."

Plans for plant improvement and expansion involving at least $9,000,000 were presented today by the American Rolling Mill Company in a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for issuance of 450,000 shares of cumulative convertible preferred stock, $100 par value, and an undetermined amount of $25 par value common stock to be reserved for the conversion of the preferred.

Charles L. Baird, who retired in 1930 as treasurer of the Baird Bartlett Company, Boston paper board concern which he helped to organize in 1907, died last night at his home in Wellesley after a long illness. He was 77 years old.
A youth booked as Vincent Rice, 16, of Stockton, N. J., was in jail today on a charge of carrying a concealed weapon.

Decision was reserved yesterday by Federal Judge Patterson on a motion to review the sale of Orpheum Circuit, Inc., to Stadium Theatres Corporation, which was sanctioned recently by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy. Both companies are affiliates of RKO.
Down through the San Clemente naval drill waters off Southern California. where shells shriek and bombs burst during the gunnery season, the United States fleet moved silently today.

A much smaller "commercial zone" for New York City than had been recommended by the Port of New York Authority and other business and commercial organizations of New York City and State was prescribed today by the Interstate Commerce Commission for purposes of exemption from Federal regulation under the Motor Carrier Act.
THE FIRST AMERICAN REVOLUTION, by Jack Hardy. (International Publishers, $1.) A MarxistLeninist interpretation of the American Revolution of 1776.

On April 29 the New York Stock Exchange will consider admission of the firm of Simmons Peckham, to be formed by Edward C. Simmons, Henry A. Peckham, James S. Martin, Lillian H. Martin and Alfred F. Smith. The last two are to be special partners.

About 100 fishermen, apparently influenced by strike reports in the newspapers, refused today to make the morning haul from the offshore stake nets of four fishingboat captains, demanding pay increases from $65 to $85 a month with room and board.
Tommy Farr, 23-year-old Welshman, who "struck a blow for British boxing" by beating Maxie Baer, found himself a famous and much-soughtafter man today.

General Motors of Canada strikers accepted proposals for a settlement of the Oshawa strike, excluding C. I. O. and U. A. W. A. international representatives from negotiations, which begin today in Premier Hepburn's office. Page 1.
The president of Yale University attacked governmental unemployment relief today as the cause of a "most imperative problem" facing the nation.

Churches of all faith will participate in the general choir music festival observance which begins today and continues through April 30. The object is "to bring sacred music composed by master musicians of history to the attention of music-loving people." There will be several union musical services.

Plans for the annual convention of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, which is to be held in this city on April 28 to 30, were announced yesterday by Carl M. Spencer, presidetn of the association and head of the Home Savings Bank, Boston.
The Madrigal Singers, Lehman Engel conductor, were heard last night at the WPA Theatre of Music in a request program. Motets of Heinrich Schutz and de Victoria opened the evening.

Street car and bus operators went on strike in Akron today. Every unit of the Akron Transportation Company's yellow fleet stood still in its barns, with 300 motormen and drivers idle, pending the completion of negotiations for a new pay schedule.

Movements on the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 8,000, including 3,500 direct. Market strong to $10 higher than Thursday's average; spots up more on medium grade lightweights; top $10.30; bulk good and choice 200-300 pound, $10.05-.25; 150190 pound, $9.60-$10.15; packing sows largely $9.50-.75; bigweights down to $9.25 and under.
Harry Elias Asbury, a hardware manufacturer, died last night at his home in Melrose Park at the age of 70.

The local outdoor track season will get under way today with the twenty-ninth New York University invitation interscholastic meet at Ohio Field. Fifty-one high and prep schools have entered more than 800 athletes for the sixteen-event program.

The government news agency reported today from Andujar that an eight-month siege had been broken by government troops who captured the mountain-top sanctuary of Santa Maria de la Cabeza in Jaen Province.

Union workers at the Celanese Corporation of America plant today forcibly ejected twenty nonunion workers from the weaving department. The management stopped the looms and said they would not run until all employes were allowed to work.
The impeachment of Paul N. Coulcher, Aladar Retek and Charles B. Baum by Local 16 of the Waiters Union was announced yesterday by William Albertson, acting secretary of the union.
Authority to issue and sell $10,635,000 of equipment trust certificates was sought today by two subsidiaries of the Southern Railway in applications to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Expressing doubt as to the constitutionality of the amended Tennessee Valley Authority Act, Newton D. Baker, war-time Secretary of War, said today that the "TVA is spreading propaganda all through the Tennessee Valley of its intention to destroy private utilities and take them over."

T. R. Thompson, area manager for RKO Film Distributor, said today that the Kansas Board of Review had ordered remarks of Senator Wheeler opposing President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan, eliminated from March of Time, a news picture.
Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, announced yesterday the opening today of two new playgrounds, two new park buildings and two remodeled park areas in various sections of the city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: George Clarke Cox in his letter to THE TIMES calls upon us to "stoutly resist the charge that capitalism is responsible for leaving one-third of the population wretched, undernourished, neglected," and asserts that "capitalism purged of its errors and sins is by far the best hope of the underprivileged now. It alone can increase real wealth largely."
The freighters Frontenac and Peter White locked in the ice field outside of the Superior entry last night, broke through the pack this afternoon, the United States Coast Guard said.

Miss Maude Beatrice Pfalzgraf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Pfalzgraf of Maplewood, was married this evening to Horace Darlington of Brookline, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hart Darlington of Maplewood, in St. George's Episcopal Church here. The Rev.

Resignation of E. T. Cunningham as president of RCA Manufacturing Company of Camden, N. J., subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America, was announced yesterday by David Sarnoff, president. Mr. Cuningham will continue as a member of the board of
The Tigers scored a run without getting a hit in the thirteenth inning today to defeat the Reds, 1 to 0, in the second of their fourgame exhibition series.

The record of the present city administration should be judged carefully by the business interests here to determine whether it should be supported or opposed at the election next November, Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., said yesterday at a luncheon at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, attended by a group of bankers, industrialists and others.

W. E. Hutton 2d denied today, paragraph by paragraph, each charge of manipulating stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation made against him and the brokerage firm of W. E. Hutton Co., which he represents in Detroit.

The market for almost all classes of bonds was dull yesterday, with prices fluctuating irregularly within a restricted trading range. The trading pace also slackened considerably, the turnover in all bonds on the New York Stock Exchange reaching only $9,523,400, compared with $11,746,100 on Thursday.
Four new Diesel cargo carriers will be constructed within the next two years for Kokusai Kisen Kabushiki, to be used in the Japan-Los Angeles-New York silk trade.

Contracts were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot today on 20,000 pairs of lambskin-lined horsehide mittens for the army, under invitation 258, as follows: Olympic Glove Company, net, 10,000 at $1.75 a pair, and the Des Moines Glove Manufacturing Company, net, 10,000 at $1.79 a pair. Charles A.

Miss Virginia Hopkins, a tall, 15-year-old mermaid from Miami Beach, Fla., came up with a spectacular closing spurt tonight to conquer Miss Halina Tomska of Detroit in the women's national A. A. U. 220yard free-style championship race in the Lake Shore Athletic Club pool.

Estate, more than $10,000. To William H. Connolly, brother, Wellsville, N. Y., life estate in residue; two specific bequests; Hoffman Lodge 412, Free and Accepted Mason Hall and Asylum, Middletown, N. Y., and trustees of Masonic Hall and Asylum Fund, remainder interests in residue. Guaranty Trust Co. of New York, 140 Broadway, executor.

A project for the construction in this country of the fabricated parts and equipment of a battleship armed with 16-inch guns for Russia has been broached to the State Department, it was revealed today.

Retail distribution was affected this week by the vagaries of the weather, although gains were general in comparison with the volume in the corresponding period last year, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. For the country as a whole, sales were estimated at 8 to 15 per cent ahead of those in the same week in 1936.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that at the request of the applicants it had consented to the withdrawal of the following registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933:
The Iron Guard's championship of Prince Nicholas's cause is creating a serious situation, the outcome of which is at present obscure.

A number of vigorous measures for increasing the birth rate in accordance with the decisions the Fascist Grand Council took in its March session were approved this morning by the Cabinet at a meeting over which Premier Benito Mussolini presided.
The first stake test of the Spring season at five furlongs for juveniles is scheduled for today at Jamaica, when the Youthful will be contested over that distance with nine entered.
An unauthorized ride in a Missouri Arkansas locomotive cost Donald Donaldson, 24, $131 in Municipal Court.

Trustees of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival today named Eliel Saarinen of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., famous Finnish architect, to design a permanent Summer musical pavilion here for the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

BALDWIN, MARY R. (Jan. 26. 1936). Gross assets. $27,730; net, $24,903. To Jane Van Cleve, residue; First Presbyterian Church of East Orange, N. J., $400; Women's Association of the First Presbyterian Church of East Orange and Presbyterian Home of the Synod of New Jersey, $300 each. Chief assets, powers of appointment, $17,729. Knox Deignan, attorneys. 110 E. 42d St.

87th St., 233-37 E., 75x100 8 1/2 Emigrant Bank to Jack Lavinstein, 67-18 Woodside Av., Woodside ($92). 114th St., 77 E., 25x100.8: same to Jose Franco, 63 E. 114th St. ($15.50). Amsterdam Av., 1,710-12, 50x84; same to Ronard Holding Corp., 22 W. 48th St. ($65). 104th St., 314 E., 25x101; Joseph J. Sheehan to Louise F. Henry, 5 E. 93d St.; consideration, $8,000, foreclosure.

The twentyseven governments on the nonintervention committee are relying on the good faith of the United States, it became known today, and are not asking Washington to co operate further in keeping war sup plies from Spain.

The death of Josef Riedel, National Socialist bloc leader in Buenos Aires, who was shot by unidentified assailants and, according to the German press, died with "Heil, Hitler!" on his lips, took the main headlines today.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York has been advised from Stockholm that the liquidators in the Swedish bankruptcy of the Kreuger Toll Company expect to pay a dividend of 26 per cent on claims allowed in that bankruptcy.

Retail trade here during the week was fairly active, but did not quite measure up to expectations despite the mild weather on several days. Department store executives estimated the gain as ranging around 5 per cent over the comparative 1936 week.

There has been a growing realization that the necessary activities of private charity cannot be accompolished by tax-supported agencies of public welfare, Cardinal Hayes declared in a pastoral issued yesterday in opening his 1937 appeal for Catholic Charities.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May in Special Term, Jamaica, Queens, granted a temporary injunction yesterday to B. Gertz, Inc., department store at 162-10 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, which is one of the large advertisers in The Long Island Daily Press, restraining the American Newspaper Guild, the Newspaper Guild of New York and the Press Unit of the Guild from picketing within 200 feet of the store.

The first effort of the National Labor Relations Board to solve the labor problems of a major corporation since the Supreme Court legalized its activities by approving the Wagner act appeared yesterday to Have proved successful.

The special meeting of stockholders of Hupp Motor Company, adjourned previously owing to a lack of quorum, again was adjourned yesterday until noon today. The meeting is to consider a proposed reduction in par value of stock from $10 to $1 a share and an exchange of two present shares for one new share of stock.
Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, said tonight that the union would charge the Ford Motor Company with violation of the Wagner Labor Disputes Act.

The Red Sox shut out Holy Cross, 5 to 0, today in an exhibition game before a crowd of 7,000. Rube Walberg worked for three innings and held the Crusaders hitless, while Cy Henry was nicked for five blows.
Dr. Vincent J. Fenerty died in Episcopal Hospital yesterday in his fifty-first year. He was a member of the staffs of Episcopal and Kensington Women's Hospital. ton Women's Hospital.

New construction in thirty-seven Eastern States advanced sharply last month, when the total was $231,245,900, as compared with $188,257,300 during the previous month and $198,761,900 during March, 1936, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.
Baby LeRoy, one of Hollywood's major tragedies because he was through at 3, is to attempt a comeback at the age of 5. RKO is drawing up a contract for him to appear in Martin Mooney's "Junior G-Men."

Mount Asama, Japan's most active volcano, erupted today after two months of slumber. American tourists witnessed the display. It emitted a shower of stones and a great cloud of smoke and fire while molten lava streamed down the mountainside. The eruption lasted twenty minutes but the giant crater continued an onimous rumbling.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 15 unless specified: San Diego to San Pedro: Bobolink, Partridge, Robin. San Diego to Puget Sound Yard: Cincinnati, Concord, Dewey, Hull, MacDonough, Worden. At San Pedro; Brant, Brazos, Kingfisher, Neches.

Commonwealth Congress, Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixtyfourth Street. Speakers: John T. Bernard, Elinore M. Herrick, Harold Loeb, Benjamin C. Marsh, 10 A. M. Dinner at Mayflower Hotel, 7 P. M. Speakers: Thomas R. Amlie, Morris Ernst.
Miss Katherine M. White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Stockton White of Malpas, Devon, was married this afternoon to Lawrence Illoway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Illoway of Chestnut Hill.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, Wellesley graduate, told yesterday, in the first of a series of articles on the Sian kidnapping, of her determined effort in Nanking to avert civil war in China. Militarists wanted to attack Sian, where Generalissimo Chiang was held captive.

Two men were killed and two others were seriously injured when an automobile, northbound on Woodhaven Boulevard, at Sixtythird Drive, Rego Park, Queens, struck a stanchion supporting a traffic light at 12:50 o'clock this morning.
Although the stock markets were restricted today by the end-of-the-account slackening, there were a number of firm features. Gild-edge issues continued steady, and foreign loans generally improved.

Detroit Street Railways -- Nine months to March 31: Net income after all charges and sinking fund requirements, $334,126, against $400,300 last year. March: Net income, $14,742, against $60,451 in March, 1936.

An estate of about $100,000 real and $35,000 personal property was left by Mrs. Celia Kadesh, who was murdered by a robber in her apartment at 324 Franklin Place, Plainfield, on March 21. About $10,000 personal was left by her daughter, Miss Bessie Kadesh, who also was beaten by the intruder and died a week later.

Dismissal of a $203,000 suit against Maude Adams, the actress, was approved unanimously by the Appellate Division yesterday. The action was brought by John D. Williams, former Frohman press agent and director, who had a part in inducing Miss Adams to return to the stage in 1927 and in 1930.

A gift of $51,000 to the building fund of the New Rochelle Hospital Association was announced today. The donor was Earl C. Sams, chairman of the hospital's board of governors and president of the J. C. Penney Company.

Regulation of lobbying and of pressure groups was proposed yesterday by Alonzo F. Myers, Professor of Education at New York University, in an address before the twelfth annual Spring conference of the Eastern-States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers at the Hotel Commodore.

Nearly 1,000 young people are expected at a United Christian Youth Conference next Friday beginning at 5 P. M. and continuing through Sunday afternoon, April 25. Except for Sunday morning the meetings will be held in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventythird Street.
F. Colwell Conklin; director of music in the Mamaroneck public schools, today was elected president of the Eastern Music Educators Association at its convention.
Thousands of Paris circus fans tonight were mourning their favorite clown, Parantel, who is believed by the police to have been poisoned.

Martin J. Hekking, marine engineer, died on Thursday at his home in West New Brighton, S. I., after a brief illness. He was 67 years old. Mr. Hekking was born in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, and came to this country at the age of 21. He had been graduated in Rotterdam from two technical schools, the Openbaar Onderwijs and De Ambachtsschool.

Three amateur hold-up men were held in $25,000 bonds tonight, following their arrest for an attempted $25,000 payroll robbery at the Raybestos Manhattan plant. Those under arrest are William C. Olah, 40; William Sherwood, 30, and Bronislaw Szeliga, 30.

Termination of the insured status of the North Bergen Trust Company of North Bergen, N. J., effective on May 1, was announced today by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

William L. Lyall, chairman of the board of directors of Brighton Mills, Shannon, Ga., and former president of the company when its plants were located in Passaic and Allwood, died suddenly at his home here today of a heart attack. His age was 73.

John T. Daily, secretary of the Arundel Corporation, prominent Catholic layman and philanthropist, died here today at the age of 74. A native of Baltimore, he was graduated from Calvert Hall College and began his business and financial career with the banking house of J. J. Nicholson Sons.

The wedding of Miss Frances Ann Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Moore of this place, to Wilbur Ward Hiler, son of Henry E. Hiler of Brockport, N. Y., took place this evening in Christ Church here.
The leading social event of the year at Mount Holyoke College, the junior promenade, took place tonight in a Chinese setting. Tea dances and other entertainment will complete the three-day week-end.

Controller Frank J. Taylor altered the course of the proposed relief investigation yesterday when he moved at a Board of Estimate meeting in City Hall to include a study of the basic factors underlying relief in any inquiry that may be made.

Regret at the loss of a figure at once so spectacular and so genial from the speedways of the sky will be mingled with approbation for the decision of FRANK HAWKS to retire from the field of air record-making and hereafter fly only for pleasure. Aviation owes much to HAWKS.

The marriage of Miss Betty Wells, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Harold B. Wells of this city, to Edwin Forrest Hann Jr. of Bordentown was performed here tonight in Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church by the Rev. Edwin F. Hann of Woodbury, father of the bridegroom, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Harry Hummer, the pastor.

Miss Marion Elizabeth Hobbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Hobbs of this place, was married to Dr. Herbert H. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Smith of Brookline, Mass., this afternoon in the Reformed Church here.
The Gordon String Quartet, and Gertrude Bonime, pianist, gave the last of a series of five chamber music concerts sponsored by the Ernest Bloch Society last night at the Concert League Hall.
Governor Lehman signed today the Feinberg bill to bar commercial aircraft from landing on or taking off from the waters of Lake George. Violation of the law will be a misdemeanor.

The national public debt of Colombia amounted to 226,298,715 pesos (about $113,149,300) at the end of 1936, according to a report by the Controller General. The largest part of the total consists of bonds amounting to $55,409,325, and sold on the American market.

Members of the New York Junior League gave a preview of the fashion show, one of the features of the Junior League "Follies" to be held at the New Amsterdam Theatre on April 23 and 24, yesterday afternoon in the Netherland Cafe for members of the cast and their friends.

A new book by Hilaire Belloc has just been announced as published by Sheed Ward. The title is "The Nature of Contemporary England" and, as the publishers point out, Mr. Belloc's career fitted him well to make this survey.

Graydon T. Gesner, general auditor of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, 230 Park Avenue, New York, died of a heart attack on Wednesday in Chicago. Mr. Gesner lived in Upper Ridgewood. His age was 43.

The Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corportion was found to be the low bidder for the contract to build three new ships for the Panama Railroad Steamship Company when estimates were opened yesterday at the offices of George G. Sharp, naval architect.
Charles Francis Adams, former Secretary of the Navy, acting as chairman of the bondholders' protective committee for Brown Company first mortgage twenty-year 51/2 per cent gold bonds.

The church and the theatre should not be too antagonistic to one another, for both have the duty to interpret life, lift popular taste and create public sentiment, the Rev. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Episcoal Actors Guild, held at the Empire Theatre.

New York baseball fans will get their first glimpse of the Giants of 1937 this afternoon when Manager Bill Terry's charges face the Cleveland Indians at the Polo Grounds in the seventeenth game of their current exhibition series.
Thomas F. Heffernan, publisher of The Sunday Independent, today was elected president of the WilkesBarre Deposit and Savings Bank, to succeed the late Benjamin F. Williams.

Although the trial of the seven Catholics on charges of high treason is still in its early stages, sharp attacks appear in the press against the Rev. Joseph Rossaint, who so far has been the central figure among the accused.
In its first start of the season, Columbia's freshman baseball team overwhelmed the Horace Mann School nine, 17 to 2, on the losers' field yesterday. The score by innings:
Hatchery stocking of legal-sized trout increases the angler's "take" approximately 50 per cent, it was disclosed today by the Conservation Department.

Sitting quietly in a wheel chair at a meeting of the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly yesterday, John Picone, a crippled former policeman, heard the members adopt a local law which will give him at least threefourths of his previous pay.

A new play by Lord Dunsany is always an event. However, in "Lord Adrian," presented at the Gate Theatre tonight, he is thought to have made little use of his opportunities to satirize one of the more fatuous practices of today, rejuvenation.

Bette Davis will play the role of the temperamental actress, originally designed for Ina Claire, in Leslie Howard's "Gentleman After Midnight" if efforts to rearrange the Warner schedule are successful.

The net gain in telephones in service of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania for the first quarter of this year was 28,262, a new high record for the period, according to Philip C. Staples, president.

The Rev. Dr. Orlando T. Steward, for twenty-seven years executive secretary of the Baptist Union of Philadelphia and vicinity until his retirement last June, died at his home in Roxborough yesterday, after an illness of three months.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, which was recently notified by Mayor La Guardia that neither he nor the Board of Transportation objected to its proposal to organize workers on the city's Independent Subway, claimed yesterday that it had enrolled about 900 men out of approximately 1,100 eligible to join its ranks.

Few theatrical producers are able to have dramatic characters step ashore from an Atlantic liner to give point and meaning to a new play, but that is what happened yesterday when Professor Hans Mamlok, once a dental surgeon of Berlin and now an expatriate, arrived on the United States liner Manhattan.

The New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church adopted last night a resolution which said it "looked with disfavor" on the President's plan for changing the Supreme Court and advocated that any such changes be made by the people through the ratification of an amendment to the Constitution.

Col. Floyd D. McLean, Inf.-Res., 12 Millard Av., Binghamton. N. Y., recently promoted, is assigned to the 1,215th Service Unit. Ist Lt. Harry C. Smith, Engr.-Res., N. Seneca St., Weedsport, N. Y., is relieved from assignment to the 323d Engineers, and attached for training (not eligible for assignment, active duty or promotion) to the 433d Engineer Battalion (Sep.) 2d (colored).

Yale today turned back the strong St. John's University nine, 4-2, in a pitchers battle between outstanding left-handers, Monroe Jubitz of Yale, who allowed but four hits and fanned nine, and Frank Weynand, who yielded seven blows and struck out three.

Eugene Gladstone O'Neill of New York City, son of the playwright of the same name and former honor student at Yale University, was sued for divorce here today by Mrs. Elizabeth Greene O'Neill. She charged cruelty.

A major offensive against the vanguard broke loose with telling results in yesterday's session of the American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery armory. When six shifts of singles and doubles keglers had ceased firing, changes had been effected in both those divisions in addition to major revisions being made in the all-events standing.

Three more of the seventy-one individual defendants named in indictments charging violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law in the government's oil cases pleaded innocent yesterday. They were Edward Seubert, president,
Gaining three points in the last foursome, Fordham's golf team defeated Haverford by 5-4 in a match at the Merion C. C. today.

The British Commonwealth of Nations as the spiritual leader of the world was envisaged by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin tonight when he addressed the entire empire over the radio from his country home at Chequers.
One thing about a night club audience that this department approves is its invariable inclination, when properly induced, to wax warmheartedly mellow and indulge in a nostalgic spree.

College rowing in the East will make its season's debut today when Columbia and Manhattan meet on the Harlem River. It will be a three-race informal affair with the contests being rowed upstream and ending opposite the intersection of the Harlem Speedway and Dyckman Street. Columbia will officially open its campaign against Navy at Annapolis next week.
The House of Commons defeated today a motion to eliminate desertion as grounds for divorce from a new bill to moderate Britain's rigid divorce laws. The bill itself was not acted upon.

The present social studies curricula in the nation's public schools are failing in their task of making good citizens, according to Dr. Irving R. Melbo of Teachers College, who yesterday disclosed results of a series of seven tests conducted among 4,700 California high school seniors in which the students demonstrated only a scant knowledge of social trends and issues.
Ford Frick, president of the National League, yesterday announced through The Associated Press the following umpire assignments for opening games.
Word spread today that "Cactus Jack" Garner thinks the Senators look "purty good" and will finish higher than their fourth position of 1936 in the American League.
That the Supreme Court would review at this term the decision of the First Circuit Court of Appeals at Boston today, holding the Social Security Act unconstitutional, was regarded here, as unlikely.

The Reformed Dutch Protestant Church leased for twenty-one years to the Naston Realty Corporation, represented by S. I. Goldberg, attorney, the property 63 by 160 feet at 204-210 Broadway and 146-156 Fulton Street.
Governor Marland said today to major oil companies that if a "substantial increase" in the price for crude petroleum was not made immediately, "we will have a severance tax on oil."

Edward D. Fales of Menands, patent attorney, died suddenly on a street car today after he had run a block to catch the vehicle. Death was due to a heart attack. Mr. Fales is survived by his widow, a daughter, Mrs. Zoe B. Fales Christman, Albany newspaper woman; a son, Edward B., who is with The Associated Press in Buffalo, and another son, John D. of Albany.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Swezey of this place observed their fiftieth wedding anniversary this evening. Mr. Swezey is in his seventy-sixth year. He was born at Mattituck, L. I. He has been a newspaper writer for more than sixty years, having been connected with The Roanoke Herald, Virginia, and the old New York World.
James A. Ostrand, former associate justice of the Philippine Islands Supreme Court and former chief justice of the Santo Domingo Appellate Land Court, died here yesterday. He was 65 years old.
Miss Eunice Guthrie, 21-year-old telephone operator who "remained at the switch" eighty-four hours without relief during last Winter's flood, is to be rewarded.
The National Gallery of Canada, in Ottawa, has purchased a painting by Piero di Cosimo, "Vulcan and Aeolus as Teachers of Mankind," from the Schaeffer Galleries, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The Right Rev. G. Ashton Oldham, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Albany, N. Y., has been named by the Most Rev. and Right Hon. William Temple, the Lord Archbishop of York, England, to be a member of a special committee of thirty-five to spend a week at the Archbishop's Palace arranging details for the World Conference on Church, Community and State, to be held July 12-26 in Oxford, England.

The Johns-Manville Corporation and subsidiary companies in the first three months of 1937 showed a consolidated net profit of $1,021,918 after all charges and provision for depreciation, depletion and income tax accrual, but before surtax on undistributed earnings, Lewis H. Brown, president,

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

A minister wanted to telephone a notice of a Sunday baptismal service to a Cannelton newspaper today, and a farmer sought to call a general store to order some kerosene, but Miss Mae Leaf, the Tobinsport Telephone Company's sole operator, said "No."

Robert V. Pogue, president of H. S. You Company, died at his home ere today. He was 64 years old. Mr. Pogue was for twenty-five ears head of the department store hearing the family name. He was ctive in the business, civic and soial life of Cincinnati. Son of Mr.

The Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday leased the New York Hippidrome for two more years with an option to purchase the building at the end of that time. Mike Jacobs, president and organizer of the club, closed the deal with the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, acting as agents for the owners.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In regard to the letter by Solon Gartenlaub which appeared in THE TIMES last week and the accompanying editorial note, it appears that Mr. Kieran has not examined the subject of organized baseball players beyond the surface.

Dairy farmers of the Northeastern States, whose production cost has been increased by a rise ih the price of feed for livestock because of last year's drought received assurances yesterday that the conservation program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration

The Burly Amusement Corporation, owner of Minsky's New Gotham Theatre in East 125th Street, which was found guilty last April 8 by Justices Gresser, Perlman and Doyle in Special Sessions of indecent "strip tease" performances in the theatre by five young women, was fined $500 yesterday by the court.

Pensioned On his own application: LIEUTENANT--Henry E. Gerken. 47th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Sept. 27, 1905. Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANT-Martin T. Donelon, from 8th Division to 47th. Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

Joe DiMaggio, Yankee outfielder, had his tonsils and adenoids removed yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital. Dr. Girard Oberrender, personal physician to Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the club, performed the operation.

Hope that the Lindbergh anniversary transatlantic air race would be postponed, if not canceled altogether, was expressed in aeronautical circles here today with the disclosure that Charles F. Horner, president of the National Aeronautical Association, had written to the Aero Club of France, asking for a postponement for at least one year.
Nicholas Kopp, who perfected selenium ruby glass, used widely in railroad signals and air beacons, died today in his seventy-second year.

The new vehicular tunnel under the Hudson River between West Thirty-ninth Street, Manhattan, and Weehawken, N. J., will hereafter be known as the Lincoln Tunnel, the Port Authority announced yesterday.

The State Banking Department announced today that it had received and filed a certificate showing that the Italian Plan Company, Inc., with offices at 2 Lafayette Street, had been dissolved and its corporate existence terminated.

Miss Helen Slingerland of this place and Richard W. C. Sim, son of Mrs. Mahlon S. Averill of East Orange, were married here this evening at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Archibald F. Slingerland, in Marion Avenue.

Auction sales of Bronx properties yesterday involved two parcels which were bought in by the plaintiffs. The three-story brick and frame tenement at 1,231 Washington Avenue, on a plot 18 by 100 feet, was awarded to Elizabeth Noe in an action against Lena J. Baird, for an amount due of $3,890.

Fifty-three traffic officers from all parts of New Jersey, comprising the first graduating class of the Rutgers University Traffic Officers Training School, were praised by Governor Hoffman tonight for "attacking the terrible accident situation on a scientific basis."
Ray Flynn, production manager at the Twentieth Century-Fox Studios, died of pneumonia today in a hospital after an illness of a little more than a week. He was 44 years old.

Walter Watkins, attorney and member of a prominent Tennessee family, died today after a threemonth illness. He was 59 years old. His father, the late Colonel Edmund Watkins, was Mayor of Chattanooga in 1898.

Dr. Harold Longsdorf's Gar Wood, which showed at recent trials that he was headed for important victories, today captured the all-age junior stake, opening feature of the three-day meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club.
A man listed as Harry Howard, 50, hotel houseman, was sentenced to serve one year in State prison today for larceny of jewelry valued at $24,000 from Mrs. P. A. B. Widener of Philadelphia.
The Hippodrome Opera Company last night inaugurated its fifth season of popular-priced opera with a performance of Verdi's perennial "II Trovatore."

Thomas H. MacDonald, chief of the Bureau of Public Roads, said today that Georgia and New Jersey might receive reduced Federal road funds because they diverted gasoline tax and auto license receipts to purposes other than road building.

Senator Desmond, Orange Republican, introduced a resolution today proposing that Congress be memorialized to enact a broad program of tax revision. Under the terms of his resolution Congress would be asked to abolish income tax exemption for all employes, repeal the capital gains and losses provision, abolish tax exemption for securities and lower

An examiner for the Federal Power commission granted permission today to the commission's counsel to introduce statistical evidence intended to refute the charge that the commission has no jurisdiction to investigate the management and operation of six affiliates in the Associated Gas and Electric System in Pennsylvania.

A compromise solution of the situation which has delayed the appointment of an Under-Secretary of State was prepared to day when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a bill re-creating the old office of Counselor of the State Department at a salary of $10,000 a year, the same as is provided for the Under-Secretaryship.

A plan of Federal financing which will bridge the new gap caused by failure of revenues to meet expectations and at the same time permit the administration to avoid both a tax increase and heavy long-term borrowing in the near future was reported today to have been devised by President Roosevelt and his fiscal advisers.

The defense is ready to proceed with the trial of Ellis H. Parker, chief of Burlington County detectives, at any place set by the Circuit Court of Appeals, and will not attempt to appeal if the court should vacate the restraint against holding it in Newark, former Governor George S. Silzer, attorney for Parker, said today.

The sale of several large tracts of land in Queens, close to the site of the World's Fair, to developers and investors were reported yesterday by brokers. In all, 640 building lots are involved, part of which will be immediately improved with residential developments, including both one-family homes and apartment houses.
Philibert Casas, delegate of the Catalan Government sent to France to buy food for Barcelona, turned up today after spending a night in the open after an automobile accident.
An engine explosion on the Italian-built Brazilian submarine Humayta injured twenty men this afternoon. Six, including two officers, were seriously hurt.

The efforts of George A. Ball, glass manufacturer of Muncie, Ind., to sell control of the Midamerica Corporation to interests connected with the General Motors Corporation reached an impasse yesterday as a result of legal problems which are to be faced in completing the transaction.

Eight-year-old Harvey Isbitts returned to his native Brooklyn yesterday after an absence of four years in Belgium, where he learned to speak foreign languages fluently. He arrived on the United States liner Manhattan with his mother and younger brother Karl.

Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth. returned to New York for a brief stay yesterday after a visit to Mexico. He warmly praised President Lazaro Cardenas and the work being done in Mexico.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 994,000 bales, against 1,007,000 a week ago, 1,020,000 two weeks ago, 969,000 three weeks ago and 724,000 a year ago; of which American 438,000 bales, against 439,000 a week ago, 443,000 two weeks ago, 423,000 three weeks ago and 335,000 a year ago.

A sinus infection sent Jimmy Foxx, slugging first baseman for the Boston Red Sox, to a hospital today. Dr. Herbert Goddard said Foxx would be kept under observation and would be out of the line-up for the opening game with the Athletics next Tuesday.

The senior promenade of the Horace Mann School for Boys at 231 West 246th Street was held last night in the sky garden of the Hotel St. Moritz. The faculty of the school and their guests and seventy-five couples were present.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee said today that it was preparing to file charges with the National Labor Relations Board that the Weirton Steel Corporation had violated the Wagner act by discharging 124 workmen for union activities in its plants at Weirton, W. Va., and Steubenville, Ohio.

The fourteen-year-old story of the fraudulent leasing of government oil lands by former Secretary Fall to Edward L. Doheny came to an end today when the Department of Justice announced that the Doheny executors had paid $3,000,000 to the government yesterday.

Miss Doris R. Asiel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson I. Asiel, was married yesterday afternoon to Bruce A. Gimbel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of The Chieftains, Port Chester, at the home of her parents, 15 East Sixtythird Street. The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony.
The Argentine Government reduced today from $42,000,000 to $35,000,000 the amount of its proposed offer of 4 per cent sinking fund external conversion bonds in this country.

Several Britons motoring in the neighborhood of Algeciras, Spain, dashed at full speed to Gibraltar tonight when they heard the roaring of Spanish Government airplanes approaching Algeciras, apparently from Almeria.

At the sixteenth biennial State convention today of the Catholic Daughters of America in the Hotel Traymore, a resolution adopted unanimously denounced communism as diametrically opposed to the Christian religion.

An indication of the speed at which things are moving in professional golf these days is seen in the list of stars named by President George Jacobus of the Professional Golfers Association to compete for the four open places on this year's Ryder Cup team.

Exports of Canadian goods in the fiscal year ended on March 31 were $1,061,181,906, the National Revenue Department reported today. This was an increase of $212,151,489 from the exports of $849,030,417 in the previous fiscal year. Imports reached $671,868,661, an advance of $109,165,572 over the $562,703,089 of the preceding period.

Failure of several foreign guests to remove their overcoats in the presence of Emperor Hirohito at a cherry blossom festival was construed today by official Japanese sources as a breach of etiquette against the throne.
Without specifically naming that power, Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, tonight appealed again to Japan not to build huge battleships with monster guns.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, saw "trouble ahead" today "if John L. Lewis pursues his present advantage and obtains a closed shop and then wants a check-off (deduction of union dues directly from workers' paychecks)."

Striking municipal employes stopped light, street car, telephone and water services at Medellin today as a protest against adjournment of the Municipal Council without considering their demands for higher pay. Taxicab drivers struck in sympathy.
A crowd of 6,552 fans greeted the world champion Yankees and the Dodgers yesterday as two of Gotham's major league baseball clubs made their initial 1937 appearance in frigid Ebbets Field.

The third annual morning musicale and luncheon of the Godmothers League Day and Night Shelter for Babies, 115 East 101st Street, will be held April 28 at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. David Sarnoff, chairman of the league.

J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N. J., and Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., came through to the final round of the United North and South tennis championship today at the Pinehurst Country Club and will meet tomorrow for the title won last year by Donald Budge.

Awakened by smoke and the crackling of flames on the floor below, Betty Trubee, 10-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dayton 0. Trubee of 128 Beechwood. Avenue, groped her way to her bedroom window early this morning, broke the glass and climbed out onto a porch, screaming "Fire" at the top of her lungs.

Jacob H. Klein Sr., former -assistant city treasurer, died at his home today. He was 73 years old. Mr. Klein's son,. Jacob H. Klein Jr., retired commander of the United States Navy, flew the dirigible Los Angeles from Germany when it was purchased by the navy.
Thirty were injured in the Northern Bohemian town of Niedergrund last night when members of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten party invaded a meeting of the German Socialist party.

Alfred Harris Swayne, vice president of General Motors Corporation and chairman of the board of directors of General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died at 7:30 o'clock last night at New York Hospital. Mr. Swayne was taken to the hospital two months ago from his home at 720 Park Avenue. He was 67 years old on April 5.

Primitive Indians still dominate and hold as their domain certain sections of South America. One may take off in a passenger plane from New York and fly to the edge of these Indian confines, 2,000 miles away, in forty-eight hours or less.
Leasing of industrial and factory properties in Hudson and Bergen Counties, N. J., has shown increased activity in recent weeks, according to J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers.

Wesleyan University is bringing to a close its annual last semester series of informal discussions for seniors on sex, marriage and family life, which are conducted under the direction of President James L. McConaughy, Professor Edward C.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jackson of Mount Vernon, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Jackson, to Donald Chadwick Dayton, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Nelson Dayton of Minneapolis.
The last Piccadilly dance of the season in the Bellevue-Stratford Rose Garden tonight was the occasion for many dinner and supper parties.

Howard Bradstreet, director of the Hartford Bureau of Adult Education, died today in Hartford Hospital after a short illness. His age was 68. Mr. Bradstreet was born In Rochester, N. Y., and was graduated from the University of Rochester in 1891. He went to New York in 1907 and for several years had charge of the recreational division of the Park Department of the City of New York.

Miss Gertrude Case, daughter of Charles E. Case of this place and the late Mrs. Case, was married to Warren William Stearns of Boston, son of William C. Stearns of West Paris, Me., and the late Mrs. Stearns, here this afternoon in Calvary Church by the Rev. W. Ovid Kinsolving, the rector.
The annual Beaux Arts ball will be held on Friday at the County Center here, under the auspices of the Arts and Crafts Guild and the Westchester Workshop.

DURING its season which closes today the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra gave 378 performances of 162 compositions, representing sixty-eight composers, exclusive of works played at the Young People's concerts. Of the composers whose works came to a hearing twelve were Germans.

A fashion revue of the latest costumes for beach wear entitled "Down to the Sea in Suits" will be held in conjunction with a luncheon on Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club.

Developers in Union County, N. J., are busy preparing to care for the influx of new residents to result from the opening of the new General Motors plant in Linden. The demand for homes in this district has brought an increasing volume of home mortgages to the New Jersey division of the Federal Housing Administration.

AS the first balmy day of Spring forecast the Summer season in the Northeastern section of the country the most enthusiastic group in American aeronautics rushes feverishly through final work of building, rebuilding, strengthening, polishing and putting the finishing touches on gliders.

The monthly payments by employers under the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law are not affected by the decision of the United States First Circuit Court of Appeals holding the unemployment compensation and old-age annuities sections of the Federal Social Security Act unconstitutional, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday.

Miss Catherine Rogan has been elected prefect of the Sodality of Our Lady at the College of St. Elizabeth here. Other officers are Miss Adelaide Brown, vice prefect; Miss Eleanor Wishbow, secretary, and Miss Ruth Healy, treasurer.
Sixty persons, thirty-eight of them children, were routed late last night by a fire that swept through the three-story frame dwelling houses at 780-788 West Side Avenue, Jersey City.

Mrs. John Jay White will give a musical on Friday night at the Colony Club as the fifth in a series of receptions and other entertainments given by women of prominence this Spring in the interests of the MacDowell Colony for creative artists at Peterborough, N. H.

Hero of the transport plane crash on the Pacific Coast Jan. 12 in which Martin Johnson, explorer, was killed and eleven others critically injured, Arthur S. Robinson of Rochester, a 1930 graduate. of the Manlius School, will receive on Sunday the school's highest award. for heroism, the Cross of the Manlius Legion of Honor.

Today New York League of Girls ClubsTea dance, 4 P. M., League House. Monday Bound Brook Woman's Club-Meeting. Frederick F. Rockwell of THE NEW YORK TIMES, speaker on "Spring Work in the Garden." Brooklyn Woman's Club-Members' exhibit of art, auspices music and art department, 2:30 P. M., clubhouse.

Sister Rebecca, oldest member of the Sisterhood of the HolyNativity, niece of the Mother Foundress and one of the original members of the group which established the order, died here early today in her ninetysecond year.

Three New York State jurists today heard the final moot court case argued by first-year students in the Cornell Lew School. On the bench were Leonard C. Crouch of Syracuse, former associate judge, Court of Appeals;
Temple, by rallying in the sixth inning with seven runs, defeated New York University at the Owl's field today, 11-7. The Violets were in front 7-1, when the big drive got under way.

A permanent organization of the student councils of colleges in the metropolitan area was formed yesterday at a meeting at City College attended by twenty representatives of ten collegiate student organizations.

An opinion recently rendered by Justice Nathan Sweedler of the Municipal Court in favor of the landlord is regarded with interest by lawyers as it indicates that the original tenant of an apartment is not relieved of the usual, obligations between landlord and tenant when the apartment is subleased.

Hailing a farm labor alliance, "which alone could give us the power and unity to achieve what we all believe to be our national destiny," Rexford G. Tugwell, former head of the Resettlement Administration, writing in Harpers Magazine for May, expresses serious doubts that any such welding of political forces lies on the political horizon.

PRIZE-WINNER: Mrs. Mary Flanagan, 45-year-old mother of ten children, came to New York last week from Montrose, W. Va., as part of her reward for writing a prize essay last year on why President Roosevelt should be re-elected.

Inspectors of the animal quarantine station at Clifton, N. J., had one of their busiest sessions in years recently when a steamship entered New York carrying two dozen assorted llamas, antelopes arid camels and several thousand birds.

ASHINTULLY, one of the most imposing estates in Massachusetts, has been sold by Mrs. Lawrence Coolidge of Boston to Real Properties, Inc., a group of Boston operators, and transferred by that group to Albert Tacy of Lee, Mass.

A luncheon will be given by the People's Institute, United Neighborhood Guild, on Tuesday at the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn. Among the guests arid speakers will be Katherine Anthony, Josephine Lawrence, Elaine Stern Carrington, Dorothy Dunbar Bromley, Leane Zugsmith and Burgess Meredith.

Stroked by John Mauger of Larchmont, N. Y., the junior crew wol the annual Penniman Bowl race on the Schuylkill River today. Four University of Pennsylvania shells started, with the juniors beating the sophomores by a half a length.

ARTISTS on the radio have always been irked by the commercial announcements, but despite the fact that such interruptions mar artistry, the musician has learned to turn his back while the announcer speaks, because he realizes it is the program's "bread and butter."

Almost three years after young Henry Grob and Theodore Jones found a "buried treasure" in old gold coins, the legal battle over their fortune still rages. In the latest legal move yesterday, attorneys for the once-penniless boys sought to clinch their right

A word from President Roosevelt, in view of the Supreme Court's decisions upholding the National Labor Relations (Wagner) Act, apparently is all that Congressional leaders await to unleash a number of proposals for further legislation to deal with labor matters.
A. P. Madden, chief of the Chicago Intelligence unit of the Treasury Department, left here for Washington today for a conference on the Lindbergh case rewards.

A week ago tonight The Players held what they called a British Empire Night, one of the speeches threat being the following, written by Abraham Sofaer and delivered by the current King Richard II, Maurice Evans:

Dr. John M. Cooper, Professor of Anthropology at Trinity College and at Catholic University, Washington, will be the guest of honor and speaker at the annual Spring luncheon of the Trinity College Alumnae Association, which will be held today at the Barbizon.

Three gains more than offset the four losses recorded by components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business. activity for the week ended April 10, and the combined index figure advanced to 106.3 from 105.9. It was 95.3 for the week ended April 11, 1936.

Sweeping wildly across Grand Central Parkway near Flush ring at about 5 P. M. yesterday, a plane struck the automobile' driven by Dr. Alex Sved of 68 Hen. ry Street, Merrick, L. I. The head. lights and radiator of the machine were damaged by the plane, but he escaped injury.

Miss Dorothy Laura Berlinger, daughter of Mrs. William G. Berlinger of Melrose Park and the late Mr. Berlinger, was married this afternoon to Richard MacMeekin, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Stinson MacMeekin of Overbrook.

FROM now until June those who go to Central Park will be finding a flutter and flurry of strange bird wings. Migration season has begun, and the warblers, the thrushes, the field sparrows and the orioles, with all their remote and colorful cousins

Miss Doris! Elizabeth Brennan of the Olneyville Boys Club, Providence, R. I., the "hard-luck" girl of the women's national indoor A. A. U. swimming championships, caught up with good luck tonight, winning the 500yard free-style championship by three yards from Miami Beach's Miss Katherine Rawls.
ALL game animals within our nation's borders are being counted during the present era of restoration as methodically as the human beings who make up the census rolls.

Imagnation, good health and a definite idea of what one wishes to do were emphasized as essentials for a successful career by six speakers at the annual conference here today on fields of work for women.

A mandamus suit to compel Postmaster General Farley to turn over to him the postmastership of Milford, Mass., was filed today in the District of Columbia District Court by John F. Curran, who contends that he is the duly appointed postmaster.

Mayor La Guardia will present a gold medal to Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, on behalf of the Home of the Daughters of Jacob, 167th Street and Teller Avenue, the Bronx, at a testimonial luncheon in her honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Thursday, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Peter J. Schweitzer, president of the home.

When the mortgage moratorium is lifted and the support' it now affords to the mortgage market is withdrawn, necessitating the refinancing of many properties, the likelihood of an insufficient supply of mortgage funds will be removed if the State mortgage banks permitted by legislation now pending in Albany are created, according to Herman A. Acker, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

The sophomores won the laurel wreaths at the thirty-fifth Greek Games held at Barnard College yesterday afternoon before 1,000 persons. In this contest of athletics, lyrics, costumes, music and dance, the sophomores won 53.5 points of the grand total of 100 points.

The Municipal Art Commission has approved three WPA Federal Art Project murals for city buildings. One of these is the first panel of "Early and Modern Bronx," by Francis Costa, allocated to P. S. 11, at 169th Street and Ogden Avenue, the Bronx, where it is to cover 322 square feet of wall space in the school's auditorium.

HERE has been considerable talk, much of it loose in character, about labor troubles and the probability of a strike within the industry. Such predictions not only are unwise but are almost impossible to make, since there are many elements that complicate the labor situation here and make a penetrating analysis difficult. It is a fight in which neither faction could hope to enlist much sympathy.
