Forty-four students of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, 400 First Avenue, will be graduated tomorrow night at exercises in the school's auditorium.

The American League White Sox evened Chicago's Spring city series at five--all today by defeating the National League Cubs, 3 to 2, on consecutive doubles by Dixie Walker and Zeke Bonura. with two out in the eighth.

The Class I railroads spent more than $1,100,000,000 for capital improvements to rolling stock, roadway and structures and for fuel, materials and supplies last year, according to a review based on complete reports for 1936 issued by the Association of American Railroads.

Discussing the reasons why real estate should be purchased at the present time, Cadman H. Frederick, president of the Suffolk County Federal Savings and Loan Association, states that real property is the safest and most tangible of all equities in periods of prosperity, when money values fall and commodity and equity values rise.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has revoked the registration, as a broker or dealer in the overthe-counter market, of Lewis S. Parsons, doing business as L. S. Parsons Co., 345 Powers Building, Rochester, N. Y.
Major Lawrence (Biff) Jones said today that University of Nebraska football candidates "had come a long way in Spring practice."

The property known as the Garrison Lodge, consisting of a twentysix-room house on a tract of seven acres near Pleasant Valley, Dutchess County, and bordering on Wappingers Creek, has been sold by Mrs. Lotta Briggs to P. Zukelly of New York City. Homer W. Guernsey was the broker.

A supper dance under the auspices of the Almoners will be held next Friday at Sherry's for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital. Miss Virginia Haggerty heads the group in charge of arrangements.

The Red Sox opened their two-game intracity series with the Bees with a 7-5 victory today before 6,200 chilled fans at the National League park. Frank (Pinkey) Higgins started the American Leaguers on the right path in the second inning when he belted a homer into the left-field pavilion.

Three bills providing for public ownership of power facilities, and involving territory now served by the Northern States Power Company, an operating unit of the Standard Gas and Electric System, have been defeated in the last two months by the Minnesota Legislature.

The exhibition feature of the Sixth Building Modernization Exposition, to be held May 3 to 8 in the Lincoin Building, 60 East Forty-second Street, will be supplemented by a daily lecture series, according to Harry D. Phillips, director of the exposition, who announced yesterday the list of speakers and subjects.
JOHN KEATS cherished the notion that there was a Good Genius presiding over his affairs, and he once ventured to hope that its name was Shakespeare.

General Jay Johnson Morrow, retired army officer and former Governor of the Panama Canal, died at his home here late last night. He was 67 years old. His ashes will be scattered over the waters of the Chagres River, life stream of the canal, where General Morrow spent the most effective years of his military career. Funeral services will be held at his home tomorrow at 4:30 P. M.

QUITE the best report of himself John Whorf has thus far given is in evidence at the Milch Galleries in the current one-man show of the artist's recent water-colors (until April 30). In the wake of Millard Sheets's exhibition of large, sketchy and decorative papers, Whorf's work affords a striking contrast.

The Spring convention of the Associated Traffic Clubs of America will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Hotel Commodore. H. S. Snow, president of the organization, will preside at the opening session, at which Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, will speak.

One of the first of all shrubs to bloom, in country and suburb, and even in the city, is the forsythiathe "Golden Bells" that rang in the Spring in great grandmother's Colonial garden. It is now supplemented by a number of splendid varieties which she did not know.
The junior all-age stake in the thirteenth annual Spring trials of the Mid-Jersey Field Dog Club was won by the pointer Bimpkins Bourbon Boy today.
Miss Virginia Stuart Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Henry Ward Jr. of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Jon Moale Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Oliver Warner of Baltimore.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Knox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Knox of this place, was married here tonight in the First Presbyterian Church to Albert Corwin Brumley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Brumley of Scarsdale; by the pastor, the Rev. Raymond Ketchledge.
Class 2. Troopers Mounts-First. Captain James M. Callicutt's ch. g. Bay Bridge; second, Squadron A's ch. g. Stony Brook; third. Squadron A's ch. g. Ten Percent; fourth, Squadron A's ch. m. Jollyette.

National workers' schools, suggested recently by the president of the International Textile Workers in an address heard by 1,200 educators in New York, are not a novelty. For thirteen years the Women's Trade Union League of New York has carried on an educational program, which is only now reaching a fine flowering through adding literature and art to the study of English and public speaking.

Dick (Lefty) Baldwin hurled Lafayette to a 3-2 victory over Moravian today, yielding seven safeties and fanning seven. Ross, Moravian mound star, allowed only three hits, but bases on balls and errors proved costly.
An exhibit of art weaving, consisting of samples of work done by students in New York City's vocational schools, opened yesterday in the office of Mrs. Johanna M. Lindcation, at 500 Park Avenue.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 16 unless specified: San Diego to Sea: Aylwln. Bainbrldge, Bushnell, Brooks, Boris, Barry, Broome, Chandler, Childs,' Dale, Dolphin, Detroit, Dallas, Dobbin, Farragut, Fox, Goff, Hovey. Hopkins. Holland, Humphreys, Reuben James, King, Langley, Lawrence, Lexington, Litchfield, Long, Memphis, MacLeish, McCormick, Melville, Monaghan, Nautilus.

Members of the Blind Workers Union, who have been conducting a sit-down strike in two charitable workshops for two weeks, refused again yesterday to vacate the shops as a preliminary to negotiations for settlement of the strike.
The Quai d'Orsay and the British Foreign Office have agreed on the text of the joint declaration which both will make during the coming week to Brussels.
Colonel "Reddy" H. Hart, instructor in marksmanship in the Costa Rican Army is detained at Bella Vista barracks and placed under military guard.
A party conference nominated Richard M. Simpson of Huntingdon County as the Republican candidate for Representative in the Eighteenth Congressional District.

WHEN Arthur Foote came to his seventy-fifth birthday and was asked to write a sentiment he did so. He wrote, "may the next quarter of a century"--referring to the life of the world--"be as interesting as the last."

Miss Ida M. Smith gave a luncheon here today at the Women's City Club, at which announcement was made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Allen of this city to Charles M. Gilbert, also of San Francisco.

A TOLL checking device now in operation on the Triborough Bridge is speeding traffic, as it frees the toll collectors at the twenty-two toll gates from the necessity of issuing or collecting tickets or inserting the money in cash registers. Under the new system, all they have to do is handle the cash and press a few buttons to record each toll paid.
Michigan's high-powered track and field team defeated California, 81 1/2 to 49 1/2, today in the intersectional meet renewing athletic relations between the two universities.

Dr. Henry Medd, known in the Kensington section as "the doctor who never sent a bill," died last night at his home here in his eightieth year. He was a graduate of the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and of Jefferson Medical College and operated a drug store as well as conducting a medical practice. Surviving are his widow, two sons, Henry Jr. and Frank Medd, and a daughter, Miss Emily Medd.

Dave Gould, movie dance director, married Mitzi Haynes, Broadway show girl, here today. Police Judge E. C. Gober officiated. The couple arrived from New York last night by airplane. Immediately after the ceremony they resumed the plane trip to Hollywood, where the bride, who has been appearing in the Broadway play "Behind Red Lights,"

Reform of the Regefit's prerogatives was advocated recently by Tibor Eckhardt in a speech. He recalled he had already proposed that the late Premier, Julius Goemboes, introduce such a reform at the same time he drafted the new electoral law calling for the secret ballot.
The neutral body at Hamilton College leads again in the fraternity scholarship averages for the first semester of the present college year, according to a new table released by the faculty.

Hundreds of pairs of anxious eyes were turned skyward and as many pairs of pursed lips were trying to "whistle up a wind" in Central Park yesterday as 300 youthful skippers gathered near the placid waters of Conservatory Lake to watch their almost becalmed model yachts compete for prizes in the ninth semi-annual regatta staged by the Park Department and R. H. . Macy Co.

Overwhelming their opponents with a deluge of places in every event of the program, the swimmers of Public School 51 of Manhattan carried off the elementary school championship of the Public Schools Athletic League for the first time by rolling up a total of 31 points in the title meet at the City College pool yesterday.

A struggle for supremacy between Mrs. Adele Rivero of Manhattan and Mrs. Mary Bain of Astoria marked the play in the eighth round of the women's championship tournament for the Hazel Allen Trophy, at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

Ricardo Pittini, Archbishop of Santo Domingo, arrived here this afternoon. He is on a mission to collect the contributions promised by the various Latin-American governments toward the early construction of a gigantic lighthouse in the Dominican Republic in commemoration of Christopher Columbus's discovery of the New World.

With construction of medium and low priced houses proceeding at a rapid pace, many builders in Long Island announced last week that new model homes in their developments were being opened for inspection.

THERE can hardly ever have been a cub reporter who did not at one time or another imagine himself as a war correspondent, standing coolly under fire, galloping around with exclusive stories ready to file, beating the world on news of battles;
Providence College gave the Long Island University nine a merry chase, but never quite caught up and the Blackbirds turned in their ninth victory, 6--4, at Dexter Park yesterday.

The Glee Club of Rosemont College near Philadelphia, will present Gilbert and Sullivan's "Mikado" tonight and tomorrow night in the college gymnasium. In the title role is Ruth Senker, '37, of New York. The cast also includes Charlotte Schwartz, '39, of Philadelphia as Nanki-Poo;

Banchory Varnish of Wingan, Labrador owned by Jay F. Carlisle of this town and handled by David D. Elliot, today was awarded first prize in the open all-age stake of the third annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club.
Pound fishermen along fifty-five miles of New Jersey coast won pay rises tonight as a settlement ended a strike which tied up five fisheries and their dozen boats for two days.

AARON COPLAND'S "The Second Hurricane," a play-opera to be sung and performed by young people, will be given for the first time anywhere Wednesday night, under the auspices of the Henry Street Settlement. Another music-play for children, Paul Hindemith's "Let's Build a Town," will have its first New York performance this afternoon at the MacDowell Club.

Three men were sentenced to death and nine others received prison terms up to ten years on charges of participation in a Communist attack on a Nazi Storm Troop cafe on May 12, 1932, in which one Nazi was killed and four injured.
A bouquet from an 11-year-old admirer and attendance at a routine secret session of the Supreme Court marked the seventy-eighth birthday of Associate Justice Willis Van Devanter.

Savings, building and loan associations participating in the FHA insured mortgage system now number 1,107, Administrator Stewart McDonald announced yesterday. This is a 64 per cent increase over the 672 institutions active in the program on Feb. 29, 1936.

The ratio of position-seekers to available jobs in office employment continues to shorten, with supply indexes averaging 3 to 8 points below those of last year, according to the semi-annual report of the National Employment Service, Inc.,

Opening its final Winter dinghy racing with a team competition between the Class B one-design and Class X boats, the Larchmont Yacht Club today held the first of two sessions in an endeavor to settle once and for all the much-disputed matter of the speed of the two divisions.

COMMENTING on the disposal of the charges by the Federal Trade Commission respecting the 6 per cent financing plan of certain motor manufacturers and finance companies, P. W. Haberman, vice president and general counsel of Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, said last week:

American importers, seeking to utilize special accounts in barter transactions with Germany, are no longer required to qualify through taking a minimum volume of 50,000 reichmarks annually, according to word reaching the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce yesterday.

George Esser, secretary of the Virginia Soft Coal Producers Association, announced tonight that an agreement had been reached with the United Mine Workers of America which will send 7,500 Southwest Virginia bituminous miners back to work early next week.

Columbia shook up its batting order yesterday and Fordham proceeded to shake up Columbia with fifteen hits of assorted sizes as the Rams crushed the Lions, 12 to 1, at Baker Field. The Maroon just had one of those days when everything clicked to perfection and the Light Blue,

Before the Spring concert to be given by the People's Chorus of New York on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, a cocktail party and dinner will be given for members of the junior committee of the chorus and their friends.
CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa.--The South African government has embarked on a highly important investigation of the nation's resources available in the event of war.

Even exceptionally large persons--either way--will be pleased with three new and radically different private room accommodations for day and night railroad travel soon to be introduced by the Pullman company.

Miss Margaretta Trasel Rowland, whose marriage to Alexander Boyd of Harrisburg, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Boyd, is to take place May 26, will be escorted by her oldest brother, E. Trasel Rowland.
Featuring the general activity in New Jersey last week was the sale by the Fidelity Liquidating Trust of Ridgewood of thirteen one-family homes and a store and residence building.

Lads from 2 1/2 to 15 years, sons of naval officers stationed here, engaged this morning in the eighteenth annual boxing tournament of navy juniors, conducted during that period by Spike Webb, coach of Naval Academy boxers.

THE title of this remarkable book is drawn from Shelley. A great stream Of people there was hurrying to and fro, Old age and youth. manhood and infancy, Mixed in one mighty torrent, the idea of the author being that history becomes doubly and trebly illumined when viewed not merely as a procession of facts and events but also as a succession of powerful personalities.

MESSIANIC and millennial sects abounded in this country throughout the nineteenth century. None has left a nobler record of achievement than the Shakers. These followers of Mother Ann Lee called themselves the United Society of Believers in Christ's Second Coming.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas for March were about 18 per cent higher in dollar volume than for March, 1936, and were almost 30 per cent above those for the same month of 1935,

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Richard Parker of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Mulford Parker, to Clifford Jewett Swift Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Jewett Swift of Columbus, Ga.
Mr. LIU CHIH is at present a director of Northeast University in Peiping. The student body wishes him to become president

HERE in New York the French flame continues to be replenished, although our Spring season has begun to sweep its hearth and will ere long think about letting Winter's back-log cool into Summery quiescence.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 14, aggregated $8,835,000,000, or 11 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 5 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The North American Homes Exposition announced yesterday it had been informed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt that she would serve on the women's committee for the exposition, to be held May 12 to 23 at Madison Square Garden. Mrs. V. G. Simkhovitch is chairman of the committee.

Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., the defending world's pocket billiard champion, rallied in the face of overwhelming odds last night at Ponzi's Academy and defeated Ralph Greenleaf of New York, 125 to 107, in twenty-two innings.

IN the death of Charles-Marie Widor, Paris has lost one of her oldest and most distinguished musicians. Widor's long musical life (he was born in Lyon in 1845) was an active one. Gounod and Saint-Saens were instrumental in obtaining Widor's appointment in 1870 to the post of organist at l'Eglise de SaintSulpice, a position which he held to the end of his life.
Mrs. Arthur Osgood Choate heads the committee for the English Folk Dance festival which will take place the afternoon of May 1 in the Seventh Regiment Armory. Mrs.

Prompt adoption by the Board of Estimate of the recommendation of Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan for the creation of a new "super retail use district" in the midtown Fifth Avenue section has been urged by the Fifth Avenue Association in a petition to the city authorities. according to Captain William J. Pedrick, president nf the association.
A fleet of fifty-eight freighters moved into the open water of Lake Superior early today and thirty-five westbound boats lifted anchor later.

Prizes were awarded last week at the sixth annual architectural competition for students at the Beaux Arts Institute of Design, 304 East Forty-fourth Street. The competition is sponsored by the institute and the Illuminating Engineering Society.
Psychologists have come to the aid of thousands of children who have rebelled in the past against drab, routine problems in addition or subtraction.

The marriage of Miss Cathryn Steinwart, daughter of Mrs. Henry Louis Steinwart of Cincinnati, to William Jackson Keith of Boston took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's brother-inlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Edward Rader. The Rev. George A. Edmison, pastor of First Presbyterian and Trinity Church, South Orange, performed the ceremonv.
Three Detroit yachtsmen arrived at the Englewood Basin after dark last night on the first leg of a thousand-mile cruise from Wilmington, Del., to Detroit.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on. the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

The marriage of Miss Sophie Kilbreth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Kilbreth of New York and this community, to Ernest Patrick Bernuth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar M. Bernuth of the Oaks, Cedarhurst, and New York, took place this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church, Hewlett.
Two New York State gangsters were held in the Jackson County jail here tonight, facing a penalty of death by hanging if the government agent they shot should die from his wounds.

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Kirkmari of 43 East Sixty-eighth Street gave a dinner dance last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Lefferts and Waring Strebeig sons of Mr. and Mrs. Robert 14 Strebeigh of this city.

With the beginning of the Spring term at Brown University this week, the board of management of the university's outing reservation is arranging for increased use of Brown's 100-acre wooded tract in the hill country of Central Rhode Island,

The Trinity School baseball team inaugurated its drive in the Eastern Private Schools League by hammering out a 13-5 victory over Poly Prep on the latter's field yesterday. The contest also was the circuit opener for Poly.
Major findings of the Hospital Survey for New York, backed by the United Hospital Fund and initiated two years ago, will be announced at a luncheon on Wednesday, April 28, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alston H. Garside of Scarsdale, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy M. L. Garside, to Joseph C. Robbins Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Robbins of White Plains.

Some four hundred papers were read before the American Chemical Society. Even the romanticist, LIEBIG, would have been astonished at their range. In his day it was still a feat to tear matter apart and discover its constitution or to show the relation of chemistry to agriculture or soap-making.

Marblehead is to have the highest spite fence in New England. Being constructed for Mrs. A. Lawrence Rotch of Boston and Marblehead on her Summer estate on Goodwin's Court, it will be of matched boards, painted brown, and will be 45 feet high and 200 feet long.

Four young non-Nazi photographers looked around for other trades today after "flunking" the Propaganda Ministry's test of whether a news camera would be safe in their hands. Another aspirant, the only Nazi in the group, was promptly passed.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Pauline Gunnison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond M. Gunnison of Scarsdale, N. Y., to David Enequist, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Enequist of Harrison, N. Y.

A six-week geology expedition into Montana and Wyoming to prospect for possible new oil supplies is being planned this Summer by four members of Williams College. Under the direction of John R. Fanshawe of the Geology Department, the group will study problems in mapping this uncharted country,
Fritz Crisler's Princeton football squad culminated a week of intense practice on Fitzpatrick Field today with an informal two and a half hour scrimmage with Lehigh. Sixtyseven men saw action.

The Westchester County Gardens and Homes Exhibit, sponsored by the Bronxville Women's Club, will be held at the clubhouse, here, from Friday through Sunday, it was announced today 'y Mrs. L. Ahndrew Reinhard, chairman of the exhibit.

THE Ernest Williams School of Music is sponsoring what is said to be the first school band festival in this city on May 29 at Town Hall. The first part of the program will consist of the finals in the Edwin Franko Goldman composition contest held annually among the students of the Williams School.

Names and itineraries of some of the long-range air travelers, fortytwo of whom have booked roundthe-world passage, beginning with the opening of this commercial service on April 28, have been given out by Pan American Airwavs.
Commodity futures were irregular in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber and cocoa futures advanced, while other futures were irregular to lower.

The sixty-three passengers and the crew of the French liner Bretagne had to drink wine or beer or go thirsty while the San Francisco-bound ship was aground sixty hours on the Colombian coast, officers related when the vessel reached here today.
The an- i nual freshman week-end at Milwaukee-Downer College opened with a rally which proved to be a rather pretentious literary festival.

ACQUES IBERT, interviewed by your correspondent on the occasion of the recent "L'Aiglon" premiere at the Monte Carlo Opera, talked of his plans for Villa Medici in Rome, where he has been appointed director, the first musician to hold this post after more than a century of painters and sculptors.
Lying at Ben Pine's wharf is the fishing schooner Henrietta, which has for twenty-two years, through storm and calm pursued the cod and the haddock on the Banks.

Eight hundred thousand new dwelling units per year must be built if a shortage of housing is to be avoided in the United States, according to the conclusion drawn by George Terborgh of the Economics Division of the Federal Reserve Board from a recent study, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Until a century ago the three Basque Provinces, in the angle of the Bay of Biscay on the northern coast of Spain, constituted "a land apart," paying allegiance to the King of Spain, but making their own laws, following their own customs, speaking their own language.

IT used to be that Washington received the privilege of starting a full stride ahead of other major league cities because the District of Columbia could furnish the President of the United States to toss out the first ball.

Students of Wilson College have elected Barbara Bitner of Berwick president of the Wilson College Government Association. Other officers elected are: Catherine Thompson, Washington, Pa., vice president; Anna Kratz, Norristown, President of student council;
A home run to left field by Shortstop Roy Shankus in the ninth inning enabled Pratt Institute to score a 6-to-5 victory over Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute of Troy on the victor's field yesterday.

The steamship Yorktown, inbound from Norfolk with forty-two passengers, and the freighter Alamar were in collision in the harbor today, injuring two passengers and shaking up the others severely. Both vessels made port under their own power.

As General Chiang Ting-wen [one of Chiang Kai-shek's most trusted generals, who was arrested at Sian during the mutiny] had already been in and out of Sian, I requested him to accompany me in case the Generalissimo needed an officer of his standing as representative.
Events of the past week have proved to the British Government that restraint can often be a more effective weapon of diplomacy than rattling of the saber.

Under the direction of James D. Preston, assistant administrative secretary of the National Archives, the records of the Senate proceedings, some of them dating back to 1789, are being moved from an attic storeroom in the Capitol to the new Archives Building.
With the demand for Spring merchandise stimulated by more favorable weather conditions, business showed satisfactory progress in most sections of the country last week.

In her thoughtful and characteristically human reply, Miss Lathrop wrote:

Miss Isabel Morrison West Jackson, daughter of Mrs. William Benjamin Jackson and the late Colonel Jackson, was married to Dr. Thorborn S. McGowan of the United States Public Health Service in the First Congregational Church here this afternoon.

The will of Mrs. Minnie Nichols were Hunt, former wife of Frank C. Hunt, filed for probate here today, revealed an estate of $243,232. She died here on Sept. 17. The estate consists chiefly of twenty-eight parcels of real estate,
THE comparative costliness of silverware tends to make its design conservative and changes of fashion less frequent than in furniture or fabrics, for example.

Employes of the Jordan Marsh Company, estimated by the department store to number thirty-seven and by union leaders 500, went on strike today.

CURACAO.--The Canadian Eagle Oil Company, whose capital is mostly held in England, has just started to erect storage tanks at its refinery on the neighboring island of Aruba to take care of an additional 3,000,000 barrels of oil.

Jay Phillips, 17 years old, a student, of 780 West End Avenue, died in Roosevelt Hospital last night from injuries he received late yesterday afternoon when a horse which he was riding on the Central Park bridle path, near the entrance at Fifty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, bolted and threw him to the roadway.

Authentic gowns, some of which are family heirlooms, depicting the fashions of a century, will be worn at the fashion show, luncheon and bridge on Tuesday at the Carlyle for the benefit of the Cape Cod Institute of Music.
TWELVE years of agrarian agitation to bring the farmer out of his semi-bankrupt state gave birth to the AAA on May 12, 1933. A long legislative struggle with clashing programs had preceded it.

The Wembley Lions, National League champions of England, whipped the Hershey sextet from the United States, Eastern Amateur Hockey League titleholder, by 6-3 tonight in the first game of the round-robin world amateur hockey series.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Webster Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Jackson of White Plains, N. Y., to Ernst Carl Strangmeier of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Frederick Ernst Strangmeier of Quackenbruck, Germany, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Prime Minister, J. B. M. Hertzog has handed to the German Minister a note replying to the German protest against the proclamation issued April 2 excluding aliens in Southwest Africa from public affairs and prohibiting their membership in political organizations.

Using the ratio of one place for every eighteen members in good standing, the Professional Golfers Association yesterday allotted one hundred places to be competed for in the sectional rounds of the 1937 P. G. A. championship which will be held at the Pittsburgh Field Club on Mav 24-30.

At the end of the five days which have passed since the Supreme Court, 5 to 4, decided the manufacturing cases under the Wagner act, the net political effect seems to be a stronger hope in Congress that some compromise can be reached with the President on the form and method, but not the basis, of his legislative proposals respecting the Supreme Court.

The entire 4 German press today publishes the orig.nal army citation of July 31 1918, in which Adolf Hitler, then a corporal in a Bavarian infantry regiment, was proposed for decoraFinn with the Iron Cross. first class.

Existing plans for home financing are more than adequate and the solution to the housing problems in this country is mass production combined with intelligent merchandising by well-financed national building organizations, declares N. K. Winston of the firm bearing his name.
Akron, deprived of street-car and bus service by an unexpected strike of operators yesterday, looked hopefully to a union meeting tomorrow.

LINZER--Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Linzer announce the confirmation of their son, Morton A., at the Temple Adareth Israel, Grand Concourse and 169th St., Saturday, April 24, at 10 A. M. LONDON--Mr. and Mrs. Otto, 450 West End Av., announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Richard Hart, Saturday, April 24, Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83d, 10:15 A. M. At home after 7 P. M. No cards.

The rolling hills of Westchester County are bustling with activity as developers usurp more and more formerly idle land and transform it into new residential neighborhoods. With the Spring demand centering in dwellings in the medium price range, builders are concentrating on this type of house.

John Hay Whitney uncovered another startlingly fast juvenile before 20,000 persons at Jamaica yesterday when his Inhale led from end to end of the Youthful Stakes to click off the fastest time made in years.

Miss Katharine E. Williamson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. S. Williamson of Jamesport, L. I., was married to Herman Eugene Talmadge, son of Eugene Talmadge, former Governor of Georgia, and Mrs. Talmadge of McRae, Ga., yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine in the presence of the immediate families and a few friends.

The estate of James Donald Cameron, once Senator from Pennsylvania, must pay a State and county personal property tax of eight mills on $4,123,460 instead of on $481,477, the amount given in a return to the Board of Revision of Taxes last January by the Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company, trustee.

Organized labor has formally agreed that there shall be no interruptions in construction on any low-cost housing program undertaken in the city, Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday. Under the terms of the agreement wages will be stabilized in advance.

Fellowships have been awarded to eight students who plan to teach in American colleges by the National Council on Religion in Higher Education, the executive offices of which are at 437 West Fifty-ninth Street.

THE milkman never rings at all. An empty bottle on our threshold is enough to evoke this modern genie of the night. It is the only welcome he demands. He moves serenely through his chosen orbit; even the latest milk war has failed to touch him or to stay his steps.

For months after Mayor S. Davis Wilson announced last November that he was turning over the "problem of crime and vice" to a committee of clergymen, Philadelphia waited, more or less impatiently, for action.
Else Fitz Randolph, principal of P. S. 13 at Rosebank, S. I., will be tendered a testimonial dinner tomorrow night by the teachers of his school in celebration of his fiftieth year of teaching.

The Earl of Londesborough, a noted master of foxhounds, sportsman and soldier, died today of pneumonia at the age of 42. He was a cousin and lifelong friend of the Earl of Westmorland, who was boarding a liner at Southampton to recuperate from a severe attack of pneumonia when he heard of his kinsman's death.

A maximum of jubilation and a modicum of condemnation among women's organizations greeted the Senate's sweeping approval of minmum-wage legislation at Albany last week, minus the amendment which sought to extend the bill to include men. Anticipation of its ratification by the Assembly, already keen, took new assurance from the ratio of the vote as the measure landed in the lap of the lower house.
The four-story apartment house at 650 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Mrs. Felicia Schaparia to an investor through Hy. D. Agar, Inc., broker.

Hundreds of American cities and a dozen foreign countries will celebrate Boys' and Girls' Week beginning next Saturday. Guided by a national committee, headed by Walter W. Head of St. Louis, national president of the Boy Scouts of America,
The seventh annual .30-caliber rifle match for metropolitan Reserve Officers Training Corps teams, held under the auspices of the Manhattan Reserve Officers Association, was shot at Camp Smith today.

HERE, from Japan, is grace and intimacy. And here, too, accompanying this text by an Englishwoman long resident in Tokyo, is an enchanting array of very individual drawings, most of them in color, by a Japanese artist. The whole makes "Living in Tokyo" a volume of exceptional charm and distinct human value.

An international industrial tour in which, it is stated, about 100 representatives of banking, industrial and construction interests will participate, will sail from New York City on the steamer Champlain, May 14, under the auspices of the division of engineering of the Naionnl Research Council.

BERIZZI--CORSETTI--Mr. Luigi Berlzzi and Mrs. Bianca Corsetti married at the Church of St. John the Baptist at 76th St. and Lexington Av., on April 14, 1937. DE HEYSER--LEVINE--Mrs. Nat. Levine of 25 Central Park West announces the marriage of her daughter, Grace, to Richard De Keyser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel De Keyser, on April 11, 1937.

Fighting off a succession of scoring threats, Manhattan College defeated Seton Hall today, 3-2. Seton Hall had two or three bases filled in nearly every inning but was prevented from scoring until the eighth.

Strangers roamed through this city's historic homesteads today, but not the home of John L. Lewis. Mrs. Lewis withdrew their Colonial residence from today's tour and one to be held on April 26 after Mrs. Berenice Holland had objected to its being included in the latter because she disagreed with Mr. Lewis's labor policies.
Early expansion of British investments in Southern China is expected because of the growing Chino-British friendship and cooperation.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Replogle entertained with a dinner tonight at the Beach Club, having as guests Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. Luis Martinez de las Rivas, Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, Mrs. Annie F. Breniser, Sir Robert Throckmorton and Prince Georges Scherbatoff.
Charlton Athletic dropped out of the running for the English Football League championship today when held to a 2-2 draw at Everton. Manchester City,

General Jackson Jr., a black and white English setter champion, topped one of the greatest fields of hunting dogs this year when he captured the open all-age stake of the Orange County Field Trial Club among thirty-seven entries.
Youthful Tommy Walker, brilliant Heart of Midlothian strategist, was toasted north o' the Tweed today as the spark-plug of Scotland's twentyeighth victory over England in international soccer.

The Thomas Paine exhibition which was opened yesterday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, includes an old roadmap showing the town where Paine was born 200 years ago. His death mask is also an exhibit.

City College of New York and Brown played eleven inning to a 3-3 tie in a game halted by darkness today. The game lasted three and one-half hours.

A brief urging that legislation be sought to establish licensing requirements for builders has been sent to Mayor La Guardia by the Associated Builders of Kings County. Modern builders must know something of "several dozen" trades, the organization holds, and only men qualified by knowledge and experience should be permitted to supervise building.

From New York, New Jersey, and Delaware, 2,464 Army Reserve officers will be called into active training for two-week periods at seventeen army posts this Summer under plans for organized reserves training announced yesterday at headquarters of Major Gen. Frank

United Public Service Corporation--For 1936: Total income, $80,063, against $83,778 in 1935; net income, after deducting all expenses, $52,875, or 16 cents a share on 315,532 shares of capital stock outstanding at end of 1936, compared with net of $54,846, or 17 cents a capital share, in 1935.

The trustees of Clark College and University announce that a drive will soon be started here to rais $150,000 on the proposed $425,000 building program. Faculty, students and alumni have already pledged $275,000.
The King and Queen have taken the royal box at -Covent Garden Opera House for the coronation season of international opera commencing on Monday.

HENRY MIDDLETON RUTLEDGE, who led his sharp shooters so valiantly in some of the Civil War's most terrible battles, was the youngest colonel in the Confederate Army. He was only 24 when the war ended, and he went back to "a ruined estate and a collapsed civilization."

" International Interdependence" is to be the theme of the activities for Peace Week, beginning Monday at Skidmore College. A peace strike on Thursday noon will be given with the consent of the faculty and administration,
Leonard S. Wolff of New York has purchased the Albert Krauter property on High Ridge Road, Stamford, Conn., through Kenneth Ives Co., brokers.

The housekeeper who casts a critical eye over her kitchen equipment and finds chipped or dented pots and pans and an incomplete assortment of utensils may want to replenish her supply at this time. If she does, she will find kitchenware departments full of new and handsome household helps.

The Committee for Special Jewish Interests today issued a protest against the prohibition by Germany of all Jewish meetings for sixty days in retaliation for Mayor Fiorello La Guardia's speeches in New York.

Two sets of twins in one family figured in a church wedding here today. Miss Mary E. Lester became the bride of Francis E. Church. Francis Lester, the bride's twin brother, was best man, and her sisters, Gertrude and Grace Lester, twins, attended her.

Eddie Blunt, Corona heavyweight knocked out Jim Howell of Harlen in 0:48 of the fourth of their scheduled ten-round bout at Rocklad Palace last night. Howell was unable to continue because of a dislocated right shoulder.

Characters from "Alice in Wonderland" and some of the finer points of Jabberwocky will be materialized into games of skill and amusement at the Charity Ball to be given for the benefit of the New York Osteopathic Clinic on April 26 in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Senators came to the end of a three-in-a-row exhibition game winning streak today when the Baltimore Orioles beat them by a 4-2 score. Cecil Travis, Washington shortstop, was spiked above the right knee while making a put-out at second.

Under auspices of the Soroptimist Club of Bronx County a poll of members of eighty organizations in that area has been conducted to determine the woman resident who rendered the greatest service to the county during 1936. Her identity will be disclosed at a dinner in her honor Saturday night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel at which Assistant Attorney General Bertha Schwartz, president of the Soroptimists of the Bronx, will be in charge.

Eleven homes are nearing completion at Packanack Lake, in Wayne Township, near Mountainview, N. J., according to the John R. Franke Company, developers. Plans have been drawn and sites selected for fifteen additional houses.

GEOFFREY FABER has started, in The Publishers' Cirular, a brisk discussion of the spate of new bocks. He is not, he says, the only publisher who regards with apprehension the progressive rise in their number. From 6,738 in 1906 it reached 10,407 in 1936.

Miss Edna Monica Steck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave J. Steck of this city, was married this morning to John Joseph Cabrey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Cabrey of Narberth, Pa., in Blessed Sacrament Church here. The Rev. Edward Lang of Netcong performed the ceremony and was celebrant of the nuptial mass that followed.
More than half of the families buying homes under the FHA plan have incomes of $2,500 a year or less, states Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator.
Summer schools throughout the country generally will show increased enrollments this year, Henry G. Arndorf, registrar of New York University, predicted yesterday.
With his church in a suitcase, the Rev. Dudley S. McNeil, young Elgin, Ill., Episcopal clergyman, has started West for the missionary field in the sparsely settled southwestern section of Wyoming.

The American premiere of "Close Quarters," starring Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper, was well received here tonight in McCarter Theatre by a capacity audience of more than 1,000 persons. The play, which ran two years in London, was written by W. O. Somin and adapted by Gilbert Lennox.

Many gardeners have, within recent years, used a seed-bed medium composed of a mixture of sand and peat moss, but now-if they follow the advice given in a recent bulletin of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station-they may discard the peat and use sand alone. Nothing but sand. It sounds rather impractical, but it works.

A preview exhibition of royal robes and court gowns worn at the coronation of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra of England will be held on the afternoon of April 30 at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, 30 East Fiftyseventh Street.

BIEGEI--Mr. and Mrs. Herman C. Blegel announce the birth of a son, Richard Lewis, on April 7, 1937. BIELEFELD--Mr. and Mrs. David C. Bielefeld (nee Ruth Cohen) announce the birth of a daughter April 15 at Woman's Hospital.

Smith College seniors, 480 of them, appeared at the college assembly this week wearing their caps and gowns for the first time. Anually at the first assembly following the Spring vacation the seniors don their academic attire. They sit together in the center front section of John M. Greene

PROFESSOR ARNETT thinks that a "realistic acquaintance" with Kitchin's career "should impress historians with the obligation which devolves upon their profession to rectify the grossly distorted impressions" of Kitchin "created in his day by the press and other agencies of propaganda."

Named in honor of the late Dr. Charles P. Vaughan of Philadelphia, the first unit completed in Bucknell University's new building program will be known as Vaughan Literature Building. For five years preceding Dr. Vaughan's death last year, he served as chairman
Shailer Mathews, dean emeritus of the University of Chicago Divinity School, said. today that "jazz orthodoxy typifies the present religious trend in the nation."

Wellesley College students become bilinguists in English. In the speech courses, through which every one must pass, the students are introduced to the beauties and practiability of "standard English," but they are no longer forced to abandon the local peculiarities of their "native dialects."

Spring air-conditioning for homes, resulting from refinement of the methods used during Winter weather, and based upon the principle used to condition the newest airplanes, is the latest development in the industry, according to William H. Emory, manager of the New York branch of the American Radiator Company.

Mrs. R. Clifford Black of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and Mesacrest, Broadmoor, Colorado Springs, Col., has announced the engagement of her younger daughter, Miss Judith Black, to Farish Alston Jenkins, younger son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edgar Jenkins of St. Louis. The announcement was made at a dinner and dance given by Mrs. Black last night at her Pelham Manor home.
The round, weather-beaten face of 99-year-old "Soda Ash Johnny" Horan glowed today as high officials of the Milwaukee Railroad paid tribute to his eighty-two years of continuous service.

SINGLE file, in a line which will extend for nearly 1,500 miles from Key West to New York, the largest fleet of private yachts ever to travel the East Coast of the United States is now on its way north.

The Supreme Court's decision upholding the Wagner Act is expected to have far-reaching effects favorable to the Committee for Industrial Organization in its battle, through its affiliate, the United Automobile Workers of America, to unionize the motor industry.

The Phillies bunched 10 of their hits in the first three innings to score nine runs, then fought off a belated rally by the Athletics to defeat their city rivals, 9--7, today. Seven of the runs were scored off George Turbeville, who lasted only two innings.

A lot of good pitching plus a little luck enabled the world champion Yankees to down those impudent Dodgers at Ebbetts Field yesterday and square the team's Spring series at two games each. The 2-1 score wasn't so emphatic, but it was enough.
Two trustees will be elected when this village's annual election is held on April 27, but Republicans will remain in control of the Board of Tuustees even if Democrats win both positions.

The syndicate headed by Nathan Wilson has added the Wick property to its holdings in the Briarwood section of Jamaica. The property includes a large tract in eighty-fourth Drive, Burden Crescent and Pershing Crescent adjacent to the Queens Boulevard parcel recently acquired.

Edmund Kent Arnold, a Boston lawyer, was killed last night by a fall from the eighth floor of the Phillips House, Massachiusetts General Hospital, where he had been under treatment for a nervous disorder. It was the first such mishap in the history of the hospital.

THE National Association for Travelers Aid and Transient Service, twenty years old this month, will celebrate its anniversary in New York from April 22 to 24. In 100 cities all over America, in railway stations, at steamship piers and bus terminals, the worker at a resk and the familiar insignia of globe and lamp represent the Travllers Aid and its helping hand.

A RADIO popularity poll conAducted by the Gramercy Boys Club "among 1,000 boys in the gas house district,". reveals their five favorite programs in this order: Eddie Cantor, Jack Benny, Joe Penner, the sketch, "Gang Busters," and the Hit Parade.

A blank space on a map calls to the explorer. In the same manner the ambition of the political observer is to uncover the mysterious corners of the domain of international relations. In Europe today the greatest mystery of all is the problem of the true relationship between Hitler's Germany and Stalin's Russia.

When the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria opens for the late Spring and Summer season on the night of May 6, net proceeds from dinner and supper dancing will be donated to the Masters School Day Nursery of this city.

President Roosevelt stayed today in his study at the White House, spending most of the time preparing for his message next week carrying estimates for relief expenditures for the coming fiscal year and a recast of the budget figures for the same period, ...

Departure from the established wholesale "price grooves" may be necessary as solution of the "price problem" of the dress manufacturers, Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

Brutalities by hired thugs and "hatchet men" on both sides were alleged today in the-labor warfare at Weirton Steel Company plants. The Committee for Industrial Organization has announced that it will prosecute the Weirton company on charges of violation of the Wagner Labor Act.

Whitehaired Bertrand Russell, whom sophisticates know for his unique views on sex, marital relations, how to bring up children and international affairs, was proud tonight after becoming a father at the age of 64.

The present-day architect to be successful no longer can confine himself to the technical and pictrial solution of a problem which is outlined to him by a client, decared H. I. Feldman, architect, who discussed the problems encountered in the design of modern apartment houses before the apartment house group of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York at the Town to Hall Club last week.

Winning one game in the seventh round but losing his adjourned match from the fifth, Reuben Fine of New York was still leading in total points at the close of play tonight in the international chess masters' tournament at the Casino.

Joseph Heckl, 28 years old, was arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday in Brooklyn for complicity in the robbery on March 12 of the Northern Westchester Bank at Katonah, N. Y.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Goodell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Goodell of this place and Cotuit, Mass., to John Abendroth Bogart of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Bogart of Brockton, Mass., took place tonight in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert W. Trenbath, the rector.

Despite the duties imposed by full teaching programs and the neces- ass sity for traveling between the various scattered buildings of Hunter College, thirty-two members of the college staff have published within the last year more than 136 articles, reviews and books,

How readily yesterday's gospel can become- today's heresy! The heavy guns of the Russian Communist party have now been turned on the works of the late Michael Nikolaivitch Pokrovsky, who until his death in 1932 was almost idolized as a Marxist historian, and on the younger Soviet historians who studied under him and now are accused of being active Trotskyists.

Three fellowships, each carrying a stipend of $500, have been awarded by the honor society of the Phi Kappa Phi for graduate study during 1937-38, according to an announcement by Dr. Lawrence R. Guild, secretary-treasurer.

A SPORT combining swift action and adventure has recently won a following in this country. The name of it is "Folboting" (pronounced foalboating), and the idea is to fold your boat into what appears to be a golf bag and a briefcase, ride to the headwaters of some river-or at least to a point upstream--assemble the boat and paddle or float back home.

CAR manufacturers, once again rid of serious strikes, are heading into ther ?? active period since 1929. It has been eight years since the monthly production figure rose to 600,000 units, but that total may be reached next month.
Annual communion breakfast of the New York Fire Department Holy Name Society (Manhattan, Bronx and Richmond Branches), Hotel Astor, 9 A. M. Speakers:Mgr. J.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--Following its usual precedent, the Romany Chorus is outlining plans for next season's major undertaking before the departure for the North of its founders and patrons, Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne.

Amateur journalists who have at-tained prominence in other pursuits or who are still engaged in journalism will chat about old times and discuss past editorial policies at the annual reunion of The Fossils, Inc., on Saturday afternoon and evening at the Hotel Astor.
HERE is a volume which assembles a surprising number of elements of interest -- miscellaneous titbits for the curious about American backgrounds.

BELGRADE. -- In the Balkan lands, where all governments now have openly assumed varying degrees of dictatorship, the popular strength of a government can be judged inversely by the strictness of its press censorship.
By unanimous vote, clergy of the Wyoming Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church today approved proposed unification of the Methodist Episcopal, Methodist South and Methodist Protestant Bodies.
With week-end covering and diminished liquidating pressure creating steadier commodity markets yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered $1 a bale to end with net gains of 15 to 19 points.

Miss Coniston Roberts, daughter of Mrs. A. Newton Roberts, and Robert E. Wilmot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross Wilmot of River Edge, N. J., were married this afternoon in the Pro-Cathedral Episcopal Church of the Nativity by the Rev. Arthur Glazier. acting dean.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were somewhat larger in volume than in the preceding week and included several large retirements. Prepayments thus far scheduled for this month total $317,254,000, compared with $249,224,000 in March and $348,563,000 in April, 1936, for the corresponding periods.

Miss Adelaide Ferry Hooker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elon Huntington Hooker of this city and Greenwich, Conn., was married to John Phillips Marquand, the author, yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents here, 620 Park Avenue.

THE great wave of Wagnerian interest has engulfed not only the Opera House but has penetrated such seemingly remote fields as the screen. For proof, note that Kirsten Flagstad, engaged by Paramount for a brief appearance in "The Big Broadcast of 1938," will be seen and heard as Bruennhilde in the Ho-Yo-To-Ho from "Die Walkuere" and as Elisabeth in the air, "Dich, teure Halle," from "Tannhaeuser."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 15: COMMANDERS English, R. H., Washington, D. C., to the Portland as executive officer. Teasley, W. A., Philadelphia, Pa., to command Mobile Target Division 1.

The marriage of Miss Florence Valleau Stinson, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. R. M. Stinson of Bryn Mawr, to Roland B. Whitridge Jr. of this city will take place on May 8 in the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Andrew Mutch, the pastor, will officiate and will be assisted by the Rev. Rex Stowars Clements. A reception at the home of the prospective bride will follow.

Benefits to be obtained from good office illumination were stressed by H. F. Richardson, of Meyer, Strong Jones, consulting engineers, before a recent meeting of the operating forum of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York.

New York and Northern New Jersey Alumnae Clubs of Pi Beta Phi, national women's fraternity, will celebrate the seventieth anniversary of the organization with a luncheon Saturday at the Beekman Towers.
Two Grand Trunk-Pennsyvania road carferries were tied up here tonight by a walkout of members of three marine unions.
Army took the lead early in today's lacrosse game with Yale and although the Elis held them to a 3-2 advantage at half time, an Army spurt in the last two period produced a 10-4 victory.

The last week has proved beyond further question that the evil spirit which has embittered relations between Britain and India for nearly a generation is not to be exorcised by mere recitation of the phrase "self-government--with safeguards."

Only two more weeks remain of the field-trial season for pointers and setters in the section readily accessible from New York City. This week-end is decidedly overcrowded, with three events scheduled.

Dr. Hans Luther, retiring German Ambassador to the United States, attacked American critics of Nazi Germany tonight in an unexpected speech to members of Congress and newspaper men attending his an- out] nual bock beer party.

PENNY WISE--Tomorrow evening at the Morosco Theatre. A play by Jean Ferguson Black, one which tells the story of a playwright and his patient wife. Kenneth MacKenna, Linda Watkins, Irene Purcell, Mildred Wall, Bertram Thorn, Nancy Sheridan and Albert Bergh are in the cast.

The Summer home of the late Charles L. Wetherbee, consisting of forty-two acres with a residence of twenty-five rooms and seven baths, at Great Barrington, Mass., in the Berkshires, has been sold by W. Barton Baldwin, executor of the estate, to a buyer who proposes, after extensive alterations, to operate it as a hotel.
The one-family brick house at 6116 Sixty-fourth Street, Maspeth, L. I., was sold by Mrs. Helen Cole to Hans Vetter, represented by Theobald Dengler.

Superbly balanced, the Evander Childs High School squad, coached by Walter Degnan, repeated its victory of a year ago in the twentyninth annual track and field meet staged at Ohio Field by New York University yesterday.

A pinched finger, incapacitating an employee for several weeks, ended the longest safety record of any plant of the United States Leather Company. The accident was the first in the Union tannery here since July 5, 1935.
Realtors of New York and six other States of the Central Atlantic region of the National Association of Real Estate Boards will hold their convention on May 14 and 15 at the Hotel Biltmore.

A NEW radio doctrine between the United States, Canada, Mexico and Cuba is now described as "freedom from interference within the borders of a country," rather than the old theory of "international coverage" even at the expense of causing interference in neighboring nations.

Characters familiar in the history of Mount Holyoke College will live again during the May centenary celebration, in the presentation of an historical episode, "Mount Holyoke Opens," written for the occasion by Dr. Sydney McLean of the Department of English.

A forum on international relations of the United States, sponsored by the New York Circle of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, will be held in the auditorium of Good Counsel College, tomorrow, beginning at 2:30 P. M.

In one of the most exciting sessions of the American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory the Waldorf Golden Bock quintet of Cleveland last night rolled its way into second place in the five-man division with a score of 3,109.

ALMOST from the beginning New York was a town of cosmopolitan population. Even as New Amsterdam it was a polyglot resort of traders. So that it was never devoted to homekeeping and home-cooking as many lesser towns have been.
A Congressional controversy developed today out of an administration proposal to increase farm interest rates as a means of preventing an inflationary "land boom."

In Bronx Botanical Garden and in Brooklyn Botanic Garden, if today is fair, daffodils will display themselves. At the foot of the Brooklyn garden's daffodil-clad Boulder Hill a border of star magnolias is so laden with flowers that it resembles a snowbank.

As a means or preventing undue congestion in the mortgage application files of the Federal Housing Administration, Parker S. Maddux, president of the San Francisco Bank, suggests that private lending institutions should submit to the FHA only those mortgage applications which are considered acceptable under the best practices of sound banking.
Officials of the Metropolitan Opera Company of New York announced here tonight that a new world's record for a single week of opera attendance had just been set at Cleveland's Public Hall.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Logan MacCoy of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Wood MacCoy, to Arthur Merriam Rogers of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. William O. Rogers of Madison, N. J., and nephew of Mrs. Arthur Merriam of 823 Park Avenue.
The Reserve Officers Association of the State of New York will hold its annual convention on May 7 and 8 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. It is expected that about 500 persons will attend.

Rensselaer PolyLechnic Institute and the College of Engineering of New York University are considering the joint establishment and operation of a weather observatory and meteorological laboratory on Whiteface Mountain, Dr. William Otis Hotchkiss, president of Rensselaer, announced today.

The exclusion of Prince Nicholas from the royal family, with deprivation of his offices and titles, leaving him the only Rumanian without even a name, is the latest in a long series of personal tragedies of the Rumanian royal house.

The Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventysixth street and Park Avenue, in 1936, for the first time in a generation, reported a balanced budget and was not obliged to draw on capital to meet a net deficit, it was stated in the annual report made public yesterday.

Free distribution of documents for government departments in 1936 showed nearly 100 per cent increase over the previous year, according to figures recently made public by Alton P. Tisdel, Superintendent of Documents.

The marriage of Miss Mary Ridder, daughter of Victor Frank Ridder, New York publisher and chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare, to Dr. Hans Hartmann, son of Adolf Hartmann of Hanover, Germany, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her father. 81 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Five health stations for infants in crowded districts of Manhattan will benefit from the luncheon, bridge party and fashion revue to take place in the outdoor garden of the Park Lane on May 4 under the auspices of the New York Diet Kitchen Association.
Before a splendid gathering that filled boxes and seating accommodations almost to capacity, the first Spring horse show of Squadron A, featuring military classes, came to a close last night.
Mrs. William A. Becker, President General, predicts a record attendance at the forty-sixth continental congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution, which opens Monday night.

The Glee Club of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, will give its annual concert on the evening of April 30 in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium, on the college campus, it was announced last night.
Mr. and Mrs. Adam N. Mitchell of Rutherford, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Mitchell, to Arthur Bloete, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bloete, also of Rutherford.

An intercollegiate literary conference, marking the first effort on the part of Eastern colleges and universities to provide opportunities for the exchange of undergraduate literary thought and method, will be held at Princeton University on Friday and Saturday, Professor Christian Gauss, dean of the college, announced today.

Remodeling of two "old-law" tenements at 710 and 712 Ninth Avenue, whose previous lack of modern facilities made them an economic liability to the owner, so changed the desirability of the buildings that they were completely rented upon completion of the renovation, according to George A. Bowman, Inc., agent.
Montana must "do something and do it quickly" to save hundreds of famishing deer and elk on overgrazed land, according to Major Evan W. Kelley, regional forester.

Displaying an effective three-quarter running attack, Princeton's varsity rugby team repulsed a favored Long Island University fifteen, 11-0, on Bedford Field today for its second victory of the season.
Rentals of office, showroom and store space reported yesterday covered a wide area in the city and outlying sections of the metropolitan area.

While rising prices, particularly in men's clothing and shoes, and the poor showing in clothing volume during March have occasioned some uneasiness, chief apprehension over a possible setback in business is felt by manufacturers and retailers for the Fall season, a survey among both groups revealed yesterday.

Sales of real estate and mortgages aggregating $11,624,391 have been made by the realty division of the Title and Mortgage Rehabilitation and Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department up to April 1, according to a report yesterday covering activities of the division from its inception in August, 1935. Sales for March amounted to $1,972,350.

The calmer tone that began to be noticeable in the Italian press yesterday continued today. The desire to allay the fears of the public, which has lived for some weeks amid constant alarms, has reached such a point that the Tribuna's editor prints a long editorial developing this thesis:

Miss Mary Paulding Murdoch, daughter of Mrs. James Paulding Murdock of this city and the late Commander Murdoch, U. S. N., was married to Hugh McDonald Martin Jr. of New York, a son of the Rev. Hugh McDonald Martin of Fredericksburg, Va., and the late Mrs. Martin, here tonight in Trinity Church.

FOR the first time the Britishcontrolled port of Aden has postage stamps of its own. The town is located south of Arabia on the Gulf of Aden, an arm of the Indian Ocean, and is easily accessible to ships plying the Indian Ocean and the Red Sea.
Former Prince Nicholas early today repudiated efforts to create a political disturbance because of his ouster from the royal family.
ON April 1 at 8:20 A. M., a Breda 88 landplane piloted by Fario Niclot took off from the airport of Montecelio, near Rome, with a view to a new speed record over 100 kilometers.
For the past week Leon Trotsky has risen twice daily to testify and proclaim his innocence of anti-Soviet conspiracy before a subcommission of inquiry headed by John Dewey.

The engagement of $5,685,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York Of this amount, $3,300,000 was purchased in London yesterday, and the remaining $2,385,000 on some previous day.

With two Olympic champions and nearly a score of Olympians dressing up the show, the fortythird annual Penn Relay carnival, a two-day extravaganza of swiftmoving action and kaleidoscopic color, will be staged at Franklin Field on Friday and Saturday.
Discovery of Hans Holbein's original sketch for his painting, "Triumph of Riches," was announced here. today by Harry Noyes Pratt, director-manager of Crocker Art Gallery.
An active committee of North Jersey and New York residents is completing arrangements for the junior class annual Spring dance of Georgian Court College, April 23, in Manhattan.
The Reichsbank's statement as of April 16 shows the following changes from the proceeding week, in thousands of marks:

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Laidlaw of 270 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Lane Laidlaw, to William Edward Dillmeier, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Dillmeier of Garden City, L. I.
San Fransico hotel operators agreed to a 40-hour week and preference for union members in employment, averting a threatened strike of 3,000 workers.

Greatly increased responsibility for the Executive in the fiscal policies of the Connecticut State government is a very real possibility with a favorable report due early next week to the General Assembly on one of the major bills in the State reorganization program.

Mayor La Guardia's City Song Committee, appointed months ago to conduct a contest for the sel tion of a city anthem, announced yesterday that the date for receiving entries had been extended to July 1. The contest, for a $2,000 award, supposedly had been closed last Fall.

Both wings of organized labor-the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization-are united in the strong belief that the Supreme Court's decisions of last Monday on the National Labor Relations Act will prove an immediate stimulus to labor organization.
LENIN is, without question. the most outstanding and the most influential political figure to emerge from the upheaval of the World War.

AT press time Hollywood was still setting a record pace in recruiting stage personalities. More theatre people have turned to films in the current season than ever before. During the last week ten more signed up for pictures, and Beatrice Lillie and Fanny Brice were being besought by Universal to make it a round dozen. Katharine Cornell was still a holdout, however.

TBACK EVENTS 120-Yard High Hurdles--Won by Jerry Akerman, East Orange; Charles Rohrman, Jefferson, second; John Schroeter, Textile, third; B. Frankel, Evander, fourth; E. McCaffrey, Evander, fifth. Time--0:16. (New meet record: former record, 0:16.1, made by Akerman in 1936.)

The model home which will be the feature of the Rockville Center Building and Industrial Exposition, to be held from May 25 to June 2, on Sunrise Highway at North Forest Avenue, is now in its final phase of construction, according to the show's sponsors. It is expected to be opened for inspection on Mav 1.

INTEREST stirred by the exhibition of "Masters of Spanish Painting," current at the Pennsylvania Museum in Philadelphia until May 10, may be said to be three-fold. First, it is broadly illuminating as a survey, even though far from inclusive, that embraces a perspective of some five centuries.

A national appraisal forum to discuss appraisal data procurable from Federal agencies, private institutions and research bodies of various universities and foundations will be held in Washington, D. C., during September. The exact date and location of headquarters are to be announced later.

Making his first start of the season, Inshore, J. W. Y. Martin's entry in the thirty-eighth running of the Grand National point-to-point, got off on the right foot today, repeating his victory in the same race last year.

WELLINGTON, N. Z.--Figures now available on the first year of New Zealand's New Deal, inaugurated by the Labor Government elected in November, 1935, indicate that the number of State employes has been increased by some 3,600.
IN order to get a clear picture of the progress which has taken place in air transport flying since 1929, it is necessary to appreciate conditions as they were at that time.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hoffberg of 275 Central Park West of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beulah Hoffberg, to Leslie Handler, son of Mrs. George Handler of this city and the late Mr. Handler.

Unusual among the libraries of the State is the Palmer Memorial Library at Connecticut College. This collection, housed in a memoral room in the Palmer Library, represents the life hobbies of Elisha L. Palmer and George S. Palmer

Canada's way of handling labor troubles is in some respects different from that of the United States. Strikes in Ontario and Quebec, the two industrial Provinces of the Dominion, have been comparatively infrequent and relatively peaceful and orderly.

The New York State Assembly several weeks ago adopted a resolution to adjourn the current session on April 14. Sent to the Senate, the resolution was tabled. The wisdom of that move was apparent last week when April 14 came and went with many major problems still awaiting final action.

The four-story brick building at 165 W. 71st St. will be sold at auction by Henry Brady tomorrow. A brick, stone and stucco residence has been completed by the Lakeville Gardens Construction Co. at 27 Oakley Place, Little Neck, L. I., for Roger E. Warden.

An advance in scholastic rating over results of last year gave Ivy Lodge, a local club at Rutgers University, the lead in scholarship over all other campus fraternities for the first term of the present school year, Luther H. Martin, registrar, announced today. announced today.

Attorneys of the Works Progress Administration project known as the "Analysis of All Laws Affecting Real Estate," sponsored by Martha Byrne, New York County Register, have drafted three bills affecting real estate which were introduced in the State Legislature and are now in the committee on codes.

Marymount College will hold its eleventh annual May Day festival on the campus Sunday, May 2. Miss Sheila Egan, president of the student body, will be crowned queer by Miss Eleanor. McGrath, 'president of the senior class.

The two-story building at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-second Street, formerly occupied by Sherry's, has been sold by the Henry Phipps Estates to an investor, it was announced yesterday.

Many dinners will be given in advance of the annual Tip Top Ball in behalf of Stony Wold Sanatorium, which will take place on Friday in the Colonnades of Essex House, under the auspices of members of Auxiliary No. 5 of the sanatorium.
The Fordham University freshmen accounted for their second victory in as many games, halting Dickinson High of Jersey City, 8-7, at Fordham Field yesterday.

Miss Lidie Lee Sloan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew S. Sloan, was hostess last night at a supper in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Isabel Livingston Fountain, daughter of Mrs. Livingston Fountain of this city and Quogue, L. I., and George Frederick Brackett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Brackett of Ridgewood, N. J., who will be married next Saturday in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

No early marked change in the demand for farm products is expected and the general level of farm prices is not likely to change greatly during the next few months, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today in its report on the current demand and price situation.

The Mortgagees Realty Service, Inc., the real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company, reports the sale of approximately fifty dwelling properties since Jan. 1, as agent for various individual and institutional investors.

John W. Davis, president of the English-Speaking Union of the United States, announced yesterday the members of the general committee in charge of all plans for the union's Coronation dinner to be held Wednesday, May 12, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Kroll of Plainfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Else Kroll, to John Bayard Cuningham of Brooklyn Heights, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Cuningham of Hamilton, Ohio.

With retailers challenging the right of a trade group to fix discounts by agreement because "discounts are a part of price," and with boys' clothing manufacturers asserting they are moving to limit volume discounts to "justifiable savings" under the Robinson-Patman act in order to end "chaotic" conditions, a sharp conflict on trade terms appears in the making.
A. Q B. Genung, government economist, reported today that 66,000 farm families in the paths of the recentC Ohio and Mississippi River floods faced a huge job of rehabilitation.

A loan extended by the Railroad Credit Corporation to the New York Central Railroad, which originally stood at $5,700,000 and which was reduced to $2,400,762 in 1935, was cut further to $198,439 last year, according to the railroad's annual report.

Soviet concern over rising prices and slow deliveries of machinery and materials, especially steel and non-ferrous metals, ordered in England was shown again today in a statement by N. A. Bogomoloff, Soviet trade representative in England.

Western Oklahoma will have a bumper wheat crop, the first since 1931, Matthew S. Sloan, chairman of the board and president of the MissouriKansas-Texas Lines, predicted today after having made a four-day trip over the Katy's northwestern district, extending from Wichita Falls, Texas, to Keyes in the Oklahoma Panhandle.

Discussions are under way between officials of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and minority holders of common stock of the New York Steam Corporation, an affiliate of Consolidated Edison, for the acquisition of the remaining common shares of Steam now in private hands, it was revealed yesterday at the offices of the parent company.

FOR weal or woe, the motion pictures rank today as an important factor in popular education. Through eye and ear they make their impress on the mass mind. During their progress through slapstick and farce and melodrama, much of the comment on their cultural significance sounded a derogatory note. Today, however, the studios have shelved the custard pies and opened the classics. Of their own volition they choose to go in off the deep end.

The football teams of Columbia and Villanova battled through a three and one-half hour scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field and the Pennsylvania outfit had the upper hand. It was the second time this Spring that both squads met as part of their pre-season training.
Edward Allan Wood, New York Stock Exchange member of Pouch Co., 1 Wall Street, died on Friday night in a New York hospital after an illness of two months. He was 57 years old.

Tragedy for the whole of China, not merely for the head of the State and his indomitable wife, was very near last December. The imminence of outbreak of disastrous civil war becomes increasingly evident as the dramatic narrative of the kidnapping of General CHIANG KAI-SHEK, and his rescue by Madame CHIANG KAI-SHEK, is unfolded by these two creators of modern China in the current series of articles in THE TIMES.
Carl MacHenry of Atlantic Highlands was elected president this week of Tau Beta Pi Chapter of the National Honorary Society of Engineering Colleges at Stevens Institute of Technology.

Suggestions for arms reduction which Rickard J. Sandler, the Swedish Foreign Minister, has proposed placing before the disarmament conference bureau in Geneva May 5 are reported to be developing into a treaty between the countries

POETIC drama on the radio may suggest ancient pageantry; nevertheless it strikes a futuristic note in the opinion of broadcast showmen. Recently they tested the idea as an innovation by presenting Archibald MacLeish's "The Fall of the City"; they called it a milestone in the art of broadcasting.

In a letter urging economies to the heads of all government departments, President Roosevelt last week moved to reduce government expenses as a result of the unexpected slump in revenues for the fiscal year ending next June 30.

An unexpected showing of Senatorial courtesy inspired the Senate Judiciary Committee today to continue public hearings on President Roosevelt's Court Reorganization Bill for another ten days if witnesses could be found to give testimony.

Attor ney General Cummings announced today that a petition would be filed immediately with the Supreme sor Court for a review of the adverse decision made yesterday by the First Circuit Court of Appeals at Boston on the validity of both the unemployment insurance and old age benefit sections of the Social Security Act.
