The Army nine today celebrated its first visit to Yale in baseball history with an 8-to-5 victory on a wind-swept diamond before 3,500 fans. The visitors led, 2-1, in the initial inning; 3-2 in the third, and clinched the verdict with a four-run harvest in the fourth.

Support for the Brownell water grant bill now before the, State Legislature was given last week by the Twenty-third Street Association to State Senator William J. Murray, .chairman of the Committee on Affairs of the City of New York.

Although an increasing demand is noted for structural steel for buildings and other similar private work, highway construction continues to afford the chief market for such material, according to the American Institute of Steel Construction.

Endorsed by the National Youth Administration, a campaign designed to counsel Negro youth in regard to job opportunities and training will be conducted this week in 200 high schools and colleges for Negroes in fifty urban centers.

Miss Carol Elizabeth Tomlinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Harry Tomlinson of Maplewood, was married to Edward Henry Balevre Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Balevre of South Orange, this afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church, Montclair, by the rector, the Rev. James T. Lodge.

Miss Helen D'Olier, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Franklin D'Olier of 98 Madison Avenue, this city, was married to William Esty Stowell, son of Mrs. Donald Durant of New York and Cornwall-on-Hudson, this afternoon, in St. Peter's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. David K. Montgomery. It was followed by a reception at the bride's home.

Princeton University's Theatre Intime, in collaboration with the Theatre Arts Department of the Finch School of. New York City, will present Shakespeare's "Tempest" in McCarter Theatre the evenings of April 30 and May 1 as one of the highlights of the' annual Spring house-party week-end.

The wedding of Miss Helen Vreeland McEwan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick McEwan of The Holt at Convent, to Lewin B. Barringer, son of Mrs. Mareau Barringer of Philadelphia, took place this afternoon in St. Peter's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David K. Montgomery, rector, followed by a reception at the McEwan home.

Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas issued a note today explaining why Argentina had refused to cooperate with the committee of experts for the codification of international law, whose meeting at Washington April 5 adjourned because of Argentina's stand.

DIVISION I Boys, 6; New Utrecht, S Morris Schendelman, Boys, defeated Robert Schuster. 5-1; Charles Steinhardt, 5-3, and Julius Kulkin, 5--0; Irving Wexler, Boys, defeated Schuster, 5-3, and Kulkin, 5-2; William Hoppe, Boys, defeated Schuster, 5-4; Steinhardt, New Utrecht. defeated Hoppe, 5-0; Kulkin, New Utrecht, defeated Hoppe, 5-1; Bert Rosen, New Utrecht, defeated I. Smith, 5-4.

More than 400 members of the Greater New York Furriers Association held a dinner last night at the Hotel New Yorker to mark the tenth anniversary of the founding of the association. Speakers were H. J. Kenner, president of the Better Business Bureau of New York;
THOSE who have television sets saw the Dionne quintuplets scamper through the New York air during the past week from a film unreeled at the television station atop the Empire State Building.

Miss Ruth McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles McDonald, and Carl Lesring, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Lessing, were married tonight in the First Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. George G. Dunshee.

THE rude jangling of an alarm clock breaks the early Sabbath calm in many a metropolitan home and apartment these days. For the outdoors "specials"--those increasingly popular one-day excursion trains that speed the locomotive enthusiast, the fisherman, the bicyclist, the hiker and other sportsmen to playgrounds beyond the city's confines-are resuming their weekly runs. And you have to get up early if you want to get aboard.

The Mortgage Commission of the State of New York announced yesterday that by keeping up the premiums through the use of its fund of $100,000, provided for the purpose two years ago, it has saved at least $50,000 worth of mortgaged property from possible fire loss during the last two years.
THIS is the time of year when the trout fisherman goes through his day's work with a far-away look, which alternates with sudden starts of near panic.

Although the New York Anti-Vivisection Society is disbanding, Mrs. Diana Belais, one of the founders and the society's president for more than twenty years, presided again yesterday afternoon at the semi-annual animal hero awards in the South Garden of the Hotel Astor.
Frederick C. Lawyer of 30 Odell Av., this city, a New York attorney, and a descendant of President Martin Van Buren, died of a paralytic stroke in the Runnymede Hotel, Atlantic City, on Thursday.

Plans for Manhattan College's fifth annual Campus Day and the committees for this event, scheduled for May 2, were announced yesterday by Harold J. Swenson of Plainfield, N. J., president of the junior class, direction the program will be conducted.

Attention is called by the New York Taxpayers Association to the fact that many owners and janitors continue to turn off the lights in vestibules and alternate floors after 10 o'clock at night. The Multiple Dwelling Law requires that all hallways and vestibules be lighted from sunset to sunrise.

Seabiscuit, 2-5 favorite, owned by Mrs. Charles S. Howard of Sa?? Francisco, won the $10,000 adde?? Marchbank Handicap by thre?? lengths from Grand Manitou, with Sobriety third, at Tanforan today The time for the mile and a fu?? long was 1:484-5.

An architectural "field trip" through Northern Europe, visiting the important centers of great historic buildings between London and Moscow, will be conducted in July and August this year by the Harvard University Summer School.
TWO thousand chemists assembled last week at the University of North Carolina, in Chapel Hill, to participate in the ninety-third meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Governor Lehman renewed his demand upon the Legislature today for approval of his proposed $60,000,000 bond issue for permanent improvements. The Governor made his request in vetoing the McElroy bill to expend $325,000 for the construction of an armory in Syracuse.

The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today developments in concentration of phosphatic fertizers which hold promise of enabling farmers to halt erosion and restore fertility on millions of acres. By reducing the cost of phosphorus to farmers, it is expected to make possible greater use of this mineral plant food, deemed essential by TVA agriculturists to a sustained agriculture.

FOR years Fritz Kreisler has been familiar to record lists as virtuoso, composer and self-appointed ghost for long dead musicians. He now appears as first violin In a string quartet bearing his name and what is to be hoped is only its first recording is also his own (Victor album M-335).

The United States Fleet was "fighting" its way to the Hawaiian Islands tonight. Every hour is an hour of action. All units are engaged-the battle force, scouting force, aircraft squadrons, destroyer divisions, cruiser divisions, submarine divisions, minecraft and the base force of supply and repair ships.

Among the 1,075 passengers who sailed last night on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen for Channel'ports were' Mrs. Alvan T. Fuller, Miss Lydia Fuller, Count Robert de Cabry, Charles and Kathleen Norris, John R. Morrow, Professor Thomas Whittemore, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Herrick, Baron Friedrich Waitz, Devereux Milburn Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Hiter King, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Mixell, John Pannes and Sir Aldo Castellani.

A NEW gadget has been added to Japan's elaborate machinery for thought control. The Protective Surveillance Law provides aftercare for repentant Communists. It has been found that "thought criminals," once behind bars, are disposed to agree that Paris is worth a mass and liberty worth a timely renunciation of Marx and all his works.

Five thousand North Carolina teachers and students will gather in the stadium of Duke University next Friday to participate in a pageant celebrating the one hundredth birthday of public education in the State.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in a letter to Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of Namm's department store in Brooklyn, made public yesterday 1 the results of the recent police survey to determine the number of automobile accidents on streets with elevated railroad pillars as compared to casualties on other streets.
Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in an address today before the American Society of Newspaper Editors, opposed sit-down strikes.

It was with mingled sentiments that the National Labor Relations Board heard this week of the Supreme Court's validation of its organic law. There was relief from the tension and uncertainty that reflected itself in the board's administration of the law since the first challenge of its validity was brought more than a year ago.

The International Seamen's Union challenged yesterday the right of the National Labor Board to interfere in the factional fight between "insurgent" and "old guard" groups in the union. It declared that the agreement reached early Friday morning between the "insurgent" sailors' unions and the International Mercantile Marine was "illegal."

THE time is rapidly approaching when women will want sheer town frocks. Spring, especially in New York, seems short-lived. No sooner have the cherry blossoms in Central Park dropped from the branches than warm days are upon us.

French and English eighteenth century furniture, silver, eighteenth century Wedgewood jasper ware, Oriental rugs and other property will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday and Friday afternoons.

THE CONTESTANTS Brooklyn College--Miss Jean Marmorstein. Miss Elizabeth Bruskin, Miss Muriel Levitt. Miss Diana Kass. Miss Ruth Greenberg and Miss Clara Ziliette. Cornell University-Miss Carol Young. Miss Cynthia Kerr and Miss Geraldine Mason. Hofstra College--Miss Helena Mroczkowska, Miss Grace Bayer. Miss Dorothy Wahl. Miss Betty Lou Speakman, Miss Betty Davison and Miss Dorothy Steinberg.

Plans have been completed for the fourth annual Fashion Congress, to take place at the Bellevue-Stratford ballroom on Wednesday and Thursday for the benefit of the Reed Street Neighborhood House and Summer Camp for Children.
Major Gen. Douglas MacArthur and his aide-de-camp, Captain Thomas J. Davis, are at the Astor. Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Shaw Safe have come from Providence to the Pierre.
Bacardi rum now being produced in a branch plant in San Juan, Puerto Rico, will be brought into this market in the near future, according to officials of the Bacardi company.

Newton D. Baker, Scretary of War during the World War, said here tonight that "Europe is in a more dangerous situation than I have ever known it to be." "Not only is the danger of war greater, but the character of war promises to be much more savage," he added.
Some strange-looking channels, creeks and inlets are going to greet the cruising yachtsmen when next month they finish their fittingout and go to sea.

On their own applications. LIEUTENANTS--To take effect 12 midnight, April 18: John P. Crowley, 108th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Nov. 13, 1899. To take effect 12 midnight, April 19, Michael J. Cuozzo, Traffic Precinct P, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed June 16, 1909.

A blockfront building plot 200 by 100 feet on Polk Avenue between Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Streets, Jackson Heights, has been sold to Robert E. Simon Jr., for the erection of a one-story taxpayer with theatre and stores.
While there was general selling of wheat futures in foreign markets today, said to be additional liquidation by longs, the effect of the foreign decline on North American markets was limited.
A May Day festival under the auspices of the Girl Scouts of Greater New York will mark the opening of the Gardens of the Nations in Rockefeller Center on May 1.

A VERY significant exhibition of work by Edvard Munch is being held at Konstakademien, here in Stockholm. In addition to many of the old favorites by this Norwegian artist appear several canvases from his own studio home, Ekeby, in Oslo.

THIS city is preparing to observe next year the tenth anniversary of the death of Leos Janacek, most of whose operas received their first productions in the Bruenn Landestheater. This house will give a complete cycle of Janacek's works.

A plea for a certified building registry somewhat similar to the method of rating ships was made by Maurice Deutsch, New York engineer and architect, at the recent conference in Philadelphia of the National Association of Housing Officials.

More than fifty amateur photographers have entered prints in the exhibition of amateur photography for the benefit of the American Colony Charities Association, which will open Saturday in the art galleries of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue.

The English eighteenth-century furniture, tapestries, carpets and other objects of art sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries netted $24,810. The pieces were taken from various collectors,

W. Archer Coale, a food broker and former banker and real estate dealer, died at his home in Germantown yesterday in his fifty-first year. He was associated with T. A. Jones Co., food brokers, from 1919 until 1925 and then for two years served as president of the Security Title and Trust Company.

The security markets last week were dull and slightly higher; commodities were active but on the side of the decline. Stocks moved higher in the first half of the week and lost part of this advantage in the latter half, but regained, on the average, about half of the ground lost the week before.

New Jersey-Delaware Area The following infantry reserve officers are relieved from 37th Infantry and are released for assignment purposes to senior instructor and executive officers, Southern New York area: 1st Lt. Kenneth V. Coombes, care of Nicholas Copper Co.. Laurel Hill, N. Y. 1st Lt. John F. Hagen (C. H. A. P.), New York M. A., Cornwall-on-Hudson, N. Y. 1st Lt. Louis E. Klein. 919 Dinsmore Av., Far Rockaway, N. Y.

Mrs. Leonard Nelson. telephoned to the Chicago Maternity Center yesterday when she discovered she had not time to get to a hospital for the birth of an expected baby. The obstetrician in charge said he would send a physician,

A fire engine crashed into a fire insurance patrol truck in West Philadelphia today, the engine then hitting an elevated railway pillar with such force that the driver was killed and three other firemen were injured seriously. Two bystanders also were hurt.

The general goal of the government's fiscal policy in the next decade should be the reduction of the debt "by an average amount of at least $1,000,000,000 a year, taking good times and bad together," according to a special committee on government credit of the Twentieth Century Fund, 330 West Forty-second Street.

The Congress shall have power * * * to regulate commerce with foreign nations, and among the several States and with the Indian tribes. The meaning of this clause of the Constitution has been at issue almost since the day it was written, with the result that the power of Congress to regulate "interstate commerce" has become a perennial legal argument.

The ninth anniversary of "National Child Health Day" will be marked here on May 1 by a gala luncheon and celebration, to be held by the Child Welfare League of America in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Rumors or an impending Soviet-German rapprochement are branded by Vigilis, a Kremlin spokesman writing in today's Izvestia, as inventions inspired by Germans with the object of helping Germany obtain foreign credits for the purchase of food and war materials abroad.
Miss Lillie Louise Hetzer, dean emerita of the Lowthorpe School of Landscape Architecture here, died today at her home after a long illness. She was in her seventy-third year.
Dartmouth started its Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball campaign by defeating Pennsylvania on Franklin Field today, 5-3. Just a week ago the Red and Blue beat Cornell here.

Joey Wach, East Side featherweight, scored a technical knockout victory over Al Reid of the Bronx in 1:48 of the third round of the feature bout scheduled for eight sessions at the Ridgewood Grove last night.
ABOUT Woodrow Wilson the maker of history, libraries have been written. This book is different. As an eyewitness, a daughter describes

Legislation which the Securities and Exchange Commission will ask Congress to enact, extending Federal control to cover reorganizations, protective committees and the corporate trustee under indenture, was outlined today by W. O. Douglas, a member of the commission, before the Graduate School of Public Affairs of the American University and the Graduate-School of the Department of Agriculture.

Members of minority political groups, who met yesterday at the call of the New York Civil Liberties Committee joined in a telegram to Governor Lehman urging him to veto the Berg bills, which would make it more difficult to make independent nominations.

A gift to the Princeton University Library of an American Whig Socity diploma originally issued to David Ayres Depue, of the Class of 1846, of Newark, later Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of New Jersey, was announced today by James T. Gerould, librarian.

Free courses in journalism, short story writing, homemaking, cooking, health education, sewing and salesmanship are offered at Public School 11, 314 West Twenty-first Street, to persons over 17 years of age. These courses are conducted by the WPA-Adult Education Project.
Provisions for the prevention of tax avoidance in income tax statutes, carried to extremes, may tend to defeat the primary purpose of such legislation which is, of course, the production of revenue.

The Boerse closed firm today after a session of lively trading, both in stocks and in bonds. Almost all the principal stocks enjoyed gains, only I. G. Fargen in. dustrie and linoleums registering slight declines.

Miss Shirley Ludlam Woodward, laughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cedric R. Woodward, who will be wed to H. Fletcher Eggert Jr. of New York and Quogue, L. I.,. next Saturday, was the guest of honor at a "spinter's dinner" given tonight by Miss Carol Carpenter at her home In Louden Woods, Rye.

F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, announced yesterday that D. Owen Stephens, painter of astronomical subjects, and Dana K. Bailey, senior at the University of Arizona and a Rhodes Scholarship winner, have been added to the members of the Hayden Planetarium-Grace Exhibition, which will observe the June 8 eclipse of the sun from the coast of Peru.

The 1937 Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, which will meet at Williams College, Williamstown, Mass., this Summer, will discuss "Public Opinion in a Democracy," Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, director of the institute, announced yesterday.
Pan American-Grace Airways will inaugurate a new international service tomorrow between Santiago and La Paz, Bolivia, passing through the Argentine cities of Mendoza, Cordoba, Tucuman and Salta.

President Roosevelt today laid down a policy that English should be taught "with vigor, purposefulness and devotion" in the schools of Puerto Rico. His announcement of this policy was contained in a letter to Dr. Jose M. Gallardo, just appointed Commissioner of Education for the island.

AREMARKABLE concert consecrated to the works of Maurice Ravel was given in the Salle Pleyel by the admirable orchestra of the Philharmonic Society under the direction of M. Charles Muench. The "Rhapsodie Espagnole," "Valses Nobles et Sentimentales," the second hearing in France of Ravel's concerto for the left hand, and the choreographic symphony "Daphnis and Chloe" (given in its authentic entirety with chorus) comprised the program.
Pounding Paul Dean and Bob Weiland, the Browns turned the opener of a two-game "city championship series" with the National League Cardinals into a rout today, winning by 17 to 5.
Warmer weather having arrived and the soil being in good condition for planting, gardeners are losing no time in planting the seeds of the hardier annuals out of doors.

Eighteen New York City high houses schools have entered their newspapers in the sixth annual metropolitan press contest conducted by the Fourth Estate Club, journalism society of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East.

The Joseph H. Bearns award in musical composition, carrying a prize of $1,200, has been given this year to Roland J. Leich, instructor in music at Dartmouth College, whose string quartet in D flat major was selected as the best contribution in a nation-wide competition, judged by a committee headed
The cost of wheat has risen so high that bread is being made by the addition of corn flour. To maintain the price

Corn Belt farmers have been buckling down to Spring work with extra energy during the past week. They had to make up for lost time. Their normal schedule was upset by wet ground, the first time that has happened for several years.

COMEDIANS being notoriously serious fellows and Ed Wynn being one of the very gravest of the fraternity, he has been pondering long and deep on a theme for the musical show in which he will appear for Lee Shubert next season. Let it be reported this morning that the sum of his thinking is this: all the evils of the world--war, disease, everything--are susceptible to cure by laughter.

The erratic fluctuations in the raw cotton markets will continue until the early part of July, when the first government crop report will appear, according to opinions expressed by cotton-goods executives here yesterday. In the interim cotton will be affected chiefly by stock market developments and other outside influences.

BANKS--On April 16, 1937. In Duluth, Minn., J. Fisher S. Banks. husband of the late Alida Van Schalck Oddle. son of the late James Lenox Banks. M. D.. and father of Mrs. Frank C. Tenney of Duluth. Interment at Wappingers Falls. N. Y.

More money spent on education would help reduce the "terrific toll taken by criminals," County Judge Charles S. Colden of Queens said yesterday at a luncheon in honor of James P. Warren, who has been principal of Bryant High School for ten years, at the Hotel Pierre, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

THIS quaint Texas city, with crumbling seventeenth century missions basking in the sun against a backdrop of skyscrapers, is ready for Its annual Spring fiesta-the Battle of the Flowers and the Pilgrimage to the Alamo. The fiesta will begin at sundown on tomorrow and end at twilight on Saturday.

The marriage of Miss Gertrude Richardson, daughter of Mrs. John MacLaren Richardson of this city, to Thomas Leroy Bennett, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Orwin W. Bennett of Cincinnati, took place this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church of Bridgeport.

With a promise by State Senator Pierre J. Laramee to "blow the lid off this thing," a special legislative committee, armed with full powers to subpoena witnesses, opened an investigation today into the alleged maltreatment of young girls at the Windham County Temporary Home for Children.

The effort of the lower house of the Missouri General Assembly, with a preponderance of Democrats, to ride two horses simultaneously--loyalty to President Roosevelt and disapproval of some New Deal measures--has caused merriment among persons on the sidelines, who wonder just how far this game of politics can be played without some one's being seriously hurt.

ON May 14 Doubleday. Doran Co. will publish "The Supreme Court and the National Will," by Dean Alfange. This is the book that was awarded the $2,500 prize in the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Award Contest for the best manuscript dealing with a major aspect, international or national, of America and American life.
THERE is a stir, an air of suppressed excitement, as the workmen take up their tools in the brisk air of early morning on Monte Alban. Among the men the word is passed again:

EXPERTS who know well the value of the gems of philately that they have gathered with painstaking care over a long period from all parts of the world are preparing their choicest items for display in a series of stamp conventions and exhibitions to be held during the Spring and Summer months.

A traedition of Goucher College practically as old as the college will be followed again on Wednesday evening. A junior-senior banquet has been an annual event since before 1900 and has continued without a break except during the war years.
In building trades circles one of the questions which has been widely discussed for several months is that of a labor shortage in the construction industry.

A typical American home rented for the last twenty years has averaged about eleven different rental prices in that period and the tenant has paid "high" rents in more years than he has paid "low" rents, according to the Home Building and Home Owning Committee of the United States Building and Loan League.

Plans for a $4,000,000 expansion program were announced this week by the Westchester Lighting Company and the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company. The concerns are units of the Consolidated Edison Company, which granted funds for the work.

The season's first big catches of salt-water mackerel, now in the market, have sent prices trailing downward, according to the City's Consumers' Food Guide, more than 6 cents a pound. Freshly caught mackerel is available in retail stores at from 35 cents a pound in the "gold coast" areas of the city to 18 cents a pound in certain bargain belts.
THE civil war in Spain will mystify all who try to appraise it by the standards of the outside world or by study of superficial events there since the revolution of 1931.
The death of Jose Cancela, one of the partners in a well-known Havana resort (Sloppy Joe's), aboard the Hamburg-American liner Orinoco, tonight confronted police with a mystery.

Police decided today to make a radio appeal to the conscience of a pickpocket who stole an address book and more than 200 yen from the secretary of Helen Keller, blind educator, at Yokohama before she came here Thursday.

The prediction, occasionally heard nowadays in the grain trade, that if the season favors our harvests in 1937, the United States may resume its old position as a wheat-exporter, is a least interesting. Export in quantity of highpriced American wheat has been an outstanding event of this country's recovery from previous depressions. Precisely the opposite has occurred in this depression.

In the two weeks' period ending April 3, the certificates of automobile registration and licenses to drive in 7,11 cases were either revoked or :qspended, according to Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of motor vehicles. Of this number 240 will require proof of financial responsibility before new licenses wi'! be issued.

Haverford College, with a five-run attack in the seventh inning, today defeated Stevens Institute of Hoboken, 8--4. Stevens threatened in the eighth, but Ham Welbourn pitched himself out nicely, allowing only two runs.

FEW women writers have been the center of such intense controversy as Harriet Beecher Stowe. The author of the world's most famous propagandist novel, she was extravagantly praised for it by the anti-slavery and humanl tarian forces of her day and as bitterly excoriated by their opponents.

Honestly, the American League race has me up in the air this year and I am mighty glad. Two or three weeks ago it was my opinion that the Yankees, world champions, might make a runaway race of it again, but now I am not so sure.

IN days gone by a railroad station was just that and nothing more, but Raoul Dautry, director general of the French State Railways, has transformed the Gare St. Lazare (where most American tourists alight) into a diminutive city, with a transitory population of 300,000 souls a day.

The Progressive City Committee, an outgrowth of the Progressive committee that supported President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman for re-election, called upon Mayor La Guardia to run again at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The heritage of the past is the seed that brings forth the harvest of the future.--Inscription on the new Archives Building. ONSIDERABLE controversy seems to have been stirred up at Washington over the proposed Thomas Jefferson Memorial as designed by John Russell Pope, New York architect. The papers there are full of it.
Old shrubs with brand new features are heralded far and wide, while other old ones of charm and distinction go unnoticed year after year. year.

Hyman Green of the Brooklyn contracting firm of Green Co., reports that he has just completed the renovation of the old apartment building at 320-28 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, at a cost of $18,000, and that it is showing an annual rent roll of $9,500, averaging $10 a month per room.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was exceedingly dull with prices varying but little on a relatively light turnover. The market generally, however, was firm to slightly better with almost all classes of bonds participating, to some degree, in mild improvement.

The opening of the Promenade and Casino-on-the-Park of Essex House May 1 will aid the Child Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association. Various divertissements have been planned for the occasion including a special showing of children's fashions for park and sportswear. The committee has placed about 5,400 children in foster homes since its founding in 1898.

Members of the Chaminade, Brooklyn, of which Mrs. William A. Phillips is president, will give their annual breakfast on Saturday at the Hotel Astor. It will be preceded by a reception, and in the receiving line will be officers of the organization and guests of honor.

A national intercollegiate record was shattered, four other meet recwords were broken, the great Glenn Cunningham met defeat at his pet distance and the University of Indiana ran wild in the relay events as Midwestern and Southwestern track and field aces wrote

THE author of this book was born and brought up in the region of the Great Smoky Mountains, and she still spends part of every year rambling with her camera among the peaks and valleys and rounded woodlands of what is now our newest national park.

Walter L. Biery of 250 Bronxville Road, Yonkers, an executive of the McCall Corporation, publishers of McCall's Magazine, 230 Park Avenue, New York, died here this afternoon of a heart attack while playing golf on the course of the Leewood Golf Club. He was 45 years old.

Prefabricated housing as a factor in solving the low-cost housing problem has thus far not achieved its goal because it has been predicated upon the assumption that building supply manufacturers would limit production to standardsized equipment, according to the April issue of The Architectural

The Harvard freshmen nine took advantage of Exeter misplays early in the game today and won by a score of 8 to 5. Exeter made a three-run rally in the ninth when Harvard made three errors while timely hits by Thayer and Saunders accounted for the scoring.

The Tigers staged two big rallies in as many innings today and came from behind to defeat the Reds, 9 to 8, in the third game of their exhibition series. The victory gave Detroit a 2 to 1 advantage in the series, which concludes tomorrow in the Reds' first appearance in their home city.
A Pan-American exhibit will be held by Barnard students of Spanish on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday in the Riverside Building at Barnard College.

The fifty-first annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York will be opened on Wednesday evening at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. More than 400 architects and artists will be represented by sketches, plans, elevations, photographs, murals and sculpture.

Labor, wages and prices will be the subject of the seventh annual Economics Conference for Engineers at the Stevens Engineering Camp at Johnsonburg, N. J., from June 18 to 26, it was announced today by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology.
HOT SPRINGS Va.--The tournament season at Hot Springs gets under way to morrow with the qualifying round of the seventh annual Old Dominion Golf Tournament.

Although it was established only a few years ago, the Department of Archaeology of Hebrew University in Palestine already has amassed about 2,500 objects of historical and archaeological importance and its scientists are busily adding new items to the prized collection.
Richard Lunn, veteran Washington golfer, made a second-round come-back to win the thirty-six-hole final match of the Mason-Dixon Tournament today from Cincinnati's Albert J. Marshall. 5 and 4.

The passage by the House of Representatives on Thursday of the Gavagan bill, providing Federal punishment for officers surrendering prisoners to lynch mobs, climaxed a half century of agitation and organized effort for the enactment of Federal legislation to combat lynching.

Forty-five minutes from Broadway, or less, though he may live, the average high school boy or girl in New York City rarely goes to a professional play, according to a survey made public today by the research department of the WPA Children's Theatre.

Charging that Japanese interests are reaping many of the benefits granted American textiles as a result of the Cuban reciprocal trade agreement, cotton textile exporters last week appealed to Washington authorities to find some means of checking the re-export, as American goods, of Japanese textiles processed in the United States.
The University of Washington made a clean sweep today in its thirtyfourth annual regatta with the University of California, winning all three crew races by wide margins.

The marriage of Miss Eloise Wentworth Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Loring Lane of 395 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, I to Edwin Willis Hicks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hicks of Westbury, L. I., took place last night in the Clinton Avenue Community I Church in Brooklyn.
As long as the constitutionality and range of application of the Wagner act remained in doubt it was not thoroughly analyzed on its own merits. This was only natural.
Judge Merrill E. Otis, sentencing five men to prison and jail for vote fraud conspiracy, expressed the belief today that "somewhere beyond the polling place that day there were others more guilty."

A new six-year course in city planning, combining actual field work in various offices of local, State and regional planning boards with professional training, will be opened by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology next Fall.

One of the largest business sales in Jamaica, L. I., in some time has been closed in the purchase by a building syndicate of the northeast corner of Hillside Avenue and 169th Street, having a frontage of 150 feet on Hillside Avenue.

Underprivileged children aided by the Roosevelt Hospital Social Service Committee will be the beneficiaries of a rummage sale to be held by members of the organization on Tuesday at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue.
Dealers in chinaware report a big demand for "coronation china." But, strange to say, the call is for souvenirs of a coronation that will never take place, that of Edward VIII.
FOR some years the results of our American expedient of judicial review of the constitutionality of legislation have been the subject of wide public discussion.

HERE is a distinctive tale by the author of the wistful "Lightship." Archie Binns builds up his book by chains of episodes-short stories, descriptions and fragments of thought and action in series, leaving out everything in between.

RUBBER companies are accustomed to getting requests for adjustments on tires, but one just received from Brian Stack, 7 Mowbray Road, Edgware, Middlesex, England, by the B. F. Goodrich Company is amusing officials. It asks for an adjustment on tires that have been in service thirtyseven years, or since 1900.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Herbert Post Green of Forest Hills Gardens of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Natalie Green, to Lloyd Luther Maurer of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Maurer of BeloIt, Wis.
The Rev. Alfred Loaring-Clark, negotiator of two local strike settlements in as many days, contended today the church has a moral obligation "to denounce and attempt to correct obvious injustices."

Figuring that any change would be for the better after four losing starts this season, Coach Arthur Musicant of Brooklyn College started Ed Kleiner, freshman righthander, against Savage, and the result was a 9-3 triumph for the Kingsmen at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

If one may judge from the multitude of questions arising among amateurs concerning the role of humus in the garden, the lawn and the greenhouse, the conclusion is that to them the subject is obscure. Yet, in garden circles, humus is a word heard almost daily.

The committee on legislation of the Citizens Union announced yesterday its approval of the Desmond bill for competitive examinations for election inspectors, clerks and voting-machine custodians, and the Esquirol-Holley bill for rigid control of the advertising and sale of foods, drugs, patent medecines and cosmetics.

Whopper, Hal Price Headley's big bay horse, shouldering top weight of 122 pounds, had just enough left today to stave off the Araho Stable's New Deal at the finish and win the mile-and-a-sixteenth Philadelphia Handicap.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:
Trouble within the ranks of Premier Blum's unified Socialist party may lead tomorrow to a scission or exclusion of some "revolutionary elements" when the National Council meets at Puteaux.
Under the auspices of the Radcliffe Club of New York a lecture will be given by Lyman Beecher Stowe on "New Englanders Throughout America" tonight in the ballroom of the Women's University Club.

The volume of mortgage insurance issued by the Federal Housing Administration on homes in and near New York City has more than doubled in the first quarter of this year, as compared with the same period of last year, according to Thomas G. Grace, State director. Transactions for the whole State showed a ratio nearly as great.

A report assailing the liquor industry and the Federal administration for failing to keep promises to aid the cause of moderation, and calling on all Christian forces to unite in a third crusade for prohibition was adopted unanimously by the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at its session yesterday in Grace Church, 131 West 104th Street.

Two courses in real estate appraisal will be presented at Columbia University this Summer under the auspices of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers and the School of Business at Columbia, according to an announcement by John R. Hoyt, president of the New York Chapter of the institute.

Members of the Ladies Aid Society of the Lenox Hill Hospital will hold their annual card party in behalf of the charitable work of the hospital. on Tuesday afternoon in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE intelligent artist is always concerned with his relation to society; but in an age when loyalties are confused or feverish poverty may tumble him into a self-consciousness that is deadening he wears his work, and all the attitudes that go into it, like Coleridge's albatross.

Champion Briggus Princess, a magnificent airdale owned by Rinson Stiles of White Plains, N. Y., was adjudged best in show at the twelfth annual dog show held today under the auspices of the first company, Governor's Foot Guard Athletic Association in the State armory.

The sentence of a year and a day imposed on Louis Underwood Rountree, who has already served four months since his conviction for mail fraud, was reduced yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell.
One prime essential for the real estate appraiser in forthcoming years will be a knowledge of population trends and statistics, states the current issue of the Federal Home Loan Bank Review.

PEOPLE are forever popping in and asking, with a sixinch chip on their shoulders, what are my standards of criticism. They want to know what criteria I employ to justify blunt assertions that this direction in good, that performance bad, this script uneven. It is quite embarrassing, even when I do not have to answer truthfully.
S. J. (Slim) Scarborough, life-term killer who has escaped six times from Georgia chain gangs, surrendered to police today in his attorney's office here.

The countryside near here was shaken as if by an earthquake today when 300,000 tons of rock were ripped away in the John T. Dyer Company quarry at Monocacy in the first important test of nitramon, a new explosive described by experts as safer and more powerful than dynamite or nitroglycerin.

An assertion that the American Federation of Labor will not tolerate racketeering in any form was made today by William Green, its president, in announcing that charges alleging employment of "criminals, ex-convicts and racketeers" would be placed before the executive council during its meetings which open here on Monday.

FOREBODING: "I see a danger ahead that our people may become mechanized. I dread the mass mind, the growth of that materialistic view of life which is a danger to body and soul."--Prime Minister Baldwin.

Representatives of the Skating Club of New York carried off the premier honors in seven of the nine events at the Middle Atlantio figure skating championships at the Ice Club last night after Philadelphians had won the two junior individual crowns earlier in the day.

Based on closing bids of March 31, the net asset value behind the capital stock of the Spencer Trask Fund, Inc., was $22.58 a share, compared with $19.77 at the end of the previous fiscal year, after allowance for the New York State tax on unrealized appreciation, according to the annual report sent yesterday to shareholders.

In behalf of the Brooklyn Home for Aged Men and Couples a card party will be held on Thursday at the home, 745 Classon Avenue, Brooklyn. Mrs. J. Harry Alexander heads the group in charge of arrangements.

The first sound and motion "pictures" ever made of the brain in action, which make visible audibly projected equivalents of certain functions in the brain of a living animal, were shown here last week before a large audience at the American Museum of Natural History.

Construction has been started at Vineland, N. J., on a new twostory building, on a plot 233 by 290 feet, which will house the Kimble Glass Company, manufacturer of glass tubing and chemical and pharmaceutical glassware.

Pleading in behalf of Catholic Charities, Alfred E. Smith declared yesterday that "the obligation of the corporation is just as binding and just as serious as the obligation of the individual" to contribute to the annual fund campaign which starts today.

Almost lost sight of during the prolonged controversy which led up to the deadlock between Governor Lehman De and the Republican legislative leaders over his revenue program, the Republican bills which still await action will be placed before the Assembly and pushed in the days that remain of the session.

TRADITIONS die hard in Provence. This explains why Saint Sarah's pilgrimage, which originated in the eleventh century, will be staged once again on May 24 and 25 in this quaint old village on the Mediterranean.

The award of nineteen grants, with a total value of $19,200,-by the committee on research of the American Philosophical Society has been announced in advance of the society's general meeting here next Thursday to Saturday.
The strike-troubled Colonial Press, Inc., which employs 550 persons and has a $500,000 yearly payroll, closed its plant today and prepared to move to New York City.

As the election campaign approaches its climax it is developing Gilbertian qualities. Comparisons drawn with American party struggles or efforts to estimate the contest in terms of Democratic, politics in other countries get nowhere.

Club women of the metropolitan district will be engaged tomorrow and Tuesday with their Spring conferences, at which directors of the New York State Federation will be elected. The second district gathering will be at the Great Neck Woman's club tomorrow-an all day affair with luncheon at the clubhouse.

The body of a boy about 15 years old, found floating at 8 o'clock last night in Brady's Pond, Grassmere, S. I., by two fishermen, remained unidentified at the Stapleton morgue, although the police believed it was that of William Wilcox Jr., 15, who disappeared from his home at 256 Gordon Street, Stapleton, on March 19.

ALEXANDER. LOUISA G. (March 13). Estate. less than $5.000. To Gertrude Heitler and Virginia Bardes. great-grand,nieces, 132 WV. Merrick Road. Merrick. L. I., and Gertrude L. Miller. 650 Palisade I Av.. Jersey City, N. J., one-third residue each. Mary De Nardo. 507 E. 87th St., and Mae Heitler, 133 XV. Merrick Road. Merrick, L. I., executors.

Miss Sarah Louise Fairfax, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Fairfax, was married here to W. Hall Harris 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Hall Harris Jr., this afternoon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Dr. Arthur B. Kinsolving, the rector, was followed by a reception at the residence of Mrs. William Hilles in Guilford.

Three American citizens of foreign birth will receive awards for their "significant contributions to American life" at the second dinner of awards of the National Insti. tute of Immigrant Welfare at the Hotel Biltmore next Thursday night.
The second and last for this season of the After-Dinner Dances, a subscription series for young martried couples and former debutantes, took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

For the third time in six weeks, burglars cut a window early yesterday morning at the Famous Fairsex, Inc., a dress and fur shop at 473 Fifth Avenue, directly across from the public library, removed several silver fox skins and escaped.

AS Spring now comes of age in New York's latitudes, nature's chorus of greeting approaches a crescendo. The lately scattered chirps of robins in sidewalk maples resolve into a fabric of sprightly song.

IN this brilliant pastiche Angela Thirkell has blended fiction and actuality so successfully as to produce a picture of early Victorian England, particularly of the coronation year. 1838, that would be very hard to beat for charm and verisimilitude.

Miss Alice Depew, daughter or Dr. Arthur Depew of East Orange, was married today to Robert Mauriello, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Mauriello of Orange, in Hillside Presbyterian Church, Orange, by the Rev. Dr. John A. MacSporran.

Richard L. Healey of Paterson, N. J., was elected chairman of senior week activities in Fordham College, it was announced yesterday. Healey, a member of the football squad for the last three years, will be in charge of all activities of senior week, beginning June 13,

The Acme Steel Company and subsidiary reported yesterday a net profit of $1,094,941 for the first quarter of this year, after deducting depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, surtax on undistributed earnings and other charges.

Several of the important problems confronting realty interests for the coming year were discussed by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, before the apartment house group of the management division of the board recently.

National Council of State Garden Clubs annual meeting takes place in Cleveland on May 25, 26, 27 and 28 at Wade Park Manor. On the evening of May 24 a meeting of the committee of eleven of the executive board will be held.

The John A. Savage Company of Duluth, Minn., which has operated in the Lake Superior region for twenty years, will begin in August the installing of machinery on Kooland Island in Yampo Sound for mining iron ore. It will employ 200 Australians.

Miss Jean Isabelle Daniels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Daniels of this city, was married tonight to R. Gray Aitchison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Aitchison, also of New Rochelle, in the First Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Robert R. Hartley, the pastor, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Robert Gardner McGregor, pastor of the North Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Gross revenues of the Seaboard Air Line Railway in March were about $4,500,000, against $3,686,000 in March, 1936, according to R. Parke Jones, chief finance officer. Net operating income was about $890,000, against $504,000. Railway statements for February follow:
Fifty arrests have been made as a result of Thursday's clash between Socialists and Henleinists in the Northern Bohemian town of Niedergrund.

The Board of School Trustees voted unanimously last night, it was learned today, to let churches of each recognized denomination use the new $1,000,000- school building here one afternoon each week to inculcate moral precepts in the minds of the youth of Haverstraw.

THIS provocative book, first published in England, was written primarily for the British public. It is a clarion call to British imperialists to challenge Japan's claim for paramount influence in Asia. "Japan is putting up a big bluff to the world," Dr. Utley begins.

RETAIL trade moved last week into a period which compared with post-Easter a year ago and, while some sections reported sizable gains, there was more than one- area where it was admitted that business was not "up to expectations."
Busy "blue carders." American Federation of Labor members now, set themselves tonight for a gay week-end in the tri-State lead and zinc area, beset last Sunday with labor strife.

Five persons were drowned in the Wabash River south of this city today when an automobile in which they were riding got out of control and plunged from a ferryboat into the river. The dead are Peter Milam, his wife, Mrs. Blanche Milam,

Recent Spanish Loyalist victories will be celebrated and the "Italian and German invasion of Spain" will be assailed at a mass meeting at the Hippodrome at 2 P. M. to lay. The meeting has been called by the North American committee to aid Spanish democracy,

The performance of "Miss Quis" on Wednesday night at the Henry Miller Theatre has been taken over by members of the Brooklyn divisions of Ivriah to raise funds for the Ivriah Kindergarten and Scholarship Endowment Fund of Ivriah, the women's division of the Jewish Education Association.

Any adventurous person who wants to get thrills or moving picture and book material out of Ecuador's wilds hereafter will have to pay for the privilege. There are still about 171,287 square miles of wild territory in the country that have never been visited by white men

Carleton Beals, well known author, resigned formally today from the subcommission of inquiry investigating the Moscow charges that Leon Trotsky conspired with Germany and Japan against the Soviet Union.

Miss Doris Dautrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Dautrich of Milford, Conn., was married to Aynsley Tweddell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Tweddell of Plandome, at noon today in All Saints Episcopal Church here by the rector, the Rev. Alexander McKechnie.

With the celebration this week of the centenary of the kindergarten, educators in effect are honoring the beginnings of progressive education. For it was with the kindergarten movement, which came to us from Germany, that the conception of education as individual development started in this country.

Briggs Cunningham expertly handied his new American six-meter yacht Lulu today to win the King Edward VII Challenger Cup match race, defeating Eldon H. and Kenneth F. Trimingham's Saga, the Bermuda entry, by twenty-one seconds over a nine-mile course.
One is so accustomed to think of Spain as a battlefield that it is worth while for once to halt and consider that some ninety-nine one-hundredths of the peninsula is outside the fighting zone.

The Rev. Dr. James Shepard Kittell, for the last ten years secretary of the Board of Domestic Missions of the Reformed Church in America, died yesterday at his home, 37-28 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, of the effects of a stroke suffered on Tuesday morning. He was 64 years old.
A student conference this morning with Dr. Alexander Meiklejohn, former Amherst College' president, who spoke last evening on "The Classical Theory of Education and the Pragmatic Revolt Against It,"

The current system of financing improved real properties through short-term mortgages which customarily, at maturity, are extended for a further short period in consideration of a slight reduction in the principal, should be reformed according to Daniel A. Brener of Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc.
Early returns today indicated an exceptionally heavy registration of women eager to achieve permanent women's suffrage in the Philippine Islands. Today was the last day

FRANZ WERPFEL was asrounding the public with his virtuosity at 20, and during the quarter century that has since elapsed he has produced at least thirty-five distinct volumes--novels, collections of short stories and poetry, and plays.

Under the direction of the House Plan, the social activities center at City College, a coordinated unit with representatives at Brooklyn College and Hunter College will sponsor a ball at the Mecca Temple Casino on May 7 to celebrate the ninetieth anniversary of the founding of the college.
ONE hundred and fifty miles below the Rio Grande. A different world, different people, strange costumes, Old World habits, primitive modes of transportation.
Stocks steady in slowest trading for a Saturday since August; turnover, 444,100 shares. United States Government isues higher in quiet trading, other bonds firm; transactions $5,314,800.

Hammering eight doubles, three triples and three home runs, the Pirates today had a field meet at the expense of the Springfield Western Association club, winning by 27 to 5. The victors made thirty hits.

THE Everglades jungle, sprawling over 2,500 square miles across the southern tip of Florida, commanded new attention last week as representatives of the Federal Government arrived to give the area further consideration as a national park that would be second only to Yellowstone in size.
Six one-family bungalows in the Hollywood Homes development at Kings Highway and East Fiftyfirst Street, Brooklyn, were reported sold last week.

With eight weeks of intensive training completed along a front that extended from Cuba in the Atlantic to Catalina in the blue Pacific and swept as far South as Mexico City, the sixteen clubs comprising baseball's two major leagues
Receipts from delinquent taxpayers for the first nine months of the current fiscal year were $171,994,729, or about $19,000,000 more than a year ago, according to the Internal Revenue Bureau.

Twenty-seven members of the senior class of Blakely High School were on their way to Washington today in a bus, which they purchased because they did not have enough money to take the long-planned trip any other way.

Present neutrality legislation was critIcized at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science today by William R. Castle, former Under-Secretary of State, as strongly contradicting the State Department's policy of building up "friendly international trade," as adding nothing to neutrality and as striking at the developing rules of international law.

THE big, dull problems of the movie industry, those in the solution of which the really important money lies, are much the same the world over. Australia and New Zealand, for example, have kangaroos, Bushmen, emus, wild dogs, boomerangs and Maoris--as promised in the tourist catalogues--but they also have the antipodean equivalent of a Hays office, a joint organization presided over by Sir Victor Wilson, a former Minister of the Commonwealth.

Forecasts of the chances of their teams were made yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the managers of the three local major league baseball clubs. The statements of Bill Terry of the Giants, Joe McCarthy of the Yankees and Burleigh Grimes of the Dodgers follow:

Conditions in major commodity markets and the trends likely to develop in the course of the Summer months will be the major topics for consideration at the twenty-second annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents in Pittsburgh, May 24 to 27, it was announced here yesterday.

Great Britain is determined to tolerate no cruelty to animals, even rubber on The cinematograph films (animals) bill, awaiting a third reading in the House. of Commons, will prohibit production of such films depicting or purporting to depict suffering of animals, either at the hands of humans or in wildlife conflict.

Completing the first systematic study of forty-four tablets in the Yale Babylonian collection, the largest in the United States, Professor O. Neugebauer of the University of Copenhagen has carried the history of mathematics fifteen centuries beyond Greek culture.
Osaka Geisha Girls, Inc., including many of the. entertainers who recently staged a Buddhist temple sitdown strike, held its first stockholders' meeting today in solemn parliamentary manner.

A new series of Canadian coins will be minted this year, with the likelihood of getting into circulation soon after the coronation, Finance Minister Charles Dunning has announced. The denominations will range from 1 cent to $1.

Thomas F. McMahon, State Director of Labor, announced tonight after several hours of conference that an agreement had been reached which ended a strike of several weeks at the American Silk Spinning Company.

CLAUDIUS THE BEE" is a delightful and original book that starts off and continues at a lively pace. The story begins with Mr. Tawney, a youthful gardener, who has a natural bent for helping animals, having discovered that they do all manner of silly things to get themselves into trouble. There were creatures of all sorts about the garden and sometimes Mr. Tawney was kept very busy.

Thomas Jefferson, who was upsetting Washington 136 years ago this Spring by the social informality of his regime at the White House, is the center of an equally intense 1937 emotional storm over a question of strictly formal decoration.

David Dudley Field of New York has deeded to the Laurel Hill Association of Stockbridge, the oldest village improvement society in the United States, a six-acre tract of land on the western slope of Prospect Hill as a memorial to his great-grandfather, the Rev. Dr. David Dudley Field, minister of the Stockbridge Congregational Church from 1819 to 1837 and author of "Field's History of Berkshire County," published in 1829.

Sweeping all of its bouts, Stuyvesant High School continued its domination of Division 1 by blanking Richmond Hill High, 9-0, in one of seven team matches in the P. S. A. L. fencing championships at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium yesterday morning.

HE lives in every farming county of the United States, a nation whose biggest industry is agriculture. With three million others in the same fix as himself. he makes up more than half of the total number of workers in that industry.
Summer schools throughout the country generally will show increased enrollments this ye?? Henry G. Arndorf, registrar of New York University, predicted yesterday.
THE storm that swept King Edward VIII from his throne last December was started by an apparently casual criticism from the Bishop of Bradford.
Six persons were killed and four others injured in a collision of an automobile and a truck at Keck's Corners, forty miles east of here.

The Onario Department of Mines will lake geographical studies of sixeen ore zones in the Province this ear; ten in the northwestern secion and six in the eastern. Sixtywo men will be attached to the survey project, the largest undertaking of its kind yet attempted by the rovincial government.

TO a certain group in the United States and other parts of the world the hobby of hobbies is astronomy. Many enthusiasts construct their own instruments of far-flung vision and even grind and polish the lenses and mirrors for their telescopes. With about $10 worth of materials one can build an instrument that in definition and power compares favorably to a telescope costing much more. Spring is the time when they get busy.

About 330,690 acres in Arizona, comprising "a desert country so waterless and formidable that it has rarely been visited by white men" has been made a perpetual government preserve by proclamation of the President.

Hard-pressed defenders of the Basque country tonight mowed down Insurgents who tried to push through Eibar, a vital point in General Emilio Mola's line of march against Durango and Bilbao. Heavy casualties resulted when the Basques stopped the attack with artillery and machine-gun fire.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association, representing more than 5,700 department, dry goods and specialty stores, has become a member of the American Standards Association, it was announced here yesterday.

Milk, after it has gone through certain processes, is no longer an "agricultural commodity" but a "manufactured product," according to a definition published today by the Bureau of Motor Carriers of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
A conference on "The Objecties of the Junior College" will be held at Centenary Junior College next Saturday to mark the seventieth anniversary of the granting of a charter to the institution.

The increased popularity of the Supreme Court among the sightseers who visit Washington is a constant source of wonder to Frank K. Green, who has been marshal of the Supreme Court for twenty-two years.

Counsel to Ellis H. Parker, Burlington County detective, and his son, Ellis H. Parker Jr., agreed this afternoon to stop their efforts to prevent the trial of the Parkers and three co-defendants in the United States District Court in Newark.

VISITORS to the Paris Exposition will benefit by the measures of a new bill adopted by the French Chamber of Deputies providing for government stabilization of hotel and restaurant prices. The measure will regulate prices not only in the first-grade hotels but also in the smaller but acceptable inns and possibly also in the city's many boarding houses.

The Philadelphia Germans, national soccer champions, who will be supplanted today by the winner of the East-West Cup final at Starlight Park, battled for ninety minutes on the same field yesterday to a 0-0 draw with the Brookhattans in their American League fixture.
Paris banks inaugurated a five-day banking week today with large signs on bank doors informing customers that all departments would be closed every Saturday.

Thomas E. Colleton, State director of the FHA in New Jersey, reported yesterday on the occasion of the end of his second year in that position that the FHA insured mortgage business in that State has increased from 500 cases, totaling about $2,500,000 in 1935, to 15,000 mortgages, totaling $75,000,000 at present.

Timed by the flowering of the Japanese cherry trees along the Tidal Basin in the national capital, the first of the two annual excursions under auspices of the Catholic Young Women's Clubs left New York yesterday for a week-end in Washington. A smaller group of twenty-five members of the Outing Vacation division of the Carroll Club also departed in buses for the same destination.

Nineteen States have adopted legislation providing for participation in the New York World's Fair of 1939, Grover A. Whalen announced yesterday. Missouri leads the list in the amount of funds provided with an appropriation of $250,000.

Necessity for a balanced program of driver education and control is stressed in this paper, by the director of the Public Safety Division of the National Safety Council, which he presented at last week's convention of the Greater New York Council.

" The pronounced trend away from special concessions to larger buyers is unquestionably resulting in the rehabilitation of the independent store," according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

THE "Kingdom of Reason" holds within itself the pervasive and charming quality of a fairy tale. And it is not the least characteristic of the paradoxes of Denmark that in its most fairylike aspects it remains wholly logical and clear: even practical.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James T. Grady of 420 Riverside Drive of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Patricia Grady, to the Rev. John William Hammons, son of the Rev. and Mrs. J. Daniel Hammons of Little Rock, Ark.

BLUNIBERG--KOHEN -- Mrs. Belle H. Kohen, Amityville, L. I., announces the engagement of her daughter, Carol S., to Eugene J. Blumberg, formerly of Detroit, Mich. BRAND--MARKUS--The engagement is announced of Miss Buddy J. Markus, daughter of the late Charles and Ernestine Markus, to Mr. Jesse E. Brand, son of Mrs. Sarah Brand and the late Herman S. Brand.

Both the doubles and distance championships of the New York Athletic Club were decided in 100-target events at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. In the doubles shoot the title was annexed by C. W. Phellis, who broke 97.
THE TIMES reports that Idano's game warden is directing a drive of extermination against the golden eagle, because of its alleged depredations against sheep and game.

Since announcing her determination to discard the role of a mere pawn in the game of European politics, little Belgium suddenly finds herself ardently wooed by the Reich, whose statesmen have promptly read into their western neighbor's new foreign political orientation a development presaging practical benefits to Germany.

In their rejoicing over the Supreme Court's upholding of the Wagner Labor Relations Act, spokesmen for C. I. O.'s Steel Workers Organizing Committee say that so far as the steel industry is concerned the ruling will simply hasten the company union on its "inevitable way out."

The Princeton nine today won its eighth successive victory of the season when it beat Harvard, 10 to 4. behind the four-hit pitching of Dick Bell, who last Monday held Penn State to just a pair of bingles. The Tiger victory was all the sweeter because it was its first registered against a Crimson nine since early in 1926.

One of the few streamlined trains to be built in a railroad's own shops will be placed on exhibition by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad at the Jersey City terminal of the Central Railroad of New Jersey Wednesday.

Miss Gertrude Marie Henderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Henderson of this vilage, was married this morning to Paul J. Mulcahy, son of Mrs. Davis B. Mulcahy of Newark and the late Mr. Mulcahy.

Mrs. Charles de Kay will give a reading from the manuscript of her new book, "Adventures of a Young Wife in the Nineties," Tuesday afternoon at the home of Miss Sarah Diodati Gardiner, 3 East Eightysecond Street.

Members of society here as well as prominent Italians living in New York are among the sponsors of a gala supper dance to be given by members of the Italy America Society and the American Society of the Royal Italian orders on Wednesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the Italian Ambassador, Fulvio de Suvich, and Mrs. de Suvich.

Anderson hit a homer over the leftfield embankment in the first inning today, driving three Navy runners across the plate ahead of himself to feature the middies 8-2 victory over the University of Michigan.

Mrs. Margaret Pease Loder, wife of George E. Loder, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday at her home here. Born in Berkeley, Calif., Mrs. Loder had been a resident of Montclair for the past fifteen years. She was a member of the Montclair Women's Club and the College Women's Club.

An exhibition of Japanese flower arrangements under the auspices of the Japanese Women's Club of New York, of which Mrs. Rioichiro Arai is president, will be held Thursday afternoon at the Nippon Club, 161 West Ninety-third Street.

Georgetown University celebrated its 148th Founders Day anniversary tonight by conferring an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws upon Manuel Luis Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, before a distinguished throng of diplomats and alumni.

Parades, oratorical demonstrations, peace assemblies and symposlums are scheduled for the antiwar strike next Thursday morning at 11 o'clock. This day has been set aside by various student organizations as a protest against war.

The golden anniversary meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the annual meeting of The Associated Press which precedes it will bring to New York City this week more than 500 of the leading newspaper publishers, editors and business managers of the United States and Canada.

The three-story dwelling at 69 West Ninety-fourth Street, on a plot 20 by 100.8 feet, will be sold on Friday in the Vesey Street auction rooms by B. Hollander Son.

With a barrage of two-base drives to left field in the ninth the Lehigh Engineers swamped Ursinus College today, 14-5. Five--all in the sixth, the game blew up in the last three innings when Coach Allen's batsmen began to open up on Zoll's offerings, scoring six runs in the last inning.

Miss Marjorie Kay Lucas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Lucas of this place, was married this afternoon to Henry Leavitt of Bryn Mawr, Pa., son of Mrs. Harry Leavitt of Sharon Hill, Pa., and the late Mr. Leavitt.

An expansion in all forms of traffic on the ships of the Gdynia America Line, which operates under the Polish flag in the transatlantic service, was noted in 1936, according to a report submitted to the Department of Commerce. The company operates the motor liners Pilsudski and Batory between Gdynia and New York.

With word reaching London that Captain "Potato" Jones of the ship Marie Llewellyn had given up his attempt to break through General Francisco Franco's Spanish Rebel blockade of Bilbao and had left Saint-Jeande-Luz, France, James Maxton and Fenner Brockway of the British Independent Labor party announced tonight they had obtained an option for the purchase of a ship to carry food to Bilbao.

Hughes of Champaign, Ill., to Tirana, Albania, as consul and second secretary; orders to Teheran canceled.
