Georgetown University celebrated its 148th Founders Day anniversary tonight by conferring an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws upon Manuel Luis Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, before a distinguished throng of diplomats and alumni.
Hunter College's formidable array of duelists last night accomplished what no other team has been able to do in the nine-year history of the Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association championshiDs.

Kansas City's annual Spring cleaning will begin May 3 and last until May 13. During the ten-day period, clubs, schools, churches and civic organizations as well as individuals will join to give the city a spic and span look to harmonize with the beauty of budding flowers and growing foliage.

With Jersey City again represented in the circuit after a lapse of several years, the International League baseball season is scheduled to get under way on Thursday afternoon with games slated at Jersey City, Newark, Syracuse and Baltimore.

Darien High School students have resorted to motion - picture production of school activities, with candid "shots" of pupils and teachers alike, as a means of what George Tyler, a senior, termed the school's way of "presenting its wares to the world."

Imminent departure of a New York delegation of twenty-five for the twentieth convention and American Music Festival of the National Federation of Music Clubs corroborates the country-wide interest in the event opening at Indianapolis this week, which in spite of unprecedented difficulties will draw, it is predicted, an attendance of more than 5,000. Musical personages from this section are scheduled to converge on the Midwestern capital also for program appearances.

There is every week just now new confirmation in the diplomatic world of Europe that the victory of the Spanish Government troops at Brihuega in driving back the encircling movement around Madrid of the Italian contingent among General Francisco Franco's forces was of major importance.

Miss Anne Kirkham Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Wait Lord of 238 East Sixty-eighth Street, was married in the chapel of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square, yesterday afternoon, to Wolcott Erskine Andrews of this city and Wiscasset, Me., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Martin Andrews.
Four additional endowed citizens medals of valor will be awarded this year to members of the Fire Department, Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday.
With the arrival of the season when industrial corporations and business firms scan the college campuses for promising recruits from the graduating classes,

The Duchess of Atholl, Conservative member of the British House of Commons, and Miss Ellen C. Wilkinson, Laborite member, were sitting with friends in a hotel dining room here when a shell burst during today's Insurgent bombardment.

In summarizing today the points which the Supreme Court's decision on the Wagner National Labor Relations Act established, The Washington Review, weekly publication of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, pointed out that "various rights of employers have not yet been passed upon."

Harold D. Walker, Boston architect, died suddenly today at his home here in his fiftieth year. A native of Brookline, he was the son of the late C. Howard Walker and Mary Louise Huckins Walker. He was graduated from Harvard in 1909 and from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1911.

Miss Mina Ballard Curtiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard C. Curtiss of Darien, was married this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church here, to C. Frederic Underwood, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence F. Underwood. The Rev. Dr. George Stewart, the minister, performed the ceremony.
The airship Hindenburg will make eighteen trips to the United States this Summer, establishing weekly transatlantic service from May to October, it was announced today.

The Torrington Company, manufacturer of certain equipment and appliances for sewing machines, bicycles and automobiles, has withdrawn an appeal in the Federal courts from an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission and has consented to the publication of data concerning salaries of executives, for which it had asked confidential treatment in registering its securities under the Securities Act of 1934, the SEC announced today.

The positive achievements of the tripartite technical conference on the textile industry, which has been in session here for two weeks and ended today, were described in glowing words at the final session by John G. Winant, chief of the American delegation;
Higher transpacific passenger rates and possibly freight tariffs will be seriously discussed at a meeting of Transpacific Conference members at Del Monte Monday.
Word was received here last night of the death yesterday in the Monson Hotel, St. Augustine, Fla., of Albert Potter Wills, who had been Professor of Mathematical Physics at Columbia since 1909.
FOR use of the "ether" waves broadcasting stations will be taxed if Congress adopts a plan proposed by George Henry Payne of the Federal Communications Commission.
Reports from Tirana, Albania, state that the Consul and First Secretary of the United States Legation, Benjamin Reath Riggs, was the victim of a somewhat mysterious accident.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Eugenia Crane, daughter of Mr. and' Mrs. J. Einest Crane of this city, to George Bishop Marshall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bishop Marshall of Glassboro, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Earl Ledden of Providence, R. I., uncle of the bridegroom.

MODERN travel offers facilities to satisfy the traveler's most exotic whim. Time was when New Yorkers soothed their Daniel Boone yearnings with timid excursions to Palisades Park, but today they get a better break.

The world's gold production increased 204 metric tons since 1934, when the United States raised the price to $35 an ounce, according to an estimate published today in the League of Nations monthly statistics bulletin. It gives the 1936 total as 1,050

To the Editor of The New York Times: The announcement of the Open Market Committee that it is prepared to support the bond market comes as a shock to the observer of recent monetary events. First, the administration embarks upon an expansionist policy, which, together with the policy of public spending, probably contributed greatly to recovery.

A makebelieve coronation procession, complete to the gilded coach of state, will file through London streets early tomorrow morning. It will be the first of two important rehearsals for the crowning of King George May 12.

To the Drama Editor: While the, WPA Federal Theatre Project is indeed grateful to Archibald MacLeish for his favorable reference to the WPA theatre in his article on the poetic drama printed in THE TIMES of April 4, I think it not amiss to point out the several errors of fact, obviously unintentional, which appeared in the piece and which lead to an inaccurate picture of the project.

Alfred Turner Wells of Southbridge, Mass., has applied to the Governor in Council for permission to purchase an acre of property for residential purposes on St. David's Island, adjoining and overlooking the waters of Castle Harbour. Richard Alden Stevens of Hartford, Conn., desires to buy property in Pembrooke Parish.

The War Department released the following orders today dated April 16: MAJOR GENERAL Sunderland, A. H., Chief of Coast Artillery. three days leave. April 20. BRIGADIER GENERALS Merrill, D. T.. one month and fifteen days leave, June 1. Humphrey, C. F. Jr.. Fort Francis E. Warren Wyo.. to command Third Brigade, Fort Sam Houston, Texas, about June 30.

Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Goldsmith Carter of 1,440 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stella Rae Carter, to Alvah Weeks Haff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvah C. Haff. also of Brooklyn.

THE inception of the Popular Front regime in France let loose new forces that are vitalizing the moribund French movie industry. Labor's victories have given impetus to organization and unionization in the cinema. Film groups have sprung up, catering to the needs of the film-going public and film workers.
Students of the College of New Rochelle will debate the acceptance of President Roosevelt's court reorganization bill with three graduates of Fordham Law School Monday evening at the college here.

Federal intervention in lynchings, as approved by the House of Representatives in Washington, is hailed by the Brazilian press as "civilization's victory." In the past, lynchings have been to Europe's subsidized press the "plate du jour" in its anti-American campaign in Latin America.

The nation's farmers are not getting their historic percentage of the national income because "they haven't been able to grab off as much of the Federal power as the corporations or labor unions," Secretary of Agriculture Henry Wallace declared yesterday.

During the past two years there has been a considerable increase in the manufacture of electric fans in India and three new factories were established in 1936, bringing the total to ten, according to American Trade Commissioner George C.

The 102-acre estate, known as the Priory, of Colonel H. Stanley Todd, portrait painter, on Old Country Road at Dix Hills, Huntington, L. I., has been placed on the market through J. Edward Breuer, Inc.

Training for active citizenship has taken a new turn at Syracuse University, where women students have applied their political science theories to the practical problems of student government and watched their recommendations work out in the form of rules and by-laws.

AFTER the trilogy "Les Destinees Sentimentales" (which we reviewed here a year ago), M. Chardonne has returned to his favorite subject--the study of marital relationship--with a dense, compressed novel, where, as is usual with him, rigorous thinking and a virile sense of drama keep him away from any weak gush of feeling.

A large committee,headed by Mrs. Gordon Knox Bell, and Miss Augusta de Peyster, is taking an active interest in the sale of tickets for the lecture and motion-picture, "Wandering Windjammer," to be given by Captain Alan Villiers the afternoon of May 1 at the -Heckscher Theatre for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

The solution of the housing problem in Great Britain, to the extent that 270,000 dwelling units are now being constructed yearly by private enterprise, underwent an evolution lasting twelve years, according to Sir Charles Morgan-Webb of

Stockholders of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation approved today, by a vote of more than two-thirds of the outstanding stock, the recapitalization plan submitted by the board of directors which will provide $2,600,000 in new capital.

Contrary to the general impression that the first railroad sleeping car was built in the United States, the Canadian National Railways Magazine claims that it was constructed at Brantford, Ont., in 1859, the year before Albert Edward, Prince of Wales, afterward King Edward VII, visited Canada.

Despite all the difficulties that have been encountered, it is still hoped that the Paris Exhibition will open before Whitsunday, May 16, according to Pierre Mortimer, head of the publicity department.

Senator and Mrs. Edouard L. Jonas, who have been in this country for two months, during which time Senator Jonas, Deputy Minister of the Riviera District, carried on a special study of tourism in the United States for his government, gave a farewell tea yesterday at their New York home, 998 Fifth Avenue.
Houses cannot be produced or sold like automobiles, points out Frederick L. Ackerman of the housing committee of the American Institute of Architects.

Colonel Bill Terry put his Giants on display for New York's baseball fans for the first time this season at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the exhibition was voted a success by 6,000 slightly chilled fans.
Statisticians estimated today that strikes in the automotive industry for five months cost workers $65,000,000 to $70,000,000 in wages.

Miss Mary Thayer, daughter of Mrs. Aaron Claflin Thayer of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Thayer, was married to Ralph McLean, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis MeLean of Philadelphia, yesterday afternoon at the Park Lane Hotel here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. J. Frederick Berg.

The Marshall-Wythe Hall, which houses the administrative offices and the Marshall-Wythe School of Government and Citizenship at the College of William and Mary, will be dedicated next Friday afternoon.

BEFORE you are half way through this book Mr. Carr will have you almost believing in witchcraft, black magic, the "non-dead" and other spine-chilling phenomena contrary to the laws of nature as we know them.
Arentinians have refused to get exted over the death of the local lazi leader, Josef Riedel or to give the political significance Berlin trying to give it.

ONE hour after I arrived in Spain, after an unforgettably beautiful flight over the Pyrenees from Toulouse to Valencia, I got my first (and my last!) sight of Spanish revolutionary theatre. It was all quite accidental.

Brussels announces that Premier van Zeeland is going to the United States to see President Roosevelt about the possibilities of an economic conference and that, incidentally, while he is in the United States he will receive a degree from Princeton.

What will the giant Bonneville Dam do to the salmon in the Columbia River? This question threatens to rank with the problem of providing power policy for the vast supply of hydroelectricity to be produced at the great barrier.

Creation of a large industrial center in the south-central part of Poland, building of a number of] strategic railways, construction of a naval base and a shipbuilding plant near Gdynia, protected by fortifications, and modernization of the Polish Army and air force are some of the national defense projects Poland has already started or is planning to start this year.
Mrs. Harrybelle Stark, war nurse who served with the United States Army Nursing Corps in France, died yesterday at Castle Point Veterans Hospital here.

The 2,500 sand hogs who will help construct the new Queens Midtown Tunnel under the East River will be protected by the most modern and elaborate safety devices, designed to ward off "the bends," the most dreaded affliction of all workers under compressed air.

J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N. J., and Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, are the United North and South tennis champions for 1937. In the final round of the men's singles today Hall, after a faltering start, overcame a 0-4 deficit

AMPERED by code interference for the past six months, Iceland's strong short-wave signal is now heard "in the clear," and the twenty-minute programs from Reykjavik have been tuned the past two Sundays with unusual clarity on the 12.24 megacycle channel.

BECAUSE the great growth of interest in the dance in edunational circles constitutes perhaps the most important single development in the contemporary field, the convention of the American Physical Education Association here this week becomes especially interesting.

TUESDAY afternoon the Grand National tournament begins at the Hotel Montclair. The last large tournament of the regular bridge season, it offers as its principal attraction a trip to Budapest for the winning team of four.

Postmaster James A. Parley and former Mayor James J. Walker were tablemates last night at the twelfth annual dinner of the First Avenue Boys, Inc., at the Commodore. More than 2,000 persons attended the dinner, the proceeds of which will be used for the organization's charitable work.

Mayor La Guardia wanted to present the keys of the City of New York to 150 visiting members of the House of Representatives, their wives and friends, at a luncheon yesterday, but he said he could not do it because the keys had disappeared long ago.

The program for the eleventh annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic Division of the Model Assembly of the League of Nations, to be held at Cornell next Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, was announced today.

Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black was elected president of the New York Southern Society at the organization's annual election of officers, which took place on Thursday night in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
After ten years of existence, the Guidon, only magazine published nationally by Republican women, has been reduced to its original size of 5 1/2 by 7 1/2 inches for tomorrow's issue.
An animal census is in progress throughout the 65,000 acres of Allegany State Park, near Salamanca. It is designed to record the species and abundance of wild mammals
Mars Shield, fleet Milky Way Farm's filly, responded -to brilliant urging in the stretch by Jockey Alfred Robertson to win the $15,000 added Texas Derby before 25,000 fans at Arlington Downs today.

Manhattan mortgage financing and extensions, transfers and building permits showed gains in February as compared with that month one year ago. With the exception of the transfers, all showed gains in both number and volume.

Miss Elizabeth Benedict, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hobart L. Benedict of this place, was married to Owen W. James, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. James of Williamsport, Pa., this evening in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Millburn, by the Rev. Hugh W. Dickinson.

News with authentic early Americ of her election to the presidency of the William Smith student body was taken to the bedside of Miss Margaret Allen as she was recuoperating from a cold in the college infirmary. Miss Allen, a junior from Honesdale, Pa.,

Activity slackened somewhat in the New York wholesale merchandise markets last week, and mail requisitions were spotty, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. Retailers generally reported increases in business, although these were not up to expectations. The report continues:

NEARLY everybody has toyed once or twice with the droll idea that underlies Victor Wolfson's "Excur??." Nearly everybody has childly imagined that it would be entanting to navigate a plain harbor ??sel out of New York to one of ?? ineffable isles.
The Capitol police force during 1936 made 322 arrests, Kenneth Romney, sergeant-at-arms, recently revealed to a House committee.

Revolt is no novelty in Spain. Off and on for nearly 130 years--since Napoleon forced Joseph Bonaparte on them as King in 1808--the Spanish people have periodically risen against one ruling power or another.

Retailers generally reported increases in business, although these were not up to expectations. The report continues:

Mrs. Harrybelle Stark, war nurse who served with the United States Army Nursing Corps in France, died yesterday at Castle Point Veterans Hospital here.

The 2,500 sand hogs who will help construct the new Queens Midtown Tunnel under the East River will be protected by the most modern and elaborate safety devices, designed to ward off "the bends," the most dreaded affliction of all workers under compressed air.

J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N. J., and Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, are the United North and South tennis champions for 1937. In the final round of the men's singles today Hall, after a faltering start, overcame a 0-4 deficit

AMPERED by code interference for the past six months, Iceland's strong short-wave signal is now heard "in the clear," and the twenty-minute programs from Reykjavik have been tuned the past two Sundays with unusual clarity on the 12.24 megacycle channel.

BECAUSE the great growth of interest in the dance in edunational circles constitutes perhaps the most important single development in the contemporary field, the convention of the American Physical Education Association here this week becomes especially interesting.

TUESDAY afternoon the Grand National tournament begins at the Hotel Montclair. The last large tournament of the regular bridge season, it offers as its principal attraction a trip to Budapest for the winning team of four.

Postmaster James A. Parley and former Mayor James J. Walker were tablemates last night at the twelfth annual dinner of the First Avenue Boys, Inc., at the Commodore. More than 2,000 persons attended the dinner, the proceeds of which will be used for the organization's charitable work.

Mayor La Guardia wanted to present the keys of the City of New York to 150 visiting members of the House of Representatives, their wives and friends, at a luncheon yesterday, but he said he could not do it because the keys had disappeared long ago.

The program for the eleventh annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic Division of the Model Assembly of the League of Nations, to be held at Cornell next Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, was announced today.
Mr. and Mrs. John Nickerson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Alicia Nickerson, to Walton Campbell Ament of New York, son of James M. Ament of Wilmerding, Pa.
The bullets of two New York gunmen he sought to trap two days ago claimed the life of a young Federal agent as his fellow agents were clamping an $11,000 web of evidence about the gangsters today.

Soy bean futures on the Board of Trade advanced 1/8 to 1 cent a bushel yesterday. The May delivery closed at $1.76, a net advance of 21/2 cents for the week, while the July finished at $1.71, a gain of 31/2 cents.

One of 1935's Summer theatre children, "Penny Wise," graduates to Broadway this evening, arriving at the Morosco. It is a comedy by Jean Ferguson Black, last represented by an adaptation of "Thunder on the Left," and among those present in its cast will be Kenneth MacKenna, Linda Watkins and Irene Purcell. Juliana Morgan is the producer, Arthur Sircom the director, and the curtain rises at 8:40 o'clock.

Six persons were rescued today from a three-story brick apartment house at 333 Jackson Avenue as a fire in a clothing shop on the first floor sent dense smoke into the living quarters on the upper floors.

Former Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Van Kirk, who was presiding justice of the Appellate Division, Third Department, from 1928 until his retirement at the close of 1932, died here this afternoon at his home after a three weeks' illness. His health had been failing since October. He was 74 years old.

Columbia College has taken a preliminary step in what appears to presage an extensive program to stiffen its entrance requirements. The Columbia catalogue, issued yesterday, listed two alternative plans to be used by incoming students for admission in September.

Angelo Trulio, the defending champion, and Eddie Linz, New York A. C. star, were among the victors in second-round play of the metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall soft-ball handball tournament at the Pastime A. C. yesterday.

" There can be no Christian religion that is not about Jesus," Professor Robert K. Rudolph of the Reformed Episcopal Theological Seminary of Philadelphia said in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Reformed Episcopal Church, 317 East Fiftieth Street.

Activity was general in the wholesale apparel market here last week, and ready-to-wear was purchased in considerable volume. Striped chiffon street dresses moved well, and numerous orders were placed for Summery floral prints on light backgrounds.

A new official poster, telling employes covered under the amended State Unemployment Insurance Law how, when, where, how much and for how long they may get unemployment benefits, is now being distributed among all employers subject to the law.

L. F. Sanman dominated the competition at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the high gun long trophy with a card of 96, then mine scored in the doubles scratch contest with a 27 out of a possible 30.

Discussing the sit-down strike as a piece of labor technique and as a sign of a growing philosophy of social life, John Haynes Holmes, minister of the Community Church, meeting in Town Hall, declared yesterday that labor's new weapon soon would win acceptance for itself and, with the aid of the Wagner act, would stand as the beginning of the Magna Charta of the working class.

The family spirit of "sharing rather than giving" is the keynote of the current Catholic Charities appeal for funds, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, told a congregation at high mass yesterday.

April showers accompanied by thunder arrived suddenly last night after a bright Spring day, but they were too late to mar the spirits of motorists, walkers and other seekers of the New York outdoors. Sunny skies drew the first large crowds of the season to the highwavs and shore resorts.

The Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church Grand Concourse at 175th Street, the Bronx, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "the place of religion in American life has been from the beginning a most significant one and its influence is realized in the patterns of thought that make up our legal, political, educational and cultural life."
New Jersey's infant celebrities, the Kasper quadruplets, received a church christening this afternoon in a world-series atmosphere.

For the first time in many years elected representatives of the people will be members of the Venezuelan Congress which opens at Caracas tomorrow. The Congressmen appointed by the late dictator, Juan Vicente Gomez, however, will constitute two-thirds of the membership.
Champlain Lord Riley, a member of the firm of Clark, MacMullen Riley, consulting engineers of 101 Park Avenue, New York, died Friday night at his home here of heart disease. He was 60 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Ledyard Mitchell of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Adeline Mitchell, to John E. O'Keefe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. O'Keefe of Carthage, Mo.

Praising the contributions of Jews to German culture, Thomas Mann, German author and Nobel Prize winner, declared yesterday that anti-Semitism was "among the evil and obnoxious reactions to suffering of this time."

Of 2 about $667,000,000 loaned in 1936 for home financing purposes by 10,000 savings, building and loan associtations in the United States, $518,000,000, or 77 per cent, was provided by members of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, according to a survey of home lending just completed by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

The second conference on Canadian-American affairs under the auspices of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace will be held from June 14 to 18 at Queens University, Kingston, Ont., it was announced yesterday in the annual report by Dr. James T. Shotwell, director of the division of economics-and history of the endowment.

Mary M. Phillips, founder of the Junior Red Cross Society, died here tonight. She was 81 years old. An outstanding Red Cross worker when the first Canadian branch was formed in 1909, Miss Phillips later started spreading its ideals among children.

Bruce Wendell, a native of Antigua, B. W. I., gave a piano recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon before a sizable and appreciative audience. Mr. Wendell received his musical education in London, where he made his debut a decade ago.

Both stocks and company bonds advanced on the average last week. This was in spite of the week's rather emphatic decline In grain prices, textiles and non-ferrous metals; it occurred, also, while labor unrest and the belligerent strikes in which it expressed itself figured each day on newspaper front pages.
A brain disease caused by bacteria in raw milk was reported today to the American College of Physicians on the eve of its twenty-first annual meeting.
The Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures showed a "considerable profit" for 1936, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., the commissioner, declares in his annual report, made public yesterday.

A two-run rally in the ninth inning by the Phillies fell short today and the Athletics took the final game of the city series, 5 to 4, before 4,500 fans. Chuck Klein left two runners stranded with a fly to Bob Johnson for the final out of the game.

DENMARK provided the setting for the world's greatest play and the most memorable fairy stories. Today it is without Hamlets or pathetic Little Match Girls. It is peopled by the contented and the well fed. Through legislation and cooperation the Danish flesh has been disinherited of many of its natural shocks.
The stock market here was active and firm all this week and closed well above the year's earlier high level. Trading began with a heavy demand for steel, lignite, private railroad and bank shares.
Marked by special services during the morning and afternoon, dedicatory exercises were here today for the opening of the Garden City Community Church at Stewart Avenue and Whitehall Boulevard.

The great library on tobacco that George Arents Jr. has been assembling for forty-five years is destined ultimately to repose in some public library or other institution, it was disclosed yesterday by the owner.

John R. Davies, former official referee in the Supreme Court, will be elected and installed as the new president of the National Republican Club at its clubhouse, 54 West Fortieth Street, tomorrow evening.

True spiritual and bodily health can be obtained only by contact with God through the "divine spark within us," Dr. Emmet Fox decleared yesterday in a sermon before the congregation of the First Church of Divine Science, which met in the Hippodrome, Forty-third Street and Sixth Avenue.

A revival of the Protestant-American customs of saying grace before meals and of reading the Bible aloud at home as a means of making our youth more spiritual was urged yesterday morning by Homer Rodeheaver in his sermon at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

A total of $321,518 was given by the Milbank Memorial Fund in 1936 for projects and grants-in-aid in the fields of public health, medicine, education and social welfare, according to the annual report of the fund, made public yesterday.

About 200 are expected to start tomorrow in the fortieth running of the famous Boston A. A. marathon. The winner's rewards will be an impressive trophy and a few days of fame and the next thirty-four finishers will be rewarded with medals.

Commanders of warships of four nations received instructions tonight for taking up a patrol of the Spanish coast tomorrow at midnight, the time set for inaugurating an international plan to isolate the civil war.
Seasonal industrial recovery continues with the number of unemployed in March decreasing by 366,000 to 1,245,000, against 1,937,000 in March, 1936.

The dove of political peace hovered over the Capitol tonight, but whether it will alight depends on the fulfillment of reports that the Republicans and Governor Lehman will reach an agreement on taxes.
The cornation music season will be in full appeal swing tomorrow night, when Sir That Thomas Beecham raises his baton closing for the orchestral overture opening mean the opera at Covent Garden.
One reason why Mr. ROOSEVELT might decide to change his attitude on the Supreme Court is that he does not have to.
The index number for French industrial production in February was 103, compared with 101 in January, and with 99 in February, 1936.

The rejuvenated St. Louis Browns cleaned up a two-game city series against the Cardinals today by winning a bitterly contested twelve-inning struggle, 5 to 4. The game required 3 hours 42 minutes to complete.

Today Joe McCarthy's Yankees have no blot on the title they blasted away from the Giants last Fall. For yesterday at Ebbets Field they won the fifth and deoiding game of the "Lilliputian World Series" from the Dodgers, 6--4, while nearly 18,000 baseballhungry Flatbush fans cheered the vain but persistent efforts of Bur leigh Grimes's boys to annex even that empty title.

The New York Rugby Club and the French Rugby Club scored convincing victories in the doubleheader at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx yesterday before a crowd of 1,500. In the opening game New York defeated the Boston Rugby Club, 14-3, while the French scored over St. Andrews of South Orange, N. J., 9-3.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary due today from Southampton and Cherbourg includes Sir George and Lady Schuster, Lady Ina Gage, Sir Alvin R. Dickinson, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzburger, Derek Hall Caine, Sir Leonard Pearce, Colonel and Mrs. J. E. Smallman,

Triumphing in a keenly contested third set, which lasted almost an hour, Ellsworth Vines defeated Frederick J. Perry at the 106th Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night to hold the lead in their long series of professional tennis singles matches.

Sportsmen in the United States and Alaska paid nearly $10,000,000 for hunting licenses and Federal migratory bird-hunting stamps in 1935, the latest year for which figures are available, says the United States Biological Survey.

Rushing three runs across in a rousing ninth-inning rally, the Giants tossed a. crowd of 31,486 spectators into a grand pre-season turmoil of excitement at the Polo Grounds yesterday by upsetting the Indians, 5 to 4, in the concluding struggle of the 1937 training campaign.

The Cuban government plans to spend $1,000,000 in a four-year program to develop tourist trade and travel, it was announced yesterday by Samuel T. Tolon, Havana business man and government representative, who is touring this Country in the interests of Cuba's tourist business.

Miss Katherine Cheney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth Leslie Cheney of Manchester was married here at noon yesterday in St. James's Church to George Fiske Hammond of Santa Barbara, Calif., son of Mrs. Gardiner Greene Hammond. The Rev. William P. Reidy performed the ceremony.

Mr. and Mrs. Guy Hutchinson of New York and Hastings-on-Hudson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Hutchinson, to Malcolm Young Jr., son of Mrs. Robert H. Strahan of New York and Sands Point, L. I., and of Colonel Malcolm Young of Santa Barbara, Calif.

The members' all-age stake in the thirteenth annual Spring field trials of the Mid-Jersey Field Dog Club was captured today by Middleburg Dan, white and black pointer owned and handled by L. R. Durbrow of Maplewood. The victory was the forty-fifth for Middleburg Dan.

Make-Up Box, the dramatic society at Hunter College, and the college acting and play production classes will present five one-act plays Friday and Sunday evenings at 8:45 in the auditorium of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra's concert last night in the WPA Theatre of Music was to have been conducted by Chalmers Clifton, New York director of the Federal Music Project, but a recent illness prevented him from rehearsing the program, and he directed but one number.

Mrs. Anna Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, announced yesterday that New York State had received a Federal grant of $652,751.33 for administraiton of its Unemployment Insurance Law for the quarter from April 1 to June 30.

The study of a proposal for affiliation with the Metropolitan District of Reformed Jewish Congregations, which is centered in New York, was urged here today upon members of the New Jersey Association, Union of American Hebrew Congregations, by Rabbi Marius Ranson of Temple Sharey Tefilo of East Orange. He was a speaker at the annual conference of the association in the temple. About 100 attended.
THE GAUDY EMPIRE, by Alfred Neumann. (Knopf, $2.75.) The fantastic story of the Second Empire in France told in fiction form.

Persistent reports of Russian submarine construction on an unprecedented scale are heard throughout Europe. One usually well-informed British naval correspondent places the number of Russian submarines built or building at forty at Vladivostok and "at least ninety others completed or building in the Baltic."

A Protestant, a Jew and a Catholic, each prominent in the affairs of his respective faith, joined last night in a discussion under the auspices of the Judaeans, a Jewish cultural society, at the Emanu-El Community House, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Paul Hindemith, the German composer, was the guest of honor at the recital-reception given by the League of Composers last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. The reception, which was the last of the three tendered to visiting composer-conductors this season by the league, was attended by a capacity audience and one which received Mr. Hindemith and the other artists participating in the musical program with unbounded enthusiasm.
Ten teams, including the Los Angeles Bulldogs, will be represented in the American Professional Football League next Fall, The Associated Press reports.
Major crimes increased 1 per cent in New York City in 1936 as compared with 1935, according to the annual report of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, made public yesterday.
The police conducted a germ hunt yesterday. They were told to "detain" a taxicab driven by Francis E. Friedly of 2,440 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, but that was all they knew about it.

Mrs. Elinore H. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, denied yesterday afternoon charges made Saturday by the International Seamen's Union that the labor board had acted "illegally" in obtaining an agreement between the "insurgent" sailor's unions of the international union and the International Mercantile Marine.
The hundredth anniversary of the death of Elijah Parish Lovejoy, martyred Abolitionist editor, will be honored by his alma mater, Colby College, on Nov. 7.

Formation of a new firm, S. Bleichroder New York, Incorporated, which will act as correspondent for the Berlin house of Gebr. Arnhold and will bear the name of the old German house of S. Bleichroder, private bankers, of Berlin, founded in 1813, was announced yesterday.

Lawrence Marx, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, announced yesterday that Paul Felix Warburg will be in charge of the campaign for funds to be conducted jointly by the Manhattan Federation and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.

Some 5,000 women, arriving in Washington over the week-end to attend the Forty-sixth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution, found the nation's capital sweltering in the heat of premature Summer weather.

Syracuse University's baseball team, handicapped by adverse weather, but better fortified than usual with pitchers, opens its 1937 campaign here Saturday against Union, inaugurating an eighteen-game schedule.

Hitting their winning stride again, the St. John's University ball tossers snapped the Long Island University streak of nine straight victories when they turned back the Blackbirds, 7-3, at Dexter Park yesterday.
